title: RYAN HURLS 2-HITTER AS METS LOSE 15TH
description: Nolan Ryan, taking a no-hit bid into the eighth inning, wound up with a two-hitter last night while the Mets ended up with their 15th defeat in a row. The Mets got singles in the eighth and ninth inning as they were shut out by the Houston Astros, 4-0, at Shea Stadium.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bangor Hydro-Electric Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 750,000 common shares, through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.

title: DANCE: NOH THEATER
description: THE noh theater of Japan is probably one of the hardest of Asian performing arts for the uninitiated to grasp. Five centuries of performing have internalized a formal, highly codified system within the bodies and minds of noh actors and musicians. The theater that flows out, so serenely that its changes are sometimes almost imperceptible, seems to fill the stage space with simple, luminous essence. One can open oneself to its stylized abstraction as if to a state of mind, suspending impatient Western expectation, but something very precise - and even urgent - is going on on stage.

title: CRITICS OF E.P.A. ARE RIGHT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has come increasingly under fire for its perceived unwillingness to carry out its role as protector of the environment. Its Administrator, Anne M. Gorsuch, has responded to critics by asserting that the E.P.A.'s recent record proves otherwise. As E.P.A. employees, we wish this were true but we must confirm the public perception: The E.P.A. is rapidly losing its ability to discharge its responsibilities effectively.

title: MIXED RECEPTION FOR RAIDERS
description: Cliff Branch stepped out of the shower and into the dressing area, a home-team locker room more spacious than the one in Oakland, and considered the tens of thousands of empty seats he had just played to in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: MAYOR DELIVERS A STRONG ATTACK AGAINST REAGAN
description: In one of his strongest attacks on President Reagan, Mayor Koch yesterday accused the Reagan Administration of ''destroying the American dream'' with its budget cutbacks and tight money policies.

title: Voicing a Vote
description: In the minds of Yankee fans, there is no doubt that Phil Rizzuto was one of the greatest shortstops in baseball history. To them, his ongoing absence from the Hall of Fame is one of baseball's great injustices.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rights Group Is Set Back In Cincinnati School Suit
description: A Federal appeals court dealt the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People a major setback today by reaffirming a 17-year-old ruling that cleared Cincinnati school officials of intentional segregation through mid-1965.

title: PETS AS THERAPY
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Pets noncritical, nonjudgmental, nondemanding? Anybody who has ever been subjected to a pet cat's reproachful stare for failing to perform some expected task knows better.

title: Steelers Cut Greenwood
description: Yesterday was another cutdown day in the National Football League, the teams reducing to 60 players on the way to the regular-season limit of 49. There were some prominent names among those who fell victim to the trims, but none more prominent than L.C. Greenwood, nearing his 36th birthday and the last active member of Pittsburgh's original Steel Curtain defensive front four.

title: Sybron Purchases Dental Operation
description: The Sybron Corporation, a maker of medical instruments and products, said it had acquired the dental operations of the American Hospital Supply Corporation, a maker of health care products, for $86.8 million.

title: Sanyo Settles Suit On Stereo Prices
description: Sanyo Electric Inc. and its southern California sales representative, CMA Sales Inc., have agreed to pay $109,437 in penalties and court costs to settle an antitrust suit that charged the two companies with price fixing.

title: MOTA IS ACTIVATED
description: Manny Mota, baseball's career pinchhit leader and the Los Angeles Dodgers' 44-year-old first-base coach, will be activated Wednesday for the pennant drive, the club said today. Mota did not play last season, but in 1980 he was activated in late August and got three pinch hits in seven times at bat. In 19 major league seasons Mota had 154 pinch hits, six more than Smokey Burgess.

title: LIMITED EFFECT SEEN IN SWISS ACCORD
description: Individuals seeking to engage in insider trading on American stock markets are likely to turn to banks in countries other than Switzerland as a result of the agreement reportedly reached yesterday between United States and Swiss authorities, according to bankers in New York.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HEADED UNEMPLOYMENT BOARD
description: Louis J. Naftalison, former chairman of the Unemployment Appeal Board of the New York State Department of Labor, died Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 83 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: M & T MORTGAGE INVESTORS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ITALIAN SOCIALISTS WITHOUT SOCIALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: EUGENE LORING, 72, CHOREOGRAPHER WHO CREATED 'BILLY THE KID,' DIES
description: Eugene Loring, the dancer and choreographer who created ''Billy the Kid,'' an American ballet classic, died Monday in Kingston, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At Queens College, The Door Is Open

title: LIL' CHAMP FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split

title: INDIAN ARTIFACTS FROM A MUSEUM FOUND BY POLICE
description: Four of five wooden Indian masks and ceremonial headdress ornaments that were reported stolen last June from the Museum of the American Indian were recovered yesterday after a dealer attempted to sell them to the museum, the police said. The four recovered items were valued at $1,150,000 by the museum.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Personal Health column of Aug. 18 incorrect information was given on two drugs listed under diuretics.

title: REFERENDUMS WOULD GET AMERICANS TO THE POLLS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON REPORTER LOSES FREEDOM BID
description: A reporter who refused to testify in a murder case returned to jail tonight after a Supreme Court Justice took no action on his last-minute bid to remain free.

title: A FEARFUL REMINDER LINGERS FOR ASIANS IN KENYA
description: A day after the attempted coup in Kenya a month ago, the Asian trader who runs a bakery at the Westlands shopping center, a suburban complex that had been badly looted, was doing a brisk business. So was the Asian shopkeeper farther down the block who runs a library of pirated videotapes, everything from ''Dallas'' to classic Bogart films.

title: LOCAL COOKBOOKS: A REGIONAL TOUCH FOR FUND-RAISING
description: HREE years ago choir members at St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church in Palisades Park, N.J., wanted to raise money to repair the stairway leading to their choir loft. They decided to publish a cookbook based on family recipes handed down over the years in their predominantly Italian parish. The small spiral-bound book has sold so well that they have not only repaired and recarpeted the stairs but also replaced a stained-glass window in the back of the church.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Importance of Labels
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Your article of Aug. 18 on ''natural food'' ('' 'Natural' Food: Telling the Real From the Artificial'') and the problems allied with it were close to my needs.

title: HOW MUCH CAN THE ECOSYSTEM TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is high time, says Edward Spitzer, that a new organization receive the prominence that is clearly its due. ''The group is designed,'' he says, ''to do basic research into, and publicize, available responses to those people who say, 'Have a nice day,' or as it is usually put, 'Havanizeday.' ''

title: SOUTH CAROLINA JOB TRAINING SYSTEM'S BUDGET UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Since it was established in 1961, South Carolina's nationally recognized Technical Education System has been widely praised as a model program for training industrial workers and has helped attract some of the world's wealthiest corporations to the state.

title: Briefs on the Arts Philharmonic Will Give Free Argentine Concert
description: As an unusual ''good-will gesture'' to the people of Argentina, the New York Phiharmonic, now in the middle of a triumphant South American tour, will play a free concert in Buenos Aires this Sunday. The announcement was made yesterday in the Argentine capital by Zubin Mehta, the orchestra's music director.

title: U.S. to Restore Air Rule On Double Fare Penalty
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it would reinstate on Oct. 1 the requirement that would give airline passengers bumped from a flight double compensation if they were not promptly provided transportation.

title: To Ease the Pain of Death
description: For too many, the end of life is a nightmare of lonely hospital rooms and sterile combat against unstoppable disease. But there is an alternative: hospice care, an inspiring concept imported from Britain. The idea is to let the terminally ill remain at home for as long as possible so that friends and family can provide care under the supervision of a physician. Both the patient and the family receive help in coping with death.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $7,000 for the qr and $37,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $11,000 for the qr and $66,000 for the 9 mos

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Auditions for Singers

title: SUNSET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Military Analysis
description: The costly and protracted war between Iran and Iraq appears to be moving toward another period of intense activity, according to military experts, and will probably result in more casualties, but only in minor changes in the general situation.

title: TRUCK DRIVERS REACH ACCORD WITH BUILDERS
description: After a two-month strike that halted work on many major projects in the city, the truck drivers who deliver concrete for heavy construction reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the General Contractors Association.

title: Bridge: Sacrifices Are Encouraged
description: By Present Scoring Table By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Le Corbusier Show

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Performs in Frankfurt
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra arrived here Sunday to give the first of two concerts at the city's lavishly restored Alte Oper, which reopened to widespread praise from musicians a year ago. The concert was a repeat of the program offered by the 112-member orchestra in Vienna on Saturday.

title: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1982; International
description: President Reagan was urged by four senior officials to soften trade sanctions against the European companies that violate his Soviet pipeline embargo, according to an Administration official. He said they also told the President he should apply the sanctions evenly. (Page A1.) British-made components for the pipeline were loaded onto a Soviet vessel in Glasgow. It will be the second shipment from Europe in defiance of the Reagan ban. (D1.)

title: Subsidiary of G.E.  Chooses New York
description: The General Electric Trading Company, a newly formed subsidiary of the General Electric Company, announced at City Hall yesterday that it had established its world headquarters in New York City.

title: BOY SAVED FROM ICE KILLED BY QUEENS BUS
description: A 10-year-old boy who was saved when he fell through the ice on Central Park lake last February was run over and killed by a bus last night in Queens, the police said.

title: U.S. SAID TO BE LAGGING IN FISH CONSUMPTION
description: The typical American ate 13 pounds of seafood last year, including 6.5 ounces of sardines, 8 ounces of canned salmon and 3.1 pounds of tuna.

title: Clarence J. Myers, 85; Headed New York Life
description: Clarence J. Myers, retired president and chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Monday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX ROSE BY 13% IN JULY
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.3 percent in July, the fourth monthly increase in a row, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include investment and research and development tax credits of $117,000 for the qr and $305,000 for the yr

title: Executive Has Faith In Hearts of Tomorrow
description: In the future, people may get artificial hearts when their own wear out. John C. Moise is betting on it. Mr. Moise, 57, has organized a new research and development company called Nimbus Inc., based in a suburb of Sacramento, Calif. He had worked at the Aerojet-General Corporation for 27 years, the last 10 on artificial heart research, and when Aerojet decided to divest itself of the program and concentrate on defense contract work, Mr. Moise and a group of other employees stepped in.

title: SURVEYS ON WOMEN'S REACTION WORRY WHITE HOUSE
description: With the fall elections two months away, the Reagan Administration is making a major effort to shore up wavering support among women.

title: JUSTICE WHO REFUSED TRANSFER IS CENSURED BY STATE COMMISSION
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct yesterday censured a State Supreme Court Justice who had refused to accept a transfer from the Criminal to the Civil Division and thus had no cases assigned to him for more than six months.

title: Economic Scene; Capitalism And Crises
description: THE world economic system is suffering the most acute stress it has known in half a century. The Mexican economy is in a state of collapse, and the International Monetary Fund, with the full support of the United States, is moving to rescue it from default on some $80 billion in foreign debt. Meanwhile, other developing countries of the third world are swimming in a cumulative debt of some $500 billion.

title: APPLES: FROM EVE TO GRANNY SMITH
description: THE apple is now associated with good health, rosy coloring and a well-known large city - all quite an accomplishment for a fruit that was blamed for the downfall of mankind.

title: Kate Baxter Becomes Bride of Fergus Reid 3d
description: Kate Davis Baxter, daughter of Mrs. Elwood R. Quesada of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Bar Harbor, Me., and the late Henry Ware Putnam of Dedham, Mass., was married yesterday to Fergus Reid 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid Jr. of New York and York Harbor, Me. The Rev. Robert Bryan performed the Episcopal ceremony on the lawn at the Bar Harbor home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Lieutenant General Quesada, U.S.A.F. retired.

title: Market Place; Winn-Dixie: Steady Income
description: DIXIE INC., a Sun Belt-based grocery chain, is unusual in offering income-seeking investors what many of them want in a stock: monthly dividends.

title: CONGRESSMAN LOSES GEORGIA GUBERNATORIAL RUNOFF
description: Joe Frank Harris, a state legislator, won Georgia's Democratic nomination for Governor tonight, defeating United States Representative Bo Ginn in a runoff contest.

title: COSMOS MAY CALL ON ROMERO
description: With two of their starting midfielders, Johan Neeskens and Wim Rijsbergen, out of the deciding playoff game against Tulsa Wednesday night because of injuries, the Cosmos decided today to have Julio Cesar Romero in uniform for the game at Giants Stadium.

title: WHEN WEIGHTING A STUDY OF EXECUTION
description: Frank J. Coppola was electrocuted for murder the night of Aug. 10 after the Supreme Court quickly cleared the way at the request of the state of Virginia, apparently without taking time to consider papers prepared by lawyers opposing the execution.

title: Jan Merrill to Run
description: Jan Merrill, a two-time Pan American Games champion in the women's 1,500-meter run, has entered Fifth Avenue Mile Saturday. She finished fourth in the first running of the race last year.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: ANY day now they'll be off to school in their new clothes, backpacking schoolbags and with new accessories for doing homework. Stores are ready for the invasion of parents and children shopping for back-to-school necessities and things just for fun. 1. Crayon Box Book Bag A book bag with back straps, made to look like a giant Crayola crayon box, is in green and yellow canvas that buckles at the front. It's $6.77 at F.W. Woolworth stores.

title: EL SALVADOR REPORTS ITS CASUALTIES
description: Government troops had 3,801 casualties - estimated at more than one-fifth the army's strength - fighting leftist guerrillas in the 12-month period ending June 30, Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia said today.

title: President Adds Title of Chief at Bacardi Unit
description: William A. Walker, who worked his way from an advertising account executive for Bacardi rum to president of its United States distributorship, Bacardi Imports Inc., has added the title of chief executive.

title: A 'SWOLLEN STATISTIC' SUITABLE TO REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: star-turned-preacher, will be making his Broadway debut next week as Patti La Belle's costar in a new production of the gospel musical ''Your Arms Too Short to Box With God.'' The Broadway stage would seem to be a somewhat unlikely forum for Mr. Green, a singer of uncommon brilliance and uncommon volatility who can range unpredictably from a barely audible whisper to a bullish shout and back to a whisper in the course of a single number. But when Mr. Green gave up pop music to become minister of the Full Gospel Tabernacle in Memphis, preaching seemed an unlikely forum for him, too. After all, he had been one of the most sensual and erotic of contemporary soul singers.

title: Kenilworth Filing
description: The Kenilworth Systems Corporation said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Liberian Expects French Aid
description: The Liberian head of Government, Samuel K. Doe, said today after conferring with President Francois Mitterrand that he had obtained French economic aid for Liberia. ''We now hope to receive aid from France very soon,'' he said.

title: William D. Hunter, 66; I.B.M. Computer Expert
description: William D. Hunter, who helped set up computerized controls for the New York Power Pool formed by electric utilities after the 1965 Northeast blackout, died Sunday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 66 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: 19.7% Youth Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate for youths at the peak of this summer was 19.7 percent, the Labor Department reported today. The department said that 3.4 million people 16 to 21 years old were unemployed and looking for work in July at the peak of unemployment.

title: HUSSEIN FEARS A THREAT TO JORDAN FORM ISRAEIL STAND ON PALESTINIAN
description: King Hussein fears that Jordan's territorial integrity may be threatened if Israel continues to look to his kingdom as a state for the Palestinians.

title: Pets as Therapy
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane Brody's thorough article on pet therapy (''Personal Health,'' Aug. 11) was thought-provoking. Maybe not only the elderly and severely mentally ill can be reached through ''animal assisted'' therapy - perhaps ''normal'' students in secondary schools and perhaps even colleges might be tempted to resort less to drugs and alcohol if they had more access to the responsibilities and joys of pets. SUNNY MCMILLAN Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 2% IN JULY
description: New orders for manufactured goods rose 2 percent in July, the Government reported today. It was the third consecutive monthly gain and the biggest increase since the end of 1980.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS FALL 0.7%
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw products declined seven-tenths of 1 percent in August and averaged 2.2 percent less than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. It was the 13th consecutive month in which the index averaged below levels of a year earlier, according to department records.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A judge of the Orphans Court today directed Girard College to admit girls as soon as facilities and programs for them could be provided.

title: BRIGHT, T G, & CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPECIALIZED TABLEWARE
description: WHEN fish is ordered in an American restaurant, it generally arrives at the table skinless, headless, tailless and boneless. All that remains is white flesh that gives no clue to the size, shape or color of the original. European restaurants generally serve the entire fish except, of course, for the entrails.

title: Rikers I. Guard Held in L.I. Killing
description: A New York City correction officer was arrested and charged with second-degree murder Monday night with the fatal shooting earlier in the evening of a neighbor in Bay Shore, L.I., where both men lived.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid on Sept 10

title: JOHN MAZZOLA WILL QUIT AS LINCOLN CENTER HEAD
description: John Mazzola, president of Lincoln Center, announced his resignation yesterday, saying he will leave at the end of the year and serve as a special consultant through 1983.

title: Dawkins Not Resentful
description: Darryl Dawkins said he held no grudge against the Philadelphia 76ers for the surprise trade last Friday that sent him to the Nets.

title: Ohioan's 68 Leads U.S. Amateur by 1
description: Bob Lewis of Warren, Ohio, held a one-shot lead today with a two-under-par 68 after the first round of the United States Amateur golf championship. Lewis, who played on the Charles River Country Club course in neighboring Newton, had five birdies.

title: 3 DIVISIONS LISTED FOR U.S.F.L.
description: The United States Football League announced today that its 12-team league would begin its first season, starting the first weekend in March, divided into three four-team divisions.

title: Mobil Extends Discount Program
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it is asking dealers in 11 Middle West states to cut their gasoline price by 4 cents a gallon for motorists who pay in cash, starting Wednesday.

title: PALESTINIAN ISSUE AND JORDAN: LINKED TOGETHER FOR DECADES
description: The United States is seeking to reassure Jordan and to persuade Israel that the Palestinian problem cannot be solved by declarations that the Kingdom of Jordan constitutes a Palestinian state, an Administration official said today.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: JERSEY ELDERLY HAVE THEIR SAY ON THE FATE OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: No public issue carries more urgency for 71-year-old Edith Edelson than the immediate future of the Social Security system. She had spent most of Monday night thinking about it and she arose at 7 A.M. to type out her thoughts for a hearing today by the House Select Committee on Aging.

title: MARIETTA IS SEEKING '3D PARTIES'
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, continuing to resist an unfriendly takeover offer from the Bendix Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it expects to hold merger talks with unidentified ''third parties.''

title: BORG'S FAME AFFECTS SWEDES
description: ''So who is that one?'' asked the woman in designer tennis clothes. She was standing near the fence surrounding court 18 at the National Tennis Center, watching the first day of competition at the United States Open yesterday. A companion looked through a program in an attempt to find the answer to her question. But before he could do so, she said: ''Oh, look at his hair. He must be one of those Swedes.''

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $101,000 for the qr and $180,000 for the 6mos

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is inevitable that certain basic ingredients appear more frequently in a column on hasty cooking than others. Among them is one that, to my mind, is one of the greatest convenience foods in America - skinless, boneless chicken breasts. The reasons for the recurrence are obvious: they require a shorter cooking time than almost any other meat, and if your butcher is capable, they require the least preparation before they are added to your skillet, saucepan or grill.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it had increased its stake in Allis-Chalmers Corp.'s series C cumulative preferred shares to 12 percent, through the purchase of 33,000 shares.

title: JET RECEIVERS CALLED BEST ASSEST FOR NOW
description: With the beginning of the season 12 days away and with one exhibition game remaining, the Jets are still a team of parts.

title: THE BIG CHEESE CAPER
description: Friend, are you dying to get barrels of mail calling you a dumbbell? If so, just publish a newspaper column calling Liederkranz a German cheese.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago net for both periods restated to reflect change to LIFO accounting

title: HONDURAN OFFICER DENOUNCES HIS CHIEF
description: A senior Honduran military officer charged today that the chief of the Honduran armed forces, Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, was leading the country toward a military confrontation with neighboring Nicaragua.

title: News Analysis
description: The Manville Corporation's decision to file for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act has been at least as trying for the financial institutions and suppliers to which it owes money as for the company itself.

title: THE U.S. ON THE U.S.
description: The Government has just published the latest edition of a comprehensive handbook about itself, a commendable effort that attempts to map the Federal maze in a mere 912 pages of useful information ranging from the Declaration of Independence to the latest personnel changes in the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation.

title: SOME MEXICANS JOIN BUYING BOYCOTT
description: Over the last week, unsigned leaflets have circulated throughout the city calling on shoppers to stay home and boycott all stores today as an anti-Government protest on the eve of President Jose Lopez Portillo's final State of the Union address.

title: SOMETIMES ONLY A BALL GOWN WILL DO
description: THEY are hardly as essential as winter coats or as functional as sweaters, but to the fashion designer who concentrates on more expensive styles, they are a necessity. ''If you don't have ball gowns, you might as well go out of business,'' says Bill Blass.

title: Amfac-Bass Plan
description: Amfac Inc. and the Bass family of Fort Worth said they had formed a partnership to renovate and develop certain Amfac properties in Hawaii and to reduce short-term borrowings. Amfac said the partnership, named Fort Associates Limited Parnership, has borrowed $123 million through a group of lenders led by Merrill Lynch Private Capital. Amfac will get about $70.5 million and about $52.5 million will go to Bass interests.

title: LONDON'S CEREMONIAL SHERIFF
description: Almost 1,000 years of tradition went by the boards when Lady Donaldson assumed the oldest civic position in the capital, that of Sheriff of the City of London, the financial district. Although one tradition has ended, in her year as the first woman to hold the post she has made no changes in the quaint trappings and customs of what had been a male preserve.

title: SMALL HEPATITIS OUTBREAK IS REPORTED
description: A small outbreak of a milder form of infectious hepatitis that appears confined to a few blocks of the Chelsea section of Manhattan's West Side was reported yesterday by Dr. David J. Sencer, the City Health Commissioner.

title: 5-Year U.S. Note at 12.68%; Most Prices Decline a Bit
description: The Treasury sold $4.5 billion of new 12 5/8 percent five-year, two-month notes yesterday at an average rate of 12.68 percent, down sharply from yields in the secondary market in June and July. Elsewhere in the Treasury market, prices declined modestly in quiet trading.

title: JOHN IS TRADED TO ANGELS FOR 3 MINOR LEAGUERS
description: Tommy John, who in his first three years with the Yankees won more games than any other American League pitcher, was granted his wish today when the Yankees traded him to the California Angels.

title: CUBA DISRUPTS U.S. RADIO AS DISTANT AS DES MIONES
description: The Cuban Government, apparently responding to Reagan Administration plans to transmit radio programs into Cuba, disrupted American programming Monday night by broadcasting news and music programs on five AM frequencies.

title: PETS AS THERAPY
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Owning a pet can also drive neighbors crazy.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased John Curtis, left-handed pitcher, from San Diego.  MILWAUKEE (AL) - Acquired Don Sutton, right-handed pitcher, from Hous- ton for three minor league players to be named later.  PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Acquired Bob Molinaro from Chicago to complete trade of last year.  SAN DIEGO (NL) - Acquired Mike Griffin, right-handed pitcher, from Mont- real to complete an earlier deal in which the Expos traded Jer
description: BUFFALO (AFC) - Placed on waiv- e rs: Keith Clark and Rick Dennison, line- b ackers; Robert Geathers, defensive end; M al Najarian, running back, and Nolan F ranz, wide receiver. CHICAGO (NFC) - Released Joe Turn- e r, cornerback; Kris Haines, wide receiv- e r; Mike Cobb and Bob Fisher, tight ends; G ary Johnson, defensive lineman; Clinton D avenport, defensive tackle; John Skibin- s ki, fullback, and Bill Jensen, offensive t ackle. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Released S omoa Samoa, running back; Paul Soren- s on, free safety; Ben Needham, lineback- e r; Dan Feraday, quarterback; Patrick W alker, wide receiver; Ron Hausauer, g uard, and James Bettis, halfback.

title: TEXAS SCHOOLS FIND NO MEXICAN INFLUX
description: As public schools across Texas open for the year, some districts are reporting increases in enrollments of illegal aliens, but not large ones.

title: Careers; Selecting Marketable Courses
description: AS the college year gets under way, students going through the rites of signing up for courses are perhaps more than ever thinking in terms of job-getting programs.

title: TANNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: the 1981 net includes a gain of $461,000 or 20 cents a shr from settlement of alawsuit

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 15 percent stock divd in Feb

title: A BOOST FOR 'PLEBEIAN' FARE
description: THERE is a category of foods that has been labeled plebeian, peasant style and bourgeois. These foods are also referred to at times as nourishing and stick-to-the-ribs. They are the most basic, country-style, garden-variety vegetables, such as carrots and cabbage, cauliflower and kale, brussels sprouts and broccoli.

title: STATES BALANCING THEIR BUDEGETS IN OBLIQUE WAYS
description: The Federal Government is now considering a legal requirement that its budget be balanced, a mandate that 49 states have already set upon themselves in one form or another. But the methods by which they meet their own laws do not always respond to the intent of the laws.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in the Briefing column on yesterday's Washington Talk page erred in reporting the sources of in- come of The Reporter, a current af- fairs magazine that went out of busi- ness in 1968. A corrective article ap- pears in the Briefing column of today's paper, Page A20.

title: COAL SLURRIES ARE UNNECESSARY
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN AND COUGAR MEET IN THE WEST
description: It was nearly dark when the neighborhood dogs started yapping and howling. But what really got Margaret Boden's attention was a snarling sound, deep, throaty and louder than any cat she had ever heard. She went outside to see what was the matter; that's when she saw the mountain lion.

title: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to the adoption of the LIFO method of inventory valuation for certain inventories

title: POLISH PROTESTERS IN SEVERAL CITIES ROUTED BY POLICE
description: Polish riot policemen fired barrages of tear-gas grenades here and in other cities today to break up demonstrations called by underground Solidarity leaders.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in ''New York Day by Day'' Monday incorrectly identified the donor of an American flag to the Old Stone House in Brooklyn. The flag was the gift of Elizabeth Holtzman, the District Attorney of Kings County.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1982
description: International Widespread protests by Poles prompted the riot police to fire barrages of tear gas at throngs in Warsaw and several other cities. The Government reported clashes lasting up to four hours between the police and thousands of people demonstrating at the behest of leaders of the suspended union Solidarity. (Page A1, Col. 6.) An opening in Swiss bank secrecy was expected by officials in Washington. They said that Swiss bankers had agreed for the first time to relax their rigid secrecy laws to give American officials access to details about customers who use accounts in Swiss banks to evade United States securities laws. (A1:3-4.)

title: A Slot Machine Is a Slot Machine
description: You activate the game by inserting coins. If you win, sirens and bells go off and the machine issues you a ticket for a cash prize. In other words, it's a slot machine. No it isn't, says Hazel Gluck, director of New Jersey's Lottery Division; it's just a reflection of the electronic age we live in and the logical next step for the state lottery.

title: Weinerwald Cites Healthy Sectors
description: The Wienerwald Group is solvent and can continue to operate its healthy sectors, Guenter Steinberg, chairman of Wienerwald Holding A.G., said at a news conference.

title: BRITISH LOAD PARTS FOR SOVIET
description: Huge blue cranes began loading a Soviet ship today with British-made components for the natural gas pipeline that will run from Siberia to Western Europe. It is the second such shipment from Europe in defiance of President Reagan's attempts to block Western help for the project.

title: U.S.-ALASKA LAND SWAP IS SET
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt is planning to exchange land in three national parks in Alaska for state land that now lies within a fourth national park there, the Interior Department said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two articles Sunday on contributions to candidates for the House of Representatives incorrectly stated the total contributions by political action committees to the campaign of Joe Merlino, Democrat of New Jersey. His report to the Federal Election Commission of June 30 cited contributions of $38,762, which placed him 12th nationally, not first, among nonincumbents.

title: CHAMBER MEETS ON TAX RIFT
description: The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, embarrassed by a split between its chairman and president over the $98.3 billion tax increase approved by Congress this month, apparently resolved its differences ''internally'' today in a special closed session of its board of directors.

title: HOW MUCH CAN THE ECOSYSTEM TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: SLAIN MAN HAD ROLE IN INQUIRY
description: Law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday that Nathan Masselli, the slain son of a Federal witness, had been an undercover informant for Leon Silverman, special prosecutor in the investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: STABLE DRESSER'S ROCKY YEAR
description: In its 102-year history, Dresser Industries has been led by only five chief executive officers. Until early this year, it had reported 41 quarters of moderately rising profits.

title: Leader Departing From Britain's BL
description: Sir Michael Edwardes, chairman of BL, the state-owned British auto maker formerly known as British Leyland, has announced in a letter to employees that he is leaving in November.

title: Pipeline Machismo
description: Yesterday's demonstrations may not change the policies of Poland's military rulers. But the brave show of support for political freedom casts a bitter light on the squabble in the West over how to punish the Soviet Union for transgressions against the Polish people.

title: TAX MEASURE OFFERS NEW BENEFITS FOR HOSPICE CARE OF TERMINALLY ILL
description: The tax bill recently passed by Congress contains a provision that is regarded as sure to strengthen a movement providing special care for the dying.

title: Today's Featured Matches; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Vitas Gerulaitis vs. Fritz Buehning. Second Match - Tracy Austin vs.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pacific Telephone Asks for Rate Rise
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had filed with the California Public Utilities Commission for a $864.5 million rate rise, to take effect at the end of 1983.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $31,000 and a gain of $359,076 from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $187,095 from discontinued operations

title: Mao's Widow Expected To Get Sentence Eased
description: Chairman Hu Yaobang of the Chinese Commuinist Party said today that he expects a court to reduce the death sentence of Mao's widow, Jiang Qing, when it comes up for review early next year.

title: Argentines Again Accuse Britons of Buzzing Boats
description: Argentina, in its third protest this month, said today that a British helicopter buzzed two Argentine fishing vessels outside the British-declared exclusion zone around the Falkland Islands.

title: FORCED TO WORK ON THE SIBERIAN PIPELINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Braniff Told to Pay 2 Unions' Pensions
description: The Braniff International Corporation must pay full pension benefits in September to retirees represented by the airline's two largest unions, although retired pilots and managers will see their pension checks cut, a Federal bankruptcy judge said today.

title: Real Estate; Financing Hospital Expansion
description: AT a time of declining Federal subsidies, reduced state money, high interest rates, growing building costs and general economic woes, hospitals are trying to come up with new ideas on how to finance expansions and construction.

title: MRS. KING OUSTED BY MISS MASCARIN, 18
description: Billie Jean King, so glorious at Wimbledon, was beaten on the first day of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday by an unheralded teen-ager, Susan Mascarin.

title: BRIEFING
description: For Sale: Seized Exotica

title: FOSSIL OF HUMANLIKE MAY FILL MAJOR EVOLUTION GAP
description: Paleontologists have unearthed in Kenya the jawbone of a ''humanlike'' creature, believed to be eight million years old, that they say may supply a key link in the fossil record of human evolution.

title: LLOYD WEBBER'S 'CATS' HIS 3D BROADWAY SHOW
description: When ''Cats'' opens on Broadway this month, joining ''Evita'' and ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber will have the extraordinary distinction of seeing three of his shows running on each side of the Atlantic.

title: RUBY GILLESPIE ALLEN
description: Ruby Gillespie Allen, who worked in the New York City school system for more than 25 years, died Monday at New York Hospital after a long illness.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NOVEL ON WORLD WAR III NOW HAS A SEQUEL
description: Three years ago when Macmillan published Gen. Sir John Hackett's novel ''The Third World War: August 1985,'' it scheduled a first printing of 10,000 copies. But the publisher went back to press six more times. The book sold more than 190,000 hardbound copies in the United States and worldwide it has sold some 3 million copies in 10 languages. Now General Hackett is back again, this time with ''The Third World War: The Untold Story,'' in a Macmillan printing of 75,000 copies currently in many bookstores.

title: ISRAEL 'INTOXICATED BY ITS MILITARY POWER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Socal's Belgian Cutback
description: Chevron Oil Belgium, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, said today that it would close its refinery near Brussels. The plant lost $17 million last year and $80 million in the first half of 1982, the company said.

title: YELLOWSTONE GRIZZLY REPORTED IMPERILED
description: Unless something is done soon to stop illegal hunting and control nearby land development, Yellowstone National Park is in danger of losing its grizzly bears, according to a National Park Service memorandum.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
FRENCH FAKE A MURDER TO AID RUMANIAN SPY
description: A Rumanian spy decorated for having ''liquidated'' a political dissident - a murder that in fact never took place - and the man he was supposed to have killed said today that the entire episode had been faked to enable the spy to defect.

title: JAZZ: STING AT LUSH LIFE
description: LEROY JENKINS'S Sting promises to be the violinist's best group since the Revolutionary Ensemble. The new sextet includes two violins, two guitars, drums and electric bass, and had its first club engagement Sunday and Monday at Lush Life, 184 Thompson Street.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
6 Suspicious Fires Strike Boston Neighborhoods
description: Half a dozen suspicious fires erupted in the blue-collar neighborhoods of Boston today just hours after Mayor Kevin H. White increased rewards for turning in arsonists responsible for the city's wave of fires.

title: McDonald's Votes 3-for-2 Stock Split
description: The McDonald's Corporation said its board had voted a 3-for-2 stock split, payable Oct. 6, to shareholders of record Sept. 14.

title: FROM THE MANY REGIONAL COOKBOOKS, A SELECTION OF FAVORITES
description: AS much as one might prize professionalism in the writing of cookbooks, there is an unmistakable charm about many amateur efforts prepared as fund-raisers for good causes. At their best they offer valuable insights into old or quirky regional recipes that do not find their way into mass-appeal, professionally published books. They are often full of lore and history as well. Almost all have the same faults: the imprecision of the recipes, the many dishes based on convenience ingredients (especially dehydrated onion soup mix and canned mushroom soup) and the ''fancy'' salads of diverse ingredients encased in orange or lemon gelatin.

title: EDWIN P. STEVENS
description: Edwin P. Stevens, a former partner in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, died Saturday at his summer home in Biddeford Pool, Me. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CUOMO HAILED BY STATE A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Greeted by amplified music from the movie ''Rocky'' and an auditorium filled with applauding union members, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo promised ''jobs and justice'' today and appealed to the State A.F.L.-C.I.O. to help him win the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Comings and Goings
description: The last-place Toronto Blue Jays have rehired Manager Bobby Cox and his four-man coaching staff for next season. Cox was signed to a oneyear contract before this season. ... John Giles of the Vancouver Whitecaps has been voted coach of the year in the North American Soccer League.

title: Travelers' Manville Plan
description: The Travelers Corporation said today that it had proposed a temporary solution for paying settlement and defense costs in liability claims filed against the Manville Corporation. Under the plan, insurance companies involved in the case would contribute to a pooled fund until the court resolved complicated coverage issues. Travelers provided primary general liability insurance policies to Manville from 1947 to 1976.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES' BOGGS RETURNS AND HALTS PHILLIES BY 3-0

title: ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: the company is a unit of Gulf & Western Industries

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INCREASINGLY, THE BUSINESS DAY BEGINS AT BREAKFAST
description: It's a few minutes past 5 A.M., more than an hour before sunrise, and the vacationing Federal city seems to have succumbed to siege by a million chattering crickets. The Capitol, as usual, glows bright like an alabaster moon while the White House lies eerily shrouded in the late-summer dark.

title: AIDES SAID TO URGE PRESIDENT TO EASE PIPELINE SANCTIONS
description: Four senior Administration officials recommended to President Reagan today that he soften his trade sanctions against the European companies that violate his Soviet pipeline embargo, an Administration official reported today.

title: Iowa Nonregistrant Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Gary J. Eklund for failing to register with the Selective Service. Mr. Ekland, 22 years old, is the sixth person indicted in a crackdown by the Reagan Administration on nonregistrants.

title: SOME ADVICE ON HOW TO PRODUCE A COOKBOOK
description: THE Hays, Rolfes & Associates consulting company in Memphis has some suggestions for organizations that are considering publishing a cookbook to raise funds.

title: Just Waiting to Be Collected
description: T his is a time of year when banks in New York are required by law to inform depositors about unclaimed property on their books - basically accounts that have lain dormant for five years. Any unclaimed money will be turned over the state treasury Nov. 1.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:35 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT SHOOTING DOWN SYRIAN PHOTO JET
description: The Israeli military command said today that a Syrian MIG-25 on a photographic reconnaissance mission had been shot down over the Beirut area, and that no Syrian aircraft would be permitted to cross the cease-fire lines into the airspace over Israeli-held parts of Lebanon.

title: Soccer Bagels
description: Having dropped its nationally known basketball program, the University of San Francisco has turned to promoting the other sport in which it has a national reputation - soccer. The Dons have won four National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, although they had to vacate their 1978 title because a player was found to have forged a transcript to make himself eligible.

title: THOUSANDS OF POLES CLASH WITH RIOT POLICE IN THE STREETS OF GDANSK
description: Polish riot policemen used tear gas, water cannons, flares and concussion grenades today to beat back thousands of anti-Government demonstrators in this port city where the Solidarity union was signed into existence after a victorious strike two years ago.

title: Sorrel in Jewish Dish
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Sorrel, which many Americans are discovering (''Americans Are Discovering the Pungent Personality of Sorrel, Aug. 11), has been used for decades by the Jewish community as a cold soup called schav.

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boat Found Afire On L.I. Sound
description: A 36-foot cabin cruiser was found burning at anchor this morning on Long Island Sound, off New Rochelle. United States Coast Guard officials said they did not believe anyone had been aboard the craft.

title: NEGATIVE POLITICAL ADS BACKED
description: ''Negative campaigning,'' especially television commercials that attack opponents, is likely to become a lasting feature of the political scene, a leading Republican pollster contends.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VIEWS OF THE SOUTH

title: On the Boxing Beat
description: Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association's light-heavyweight champion, was at a midtown news conference with fourth-ranked John Davis to announce formally their title fight on Sept. 18 in Atlantic City. It could have been easy for the champion to look beyond Davis, because among those present was Dwight Braxton, the World Boxing Council's titleholder, whom Spinks hopes to meet in a unification bout in the winter.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Good News for the City
description: N ow that the phrases ''New York'' and ''fiscal crisis'' are no longer inextricably linked, there are occasional notes of upbeat news about municipal finances. A few were struck yesterday on Park Avenue at the law firm of Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison.

title: Commodity Options Set
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today designated four commodities exchanges to trade options on futures contracts, as part of a three-year pilot program, beginning Oct.1.

title: Campaign Outlook; First of a series of articles on the 1982 Congressional campaign.
description: Authorities in both major parties forecast difficulty for the Republican Party in this fall's election in holding together the coalition of voters, including many traditional Democrats, that won the Presidency for Ronald Reagan in 1980. Although most campaigns for the Senate and House have yet to take shape, doubts have been voiced that the Republicans can retain the kind of broad support that coalesced two years ago behind Mr. Reagan and other party conservatives.

title: THOSE MUSICAL GALAS THAT MARK MILESTONES
description: AS our major musical institutions - the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera and Carnegie Hall -approach or proceed through their second century of life, a genre of musical performance is coming to maturity. It will probably play an increasingly important part in our musical culture. It might be called the ''institutional performance.''

title: 'COMMUNIST THREAT' LOOMS LARGE IN TAIWAN LIFE
description: Even through the late-summer haze, the shoreline of mainland China is clearly visible from the small island of Quemoy 180 miles west of Taipei.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Not by Bread Alone

title: The Police Blotter
description: A Bronx resident identified as 77-year-old James Briggs was found bound and stabbed to death shortly after noon yesterday in his apartment at 1790 Story Avenue, part of a public-housing project in the Clasons Point section. .. Two men drinking in a Brooklyn afterhours club at 4:30 A.M. yesterday announced a holdup, took out guns and, apparently meeting resistance, seriously wounded three employees of the club at 2210 Church Avenue, in the Flatbush section. The gunmen escaped. The police identified the victims as Charles Ramsey, 44; Calvin Watson, 21, and Amelia Richardson, all of Brooklyn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Jordan is a home to Palestinians on Jordanian soil but this has never been a substitute, even under the Constitution which brought the unity of the East and West Banks in the early 1950's.

title: SWISS BANKERS EXPECTED TO RELAX SECRECY ON U.S. STOCK VIOLATIONS
description: Swiss bankers are believed to have agreed today to relax their rigid secrecy laws to give United States officials access to details about customers who use Swiss bank accounts to circumvent American securities laws.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C.R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., has named David W. Prigmore group executive.

title: 1,600 LEAVE BEIRUT BY LAND AND SEA
description: About 1,600 more Syrian troops and Palestinian guerrillas left west Beirut today, and Lebanese and Israeli officials said the withdrawal might end Wednesday.

title: Group Assails Rules Changes On Education of Handicapped
description: The American Foundation for the Blind asked the Reagan Administration today to stop any efforts to relax rules on the education of the handicapped.

title: AGENT ORANGE STUDY WON'T BE COMPLETED UNTIL '89, V.A. SAYS
description: The Veterans Administration said today it would probably take until 1988 or 1989 to complete a study on whether exposure to the toxic herbicide Agent Orange damaged the health of Vietnam veterans or their offspring.

title: GUIDRY WINS 100TH ON NETTLES CLOUT IN 9TH
description: Ron Guidry pitched in the Metrodome for the second time tonight, and this time he kept the ball on the playing field as the Yankees defeated the Minnesota Twins, 3-1.

title: No Interview With G.I., North Koreans Say
description: North Korea refused a United Nations request today for an interview with a G.I. who it said crossed the demilitarized zone and asked for political asylum.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $58,000 for the qr and $225,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $275,000 for the qr and $2.5 million for the 9 mos; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the LIFO method of accounting for inventories adopted in the fourth qr of 1981

title: NORTHWEST ACCEPTANCE reports earnings for QTr to July 31
People
description: * George G. Guimaraes has joined SSC&B/New York as an executive vice president.

title: PLAYS
description: B ob Watson sat on the Atlanta Braves' bench for more than seven hours Monday night, first watching his team lose to the Phillies, 6-1, and then watching as the Braves lost an early five-run lead in the second game of a doubleheader at Philadelphia. He continued to be a bench spectator until well after midnight as the game went into extra innings.

title: U.S. to Aid Areas Near Philippine Bases
description: The United States signed an agreement with the Philippines today under which it will spend $50 million on developing areas surrounding the American bases in the country, the presidential palace said.

title: Why Cover Up?
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In answer to Jacqueline Morse, who comments on Enid Nemy's article of July 14, ''Hiding What a Swimsuit Reveals'': It is a sad commentary indeed that our beauty- and youth-oriented society forces people to want to cover up their less than perfect bodies.

title: Conductor's Body Is Found in Pond
description: State police recovered the body of Calvin Simmons, the Oakland, Calif., symphony conductor, from Connery Pond near here today after 11 days of searching.

title: Sculpture Leaving U.N. Site
description: D uring the June 12 peace march, thousands assembled near it in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, but the War Resisters League can only assume that its sculpture of a giant red Stop sign - with a raised hand warning ''Stop World War III'' - was seen by disarmament delegates and others wrangling at the United Nations.

title: GREYHOUND LINES OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $632,285 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of property

title: Outpatient Is Held In Trooper's Death
description: A 33-year-old man with a history of violent outbursts and treatment at mental hospitals was charged with first-degree murder today in the death of a state trooper, officials said.

title: G.M. LOWERS PRICES ON MANY 1983 CARS
description: Reacting to the worst auto sales in two decades, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it would lower or freeze the prices of half its 1983-model cars.

title: ONLY AGE CAN OUTSTARE MRS. KING
description: B efore she went out to play on center court at the United States Open yesterday, Susan Mascarin was warned by her coach not to look at her opponent because ''Billie Jean can outstare me, I think.''

title: EFFECTS OF EXERCISE ON MENSTRUATION
description: * A 14-year-old junior high school student who is an excellent swimmer was barred from interscholastic competition because she had not yet begun to menstruate.

title: Losing Track of Timepieces
description: P inchas and Eugenia Zukerman seem to have their troubles with time.

title: At 38, McGraw Still Has a Ball
description: How does a professional athlete celebrate a 38th birthday? If you're Tug McGraw, the former Mets relief pitcher who now performs for the Philadelphia Phillies, you go out to the ball park, sit around for 19 innings and seven hours, then get called on to pitch at a critical moment.

title: U.S. Planning Aid at Border
description: As much as $200 million in loans and guarantees will be available to companies near the Mexican border that were hurt by the devaluation of the peso, the Small Business Administration said today.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: MAJOR CHANGES ARE EXPECTED
description: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, today opened the 12th congress of the Chinese Communist party, which is expected to abolish the party chairmanship and thoroughly revamp the leadership.

title: U.S. to Help Jersey Buy Pinelands Site
description: A $2.8 million grant to New Jersey to purchase 7,000 acres in the Bass River area of the Pinelands National Reserve has been approved by Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have an old iron skillet that has been in my family for half a century. It is unusable at the moment because of a thick layer of rust, top and bottom. I am told that there are special ways to ''cure'' iron skillets. Can you tell me how?

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE;
description: The recent announcement by the Environmental Protection Agency of new regulations governing lead levels in gasoline seemed to be a startling departure from the Reagan Administration's pattern of changing environmental and public health rules to ease their burden on industry.

title: No Zenith Payout
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation said it would omit the quarterly dividend.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $315,000 for the qr and yr

title: THE MAGIC DIES HARD AT SHEA
description: T his was before the bad news about Phil Simms. This was on Friday night, when somebody decided to go to Shea because Joe Torre was back in town and, according to the weather report, it was supposed to rain on the Mets' losing streak and if somebody stayed home he would have to watch Torontos with names like Garth Iorg and Rance Mulliniks subdue the doughty Steins of Brenner while listening to Rizzuto continue to be mystified by the existence of nations as far away and as enigmatical as Canada.

title: Books: Dewey's Career
description: THOMAS E. DEWEY AND HIS TIMES. By Richard Norton Smith. 703 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.50.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Advertising; Videotex In Years To Come
description: Bemused, bothered and bewildered about the fledgling video screen technologies known generically as videotex? Relax - your troubles are over. Put your feet up on your limousine's jump seat. Slip off your Guccis. Ask your chauffeur to mute the Muzak.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WINE TALK
description: VINEBURG, Calif. HUGGING the green flanks of the Mayacamas Mountains in the Sonoma Valley is one of California's oldest wineries, founded in 1858 by Jacob Gundlach, a German brewer who emigrated to San Francisco in 1851 and decided he preferred wine making to beer brewing. He found a site near the village of Sonoma, planted vines on 400 acres there and built a stone winery against a limestone hillside. His vines thrived, and the place became known as Vineburg, which has its own post office today.

title: MOB ALLIANCE TO SHARE CASINO RICHES REPORTED
description: With fabulous riches pouring into this old resort city from casino gambling, the major organized-crime ''families'' of New York and Philadelphia have formed an alliance to share the wealth, law-enforcement officials have concluded after more than four years of constant surveillance and investigation. ''They've set up a kind of free-trade zone,'' said George E. Wilson, who heads the Camden field office of the Federal Justice Department's Strike Force on Organized Crime.

title: The Talk of Manville
description: The Manville Corporation created this town, built it, named it. It donated the land for the high school football field and the money for the ambulances, the pipe for the water system and the brick and mortar for Borough Hall and two firehouses.

title: 8.01 GAIN PUTS DOW OVER 900
description: The stock market's rally caught fire again yesterday with a broad advance that sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its first closing above 900 in a year. Trading was heavy.

title: U.S. SAYS REPRESSION WILL NOT SOLVE POLAND'S ILLS
description: The State Department said today that demonstrations in Poland ''show once again that repression will not solve Poland's problems'' and called for ''reconciliation'' in that nation.

title: Same Problems
description: The University of Tennessee is planning to build a $30-million arena for basketball and other events, such as concerts, on its Knoxville campus. In preparation, the university's athletic director, Bob Woodruff, yesterday brought an architect and an engineer to East Rutherford, N.J., to examine Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Hearst Purchase
description: The Hearst Corporation said it had completed the previously announced acquisitions of Redbook magazine and Charter Data Services, a magazine subscription fulfillment company, from the Charter Company. Both companies declined to disclose terms of the transaction, but it reportedly involved about $23 million in cash and notes, as well as payments based on Redbook's future performance.

title: Produce Recall in 3 States
description: A food wholesale concern is recalling produce from 700 grocery stores in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa because of a leak of the toxic chemical, polychlorinated biphenyl, or PCB, at a warehouse. Gateway Foods Inc. announced the recall Monday after Federal officials said the leak from an electrical transformer might have contaminated some items.

title: A CHIP OFF THE OLD BLOC
description: Bulgaria is probably the only country - Communist or not - where the Russians are neither feared nor hated.

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Diet for 'Brute Strength'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: It is commendable that athletes are taking nutrition into account when making food choices (''The Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner of Champions,'' Aug. 11).

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard CAMUS. By Patrick McCarthy. 359 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Guardian Plant
description: The Guardian Industries Corporation, a flat glass manufacturer, said it had signed a definitive agreement to purchase a reflective glass facility in Northville, Mich., from the Airco Inc. unit of BOC International Ltd. for undisclosed terms. In an unrelated development, Continental Mortgage Investors, which has been operating under Chapter 10 of the Bankruptcy Act since 1976, said it had signed a letter of intent under which Guardian Industries would invest $25 million in the company to aid Continental Mortgage's plan of reorganization.

title: AIRLINE COLLECTING HIGHER TAX
description: Airline passengers began paying a higher Federal tax on tickets today in line with legislation passed 12 days ago but as yet unsigned by the President.

title: UNITED ARTISTS GETS INTERIM CHIEF
description: Frank E. Rosenfelt was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of United Artists, the movie studio, until a permanent appointment is found. The posts have been empty since David Begelman was removed in July.

title: Ingrid Bergman Is Cremated At Private London Ceremony
description: The body of Ingrid Bergman was cremated today at a private funeral ceremony attended only by close relatives and five friends.

title: Mrs. Gandhi to Visit Soviet
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, whose visit to the Soviet Union was postponed from June to September, will make the visit Sept. 20 to 26, officials said today.

title: Muncie Rejoins Team
description: Chuck Muncie, the running back, reported to the San Diego Chargers yesterday after three weeks of drug treatment. Muncie left training camp at La Jolla, Calif., on Aug. 9 for what the club called ''a second phase of rehabilitation'' after missing a bed check and a practice.

title: Spanish Socialists Seek Safeguards on Bases
description: Spain's Socialist Party, favored to win next month's scheduled general elections, said today that it would demand changes in the Washington-Madrid defense pact signed in June and not yet ratified by the Parliament.

title: Feature Matches At Open Today; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Chris Evert Lloyd vs. Kelly Henry. Second Match - Yannick Noah vs.

title: 101-Year-Old Man Is Found After a Day Lost in Rockies
description: A 101-year-old man reported missing during a mushroom hunt near Beaver Lake in the Colorado Rockies was found today, scraped and scratched from a night in the wild but otherwise unharmed.

title: TOUGH AND RESILIANT AT AGE 17
description: I n the days when women were supposed to step daintily on a tennis court and never raise a sweat, Andrea Jaeger would have been called a tomboy. She is a street-fighter, compared with the seemingly unemotional programmed manner of Tracy Austin, or the gracefulness projected by Chris Evert Lloyd. Understand that Miss Jaeger likes being called tough. But those qualities can work against a tennis player, too, and in Miss Jaeger's case, they have threatened her career.

title: Missing Plane Found; No Survivors Reported
description: A military cargo plane, missing on a training mission with a crew of nine, was found late tonight in a wooded area about 30 miles south of Knoxville, Tenn., the Air Force said.

title: Western Airlines
description: Western Airlines of Los Angeles announced it had signed a master agreement covering all the debt that had been in technical default because of a violation of loan covenants setting certain debt-toequity ratios and minimum net worth requirements. The company said it had never been behind in payments of principal and interest, and that the lenders had granted interim waivers allowing it to go forth on a ''survival plan'' aimed it restoring it to profitability by restructuring management, gaining wage concessions and establishing a hub-and-spoke route system centered in Salt Lake City.

title: Three Mergers Of Thrift Units
description: Federal regulators have approved three mergers of savings and loan associations, officials said today, bringing the year's total to 28, compared with 23 in 1981 and 11 in 1980.

title: Newbery Energy
description: The Newbery Energy Corporation of Phoenix said it had signed a final agreement with a group of Canadian lenders that releases it from the $11 million (Canadian) of guaranteed debt and other financial obligations of a Canadian subsidiary to those lenders. Under the agreement, Newbery paid $2 million (Canadian) and issued warrants to Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Saskatchewan Economic Development and CCB Leasing Ltd. to buy about 158,000 shres of Newbery common stock for $1 a share. A separate agreement with the Montreal Trust Company allows Newbery to pledge a $100,000 (Canadian) deposit as additional collateral to a Montreal Trust loan and releases Newbery from its guarantee.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Met's Art Visiting Various Neighborhoods

title: A BOUNTIFUL COLLECTION OF NEW WORDS IS OUT
description: The second college edition of the American Heritage Dictionary, containing 1,568 pages and 200,000 definitions, has begun moving into bookstores. Hailed by its publisher, the Houghton Mifflin Company, as the first new dictionary in 10 years, the book includes 10,000 new general vocabulary words and meanings and 5,000 drawn from the fields of applied science, computer science and technology.

title: YANKEES, RIGHETTI ROUTED
description: The Yankees tried for the third time this season to go five games over .500 tonight, but once again they were thwarted as the Minnesota Twins knocked out Dave Righetti in the fourth inning and went on to win, 7-2.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hinckley Letter for Sale

title: ISRAEL REACTS ANGRILY TO PLAN; News Analysis
description: In his appeal for a new effort to solve the Israeli-Arab dispute, President Reagan moved from the role of a mediator to that of a full participant in the negotations, laying out by far the most detailed formula for a settlement offered so far by the United States.

title: KEEP I.M.F. STRONG
description: The Reagan Administration's misguided policy toward the World Bank and International Monetary Fund is contributing to the gloom and pessimism that will accompany their annual meetings next week. The Administration is intent upon abandoning Washington's traditional leadership role in both institutions. True, the bank and I.M.F. undoubtedly make the world a better, more stable place to live in, but there is a more compelling argument for vigorous United States support for them: old-fashioned economic self-interest.

title: Lewis, Stanger Golf Co-Medalists
description: Bob Lewis, a Walker Cup player, and Bob Stanger, competing in the event for the first time, shared medalist honors, and the defending champion Nathaniel Crosby led the qualifiers today at the United States Amateur golf tournament.

title: Plane Off Course Before Collision
description: A single-engine airplane in which two men were killed last Sunday after a collision with another aircraft was slightly off course at the time of the accident, a Federal official said today.

title: RESISTING THE DRAFT
description: Of the approximately 8.5 million Americans required to register for the draft, 700,000 have not. This represents a serious challenge to democratic government. We must not allow a small minority to thwart the people's will as expressed in an act of Congress.

title: GATX Unit Shut
description: The General American Transportation Company announced that it would temporarily close its Sharon, Pa., tank car manufacturing facility, idling 500 employees. The gradual shutdown will be completed in November.

title: BULGARIA, ON THE U.S.
description: ''How far can you go in this confrontation started by the Reagan Administration against the socialist countries? I keep wondering whether there are any sober-minded people in the United States who have an understanding of what 'thermonuclear' means. What will happen to the planet, to humanity in general?''

title: WHITE HOUSE REMAINS EVER POPULAR
description: While the decline in the economy has caused a slowdown in the annual summer flow of tourists to many Washington attractions, the White House remains the most consistent draw.

title: Almost Half of Salvador Is Now Without Lights
description: Nearly 50 percent of El Salvador has been blacked out by sabotage against power installations, military officials said today.

title: A PEEK AT U.S. ORCHESTRAS' FINANCES
description: ONE still hears talk today of an American orchestral ''big five,'' meaning New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago and Cleveland, not necessarily in that order. Sometimes Los Angeles is added to the list, in deference to the size of its budget. But except for the generalized statements in their annual reports, the orchestras remain largely guarded about the details of their income and expenditures. That is why a confidential, comparative financial study of the top 34 American orchestras, prepared by the American Symphony Orchestra League, is of such interest.

title: Bruce Bochy's Big Problem
description: How can anyone playing for the Mets have a big head? Bruce Bochy can't help it. The catcher, who came up from the minors after John Stearns was placed on the disabled list, has always had an extra-large head - size 8.

title: THE HIGH PRICE OF A SHIFT TO PHONETIC SPELLING
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS GAIN SEMIFINALS BY 1-0
description: Steve Hunt ended a frustrating game for the Cosmos here tonight by scoring a goal with 1 minute 38 seconds left for a 1-0 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks and a berth in the semifinal round of the North American Soccer league playoffs.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS BAR LOCKOUT OF PLAYERS
description: The National Football League Management Council, after a meeting with league executives that lasted most of the afternoon, announced last night that the club owners would not lock out the players despite the absence of a collective-bargaining agreement.

title: REGAN ASSERTS U.S. WILL SHARPLY EASE PIPELINE SANCTIONS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration would sharply reduce the scope of sanctions it had applied against two French companies that shipped equipment to the Soviet Union for its natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $420,000

title: MEMO CAUTIONS ON STRIP MINING IN U.S. PARKS
description: The National Park Service has warned that rule changes being considered by the Office of Surface Mining could lead to strip mining in 26 national parks.

title: HEAD OF S.B.A. PRAISES A PLANT IN SOUTH BRONX
description: The head of the Federal Small Business Administration toured a South Bronx manufacturing company yesterday and found it a ''great example of success.''

title: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'NETWORKS LISTEN WHEN MONEY RUSTLES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cranston Tells Metal Workers He May Run for White House
description: Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, said again Tuesday that he was ''inclined'' to run for President because he felt President Reagan was ravaging vitally needed social programs with ''severe'' budget cuts.

title: F.D.I.C. Issues Securities Ruling
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, citing a 1981 Supreme Court decision, declared today that Federal law allows nonbanking subsidiaries of banks that do not belong to the Federal Reserve System to engage in the securities business.

title: SHORT TERM RATES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Short-term rates rose and long-term rates fell yesterday, but in most cases the changes were very slight. Securities dealers said that the increase in short-term rates was a reflection of the higher rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market, which averaged about 11 3/8 percent, compared with 9.96 percent in the previous six days and 9.04 percent in the week ended Aug. 25. Dealers' financing costs also increased, with overnight borrowings secured by Treasury securities rising to 8 3/4 percent, up half a percentage point.

title: TAKEOVER PLEASES U.S. BANKS
description: The nationalization yesterday of Mexico's private banks was decreed by the Government to save them from insolvency, according to bankers in the United States.

title: THE HIGH PRICE OF A SHIFT TO PHONETIC SPELLING
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Yacht Wins
description: The United States defender, Patient Lady V, won her second race from the Italian catamaran Signor G in the 17th Little America's Cup series today on Long Island Sound off Norwalk, Conn.

title: ON THE HILL, THE TOURIST BUSINESS IS BIG BUSINESS
description: From March through October they come by the thousands, dressed in shorts, three-piece suits, saris and tennis warm-ups, speaking English, French, German and Japanese, carrying babies, backpacks and cameras - the ubiquitous Washington tourists.

title: MASSELLI SLAYING SUSPECT IS PICKED OUT IN A LINEUP
description: Salvatore Odierno, the chief suspect in the slaying of Nathan Masselli, a Federal informant, was picked out of a police lineup yesterday by a witness to the slaying, law-enforcement officials disclosed.

title: MISERY A COMMUTER ON L.I. EXPRESSWAY
description: It sometimes seems that Long Islanders have three things in common - a belief that anyone who moves to Manhattan is enormously wealthy or short of common sense, a suspicion of local officials who want to raise property taxes and a sure knowledge that no force can improve conditions on the Long Island Expressway.

title: SOVIET ARMS-CONTROL EXPERT ASKS NUCLEAR BALANCE
description: A member of the Soviet General Staff has said in an interview here that no arms control agreement ''will be of any value'' if the United States starts a cruise missile race while seeking reduction in the number of heavy missiles.

title: Painted Screens
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In Michael Wentzel's article on Baltimore's painted window screens (''Baltimore Folk Art Form,'' Aug. 12) he penetrates no farther than the surface when he says that there will be a ''small'' exhibition of screens in the fall. In fact, this will be the first major display in the United States of this unique urban folk art.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ISRAEL REACTS ANGRILY TO PLAN; Transcript of speech, page A11.
description: President Reagan, calling for a ''fresh start'' in the Middle East peace process, tonight endorsed ''full autonomy'' under some form of Jordanian supervision for Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: McCann-Erickson Closing Chicago Office
description: McCann-Erickson is closing its full-service Chicago office, either at the end of the year or whenever its clients have become established with other ad agencies, it was announced by Willard C. Mackey Jr., president and chief executive officer of McCann-Erickson Worldwide.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
ISRAEL REACTS ANGRILY TO PLAN
description: Israeli officials reacted angrily today to a letter from President Reagan that was reported to have asked for a freeze on Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and to have suggested that the territories ultimately be linked in confederation with Jordan.

title: MEXICO SEIZING BANKS TO CURTAIL FLIGHT OF CAPITAL
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo announced today that private banks would be nationalized to end the ''looting'' of Mexico through the flight of capital.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ballet Theater to Offer New Scholarship Program

title: CITY ENFORCES NEW RULES ON TOXIC CARGOES
description: Amid confusion and traffic tie-ups, new regulations restricting the transportation of hazardous materials through New York City took effect yesterday. The rules virtually eliminate the use of Manhattan streets as a truckers' shortcut between New Jersey and New England.

title: G.N.P. Falls In Canada
