description: Canada's gross national product tumbled 2.1 percent in the quarter ended June 30 and is falling at the fastest annual rate since World War II, according to Government statistics released today.

title: Washington and Lee Selects New President
description: Dr. John D. Wilson, 51 years old, executive vice president and provost at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, was named president today of Washington and Lee University.

title: JUDGE RULES SMOKE VICTIM LEGALLY HANDICAPPED
description: A man who gets sick around tobacco smoke is legally handicapped, but smokers have rights, too, a nonsmoking Federal district judge says.

title: Schmidt in Skirmish With Economy Minister
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt sharply criticized Minister for Economic Affairs Otto Lambsdorff today for remarks Mr. Lambsdorff made in a newspaper interview.

title: CHATMAN ADJUSTING TO GIANTS
description: After Cliff Chatman, a fourthround draft choice, reported to training camp last season, the Giants were disappointed. Now that they have had their first look at him in a game, they are pleasantly surprised.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS TO NATION ON WEST BANK AND PALESTINIANS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech tonight on the Middle East, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: FRANCE IN BUDGET SHIFT, TO CURB STATE SPENDING
description: France's Socialist Government today conceded the failure of its attempt to spend its way out of the world recession: It introduced a cautious 1983 budget that puts the emphasis on controlling public expenditures, fighting inflation and staving off a third devaluation of the franc.

title: Norris-Lindsay Case
description: Bruce Norris, who sold the Detroit Red Wings last spring, is deeply involved in litigation with Ted Lindsay, his former general manager and coach. In 1977, when Lindsay was hired as general manager, he and Norris reached an oral agreement that was to cover the next five years.

title: HERS
description: ISUPPOSE I should have been flattered. Would I, the ABC News producer wanted to know, go to Israel? Sure, I said, flashing back to my last trip there in '69, when nice old Look magazine sent me over to do the women's army. Gee, I thought, maybe ABC wants the same story -or maybe something on a kibbutz - or maybe .... But when I stopped fluttering and started listening I found out the producer didn't want me to cover the women's army, but the men's. He wasn't asking me to go over there and soak up a commune, but to beef up the front. He was inviting me to be ''their man,'' as John Chancellor used to say, in Israel. A big assignment. An assignment that could really get you somewhere. An assignment to which you'd have to be crazy to say no.

title: METS WIN AFTER 15 LOSSES
description: It wasn't quite like winning a World Series, but the Mets ended their losing streak, the longest in the major leagues this season, at 15 games last night.

title: LEADERS SAY VETO WILL BE SUSTAINED
description: Congressional leaders of both parties unanimously predicted today that President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental appropriation bill would be sustained when Congress reconvenes next week.

title: McCoy Industries
description: McCoy Industries, a wood products manufacturer, said it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: DR. BENJAMIN F. BARNES
description: Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, a general physician and psychiatrist who was a former Mayor of Yonkers, died Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived in Water Mill, L.I.

title: OUT OF THE WAY STORAGE UNITS THAT HANG FROM THE CEILING
description: THE Safavis, Bijan and Zuzu, represent a typical young couple in a typical situation. He is an architect who works from his home; she has a press liaison post at the United Nations. They have a 4-yearold daughter, Nili.

title: Gomulka's Polish Pride
description: The career of Wladislaw Gomulka, who died yesterday at the age of 77, was defined by the nationalist workers' movements that prepared the ground for Solidarity. If this week's massive demonstrations against the regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski reflect the continued strength of those movements, they also echo the events of Mr. Gomulka's years in power.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The shr earnings for the yr-ago periods are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stocksplit issued in June 1981

title: YANKS SOUGHT ANGELS' BAYLOR
description: In their protracted negotiations with the California Angels over a trade for Tommy John, the Yankees tried diligently to gain the right to talk to and, if possible, sign Don Baylor, the Angels' designated hitter, before Baylor could become a free agent.

title: POLAND DISCLOSES TWO DEATHS IN TUESDAY'S PROTESTS
description: Two demonstrators were shot and killed in the copper-mining town of Lubin, the Polish authorities said today, as details began to emerge about Tuesday's protests.

title: Nuclear Policy for 10,000 Years
description: Is Congress capable of finding a rational solution to the problem of nuclear waste disposal? Not long ago the House Energy and Commerce Committee bravely grasped the nettle and resolved that a national nuclear waste depository should be established. Startled by its courage, the committee then quickly added an amendment that effectively bars any member's state, or indeed any other known state of the Union, from being chosen as the site of the repository.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Herbert Mitgang THE SEVENTY MILLION DOLLAR DECIMAL. By Matthew J. Culligan. 304 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95. THE LAST OF ALL POSSIBLE WORLDS. By Peter F. Drucker. 218 pages. Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: Low Inflation in Japan
description: Japan had the world's lowest inflation rate last year, 4.7 percent, down from 7.1 percent in 1980, the International Labor Organization reported today. Argentina had the highest inflation, 131.3 percent, up from 87.6 percent.

title: OUR FRIENDS IN GRENADA
description: To the Editor:

title: The Golden Road
description: Chauffeuring tennis players to and from the All England Club has been a custom during the Wimbledon championships.

title: Sawdon & Bess Wins A Wendy's Account
description: Wendy's International has named Sawdon & Bess the advertising agency for its Northeast region (New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island). The region, comprising about 90 restaurants, was previously handled by Savitt Tobias Balk, which had to relinquish the $1.5 million account because of a conflict resulting from its acquisition in July by Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, agency for the local McDonald's business.

title: Civil Servants Strike In British Columbia
description: Government workers here walked off the job here today for the second time in less than a month.

title: LED SOCIAL REFORM
description: Helen Hall, an internationally known social service leader and executive director of New York City's Henry Street Settlement from 1933 to 1967, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: THE REAL SEASON
description: H orse racing returned to Belmont Park yesterday after a month at Saratoga and every big horse in the country was either quartered there or headed there. And for the best of reasons. During the next 38 days, one of them will win the title that brings the most glory and the most money in racing: horse of the year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Tonight I am calling for a fresh start. This is the moment for all those directly concerned to get involved -or lend their support - to a workable basis for peace.

title: INGENIOUS REMEDIES FOR TOO-SMALL APARTMENTS
description: FOR years, one of the most available types of Manhattan apartment was the one-bedroom rental in a postwar high-rise. Though boxy in shape and predictable in layout, their crisp white walls and modern appliances were well suited to one or two people.

title: Special Pay At Pillsbury
description: A Pillsbury Company executive will be paid $350,000 in addition to his salary of more than $300,000 a year because of job-related inconvenience.

title: Market Place; A 'Buy Allis' Scenario
description: CHALMERS, which is experiencing its most troubled period in years, is trading below 10, as it did in 1974 - when it was in worse condition. But a few fans argue that Allis is a slimmer, more viable company today - far less dependent on farmers than International Harvester, whose deep-set problems reflect the depression in agriculture.

title: Topics Cultural Imperatives
description: Tears

title: A 'SURPLUS POPULATION' FATHERED BY POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCURY MORRIS'S OTHER IDENTITY
description: Others still call him Mercury, but Eugene Morris calls himself Gene. He chooses the more common name because he knows himself to be a frightened man facing at least 15 years in jail for trafficking in cocaine, rather than the quicksilver running back who starred for the Miami Dolphins' undefeated 1972 team.

title: Lebanese Paper Puts Toll at 17,825 Killed
description: The independent daily An Nahar tonight was preparing to publish an estimate of the dead and wounded since the Israeli invasion that puts the total, not including Israelis, at 17,825 dead and 30,103 wounded.

title: Tropical Storm Beryl Moves Slowly Across East Atlantic
description: The slightly weakened tropical storm Beryl moved slowly across the eastern Atlantic Ocean today, and forecasters watched two other tropical disturbances they said were causing rain in the Bahamas and the Caribbean.

title: SAFETY UNIT STRESSES ALCOHOL HAZARD
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is best known for the grisly work it does sifting through the remains of airliners for clues to crashes.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IN the last few years devices for hiding and protecting valuables in the home have proliferated. They range from a false-front electrical wall outlet that swings open and a hollow book to small safes to be installed in the floor and fireproof files for papers.

title: 50-Year High For Failures
description: More businesses failed last week than in any week since the Depression, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a business information concern, said yesterday.

title: RAP MUSIC: KURTIS BLOW
description: FRESH from serving as host for the Clash concert at Pier 84 on Tuesday, Kurtis Blow, the king of rap music, appeared at the Peppermint Lounge with a six-piece band and put on a show of impressive polish and humor.

title: Bond Issue Authorized For Coast Train Service
description: The California Legislature has authorized the issuance of $1.12 billion in tax-exempt state revenue bonds to set up a 160 mile-an-hour train service between Los Angeles and San Diego.

title: Cobb's Corner
description: Even after Don King, the promoter, announced last week that Randall (Tex) Cobb would challenge Larry Holmes for the World Boxing Council heavyweight title, probably in November, Cobb was still undecided.

title: SECURITIES SALE RULE EXTENDED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended for one year the so-called shelf-registration rule for bringing new securities to market. The rule, originally adopted in March, was extended one year beyond its original expiration date of Dec. 10, 1982.

title: MOVE ON HINCKLEY POEM GAILS
description: The Justice Department said today that it had decided not to prosecute The National Enquirer for publishing a purported ''threat'' by John W. Hinckley Jr. to murder Jodie Foster.

title: Phillips Petroleum
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced the sale of its Phillips Products Company subsidiary to Duraco Products Inc., a new company controlled principally by Phillips Products employees.

title: Insurance Unit Bought
description: The Continental Corporation and Penncorp Financial Inc. said yesterday that a subsidiary of Continental had purchased the William Penn Life Insurance Company of New York, which principally writes individual life insurance and annuities, from a subsidiary of Penncorp for $22 million. The deal has been approved by directors of both companies and by regulatory authorities.

title: WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Plant and Transplant Plants wind down top growth at this time of year and concentrate energy on establishing roots, which makes September ideal for digging and dividing spring-blooming perennials. New perennials, especially peonies and poppies, must be planted this month. Fall is also the best season to move trees and shrubs, both evergreen and deciduous. Before any plants are transplanted, the soil must be prepared well. Incorporate a three- to four-inch layer of peat moss or better, well-rotted compost, into each planting hole or flower bed. Plant spring-flowering hardy bulbs, particularly the little bulbs that bloom early: crocus, snowdrop, glory of the snow, squills, winter aconite, puschkinia and windflower. These are best tucked near the house where the early flowers can seen. Lawn Care This is the month to complete lawn care. Cool growing weather is ideal for grass plants to establish roots, whether sod or seed. If the lawn is thriving now, it may not need to be fertilized until later in the year, after leaves fall and before cold weather. If the lawn is skimpy, apply fertilizer now. Follow application rates given on the bag, and distribute only with a mechanical spreader to prevent overdoses and burning. If the lawn has not been limed in recent years, it may need it. A pH reading somewhere between 6 and 7 is ideal for lawns; otherwise, soil nutrients are not soluble. To be sure, make an accurate soil test with home kits available at most garden centers.

title: CALENDAR: DESIGNERS ON TAPE
description: Interior Design: The New Freedom, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS ARE LOSING U.S. AID
description: The Federal Government is sharply cutting back its support for private nonprofit organizations at a time when the Reagan Administration expects them to take over many of the responsibilities borne by the Government, according to a study issued today by the Urban Institute.

title: 23 FILIPINO LABOR LEADERS SEIZED
description: Twenty-three more Philippine trade union leaders were arrested Wednesday, bringing to 38 the number jailed or picked up for questioning since President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced the discovery of what he described as a nationwide terrorist plot to disrupt his Government.

title: Harvester Bid Reported
description: The International Harvester Company is considering the sale of a truck assembly plant at its Australian subsidiary, International Harvester of Australia, to the Nissan Diesel Motor Company of Japan, Nissan said. A spokesman said that Nissan had received an unofficial approach through a Far East agent of Harvester. Industry sources said that the plant, in Melbourne, is producing 3,000 to 4,000 trucks a month and is estimated to be worth $190 million.

title: INDIANS HAVE RETURNED TO ANCIENT CHILI TRADE
description: Hundreds of years ago the Tigua Indians grew chili peppers in the lush Rio Grande Valley near El Paso. Today the Tiguas are back in the chili business, but primitive tools have given way to dehydraters, huge grinding mills and cardboard drums.

title: WE ARE ALL EXPERTS ON NUCLEAR POWER POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Railroad Strike Ended On Order of U.S. Judge
description: Striking trainmen and conductors of the Boston & Maine Railroad returned to work today after a Federal district judge issued a temporary order against the walkout.

title: Campaign Outlook Second of a series of articles on the 1982 Congressional campaign.
description: Probably not since just after World War II has the country headed for a midterm Congressional election in which the outcome hinged so heavily on a single issue as it does this year on public reaction to the Reagan economic program. In 1958, President Eisenhower faced a midterm recession, but Republicans were also buffeted by the Soviet leap into space, which shattered the nation's self-confidence. In 1970, President Nixon saw another recession rob the Republican Party of expected gains, but law and order and the Vietnam War were also compelling concerns. In 1974, Republicans were badly damaged by two issues: inflation and the Watergate affair, which kept ashamed Republican voters home. The last time either party made big gains on the single issue of the economy was in 1946, when wartime price controls, imposed under the Democrats, were lifted.

title: Farm Income Fall Seen
description: A long-awaited Agriculture Department report said today that net farm income this year is expected to drop to about $19 billion, the third annual decline in a row. Last year, net income was calculated at $25.1 billion, after adjustments for changes in value of inventory, and $19.6 billion before adjustment. Early this year, when it appeared that farm income might decline even more sharply, the department suspended making quarterly projections and announced the first estimate would not be ready until September.

title: SYRIA SAID TO SEEK TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: Diplomats here say there are strong indications that President Hafez al-Assad has decided to find a way to start ending Syria's military and political presence in Lebanon.

title: NEW CHARTER DUE FOR CHINESE PARTY
description: Over the next week and a half, the delegates at the 12th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party are expected to approve some significant structural changes in the world's largest Communist party, now numbering more than 39.6 million members.

title: Michigan Panel Spurns Budget-Cutting Proposal
description: Gov. William G. Milliken's order to cut the state budget by an $150 million more was rejected today by lawmakers opposed to further reductions in education aid and revenuesharing payments to local governments.

title: 3 PHYSICIANS LOSE LICENSES IN RAPE
description: Three doctors convicted of raping a nurse were stripped of their medical licenses today by a state licensing panel.

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DIRECTED CITY EFFORT TO ATTRACT TOURISTS
description: Royal W. Ryan, retired executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, died Tuesday at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness.

title: KEMPER TO ACQUIRE 80% OF PRESCOTT BALL IN A $64 MILLION DEAL
description: The Kemper Group said today that a subsidiary had agreed in principle to acquire 80 percent of Prescott, Ball & Turben, a securities firm based in Cleveland, for $64 million in cash and Kemper stock.

title: BUILDING DECLINED 0.7% IN JULY
description: New construction dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, the first decline since February, despite a solid increase in new home building, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S.F.L. Sees Benefits
description: Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League, acknowledges that the effect of a player strike in the National Football League could possibly help launch his league. But, Simmons says that a crisis in the N.F.L. would do more harm than good to his league, which plans to begin play next March.

title: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a gain of $911,000 or 14 cents a shr from the repurchase of debentures

title: ALGONQUIN MERCANTILE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $448,936 from the sale of assets and tax credits...C-Including a gain of $5,280,718 on the sale of assets and tax credits

title: JOURNALISTS PLEA FOR STAY DECLINED
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court today formally declined to stay the 90-day sentence of a Boston newspaper reporter jailed for refusing to testify about interviews he had with a murder suspect.

title: LEGAL AND TAX ADVISERS JOIN TO OFFER ONE-STEP SERVICES
description: In the Valley Forge shopping center there are two signs in the window of the office flanked by the luggage shop and the vacant shoe store: ''Hyatt Legal Services'' and ''H&R Block.''

title: TEAHOUSE REGAINS ITS GLORY
description: Only in Newport, where the social arts function with the force of great money, could the event planned for today transpire: at the behest of the First National Bank of Chicago, China's Ambassador to the United States has consented to come here to honor the restoration of a teahouse built almost 70 years ago for Alva Vanderbilt Belmont.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ARAFAT IN GREECE IN SNUB TO ARABS
description: Yasir Arafat, wearing a combat uniform and vowing continued resistance to what he described as the ''barbarian, savage'' Israelis, arrived here today to a warm reception.

title: Judge Laurance T. Wren, 56; Presided at Trial of Miranda
description: Judge Laurance T. Wren, who presided over a rape trial that ultimately led to a Supreme Court decision requiring the police to advise criminal suspects of their right to remain silent, died Tuesday night. He was 56 years old.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $5,000...C-Including an extraordinary chredit of $12,000

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sunken Hashish Linked to 5 Men
description: Five men were indicted today on drug charges in connection with an 18-ton cargo of hashish that sank in rough waters in the Atlantic Ocean last October. Bales of hashish washed up on the coast of Monmouth and Ocean Counties in early October, United States Attorney W. Hunt Dumont said.

title: TAX STOCK TRANSFERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGIAN SAYS OPPONENT'S CAMPAIGN 'BACKFIRED'
description: Joe Frank Harris, a Georgia legislator who came from behind to win the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in a runoff election Tuesday, said he won because his opponent's ''desperation campaign backfired.''

title: THE HIGH PRICE OF A SHIFT TO PHONETIC SPELLING
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn to Back AEG Loans
description: The West German Government announced today that it had decided to guarantee up to $440 million in new bank loans to insolvent AEG-Telefunken A.G.

title: AIRPORTS TO CONTINUE SEEKING LOCAL LEVY ON AIRLINE TICKETS
description: The country's airports, which recently won a $4.3 billion development assistance bill from Congress, plan to continue their fight for Federal authorization to levy local taxes on airline tickets for the support of airports. Airline tickets are now subject to an 8 percent Federal tax.

title: A.M.C. Jeep Delay
description: The American Motors Corporation will delay introduction of its new fuel-efficient Jeep line by at least three months because of concerns about quality, said Lawrence H. Hyde, an executive vice president of A.M.C. The new four-wheel-drive sports utility vehicle had been scheduled to make its debut next spring as an early 1984 model.

title: Indonesia Bars Seizure
description: Oil Minister Subroto of Indonesia has rejected a proposal that Indonesia nationalize its biggest foreign oil producer, Caltex Pacific Indonesia, which is jointly owned by the Standard Oil Company of California and Texaco Inc. Labor officials had called on the Government to take over the company when its contract expires in November 1983. Caltex, which produces about half of Indonesia's 1.3 million barrels of oil a day has so far failed to reach agreement with the state oil company, Pertamina, on terms for a new contract, but Mr. Subroto said that negotiations were continuing.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1982
description: International ''Full autonomy'' for Palestinians, under some sort of Jordanian supervision, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip was endorsed by President Reagan. In a televised speech, Mr. Reagan also called for a halt in Jewish settlement of the occupied areas that he said was essential for peace. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli officials reacted angrily to a letter from President Reagan in which he asked for a freeze on Jewish settlement in the occupied territories and suggested that they be linked in confederation with Jordan. (A1:3.)

title: Dow Falls 6.26, to 895.05; Trading Heavy
description: Stock prices staged a moderate retreat yesterday following the market's spectacular advance during the final half of August. Trading continued heavy.

title: S.E.C. Censures Bache
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has censured Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., citing improper supervision in more than $600,000 in in-house thefts at Bache's Corpus Christi, Tex., and Hartford offices, an S.E.C. official said today. The firm has agreed to institute new controls, he added. Censure is a public statement of improprieties.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., has elected to its board Rocco C. Siciliano, chairman and chief executive officer of Ticor, Los Angeles.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax adjustment credit of $7,000 and a tax adjustment charge of $132,000...C-After a tax charge of $233,000 for the qr and a tax credit of $190,000 for the yr...D-Including a tax credit of $1,940,000; yr-ago sales figures reflect a change in the method of accounting for vanadium pentoxide from joint producty by product

title: SEX OFFENDER FREED BY JERSEY JUDGE IS RETURNED TO PRISON AFTER A FUROR
description: A State Superior Court judge today reinstated the 15-year prison sentence of a 565-pound sex offender whose release early last month caused a public outcry.

title: 3 Milk Co-ops Cited on Sales
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the three biggest dairy cooperatives in the Middle West conspired to monopolize milk sales in the region.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Learning to Smooth The Flow of Traffic

title: CONCERT: THE CABRILLO MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: The Cabrillo Festival, which ended its 20th season with an orchestral concert here Sunday night, deserves to be better known. Unlike the Fromm week of contemporary music at Tanglewood, new compositions here are mixed with more accessible - but never hackneyed - repertory. Audiences have responded avidly.

title: DROP IN FLU CASES LINKED TO 2 DRUGS
description: Either of two drugs, if taken early in an outbreak of influenza, can greatly reduce the chances of getting that serious and common viral infection, according to a study of 450 volunteers in Burlington, Vt.

title: HOME BEAT
description: The potter Polly Frizell has done a 15-inch serving platter with a farm scene; $75 at Mythology, 370 Columbus Avenue (78th Street).

title: ROBERT E. SHELTON
description: Robert E. Shelton, a public-relations executive who served in three city administrations, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center after a brief illness.

title: PLAYS
description: Crucial Break of Serve

title: Figure in Slaying Gets Freedom on Weekends
description: The director of a state mental hospital said today he would not curtail weekend passes for a man accused of killing a City Councilman, despite a barrage of criticism from the police.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Linda McCartney Show Of Photos Scheduled

title: CROWD IN TIMES SQ. AREA ATTACKS OFF-DUTY OFFICER
description: An off-duty New York City police officer in civilian clothes was attacked by a group of men in Times Square early yesterday, wounded one of them and a bystander, and then was fired at by two policemen who did not know he was an officer, the police said.

title: Ford Pickup's New Features
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer diesel engines and four-wheel-drive on its Ranger pickup trucks, beginning with 1983 models.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Amdisco Buy-Out
description: The Amdisco Corporation, formerly the American Distilling Company, said its chairman, Bernard Goldberg, had offered to buy the company for $21.25 share in cash. Mr. Goldberg owns about 40 percent of the company's 849,000 common shares outstanding. Amdisco said it had appointed a committee of outside directors to explore the feasibility of the proposed transaction. Amdisco's stock fell 1/8, to 20 1/2 bid, yesterday in the over-the-counter market.

title: RUTGERS REOPENS A BUILDING ORDERED SHUT AS CANCER RISK
description: A Rutgers University academic building and research laboratory that was closed almost seven months ago after unsafe levels of a suspected cancer-causing hormone were discovered in the air was ordered reopened today by the university. Eight persons who worked in the building have been found to have cancer since 1977.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST PLAN
description: On the day before George Shultz was confirmed as Secretary of State, President Reagan told him, ''Put a Mideast plan on the front burner.''

title: PRIVATE'S FAMILY DOUBTS HE DEFECTED
description: The parents of Pfc. Joseph T. White say they do not believe assertions by North Korea that the Army infantryman has asked for political asylum.

title: GERULAITIS IS TOPPLED BY BUEHNING
description: Two more seeded players, Vitas Gerulaitis and Jose-Luis Clerc, were eliminated in the United States Open tennis championships yesterday. Fritz Buehning, a 6-foot-5-inch pro from Short Hills, N. J., whose temper has often been as explosive as his serve-and-volley game, stunned the fifth-seeded Gerulaitis, 6-4, 7-6, 6-3. Last year Gerulaitis extended John McEnroe to five sets in the semifinals at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: HUNTING AND SAVORING MAINE'S RARE FLORA
description: A gigantic and successful detective game has been under way in Maine in recent years, a game that has uncovered hidden treasure using century-old clues. It's a game led by a professional, Susan C. Gawler, but amateur searchers have contributed much to its success.

title: Charles E. Schatvet, 70, Dies; Chairman of Printing Concern
description: Charles E. Schatvet, chairman of the Adams Group Inc., a printing company in Manhattan, died last Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived on Pratt Island in Noroton, Conn.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of Transport Life Insurance Co. for $26.50 a share cash, or $152 million.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $654,000

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Tuesday in Science Times on the use of computers in continuing education for executives incorrectly identified the developer of Electronic Information Exchange System, a computer conference network. The network was developed by the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark.

title: CULTURAL IMPERATIVES; Smaller World
description: Video games are under attack around the world. A man who tried to open a game parlor in New York City's Riverdale section had to close his doors; parents feared lunch money would be gobbled up by Pac-Man.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1982; International
description: The U.S. will reduce sharply the scope of sanctions it has applied against two French companies that defied its ban on equipment for a Soviet pipeline, according to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. He said the sanctions would be directed only against oil and gas equipment and would no longer bar violators from receiving all U.S. products. (Page A1.)

title: WLADYSLAW GOMULKA OF POLAND IS DEAD
description: Wladyslaw Gomulka, who led the Poland's Communist Party from 1956 until his ouster in 1970, died today of cancer, the official Polish press agency P.A.P. announced. He was 77 years old and had been hospitalized for months.

title: A Right to Livestock Restored to Russians
description: The Soviet people have been given back the right to keep their own horse, mule, donkey, bullock, buffalo or camel.

title: Briefs on the Arts Leon Fleisher Returns To Orchestra's Applause
description: Leon Fleisher, the brilliant pianist who lost the use of his right hand 17 years ago, had a quiet triumph last week. With his family looking on, and amid high anticipation in the orchestra, Mr. Fleisher played the 15-minute-long Cesar Franck Symphonic Variations at a rehearsal with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Blossom Dearie Booked

title: Head of Troubled Mego Is Convicted of Fraud
description: The chairman of Mego International, a New York-based toy company in bankruptcy proceedings, was convicted yesterday on Federal charges that he had defrauded the company and its stockholders in transactions stemming from the sale of inventory.

title: Last Marine Biology Cruises Scheduled
description: For those who enjoy marine biology, an introduction to the subject will be offered this weekend to riders aboard the Enviro-Lab, a training vessel run by Project Oceanology, a private educational group in Groton, Conn. As the boat cruises the Thames River, a net will be dropped and the fish captured will be studied by staff biologists and teachers.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS more homeowners become interested in renovating and redecorating their bathrooms - often on a do-it-yourself basis because of the cost of professional work - many are finding that the walls around the tub and shower enclosure pose a serious problem.

title: TUNISIA USES REMOTE CAMP TO HOUSE P.L.O. GUERRILLAS
description: In a former agricultural training center in this remote flat stretch of Tunisia, about 1,100 Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut are temporarily housed in tents and dormitories as they wait for instructions from their leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Feast of Santa Rosalia

title: Amoco Funds Distribution
description: The Department of Energy said today that it would conduct a public hearing Sept. 22 to take comments on its proposal for the distribution of funds from the 1980 settlement of the Amoco Oil Company's product overcharges. Amoco is a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: LAST GUERRILLAS QUIT WEST BEIRUT
description: The withdrawal of Palestinan guerrillas and Syrian troops from west Beirut came to an end today as the last shipload of guerrillas left the port of Beirut and headed for Syria.

title: I.M.F. SPLIT ON CONTRIBUTIONS
description: Poland, Mexico, Rumania, Argentina, Zaire, the Sudan. The list of countries that are financially hard pressed runs on and on.

title: MARIETTA IN TALKS ON BENDIX ASSETS
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation has been holding negotiations to sell a major part of the automotive business of the Bendix Corporation, for which it has made a $1.5 billion takeover bid, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Court Hears Arguments On Haitian Guidelines
description: A Federal appeals court heard arguments today on whether the Attorney General or a Federal judge should set guidelines for the release of Haitian refugees who have been detained in this country.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The baseball commissioner's office has canceled a trade made last December that brought Bob Molinaro to the Philadelphia Phillies from the Chicgo Cubs because the deal violated a baseball rule. According to Bill Murray of the commissioner's office, an unnamed player in a trade, who has been on the active list of any club during any part of the regular season, cannot be assigned to another club in the same league.

title: ALEXANDER SAYS ASSETS ARE MISSING IN BRITAIN
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a major New York-based insurance brokerage, said yesterday without elaboration that it had found a pretax shortage of up to $25 million in the net assets of its British subsidiary, which it acquired in January for $300 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Finding the Right Sound

title: Publicker Sale
description: Publicker Industries, one of the nation's largest producers of industrial alcohols, said that certain members of the Neuman and Publicker families are considering selling their controlling interest in the company to a group of private investors at a price of $5 a share. The Neuman and Publicker families own or control about 3.1 million shares, or 38 percent of the stock outstanding. The stock closed unchanged at 2 7/8 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: People
description: * Lewis M. Phelps has been named vice president, public relations, at the Southern Pacific Company, San Francisco.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Every winter our aluminum windows sweat and cause damage to the wood frames around them and create water stains that have to be painted. We live in a condominium in a high-rise building. Do you have any suggestions as to what we can do to prevent this happening again this coming winter? - N.A.S., Berea, Ohio.

title: LEAD LEVELS FOUND HIGHER IN BLACKS
description: A new nationwide study has confirmed that levels of lead in the human body are greater in black children than white children. However, it found that the difference could not be explained simply by income levels or residential areas, as had been proposed in the past.

title: ABC WILL USE ACTORS IN ITS REPORT ON SADAT
description: ON Oct. 7, a year and a day after television viewers watched videotapes of the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, ABC News' weekly magazine ''20/20'' will offer another view of that event, one with an unusual wrinkle.

title: MORTON IN FIGHT FOR NO. 1 JOB AGAINST JETS
description: The final score of the exhibition game Saturday night between the Jets and the Denver Broncos at Giants Stadium will have no significance. But individual performances will make a difference to several young players, such as Marion Barber, the fullback for the Jets, who are fighting for jobs.

title: AN ENTERPRISING COMPUTER VACATION
description: WHAT did you do on your summer vacation? It's the sort of question most of us still ask each other despite its banality in the hope that we will receive an interesting reply. It rarely happens.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp.'s $50 million issue of notes due 1992 was priced at 99.095 to yield 13.29 percent, with a 13 1/8 percent coupon, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: INDIAN TREASURE: OFFSHORE OIL
description: ''It's right out there, 200 kilometers,'' said A.K. Malhotra, who is directing India's largest oil-exploration effort. Mr. Malhotra gestured toward the rainy, monsoon mist across the gray-brown waters of the Arabian Sea, whose waves crashed against the sea wall below his 12th-floor office in Bombay's financial district.

title: Collection of Tax Is Upheld
description: Sellers of aviation fuel can legally collect a new tax before the bill authorizing the levy becomes law, but the Internal Revenue Service cannot collect it until the tax bill is signed, Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene ruled tonight.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Holders Group In New Pabst Bid
description: A group trying to take control of the Pabst Brewing Company has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is seeking the support of other shareholders in its efforts.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Phoenix Theater Opening Season in New Home

title: Bid to Avert Layoff At G.M. Is Begun
description: Federal, state and local officials have met with representatives of the General Motors Corporation's assembly plant division in North Tarrytown to discuss ways to avert layoffs of 2,000 employees, according to the village's mayor, Philip Zegarelli.

title: BRITISH DEFENSE MINISTER TO QUIT
description: Defense Secretary John Nott, the Cabinet minister responsible for Britain's armed forces throughout the Falkland Islands crisis, announced tonight that he would not run for re-election in the next general election.

title: Valle's Sale Set
description: Valle's Steak House stockholders have voted 1,867,960 to 452,806 to sell the 30-restaurant chain for $7 a share. Valle family members and family trusts own 66.7 percent of the company, which is to be sold for $17.9 million in cash, notes and warrants. The new owners will be Arthur W. Hanson, Valle's president; Robert L. Simon, the company's executive vice president; Joseph F. McDonald, the company's treasurer; William Sword & Company of Princeton, N.J., an investment advisory firm, and Richard D. and Judith A. Valle, son and daughter of the company's founder, Donald D. Valle.

title: AS N.O.W. TAKES AIM
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: HEIR APPARENT SEEN IN CHANGES AT ESMARK
description: Donald P. Kelly, the 60-year-old president and chief executive officer of Esmark Inc., has been elected to the additional post of chairman, which had been vacant since 1977. Although Mr. Kelly says he has no plans to resign or retire soon, some analysts speculated that he might be laying the groundwork for his eventual successor.

title: Pakistan Says Air Incursions From Afghanistan Are Halted
description: A senior official said today that Pakistani airspace was no longer being violated by aircraft from Afghanistan, where Soviet soldiers are helping the Government fight a war against Moslem rebels.

title: REALTY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Clue to 'Euphoria'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I wonder if Betty Rollin writing in Thursday's ''Hers'' column (Aug. 19) on chronic self-doubt which, she asserts, afflicts so many women, realized that her feelings of ''near euphoria'' every time a piece of her writing is accepted may offer a clue to an answer to her question why we are so afflicted.

title: Steel Import Testimony
description: The Federal Trade Commission urged the International Trade Commission today to act cautiously in deciding whether to approve duties on steel imports, saying an erroneous decision could cost the American economy up to $480 million yearly.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing: Al Carter vs. Tyrone Crawley, lightweights, 12 rounds, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. Carter has won 26 bouts ( 25 by knockouts) and has lost 3; Crawley is 8-0.

title: Advertising; New Ideas For Record Promotions
description: IT is a late summer morning in Beverly Hills and Charles Koppelman, still in his bathrobe, is smoking a Monte Cristo cigar in his bungalow on the grounds of the Beverly Hills Hotel. He has been up since 7 A.M., talking on the phone with New York and listening to five cassettes of new songs. Lively new songs.

title: TEACHERS' STRIKES IN FIVE STATES DELAY SCHOOL FOR 154,000 STUDENTS
description: Strikes by about 7,300 teachers delayed the opening of school for 154,000 students in five states yesterday, but union officials said they expected comparatively little labor strife this year in comparison with past years.

title: I.M.F. Aid To Mexico
description: The International Monetary Fund expects to have a $4.5 billion to $5 billion aid package ready for Mexico by the end of next month, monetary sources familiar with the complex negotiations said today.

title: No Headline
description: BRAVES SHUT OUT PHILLIES

title: 4 GUBERNATORIAL HOPEFULS JOIN IN DEBATE
description: The four major candidates for Governor sat side by side today and occasionally crossed party lines as they differed on prisons, abortion, Indian claims and the death penalty.

title: U.S. Says Farm Income Is Down 24% in 1982
description: Net income for American farmers is projected at about $19 billion in 1982, down 24.3 percent from last year, the Government said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALK OF JAZZ

title: Technology; Has Asbestos A Substitute?
description: but hazardous - component in more than 2,500 industrial and consumer products, may be the subject of more intense scientific research and public controversy than any other mineral substance.

title: PICKEREL PLENTIFUL IN NORTHEAST
description: I f your favorite streams are so low that trout sulk in the tepid water, making only occasional after-dark and early-morning forays for food, you might enliven your days with pickerel.

title: Norcross Files For Chapter 11
description: Norcross-Rust Craft, the big greeting card company, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Bridge: A Book on Pairs Contains Helpful Tips on Thinking
description: If the cognoscenti were polled in an effort to determine the fastest thinker among the experts, there would be several American candidates. In Europe, most votes would probably go to Martin Hoffman, who adopted England as his home in 1945 after spending three years in German concentration camps as a teen-ager.

title: ANCIENT GREEK THEATER FOUND
description: Archeologists announced today that they had discovered the theater where King Philip II of Macedonia, father of Alexander the Great, was assassinated in 336 B.C.

title: BRIEFING
description: Acid Rain Exchange

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shr earnings for the yr-ago periods are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stocksplit in June 1982

title: RENT INCREASE TOO SMALL, LANDLORDS CHARGE IN SUIT
description: Five major New York City real estate organizations yesterday filed a suit seeking to set aside new rent increases for rent-stabilized apartments. The landlords contended that the increases were not large enough and had been approved in a ''mob atmosphere'' that violated their constitutional rights.

title: Dealer Incentives Announced by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation announced new dealer incentives on its 1982 subcompact, compact and intermediate cars and the Cadillac Seville today to reduce inventories before the 1983 model year begins.

title: ECONOMIST FROM PERU HEADS FIRST BOSTON UNIT
description: Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski has had a varied career. He has worked for the World Bank as chief economist for Latin American affairs, has been a corporate chief executive in Pittsburgh and has been Peru's energy minister.

title: Boxing Cards Changed
description: Pipino Cuevas, former welterweight champion of the World Boxing Association, has torn a rotator cuff in his left shoulder, and his bout Saturday against Donald Curry in San Antonio, Tex., has been scratched. ... ... The date for Wilfred Benitez's defense of the World Boxing Council's superwelterweight title against Thomas Hearns has been set for Dec. 3, according to the promoter, Don King. But no site has yet been chosen.

title: FUEL COOPERATIVES HELP CUT THE COST OF HOME OIL HEAT
description: WITH the first wisps of fall in the air this week, many homeowners may be thinking once again about heating their houses and about ways to keep fuel-oil bills down. An option worth considering is joining one of the growing number of fuel-oil cooperatives, made up of consumers who have banded together to get lower prices from suppliers.

title: Credit Plan For MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company announced it had executed a new consolidated credit agreement totaling $525 million, through seven commercial banks.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Swiss Bank Pact Details
description: The United States and Switzerland today released details of their accord allowing Swiss banks to cooperate with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in its investigations of inside traders who hide their illegal profits in secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: NEW LOOK IN SAN DIEGO AT SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL
description: This city's 1,400-acre Balboa Park is a uniquely exhilerating place to go to the theater. It may be that the bougainvillea and birds of paradise, the steep ravines and gnarled eucalyptus, even the dusky scents and broken cries of the animals in the nearby zoo, are as much a lure as the Shakespeare.

title: Discretion and Justice Leff
description: James Leff, a justice of Manhattan's trial court, is a valuable irritant in New York's judicial system. He is bright, articulate, industrious and impatient with judges he considers lazy or slow.

title: MARXIST PURITANS SCOWL AT SOVIET LONELYHEARTS
description: Like other countries, the Soviet Union has its share of lonely people hoping to find partners in marriage. But years after they became commonplace in the United States and elsewhere, ''rendezvous'' clubs, lonelyhearts advertisements and marriage brokers raise questions of propriety here that are still being wrestled with by the authorities.

title: Off the Hook
description: ''A friend of mine called me up the other night and said Ray Perkins was on a TV show saying he needed offensive-line help and was going to call some older veterans,'' said Jim Clack, who was the Giants' center for four years. ''I said I was taking my phone off the hook.''

title: Teacher Weds Dorothy Bush
description: Dorothy Bush, the only daughter of Vice President and Mrs. Bush, was married this afternoon to William H. LeBlond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. LeBlond 2d of New Canaan, Conn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Not All That Hot

title: Chesapeake Creature Believed to Be a Snake
description: A creature reported to be about 30 feet long and dubbed ''Chessie'' that was videotaped in the Chesapeake Bay last spring is apparently a snake, a researcher investigating the case said Tuesday.

title: News Analysis
description: Limiting American cruise missiles may now have become the main Soviet goal in the strategic arms reduction talks in Geneva. At the same time, the Soviet Union seems to be laying the groundwork for deploying large numbers of its own cruise missiles.

title: Young & Rubicam Given Long Lines Task
description: The Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has named Young & Rubicam to handle the introduction of two new products: credit cards and gift certificates.

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BY PAULA DEITZ
description: WASHINGTON SINCE 1937, the Lindens, one of the great American frame houses of the Georgian period, with its prized collection of 18th-century antiques, has been the private home here of the Morris family. It has been their home, that is, since they had it dismantled in Danvers, Mass., and reassembled here on Kalorama Road, a quiet residential street in the fashionable northwestern section.

title: Foremost Dairies
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Foremost Dairies division to a group of private investors for about $65 million in cash as part of its plan to emphasize its distribution business and other proprietary product lines. In the fiscal year ended March 31, the division had revenue of $689.4 million.

title:
SCOUTING;
Calm in a Crowd
description: The pressure was great on Tab Ramos from Harrison, N.J., but with 64,000 people rooting against him Wednesday night, he kept cool. This was in Guatemala, where the United States national youth soccer team was playing its Guatemalan counterparts in a match that would eliminate the loser from a berth in the World Youth Cup next June.

title: U.S. AIDE HOPING SUPPORT BY ARABS WILL SWAY ISRAELIS
description: The State Department said today that it was not surprised or disappointed by the Israeli Cabinet's vehement objection to President Reagan's proposals for a Middle East peace agreement.

title: QADDAFI VOWS TO TOPPLE 'COWARDLY' ARAB CHIEFS
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, increasingly isolated in the Arab world, has threatened to send ''revolutionary committees'' beyond his borders to destroy other Arab governments for their failure to intervene militarily on the side of the besieged Palestinians in Beirut and prevent their withdrawal.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAX GORDON NOW A JAZZ 'INSTITUTION'
description: AMONG the jazz clubs that are hosts to the eight-day Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, none is better known than the Village Vanguard, the tiny basement bistro at 178 Seventh Avenue South, near Perry Street, where the alto-saxophonist Arthur Blythe will be featured through Sunday.

title: Queen to Visit Jamaica
description: Queen Elizabeth and her husband, Prince Philip, will visit Jamaica next Feb. 13-16, Sir Florizel Glasspole, the Governor General, said today. The royal couple last visited here in 1975.

title: Lawyers Sue Lane Bryant
description: Weil, Gotshal & Manges, the law firm that represented Lane Bryant Inc. in its sale to Limited Stores Inc. last spring, is suing Lane Bryant for $426,835 in legal fees.

title: DORMITORY AGENCY CRITICIZED ON ITS INVESTMENT PRACTICES
description: With more than $260 million of its funds tied up in a bankrupt Wall Street securities concern, the New York State Dormitory Authority has come under sharp criticism for its investment practices from private bankers and state officials familiar with them.

title: TRADE TALK SPECIALIST
description: He likes to tinker - with the ancient, luminous, fire-engine-red Austin-Healy in his garage or with the odd chair made out of driftwood or with the lamp made out of a wine bottle in the den.

title: WALLACE STAYS AHEAD OF 2 OPPONENTS
description: At a rally in a small town in the northwest part of Alabama Wednesday night, the country music singing star Tammy Wynette, shimmering in silver and sequins, brought hundreds of George C. Wallace devotees to their feet when she belted out her hit song, ''Stand By Your Man,'' as their man came into the auditorium.

title: Fast-Food Post Filled at Grace
description: Louis P. Neeb, former chairman and chief executive of the Burger King Corporation, was named yesterday to head a newly formed fastfood division at W.R. Grace & Company.

title: Jobless Claims Soared In 3d Week of August
description: The number of unemployed Americans filing initial claims for government benefits soared by 621,000 in the week ended Aug. 21, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. It was the third highest seven-day filing action this year.

title: Six More 'Plotters' Seized in Philippines
description: Six more people described as anti-Government plotters were arrested today, bringing to 29 the number of Government opponents seized in the last two days.

title: 76ers SIGN MALONE TO $13 MILLION OFFER
description: Moses Malone, the most valuable player in the National Basketball Association last season, signed a reported $13 million offer sheet today to play with the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Decision File Televised Violence And Children

title: GILES WINNING JOB WITH GLOVE AND BAT
description: George Giles never told his grandson much about life in the old Negro baseball leagues - the racial pressures, the endless barnstorming, the sleazy hotels, the $185-a-month salary.

title: A.T.& T.'S WEAKEST OFFSPRING
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, the largest of the local Bell System companies scheduled to become independent in January 1984, continues to stagger from a long-running regulatory war between the State of California and Pacific's parent, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: THE THIRD REALITY
description: President Reagan's proposal for Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza, and their eventual association with Jordan, put the intentions of both sides squarely to the test - but Israel's more immediately. The quick, negative response of the Begin Government is no service to itself or anyone.

title: U.S. GIVES LEBANON $30 MILLION MORE
description: The United States has decided to increase aid to Lebanon by $30 million, to $95 million, to help rehabilitate west Beirut and the southern part of the country.

title: Coming to the Rescue of WIC
description: President Reagan may have promised not to balance the Federal budget on the backs of the poor, but his Administration apparently has no compunctions about extracting some savings from the plates of poor women, infants and children with special nutritional needs. A Federal judge has finally ordered an end to a dismaying example of official insensitivity.

title: Harness Driver Dies of Injuries
description: Shelly Goudreau, one of the leading harness racers in North America, died today of head injuries suffered in a race-track spill last Friday night.

title: U.S. Officials Deny Meeting With Syrian
description: State Department and White House officials said today that reports from Damascus that Rifaat Assad, the commander of Syria's security forces, had conferred with high State Department officials during a visit here last week were unfounded.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: The assets of the nation's 248 money market funds dropped $899 million, to $226.39 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: LAWS ACROSS THE BORDER STRAIN U.S.-CANADIAN TIES
description: A United States newspaper reporter was sentenced by a Canadian court last week because an article he wrote for a Maine daily referred to Canadian court proceedings that cannot be publicized under Canadian law.

title: Crosby Is Upset In Amateur Golf
description: Jay Sigel, the 1979 British Amateur champion, avoided an upset, but the defending champion, Nathaniel Crosby, was ousted today in the the 82d United States Amateur golf championship.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was a typical cocktail party in a Manhattan apartment. The tiny kitchen had been turned into a bar. C heese and pate were arrayed on the glass-topped dining table, and g uests introduced themselves to one another, in the typical New York f ashion, by name and profession.

title: A Summons to Middle East Moderates
description: President Reagan's formula for new Arab-Israeli negotiations is reasonable and well-timed. Israel's rejection is lamentable but not unchangeable. The Begin Government prefers to seize the West Bank rather than this propitious moment for diplomacy. But Israel's position and politics can change if - and here is the crucial Reagan gamble - the Arab League openly recognizes Israel and offers to negotiate a gradual exchange of security arrangements for release of most of the territory.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the retroactive adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: Texas Youth Sentenced To Death by Injection
description: The jury that convicted a teen-ager of raping and murdering a 76-year-old nun in her convent room sentenced him today to death by injection.

title: News Analysis
description: Administration officials said today that they had received cautiously worded positive reactions from Arab nations - including Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Egypt -to President Reagan's Middle East proposals before his speech Wednesday.

title: Maree and Scott Run to the Front
description: When it comes to middle-distance runners, we constantly hear about Coe and Ovett, Ovett and Coe. The two Englishmen, Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett, undoubtedly are the world's most famous milers these days, and maybe they are the best.

title: Smith's 65 Leads B.C. Open Golf
description: Mike Smith, who has struggled on the PGA Tour, shot a six-under-par 65 today to take a two-shot lead in the first round of the $275,000 B.C. Open.

title: WOMEN OF TENNIS GATHER OFF COURT
description: Oh, it was festive all right, with islands of potted palms and ficus trees surrounded by helium-filled pink, aqua and yellow balloons lettered ''You've come a long way baby'' amid a flotilla of dining tables. There was a long buffet piled high with roast beef, ham and watermelon, and Harvey Lane, a one-man band who simulates a piano, an organ and drums on an electronic keyboard, was playing gently. Yet the reception at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, was less a party than a class reunion, a virtual retrospective of women's tennis, a setting for reminiscence.

title: 2 stops in Burma, midtown French.
description: one on Prince Street in SoHo and the original on Henry Street in Chinatown - it is a spicy, diverting cuisine with pungent curries somewhat like those of Thailand. They are served with rice, generally cooked in coconut milk, and two interesting breads - a thousand-layered pancake that is a flat coil of crisp dough much like puff pastry and a grainy ''patty'' that recalls Indian griddle-fried breads. Although chopsticks are available, the Burmese actually eat with forks and spoons, as do the Thais, or with their fingers, as in India.

title: LEGAL LOTTERY A HIT, BUT THE NUMBERS ARE STILL RUN
description: The most concise bit of punditry that followed the viewing of President Reagan's Middle East speech last night was uttered by a civic minded gambler named Steve.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for overstatements of inventories

title: Datapoint Net Slides 75.4%
description: The Datapoint Corporation of San Antonio said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit plunged 75.4 percent from a year earlier although revenue rose 16.3 percent.

title: MEXICO'S BUSINESSMEN ENRAGED AT BANK SEIZURE
description: Mexico's private sector reacted with anger and dismay today to President Jose Lopez Portillo's announcement Wednesday that all private banks would be nationalized. The measure was strongly applauded by leftist parties and labor groups.

title: RUSSELL C. TAYLOR
description: Russell C. Taylor, a former president and chief executive officer of ACF Industries, died Monday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla., after a long illness.

title: Light Show Ending
description: For the last seven years, visitors to the Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History have seen and heard ''Laserium,'' a laser light show set to music.

title: Campaign Outlook; Third of a series of articles on the 1982 Congressional campaign.
description: By now, the grandfatherly mail carrier in a Republican National Committee commercial is a familiar figure to millions of television viewers. ''For gosh sakes,'' he says as if counseling a group of impatient children, ''let's give the guy a chance.'' The ''guy,'' of course, is President Reagan. Democratic spokesmen have stewed for weeks about the political advertisement depicting the postman delivering Social Security checks with a cost-of-living raise and crediting Mr. Reagan for it. The Reagan Administration had actually sought to reduce the increase, the Democrats say.

title: Doubt on Japan Outlook
description: Japan's economic outlook is not as promising as implied in Tuesday's report that the gross national product climbed 1.3 percent in the second quarter, according to statistics released by the Economic Planning Agency today. Japan's index of leading indicators fell in June, normally a sign that the economy would weaken about three months hence. However, an agency official said the economy was already weak now and that the indicators suggest continued weakness instead of further decline.

title: Grandpa Kheel, a 4th Time
description: Originally, he said, he was ''very pleased that the connection was not noted'' but yesterday Theodore W. Kheel was, more characteristically, quite willing to talk about being grandfather to the city's first ''test tube'' baby.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JOHN SHAMBO
description: John Shambo, a leader of the International Union of Electrical Workers and a representive of employees of the General Electric Company for more than 30 years, died Wednesday of cancer at Ellis Hospital here. He was 59 years old and lived in Schenectady.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1982
description: International Israel rejected Washington's plan for Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, asserting that President Reagan's proposals would help create a Palestinian state that would endanger Israel's security. Despite Mr. Reagan's appeal for a freeze in Jewish settlement of the occupied territories, Israel's Cabinet also voted unanimously to press the establishment of a Jewish population in the areas to consolidate Israel's hold on them. (Page A1, Columns 4-6.) Jordan reacted favorably to the American peace initiative. Amman withheld formal comment, but made clear that it viewed the proposals as promising as long as some doubtful provisions were clarified. (A8:1.)

title: DON'T SHUT COURT DOORS ON ALIENS
description: To the Editor:

title: Aetna Money Manager Joins Bridge Capital
description: In his 20-year career at Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford, Hoyt J. Goodrich figures he has invested about $4 billion of the insurance company's money. Now Mr. Goodrich has joined Donald P. Remey in a new company called Bridge Capital Advisors Inc. to do some investing on their own.

title: 'YOU ARE NOT ALONE, YORICK!'
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY'S PLAN ON NEW JAIL IS ASSAILED
description: Chinatown business and civic leaders have formed a group to oppose a proposed city jail on the western edge of the neighborhood, and they vowed yesterday to fight the plan with public protests and legal action.

title: U.S. Ends Investigation Of Town Bully's Slaying
description: United States Attorney Robert G. Ulrich said today that the Federal authorities had ended their investigation into the 1981 vigilante-style slaying of Ken Rex McElroy and would not return any indictments.

title: A BREWER AND YACHTSMAN, 82
description: Rudolph J. Schaefer - the brewer and yachtsman who ran one of the country's largest and most famous regional breweries for 42 years while also supporting the American tradition of yachthing - died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Denver Couple Gets $560,000 In Formaldehyde Fumes Case
description: A couple who contended that their health was damaged by formaldehyde fumes in their mobile home has won a $560,000 judgment against the manufacturer of the home and the makers of its flooring and paneling.

title: CAMP DAVID EXCERPT
description: Following is an excerpt from the agreement signed at Camp David on Sept. 17, 1978, by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel: West Bank and Gaza (1)

title: Today's Featured Matches; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - John McEnroe-Marty Davis. Second Match - Martina Navratilova-Jill Davis. Third Match - Jimmy Connors-Hank Pfister.

title: Israel's Justices Order Reversal of El Al Move
description: The Supreme Court ordered the Government today not to carry out its decison of last month to halt flights of the national airline, El Al, on the Sabbath and holidays, Israel's state radio reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Since the positions of the Government of the United States seriously deviate from the Camp David agreement, contradict it and could create a serious danger to Israel, its security and its future, the Government of Israel has resolved that on the basis of these positions it will not enter into any negotiations with any party.'' -The Israeli Cabinet. (A8:6.)

title: THRIFT UNIT REGULATOR SUSPENDED
description: The top regulator of California's savings and loan industry was suspended late Wednesday, eight days before she planned to encourage the Federal Reserve Board to block Citicorp's plan to acquire a major California thrift unit.

title: MARIETTA IS SUED BY BENDIX
description: The Bendix Corporation yesterday asked a United States District Court in Detroit to block a $1.5 billion takeover bid by the Martin Marietta Corporation. Bendix contends that the offer was designed to thwart a $1.5 billion bid that it had made for Marietta.

title: 21ST MARK TWAIN BOOK SALE STARTS IN CONNECTICUT
description: In 1908, when Mark Twain decided to raise money to build a library in his adopted hometown of Redding, Conn., he opined, ''It seems best to use coercion.'' So the author summoned the local gentry - whom he referred to as ''fellow farmers'' - to a soiree. And there he levied a $1 tax ''not upon the valuable sex,'' as he put it, ''only the other one.''

title: CO-OP CONVERSIONS VARY, BUT RESULTS SEEM SIMILAR
description: Recent studies of the cooperative and condominium market in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and in Manhattan by the real estate consulting companies of Yale Robbins Inc. and the Corcoran Group offer interesting perspectives on the market today.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Aug 14
Madlock to Be Captain
description: When Willie Stargell retires at the end of season, Bill Madlock will take over as captain of the Pittsburgh Pirates. Madlock, a three-time National League batting champion, was told of the assignment this week by Manager Chuck Tanner. ... Fred Lynn, the California Angels' outfielder, has a cracked rib and will miss a week of play, the team said yesterday.

title: ITALIAN LEGISLATORS APPROVE SPADOLINI'S SECOND CABINET
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini's second Cabinet and Italy's 42d since the end of World War II, won the confidence of the Chamber of Deputies today. The 27 ministers who received parliamentary approval were the same ones who resigned along with the Prime Minister on Aug. 7.

title: PRELATE IN CATHOLIC SECT
description: Archbishop Richard Arthur Marchenna, primate of the Old Roman Catholic Church in North America, died Thursday at St. Dominic's Church, 602 Leonard Street, Brooklyn, where he had lived for many years. He was 82 years old.

title: EUROPEANS PLAN TALKS ON PIPELINE CONFLICT
description: Senior civil servants from four countries of Western Europe will meet here Friday to discuss ways of easing the dispute with the United States over supplying components for a Soviet gas pipeline, officials of the British Foreign Office said today.

title: PEKING HOPES, BY 2000, TO QUADRUPLE ITS OUTPUT
description: China's farms and factories will try to quadruple their output by the year 2000, according to the Communist Party chairman, Hu Yaobang.

title: BUS FUMES AND SALSA
description: ''What next?'' asked Frederick Knowles, a racing commuter stopped dead in his tracks at the sight of a 14-piece jazz band playing a lively concert in the Port Authority Bus Terminal. ''Opera?''

title: HUNT PUTS COSMOS INTO SEMIFINALS
description: T he Cosmos were stretched to the limit many times this summer. They were constantly on the losing end of the score, hanging there until perilously close to the game's end. Most times, they snapped back and won - as their 23-9 regular-season record shows.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Is There Any Hope for the Farmer?
description: ''I know members have heard time after time about the problems of farmers. Let me tell them, this time our farmers really have problems.'' - Representative Berkley Bedell

title: CITY TRANSIT OFFICIAL GUILTY OF EXTORTION GETS A $10,000 FINE
description: A former New York City Transit Authority official convicted of Federal extortion charges stemming from his involvement in the purchase of defective R-46 subway cars was fined $10,000 yesterday and placed on one year's probation.

title: ART: RARE TREAT IN RARE BOOK AT MORGAN
description: IT is difficult for a museum to know what to do about the Books of Hours, some of the greatest achievements of medieval art. These books - most of them quite small, and some of them very small indeed - brought both a rare intensity and a command of microscopic detail to the task of marking the hours of the day and night at which the devout went to their devotions. Matins, lauds, prime, tierce, sext, nones, vespers and compline formed an unvarying sequence, and it was to the illuminator to match the gravity of the moment.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TERMS IT 'A SERIOUS DANGER'; The Israeli communique, page A8.
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted unanimously today to reject President Reagan's plan for Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, asserting that the American proposals would lead to a Palestinian state and ''could create a serious danger'' to Israel's security.

title: Mrs. Truman Hospitalized
description: Bess Truman, the 97-year-old former First Lady, was rushed from her home in Independence, Mo., to a hospital tonight for an undisclosed emergency. But she was reported by her physician, Dr. Wallace Graham, to be ''stable, resting and in no pain.'' The hospital said the nature of her illness would not be disclosed until tests were completed.

title: A WARNING BY GARVEY
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said yesterday that any strike by the players would not necessarily have to wait until after three games of the regular season.

title: Hinckley Letter Withdrawn
description: A letter written by John Hinckley to a New York Post reporter will not be put up for auction later this month. After an item on the sale appeared here yesterday, the reporter took back the letter from the auctioneer, Charles Hamilton. ''On our instructions,'' explained The Post's metropolitan editor.

title: No Headline
description: AOUND THE WORLD; Mrs. Gandhi Recasts 10 Cabinet Posts

title: Seller of Stolen Books Receives 3-Year Term
description: A former Columbia University graduate student convicted of selling rare books stolen from university collections in London was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to three and a half years in prison and fined $28,000.

title: Richmond Closure
description: The Richmond Tank Car Company, a Houston concern, said it would temporarily halt production of new tank cars, idling 400 workers for six weeks, because of poor market conditions.

title: Lieut. General John C. Oakes, Ex-Leader of Seventh Army
description: Lieut. Gen. John Cogswell Oakes, retired, a former commander of the Seventh Army, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 75 years old and lived in the capital.

title: NOAH IMPRESSIVE IN 3-SET VICTORY
description: John McEnroe won his opening match yesterday, saying that he was ''a little tentative,'' but Yannick Noah continued as the first-week force in the United States Open tennis championships.

title: The Unexpected
description: One would think that a world-class tennis player would need a pretty good physique. But both Steve Denton and Mark Edmondson, two of the power hitters on the men's professional tennis circuit, lack that natural advantage in one aspect: Each has one leg shorter than the other.

title: A Saudi Warplane Crashes
description: A Saudi Air Force F-15 fighter crashed near the city of Dhahran Wednesday after an engine caught fire, Government sources said today. The pilot reportedly parachuted to safety.

title: Bridge: The Wise Declarer Knows When a King Should Fall
description: A vast command of the English language, and a very limited understanding of bridge, once permitted Sir Winston Churchill to declare: ''The king cannot fall unworthily if it falls to the sword of the ace.'' The beginner, it is true, tries to arrange for his aces to capture kings. But there are some paradoxical situations in which the expert will be doing his best to arrange for the opposing king to collect a trick.

title: Cummins Layoffs Trimmed in U.S.
description: The Cummins Engine Company said that it would lay off about 300 fewer employees in its southern Indiana plants than the 653 announced last week, but that an additional 380 would be laid off in its Darlington, England, plants because of continued declines in orders, principally from Mexico.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bombardier Inc. said it was considering selling four Quebec plants that make snowmobile parts to a group of its employees.

title: Lyons to Play With Hand Cast
description: The Jets' front four, known as the New York Sack Exchange, will be reunited for the first time in exhibition play this season against the Denver Broncos at Giants Stadium Saturday night.

title: 'RIDGEMONT HIGH'
description: CAN there be anything about life in high school, particularly life in a suburban California high school, that the movie-going public hasn't already seen? Well, maybe there can. A little bit of it turns up in ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High,'' a jumbled but appealing teen-age comedy with something of a fresh perspective on the subject. ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High'' opens today at the Gemini and other theaters.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SOMEBODY IS LYING. The Story of Dr. X. By Myron Farber. Doubleday. 367 pages. $17.95

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices advanced strongly again, closing at the highest level of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average, buoyed by a surge of institutional buying in big-capitalization issues, climbed 14.35 points, to 909.40. Analysts said the market, continuing the pattern that has prevailed since the rally began in mid-August, turned strong as soon as profit taking had subsided. (Page D1.)

title: Virginia Electric
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company said it had signed an agreement with the Transco Energy Company of Houston to take initial steps toward developing a pipeline across the state to carry coal slurry, a mixture of ground coal and water. Transco operates one of the nation's largest gas pipeline systems through a subsidiary, the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation.

title: Saints May Alternate
description: Bum Phillips, coach of the New Orleans Saints, hinted yesterday that he may try juggling two quarterbacks a game when the Saints open the regular season next week. Archie Manning and the newly acquired Ken Stabler, who played for Phillips in Houston, are the candidates.

title: WHERE HORSES STAY YOUNG
description: A pink balloon held by an unseen child sways above the railbirds as the horses approach the starting gate. A self-conscious gambler hurrying away from the special stall-like booth where $50 parimutuel tickets are sold dodges a woman pushing a baby carriage. A vacationing father balancing his young son on his shoulders for a better view passes a vendor in a uniform of Italian red, white and green, who urges him to ''get your fresh cannolis here.''

title: SURREALISM IN POLAND
description: The struggle between the Polish regime and its people remains at an impasse. It is deadly earnest and deteriorating. When the Government and the newborn union Solidarity signed an agreement in the Gdansk shipyard on Aug. 31, 1980, there was a great surge of hope. Compromise seemed possible.
