The people were prepared to accept Marxist rule and the Soviet alliance provided they could have a say in making it produce effectively and give them some room to breathe freely.

title: ANTICRIME CHANGES UPHELD ON COAST
description: The California Supreme Court ruled today that passage of the Proposition 8 crime initiative, the ''victims' Bill of Rights,'' did not violate the State Constitution.

title: New Brandy Account
description: Premiere Wine Merchants Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of E. Remy Martin of France, will be introducing this fall into the United States a premium Franch brandy called Grand Empereur. The print campaign, created by Geer DuBois Inc., will begin in the October issues of Time, Playboy, Sports Illustrated, Money and Newsweek, and continue in newspapers and outdoor. No budget figure was available.

title: Advertising; A Silent Boardwalk Television; "In all honesty," said Steven R.  Tanenbaum, ''to see a beautiful girl way up in the air is usually more appealing than trying to stare at the same girl on the beach 30 feet away.''
description: That arguable hypothesis will be tested by a new communications medium that you might call Boardwalk television. In the months to come, a 20-by-30 foot outdoor color television screen set 40 feet above Atlantic City's Boardwalk will be featuring all sorts of images, including 15- , 30- and 60-second advertising segments - all of which will be visible by day as well as by night.

title: July Building Index Off 12%
description: The Dodge Index for new construction contracting fell 12 percent in July, after a sizable advance in June, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company announced yesterday.

title: LEBANESE POLICE TAKE CONTROL OF WEST BEIRUT
description: Lebanese Government security forces assumed exclusive control of the western sector of Beirut today for the first time since the civil war of 1975-76.

title: ROMERO RISES TO OCCASION
description: A day after he was back in the good graces of the Cosmos, Julio Cesar Romero not only started in midfield but played a key role in the elimination of Tulsa. By beating the Roughnecks, 1-0, at Giants Stadium Wednesday night, the Cosmos gained a berth in the semifinal round of the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: MASSELLI SLAYING LINKED TO MONEY DISPUTE
description: New York law-enforcement officials said yesterday that, at this stage of a nine-day-old investigation, they believed that Nathan Masselli had probably been murdered because of a dispute over money with associates of his father and not because of any involvement in a Federal inquiry into allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Northrop Wins Saudi Contract
description: The Northrop Corporation won a $666 million contract to provide training, maintenance and supply services for the Royal Saudi Air Force Peace Hawk VIII, F-5, and F-15 programs, the Defense Department said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corporation's $50 million of notes due in 1992 were priced at 99.095 to yield 13.29 percent, with a 13 1/8 percent coupon, through Goldman, Sachs.

title: ADVANCED PATENT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
York's New Campaign Is by Dancer Agency
description: In a $5 million, six-month advertising campaign to begin in the fall, Peter Paul Cadbury Inc. will begin using an ''I Love New York'' theme to promote the addition of 10 percent more chocolate to its York Peppermint Patties. The budget is almost twice as large as the amount spent in the previous period.

title: WEEKEND JAZZ FILMS AT THE BLEECKER ST.
description: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival is offering a series of films at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street (674-2560), with admissions of $4 (half-price with festival pass) for each program. Reviews of this weekend's bills by Jon Pareles and Robert Palmer follow: Today at 6 and 8 P.M.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Audition Fuels Flight To Debut at the Met

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
10 Horses in Woodward
description: Silver Buck and Winter's Tale will start from adjacent stalls in the $200,000-added Woodward Stakes at 1 1/8 miles tomorrow. The race is the first of three during Belmont Park's fall season that are likely to determine the horse of the year.

title: A LONG AND HONORED CAREER
description: H e has always been the smoothest of world-class athletes, with the regal calm of an Elgin Baylor or a Henry Aaron, but the last days of his career are marked by nerves and pain for Carlos Alberto of the Cosmos.

title: TO INDONESIA WITH COMUTER 'UNDERWEAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS WAIVE LOUIS JACKSON
description: The Giants, with too few tight ends and too many running backs, did something about both problems today. On the eve of their final exhibition game, they acquired a rookie tight end with the unlikely name of Van Heflin and put Louis Jackson, a second-year running back, on waivers.

title: Harvester Partners
description: Neither of the two Dutch shareholders in DAF Trucks NV plans to buy the 37.5 percent stake in DAF held by the International Harvester Company, A. van der Padt, board vice chairman of DAF, said today.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: STUDY TIES TINY GENE DEFECT TO GROWTH OF CANCEROUS CELLS
description: The difference between a normal human gene and one that can transform cells into cancer or a cancer-like state of undisciplined growth can be as small as only one chemical sub-unit among several thousands, according to a report to a scientific meeting here today.

title: High-Yielding Bond Funds
description: MANY individuals living on income from money market funds will be seeking new havens now that interest rates are easing. A few months ago, the money funds produced returns of about 14 percent. But yields are lower now and could drop to 10 percent or less.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Ruby Gillespie Allen Wednesday omitted one survivor, a son, Charles Allen Jr. of Long Island City.

title: 2 HELD
description: A 16-year-old boy drowned in a northern New Jersey lake early last Monday after two other boys kicked and punched him to keep him from coming ashore, authorities said yesterday. The two youths have been charged with homicide.

title: New CBS Singles
description: CBS Records, a subsidiary of CBS Inc., said it would begin shipments Tuesday of its new line of one-sided 45-rpm single recordings. The budget singles, with recordings on only one side, are expected to retail for less than $1, compared with about $1.29 for a two-sided single, and will carry a wholesale price of 29 cents.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Natural Gas Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY ADVISER ON STAGE, MOVIES AND ART
description: Labor Day weekend has traditionally been a time when many New Yorkers leave the city for one last taste of summer. Their exodus can be a gain for those who remain in town. This is one of those weekends when canny natives know they can get to the theater and find tickets to nearly every play and musical on the boards, see a first-run movie without having to wait on long lines and take in art exhibitions at the museums without being jostled by crowds of other seekers after enlightenment and pleasure.

title: Soviet Defense Minister Sees Softening of Tone by Reagan
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that President Reagan had toned down his attitude because of a growing world peace movement, but still harbored aggressive intentions.

title: Economic Scene; American Plan For the I.M.F.
description: THE top issue confronting the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, which opens in Toronto today, is how to increase the resources that may be needed to rescue troubled nations and the world monetary system from collapse. The bailout of Mexico could be the model for future rescue operations. But the problem is how to bail out others, if there should be several Mexicos, without creating so much additional money as to regenerate inflation.

title: Diamond Plans Sales to Wesray
description: The Diamond International Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Heekin Can division to Wesray Packaging Inc. for cash and notes valued at more than $80 million and the assumption of certain liabilities.

title: NUCLEAR TRANSPORT CITED
description: Two companies involved in the delivery of nuclear fuel to the Shoreham nuclear power station on Long Island on July 25 were charged yesterday by New York City's Health Department with having shipped the material through the city without notifying the department.

title: President Resigns At Beatrice Foods
description: Donald P. Eckrich, 58 years old, resigned yesterday as president of the Beatrice Foods Company, the nation's second-largest food operation after Dart & Kraft Inc.

title: A Mute Plea by Morris
description: A Circuit Court judge entered a plea of not guilty on behalf of Eugene (Mercury) Morris today when he refused at his arraignment to acknowledge the cocaine-trafficking charges against him. The judge, Ellen Morphonios-Gable, set a Nov.1 trial date for Morris, the 35-year-old former Miami Dolphins running back who was arrested with two men Aug.18 and charged with attempting to sell ''more than a pound'' of cocaine to undercover detectives.

title: MORE THAN JUST MAIL AFTER WAR
description: The news media have had a good time commenting on the Postal Service's testimony on its preparedness for continued operations after a nuclear attack on the United States. Editorial and headline writers and cartoonists seemed unable to resist whimsical treatment of the idea of mail service after nuclear war. Such a reaction, I suppose, is predictable. But amid the levity the media lost sight of (or preferred to ignore) the less colorful facts of why the Postal Service bothered to think about what it would do if the unthinkable ever happened.

title: Pan Am to Cut Several Routes
description: Pan American World Airways said it will suspend domestic flights out of several American cities this fall as part of a plan to cut expenses.

title: Back Afflictions
description: A painful back ailment that has caused him to miss most of the Los Angeles Raiders' exhibition season is threatening the career of John Matuszak. The 6-foot-8-inch, 285-pound defensive end is undergoing diagnostic tests at Cedar-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where doctors are attempting to deal with the problem without resorting to surgery.

title: MIDDLE EAST: BASIS OF FUTURE BLOODSHED?
description: To the Editor:

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''THE MESSAGE'' is blasting out of radios and portable cassette players on the subways and in streets all over the city, but especially in predominately black neighborhoods. And ''The Message'' is angry. It's like a jungle Sometimes it makes me wonder How I keep from going under chants a voice over a sparse, hypnotically repeating pattern of percussive synthesizers. Don't push me 'cause I'm close to the edge I'm tryin' not to lose my head!

title: BRIEFING
description: Agriculture Responds

title: CITY SCHEDULED TO HALT USE OF ITS DETENTION FACILITIES
description: The Legal Aid Society yesterday sued the City of New York and its Correction Department to bar use of ''subhuman'' pre-arraignment detention facilities in the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street. The facilities are operated by the Correction Department.

title: Du Pont Expansion
description: The Du Pont Company said today that its Netherlands subsidiary was beginning the second step in a $140 million expansion program for fluorine-based products at its Dordrecht works in the Netherlands.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: Lady Iris Mountbatten; A Cousin of the Queen
description: Lady Iris Mountbatten, greatgranddaughter of Queen Victoria and a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, has died here, it was announced today. She was 62 years old.

title: DES MOINES STATION AT 'WAR' OVER CUBA WITHOUT ENLISTING
description: For all these years, radio station WHO in Des Moines has been minding its own business, acting as the predawn companion to farmers throughout the Middle West, providing them with weather reports and updates on such matters as the price of livestock and feed grain.

title: LATIN PROBLEMS CITED
description: Gold's price soared more than $32 an ounce in New York yesterday in response to growing fears about the stability of the world financial system. The price climbed to $438 an ounce, its highest level in 10 1/2 months.

title: Coach and ABC Settle
description: Gordon Wood, a high school football coach from Brownwood, Tex., has settled out of court in a lawsuit against ABC-TV, in which the network suggested that he hit his players. Now he just wants to get back to winning football games.

title: Ex-Stenographer Wins $119,985 in Sex Bias Case
description: A jury has awarded $119,985 to a former stenographer for the General Motors Corporation who said she was dismissed after dropping an idea on equality for women into the company suggestion box.

title: NATO Confident on A-Talks
description: The Supreme Allied Commander of NATO forces in Europe said today that deployment of American missiles in Western Europe would press the Soviet Union toward ''serious negotiations'' on disarmament. The commander, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, said the Soviet Union's willingness to negotiate arms reductions ''would increase considerably'' if the NATO allies went ahead with deployment of the missiles.

title: THE POLITICAL ISSUE OF SEXUAL ORIENTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL METS (NL) - Activated Tom Veryzer, infielder.
description: MILWAUKEE (AL) - Returned Jerry A ugustine, a reliever, to roster after hav- i ng designated him for reassignment. BASKETBALL PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Signed a free agent, Moses Malone, center, to an offer sheet of $13.2 for six years.

title: B.P. Net Off 20.3% in Period
description: The British Petroleum Company, one of the world's largest oil companies and a 53 percent owner of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said today that its earnings in the second quarter fell 20.3 percent from the corresponding period last year.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PUBLISHING: NIXON'S BOOK DUE
description: IN about 10 days, Warner Books expects to have finished copies of Richard Nixon's ''Leaders,'' and it plans to begin shipping the book to stores on Sept. 20, well before the Oct. 25 publication date.

title: Centigrade Takes A Back Seat
description: Radio station WQXR is giving up its years-old policy of announcing temperature readings on its weather reports in centigrade degrees first and then in Fahrenheit.

title: B.Y.U. Wins, 27-0
description: Steve Young passed for 271 yards tonight as Brigham Young defeated Nevada-Las Vegas, 27-0, in the opening game of the college football season. Young, a left-handed passer, completed 19 of 26 passes as Brigham Young's offense gained 468 yards.

title: VILLAGE FESTIVAL IS A JAZZ BARGAIN FOR CLUB HOPPERS
description: JAZZ fans are always telling new versions of an old legend: the myth of the Great Lost Solo, played for a tiny club audience and gone forever. Walk through the Greenwich Village streets around 10 o'clock most nights, and you can hear why. Snatches of jazz drift up from basements and out from bars, played by geniuses and journeymen who still have two sets to go. It's impossible to hear them all, and, as clubgoers know, expensive to try.

title: One-Road Open
description: Those who summer in Southampton - or any place east of there on Long Island's South Fork - are already worrying about the summer of 1986. Southampton's venerable Shinnecock Hills Golf Club will hold the United States Open that year, and since the entire South Fork is served by only one main road, the two-lane Route 27, residents fear horrendous traffic jams.

title: Nun Who Sued Diocese Is Denied Teaching Card
description: The Diocese of Manchester said today that a Roman Catholic nun who sued the diocese was no longer a good enough Catholic to retain her teaching certificate despite 29 years on the job.

title: THE MIDDLE EAST: BASIS FOR FUTURE BLOODSHED
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Rebuts Israelis On Reagan Proposals
description: Former President Carter today disputed an Israeli Government statement that President Reagan's plan for new Middle East negotiations represented a retreat from the Camp David peace plan.

title: 'THE SOLDIER'
description: ''THE SOLDIER'' is the top-secret code name for one of those superheros so beloved these days in espionage fiction - in narratives that exalt the most outrageous kind of unmonitored, strong-arm behavior to make the world safe for democracy. After watching James Glickenhaus's new melodrama, ''The Soldier,'' and other films like it, you somehow get the feeling that what the ''free world'' really needs are a few more dictators who'll not only make airplanes run on time but will also drop nuclear bombs when necessary.

title: Move Upheld On Fidelity
description: The United States Government legally seized the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of Oakland, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today, reversing a lower court.

title: Hearing for Rights Activists In Chile Has Been Postponed
description: A court hearing in Santiago, Chile, that was to consider an appeal by human rights activists concerning their exile from Chile has been postponed until Sept. 21, according to an American lawyer who had planned to observe the hearing.

title: Wurlitzer Outlets
description: The Wurlitzer Company said it had decided to distribute its keybord products entirely through independent dealers and would sell or close its 20 remaining retail outlets. It said agreements had been reached for the sale of many of the company-owned stores and that in each case, the new dealer would continue to sell the Wurlitzer line of keyboard instruments.

title: MAN SAYING HE HAD GRENADE GIVES UP AFTER 10-HOUR TALKS
description: A man who said that he was holding a live grenade and that he also had an explosive device in a briefcase kept dozens of Brooklyn police officers at bay for 10 hours yesterday, but surrendered late last night to police negotiators.

title: HEARTENING THE ARABS A LITTLE
description: President Reagan's policy statement on the Middle East, although short on specifics, is a positive indication that the United States is moving to contain the danger of leaving the Palestinian question unresolved.

title: Danish Cabinet to Quit; Economic Issues Cited
description: Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen of Denmark said today that his minority Cabinet would resign because of opposition to its economic policies.

title: Policeman Is Charged With Sale of Heroin
description: A New York City police officer with more than nine years on the force was arrested and charged with possession and sale of heroin yesterday, authorities said.

title: COLLINS REQUESTS A TRADE
description: Dave Collins, the highest-paid player in baseball without a regular job, gathered six months of frustration today and, like Tommy John before him, poured them into three little words: ''I want out.'' And the Yankees, who had promised Collins that he would have a regular job, were now saying that they would do what they could after the season to trade him.

title: COLONIAL SUBJECTS' MESSAGE TO THE DECOLONIZERS AT THE U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-Net income after a $5,449,015 gain on sale of securities

title: Despite Appearances, Visitors Are Welcome
description: Overnight Wednesday, the Travelers Services and Visitors Information bureau in Times Square got enclosed with a chain-link fence and several blue police barricades - almost as though a ''Not Welcome'' mat had been spread. No hostility was intended at the former Crossroads Building, now city-owned, on the south side of 42d Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue.

title: Vatican Is Frowning On Test-Tube Babies
description: The Vatican radio today condemned the phenomenon of test-tube babies, saying that scientists had ventured into the realm of immorality.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOUSING IN NEWARK APPALLS A U.S. AIDE
description: A Federal housing official said today that living conditions in some of Newark's 26 public housing developments were among the most deplorable he had seen anywhere in the country.

title: Florida Court Vacates Two Death Sentences
description: The Florida Supreme Court today vacated the death sentences of two men, one convicted of killing a 10-year-old girl and another who pleaded no contest in the death of a fruit-stand operator.

title: TEXT OF ISRAEL'S COMMUNIQUE ON THE REAGAN PLAN
description: Following is the text of the communique issued today by the Israeli Cabinet on President Reagan's Middle East proposals. The document was distributed in English by the Government Press Office.

title: Evans Firm Is Now Part Of McMahan
description: Michael K. Evans, the controversial Washington forecaster who early on adopted a supply-side model of the economy, has sold his firm to a Wall Street company.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Renegotiation of Debt Is Requested by Cuba

title: JOHN O'CONNELL, EXECUTIVE EDITOR OF HEARST NEWSPAPERS, DIES AT 61
description: John James O'Connell 3d, executive editor of the Hearst Newspapers and director of the Hearst Feature Service, died of cancer yesterday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 61 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: MIDDLE EAST: BASIS OF FUTURE BLOODSHED
description: To The Editor: It is ironic that the same Arab nations that are now welcoming the P.L.O. evacuees with two fingers raised for ''V'' as in victory didn't raise a single finger to help them when the fighting was going on. EUGENE SHAPIRO Long Island City, N.Y., Aug. 30, 1982

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption with a picture yesterday on the Presidential veto of a supple- mental appropriations bill incorrectly identified a man with Senators How- ard H. Baker Jr. and Paula Hawkins. He was Prime Minister Andries van Agt of the Netherlands.

title: Radisson Failure
description: Radisson Furniture Ltd., once Quebec's largest furniture manfacturer, has declared bankruptcy after a fruitless search for a buyer acceptable to TIW Industries Ltd. of Ottawa, its former parent company, and the four banks that are owed $36 million (Canadian) by Radisson.

title: RESEARCHER SAYS DRUG AIDS VICTIMS OF PARALYSIS
description: Dr. N. Eric Naftchi, a New York University professor in rehabilitation medicine, reported yesterday in the journal Science that, through the use of a drug, he could make cats that were chronically paralyzed walk again and restore many normal sensations.

title: Banks Block AEG Plan
description: Efforts to help AEG-Telefunken avert bankruptcy met a fresh stumbling block today, after the company's creditor banks refused to accept conditions linked to a package of Government-backed credit guarantees.

title: INTEL TECHNOLOGY PROVIDED BY I.B.M.
description: The Intel Corporation said the International Business Machines Corporation had agreed to buy its technology for I.B.M.'s latest 64K RAM, or random access memory, computer chip, which can store 65,536 characters of information.

title: The Talk of Port-au-Prince
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti - There is a saying in Creole, the language of the streets here, that translates, ''Beyond the mountains, more mountains.'' It is both literally and figuratively the story of this country, where life is increasingly a daily contest between nearly insurmountable poverty and nearly unbreakable faith. Haiti is an orphan of a place, an isolated, French-speaking nation of West African origin plopped in the middle of the Spanish and English Caribbean. It seems to be separated from the neighboring Dominican Republic, with which it shares the island of Hispaniola, not so much by a border as by a time warp.

title: Ovett to Miss Meets
description: Suffering from the recurrence of a hamstring injury, Steve Ovett withdrew yesterday from the European track and field championships next week at Athens and the Commonwealth Games beginning Sept. 30 in Brisbane, Australia. Ovett, the 800-meter champion in the 1980 Olympic Games and the holder of the world record in the 1,500 meters, had been scheduled to defend his European 1,500 title and had been named to run in the 800 and the 1,500 at Brisbane.

title: Cheyenne Pipeline
description: The Husky Oil Company said it had purchased the Cheyenne Pipeline from the Cheyenne Pipeline Company. Terms were not disclosed. The main line of the system is a 209-mile, 6-inch pipeline with a 22,000-barrel-a-day capacity from Cheyenne, Wyo., to North Platte, Neb.

title: Part-Time Idea
description: There is a possibility, although a rather remote one, that Bill Walton, still considering a comeback from his foot injury, will try to play part time for the San Diego Clippers. The big center said in Hawaii that he was not capable of playing an 82-game schedule but that he would like to play one game a week while attending his second year of law school at Stanford.

title: IN CAPITAL, IT'S SCOTT'S FOR RIBS
description: Partisan politics reign in this town, but members of the White House press office admit to sharing one passion with their counterparts in the Carter Administration - a hankering for Scott's barbecue.

title: 2 BROTHERS FOLLOW JOE MORRIS
description: The Syracuse football team may be short of experienced offensive players this season, but the Morris family is still well represented on the roster. There are two Morrises who will play against Rutgers tonight at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Mike Morris will be a starter at wide receiver, and Larry is a reserve running back.

title: Buyer's fees, end of a battle.
description: AUCTION houses call the fee they charge to successful bidders the ''buyer's premium.'' This fee, which the two London-based auction giants -Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's - introduced in 1975 caused a dispute that raged for seven years. In the process, two British associations of dealers in art and antiques took legal action and the British Government opened an investigation to see whether there were grounds for charges of collusion between the two houses.

title: Friday; 'GRASS HARP' RETURNS
description: The Apple Corps Theater, at 601 West 51st Street, is presenting its first musical, a revival of ''The Grass Harp,'' which appeared on Broadway in 1971. Based on the novel by Truman Capote about growing up in a small Southern town, it focuses on a teen-age boy, his two maiden aunts, a black woman who believes she is an Indian and the eccentric people who touch their lives. The book and lyrics are by Kenward Elmslie, the music by Claibe Richardson. Nicholas Deutsch is the director. Performances, through Sept. 26. are at 8 P.M., Thursdays through Saturdays, with matinees at 3 on Saturday and Sunday. Tickets are $6. Reservations: 664-0027. FABRICS OF AFRICAN LIFE

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $372,000 for the qr and $656,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: Down the Avenue, Fifth Avenue
description: They've been marching up Fifth Avenue for years, and Michael Grosso has never liked it. Tomorrow, they'll be running down the avenue, and Michael Grosso doesn't like it any better. Mr. Grosso is executive vice president of the Fifth Avenue Association, and it has been his mission to protect the avenue from such untoward intrusions.

title: BELIEVED PART OF RING
description: Three men believed to be part of a group that has been breaking into East Side boutiques were arrested early yesterday after they broke into a dress shop on East 79th Street, the police said. Five others were said to have escaped with $14,000 worth of gowns and dresses.

title: HEAD OF INDIAN POINT INQUIRY QUITS, SAYING SAFETY CRITICS ARE BLOCKED
description: The chairman of a three-judge panel conducting hearings on the safety of the two Indian Point nuclear power plants resigned yesterday, saying that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was not giving opponents of the plant a fair chance to state their case.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. NOW SAYS SOLDIER WENT OVER TO THE NORTH KOREANS VOLUNTARILY

title: NATIONAL VALVE & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MISS GARRISON CUTS A MOLD OF HER OWN
description: It isn't likely, Zina Garrison says. But maybe some day if she fulfills her potential as a tennis player everyone will stop comparing her with Althea Gibson, who in 1957 became the first black woman to capture the United States Open and Wimbledon titles. It isn't that Miss Garrison, who is also black, minds being compared with Miss Gibson. But if it were up to her, she would rather be compared to John McEnroe.

title: CLASHES IN POLAND GO ON FOR 3D DAY IN MINING TOWN
description: Demonstrators and riot policemen clashed for the third day in a row in this southwestern copper-mining town, where two people were reported killed on Tuesday.

title: TEXT OF SECURITY COUNCIL'S RESOLUTION 242
description: Following is the text of Resolution 242, which was approved by the Security Council on Nov. 22, 1967:

title: Service for Calvin Simmons To Be Conducted on Tuesday
description: A funeral service for Calvin Simmons, the young conductor who drowned Aug. 21 in a canoeing accident, will take place Tuesday at 11 A.M. in Grace Cathedral in San Francisco.

title: FAREWELL TOAST TO SUMMER IN CITY AND SUBURBS
description: NEW YORKERS will stroll, march, run, fly and even jump from parachutes this Labor Day weekend.

title: JORDAN WELCOMES THE REAGAN PLAN
description: The Government of Jordan withheld formal comment today on President Reagan's new Middle East plan, but it made clear through authorized sources that its reaction was ''favorable, with reservations about some points that have to be clarified.''

title: No Headline
description: Indians 4, Brewers 2

title: TOURING HUSHED WORLD OF CITY MANSIONS
description: Eras end long before their death warrants are signed, but it might reasonably be argued that when Nikita S. Khrushchev stepped onto the balcony of the home of Percy Rivington Pyne 2d, built 49 years earlier to the designs of McKim, Mead & White, the time was past when the Upper East Side was the exclusive province of those who were mentioned in the papers only at birth, marriage or death.

title: 'TESTAMENT,' 'HOOKER'
description: ONE handy solution when the programming pickings are slim is to put together a ''thematic'' package. So this week WNET-TV, Channel 13, is offering a series of programs as part of a package designed to salute the American worker. Tonight at 10 o'clock, ''Miles of Smiles, Years of Struggles,'' produced and directed by Jack Santino and Paul Wagner, offers a history of the Pullman porters, a group of workers who began forming themselves in the mid-1920's into the country's first black union.

title: 'Dance a Little Closer' is closer to curtain time.
description: ''IT'S one of those terrible colloquialisms: all systems are go,'' Alan Jay Lerner announces. And so, he and Charles Strouse are getting ready to launch their new musical, ''Dance a Little Closer.'' They have just found their two leading men, Len Cariou and George Rose. Mr. Cariou was last seen on Broadway playing the title role in ''Sweeney Todd,'' and Mr. Rose is currently ''the very model of a modern major general'' in ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' The leading lady, Liz Robertson, who is also Mrs. Lerner, has been set for some time.

title: CHELSEA RESTAURANT SHUT IN HEPATITIS INQUIRY
description: The Department of Health yesterday ordered a restaurant in the Chelsea section of Manhattan closed because it was the ''probable source'' of a recent outbreak of Type A hepatitis, the department said.

title: RULES ISSUED FOR GLIDERS AND ULTRALIGHT AIRCRAFT
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, reacting to surging national interest in hang gliders and ultralight powered aircraft, announced today the first Federal rules for their operation.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates fell yesterday, with all of the decline occurring after 2:30 P.M., when rumors began circulating that Argentina had defaulted on an international payment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Monitoring Systems Inc., Broomfield, Colo., has appointed Gale D. Burnett chairman; Roy Lee Steelman president; A. Bryant Nelson executive vice president, and Ralph P. Baker vice president.

title: U.S. DRIVE ON TAX HAVENS
description: The Federal Government is pressing to negotiate agreements with a number of countries that are havens for the laundering of money and the evasion or avoidance of taxes.

title: THE BALLET THEATER CALLS OFF PARIS VISIT
description: American Ballet Theater yesterday canceled its two-week Paris season, scheduled to begin Oct. 12, after the company's dancers, whose contract expired on Tuesday, voted 81 to 1 to reject management's latest offer.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW LIMITS ON DEDUCTIONS
description: Everyone should pay a fair share of the tax burden. That is a key theme in the new tax bill. For the individual taxpayer, this takes the form of reduced deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses, and a newly structured minimum tax that broadens the base of income subject to the tax. Tax advisers say that these changes should prompt people to review some aspects of their finances. The new limitation on deductions for casualty losses, for example, may mean that increased insurance coverage will be desirable. And the new alternative minimum tax could make certain investments, such as incentive stock options, appear less attractive.

title: Jennifer Leigh and her trip from X to R.
description: ''FAST TIMES AT RIDGEMONT HIGH,'' opening today (a review appears on page C6), has an R rating. For a while, it had an X rating, but a scene between Jennifer Jason Leigh and Robert Romanus made the young women in preview audiences so uncomfortable that Universal toned it down.

title: Senior Executive Leaving Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company said today that its chief technical officer had resigned. In addition, the company said about 7,000 Harvester workers would be affected within the next two weeks by extended layoffs at Quad-Cities plants and two-week work suspensions at three truck plants.

title: EUROPEANS REBUFF U.S. ON PIPELINE
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to negotiate a settlement of its dispute with its European allies over the Soviet gas pipeline has been set back by the apparent refusal of the Europeans to meet with a United States emissary of less than Cabinet rank.

title: WHITE SUITS FOR LUXURY
description: Red, white and blue are the traditional colors for the resort season, and this time, the most significant of the three is white. White sweaters, blouses, pants, dresses and skirts abound in the first warm-weather fashion collections. Shown recently on Seventh Avenue, they will appear in the stores starting next month for women planning midwinter vacations or those who live in the South. The most important category of white clothes is the tailored suit.

title: RIVER;
description: New York City hopes to open part of its new sewage treatment plant on the Upper West Side a year ahead of schedule but to abandon construction of some or all of the rest, reducing the treatment of matter going into the Hudson River.

title: A TIME TO INVEST IN ADULT EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE STAYED UNCHANGED AT 9.8.% IN AUGUST
description: The nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 9.8 percent in August, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Haskell Brooks Curry, Math and Logic Expert
description: Dr. Haskell Brooks Curry, a specialist in applied mathematics and symbolic logic and professor emeritus at Pennsylvania State University, died Wednesday at Centre Community Hospital in State College, Pa., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Robot Maker Accord
description: The Nordson Corporation agreed today to market robots produced by the Yaskawa Electric Manufacturing Company of Japan. The robots are used to apply adhesives, sealants and caulking materials.

title: Letter: On Fitness Standards Testing Female Firefighters
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICAN BANKS SEEN EASING RATES
description: Mexico's banking system, nationalized this week, will lower interest rates when banks reopen Monday in the hope of appeasing business opposition to the takeover, according to wellplaced officials.

title: ARAFAT TO DISCUSS REAGAN PLAN
description: Yasir Arafat, arriving in Tunis from Greece, called a meeting of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Central Committee for this weekend to discuss President Reagan's Middle East peace proposals.

title: CONVICTIONS OF 4 IN ABSCAM CASE UPHELD BY COURT
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the convictions of four former Congressmen who took payoffs from undercover agents in the Justice Department's two-year Abscam investigation.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1982
description: International A national debate in Israel will be initiated by Shimon Peres, the leader of the Labor opposition, over President Reagan's proposal for Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Mr. Peres said the Labor Party will put the issue before a special session of Parliament next week. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Israeli Army is ready for action across Lebanon. Its tanks, longrange artillery and infantry face the Syrian Army across a ceasefire line that extends from 15 miles east of Beirut and sweeps for about 45 miles southeast to within a few miles of the Syrian border, placing artillery within shelling distance of Damascus. (1:4.)

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to july 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1982

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: WASHINGTON AFTER an airline sends your tennis racquet on a world excursion without you or after a moving company drops your piano off a truck, you may want to complain to the highest authorities - the state and Federal regulators. But you might also want some free advice on planting a fall garden on a Manhattan balcony or information about Federal college loans.

title: Killer of 13 Women Gets 60-Year Sentence
description: A judge wearing a bulletproof vest today honored a plea bargain promise and sentenced a confessed killer of 13 women to 60 years in prison ''because the death penalty is not available to me.''

title: GUNMEN IN SICILY KILL HIGH ITALIAN POLICE OFFICIAL
description: Gen. Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, one of Italy's highest ranking police officials, was assassinated by gunmen tonight in the center of Palermo, Sicily. His wife and a police escort were also slain.

title: SOLVING DANCERS' HEALTH AND EMOTIONAL PROBLEMS
description: Airborne and forever young, dancers have long seemed to be creatures without a past, present or future. But attention is being paid now to the reality that often lies behind that picture. Muscles are pulled. Backs are strained. Psyches are bruised. And, to make matters worse, many dancers view medical treatment as careerthreatening and an expensive luxury.

title: 3 IN GREENWICH ARE FOUND SLAIN AT THEIR HOME
description: A woman and her 14-year-old daughter and 11-year-old son were found shot to death in their Greenwich, Conn., home yesterday morning, and the police later said the mother, who had a recent history of depression, apparently had killed the children and herself.

title: Soviet Restricts Incoming Phone Links
description: The Soviet Union has cut automatic telephone links with Western Europe, citing a reorganization of its internal telephone network and unspecified technical grounds for the move.

title: Consecutive Aces Defy Golf Odds
description: A letter last week asked what the odds were against two people in the same foursome each shooting a hole-in-one on the same hole. ''It had happened at Springdale Golf Club in Princeton, N.J.,'' the letter continued. ''My husband, Bill Bonthron, had one, and Mrs. Leroy Purvis had the second, on the 15th hole.''

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 125 Years of Fashion At the Cooper-Hewitt

title: U.S. DENIES BREAKING ITS PROMISE TO CONSULT ISRAEL ON PEACE PLANS
description: The State Department today denied Israeli assertions that it had violated commitments to consult Israel before undertaking Middle East peace initiatives such as President Reagan's proposal this week.

title: Boston Youth Ordered to Jail For Harassing Black Family
description: A white teen-ager was sentenced to 60 days in jail Thursday for urinating in front of a black family in defiance of a court order prohibiting him from racial harassment.

title: Stolen Durers Displayed After Their Return
description: Two paintings by the German master Albrecht Durer, worth an estimated $3 million to $5 million each, were on display here again today - 37 years after they were stolen by an American soldier who later sold them for $450.

title:
Patents;
Laser Used For Optical Storage
description: WASHINGTON A laser smaller than a grain of salt, but described by its inventor as the most powerful of its kind in the world, was patented this week for the RCA Corporation. Dan Botez, the research scientist in optoelectronics for RCA who obtained patent 4,347,486, believes the laser could revolutionize optical storage as well as communications systems that transmit light through fibers.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Phillies vs. Houston Astros, at Philadelphia. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Denver Broncos, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. The New York Sack Exchange, recovered from injuries, will be together for the first time this season, in the final exhibition game. (Television - Channel 5, 11 P.M., tape. Radio -WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.) Cowboys vs. Houston Oilers, exhibition, at Dallas. (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) Grambling vs. Morgan State, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M. This is the annual benefit game for the Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Scholarship Fund.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The shr earnings results are reported on shrs of 2,755,305 the total shrs outstdng after adjustment for the 3-for-2 stock split which was effective Oct 20, 1981

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15. 1. Lady Donaldson, pictured above, holds what is thought to be the oldest civic position in the City of London, a job that in some American cities would be a starring role. What position is it?

title: WILL 'BUTTLEGGERS' LOSE THEIR FEDERAL OPPOSITION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvester Reports On Dresser Pact
description: The International Harvester Company said that it had received about 22 cents on the dollar when it sold its construction equipment business to Dresser Industries last month.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRAND NEW HOUSE

title: News Analysis
description: Washington's proposal for Palestinian selfrule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip has swept away a major hope by Israel that the Reagan Administration would provide a respite from years of American pressure to give up the occupied territories.

title: OFFPUT BY THE UPWARD
description: In New York and maybe in your town too, news broadcasters habitually speak of weekends as though they were masses of ill-digested food. At present, for example, we are in the midst of what they have for days been calling the upcoming Labor Day weekend.

title:
PATENTS;
Snake Bite Treatment Lessens Tissue Damage
description: A method of treating snake bites was patented this week. Eugene L. Giroux, a biochemist, assigned patent 4,347,255 to Merrell-Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc., a subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, in Cincinnati.

title: ISRAELI OPPOSITION TO OPEN A DEBATE ON REAGAN'S PLAN
description: Shimon Peres, the leader of Israel's Labor Party opposition, said today that his party would open a major national debate in Israel over President Reagan's plan for Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.5 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $1.5 billion in the latest reporting week, the fourth increase in five weeks. The announcement yesterday by the Federal Reserve of the increase in the M-1 money supply, to $456.3 billion for the week ended Aug. 25, caused little change in the credit markets. Interest rates rose after the announcement at 4:10 P.M. but still ended the day at lower levels than on Thursday.

title: THE EDSEL: REQUIEM FOR A FLOP
description: Twenty-five years ago today, after a drumbeat of hoopla and fanfare unmatched in the history of the auto industry, Ford introduced the Edsel.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $77,545...C-Net loss; yr-ago shrs outstdng have been adjusted to reflect stock splits

title: PANEL TO STUDY REPORT THAT DRUG AIDS PARALYTICS
description: New York University plans to appoint an expert committee to investigate the assertions made by a professor at the university that a drug has helped paralyzed patients regain some sensations and use of their muscles.

title: India's Journalists Strike Over Press Law Proposal
description: More than 10,000 journalists went on a 24-hour strike today, shutting India's newspapers and broadcasting stations, to protest a proposed law that would authorize the jailing of those who published ''scurrilous'' articles.

title: ODIERNO INDICTED IN SLAYING OF INQUIRY FIGURE IN BRONX
description: Salvatore Odierno was indicted yesterday on charges of killing Nathan Masselli in what investigators characterized as an underworld business dispute rather than an incident connected to the victim's role as a witness in the Federal inquiry into Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income; shr earnings have been adjusted for preferred divds of $3.00 a shr paid in Mar

title: HAITIAN REFUGEES NOT SHOWING UP FOR HEARINGS TO DETERMINE STATUS
description: About one-third of the Haitian refugees scheduled for immigration hearings after being released under a Federal court order last month have been failing to show up. The hearings are being held to determine whether they will be able to remain in this country.

title: GIANTS LOSE IN OVERTIME, 16-13
description: The Giants ended their exhibition season tonight with a 16-13 overtime loss to the Miami Dolphins. The defeat did not seem to bother them because they saw enough good things to feel confident they are headed for another winning season.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Sheriff. 2. The radio station in Des Moines where President Reagan began his broadcasting career. The Cuban Government disrupted programming on WHO and on four other AM frequencies in the United States, apparently in response to plans by the Reagan Administration to transmit radio programs to Cuba,

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago 6 mos results include revs of $6.8 million from Southern Stores, sold inApr 1981; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Aug

title: STOCKS RISE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Buyers poured into the stock market yesterday and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest level in more than a year. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, fed by buying demand from pension funds, individuals and foreign investors, was the third largest on record at 130.9 million shares.

title: F.B.I. Investigating One of Its Supervisors
description: The Justice Department acknowledged today that a supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been under criminal investigation for two years. Newpaper reports have tied the investigation to seven bank robberies.

title: THE INVISIBLE PEOPLE OF THE UNITED STATES OPEN
description: The United States Open has come to Queens, a carnival with Lacoste shirts. There are bright yellow and white tents, and little pavilions hung with philodendrons, and stands that offer commemorative T-shirts and hardcover editions of the life stories of Billie Jean King, Bjorn Borg, even Ilie Nastase.

title: New York Gold Up $20; Price Highest in a Year
description: Continued nervousness about financial stability in Latin America pushed the New York price of gold up a further $20 yesterday, to $458 an ounce, its highest level in almost a year.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT YANKEES
description: Before the game, someone asked Jay Howell what he thought about being a Yankee. ''I'm not even thinking,'' the rookie pitcher said, nervously awaiting his start against the hard-hitting Kansas City Royals.

title: Pact on Miami Filming
description: A modernized version of the early 1930's gangster movie ''Scarface,'' whose production the producer had threatened to move from Miami because of opposition from the Cuban community here, will be filmed in Miami. Mayor Maurice Ferre said at a news conference Thursday that the producer, Martin Bregman, had agreed to film the movie in Miami despite his earlier threats to take the production elsewhere.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET EDITORS SHARE DREAM
description: Here in remote middle New Hampshire, in an old wooden schoolroom on the campus of Colby-Sawyer College, Soviet and American editors came together and talked about their roles as journalists and citizens in a time of commonly felt nuclear threat.

title: DEMOCRATS BASE CAMPAIGN PLANS ON REAGAN ECONOMIC RECORD
description: If the Democratic strategy for the November elections could be condensed into a bumper sticker, it might read, ''Don't Blame Us, Blame Reagan.'' As the races for House, Senate and gubernatorial seats get under way in earnest, most candidates are focusing their campaigns on the record of the Reagan Administration, mainly on economic matters. The Democrats argue that the White House program has failed. They say that it is particularly unfair to the hard-working, middle-class voters who traditionally vote Democratic but might have strayed to Mr. Reagan and the Republicans in 1980, and that it is insensitive to minorities and the handicapped.

title: Cage to Mark Birthday With a Radio Premiere
description: John Cage, the avant-garde composer, will observe his 70th birthday tomorrow by participating in what he has called an ''audio experience for radio,'' the world premiere of his new work, ''15 Domestic Minutes'' which will be broadcast in New York on WNYC-FM, 93.9, during ''The Sunday Show.''

title: BLACK CHEERLEADER BALKS AT WAVING THE 'REBEL' FLAG
description: Confederate flags swirled about John Hawkins's head Thursday night but never touched his hands or his heart.

title: Outdoor Site at Church Set for Yugoslav Play
description: A 13.5-acre site on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will be the stage for the Zagreb Theater Company of Yugoslavia's production of ''The Liberation of Skopje.'' The play, which will be presented by the cathedral and the La Mama E.T.C., will have a run of 10 performances from Sept. 16 to 26.

title: WOODWARD TALE
description: S hakespeare's ''The Winter's Tale'' was first performed in 1611, 202 years before Sir Walter Scott wrote the epic poem ''Rokeby.'' Paul Mellon, a lover of most things English and literary, used the titles of those two works in naming his stable and the gelding who will carry its colors today in the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park. Winter's Tale, the pride of Mellon's Rokeby Stable, is a leading player in a saga as intricate and complex as Shakespeare's or Scott's.

title: Reynolds Buys Heublein Shares
description: SALEM, N.C., Sept. 3 (Reuters) - R.J. Reynolds Industries said it had bought 4 million Heublein shares from the company under its previously announced offer for $63 a share, for a $252 million total purchase.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 16 weeks to June 24
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,168,000...C-Net income

title: Argentine Communists Rally
description: An estimated 15,000 people, many waving red flags and chanting ''The military dictatorship is going to end!'' filled a downtown sports arena tonight at a Communist Party demonstration. It was the party's first rally since President Reynaldo Bignone lifted a ban on political activities on July 1.

title:
PATENTS;
Computer Monitors Health of Employees
description: A computer system for surveying the health of employees in various plants, with consideration of potentially hazardous materials such as asbestos, has been invented for the Diamond Shamrock Corporation of Dallas. Patent 4,347,568 was granted Edward L. Giguere and four other employees this week.

title: RUNNING A PLEASURE FOR SCOTT
description: A s far as the purists are concerned, Steve Scott and other worldclass milers have desecrated the most glamorous event in track and field by taking it into the gutter. It doesn't do any good to argue that these are famous byways - the Piazza Navona in Rome, the Champs Elysees in Paris and Fifth Avenue in New York, where one-mile road races are being run this year. No, it seems that one must run four times around an oval in spike shoes for it to be recognized as a true mile. Running a mile of city streets is considered cheating.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PATENTS;
Method Helps Detect Presence of Antibotics
description: The presence of penicillin or other antibiotics in milk constitutes a public health problem.

title: TACKLING THE CRISIS IN SECONDARY SCHOOLS
description: The issue of names has surfaced in a surprisingly serious way in the debate about how to remedy a crisis in the quality of secondary school education. This is a crisis whose causes and dimensions are the subject of some dozen major inquiries, including one by a commission appointed by Secretary of Education Terrel H. Bell.

title: MAGNUSON COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Truman's 97-Year-Old Widow Is Listed in Serious Condition
description: Bess Truman, the 97-year-old former First Lady, received blood intravenously and remained in serious condition, but her hospital said her internal bleeding had apparently stopped.

title: SUPPLIERS CONTINUE MANVILLE BUSINESS
description: Suppliers of the Manville Corporation have indicated that they will continue to do business with the legally beleaguered asbestos manufacturer despite its bankruptcy petition.

title: County Averts Payday Crisis
description: A payless payday today for 3,800 Wayne County government employees was averted when the county treasurer agreed to transfer $4 million from the delinquent tax account to the county general fund. The treasurer, Raymond Wojtowicz, said a direct transfer of $2 million would cover today's payroll and an advance of another $2 million would guarantee the Sept. 10 payroll. The financially troubled county encompasses Detroit, where the unemployment rate for July was 15.2 percent.

title: Kaiser Accord On Texaco Gas
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to pay Texaco higher prices for future deliveries of natural gas under an existing contract and in turn Texaco Inc. will pay it about $181 million in cash.

title: U.S. APPROVES JERSEY LINK TO THRUWAY
description: The completion of a 20-mile section of Interstate 287 to extend it to the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in New York State has been approved by Federal highway authorities after a decade of hearings and studies.

title: AN OVERSEAS TRIP: FUNCTIONS OR FUN?
description: As Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has kept a very low profile in Washington. But lately, by his own account, he has been receiving a lot of attention in China, Hong Kong and Egypt.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices rose sharply again on heavy buying by pension funds, individuals and foreign investors. Volume soared to 130.9 million shares, the third highest on record. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 15.73 points, to 925.13, its highest level in more than a year. Analysts also cited an influx of cash from Latin America. (Page 1.) The money supply rose $1.5 billion in the week ended Aug. 25, reflecting in large part money as it flowed into stocks. (30.)

title: Identity Crisis
description: As is customary, sports department offices this week received the 1982 collection of American Football Conference press guides.

title: Bomb Explodes at Door Of Consulate in Miami
description: A bomb exploded at the Venezuelan consulate here Thursday night and a telephone caller today said that an anti-Castro group, Omega 7, took responsibility as a protest of Venezuelan treatment of an imprisoned terrorist, Orlando Bosch.

title: People Express To Cut Fares
description: People Express Airlines Inc. said that effective Sept. 13 it would cut prices on most of its scheduled service. The airline said that new fares for all seats on all flights would be $29 between Newark and Boston, $39 from Newark to Columbus, Ohio, $49 between Newark and Jacksonville, Fla., $69 between Pittsburgh and Sarasota, Fla., and $19 from Newark to Syracuse.

title: The Willowbrook Plan Worked
description: ''Deinstitutionalization'' - moving mental patients from enormous, remote hospitals into small community residences - has become another symbol of do-goodism gone wrong. When in recent years New York State officials removed tens of thousands of inmates from mental hospitals without adequately funding or planning for their care in communities, many wound up on the streets.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Bonanza for a Violinist

title: Drug Warning Asked For Pregnant Women
description: The Government today proposed requiring a standard warning on most nonprescription drugs advising pregnant women and nursing mothers to seek professional advice before taking the medicines.

title: Uganda Passes Bill To Compensate Asians
description: Uganda's Parliament passed a bill that would return to Uganda's Asians the property that was seized by the dictator Idi Amin 10 years ago, Uganda Radio said today.

title: 4 INTERNED POLISH DISSIDENTS ARE CHARGED WITH TREASON
description: Polish authorities today accused Jacek Kuron and three other leaders of the dissident intellectual group KOR of trying to overthrow the state by force.

title: 'INCUBUS,' SUPERNATURAL
description: ''The Incubus,'' which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and other theaters, is a supernatural horror film about rape, a subject that the R-rated movie takes a firm stand against even as it's smacking its lips. Most of the time the incubus looks like an ordinary human being but, at the end, when it's seen for the first time as its true self, it looks like a large, shaggy, extremely mean E.T. with bad teeth.

title: Bendix Shares Jump by $2.625
description: The Bendix Corporation's shares jumped $2.625, to $58.50, on the New York Stock Exchange as sentiment spread that the Martin Marietta Corporation might take in a partner in its $1.5 billion takeover bid for Bendix.

title: Weinberger Arrives in Cairo
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, on the third leg of a Middle East mission, arrived in Cairo tonight to promote President Reagan's new peace plan. He was greeted at the airport by the Egyptian Defense Minister, Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala.

title: 300,000 RALLY TO BACK MEXICAN LEADER
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo, who just days ago appeared to have lost all power and popularity, stood on the balcony of the National Palace today and received the support of some 300,000 workers, peasants and civil servants for his decision to nationalize the country's private banks this week.

title: SENATOR EAST'S CULPRITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of the Times
description: VISIONS FROM SAN FRANCISCO BAY. By Czeslaw Milosz. 226 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $14.95.

title: GAS LEAK IS FOUND AT JERSEY A-PLANT
description: Low levels of radioactive gas were released Friday at the Salem nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey, and officials said today that they believed that the release had been caused by tampering with a valve.

title: Hospital Worker Wins $1.3 Million
description: A 44-year-old hospital maintenance man is the winner of a $1,392,520 top prize in Thursday's Pick-6 Lotto drawing, state lottery officials announced today.

title: Your Money; Zero Coupon, Insured C.D.'s
description: IN recent years, the public has become quite familiar with bank certificates of deposit, which are now available for periods ranging from seven days to more than seven years. But one type seems to be little known to most depositors: zero coupon certificates.

title: Joseph P. Vaccarella, 80, Dies; Ex-Mayor of Mount Vernon (NY)
description: Joseph P. Vaccarella, former Mayor of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died Wednesday at Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Pembroke Pines, Fla.

title: ADULT TRIALS SOUGHT FOR 2 ACCUSED IN YOUTH'S DROWNING
description: The Sussex County Prosecutor today asked that two teen-age boys be tried for murder as adults in the case of a 16-year-old youth who drowned in Lake Hopatcong.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Litigious City

title: LAYOFFS SHRINK U.S. TEACHING FORCE
description: Ralph DeBaske sat in his living room in this pleasant suburb west of Detroit and commented wryly on the progress of his career: ''On the whole, I guess I'm not where I expected to be at this point.''

title: Sockers Will Play
description: The Cosmos will play the San Diego Sockers in an opener of the North American Soccer League playoff semifinals tomorrow night, despite a threat Thursday by the Sockers' owner, Bob Bell, to forfeit the game. ''We're playing the game,'' Jack Daley, San Diego's general manager, said yesterday.

title: CHOOSING THE BEST CHILI IN A CAN
description: Chili con carne, with or without beans, is one food preparation that lends itself perfectly to canning, so it is reasonable to expect that perfect canned chili would be widely available, at the ready to be reheated into soul-satisfying quick meals. But as recent tastings of six brands and 11 variations indicated, that is not the case at all. Only Ray's Chilli, available by mail from Springfield, Ill., offered a first-rate option. Perhaps that extra ''l'' makes the difference.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day Aug. 25 on the planned sale of several television and radio stations incorrectly identified the purchaser of WMET-FM in Chicago. The Doubleday Broadcasting Company agreed to buy the station from Metromedia Inc.

title: Ex-Watergate Guard Freed
description: Frank Wills, the security guard who discovered the June 1972 break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate complex, which eventually led to the resignation of President Nixon, was released today after spending two days in jail on a charge of shoplifting a $17 pair of tennis shoes.

title: ONE OF THE WORLD'S LEADING PIANISTS
description: Sir Clifford Curzon, the world-renowned British pianist, died Wednesday in St. Thomas's Hospital in London after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Begin Said to Meet in Secret With Beirut's President-Elect
description: The Israeli radio reported today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin met secretly last Wednesday with Presidentelect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon.

title: Nuclear Rules Assailed
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, helping dedicate a $5 million Westinghouse service center for nuclear power plants Thursday, criticized the regulations involved in the licensing of such plants.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $15,000

title: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-The company broke even for the latest qr

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Phillies 2, Astros 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Mike Schmidt hit a two-out, ninth-inning home run to lift Philadelphia behind the two-hit pitching of Steve Carlton. Joe Niekro (13-10) retired the first two batters in the ninth before Schmidt hit his 29th home run.

title: PRAISE FOR THE BUDGET PROCESS
description: It may be the only secret left in Washington: The budget process works, and it works well. Congress's budget machinery manufactures tax and spending policy to meet the demands that the electorate places on its Government. Like all political machinery, it generates a lot of heat and smoke and noise. The heat, the smoke and the noise make rousing television footage and lively newspaper copy, but they obscure the machine's productive output.

title: LONG OVERDUE TO 'CHEAP POWER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dome Unable To Meet Debts
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. disclosed that it is unable to meet debt repayments of $1 billion by the Sept. 30 deadline set by its creditors. The company also said that it had been delaying, with the agreement of its creditors, the repayment of some principal on certain obligations that was due June 30.

title: REAGAN APPROVES BIG TAX INCREASES
description: In the privacy of his mountain ranch near here, President Reagan today signed a bill raising taxes by $98.3 billion over the next three years.

title: STORE DELIVERY CHARGES COVER WIDE RANGE
description: With few exceptions, free department store deliveries are extinct in New York City, having gone the way of free road maps, free admission to museums and service with a smile. Even B. Altman & Company, one of the last department store holdouts for free furniture delivery within the local area, began charging for the service late last month.

title: 2 Are Accused In Stabbing Case
description: A Manhattan woman and a companion have been seized in the stabbing of the woman's husband, the police said yesterday. The two - 40-year-old Michelle Jacobs, and Charles Coull, 50, of 144 West 125th Street - were charged with first-degree assault in the Thursday night stabbing of Richard Jacobs, 64, a record producer, at the couple's apartment at 400 East 56th Street. He was listed in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital.

title: Today's Featured Matches; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Yannick Noah-Eric Korita Second Match - Martina Navratilova-Nancy Yeargin Third Match - Ivan Lendl-Harold Solomon Evening Program

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Urban Anthropology

title: REAGAN'S PLAN INS OFFICIAL AND EDITORIAL BACKING IN EUROPE
description: President Reagan's proposals for a Middle East settlement have won applause in Western Europe. In a typical comment, The Times of London said this morning that the President's initiative ''is the best and most hopeful forign policy move to come out of his Administration.''

title: New Blow at L.S.U.
description: The Louisiana State basketball program, which already in recent months had lost four players from a team that did not include any seniors last season, suffered a big setback yesterday when Derrick Taylor was declared academically ineligible. As a freshman point guard last season, Taylor led the team in assists and was the secondleading scorer. The Tigers had previously lost two players who quit, one who transferred and another who was found ineligible.

title: DINNER BY HOMOSEXUALS WILL AID POLITICAL DRIVES
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale will give the keynote address. The leader of the Brooklyn Democratic organization, Meade H. Esposito, and Brooklyn's District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, will be on the dais.

title: 100,000 AT OPENING OF 3-DAY COAST ROCK FESTIVAL
description: Nearly 100,000 fans braved searing temperatures and stifling smog today to take part in a vast three-day festival celebrating hard rock and high technology.

title: FISHING: A BITTER HARVEST
description: Like their fathers and grandfathers before them, New England's fishermen have learned to accept an occasionally meager harvest or brutal storm. These are costs willingly borne for the independence of harvesting the ocean instead of working on an assembly line to earn a living.

title: McENROE DEFEATS DAVIS; MISS NAVRATILOVA GAINS
description: John McEnroe and Martina Navratilova, the top-seeded players, struggled during the early stages of their matches yesterday before emerging with straight-set victories at the United States Open tennis championships.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 2 Premieres for Chicago

title: Widow Wins Case In Death at Attica
description: The State of New York used excessive force in retaking Attica state prison during an inmate uprising 11 years ago, a judge ruled today in awarding $550,000 to the widow of a hostage killed when the prison was retaken on Sept. 13, 1971.

title: RAGAN, BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including gains of $86,000 for the latest first qr and $96,000 for the yr-agofirst qr from the sale of buildings

title:
THE REGION;
Westchester Plans Bus Runs to City
description: Westchester County will begin a new commuter bus service to Manhattan Tuesday that will compete with Conrail and with existing express services to the city.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Marcos Plans Visit To U.S. on Sept. 15

title: No Time for Tightwads at the I.M.F.
description: For the United States, the annual gathering of the International Monetary Fund, which begins tomorrow in Toronto, offers an opportunity to demonstrate enlightened leadership - and a risk of once again playing the tightwad.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review yesterday gave an incorrect location for the Crepe Suzette. It is 363 West 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: CURRAN, AT FAIR, CALLS LEHRMAN NAIVE
description: Paul J. Curran, accompanied by his wife, Barbara, and four of their seven children, visited the state fairgrounds today to greet people and to attack his opponent in the Republican gubernatorial primary as either being ''naive'' or a man attempting to sell ''snake oil.''

title: NEW FROM CBS: THE RECORD WITHOUT A FLIP SIDE
description: The latest innovation in record marketing is a return to the oldest disk format: the one-sided record. CBS Records announced yesterday that on Tuesday it will release eight one-sided singles - 45-rpm disks with just one song rather than the usual A and B sides. The one-song singles, which will also be released in a two-sided format, include new material by such millionselling acts as REO Speedwagon and Luther Vandross, and a duet by Kenny Loggins and Journey's Steve Perry. Selections by Elvis Costello, Santana, Ricky Skaggs and Paul Carrack complete the release.

title: Atlantic City's Bad Bet
description: Atlantic City was an ugly, dying resort when the first casino opened four years ago. Today it is alive with nine glittering gambling dens that drew 19 million visitors last year. They employ 28,500 people and yield $200 million in taxes to city, county and state, and the state's receipts go to aid the disabled and elderly.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting method from completed contract basis to a percentage of completion basis in order to better match revs and expenses within accounting periods by Summit Gear, a subsidiary

title: Bridge: Errors in Tournament Play Aren't Usually Very Funny
description: Shakespeare wrote only one play called ''The Comedy of Errors'' - but many tournament bridge performances deserve the title. However, in such cases very few of the errors are in themselves comical. One of the exceptions was noted by Fred Neuburger at a recent tournament in Rochester.

title: JUDGE HALTS WORK ON A REACTOR SITE
description: A Federal District Court in Atlanta has ordered a halt to preparation of the site for the Clinch River breeder reactor until an environmental impact statement can be completed.

title: Man, 23, Is Slain in Dispute With Group of Youths on S.I.
description: A 23-year-old man was beaten and stabbed to death during a dispute with a group of young people near his home on Staten Island, the police said yesterday.

title: Pirates 3, Dodgers 2
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI) - Consecutive singles by Johnny Ray and Bill Madlock drove in the decisive two runs in the seventh inning for Pittsburgh. Don Robinson (15-8) posted his third victory over the Dodgers this season without a loss.

title: WHEN TO HIRE AN EX-OFFENDER
description: To the Editor:

title: CAVENHAM USA INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to June 24
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,170,000...C-Net income

title: Players Reject Mediation Offer
description: The National Football League Players Association has rejected an offer by the N.F.L. Management Council to meet at 1 P.M. Monday at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in an effort to work out their differences.

title: HENRY FORD 2D KEEPS WATCH ON SIDELINES
description: The man with the most famous name in American business becomes 65 years old Saturday, but unlike many other executives reaching that age, he is not likely to fade quietly from the scene.

title: MUGABE'S ZIMBABWE: WINNER TAKES ALL
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe let it be known recently that when elections fell due in 1985, his political party, rooted in black nationalism, would for the first time field candidates from the diminishing white minority.

title: I.R.S. FURLOUGHS ARE PLANNED
description: Nineteen thousand Internal Revenue Service employees, about 22 percent of the agency's 87,000 workers, were told today that they would be laid off indefinitely at the end of the day Tuesday.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S UNEMPLOYED UP SHARPLY
description: Unemployment in New York City, which had been resisting the effect of the recession, increased sharply last month, to 10.7 percent. The unemployment rate rose even more steeply in New Jersey, while the rate for New York State increased slightly.

title: NEWPORT PETROLEUMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including an Alberta royalty tax credit of $404,344...C-There are no comparable yr-ago results because in the past the company did not report results on a quarterly basis

title: I.B.M. INTRODUCES POWERFUL COMPUTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced its most powerful computer, which is nearly twice as powerful as the existing top-of-the-line model.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Compound Recycling At the World Trade Center

title: VICTIMS OF J-51's DEFEAT
description: Government policies seldom succeed in distinguishing good guys from bad guys, or even big guys from little guys, but that is just what citizens expect in programs that confer enormous financial benefits. Take, for example, New York City's J-51 tax abatement for rehabilitated housing.

title: Husky Ends Role In Oil Project
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said it was withdrawing from a group of companies planning a heavy-oil plant in Saskatchewan, and instead would plan a 50,000-barrel-a-day heavy-oil upgrading project in the northwest part of the province.

title: Wilkins Sent to Hawks
description: The Utah Jazz traded Dominique Wilkins, the third player selected in the National Basketball Association college draft this year, to the Atlanta Hawks today for John Drew, Freeman Williams and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY REGAINS
description: ''Every company should go through what we went through. It teaches you to manage cash.'' Thus does Frank Gabron, president and chairman of the Helix Technology Corporation, reflect on his company's recent ordeal. Helix, a leading maker of cryogenic, or ultralow-temperature, equipment for the military and for the semiconductor industry, had a loss of $2.9 million in 1979, followed by a $5.8 million loss in 1980.

title: Briefs on the Arts Opera-Ticket Sales Open at Met Tomorrow
description: The Metropolitan Opera box office will open tomorrow at noon, selling tickets for the first four weeks of the 1982-83 season. Opening the season on Sept. 20 will be Richard Strauss's ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' with Kiri Te Kanawa, Tatiana Troyanos, Judith Blegen and Kurt Moll and with Luciano Pavarotti in a one-aria star turn.

title: DEADLY ALTERNATIVES TO ILLEGAL HANDGUNS
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR UTILITIES HUNT FOR ALTERED PIPE X-RAYS
description: Power companies operating 39 proposed or functioning nuclear plants across the United States have been re-examining X-rays of pipe welding in recent weeks because of suspicions that the X-rays had been ''artificially enhanced'' to pass safety tests.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Coveted Byproduct Of the New Bus Lanes

title: U.S. VOTING AGENTS SENT INTO 2 STATES
description: In actions aimed at guaranteeing voting rights for blacks, the Department of Justice announced today that it would assign Federal observers to monitor Tuesday's primary elections in nine Alabama counties and send special examiners to register black voters in two Georgia counties.

title: PRESIDENTIAL BOW TO ECONOMIC REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT'S RULING ON ABSCAM APPEAL
description: Following are excerpts from a unanimous ruling yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upholding the convictions of four former Representatives and three other defendants in the Abscam investigation. The opinion was written by Judge Jon O. Newman.

title: Body Given to North Korea
description: The United Nations Command returned the body of a drowning victim to North Korea, a United Nations spokesman said today. The transfer was made today at the 470th meeting of the Korean Military Armistice Commission at the truce village of Panmunjom.

title: Return to Sender
description: The number on the building reads 604 Fifth Avenue. A little to the left of the doorway hangs a battered blue plastic sign, its top left corner broken off.

title: ISRAELI AND SYRIAN ARMIES DIG IN AS DIPLOMATS SEEK WITHDRAWLS
