description: The following article was altered by Israeli military censorship. WITH THE ISRAELI ARMY in the Bekaa Valley, Lebanon, Sept. 2 - The Israeli Army is deployed in significant strength across the width of Lebanon, ready for war or peace.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Ultimate In Chopped Liver

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The evidence shows four Congressmen jumping at the chance to take a bribe and discussing investments in their districts as a convenient cover to justify their rendering of purchased legislative services." - Judge Jon O. Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. (1:2.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Where There's a Will

title: MFY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $389,000 on the sale of restaurants

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES OFF 32.1%
description: Sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers dropped 32.1 percent in the last 10 days of August from the similar period in 1981, bringing sales to their lowest daily selling rates since 1962.

title: SYRACUSE DEFEATS RUTGERS, 31-8
description: Jaime Covington, a tailback who broke his left leg two years ago and his right leg last year, scored two touchdowns, and Steve Peach, a quarterback who had never played in a varsity game, accounted for two other touchdowns tonight to lead Syracuse to a 31-8 triumph over Rutgers.

title: ISRAELIS MOVE ACROSS TRUCE LINE INTO WEST BEIRUT
description: Israeli troops moved one mile into west Beirut today, coming up from the south across a milelong cease-fire line that had not been occupied by the Lebanese or members of the international peacekeeping force.

title: NOBEL SCIENTISTS ASK ATOM FREEZE
description: Ninety-seven scientists who have won Nobel Prizes called today for a freeze on the deployment and development of nuclear weapons, warning that ''time is fast running out'' to prevent a nuclear holocaust.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $75,000...C-Net income...D-Including a gain of $354,000 related to tax credits from foreign operating losses incurred prior to 1982; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: 900 Series Unofficial
description: Nobody had ever bowled three consecutive 300 games before Glenn Allison achieved the feat in July at La Habra, Calif.

title: REDS DEFEAT METS ON A BALK BY OWNBEY
description: Rick Ownbey may be a relative newcomer, but the Mets' rookie right-hander provided them with still another way to lose last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said it had filed a petition with the Federal Economic Regulatory Administration asking it to halt the importing of liquefied natural gas from Algeria by one of its suppliers, the Trunkline Gas Company, a unit of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company. The petition, similar to one filed by the Michigan Public Service Commission, asked the agency to suspend Trunkline's import license and following public hearings to withdraw permanently the license to bring Algerian liquefied natural gas into the United States.

title: PRETORIA TO EXPEL 400 DOCKWORKERS
description: Nearly 400 black dockworkers have been dismissed from their jobs and are to be deported from South Africa in a move that labor leaders fear could provoke a national dock strike.

title: No Headline
description: Zoeller's 62-130 Leads

title: BERKEY, 71, WILL LEAVE PHOTOGRAPHY COMPANY
description: Benjamin Berkey will step down Sept. 16 as chairman of the pioneer photofinishing company that bears his name, it was announced yesterday.

title: PARIS AIDS AILING FRANC
description: The troubled French franc came under heavy pressure today on foreign exchange markets. The Bank of France acknowledged that it was once again losing reserves at a dangerously rapid rate and that it was struggling to avert the third devaluation of the franc since the Socialists came to power 15 months ago.

title: Foreign Policy
description: The position of center on Fordham University's basketball team has become a case study in international relations. First there was Dud (pronounced Dude) Tongal, the 7-foot center from the Sudan.

title: POLICE GET $1 MILLION GIFT TO EXPAND DATA SYSTEM
description: A charitable trust has given $1.1 million to the New York City Police Department to expand a computer system on robbery suspects and to finance the production of instructional films, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire announced yesterday.

title: Eyes on Japanese Ice
description: Guy Lafleur, frustrated in his efforts to renegotiate his $375,000-a-year contract, said that if he could not reach agreement with the Montreal Canadiens he might play professional hockey in Japan. If he does, Lafleur said, he will probably take with him Larry Robinson, another unhappy Montreal star. Lafleur said he had been talking with clubs in the six-team Japanese National League, in which several former National Hockey League players have competed.

title: Gulf Resources Chief Resigns
description: Gary A. Childress, chief executive of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation since a dissident group won control of the company in June, resigned yesterday to pursue other interests, the company said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OUR ALLIES MUST SHARE IN THE DEFENSE BURDEN
description: The United States bears too heavy a burden for the defense of its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies and Japan. The United States is wounding its economy by footing 53 percent of the total allied spending on defense. This spending loots the economy of capital that could and should be invested more wisely and humanely to put Americans back to work. It allows NATO and especially Japan to allocate larger shares of their resources to more efficient, productive uses and, in effect, bomb America's economy. All of this is happening while some allies and Japan rig the rules of free and fair trade and export unemployment to the United States.

title: Jay Novello, Character Actor; Mayor in TV 'McHale's Navy'
description: Jay Novello, the character actor who was a veteran of hundreds of movies and television roles, died of cancer Thursday in Riverside Hospital, North Hollywood.

title: Officer Is Stabbed In Drug Case
description: An undercover police officer was stabbed and robbed of $800 yesterday while trying to buy drugs from a dealer in Harlem, the police said.

title: Man With 'Bomb' Awaits Arraigning
description: A man who kept the police at bay for 10 hours on Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn by threatening to detonate what he said were a hand grenade and a bomb was in custody yesterday pending his arraignment today in Criminal Court in Brooklyn.

title: A Rustic Farewell
description: The veteran heavyweight boxer Earnie Shavers plans to bring his career to a close tomorrow in a ring placed in a field next to a small tavern. ''I don't want to kill anyone anymore,'' said the 38-year-old Shavers, who will meet Chuck Gardner of Minneapolis in a 10-rounder.

title: CHECKER MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drug-Sniffing Dogs Sought
description: The Customs Service is looking for a hundred dogs in good physical condition as donations from the public for use in sniffing out illegal drugs. ''We have always asked the public to donate unwanted dogs to us, but this is the first time we have needed so many dogs at one time,'' a spokesman said. Information is available from the Customers Canine Enforcement Training Center, Rural Route 22, Box 7, Front Royal, Va. 226630.

title: A DICTIONARY OF CRACKER BARREL ENGLISH
description: A group of dedicated lexicographers has been holed up in the offices of the University of Wisconsin for the last 17 years collecting, sorting, mapping by origin and defining words to document regional uses of American English. Casual observers might believe there are more worthwhile pursuits for scholars, but to suggest as much to the editors of the Dictionary of American Regional English is to invite the resounding rebuke ''Applesauce!'' and vehement argufying.

title: Steelers 27, Eagles 24
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) -Terry Bradshaw threw a 15-yard touchdown pass to Bennie Cunningham with 1:59 left to cap a 98-yard drive as the Steelers rallied to win. Pittsburgh trailed, 24-7, before Bradshaw passed for two touchdowns and ran for another.

title: AT HOME AT SEA
description: ATLANTIC HIGH A Celebration. By William F. Buckley Jr. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $22.50.

title: Resurgence of Narrative History
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamaican Upsets Duran
description: Kirkland Laing, a Jamaican fighter, won a split decision tonight to upset Roberto Duran in their 10-round junior middleweight bout at Cobo Arena.

title: CANINE ARISTOCRACY READYING FOR SHOW
description: EVERY September, the county becomes the focal point in America for dog lovers. This year, it will be next Sunday when the gates of a famous estate on the Hudson swing open to the country's canine aristocracy, as the Westchester Kennel Club holds its annual extravaganza.

title: Bruce Clifford Feiring 2d Marries Susan Zita Porges
description: Susan Zita Porges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Porges of Rumson, N.J., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Bruce Clifford Feiring 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Feiring of Monmouth Beach, N.J. The Rev. Thomas R. Rittenhouse performed the ceremony in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson.

title: MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: THE VANISHING RACE AND OTHER ILLUSIONS Photographs of Indians by Edward S. Curtis. By Christopher M. Lyman. Introduction by Vine Deloria Jr. Illustrated. 159 pp. New York: Pantheon Books/The Smithsonian Institution Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $14.95. THROUGH INDIAN EYES By Judith Mara Gutman. Illustrated. 198 pp. New York: Oxford University Press/International Center of Photography. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $16.50. By ANDY GRUNDBERG

title: Lines Drawn for Renewed Battles Over Abortion
description: The battle over women's constitutional right to obtain abortions has been fought in two main arenas -Congress and the Supreme Court. Antiabortion forces have changed tactics on both fronts, from trying to outlaw abortion to cutting off access to it. Now, pro-choice forces are trying to break the blockades.

title: APPRAISING STANISLAVSKY'S LEGACY TODAY
description: In one of those apparent cultural coincidences that are actually the result of broad intellectual currents that cross national boundaries at certain moments, the year 1898 saw both the founding of the Moscow Art Theater by Konstantin Stanislavsky and Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko, and Freud's starting to write ''The Interpretation of Dreams,'' the book that formed the foundation of all his future work.

title: Susan Wey Wed To William Crum
description: Susan Marjorie Wey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Wey of Needham, Mass., was married there yesterday to William Colyer Crum, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Coyler Crum of Weston, Mass., and Sunapee, N.H. The Rev. Howard Grinager performed the ceremony in the Carter Memorial Methodist Church. He was assisted by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Benjamin LeFevre.

title: Index; International
description: Italians are angry at funeral of slain police general 3 Around the World 5 Trudeau is turning attention to domestic concerns 6 China expresses concern that U.S. abide by communique 7 Survival of Bonn ruling coalition seems less and less certain 9 Reagan plan eases fears of de- stabilization in Jordan 12 Irsaelis reported still in area of west Beirut 12 Lebanese are divided over sign- ing a treaty with Israel 12 Government/Politics White House blames Congress for impending furloughs 22 California awaiting deluge of trials after ruling 24 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Tomorrow is Labor Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Labor Day parade begins at 10 A.M. and moves up Fifth Avenue from 26th to 52d Street. Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - May be closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: SOUND AND FURY
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann commendably tries to move beyond the tired liberal-conservative debate on poverty. As she writes, it is not enough to call for more welfare spending or to tell the beleaguered poor to ''get a job.''

title: Drag-Race Record
description: Gary Beck drove the fastest quartermile ever in drag racing Friday, but his time of 5.54 seconds was not recognized as a national record until he backed it with a 5.55-second clocking today. He got the No. 1 qualifying position for the Top Fuel eliminations in the Nationals Monday.

title: PLAINS-ROCKY MOUNTAINS
description: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, REGION BY REGION By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

title: CENSORSHIP ACTION ANGERS SCIENTISTS
description: The Defense Department blocked the presentation of about 100 technical papers just before they were to have been delivered at an international convention on optical engineering held in San Diego late last month.

title: COUPLE LEAVE VIRGINIA AFTER 5 YEARS OF STRIFE
description: A couple whose Communist beliefs prompted the adoption of a Congressional amendment that sought to block them from receiving Federal job training have quietly left here for New York City.

title: Miss Wood Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: In St. Vladimir's Ukrainian Catholic Cathedral in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Stephannie Anne Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Wood of Darien, Conn., was married to Dr. Marko Mykola Gregory Slusarczuk, son of Mr. and Mr. Atanasy Slusarczuk of Southfield, Mich. The ceremony was performed by Msgr.

title: TRINKETT CLARK, NICK CLARK WED
description: Jane Banker Clark, an assistant curator of 20th Century art at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and Henry Nichols Blake Clark, director of the Lamont Gallery at Phillips Exeter Academy, plan to be married in Washington in November.

title: Food Program for Needy Being Resumed in State
description: Local officials across New York State have been told to resume a program of food distribution to needy mothers and their young children that was halted three weeks ago in a dispute with the Federal Government.

title: MEXICO'S AFFLUENT ELITE SHUDDERS OVER DRIVE ON ECONOMIC 'TRAITORS'
description: The wealthy politicians and businessmen who took billions of dollars out of Mexico and helped accelerate this country's worst financial crisis in memory are now being condemned as traitors.

title:
FASHIONS;
EXPANDED HOROZONS FOR AZZEDINE ALAIA
description: One of the best-kept fashion secrets in Paris will be revealed in New York Wednesday at Bergdorf Goodman when Azzedine Alaia presents his first fashion show.

title: A TRAVEL DIARY: CAUGHT IN CROSSFIRE OF KENYA UPRISING
description: MY wife, Joan, and I left London on our flight to Kenya on Friday night, July 31, and landed in Nairobi on schedule Saturday morning. Our Scarsdale friends, Joe and Ann Condon, met us at the airport and took us to the Norfolk Hotel, Nairobi's best known, most luxurious and quietest. In the evening, we dined with our safari guide, Joe Cheffings, who was to pick us up Sunday morning. We could hardly wait for morning to come.

title: Federal Funds Awarded To Fix Subway Stations
description: The New York City Transit Authority has been awarded a $66 million grant by a Federal transportation agency to repair and remodel several subway stations and for a wide range of other maintenance projects.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
THE DEATH AND LIFE OF MURRAY HILL SQUARE
description: LINNEA BRISTOL recalled that when her brother came to visit her in h er new two-bedroom condominium, he said, ''I didn't know you had m oved to Frontierland.''

title: POLICE WARN OF NEW TWIST IN OLD CONFIDENCE GAME
description: In a new variation of a confidence game, some thieves in New York have been posing as detectives and Federal agents to steal money, particularly from the elderly, according to the police.

title: Mailbox; City Bike Race Is Mourned
description: To the Sports Editor: New York City calls itself the ''Big Apple,'' proudly and almost defiantly presenting itself as the greatest city in the world. Many people would agree.

title: WOODSBURGH PLANS OWN POLICE FORCE
description: WOODSBURGH AFTER four years of legal wrangling with the Nassau County government and the Nassau Civil Service Commission, this small upper-income village in the Five Towns area has decided to create its own police force, effective Dec. 31.

title: PASTA TAKES THE SPOTLIGHT
description: RISTORANTE SAN GIORGIO in Westbury is a pleasantly attractive and friendly Italian restaurant that is small enough for the dining room to be comfortably intimate and yet formal enough to appear fairly elegant. It offers a moderately wide range of mostly typical choices on the printed menus. These are augmented by a list of daily specials so extensive that it is almost impossible to remember them as they are announced.

title: WACKY BOAT RACES
description: A couple of wacky boat races are scheduled for 2 P.M. today and 3 P.M. Saturday, if a raft may be called a boat at all. The rafts that will push off from City Pier in New London today in the sixth annual Flotsam-Jetsam Raft Race defy definition. Constructed of what a spokesman termed ''Junk. Floating or sunk junk,'' the craft, which may be of any size, may be propelled by a crew of one to 50, using paddles, oars, poles, hands, feet, sails, in fact anything but a motor. No commercially produced equipment or parts are allowed and the entire structure must be handmade.

title: MACEDONIANS GATHER HERE
description: PRAYERS of thanksgiving, ceremonies, folk dancing and a six-hour soccer tournament mark the eighth convocation of the American-Canadian Diocese of the Macedonian Orthodox Church this weekend in New Jersey.

title: TWIN PANDAS BORN IN MADRID
description: Shao-Shao, a giant panda, gave birth today to the first panda twins born in captivity in the Western Hemisphere. ''The animals are in perfect health, and we believe they can survive,'' a spokesman at the Madrid zoo said. The only other recorded instance of twins being born to a panda in captivity was in China in 1978. They were the product of artificial insemination, as were the pandas born today. One of the cubs born in China died after 120 days.

title: No Headline
description: Florida Stuns Miami by 17-14

title:
STAMPS;
FOR WOLF TRAP PARK
description: An unexpected new commemorative, unheralded by any prior announcements, has just been put out by the United States Postal Service for the Wolf Trap Farm National Park, which is located in the Virginia hills of Fairfax County in Vienna, which is across the Potomac a short distance away from Washington, D.C.

title: Morristown's Green: A Question of Scale
description: From some angles, the Green -in the center of the community and as old as Morristown itself - gives the town the appearance of a New England village. But one side of the lovely old park is dominated by Bamberger's and abutting another is an urban-renewal site that will change the face of Morristown.

title: 6 African Nations Reject Namibia-Angola Link
description: Six southern African leaders today rejected what they termed United States attempts to link the independence of Namibia with the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: CHATMAN, MAYOCK LIKELY TO MAKE TEAM
description: Now that their exhibition season is over, the Giants face the meanest cut of all, the final roster reduction from the present limit of 60 to the regular-season quota of 49.

title: THEY ARE NOT QUITE READY TO RETIRE
description: The bridge column written by Jose Le Dentu of Paris in ''Le Figaro'' has long been regarded as one of the world's best. He recently posed the following question: Should players be expected to retire from serious competitive play on reaching the age of, say, eighty?

title: TRUDEAU TURNING ATTENTION TO ECONOMIC CONCERNS
description: This week's decision by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to cancel a long-planned Asian trip is regarded here as a sign that he is withdrawing, at least tactically, from a preoccupation with international concerns in order to turn more of his attention to pressing economic issues.

title: SCREEN BEAUTY TELLS ALL
description: LANA The Lady, the Legend, the Truth. By Lana Turner. Illustrated. 311 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $14.95.

title: A Judge Cries Foul At Indian Point
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission suffered an embarrassing right hook last week in the long match at Indian Point. Louis J. Carter, chairman of an N.R.C. panel investigating the safety of two nuclear power plants there, resigned.

title: No Headline
description: Jo Ann Washam carded an eight under-par 64 today and took the first-round lead in the $125,000 Rail Charity Classic.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LONG ISLAND has again been designated as the official site for the ''I Love New York Fall Festival,'' the tourist industry's annual effort to extend the traditional vacation season. The festival is designed to show off the Island's attractions as well as to salute one of its growing industries: tourism.

title: Soviet Officials Hint Brezhnev May Retire
description: In an unusual burst of news leaks, unofficial reports are circulating here that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the 75-year-old Soviet leader. will retire by the end of the year.

title: Nancy Beekman To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Beekman of North Caldwell, N.J., and Bennington, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Leigh Beekman, to James Robert Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Murray of Ellenville, N.Y.

title: WHITE HOUSE BLAMES CONGRESS FOR IMPENDING LAYOFFS AT I.R.S.
description: A White House spokesman today blamed Congressional inaction, rather than President Reagan's veto of a supplemental appropriation bill, for the impending layoff of 19,000 Internal Revenue Service employees.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
HOW NOT TO BALANCE THE FEDERAL BUDGET
description: ON Aug. 4, 1982, the Senate approved by a vote of 69 to 31 a c onstitutional amendment altering the process of fiscal policy m aking. If successful, this amendment would revolutionize economic p olicy more than any step since the introduction of Federal budgetingo r central banking more than six decades ago.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Kleistfest

title: 'SWEENEY TODD' TRIES TO CUT A SLICE OF MANHATTAN'S CULTURAL CABLE PIE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- James Traub frequently reports on the television scene. BY JAMES TRAUB

title: A WOMAN'S LIFE IN THE PRIESTHOOD
description: Ten years ago, Martha Blacklock went to England for a contemplative vacation. She was trying to decide whether or not to become an Episcopal nun. ''I made long lists of reasons why I should or should not. The 'Yes' side was plenteous, yet the answer kept coming out 'No,' '' she says. ''It sounds hokey, but literally in the middle of a worship service, I had this thought -it was very clear - that I should go to a seminary and seek ordination as a priest. So I came back to this country and the following year started seminary.''

title: Cynthia Spencer Wed To Dennis Paul Lund
description: Cynthia Palmer Spencer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Haines Spencer of Pittsfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Dennis Paul Lund, son of Mrs. Henry J. Ritchie of Duluth, Minn., and the late Paul Louis Lund. The Rev. Emrys P. Thomas performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Christ in Pittsfield, Mass.

title:
GARDENING;
CARE AND CULTIVATION OF THE DAHLIA
description: AS SUMMER draws to a close, the flowers begin to fade one by one. Among the exceptions is the dahlia, which seems to come into its own near the end of the season. Even the bedding sorts that were in flower when planted out in May will still be in full bloom, assuming that someone has made an effort to deadhead them throughout the summer.

title: ALFRED TEST 3RD TO WED LINDA G. GEORGE OCT. 2
description: Mr. and Mrs. William I. George of Rehoboth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Gayleen George, to Alfred Langstaff Test 3d, sone of Mr. and Mrs. Test Jr. of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for Oct. 2.

title:
CAMERA;
ADDING IMPACT FOR MORE INTERESTING PICTURES
description: Jack Neubart is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: PARITY TAKES THE PLACE OF POWERHOUSES
description: FOR this season's evaluation of the 28 teams in the National F ootball League, last season's results are meaningless. Even the A merican Football Conference has no perennial powers any longer. Lasts eason's mediocre team could be this season's Super Bowl winner, or s imply another loser. And even the most sanguine fan of the C incinnati Bengals knows that if the quarterback Ken Anderson were i njured, the team could sink to the bottom.

title: TEACHING AND TREATING AUTISTIC CHILDREN
description: In reply to Stanley Goldstein, Ph.D., author of ''Troubled Children/Troubled Parents,'' who writes such things as the symptoms of infantile autism ''are produced by serious deviations during the development of ego capacities,'' etc., etc., I say, on behalf of the ''troubled parents'' of autistic children: baloney.

title: A WRINKLE IN REDISTRICTING
description: to sign her petition to be placed on the ballot for the Nov. 2 election. In an hour, several dozen did and one told her it was a free country so she was free to go to Russia.

title: Transit Rollback
description: In May, Boston reduced its rapid-transit fare from 75 cents to 60 cents. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority hoped that the rollback would bring back many of the riders who had deserted the system when the fare was increased from 50 to 75 cents nine months earlier.

title: EX-UNION CHIEF WORKS ON A LABOR MUSEUM
description: Sol Stetin, the former president of the Textile Workers Union of America, sat in the kitchen of the historic Botto House the other day, sipping coffee and talking of a dream that appears soon to become a reality.

title: Elizabeth S. Compton Becomes Bride of Ralph Lee
description: Elizabeth Sudler Compton, daughter of Mrs. John H. Bickford of New Vernon, N.J., and the late Wilson M. Compton Jr., was married in Salem, N.Y., yesterday to Ralph Minor Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Storrs Lee of Pemaquid Point, Me., and Kihei, Hawaii. Justice of the Peace Al Barber performed the outdoor ceremony at the farm that is headquarters for the Mettawee River Theater Company, of which the bride is a founding member and Mr. Lee is artistic director.

title: JAZZ
description: Back in the mid-1950's, the pianist Mal Waldron accompanied Billie Holiday and supervised jam session recordings for he Prestige label. His jam sessions featured John Coltrane, jackie McLean, Gene Ammons, Donald Byrd, and other top-ranking players, and they were always beter organized, and perhaps a bit darker in emotional hue, than similar sessions run by the other independent labels of the day.

title: HOW ANTENNAS CALL THE TUNE
description: Ancient astronomers believed the sky to be filled with music produced by the movement of the stars, and they called it Harmonia Mundi - the Harmony of the World. Modern astronomy, largely a science of quite violent events, makes no such allowance for celestial music. Yet these days the sky around our planet is indeed filled with music - the music injected into it by our radio stations - and what others can know of us may well depend on their ability to decipher the electronic emissions of Beethoven and Blondie.

title: POSTINGS
description: Cubbyhole Co-ops A Bit of Charm at $35,000 and Up

title: CBS FINANCES PROJECT TO AID HISPANIC PEOPLE
description: CBS Inc. has given $250,000 to establish a New York-based organization that will devote itself to the concerns of the country's Hispanic population, particularly with regard to employment, secondary education and social services.

title: FUN, HORROR AND ADVENTURE
description: The comic book, that glossy-covered, newsprint-filled, gaudily colored anthology of fun, horror and adventure, was ''invented'' in 1935, after years of experimentation with various formats. Originally intended as a premium giveaway of previously published newspaper comic strips, it soon became an original production, with its own cast of new cartoon creatures and characters. Superman, Batman, Captain Marvel, The Spirit and Pogo are among those born of comic books and now firmly rooted in popular culture. During its heyday, before 1955 (when a Senate committee investigating the effects of comics on American youth fostered the industry's self-censoring ''Comics Code''), millions of copies were sold every month. Since then, with the exception some of Stan Lee's Marvel Comics and the underground ''comix'' renaissance, little of creative merit has been produced.

title: Israeli Entry Doomed by Vote
description: The Congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation today voted, in effect, to allow the Asian Games Federation to exclude Israel from further competition in the Asian Games, the continent's quadrennial Olympic-style sports festival.

title: Turkey Says It Will Stop Terrorism by Armenians
description: The military Government vowed today to take action abroad to stop Armenian terrorists from staging attacks such as the slaying nine days ago of Col. Attila Altikat, Turkey's military attache in Canada.

title: FREDERIC DANNAY, 76, CO-AUTHOR OF ELLERY QUEEN MYSTERIES, DIES
description: Frederic Dannay, the co-author of the more than 35 Ellery Queen detective novels, died Friday at White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years old and had resided in Larchmont, N.Y., since 1947.

title: VATICAN CLARIFIES ORDER ON OPUS DEI
description: The Vatican has partly justified the fears of Roman Catholic liberals by giving a conservative group of laymen and priests greater standing in the church.

title: Brooklyn Stadium
description: Were the Dodgers returning to Brooklyn? Not likely. But State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn said he would like ''to bring major league baseball back to the borough that proved you can win by losing,'' and in February he got the State Legislature to approve $30,000 for a feasibility study of building a domed sports stadium for the borough.

title: 'MAGIC' IN CHILDREN IS AUTHOR'S DELIGHT
description: ''IALWAYS feel there are arrows in life pointing you in certain directions,'' said Maggie S. Davis of Wading River. At the age of 39, Miss Davis can look back on a life that has included bachelor's and master's degrees in English, two marriages, one divorce, two children, running a nursery school on an Air Force base, teaching children with reading disabilities, serving as a counselor in a citizens' dispute settlement center, traveling around the country and working as a waitress in a fashionable restaurant.

title: SIZING THEM UP
description: SOME things I know about buying school clothes:

title: Susan Jane Filenbaum, Lee Wolansky to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Filenbaum of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Filenbaum, to Lee Michael Wolansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Wolansky of Cranford, N.J.

title: MEXICO'S BANK SEIZURE
description: Mexican President Jose Lopez Portillo (right), seeking to halt what he called the ''looting'' of Mexico through the flight of capital, nationalized the country's private banks.

title: DESEXING OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE
description: Fortunately, it is true that, as Edward Sapir and George Orwell taught us, the language that we use - for whatever reasons we adopt it -sinks in. Each time a speaker stutters over ''chairm-,'' his or her consciousness is poked awake. Winning equality in the language was necessary; and while the winning shouldn't be overestimated, it will work - like the drops of water on the rock - to change consciousness, and in time, unconsciousness. CAROL T. WILLIAMS Associate Professor, Humanities Roosevelt University Chicago

title: FESTIVAL OFFERINGS
description: Among the attractions at the Fifth Annual Philipstown Festival in Cold Spring Saturday are a 10,000-meter marathon race beginning at 10 A.M. in Garrison, sponsored by the Taconic Road Runners, and a walking tour that includes an 1818 ironworks where the engine for America's first locomotive train was built.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Connecticut Audubon Society has begun a new phase in its effort to stimulate interest among homeowners in alternative energy resources, with the start of work on a passive solar greenhouse at its state headquarters in Fairfield.

title: STUDY LINKS INCOME OF FAMILY TO DEATH RATES
description: Children from low-income families die at a rate nearly seven times greater than other children in Maine, according to a report made public by Nichael Petit, the State Commissioner of Human Services.

title: WHEN A CHILD DISAPPEARS
description: Names and other material that could identify the people in the following article have been changed. THE red bicycle with training wheels stands in the basement of the blue-gray split-level house, its tires slowly going flat. It has been there, riderless, since last Christmas.

title: CHINA TRADE:NO BED OF ROSES
description: Despite China's exuberance about its offshore oil potential, some Western experts say that American involvement in its development may not be an unmitigated bed of roses.

title: ISRAEL, ANGERED AT U.S. SANCTIONS, BALKS AT PASSING OVER WAR DATA
description: Israel will not share military intelligence from the war in Lebanon with the United States until the Reagan Administration removes a variety of sanctions against Israel, according to Administration officials.

title: Rio Grande
description: To the Editor: Save the Children's Chicano Program, headquartered in Espanola, Rio Arriba County, N.M., has sponsored a project for several years to revive the Rio Grande weaving tradition. We were, therefore, much interested in Catherine C. Robbins's article, ''Weavers of the Rio Grande'' (Travel, July 18).

title: STREET TREES
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES FEARS HAVE EBBED
description: For public-sector unions, 1982 has been a good deal less disappointing than many of their leaders gloomily expected last Labor Day.

title: Karen Goldstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Goldstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Goldstein, to Dr. Joseph D. Frager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Frager of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for November. Miss Goldstein is a programmer analyst with Pfizer Inc., in New York. Dr. Frager is a gastroenterologist with Montefiore Hospital.

title: HIS 'DORSEY TONE' RESOUNDS
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON ''YOU have to give the man credit,'' said Bob Alexander, the trombone-playing veteran of the Benny Goodman and Dorsey brothers bands. ''He's got the courage and the fortitude to put up the kind of money that will attract good jazz musicians at a time when not many people will do that.''

title: Shipwrecks And History
description: We were very interested in the recent article describing sport diving off Long Island (''Diving for the Secrets of the Deep''). Our coastal waters have long offered both sports enthusiasts and marine scientists a glimpse of the underwater world of the diver.

title: Swiss Rider Killed
description: Ernst Baumann of Switzerland was killed today in an accident at the international military equestrian championships. The 33-year-old Baumann was thrown against a wooden barrier when his mount, the 11-year-old stallion Beaujours, fell while attempting to clear the barrier. Baumann's chest was crushed and he died on the way to a hospital.

title: Emily Wachtel Married
description: Emily Louise Wachtel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Richard Wachtel of Ossining, N.Y., and Hampton Bays, L.I., was married yesteday to Howard Mark Gill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Gill of Brooklyn. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony at the Harrison Jewish Center. The bride's father is a senior partner of the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae. Mr. Gill's father is traffic manager of Joseph Lowenstein Inc., importers and exporters in Brooklyn.

title: CANDIDATES FOR CONGRESS TO VIE IN PARTY PRIMARIES TUESDAY
description: HARTFORD WHAT began early this year as a long list of contests in both major parties for nominations for Governor, United States Senator and other major offices has dwindled to a precious few in Connecticut's primary election on Tuesday.

title: To The Editor: In an Aug. 15 letter, John Silber, president of Boston University, called for a federally financed ''tuition advance fund,'' which would enable students to borrow large sums of money for college, paying it back over many years through the income tax.
description: This idea, usually referred to as the student loan bank approach, has been proposed by a number of people since the 1950's, beginning with Milton Friedman. It has always been strongly opposed by the overwhelming majority of spokesmen for both public and private higher education. Today, I know of very few people who support either T.A.F. or any of its many variations.

title: 5 Die in Helicopter Crash After Rescue in Colorado
description: An Army helicopter crashed and exploded into flames today, killing four soldiers and a man they had rescued from a mountain ledge, the authorities said.

title: SCHOOLS OFFICIAL SETS OUT PRIORITIES
description: SHORT HILLS ''IWOULD be pleased if every TV set in New Jersey were turned off from Sunday night to Friday.'' This, said Dr. Saul Cooperman, the state's new Commissioner of Education, would clear young minds for homework and school and men more and better learning and higher grades.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: A JOBS-WATCHER HOLDS LITTLE HOPE FOR QUICK IMPROVEMENT
description: THOUGH the White House called the 9.8 percent unemployment reported again last week ''unacceptably high,'' the Administration sees the jobless rate as an aberration in a generally improving economy.

title: What Congress Faces
description: ''We just can't seem to get away from the fiscal issues,'' Senate majority leader Howard H. Baker Jr. lamented last week. The 97th Congress, due to resume work this week after its Labor Day holiday, seems doomed to end as it began - bickering over Government spending, though now with the White House too.

title: World Trotting Derby To Diamond Exchange
description: Robert Williams drove Diamond Exchange to an upset victory today in the $494,260 World Trotting Derby.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
BOUNTIFUL HARVEST
description: With backyard gardeners currently harvesting their do-it-yourself investments, it's a good time to learn how to preserve the bounty. Today at 1 P.M. the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County will present ''Home Canning - Doing It Safely'' at the County Farm on Yaphank Avenue in Yaphank. The program is free, and so is a sheep shearing demonstration set for Saturday at 1 P.M. and the selfguided tours of the farm today, Saturday and next Sunday from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. For information, call 369-2100 (ask for Tape 1040).DANCING IN THE PARK

title: 'EASYGOING' JOE FERGUSON
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. JOE FERGUSON, the quarterback who came in from the cold, hasn't been slamming his helmet on the ground. Things may not be going well for the Buffalo Bills, but not even Joe Ferguson can blame Joe Ferguson this time.

title: MONEY ISN'T EVERYTHING IN A PRIMARY BUT IT HELPS
description: How does a businessman who never held public office, never ran for elective office and claims that he's been a legal New York resident - and a Republican - for less than six years, become the leading candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in the Sept. 23 primary?

title: YVES MONTAND - FROM THE MUSIC HALL TO THE MET
description: Frank Sinatra may have conquered the Pyramids, but can Yves Montand fill the Metropolitan Opera House all by himself? And can he - alone in front of an enormous auditorium - hold that stage which is large enough to accommodate the elephants in ''Aida''?

title: NO. 1 POTEMKIN PLAZA - THE REAR APARTMENT
description: The last few months have furnished no sadder spectacle than the decline of one of my sturdier, and as I had thought stronger-minded, friends. He feels that he can no longer hold up his head in public.

title: FOR A SIMPLE MAIN COURSE: RED SNAPPER OR BASS
description: BASS and red snapper are tailor-made for the table. Cooked whole on a bed of seaweed, broiled on fennel stalks over coals or baked with oranges, lemons or herbs they are easy to prepare and make a simple course for a dinner party. They have a sweet, firm white flesh and are simple to stuff, the cavity held together with toothpicks or even left open. They can also be poached in a court bouillon and served simply with maitre d'hotel butter or hollandaise sauce.

title: Future Events; Season Under Way
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated.. Night on the Town Sept. 9 - The Westchester Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital/National Asthma Center in Denver is sponsoring a dinner and theater party to raise funds for the newly implemented Young Children's Group program to aid chronically ill children under 6 years of age and their families. Dinner at the Tower Suite will be followed by performance of the musical ''Nine'' at the 46th Street Theater viewed from orchestra seats. Tickets, $165, from 382-0711 or 914-253-9360.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: IS THE state's regulation of aerial pesticide spraying too lax? According to Anne Morris of the Association of New Jersey Environmentmental Commissions, it is almost nonexistent.

title: Abused Boy Flown to Father
description: A 7-year-old boy who was locked in a basement for three months and weighed 32 pounds when he was discovered has been flown to his father, a West German restaurant worker.

title: FLIP-FLOP
description: When a reporter asked President Reagan if his reversal of past form - to support a tax increase - could enable critics to say that he had ''flip-flopped on the tax issue,'' the President replied: ''There is not any flip-flop on this at all.''

title: WHY JIMMY'S STAYING HOME
description: JIMMY has always been here. It feels as if he has been a permanent fixture in our home, much like the dining room table or the mailbox. He is known and accepted by each family member, but I am the lucky one who has developed a unique relationship with him.

title: No Headline
description: CHINESE PLAN TO ABOLISH THE POST OF COMMUNIST PARTY CHAIRMAN

title: FALLING ENERGY REVENUES PUT RAINY DAY PLANS INTO ACTION
description: During the 1970's, the rush to develop new domestic sources of raw materials and energy touched off a storm of mining and oil exploration throughout the Rocky Mountain region. Thousands of workers swarmed into scores of remote mountain villages.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW MEDAL SERIES?
description: Through the years, the Mint's chief engravers have designed the great majority of this nation's regular coins (as distinguished from commemorative issues), yet, for all the widespread use of their creations these artists have labored in relative obscurity - known by almost no one outside of numismatics and frequently unacclaimed even among collectors.

title: A PLACE WORN THIN BY HISTORY
description: FROM the flinty Judean hills to the breathless heat of the Jordan Val-ley and the Dead Sea, the West Bank is an area hard used by man. Much of it is barren, eroded and baked. But like a lovely old rug it retains a scuffed though indelible beauty. Even more enduring is its emotional and historical appeal -containing the tomb of Abraham, the common patriarch of Jew and Moslem, the Christian Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem and the outskirts of Jerusalem.

title: POlish Regime Gets the Trouble It Expected
description: Poland's beleaguered free spirits were outmaneuvered but not entirely abashed last week as riot police broke up Solidarity demonstrations in 54 cities and towns. Dissidents constructed a cross of police tear-gas cannisters on a Warsaw street - the latest symbol of Roman Catholics' resistance to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's eightmonth-old martial law regime.

title: PARTY NEEDS A CREDIBILITY REVOLUTION
description: As China's 12th Communist Party congress opened last week amid paeans of self-congratulation, a Peking taxi driver switched off his radio, silencing Party Chairman Hu Yaobang in mid-sentence. ''I don't like to listen to it,'' he said, reflecting the apathy with which many Chinese regard the ideology that has dominated virtually every aspect of their lives.

title: Carrie Doremus, John L. Keating Will Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Doremus Jr. of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carrie Shaw Doremus, to John Lindsay Keating, son of Mrs. Joseph M. White of Little Silver, N.J., and James M. Keating of Sea Girt, N.J.

title: NEW FAUCETS ARE EASIER TO INSTALL, ONCE THE WAY IS CLEARED
description: A FAUCET that drips or leaks around the stem can almost always be fixed, but there are many instances when the homeowner will find it preferable to replace the faucet entirely - not only so he can end up with one that works properly, but also one that looks better.

title: THE JOY OF ANGER
description: The Joy of Anger

title:
SCHOOLS RESUME WITH EYE ON COSTS;
Suffolk County
description: DECREASES in enrollment and increases in expenditures in Suffolk County's 72 school districts will continue in the school year starting this week, forcing a number of changes, administrators in the county say.

title: Klan Holds Rally in Georgia; Seeks to Forge United Front
description: Ku Klux Klansmen from both sides of the Mason-Dixon line met today to try to forge a united front and to rally around a burning cross on Stone Mountain, as they have done on Labor Day weekend for the last 57 years.

title: MUST SAD HISTORY REPEAT ITSELF?
description: ONE of the reasons I am a neurotic adult (one of several reasons, no doubt, but a big reason, I am sure) is that when I was a young child I lived with a large, shapeless, overwhelming fear of nuclear war.

title: POP: MARIA MULDAUR
description: When Maria Muldaur's career was at its zenith seven years ago, the former Greenwich Village folk singer was one of several prominent women, including Bonnie Raitt and Linda Ronstadt, who had helped to inject a new naturalness into mainstream pop singing. This naturalness stemmed from the singers' affection for American roots styles of blues and folk.

title: LOCKUP ORDERED AFTER ATTICA FIGHT
description: All 2,138 inmates of New York State's Attica Correctional Facility were locked in their cells yesterday as correction officers made a search for weapons after a brawl in a recreation yard Friday night in which three prisoners were stabbed.

title: Court in Missouri Sentences 3 Inmates to Die Next Month
description: The Missouri Supreme Court has upheld the death sentences of three prisoners and sentenced them to die in the gas chamber Oct. 16.

title: China Makes Call to U.S.
description: The Communist Party Chairman, Hu Yaobang, has emphasized China's concern that the United States abide strictly by the provisions of a communique issued last month in which the Reagan Administration pledged to gradually reduce American arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Brewers 8, Angels 2
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Ted Simmons singled in the go-ahead run, and Gorman Thomas followed with a two-run triple.

title: MUSICAL MELANGE
description: For those who might prefer more modern sounds, 'FM-TV,' the fourth and final presentation in this series of previously recorded muscial events, will feature Pul McCartney and Stevie Wonder in a performance of 'Ebony and Ivory,' Pete Best in a tribute to John Lennon, Duke Ellington playing 'Sophisticated Lady,' a laser light show with Michel LeGrand and the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, Natalie Cole, and the late Bob Marley performing his reggae hits Get Up, Stand Up' and 'Lively Up Yourself.' The two-hour broadcast starts at 5 P.M. Sunday on Channel 9.

title: Susan Ann Finkelstein Becomes Bride
description: Susan Ann Finkelstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Finkelstein of Remensburg, L.I., was married there yesterday to Frederick Clement Westphal 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Westphal Jr. of St. Francisville, La. State Supreme Court Justice Paul J. Baisley performed the ceremony at the Remensburg Community Church.

title: NEW TWIST ON THE BALL
description: This year's coverage by CBS Sports of the U.S. Open Tennis Championships from Flushing Meadows-Corona Park will continue live and videotaped throughout the entire week, leading up to the finals on Sunday, Sept. 12. The planned 32 1/2 hours of coverage should keep tennis buffs happy, though devotees of 'The Young and the Restless,' 'Days of Our Lives,' 'As the World Turns' and the rest of network's afternoon 'soaps' may feel otherwise. On Friday, both of the woman's semi-finals - for the first time in the 15 consecutive years that CBS has been televising the championships - will be covered live, beginning at 12:30 P.M. and continuing till 5.

title: THE DETERRENCE MYTH
description: Mayor Ed Koch of New York, who wants to reinstate the death penalty in New York, conceded in a recent debate with other gubernatorial candidates the possibility that an innocent person might be executed by mistake.

title: Correction
description: A chart on page one last week incorrectly stated the size of the world's proven oil reserves. The figures in the chart represented billions of barrels of oil.

title: 36 CHEFS GO TO EAST HAMPTON TO PREPARE BIRTHDAY BANQUET
description: The mingled aromas of frying catfish, tandoori chicken, spit-roasted lamb, baking bread, shrimp gumbo and hickory-smoked chicken could be detected, even inhaled, a good distance from Craig Claiborne's house on Clamshell Road in this Suffolk County village today.

title: Cynthia A. Tufts Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Ann Tufts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Winston Tufts of East Greenwich, R.I., and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to James Tyner Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Anderson 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert A. Storer, assisted by the Rev. Fayette Severence, performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Annisquam Village Church.

title: REagan Softens The Sanctions
description: The Administration last week took a step back in the battle with its chief allies over the new Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe. President Reagan, perhaps heeding appeals from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, was said by Administration officials to be preparing to soften sanctions imposed Aug. 26 on foreign companies that provide American-licensed components for the pipeline. As modified, the sanctions would forbid offenders to buy American oil and gas equipment, but would no longer ban other types of purchases of United States goods.

title: Barbara Visocan Is Married to Dr. Lloyd W. Klein
description: The marriage of Barbara J. Visocan, a registered dietitian at the Bronx Veterans Administration Medical Center, to Dr. Lloyd W. Klein, an instructor in medicine and cardiology at Mount Sinai Hospital, took place in New York yesterday. Rabbi Al Sturmer performed the ceremony at the Warwick Hotel.

title: VOLUNTEERS COMBAT ADULT ILLITERACY
description: JAMES SAMUELS probably will not be reading this story today. It is not that newspapers aren't available at the Ossining Correctional Facility, where he is serving time for parole violation - he just is not ready to deal with a newspaper article yet.

title: Boy, 13, Slain; Friend Seized
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was fatally shot in his bedroom Friday while he and a friend were handling a .44-caliber gun, the police said yesterday. The youth, Ray Charles, of 125 Sanford Street in the Williamsburg section, was shot in the head with a gun the friend had brought to the home, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Thomas Fahey. The youth was pronounced dead in his bedroom at 1:30 P.M. His friend, Michael Alston, 17, of nearby Walworth Street, was charged with second-degree murder, Sergeant Fahey said.

title: Melville
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Out of the Trough?

title: Beirut College Official Is Believed Still Alive
description: David Dodge, the acting president of the American University of Beirut, who was kidnapped July 19, is believed to be still alive, the United States Embassy said today.

title: KIMBERLY MAY PLANS WEDDING
description: The engagement of Kimberly May to William H. Sweney 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. May of South Dartmouth, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Richard Borden of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Sweney Jr. of St. Paul and a grandson of the late Lewis H. Brown, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Johns-Manville corporation.

title: ON TENNIS UMPIRES, THERE'S ARGUMENT
description: THE ball landed close to the line, very close, and Ilie Nastase, who could not reach it, quickly looked at the linesman, his eyes demanding that the ball be called ''Out!'' But the linesman, leaning forward intensely in his chair, extended his arms, palms downward, signaling that the shot had been good.

title: Utah Father's Shooting Held Lawful by Court
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed a $111 million suit filed by the widow of John Singer, a farmer who was shot to death by law enforcement officers who were attempting to arrest him in 1979. The suit was rejected on the ground that there was no evidence to support the assertion of wrongful death.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Coast Music Festival Enters Its Second Day
description: About 185,000 rock fans stayed on today for the second day of a music and computer festival, despite temperatures above 100 degrees and thick desert dust.

title: HOSPITAL-MEDICAL SCHOOL IS TAKEN TO TASK
description: I read with wry amusement the article on Aug. 15 about the new Middlesex General Hospital/University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-Rutgers Medical School complex. The greatest problem for the hospital's public-relations department may be what to call the complex, but that is hardly a problem for the staff.

title: SUBTLETY IS ELUSIVE IN 2 WILLIAMS PLAYS
description: LINDENHURST TENNESSEE WILLIAMS'S ''Suddenly Last Summer'' has such built-in momentum that the play practically propels itself to a sensational climax. The Studio Theater's production gives it no outside, or inner, help. Robert Wallace's direction takes the play at narrative surface value, and the acting is routine.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''DON'T be shocked when you pass a bookstore window and standing there - looking like the characters from the comic strip 'Little Orphan Annie' - is a live Daddy Warbucks, a fuzzy-haired tyke and a remarkable brown dog,'' said Charles R. Walther, the president of New Century Publishers in Piscataway.

title: SPIES AND PREACHERS
description: TOUCH THE DEVIL By Jack Higgins 251 pp. New York: Stein and Day. $14.95.SPELLBINDER By Harold Robbins. 365 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: LET GOVERNMENT
description: AS many as 5,000 asbestos workers will become disabled or die of a sbestos-related causes each year until the end of the century, a ccording to estimates. As many as 50,000 of them could be left w ithout any compensation because of the inadequacy of the existing s ystems for providing compensation for this type of occupational d isease - workers compensation boards and the courts.

title: DANCE
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble, which performs at the Theater of the Riverside Church starting Wednesday, happens to be the junior company for the Aileytroupe proper. And so you may get to see its dancers i a year or two at City Center.

title: PENN STATE PASSING ROUTS TEMPLE, 31-14
description: Penn State displayed its new ''open'' offense today in convincing style. Todd Blackledge, a junior quarterback, tied a school record for touchdown passes in a game with four as the Nittany Lions opened their 96th intercollegiate football season with a 31-14 victory over Temple before 80,000 in Beaver Stadium.

title: MEdicine And Money
description: For those who can afford them, physicians in New York are fairly abundant. The city has more than 2.4 doctors for every 1,000 people, while the national rate is 1.6.

title: THE REAL AMERICAN TRAGEDY
description: Memory recalls those frail, bent old survivors from the Grand Army of the Republic riding in Memorial Day parades years ago. They were the veterans of the real American Tragedy, when brother fought brother in our Civil War.

title: ATTITUDES TOWARD SPORT IN 18TH-CENTURY BRITAIN
description: NEW HAVEN AT the Yale Center for British Art on Chapel Street, 94 paintings, drawings, prints and books are seeking to make a serious case for British attitudes toward sport, as manifest in 18th century art. Sport, in this case, means the leisure pursuits of the privileged - horse racing, riding to hounds, shooting (with and without beaters) and angling.

title: Exploring the Ocean World
description: The ocean world has so much excitement and mystery that it is hard to describe it to one who has never had the experience of exploring the wet world (''To the Great Barrier Reef and Beyond,'' by James Sterba, July 25). Mr. Sterba's love affair with the Great Barrier Reef takes those who have never been on scuba down to 80 feet, and helps those who have prolong the fantasy. As an instructor in the Middle West's Y.M.C.A. scuba program, I have tried to teach the sanctity of the underwater world.

title: LONG-RANGE SIGHTS SET ON NEW AIR FORCE ONE
description: After his first ride on Air Force One, President Reagan surveyed the luxurious Boeing 707 and commented, ''It was rather small, but it will do.'' If re-elected to a second term, he will probably fly around in a much larger wide-body aircraft.

title: Dr. Scott Michael Kessler To Marry Debra Silverman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Silverman of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Lynn Silverman, to Dr. Scott Michael Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kessler of Hillsdale, N.J.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The stock market's rally continued as investors flocked toward quality stocks and gold in reaction to uncertain world banking conditions. On Friday, the Dow had it highest close of the year, 925.13, up 41.66 points for the week - and up 146 points days since mid-August. Friday's volume of 132 million shares was third-highest in market history. Gold also rose sharply late in the week, reaching $458 an ounce in New York on Friday, up $20 for the day - after a $32 rise Thursday.

title: Czech Skier Flees to West
description: Josef Samek, a Czechoslovak ski jumper, fled to West Germany last month and joined a ski club in Willingen, club sources said today. They said Mr. Samek, 24 years old, had applied for West German citizenship.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Fantastic Times. This has been a high-flying summer for science fiction and fantasy. Seven novels of that literary genre enjoyed runs on our hard-cover and paperback best-seller lists. Occasionally in years past, a book tied to a movie or television feature like ''Star Trek'' and ''Star Wars'' or a literary phenomenon like J.R.R. Tolkien's romances about Middle Earth made bookstores' cash registers ring, but this is the first time there's been a band of them - the creations of writers like Frank Herbert, Robert A. Heinlein, Stephen R. Donaldson, Terry Brooks and Vonda N. McIntyre.

title: Portland Daily Dies in Merger With a Morning Newspaper
description: The last edition of the 81-year-old Oregon Journal was put out today.

title: SPARRING OVER DEBATES
description: HARTFORD WITH less than two months to go before the Nov. 2 election, this year's campaign for Governor of Connecticut has been mostly a debate over debates up to now.

title: Space Center Gets Pact With Union for Guards
description: A security company and the union representing guards at the Kennedy Space Center near here reached agreement Friday on a 15-month wage freeze, averting a management threat to lock the guards out.

title: LIFE AND DEATH OF A CAMPUS DRUG DEALER
description: When his body was finally found -in a green plastic bag jammed between two decaying buildings on Manhattan's Lower East Side - Barry Stanford Weinbaum was dressed in the collegiate clothes that had been his trademark.

title: Desexing the English Language
description: In ''The Desexing of English,'' (On Language, Aug. 1), Sol Steinmetz wonders that so many changes have been made without any appreciable outcry. Many points were valid and even antifeminists have seen the hopelessness of arguing against them.

title: Tracking Down a Cancer Mystery
description: Like detectives tracing a murder weapon to a neighborhood, a house and then a room within the house, some medical researchers are trying to trace the cause of cancer to a cell's genetic material, a single chromosome of that material, a single gene on the chromosome. Scientists from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the National Cancer Institute reported last week that they may have gone one better - tracing a cancer mechanism to a single chemical subunit of a gene.

title: NUMBERS TALK FOR ONE OF SPEECHLESS DISABLED
description: The number 5 flashes on the computer screen. Watching intently, a 14-year-old boy drops his frail arm with a loud ''thump.''

title: Court Approves Death-by-Drugs
description: American public opinion may seem torn lately between desire for capital punishment and distaste for its barbaric implications, but a Federal judge ruled last week there is no doubt that states may use drug injections to kill the condemned. Death row prisoners in Texas and Oklahoma had challenged the method, saying that it is not as humane as advocates claim and that the Food and Drug Administration has not approved drugs for this purpose.

title: SUNDAY, SEPT. 5, 1982
description: International The necessity to give more aid to poor nations to help them in paying their debts was agreed on by 10 leading industrial democracies, concerned about strains in the international banking system. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said that the 10 nations, members of the International Monetary Fund, decided at a meeting in Toronto, to work towards an increase, still to be determined, in contributions of individual donor nations to the Fund. (Page 1, Col.6.) China plans to abolish the post of Communist Party chairman, which was created for Mao Zedong, as part of efforts to emphasize collective leadership, the Communist Party Chairman, Hu Yaobang, has told the 12th Chinese party congress. The New China News Agency today quoted Mr. Hu as saying that the party would in the future be headed by a general secretary responsible to the political bureau. He would preside over the Secretariat, which deals with day-to-day party affairs. Mr. Hu, the chairman since last year, has already indicated that he will be the sole candidate for the post of general secretary.(1:1-2) Secret intelligence gathered by Israel during the war in Lebanon will not be shared with the United States until the Reagan Administration removes sanctions imposed when Israel invaded Lebanon in June, Administration officials said. (1:4-5.)

title: THE WESTCHESTER: A RIDE ON THE NOSTALGIA LINE
description: NEW ROCHELLE I stopped my car recently to watch three teen-agers playing stickball in a remote part of a supermarket's parking lot in the Wykagyl section of this city. The batter hit a long fly ball that dropped through the tall bushes lining the back wall of Saparito's, an Italian restaurant that sits on a slight elevation.

title: SIGEL AND TOLLEY GAIN AMATEUR FINAL
description: Jay Sigel of Pennsylvania and David Tolley of Virginia scored victories on the 18th hole today to advance to the final of the 82d United States Amateur golf championship.

title: IRAQIS REPORT SINKING 4 SHIPS
description: Iraq said today that its navy and air force had destroyed four ships in the Persian Gulf, including two tankers sailing toward Iran's main oil terminal on Kharg Island. Iran denied the claim.

title: AN ACTORS'S NEW HIT
description: THERE seem to be no limits to the horizons of Paul Newman. Not content with being a popular actor, a pretty fair race driver and a political activist, Mr. Newman has invaded precincts hitherto the personal preserves of the likes of James Beard or Julia Child.

title: CHINA STARTS TO PLAY ITS OIL CARD
description: WASHINGTON Chain-smoking his pungent Chunghwa cigarettes, China's Deputy Prime Minister, Kang Shien, arriverd here with a startling message for the American Government in June 1979.

title: POSTINGS
description: Conversion Windfall

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: four previously published reviews, articles and essays. GOD'S GRACE, by Bernard Malamud.

title: Temporarily Murdered
description: In Rumania, spies come in from the heat. Seems one of them, identified only as ''Mr. Z,'' was assigned a few months ago to do away with fellow Rumanian Virgil Tanase, a dissident writer living in Paris.

title: Walker Awaits Word
description: When Georgia and Clemson meet tomorrow night in a college football game that will be nationally televised by ABC, the question on everyone's mind will be the availability of Herschel Walker, the Georgia running back. The right thumb of Walker, who gained 3,507 yards and scored 35 touchdowns in his first two seasons, was broken in a scrimmage two weeks ago and he probably will not be able to play until Saturday against Brigham Young.

title: Jewish Travelers
description: To the Editor: In the Q and A column (Travel, May 23) a couple desired information concerning destinations which might be of specific interest to Jewish travelers. While in Europe myself, I visited a number of Jewish points of interest, including the Jewish Museum (Woburn House, Upper Woburn Place, London) and discovered a reference book that I have found to be invaluable to the Jewish traveler. This is the ''The Jewish Travel Guide,'' and it is published yearly by Jewish Chronicle Publications, 25 Furnival Street, London, EC4A 1JT, England, and available for $8.50 at the Complete Traveler, 199 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y., 10016 (212-679-4339). IRENE FELDMAN Mahwah, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
CARE AND CULTIVATION OF THE DAHLIA
description: AS SUMMER draws to a close, the flowers begin to fade one by one. Among the exceptions is the dahlia, which seems to come into its own near the end of the season. Even the bedding sorts that were in flower when planted out in May will still be in full bloom, assuming that someone has made an effort to deadhead them throughout the summer.

title: REAGAN'S 'FRESH START' IS BEGIN'S ANATHEMA
description: JERUSALEM WAR and diplomacy in the Middle East follow a cycle. Negotiations stall, positions harden, diplomacy congeals, and then as tensions rise, war erupts, bursting the old alignments and power relationships, creating sudden new fluidity in which diplomacy can work again. Such has been the pattern of this summer.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: EPPIE The Story of Ann Landers. By Margo Howard. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95.

title: SELF-HELP FOR VICTIMS OF ABUSE
description: When the extent of the physical abuse of wives by husbands began to emerge in the mid-1970's in the wake of the intensification of the women's movement, the simple and obvious solution to most feminists seemed to be: end the relationship.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN OUTDOOR MARKET IS SET IN SALISBURY
description: SALISBURY LIKE salmon that swim back each year to the place they were spawned, many dealers who set up their first show in Russell Carrell's cow pasture return here each September to take part in America's oldest outdoor market.

title: AN ARTIST WITH A SENSE OF FASHION
description: In the Cleopatra headdress made by her assistant, Niki de Saint Phalle looks like the avant-garde French artist she is. Without it, curled up on the sofa in her suite at the Carlyle, she looks like a Brearley girl, which she once was. Except that a Brearley School alumna is not likely to wear an ankle-length blue panne velvet dress, designed by Dior's Marc Bohan, with bright red stockings and red flats.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 5 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 2 2 14 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 3 4 7 THE CASE OF LUCY BENDING, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A psychiatrist finds that an aberrant 8-year-old girl epitomizes the society of Florida's Gold Coast, where she lives. 4 3 25 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 5 11 2 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 6 6 17 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) A Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past during a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I. 7 5 10 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Travis McGee investigates a suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 WASHINGTON! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam,

title: Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron; Concern Rises Over Donovan
description: Whether or not the murder of a second witness in special prosecutor Leon Silverman's investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan was linked to that inquiry - last week it appeared not to be - there was increasing speculation about Mr. Donovan's effectiveness as a Cabinet member in light of continuing probes of his conduct.

title: Gondolas
description: To the Editor: The caption underneath Guiseppe Carli's ''Forcole Veneziane'' in the letters column (Travel, Aug. 1) has confused two important L's - Leonardo and Le Corbusier. The style in which Mr. Carli has illustrated the proportional derivation of his gondola oarlocks may be correctly attributed to Le Corbusier (nee Charles Edovard Jenneret, 1887-1965), not Leonardo (1452-1519). Le Corbusier first enunciated his theory in 1948 with the publication of ''The Modulor: A Harmonious Measure to the Human Scale Universally Applicable to Architecture and Mechanics.'' DANIEL S. FRIEDMAN New York

title: JORDAN SAYS PLANS BY U.S. EASE DESTABILIZATION FEARS
description: Jordanian officials say that one of the most immediate effects of President Reagan's proposals on the Middle East has been to ease Jordan's fear of internal destabilization by Israel or by Palestinian extremists backed by Syria.

title: A TIME TO STAY ON THE SIDELINES
description: THIS is a time for individual investors to indulge in anguished s elf-criticism over failure to join in the biggest bull rally ever. I t is also a time to reflect on the value of caution in troubled t imes.

title: ALBANY BILL LETS 14 SCHOOLCHILDREN STAY IN CHAPPAQUA
description: MOUNT PLEASANT LIKE many of the young families with school-age children who moved to Heritage Court in recent years, one reason Thomas and Janice Cleland were attracted to the 220-acre development was its location in the Chappaqua school district, considered to be one of the best in the country.

title: Michael Taylor, Writer, Marries Victoria Larimore
description: At the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights yesterday Victoria Larimore, an independent film producer, was married to Michael Taylor, a writer-researcher at WNET-TV. The Rev. Orlanlda Brugnola performed the ceremony.

title: DISPUTE CLOUDS UNVEILING OF GOMPERS STATUE
description: A dispute between a sculptor and A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials threatens to mar the unveiling of a statue of Samuel Gompers, who helped found the American Federation of Labor. The labor group has planned the event as a highlight of the nation's Labor Day celebration.

title: Labor Leader Attacks Reagan Economic Plan
description: In a strong denunciation of President Reagan's economic policies, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that Americans ''have less to celebrate on Labor Day 1982 than at any other time in nearly a half-century.''

title: WALL STREET'S RUNNING OF THE BULLS
description: IT has been often likened to a soap opera. Others prefer to draw their analogies with a casino. In the last few weeks, people tended to think of it as heaven. They poured their money in and, like figures in a Biblical parable, found themselves enriched.

title: SUPPLY-SIDERS LOSE A BATTLE - AND WIN THE WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CONFLICT FEARED ALONG AFRICA'S LAST COLOR FRONTIER
description: In a corner of Africa where the confrontation lines between black and white meet and become entangled, two seemingly unrelated events recently signaled warnings of heightened conflict. In Maputo, the Mozambique capital, a letter bomb that Mozambican police said was mailed by South African agents via an unofficial United States-based information agency detonated last month in a small office and killed Ruth First, a prominent exiled South African political activist, journalist and author. Just inside Zimbabwe, 250 miles to the northwest in the humid bushlands known as the Lowveld, three white men in Soviet bloc military uniforms were shot dead by an army patrol after being intercepted at the start of what Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said was a clandestine South African-inspired mission of sabotage.

title: U.S. GROUP ASSAILS SOVIET REPRESSION
description: Twenty American leaders of the movement to freeze Soviet and American nuclear arsenals have protested what they described as Soviet efforts to ''harass and persecute'' their Soviet counterparts.

title: TOURIST REVENUES GAIN
description: Continued recession in major industrial countries did some damage to the international tourist industry last year. At the same time, however, the rise in the value of the dollar against other currencies and the decline in domestic rates of inflation caused real revenues to rise rather strongly.

title: WAITING FOR CONSUMER RATES TO FALL
description: THE sharp break in interest rates in August was fine for the surgings tock market, but will it help the consumer? Will auto loans and m ortgages get cheaper? Will rates for unsecured loans and credit c ards drop?

title:
SCHOOLS RESUME WITH EYE ON COSTS;
Nassau County
description: AS Nassau County's 57 school districts open this week, they face a decline in enrollment of 4 percent and an 8 to 10 percent increase in costs, according to Richard L. Ornauer, a former president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Board Association and now a director of the State School Board Association.

title:
GARDENING;
CARE AND CULTIVATION OF THE DAHLIA
description: AS SUMMER draws to a close, the flowers begin to fade one by one. Among the exceptions is the dahlia, which seems to come into its own near the end of the season. Even the bedding sorts that were in flower when planted out in May will still be in full bloom, assuming that someone has made an effort to deadhead them throughout the summer.

title: DR. PAMELA INGBER PLANS NUPTIALS
description: Dr. Pamela S. Ingber, clinical assistant professor of psychiatry at the Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Steven A. Stuchin, assistant professor of orthopedics at the Hospital for Joint Diseases-Or-thopedic Institute, will be married on Oct. 17. Their engagement has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barnet Ingber of New York.

title: STEEL IS TROUBLED BUT TEAMWORK CONTINUES
description: The anger and mistrust that exploded in union rejection of the steel industry's call for sharp contract cutbacks have not choked off rank-and-file enthusiasm for labor-management teamwork at the mill level to enhance efficiency and make jobs more satisfying.

title: SOUND AND FURY
description: To the Business Editor: ''Our national discussion of poverty is superficial,'' wrote Professor Bergmann. As her discussion of poverty proceeded, she proved her point.

title: Lesson for Mets And the Yanks
description: To the Sports Editor: If the Mets and Yankees are to improve in 1983 they must both learn the very same lesson.

title: Matching Malone Offer
description: Moses Malone, the 27-year-old 6-foot-10-inch center, is on the verge of becoming one of the highest-paid professional athletes, but where he will be earning his millions is still in question. Last week, Malone signed a $13.2 million six-year offer sheet with the Philadelphia 76ers. Friday, the Houston Rockets, whom Malone played for last season, said they would match the offer to retain their rights to Malone under the National Baskeball Association's system of first refusal.

title: HOW TO CAMPAIGN ON THE 6:13
description: IWAS bolting down the steps of Penn Station recently, headed for the 5:39 when, lo and behold, t here was Mayor Koch, in shirtsleeves and klieg lights, doing a bit o f glad-handing for his gubernatorial campaign.

title: Military Enlistments on Rise; Armed Forces Meeting Their Manpower Goals
description: The armed forces are headed for a ''bumper crop'' of recruits and an increased rate of re-enlistments this fiscal year, a senior Pentagon official says.

title: Barbara R. Lasko Wed To Daniel J. Whalen
description: Barbara R. Lasko, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lasko of Essex, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel J. Whalen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Whalen of Summit, N.J., and Dorset, Vt. The Rev. Joseph Lagor performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Vt.

title: ACCORD ON UTILITY IS CALLED ILLUSORY
description: TRENTON THE consensus that seemed to have been reached last Wednesday by state officials on the desirability of a bill requiring the Board of Public Utilities to determine who was at fault in the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant may be an illusion, according to State Senator Daniel J. Dalton, Democrat of Blackwood.

title: Deer Isle
description: To the Editor:

title: SHALLOW MIDTERM CAMPAIGNS BELIE IMPORTANCE OF ELECTIONS
