description: Midterm election battles customarily begin on Labor Day, and this year's battles, accompanied by the highest unemployment since 1941, appear likely to have results far more profound than the campaigning so far might suggest.

title: CONSTRUCTED BY DAVIDS, OCCUPIED BY GOLIATHS
description: Camp David has been very much in the news. We've see Ronald Reagan strolling through the woods of the Presidential retreat with the Secretary of State, and Congressmen were invited there when the President wanted to persuade them of the soundness of his tax increase.

title: The Airbag Cometh
description: It's the law of the land. Unless they are spared by an eleventhhour stay from the Supreme Court, auto manufacturers will be required to build automatic restraint systems into their 1984 models.

title: LEBANESE ARE SHARPLY SPLIT OVER TIES WITH ISRAEL
description: Lebanese Christians and Moslems, until recently divided over the presence here of Palestinian guerrillas, now appear to be just as sharply split in their attitudes toward Israel.

title: SHARP DIFFERENCES OVER A SCHEME THAT GOES BEYOND CAMP DAVID
description: WITH the last of the Palestinian and Syrian fighters out of Beirut and life in that battered city returning to a semblance of normality last week, the Reagan Administration lost no time in launching its grand scheme for general peace in the Middle East. Everywhere it was greeted as the boldest American initiative in that area since the Camp David accords ended the state of war between Israel and Egypt in 1979 though opinions on its worth differed sharply.

title: CHAMBER OFFERINGS SWELL FALL LISTS
description: LAST week, this column previewed a number of chamber concerts scheduled for the fall; swelling that list are the varied programs offered by three major performing-arts packagers, plus a new organization that believes chamber music belongs in the home.

title: SEAT BELT USE DROPS OVER DECADE, POLL FINDS
description: The percentage of American motorists who wear seat belts has declined significantly in the last decade, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: IN DEFENSE OF DEFENSE
description: Why is it that defense is praised mostly when it does not succeed? For every time you hear, ''What a fine, cool defense - really riddled that attack, didn't it?'', you hear 10 times over: ''He put up a great defense, didn't he? Too bad he couldn't avoid getting crushed.''

title: CRAFTS
description: DEMAREST CENTER CRAFT '82, a fair jointly sponsored by the New Jersey Designer Craftsmen and the Old Church Cultural Center, will take place next weekend at the center here.

title: MISSING CHILDREN: A LEGAL THICKET
description: LAST Halloween, at 6:30 P.M., 17-year-old Maria Ciallella left her home in Brick Township, assuring her parents she would be back before midnight. She was last seen at 12:20 A.M., walking west on Route 88 in Point Pleasant Borough, toward her home.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: ON Labor Day weekend, one can count on several things: there are lots of cars on the highways, back-to-school ads fill the newspapers and on telvision, the Muscular Dystrophy Telethon is under way. Along with blue cloth-covered notebooks and the dissembling of lifeguard stands, the telethon has become a yearly signal that summer is officially over.

title: SOVIET GROUP PRESSES FOR AN ARMS 'DIALOGUE'
description: A founder of an independent Soviet disarmament group who recently emigrated says that the objective of the movement is to start a ''four-sided dialogue'' among the Governments and peoples of the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: SENATE PANEL CALLS ABSCAM MIDDLEMEN
description: WASHINGTON ASENATE select committee charged with examining undercover techniques used in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation is preparing to call a group of witnesses whose roles lie at the heart of the ongoing controversy about the operation.

title: Israelis Kill Arab Youth
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a 17-year-old Arab in the occupied West Bank today after being attacked by a mob of stone-throwing youths, Arab sources said. They said an army patrol fired warning shots when it came under a hail of stones in Nablus.

title: CAN LOVE MATCH THE LURE OF TENNIS?
description: I have become a tennis widower. I know I still have a wife because she continues to take pains to give ourc hildren a proper raising and tend to my creature comforts. I even s ee her from time to time, most often freshening up playing togs, w rapping the handles of her racquets with fresh tape or packing a newt in of balls into her bag.

title: WHOSE PARK IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: On the third floor of the red-brick fortress called the Arsenal, at 64th and Fifth, in Central Park, Gordon J. Davis, commissioner of the Department of Parks and Recreation, is making plans for next month's opening celebration of Belvedere Castle. Two floors below, Elizabeth Barlow, administrator of Central Park, inspects plans for rebuilding a rustic shelter. In the basement, Geraldine Weinstein, the Central Park horticulturalist, reviews fall plantings. On a golden latesummer day, happy sounds from the zoo bubble up into the building. The atmosphere in the department, however, is not recreational. For the everyday work of the historical restoration of Central Park is full of plans and promise and, just as likely, full of troubles.

title: Recent Sales
description: Alpine $450,000 Ruckman Road *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath,2-year-old colonial; beamed cathedral *2*ceiling in family room, brick patio; taxes $3,852. Cresskill $143,000 64 Engle Street *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old colonial Cape Cod; fireplace, *2*newly stained floors, screened porch; taxes $2,601. Demarest $167,000 6 Drury Lane *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; fireplace, *2*basement, deck; taxes $3,686. Englewood $117,000 185 Palisade Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath condominium, *2*air-conditioning; taxes $2,000. Maywood $72,000 131 Stewart Street *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial Cape Cod; *2*air-conditioning, new redwood deck; taxes $1,449. Old Tappan $210,000 11 Walter Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; *2*fireplace, air conditioning; taxes $3,553. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. $111,171 64 Byron Drive *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old condominium; view of golf *2*course; detached unit; monthly charges $146; taxes $1,424. Bronxville, N.Y. $142,500 94 Eton Road *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old stone-brick ranch; terrace, *2*new furnace and roof, 100-foot-square lot; taxes $2,998. Sands Point, L.I. $335,000 85 Sands Point Road *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; *2*1 1/2 acres, water view, pool; taxes $6,000.

title: HOW THE BAGGAGE WE BRING REFLECTS ON THE SILVER SCREEN
description: Some moviegoers like to sit in a theater's very first row, surrounded by the screen and an image that, to other eyes, looks like pointillism gone crazy. Other people prefer to watch the screen from a functional sort of middle-distance, not too close and not too far away, while still others choose the back row, so that the images on the screen look reassuringly like those on a television set.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TO A CHILD GOING BACK TO SCHOOL
description: WALKING into the room just now, I found you asleep on the couch, television on. You haven't yet adjusted to the regimented, sometimes grueling schedule that fall brings, as this involuntary predinner nap shows.

title: A TIDY DOZEN OF WORK-FREE PERENNIALS
Headliners; Murphy's Consolation
description: Four former Congressman who said they were led down the garden path to their convictions in the Abscam case remained on the road to prison last week. Of the four, only John M. Murphy of New York scored any points with a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan.

title: Going Gets Tough Even for Grizzlies
description: Ursus horribilis may be fabulous, but its life is perilous - at least in Yellowstone National Park. The number of grizzly bears there is down almost 40 percent since the early 1970's to 187, with females perhaps as few as 30, according to a Park Service memorandum released last week.

title: FREE RIDES; Computer Guard
description: Sometimes we hear funny noises at the door and even funnier noises at the windows, and there have been moments when the sound of the refrigerator starting up has stopped our heart. Our nights are seldom serene.

title: BALLOONS AND ABDUCTIONS
description: A BLOODSMOOR ROMANCE By Joyce Carol Oates. 615 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: THAT SONG IN DIFFERENT KEYS
description: BREATHE a sigh of relief for the end of the summer season. The year-round residents of the East End jump for joy when the summer people fold their folding chairs and raucously rattle away.

title: Padres 4, Cubs 1
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Terry Kennedy smashed a pair of two-run homers and Tim Lollar hurled a three-hitter to lead San Diego.

title: The Region in Summary; FAster Action In Rent Disputes
description: Faced with a backlog of 7,000 tenant complaints, the panel that administers New York City's rent stabalization law voted last week to speed things up by penalizing foot-dragging landlords.

title: CRIME
description: It has taken a little time, but Elmore Leonard is beginning to be taken seriously as a writer, admired for his strong style and infallible ear. Since he first attracted attention with ''Fifty-Two Pickup'' in 1974, there have been four deftly written action mysteries - the last one, ''Split Images,'' only a few months ago. CAT CHASER (Arbor House, $13.50) also demonstrates the quality that has given him such a wide following.

title: BRITAIN'S BEST AT TEATIME
description: SANDRA SALMANS is a reporter for the Business section of The Times. BY SANDRA SALMANS

title: Fall Colors Prompt Trips To Northeast
description: Astronomers and the calendar may argue to the contrary, but for multitudes of travelers, tomorrow - Labor Day - sounds the knell of summer and ushers in the beginning of autumn. If there is a single image that conjures up the new season, it is, perhaps, a white New England steeple outlined against the eye-warming oranges, yellows and reds of the seasonal foliage.

title: No Headline
description: EGYPTIANS PRAISE 'POSITIVE ASPECTS' IN REAGAN'S PLAN

title: Rachel Solomon Becomes Bride of Dr. Steven Ravich
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue last night Rachel Solomon, a doctoral candidate in psychology at Columbia University, was married to Dr. Steven Jay Ravich, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: The Philosopher's Roof
description: Marilyn Bethany's article ''Upward Mobility'' (July 11) suggests that rising through rooftops is a recent phenomenon. Not so. In doing research for a book I am writing on Charles A. Eastman, an American Indian writer (1858-1939) and his Berkshire-born wife, Elaine Goodale Eastman (1863-1953), I discovered that Elaine Goodale's father, Henry Stirling Goodale, had, in the late 1880's, redesigned the Windermere Building on 57th Street in New York City, and in the process extended his top-floor apartment through the roof.

title: BISTATE AGENCY HOLDS TIGER'S TAIL
description: SALEM ASUIT filed in Federal Court to restrain this 307-year-old city from reviving a port facility dormant since 1870 has led to a call for a Congressional hearing on the power of the Delaware River and Bay Authority and damage suits for $1.6 million against the authority.

title: JAMES PATTERSON TO MARRY LAUREN BROWN IN OCTOBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Brown of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Diane Brown, to James Bryant Patterson, sone of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Patterson of East Hills, L.I. An Oct. 2 wedding is planned.

title: Teaching and Treating Autistic Children
description: Dr. Stanley Goldstein, in a recent letter to the editor, attempted to defend the distinction between education and treatment as they relate to autistic children. He maintained that the symptoms of autism are the result of ego deficiencies that are best treated through long-term, intensive reconstructive psychotherapy. In addition, he suggested that teachers should keep their educational pursuits, and leave the ''healing'' to professionals like himself.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE New Jersey Lottery Commission faces opposition on its plan to cash in on the popular video-game craze. The commission plans a sixmonth test program , starting in April, to see how well instant electronic lottery games are received.

title: Woodcock Season Altered
description: WOODCOCK hunters in Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire and upper New York State will have less opportunity to pursue their sport this year because the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, concerned over diminished numbers of the birds on their breeding grounds this last spring, has, in effect, shortened the hunting seasons in those states.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AFTER a legislator described the move as ''in the best interests of the county,'' the county's Board of Legislators last week authorized leasing the unused Glen Island Casino, a popular nightspot of the Big Band era, to four investors - two Bronx builders, a Manhattan restaurant owner and his son, a Wall Street executive.

title: To the Editor:     With the refusal of many young men to register for the draft (some say the number is as large as 600,000), our criminal justice system faces an almost impossible situation: You simply cannot prosecute, fine and jail such a large group, and to select a few to serve as an example seems arbitrary and unfair.
description: Most of these young men are simply expressing a misguided idealism, responding to peer pressure or demonstrating a lack of maturity. Still, they must be made aware that citizenship carries responsibilities.

title: A PROPOSAL TO FOSTER TEACHING SKILLS
description: THE New York State Board of Regents has embarked on an ambitious and some say even courageous task, to improve the performance of the educational institutions which it governs.

title: Edward C. Leber Jr.  To Wed Toni Eugene
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton McIntyre Brown 3d of Arlington, Va., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Brown's sister, Jean Antoinette Eugene, to Edward Charles Leber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leber of Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: WORKERS' HERITAGE
description: As part of channel 13's current tribute to the American worker, 'The Inheritance,' an hour-long documentary film completed in 1964 by Harold Mayer, will be shown Monday at 8 P.M. It is a history ofthe United States from 1900, through the eyes of working men. Financed by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, the film, narrated by Robert Ryan, written by Millard Lampell and with a then-unknown Judy Collins singing, describes the effect immigrants had on America ad how this country affected theimmigrant worker. According to Lynn Mayer, Mr. Mayer's wife and partner, the film's lesson 'is that each generation has to win its freedom all over again.'

title: WHY C.A.B. TIGHTENED THE RULES
description: WHEN the Conciliation and Appeals Board, which administers the New Y ork City rent-stabilization law, decided to revise its method of s ettling overcharge complaints, all sides involved agreed that it dids o of necessity.

title: MUM ON MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: Intellectually speaking, it's always high tide on Lucy Vincent Beach at Martha's Vineyard. I sit surrounded by the flotsam and jetsam of a dozen disciplines. There are more ideas here than pebbles on the shore; the people are more brilliant than the sun. Each of them has a knapsack or carryall crammed with books. There is even a hawker, the kind that sold hot dogs or ice cream when I was a child at Coney Island, but here he cries the titles of paperbacks.

title: Mrs. Truman Has An Ulcer
description: Bess Truman, the former First Lady, was diagnosed today as suffering from an ulcer of the small intestine, according to her physician, Dr. Wallace Graham.

title: Disturbing Data On Lead Risks
description: Lead poisoning has long been seen as an affliction of the poor, confined mostly to children who eat lead-based paint peeling from dilapidated walls. That view may be only partly correct, according to the federally-funded National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, portions of which appeared last week in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Aaron Statue Arrives
description: The long-awaited nine-foot high statue of Hank Aaron, showing him hitting his record-breaking 715th home run in Atlanta on April 8, 1974, has arrived at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and will be unveiled Tuesday afternoon.

title: DIP IN LOAN RATES STIRS SLUGGISH MARKET
description: A dip in mortgage interest rates over the last few weeks has led a number of real-estate brokers in the metropolitan area to report a flurry of interest in home buying. It has created an unexpected windfall for those buyers using mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration whose mortgage applications were pending when the rate was falling. It has set the phones to buzzing in realestate offices as potential buyers most urgently in need of housing watch each marginal shift in rates.

title: DESEXING THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE
description: Like most attempts at reform (linguistic or otherwise), the desexing of English makes sense until it is carried too far. Any fair-minded observer will, I'm sure, agree that English betrays a definite sexual bias, and that the attempts of feminists to correct it are only fair and worthwhile.

title: FILM HOUSE AWAITING WRECKER
description: ''THE Lincoln Theater,'' said a Yale graduate, class of '55, is the perfect place to see movies like 'La Strada.' '' Many a Yale studenthas been educated about motion pictures in the tatty old white clapboard building that stands at the head of Lincoln Street in New Haven. Even on rainy nights, a long line of movie buffs snakes down the block, waiting for tickets to, say, a Bergman film - Ingrid or Ingmar. For almost 40 years, the Lincoln has shown many classics.

title: MODERN TRAUMA: LABEL-LESS LIMBO
description: HAVING been told for years by authorities (my husband and children) that I tend to be compulsive, I've finally made my peace with the label. Recently, while reading the newspaper, as I do every day, I found, tucked away in an obscure corner, a small item noting that psychotherapists are having second thoughts about the jargon that they've developed and that we have all come to know and love.

title: Data Update
description: *4*HOUSING COSTS N.Y. *4*Northeast N.J. area* (Index: 1967 = 100) % change % change from previous July from June July RENTS 231.1 0.7 5.9 HOME OWNERSHIP 318.2 - 0.2 9.5 FUEL AND UTILITIES 390.6 0.2 3.3 *4*Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics *Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) NEW YORK Week of Aug. 30 Week of Aug. 23 Week of June 7 Conventional 16.96 15.84 17.36 Rollovers 16.82 16.17 17.01 Adjustable Rate 16.47 15.50 17.01 *4*Source: HSH Associates NEW JERSEY Conventional 16.88 15.63 17.56 Rollovers 16.66 15.72 16.81 Adjustable Rate 16.45 15.51 16.82 *4*Source: HSH Associates CONNECTICUT Conventional 17.63 16.47 17.56 Rollovers 17.00 15.06 17.50 Adjustable Rate 16.58 15.50 16.70 *4*Source: The Millard Group Inc. CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 18.32 17.13 18.27 Rollovers 17.23 16.29 17.70 Adjustable Rate 17.28 16.02 17.83 *4*Source: HSH Associates

title: Miriam Olivia Westervelt to Be Bride Of Wesley Raymond Henry Jr. in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger Tory Peterson of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Peterson's daughter, Miriam Olivia Westervelt, to Wesley Raymond Henry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry of Cresco, Pa.

title: NEW MUSIC
description: This season's presentations at most of the major halls are pretty standard stuff. An orchestra might offer an overture, a concerto and a symphony - with an average age of a century; an opera house might also offer the 19th-century regulars spiced by a handful of more recent efforts; even pianists might offer the sort of repertory that their teachers studied with their teachers.

title: JAZZ: CONTINUUM, QUINTET
description: Continuum's opening set Thursday at Seventh Avenue South could have been chosen in 1952. It had tunes by Thelonious Monk, Tadd Dameron and Jackie McLean, toppped off by ''The Theme,'' a be-bop trademark.

title: TWO HAMLETS ON TWO LONDON STAGES
description: And still they come. ''Hamlet'' has been by far the most frequently revived of Shakespeare's plays in London over recent years; and while London awaits newer aspirants to show their mettle in the new season, this August alone has brought the city another two sweet (or sweetish) princes. Each is to be seen on one of those small, stark stages currently proving so popular with producers of the classics, and each is performed in what seems to be a returning fashion, in a relatively straightforward manner, without an obvious overlay of contemporary or experimental ideas. Edward Fox's version, of which more later, was awaited with a certain incredulity, but Anton Lesser's with genuine excitement, though more because of the name and nature of his director than his own proven talents. Lesser's first Hamlet was also to be Jonathan Miller's farewell to the theatre.

title: MODERN JEWISH MOTHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annie Gottlieb is a freelance critic. THE LOVE OF ELSPETH BAKER By Myron S. Kaufmann. 680 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95. By ANNIE GOTTLIEB

title: TRI-STATE'S DEMISE LEAVES GAP IN PLANNING
description: The telephone number on the 82d floor of One World Trade Center is the same, but these days the receptionist answers it with a new name -''Council.'' The Tri-State Regional Planning Commission, which for more than 20 years was the conduit for a total of about $3 billion in Federal aid to counties and municipalities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, is gone.

title: A VAST SET TRACES A REMARKABLE CAREER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tim Page writes frequently about music and musicians. BY TIM PAGE

title: Don't Tamper With Grand Slam
description: To the Sports Editor: Several years ago, the recording industry's major award for a hotselling album was the ''gold record.'' Eventually, mostly due to inflation, I suppose, the attainment of gold-record status was no longer that extraordinary.

title: EX-ENVOY DUBIOUS OVER CUBAN ARMS
description: The former chief of the United States diplomatic mission in Havana says that the evidence of Cuban arms shipments to El Salvador ''has never been solid'' with respect to either their magnitude or their timing.

title: POSTINGS
description: At the St. George A Delicate Task Of Restoration

title: PIPE DREAMS AND FOND WISHES FOR THE COMING SEASON
description: What if the words ''television'' and ''quality'' could be uttered in the same breath? How about just television and fun? What if cable were more than movies, sports and using ''impact'' as a verb? What if life was fair? Pipe dreams these, but then this is the time of year for dreams. The fall season has yet to begin, and logic suggests that things can only get better. As summer lingers on, we are subjected for a second time, or even a third, to last season's thin gruel. Famished for something new, we forget the disappointments of the past. Here then a run down of one viewer's extravagant hopes for the new season - before the fall.

title: All Cranked Up For the Drive To November
description: Ready or not, here comes the homestretch of Campaign '82. This year's midterm Congressional skirmishes may turn out to be more interesting than most because of all the unknowns:

title: U.S. Suspends Exports To Defiant Italian Firm
description: The Administration said today that it has suspended exports to an Italian firm that defied President Reagan's ban on exports of United States technology for use in the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: MINIATURE MODELS FOR INVENTIONS
description: The people at the Garrison Inn, which overlooks the Hudson River at its deepest point, near West Point, N.Y., talk about their job as if every day were Christmas. They are in the midst, after more than three years, of uncrating and processing approximately 35,000 patent models -those miniature samples inventors were once required to submit to the patent office in Washington, D.C. -from the collection of Cliff Petersen, who, at the moment, has something of a corner on this singular market. Since invention is a quintessential American mania, and the imaginations of aspiring Edisons were seemingly inexhaustible, each unveiling continues to be a surprise.

title: WHY TEACHERS DROP OUT OF SCHOOL
description: FOR the first time in 10 years, B.J.Voorhees of Toms River doesn't know what she will be doing in September. Miss Voorhees had hoped until the last minute that her job as business education teacher in the Matawan-Aberdeen Regional School District in Monmouth County would be hers again. As recently as two weeks ago she was still waiting, but rapidly losing hope.

title: ROCK-RAP: THE CLASH
description: The Clash's opening-night concert of a three-night stand at Pier 84 last Tuesday was everything that last year's debacle at the Bond International Casino wasn't. The sound system made the band's leftist poltical slogans relatively clear, and the open-air setting gave both them and the audience room to breathe.

title: Olympia
description: To the Editor: The identification of the archaic stone head from Olympia illustrating Peter Levi's article ''Olympia: Sacred Wood of the Games'' (Travel, July 25) as ''Head of Hero, 560 B. C.'' is faulty or misleading.

title: Chinaglia Honored
description: Heading the 11-man all-North American Soccer League team announced yesterday was Giorgio Chinaglia, the striker of the Cosmos who was selected for the sixth time. Other Cosmos named to the team in balloting conducted by The Sporting News were Vladislav Bogicevic, midfielder; Andranik Eskandarian, defender, and Hubert Birkenmeier, goalkeeper. Rounding out the squad were Seattle's Pete Ward and Jacksonville's Ricardo Alonso, forwards; Ace Ntsoelengoe of Toronto and Arno Steffenhagen of Chicago, midfielders, and Frantz Mathieu of Montreal, Young Jeung Cho of Portland and Peter Nogly of Tampa Bay, defenders.

title: OFFICIALS BELIEVE THAT A GAS LEAK AT JERSEY A-PLANT WAS ACCIDENTAL
description: Federal and utility officials investigating the release of a small amount of radioactive gas from the Salem nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey say they believe that the leak was accidental and was not the result of tampering.

title: BREEDER REACTOR IN THE WORKS
description: ORADELL THE approval of site-clearing for the 350-megawatt Clinch River Breeder Reactor Project near Oak Ridge, Tenn., was good news for an Oradell company that has spent 10 years preparing the blueprints for the nation's first large breeder.

title: Miss Katz, Oboist, Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Katz of Fort Lee, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Katz, to Michael Willner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Willner of North Miami, Fla.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON COLLEGE ROUTS TEXAS A&M, 38-16

title: UPROOTED NICARAGUAN INDIANS UNHAPPY IN NEW HOMES
description: A group of Miskito Indians, part of more than 2,000 people driven here in the last year from their homes on Nicaragua's remote Atlantic coast, are bitterly unhappy about their new living conditions.

Rams Nov. 8-at Miami* 14-New Orleans 22-at Raiders* 28-Denver Dec. 5-at Clev. 11-at San Fran.

title: Miss Hughes Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Roberta Graham Hughes to John Arthur Stineman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Hughes of Wellesley Hills, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert George Stineman of Wilmette, Ill.

title: Unusual Strategies Planned
description: Administration officials, determined to minimize the disruption of Government services because of the veto, have devised unusual strategies to avoid the furlough of more Federal employees.

title: Richard Leidl to Marry Amelia Karen Duroska
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig P. Duroska of Little Falls, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amelia Karen Duroska, to Richard John Leidl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph F. Leidl of New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: THE DESEXING OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE
description: The apostrophe offers a solution to one problem of desexing English that does not go against the grain of language. When Cole Porter writes, ''Let's do it, let's fall in love,'' we know he means, ''Let us do it.'' We accept ''doesn't'' and ''isn't'' and ''can't,'' and I see no reason why we should not say ''chair'an,'' allowing the apostrophe to stand for ''wom'' or ''m,'' avoiding the unpleasant connotation of ''person,'' as in ''the crime was committed by a person or persons unknown.'' DEVERA SIEVERS New York City

title: 2 YANKEE HOMERS DOWN ROYALS, 3-2
description: Lou Piniella has an advantage over other hitting coaches, He can tell his students how to hit, then go out and show them how to do it in a game.

title: R.R. Ream Weds Miss Prendergast
description: Mary Kay Prendergast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Prendergast of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Roger R. Ream, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Norman S. Ream of Brookfield, Wis. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the University Chapel at Fordham University.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTERS
description: Computers have no problem dividing two 10-digit numbers or exploring 10,000 possible chess moves. In fact, they are best at tasks that are tough or impossible for people. But give a computer a task that even a child can do - like identifying a horse in a photograph of a meadow - and it shows its ignorance.

title: A VIEW OF BLACKS OVER THE YEARS CONTINUES TO GROW
description: MOUNT VERNON ''THE Image of the Black in Western Art'' is a book that's been in the making for 15 years and is still not complete. Written by a group of French and American scholars working under the auspices of the Menil Foundation, the three volumes start in ancient Egypt and will end in 20th-century Europe and America. Dominique de Menil, the wellknown Texas collector of art and patron of artists, says that the survey was prompted by the realization that in the United States a measure of segregation still existed in spite of having been outlawed by the Supreme Court in 1954.

title: THROUGH THE WALL TO EAST BERLIN
description: RICHARD KOSTELANETZ is completing a book with photographs on ''The Great Jewish Cemetery of Berlin.'' His poetry, fiction and criticism have been widely published. By RICHARD KOSTELANETZ

title: DANCE: MURRAY SPAULDING
description: Murray Spalding showed either courage or a certain foolhardiness when she returned to New York, where she trained, and presented a single formalist dance at a studio that has seen such incisive practitioners as Dana Reitz and Kathy Duncan. On Friday, the Washington-based choreographer presented ''Crossings'' at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: Of City and Suburbs, 'Bests' and 'Worsts'
description: The suburban snobbism exhibited by Gerald Eskenazi has led him to a put-down of New York City in general and its schools in particular (''About Long Island,'' Aug. 1).

title: No Standard Bearer
description: John Hawkins isn't averse to a little flag waving, but he is particular about what banner it is. Mr. Hawkins, the first black cheerleader at the University of Mississippi, refused to carry a Confederate flag, the school's symbol, at a pep rally last week. He said he declined the traditional duty of male cheerleaders at Ole Miss because of ''what my ancestors went through and what the Rebel flag represents.''

title: ISRAELIS REPORTED STILL IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Israeli troops were reported to be still occupying an area of southwestern Beirut tonight that they moved into Friday across the cease-fire line.

title: NO. 208 WON BY ROBINSON
description: Grambling last night beat Morgan State, 42-13, to continue its domination of the annual benefit game for the Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Scholarship Fund at Yankee Stadium.

title: 3 Drug Manufacturers Raided by Authorities
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that agents had raided three drug manufacturing concerns and seized thousands of so-called pep pills containing an illegal combination of nonprescription ingredients.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
IRVING PENN - DANGERS OF THE PAINTERLY APPROACH
description: The strength as well as the weakness of Irving Penn is that he thinks more like a painter than like a news photographer. And his weakness as well as his strength is evident in the exhibition of recent photographs opening Wednesday at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street (through Oct. 2).

title: A Bloody Chance for Peace
description: President Reagan's shrewdly cast peace plan for the Middle East is written in Lebanese, Palestinian, Syrian and Israeli blood. All who welcome last week's dispersal of the P.L.O. and the new Reagan approach to a West Bank deal had best begin by acknowledging the debt to Prime Minister Begin's bold and cruel march to Beirut.

title: GONDOLAS
description: To the Editor: The Modulor design originated by Le Corbusier and employed by Mr. Carli in his drawing of the Venetian oarlock is a measure based upon mathematics and the human scale. Using as a basis the drawing of a man with upraised arm, Le Corbusier chose dimensions in designing buildings and objects; they being ''containers or extensions of man.'' The oarlock in Mr. Carli's drawing is descriptively shown to be an object and extension of man in the fullest sense. LEE S. JABLIN Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: GREAT ZOOS OF THE WORLD-BAZEL TO THE BRONX
description: ROBERT BENDINER, formerly a member of the Editorial Board of The Times, is the author of ''The Fall of the Wild, the Rise of the Zoo'' (Dutton). By ROBERT BENDINER

title: LET'S REVERSE THE SLIPPAGE ON TAX REFORM
description: ONCE again, New Jersey appears to be slipping back into its historic reliance on the property tax as the principal source of governmental revenue, and once again, it is imperative that government step in to reverse that dangerous trend.

title: PRIDE AND SENSITIVITY DIVIDING MRS. LLOYD, MISS NAVRATILOVA
description: They are from different cultures and backgrounds, and their personalities and playing styles are equally dissimilar. But Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd share a common quality, pride, which has become the source of increasing differences between the top two seeded women at the United States Open championships.

title: CEntral American Troubles Go On
description: Central America's cauldron of trouble never really stops bubbling. In El Salvador, guerrilla bands blacked out almost half the country last week by sabotaging power lines.

title: FACIAL SURGERY BRINGS NEW HOPE
description: DIX HILLS ''IDON'T have a great deal of control over my destiny, but this was one choice I did have,'' said 18-year-old Laurie Ornstein of Dix Hills. The choice she was talking about was orthognathic surgery, a dramatic new operation that corrects facial deformities by cutting and repositioning bone.

title: AT LEAST 19 KILLED IN BLAZE ON COAST
description: A fire spread through an aging downtown apartment building Saturday, killing at least 19 people who apparently panicked and ran to their deaths in burning hallways, the authorities said.

title: AMC AND RENAULT'S ALLIANCE
description: THE car is an aerodynamic wedge, stylish in today's mode. It is compact, comfortable, fuel-efficient to a fare-thee-well. It is the first offspring of the marriage between Renault and American Motors, and it may well be the vehicle that finally puts France on the American map.

title: MAYOR OF DETROIT SUBPOENAED IN GRAFT INQUIRY
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young has been subpoenaed to testify before a grand jury investigating accusations of kickbacks in the Detroit Water and Sewage Department.

title: Council Invites Sheik To Come to Cleveland
description: Sheik Mohammed al Fassi's generosity to the cities he visits is well known, so when the Mayor of Cleveland didn't rush to invite the Saudi billionaire for a visit, the City Council stepped in.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
BEETHOVEN GETS A YOUNG ACCENT
description: OYSTER BAY LAST year, when he was a volunteer ''go-fer'' at the Friends of the Arts Beethoven Festival at the Planting Fields Arboretum here, Robert Apostle managed to sneak in a few minutes of fingering the Imperial Bosendorfer piano. ''Nobody was looking one day when I passed by,'' the 19-year-old second-year piano student at Juilliard said, ''so I just sat down and played for a while.''

title: Anti-Somali Guerrillas Report New Successes
description: Anti-Somali guerrillas said today that they had routed Somali Government troops in two major battles in the Ogaden region, killing 87 soldiers and capturing large quantities of newly arrived American weapons.

title: BROADWAY SALUTE
description: Ask Ethel Merman, the musical doyenne - she has appeared from time to time on Broadway for almost 50 years in more than 16 shows - if the songs in today's musicals are as good as they used to be, and her immediate response is, 'No way, no. They're not singable.

title:
ART;
VARIED STYLES IN A GALLERY'S NEW HOME
description: SOUTHAMPTON AT the new home of the Louise Himelfarb Gallery, formerly on Montauk Highway in Water Mill but now at 38 Main Street in Southampton, a varied selection of sculpture, paintings and fiber art is on view through next Sunday.

title: PLANT WEIGHS OPTIONS UNDER BOTTLE LAW
description: NEW ROCHELLE ALMOST half a billion cans and bottles are turned out at a New Rochelle soft-drink plant every year. Beginning next July, the half billion containers could all be turned in, empty and dirty, because of the new state bottle-deposit law.

title: FUNEREAL AIR HANGING OVER BONN POLITICS
description: With West Germany's governing coalition nearing its 13th anniversary in power, officials here acknowledge that a deathbed, if not a funereal, atmosphere has enveloped the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: Geology of Palisades Clarified by Scientist
description: In the article ''Palisades Waterfront: A Facelift?'' (July 11) the Palisades were called ''the tip of a 1,000-foot-thick laval flow that thrust its top skyward eons ago.''

title: SHOPPER'S WORLD
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a writer who lives in New York. By ROBERT PACKARD

title: A 'GHOSTS' THAT GROWS EVER MORE LIGHTWEIGHT
description: I will admit to considerable surprise the moment the curtain went up on the new revival of Ibsen's ''Ghosts'' at the Brooks Atkinson. I'm not accustomed to seeing the old warhorse, of which one can become foolishly fond, played in a setting that might do well enough for a stock company mounting of something by Philip Barry. I'm used to a ''Ghosts'' that's a bit more overstuffed: a lot of horsehair and heavy oak doors that rumble ponderously shut and big fat gaslamps perched next to handsomely tooled books, all that. Not that Ibsen's play is supposed to look eerie, as though poltergeists would begin banging away on the attic floor any minute. The ghosts in the play aren't, of course, ectoplasmic figures at all; they are echoes of the past, genetic hand-me-downs that tend to determine our present destinies (''We're all ghosts,'' ruminates Liv Ullmann as Mrs. Alving, ''Our mothers and fathers live on inside us''). But if a production of ''Ghosts'' has nothing whatsoever to do with ''The Castle of Otranto'' or even ''The Turn of the Screw,'' shouldn't it at least look substantial and, preferably, serious?

title: Girl Plays Football
description: Vicky Smith, a junior at Shorewood High School, on Friday night became the first girl in the Milwaukee area to play in a varsity football game. Miss Smith, who is 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighs 157 pounds, took part in two plays in a 27-0 loss to Port Washington.

title: Family of Comatose Woman Asserts She Had an Abortion
description: A comatose accident victim had an abortion last week, two days after the mother of the 23-year-old woman got court approval, the family has disclosed.

title: CODE AGENCY IS SAID TO DEMAND PAPERS
description: A study of the top-secret National Security Agency, which is responsible for worldwide electronic surveillance, will be published by the Houghton Mifflin Company of Boston on Sept. 23, but the book has already touched off controversy.

title: PATTERNS OF LACE AND LABOR
description: GEORGE KLEVA, a lace worker at the Thomas J. Wilson Company and section president of the Amalgamated Lace Operators of America, expects to spend Labor Day this year in much the same way he has spent it over the last quarter-century - at the beach, and content to go back to work the next day. A six-week strike at the 143-year-old lace mill here - the oldest in the country - has been settled.

title: Mark S. Kessler to Marry Laurette Joy Siegle Dec.11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Siegle of Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurette Joy Siegle, to Mark Stuart Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kessler of Longwood, Fla.

title: 54 in India Die After Drinking Homemade Liquor at Festival
description: A team of 75 doctors is treating a growing number of people poisoned by a bootleg liquor that has killed 54 people and left more than 600 hospitalized in the southern state of Kerala, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: Miss Martin Plans October Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Martin Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Alexander Martin, to Colin Morgan Spence, son of the Rev. and Mrs. James G. Spence of New Milford, Conn.

title: BOND ISSUE IN NEW JERSEY FOR PRISON EXPANSION ON NOVEMBER BALLOT
description: New Jersey voters will decide Nov. 2 on a $170 million bond issue that would finance the building of three new state prisons and the renovation of others.

title: U.S. BACKS DECISION TO RAISE I.M.F. AID TO POOR COUNTRIES
description: The United States agreed with nine other leading industrial democracies today on the need to provide additional funds to assist financially ailing countries in paying debts.

title: Eve Clark Wed to W.T. Woodhull Jr.
description: Eve Bradnick Clark, daughter of Jean Bradnick of Winchester, Conn., and the late Elise Gildea Bradnick, was married yesterday to William Tennent Woodhull Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodhull of Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Ernest L. Bengston performed the ceremony at the Winchester Center Congregational Church.

title: Tracy Huntington Is Married
description: Tracy Brent Huntington, daughter of Mrs. John A. Snyder of Darien, Conn., and the late Robert Dinsmore Huntington Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Louis Busch Hager Jr., son of Mrs. John Mithoefer of Charleston, S.C., and Mr. Hager of New York. Canon George F. French performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Brovart Cannon, former assistant headmaster of the Hoosac School in Hoosick, N.Y.

title: SAMARITANS FIND CITY A TROVE OF SACRED LORE
description: For centuries, tourists, pilgrims and biblical scholars visiting the Middle East carried away manuscripts bearing on the history of Benyamim Tsedaka's people, the Samaritans of Israel. While the documents, some of them sacred to the Samaritans, were being scattered around the globe, the community dwindled until it was nearly extinct.

title: Paris Environs
description: To the Editor: With the help of our high-school French, we took off and sortied out of Paris to visit Saint-Germaine-en-Laye, which was mentioned in ''Day Trips for Fine Dining Outside Paris'' by Patricia Wells (Travel, July 11). First, we stopped at the Museum of Antiquities, then used several rolls of film on the magnificent gardens.

title: THAT SONG IN DIFFERENT KEYS
description: DESPITE the warmth of the September sun, a chill of apprehension crept up inside me, for Labor Day, the end of the summer vacation, was approaching. Even the sparkle of the ocean took on an ironic glint. The day before the end, we went in for our last dip. ''Let's not have any wet suits in the car this time,'' my wife said.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TOUCH OF THE PAST IN CAPE MAY
description: CAPE MAY is outstanding for its preservation of many of the charming buildings from the resort's heyday before the turn of the century. Fortunately for us, the fashionable moved on to other watering holes early in this century and many of the fanciful Victorian houses were left intact instead of being replaced by motels and parking lots.

title: Amy Richter Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gustave J. Richter of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Joan Richter, to E. Ronald Gushue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gushue of Bedford Hills, N.Y. Miss Richter is an art associate with Sports Afield, a monthly magazine published by Hearst Magazines. Her fiance is an architect.

title: SEEING MORE THAN JUST FUN IN LICHTENSTEIN; SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.
description: Summer shows in summer places often melt in the memory like sherbet in the sun. But no one could say that of the exhibition of paintings by Roy Lichtenstein that can be seen at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, Long Island, through Sept. 19. Lichtenstein has been a constant but reclusive presence in Southampton for quite some time, and he could perfectly well have lent his name to the show and allowed the museum to hang whatever it could pick up here and there. But this is, on the contrary, a serious retrospective that covers more than 30 years, includes many things that have rarely or never been seen before, and is a credit to the artist, to the museum and to Olivia Motch, who acted as guest curator.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ENDING THE SEASON WITH A SPLASH
description: AS SUMMER winds down and schools start, September weekends are times for some last carefree outings, especially for families, before the onset of normal antiques business schedules.

title: LOS ANGELES AREA DRAWS PLAN TO BATTLE SMOG
description: Officials have introduced a blueprint for cleaning up the beige haze that hangs over the country's smoggiest region here.

title: THE MIDWEST
description: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, REGION BY REGION By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

title: BOLD U.S. PLAN PUTS ARAFAT CENTER STAGE
description: man Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization met in Tunis yesterday to consider the Reagan plan for the Middle East. Yasir Arafat was in the chair and the international spotlight was on him once more. It was only four days after he left the ruins of Beirut and three days after he arrived to a statesman's welcome in Athens, a non-Arab capital he had chosen because he wanted to underline his distance from all the Arab regimes and his contempt for most of them.

title: Q and A
description: Question:My husband and I are planning to visit Egypt and Israel in the fall. Are we likely to contract malaria in either country? Are there many insects and will we need an insect repellent? - J.L., Bronx, N.Y. Answer:It is possible but unlikely that tourists would contract malaria in either Egypt or Israel, according to Dr. Kent Campbell, a malaria specialist with the United States Public Health Service at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, Ga.

title: A SMORGASBORD OF MUSIC IS ON THE WAY
VERPLANCK HATCHERY TO ADD THOUSANDS OF BASS TO RIVER
description: BECAUSE of the high price it commands at the Fulton Fish Market, commercial fishermen call it the money fish. Sport fishermen know it as the glamour fish. To scientists, the striped bass is merely Morone saxatilis, a Latin name meaning ''stupid found among rocks.''

title: PLIMPTON: OPENING DOORS TO MANY WORLDS
description: SOME 15 years ago, George Plimpton sat down and began his first - and as yet unfinished - novel. It was the story of a 70-year-old photographer, blessed with both extraordinary luck and a conspicuous knack for failure. Seated at a cafe in Sarajevo in 1914, the photographer witnessed the murder of Archduke Ferdinand, but managed only to get a picture of shocked onlookers as they watched the assassin flee. Aboard the Lusitania's last fateful voyage, he whipped out his camera, but photographed only a snippet of the ship's bow as it sank into the ocean.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT has been years since the robbery, but he has not forgotten, and will not. Those 15 minutes are locked in his memory, hard-edged and brilliant as one of his own diamonds.

title: HOW MUCH DOES A GOOD ONE COST?
description: NATURE can be expensive. A view of mountains or the shore, a CentralP ark panorama or windows framing a forest, river, or lake can add 25 p ercent or more to the value of a property. A truly magical view - t he kind that turns up in the movies -can double the value.

title: Thomas Baird Fulweiler 2d Marries Marcy Merrill
description: Marcy Vought Merrill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Vought of Schenectady, N.Y., was married in Sanbornton, N.H., yesterday to Thomas Baird Fulweiler 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulweiler of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. David A. Robbins, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Upper Bay Meeting House.

title: Miners Saved in South Korea
description: Four coal miners trapped by a cave-in 800 feet underground were rescued 14 days later in fair condition, officials said today. Rescue workers said the miners survived by drinking from puddles and eating bark from timber inside the pit.

title: DON'T LET INDUSTRY SHIRK ITS DUTY
description: THE startling decision by the Manville Corporation to file for reorganization under Chapter 11 oft he Bankruptcy Act will hopefully accelerate the creation of a p rocess for assuring that victims of asbestos diseases receive a dequate compensation on a timely basis.

title: MORRISTOWN
description: IN its two and a half centuries, Morristown has evolved from a m ining town to the Revolutionary War capital, to the playground of m illionaires from the last quarter of the 19th century to the Great D epression and, finally, to the suburban home of corporations that iti s becoming today.

title: TRENTON
description: year-old experiment with casinos in Atlantic City, will hold hearings next month that could lead to important changes in the industry.

title: Featured Matches Today; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Andrea Jaeger-Andrea Temesvari. Second Match - John McEnroe-Vince Van Patten.

title: Sara Hendrie To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hendrie of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Alexandra Hendrie, to David McKey Sessions, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis William Sessions of New Canaan, Conn.

title: PRETTY AND DELICIOUS FRENCH FOOD
description: RIDGEFIELD LE COQ HARDI is a tiny gem of a French nouvelle cuisine restaurant. The restaurant itself is as pretty as the food looks and tastes. In the basement of a completely restored 200-year-old building, a small space that once was a blacksmith's shop has been artfully turned into a stylish, understated restaurant. Original fieldstone walls and log-beamed ceilings have been retained. Two separate, small dining alcoves have been created, with banquettes, inviting pale-pink tablecloths, a single unusual flower on each table and a few pictures of roosters on the walls.

title: METS STOP REDS, 3-2, WITH AID OF BULLPEN
description: The Mets' bullpen, which has absorbed 27 of the team's 81 losses, came through last night in a 3-2, victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium.

title: FREE RIDES; Plastic Trade-Off
description: It was a marketing coup. When virtually every other bank began charging annual fees for MasterCard and Visa accounts, the Bank of New York went against the grain.

title: Education Aide to Be Named
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Lawrence Davenport, associate director of Action, to be Assistant Secretary of Education for elementary and secondary education, the White House says. Mr. Davenport, who is 37 years old, has been associate director of Action since 1981 and previously served as provost of the San Diego Community College District. He will succeed Vincent E. Reed.

title: SLUDGE IN WATER CURTAILS USE OF SOME FIRE ISLAND BEACHES
description: Swimming and other beach activities were curtailed for hundreds of people on Fire Island today as windblown sludge that had apparently drifted in from offshore dumping grounds kept some federally controlled beaches closed.

title: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENATIVES, REGION BY REGION
description: Although President Reagan's spiritual wellspring is still the far West, shifts in the political climate since 1980 could yield some interesting changes of seats in those states, which include California, Nevada, Oregon and Washington.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
CORVETTE CONVENTION
description: More than 100 gleaming, growling Corvettes - America's answer to the Jaguar - will roll into Millville Sunday for Wheaton Village's third annual Vettes in Glasstown show.

title: HEARINGS NEAR ON HOW TO PAY FOR SHOREHAM
description: THE state's Public Service Commission begins proceedings Wednesday on the thorny issue of how the Long Island Lighting Company will pass along the costs of building its $2.63 billion Shoreham nuclear plant. Early in these proceedings, Lilco will give details for the first time about the plan it prefers.

title: Sports of The Times; Sharks on the Boardwalk
description: HE shudders as he walks past the hardened professionals of Flushing Meadows, remembering the morning he went head to head with them. He could not have been outclassed more thoroughly if he had taken his old wooden racquet onto center court and challenged Connors or McEnroe.

title: WAKE FOREST 31, WESTERN CAROLINA 10
description: SALEM, N.C. (AP) - Gary Schofield threw for two touchdowns, and Dan Dougherty scored twice to lead the Demon Deacons. Scholfield, who passed for 243 yards, threw his scoring passes in the first half. The Demon Deacons added two touchdowns in the final period.

title: FOR MONROE, IT'S BACK TO SCHOOL IN SHELTON
description: SHELTON EVERYTHING about the grammar school is Monroe: the principal, teachers, students, custodians and bus drivers. Even the stationery and outdoor sign proclaim ''Monroe Elementary School.'' East, that is. It is here in Shelton, in the building most people knew as Sunnyside School, that 400 children from Monroe will begin classes Tuesday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THIS STRANGE NEW FEELING By Julius Lester. 149 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $10.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By MAUREEN HOWARD

title: Topics; Free Rides; Gravy Train Justice
description: Some New York subway riders may take odd comfort from knowing that Edward O'Grady, the former superintendent of quality control and newcar engineering, is a convicted extortionist. Budget shortages or mere mismanagement don't always explain a bad ride.

title: Network Debate
description: To the Business Editor: There are several inaccuracies in the article, ''Debate Over Office 'Networks,' '' (Aug. 15). Digital Equipment Corporation, the Intel Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, far from ''quibbling,'' have worked together closely for three years in writing and promoting specifications for Ethernet, the best-known local area network on the market.

title: Sound and Fury
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Sound and Fury Over Poverty'' (Aug. 22), Barbara R. Bergmann's analysis of the failure of conservative and liberal antipoverty programs was excellent. Unfortunately, her own proposed solutions - affirmative action and getting absent fathers to contribute to the support of their children - would also fail.

title: GEORGE WALLACE'S BID FOR THE NEW SOUTH
description: Bloody Lowndes, they used to call the county. I walked into its courthouse in Hayneville, Ala., on a summer's day in 1965 representing a New York newspaper. Any connection with the North was looked on with suspicion, so I was surprised to be greeted graciously by a man of late middle age. Speaking in the educated voice of the landed gentry, he chatted for half an hour about the place and the people. I remember especially the affection he expressed for the architecture of the 19th-century courthouse.

title: THE SOUTH
description: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, REGION BY REGION By REGINALD STUART

title: Sinatra House
description: The owners of a house in Hoboken, N.J., that Frank Sinatra lived in as a youth thought they were in for a big profit. They had decided to sell the house, with a $150,000 minimum bid.

title: AH, FOR THE DAYS WHEN TALKIES REALLY TALKED
CHOOSING NOT TO KILL
description: NAMESAKE By Michel Goldberg. Illustrated. 192 pp. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $13.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN CUISINE AND A BIT MORE
description: THE Italian steakhouse, a product of Yankee ingenuity, promises plenty for those who are concerned that a hefty slab of beef might be too plain to satisfy and crave additional enrichment from Italian cuisine favoring, for example, spicy antipasto; thick, rich minestrone; mouth-filling pasta in acid-edged tomato sauces or sweet garlic and oil. Judging from the success of such restaurants, that union is a popular one.

title: Security Accounts
description: Question: Does the landlord of a three-family building in which he himself lives have to segregate security deposits from his own funds, keep such deposits in interest-bearing accounts and pay such interest to tenants annually? It is my belief that all of the foregoing applies only to buildings housing six or more tenants. ... J.H., Brooklyn Answer: According to the Attorney General's office, an owner must segregate tenants' security deposits from his own funds. However, the owner of a building with fewer than six apartments may - but is not required to - keep security deposits in an interest-bearing account. If he chooses to do so, then he can deduct a 1 percent annual administrative fee from each tenant's account. Owners of buildings with six or more apartments must keep security deposits in interestbearing accounts and pay tenants prevailing interest rates minus the 1 percent administrative fee.

title: GREENWICH TO TEST XEROX TRACT RULING
description: GREENWICH THIS community of 50 square miles, which contains some of the most luxurious homes in the nation, is attempting to hold back what appears to be an inexorable tide. Long considered the ultimate address for those who had ''arrived,'' the town has fought plans to use the land for nonresidential purposes - particularly the relocation of large corporations to campus-like spreads.

title: Jorky of France Wins Challenge Cup Trot
description: Jorky of France won the $100,000 Challenge Cup Trot at 1 1/2 miles at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, with Sweden's Nino Blazing second and Spice Island of the United States third.

title: Rachelle H. Hill Married
description: Rachelle Hervie Hill, daughter of Mrs. George Madison of Cambria Heights, Queens, and Leroy F. Hill of Wilmington, N.C., was married yesterday to Keith Bernard Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cooper of Westbury, L.I. The Rev. Floyd H. Flake performed the ceremony at the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens. Until recently, the bride was a systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation in Northfield, Ill. Mr. Cooper was an investment banker with Goldman Sachs & Company in Chicago.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATHENS
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The Times from Athens. By PAUL ANASTASI

title: Lieut. A.A. Cucolo 3d Marries Raye V. Allen
description: Raye Virginia Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kiper Allen of Temple, Tex., and Washington, was married yesterday to Lieut. Anthony Arthur Cucolo 3d, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cucolo Jr. of Houston, formerly of Suffern, N.Y. Msgr.

title: Pamela Gardner Wed to James Jelinek
description: Pamela Mylar Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Hartwell Gardner of Wilton, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., yesterday to James Stephen Jelinek, son of Col. Howard C. Jelinek, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jelinek of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Martyn Minns performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: JAZZ: SOME NEW MUSIC
description: Maybe the concert title, ''Recent Developments in Jazz,'' scared people away from Loeb Student Center Wednesday. A half-full house greeted Howard Johnson and Gravity, Oliver Lake and Jump Up, and the Chico Freeman Quartet, none of whom are abstruse or revolutionary.

title: SCHOOLS OPENING WITH STATE AID $83 MILLION SHORT
description: WHEN schools open this week, many will be hard-pressed to offer the state's projected 1,158,000 students all the academic advantages they had last year.

title: INDUSTRY'S SUMMER JOB PROJECT HAILED
description: A private program to provide summer jobs for poor New York City youths has reported that it put 15,789 of them to work this summer, about 6,500 more than last year, the program's first.

title: THE EAST
description: CLOSELY WATCHED CONTESTS FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, REGION BY REGION By RICHARD L. MADDEN

title: OPENING OF SCHOOL, A MATERNAL FIESTA
description: IT'S the first day of school. My boys have been fed, trimmed, scrubbed, outfitted and inspected. Time to go to the bus. The air is charged, expectant. They worry: Is their teacher as mean as they say? What's the philosophy on recess? What if I'm allergic to long division?

title: No Headline
description: Calvin Peete, helped by an eagle 2 on the 441-yard 13th hole, took a one-stroke lead today after the third round of the $275,000 B.C. Open.

title: WASHINGTON LOOSENS THE STRINGS ON AID
description: The Reagan Administration is softening somewhat its approach to the economic problems of the third world. But despite signs of greater generosity, it is still at odds with most other countries over the resources and policies needed to head off a world financial crisis brought on by too many countries owing too much to too many commercial banks.

title: CALIFORNIA AWAITS A DELUGE OF TRIALS
description: When California's Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of a voter-initiated referendum to establish a ''bill of rights'' for crime victims, it set in motion a delayed statewide effort to carry out the three-month-old measure.

title: ITALY'S ANGER RISES AT GENERAL'S MURDER
description: A funeral was held today for Gen. Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, the high-ranking police official assassinated by gunmen Friday night in the center of Palermo in Sicily, and it provided an occasion for expressions of anger and frustration over the Government's seeming inability to provide law and order.

title: STEVENS WELCOMES FRESHMEN TO AGE OF COMPUTERS
description: HOBOKEN EVERY year about this time, more than 2.5 million young men and women begin drifting onto college campuses on lazy end-of-summer afternoons, wandering around for the first time, staring at class schedules and sitting through endless orientation sessions.

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. SPLIT ON LEGISLATURE POST
description: SUFFOLK Republicans are deadlocked on the choice of a Presiding Officer of the County Legislature to succeed William C. Richards, who resigned effective last Monday.

title: FRANKFURT, West Germany When Judith Somogi ascended the podium at the Frankfurt Opera earlier this week to conduct Rossini's ''Il Turco in Italia,'' she had gone considerably beyond the overture and into the opera's action before the eyes of the audience wandered from her petite, animated figure to the singers on stage.
description: Miss Somogi, born in New York, and the first woman conductor at Frankfurt's Opera, is something of a curiosity here. Not that she is the first American to invade German opera. According to a recent survey of Germany's 50 or so opera houses, roughly one-fourth of their soloists, not to mention countless chorus singers, dancers and musicians, are Americans. Nor is she the first woman conductor. Sylvia Caduff, the Swiss conductor, is music director at Solingen's Opera House, and Alicija Mounk conducts at Munich's Gartner- platz Theater. But women remain a rarity in German orchestras, and traditional barriers fall slowly. After 100 years, the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra shattered tradition earlier this year when it hired its first woman, the Swiss violinist Madeleine Caruzzo.

title: N.R.C. MEMBER DEFENDS INDIAN PT. INQUIRY'S FOCUS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission limited testimony in the Indian Point hearings to focus the proceeding on questions the commissioners wanted answered, not to silence the public comment, according to the acting head of the commission.

title: Jeannine Esswein Wed to a Lawyer
description: Jeannine Renee Esswein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Esswein of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel James Thomasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon J. Thomasch of Rockville, Md. The Rev. John Pazo performed the ceremony and celebrated a nuptial mass in the Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Manila Formally Charges 68 With Subversion
description: The Government today formally charged 68 people, most of them labor leaders, with plotting to mount an insurrection during President Ferdinand E. Marcos's visit to the United States later this month.

title: MARKETING THOSE MILLION-DOLLAR MANSIONS
description: JAMES STEPHENSON is a man with a million-dollar problem - $1.25 m illion, to be precise. That is the price Dr. Stephenson, a physiciani n private practice in New York City, and his wife are asking for B ella Vista, his four-acre estate in Southport, Conn., on which s tands a Georgian brick mansion in formal gardens overlooking Long I sland Sound.

title: WASHINGTON - Cuba continues to have much the same effect on United States Administrations that the full moon reputedly had on werewolves. Perhaps there is no sprouting of hair, but a certain frothing at the mouth and loss of rationality are notable.  Indeed, Cuba is such an emotional issue that clear and objective analysis is extremely rare. The Reagan Administration follows the pattern.
description: Certainly there is nothing new in its approach to Cuba. On the contrary, it seems determined to make past mistakes all over again, and again and again. It came to office striking fierce postures and warning that no option was excluded, not even blockade or invasion. In expecting Fidel Castro to be cowed, the Administration displayed an abysmal insensitivity to history.

title: Pirates 1, Dodgers 0
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Lee Tunnell, a rookie right-hander making his first major league appearance for Pittsburgh, blanked Los Angeles over seven innings before relievers Rod Scurry and Kent Tekulve took over to complete the shutout.

title: FLEETS TURN TO IMPORTS
description: Enticed by lower prices, better fuel efficiency and high resale values, American businesses are discovering what individual car buyers have known for a long time: Foreign-made autos are a good buy. The results show up in sales by foreign manufacturers to the ''fleet'' market, where new cars are bought en masse (at least four at a time) by corporations, government agencies, small businesses and leasing and rental agencies.

title: HISTORIANS USE CINEMA TO STIMULATE STUDENT INTERESTS
description: When Woodrow Wilson saw ''The Birth of a Nation'' in 1915, he described the movie epic about race relations after the Civil War as ''history written in lightning.'' His comment referred not only to the flicker of light upon the silver screen, but also presumably to the emotional effect of the film.

title: Cup Challengers Are Hopeful
description: As the sleek 52-foot Magnum roared across the ocean chop between the groups of 12-meter yachts in training for the next America's Cup, the Australian designer aboard almost jumped for joy.

title: SUPPORT FOR SOLIDARITY TESTS WARSAW'S CONTROL
description: The demonstration sites called for in furtively distributed Solidarity leaflets had been turned into armed camps last week long before the appointed hour. They filled up with feared ZOMO riot police, helmeted and armed with water cannon and with long truncheons, many of them bent from previous use. Still, the people turned out, gingerly at first, then more boldly by the tens of thousands in cities and towns across Poland in the largest anti-Government demonstration since the imposition of martial law Dec. 13.

title: Bonn Seizes Danish Reporter On Suspicion of Being a Spy
description: A Danish journalist has been arrested by the West German authorities on suspicion of spying for East Germany, the Federal Prosecutor's Office said today.

title: THE WORKPLACE IN TRANSITION
description: TOMORROW is the centennial of Labor Day, an event that began in 1882 with a parade by the Knights of Labor to honor working people. But on Labor Day 1982, the 1.5 million people now employed in Connecticut -almost all of whom will have the day off - bear little resemblance to the workers who feted themselves in New York City so long ago.

title: THEFTS CUT SHARPLY IN GARMENT DISTRICT DRIVE
description: A ''dramatic reduction'' in rack robberies and truck burglaries in the garment district has been reported by city, police and industry officials.

title: AFTER THE GLORY IS OVER, TENNIS IS STILL FUN
description: WEST HARTFORD CAN a woman who has won the United States, Wimbledon, French and Australian tennis championships and is enshrined in the Tennis Hall of Fame find happiness as a club player? Shirley Fry Irvin has, at the Hartford Tennis Club, where she has been playing ''social tennis'' for the last 20 years.

title: GETTING LOST IN TRANSLATION
description: L. R. SHANNON is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. BY L.R.SHANNON

title:
LABOR'S ENEMY: LABOR;
MADISON, Wis. - Much has been written about the decline of organized labor. But in one crucial respect - the willful neglect of the rights and needs of minorities - organized labor has become its own worst enemy. A case in point is the sad history of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliate.
description: In 1971, when electrical contractors in New York City were barred from bidding on municipal construction contracts because of discriminatory apprenticeship practices, Local 3 entered into an agreement with the city to conduct a training program to prepare black and Hispanic workers for union membership and jobs. This program, subsidized by public funds, was the culmination of more than two decades of minority protests against Local 3, which controls all hiring in its jurisdiction in the metropolitan area.

title: Capital Vigil Planned On Vietnam War Dead
description: For 48 hours and 29 minutes over three days in November, the names of 57,709 Americans killed or missing in Vietnam are to be read aloud by volunteers in the Washington Cathedral.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LONE PILGRIM. By Laurie Colwin. (Pocket Books/Washington Square Press, $3.95.) Thirteen stories by the author of ''Happy All the Time,'' whose new novel, ''Family Happiness,'' comes out this month. Limning relationships between men and women, Laurie Colwin writes with ''sunny skill'' and ''tireless enthusiasm,'' said our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, adding that ''at least one story, 'Girl Skating,' which touches upon issues rather more weighty than romance, is very good indeed.''

title: A FINANCIAL PUBLISHER, TURNED CONDUCTOR, READIES HIS BATON
description: BY any measure, one of the unlikeliest financial and cultural eventso f the season will take place this Thursday, when many of the i nternational bankers gathered in Toronto for a meeting of the I nternational Monetary Fund will regroup at New York's Avery Fisher H all.

title: FRANCE CUTS BACK ARMS OUTLAY PLAN
description: The French Government has made an important modification in its priorities, scaling down, for the time being at least, its strong and aggressively stated initial commitment to increased military spending.

title: The Adventurous Doris Lessing
description: So Doris Lessing's readers are dismayed by the new direction in her latest books, the ''Canopus'' series (''Doris Lessing on Feminism, Communism and 'Space Fiction,' '' by Lesley Hazleton, July 25). As Lesley Hazleton points out, Doris Lessing ''has ventured into outer space and ... left her readers helplessly earthbound.''

title: A TIME FOR CHOICES ON CAMPUSES
description: THE academic year that began Wednesday at the four state colleges saw a fundamental change in their role within Connecticut public higher education.

title:
GARDENING;
CARE AND CULTIVATION OF THE DAHLIA
description: AS SUMMER draws to a close, the flowers begin to fade one by one. Among the exceptions is the dahlia, which seems to come into its own near the end of the season. Even the bedding sorts that were in flower when planted out in May will still be in full bloom, assuming that someone has made an effort to deadhead them throughout the summer.

title: Zurich
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing: 'Autonomous In Its Own Right'
description: Although salaries and working conditions are undoubtedly critical issues in the recruitment of nurses to Long Island hospitals, I believe that another, perhaps even more important concern of nurses is reflected in the last several paragraphs of the recent article ''Outside Recruiting of New L.I. Nurses Affecting Hospitals.'' It is intimated that the upgrading of nursing in authority and status is accomplished through specialized training in medical diagnosis, treatment of patients with minor illnesses and writing of prescriptions.

title: WORKERS, COMPANIES ALIKE FEEL ASBESTOS EFFECTS
description: John Ritchie, gaunt and haggard beyond his 64 years, suffering from pelvic cancer, painfully short of breath and always feeling weak and tired, is not quite sure what has happened to him.

title: Greece
description: To the Editor: It seems to me that the letters (Travel, July 11) complaining that travel agents and tour organizers are giving inaccurate information about visiting historic landmarks in Greece and of tourists arriving at many after they are closed miss the point of what is really happening.

title: Reagan Puts His Stamp On U.S. Foreign Policy
description: For months, people have watched for the trademarks of President Reagan's foreign policy but they have been stymied by Mr. Reagan's long hesitation to go much beyond the sharp rhetorical anti-Sovietism of his 1980 campaign.

title: No Headline
description: Expos Beat Braves On Cromartie's Hits

title: NATION'S SCHOOLS IN FISCAL SQUEEZE AS STUDENTS RETURN TO CLASSROOMS
description: The nation's schools began opening this week with far fewer employee strikes than last year but with many school districts facing financial problems that have significantly curtailed their programs.

title: MICHAEL MCDONALD MAKES A SOLO DEBUT WITH SONGS OF LOVE
description: Michael McDonald's solo album debut, ''If That's What It Takes'' (Warner Bros. 23703-1), opens a new chapter in the career of one of the most widely admired young male pop singers in America. Its release coincides with the farewell tour of the Doobie Brothers, the California-based rock group he joined seven years ago as the keyboardist and co-lead singer. At the end of this summer, the group will officially disband, and the admittedly stage-shy singer with a voice like melted chocolate will finally be free to pursue the solo career that critics and music business insiders have been urging him to undertake for some time.

title: UNNECESSARY PRECAUTIONS
description: OBASAN By Joy Kogawa. 250 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $12.95.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: When Elizabeth and Arthur Wilson moved from East Hampton, L.I., to Scottsdale, Ariz., a few weeks ago, they took with them the family pets: one small cat, one medium-size cat and one large dog. Their trip was not undertaken lightly. Among other things, the Wilsons had their animals checked out by a veterinarian to make sure that their inoculations were up to date and that they were in good health and able to travel. They also booked all their motels well in advance, from a brochure called ''Touring With Towser'' (available from Gaines TWT, P.O. Box 1007, Kankakee, Ill. 60901, for $1.25), which contains a state-by-state listing of hotel and motel facilities that accept pets.

title: ISLAND WHIRL IN BELMONT UPSET
description: Island Whirl, who arrived from San Diego only four days ago and whose trainer stayed there yesterday, led every step of the way to post a five-length upset victory in the $227,500 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: DARK DAYS FOR COFFEE
description: Along with others in the commodity business, coffee producers have had a difficult year. High interest rates and the recession have overwhelmed a drop in prices and dampened what was already slack demand. Moreover, much to the growers' misfortune, the drop in economic activity has taken place at a time when coffee's production cycle reached its peak.

title: Group Assails Rules Changes On Education of Handicapped
description: The American Foundation for the Blind has asked the Reagan Administration to stop any efforts to relax rules on the education of the handicapped.

title: DOCTORS REPORT BIRTH OF BABY IN 1981 TO BRAIN-DEAD WOMAN
description: Physicians at Children's Hospital here kept a woman clinically alive for six days in 1981 until her baby could be born with a better chance of survival, according to an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: ARMS AND CHILDREN
description: 'There are a million kids out there who are little hawks,' Gail Levin, a senior producer at WNBC-TV, said last week. 'They're playing video games, and they're very aggressive and they're fascinated by technology and weaponry.

title: SATELLITE WEAPONS: THE U.S. PRIORITY IS NOT TO LAG BEHIND
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Sees No Hope For Reagan Peace Plan
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that there was ''no chance'' Israel would accept President Reagan's Mideast peace plan.

title: JETS, IN DISARRAY, LOSE TO BRONCOS, 20-13
description: In a chilling prelude to the real season of pro football, the Jets tonight wound up their exhibition schedule with two members of the Sack Exchange sidelined, their kicking game in disarray and a quarterback intimating changes should be made.

title:
IN THE ARTS: CRTICS' CHOICES;
PHOTOGRAPHY
description: The vision of America as a land that is hopeful and strong in spite of its troubles was never better realized than it was in the pictures taken during the Depression years by a handful of roaming photographers working for the Farm Security Administration. Their mission was to show America's city dwellers why taxes raised in he cities should be spent in the country, and the picture of rural life that they presented was filled with gnarled hands, tumbled-down shacks and backwoods poverty of a sort that scarcely exists today except in the comic strips.
