title: APPEAL PANEL RULES PRIMARY POLL HOURS IN STATE MAY DIFFER
description: New York's practice of allowing longer voting hours for primary voters in the more populous areas of the state has been upheld by a state appeals court.

title: Arthritis Medicine Exempted From Child-Proof Cap Rules
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has exempted an arthritis drug from packaging requirements that make container caps difficult to remove.

title: FRUSTRATED AND WARY, LABOR MARKS ITS DAY
description: "LABOR Is Alive.'' Unionism's high command is rallying around that declaration of faith on this 100th anniversary of Labor Day. It is the central slogan of the key celebration - the unveiling in Texas of a monument to Samuel Gompers, founding father of the American Federation of Labor. But this exercise in ancestor worship is itself an ironic reflection of the cross pulls between barnacled tradition and the need for change that make the union movement's future health decidedly problematical.

title: Miss Adams The Fiancee Of a Student
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Rule Adams Jr. of Bethesda, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Rule Adams, to Hoyle Haywood Miller 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller Jr. of Annapolis, Md.

title: WILL CHOREOGRAPHY EVER BY RESPECTED AS AN ART FORM?
description: Let's not mince words, but say what has to be said as bluntly as possible. So here goes: Dance, as an art form, is too often an absolute mess. There, now, it's been said.

title: BYERS WINS FIFTH AVENUE MILE
description: They came down Fifth Avenue as tightly packed as a rush-hour crowd. ''It was anybody's race,'' said John Walker, the New Zealand runner. Then Tom Byers made it his race in the last block between 63d Street and the finish line at 62d Street.

title: THE ADVENTUROUS DORIS LESSING
description: The ''Canopus in Argos'' series certainly took me by surprise - but it need not have. Earlier works, such as ''The Summer Before the Dark,'' ''The Memoirs of a Survivor'' and ''Briefing for a Descent Into Hell,'' explored dreams, altered perceptions and even alternate worlds parallel to and linked to our world.

title: Women Alone
description: To the Editor: In the article, ''A Guide to the Cafes of Paris'' (Travel, June 6), it was noted that Le Fouquet still adheres to the old (and somewhat chauvinistic) policy of permitting an unescorted woman to sit only at a table rather than at the bar for drinks. Compared to the Noga Hilton in Geneva, Switzerland, the Fouquet is for feminists. v. hile visiting Switzerland recently, I stopped one evening in the lobby lounge bar of the Noga Hilton for a drink prior to returning to my own hotel for the evening. I sat down at a table in the corner and signaled a waiter to take my order. When the waiter asked me if I was alone and if I was staying at the hotel, I assumed that the purpose of his questions was to determine whether or not I would sign for my drinks or pay in cash. I informed him that I was not staying at the hotel and would thus be paying in cash.

title: SIR DOUGLAS BADER, WORLD WAR II ACE
description: Sir Douglas R.S. Bader, Britain's legendary legless fighter pilot of World War II, died early today, the London police reported. He was 72 years old.

title: BAN ON MOBILE SIGNS SOUGHT
description: THE days for roadside mobile signs may be numbered in Brookhaven Town, where officials will hold a public hearing Tuesday on a proposed law to ban such signs by 1985.

title: Somerset Senator's Observations Called Misguided
description: Senator Gerald Cardinale, in an Aug. 8 Opinion article, criticized the Legislature's Joint Appropriations Committee for its actions on the state budget. For the record, Senator Cardinale never served on the committee or attended its meetings. Hence, what he set forth as ''facts'' are, at best, incorrect and misguided conclusions based on second-hand information.

title: MExico Seizes Private Banks
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo, three months from the end of his term, demonstrated last week that for a lame duck, he still has some kick left. Reacting to Mexico's financial crisis, Mr. Lopez Portillo announced in his last State of the Union address that he was nationalizing the banks to give the Government a stronger hand in halting a flight from the much-devalued peso.

title: HILLS AND HOLLOWS AND FOLKLORE GALORE
description: JANET DAILEY, the author of 69 novels, of which the most recent is ''This Calder Range'' (Pocket Books), lives in the Ozarks, in Branson, Mo. By JANET DAILEY

title: Carr Sent to Seahawks
description: Roger Carr, the wide receiver with the Baltimore Colts who has made no secret of his animosity toward Frank Kush, the new Baltimore coach, got his wish yesterday. When he reported to the Colts' training camp in August, he said he wanted to be traded because he didn't want to be part of the changes being made by Kush. Yesterday, after having been suspended twice by the Colts, he was sent to the Seattle Seahawks for an undisclosed draft choice. Carr will be reunited in Seattle with Coach Mike McCormack who was dismissed by Baltimore last year after a 2-14 season.

title: WHY MUST THEY JUMP ON TABLES TO SING?
description: Want a sure sign of malfeasance by an operatic stage director? It's when the tenor (sometimes a baritone, but usually the tenor) leaps ebulliently on top of a conveniently placed table, stretches his arms heavenward or audienceward and belts out a testimony to joy, spontaneity and freedom. Almost invariably, the sheer predictability of this action - knowing opera-lovers scout any low-lying items of furniture as soon as the curtain rises, calculating the likelihood of their being used as tenorial launching pads - precludes anything like joy, spontaneity and freedom. Glum, curdled routine is more to the point.

title: AN UNCOMMON MIX
description: Over the past few years, we often have extolled the virtues of a sauce that has become uncommonly fashionable in the world of food. It is called beurre blanc, or white butter sauce, and it is impressively easy to make. One reason for its upsurge in popularity undoubtedly has been the introduction of nouvelle cuisine. A beurre blanc is much more delicate than, for example, a hollandaise or a bearnaise.

title: Car Rentals
description: To the Editor:

title: RACIAL TENSIONS LINGER IN BOSTON'S HYDE PARK
description: On the same corner where whites assaulted a black woman in July, capping several years of racial incidents in the Hyde Park area of South Boston, neighbors are going to hold the First Annual Get to Know Your Neighbor Picnic to promote racial harmony.

title: The Nation In Summary; Far to Go, by Any Measure
description: Though an E.P.D index is not among the indicators rolled out by the Federal Government and private financial institutions, perhaps it should be. Last week, there was Eco-Political Discomfort all over.

title: JAZZ: REGGIE WORKMAN UNIT
description: John Coltrane's modal harmonies and ''sheets of sound'' arpeggios have become common parlance in jazz since the 1960's. No one has a better right to them, however, than Reggie Workman, who played bass in Mr. Coltrane's late-1960's quartet and who led Top Shelf at Lush Life through last night.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
THE FEAR FACTOR IN PRO FOOTBALL'S CONTRACT TALKS
description: SIGNING the standard-form player contract is the last input most players have over the life of that contract with respect to their National Football League careers (other than performance on the field). Once the player signs, the club is in control of their lives. The club tells the player how much he should weigh, how strong he must be and when and where to report.

title: BIKE CLUB SPONSORS RACES
description: PORT CHESTER ''IN America, they say little acorns grow into big trees and that's what's happened to our bicycling club,'' said Draha Strnad, a former top junior speed ice-skating star in her native Czechoslovakia. ''Today, we have almost 100 members. When we started to organize three years ago, we had only five.''

title: FROM PUERTO RICO TO EL BARRIO
No Headline
description: Palmer Wins on 1-Hitter

title: RENT A ROOM TO A COLLEGE STUDENT
description: ALOT of people in our township have funny ideas about students. Take the three lone women living along our road, rattling around in their large houses and admitting to night fears. Suggest that they rent a room to a student and they recoil. Students would give wild parties, drink, take drugs, play that horrible music, bring dirt and disorder.

title: An Award for Kuhn
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, has been opposed by some major league owners who would like to see him removed from his office, but he still has friends in amateur baseball. Yesterday in Seoul, South Korea, the site of the 27th world baseball championships, Kuhn was presented with the first President's Award of Honor by the International Association of Amateur Baseball, the governing body of the sport. The award was presented by Dr. Robert E. Smith, the association president, who said: ''Baseball's strength worldwide has grown immeasurably in recent years and we could not have achieved many of our important steps without his dedicated and continuing leadership.

title: G.M. PLANT IN SOUTH UNIONIZED WITHOUT VOTE
description: The United Automobile Workers has been recognized, without an election, as the bargaining agent for the Saginaw Steering Gear Division's three-plant complex near here, the largest nonunion General Motors plant in the country.

title: COSMOS' DEPTH GIVES THEM EDGE IN SOCCER SERIES
description: Having to choose between Hubert Birkenmeier, voted goalkeeper of the year by the players in the league, and David Brcic, the best goalkeeper in the playoffs with only one goal against him in three games, gives an idea of the Cosmos' depth.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
WHEN THOROUGHBRED RACING LETS THE MONEY CONQUER ALL
description: IN the Travers Stakes when Conquistador Cielo failed to clip Pegasus's wings and was subsequently retired, this dual disappointment highlighted disturbing facets of society and sport.

title: LENDL AND MAYER WIN
description: The power principle that is causing such commotion in men's tennis these days almost flattened Yannick Noah yesterday in the third round of the United States Open championships.

title: ONE PLAN WOULD PUT ALL MX'S IN ONE BASKET
description: There is an adage in politics, to wit: Problems should not be defined in such a way that they can't be solved. It may be that the Reagan Administration did just that when it made the closing of the window of vulnerability - the theoretical vulnerability of American land-based missiles to a successful Soviet first strike - its top strategic priority.

title: ARTHUR LAFFER FIANCE OF TRACI HICKMAN
description: Betty Jane Hickman of Ontario Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Traci Lynn Hickman, to Arthur Betz Laffer of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif., son of William Gillespie Laffer of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., and the late Mrs. Laffer.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:30 P.M. Albums with photographs of all Met players and coaches will be given to fans who attend the last game of the season between the two clubs. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio-WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Kansas City. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio-WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Boxing James Kinchen vs. Odell Hadley, 10 rounds, middleweights, at Pacific Center, St. Joseph, Mo. Both fighters are unbeaten. Kinchen's record: 20 victories, including 17 knockouts, and one draw. Hadley is 12-0-1, including nine knockouts. (Television-Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Kid Gloves Championships, at an outdoor ring set up at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, noon. Twenty-two final bouts for youngsters between the ages of 10 and 15.

title: Letters; Street Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Most U.S. Babies Born In Hospital, Study Says
description: Despite ''much publicity'' about childbirth at home, 99 out of every 100 American babies are born in a hospital, in the same proportion as six years ago, according to the head of a physicians' group.

title: SCOTT RIEGER TO MARRY JANET MCLANE IN FALL
description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. C. Rogers McLane of Fort Worth of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lynn McLane, to Schott A. Rieger of Cincinnati.

title: RUTGERS REOPENS A BUILDING AND A CONTROVERSY; DIsputed Building Rutgers University officials last week ordered the reopening of Smith Hall, an academic building and research laboratory that was closed seven months ago after it was found to contain unsafe levels of a suspected carcinogen. But the people who normally work and study there, among whom there have been eight cancer cases since 1977, were in no rush to return.
description: Norman Samuels, acting provost of Rutgers's Newark Campus, said the State Health Department, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health and the university's own scientists concurred that on the basis of samplings taken in February and March, the building was safe for occupancy. However, Wells Keddie, president-elect of the Rutgers chapter of the American Association of University Professors, said the building's safety had not been established and ''people should not go back in.''

title: ACROSS CONNECTICUT A GATHERING OF GREENS
description: THOMAS A. GAINES, an architectural designer, lives in Connecticut. BY THOMAS A.GAINES

title: No Headline
description: JOHNNY BENCH is probably right: It's unfair to invoke the memory of the Big Red Machine of the 1970's and ask what happened to it in the 1980's.

title: F.B.I. Advertises for Fugitive Long on List of Most Wanted
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, after a three-year search for a man on its list of most wanted fugitives, is putting his face on billboards here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''That's a terrible word, 'unemployed.' It means hardship, uncertainty, frustration, helplessness.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. President, you and I chose for the last two years to call our countries 'friends and allies.'

title: FRANCE, BACK FROM THE SEASHORE, FEELS ADRIFT
description: Normally, summer ends in France with a thud, the noise of millions of car doors and trunks slamming shut, as synchronized an element of public behavior as the French manage to produce. It is as if there were 50 million people sitting on a dock on a bay watching the sun set, then rushing for the parking lot.

title: CITY IS DROPPING A PLAN TO COUNT HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: New York City has abandoned its plans to count the number of homeless people on its streets. Officials of the Human Resources Administration said they were persuaded by consultants who deal with statistics that it would be too difficult both to count the homeless and to survey their characteristics. And the latter, the city said, was its prime motivation for doing the census.

title: Rams Say Rutledge Is a Giant
description: The Rams said yesterday in Los Angeles that they have traded Jeff Rutledge, a reserve quarterback, to the Giants for an undisclosed draft choice, but the Giants would not confirm the deal.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Financial Briefs col- umn on Thursday misstated details of a common stock offering by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A.T.& T. agreed to sell eight million shares to a group of five underwriters, for resale to the public.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1982
description: International Israel's plans for more settlements in the occupied West Bank went ahead despite President Reagan's call for a freeze on Jewish settlements. The Government allocated $18.5 million to build three new settlements and announced approval of seven others. Its action coincided with the release of the text of a letter of protest from Prime Minister Menachem Begin to President Reagan, warning that the American proposals for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip would lead to a Palestinian state and ''a Soviet base in the heart of the Middle East.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The Administration told Israel that its position on the future of the West Bank and Gaza Strip ''remains unchanged and shall remained unchanged'' in a statement that condemned Israel's plan to establish more settlements in those areas. (1:5.)

title: Giants 5, Cardinals 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Joe Morgan's two-run double capped a fourrun eighth inning as San Francisco completed a sweep of a three-game series. St. Louis is now only one-half game ahead of Philadelphia in the National League East.

title: OF PALESTINIAN AUTONOMY AND 'BLACKMAIL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Chad Leader Is Reported Toppled
description: The leader of southern Chad, Col. Abdelkader Kamougue, has fled to Cameroon and his headquarters has been taken over by dissident soldiers, according to a broadcast on the Chad radio.

title: NATIONAL CATHEDRAL, UNFINISHED AT 75
description: Vincent Palumbo is carving a statue of St. Paul. ''It's not that easy,'' said Mr. Palumbo in his thick Italian accent, turning the statue on its pedestal. ''Even if he's outta stone, you gotta make him look like he's alive.''

title: LABOR LEADERS URGE CHANGES IN TRADE POLICIES TO SAVE JOBS
description: Two labor leaders, lamenting high unemployment, predicted today that jobs would become even scarcer unless the United States got tough with its trading partners.

title: Sara L. Merwin Wed To Ross C. Lumpkin
description: Sara Lynn Merwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Merwin of San Francisco, formerly of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ross Counsil Lumpkin, son of Capt. Pickett Lumpkin, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Lumpkin of San Antonio. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Albert A. Ahlstrom, the Lutheran chaplain of Columbia University, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Jeffrey Holden Wachtel Marries Gwyn Rita Felt
description: Gwyn Rita Felt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Felt of Memphis, was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Holden Wachtel, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Wachtel of New York. Rabbi Harry Danziger performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

title: Checker Earnings Up
description: Citing the sale of two subsidiaries, the Checker Motors Corporation has reported earnings of $4.9 million, or $7.48 a share, in the second quarter ended June 30, in contrast to a net loss of $194,000 in the same quarter of 1981. Sales for the quarter were $14.15 million, down 31 percent from the $20.6 million reported in the same period last year. Checker, based in Kalamazoo, stopped making its large, boxy taxicabs in July.

title: TEXT OF BEGIN'S LETTER TO REAGAN DEALING WITH LEBANON AND THE WEST BANK
description: Following is the text of the letter sent by Prime Minister Menachem Begin to President Reagan that was made public today by the Government press office:

title: TIMELY WRITER GETS TOUGH TEST TODAY
description: Timely Writer, an invalid at Triple Crown time but now the only 3-year-old racing with a chance to be named the horse of the year, meets his toughest challenge today since his return to the races. He faces eight rivals in the Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Remains of Man Discovered In 9 1/2-Foot Shark Off Florida
description: A fisherman who reeled in a 364-pound tiger shark Saturday discovered inside the leg of a man and a bone from another leg, the authorities said.

title: JET OFFENSE IS FACING CHANGES
description: The Jets celebrated their second annual ''Swarm Party'' today. But their head coach, Walt Michaels, had other things on his mind besides a party.

title: TOBACCO INDUSTRY FACES CHANGE AND CHALLENGE
description: The importance of tobacco in America's past is unchallenged. For example, Benjamin Franklin used it as collateral for French loans to help underwrite the Revolutionary War. But what is being called into question is its importance, if any, in the nation's future.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Sports World Specials; Behind Every Great Man
description: A phenomenon of the sports world that is seldom considered is the role of the wife of a major league baseball player. It is examined in ''Baseball Wives,'' a three-character comedy by Grubb Graebner that will open at the Harold Clurman Theater on Sept. 21. In May the play had a successful off-off-Broadway run at the American Renaissance Theater that lasted four weeks.

title: HEAD OF ITALIAN POLICE GROUP NAMED TO CRIME POST
description: The Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini today created a post of high commissioner for the fight against organized crime.

title: Ottumwa, Iowa, Mayor Assails Attacks on Saudis
description: City officials, upset by the loss of a $2 million training program following attacks on Saudi Arabian students, said today that ''vandals and troublemakers'' had managed to ''embarrass us internationally.''

title: NUCLEAR ARMS FOES RALLY IN WEST GERMANY:
description: Demonstrators marching in Dusseldorf carried a sign showing a nun smashing a nuclear bomb. The rally, which called for disarmament by Eastern and Western powers, coincided with the closing of a Roman Catholic conference and was organized by ''The Underground Church,'' a dissenting group.

title: NEW MEMBERS REFLECT DIVERSITY OF THE HOUSE
description: Jean Ashbrook is a conservative Republican from rural Ohio. Matthew Martinez is a liberal Democrat from urban California.

title: FOREIGN POLICY ISSUES MAY AFFECT OUTCOME OF SOME FALL RACES
description: Politicians typically say foreign policy does not swing Congressional elections nationwide, and this year is no exception. But there are about a dozen races for the House of Representatives and at least one for the Senate where such issues as a freeze on nuclear weapons and rising military spending could tip the balance.

title: JAILED ALCOHOLICS REQUIRE TREATMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPOS GET ONE HIT, BEAT BRAVES ON ERROR
description: The Montreal Expos were almost completely baffled by Rick Mahler and Gene Garber yesterday at Olympic Stadium in Montreal. The Atlanta pitchers allowed them just one hit, Al Oliver's 20th homer of the season, and permitted only six base runners in all.

title: SPORE WARS, OR WHO'S GOT THE TRUE POLLEN COUNT AROUND HERE?
description: At the outset of the Labor Day weekend, the pollen count in the New York City area was 150. On the other hand, the pollen count in the New York City area was 6.

title: Cost Rise Seen For Better Oil
description: A price committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has backed an increase of up to $2.30 a barrel for high-quality oil, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: WEINBERGER PRAISES THE EGYPTIAN STAND ON REAGAN PROPOSAL
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today applauded Egypt's stand on President Reagan's Middle East peace plan and said a special Washington-Cairo relationship was a key link to any Arab-I@sraeli settlement.

title: Touch of Class Takes Jumpoff
description: Touch of Class, ridden by Conrad Holmfeld, won the $20,000 Almaden Vineyards-Hampton Grand Prix at the Hampton Classic Horse Show today.

title: THE SUBTLETIES OF GO DRAW 115 TO A CHAMPIONSHIP
description: The game was go. It is an ancient game, perhaps 4,000 years old. It involves the slapping of small black and white disks - about the size of nickels - on a board. The point is to gain and guard territory.

title: SEMICONDUCTOR HOPES REVIVE
description: Last spring a surge of orders lifted hopes in the semiconductor industry that its two-year recession was over. Summer has dashed those hopes. Orders dried up again, and layoffs spread through Silicon Valley. Now executives and analysts alike say that if things don't look up in September it will be well into next year before the industry resumes growing.

title: ART IS FOR SHARING
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Meeting at Winkel
description: NO PLACE ON EARTH. By Christa Wolf, translated from the German by Jan van Heurck. 130 pages. Farrar, Straus & Gi- roux. $11.95.

title: Miss Green Rides To Gold Medal
description: Lucinda Green of Britain, riding Regal Realm, won the gold medal today at the World Horse Trial Championships.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE FOOTBALL PREVIEW: TRADITION ALTERED
description: COACH Joe Paterno of Penn State, who was an Ivy League quarterback at Brown 33 years ago, said last Dec. 4: ''The Ivy League is in another world all by their own. They are in another world. I'm in the real world.'' He was speaking as an advocate of the new realignment of college football.

title: MILITARY-SCHOOL MOVIE WORRIES THE CITADEL'S CHIEFS
description: For 140 years the Citadel, one of two state-supported, all-male military colleges in the nation, has jealously protected its reputation as a molder of young men.

title: An Old Man of 23
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' linebacker, may have been the best defensive player in the National Football League last season. But, he admits, he is not immortal.

title: ISRAEL TO FINANCE MORE SETTLEMENTS IN OCCUPIED LANDS
description: The Israeli Government, ignoring President Reagan's call for a freeze on Jewish settlements, allocated $18.5 million today to build three new settlements in the occupied West Bank and announced approval to build seven others.

title: GOVERNOR'S RACE IN ILLINOIS HEATS UP
description: The race to control the Illinois governorship for the next four years, a powerful position as the 1984 Presidential election approaches, heated up last week with the two candidates exchanging charges of telling falsehoods and doing nothing for the citizens.

title: CHANGING IMAGES OF LABOR IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Hubert Andrews has a hard, hot job. Mr. Andrews, 40 years old, married and the father of four children, works at furnaces and a huge die hammer at Nepco Forged Products, in Brooklyn. With a crew of three men, Mr. Andrews makes steel flanges, large steel rings and other steel products.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in SportsMonday last week misidentified a racing car in the Swiss Grand Prix. It was driven by Alain Prost.

title: Turks Register for Vote
description: Turks stayed at home today on orders from the Government to be registered for a referendum on the draft constitution due to be held before the end of the year. Some 500,000 officials took part in the countrywide count to register eligible voters over the age of 21. Officials said about 21 million people were expected to be registered.

title: Football Player Dies in Accident
description: One Portland State football player was killed and another injured early today in a motorcycle accident near the Portland Civic Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Polish Foreign Minister To Make a Soviet Visit

title: Susan Gail Smith and Steven Jay Linder Married
description: Susan Gail Smith and Steven Jay Linder, who are with the Internal Revenue Service in Washington, were married yesterday at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Louisville, Ky. Rabbi Simca Kling performed the ceremony assisted by Cantor Joseph Handlin of New York.

title: Dodgers 2, Pirates 1
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI) - Doug Frobel, playing in his first major league game, lost a fly ball in the sun with one out in the 10th inning, allowing Ron Roenicke to score the run that gave Los Angeles the victory.

title: BRIEFING
description: P.L.O. 'Action List'

title: G.D. Johnston 3d Weds Miss Dinse
description: Pamela Ruth Dinse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Dinse of Shelburne, Vt., was married there yesterday to G. Donald Johnston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and John's Island, Fla. The Rev. Charles Lawrence performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: ERITREAN SAYS REBELS AWAIT ETHIOPIAN BUILDUP
description: An Eritrean rebel leader says that Ethiopian troops in the troubled province are incapable of starting a new offensive and are playing for time until they can build up their forces there.

title: Report Cites Kickbacks In Sales of Pacemakers
description: A Federal investigation of the heart pacemaker industry has found questionable sales practices that may be costing the Government up to $200 million a year.

title: TV: 'THE INHERITANCE'
description: ''The Inheritance,'' on WNET, Channel 13, from 8 to 9 this evening, is a singularly appropriate presentation for Labor Day. Produced and directed by Harold Mayer, the film was commissioned by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. Lending the broadcast another fillip of interest, ''The Inheritance'' was made 18 years ago, in 1964, in conjunction with the union's 40th anniversary. It was shown on the BBC in 1965, and it has garnered a slew of awards over the years, but this will mark its debut on American television.

title: NASTASE PUTS OUT KRIEK
description: For the purists, John McEnroe's straight-set victory over Vince Van Patten in the third round was especially noteworthy. For the upsetminded, the defeats of Bettina Bunge, Chip Hooper and Fritz Buehning merited more than routine consideration.

title: ORIOLES TOP TWINS FOR 8TH IN ROW, 5-4
description: The Baltimore Orioles are on a tear. Since Aug. 20, when they were in third place in the American League Eastern Division, seven and one-half games behind the Milwaukee Brewers, the Orioles have been the best team in baseball, winning 15 of 16 games.

title: U.S. ACTS TO EASE DISPUTE ON RENT FOR PACIFIC ATOLL MISSILE TEST SITE
description: Washington has moved to defuse a 10-week-old dispute with the local landowners on Kwajalein atoll, the site of a billion-dollar United States testing range for intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: THE REAGANS' GIFT TO PRINCE WILLIAM
description: As the official gift from the nation to Prince William of Wales President and Mrs. Reagan have selected a handsome handcrafted reproduction of a Chippendale corner chair with needlepoint seat, scaled to child size.

title: Washington Watch; Economic Board's Role
description: WASHINGTON WHEN President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board meets at the White House Wednesday, it will have a new chairman, Walter B. Wriston, who is also chairman of Citicorp. Mr. Wriston succeeds George P. Shultz, the Secretary of State, who lost his eligibility to be a member of the advisory group when he left the Bechtel Corporation for Federal service.

title: Pan Am 'Mystery Passenger' Is Identified as a Florida Man
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation fingerprint experts have identified the ''mystery passenger'' of the Pan American jetliner that crashed near here on July 9, the authorities said today.

title: A CHAMPION IS A HUMAN
description: THE pains began early Saturday and became so bad by Saturday night that Chris Evert Lloyd called a doctor. By early yesterday, she was sick enough to know that there was one thing she didn't feel like doing, and that was going into the grandstand at the United States Open and playing a game of tennis.

title: Mary Ellen Pinto a Bride
description: The marriage of Mary Ellen Pinto, daughter of Mary Pinto of Woodridge, N.J., to James B. Slade, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard N. Slade of Floral Park, L.I., took place yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein and Cantor Shlomo Bar-Nissim performed the ceremony.

title: King of the Gumball
description: Clyde King, the Yankees' manager, was talking about some of the deceptive maneuvers he has executed in his athletic career and the subject of illegal pitches arose. King admitted to having thrown such a pitch once - a bubble-gum pitch.

title: TEXTS OF EXCHANGE OF LETTERS
description: Following are the texts of the exchange of letters between President Reagan and Mayor Elias Freij of Bethlehem as made public today by the White House: Mayor Freij's Letter

title: CHINA'S PARTY MAPS REVISIONS TO END MAO'S RADICAL LEGACY
description: China's Communist Party is undertaking a major reformation to erase the radical legacy of Mao Zedong and improve the caliber of its vast membership.

title: SIZE OF AID TO I.M.F. UNCERTAIN
description: Though the United States is prepared to contribute more money to the International Monetary Fund to help countries balance their international accounts, serious questions remain about the extent of this assistance, American officials said today.

title: THE SOVIET PIPELINE NEEDS NO HARD LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 100-Year March of Labor

title: NEW YORK STORE SALES UP BY 0.9%
description: Sales by New York City's largest retailers in August rose only nine-tenths of 1 percent from the year before, the smallest such gain in the last five months, according to a spot-check.

title: LEHRMAN AND CURRAN SPAR OVER ABORTION
description: Although opposed to abortion and the use of Medicaid funds to pay for it, Lewis E. Lehrman and Paul J. Curran, rivals for the Republican nomination for Governor, disagreed yesterday on a constitutional amendment to outlaw abortions.

title: OUTLOOK CALLED DIM FOR HYDRO POWER
description: Cold, clear water thundered through the gaps of a ledge behind John Downs, who owns a share in the property here. ''It's a tragedy,'' Mr. Downs said, bemoaning the fact that the water would not be used at any time soon to generate electricity.

title: Briefs on the Arts Discounts at Carnegie
description: Concertgoers 62 and older will be able to purchase discount tickets to Carnegie Hall beginning Oct. 3, the opening of the 1982-83 season.

title: Landaluce First
description: Landaluce, the unbeaten daughter of Seattle Slew, raced to a 6 1/2-length victory in the 32d running of the Del Mar Debutante Stakes for 2-year-old fillies today at Del Mar. Ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., Landaluce raced the mile in 1:35 3/5, just three-fifths of a second off the stakes record set by Table Hands.

title: WAGNER'S ALONZO PATTERSON A BIG GAINER
description: THE folks at Wagner College have something to sell, and they're doing it with a promotional brochure worthy of a Division I-A powerhouse rather than a Division III outpost atop Staten Island's green and tranquil Grymes Hill.

title: Three Persons Arrested In Anti-Busing March
description: Three persons were arrested by police here tonight in an anti-busing march, the second such demonstration of the day along busy Dixie Highway in suburban Valley Station.

title: Mrs. Truman 'Improved'
description: Bess Truman, who is suffering from an ulcer, was ''much improved'' today. Her doctor said the former First Lady might be released in two weeks if she continues to make progress, and her condition, earlier listed as serious, was called fair. Dr. Wallace Graham said his 97-year-old patient's bleeding ulcer had been controlled and her vital signs were strong.

title: HAVEN FOR MOTHERS OF AILING CHILDREN
description: It would not be out of place in any subdivision. It looks like the quintessential suburban house with brick and aluminum siding, its front walk lined with marigolds, petunias and violets, its roof shaded by tall oaks, its well-tended lawn bordered by smaller maples.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1982; International
description: Mexico announced broad monetary reforms, including the creation of a two-tier fixed exchange rate for the peso. Mortgage interest rates were lowered, while yields on savings accounts were raised fourfold. For most activities, including tourism, the new currency rate will be 70 pesos to the dollar. But for the financing of interest payments and key imports, it will be 50 to the dollar. The new rates take effect today, when the country's newly nationalized banks reopen for the first time in almost a week. (Page 3.)

title: Miss Koopman Becomes Bride Of Mark Freund
description: The marriage of Beatrice Fox Koopman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Koopman of West Hartford, Conn., to Mark Freund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gareth Freund of Los Angeles, took place yesterday. Rabbi Neil Kominsky, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Koopman home.

title: Keith Sebelius, Congressman From Kansas Until 1980, Dies
description: Keith Sebelius, a member of the House of Representatives from the western Kansas First District for 12 years, died today.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS TO COMMUTE BOSTON REPORTER'S SENTENCE
description: Gov. Edward J. King announced today that he would recommend commuting the 90-day sentence of a newspaper reporter who was jailed after refusing to testify about an interview with a murder suspect.

title: West Bank Town in Uproar
description: Disturbances continued for a third day in the Israeli-occupied West Bank town of Nablus today as Arab youths threw stones at Israeli soldiers and many merchants closed their shops to protest Friday's death of a 17-year-old Arab youth who was shot and killed by an Israeli soldier.

title: STREET FAIR FUN SPICED WITH POLITICS
description: ''Fran, look, it's all women!'' came the shout from the crowd. Indeed, they were - in blue T-shirts, blue hard hats and blue jeans - and they were building a frame house, complete with electricity and plumbing, in the middle of 42d Street.

title: Laurie Rachel Ryder Wed In Jersey to Peter E. Zahn
description: The marriage of Laurie Rachel Ryder and Peter Entin Zahn, alumni of the Rockland Country Day School and George Washington University, took place yesterday at the Palisadium in Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: Pakistani Judge Attacked
description: Two men on a motorcycle fired shots at the home of a High Court judge here today, killing a policeman on guard duty, authoritative sources said. The judge, Saeedur Rahman, was asleep when the two men attacked the house at about 4 A.M., the sources added. The attack appeared to be part of a campaign of violence against supporters of the military Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, they said.

title: YOSEMITE MAGISTRATE HAS FULL DOCKET
description: In the heart of Yosemite Valley, on a tree-lined meadow between the 2,400-foot Yosemite Falls and the winding Merced River, sits one of the nation's most unusual Federal courts.

title: Peter Edward Randall Marries Ruth Eddy Feuer
description: Ruth Eddy Feuer, daughter of Herbert J. Feuer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Helen Denny Feuer of New York, was married yesterday in Rye, N.Y., to Peter Edward Randall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Randall of Norwalk, Conn. The Quaker ceremony was performed at the Wainwright House, which is the headquarters of the Center for the Development of Human Resources.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dispelling Postal Perplexity

title: Bendix Counts Marietta Shares
description: The Bendix Corporation was ''still ascertaining'' the number of shares that had been tendered in its $1.5 billion bid for the Martin Marietta Corporation, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: MEXICO FIXES DUAL RATE FOR THE PESO
description: Mexico's Government has announced a series of drastic monetary reforms that will go into effect Monday when the country's newly nationalized banks reopen for the first time in nearly a week.

title: Danelle D. Hahn Married to Chef
description: Danelle Dorothy Hahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Hahn Jr., of Garden City and Centerport, L.I., was married yesterday to Bernd Rudiger Kensbock of Houston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno Kensbock of Nuremberg, West Germany. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at the St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NEW YORK TO CELEBRATE SCANDINAVIA
description: ''Scandinavia Today,'' a 15-month celebration honoring the cultural and intellectual life of the five modern Nordic nations of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden opens next Monday in New York City. Works of art from Scandinavian countries will be shown at major museums and institutions in the city, and dozens of programs of music, theater, dance, film and lectures are scheduled over the next few months.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FAR FROM THE CROWD

title: Barbara Shecter Wed
description: Barbara Gail Shecter, daughter of Lois Shecter of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Charles Shecter, was married yesterday to Yaakov Avitan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Masud Avitan of Beit Shean, Israel. Rabbi Joshua Hertzberg performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Friedberg, cousins of the bride, in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Shavers Retiring After a Victory
description: Earnie Shavers, the 38-year-old former heavyweight contender who twice fought for the championship, retired today after knocking out Chuck Gardner.

title: Phillies 4, Astros 3
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Mike Schmidt tied the score in the sixth with a two-run homer, and George Vukovich hit a home run on the next pitch to help Philadelphia complete a sweep of a three-game series.

title: Patricia Foisie Is Married To Matthew Bart Schiff
description: Patricia Abbie Foisie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Foisie of Tamalpais Valley, Calif., and Johannesburg, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Matthew Bart Schiff, son of Ivy Graber Schiff of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Lawrence Robert Schiff.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT SOCKERS
description: Jeff Durgan scored a goal with 52 seconds left tonight to give the Cosmos a 2-1 victory in the opening game of their semifinal playoff series against the San Diego Sockers.

title: Biscayne's Founder, 74, Is Retiring
description: E. Albert Pallot, who founded the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association in Miami 26 years ago, is retiring at the age of 74 at a time when he sees the thrift industry returning to financial health.

title: ANTI-UNIONISM'S GEAR: NOT BRASS KNUCKLES, BUT ATTACHE CASES
description: It is bad enough that unemployment is near 10 percent and that many of those who still have jobs are being pressed by their employers to give back wage hikes and other benefits under management threats to move plants to new locales or close them down altogether. But far more ominous is management's new attitude toward workers: Antiunionism is becoming respectable again. If allowed to continue, this trend will ferment violence and further disrupt the already crumbling economy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. has elected Keith S. Wellin vice chairman of the company and of the Dean Witter Financial Services Group. The company also announced the appointment of Charles A. Fiumefreddo as chairman, president and chief executive officer of Dean Witter Reynolds Intercapital.

title: CLEMSON IS TRYING TO MAKE LASTING IMPRESSION
description: kept secret 30 miles from the Georgia border. The campus is pretty, and Clemson students say, ''There is something here that will reach out and make you want to stay.'' But since the university takes its name from this little country town, it has always had a problem establishing an identity in the outside world.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Some taxpayers, particularly those in upperincome brackets, have been wondering whether they were short-changed in the 10 percent Federal income tax cut that took effect July 1.

title: MOYNIHAN MIXES POLITICS AND HISTORY ON BOAT TRIP
description: Wearing tennis shoes, gray flannel pants and a cotton blazer, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan boarded a 40-foot houseboat today for the second day of a leisurely journey of politics and history along the Erie Canal.

title: EXPECTANT FATHERS' SYMPTOMS
description: MORNING sickness, weight gain, backaches, food cravings. The s ymptoms appeared, only to disappear nine months later, when his wifeg ave birth. ''I was eating more to keep her company,'' he told the o thers in a class on parenthood at the 92nd Street Y. ''When she got s ick, I got sick. Empathy, I guess.''

title: JAPANESE GAINING IN U.S. GRAIN TRADE
description: Agrex Inc., operating out of a cramped office near the pit of the Board of Trade here, is a little-known company. One white-haired executive with more than 30 years' experience at the Board of Trade says he has never heard of it.

title: Salvador Prelate Reports Sharp Rise in Killings
description: Acting Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of San Salvador, condemning a sharp rise in the country's political violence, said today that the church recorded more than 200 killings last week.

title: Enterra President Quits Over Funds
description: Alan M. Rauch has resigned as president and a director of the Enterra Corporation, an oilfield service company in Radnor, Pa., after repaying $117,000 that the company said represented expenditures made at his direction that were not for business purposes.

title: AID UNCERTAINTIES SPUR ENROLLMENTS IN PUBLIC COLLEGES
description: As the New York metropolitan area's colleges open amid extraordinary last-minute confusion over financial aid, more and more students are abandoning plans to go away to private colleges and are turning to low-cost public colleges close to home, according to admissions officers and students.

title: SPEAKING OF THE BREAKUP OF 'THE TEAM'
description: It is time now to speak of the likelihood of changes on the Reagan team. For 18 months, President Reagan's men have enjoyed the political equivalent of a championship season. But it is hard to find anyone among them who thinks all the key players will remain at their old positions far into the second half of the term.

title: UTOPIAN COLONISTS REUNITED IN A PASSIONATE CELEBRATION OF ISMS
description: More than 200 people, spanning three generations, gathered in a shady picnic grove here today for a reunion to celebrate their one special bond - an anarchist colony that was founded 10 miles away almost 70 years ago.

title: No Headline
description: SIGEL, 38, CAPTURES U.S. AMATEUR GOLF

title: AS TIME GOES BY
description: After the death of Ingrid Bergman last week, most of the commentary centered on the change in mores in one generation. Thirty years ago, people became all uptight and selfrighteous when a celebrated woman left her husband and had a baby with her lover; today it would not be seen as ''that big of a deal.''

title: STRONG INSURGENT TESTS LEADER OF MINE WORKERS
description: Sam M. Church Jr., the president of the United Mine Workers, flew from coalfield to coalfield this Labor Day weekend, touting ''one-hundred-dollar day.''

title: STERILIZATION WITHOUT SURGERY HAS PROMISE
description: Patty Spiegel of Cedarhurst, L.I., became convinced a year ago that she should change her method of contraception. She was 39 years old, she had used the birth-control pill for six years, and she smoked heavily, a habit that the medical community says increases the risk of heart attack for longtime users of the pill.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Leontyne Price to Open Lincoln Center TV Series

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL WEIGH OPENING BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: Israeli officials conferred today with a United States official on the possible reopening of the Beirut airport and withdrawal of United States marines from Lebanon.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS EIGHT OF ITS SOLDIERS APPARENTLY CAPTURED BY SYRIANS
description: Eight Israeli soldiers were apparently captured Saturday at an observation post north of Bhamdun, Lebanon, the military command announced today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Hydro-Quebec will issue $50 million of foreign bonds maturing in 2015 and carrying a margin of 190 basis points above the 13 1/2 percent government stock maturing in 2008.

title: Big Questions, on Labor's Big Day
description: On Labor Day, politicians begin serious campaigning by saluting the working man. Yet the political clout that created this tradition of respect has waned; the labor movement may be at its lowest ebb since World War II. Unemployment aproaches 10 percent; protections that workers have long taken for granted are being challenged and inflation, though now abating, has eroded the wage gains of decades.

title: BRITISH STEEL: A COMPANY TRANSFORMED
description: Twenty-eight months after the British Steel Corporation reached outside the country and chose Ian MacGregor, a New York investment banker born in Scotland, to be its chairman, the company has been transformed.

title: Glider Manufacturer Is Killed
description: The owner of a company that makes gasoline-powered hang gliders died today when the wing on his craft failed and he crashed during a flight, the authorities said. The victim was identified as Germels Johnson, 27 years old, of Milpitas, Calif., head of the Bay Area Ultra-Light Flight Company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Joining in Prayer

title: POP: DAN HICKS REAPPEARS
description: Dan Hicks, the self-proclaimed ''father of folk-swing,'' enjoyed a vogue in the early 1970's but not much commercial success. After lying low in recent years, Mr. Hicks recently came out of semiretirement, and Friday and Saturday, the San Francisco singer, songwriter and guitarist appeared with his sidekick, Turtle Vandemar, the guitarist, at the Other End.

title: VALENTINE RETURNS WITH A HOMER AS METS WIN, 10-2
description: Ellis Valentine, the outspoken right-fielder, returned to the lineup yesterday after missing three games with an injured wrist. He quickly strengthened his position as to why the Mets should prevent him from testing the free-agent market after the season.

title: 2d Loss for U.S.  In World Baseball
description: The United States lost for the second time, and Japan, the Dominican Republic, Taiwan and South Korea advanced today in the world amateur baseball championship.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT ROYALS, 18-7
description: Who said the Yankees aren't in the pennant race? They were very much in Kansas City's pennant race this weekend, and now they head home to try to inject themselves into Baltimore's and Milwaukee's pennant race.

title: CASHEN SET FOR CLEANUP
description: FRANK CASHEN laughs when you remind him what he said last October when the Mets dismissed Joe Torre as manager: ''We want desperately to win, and the club simply decided to go in another direction.''

title: TO THOSE WHO READ BOOK DEDICATIONS
description: Years ago Arthur Hailey dedicated an original television play to his producer, but he had sworn off dedications by the time he began writing books. ''I don't believe in them,'' he said recently. ''I always told my wife that dedicating a book is like making love in public.''

title: Vineyard Race To Morning Star
description: J.P. Ambrose Jr.'s Morning Star, a 45-foot sloop from the Larchmont Yacht Club, won the Vineyard Trophy for best corrected time in the Stamford Y.C.'s 48th annual race that started Friday afternoon.

title: Poll of Drivers Shows Third Break Speed Law
description: Americans continue to overwhelmingly support the 55-mile-per-hour highway speed limit even though nearly a third of them admit to having been stopped for breaking the law, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: JACK TWORKOV, PAINTER AND ART TEACHER, DEAD
description: Jack Tworkov, a Polish-born American painter and teacher who was one of the most respected artists of the New York School, died Saturday in Provincetown, Mass. He was 82 years old.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Jeanne Moreau as Director And as Actress in Festival

title: Bridge:; The Lead That Cost a Title; Won't Fade From Memory
description: If one wished to compare an international bridge championship to a track race, the appropriate distance would be a mile rather than 100 yards. Two contestants may be close at the finish, but the judges will very seldom need to consult a photograph.

title: Man, 19, Killed With Shotgun At House Party in the Bronx
description: A 19-year-old Westchester County man was shot to death by an unidentified man who fired on him with a shotgun at a house party on City Island in the Bronx early Sunday, the police said.

title: U.S. GENERAL ACCLAIMS ISRAELIS
description: A retired United States general says he believes that the Israeli Army was at ''its professional best'' in Lebanon and that it tried hard to be ''discriminating and careful'' in civilian areas.

title: Cause Still Not Known In Blaze That Killed 19
description: A fire that killed 19 residents of an aging, overcrowded apartment building Saturday began in a space between floors.

title: Letter: On Protectionism No Canadian 'Squeeze' for U.S. Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Balance of Coinage

title: SOCIALISTS (GASP!) SPAWNED LABOR DAY
description: .8,2Now that Labor Day is 100 years old, the time has come to admit that this national holiday was spawned and hatched by socialists - a fact that Labor Day orators seldom see fit to mention.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States and Canadian stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Labor Day. Other markets around the world are open.

title: United Press International
description: For one who has been under the magnifying glass, Jackie Sherrill did not seem to be fazed by the upsetting first game as the new Texas A&M football coach Saturday night.

title: S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: A batter lunges for a wide pitch and steps on home plate as he drives the ball into the outfield for a single. What is the ruling? Does it change the ruling if he makes contact with the ball before he steps on the plate?

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Bountiful Fall at 'Y' With Music and Lectures

title: 'COOPERATIVE' CONTROL OF INDUSTRY WOULD AID WORKERS, BISHOPS SAY
description: Thirty Episcopal bishops from industrial and urban centers in the United States have issued a Labor Day pastoral letter calling for localized, cooperative control of the nation's industries and criticizing what they call ''the growing wave of anti-unionism'' in the nation today.

title: Horse About Town
description: Niatross, whom many harness-racing authorities and fans consider the greatest standardbred of all time, is a valuable piece of property. He proved that in 1979 and 1980, when he won 37 of 39 races and earned $2,019,213. That was a record and so was the $10 million syndicate put together in 1979 by Morton Finder and Lou Guida. Finder, the president of Pine Hollow Stud Farm Inc., now estimates Niatross's value at $30 million, based on the most recent sale of shares in the horse.

title: Let the Juries Speak
description: The jurors who acquitted Joseph Paul Franklin of shooting civil rights leader Vernon Jordan apparently were convinced that the accused fired the shots. But they were not persuaded, some of them said later, that the avowed racist's act violated Federal civil rights laws. Whether they were right or wrong, it was good to get this glimpse of their thinking. By speaking out last week, they dispelled doubt about whether the Justice Department had prosecuted the right person.

title: Officials at Attica Continue Lockup
description: Officials at the state correctional facility at Attica, N.Y., kept all 2,138 inmates locked in their cells for a second day yesterday and uncovered a variety of homemade weapons in a search as prison activities remained curtailed in the wake of a Friday night recreation-yard melee in which three prisoners were stabbed.

title: IT'S TIME TO EXPLORE INDUSTRIAL POLICIES THAT AID COMMUNITIES
description: Labor Day finds working people around the world facing severe economic upheaval. Not since the Industrial Revolution has the place and role of work undergone such revision and dislocation. The internationalization of investments and production, combined with new technologies, places the economic future of millions of families and hundreds of local communities in jeopardy. Even with an improvement in business conditions, millions of workers in the United States will never return to former jobs because those jobs have disappeared or have been transferred thousands of miles away. All this comes on top of the plight of a permanent underclass of people who have never worked - an underclass in which minorities are tragically overrepresented.

title: KEMPER CHIEF STRESSES VALUE OF A GOOD OFFENSE
description: Joseph E. Luecke, the 55-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Kemper Group, is finding that the best defense is a good offense. Last week, Kemper - a holding company based in Chicago with interests in insurance and financial services - acquired 80 percent of Prescott, Ball & Turben, a Cleveland securities firm, for $64 million. It was Kemper's third acquisition of a regional brokerage firm this year. Earlier it bought the Loewi Financial Companies of Milwaukee and Bateman Eichler Hill Richards Inc. of Los Angeles.

title: Washington's National To Be Closed a Full Year
description: The National Theater, where Helen Hayes saw her first play when she was 5 years old, will remain closed until next September, the theater's board of directors has voted.

title: ORAFLEX'S DUBIOUS DISTINCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline S. Lackman Is the Bride of Uriel P. Bauer
description: Caroline Susan Lackman, daughter of Anne Berry Lackman of Bedford, N.Y., and Harold Lackman of Silver Springs, Md., was married yesterday to Uriel Philip Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bauer of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Yale Fund Drive Sets a Record
description: Yale University's Alumni Fund has set a record by collecting $16,420,748 since July 1, 1981, more than it has collected in any year in its 92-year history, officials said.

title: AGE OF AQUARIUS MEETS AGE OF THE MICROCHIP
description: If Woodstock was the hallmark of the Age of Aquarius, the Us Festival will mark the age of the microchip. About 200,000 people were drawn here this weekend to a parched pocket in the mountains near San Bernadino for a three-day festival of nearly continuous electronic music and a desert bazaar of video games and home computers.

title: FRIENDS OF JOSE MARTI
description: To the Editor:

title: Weaver to Serve as a Scout
description: The Baltimore Orioles announced today that Earl Weaver, who retires at the end of the season after 14 1/2 years as manager, would remain with the organization for the next two years as a special consultant.

title: A-Plant Gas Leak Termed Accidental
description: Federal and utility officials investigating the release of a small amount of radioactive gas on Friday from the Salem I nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey now say they believe that the leak was accidental and not the result of tampering.

title: SIR DOUGLAS BADER, WORLD WAR II ACE
description: Sir Douglas Bader, Britain's legendary legless fighter pilot of World War II, died early today. He was 72 years old.

title: COMPUTERS: NO MORE A 'WOMEN'S WORLD' THAN ANY OTHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Leftists Return 2 Areas Won in Lebanese War
description: Leftist guerrillas today turned over two key Beirut strongholds won in the 1975-76 civil war to the Lebanese Army and police.

title: 4 ARAB CHIEFS SAID TO DISCUSS REAGAN'S MIDEAST PEACE PLAN
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and the Kings of Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Morocco met privately today to discuss President Reagan's Middle East plan and a possible joint Arab peace proposal, Arab League sources said.

title: American Fiat Names Chief
description: Antonio D'Emilio has been named president and chief executive officer of Fiat Motors of North America Inc., the company has announced.

title: MARYLAND GROUP CHALLENGES CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL EFFORT
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee has begun airing its latest round of television advertisements aimed at unseating Senator Paul S. Sarbanes.

title: DOWN THE MIDDLE
description: The wisdom of President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative, and its shrewdness, have been made clear by its immediate effects. It has redefined the fundamental political choices for Israel and Israelis. It has appealed to the realism of moderate Arabs. It has set the agenda for peace.

title: ARMY CHIEF'S OFFER TO RESIGN MUDDIES OUTLOOK IN PANAMA
description: The powerful head of Panama's national guard, Brig. Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes, unexpectedly offered to step down from his post Sunday, although it was still unclear whether his resignation would be accepted by President Ricardo de la Espriella.

title: The Latest Devil in Massachusetts
description: Nearly 300 years ago, 19 women and men were executed in Salem, Massachusetts for witchcraft. The evidence against them came from seven females, all under 20 and several of them children, who had spasms, visions, inexplicable bite marks and bad dreams. Contemporary chronicles referred to them as ''the afflicted.''

title: AREA'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a settlement of the Israeli-Arab dispute must include establishment of ''a totally demilitarized area'' covering all of the West Bank if that area is to become an autonomous Palestinian homeland associated with Jordan.

title: The Wilson Brothers
description: The Mets are hoping their farm system is about to produce another player like Mookie Wilson. If family traits have anything to do with it, it will. Playing this season in the outfield at the Mets' Little Falls, N.Y., Class A farm in the New York-Penn League was John Wilson, the 20-year-old brother of the Mets' outfielder. When his season ended Wednesdy, he finished with a .302 batting average, 33 runs batted in and 19 stolen bases in 28 attempts.

title: G.I.'s Phrases Stilted, U.N. Korea Office Says
description: The United Nations Command said today that statements attributed by North Korea to an American soldier quoted as having said he defected ''must be considered suspect.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Conservation in the Kitchen

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. In what seems their last chance to make a move upward, the Yankees begin a 14-day stretch in which they play Baltimore and the Milwaukee Brewers seven times each.

title: U.S. Defeated, 1-0, In Youth Soccer
description: The United States National Youth soccer team lost, 1-0, to Honduras in double overtime today in the finals of regional qualifying for next year's world championships.

title: Dialogue With A Gag
description: While the police were showering people with water cannon and perfuming them with thousands of canisters of tear gas because they stood on the streets of Warsaw last week, an international gathering of scientists was drawing up another big appeal against nuclear weapons.

title: Market Place; Why the Jump In Manville?
description: HERE'S a Wall Street mystery story. Why did the shares of the deeply troubled Manville Corporation soar last Thursday? Was it because a regional broker praised the shares or because Drexel Burnham bought Manville heavily after its Chapter 11 filing?

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan Moves on Abortion

title: Bulgarian Trawler Is Seized
description: A Bulgarian trawler was seized by the Coast Guard today for catching more fish than allowed within the 200-mile fisheries management zone.

title: Keep Talking, Senators
description: This week the Senate must choose between talking about abortions and school prayers and doing something about them. We favor talk. The proposal on the floor so disfigures the law, the Constitution and individual liberties that still more wind from Capitol Hill is preferable by far.

title: 10 CONVICTS FLEE QUEENS FACILITY BY USING TIED-TOGETHER BEDSHEESTS
description: At least ten state convicts who were being held for parole violations escaped from a state detention center in Queens late last night, according to the police and state authorities.

title: Talks on Credit At Wienerwald
description: Wienerwald, the West German subsidiary of the Swiss-based Wienerwald Holding, has disclosed that it has opened credit talks with Bayerische Landesbank after seeking reorganization proceedings six days ago.

title: THE BIOLOGY OF FEAR AND ANXIETY: EVIDENCE POINTS TO CHEMICAL TRIGGERS
description: INJECTIONS of a synthetic substance made for studies of the chemistry of human emotion have produced severe anxiety in monkeys within seconds. The animals became agitated, their hair rose, they squirmed and they displayed other outward signs of extreme alarm. These effects could be quickly halted by other chemicals.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The Milky Way is formed by the stars of our own galaxy and it seems these stars should be closest to Earth. Why is the Milky Way a pale streak in the night sky instead of a bright band of sparkling light?

title: Marsha A. Cohan and Alan Leslie Fischl Married
description: Marsha Ann Cohan and Alan Leslie Fischl, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Robert Aronowitz of Fair Lawn, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Fire Survivors Are Critical
description: Five survivors of an apartment house fire here Saturday remained in critical condition today, and the authorities were trying to identify some of the 19 people who died in the blaze. The cause of the fire, which swept through the four-story Dorothy Mae apartment hotel, has not been determined.

title: Percy Says That He Supports Reagan's Mideast Initiative
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, gave his full backing today to President Reagan's proposals on the Middle East.

title: Access: A Storybook Catalogue
description: SEE Linda (in her $70 Ora Feder teddy) bound out of bed for her 6 A.M. jog (in her $63 Sweats bi Chego). See Linda prepare breakfast (with her $80 Braun coffeemaker) and leave for the office (dressed for success in a $220 Liz Claiborne suit). See Linda relax (on a $349 Einstein Moomjy rug) with husband, Bob, and friends, Andrea and Neil, and listen to music (from a $150 Casio mini keyboard).

title: Farewell for Stargell
description: President Reagan called him ''one of the great ones,'' and thousands of Pirate fans roared their approval as Willie Stargell saw his uniform No.8 retired in a ceremony at Three Rivers Stadium today.

title: Rival Klan Factions Vote To Merge as One Group
description: Rival Ku Klux Klan factions from eight states and Canada agreed today to unite under one organization, the Confederation of Klans, which its new leader said would have 60,000 members, or 80 percent of Klan members nationwide.

title: KATHERINE M'C. ELLIS
description: Katherine McClintock Ellis, who had been in charge of the precollege division at the Juilliard School of Music in New York, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Needham, Mass.

title: COKE BRIGHTENS OUTLOOK FOR SSC&B PRESIDENT
description: Recession or no recession, Malcolm D. MacDougall, 53, the president of SSC&B/Lintas Worldwide, says his cup is running over after 12 months in the job.

title: Chess: A Galloping Grandmaster Takes a Very Harmful Fall
description: When you're riding high, it's a good idea to make sure that you haven't lost touch with the saddle. The enthusiasm generated by a brace of victories over formidable rivals can easily slip the bit and lead to a damaging fall.

title: POLITICIANS OPEN FALL DRIVE AT LABOR DAY PARADE
description: Preceded by a a contingent of actors chanting ''Shame on Koch'' and followed by a horn-tooting van festooned with ''Cuomo for Governor'' posters, Mayor Koch marched cheerily up Fifth Avenue in the Labor Day Parade yesterday.

title: CAROL BAUM JARRETT
description: Carol Baum Jarrett, a former director of admissions for St. Ann's School, a private preparatory school in Brooklyn Heights, died of cancer yesterday at Vineyard Haven Hospital, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where she was vacationing.

title: PLANNERS ON ENERGY THRIVING
description: For the Masonite Corporation, the huge cost of its energy bill each month brought with it an urge to conserve. But, like many companies trying to cut such costs, the nation's No.1 maker of hardboard found it had to bring in outside help.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States and Canadian stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. Other markets around the world were open.

title: Empire Oil Petition
description: The Empire Oil and Gas Company has announced that it has filed a Chapter 11 petition for protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: BRINGING UP BABY IN A LOOKOUT TOWER
description: It is a view of the world few children grow up with: Snow-mottled peaks stretch to the horizon in all directions, while below the silver ribbon of the north fork of the Flathead River flows south, out of sight.

title: AVANTE-GARDE: TRIO POWER
description: THE Linda Hudes Power Trio faced a problem Sunday evening as part of ''Art on the Beach'' on the Battery Park Landfill. The setting, with the buildings of lower Manhattan on one side and the Hudson River on the other, nearly always distracted from the music.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1982
description: International A decision to increase lending by the leading industrial countries to nations with acute debt problems was praised by Jacques de Larosiere, the top official of the International Monetary Fund. But, in opening the fund's annual meeting, he urged a speedy implementation of the program to ''assure the stability of the international financial system.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) An Arab League conference opened in Fez, Morocco. The Arab leaders are expected to focus on the plight of the Palestinians after their military rout by the Israelis in Lebanon. (A1:3.)

title: LEADING PRO-ISRAELI LOBBYIST SEES 'A LOT OF VALUE' IN REAGAN'S PLAN
description: The director of a leading pro-Israeli lobbying organization in Washington said today there was ''a lot of value'' in President Reagan's Middle East initiative.

title: INJURIES INFLUENCE CUTS BY JETS
description: The Jets dropped 10 players today to reach the roster limit of 49, and three of the 10 were veterans: Kenny Lewis, a running back; Steve Stephens, a tight end, and Al Washington, a linebacker. The final sorting-out process left eight newcomers on the squad, including the first and third-round draft choices, Bob Crable and Dwayne Crutchfield.

title: SOCIAL SCIENTISTS BELIEVE LEADERS LACK A SENSE OF WAR'S REALITY
description: One expert on international affairs has an unorthodox proposal to slow the hand of any President who might be tempted to unleash a nuclear attack. It has long been feared that a President could be making his fateful decision while at a ''psychological distance'' from the victims of a nuclear barrage; that he would be in a clean, air-conditioned room, surrounded by well-scrubbed aides, all talking in abstract terms about appropriate military responses in an international crisis, and that he might well push to the back of his mind the realization that hundreds of millions of people would be exterminated.

title: FLORIDA BABY BORN WITH A BULLET IN THE BRAIN IS THRIVING INFANT
description: Three months after he was born with a bullet in his brain, Daniel Ennis Whiteside has not only survived, but thrived.

title: NEW YORKERS FLOCK HOME ON A FINE SUMMER'S DAY
description: With many sighs of regret and not a few ouches from sunburns, New Yorkers came pouring back into the city yesterday as the Labor Day weekend, the unofficial end of summer, drew to a close.

title: News Analysis
description: Government officials and bankers attending meetings of the International Monetary Fund here fully recognize that the world financial system has been undergoing the greatest peril of the postwar period, but say they feel that the danger of a collapse has now been warded off. The apparent success of the United States and the International Monetary Fund in assembling rescue programs that have involved private banks as well as public institutions has encouraged the belief here that similar rescues would be conducted to prevent defaults by other debt-laden countries.

title: PRAVDA CRITICIZES REAGAN ON MIDEAST
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda criticized President Reagan's Middle East proposals today, describing Israeli rejection of the plan as a charade intended to win it adherents among the Arabs.

title: United Technologies Calls on Haig Again
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Secretary of State, has been rehired by his old employer, albeit on a part-time basis. The United Technologies Corporation, one of the nation's biggest industrial concerns, announced yesterday that Mr. Haig, who stepped down as Secretary of State late in June, would act as a consultant and chairman of a soon-to-be-formed International Advisory Committee that will counsel the company on global business policies.

title: NEW DEBT PLNAS SET BY MEXICO
description: Mexico has decided to suspend all principal payments on its huge foreign debt until the end of next year, but will use its oil revenues to keep up interest payments falling due over the next 17 months.

title: Paris Bomb Disposal Expert Dies of Injuries From Blast
description: A police officer who lost his arms and legs in the explosion of a terrorist bomb two weeks ago died early today in his hospital room, police sources said.

title: A 'BRIDGE' GOES WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE APPROVE A PARTY CHARTER
description: China's 12th Communist Party Congress approved a new constitution today that eliminates previous glowing references to Mao Zedong and makes provision for honorable retirement of overage officials.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Taking Taxes Personally

title: HALLMARKS OF A KENTUCKY GENTLEMAN
description: The Congressional negotiators on a key spending bill were bogged down. The House conferees blamed the Senators for failing to consult them in drafting the bill. The Senate conferees countered that the House members had gone off on early summer vacations.

title: U.S. Wins, 14-4,
description: The United States defeated Australia, 14-4, today for its first victory in the 27th World Amateur baseball championship.

title: CROFTER'S LAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia Wins; Walker Plays
description: Buoyed by the presence of Herschel Walker in the lineup - against the expressed wishes of his doctor - Georgia survived a shaky start by John Lastinger, its junior quarterback, and beat Clemson, 13-7, tonight before a sellout crowd of 82,122 in Sanford Stadium.

title: Mrs. Carner Wins by 6
description: JoAnne Carner, with six birdies in the last eight holes, shot a five-under-par 67 today to win her third consecutive tournament, a six-stroke triumph in the Rail Charity Golf Classic.

title: Coe Takes Heat In 800-Meter Run
description: Sebastian Coe scored an easy victory in his first-round heat of the 800-meter run on the opening day of the European track and field championships today.

title: South Africa Gets A Kissinger Warning
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned South Africa today that the world would not wait forever for it to change its racial practices.

title: Election Set Today For Jersey Senate
description: Voters in Atlantic County go to the polls Tuesday for a special State Senate election.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE the American fashion world is hoping that its new fall clothesw ill set the world of style on fire, or, at the very least, burn a h ole in the consumer's pocket, London continues to move at its own r ate of idiosyncratic development. Now the city that sent punks, new w avers and pirates to our benighted shore has come up with something a lmost new.

title: Pope Sees Spanish Clerics Over Delaying Trip
description: Pope John Paul II met today with leading Spanish church officials to discuss a possible postponement of his October visit to Spain to avoid interfering with Spanish elections.

title: NUTRITION PROFESSOR IS FOUND SLAIN AMID FOOD AT FLORIDA APARTMENT
description: A popular professor of nutrition at the University of Florida was suffocated by killers who ate a ritual meal in his apartment, the police said Monday.

title: WILLIAM STAVELY WILSON
description: William Stavely Wilson, a former senior vice president of Janney, Montgomery & Scott, stockbrokers, died Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., after a long illness.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The Federal Reserve Board has passed another hurdle in its battle against inflation and its struggle for credibility.

title: A POET IN PERIL
description: Like the Haitians and Ethiopians, the South African poet Dennis Brutus is a victim of the Administration's curious immigration policy toward black political refugees. By default and by explicit actions, the Administration has created a climate in which black people seeking a haven from political oppression have difficulty getting a fair hearing from those who formulate and execute American immigration policy.

title: No Headline
description: CARDINALS BLANK EXPOS

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 5,200 Weeks of Light

title: LABOR INTENSIFIES 1982 CAMPAIGNING
description: Organized labor, battling to regain political influence, has sharply increased its contributions to House and Senate candidates at a time when donations from corporations have been growing only modestly.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS FAVORED BY 50 PERCENT IN U.S.
description: THE American people, according to a Gallup Poll, have reaffirmed their overriding belief in the importance of education. But nearly half of them would prefer to send their children to private schools, if money were no object.

title: Susan Eckstein Wed To Dr. R.N. Perelman
description: Susan Nina Eckstein, daughter of Mrs. H. Philip Eckstein of Massapequa, L.I., and the late Mr. Eckstein, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Nathan Perelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Perelman of Union, N.J. Rabbi Sanford Jarashow performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Cantor Robert Applestone assisted.

title: TAIWAN DEVELOPING HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: New brick buildings are sprouting up all over one corner of a 5,200-acre field here, 40 miles southwest of Taipei. Workmen are marching in every direction through half-finished offices and apartments. The smell of mortar and plaster is heavy in the air. The sound of hammers, it seems, can be heard down every hallway.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8:20 P.M. The Orioles, the best team in baseball since late in August, send Mike Flanagan to the mound in their pursuit of the first-place Milwaukee Brewers.

title: ITALY GIVES WIDE POWERS TO ANTI-MAFIA CHIEF
description: The official charged with leading the fight against the Mafia was given sweeping new powers today as he took over from his slain predecessor.

title: JAMES A. HUGHES
description: James A. Hughes, former professor of English at New York City Community College in Brooklyn, now New York City Technical College, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: Regan Asks Pipeline Solution
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the United States would welcome proposals by its European allies to settle the dispute over the Siberian natural gas pipeline.

title: Paying for the Asbestos Tragedy
