description: The Manville Corporation's bankruptcy filing draws renewed attention to one of the worst industrial health tragedies in history. From now until the end of the century, there will be an estimated 8,500 to 10,000 deaths a year from asbestos-caused disease. That is the price of having allowed 27.5 million workers to be exposed to asbestos over the last 40 years. The immediate issue is what can be done to aid the victims and their families. Relevant to that is the question of who was responsible.

title: MR. JUSTICE, MR. POLITICS
description: In today's nothing-sacred, ''Mommie Dearest'' era, deceased personalities are increasingly being debunked. History-juggling sensationalists profitably huckster ''revelations'' about alleged indiscretions, improprieties and villainy of public figures unable to answer from the grave.

title: Poll Says Public Wants More Money for Schools
description: The American people want more money but less interference by the Federal Government in school operations, according to the 14th annual Gallup Poll on attitudes toward public schools.

title: Avellini Has Edge
description: Bob Avellini appears to have a slight edge over Vince Evans in the Chicago quarterback derby to determine the starter for the Bears' game Sunday against the Detroit Lions. Jim McMahon, the rookie from Brigham Young, had a poor showing in the exhibition last Sunday against the Baltimore Colts.

title: NURSING HOME CLOSED BY STATE IS UNDER STUDY
description: New York State's Medicaid fraud control unit is conducting a criminal investigation of a Staten Island nursing home that figured prominently in New York's nursing-home scandals and helped lead to the unit's creation in 1975.

title: Thomson-Brandt Sale
description: State-owned Thomson-Brandt S.A. has agreed to sell 56.4 percent, or 390,000 shares, of Cie.

title: DESEGREGATION PLANS IN PERIL
description: The Federal Government has sharply reduced the amount of money available to finance the desegregation of public schools in many big cities this year.

title: Bridge: Opponents' Bid Has Effect Of Negating a Convention
description: Many inexperienced players do not comprehend that most artificial conventions disappear in the face of enemy action. An obvious example is Stayman: Two clubs in response to one no-trump becomes natural if there has been an intervening double.

title: DISMISSAL OF A RAPE CASE: THE PROSECUTION'S FINEST HOUR
description: To the Editor:

title: Olin's Chlorine Price Up
description: The Olin Corporation has announced that it is increasing its off-list prices of chlorine by $30 a ton, effective immediately for spot customers and according to terms for contract customers.

title: NEW YORK HOPES TO SET A RECORD FOR APPLE CROP
description: A record crop of apples in New York State was predicted today on the eve of the annual harvest of McIntoshes, the state's leading apple.

title: ENROLLMENT DROP GROWING THREAT TO PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: AN aging population, in which a declining proportion of adults have children enrolled in the public schools, poses a growing problem for public education. The demographic statistics could have dire consequences for the public schools during the 1980's as they seek support for bond issues and budgets, as well as for programs generally.

title: BENDIX BID DRAWS 58% OF MARIETTA
description: The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that about 58 percent of the outstanding shares of the Martin Marietta Corporation had been tendered to Bendix, well more than were sought under its $1.5 billion takeover bid.

title: 'WIN ONE FOR THE DUCK'
description: E arly this season the Baltimore Orioles were clacking through the runway to their clubhouse after a victory, when the second baseman Rich Dauer spoke up.

title: POLISH REBELS SEIZE EMBASSY IN BERN
description: Armed men claiming to belong to a Polish resistance group seized Poland's embassy here today and threatened to blow it up if the Warsaw Government did not lift martial law.

title: PRIMAL THERAPY ON THE MOUND
description: P erhaps it is their proximity to the batter that makes some pitchers behave strangely, giving them the same threatening feeling someone gets when sitting in the first row in the movie theater when a horror film is playing. Batters do appear ghoulish when seen up close, waving 36 ounces of wood and staring menacingly.

title: TOP-EXECUTIVE PAY RISES LAG
description: Pay rises for top executives in American corporations slipped to 13 percent in l98l from the 1980 average of 14 percent because of lower inflation and declining profits, according to an annual study of about 16,500 executives released yesterday.

title: Hobbies Corp.  In Chapter 11
description: The General Hobbies Corporation of Philadelphia has announced that it, and its subsidiary, Associated Hobby Manufacturers Inc., have filed petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Warwick's Ace Exactly To the Point
description: E very sport, be it team or individual, claims its version of what is most popularly called the ''in-your-face'' play. It comprises three elements. It must be quick and to the point. It must also have impact. A dunk in basketball or baseball's home run fulfill both requirements here. And the true in-your-face move must also be welltimed - a game-winner or game-breaker.

title: Today's Featured Matches; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Guillermo Vilas-Steve Denton. Second Match - Martina Navratilova-Pam Shriver. Third Match - Tracy Austin-Hana Mandlikova.

title: C.D'S SEEN LURING INVESTORS
description: Amid many predictions of declining interest rates and with yields down sharply on short-term investments in money market mutual funds and new six-month savings certificates, investors are looking around for higher yielding but safe investments.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Perils of Kindergarten

title: Labor Pioneer Praised; Reagan Policy Assailed
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., termed the Reagan Administration insensitive to workers today in a Labor Day speech at the unveiling of a statue of Samuel Gompers, a pioneer of the American labor movement.

title: GOLD AT 15-MONTH HIGH; DOLLAR GAINS STRENGTH
description: Individual investors joined the rush for gold on Europe's bullion markets today, dealers said, and the price soared to a 15-month high.

title: Den Herder Returns
description: Quite a few top-name players fell victim to the final cuts, but at least one veteran made his return yesterday as National Football League teams set their rosters at 49 men. Vern Den Herder, a defensive end, is rejoining the Miami Dolphins after retiring at the end of last season. Den Herder, 33 years old, played 11 seasons with Miami. Among the prominent casualties were two Buffalo Bills, Mike Kadish, a nose tackle, and Lemar Parrish, a defensive back. Kadish, a 10-year veteran and the backup to all-pro Fred Smerlas, was the second player representative cut recently. Earlier, the New Orleans Saints released Benny Ricardo, their place-kicker, a move that angered Ed Garvey, executive director of the players association. Garvey suggested that teams were penalizing representatives. But Coach Chuck Knox said that cutting Kadish was ''based on going with a younger player.'' Parrish, a 13-year player, came to Buffalo from the Washington Redskins in the offseason. ... Surprising cuts were made by the Philadelphia Eagles, who placed Wally Henry and Rodney Parker, wide receivers, on waivers. And Rich Caster, a veteran receiver and a former Jet, was waived by Washington. ... The Raiders made another notable cut when they dropped Mark van Eeghen, the leading rusher in the history of the franchise, which moved this year from Oakland to Los Angeles. Van Eeghen, out of Colgate, had been with the Raiders since 1974, but in 1980, he started only three games after 107 consecutive starts.

title: FIFTH AVENUE MARCHERS CELEBRATE LABOR AND DEMAND WORK FOR ALL
description: Labor marched through a canyon of commerce yesterday - wave upon wave beneath unfurled union banners and a startlingly blue sky - celebrating solidarity and demanding full employment.

title: U.S HOLDS EDGE IN PIPELINE TECHNOLOGY
description: ALL the controversy over the shipment of pipeline technology to the Soviet Union has focused worldwide attention on American equipment for pumping natural gas hundreds and thousands of miles from wellhead to market and on the nature of its design.

title: Japanese Cite Gains in U.S.
description: More than 70 percent of the Japanese manufacturing companies operating in the United States have reported doing brisk business despite the recession, a semiofficial trade promoting agency has disclosed.

title: ELEANOR SHERMAN FONT
description: Eleanor Sherman Font, a former curator of the Hispanic Society of America, died Friday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I., after a long illness. She was 86 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: N.F.L. Brothers
description: Once, Richard Baldinger picked up the family television set and threw it at his older brother, Brian. The sibling rivalry will continue in the National Football League this season now that the Baldinger brothers of Massapequa, L.I., have survived yesterday's final roster cuts.

title: LEFTISTS IN BRITISH UNION GROUP SUFFER SETBACK
description: Delegates to the annual conference of the Trades Union Congress voted today to give some of the smaller unions the right to select their own representatives on the labor movement's general council.

title: TALKING THROUGH THE I/O PORTS
description: THERE is no logical reason for it, but the first time I came across ''I/O'' in computerese, I thought of portholes. I'm sure Freud (actually I'd prefer Jung) could have made a great deal of my seaborne image. Whatever the case, electronically, portholes almost make sense. In fact, I/O is more specifically referred to as the ''I/O port,'' or the ''input/output port.''

title: Michael M. Skodnick, 73, Dies; Former Criminal COurt Judge
description: Michael M. Skodnick, former judge of Criminal Court, died Sunday at Presbyterian Hospital.

title: LEBANESE MOSLEMS OFFER PRESIDENT-ELECT A GESTURE
description: A group of Lebanese Moslem leaders indicated for the first time today that they were willing to open political contacts with President-elect Bashir Gemayel, a Maronite Christian whose election they opposed.

title: Business and the Law; Asbestos Suits Divide Insurers
description: THE insurance industry has been split into two warring camps by the flood of asbestos-related lawsuits that led the Manville Corporation and UNR Industries Inc. to file for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Southern 500 To Yarborough
description: Cale Yarborough held off a late charge by Richard Petty today and won the Southern 500 Grand National stock-car race for the fifth time, a record.

title: PURCHASERS SEE WORSE QUARTER
description: The third quarter will be worse than the second quarter for most businesses, according a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Kotar in Private Room
description: Doug Kotar, the Giants' retired running back who is hospitalized with an inoperable malignant brain tumor, has been moved from intensive care to a private room in the College Hospital of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark. Hospital officials said Kotar remained in guarded condition.

title: Israeli Soldiers Hurt in Blast
description: Six Israeli soldiers were injured when their truck blew up near Tyre in southern Lebanon, the Israeli radio said today. The radio said a smoke bomb carried by one of the soldiers in the truck blew up, causing hand grenades and other arms to explode.

title: MARCOS SEEKS TALKS ON FUTURE OF 2 U.S. BASES IN PHILIPPINES
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said here today that he would like to discuss with President Reagan the defense strategies for Asia and for the Philippines with a view to reassessing the usefulness of American military bases in this country.

title: Czyz Could Move Up
description: Bobby Czyz will finally fight an opponent ranked in the top 10 if he gets past Norberto Sabater in a 10-round fight Sept. 25 at the Americana Great Gorge Hotel in McAfee, N.J. Czyz, the undefeated middleweight from Wanaque, N.J., who is billed as ''boxing's matinee idol,'' will be testing his left shoulder, recently injured, against Sabater in a bout to be televised by the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network cable company. If he wins, said Dan Duva, the promoter, Czyz would be matched with the undefeated Bernard (Superbad) Mays.

title: Boycott of Busch Beers Sought by Jesse Jackson
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is urging blacks to boycott Anheuser-Busch beers until the brewer agrees to help increase the number of minority distributorships in the industry.

title: The Editorial Notebook; What the Asbestos Industry Knew
description: Documents brought to light in litigation bear on the question of what the asbestos industry knew about the health hazards of its product. Whether or not they prove legal culpability is a matter for courts to determine. Yet despite the danger of making judgments in hindsight, they raise disturbing ethical questions. They suggest that even in the 1930's the industry's leaders were more concerned with minimizing discussion and countering claims than with exploring the real extent of the hazard.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Abusing Science: The Case Against Creationism By Philip Kitcher. 213 pages. The M.I.T. Press. $15.00. Remember when Clarence Darrow, or perhaps Spencer Tracy playing Clarence Darrow, walked out of that hot Tennessee courtroom after winning the big one for John T. Scopes, scientific reason, and the theory that man evolved from lower life forms?

title: ORIOLES DEFEAT YANKEES
description: The Baltimore Orioles recorded their ninth straight victory yesterday when Scott McGregor, who had not won in almost six weeks, beat the Yankees, 8-2, while holding them to two hits in five and two-thirds shutout innings.

title: U.S. ECONOMIC SUCCESS IS A SINGULAR CHALLENGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodities; Factors Depressing Lumber
description: THE ''for sale'' signs on many houses are only one reminder of the sad state of the housing market - and the lumber industry. Lumber prices reached some contract lows in recent weeks on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: CAVEATS FOR OUR CITIZEN CRIMEFIGHTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JANET GAYNOR AND MARY MARTIN HURT IN CRASH
description: Mary Martin and Janet Gaynor, two of the most famous actresses of their time, were seriously hurt Sunday night in an automobile accident that killed Miss Martin's personal manager and companion.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Finding Happiness At the City Ballet
description: Christopher d'Amboise has written a book about the experiences of a young man leaving high school and finding happiness as a dancer at the New York City Ballet. ''Leap Year'' will be published by Doubleday in November.

title: FOR A TRIBE IN CONNECTICUT, ONE TOO MANY CHIEFS
description: Many were the misfortunes of the Schaghticoke Indians. In 1756, the tribe asked the Colony of Connecticut to appoint a white overseer, and the one they received, Abraham Fuller, rented or sold 4,000 acres of their land to pay his medical bills. A few years later, a merchant from nearby New Milford tried to kidnap a tribesman's three children as collateral on a debt. And as recently as the 1950's, the state sought to discourage settlement on the reservation here by bulldozing or burning the homes of elders after they died.

title: Carrion Bees
description: An entomologist at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama has discovered a strain of bee that does not gather pollen from flowers. Instead, it obtains its needed protein solely by ingesting the flesh of dead animals, including lizards, monkeys, snakes, fishes and birds.

title: State Fair Near A Record Turnout
description: The New York State Fair, with expanded exhibits, newly refurbished grandstands and other improvements, appeared headed for a record attendance as its 10-day run drew to a close today.

title: 5TH AVE. TO GET BUS LANE ALONG MIDTOWN STRETCH
description: After a long debate about how to ease traffic congestion on Fifth Avenue, the city and the Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday that they had reached agreement on setting up a bus lane.

title: Spain's Twin Pandas Are Expected to Live
description: Shao Shao the panda and her twin cubs are progressing very well, and all are expected to survive, the technical director of the Madrid zoo said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Other nations have to realize that even the United States has its limitations.

title: Engine Trouble Halts A Voyage of the QE2
description: The luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2 turned back from an Atlantic crossing today because of engine trouble and anchored off southwestern England to await spare parts.

title: SOLAR FLARE TREATS U.S. TO AURORAL DISPLAY
description: Dramatic auroral displays were visible across much of the United States Sunday night after the shock front of a solar flare or explosive eruption struck the outer magnetic field of the earth at about 6:50 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: BOMBAY IS NOW HOME OF THE ELITE AND THE HOPELESS
description: Bombay is India's El Dorado, in many respects its New York, Hollywood and Houston rolled into one. It is a center of finance, commerce, industry, shipping, publishing, film-making and offshore oil exploration; a place of glitter and dash, of almost tangible verve and vitality whose rhythm and throb and cosmopolitan atmosphere would be instantly recognizable to any New Yorker.

title: PANAMA'S ARMY CHIEF KEEPS POST
description: Panama's President, Ricardo de la Espriella, confirmed Brig. Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes as commander of the country's 10,000-member national guard tonight just 48 hours after the officer unexpectedly offered to resign.

title: CAMPAIGNS END IN PRIMARY RACES FOR CONNECTICUT
description: Candidates for Secretary of the State, Congress and the state legislature made their last-minute rounds of town parades and picnics today in advance of party primary elections in Connecticut Tuesday.

title: JAPANESE 'STATION'
description: IT'S not easy to get in sync with Mikami (Ken Takakura), the hero of Yasuo Furuhata's 1981 Japanese film, ''Station'' (Eki), which opens today at the Public.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Portraits in the Wild: Animal Behavior in East Africa By Cynthia Moss. Second Edition, 371 pages, illustrated. University of Chicago Press, $12.50 (paperback)

title: NEW APPROACH AT STATE IS TO 'TALK THINGS OVER'
description: For as long as anyone can remember, the Secretary of State's conference room has contained a long mahogany table in two sections, embraced by two dozen or more chairs, with more chairs stacked arm-to-arm along the wall. Sometime after George P. Shultz's arrival in the building, the furniture was rearranged.

title: 750 Beavers in Idaho May Have to Be Shot
description: The Idaho Humane Society said today it was looking for homes for 750 beavers that may be shot next Sunday and buried in a city dump because a bankrupt fur farm says it cannot afford to feed the animals.

title: DROP IN PRESCRIPTIONS CUTS SALE OF METHAQUALONE PILLS
description: A sharp drop has been reported in prescriptions by New York physicians for methaqualone, a dangerous sedative commonly known by its trade name Quaalude, and law enforcement officials believe the decline has reduced the amount of the drug diverted into illegal channels.

title: FINDS FOR FALL: BAUBLE, BANGLE AND BLACK
description: Labor Day signals the end of summer, and the New York retailers couldn't be happier. After a slow season they are hoping that the fall merchandise packing their stores will be just the thing to brighten the sales picture.

title: NEW BANKRUPTCY JUDGE READY FOR BUSY DOCKET
description: 'They barely give you time to put your robe on and get started,' said Prudence Beatty Abram as she began her new duties as a bankruptcy judge in the Federal court system's Southern District in Manhattan.

title: McFarlane Is Acquired
description: Global Natural Resources yesterday completed the acquisition of the McFarlane Oil Company after a temporary restraining order by a United States District Court expired on Friday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Elusive Innovation

title: Puerto Rican Policeman Arrested in Kidnapping
description: A high-ranking Puerto Rican police officer has been arrested in connection with the kidnapping last week of the son of a wealthy San Juan jeweler, the authorities said today.

title: A FREEZE MEANS THIN ICE
description: Though the House voted down the nuclear freeze, resolutions favoring a freeze will appear this fall on ballots in more than a half-dozen states representing nearly a quarter of the country's population. The results will send an important signal to friends and foes abroad.

title: A Singapore Socialist Freed From Confinement
description: The Singapore Government lifted orders today that had confined a former Socialist Front leader named Lim Hock Siew to a nearby island for the last four years.

title: A Lost Payday
description: Tony Ayala Jr., under treatment for alcoholism and other personal problems, watched a $650,000 payday disappear Saturday night when Roberto Duran was upset by Kirkland Laing of Britain. ''He took it in stride,'' said Dan Duva, who was to have co-promoted, with Don King, Ayala's bout with Duran on Nov. 19.

title: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Recalled Gary Redus, outfielder, and Mike O'Berry, catcher, from Indianapolis of the Ameri- can Association.; Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Waived Wilson Faumuina, defensive tackle; Terry Bee- son, linebacker, and John James, punter.  Placed Harry Stanback, defensive end, and Tony Daykin, linebacker, on injured reserve.  BALTIMORE (AFC) - Waived Rob Taylor and Randy Van Divier, tackles; Chris Foote, center; Brian DeRoo and Randy Burke, wide re
description: BUFFALO (AFC) - Cut Mike Kadish, n ose tackle; Lemar Parish, defensive b ack; David Bayle, tight end; Gene Brad- l ey, quarterback; Gary Anderson, kicker; D anny Garcia, wide receiver; Dennis Ed- w ards, defensive end, and Mike Humiston, l inebacker. Placed Byron Franklin, wide r eceiver, on injured reserve. CHICAGO (NFC) - Cut Bob Thomas, k icker; Lee Kunz and Rod Shoate, line- b ackers; T.K. Ehlebracht, wide receiver; P at Dean, defensive tackle; Ted Vincent, d efensive end; Hasan Houston and Terry P orter, defensive backs; Greg Fairchild, g uard, and Duke Fergerson, wide receiv- e r. Placed Brian Cabral, linebacker; Cal- v in Thomas, running back, and Kurt B ecker and Perry Hartnett, guards, on the i nactive list. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Cut Thomas B rown, defensive end; Larry Friday, safe- t y; Don Stump, kicker; Steve Michuta, q uarterback; Aaron Hill, defensive back; G ary Davis, running back; Milton Baker, t ight end; Kevin Turner, linebacker, and J erome King, cornerback.

title: RHODEN OF PIRATES STOPS THE METS, 6-1
description: Pete Falcone suffered only two serious lapses against the Pirates today, but they were enough to send the Mets to a 6-1 defeat.

title: MEDICARE DIAGNOSIS
description: To the Editor:

title: QUICK MOVE URGED TO ASSIST NATIONS IN MEETING DEBTS
description: Opening the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund here today, the fund's top official welcomed a decision by the leading industrial members to help meet the acute debt problems of many countries around the world.

title: POLAND GIVES GOMULKA A HERO'S FUNERAL
description: The Polish martial-law authorities gave a hero's funeral today to Wladyslaw Gomulka, the nation's twice-purged Communist leader, in a ceremony apparently intended to confer continuity and legitimacy on the military Government.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1982; International
description: Additional funding to help debt-ridden nations is needed soon, to ''assure the stability of the international financial system,'' the head of the I.M.F. said. Jacques de Larosiere, the group's managing director, said he hoped for an increase in the fund's resources by April. He spoke at the fund's joint annual meeting with the World Bank in Toronto. (Page A1.)

title: WHERE 'WEALTH' IS WASTE-AND VICE VERSA
description: To the Editor:

title: REVIVED DANCES THRIVE ALL NIGHT
description: The last dance, the one that ended just after 7 A.M. today with about 150 diehards collapsing into joyous hugs with partners and friends, was a familiar waltz. Outside the recreation hall, the sun was nowhere to be seen, but the sunrise behind Mount Wantastiquet on the other side of the Connecticut River in New Hampshire had suffused the thick fog with a groping, albeit promising, light.

title: SHARON SPEAKS OUT ON MISSING ISRAELIS
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that Syria would be responsible for the safety of eight Israeli soldiers reportedly captured on Saturday.

title: River Plunge Kills Man, 36, and Son
description: A 36-year-old postal worker killed himself and his 3-year-old son when he drove his car off a boat dock under construction next to Liberty State Park here, the police said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Places of Honor

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE MEANS AND THE END

title: FOCUS IS ON P.L.O.
description: Fifteen Arab leaders arrived here today for the start of an Arab League meeting that is expected to focus on the plight of the Palestinians after their military rout by the Israelis in Lebanon.

title: GROUPS AIM TO COUNTER BOOK BANS
description: There has been a threefold increase in attempts at book censorship in the nation's libraries in the last two years, according to publishing, bookselling, librarian and authors' organizations that have been monitoring such attempts all over the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STOLEN LIGHTNING: The Social Theory of Magic. By Daniel Lawrence O'Keefe. 581 Pages. Continuum. $24.50.

title: Rochester Spared Teachers' Action
description: Teachers in the Rochester school district will be in their classrooms when school starts Wednesday, union representatives decided today.

title: PHILHARMONIC TOUR BIG HIT IN ARGENTINA
description: The strained relations between the United States and Argentina since the end of Argentina's war with Britain for the Falkland Islands three months ago have been assuaged a bit by the New York Philharmonic in a triumphant tour that ended here today.

title: The 1982 Tax Law Fifth article of a series appearing periodically
description: When Congress finally approved its omnibus tax bill, merger specialists breathed a sigh of relief, for the new rules governing mergers appeared to be relatively painless.

title: Rutledge Reports; Reed Cut
description: Today, when all National Football League teams had to cut their rosters to the season limit of 49, the Giants added a quarterback and surprisingly dropped one.

title: OPERA OPENING RENOVATED STATE THEATER
description: THE New York City Opera opens its season at Lincoln Center tonight with a new production and a new sound. Franz Lehar's ''The Merry Widow,'' freshly dressed and designed, will provide the entertainment, but this evening's real debutant will be the reshaped acoustics of the New York State Theater.

title: LANDON, NEAR 95TH BIRTHDAY, FINDS GLOBAL UNREST AT A PEAK
description: Alfred M. Landon, who fell in love with politics when Theodore Roosevelt ran for the Presidency 70 years ago, has lost none of his interest in people and news.

title: Signing of Malone Has Few Critics
description: When Harold Katz, who owns the Philadelphia 76ers, signed Moses Malone to a $13.2 million offer sheet last week, none of his fellow National Basketball Association owners were heard to cry out that his actions would put the league on a path toward financial ruin. There was nothing like the criticism heard last summer, when Ted Stepien, the Cleveland Cavaliers' owner, signed several free agents to expensive offer sheets.

title: WEEKS
description: Congress will confront four major fiscal issues and two major social issues when it reconvenes Wednesday for the final weeks of the session.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Crum and Forster has elected to its board Frances R. Hesselbein, national executive director of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 20 Are Reported Dead In Teheran Bomb Blast

title: BUSY BARBARA TUCHMAN
description: COS COB, Conn. BARBARA TUCHMAN is working on yet another big book, ''Folly in Government,'' and while it would be inexact to say that she is barricaded behind a phalanx of stately pink foxgloves, hiding from a fractious world that would intrude, even the conspicuously accurate Mrs. Tuchman would agree that she's doing her best to be unavailable, refusing the lures and harangues of those who would disturb her.

title: WORDS SEEM TO FAIL FIFTH AVENUE MILE
description: A visual-aural dissonance plagued ABC-TV's presentation of the Fifth Avenue Mile last Saturday. What we saw was quite attractive; what he heard was first excessive, then insufficient.

title: U.S. CONTINUES DEFENSIVE GERM WARFARE RESEARCH
description: The United States officially renounced biological warfare in 1969. But here, in a small corner of the military base where the American germ-weapon effort was located, Army scientists are still involved in what they call ''medical defensive B.W. research.''

title: MAN ON FIRE DIES IN 14-STORY FALL OFF HOTEL LEDGE
description: Moments before firemen and a security guard might have reached him, a man engulfed in flames plunged 14 stories to his death yesterday afternoon from the window ledge of his blazing room at a hotel on Manhattan's West Side.

title: PRIVATE CONCERN TO LAUNCH ROCKET
description: Promoters of America's first commercial rocket test-fired a miniature version, resembling a ''stovepipe,'' today and said signs were good for a scheduled launching Wednesday.

title: Stewards Scratch Timely Writer
description: The hard luck that has dogged Timely Writer's racing career struck again yesterday when the Belmont Park stewards scratched the colt from the Jerome Handicap on the basis of a pre-race blood test.

title: PROPER HELMSMEN: THE COURT
description: The Senate adjourned for Labor Day in the middle of what most people believed was a filibuster against an amendment that would reverse the Supreme Court's historic 1962 decision preventing states from requiring prayer in public schools. Nothing could be further from reality.

title: COLLEGES BUZZ WITH LIFE AS ANOTHER YEAR BEGINS
description: Juggling class schedules, meeting classmates, signing up for extracurricular activities and lining up at financial-aid offices, nearly 1.5 million students have begun settling in at colleges across the New York metropolitan area.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Baby Checkup Book: A Parent's Guide to Well Baby Care in the First Two Years By Sheilah Hillman in consultation with James H. Moller, M.D. and Robert S. Hillman, M.D. 335 pages, illustrated. Bantam Books, $6.95.

title: No Headline
description: Thunder Puddles Wins the Rutgers

title: CORPORATE ISSUES DUE
description: Investment bankers have scheduled nearly $1 billion of new corporate note and bond issues this week, but warn that the volume could be significantly greater if investor demand is strong.

title: TV: MOYERS ON ROOSEVELT AND HITLER
description: BILL MOYERS is officially employed by CBS News but that technicality hasn't hampered his ambitious need for special projects. Since returning to CBS, he has completed a series on ''Creativity'' for public television. And now, beginning tonight at 8:30, he can be seen on 20 hour-long programs produced for CBS Cable (carried on Manhattan Cable's Channel K in New York City).

title: A MAN WHO CARED TOO MUCH
description: On Friday night, Aug. 20 - two months after he had been elected chairman of the New York Cotton Exchange and two weeks before his wedding date - Philip Leland Hehmeyer went home to his luxurious apartment on Manhattan's East Side, bolted the door and abruptly ended his life with the blast of a shotgun.

title: MCENROE, LENDL, WARWICK IN LAST 8
description: Minutes after he destroyed Mats Wilander last night, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2, Ivan Lendl was oozing with confidence as a quarterfinalist in the United States Open tennis championships.

title: CAR ALARMS THAT MUST NOT BE SHUT UP
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Schedule; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Completion of Tracy Austin-Hana Mandlikova match. Second Match - Ivan Lendl-Kim Warwick.

title: Utah Coal Venture
description: Rio Grande Industries said it had agreed in principle to a $70 million venture with the Du Pont Company's Consolidation Coal Company to build and operate a 62-mile railroad between Acco and Emery, Utah. Construction is to start early next year, and the intention is to complete the line by the end of 1984 to help Consolidation and others to develop coal reserves.

title: Microcomputer Piracy Fine
description: In what was hailed as a breakthrough in combating piracy in the microcomputer industry, a Federal judge has awarded $250,000 and reimbursement for legal expenses to two companies that had brought suit for copyright infringement.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST INITIATIVE
description: President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative is a week old. The Arab-Israeli confrontation is 34 years old - as old as the state of Israel. And the struggle between Zionists and Palestinians is older than this century. Will the Reagan approach mark a turning point or become one more bleak milestone on the welltraveled road of diplomatic deadlock and military strife?

title: NEW SYSTEM OF ARRAIGNMENTS IS NONSTOP, BUT HARD TO START
description: Judge Joan B. Carey had taken the bench just before 1 A.M. yesterday and was ready to arraign her first suspect under the new round-the-clock schedule in Manhattan Criminal Court. She had been told that 104 suspects were ''in the system,'' and minutes later Richard Small of Culver City, Calif., was brought before her.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McCullum Is Cut
description: Some National Football League teams were still announcing day the names of the players dropped in the 49-man cutdown. Among those waived was the Seattle Seahawks' Sam McCullum, a veteran wide receiver.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANK'S BID TO ACQUIRE STOCK FIRM FACES TEST
description: In an action that could develop into a test of the legal barrier that separates the banking and securities industries, the Federal Reserve Board will begin hearings Wednesday on a bid by the BankAmerica Corporation to acquire Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm.

title: Blast Kills Danish Worker
description: A barrel of chemicals exploded at a suburban medical products factory today, killing one worker and injuring three, the police reported. In addition, two men from an ambulance team apparently were overcome by fumes from the explosion at Novo Industries. Novo is said to be the world's largest producer of enzymes for industrial uses.

title: TRUDEAU SAYS OTTAWA WON'T 'BAIL OUT' DOME
description: The Canadian Government went on record Monday for the first time that it would not ''bail out'' financially troubled Dome Petroleum Ltd. The statement, by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau in a radio interview, appeared to contradict the federal Government's earlier position that it was willing to come to the rescue of Canada's largest oil company.

title: Market Place; Insider Buying At Recognition
description: DORMANT Recognition Equipment has awakened to post impressive stock market gains in recent sessions. The shares touched 6 yesterday and closed at 5 7/8, up 7/8, for the second best percentage gain of the day. The shares traded as low as 4 3/8 as recently as last week.

title: RICHARD A. HOEFER
description: Richard A. Hoefer, a former publisher of House Beautiful magazine and a director of the Hearst Corporation, died Friday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A DRAINED MISS NAVRATILOVA LOSES TO A FRIEND AT THE OPEN
description: In a match laden with compassion between the players, Martina Navratilova, the most dominating woman in tennis this year, was eliminated in the quarterfinals of the United States Open championships yesterday by Pam Shriver, her doubles partner.

title: REAGAN BESTOWS MEDAL OF FREEDOM ON HABIB
description: President Reagan presented the nation's highest civilian honor today to Philip C. Habib, his special Middle East envoy, for his ''skillful diplomacy and tireless activity'' in bringing about a cease-fire in Lebanon and ending the siege of Beirut.

title: Keep the Bus Shelters
description: Bus shelters are a profitable way to protect waiting riders from the elements: advertisers pay handsome fees for the right to plaster their messages on the shelters' walls. Shelters started to go up in Manhattan in 1975, but plans to extend them to New York City's other boroughs evaporated in a miasma of scandal and litigation, and the city took over shelters built by the original franchisee.

title: More Ransom Notes In Zimbabwe Abduction
description: Rebels in southern Zimbabwe have sent two more ransom notes to authorities that say six foreign tourists seized as hostages in July are still alive, Government sources said today.

title: The Small Panda Dies; Other One Doing Well
description: The smaller of two pandas born to Shao Shao died today of respiratory problems, Madrid Zoo officials reported.

title: BUDGET OFFICE ACCEPTS TIGHTENED BANK RULES
description: The Office of Management and Budget agreed today to accept a proposal by Federal bank regulators that would require commercial banks to disclose more detailed information about bad loans and the banks' financial condition.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MERRY WIDOW'
description: THE first success of the new music season, unveiled last night by the New York City Opera, turned out to be the remodeled New York State Theater, which had no trouble upstaging the company's genial but still unfocused new production of ''The Merry Widow.''

title: CACI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Woolfolk Is Cautious About New Role
description: In all his years playing football - in youth leagues, at Westfield (N.J.) High School and at the University of Michigan - Butch Woolfolk never caught a touchdown pass. In all those years, he never played on special teams.

title: IN GOSHEN, CRUISING SEASON HAS BEGUN
description: As the late-summer sun sets in this quiet Middle Western town, adolescent energy surges down Main Street. The grown-ups take off, the teen-agers move in and engines start revving to the accompaniment of punk, disco and western swing music.

title: PRIEST HOLDING HOSTAGE TALKS
description: An 80-year-old Polish-born priest, described by associates as a dynamic man with a wide range of skills and interests, took on a new task today - negotiating with gunmen holding the Polish Embassy here.

title: 56 Firefighters Treated
description: Fifty-six firefighters were treated and released at two hospitals after inhaling toxic fumes while fighting a barn fire on Monday. The Frederick County Fire Marshal said that all had been treated for ''toxic inhalation'' of Furadan, a pesticide that had been sprayed on hay.

title: Six Missing on Mount Blanc
description: Italian and French rescue teams searched today for six climbers, including an American, missing on Mount Blanc. The teams, supported by helicopters but hampered by bad weather, did not report any sightings, the police in this northern Italian town said. A Boston lawyer identified as Brenten Young, 31 years old, vanished Sunday on the Italian side of the mountain, the police said.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shrs outstdng and the shr earnings are restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb 18; fiscal yr 1981 figures include common stock equivalents

title: NEWFOUNDLAND LIGHT & POWER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GUNMEN AT EMBASSY SET NEW DEADLINE
description: Gunmen holding the Polish Embassy here have freed all but five of their 13 hostages and extended for 48 hours their deadline for Poland to lift martial law, Swiss officials said early today.

title: Icahn Offer to Buy Rest of Bayswater
description: Carl C. Icahn, a New York financier, said the Icahn Acquisition Corporation, which he owns, would offer today to pay $13 for each of the common shares of the Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation that it does not already own.

title: THE QUIET MAN
description: It's too early to tell whether President Reagan has a new policy for the Middle East or merely a new speech, but clearly he has a new Secretary of State, and that could make all the difference.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1982
description: International Israel has begun to press Lebanon to move toward negotiating a formal peace treaty to help guarantee the security of its northern border. Otherwise, it is believed, Israel will insist that southern Lebanon be controlled by a pro-Israeli Christian militia, possibly supported by an Israeli military presence, at least in the form of periodic patrols. (Page A1, Column 6.) Philip C. Habib was honored with the Medal of Freedom. President Reagan presented the nation's highest civilian honor to his special Middle East envoy for ''skillful diplomacy'' in bringing about a cease-fire in Lebanon and ending the siege of Beirut. (A10:4-6.)

title: 9 Invited to Compete For A.T.& T. Unit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has invited nine advertising agencies to present campaigns promoting its telecommunications products to business customers.

title: FURLOUGHS AT I.R.S. AVERTED BY A SHIFT OF TREASURY FUNDS
description: The threatened furlough of 19,000 employees of the Internal Revenue Service was averted today as two Senate Republican committee leaders reluctantly approved a transfer of funds in the Treasury Department.

title: Bridge: Aces Can Possess People, Even as Demons Once Did
description: Most players realize that aces are undervalued by the standard point count. Some textbooks allow the addition of a point for the possession of three or four aces, and there have been good arguments for counting an ace as 4 1/2 points instead of 4.

title: STAGE: MONTAND AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: YVES MONTAND is the first pop artist to be sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera House in its history, but he hasn't let this invitation to pretentiousness faze him a bit. The show that Mr. Montand brought to New York last night reveals an entertainer who, at age 60, is totally comfortable with himself -who knows exactly who he is, what he wants to do and how to do it. And what he wants to do has no relation to the gilt frame that surrounds him at Lincoln Center.

title: Accounts
description: * The New Jersey Devils, a new National Hockey League team, to Keyes Martin, Springfield, N.J.

title: MEDAL IS HIGHEST CIVIL AWARD
description: The Presidential Medal of Freedom, which was presented to Philip C. Habib today by President Reagan, is the highest civilian award given by the United States.

title: Florida Propane Tank Alarm
description: A propane tank on a tractortrailer sprang a leak overnight, forcing the evacuation of 300 residents as fumes spread through the neighborhood in this Gulf Coast town. The authorities were letting the 10,000-pound tank ''leak itself out'' and prepared to allow residents to return home.

title: CUOMO AND CURRAN ATTACK RIVALS AS BARRAGE OF CRITICISM CONTINUES
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo promised yesterday that if he became governor, state taxes would not go up. He said taxes would rise if Mayor Koch, his opponent in the Democratic primary, kept his pledges on new state aid.

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Wham-O Buyer
description: The Wham-O Manufacturing Company said it had entered into a definitive agreement to be acquired by Kransco, a privately held San Francisco company, for $16 a share, or a total of $12 million. The amount can be revised downward to not less than $15 a share, if Wham-O's net worth falls below a specified level. The company's $21-a-share deal with Hasbro Industries was abandoned last month.

title: PAID BY THE GOVERNMENT TO DO NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Coke in Canada
description: Canada's federal Department of Communications has recommended that the Canadian Government reject Coca-Cola Ltd.'s planned acquisition of the Canadian operations of Columbia Pictures Industries. Coca-Cola Ltd. is a unit of the Coca-Cola Company, which acquired Columbia Pictures last June. The agency wants foreign investment in Canada's movie distribution business severely restricted, as in other parts of Canada's economy.

title: Thorpe Fight Goes On
description: Charlotte Thorpe, the 62-year-old daughter of Jim Thorpe, said in Phoenix that she ''will not rest'' until her late father's trophies ''are here on American soil.'' Thorpe, a double gold-medal winner at the 1912 Olympics in Stockholm, later lost the medals when it was discovered that he had accepted $60 a month to play semipro baseball in North Carolina, negating his amateur status.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On the Road

title: Nixon, in Peking, Says Let's 'Seize the Hour'
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon called on the United States and China today to ''seize the hour'' and expand their relations.

title: MUCH TALK, LITTLE OF IT CANDID, ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: While Democrats and Republicans are arming for a political firefight this fall over the Reagan Administration's record on Social Security, the prospects for actually revising the system in the next six months have been lost in the smoke.

title: Senegalese Ex-Aide Jailed
description: In an anticorruption drive, a court has convicted a former presidential adviser, Becaye Sene, of embezzlement and sentenced him to three years in prison. He was also fined $90,000 by the court Monday. According to testimony, he embezzled about $300,000 over several years.

title: PROSECUTOR MOVES TO CLEAR A SUSPECT IN BRINK'S CASE
description: The Rockland County District Attorney moved yesterday to drop all charges against Anthony N. LaBorde, one of eight defendants in the Brink's armored-car robbery last Oct. 20 in which two policemen and a Brink's guard were killed.

title: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Included a tax credit of $1,013,500 for the qr and $1,503,500 for the yr...C-Included a tax credit of $154,000 for the qr and yr

title: 3 SOUGHT IN RITUAL KILLING ARRESTED IN MANHATTAN
description: New York City detectives have arrested three men being sought in connection with the bizarre weekend slaying of a University of Florida professor. One was arrested after a high-speed, early morning automobile chase in Manhattan yesterday. A second arrest came late last night and the third early this morning.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income after tax credits of $1,574,000 for the qr and $4,683,000 for the 6 mos and income from discontinued operations of $4,560,000 for the qr and $17,163,000 for the 6 mos; the yr-ago periods are restated

title: COOKING AHEAD FOR A WEEK
description: TANS are fading fast, sandals are being replaced by pumps and seersucker suits have been sent to the cleaners for the last time this year. In short, it is autumn in New York and the relative informality of summer is giving way once again to the usual frenetic pace with the return of city dwellers from vacations and summer retreats. In cooler weather the family cook is expected to put something more substantial on the table.

title: DISHES WITH THE TASTE OF EDIBLE FLOWERS
description: IF John McMath has his way, mothers will soon be urging their children to ''eat your nasturtiums and finish up those lily buds or you don't get dessert.''

title: No Headline
description: DODGERS TOP REDS, REGAIN FIRST PLACE

title: Mead Corp. Settlement
description: The Mead Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, said yesterday it had approved a tentative out-of-court settlement in its long-running corrugated-container antitrust case. The accord calls for the forestproducts company to pay the plaintiffs a total of $45 million over six years, resulting in an after-tax earnings charge of about $22.5 million.

title: LAW
description: The Holiday Inn on Manhattan's West Side, where a man plunged to his death from a window during a fire Monday afternoon, was in violation of the city's smoke-detector law, an assistant housing commissioner said yesterday.

title: RCA NAMES A PRESIDENT AND LIKELY HEIR TO CHIEF
description: Robert R. Frederick, an executive vice president and a career employee of the General Electric Company, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the RCA Corporation and the likely successor to Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman and chief executive.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PRIVATE SCHOOLS' CONSTITUTIONAL PRIVILEGE
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADER OF G. FOX MAPS STRATEGY FOR EXPANSION
description: After his experience as executive vice president for merchandising at G.Fox & Company, Connecticut's largest department-store chain, Marshall Hilsberg, 37, says he sees an opportunity to build on his chain's established customer base.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: People who do not know New York very well think it is a big city. In truth, it is an enormous collection of small towns. One of those small towns is on 20 acres bounded by the East River and a sluggish little tributary called Pugsley's Creek, on the Bronx coast. It is called the Castle Hill Beach Club.

title: Kean Is Released From Hospital
description: Governor Kean was released today from St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, where he had been undergoing treatment for a ruptured disc.

title: BARRIER ISLANDS THAT BELONG TO NATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE PARK PLAN TO CUT TIMBER SETS OFF A BATTLE
description: A plan to introduce extensive commercial logging for the first time in a state park is stirring a major battle in the remote and densely forested Allegany State Park here.

title: CALIFORNIAN'S PLAN TO OUTSPEND HIS FOES BACKFIRES
description: Johnnie R. Crean is a blunt, forceful, 33-year-old business executive who says that he filed for the seat from California's 43d Congressional District with the intention of outspending his opponents to buy the name recognition it would take to win.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13 weeks to July 30
description: B-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $616,000 for the 13 weeks and $853,000 for the 26 weeks

title: DISCOUNT TICKETS BOOTH PLANNED FOR BRYANT PARK
description: Beginning next spring, discount tickets for music and dance concerts will be sold at a booth in Bryant Park, similar to the successful TKTS booth in Times Square where theater tickets are sold at half price.

title: 4 Die in Mill Fire
description: A sudden blast of smoke from a fire in a yarn factory killed four workers today as they tried to extinguish the blaze.

title: 2 Stars Injured in Crash Receive Many Messages
description: Fans of Mary Martin and Janet Gaynor swamped the hospital today with messages of concern for the stars, who were badly injured when a van struck their taxi.

title: ICELAND'S PRESIDENT DISPELS SOME MYTHS
description: ''Because we are called Iceland it is thought we are a cold and reserved and distant people who aren't creative, educated and interesting,'' said Vigdis Finnbogadottir. ''People think of Iceland as a very cold place, full of ice, with very few people living there.''

title: NIAGARA FRONTIER SERVICES reports earnings for Yr to June 26
2 BIDS FAIL TO BLOCK TEST BY FIRE DEPT. FOR WOMEN
description: Two last-minute court attempts to prevent New York City's Fire Department from giving a revised version of its entrance examination to a group of women failed yesterday, clearing the way for a courtordered retesting of the women today.

title: A TIME OF TRANSITION FOR NO. 2 COURT
description: ''It's sort of the last bastion of liberalism, and the question is whether it will hold,'' said Joseph L. Rauh Jr., a leading public interest lawyer here, who fervently hopes that it will.

title: IF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL WILL NOT PROSECUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Gas Plan
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said it had approved an application by the Florida Gas Transmission Company, a subsidiary of the Continental Company, to convert a 900-mile natural gas pipeline to carry light petroleum products. The line would be sold to the Transgulf Pipeline Company, an affiliate of Florida Gas, for $236 million. Florida Gas would use $185 million of the proceeds to build a parallel replacement line with a capacity of 725 billion cubic feet a day, the agency said.

title: STUDY SAYS U.S. IS FAILING TO AVERT JOB DRAIN
description: A study prepared for members of Congress says that millions of Americans may lose their jobs to automation and foreign competition in coming decades but the Federal Government is not doing enough about it.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES ENTERS TAKEOVER BATTLE
description: In an unusual alliance, the United Technologies Corporation joined the Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday in a bid to take over the Bendix Corporation and divide its assets between them.

title: Norwegian Oil Accord
description: Two Norwegian companies have won orders to build a concrete platform and deliver mechanical equipment to the ''gold block'' field in the North Sea, the Norwegian state oil company, Statoil, said today. It said Norwegian contractors had received a contract for a $210 million concrete structure for the field, northwest of Bergen, and the Moss Rosenberg yard in Stavanger would deliver equipment worth up to $900,000.

title: Opren Drug Withdrawn
description: Eli Lilly & Company's British subsidiary, Dista Products Ltd., has permanently withdrawn its antiarthritis drug Opren after Government health authorities imposed a 90-day suspension in August, a spokesman said today. He said the group was also withdrawing Opren from markets worldwide.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Good Neighbors and Bad

title: Mental Acumen; Try to Remember
description: The pharmaceutical industry is searching for an ''intelligence drug'' that would enhance learning, attention and memory. So far the results are tantalizing.

title: KEN BOYER, EX-BASEBALL STAR
description: Ken Boyer, a star third baseman with the St. Louis Cardinals and later their manager, died today of lung cancer. He was 51 years old.

title: Economic Scene; Threatened Money System
description: TORONTO THE toughest question confronting this year's annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank here is just how much danger there is of a financial collapse of particular countries - and the world monetary system.

title: Brothers on Cup Team
description: John McEnroe, Peter Fleming and the Mayer brothers, Gene and Sandy, have been selected by Arthur Ashe, the Davis Cup captain, to face Australia in the semifinals at Perth next month. Fleming and McEnroe played in the previous victories over India and Sweden, but this is the first cup appearance for the Mayers. Their father, Alex Mayer, was a cup player for Hungary and Yugoslavia.

title: IT'S HAWK VERSUS DOVE IN STRATON-DOW BATTLE
description: There is a clash of ideas going on here in the Democratic Congressional primary that harks back to the Vietnam War, encompasses El Salvador and then dwells on the present nuclear-freeze debate.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE DAY IS SHORT. An Autobiography. By Morris B. Abram. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. 280 pages. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: Florida Gov. Bob Graham easily outpolled two rivals yesterday to win the Democratic nomination for a second term, and Florida Republicans chose Representative L.A. Bafalis to oppose him in November.

title: STUDY SAYS NORTH LAGS IN INTEGRATION
description: The segregation of black students increased in the Northeast but declined in all other regions of the country from 1968 to 1980, according to a report by the Joint Center for Political Studies.

title: EDUCATORS' GROUP INTRODUCES A NEW S.A.T. STUDY PROGRAM
description: Question: ''Prestidigitator is to magician what linguist is to what?'' Answer: ''Polyglot.'' After screening a videotaped instruction session designed to help pupils decode this and similar word puzzles, an educational group today announced the publication of a new test-preparation program geared to the 1.5 million high school seniors who annually take the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: IN PRAISE OF SALT, A FRIEND MALIGNED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon is an Episcopal priest, author and food writer whose latest book is ''Between Noon and Three'' (Harper & Row). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Science and Tech- nology - 10:30 A.M.

title: Conservatives to Govern Denmark for First Time
description: Four non-Socialist parties reached agreement today on forming a minority ruling coalition.

title: No Breakaway Runners
description: When the Pittsburgh Stealers run with the football, they never go very far. They aren't allowed to. The Pittsburgh Stealers, not to be confused with the Pittsburgh Steelers, are the football team of Western State Penitentiary.

title: CITY EXPANDING SUBWAY PATROLS BY AUXILIARIES
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that an experimental program in which auxiliary police officers patrol subway stations was being made permanent and that the number of such auxiliaries had grown since January from 12 to 1,500 volunteers.

title: First Mississippi
description: The First Mississippi Corporation said it had completed the sale of 55 farm centers and product inventories to the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation for $26.8 million. About $11.7 million is to be paid in cash, and the remainder in installments over four years, with interest.

title: Head of U. of California Announces Resignation
description: David S. Saxon, president of the University of California system since 1975, will resign at the end of this academic year, next July 1, the university announced today.

title: 7 Quit Everest Expedition
description: Six climbers and a doctor have quit a Canadian expedition that is trying to climb Mount Everest after the death last week of a colleague and three Sherpa porters, Nepal's Tourism Ministry said today. The ministry quoted a radio message from the expedition leader, Bill March, of Calgary, Alberta, as saying the seven men left the base camp yesterday to return to Katmandu. The expedition now has only nine climbers.

title: SUMMER '82 IS HOLLYWOOD'S MOST LUCRATIVE EVER
description: ''E.T. -the Extra Terrestrial,'' ''Rocky III,'' ''Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan,'' ''Poltergeist,'' ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' and ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' have won the summer box-office race.

title: Phillips Cuts Role In Solar Venture
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Acurex Corporation said that Acurex had become sole owner of the Acurex Solar Corporation, a venture formed by Phillips and Acurex in 1980 to make solar energy systems. Phillips retains a 30 percent interest in the Acurex Corporation.

title: Telethon Pledges Drop For Jerry Lewis Show
description: Jerry Lewis says high unemployment and a sluggish economy are to blame for a 10 percent drop in pledges to his annual Muscular Dystrophy Telethon.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
LIVES IN THE BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Fired On Again In Lebanon, They Say
description: Israel said today that its troops were fired upon for the second time in four days with bazookas and automatic weapons in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley in Lebanon.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amcon Group Inc., the North American subsidiary of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., said it now owns or has agreed to buy 23.4 percent of Newmont Mining Corp.'s common stock.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE Gallo brothers, Ernest and Julio, who already dominate the market for low-priced wine, are making a strong bid to capture a similar share of the premium market. They are introducing their first cabernet sauvignon, pitting themselves against most of the other producers of premium wine.

title: Heinz Income Up 1.7%
description: The H.J. Heinz Company, a diversified foods producer, reported yesterday that net income in its first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended July 28 edged up 1.7 percent, to $55.3 million, or $1.17 a share, from $54.4 million, or $1.16 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 5.7 percent, to $909.2 million, from $860.2 million.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: B-After a tax gain of $76,000

title: U.S. RATES STIR HOPE AT I.M.F.
description: Finance ministers and commercial bankers, convening here for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, expressed relief today that the United States economy finally appears to be turning up.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $271,250 for the qr and $610,250 for the 9 mos...C-Aftertax credits of $134,754 for the qr and $342,723 for the 9 mos

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 12 on the Christian Science Church incorrectly listed the architects of the new office tower at the Christian Science Center in Bos- ton. It was designed by I.M. Pei & Partners and Araldo Cossutta, Associ- ated Architects.

title: Testimony Heard On Tribal Dispute
description: The Connecticut Indian Affairs Council, meeting in Hartford yesterday, heard several hours of testimony and received evidence from two persons claiming to be the tribal chairman of the Schaghticoke Indians.

title: MENTAL ACUMEN; Street Smarts
description: Its Latin name is polygonum, for its many knees - the swollen nodes that segment the reddish stem.

title: Real Estate; Leasing Woes of A Retailer
description: FOR leased space, it is supposed be a buyer's market in New York right now. Reports from brokers and landlords indicate that owners are eager to sign leases and will make concessions now that the real estate market is softening.

title: DECISIONS TO DIMINISH THE ENVIRONMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAB LEADERS PRESS SEARCH FOR MIDEAST PEACE FORMULA
description: The Arab leaders attending an Arab League meeting here conferred late Monday night and for much of today in an attempt to devise a Middle East peace plan that the members of the league could agree upon.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chancellor Government Securities, a low-load open-end diversified managment company, said it would offer shares of its Trust-Intermediate series, with a minimum initial investment of $1,000, through Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shrs outstdng have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split that was made on July 30, 1982

title: Mrs. Truman's Doctor Says Ulcer Bleeding Has Stopped
description: Bess Truman's physician said today the bleeding from her ulcer had been stopped with medication. Dr. Wallace Graham added that her pulse, respiration and temperature were slightly high today but that the condition of the 97-year-old former First Lady was no cause for alarm.

title: PEREZ DE CUELLAR CONCEDES THE U.N. IS BEING IGNORED
description: In an unusually candid report on the state of the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar acknowledged today that the organization was being largely defied or ignored by many nations. He called for measures, including a special Security Council meeting, to strengthen the organization.

title: WITH PLAYERS' PARENTS ON TENNIS CIRCUT
description: IT is easy to spot the mothers and fathers of the teen-age tennis players at the United States Open in Flushing Meadow Park. They are the well-groomed middle-aged people in street clothes whose arms are full of tennis racquets.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After extraordinary credits of $1,264,300 for the latest yr and $422,500 for the earlier period

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Gunfire Fails to Free Six Prison Inmates
description: Six inmates at the nation's toughest Federal penitentiary attempted to escape under cover of diversionary gunfire aimed at guard towers from outside the prison today but were captured, a Federal official said.

title: Mexico To Seize Some Food
description: The Government announced tonight that it would begin seizing certain foods at border crossing points to prevent Americans from taking advantage of the reduced value of the peso by buying food in Mexican groceries.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATIONS NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Fluor Quarter Profit Up 87%
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose 87 percent from a year earlier on a 27 percent gain in revenue.

title: N.F.L. Owners Set To Offer New Raise
description: National Football League contract talks resume Wednesday, with team owners ready to raise their money offer and the players' union refusing to rule out the possibility of a strike before the start of the regular season on Sunday.

title: REBELLION BRINGS NEW FEAR TO THE LAND OF THE INCAS
description: Guerrillas attacked and burned the municipal building in this remote town in the Andean high sierras two weeks ago, killing six policemen.

title: Martin, 2 Others Fined
description: Manager Billy Martin and Fred Stanley of the Oakland A's, and Manager Sparky Anderson of Detroit have been fined undisclosed amounts by the American League for their part in a controversy over Rickey Henderson's pursuit of the major league record for stolen bases. Lee MacPhail, league president, said the three had created suspicion through the incident, which occurred during a game between the A's and Tigers on Aug. 24 in Oakland.

title: JAMAICA STILL ISN'T MAKING IT
description: Nearly two years after Edward Seaga's landslide victory over Prime Minister Michael Manley, little has changed for most Jamaicans. Consumer goods are plentiful and the country seems prosperous. But free enterprise, Seaga-style, has not done much better than democratic socialism, Manley-style.

title: Couple Found Slain
description: A Queens couple were found shot to death in execution style yesterday in their home in Whitestone, the police said.

title: Cetus Reduces Staff And Cuts Programs
description: The Cetus Corporation, the oldest and best financed of the startup companies attempting to cash in on gene-splicing, yesterday announced the first layoffs in its 11-year history and the discontinuation of several programs.

title: DOCTOR WAS NOT SURPRISED
description: He was too busy to watch his patient's tennis match, but he kept track of her score the same way he had kept track of her blood count for the last week.

title: ISRAELIS, AFTER 4 DAYS, LEAVE WEST BEIRUT POSITIONS
description: A small unit of Israeli troops retreated this morning from positions they had moved into four days ago on the southern edge of west Beirut.

title: BUFFALO COURIER-EXPRESS TO CEASE PUBLICATION
description: The Buffalo Courier-Express will cease publication Sept. 19, its owners, the Cowles Media Company, announced yesterday. The company said it had lost more than $25 million in the three years since it bought the newspaper and saw no likelihood of ending those losses.

title: Thinking the Unthinkable on Cuba
description: It is Wayne Smith's angle of vision that makes so devastating his understated critique of American policy toward Cuba. It is not every day that a career diplomat risks criticism by spilling the beans, including in this case some black Cuban ones suggesting that the Reagan Administration ignored openings for serious negotiations.

title: DIRECTOR OF MEXICO'S CENTRAL BANK
description: Long before Carlos Tello Macias was appointed director of the Bank of Mexico last week, he had already earned himself a place in Mexican history by becoming the first minister in memory to resign his job on a point of principle.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY!

title: Occidental Gets 97% of Cities Stock
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, which has agreed to buy Cities Service Company for about $4.3 billion, said it had received about 97 percent of Cities Service's common stock by last Saturday.

title: Mexico Alters View On Debt
description: Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, today backed away from a statement that his Government had decided to suspend all principal payments on its huge debt falling due over the next 17 months.

title: SCOTS' KINGS REST IN PEACE ON A FAR ISLE
description: When Edinburgh was but a barren rock and Oxford but a swamp, someone once said, Iona was famous. It is famous still, and now it is protected against commercial exploitation for many years to come.

title: Outdated Photo
description: Labor Day was Poster Day at Yankee Stadium. Some of the regulars of the press box were prepared for a good joke session, or at least a few wisecracks, as they anticipated a poster that would be hopelessly out of date because of the slew of Yankee personnel changes this season.

title: ABBOTT'S CHIEF EXPECTS PHARMACEUTICAL GAINS
description: When Robert A. Schoellhorn took over as chief executive officer of Abbott Laboratories three years ago, after 26 years at the American Cyanamid Company where he had headed its pharmaceutical division, most analysts expected big things from Abbott's pharmaceutical operations.

title: WALLACE WINS SPOT IN ALABAMA'S PRIMARY RUNOFF
description: George C. Wallace, bidding for a record fourth term as Governor of Alabama, took a strong lead Tuesday night in the Democratic primary election but appeared headed for a Sept. 28 runoff against one of his two leading opponents.

title: Gulf Air Chooses Kenyon & Eckhardt
description: Gulf Air airline, which is owned by four Persian Gulf countries: Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Quatar, has appointed Kenyon & Eckhardt International as its ad agency in Europe, the Middle East and Southeast Asia.

title: A Jab and a Fork
description: In 1975, when a young Syrian roughneck named Mustafa Hamsho jumped ship onto the docks of northwest Brooklyn from a Greek cargo-carrier, he spoke not a word of English. A cousin took him in, and soon Hamsho found a job as a dishwasher in a Syrian restaurant on Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue.

title: EXXON LEAVES DEALERS HIGH AND DRY
description: Fifteen years of gasoline shortages and gluts have made running a service station no more relaxing than life on a high wire for Jerry Haus, but now he and hundreds of other Exxon dealers face the biggest challenge of their marriage to oil and the automobile.

title: COLUMBIA'S EXPERT ON MEDIA RETIRING
description: ''I just think it's time for me to sit back and see what happens next,'' observed Karl Eller, who has announced that he will retire at the end of the month as president of Columbia Pictures' communications unit.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: what people are calling the Lower East Side nowadays - has been a rock-and-roll neighborhood since the mid-1960's, when the poets and bohemians who were beginning to infiltrate the area's East European and Latin neighborhoods started to form bands like the Holy Modal Rounders. These bands made music that was frequently sloppy, often deliberately outspoken and sometimes inspired. When the Fillmore East was open on Second Avenue, during the late 1960's, rock musicians were living throughout the Lower East Side. Later, in the mid-1970's, most of the first generation of punk rock musicians called Loisaida home at one time or another.

title: Northeast Utilities Lifts Nuclear Cost
description: Northeast Utilities increased its estimate of the cost of the Millstone III nuclear power plant by $940 million, to $3.54 billion.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to June 27
description: B-After a tax credit of $272,000

title: MISSILE DEPLOYMENT AND ECONOMICS DOMINATE DUTCH ELECTION
description: The Dutch choose a new Parliament Wednesday in an election dominated by economic issues and a major dispute over nuclear missile deployment.

title:
DISCOVERIES;
1. Double-Duty Bags
description: Paula Lippman sees no reason why the garment bags travelers carry on planes should be made of leather or plastic and come in somber colors. The ones she makes are of geometric or floral-patterned cottons and serve equally well for storing clothes in a closet. Mrs. Lippman's garment bag is 48 inches long (it accommodates an evening dress) and has handles placed so that when the bag is folded in half, it looks like a tote bag. It can be ordered from Paula Lippman, 16 Lewis Drive, Maplewood, N.J. 07040 (telephone 201-762-7638), for $35, plus $2.50 shipping.

title: GUATEMALA TRAVEL CAUTION EASED
description: The State Department has modified its warning to Americans traveling to Guatemala, recognizing that violence has been reduced since Gen. Efrain Rios Montt came to power last March, officials said today.

title: Boss's Words Hurt the Cosmos
description: Some of the Cosmos felt a nasty ringing in their ears when they flew west last night for the second game of their semifinal series with San Diego. It wasn't the altitude.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are perilously near to a new international anarchy. I believe we are at present embarked on an exceedingly dangerous course, one symptom of which is the crisis in the multinational approach to international affairs and the concommitant erosion of the authority and status of world and regional intergovernmental institutions.''

title: DEMOCRATS PICK JULIA TASHJIAN IN CONNECTICUT
description: Julia H. Tashjian of Windsor tonight narrowly won the Democratic nomination for Secretary of the State in the only statewide contest in Connecticut's primary elections.

title: People
description: * Donna J. Ashe has been appointed director of public relations for the Water Quality Association, Lombard, Ill.

title: GERALD ELSE, GREEK-LATIN SCHOLAR
description: Gerald F. Else, a professor emeritus of Greek and Latin at the University of Michigan, died Monday at Chapel Hill, N.C., where he lived. He was 74 years old.

title: Cosmetics Authority Is Burned in Accident
description: Princess Marcella Borghese, founder of the cosmetics company that bears her name, was severely burned in an accident at her son's country home in Southampton, L.I., a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Careers; Weighty Job of Chief Executive
description: FOR a chief executive officer, the climb to the top is difficult and the tenure is short - an average five or six years, according to the latest study by the Conference Board, an independent, businesssupported research organization.

title: British Ship Contract
description: State-owned British Shipbuilders said today that its Sunderland Shipbuilders division had won an order to build a 44,250-deadweight-ton open-type bulk carrier for Transportacion Maritima Mexicana S.A. Delivery is scheduled for autumn 1984, and industrial sources said the contract is worth more than 20 million.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 24
FOOD NOTES
description: Selective Eating Habits

title: JUST A FRIENDLY SHINDIG
description: If you didn't know better, you might think the Begin Government of Israel hates President Reagan's plan for a Middle East settlement. I didn't know better until I talked to Jones of the State Department.

title: Massey Offers New Debt Plan
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. may be close to reaching an agreement on a second refinancing plan it is offering its bankers, industry sources said today.

title: LEGISLATORS SAY PUBLIC IS RESISTANT TO SHARP RISE IN MILITARY SPENDING
description: Members of Congress, returning from the late summer recess and facing a final legislative push before the election campaign, say they have found the public mildly encouraged by recent economic news but more resistant than previously to large increases in military spending.

title: Roblin Debt Load
description: Roblin Industries, a metals fabricator, said it had advised its banks that it was unable to continue to pay interest on its debts. It said it was discussing restructuring the debts with the banks, the Marine Midland Bank, Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan.

title: GETTING A PLACE IN THE LISTINGS
description: If you conduct cooking classes or run a cooking school and would like to be included in future listings, write to Cooking Schools, in care of The Living Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: NEW YORK FIREFIGHTERS EXAMS
description: COMPARING THE OLD AND NEW

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Maize-Products Company, Stamford, Conn., has appointed George M. Brunner vice president, operations services.

title: FEW SIGNS OF ANY STEEL UPTURN SEEN
description: When the steel industry failed to negotiate a new contract with the United Steelworkers of America in July, some steel executives warned of dire consequences. But rather than the huge layoffs or plant closings that some predicted, the steel industry continues to bleed slowly.

title: POP: SKA REVIVAL HITS GROOVE
description: THE English Beat, a septet that appeared at the Peppermint Lounge on Monday and Tuesday, may be the pre-eminent dance band to emerge from the recent English ska revival, and the group has gained a loyal following.

title: CBS VIETNAM TAPING PUT OFF
description: CBS News has postponed ''Counting the Enemy in Vietnam,'' a program scheduled for Sept. 15 that was intended as a follow-up to ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception,'' which encountered criticism after it ran in January.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am fond of what is known as hearts of palm and have only eaten them out of a can. I am curious to know their origin. My mother insists that they are part of an artichoke plant. Can you tell me what they are?

title: THE GUIDE TO NEW YORK COOKING SCHOOLS: WHERE TO LOOK TO LEARN NEW CUISINES
description: The cooking schools listed on these pages were reviewed by Moira Hodgson and Bryan Miller. Judgments are based on the personality of the teacher and his or her knowledge of the subject, and the quality of the ingredients, kitchen and equipment used. Most of the classes were visited within the last two years. Alliance Fran,caise, 22 East 60th Street; 355-6100, ext. 464. Courses: Nouvelle Cuisine.
