Instructors: Marina de Brantes, Chris- topher Idone, Hubert (Bistro d'Hu- bert, Paris), Jacques Pepin and other guest chefs. Cost: Four lessons, $160. Morning and evening classes. Classes begin: Oct. 5. Type: Demonstration and Participation. Maximum number in class: 20. This year the Alliance Fran,caise of- fers classes each month by guest chefs such as Marina de Brantes, former owner of the Coup de Fusil restau- rant; Christopher Idone of Glorious Food; Hubert, chef of Bistro d'Hubert in Paris, and the well-known chef and cookbook author Jacques Pepin. The classes have not been observed.

title: THE 1982 GUIDE TO NEW YORK COOKING SCHOOLS
description: PERHAPS nowhere else in New York is the intense interest in food and its preparation more clearly reflected than in the city's many cooking schools, which offer students - be they beginners, accomplished amateurs or even professionals - an enormously diverse choice of techniques and cuisines. Classes are offered in French, Italian, Japanese, Chinese, Indian and even English cooking, as well as in more specialized areas, such as macrobiotic foods, bread- and cake-making, puff pastry, pizza and pasta dishes and the uses of chocolate.

title: DIGITAL RECORDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Exit: Fireman, Seaman Enter: Firefighter, Mariner

title: PLAYS
description: Although Herschel Walker's presence had nothing to do with the outcome of the Georgia-Clemson game Monday night, it did demonstrate the psychological impact the all-America halfback could have on a game.

title: OF NEWS
description: The elements of the story, first reported by CBS News the evening of June 30, were undeniably sensational. Federal law-enforcement officials, CBS News said, were investigating allegations that several unidentified Congressman had engaged in homosexual activity with teen-age Congressional pages. Two former pages, interviewed on camera in silhouette, detailed their accusations.

title: 13 More Are Accused As Anti-Marcos Plotters
description: The Philippine Government charged 13 more people today with plotting a rebellion during President Ferdinand E. Marcos's visit to the United States next week.

title: Chrysler Purchase
description: The Chrysler Corporation, in a step aimed at strengthening its dealer network, said its directors had approved the repurchase of ABKO Properties in a step that would give it control of the long-term leases of 446 dealerships.

title: RANGER VETERANS FIT AGAIN
description: The New York Ranger veterans are not required to report to training camp until next Sunday, but 10 of them, including Ulf Nilsson, Anders Hedberg and John Davidson, worked for more than an hour on their own today at the team's training facility here.

title: Crane Accident Is Basis of Lawsuit
description: A lawsuit for $50 million was filed yesterday in connection with the death in July of a pedestrian who was killed by falling debris following a crane accident on the roof of an office building at 53d Street and Madison Avenue.

title: POLICE ARREST 3 WHO HAD FLED QUEENS CENTER
description: Three of the 10 convicts who escaped from a medium-security detention center in Queens late Monday night had been returned to custody by yesterday evening.

title: BILL RATES ARE LITTLE CHANGED
description: The Treasury sold new three- and six-month bills yesterday at average rates of 8.565 percent and 9.605 percent, respectively, little changed from last Monday's auction, when average rates were 8.604 percent for three-month bills and 9.746 percent for six-month bills.

title: GALLO DROPS A GRAPE VARIETY
description: The Gallo Winery has announced that, for the first time, it will buy no Thompson seedless grapes this year. The move has sharply depressed the market for the variety.

title: DIGGING BENEATH THE PIPELINE AFFAIR
description: The great Siberian natural-gas pipeline affair seems to be coming to an end not with a bang but a whimper. The Administration has begun to trim back on the penalties to be applied to the European companies that have violated the President's sanctions. In return, European governments appear ready to offer some token compensation, probably by cutting back on credits to the Soviet Union. The alliance has been saved.

title: POLAND LINKS TERRORISTS TO SOLIDARITY
description: The official Polish press organizations have begun a campaign to link the seizure of the Polish Embassy in Bern to the suspended Solidarity union and to suggest that the underground is turning to violence.

title: NO NEED FOR ADVOCATES
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER HOCKEY, LIFE WAS TOO DIFFICULT
description: His body and talents faltered, and there came a time when there was no alternative to retirement. In this way, he was like other pro athletes. The difference was that Larry Mickey, driven by personal problems stemming largely from the loss of his career as a hockey player and coach, ultimately killed himself.

title: REPORTER WHO REFUSED TO TESTIFY FREED AS SENTENCE IS COMMUTED
description: Saying ''I'd do it again,'' a newspaper reporter was freed from jail today when his contempt sentence was commuted after he served eight days for refusing to testify at a murder trial.

title: No Headline
description: P.L.O. SHOWS CAPTURED ISRAELIS

title: THE QUARTERBACK REVISITED
description: It was nice of the quarterback to cooperate with the columnist. He did it live, and he did it on tape, Saturday night and Sunday morning, as if he knew I might watch, as I have been watching him for 20 years, most of them problematical.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ANCIENT BUT STILL USEFUL
description: BEFORE the days of food processors, blenders and electric grinders there was a rudimentary but effective culinary tool that performed the chores of all three - admittedly with considerably more elbow grease. The mortar and pestle, though neolithic in its simplicity, is still valuable in modern kitchens.

title: 2 CHURCHES PLAN JOINT COMMUNION
description: Lutherans in the United States and Canada plan to establish communion fellowship with Episcopalians even though they are not in full agreement on some points of church doctrine.

title: Atlantic City Fire Burns 5 Buildings
description: Five downtown buildings, including the well-known Jockey Club, were destroyed by a suspicious fire early today, authorities said.

title: E.T. Howard Affiliates With Hicks & Greist
description: The E.T. Howard Company and Hicks & Greist Inc. have formed an affiliation, with the E.T. Howard staff moving into available office space at Hicks & Greist.

title: Advertising; Increased Testing Is Urged
description: BESIDES being professor of marketing at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, Leonard M. Lodish is a co-owner of Management Decision Systems, a concern that provides technology for facilitating corporate decision-making in the realms of marketing, finance and corporate strategy.

title: SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1981 revs figures have been restated; B-Included a gain of $7.3 million from sale of company's gas processing business

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Editor as Conductor

title: VENEZIA HAS HEARING TO RETAIN LICENSE
description: Michael Venezia argued yesterday that his jockey's license should not be revoked for failing to report a bribe offer to fix a horse race. He said that the offer was merely idle conversation and that he did not construe it as an attempted bribe.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: The latest period results restated for F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: ORIOLES CAPTURE 10TH IN A ROW
description: The surging Baltimore Orioles rolled to their 10th straight victory last night, a 7-2 decision over the Yankees, as Mike Flanagan won his fifth game in a row while Mike Morgan was pounded off the mound in the fourth inning.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Democrats Accuse

title: PLANE MAKERS PROTEST BRAZIL IMPORT
description: American makers of commuter aircraft have squared off against a Brazilian manufacturer, saying that they will charge before the International Trade Commission on Wednesday that the Brazilian Government unfairly subsidizes a popular 18-seat turboprop plane for export to the United States.

title: WHEN THE WINNERS WRITE HISTORY BOOKS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE REAL WORLD MEETS THE ARTISTS' WORLD
description: PARIS ONE of the best shows here is free, and it runs all day long. It is in the big plaza that fronts the Centre Pompidou, the modern-art museum that is better known as the Beaubourg. Young people flock here to perform and to listen; it is their home away from home.

title: POSSIBLE SCHOOL STRIKES SEEN IN SOME AREAS NEAR NEW YORK
description: New York and New Jersey faced the threat of teacher strikes in a handful of districts as schools began reopening yesterday, while for the third straight year Connecticut will have no strikes.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: RONALD was an 18-year-old high-school graduate when he noticed the peculiar symptoms: a spasm in one heel and paralysis of the left cheek. After a series of neurological tests, doctors at the University of Minnesota concluded that he had multiple sclerosis. Despite periodic flare-ups that sometimes required hospitalization, Ronald managed to complete a college degree in psychology and develop expertise as a social worker. He met a fellow student who became his wife and mother of their three sons.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: RECENTLY in this space Henry Monroe of Manhattan unveiled the result of his creative labors: a batch of those venerable amusements, Tom Swifties. These are, of course, mock quotations from the Tom Swift books that have been twisted with a punning attribution. Among his swifter efforts were '' 'I don't know how we derailed,' the motorman said distractedly,'' and '' 'Call the plumber,' he said succinctly.''

title: VIEWS CLASH ON WORLD BANK AGENCY
description: Rats seem far removed from the chandeliers, cocktails and ice statues draped with seafood that mark the meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank being held here. But rats play a supporting role in one of the organizations' major debates.

title: EAST GERMANS WIN 3 GOLDS AT ATHENS
description: East German athletes won three of the five gold medals awarded at the European track and field championships today, and Sebastian Coe and Daley Thompson of Britain put themselves into position to win gold medals Wednesday.

title: DOW FALLS BY 10.85 TO 914.28
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in the second biggest decline since the start of the current rally in mid-August as investors sold to realize profits.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rejuvenation at the Waldorf

title: Armory to Become Apartment Project
description: Officials have received final approval from a Federal agency that will allow them to start converting the White Plains Armory into 52 apartments for the elderly and small families.

title: POPE POSTPONES VISIT TO SPAIN UNTIL AFTER OCTOBER ELECTIONS
description: Pope John Paul II has postponed his visit to Spain until after the country's Oct. 28 elections to avoid interfering in the political campaigning, the Vatican announced today.

title: BOEING 767: A CAUTIOUS DEBUT
description: The first commercial flight of Boeing's 767, United Airlines Flight 1767 from Chicago to Denver, will be made on Wednesday with a champagne christening and appropriate festivities. But because of the industry's generally poor financial condition and other factors, such as weakening oil prices and European competition, the 767 is being introduced into an atmosphere filled more with uncertainty than proud anticipation.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Jim Palmer, who has not lost in his last 11 decisions, will pitch for the Orioles.

title: ADAM BENJAMIN, CONGRESSMAN, DIES
description: Representative Adam Benjamin Jr., a Democratic member of Congress from Indiana since 1977, died over the Labor Day weekend at his Washington apartment, his office said today. He was 47 years old.

title: UConn Soccer Star
description: Pedro DeBrito, a forward with the Tampa Bay Rowdies, was voted rookie of the year in balloting by the players of the North American Soccer League. He is the second straight rookie of the year from the University of Connecticut, following Joe Morrone, who now plays for the San Jose Earthquakes.

title: Mr. Begin Protests Too Much
description: Though scorned in Jerusalem, President Reagan's bid for an Arab-Israeli deal on the West Bank is having the desired effects. The least belligerent Arabs are trying to compose a favorable response. Israel's Labor party has staked its future on the plan. American lobbyists for Israel welcome it. And a few Palestinians seem interested. In diplomacy, that's not a bad week's work.

title: SCREEN: WAR IN EL SALVADOR
description: ''DECISION TO WIN'' and ''El Morazan,'' which open today at the Film Forum, are two documentaries made by Cero a la Izquierda, a collective of Salvadoran film makers and journalists sympathetic to the anti-Government rebels there. The films are being made available for release in this country to win support for the Farabundo Marti Front for National Liberation.

title: Transit Report
description: CONRAIL: All 29 Hudson Line trains ran for the morning rush hour, but six were delayed, the longest for 20 minutes, by equipment or signal problems. All 45 trains on the Harlem Line ran, but nine were late.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1982; Companies
description: United Technologies pitched in to help Martin Marietta in its struggle to take over Bendix. United told Bendix stockholders it would buy their shares for a total of $1.5 billion. Bendix had precipitated an acquisition battle by bidding for Martin Marietta, which then countered with an offer of its own for Bendix. (Page A1.)

title: Snap-On Tools
description: The Snap-On Tools Corporation of Kenosha, Wis., a maker of hand tools, said it would suspend manufacturing operations for the week of Sept. 13 at Kenosha, Mount Carmel, Ill., and Johnson City, Tenn., to reduce inventories. About 1,200 workers will be idled.

title: ISRAELIS PRESSING FOR PEACE TREATY WITH THE LEBANESE
description: Israel has started to press President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon to move toward negotiating a formal peace treaty as a way of guaranteeing the security of the Israeli-Lebanese border.

title: MORE PIPELINE SANCTIONS
description: The Commerce Department moved today to extend the Reagan Administration's pipeline sanctions to the subsidiaries and affiliates of a French company sanctioned last week for disregarding the American embargo.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN asked whether I prefer the small bay scallops that come from the waters near my home or the larger ocean variety, I tend to hedge. My reply is that, living on the eastern end of Long Island, I am fortunate enough to have easy access to both.

title: THREE HOMERS HELP BEAT METS
description: Jason Thompson, Mike Easler and Richie Hebner each connected for a home run with two outs in an inning as they led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 9-5 victory over the Mets tonight.

title: Lions Sims Says He Will Report
description: Billy Sims, the star running back of the Detroit Lions, said today that he has ended his contract holdout after meeting with the club owner, William Clay Ford, according to a published report.

title: Japan Aluminium Aid
description: An influential advisory body to the International Trade and Industry Ministry has given its support to a ministry plan for emergency relief measures to bail out Japan's ailing aluminium industry, Ministry officials said today. The plan recommended by the Industrial Structure Council calls for the Government to buy up about 150,000 tons of surplus primary aluminium from the domestic industry for stockpiling, they said.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
3 LUTHERAN BODIES TOTALING 5 MILION DECIDE ON MERGER
description: Three Lutheran denominations voted today to form a new church for 5.5 million members that will be the third largest Protestant denomination in the country.

title: A THEATRICAL MYSTERY: THE MISSING BALCONIES
description: THE summer's great theatrical mystery was posed in Peter Kerr's recent dispatch in this newspaper about the strange disappearance of balcony seats in Broadway theaters. It seems that some innocent theatergoers shelled out $26 for ''rear mezzanine'' tickets to ''Sophisticated Ladies'' only to discover that their seats were situated against the back wall in the Lunt-Fontanne's highest reaches - an aerie that looked suspiciously like what used to be called the balcony. Complaints were lodged with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, but Camille Ranson, house manager of the Lunt-Fontanne, gave her own explanation to Mr. Kerr.

title: Magic Marker
description: Magic Marker Industries said it was cutting its work force to 100 from 145, including previous cuts, and putting a four-day workweek into force because it expected to report a loss of about $350,000 for the six months ended Aug. 31. The company said it would need additional capital unless it reached its projections for sales and for savings from the work force cuts.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AUTHORITIES CHARGE LARCHMONT MAN FOR INVOLVEMENT IN RESCUE
description: Last Thursday night, as police officers and other emergency personnel watched from below, Edward McGuire grabbed and wrestled to safety an 18-year-old man threatening to jump from the roof of a six-story apartment building here.

title: SICILY MURDERS BRING ACCUSATIONS
description: The son of the anti-Mafia prefect murdered in Palermo on Friday charged today that the instigators of the crime were to be found in the Christian Democratic Party in Sicily.

title: Postal Financial
description: The St. Paul Companies said it had sold its Postal Financial Corporation unit of Sioux City, Iowa, to the Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest bankholding company, for $27 million. Postal Financial has more than 50 offices in 14 states and had 1981 year-end receivables of $350 million. The Federal Reserve Board approved the sale on Aug. 17.

title: Review of Disability Pensions Halted Because of Backlogs
description: The Social Security Administration has stopped sending the names of people whose eligibility for disability payments it wants reviewed to 12 states to give the states time to catch up with their backlogs, officials said today.

title: G.E. Exhibits At Machine Show
description: The General Electric Company said it was demonstrating a programmable five-axis process robot and a large seven-arm robot at the International Machine Tool Show here.

title: Chattanooga Glass To Lay Off 300
description: The Chattanooga Glass Company, citing a decline in sales of soft drinks, says it plans to shut down three of its five glass-making furnaces for about a month and temporarily lay off 300 of its 425 production workers.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Marlboro Tour Program To Play in New York City

title: Pipeline Trickle
description: W hat do Rumanian pigs, East German typewriters and Russian horses have in common? Nothing, except that they are caught up in the trickle-down spirit of the Reagan Administration's political objections to Western allies' exporting American technology for the construction of the Soviet gas pipeline.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results are pro forma and the company went public in Nov 1981

title: YANKS STOP PALMER HIT 4 HOME RUNS
description: Four home runs by the Yankees and eight innings of sparkling pitching by Jay Howell last night ended the winning streaks of the Baltimore Orioles at 10 games and of Jim Palmer at 11 games.

title: Teachers Strike In North Plainfield
description: Teachers in North Plainfield voted yesterday to strike, prompting school officials to postpone classes for 2,600 students until next Tuesday.

title: Tromson Monroe Gets Caribbean Account
description: The Department of Tourism for St. Vincent and the Grenadines, West Indies, has named Tromson Monroe Advertising as agency of record.

title: The Unlucky 49
description: There are now 49 of them in the ''Carter Class,'' three having gone back to Haiti and one having won a medical release. They are called that because, of the 1,900 Haitian migrants detained in this country, they are the only ones involved in a New York case, decided last spring by Federal District Judge Robert Carter.

title: IN A SWITCH, BLACKS ASSAIL VOTE MONITORS
description: When Federal election observers swept through the Black Belt counties of Alabama in 1966, a year after passage of the Voting Rights Act, they were embraced by blacks and met with hostility by whites. Both groups saw the Government agents as symbols of the muscle behind the tough new law.

title: No Headline
description: Braves Defeat Dodgers, 12-11

title: Addendum
description: * Scientific American magazine is increasing its advertising rates 11.2 percent, effective with the January issue. The circulation rate base of the International Edition will increase 4.8 percent, to 110,000, while the rate base of the National Edition will be 10.6 percent lower, to 550,000.

title: BLUES, FLUKE AND BONITO AVAILABLE
description: 1. MARGATE, N.J.: Offshore catches of large bluefish continue and some smaller blues are mixed with them. Atlantic bonito have appeared along the beach. Fluke fishing good two miles offshore. Barnegat, N.J.: Bluefish plentiful; weakfish along the beach and in bay. Offshore over Hudson Canyon, yellowfin and longfin tuna fishing is good. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Half-day trips for fluke and night and day trips for bluefish continue. 2. SEA BRIGHT, N.J.: Striped bass of 5 to 20 pounds being caught by surf fishermen at Sandy Hook. Snapper blues are scarce, sand porgies plentiful, and kingfish to 1 1/2 pounds have been caught. Crabbing is excellent. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Angling for bluefish and blackfish good. Fluke fishing fair; weakfish good. Freeport, L.I.: Flounder fishing good, as is offshore fluke fishing. Blackfish are starting to hit as are small sea bass. Albacore and yellowfin tuna are available in Hudson Canyon as well as a few bluefin tuna in the 100-pound class. Captree State Park, L.I.: Fluke fishing is good at the mouth of the inlet as well as large flounder. Blackfishing is improving. 3. MASTIC BEACH, L.I.: Blowfish are everywhere; large snappers are plentiful; crabbing is excellent. Shinnecock, L.I.: Fluke fishing is good; weakfish are close to the beach; mediumsized bluefish are in and near the inlet. Montauk, L.I.: Giant bluefin tuna have been frolicking a few miles southeast of Nomans Land Island; few remain off Block Island and those in 200-pound class are 12 miles south of Montauk.

title: JAZZ: BLOSSOM DEARIE
description: BY conventional standards, Blossom Dearie, the admired jazz singer who opened a three-week engagement in Michael's Pub on Tuesday, is not a great vocalist. Her wispy, little-girlish soprano with a vibrato as rapid and fluttery as the beating of a hummingbird's wings, is essentially a personality voice.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani CRY TO HEAVEN. By Anne Rice. 533 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: People
description: * Stephen C. Kopcha named executive vice president, creative director at D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: World Bank Puts an '84 Loan Fund at $3.5 Billion
description: The International Development Association, an affiliate of the World Bank that makes 50-year, interest-free loans to the poorest countries, expects to have $3.5 billion to lend in 1984, under an agreement reached today by 33 donor countries.

title: Stamp Festival Opens Tomorrow at Garden
description: More than 110 stamp dealers from around the world will gather this weekend for Stamp Festival '82 at Madison Square Garden.

title: President of Wendy's Steps Up to Chairman
description: When Robert L. Barney joined Wendy's International as president in 1971, the company consisted of only two ''Wendy's Old Fashion Hamburger'' restaurants, both in Columbus, Ohio. Now, with 2,352 units in operation worldwide, Mr. Barney traded the president's post yesterday for that of chairman. Despite the recession and a perceptible flatter growth rate for the nation's fast-food chains, he is bullish on Wendy's future.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 AIRLINES ESTABLISH SHARED PRESIDENCY
description: Continental Air Lines and Texas International Airlines yesterday announced the creation of an office of the president to facilitate the integration of the two airlines. Texas International won control of the bigger Continental late last year after an acrimonious takeover battle.

title: MEXICAN EXPORT LIMITS APPARENTLY UNENFORCED
description: The Mexican Government imposed restrictions today to keep visitors from the United States from cleaning out Mexican stores in the wake of the peso's sharp fall, but there was no sign the law was being enforced.

title: Blacks End a Boycott Of Arkansas School
description: About 200 black pupils returned to public school today, ending a boycott of two and a half weeks that began after a white youth was accused of fatally stabbing a 12-yearold black classmate.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM RISES SHARPLY ON GROWTH OF DIETING CENTERS
description: Harold Katz's mother used to spend $60 a week on diet doctors, weight-loss pills and lo-cal desserts - all to no avail. ''She had the yo-yo syndrome,'' Mr. Katz said, and her weight always bounced back.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISE SLOWS
description: Cautious American consumers took on only $570 million more in installment debt than they paid off in July, the smallest debt increase since February, Government figures showed today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH many people are reluctant to tackle any kind of electrical repairs because they seem too mysterious (or dangerous), there is one that anyone can safely try: fixing a broken doorbell or chime.

title: SUNNY PASSENGERS AND CLOUDY ECONOMY USHER IN BOEING'S 767
description: The Boeing 767, the first of a new generation of airliners developed to counter rising costs with high-technology efficiency, opened regular passenger service today on a United Airlines run from Chicago to Denver.

title: N.H.L. Acts On Violence
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors voted unanimously today to make the hitting of game officials punishable by an automatic 20-game suspension.

title: Thermoplastics
description: The American Thermoplastics Corporation of Houston, a subsidiary of the Phillips Petroleum Company, said it would close its Calumet City, Ill., plant and its Houston sales office, idling 52 employees. The company will withdraw in October as a supplier of color concentrates to the plastics industry, because of poor financial performance and increased operating costs. The company said it would attempt to sell the concentrate business.

title: A New College Segregation
description: Bargain-rate public universities and colleges can thank the Reagan Administration's reductions in student aid for the lively increase in their enrollment. But this is not just a case of the affluent preferring not to spend more of their own money. There is a disturbing decline in the number of low-and moderate-income students at private colleges. The nation is unwittingly moving toward a caste system, with private institutions serving the wealthy and only a token number of the poor.

title: CARDS 1, EXPOS 0
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Keith Hernandez tripled in the only run in the third, and Bob Forsch scattered eight hits.

title: AND NOW A TRADE GROUP TO PROMOTE THE CLASSICS
description: AS a proud and elitist art form, classical music might not seem to need an aggressive trade organization to lobby for its interests. But Ira Moss, Marvin Saines and Gerald Widoff think differently, and this afternoon at 5:30 they will be hosts of the first public meeting of their newly formed Association for Classical Music. The meeting will be in Merkin Hall of the Abraham Goodman House, a well-known recital hall for classical music at 129 West 67th Street. Martin Bookspan will be master of ceremonies.

title: REAGAN OUTLINES HIS STAND ON JEWISH SETTLEMENTS
description: The United States has told Israel and Arab countries privately that although it wants a freeze on new Israeli settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, it will oppose any Arab efforts to dismantle the existing Jewish settlements.

title: 2 Steelers Hurt
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers will be without their two top 1982 draft choices, Walter Abercrombie, a running back, and John Meyer, a defensive tackle, for at least the first month of the season. Both were placed on the four-week injured-reserve list. Abercrombie, the top choice, suffered a knee injury in the second exhibition game, and Meyer, the No.2 pick, injured his knee in the first week of practice and missed three exhibition games.

title: TEXT OF 'TALKING POINTS' SENT TO BEGIN BY PRESIDENT
description: Following is the text of what Administration officials called talking points accompanying a letter sent last week by President Reagan to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. The same points were presented to Arab governments as a prelude to Mr. Reagan's peace proposals. General Principles

title: 2 Officers Suing Leader of 'Angels'
description: Attorneys for two police officers involved in the shooting of a member of the Guardian Angels last December filed suit in Federal Court today charging that the leader of the group had slandered the officers by calling the shooting ''cold-blooded murder'' and by continued verbal attacks.

title: STOCKS UP AS VOLUME CLIMBS
description: The stock market tried to resume its late summer rally yesterday after Tuesday's sharp sell-off but managed to close with only small gains in very heavy trading.

title: TO STOP THOSE WHO 'DEAL NEFARIOUSLY WITH THE PAST'
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemical Warfare Reported in Afghanistan
description: A Soviet soldier captured by Afghan guerrillas has said Soviet soldiers are using lethal chemical weapons against guerrillas in Afghanistan, according to a tape-recorded interview supplied to reporters.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Learning About Disaster

title: HOME BEAT
description: THIS seems to be the month for Americana and the Museum of American Folk Art. On Sept. 15, the museum's gift shop moves to larger quarters at 55 West 53d Street, decorated by Christina Smyth and Rubens Teles.

title: Ruling in Lawmaker's Death
description: Representative Adam Benjamin Jr., the 47-year-old Indiana Democrat whose body was found in his Capitol Hill apartment Tuesday, died of heart disease, the District of Columbia medical examiner's office ruled today.

title: KOCH IS FOCUS OF OPPONENTS DURING DEBATES
description: Mayor Koch was criticized sharply -in person by his Democratic opponent for Governor, in his absence by the two Republican candidates - during consecutive radio debates yesterday.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Student Sponge Project Set As Study of Healing in Space
description: An 18-year-old biology student hopes to gain insight into the healing process in space when the shuttle Columbia carries 18 samples of Florida Gulf Coast sponges on its next mission in November.

title: MAJOR EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAVITS SORTS OUT PAGES OF PAST FOR HISTORIANS
description: Cartons, more than 2,000 of them, jam the floor-to-ceiling shelves in the climate-controlled reading room; dozens more are piled up in the hallway near the private elevator. They contain letters, press releases, memorandums - so many of the things that helped fill the pages of Jacob K. Javits's 22 years in the United States Senate.

title: Betsy Bloomingdale Asks Dismissal of Suit
description: Betsy Bloomingdale asked a judge today to dismiss a $10 million suit a former model filed against her and her late husband, Alfred, saying that the extramarital affair between Mr. Bloomingdale and the women had been based on sexual relations alone.

title: 'SOMEONE, SOMEWHERE WILL BE KILLED BY THE STATE ERRONEOUSLY'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEMICAL TO OFFER BANKING AT HOME
description: Chemical Bank, in one of the first announcements of its kind, said yesterday that it would introduce a service that would allow its customers in the New York area to bank at home using personal computers.

title: UNCLOGGING 'HOT SPOTS' IN TRAFFIC
description: If you ask Samuel I. Schwartz about ''hot spots'' around town, he will not tell you where you can go to boogie all night. Hot spots to Mr. Schwartz are places where motorists and car engines get overheated in heavy New York City traffic.

title: HARRIED SOVIET RIGHTS UNIT DISBANDS
description: A group of Soviet dissidents that monitored Soviet violations of human rights announced today that it was disbanding because of arrests and deportations.

title: ARCHITECTS TURN TO INTERIORS
description: WHEN the economy slides from a peak to a valley, architects as a profession are among the first to reach the canyon floor. Versatility is the key to survival in this business, especially among small firms and individual practitioners who may find themselves designing a school one day and a kitchen addition the next. With the economy in one of its deepest recessions in decades, many architects are turning to small-scale interior renovation work as a means of weathering the storm.

title: Rangers Sign Bothwell
description: The Rangers signed Tim Bothwell, a 27-year-old defenseman, to a multiyear contract. The upcoming season will be Bothwell's fifth with the Rangers, but he has played only 52 games for them, because he was in the minor leagues or was injured.

title: PLAY
description: N ormally, baseball players arrive at the parks at least three hours before game time. But Jason Thompson of the Pittsburgh Pirates had a good excuse for arriving at Three Rivers Stadium only a halfhour before the game with the Mets Tuesday night. His wife, Bernadette, had just given birth to their first child, a boy.

title: B'NAI B'RITH PRAISES REAGAN'S PLAN FOR SETTLING PALESTINIAN PROBLEM
description: B'nai B'rith, the American Jewish service organization, praised President Reagan's plan for the Middle East today and said it was ''worthy of consideration.''

title: CALENDAR: ANTIQUES AND A FALL FESTIVAL
description: Stamford Antiques Fair, Yachthaven marina, West Stamford, Conn., 203- 359-4500.

title: BROWN FAILS TO GAIN ON RIVAL IN CALIFORNIA RACE FOR SENATE
description: With the general election two months away, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has failed to cut into the lead of Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego in their race for the United States Senate, Mervin D. Field, director of the California Poll, said today.

title: A RUSH TO BANKRUPTCY
description: To the Editor:

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes gains from property dispositions of $1,390,000 or 23 cents a shr forthe latest qr and $1,526,000 or 37 cents a shr for the earlier period

title: LEASE FOR U.S. OPEN
description: W hile John McEnroe's serves and Chris Evert Lloyd's forehands were evoking sighs of envy that fluttered through the grandstand at the U.S. Open like breezes rippling through long grass, the city was quietly signing a deal that should bring cheer to the hearts of tennis lovers.

title: Top Honduran General Denies Seeking War With Nicaragua
description: Gen. Gustavo Alvarez, the head of the armed forces, has denied charges that he is trying to provoke a conflict with Nicaragua.

title: LIDDY'S BOOK PROFITS AND LECTURE INCOME HELD TO PAY OLD FINE
description: Federal prosecutors obtained a court order today seizing the book, movie and lecture profits of G. Gordon Liddy to try to force him to pay a fine imposed in 1973 as part of his punishment for his role in the Watergate burglary and conspiracy.

title: Advertising; Selecting Symbol for Insurance
description: BACK when Manhattan-born Bill Giles, now vice president and group creative director at Grey Advertising, was an English major at Notre Dame, he remembers: ''They had all kinds of trees out there. A lot of snow and a lot of oaks.''

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: * Buckbee Mears Co. said it intended to acquire Cirtel Inc., a privately held manufacturer of rigid and flexible circuits for military and aerospace markets; terms were not dislosed.

title: Article 138538 -- No Title
description: A gift of $430,000 for a training program to improve the leadership skills of principals in the city's 110 high schools will be announced today by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qrt to July 31
ROOM SCENTS ARE ABOUT TO BLOSSOM
description: IF designer names can sell blue jeans, perfume and bed linens, why not fragrances for the home? Companies as diverse as Celebrity, which makes travel accessories, and Mikasa, which makes tableware, believe they can. Mikasa brought out a line of home fragrances by Larry Laslo in May, and Celebrity is introducing a line by Diane Love next month.

title: Sony's Leader Brings Diverse Interests to Job
description: Norio Ohga, the new president of the Sony Corporation, is known as a broad-gauge executive with diverse interests and a managerial style that attends more to overall strategy than to fine details.

title: DWIGHT STUART MARRIES MARIA OSMENA
description: Maria Victoria (Minnie) Osmena, granddaughter of the late Sergio Osmena, former president of the Philippines, was married in Beverly Hills, Calif., Sept. 2 to Dwight Lyman Stuart, president of the Carnation Company. Judge Charles H. Older of the Superior Court of Los Angeles County performed the ceremony at the couple's new home.

title: MARION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WALLACE WINS A THIRD OF BLACK VOTE IN CAPTURING SPOT IN PRIMARY RUNOFF
description: George C. Wallace gained the support of about one-third of the black voters in Tuesday's primary election, according to various analyses today, but this unaccustomed support still left him facing a runoff election for the Democratic nomination for a fourth term as Governor of Alabama.

title: COLLEGE PRESERVING U.S. POLES' HERITAGE
description: Fall classes began Tuesday at Alliance College, a school of 300 students established to preserve Polish culture.

title: U.S. Ruled Not Liable In Military Cancer Case
description: A Federal District Court today dismissed a suit against the Government brought by a woman who asserted that her husband died of cancer caused by exposure to an atomic bomb test in the Pacific.

title: POLISH EXILES SAY TERRORISTS ARE A MYSTERY
description: While Poland's martial-law Government charges that the seizure of the Polish Embassy here was inspired by the suspended Solidarity trade union, the identity and the motives of the four gunmen who continue to hold five Polish diplomats hostage remain unclear.

title: WRAPPING FURNITURE IN MUSLIN AND CORD
description: The first time Antonio Morello wrapped furniture in yards of cloth for a party, in 1968, the aim was to disguise ugly pieces that belonged to a friend. He got the idea from his grandmother, who covered her furniture elaborately every summer to protect it from the sun. Mr. Morello's environments for parties are created by using white muslin tied with quarter-inch cotton cord, but he has also had more luxurious commissions involving silk fabric tied with gold cord.

title: Malone Offer Held Illegal
description: The Philadelphia 76ers were accused by the National Basketball Association and the Houston Rockets of making illegal provisions in the offer sheet signed by the center Moses Malone.

title: WHAT WYMAN FACES AS HEAD OF CBS
description: Among the many challenges that Thomas H. Wyman faced when he was named president and chief executive officer of CBS Inc. 28 months ago, the most daunting may have been just holding on to his job: Over the previous eight years, CBS's chairman, William S. Paley, had forced the resignation of at least three executives whom he had selected as heirs apparent.

title: Market Place; Getting China To Pay Debts
description: A Federal court in Alabama sent a sobering message last week to g overnments in default on bonds owned by Americans. Ruling in a classa ction brought against China in 1979, Judge U.W. Clemon of the D istrict Court, Northern District of Alabama, held that China must r etire at face amount bonds issued 71 years ago. China has been in d efault on the bonds since 1930. The judge also ruled that interest m ust be paid up to the date of payment.

title: A Tough Year for Pension Funds
description: Since Comptroller Edward Regan has full responsibility for investing New York State's pension funds, those who would oppose his bid for re-election point with glee to his 1981 money management record. They observe that in a year when the prime rate hit 21 percent, the Regan funds yielded only 4.8 percent, one-third of their 1980 rate. On close examination, however, Mr. Regan's investment record seems perfectly defensible.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHINA EASES STAND ON U.S. AND SOVIET
description: The Chinese Communist Party has formally dropped from its constitution disparaging characterizations of the United States and the Soviet Union as superpowers that bully weaker nations.

title: News Analysis
description: Peru now faces a question vital to fragile democracies: how to combat a terrorist insurgency without violating the tenets of its own democracy, including the protection of human rights. The answer may well determine the future of the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry.

title: STUDY AT PUBLIC COLLEGES FINDS AID KEEPS MANY FROM DROPPING OUT
description: A typical student at a public college or university who receives some form of Federal aid could not attend college without the aid, according to the first major study of student aid at public institutions of higher learning.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 1903-04 Films To Be Shown Again

title: Briefs On the Arts Mercantile Library Adding Writers' Studio
description: The Merc - the Mercantile Library, at 17 East 47th Street - a privately endowed lending institution that was founded in 1820 and which has been used ever since as both a neighborhood and commercial library - is adding a new service to its other programs: a writers' studio.

title: REVISION OF LAW ON SPECIAL PROSECUTORS IS BACKED
description: Leon Silverman, the special prosecutor investigating charges of corruption against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, thought his mission was fulfilled last June when he reported finding no evidence to justify charges against Mr Donovan. Within a month, however, fresh allegations required him to start up again. Now he says, ''I am trying to complete it at the earliest possible moment but cannot predict with accuracy when it will end.''

title: U.S. BILLS LEAD RATE DECLINE
description: Interest rates declined yesterday as the credit markets continued to be buffeted by reports of loan defaults. The steepest rate declines were in the Treasury bill market, where the new three-month issue fell nearly half a percentage point, to 8.10 percent.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JAZZ: QUARTET OF BUCK HILL
description: BUCK HILL earns a living at the Post Office in Washington and spends his vacations on bandstands as a tough, bluesy tenor saxophonist. He is leading a quartet at Sweet Basil through Saturday that includes the pianist Kenny Barron, the bassist Buster Williams and the drummer Billy Hart.

title: THREE ARRAIGNED IN NEW YORK IN RITUALISTIC FLORIDA SLAYING
description: Two men and a teen-age boy were arraigned last evening in Manhattan Criminal Court on a fugitive warrant charging them with first-degree murder in the slaying of a University of Florida professor last weekend.

title: CITICORP'S COAST BID CRITICIZED
description: Citicorp's attempt to break into consumer banking in California through the purchase of a major savings and loan association was sharply criticized today by consumer groups and representatives of the thrift industry in hearings at the Federal Reserve.

title: Female Touch
description: Indisputably, money has become a major measuring stick of a sport or an athlete's success. The slogan, ''You've come a long way, baby,'' began to signify more than just a cigarette soft-sell when Virginia Slims began underwriting the women's tennis tour with hefty prize money.

title: Not That Many Trees
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: While your article on the garden, park and house at Les Bois des Moutiers (''Distinctively English Garden on a Norman Estate,'' Aug. 19) was accurate in all respects, there was a superlative error. We now dearly fear the descent of American dendrologists, notebook and pencil carefully in hand, who will want to count our ''5,000 species of trees.''

title: Akzona Takeover Final
description: Akzona Inc. said today that its shareholders had approved Akzo N.V.'s purchase of the 34 percent of Akzona that the Dutch company did not already own, at $16.25 a share. As a result, Akzona is wholly owned by Akzo.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LED INDIA'S STATE OF KASHMIR
description: Sheik Mohammad Abdullah, known as the Lion of Kashmir, died today after a long illness, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. He was 76 years old.

title: Tracor Merger Off
description: Tracor Inc. said today that it had ended talks on the proposed acquisition of the Systems Engineering Associates Corporation. The two companies had announced the signing of a letter of intent for the acquisition on June 28.

title: Jackson's Fan Bonus
description: Now that the California Angels have surpassed the 2.4-million attendance mark, Reggie Jackson will be more interested in the last line of the Angels' box scores, the one that gives the attendance figures. The four-year, $3.6 million contract that Jackson signed included a clause that would give him 50 cents for each person over 2.4 million that the Angels drew.

title: WATT RUNS INTO CRITICISM OF OFFSHORE LEASING PLAN
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt presented his five-year plan for offshore drilling of oil and gas on the outer continental shelf to a Senate subcommittee today and was immediately accused of ignoring environmental concerns.

title: SPRINKEL SEES A COMPROMISE ON THE FUND
description: The United States expects to reach a compromise agreement with other industrial nations by next April on an increase in the International Monetary Fund's available lending pool, a top American monetary official said today.

title: 3d Boat to Be Built For Conner Group
description: Dennis Conner, the America's Cup defending helmsman, announced today his group will build a third new 12-Meter yacht for the Cup defense next summer.

title: Greyhound Cuts Executive Posts
description: Greyhound Lines said it was eliminating 21 executive positions in a move aimed at saving about $1 million a year because fewer people are riding busses.

title: 4 Named to Science Board
description: President Reagan said today he would nominate four persons to the National Science Board. They are Charles E. Hess of the University of California at Davis, John H. Moore of the Hoover Institution, Norman C. Rasmussen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Roland W. Schmitt of the General Electric Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All I want to do is raise my right hand to Mayor Koch and take that oath to be a New York City firefighter.'' - Katrina Cannon. (A1:3.)

title: JEFFREY D. SIMON
description: Jeffrey D. Simon, a founding partner of the law firm of Quasha, Richter & Simon in Manhattan, died Sunday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 38 years old.

title: Gladys M. Pears, 81, a Model For Rockwell in 20's and 30's
description: Gladys M. Peare, one of Norman Rockwell's favorite models whose likeness appeared on many of his magazine covers in the 1920's and 30's, has died following a lengthy illness.

title: WENDERS FILM WINS AT VENICE FESTIVAL
description: A West German film described by its director as ''a horror-comedy'' won the Venice Film Festival's top prize today, the second straight year that the prize has gone to a West German movie.

title: JERSEY BUS COMPANY AND STRIKING WORKERS APPROACH AN AGREEMENT
description: New Jersey's DeCamp Bus Company and its striking drivers and mechanics were reported last night to be close to an agreement, with only a few issues still to be settled.

title: Ford Denies Plant Is Closing
description: The Ford Motor Company has no definite plans to close its 64-year-old Dearborn, Mich., assembly plant although the plant has come under ''routine'' scrutiny as the auto maker seeks to become more efficient, Derwood Haines, a company spokesman, said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OLD AMSTERDAM

title: WARMED-UP MINIMAL: SPARE BUT STYLISH
description: IN the late 1960's and early 70's the clean, open spaces, the white walls, sleek built-ins and industrial carpeting of minimalist design were the sine qua non of contemporary interiors. Then postmodernism came along, with its pastel hues and its vocabulary of classical architecture. Now, with postmodernism losing much of its novelty, some architects and designers are bringing back minimalist ideas, but in a slightly altered form.

title: Accounts
description: * The Hermark and Lancaster USA, two divisions of Beecham Ltd., to Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner Inc.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT TO APPEAL AIRBAG RULING
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that it would appeal to the Supreme Court a lower court's ruling requiring airbags or automatic seat belts on new automobiles starting next year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Surgery for Rep. Weiss

title: French Mine to Close
description: Societe Miniere et Metallurgique de Penarroya is to close its lead, zinc and silver mine at Largentiere, France, before the end of the year, a company spokesman said today. The mine was opened in 1962 and the company originally intended to operate it for 15 years, he said, but exploitable reserves have run out, making the mine uneconomic. In 1981 the mine produced 15,000 metric tons of lead, 1,700 tons of zinc and about 30 tons of silver.

title:
PLAYER;
Pam Shriver Keeps Happiness Inside
description: NO one enjoys special status on the practice courts. So Pam Shriver w as just another player when she took her turn on Court 11 late y esterday afternoon. It was the spectators, though, who seemed more i nterested in her than usual. A small crowd gathered to watch Miss S hriver exchange forehands and laughs with Fred Stolle and her coach,D on Candy. And when she was finished, a few even asked her for an a utograph.

title: HABIB'S RIGHT-HAND MAN
description: At airports in the Middle East, Morris Draper is hardly an inconspicuous figure. In a pin-stripe suit, towering over his colleagues, his white hair flowing in a wave, Mr. Draper steps quickly toward the bookstand and scoops up a half-dozen spy novels.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a pretax gain of $640,000 on the sale of property

title: Lloyd's Orders Howden Study
description: The committee of Lloyd's, London's insurance market, said today that it had instructed the Ernst & Whinney accounting group to investigate matters referred to in recent public statements concerning certain companies and individuals within Alexander Howden Group Ltd.

title: MARX 'BROTHERS,' SORT OF
description: ''I hear,'' said my Russian friend, ''that you have been playing the Internationale a lot in America this year.'' ''That's right,'' I replied. ''It's been heard in theaters from coast to coast and it almost became the theme song of the Oscar awards in Hollywood.''

title: Futures Option Deal Is Studied
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodities exchange, disclosed today that it was negotiating with the Kansas City Board of Trade to allow Chicago board members to trade options on the Kansas City exchange's Value Line stock index futures contract.

title: Sun Electric Loss
description: The Sun Electric Corporation which reported a third-quarter loss of $848,000, said it expected an improved performance in the fourth-quarter as a result of recent cost-cutting measures that were carried out. They included consolidation of 48 branches into 27, reduction of company officers to 8 from 13 and salary cuts of 10 percent for officers, 8 percent for upper management and 6 percent for all salaried employees.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Papandreou Says Turks Build Nuclear Arms
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that Turkey was building a nuclear bomb in collaboration with Pakistan.

title: MOSCOW'S NOT AMUSED BY UKRAINE SEPARATISM
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCUMENTS ARE SUBPOENAED IN DRYSDALE GOVERNMENT CASE
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office has subpoenaed the books and records of Drysdale Government Securites Inc. and its bankrupt parent, Drysdale Securities Inc., as part of an investigation into possible criminal activity in connection with the collapse of Drysdale Government last May.

title: AMERICAN INDIANS' ARTISTRY IN BASKETS
description: AN exhibition of American Indian basketry opens today at ACA American Indian Arts, a gallery devoted to providing a showcase for prehistoric and contemporary Indian art and artifacts. The gallery's specialty area is pottery, basketry and textiles from the Southwest, the origin of the majority of the more than 50 baskets on display. The pieces are from the Pima, Apache, Pomo and Yavapai, among other tribes; also represented are examples by the southern Alaskan Aleuts.

title: Technology; Cordless Telephones
description: WHEN John Vojtush bought a cordless telephone for his motorcycle repair shop in Macedonia, Ohio, he found to his dismay that the shop next door had a cordless telephone operating on the same frequency. The two shops could hear each other's conversations and would inadvertently answer each other's calls.

title: Prisoner Stabbed to Death
description: One inmate was killed and two were injured in stabbing attacks at Folsom Prison Monday, the authorities reported. The attacks brought the 1982 total for violent incidents at the prison to 46.

title: M.P.'S BACK BEGIN IN CLASH WITH U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that if the Reagan plan for the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip had been put forth as the American position four years ago Israel would never have signed the Camp David accords that led to peace with Egypt.

title: The Editorial Notebook; September Song
description: At the beach club where three weeks ago the medium-rare hamburger you ordered came in seven minutes, you will now receive instead an extremely well-done hamburger in one hour and 44 minutes. The reason for delay and overcooking is not that the summer romance between handsome chef / hockey player / theater arts major and lovely waitress / gymnast / political science major has blossomed into blinding passion. It's simply that the college students who spent the summer learning the secrets of short-order cookery have gone back to their ivy. They have been replaced by two 8-year-olds and their grandfather.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OLD TABLES AND MODERN KNEES
description: IN the name of comfort or convenience, sins have been committed against furniture whose only fault was surviving too long and being outgrown by its owners. Except for pieces that were custom-designed or individually commissioned, it has been a case of one size having to fit all. Through the years, though, the human frame has inched upward, leaving us to wonder if we are still expected to fit into and be comfortable on the possessions that came down to us.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Danzig Judaica Is Displayed

title: Comings and Goings
description: Emile Francis, the general manager of the St. Louis Blues and a former player and coach for the Rangers, was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame last night in Toronto. Also inducted were Yvan Cournoyer, who played with the Montreal Canadiens; Norm Ullman, who played with the Detroit Red Wings and the Toronto Maple Leafs, and Rod Gilbert, the former Ranger.

title: Ex-Fireman Jailed for Arson
description: A former volunteer firefighter who admitted setting fires because he liked to fight them has been sentenced to 17 years in prison for arson and bank robbery. Keith J. Frosch, 21 years old, of Mandeville, La., pleaded guilty Tuesday to four counts of simple arson. When he was arrested last October, he told the authorities he set the fires because he enjoyed fighting them.

title: Race to Stardom
description: There is many a strange Hollywood story about paths to star status, but if Bruce Penhall becomes a television star he will have one of the strangest tales to tell.

title: THE SCENARIO UPSET
description: Barely a week after the siege of Beirut ended, and events are turning expectations upside down in the Middle East. In the confusion one thing is clear: The military victory won by Israeli forces under Defense Minister Ariel Sharon is not bringing the political results that he made the premise of the operation.

title: EVERGREENS FOR WINTRY CITY TERRACES
description: CITY gardeners sometimes forget that when summer flowers vanish, terraces or yards can be dreary and gray under winter skies. The best way to prevent this is to plant several of the slower-growing evergreen shrubs and trees that will keep their leaves through the colder months.

title: U.S. Won't Appeal Bias Case
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 8 (AP) - The Reagan Administration will not challenge a Federal district judge's ruling that restricted the Government's power to cut off funds to colleges or schools accused of sex discrimination, a Justice Department official said today.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: After reading your column of Aug. 19, I had to go back and doublecheck the byline to make sure that I hadn't written the piece.  You so accurately described my own feelings - both of trepidation and elation - that I could hardly believe those words had issued forth from someone else's typewriter.
description: I plan to have the article bronzed and permanently installed over my desk. LESLIE GARISTO Manhattan

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: The 1981 figures were restated for changes in the LIFO reserve

title: Required Reading; O Those Marines
description: William P. Clark, the President's national security adviser, in a speech to the National Convention of Veterans of Foreign Wars. Los Angeles.

title: MOBILE NAMES WARD EXECUTIVE
description: The Mobil Corporation has named an outsider, Bernard F. Brennan, an executive vice president of its ailing Montgomery Ward division, and trade sources said that he was likely to step up to the presidency within two years.

title: Michael Thoma, Actor In Television's 'Fame'
description: Michael Thoma, who played a drama teacher on the television program ''Fame'' and a family friend on ''Eight Is Enough,'' died Friday after a two-year battle with cancer. He was 55 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A car parked on our driveway during a rainy night left a rust stain. What can we do to get rid of it? - M.D., Loveland, Colo.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS KNOCKING OUT A SYRIAN MISSILE BATTERY
description: Israeli jet fighters destroyed a Syrian antiaircraft missile battery in Lebanon today, Prime Minister Menachem Begin announced in an address to the Israeli Parliament.

title: Internorth-BASF Deal
description: Internorth Inc.'s Northern Petrochemical Company subsidiary said today that it had agreed with BASF A.G. to cooperate in development of gas phase technology for polypropylene production. The agreement gives both companies access to technology developed since gas phase polypropylene was released for commercial use by BASF in 1967.

title: FALCONS' LAST EXHIBITION ANNOYS COACH
description: Who are the real Atlanta Falcons? Are they the 1980 divisional champions with a 12-4 record and an aggressive, ballhawking defense or the 1981 also-rans with a 7-9 record and a Jekyll-and-Hyde personality brought about partly by injuries? Even Coach Leeman Bennett is not sure.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE SHOW OPENS TODAY
description: WHETHER they are thinking of brightening the basement of a brownstone, cleaning a stopped-up chimney or liquidating a stubborn colony of cockroaches, New Yorkers will find professional advice available under one vast roof over the next four days, at a city-sponsored event dedicated to home improvement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AFG Industries, Kingsport, Tenn., announced that Edward Sczesny, formerly vice president of corporate development for Guardian Industries, would become chairman and part owner of its newly formed subsidiary, AFG Technologies Inc.

title: HERS
description: IHOPE I never meet June Allyson. If June Allyson isn't just darling, I don't want to know about it. Of course, deep in my cranium I know June Allyson is probably no more darling than my deceased Aunt Charlotte. In fact, it wouldn't surprise me at all to find out that June Allyson is cranky as hell. I would be, too, if I lived in a world where everybody expected me to be just darling.

title: EMBATTLED BENDIX UP $6 A SHARE
description: Bendix Corporation stock soared $6 a share yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, finishing at $62.50, in reaction to the United Technologies Corporation's announcement that it had joined the Martin Marietta Corporation in a $1.5 billion takeover bid for Bendix.

title: QUEBEC JUDGE REJECTS PART OF LANGUAGE CURB
description: In a decision that enforces the primacy of Canada's Constitution, a Quebec judge ruled today that federal guarantees on education supersede aspects of a Quebec law that sought to restrict the number of children attending English-language schools.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 974 Sundays (20 Years) Of 'Newsmakers'

title: Mets Back Ownbey With 2 Home Runs
description: Rick Ownbey, who three weeks ago was playing in the minor leagues, achieved his first major league victory for the Mets tonight after pitching eight and one-third innings of scoreless ball.

title: POLITICAL CAMPAIGN STAFFS GROW LEANER
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is running for the Democratic nomination for governor with nine paid staffers. James H. Tully Jr. is seeking the Democratic nomination for Comptroller with five paid workers. Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan is seeking the Republican nomination for the United States Senate with a four-member campaign staff.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GLOBAL ALLOWED TO VOTE NEW STOCK
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C., the oil and gas concern that is attempting to fend off a takeover bid by dissident shareholders, received a boost yesterday when a Federal judge in Cincinnati denied a request for a preliminary injunction that would have prevented Global from voting newly issued shares at the annual meeting next Monday.

title: JAZZ QUINTET: MAL WALDRON
description: IN the quintet he is leading at the Village Vanguard through Sunday, Mal Waldron the composer and Mal Waldron the pianist conspire to keep the musicians on their toes.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS HELP REPAIR A CIVIL RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIFTER, 22, IS ARRIGNED IN KILLING OF 3 IN MAIN LINE MANSION IN JULY
description: A 22-year-old drifter with a long criminal record was formally charged today in the July 15 killings of the aviation pioneer Courtlandt S. Gross, his wife and their housekeeper in their mansion in the Philadelphia suburb of Villanova.

title: Other Helsinki Units Deplore Soviet Move
description: The heads of committees set up in the United States and a dozen other countries to monitor compliance with the Helsinki accords deplored the disbanding of the Soviet group.

title: DELAY OF 6 DAYS IN ARRAIGNMENT IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: An 18-year-old youth charged with stealing a bicycle was held for six days before being arraigned, and a Manhattan Criminal Court judge has ordered an investigation to find out why.

title: ARABS' PEACE PLAN IS REPORTED NEAR AT MOROCCO TALKS
description: Delegates at a conference of the Arab League said today that the 15 Arab leaders in the meeting were near agreement on a Middle East peace plan.

title: Grant to Enable Library To Extend Its Hours
description: A $100,000 challenge grant from the Bankers Trust Company will enable the Donnell Library Center on West 53d Street to extend Saturday hours for the next three years, a library spokesman announced yesterday.

title: Company Is Absolved in Fire
description: A judge has found that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation is not liable in a 1979 fire at a substation of the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation in Green Bay that killed one man and injured two others.

title: Bridge: Novices in New York Area Face Challenge Next Week
description: The biggest prize ever offered to inexperienced players will be up for grabs at a handful of clubs in the New York metropolitan area during the next week. The event is the Grand National Rookie Pairs, restricted to those with fewer than 20 master points; many of the entrants will have none at all. Players interested in competing should call their nearest club for details.

title: New Copper Alloy
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it would soon market in Japan a new copper alloy for high tensile springs used in electrical components. The alloy, called Mitsubishi MX 96, consists of nickel, tin, copper, beryllium and titanium, and is used for connectors, micromotors, slide switches and other components. Mitsubishi plans to produce 240 metric tons of MX 96 in the year beginning April 1.

title: REAGAN BACKS ANTI-ABORTION BILL AS OPPONENTS RESUME FILIBUSTER
description: As Congress returned to work today after the Labor Day recess, President Reagan fulfilled a campaign promise and threw his weight behind legislation now before the Senate that could sharply limit a woman's right to an abortion.

title: NEW PITT COACH WARY OF POLLS
description: Pitt's new football coach, Serafino (Foge) Fazio, sat today in the same big leather chair behind the same big glass-covered desk that Johnny Majors and then Jackie Sherrill used. But his attention was on a picture that did not adorn the walls of the office when his heralded predecessors worked there.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
description: B-After a special gain of $86,000; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $625,000 for the qr and $1,250,000 for the 6 mos...C-Netloss after losses from discontinued operations of $11,750,000 for the qr and $22,174,000 for the 6 mos

title: BURGLARS ALSO ROBBERS, POLICE LEARN
description: When the Police Department declared an all-out war on robbery last year, it had no reason to expect that the move would lead to a significant drop in burglaries - but that is what it got, along with a changed view of who the criminals are.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Calvin Simmons Rites Held in San Francisco
description: More than 2,200 mourners gathered in Grace Cathedral on Tuesday for last rites for Calvin Simmons, the Oakland Symphony conductor, who drowned Aug. 21 after falling from a canoe on a pond near Lake Placid, N.Y.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
EFFICIENT HELPERS FOR GARDENERS
description: WHEN it is time for end-of-the-summer clean-up in the garden some useful tools make the job easier. A large red metal wheelbarrow that folds flat is a boon if storage space is limited.

title: 15-Year Sentence
description: Jesse Phillips, a former running back for the Cincinnati Bengals, New Orleans Saints and Oakland Raiders, was sentenced today to 15 years in the Nevada State Prison for robbing a Reno jewelry store. Phillips is currently serving three years for writing bad checks totaling more than $3,000.

title: REAGAN NEUTRAL ON BID TO CURB COURT ON PRAYER
description: The White House said today that President Reagan would not oppose a bill in Congress to strip the Supreme Court of jurisdiction over school prayer cases despite the Justice Department's doubts that such an approach is constitutional.

title: Sims Ends Holdout
description: Billy Sims, the Detroit Lions' running back, ended a long holdout and reported to practice at the Silverdome.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Yankees, virtually out of the pennant race, can play the role of spoiler in the four-game series with the Eastern Division leaders.

title: 'Doonesbury' Creator To Take a Long Leave
description: Garry Trudeau, creator of ''Doonesbury,'' will take a leave of absence early next year and temporarily cease production of his Pulitizer Prize-winning comic strip in more than 700 newspapers, officials of the Universal Press Syndicate said today.

title: TRANSIT REPORT
description: CONRAIL: Four of the 29 scheduled Hudson Line trains in the morning rush were late as a result of signal or equipment trouble, with the longest delay 22 minutes. One Harlem Line train, the 7:29 A.M. from Mount Vernon West was canceled because of equipment problems, and 10 of the remaining 44 scheduled New Haven Line trains were late.

title: Petroleum Data Delay
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a delay in compiling the data because of the Labor Day holiday. The figures will be published on Friday.

title: News Analysis
description: ''The White House is playing politics with the salaries of Federal workers,'' the Senator charged. ''Let there be no confusion. There is one reason for this problem and that is the Administration's veto of an appropriation bill which reflected the kind of hard work and fiscal responsibility the American people expect and deserve from Congress.'' This attack on President Reagan's veto of the $14.1 billion supplemental appropriation bill for the current fiscal year was not made by a Democrat or a liberal, but by a moderate Republican, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

title: Indian Point Unit Back in Service
description: Consolidated Edison returned its Indian Point II nuclear generating station to service today, following a six-day shutdown caused by a mechanical failure.

title: Candidate Apologizes To Reporter in Ohio
description: Representative Clarence J. Brown, the Republican nominee for Governor of Ohio, has apologized to a reporter for what he said was a joke.

title: ART BY WRITERS BEING SHOWN AT YALE
description: ''Art for the Wrong Reason,'' a surprising collection of paintings and drawings by American and European writers assembled by the late Norman Holmes Pearson, professor of English and American Studies at Yale University, is on display at the Yale Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library until the end of the month.

title: SEMICONDUCTOR TIES UNIT TO I.B.M. CASE
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, the big manufacturer of electronic integrated circuits, disclosed today that it might face possible claims by I.B.M. in a case involving the theft by Japanese companies of United States computer secrets.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1982; Companies
description: William S. Paley will resign as chairman of CBS next April 20. The founder of the giant communications conglomerate will be succeeded by Thomas H. Wyman, who has been president and chief executive for two years. Mr. Paley will become a partner in the Whitcom Investment Company, which indirectly owns a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune. (Page A1.) Mr. Wyman has been notable at CBS for holding on to a position from which at least three previous executives were ousted by Mr. Paley. (D6.)

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago periods are restated to reflect accrued vacation benefits in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43

title: MEXICO SAID TO RESIST CURBS
description: Moves to help Mexico out of its financial crisis have been stalled by the apparent reluctance of President Jose Lopez Portillo to agree to austerity measures, officials and bankers at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund said.

title: A DEPARTING LIBERAL ON LIBERALISM
description: Joseph D. Duffey, a stalwart of Washington's liberal community for the past decade, has put aside political activism for now to accept appointment as chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

title: McENROE WINS
description: Yesterday was not an easy one for the two defending singles champions of the United States Open tennis championships. Tracy Austin was upset by fifth-seeded Hana Mandlikova in a threeset quarterfinal battle yesterday afternoon. And in the evening, John McEnroe, the men's champion, needed more than three and a half hours to survive a stirring five-set match with sixth-seeded Gene Mayer.

title: A WORLD BANKING PERIL
description: As Mexico, Poland and Argentina edge toward bankruptcy, world banking is likely to be presented with its worst crisis since the Great Depression. A coordinated strategy by the governments of the industrial democracies is indispensable.

title: McGovern Cites Atom Issue In Iowa Tour to Test Appeal
description: George McGovern, hoping to seize on the nuclear freeze issue for another campaign for the Presidency, opened a two-day tour through Iowa today to test his political appeal.

title: JAZZ: REUNION OF A DUO
description: TWENTY years ago, Steve Lacy, soprano saxophonist, and Roswell Rudd, trombonist, had an unrecorded quartet that played only Thelonious Monk tunes. Sunday at Lush Life, Mr. Rudd and Mr. Lacy reunited, playing their own music as solos and Monk's music as duets.

title: BANKERS SEEK A RISE FOR I.M.F.
description: In an effort to bolster waning confidence in the world banking system, bankers attending the annual meetings here of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have been quietly lobbying to gain United States Government backing for a substantial increase in lending authority for the I.M.F.

title: N.F.L. PROPOSAL REJECTED
description: National Football League owners bolstered their contract proposal today by offering bonuses of up to $60,000 a player this year. But the union rejected the plan and said at least one team might strike this weekend because its player representative was cut.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
CZECHOSLOVAKS' DAY AT THE OPEN
description: O n the tennis court, they seldom lose but they seldom smile. And they seldom complain. They are products of a system, rather than a sport. They are Ivan Lendl and Hana Mandlikova, each from Czechoslovakia, each only two matches from sweeping the men's and women's singles titles at the United States Open championships.

title: Searle Markets New Sweetener
description: An artificial sweetener 200 times sweeter than sugar but with virtually no calories will be on store shelves nationwide by the end of the year, G.D. Searle & Company announced.

title: 54 YEARS AFTER FOUNDING CBS, PALEY IS RESIGNING
description: William S. Paley, the founder of CBS Inc., announced yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the board of the giant communications conglomerate that he has led for more than half a century. The resignation will take effect April 20.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: S O S

title: Love It and Hate It
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Until this morning I was sure that when I turned 35 - almost middle-age, after all - I would have some sense of self-confidence that I usually know what I'm doing and generally have proved it. Now, your column (''Hers,''Aug 19).

title: Bomb Threat Empties Two Planes in Maryland
description: From 500 to 600 passengers on two World Airway DC-10's at Baltimore-Washington International Airport were ordered off the jetliners tonight because of a report that bombs were placed on board, the Maryland state police said.

title: 24 WOMEN TAKE PHYSICAL TEST FOR FIRE DEPT. AND 16 PASS IT
description: Twenty-four women yesterday became the first to take a revised physical-requirements test for appointment to the New York City Fire Department, and 16 passed.

title: 2 MORE QUEENS FUGITUVES ARRESTED: 5 OTHERS ARE STILL SOUGHT BY POLICE
description: Two men who escaped with eight others from a Queens detention center Monday night were recaptured yesterday, authorities said. One of the fugitives was arrested in a hospital bed, and the other surrendered to a newspaper reporter.

title: LEWIS H. DURLAND
description: Lewis H. Durland, treasurer emeritus of Cornell University and a former chairman and chief executive officer of the First Bank of Ithaca, N.Y., died of cancer Sept. 1 at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca. He was 74 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Genesco Wins On Dismissal
description: The American Arbitration Association has ruled that Genesco Inc., ''was fully justified'' in 1977 in terminating the employment contract and discharging John Schumacher, who had been chairman and chief executive officer of the Bonwit Teller fashion specialty store chain in 1976 and 1977.

title: PARENTS OF HANDICAPPED PROTEST ON U.S. PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is open to persuasion about its attempt to modify the education rights of handicapped children, Education Secretary T.H. Bell said today.

title: ADVERTISING
description: The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation, a $3 billion holding company engaged in insurance, broadcasting and publishing, has named Penchina, Selkowitz Inc. of New York to develop television campaigns for its Jefferson-Standard Life Insurance Company and Pilot Life Insurance Company subsidiaries.

title: Hutton Ends Link
description: The E.F. Hutton Group said it had sold its holdings in the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation for $20 million in cash, which would result in an after-tax gain of $9 million in the third quarter, ending Sept. 30. The company received the shares in May 1980 as an investment banking fee in connection with a leveraged buy-out for which it gave financial advice.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Science and Tech- nology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: IT PAYS TO SEE IF A HOUSE FITS FIRST
