description: NCE upon a time I lived in an estate area famed for its ''important'' houses. ''Do you want an important house?'' was the first question realtors asked ''lookers.'' Prospective buyers who had stumbled into the community soon found that they did want an ''important'' house. There was something romantic and amusing about the 40-room mansions that waited, slightly faded but still grand, to be ''snapped up'' for ''unbelievably low'' asking prices.

title: EILEEN CECIL, INTERIOR DECORATOR
description: Eileen Cumming Cecil, president of Rose Cumming Inc., an interior decorating and antiques shop, died Sunday at her home in New York City. She was 89 years old.

title: THE COMPUTER TATTOO
description: In a well-meaning effort to curb the employment of illegal aliens, and with the hearty good wishes of editorialists who ordinarily pride themselves on guarding against the intrusion of government into the private lives of individual Americans, Congress is about to take this generation's longest step toward totalitarianism.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $655,000 for the qr and $2,079,000 for the 9 mos

title: RECYCLING DECO SCULPTURE IN A HOUSING COMPLEX
description: LATE last February, Jerry Doty and Daniel McCarthy stood watching the sun set over the decaying West Side Highway, which was then being dismantled in lower Manhattan. Mr. Doty mused that a massive Art Deco cartouche -a highway marker for Harrison Street and Pier 23 attached to a stanchion -might make a nice, if oversized, objet d'art. Six months, one engineering study and more than a hundred telephone calls later, the cast-iron cartouche is theirs, and a neighborhood has rallied to install it permanently at a modern housing complex.

title: SONIA TOMARA CLARK
description: Sonia Tomara Clark, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, died Tuesday at the Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey, where she had been hospitalized since early last month after a stroke. She was 85 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH, GAIN FINAL
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, conspicuously quiet throughout regulation play, scored a goal less than two minutes into overtime tonight to give the Cosmos a 2-1 victory over the San Diego Sockers and a place in the Soccer Bowl.

title: REAGAN'S ARMS FREEZE STAND UNCLEAR
description: The Reagan Administration has given conflicting signals on a resolution on the Wisconsin ballot urging a ''moratorium and reduction'' in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals. The referendum is likely to be approved next Tuesday, opponents and supporters of the measure agree.

title: WHEN INDEPENDENTS TRY TO RESURRECT MOVIES THAT FAILED
description: Can a movie that was a failure at the box office when it was first released be a success three or four years later?

title: 19% RISE IN FELONY INDICTMENTS IN CITY SWELLS COURTS' BACKLOGS
description: The number of felony indictments returned in New York City has risen 19 percent so far this year, reflecting a tougher stance by law-enforcement authorities but placing continuing strains on the court system, officials said yesterday.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: HOORAY FOR YIDDISH! By Leo Rosten. 363 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: THERE'S NO WAY TO BEAUTIFY A POWER-LINE PYLON
description: To the Editor:

title: Manville Hearing On Chapter 11 Bid
description: Officials of the Manville Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of asbestos, will meet with members of Congress Thursday to discuss why the company filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: RIGHTISTS TIP THE SCALE IN DUTCH ELECTION
description: The Netherlands seemed headed for a new center-right Cabinet after conservatives drew heavy support from middle-class voters and the young in national elections today.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1982
description: International Arab leaders neared agreement on a Middle East peace plan, according to delegates at an Arab League conference in Fez, Morocco. The 15 Arab leaders apparently hope that the plan will be acceptable to the West, but reports of its provisions indicate aspects that would be unacceptable to Israel and the United States. The draft was said to call for a homeland for the Palestinians with its capital in East Jerusalem. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington's peace initiative in the Middle East was praised by B'nai B'rith, the American Jewish service organization. It said it took issue with some provisions, but that, over all, President Reagan's plan was ''worthy of consideration.'' (A1:3-4.)

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Critics to Follow Marcos Around U.S.

title: Dolphins Offer Jets a Dim View
description: The way the Jets see it, it's the great film flim-flam. In the National Football League, upcoming opponents are required to exchange three sets of films, including a reel of their last game played.

title: MISS BELLAMY ASKS CHANGES FOR WEST SIDE HOUSING PLAN
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy has called for revisions in the plans for the Lincoln West luxury housing complex on the West Side, and the developer said yesterday that an attempt would be made to ''accommodate'' her concerns.

title: House Votes to Extend Rules On Hazardous Waste in U.S.
description: The House voted today to extend rules on hazardous wastes to smaller businesses that are now exempt from regulation by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Mideast Peace Plans: Capsule Summaries
description: In working on an Arab League peace plan for the Middle East, participants in the conference of Arab leaders this week in Fez, Morocco, reportedly considered several proposals - one by President Reagan put forward last week, another by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia offered in August 1981 and a third by President Habib Bourguiba first made in 1965.

title: GUNMEN AT EMBASSY NOW ASKING SAFE-CONDUCT OUT OF SWITZERLAND
description: Swiss officials said today that the four gunmen who seized the Polish Embassy here Monday had departed for the first time from their sweeping demands and were now seeking permission to leave Switzerland without prosecution.

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
MOB LINK SEEN
description: Two brothers were shot to death in a barrage of gunfire late last night as they sat in their Queens cafe in what the police said may have been an ''organized crime-related execution.'' A third man was wounded.

title: 3 WORLD RECORDS ARE BROKEN AT MEET
description: Three world records and one world-record holder fell tonight at the European track and field championships. Daley Thompson of Britain scored 8,744 points in the decathlon, Ulrike Meyfarth of West Germany high jumped 6 feet 7 1/2 inches, Marita Koch of East Germany ran 400 meters in 48.15 seconds for the world records, and Sebastian Coe ran second in the 800 meters.

title: Data Said to Show U.S. Spied On Homosexual Rights Units
description: The Federal Government routinely spied on organizations promoting homosexual rights and compiled voluminous lists of homosexuals in the 1950's, 1960's and early 1970's, according to documents from the Pentagon and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: ASBESTOS SLUMP JOLTS QUEBEC
description: The morning mist hangs heavily over the mile-wide pit, thick and damp but less ominous than the cloud over Canada's asbestos mining industry.

title: JETS SWITCH FIELDS TO GUARD, WALDEMORE TO CENTER
description: The emergency restructuring of the offensive line of the Jets began today, only four days before they open the season by facing their major divisional rival, the Miami Dolphins.

title: Oil Minister Is Forced Out
description: Ecuador's oil minister, Eduardo Ortega Gomez, said today that he had resigned after being censured for reportedly mishandling energy policy.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson's Faculty Ratifies New 2-Year Contract
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University, the largest independent college in the state, and its 517-member faculty completed ratification of a new two-year contract today calling for base salary increases of 8.5 percent each year. The contract was ratified by mail ballot.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Comtex Scientific Corp. said its Electronic Mail Corp. subsidiary had completed a public offering of 800,000 common shares through D.H. Blair & Co.

title: WHY TITLES BECOME ELUSIVE
description: Are tennis champions under a curse at certain major tournaments? Martina Navratilova's three-set loss to Pam Shriver in the fourth round of the United States Open raised that question again yesterday. Like Bjorn Borg, who was thwarted in last year's final, Miss Navratilova has never won an Open, having had assorted problems since her first appearance in the tournament in 1973. But she and Borg are not alone in their frustrations.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''SIBERIADE,'' a three-hour version of a four-part Russian epic that won the special prize of the jury in 1979 at Cannes, opens in New York Wednesday at the Embassy 72d Street, and Andrei Mikhalkov-Konchalovsky, its director and co-author of the script, is in the city for the occasion.

title: Shelter Resources
description: The Shelter Resources Corporation, a Cleveland-based maker of manufactured housing, said it had filed for voluntary reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. It said it would continue its housing and consumer products operations, but would close three plants in its Lancer Homes division in Marysville and Corona, Calif., which employ about 250 workers.

title: A CRISIS IN NATO ON MISSILES
description: Relations between the United States and Western Europe may seem bad today but they are likely to be vastly worse a year from now, as NATO governments tremble and even fall under the weight of a divisive issue that can no longer be postponed: Euromissiles.

title: Syracuse Symphony Hit By Strike of Musicians
description: A musicians' strike has scratched tonight's scheduled season-opening performance by the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra. Performers voted 70 to 1 Wednesday for the strike.

title: THEATER: KROTZ'S 'MICHI'S BLOOD'
description: CARL and Mary, the young lovers of Franz Xaver Kroetz's ''Michi's Blood,'' live in a flat that is perhaps less appetizing than a public restroom in a subway. The walls are streaked with grime; the one window looks out on an air shaft; the tub is as filthy as a pig trough. Decoration consists of some crumpled cigarette packages taped above a sooty cot. For lighting, there are two bare light bulbs.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Swedes Cast Ballots A quiet but possibly crucial election is going on in an unusual polling place - a serene room with white walls and a beige carpet on the 38th floor of 825 Third Avenue.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Figures do not include the earnings and revs of California Minicomputer SystemsInc recently acquired by Wespercorp

title: Evan Walker, Writer, Teacher of Literature
description: Evan Walker, a writer and teacher of literature, died in Presbyterian Hospital Aug. 23 of spinal meningitis and pneumonia. He was 49 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: SUSPECT IN CONSPIRACY TO KILL JUDGE SAID TO CONFESS IN LETTER TO WIDOW
description: A woman charged with conspiracy in the murder of a Federal district judge wrote a repentant letter to the judge's widow confessing her role in the killing, the local news media have reported.

title: Accounts
description: * The F.W. Langguth Winery of West Germany to Jules Rabin Associates for advertising in North America.

title: Chicago Museum Given A Monet 'Water Lilies'
description: The Art Institute of Chicago said today that it had acquired one of Claude Monet's ''Water Lilies'' paintings from a private donor.

title: BRITISH PIPELINE SUPPLIER TO BE PENALIZED BY U.S.
description: The Commerce Department imposed trade sanctions today, as expected, against John Brown P.L.C., a British engineering company and the fourth European concern to be penalized for supplying equipment to the Soviet Union for the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: L.I. VILLAGE SETS RULES FOR JOGGING ON ROADS
description: The village trustees here have voted a new ordinance that sets rules for joggers and punishes violators with fines of up to $250 and with jail terms of up to 90 days.

title: MALONE CONTRACT COULD TOP $15 MILLION
description: Moses Malone, the Houston Rockets' free-agent center, could receive in excess of $15 million over the next six seasons under the terms of the offer sheet he signed with the Philadelphia 76ers on Sept. 2. The least Malone can make if certain bonuses fail to materialize is $11.8 million.

title: ROCK SEXTET
description: rock ensemble of considerable technical skills.

title: MOVE TO OVERRIDE REAGAN FUND VETO APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives today gave President Reagan a setback by voting to override his veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental spending bill.

title: OPERA: ''WIDOW'' CHANGES
description: WEDNESDAY evening's performance of the New York City Opera's new production of ''The Merry Widow'' introduced four different principals into the cast; the two sets will alternate for the rest of the run. All four had their virtues and faults, but their individual attributes were overshadowed by the dead hand of the production and by the continued interest in the New York State Theater's new acoustics.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income after a loss of $136,000 from discontinued operations

title: Plant for Uranium Processing In Utah Shut Upon U.S. Order
description: A uranium-processing plant in Orem has been shut because it dumped radioactive material near the laboratory and failed to tell its young employees of the hazards of the radioactive compounds.

title: INTO SPACE
description: A private corporation with only seven permanent employees launched a spacecraft made out of surplus rocket parts from a cattle ranch here today, ushering in what its promoters believe will be a new era of commercial exploitation of space technology.

title: FOR I.R.S. WORKERS, DIAL-A-FURLOUGH
description: ''Good morning,'' says a voice on the recorded telephone message, ''as of 9:30 A.M., Sept. 9, 1982, all Internal Revenue Service offices in the metropolitan area are open and operating. If there are any changes in duty hours and reporting instructions due to subsequent developments in the current appropriations situation, that information will be available through this message system. Clink.''

title: THEORY OF 'WHITE FLIGHT' CHALLENGED
description: Far fewer whites fled this city's school system to avoid court-ordered busing than had been widely assumed, according to a new report from the Office of School Monitoring and Community Relations established by the Federal District Court here.

title: RUDY MUCHA
description: Funeral services will be held Saturday for Rudy Mucha, who was a lineman on the Chicago Bears' 1946 National Football League championship team.

title: Big Bookmaking Ring Reported in Philadelphia
description: Attorney General LeRoy Zimmerman announced today that a $50 million illegal sports bookmaking operation had been cracked in the Philadelphia area.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Yes, recovery has been sighted.'' - President Reagan. (D17:1.)

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a loss of $618,000 from discontinued operations...C-Afte r losses from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the qr and $1,243,000 for the 6 mos

title: CHINAGLIA'S WINNING TOUCH
description: I t had been a close, tense, vigorous game. When the 90 minutes of regulation time expired, the Cosmos and the San Diego Sockers were tied at 1-1. Sudden-death overtime followed. But it didn't last long.

title: Nassau Approves 12% Rent Rises
description: Rent increases of up to 12 percent on rent-stabilized apartments in Nassau County have been approved by the county's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Disney Pact Ends
description: The Group W Satellite Communications Corporation said that because of ''philosophical and creative differences,'' it had agreed with Walt Disney Productions to dissolve a joint venture to establish a pay-TV system with family-oriented programs.

title: CITY AND 40 UNIONS AGREE ON 15% RAISE IN A 2-YEAR CONTRACT
description: New York City and union leaders representing its 180,000 nonuniformed employees reached a tentative agreement last night on a new contract that includes wage increases of about 15 percent over two years.

title: Economic Scene; Some Success At Conference
description: TORONTO AN annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, with 10,000 financial officials, bankers, bureaucrats and journalists from more than a hundred countries, is like a great amorphous blob. Yet such assemblies as the one now winding up in Toronto sometimes mysteriously bear fruit.

title: SHARING WITH JORDAN
description: President Reagan's suggestion that the West Bank should be linked to Jordan holds out the promise of a workable compromise. But the proposal will not be acceptable to many Israelis if it means territorial compromise - for any such arrangement simply would not be feasible in such a small piece of land. No territorial compromise can satisfy the Arab countries' minimum demands and, at the same time, meet Israel's security needs.

title: MOVE OVER, ROCK, THAT OLD TIME MELODY IS BACK
description: SOME folks would have us believe that American popular music before rock-and-roll was a Garden of Eden - a paradise where melody reigned supreme, songs were built to last a lifetime and singers never had to shout. According to them, a snake called rock-and-roll invaded the garden in the mid-1950's and seduced Adam and Eve (the country's record companies and radio stations) by offering them the cheap sensations of raucous rock hits and big bucks.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Sees Flood Area
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi inspected flooded regions of northern and eastern India today as fresh rains created new problems in areas where the monsoon tide had been receding. More than 300 people have died so far in the floods, which have swamped vast areas in the states of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Orissa, leaving thousands of people homeless.

title: Economic Bureau Gets a New Leader
description: Under Martin Feldstein, the National Bureau of Economic Research gained the reputation as an institution with a conservative bent. The institution is a nonprofit study center known widely for its dating of the beginning and end of recessions. Mr. Feldstein, its president, has just moved on to become chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: SCHMIDT CHALLENGES FOES TO OUST HIM
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt challenged the opposition Christian Democrats today to attempt to bring down his wobbly coalition by putting forward their own candidate in a parliamentary vote.

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said production at its plywood mill here would resume Sept. 27, a year after 300 plant workers were laid off and the mill was closed because of the depressed home-building industry.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Plea to Nixon on Soldier
description: The father of an Army private reported to have defected to North Korea said today he planned to seek the assistance of Richard M. Nixon.

title: COURSES FOR WOMEN IN THE CITY
description: More than 350 courses in women's studies at 53 educational institutions and women's centers throughout the city are included in a new publication from the New York City Commission on the Status of Women.

title: Hatfield Says Administration; Favors Pentagon Over Poor
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, criticized the Reagan Administration today for increasing military spending on the basis of what he called ''oversimplistic anti-Sovietism'' at the expense of the nation's poor.

title: ABC Picks Executive For Leisure Magazines
description: At ABC Publishing, Ronald W. Stuart, 35, has been named president of ABC Leisure Magazines, which includes such titles as Modern Photography, High Fidelity, McCall's Needlework and Crafts and the Schwann Record and Tape Guides.

title: SAN GENNARO LEADS A PARADE OF FESTIVALS
description: The Feast of San Gennaro, granddaddy of New York street fairs, will swirl on all weekend under arches of colored lights on Mulberry Street, where the air is rich with the aroma of frying sausages and the blare of brass bands. Elsewhere this weekend, offspring of San Gennaro can be found on Manhattan's East Side and West Side and in TriBeCa, in Brooklyn's Flatbush and in Staten Island's Tottenville section. The street music ranges from doo wop to country rock, the crafts from trinkets to treasures, and the food knows no bounds. Admission is as free as a place on the pavement.

title: Paisley Gets Permission To Visit the U.S.
description: The State Department said today that it had agreed to allow the Ulster Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, to attend the funeral of a friend in the United States.

title: POP JAZZ
description: WHEN the pianist Mal Waldron immigrated to Europe in 1965, he had a solid New York reputation. He had worked with Charles Mingus's Jazz Workshop from 1954 to 1957, when the group recorded such masterpieces as ''Pithecanthropus Erectus,'' then left the Mingus group to accompany the singer Billie Holiday in her final years. After her death, he worked with such modernists as the drummer Max Roach and the saxophonist Eric Dolphy. But when presented with the opportunity to compose a film score in Paris, Mr. Waldron had no hesitation about leaving New York behind.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: N.A.A.C.P. Moves To Brooklyn

title: U.P.S. WORKERS STAGE WALKOUT AFTER A DISPUTE
description: A strike halted United Parcel Service pickups and deliveries yesterday in New York City, Westchester County and Long Island, sending major department stores in the area scurrying to find alternatives.

title: Dow Off 3.22, to 912.53, In Diminished Trading
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in slower trading, as the late summer rally sputtered along for the third consecutive session. The Dow Jones industrial average moved in a narrow range and closed down 3.22 points, at 912.53. On Wednesday, the blue-chip indicator rose 1.47 points, and on Tuesday it fell 10.85.

title: NORTHERN LEBANESE RESIDENTS ARE FEARFUL OF MORE VIOLENCE
description: Northern Lebanon, two of whose major political leaders have declared a ''boycott'' of President-elect Bashir Gemayel, is in a state of armed suspense.

title: GIANTS ADD CURCIO AND DROP FLOWERS
description: The Giants made another roster change today by adding a linebacker, Mike Curcio, and subtracting a defensive back, Larry Flowers. Curcio, a former Philadelphia Eagle signed as a free agent, could possibly start in the opening game here on Sunday against the Atlanta Falcons.

title: BUSINESS, REACTING TO SLUMP, CUTS SPENDING PLANS FURTHER
description: American businesses, faced with a sluggish economy and high interest rates, have continued to cut their plans for expansion and modernization, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Celanese Chemical Co., a subsidiary of Celanese Corp., said it would increase bulk prices on seven of its chemicals by an average of a little more than 1 cent a pound.

title: 2 UNITS AID TRANSIT CRIME PROSECUTION
description: In a small office in the Criminal Court building in downtown Brooklyn, Michael Gary, an assistant district attorney, sits in front of a poster with a romanticized illustration of a 19th-century New York City elevated train. On his desk are documents testifying to the unromantic realities of 20th-century transit life in the city - the robberies, assaults and vandalism so common on today's subways.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Acquired Carlos Rios, shortstop, from Pittsburgh and as- signed him to Richmond of the Interna- tional League.  DENVER (AA) - The American As- sociation team announced that it is not renewing its working agreement with the Texas Rangers.  MONTREAL (NL) - Purchased Dave Tomlin, reliever, from Indianapolis of the American Association.  PORTLAND (PCL) - Announced the end of four years of affiliation with the Pittsburgh Pirates a
description: NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Claimed R ex Robinson, kicker, from Miami on w aivers; placed Andy Johnson, running b ack, and Steve Clark, defensive end, on t he injured reserve list and activated Mor- r is Bradshaw, wide receiver obtained on w aivers from Los Angeles Raiders, and L uther Henson, nose tackle. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Placed Sidney T hornton, running back, on four-week in- j ured reserve list with pulled left ham- s tring, and recalled Frank Wilson from w aivers to take his place.

title: NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
MAYORAL CANDIDATE IN WASHINGTON SEEKS TO POSTPONE PRIMARY
description: Patricia Roberts Harris, the former Carter Administration Cabinet officer and ambassador who has been trailing in public opinion polls for the mayoral primary election next Tuesday, is threatening to go to court in an effort to postpone the voting.

title: Bridge: Book on World Title Play Ranks as Best of the Series
description: An annual event of great importance to the cognoscenti is the publication of the World Championship book by the American Contract Bridge League. The book of the 1981 event, played in Port Chester, N.Y., almost a year ago, is now available. ($10.95 from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.)

title: PEERLESS MANFUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Settlement Reached In Suit by Winfield
description: An out-of-court settlement was reached yesterday in the $2,845,000 lawsuit filed last May 25 by the David M. Winfield Foundation for underprivleged children against George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankees.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BEGIN FAVORS EARLY VOTE TO TEST VIEWS ON U.S. PLAN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that he favored early parliamentary elections to test the opposition Labor Party's assertions that the Israeli people supported President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.

title: STAGE: 'YOUR ARMS TOO SHORT'
description: WHEN Al Green comes strutting down the aisle of the Alvin Theater at the beginning of the second act of ''Your Arms Too Short to Box With God,'' singing and shouting and testifying that Jesus has saved him and that he just couldn't keep the good news to himself, you forget that you're watching a play. You forget that the first act was largely a predictable reworking of the Gospel According to St. Matthew, and that Patti LaBelle's showy star turns failed to mesh convincingly with the gospel-singing cast's authenticity, passion and grit. You might even forget that you're in a theater, because Mr. Green transforms the stage into a pulpit and the play into a revival meeting. And he proves once again, after seven years in the ministry and away from the pop limelight, that he is the consummate soul singer of our time.

title: House Unit Votes Pay Freeze
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted today to freeze salaries for members of Congress at the current $60,662.50 a year. The amendment to a pending legislative apropriation bill, approved without argument, would also put a ceiling on salaries of all executive and judicial branch employees, including judges, whose salaries are at or above $57,500.

title: SOLON AUTOMATED SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Henry Ford 2d Retires Oct.1
description: Henry Ford 2d, former Ford Motor Company chairman, will retire Oct. 1 as an employee and officer of the auto maker that carries his name but will remain on the company's board of directors and serve as a consultant, Philip Caldwell, chairman, announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Better Mark for Streets

title: REGIONAL ROLL-CALL ON FUND BILL VETO
description: Following is the roll-call of votes by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in which the House voted 301 to 117 today to override President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion spending bill. A ''yes'' vote is to override the veto.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Science and Tech- nology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $13,978 for the qr and $404,000 for the yr

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES PLAN FOR RADIO MARTI
description: President Reagan's plan to set up a radio station to broadcast to Cuba was approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: New-Look Reese
description: A wire-service story from Los Angeles reported that Archie Reese, a Los Angeles Raiders defensive lineman, had conquered a weight problem that had caused the San Francisco 49ers to cut him. Reese, who is 6 feet 3 inches tall, had weighed 300 pounds when the 49ers released him. But the report let it be known that Reese had ''slimmed down to 270 pounds.'' Lawrie Mifflin William N. Wallace

title: THE CURB ON SALE OF BENEFITS
description: No part of the 1981 tax act drew more fire than the provision allowing companies to sell unused tax benefits to other companies, a practice known as safe-harbor leasing. Because of this measure, some major companies, such as General Electric, with millions of dollars of income were able to pay little or no American taxes in 1982. And others, such as Occidental Petroleum, which had losses in the United States but were profitable worldwide, were able to sell tax benefits they might not have been able to use. Both practices elicited widespread outrage.

title: U.S. ASKS ISRAEL NOT TO PRESS PACT ON LEBANESE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States would support a peace treaty between Israel and Lebanon only if it was freely entered into by the Lebanese Government and not dictated by Israeli military pressure.

title: U.S. JEWS DEBATE TIES WITH ISRAEL
description: The differences that have emerged in recent days between several American Jewish organizations and the Israeli Government over President Reagan's Middle East peace plan have opened a new discussion about the fundamental relationship between Israel and American Jews.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: B-After tax credits of $550,000 for the qr and $850,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,304,000 for the qr and $2,745,000 for the 6 mos and after a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,045,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: Argentine Navy Chief to Quit; Last Junta Member From War
description: Adm. Jorge Anaya has announced his retirement from the navy, becoming the last member of the three-man junta that presided over the Falkland war to step down.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Big V Supermarkets Inc., Florida, N.Y., has appointed Gary S. Koppele vice president, administration/treas- urer and chief financial officer.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION AND THE RIGHT OF CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 SHARE LEAD BY SHOT AT 66
description: George Archer and Ed Sneed carded 5-under-par 66's and shared the opening-round lead today in the $300,000 Bank of Boston golf tournament.

title: WATT AIDE DENIES STRIP-MINING PLAN FOR PARKS
description: The Department of the Interior added more confusion today to a controversy over whether it intends to permit strip mining in the National Park system.

title: MEMORIAL TO THE FUTURE
description: Nahum Goldmann, who died last week, has been buried on Jerusalem's Mount Herzl alongside the other historic leaders of the Zionist movement. That is fitting, though he refused to become an Israeli citizen and spent much of his life criticizing as well as helping to build and strengthen the Jewish state.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRENNAN ATTACKS COLLEAGUE'S IDEA FOR NEW COURT TO EASE WORKLOAD
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr. said today that the new appellate court proposed last month by Justice John Paul Stevens as a way of relieving the Supreme Court's workload ''would destroy the role of the Supreme Court as the framers envisaged it.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cities Service Co.'s senior debt rating was reduced to BBB+ from A+ and its commercial paper rating to A-2 from A-1 by Standard & Poor's.

title: CHANGES ROUSE COSMOS
description: Coach Julio Mazzei made several surprising moves with his players throughout the North American Soccer League season. But they were nothing like the changes he made in the match that gained the Cosmos a berth in the Soccer Bowl for the third consecutive year.

title: BRANIFF WINS DELAY IN FILING DEBT PLAN
description: Braniff International petitioned United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers today for an extra 60 days to file its reorganization plan, but the judge gave the troubled airline only until Oct. 15 to propose a way to get its planes back in the air.

title: U.S. CITES SAXON FOR FALSE DATA
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that Saxon Industries, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, and three of its executives had conspired to falsify the company's books.

title: NICARAGUA IS FEARFUL OF A REBEL INVASION BACKED BY HONDURAS
description: On a wall-size operational map in an army briefing room, Nicaraguan military commanders have marked the locations of nine guerrilla bases in Honduras, just across the border from Nicaragua.

title: HISTORIANS EXPLORE THE WATERBURY AREA'S BRASS INDUSTRY
description: For a century and a half the Naugatuck Valley, an area of wooded hills and sharp defiles from Torrington 40 miles south to Ansonia and Derby, was one of the premier industrial areas in the United States.

title: Ariane Rocket Fails In Commercial Effort
description: The first commercial mission of the European space rocket Ariane apparently failed early today after a problem with the third stage of the rocket, a spokesman for the European Space Agency said.

title: ANTHONY STADLMAN, 96, A PIONEER OF LOCKHEED
description: Anthony Stadlman, an early pioneer of the original Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, is dead at the age of 96, friends said today.

title: 5 Women Honored
description: The veteran golfer Carol Mann and four Olympic gold medalists were elected yesterday to the Women's Sports Hall of Fame, bringing the number of athletes so honored to 20. Miss Mann, the Soviet gymnast Olga Korbut and the Austrian skier Annemarie Moser-Proll were chosen in balloting by a selection committee for the ''contemporary'' category. For the ''pioneer'' category, the committee chose the late Norwegian figure skater Sonja Henie and the Dutch track-and-field star Fanny Blankers-Koen.

title: Amdahl Advance
description: The Amdahl Corporation, a manufacturer of large computers, entered the market for computer disk storage products. The company said its new 6280 disk storage unit, which can hold 1.27 million characters of information, and 6880 storage control unit, which are now being shipped, are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's 3350 storage unit.

title: MISHAP CURTAILS TELEPHONE CALLS FOR 3 BUROUGHS
description: The accidental severing of a power line in a Brooklyn office of the New York Telephone Company yesterday led to a power failure that cut off operator-assisted telephone service throughout Queens and in parts of Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: THIS WEEK, ITS 'SCANDINAVIA TODAY'
description: If your name was Lopez, Sanchez or Gonzalez, you might as well have stayed home. But if your name was Olsen, Johannsen or Knutsen, this was a very good week to be in Washington.

title: Evans Store Sale
description: The Evans Products Company said it was seeking to sell its network of 341 retail building-material stores in 20 states to reduce its debt.

title: EMBASSY GUNMEN TAKEN IN 12 MINUTES
description: A special Swiss police squad stormed the Polish Embassy here today and, without firing a shot, freed five Polish diplomats and captured the four gunmen who had held them hostage for three days. No one was hurt.

title: HELPING PAC'S DECIDE HOW TO SPEND THEIR MONEY
description: Heeere's Johnny. Johnny Kochevar, that is. And does he have a show for you! Mr. Kochevar is the director of the political arm of the Chamber of Commerce, and next week he will be introducing a new wrinkle into the complex and competitive world of political fund raising. Using satellite linkups, the chamber will present a closed-circuit television show for about 250 managers of political action committees, known as PACs, gathered in seven cities around the country.

title: BENDIX SAFEGUARDS EXECUTIVE BENEFITS
description: The Bendix Corporation disclosed yesterday that its board chairman, William M. Agee, and 15 other officers would get at least $16 million in salary and other benefits if the United Technologies Corporation succeeded in its $1.5 billion takeover bid for Bendix.

title: PREMATURE PUBERTY REPORTED CORRECTED BY USE OF CHEMICAL
description: Children suffering the physical and emotional anguish of an abnormally early puberty are being successfully treated with chemical injections to reverse or correct the condition, the Journal of the American Medical Association reported today.

title: A Tentative Settlement Over Japan's Textbooks
description: A two-month dispute with China and South Korea over Japan's new history textbooks ''has tentatively been settled,'' Foreign Minister Yoshio Sakurauchi told reporters today.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
3 Men, Including A Killer, Flee Jail
description: Three inmates, including a man who was serving a life term for killing a 15-year-old girl, escaped tonight from the Ocean County Jail here, according to authorities.

title: MANVILLE CREDITORS SAY THE FIGHT IS JUST BEGINNING
description: The organizational meeting for creditors of the Manville Corporation yesterday was like a convention for the bankruptcy community. Creditors' lawyers, who turn up at meeting after meeting, greeted each other with mixed emotions. As one said, ''Jack, it's great to see you here, but I'm sorry to see you here, too.''

title: 5th AVENUE TO BE NATION'S BIGGEST BOOKSTORE
description: THE professional football season kicks off this weekend and baseball's pennant races are heading into their final weeks, but for book lovers there is only one place to be on Sunday: Fifth Avenue from 47th to 57th Street, where ''New York Is Book Country,'' the city's fourth annual book festival, takes place, rain or shine, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. During that time, 53d Street will be closed to all but foot traffic between Madison Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.

title: LAW
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has ruled that college athletic programs were subject to sex discrimination laws if any part of the college received Federal aid.

title: EPISCOPALIANS REVISE HYMNAL
description: The hymnal of the Episcopal Church has undergone its first revision in 42 years as delegates to the church's triennial convention here enthusiasticaly adopted a book of about 600 hymns, including some contemporary compositions.

title: Pilot of a Small Plane Survives Jersey Crash
description: A single-engine plane crashed today in a wooded section of this Atlantic County community.

title: A McDonald's Victory
description: The McDonald's Corporation won a court victory today. A Cook County judge revoked the license of Raymond Dayan, a franchisee, to develop 166 McDonald's restaurants in Paris. Mr. Dayan had accused the fast food chain of trying illegally to cancel the franchise on the 14 McDonald's outlets he ran in Paris and keep him from opening 152 others.

title: Bucks Seeking Cowens
description: The Milwaukee Bucks have agreed to trade the talented playmaker Quinn Buckner to the Boston Celtics for Dave Cowens if they can reach agreement on a contract with the retired all-star, according to a report in The Milwaukee Journal. Neither Coach Don Nelson of the Bucks nor Jim Fitzgerald, the team's owner, would confirm that Buckner, who has been a starter since he joined Milwaukee six years ago from Indiana University, was part of the conditional trade.

title: TWIN BILL FOR BRAZILIAN PIANIST: CHOPIN AND MUSIC FROM HOME
description: Arthur Moreira Lima will wage the battle of the piano preludes at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow night, then walk around the corner into a different musical world.

title: New President Named For American Hoist
description: The American Hoist and Derrick Company, an old-line equipment maker founded in St. Paul in 1882, has had only six presidents in its 100-year history. Yesterday it announced that it had gone outside the company to find its seventh.

title: Federals Sign Two
description: The list of former N.F.L. performers signing up to play in the United States Football League next spring grew yesterday. General Manager Dick Myers of the Washington Federals announced the first signings for his team, and among the players were the punter Mike Bragg and the running back Buddy Hardeman, both of whom played for the Redskins. The Federals also announced that they had signed a seven-year lease to play their home games at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, which houses the Redskins in the fall. ... The Chicago Blitz of the U.S.F.L. signed Vlade Janakievski, a place-kicker who, while at Ohio State from 1977 to 1980, set Big Ten career records of 172 extra points and 295 total points kicking.

title: How They Fared
description: Now that final cuts have been made and the National Football League season is ready to begin, it's possible to take stock of how well the Giants and the Jets did in choosing players in the college draft last April. Granted, it's too early for final grades.

title: MERRILL WILL LICENSE ITS CMA ACCOUNT
description: In a move that could lead to legal wrangling on Wall Street, Merrill Lynch announced yesterday that it would require brokerage firms offering services that compete with its patented Cash Management Account to obtain licenses and was prepared to take legal action against firms that failed to obtain such licenses.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LETTERS TO A FRIEND. By T.H. White, selected and edited by Francois Gallix. 280 pages. Putnam. $14.95

title: FOES OF ABORTION LOSE SENATE FIGHT
description: A day after President Reagan strongly endorsed antiabortion legislation now before Congress, forces opposing the bill decisively won a key test vote in the Senate and said they believed the measure would not pass in this session.

title: Friday; BEETHOVEN IN OYSTER BAY
description: Beethoven in the gardens, Beethoven in the halls. A three-day festival devoted to the composer, with concerts, master classes, lectures and films, will permeate the 400-acre Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, L.I., starting tonight at 8 o'clock with Ruth Laredo playing sonatas, including the ''Appassionata.'' Among 100 musicians to perform during the weekend will be Emanuel Vardi, violist, and Erick Friedman, violinist. The music, presented by the Friends of the Arts, goes on all day tomorrow and Sunday in several places at once, some indoors, some alfresco. Daytime admission is $7.50; reserved tent seats, $10 tonight and tomorrow night, $12.50 on Sunday night: lawn seating is $5 all three nights. A ''Beethoven Passport,'' at $35, gains admission to everything. Information: (516) 922-0061.

title: Tax-Exempt Racism Revisited
description: What results when bad policy is pursued with bad tactics? Worse policy.

title: Brezhnev Tells the U.N. Chief Israelis Must Leave Lebanon
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, in a meeting today with Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, demanded the immediate withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and blamed the United States for a ''heightened danger of war.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: CHALK up another success for Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky. As 19thcentury Russian nationalist composers go, he had a small output, but his tone poem ''Night on Bald Mountain'' - which features kettle drumming that portrays thunder - lived on as the music for a segment of the Walt Disney movie ''Fantasia.''

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Included tax credits of $95,000 for the qr and $629,000 for the yr

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1982
description: International Arab leaders announced a peace plan that they said represented a united Arab Middle East peace plan containing a solution to the problem of the Palestinians. According to an unofficial translation from the Arabic, the plan, approved by the 20 Arab League members, represented at a four-day Arab summit conference in Fez, Morocco, did not contain any specific references to Israel's right to exist. But it specifically referred to the creation of ''an independent Palestinian state.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington would back a peace pact between Israel and Lebanon only if it was freely concluded by Beirut and not dictated by Israeli military pressure, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. (A1:2.)

title: SALVADORANS' BID FOR ASYLUM DENIED BY IMMIGRATION JUDGE
description: Two refugees from El Salvador have been denied political asylum in a test case here. In a decision announced today, Immigration Judge Brian H. Simpson ordered Luis Escobar, 22 years old, and Luis Sanchez, 30, to return to El Salvador within 30 days.

title: Nissan Criticizes Proposed Bill
description: Marvin T. Runyon, president and chief executive officer of the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A., said the company might not be able to produce vehicles in the United States if proposed legislation calling for about 71 percent domestic content were enacted.

title: THE MEDIA'S MISTAKE IN LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. OWNERS STUDY LOCKOUT
description: The executive committee of the National Football League Management Council met in New York for three hours yesterday and later, in a reversal, raised the possibility that the league's owners would lock out the players.

title: U.S. COMPANIES START EFFORT TO ASSIST PEOPLE OF LEBANON
description: A group of leading American companies, saying there were acting ''out of an ethical principle,'' started a multimillion-dollar relief campaign yesterday to assist Lebanese civilians.

title: ISRAELIS DESTROY 4 MISSILE VEHICLES
description: Four more launch vehicles for Syrian antiaircraft missiles were destroyed today in Lebanon by Israeli jet fighters, the military command announced. In Damascus, the Syrian Defense Ministry acknowledged the loss of three launch vehicles.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $150,000 for the qr and $450,000 for the 9 mos

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE talk Tuesday evening was all about Yves. At least it was at L uchow's, where Mr. Montand was given a party on the occasion of his o pening at the Metropolitan Opera House. (This was at the new uptown L uchow's, which is down a flight of steps, as opposed to the old d owntown Luchow's, which was up a couple of steps and is now a c abaret disco called the Palace, not to be confused with the Palace, t he restaurant, or even the Palace, the theater. ).

title: Harvester Layoffs
description: About 320 International Harvester Company workers will be laid off here Oct. 4 and truck production will be cut by 13, to 57 a day, in the latest round of cutbacks by the troubled company.

title: TENTATIVE SETTLEMENT IS REACHED IN STRIKE AT JERSEY BUS COMPANY
description: A tentative agreement was announced yesterday in the seven-week strike against the DeCamp bus company in New Jersey and operations are expected to resume by late next week.

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss which included a loss of $474,000 from discontinued operations...C-After losses of $568,000 and $1,306,000 from discontinued operations for the latest and earlier periods, respectively

title: CALIFORNIA JURY IS EXPECTED TO GET CORONA MASS MURDER CASE TODAY
description: After seven months of trial, the jury is expected to begin on Friday to deliberate the fate of Juan V. Corona, accused of mass murder.

title: A BOUNTY OF SPECIALS TENNIS, BEAUTY, MUSIC
description: it's a weekend of specials for television. The tennis will be broadcast by CBS-TV from Flushing Meadows, Queens, as the United States Open reaches the finals. The women's singles final can be seen on a live transmission that begins tomorrow at noon. The men's singles final, scheduled for Sunday afternoon, will be part of a live telecast beginning at 4. The question: Will John McEnroe, playing in his hometown, be able to extend his run of three consecutive United States Open titles? Whatever the answer, the court action is likely to be spirited. 55th 'Miss America' With New Twists

title: Florida Banks In Sales Pact
description: The Atlantic Bancorporation of Jacksonville, Fla., announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase 15 offices of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. for $33 million if and when Florida National is acquired by the Southeast Banking Corporation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A MARATHON MOVE
description: W hen Allison Roe visits a city, she usually runs. Last fall she toured New York City and turned in the fastest marathon ever run by a woman.

title: ARGENTINA DEFAULT IS FEARED
description: While world attention focuses on Mexico's foreign debt problems, international bankers say that Argentina, another major debtor, may be more in danger of a default that could upset the world financial system.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Union at Justice?

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHETHER Rangers or Knicks fans are satisfied with the performances of their teams this season or not, there is cause for cheering among those who want to have a good dinner near Madison Square Garden. Opened just three months ago, the Bistro Bordeaux on Eighth Avenue, between 30th and 31st Streets, turns out stylish versions of authentic bistro-grill dishes at moderate prices.

title: BRAVES WIDEN GAP, BEATING VALENZUELA
description: Bruce Benedict hit a grand slam, and Bob Horner and Glenn Hubbard also hit homers tonight to power Atlanta to a 10-3 victory over Los Angeles. The victory enabled the Braves to increase their lead in the National League West to one and a half games over the Dodgers.

title: 13 Cars Seized by U.S.  In Move to Collect Loans
description: Federal marshals are seizing automobiles in a campaign to collect from people who have failed to repay student loans or reimburse the Government for overpayments, officials said today.

title: RATES ON TREASURIES INCH UP
description: Interest rates for Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday. Weak investor demand led market participants to worry more about such potential problems as a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds and faster growth in the money supply.

title: REAGAN'S APPLE PIE
description: The leaves are turning early this year in the White River Valley and on the slopes of the Green Mountains. Brandon Gap (elevation 2,170 feet) is already a harbinger of autumn, with beginning shades of red and gold glowing richly against summer's fading green.

title: 32-STORY CO-OP IS BUILT ON EAST 79TH ST.
description: Despite the fact that hundreds of brownstones, small apartment buildings and former commercial and industrial buildings have been transformed into cooperative residences in the last decade, most people still envision the typical luxury Manhattan co-op as a stately building that was originally built as such. Actually, one is hard pressed to name more than a handful that were.

title: TEXT OF FINAL DECLARATION AT ARAB LEAGUE MEETING
description: Following is the text of the declaration issued today at the end of the Arab League conference here:

title: AUCTIONS
description: EVERYTHING from corkscrews to Cezannes will be up for bidding this season at New York's auction houses. The sales, which begin next week and continue through July, will include art, antiques and jewelry from both prominent and less well-known collectors.

title: Padres 4, Reds 1
description: CINCINNATI (UPI) - Tim Lollar and Luis DeLeon combined on a fivehitter, and Joe Lefebvre hit a two-run double. The loss was the Reds' sixth in a row and came before only 7,292, the lowest attendance at Riverfront Stadium since Sept. 26, 1972.

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Book Sale at N.Y.U.
description: For browsers who venture downtown this weekend, there is a book mart tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. in the atrium of New York University's Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square South. About 2,000 used hard-cover books and paperbacks donated by faculty members and students will be on sale; proceeds benefit the Mamdouha S. Bobst Book Endowment Fund, which will be used to expand the university's library. Information: 598-2484.

title: Nonwhites in Transvaal Get Union Recognized
description: For the first time, South African mine companies have agreed to recognize a nonwhite trade union, a spokesman for the Chamber of Mines said today.

title: Assets of Money Funds Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds gained $175 million in the week ended Wednesday, increasing to $226.57 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Suzuki, With 65, Leads Japan Golf
description: Norio Suzuki shot a seven-under-par 65 today and took a one-stroke lead over Bill Rogers of the United States after the opening round of the $193,798 Suntory Open golf tournament.

title: YANKEES WIN, 5-4, IN 10th
description: Jerry Mumphrey, who is usually an unemotional player, pumped his fist in the air last night as he rounded the bases with a 10th-inning home run that gave the Yankees a 5-4 victory over the first-place Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Indians 3, Orioles 0
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Ron Hassey hit a seventh-inning, two-run double, and John Denny and Bud Anderson teamed up on a two-hitter. Denny, who has been bothered by shoulder ailments, held the Orioles to two hits over five innings.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Insider Fights City Hall

title: The Editorial Notebook The Shadow Over Race and I.Q.
description: Richard Herrnstein, a Harvard psychology professor, has a grievance against the national press: it ignores to the point of censorship the science of I.Q. testing and its truth, unpalatable to egalitarians, that intelligence is largely inherited. So he argues in the August issue of The Atlantic. His complaint may be valid, but the lack of attention is richly deserved.

title: THAD (PIE) VANN
description: Thad (Pie) Vann, football coach at the University of Southern Mississippi for 20 years, died Tuesday after a long illness.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DRAFT REGISTRATION AND THE RIGHT OF CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Reagan Acts to Aid Adoption of Peruvian, 3
description: Three-year-old Anita Asto's heart was operated upon today, and the wife of the President of the United States and the wife of the President of Peru are trying to help her get an American mother.

title: GOVERNMENT DISAVOWS ANY ASBESTOS LIABILITY
description: A Justice Department official asserted today that the Government has no legal responsibility to the thousands of workers who contracted asbestos-related diseases at Navy shipyards and privately owned yards that built ships under Government contracts during World War II.

title: LAWYER IN CASES OF NOTE RESOLUTE DESPITE LOSSES
description: For Herald Price Fahringer, a Manhattan lawyer with a passion for sports and a fondness for sports metaphors, this has not been a championship season. In fact, he has been in something of a slump recently.

title: 3 June Lewis Premieres
description: Three New York premieres will be presented this weekend by Dance June Lewis and Company at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.

title: TEXT OF SAKHAROV'S LETTER TO PUGWASH PARLEY ON SOVIET POLICY
description: Following is a letter sent by Andrei D. Sakharov to the Pugwash Conference. The letter was written for delivery to the anniversary meeting of the group in Canada earlier this year, but was not received in the West until August.

title: 2 MASTERS OF INDIAN CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Of all the great non-Western Classical-music traditions, that of India is perhaps the best known to American audiences. More musically accessible than Japanese music, more politically accessible than Chinese music, more transportable than the unwieldy gamelans of Indonesia, Indian Classical music was given a further boost with the fascination felt by 60's hippies for sitars, incense and Ravi Shankar.

title: SHOOTOUT AT BARLOW FARM: OLD ARTILLERY, THAT IS
description: If the sound of artillery guns is music to your ears, the place to be this weekend is the Barlow farm in Amenia, N.Y., where the annual national muzzle-loading artillery championships of America will be held.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK HAILS REPORT ON FUTILITY OF U.N.
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick today applauded Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar's account of a paralyzed United Nations, and pledged that the Reagan Administration would help strengthen the organization's peacekeeping machinery.

title: THE DANCE: FROM BASIC TRAINING
description: THE opening of the annual Riverside Dance Festival always marks the launching of an adventuresome dance season. The avant-garde is rarely shown at Riverside but among the festival's virtues is its reminder of how much range there is still within dance's mainstream.

title: Market Place; Competition On Air Parcels
description: YEAR-OLD Federal Express could pass the $1 billion revenue mark in the current fiscal year despite the recession and tough rivalries.

title: New TV Station Approved for L.I.
description: Long Island will soon be getting a new television station. The Federal Communications Commission has granted final approval for the new station, Channel 55 in Riverhead, which hopes to get on the air next year.

title: BENDIX CHIEF PLAYING FOR HIGH STAKES
description: William M. Agee, the corporate hunter-turnedhunted in the complicated Bendix, Martin Marietta, United Technologies takeover battle, appears on the brink of either the greatest success or worst failure of his career.

title: SOME STARS MISSING FOR FIRST GAMES
description: When the National Football League's 63d season begins Sunday, Billy Sims will play. But Rob Carpenter, Joe Cribbs, Leon Gray and Bob Swenson will not. These five were the most prominent holdouts in a summer of contention for pro football.

title: Grunfeld to Sign Knick Offer Sheet
description: The Knicks are expected to announce the signing of an offer sheet with Ernie Grunfeld today and the signing of Paul Westphal to a contract.

title: Immigrant, 71, Loses Citizenship on Nazi Past
description: A Federal judge today revoked the citizenship of a 71-year-old immigrant, saying that he had made ''material misrepresentation'' about his past as a Nazi concentration camp guard.

title: ATLANTA F.B.I. CHIEF PROMOTED
description: John Glover, the official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in charge of investigating Atlanta's child murders, was named today to a top bureau post that made him the highest-ranking black in the bureau's history.

title: PUGWASH PARLEY ASSAILED ON POLES
description: Some Western scientists and scholars attending a meeting in Warsaw late last month sought unsuccessfully to have the conference ''explicitly disassociate'' itself from the Polish Government's repression of demonstrations marking the second anniversary of the independent trade union Solidarity.

title: News Analysis
description: The surprising setback suffered by President Reagan in the House of Representatives today came in a battle over spending priorities and institutional powers that some of his advisers contended was unnecessary and that the White House did not go all out to win.

title: 'XICA,' BRAZILIAN COMEDY
description: IT'S usually a sign that something is wrong when the people on the screen laugh more than the people in the audience. It's also a bit nervy. After all, a movie is supposed to entertain its audience, not the other way around.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Yankees try to continue their barrage of home runs, facing the league leaders in that category.

title: Fall Fair in Cold Spring
description: The fifth Philipstown Fall Festival is planned tomorrow, rain or shine, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. along Main Street in Cold Spring, N.Y., in Westchester County.

title: JOHN M. OLIN, EXECUTIVE AND PHILANTHROPIST, DIES
description: John Merrill Olin, honorary chairman of the Olin Corporation and a noted conservationist, philanthropist and inventor, died Wednesday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Connors Gains Semifinals For Ninth Straight Year
description: Jimmy Connors has not stoked the emotional pump yet. But after reaching the semifinals of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday for a ninth consecutive year, Connors now faces Guillermo Vilas of Argentina in what could be the liveliest weekend of the year in the sport.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Attacks Dissidents
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation filed a complaint in United States District Court in New York against a dissident stockholder group, accusing it of having violated securities laws by misrepresenting the reasons for its purchases.

title: BROADWAY
description: LARRY ATLAS could be considered a member of a rare species, and an endangered one at that. He is one of two young American playwrights who will have new works opening on Broadway this season. The other member of that select group is Beth Henley, whose ''The Wake of Jamey Foster'' will open Oct. 14 at the Eugene O'Neill. But unlike the 30-year-old Miss Henley, who won the Pulitzer Prize for ''Crimes of the Heart,'' Mr. Atlas, who is 34, does not have a track record as a playwright. His ''Total Abandon,'' which is to open on Broadway in the winter, is his first full-length play.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eddie Firmani, who coached the Cosmos from 1977 to 1979, was dismissed as head coach at Montreal yesterday after the Manic had finished in second place in the North American Soccer League's Eastern Division but then lost in the playoff quarterfinals. The Manic said that two assistant coaches, Pierre Mindru and Andy Lynch, would run the club on an interim basis. . . . The New Jersey Devils have invited Neil Hawryliw, a 26-year-old right wing who has spent five seasons in the minor leagues, to their training camp, which opens Monday. Hawryliw, a free agent from the Islander organization, spent last season at the farm club in Indianapolis.

title: Chrysler Plans A Sporty Car
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would produce a new high-performance car for sale in early 1983 with the help of Carroll Shelby, the sports car driver and designer.

title: Boy's Death Held Suspicious
description: A 5-year-old boy was found dead ''under suspicious circumstances'' in his Harlem apartment last night, the police said. The boy, Omar Wilson, of Apt. 9, 1947 Seventh Avenue, was found on a bedroom floor at 10 P.M. with bruises about his body and indications that he had drowned in the bathtub, according to Police Officer John Clifford, a police spokesman.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DISREGARD OF RISKS AND SKEPTICS PAID OFF
description: A reporter once asked Toddie Lee Wynne, an 85-year-old oil executive from Dallas who was a backer of Space Services Inc. of America, whether trying to launch spaceships commercially was too great a business risk. According to a Space Services official who was there, Mr. Wynne simply pointed to one of his oil rigs and said, ''It's a lot less risky than that business over there.''

title: ARABS ADOPT PLAN FOR MIDEAST PEACE AT MOROCCO TALKS
description: Arab leaders adopted a resolution late tonight that they said represented a united Arab peace plan for the Middle East containing a solution to the problem of the Palestinians.

title: Salvador Insurgents Cut Vital Rail Link
description: Guerrillas have destroyed a railroad trestle in eastern El Salvador, severing the only rail link to the region, the authorities said today.

title: STAGE: 'INSERTS' ADAPTED
description: IN ''Inserts,'' an unnecessary stage adaptation of John Byrum's 1975 movie, Kevin O'Connor plays a kind of directorial equivalent of the Gloria Swanson character in ''Sunset Boulevard.'' Down on his luck since the advent of talking pictures, this once-celebrated silent-movie director hides out in a decrepit Hollywood mansion, complete with a pool in the backyard. He lives on alcohol and on a memory of a tryst with Theda Bara in the Garden of Allah.

title: Tides Win, 4-0,
description: Mike Davis drilled a bases-loaded single that drove in two runs in the fifth inning and led the Tidewater Tides to a 4-0 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in the International League playoffs tonight.

title: VENDOR CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1982; The Economy
description: Business has continued to reduce plans to invest in expansion and modernization through 1982, the Commerce Department reported. Capital spending for the year was estimated at 4.4 percent below the 1981 level. The reduction comes despite the huge ''supply side'' tax cut that the Reagan Administration won for business in 1981. (Page A1.) Nonetheless, President Reagan told an audience in Manhattan, Kan., that ''recovery has been sighted.'' (D17.)

title: Cribbs, Bills Still Apart
description: Hopes were briefly raised earlier this week that the running back Joe Cribbs would end his holdout and report to the Buffalo Bills in time for the season opener this weekend. But now Cribbs, who has been trying to renegotiate his contract, says that his effort to arrange a meeting with Ralph Wilson, the team's owner, has fallen through and that the prospects of his returning this season are not good. ... Coach Monte Clark of the Detroit Lions barely batted an eye when his place-kicker, Eddie Murray, and his punter, Tom Skladany, stalked out of training camp just as Billy Sims, ending his holdout, walked in.

title: STUART'S JEFFERSON IS PURCHASED JOINTLY
description: The National Portrait Gallery and the organization that operates Monticello, the restored home of Thomas Jefferson, announced today that they had jointly purchased a rare Gilbert Stuart painting of Jefferson for $1 million and that the two institutions would display it alternately.

title: WRONG SOURCE OF FUNDS FOR A NEW YORK STATE POLICE CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: PITT EDGES NORTH CAROLINA, 7-6
description: Pittsburgh barely managed to justify its early selection as the No.1 team in the nation tonight when Dan Marino threw a 4-yard touchdown pass and Snuffy Everett kicked the winning extra point for a 7-6 victory over North Carolina in a defensive and mistake-filled season opener.

title: GROUP SHOW CELEBRATES POLLOCK LEGACY IN ART
description: WHILE the flood tide of Expressionist figure painting surges around us, the newish Harm Bouckaert Gallery (100 Hudson Street, between Franklin and Leonard Streets) has defiantly staked itself out as a bastion of abstract art. This unfashionable stance is evident in its current show, ''Recent Aspects of Allover,'' a serene display of paintings, drawings, sculptures and prints in which the rude, emotional figure that we now see in galleries all over (no pun intended) town has not been allowed to intrude.

title: Giants 5, Astros 1
description: HOUSTON (AP) - San Francisco's Dave Bergman got four straight hits, including a home run in the seventh inning, and scored three times. Bergman, a former Astro, singled in the fifth inning and went to third on a single by Milt May.

title: Javelin Title at 229-9 To Greek Woman
description: Anna Verouli, a 25-year-old Greek teacher who quit her job to train for the European track and field championships, electrified a capacity crowd of 80,000 here with an upset victory as she made the fifth-longest women's javelin throw in history, 229 feet 9 inches.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION AND THE RIGHT OF CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO PARTIES HERALD THE SEASON TO COME
description: The season, as it was once called, unofficially began Wednesday night with the opening of the Irving Penn photograph exhibition at the Marlborough Gallery, followed by the first fashion show of the snugly sexy clothes of Azzedine Alaia at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: 'ISRAEL IS MY HOME,' VICTIM OF NAZI'S TELLS RUSSIANS
description: For a survivor of the camps at Maidanek, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, Berta Shokhovsky is blessedly unmarked. She has a broad, quick smile and a warmth that permeates the cramped Moscow apartment that she shares with her daughter's family. She has barely a harsh word for anyone but the Nazis, and she has learned to deal with her memories of them with outward tranquillity.

title: Alcoa Plans a Sale
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it agreed in principle to sell its Alcas Cutlery Corporation unit in Olean, N.Y., to a group of Alcas officers.

title: Vault Talks
description: Dave Schatzle, a sophomore majoring in international studies at Manhattan College, spent seven weeks in the Soviet Union this summer, studying Russian. Because he is also a pole-vaulter on the Manhattan track team, Schatzle was intrigued when he heard that a major track meet was being held at Kiev Stadium while he was in Kiev.

title: Motherwell in Munich.
description: BEGINNING in early November, 10 paintings by Robert Motherwell, one of the leading figures of the New York School, will be on display in perpetuity at the Bayrisch Staatsgalerie Moderner Kunst - the Bavarian State Museum of Modern Art - in Munich, West Germany.

title: PANEL PONDERS BLOCKED SIDEWALKS
description: Many sidewalks in New York City are blocked by fruit and vegetable stands, clothing racks and flower displays. Members of the City Council have been aware of this for a long time, and yesterday the Council's Committee on Consumer Affairs tackled the question of what to do about it.

title: PRESIDENT CITES PROGRESS ON ECONOMY
description: President Reagan began his fall campaign travels today with a speech that prominently touched the issues of school prayer and abortion and claimed progress in ending the nation's ''long and terrible night'' of economic troubles.

title: Lionel Proposal
description: The Lionel Corporation and two subsidiaries, Lionel Leisure Inc. and the Consolidated Toy Company, which filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors earlier this year, said they had presented a plan to pay back the $136 million owed to their creditors. Lionel's unsecured creditors would be paid an initial 37 cents on the dollar of their allowed claims. The rest would be paid in minimum annual installments of 6 percent until the principal amount was amortized.

title: Playing Games With Real Money
description: Not to be outdone by the Administration's crowd-pleasing campaign to balance the budget by constitutional amendment, top Democrats in Congress propose now to lower interest rates by legislation. They, too, are being hypocritical and wrong-headed.

title: A ROLE FOR SCIENTISTS IN SHAPING NUCLEAR POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Rebuffs Pennsylvania on Funds
description: The Supreme Court today rejected a request by Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania to restore $91 million in Federal highway funds for the state that were frozen in a dispute over automobile emission tests.

title: First Women's Bank
description: The board of the First Women's Bank of New York said yesterday that it would oppose the applications of Ralph Vallone Jr., N.Y. Banco Holdings Ltd. and the Valbanque Corporation to acquire 35 percent of its stock.

title: TRUDEAU SHUFFLES 4 CABINET POSTS IN AN ATTEMPT TO BOLSTER ECONOMY
description: With renewed resolve to overcome Canada's serious and spreading economic crisis, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today directed his four most prominent Cabinet Ministers to exchange portfolios.

title: NASSAU G.O.P. REMOVES 'SUCCESSOR 'TO MARGIOTTA
description: State Senator Ralph J. Marino has been ousted as vice chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party at the insistence of Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: Neutral Against the Courts
description: Listening to the political right rather than his own lawyer, President Reagan says he will stand mute on the school prayer bill that some are trying to attach to the debt-ceiling legislation. Attorney General William French Smith rendered a worthy legal opinion in May sharply criticizing bills to strip the Supreme Court of power in cases involving prayer in public schools. But Mr. Reagan is ignoring that opinion and says he won't oppose the measure.

title: Rep. Boggs Is Injured in Fall
description: Representative Lindy Boggs is heading into Louisiana's primary election Saturday with a bit of a handicap: three cracked ribs. Peggy Hannan, an aide to the Louisiana Democrat, said Mrs. Boggs fell last week at her home in New Orleans but was going ''full speed ahead'' in preparation for the primary despite the injury.

title: After the Veto Battle
description: The showdown over the $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill - resulting in Congress's override of the President's veto - was a lesson in cynical dissembling.

title: F. Walter Bliss, State Justice Appointed by Roosevelt, Dies
description: F. Walter Bliss, who was appointed to the New York State Supreme Court by Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt, died Wednesday at Community Hospital in Cobleskill, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Middleburgh, N.Y.

title: Lake Placid Eyed As Training Site
description: This country has just one Olympic national training center, the 34-acre complex at Colorado Springs that is also headquarters for the United States Olympic Committee. But today the committee's executive board is expected to approve Lake Placid, N.Y., as a second national training center, dedicated to winter sports.

title:
PATENTS;
'Dialing', A Phone By Voice
description: AN automatic telephone device invented at Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., enables callers to reach their parties by speech instead of finger movements: It is necessary only to pronounce names or numbers. The spoken-word ''dialer,'' which is not in production, can replace rotary or push-button devices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Traffic Control, The Other Game in Town

title: Ship Ban in Falklands Lifted
description: Britain announced today that it had reopened the Falkland Islands to ships from all countries except Argentina. The Defense Ministry said restrictions limiting foreign vessels to a zone three miles off the South Atlantic islands had been lifted after the completion of mine sweeping. But it warned that ''future hazards may appear, so people wanting to enter the area should contact the harbor master or a Royal Navy ship.''

title: Your Money; Combining Insurance
description: IMAGINE having one insurance policy for coverage that previously required two, three or even more. Some policyholders need imagine no longer because such combined policies for homeowner, automobile and possibly other insurance already exist.

title: A NAVY MAN RETURNS HOME
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. A s George Welsh, the new football coach at the University of Virginia, completed preparations for his emotional trip home in the first week of his first season with the Cavaliers, Dick Schultz, Virginia's athletic director, completed a sale.

title: SEAHAWKS TO ANSWER CHARGE
description: The New York regional director of the National Labor Relations Board has given the Seattle Seahawks until Monday to answer unfairlabor-practice charges brought against the team by the National Football League Players Association on behalf of Sam McCullum, the Seahawks' player representative, who was released earlier this week.

title: FLAVOR FOOTNOTES FROM READERS
description: S everal subjects discussed in recent columns drew responses from readers with suggestions, questions and corrections that seemed worth passing along.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 30
Appeals Court Backs Varied Voting Hours
description: New York's highest court ruled today that different areas of the state can have different voting hours in the September primary election.

title: A CRITICAL MOMENT FOR JEWS
description: My father, Nahum Goldmann, was laid to rest in Jerusalem on Sept. 2 just hours after President Reagan's bold new peace initiative was presented to the Israeli Government. Father was buried on Mount Herzl alongside the five other former presidents of the World Zionist Organization, of which he was the last. Had he lived but a few days more, he would surely have applauded the courage and thrust of the American plan. Father, were he alive today, would call upon American Jews to give support to the President's efforts.

title: Bridge: Trouble May Be Greatest When It Appears Unlikely
description: There is neither a cloud in the sky nor a ripple on the water. Bringing your small boat into harbor will not, it seems, present the slightest problem. But the weather changes abruptly. In a moment you are in the middle of a storm, fighting for survival.

title: NEW RULES MAY CUT THE COST OF A FUNERAL
description: Even near the end of his life, Friedrich Neuhauser did not want to talk about death. And so one evening last summer, his 70-year-old wife, Edna, found herself learning how to arrange a funeral.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1982; Companies
description: Martin Marietta said about 75 percent of Bendix's stock was tendered by the Thursday midnight deadline. The announcement intensified the takeover struggle between Bendix, on one side, and Marietta and United Technologies on the other. Earlier, Bendix said 58 percent of Marietta's shares had been tendered to it. The outcome is said to depend on withdrawal deadlines as well as the tangle of laws in which the battle is becoming ensnarled. (Page 35.)

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.)
