Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Astros vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Houston. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Boxing Gerrie Coetzee vs. Stan Ward, heavyweights, 10 rounds, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. Coetzee has a 27-3 record, with 15 knockouts; Ward is 15-4-2, with 7 knockouts. The first of six preliminaries begins at 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Tennis United States Open, at the National Tennis Center, Flushing Meadows, Queens. Jimmy Connors vs. Guillermo Vilas, men's semifinal, 11 A.M., followed by Chris Evert Lloyd vs. Hana Mandlikova, women's final, and John McEnroe vs. Ivan Lendl, men's semifinal. (Television - Channel 2, noon.)

title: Let Profit Be Private
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ARGENTINA'S JUNTA IS RE-ESTABLISHED
description: Argentina's armed forces announced today that the air force and the navy were joining the Government of President Reynaldo Bignone, a retired army general.

title: STATE SAYS CITY MUST RETRENCH TO PAY FOR ITS NEW UNION PACT
description: The Koch administration will have to make sharp cuts in its expenses very soon to pay for the labor contract it has tentatively agreed to with municipal unions, the executive director of the state's Financial Control Board said yesterday.

title: Return of the Caveman
description: William (Caveman) Lee has regained his license to box in New Jersey after passing medical tests designed to determine whether he was a drug user. Lee's license was suspended when, having been knocked out by Marvelous Marvin Hagler after 67 seconds of a middleweight title bout on March 7, he took a postfight urine test that disclosed traces of morphine and quinine.

title: WRITERS FIND HAVEN IN GEORGETOWN
description: It turns out that Georgetown, where Indians traded furs long before the area became known as a center of Washington's social and political power, has become a writers' trading post. The local branch of the public library recently identified 88 published authors and expects to find 75 others living within the 100-block area, where minks are now trapped only on evening coats.

title: MARSHALL ASSAILS HIGH COURT ON ITS SUMMARY PROCEDURES
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall chastised the United States Supreme Court today for what he called its ''growing and inexplicable readiness'' to dispose of cases summarily, without permitting the parties to address the underlying issues.

title: Dow Drops by 5.71 On Climb in Rates
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday in response to rising interest rates and the Congressional vote to override President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental spending bill. The overriding of the veto rekindled concern by investors over the size of Federal budget deficits.

title: ROCK: THREE AT THE KITCHEN
description: The Kitchen's first musical program of its season, which began Thursday night and ends with two performances tonight, offers a formal artistic context for two rock veterans, John Cale and Bob Neuwirth, accompanied by a saxophonist, Ruskin Germino.

title: Contact Photo Prints Are Ready Immediately
description: A camera attachment for obtaining instant contact prints of pictures taken was patented this week by Martin Forscher, who operates the Professional Camera Repair Service in New York.

title: CBS REPORTEDLY OFFERS TIME TO WESTMORELAND
description: CBS News has offered Gen. William C. Westmoreland 15 minutes of unedited time during a proposed one-hour prime-time program to follow up the documentary ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception,'' which ran into criticism after it was broadcast last January, according to a source close to General Westmoreland.

title: FEEBLE ATTACK ON TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARIETTA DRAWS 75% OF BENDIX
description: The takeover struggle pitting the Bendix Corporation against the Martin Marietta Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation intensified yesterday when Martin Marietta announced that about 75 percent of Bendix's outstanding stock had been tendered by the Thursday midnight deadline.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $900 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply increased by $900 million in the week ended Sept.1. The closely watched M-1 measure of money circulating in the economy has now increased for six consecutive weeks, by $6.6 billion, to a level of $457.1 billion, above the Fed's growth targets for both the current quarter and year. The more broadly defined money supply measure known as M-2, which the Fed reports monthly, averaged $1,946.1 billion in August and is also growing faster than the central bank's targets.

title: Doctor Orders a Close Watch On Mrs. Truman's Vital Signs
description: Bleeding from Bess Truman's ulcer was reported under control today, but her doctor said the temperature and heartbeat of the 97-year-old former First Lady remained high and she was still in serious condition.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS TO FIGHT ON
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental spending bill, completing the first major defeat administered to the President by the 97th Congress.

title: 'IRREPLACEABLE' MAYAN ITEMS STOLEN AT MUSEUM
description: A thief who apparently hid in the American Museum of Natural History after it closed stole 25 Mayan jade artifacts and escaped by rope from a second-floor window, authorities said yesterday.

title: Court to Speed Appeal On Joint Seattle Papers
description: A Federal appeals court has agreed to hear an appeal of a lower court's ruling that would prevent Seattle's two daily newspapers from operating jointly.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's political instincts may tell him to exercise a string of vetoes on budget measures in the weeks ahead. But today's veto defeat, the Administration's biggest loss in Congress in 20 months, could mean that Mr. Reagan will have to choose his fights with care.

title: FRANC SLUMPS ON DEVALUATION FEARS
description: The French franc slumped to a record low today of 7.085 to the dollar, or 14.1 American cents, as fears persisted that President Francois Mitterrand might be forced to devalue the currency for the third time since taking office 15 months ago.

title: Knicks Plan to Seek Cummings or King
description: The Knicks, apparently motivated by some bold moves of rival teams in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference, have made a few ambitious plans of their own.

title: New 4-Party Coalition Takes Office in Denmark
description: Denmark's first non-Socialist Government in seven years was officially installed today amid growing rumors of a Danish devaluation.

title: BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Producer Prices Up By 0.6%
description: The Government today reported another moderate rise in the Producer Price Index, a harbinger of future consumer price changes.

title: Coast Official Gets Job Back
description: California's outspoken savings and loan commissioner, who was suspended indefinitely on Sept.1 after a clash with her supervisor in Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s administration, was formally reinstated late Thursday, it was learned today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend on popular music yesterday gave an incorrect location and phone number for reser- vations at Marty's supper club. The club is at 1265 Third Avenue at 73d Street. The telephone number is 249- 4100.

title: A LEGISLATED DILEMMA FOR THE TERMINALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Pesticide Manufacturer Reports Florida Seepage
description: The manufacturer of the pesticide Temik says tests have found excessive levels of the chemical in some Florida ground water but says it poses no risks.

title: Gold Beauty Wins by 6
description: Gold Beauty, a 3-year-old filly, excelled against males and older horses with a six-length victory yesterday in the Fall Highweight Handicap at Belmont Park. Gold Beauty ran her career record to six for six with the victory over a top field of sprinters.

title: WHIPPING WOOLCO INTO SHAPE
description: Bruce G. Allbright expected a challenge when he accepted the job of chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Woolworth/ Woolco division of the F.W. Woolworth Company eight months ago. So far, the job has met his expectations.

title: Philadelphia Bank Announces Merger
description: The Philadelphia National Corporation, Philadelphia's largest bank holding company, announced today that it would merge with the National Central Financial Corporation, holding company for the Hamilton Bank of Lancaster, Pa., in a tax-free exchange of stock valued at $146.5 million.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Arafat Will Visit Italy And Meet the President
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will visit Italy Wednesday and be received by President Sandro Pertini, the P.L.O.'s representative here announced today.

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATE IN CAPITAL DROPS COURT THREAT
description: Patricia Roberts Harris, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, today withdrew her threat to go to court to seek a postponement of Tuesday's municipal primary election.

title: SOLIDARITY'S FUGITIVE LEADERS CALL PROTESTS 'MORAL VICTORY'
description: Underground leaders of the suspended Solidarity labor union today called last week's widespread anti-Government demonstrations a ''moral victory'' that proved that ''Polish society is determined to fight for its rights.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday incorrectly described a hymn that the Episcopal Church decided not to drop from its revised hymnal. The hymn begins ''Almighty Father, Strong to Save,'' and is a variation of the Navy Hymn, which begins ''Eternal Father, Strong to Save.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Campaign Pitch: All in the Delivery

title: CHINATOWN JAIL MIGHT PUT SPACE TO PRIVATE USES
description: The New York City Correction Commissioner said yesterday that he would consider including space for community or commercial use in a high-rise jail the department would like to build at the edge of Chinatown.

title: Occidental Merger
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has deposited $1.89 billion to pay for its 45 percent interest of the Cities Service Company, thereby setting into motion its $4.2 billion takeover of the company. Warren Shimmerlik, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said in a new report on the implications of the merger that he thought Occidental was taking on too much debt at the wrong time, and lowered his estimate of Occidental's 1983 earnings to $2 a share, from $4.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: The yr-ago net income and shr earnings figures are restated to reflect certain revs refunds

title: Thayer Wendell Bride Of Byron K. Adams Jr.
description: Thayer Wendell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan L.P. Wendell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Essex, Mass., was married in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Mass., yesterday to Byron K. Adams Jr., son of Mr. Adams of Somerville, N.J., and Arlene Pugh Adams of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James J. Harrington, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Andrew Wolmsley of Christ Episcopal Church in Portola Valley, Calif.

title: DeLorean Bailout
description: A new company formed by American businessman John DeLorean has agreed to the initial terms set by receivers to purchase the car plant he built here from them, a Government spokesman said today. He said the deal, seen here as the last change to save the failed sports car factory started up three years ago by the former General Motors executive, still depended on the American company producing the necessary money. The plant closed in May because of finance problems and low sales.

title: METS SET BACK CARDINALS, 2-1
description: Dave Kingman hit the first inside-the-park home run of big league career, and Craig Swan and Jesse Orosco combined for a three-hitter tonight as the Mets knocked the St. Louis Cardinals out of first place.

title: 2 Dozen to Read Poems In Stephen Biko Tribute
description: More than two dozen poets are scheduled to participate here in a poetry reading tomorrow in honor of Stephen Biko, the South African student leader who died while he was a prisoner of the South African security police five years ago.

title: AUTHORITIES SAY RING COMMITTED 1,000 BURGLARIES
description: Two brothers from Queens were arrested yesterday and accused of having led a ring that committed about 1,000 burglaries and attempted burglaries of banks, jewelry enterprises, warehouses and other commercial establishments in the city in recent years.

title: BRITAIN, ANGRY AT U.S., AGAIN DEFIES SANCTIONS
description: The British Government warned today that Washington was ''damaging trans-Atlantic relations'' with its insistence that European manufacturers halt the shipment of parts built with American technology to the Soviet Union for a vast pipeline project.

title: Connor, in 56-8 3/4, Wins Triple Jump
description: Keith Connor, a senior at Southern Methodist University, won the triple jump at the European Track and Field Championships tonight, covering 56 feet 8 3/4 inches to defeat Vasily Grischenkov of the Soviet Union by 5 1/2 inches.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Some Back to School Cheer

title: 2 Charged With Murder Of Florida Professor
description: Two young men were taken before a county judge today and formally charged with first-degree murder in the death of Howard Appledorf, a professor at the University of Florida.

title: CITY HALL'S OMINOUS RISE AS A LANDLORD BY DEFAULT
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Sets Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said 1,300 hourly workers at its Hydra-matic division plant at Ypsilanti, Mich., would be laid off indefinitely starting Monday because of poor car sales. John T. Lynch, a G.M. spokesman, said the move would leave 8,700 workers at the Willow Run plant. The facility produces automatic transmissions for cars and trucks.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A LEGISLATED DILEMMA FOR THE TERMINALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After a tax loss of $366,000 and a $1.3 million gain from the sale of a foreign subsidiary...C-After a tax credit of $647,000

title: G.O.P. SEES HARD CHOICE IN A HOUSE RACE UPSTATE
description: Republicans here - a fairly conservative lot who found it difficult to vote for former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller but who are eager to elect Lewis E. Lehrman - are in a quandary.

title: IN LIEU OF 'NEW GIMMICKS' TO UNSNARL TRAFFIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Bolivia Misses a Debt Payment
description: Bolivia has failed to meet a $10.2 million installment on a loan owed to a group of 128 foreign banks, the Bank of America said yesterday. The installment was due Thursday.

title: What's New About U.N. Anarchy?
description: After less than a year atop the United Nations glass house, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is throwing rocks at the right targets. The nations are not united, he insists, even in a desire to avoid calamitous wars. The weak may complain, but those who feel strong, large or small, routinely ignore or defy the U.N.'s machinery for conciliation.

title: The Talk of Atlanta
description: Much of the summer conversation in this capital of the South can be dominated by tales of woe about kudzu and mildew. Kudzu is a vine that tends to embrace everything it touches and never lets go without a fight. Mildew, of course, stains everything from basement to roof.

title: Parley in Bloomingdale Suit
description: An aide to President Reagan met in the White House last month with a lawyer for Vicky Morgan, the former model who had filed a $10 million suit against the late Alfred S. Bloomingdale, the lawyer, Marvin Mitchelson, said today. Mr. Bloomingdale, a close friend of President Reagan, died of cancer last month at the age of 66. Mr. Mitchelson said he was asked to come to the White House by A. Morgan Mason, a special assistant to the President. He gave few other details of the reported meeting.

title:
Patents;
Membrane Collects Energy From Wind
description: A wind power machine that is not a windmill and has no rotating turbines is designed to generate electric power on housetops. The inventor, Donald E. Lipfert of Woolwich, Me., who received patent 4,348,594 this week, will assign the rights to Robert Zeidman Associates Inc., Greenwich, Conn., for which he is a consultant.

title: PROTESTERS MARCH IN BALTIMORE
description: Protesters marched peacefully Thursday night in a predominantly black neigborhood where a stone-throwing mob had burned a police car to protest the death of a man suspected of selling narcotics.

title: KOREAN MERCHANTS FACE IRE IN HARLEM
description: Businesses owned by Koreans along 125th Street in Harlem are at the center of a controversy stemming from charges that they exploit blacks. But Harlem residents are divided on the issue, with some urging that blacks boycott the Koreans' stores and others calling for cooperation between the two groups.

title:
Patents;
Leaching of Metals
description: The leaching of gold and silver from mining residue is often halted in winter, when the leaching liquid is frozen.

title: LARGE GRAIN CROPS SEEN
description: American grain farmers are expected to produce record wheat, corn and soybean crops this year, while the Soviet Union is expected to harvest its poorest grain crop since 1975, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Woman, 87, Survives Ordeal
description: An 87-year-old woman who was beaten, bound and imprisoned in her home by robbers spent two days gouging and kicking her way through a wall before she was rescued after a telephone repairman heard her muffled cries, the authorities said. Ednah Philley, a former music teacher, was in fair condition today in Allegan General Hospital, officials said.

title: MRS. LLOYD WILL OPPOSE MISS MANDLIKOVA IN FINAL
description: Last year, Chris Evert Lloyd and Hana Mandlikova were sitting in the players' waiting room before their Wimbledon final when Miss Mandlikova spotted a framed photograph on the wall.

title: 2 Deaths Warrants in Florida
description: Gov. Bob Graham signed death warrants Thursday against Freddie Lee Hall and Mack Ruffin Jr., saying there was no basis for altering the court-imposed sentences. The two men were convicted of the murder of a Leesburg woman, Karol Lea Hurst, and of a sheriff's deputy, Lonnie C. Coburn, in 1978.

title: The Loss of a Judge at Indian Point
description: A disturbingly deep fissure has sprung open between the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the members of its own board of hearing examiners, the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board, who are inquiring into the safety of the reactors at Indian Point. The chairman of the inquiry panel, Administrative Judge Louis J. Carter, resigned last week, explaining that the commission was imposing rules he deemed incompatible with due process. Yesterday the commission decided to postpone adoption of the controversial rules until next week.

title: HISTORY IS DEBUNK
description: One of the drawbacks about being famous is that sooner or later you're almost certain to be debunked. Even Abraham Lincoln was debunked a few years ago. You wouldn't think a man as happily entrenched in the history books as Lincoln could get himself debunked, would you? Well, Lincoln managed to do it. He got himself debunked as a racist.

title: BRIEFING
description: Coin of the Wrong Realm

title: Canadiens Make Trades
description: The Montreal Canadiens, beset by contract problems with a number of players, began breaking up that old gang of theirs with a vengeance. In perhaps the heaviest day of hockey trading by one team in recent years, the Canadiens sent two defensemen, Brian Engblom and Rod Langway, and two forwards, Doug Jarvis and Craig Laughlin, to the Washington Capitals in exchange for the star center Ryan Walter and the defenseman Rick Green.

title: HEADED MANY ORGANIZATIONS
description: Jacob Philip Rudin, rabbi emeritus of Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., and a Jewish scholar, author and lecturer, died yesterday at the Sarah Newman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Arms Control Chief Says Soviet Seeks Domination
description: The director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today that the Soviet Union wanted to bring all Europe, Asia, Africa and the Middle East under its control, leaving the United States ''no choice but to acquiesce in Soviet hegemony.''

title: SURPRISES IN STORE AT FILM FESTIVAL
description: When tickets for the 20th New York Film Festival go on sale tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall, there will be some surprises in store. The first film likely to sell out will be an obscure Yiddish talkie made in the late 1930's. The festival roster will barely contain any French films, despite the blatant Francophilia of past years. Australia, despite its recent pre-eminence in cinema circles, will not be represented at all.

title: FOR KNOPF, TURNING 90: MEMORIES OF THE GREAT
description: He is the perfect publisher. - H.L. Mencken. He has of course published books he thought very second-rate, and he has successfully done business with people who were not congenial to him. But in his own mind he kept the two sets of values apart, clear and distinct. - Willa Cather.

title: Gulfstream Stock
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation said its president, Allen E. Paulson, had bought $25 million worth of the company's stock and now owned 90 percent of the company.

title: 2 Jail Escapees Seized Near Casino in Jersey
description: John Humanik Jr., a convicted murderer, and one of the two other men who escaped with him from the Ocean County Jail were captured tonight in Atlantic City after a day at large, officials said.

title: AIR-POLLUTION 'RIGHTS'
description: On April 22, 1889, frontier settlers lined up their wagons at the territorial border of Oklahoma. At the sound of an Army cannon, they raced across the plains to stake their claims to hundreds of square miles of land. A bygone era? Hardly. Today, the Government is sponsoring an even larger give-away of public resources. The beneficiaries are not homesteaders but the largest industrial corporations.

title: U.S. MARINES LEAVE LEBANESE CAPITAL
description: The 800 United States marines who stood guard as thousands of Palestinian guerrillas withdrew from west Beirut left Lebanon this morning by helicopter and ship and rejoined the Sixth Fleet.

title: UNIFORM FORCES SAY THEY WANT THEIR OWN PACT
description: Leaders of the Uniformed Forces Coalition met promptly with city negotiators yesterday and made clear that they would not be satisfied with a contract settlement patterned after the one tentatively reached Thursday with non-uniformed employees.

title: Fighter's Friend
description: Whenever Gerrie Coetzee, the South African heavyweight, traveled to other countries to fight, he made a habit of calling home every day to make sure Wendy was O.K. When he decided to take up semipermanent residence in Vineland, N.J., in order to train in this country, Coetzee wanted Wendy at his side. So she made her first trip abroad.

title: TOSCO-AZL LINK
description: The Tosco Corporation said that it had reached an agreement to accquire AZL Resources Inc., an energy exploration and development company, for $95 million in cash and Tosco common stock.

title: IN A LESS VIOLENT BEIRUT, STARK FEAR IS DISSOLVING INTO MERE NERVOUSNESS
description: The cement layers of rubble and the twisted steel that were offices and homes remain, monuments to war and death in this once-charming capital by the blue, wind-scalloped waters of the Mediterranean.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1982
description: International Key Arab peace proposals were ''at a considerable variance'' with President Reagan's Middle East initiative, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said, but there was the possibility of a ''breakthrough'' if the Arab leaders had decided to recognize Israel's right to exist. He made the first authoritative American response to Thursday's communique issued by the Arab League in Fez, Morocco, in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. (Page 1, Column 3.) The Arab plan was a victory for Arab moderates, Western diplomats in Amman, Jordan, said, and they expected that Jordan and Saudi Arabia would play a central role in future Middle East negotiations. (4:5.)

title: ISRAEL REJECTS ARAB PLAN, TERMING IT DESTRUCTIVE
description: Israel today firmly rejected the peace plan offered by the Arab League at its meeting in Fez, Morocco, dismissing it as devoid of new proposals and as a design for Israel's eventual annihilation.

title: PEKING LEADER OPTS FOR ADVISORY ROLE
description: China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, formally became only an adviser to the Communist Party today, but none of the other members of the top leadership joined him in the role.

title: Sockers to Meet Cosmos for Title
description: The Seattle Sounders scored 1 minute 56 seconds into overtime tonight to defeat the Fort Lauderdale Strikers, 1-0, and win their North American Soccer League semifinal series, two games to one.

title: DISCLOSURE RULES FOR BANKS PRESSED
description: The decision of the Office of Management and Budget to accept, after initially disapproving, plans by Federal regulators to require much more disclosure of bank financial data is the latest in a series of such calls involving an industry that has a penchant for secrecy.

title: Acquisitions In Banking
description: Southern Bancorp Inc., a bank holding company, said yesterday that it intended to offer $18 a share, or $6.7 million, for 372,000 shares, or 40 percent, of the common stock of the National Bank of South Carolina.

title: PEAT, MARWICK SETTLES IN N.S.M. HOLDERS SUIT
description: Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. has agreed to pay nearly $6.4 million to the former shareholders of the National Student Marketing Corporation, settling the last major portion of a 12-year-old class action against the former marketing company and its auditors and legal counsel. The company's high-flying stock collapsed amid disclosures of securities fraud in 1970.

title: U.P.S. OBTAINS RESTRAINT ORDER AGAINST STRIKERS
description: A strike disrupted United Parcel Service deliveries and pickups in New York, on Long Island and in Westchester County for a second day yesterday. However, a Federal restraining order was served on the union in the afternoon, and a company spokesman said service was expected to return to normal on Monday.

title: FORBES'S HUNT FOR RICHEST 400
description: Leading the list is Daniel Keith Ludwig, builder of a shipping empire, troubled by a bad back for 50 years, but said to be worth more than $2 billion. There are Perry Richardson Bass and Sid Richardson Bass, father and son, oil barons whose joint worth is more than $2 billion. Then come other familiar names: the Hunts and Marvin Davis and David Rockefeller and Paul Mellon - names synonymous with canyons of gold.

title: News Analysis
description: Out of the annual meeting of the world's two principal lending agencies has come a consensus that the money will be provided to support the international financial system, but only if heavily indebted countries agree to a long period of economic belt-tightening.

title: Walker Ailing Again
description: Wesley Walker, the Jets' wide receiver whose career has been hampered by numerous ailments, has contracted Bell's palsy, causing paralysis on the left side of his face. But his is a mild case, and it should not affect his performance in the season opener against Miami tomorrow or his football future, according to Bob Reese, the team's trainer.

title: Cowens for Buckner
description: The Milwaukee Bucks made it official yesterday: Dave Cowens, the former all-star center, will end a two-year retirement to play power forward for the Bucks this season, and Quinn Buckner will be sent to the Boston Celtics as compensation. Cowens, 33 years old, signed a two-year contract with the Bucks, who declined to disclose its details. ... The San Diego Clippers will not become the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U. S. SEES A CHANCE OF 'BREAKTHROUGH' IN ARAB PROPOSALS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that although key Arab peace proposals were ''at considerable variance'' with President Reagan's Middle East plan, there was the possibility of a ''breakthrough'' if Arab leaders had in fact decided to recognize Israel's right to exist.

title: SENATORS FAULT PACEMAKER COSTS TO MEDICARE
description: A report by the Senate Special Committee on Aging says that much of the Medicare-covered costs associated with heart pacemakers are excessive.

title: ON PUBLIC BROADCASTING
description: More people have watched Shakespeare plays on public television since 1979 than have ever seen them in theaters throughout the world since they were written nearly 400 years ago. An entire generation of children has been profoundly influenced by such series as ''Sesame Street'' and ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood.'' Millions of people have followed public-policy issues through local broadcasts of ''The Lawmakers,'' ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Report,'' ''All Things Considered,'' ''Firing Line'' and the gavelto-gavel coverage of such important Congressional proceedings as the Senate Watergate investigation and the hearings on the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Falconbridge Closing
description: Falconbridge Ltd. of Toronto said yesterday that it was extending the shutdown of its Sudbury, Ontario, operations by 14 weeks, to Jan. 2, because continued deterioration in sales had resulted in excessive inventories of nickel.

title: WALKER'S ON PARADE FOR ARMY FOOTBALL
description: summer day schools of sailboats pass periodically in review. The legions of gray-clad cadets march in formation, offering home-cooked pageantry that makes every day seem like halftime of the Army-Navy game. By all appearances, West Point is tranquillity base. The tourists click their Canons like apprentice paparazzi, and the locals say the visitors haven't seen anything until they've seen the trees turn in autumn.

title: FEEBLE ATTACK ON TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. South-West Africa, where the United Nations seeks to create an independent Namibia from the territory ruled by South Africa. 2. c. 3. The patrolling of subway stations by volunteer, auxiliary police officers. 4. Timely Writer failed the required New York blood test and was automatically scratched from the Jerome Handicap by Belmont Park stewards.

title: Revising the Heroine
description: BECOMING A HEROINE. By Rachel M. Brownstein. 332 pages. The Viking Press. $17.95.

title: A WARNING ON LEASES AND PETS
description: THE American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals warns prospective apartment t enants to scrutinize their leases for no-pet clauses because such c lauses, according to Elinore Molbegott, the A.S.P.C.A.'s general c ounsel, are often used to force tenants out of their apartments.

title: Rome Favors Abolition Of Tolls in Connecticut
description: Lewis B. Rome, the Republican candidate for governor of Connecticut, said today that he favored ending tolls on all Connecticut roads by 1984, when bonds for the highways are to be paid off.

title: A LEGISLATED DILEMMA FOR THE TERMINALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'MICHI'S BLOOD' BY KROETZ IN CHELSEA
description: Carl and Mary, the young lovers of Franz Xaver Kroetz's ''Michi's Blood,'' live in a flat that is perhaps less appetizing than a public restroom in a subway. The walls are streaked with grime; the one window looks out on an air shaft; the tub is as filthy as a pig trough. Decoration consists of some crumpled cigarette packages taped above a sooty cot. For lighting, there are two bare light bulbs.

title: Today's Schedule; Stadium Court
description: 11 A.M. - Jimmy Connors-Guillermo Vilas, men's semifinal. Second Match - Chris Evert Lloyd-Hana Mandlikova, women's final.

title: Owens-Illinois
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. said it had purchased from companies controlled by Carl C. Icahn 1,301,440 shares of Owens-Illinois stock for $29.50 a share, or $38.4 million. That accounted for 4.6 percent of the company's 28 million shares outstanding. Mr. Icahn agreed not to buy any additional shares for 10 years, the company said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, the review of ''Michi's Blood'' in Weekend yesterday was garbled. It is reprinted today on page 10.

title: CLOSE GOVERNOR'S RACE FOR 2 IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: At noon Thursday, as the sun winked off the gilded dome of the Massachusetts Statehouse, Michael S. Dukakis, a liberal, held a rally on the steps beneath the windows of the Governor's office, which he lost in 1978 to its present occupant, Gov. Edward J. King, a conservative.

title: TOWER'S ABSENCE PUT REAGAN SHORT
description: President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion spending bill might have been sustained today if Senator John Tower, a Texas Republican, had not left the capital for a bit of politicking in his home state.

title: U.S. PHONE OFFICIALS CALL PROBLEM TECHNICAL
description: An official of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company said yesterday that the cutoff of phone service to and from the Soviet Union appeared to be the result of a technical breakdown in a Moscow switching center.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The First Robeson Scholars

title: DEFIANT REAGAN PROMISES TO GIVE MORE PRACTICE ON VETOES
description: President Reagan responded to his defeat on a budget veto today by warning members of Congress that they would have ''a lot more chances, because I'm going to do a lot more vetoing.''

title: Reggie to Rescue
description: Reggie Jackson confronted two men as they emerged from a house in Costa Mesa, Calif., yesterday, and they stood and waited with the California Angels' slugger until police arrived because ''they figured he could outrun them,'' officers said.

title: AUGUST JOBLESS PAY CLAIMS ROSE
description: The greatest number of jobless Americans in nearly eight months made initial claims for unemployment compensation in the final week of August, according to the Labor Department's Employment and Training Administration.

title:
Patents;
A Method for Sorting Microscopic Particles
description: An improved method for the sorting of body cells or other small particles is covered by patent 4,347,935, issued this week to the Department of Energy.

title: No Headline
description: HOW SENATE VOTED ON SPENDING VETO

title: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shr earnings figures are fully diluted; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45. 1. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in an usually blunt appraisal of the failures of the United Nations, said the only ''signs of a possibility of a solution'' were in the dispute over what area?

title: Crunch Bunch
description: The Giants have four outstanding linebackers in Harry Carson, Brian Kelley, Lawrence Taylor and Brad Van Pelt. But the quartet has been lacking one important asset - a catchy nickname.

title: No Headline
description: MURPHY CLOUTS 35TH AS BRAVES WIN, 8-2

title: Woman Accused Of Killing Son, 5
description: A Harlem woman was charged yesterday with murdering her 5-year-old son, who the police said they believed was either beaten or drowned. The police said they were awaiting the results of an autopsy to determine the actual cause of death of the child, Omar Wilson.

title: OFFICIALS DEFEND U.S. WITNESS PROTECTION PROGRAM
description: Frank Balderson of Alliance, Neb., speaking in a contained voice that did not conceal his anger, described his mission here as an effort ''to protest the Government's involvement in the murder of our son.''

title: 2 More Escapees Again in Custody
description: Two more of the 10 men who escaped from a Queens jail early Tuesday morning have been returned to custody, leaving three still at large. One of the fugitives surrendered late yesterday afternoon to the Queens District Attorney's office, and the other was captured early yesterday evening as he walked into his Brooklyn apartment, according to Paul Young, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Parole.

title: BRENNAND-PAIGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RIO GRANDE DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
R. Max Brooks, 75, Architect; Designed U.S. Labor Building
description: R. Max Brooks, a Texas architect who designed some major buildings for the Government, died Thursday of cancer.

title: 51 Women Pass Fire Dept. Test
description: Fifty-one women passed the revised physical-requirements test for appointment to the New York City Fire Department, Assistant Commissioner John J. Mulligan said yesterday. The test was given over a three-day period that ended yesterday.

title: A Symphonic Detour Along the Road of Life
description: Gilbert Kaplan gave a party for 2,700 very important people the other night, complete with champagne and cleverly arranged flowers and big banners and sherbet bombes and unabashed sentimentality.

title: SOVIET PHONE TIES ARE CUT FOR HOURS
description: Moscow's telephone links with much of the outside world were cut off for several hours today by what officials described as an equipment failure at the Moscow international exchange.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The members of Congress have been home. They heard their constituents.'' - Senator Mark O. Hatfield, after the President's veto of a spending bill was overridden. (1:6.)

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1.8 million from sale of a computer output microfilm plant

title: FEZ PLAN CALLED VICTORY FOR THE ARAB MODERATES
description: The Middle East peace plan announced by Arab leaders last night in Fez, Morocco, was described by Arab and Western diplomats here today as a victory for Arab moderates. The diplomats said it opened the road for Jordan and Saudi Arabia to play a central role in negotiations on the Middle East.

title: Arab Peace Plan Criticized
description: The American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israeli lobbying group that had expressed some support for President Reagan's Middle East plan, said today that the Arab League's peace proposals were a ''crushing disappointment.'' The group said the Arabs should ''be told in no uncertain terms that their position is totally unacceptable, that there can be no negotiations on the basis of the Fez communique, and that there can be no progress until they declare their willingness to recognize Israel and negotiate directly with it.''

title: ENTREPRENEURS EAGER TO EXPLOIT SPACE
description: The time seems to be approaching when private enterprise, venturing where only governments used to tread, will be launching rockets and hauling satellites to orbit with an eye to making a profit, according to space experts and Government officials.

title: Big Newspaper Unions Move Toward a Merger
description: The 29,000-member Newspaper Guild and the 82,000-member International Typographical Union took a big step today toward a merger, the unions said in a joint statement here.

title: Louisiana Officials Order A Hurricane Evacuation
description: A hurricane evacuation was ordered tonight for about 3,000 residents of southern Cameron Parish as winds up to 50 miles an hour from Tropical Storm Chris drove high tides toward the southwestern Louisiana and northeastern Texas coasts.

title: THE CITY'S NEGOTIATOR
description: When Bruce C. McIver, born under the big sky of Montana, first set his cowboy boots down on the pavement of New York he was promptly introduced to city life.

title: Episcopalians Approve A New Ministry to Poor
description: The Episcopal Church inaugurated a major new program to aid the poor today and began the long process of electing a new presiding bishop.

title: TOUGH CHOICES FACED D'AMATO, CHAFEE AND HATCH IN VETO VOTE
description: It was a tough vote for Senator John H. Chafee. President Reagan wanted the lawmaker to uphold his veto of a $14.1 billion spending bill, but the Rhode Islander joined 20 other Republicans in defying Mr. Reagan and his own party leadership.

title: U. S. TO SELL 'SHOCK' BATON TO SEOUL
description: Over strong objections from the State Department, the Commerce Department has approved the sale of 500 electric-shock batons to South Korea, Administration officials said today.

title: THE VOICES OF THE TURTLES ARE HEARD-AT HOME
description: ,0For the last few days, 15 snapping turtles have been hatching in a bucket in the living room of my Manhattan apartment. This may require some explanation.

title: BREWERS DEFEAT YANKEES
description: Among the likes of Robin Yount, Cecil Cooper and Gorman Thomas, Charlie Moore is a relatively unknown member of the Milwaukee Brewers. The Brewers, though, know what Moore has meant to them this season, and last night he provided an example of his value.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ

title: MOROCCAN CALLS ARAB PLAN A MOVE TO 'NONBELLIGERENCY'
description: King Hassan II of Morocco said today that the Arab League peace plan adopted here Thursday night represented a first step by the Arab world toward reaching a state of ''nonbelligerency'' with Israel.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Iran Agrees to Supply Natural Gas to Turkey
description: Iran has agreed to supply natural gas to Turkey through a pipeline to be built between the neighboring countries, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Thais Name Army Chief
description: Gen. Arthit Kamlangek was named army Commander in Chief, Thailand's highest military post, today. The 55-year-old general, as a division commander, rallied loyalist forces to crush an attempted coup against Prime Minister Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda in April 1981.

title: Gulf Resources Ousts Officials
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation has dismissed five of its ten vice presidents, a spokesman for the company confirmed yesterday.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'White Flight' Effect Doubted
description: After court-mandated busing got under way in 1979, many white pupils transferred out of Cleveland's public school system. However, according to a review of the effects of the program, a clear majority of the transfers apparently weren't part of a white flight that critics say is the inevitable result of busing.

title: 2,800 Rally Near White House In Support of the Palestinians
description: Some 2,800 pro-Palestinian demonstrators, including a small group of Jews, staged a rally outside the White House today to demand the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon.

title: AFTER SCHOOL, THEY STAY FOR DAY CARE
description: MERRICK ''MY parents work in the city, but I like it here,'' a 7-year-old boy said as he squirmed in and out of the brightly painted geometric dome at the Chatterton School playground. ''We have gym, art, music. We have a snack and then we go outside. I had to go to the baby sitter's house before I started to come here. There was not a lot of stuff to do there. I was bored. ''

title: NEW WESTCHESTER BUS ROUTES EXPAND TO INCLUDE WALL STREET
description: Westchester County's newest express bus route into Manhattan will begin Monday to include the Wall Street area on specific rush-hour trips, R. Raleigh D'Adamo, the County Transportation Commissioner, announced Friday.

title: COAL LAW REVIEW FOCUSES ON WATT
description: The coal industry was supplanted by the Reagan Administration as the villain this week at the House Interior Committee's annual review of the effectiveness of the Federal Strip Mine Control and Reclamation Act of 1977.

title: STAGE: STREET CARAVAN'S 'CABARET'
description: While politics are conducted in closed rooms and convention halls, political theater continues to take to the streets. Along with the Bread and Puppet Theater and the San Francisco Mime Troupe, Marketa Kimbrell's New York Street Theater Caravan operates at the grassroots level, offering object lessons in direct audience confrontation.

title: The Insanity Plea On Trial
description: As an attorney who has worked for the past nine years with patients and families in the psychiatric service delivery system, I would like to comment on Judge Irving R. Kaufman's article ''The Insanity Plea on Trial'' (Aug. 8). While Judge Kaufman admits that ''current psychiatric learning'' is ambiguous, he seems to place greater emphasis on ''the increased knowledge of the working of the mind that psychiatry now provides.''

title: Female Firefighter Worked for State in '80
description: I enjoyed the article about Firefighters Ortiz and Clay and congratulate both of them upon their successful completion of firefighter training (''Connecticut Journal,'' Aug. 15).

title: WHERE TO GET MORE CRUISE INFORMATION
description: American Canadian Line, Box 368, Warren, R.I. 02885 (401-245-1350; 800-556-7450 outside Rhode Island). American Cruise Lines, 1 Marine Park, Haddam, Conn. 06438 (203-345-8551; 800-243-6755 outside Connecticut). American Hawaii Cruises, 3 Embarcadero Center, Suite 2500, San Francisco,

title: THE QE2
description: To the Editor:

title: TRudeau Moves His Targets
description: The Canadian economy is in deep trouble and so is Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Government. The first acknowledgement of both kinds of trouble by Mr. Trudeau came on Aug. 29 when the inveterate globetrotter canceled an elaborate tour of the Far East to remain in Ottawa.

title: LEON FLEISHER'S LONG JOURNEY BACK TO THE KEYBOARD
description: In the gala opening of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra's new concert hall on Thursday, the pianist Leon Fleisher is scheduled to play Cesar Franck's Symphonic Variations. Twenty years ago, such an announcement would not have created undue stir among concertgoers. But last May, when the Baltimore Symphony released the information that Fleisher was to perform a work from the standard repertory (actually, the concerto originally scheduled was Beethoven's Fourth), it was greeted with disbelief. For Fleisher - hailed as ''the pianistic find of the century'' when he was a teen-ager; widely regarded as the heir apparent of his teacher, Artur Schnabel, in his 20's, and favored musical son of the conductor George Szell in his 30's - had not performed any piano music for two hands since a mysterious affliction left his right hand almost useless in 1965, when he was 37.

title: AS U.S. BANKERS CHEER
description: To the Editor:

title: RADIO FINDS A PLACE IN REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: Radio, for better or worse a powerful instrument of social change in much of this century, has been rediscovered as an instrument of foreign policy by the Reagan Administration.

title: BEGIN'S WEST BANK LINE SEEMS HARDER THAN EVER
description: There was considerable political motion in the Middle East last week, but not much real movement. In the wake of the Lebanon war and the Reagan initiative, both the Israeli and Arab sides conducted elaborate pageants of politics and diplomacy to proclaim their dedication to their old demands. Moderate voices were shouted down and outvoted in the Knesset, where Prime Minister Menachem Begin held fast to his claim of eternal sovereignty over the West Bank. And at Fez, Morocco, Arab leaders hammered out a ''peace plan'' that offered no peace treaty, and which may or may not have recognized Israel's right to exist, depending on who was interpreting the ambiguous language.

title: Stewart Out of Hospital
description: Potter Stewart, a retired Justice of the United States Supreme Court, was discharged Friday from a hospital here. The 67-year-old resident of Sugar Hill fell at his home Aug. 23 and suffered broken ribs and a chipped collar bone.

title: 'TOO MUCH OF A LUXURY,' GRANDMOTHER SAID
description: DURING the Depression we were poor. Of course, we never knew we were poor, because everybody was. We lived with my grandmother, whom we called Nana. Every summer, when fruit was royally displayed at the fruit stands, Nana would carefully select whatever she could afford and then ritually stand before the cherries and lament that they were 19 cents a pound.

title: ENDING A CORPORATE ADDICTION
description: LIKE junkies denied their fix, many members of the business c ommunity are complaining mightily about the recently passed Federal t ax reform act. Most strident are the loophole pushers who lobby in W ashington. Some of them made millions peddling the tax breaks they h elped create and they are bitterly upset that their supplier has s tarted to crack down. If business executives can straighten out t heir heads long enough to think clearly, however, they will fall d own on their knees, thank God for this tax bill, and beg for more l ike it.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: NORTH SALEM AT the red brick schoolhouse on Route 22 here, it is not the work being done that is unusual. Men in dust-streaked coveralls haul scaffolding over canvas-draped floors and prepare the walls for paint. Wielding rollers and brushes, they work hard and later relax over a big lunch.

title: D. A. Dufresne Weds Cary Bachelder
description: Christina Cathryn Bachelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Bachelder 3d of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Albert Dufresne, son of Randall O. Dufresne of Shrewsbury, Mass., and the late Barbara Thayer Dufresne. The Rev. Daphne W.P. Hawkes performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: AT COLLEGE, THE COMFORTS OF HOME
description: It was either somewhere around the time he unloaded his color television and the refrigerator or while he was carrying his electric typewriter and telephone-answering machine into New York University's Joe Weinstein Residence Hall that Bill Freiberger realized that the one thing he had forgotten to bring from his home in Merrick, L.I., were his clothes.

title: ANTIQUE AUTO SHOW
description: A 1915 Ford Model-T roadster that starred in the movies ''Ragtime'' and ''Reds'' will be among the 300 vehicles competing today in the 20th annual Antique Auto Festival of the Kiwanis Club of New Brunswick.

title: 'Playing the Game' And Party Loyalty
description: A lifelong Republican, I am constrained to respond to the recent article ''Margiotta Reign in Nassau G.O.P. Appears Shaky.'' Blind allegiance to political party or personae is the antithesis of what responsible government is all about.

title: UTILITIES OPPOSE BUYING ELECTRICITY OTHERS PRODUCE
description: In late 1978, after a political battle that dominated its agenda for 18 months, Congress passed a package of five energy bills designed to reduce the nation's reliance on imported oil, then totaling 8.7 million barrels a day.

title: Susan Joan Steele Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Joan Steele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Steele of Palm Beach, Fla., and Southhampton, L.I., and John Bruton Hayes Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes of Cutchogue, L.I., and Highland Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. The Rev. Edward Gannon, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: WILL OTHERS COPY SUCCESS OF THE 49ERS?
description: AS the National Football League begins its 63d season today, the d ifferences in the styles of play of the two conferences has all but d isappeared.

title: FACULTY DOCTORS FAULTED IN AUDIT
description: New York State auditors have found that physicians on the faculties of the four state medical colleges continue to exceed limitations for income from private patients despite state efforts to curb the practice.

title:
DINING OUT;
NORTH ITALIAN FARE IN MONMOUTH
description: CERVINO is a pleasant Northern Italian restaurant worth remembering when visiting the Middletown area of Monmouth County. Situated in premises formerly occupied by the Cobblestones, another restaurant, it was renamed Cervino in honor of the birthplace of the four owners, Renato and Gian Carlos Bruno, Lazaro Venegas and Dino Joyeusaz.

title: ART: THE DRAWINGS OF ARCHITECTURE
description: The passing of the International Style in architecture has evidently left a vacuum that specialists are laboring to fill with debate on the school's exact nature and its history.

title: No Headline
description: STANFORD TRIUMPHS; 333 YARDS FOR ELWAY

title: Another View on Plan For Tarrytown Building
description: It was quite disturbing to find an article on Cuddy & Feder's proposed office complex on Route 119 (''Office-Building Plan Stirs Greenburgh,'' Aug. 22) which was so incomplete and where figures were so often erroneously noted. I was, of course, disappointed that the article was not more procommunity (versus builder), but I was told that the article was to be objective. Per the above items, it certainly was not.

title: IN PLAIN ENGLISH, THERE'S A REASON
description: THIS is for college students. But the rest of you can listen in, if you want. Students: I am an English teacher. You've dealt with my type often enough. You come to our offices and ask, ''Can I have an extension on the paper? I've got to study for a bio test.'' Or you corner us in the corridor and say, ''I can't come to class this afternoon, I've got to go to a chemistry review session.''

title: GUATEMALANS ARE ADDING A FEW TWISTS TO 'PACIFICATION'
description: Pointing at a strategic map of Guatemala's highlands, the senior army officer could not resist boasting that Guatemala was more successful than El Salvador in combating its leftist guerrillas. ''Their trouble,'' he said, referring to the Salvadoran armed forces, ''is that they're taking too much American advice.''

title: JOSE DE CREEFT, 97, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: Jose de Creeft, a sculptor, teacher and leading exponent of the direct method of sculpture, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97 years old and also had a home and studio in Hoosick Falls, N.Y.

title: Susan Makrianes Wed To D.C. Bacon, Broker
description: Susan Moreland Makrianes, daughter of James Konstantin Makrianes of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Susan Lantz Makrianes was married yesterday to Daniel Carpenter Bacon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Bacon of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Francis Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: 2 FILIPINOS ARE KILLED BY EXPLOSION IN MANILA
description: Two Filipinos were killed and 25 others were injured today by an explosion in the center of the capital.

title: FALL PREVIEW 1982
description: Joseph Canon, editor in chief of E.P. Dutton, is of the opinion that a good novel can help to overcome a company's economic blues. And he cites several fall books: ''A Bloodsmoor Romance,'' by Joyce Carol Oates, described as ''the other side of 'Little Women' ''; Gerald Seymour's ''Archangel,'' by one of the authentic thriller writers, and Stanley Elkin's multi-centurial ''George Mills.''

title: WALSH'S URGENT CREATIVITY
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. WHAT you first notice about Bill Walsh, coach of the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers, is the weariness. During the football season, his face becomes the color of unbaked dough, and he continually tilts his head to one side like a martyr in a medieval painting.

title: Letters; Hitch in Bliss
description: To the Editor:

title: BRONX GROUP CELEBRATES VICTORY ON HOME SITES
description: With sirens on the community's refurbished fire engine wailing, most of the 225 families who live in the tiny East Bronx neighborhood of Harding Park gathered yesterday to celebrate the recent victory in their 40-year struggle to buy the land on which their homes are built.

title: WARMING THE HALL
description: Churches and synagogues have been beset with special problems in these days of high energy costs because of their lofty cathedral ceilings and leaky stained-glass windows that waste vast amounts of precious heat. Other difficulties are posed by the need for extensive lighting -both outdoors and indoors - and the fact that a lot of extra fuel has to be used to heat spaces that are used for services or classes only once or twice a week.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
FOR MORRIS, A HOUSING 'MATCHMAKER'
description: year-old widow, is happy because she now can l ive comfortably near her daughter and has someone to care for her, w hile 62-year-old Marie DeAngelis, also a widow, is happy because sheh as someone to talk to.

title: Pope to Meet Arafat, Vatican Aide Reports
description: Pope John Paul II will meet Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, next week, the Vatican confirmed today.

title: COMMON VICTIMS IN THE MIDEAST
description: In the national press and beyond our boundaries, honorable people continue to debate the Middle East crisis in frightening terms. The terms of the debate are frightening because they tend to represent the Israeli-Palestinian issue in ways that are inherently propagandistic, ways that can bring only counterpropaganda in the short run and, in the long run, doom. Demonstrations that one side or the other broke cease-fires or impeded negotiations, that one or the other was despised by the Lebanese, that one or the other most deserves the epithet ''terrorist,'' are inevitably partisan, peripheral, obscurantist and destructive.

title: MARTIAL ARTS FEVER SWEEPS CHINA OFF ITS FEET
description: Amid the clang of swords, the clatter of staves and the thud of fists and bare feet, the fighting skills of ancient China have become a fad for young Chinese, some of whom have neglected their studies and even run away from home in a vain search for the old masters.

title: RECITAL: DVORAK ANNIVERSARY
description: Dvorak was born Sept. 8, 1841, and Caroline Stoessinger, who is a pianist, decided to observe the 141st anniversary of his birth Tuesday with a concert devoted to his works. Enlisting the services of the Composers String Quartet and Elizabeth Coss, soprano, Miss Stoessinger presented a program at the 92d Street Y that consisted of the String Quartet No. 12 in F (''American''), No. 8 ''Liebeslieder' (Op. 83) and the Piano Quintet in A.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: A Look Ahead. The denizens of Publishers Row are busy putting finishing touches on books they hope you'll be buying and reading between now and Christmas. Here's a rundown on some likely paperbacks.

title: Giants' Neill Sidelined
description: Bill Neill, the starting nose guard, was among four players the Giants said yesterday would not dress for Sunday's season opener at the Meadowlands against the Atlanta Falcons (Channel 2, 1 P.M.).

title: Deena Rosenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Deena Rosenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rosenberg of Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Ernest Harburg. Rabbi Lloyd Tennenbaum performed the ceremony in the garden of the Rosenberg home.

title: AN ICY ENDING
description: A LITTLE MORE THAN KIN By Ernest Hebert. 224 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95. By NICHOLAS DELBANCO

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Who is going to execute all the goals set in Fez and how? All that is mentioned in the Fez statement is what every Arab wants to achieve.

title: Meredith H. Dixon Married
description: The marriage of Meredith Howland Dixon, an assistant media director at Grey Advertising, to John A. Finan, a vice president of Barclays Bank International, took place in Hewlett, L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Earle T. Pratt performed the ceremony at Trinity-St.

title: CARDINALS TOP METS, 6-3, TO REGAIN FIRST
description: All Ed Lynch wanted to do, he explained later, was to foul up the Cardinals' season as they make a final run for the pennant.

title: EMELIN THEATER CELEBRATING 10TH SEASON
description: MAMARONECK FOR the last decade, the Emelin Theater for the Performing Arts has presented performances ranging from the Tokyo String Quartet to foreign films, from Edward Villella and Dave Brubeck to the Paperbag Players. The Emelin, one of the most active art centers in the county, is marking its 10th anniversary season this fall. At the opening celebration Oct. 3, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., there will be an arts and crafts festival across from the theater on Library Lane, with 70 exhibitors, ethnic food, free entertainment and birthday cake for all.

title: A Man to Lien On
description: Whether or not the crime pays, the criminal is supposed to. But it seems that G. Gordon Liddy, convicted Watergate burglar and the author of ''Will,'' wouldn't.

title: Trim the Tree Captures Kentucky Pacing Derby
description: Trim the Tree took the lead at the quarter pole and went on to score a 1 1/2-length victory in the $312,220 Kentucky Pacing Derby for 2-year-olds at Louisville Downs tonight.

title: CARING FOR CLOTHING
description: By Ralph DiGennaro

title: NAVY SPOILS WELSH'S DEBUT AT VIRGINIA
description: At the end of another work day at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium, as the end-zone cannon went off for the last time today and the band played ''Navy Blue and Gold,'' George Welsh, the University of Virginia football coach, walked toward the east sideline and looked for the blue-and-gold jerseys.

title: California Antismog Bill Signed by the Governor
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has signed an antismog bill that is expected to lead to the end of a Federal freeze on highway and sewer funds.

title: Nancy Taylor Norton Wed To S.A.Batchelor in Darien
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday, Nancy Taylor Norton and Stuart Alexander Batchelor, graduates of the University of Vermont, were married by the Rev. Edward R. Danks.

title: COMMUNITIES TAKE ROLE IN WATCH ON CRIME
description: HUNTINGTON ''I thought we'd better get the citizens back into what they did in the old days,'' said Inspector Harold McCormick of the Suffolk County Police Department. ''When I became commander of the Second Precinct here a year ago, whenever I had a call asking me, 'What are you doing about these burglaries?' I threw the question back and asked, 'What are you doing?' ''

title: Fire at Australian Hospital
description: About 500 patients were evacuated from the Royal Melbourne Hospital today after an electrical fault caused a fire in an elevator shaft, officials said.

title: PROMOTER GETS PUBLIC TO WANT WHAT HE'S SELLING
description: WEST ORANGE PROMOTION, says John Scher, New Jersey's biggest music promoter, ''is the simple act of choosing the right attraction that people might want to see and then convincing them that they want to see it.''

title: NORTH DAKOTA GAINS
description: Alaska led the states in per capita personal income last year and Mississippi ranked last, according to figures released today by the Commerce Department.

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1982
description: International Preference for the U.S. peace plan for the Middle East was indicated by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who expressed skepticism over how the Arab peace plan proposed last week would be implemented. At a news conference in Paris, he said the Arab plan set good goals, but it ''lacks the mechanism of how to achieve its goals,'' and that he thinks ''it is better to give the Reagan initiative as much support as we can and to encourage the United States to go ahead with the peace process.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) 44 people were reported killed in the crash of a United States Army helicopter in Mannheim, West Germany, which was carrying them there to participate in an international airshow. This includes five American crew members aboard the helicopter and two others who were parachutists. (1:4-5.)

title: Elizabeth Kelly Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Mary Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edward Kelly Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I., was married in Old Westbury, L.I., yesterday to Spencer Wood Morten 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morten Jr. of Bassett, Va., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel at the School of the Holy Child.

title: POLISHING UP ANCIENT HEBREW
description: Wars generate new words, permutations of a soldier's native language to describe military life. Korea gave English speakers ''brainwashing''; Vietnam, the grim expression ''to waste'' someone.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN FORECASTING
description: WASHINGTON From little Sedona, Ariz., comes the first big look at the economy since the August plunge in interest rates and the surge in the stock market. And it is a sobering look indeed.

title: A SPIRITED LOOK FOR FALL
description: Significant changes seldom happen in men's wear. When they do, they tend to be subtle-shifts in the size of a lapel, the cut of a jacket or the width of a tie.

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN WINNER BY 20-9

title: OPERA IN EDINBURGH
description: If Jonathan Miller believes that it is more worthwhile to practice medicine than to direct ''The Magic Flute'' or that there is more nobility in the practice of medicine than in the directing of ''King Lear,'' then he must not be all that brilliant. DAVID B. ADAMS, M.D. Portsmouth, Va.

title: The Kicking Game
description: The Detroit Lions' punter Tom Skladany and the placekicker Eddie Murray, both of whom walked out of camp last week in salary disputes, will meet again tomorrow with Coach Monte Clark to discover whether their suspensions by the team will be lifted. In today's game against the Chicago Bears, the Lions will use John James, the former Atlanta punter, and Bob Thomas, who used to kick for the Bears. ... Jerome Irving, the halfback who helped Widener University win the Division III football championship last season, has been expelled again by the school because of a cheating scandal.

title: What's Taught In Schools
description: Barbra Wagner Williams states the case precisely in her article ''The Things I Wish I'd Been Taught in School'' (Opinion Page).

title: BOOK REVIEW
description: September 12, 1982 NONFICTION A BARTHES READER. By Susan Sontag. 1 THE BOOK OF CONCORD: Thoreau's Life as a Writer. By William Howarth. 15 CAMUS.

title: Ann E. Leopard Is Married To David Marion Di Fiore
description: Ann Elizabeth Leopard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Leopard of Tonawanda, N.Y., was married yesterday in Washington to David Marion Di Fiore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. DiFiore of River Vale, N.J. The Rev. E. Joseph Mackov performed the ceremony at All Souls Memorial Episcopal Church.

title: EPISCOPAL CONVENTION PONDERS NUCLEAR WAR ISSUE
description: In the event of nuclear war, unordained people should be allowed to administer Communion and officiate at marriages, says a proposal working its way through the general convention of the Episcopal Church here.

title: Nazi Activists
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM 'FOUR SAINTS' TO JOSQUIN BY WAY OF BOITO AND BACH
description: The year's new record releases will be reasonably rich in grand opera; but if there are no major trends elsewhere, there are at least interesting sub-themes.

title: WASHINGTON'S SORRY BREAKFAST ASSEMBLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN A BANK DIED IN IOWA
description: brick bank stood on South Main Street and looked out on a sun-splashed park, where one of the first things to confront visitors was a sign listing the warning signals in case of a twister. A miscellany of stores curled around the park. Your Super Drug. Harrison's 5 & 10. Cloth Patch. Rodd's Cards and Gifts. O'Connor's Clothing. Kozy Cafe. Cars glided sluggishly in and out of the 12-minute parking spots that hem in the bank. A barefoot girl fluttered merrily along the broom-whisked sidewalk. Another blazing hot, cloudless Iowa day.

title: THIS 'HAMLET' IS NOT THE MELANCHOLY DANE WE KNOW
description: In a way, it is too bad the New York City Opera has decided to give Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet'' in English, thereby depriving us of the pleasure of hearing the Prince of Denmark step forward and declaim:

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Back-to-School Sales With Equanimity

title: IF THE WORLD IS ROUND, WHY NOT THE ISLAND
description: IT has come to my attention that Long Island has transportation problems, traffic problems and commuter problems. The trip to New York City is often a pilgrimage of sorts. When inclement weather is added, living on the Island can pose dilemmas for travelers. However, after analyzing this situation closely, I recognize what is wrong with Long Island. It isn't round.

title: POLITICAL FEUD GOES BACK TO THE 40'S
description: JERSEY CITY IN THIS city, where politics often seems to be the vocation or avocation of almost everyone, there are many tales of bitter political feuds that have wrecked lifelong friendships, split families along political lines and played havoc with seating arrangements at weddings.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jack Nicklaus, scheduled to make his first golfing appearance in France in more than 20 years, was forced to withdraw from a 36-hole exhibition against Severiano Ballesteros of Spain after displacing a vertebra during a practice round. ... Alan Page, who used to chase quarterbacks for the Minnesota Vikings and the Chicago Bears, will compete today in Eugene, Ore., in the Oregon Track Club marathon.

title: MEMOIR OF A SMALL-TOWNBOYHOOD
description: As I was growing up, my mother loved to tell me about the happiness of her childhood days and I loved to listen, for I knew only the ruined and colorless landscapes of the Depression, and her talk evoked beautiful pictures of a world that was bright and sunny. But when she got to the part about her father and the inevitable, ''Now Papa was a real gentleman ... ,'' my interest faded. Though he was my grandfather, I couldn't abide his being such a splendid man. I took my revenge by shutting him out of my mind.

title: PHOTOS OF LIVES AS THEY ARE LIVED IN NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON IT HAS been said that in any given month there is, somewhere in New Jersey, a show of photographs by Donald Lokuta. The remark was made in jest, of course, but there's no doubt that Mr. Lokuta, at the age of 36, has become one of the state's more conspicuous photographers. In addition, he is active as a guest curator of photography exhibitions and as an associate professor at Kean College in Union.

title: FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITTED FOR VIOLATIONS OF CITY HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named eight that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for failure to do so.

title: SCHOOL OF ARTS SEEKS MONEY IN ITS 2D YEAR
description: As it prepares to enter its second year, the Performing Arts High School here continues to struggle through hard economic times to develop local talent for the city's growing number of theater and dance companies.

title: TALKS AT CHRYSLER BEGIN TO INTENSIFY
description: Contract negotiations between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers increased in pace and intensity today as the expiration of the old pact draws closer.

title: BLOCK ISLAND OFF SEASON
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The Times. BY BETSY WADE

title: Alexis Schade Married on L.I.
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Freeport, L.I., yesterday Mary Alexis Schade, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rolland Schade of Gilgo Beach, L.I., became the bride of Robert Justin McCormack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Michael McCormack of Short Hills and Normandy Beach, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J.T. Schnabel, assisted by the Rev. Michael Quinlan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: MURDOCH RENEWS TALKS TO BUY BUFFALO PAPER
description: Rupert Murdoch, the newspaper publisher, has renewed talks on taking over The Buffalo Courier-Express after the announcement by the newspaper's owners that they intend to close it next Sunday.

title: Orioles Defeat Indians by 8-1
description: Eddie Murray drove in three runs with a two-run double and a single today to lead the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: STUDENTS PICK UP THE PIECES OF ELLIS ISLAND'S PAST
description: A summer archeological expedition has ventured into a forgotten maze of dank rooms on Ellis Island to gather pieces of the past of the island that was the point of entry into the United States for more than 12 million immigrants between 1892 and 1954.

title: Navy And Coast Guard Ships Trap Boat Hauling Marijuana
description: A 125-foot freighter carrying a small quantity of marijuana eluded two Coast Guard cutters, a Navy destroyer and four jet fighters for 27 hours Friday before finally surrendering about 170 miles south-southeast of here, the Coast Guard said.

title: Search Team Finds Hulk Of Schooner Sunk in 1914
description: The hulk of the Pomo, a 368-ton steam schooner that sank near San Francisco in 1914, was detected in an electronic sweep of Drake's Bay, researchers from Texas A & M University said.

title: NEW PORTS OF CALL IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: VERNON KIDD is a New York actor and writer. By VERNON KIDD

title: Cambodia Mass Grave Found; Attributed to Pol Pot Regime
description: The Cambodian authorities have uncovered a fresh mass grave near Phnom Penh containing the remains of about 1,500 people, the Hanoi radio said today.

title: EDGEMONT FOOTBALL GETS A NEW CHANCE
description: SCARSDALE ''THE eyes of Westchester are upon you,'' the head coach, Jim Gold, said on a recent morning, as Edgemont High School's varsity football squad engaged in its first practice of the season. ''As you know, we haven't had varsity football on campus for two years. Now's the time to prove it belongs here.''

title: SEPT. 15 IS DEADLINE FOR RENT BENEFITS
description: BECAUSE of a recent change in the law, elderly tenants who wish to apply for a benefit check from the state to help with their monthly rental costs must now do so before Wednesday, report officials of the State Department on Aging. Previously, they had until Dec. 31 to apply.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photograph on the front page of the Aug. 22 issue of Travel was misidentified. The scene is of Porto Cervo on Sardinia's Costa Smeralda.

title: MUSIC: FROM INDIA, 2 CLASSICAL MASTERS
description: After a post-60's lull, concerts of Classical Indian music seem once again on the upswing in this country. But it will take something rather special to equal the impact of Friday evening's event at Town Hall. It wasn't always at the same high level, but when it was, it was transcendent.

title: Scott Is First in Triathlon
description: David Scott, admitting that he had a psychological advantage, captured the Manufacturers Hanover Mighty Hamptons triathlon today in 2 hours 26 minutes 9 seconds.

title: Q & A
description: Question:Three years ago my wife and I had a delightful Mediterranean cruise aboard the Navarino (formerly the Swedish American liner Gripsholm), which had been completely refurbished a year or so earlier by the Karageorgis Lines. I am now unable to find any information concerning the present status of this outstanding vessel, and I would appreciate any help you can give me as to its present itinerary. - H.T.M., Charleston, W. Va. Answer:The T.S.C.S. Navarino, as the ship is officially known, is registered in Greece, and the Karageorgis cruise line no longer maintains an office in the United States.

title: Frustration at Season's End
description: IT was last day on which 15-year-old Eli Ohlhausen of Brooklyn and I could fish together this year, and for that reason, if no other, the gods should have smiled on our endeavor.

title: ENVIRONMENT BECOMES ISSUE IN SENATE PRIMARY IN VERMONT
description: The environment as an issue and environmentalists as a political force are playing a significant role in Vermont's race for the Republican nomination for the Senate, which pits the incumbent, Robert T. Stafford, against two conservative challengers.

title: KEAN FAMILY IN LAND DISPUTE
description: JEFFERSON TOWNSHIP FOR most of this century, the people living at the northern end of Lake Hopatcong have called a 35-acre peninsula that juts into the lake Kean's Woods.

title: LEBANON SAYS MOROCCO PARLEY WAS 'DISAPPOINTING'
description: Foreign Minister Fuad Butros of Lebanon said today that his Government was disappointed by the attitude toward its problems expressed at the Arab League meeting in Fez, Morocco.

title: FLORIDA
description: To the Editor:

title: C.L. Dawson, Whitney Ray Are Married
description: Deborah Whitney Ray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ray of New York, was married yesterday to Channing Lease Dawson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Dawson of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Clifford Curtin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: A VARIETY OF SHOWS AT THE NEUBERGER IN PURCHASE
description: PURCHASE THOSE looking to romp through the county's museums and galleries should be advised that the Neuberger Museum (State University of New York here) is surprisingly well stocked for the time of year. Opening today is an exhibition focusing on the relationship between the nymph-ridden paintings of Louis Eilshemius and works by other American eccentrics such as Albert Pinkham Ryder. Also on view is the recently unveiled ''Selections From the Permanent Collection,'' which includes pieces by Milton Avery, whose ''year'' it seems to be, Edward Hopper, whose birth centennial it actually is, and Alexander Calder.

title: Drop in Life Span of Youths Linked to Drugs and Alcohol
description: So many Americans from 16 to 24 years old are dying in driving accidents related to alcohol and drugs that the life expectancy of that group has dropped to what it was 20 years ago, according to a national health educator.

title: VISITING ORCHESTRAS GALORE AND OPERA NOVLETIES, TOO
description: Metaphors abound for a New York music season: a skyful of stars, a groaning board, a can of worms. Whatever your choice, there will be something for you from now to next summer. New York can make a persuasive case for being classical music's crossroads of the world, and this season, for no obvious reason, the traffic jam should be thicker than ever. Cultural gridlock, you might call it.

title: AMERICANA: FROM AUCTION TO MUSEUM
description: The antiques forecast for fall indicates a strong focus on Americana, virtually everything Oriental and any period wares that represent the finest of their class available, including Renaissance silver and French 18th-century furniture.
