All these and much more will be in the spotlight in museum exhibitions, at antiques fairs and in auctions.

title: WISCONSIN PRIMARY IS BESET BY APATHY
description: Apathy, like the ground fog that hugs Wisconsin's lakes and rural roads in autumn, has settled over the electorate in this state's primary election next Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: Delaware 31 Western Kentucky 0

title: Rangers 5, Mariners 1
description: George Wright, Pete O'Brien and Larry Parrish hit homers in the sixth inning for Texas. Wright and O'Brien hit consecutive homers off Floyd Bannister (12-11) with one out, and Parrish followed a Buddy Bell groundout with a drive to left center.

title: LOEB PAPER FACES A TEST IN PRIMARY
description: The outcome of primary elections Tuesday in New Hampshire could indicate whether the influence of The Manchester Union Leader has diminished since the death of its longtime publisher, William Loeb, politicians say.

title: COUNTY AIDS EFFORT ON MISSING CHILDREN
description: MARY MILLER'S son was 3 years old in 1973 when he was taken from his Long Island home by his father. He was 7 when Miss Miller located him in Massachusetts. When mother and son were reunited, two years ago, he was 10.

title: CAN HUSSEIN KEEP REAGAN PLAN ALIVE ?
description: WASHINGTON EVEN though Israel has rejected President Reagan's Middle East initiative, and the Arab leaders have issued a plan of their own unacceptable to either the United States or Israel, the Reagan Administration is refusing to admit the worst.

title: FOR GRANDPARENTS, TODAY IS THEIR DAY
description: IT'S Grandparents Day today. The average person still may not know it, and it may even be a plot of the card and flower industries (certainly, a sprinkling of inquiries shows that card shops and florists are ready for it).

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE COIN MARKET HAS TAKEN AN UPWARD TURN
description: Wall Street isn't the only place that is bullish these days; the coin market also appears to be emerging from its 30-month slump and analysts are bullish on prospects for a period of healthy growth.

title: JAZZ: CAROL SLOANE, VOCALIST
description: Carol Sloane treats a song with respect. She sings the notes more or less in the order they were written, and she makes sure the lyrics are clear.

title: DUtch and Danes Veer to Right
description: Worsening economic conditions in Western Europe had political repercussions in two small members of the Atlantic Alliance last week. The Netherlands and Denmark, both with unemployment in double digits, took a turn to the right with important implications for their social welfare policies and, in Copenhagen at least, for military policies.

title: DISMISSING KUHN IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: EIGHTEEN new faces have gathered around baseball's council table since February 1969 when Bowie Kuhn took office as commissioner, an office that by all rights he should retain.

title: CROSSOVERS WITH THE ART WORLD
description: On the face of it, this looks to be a season of sequels. We'll be watching ''Atget II'' (Oct. 14-Jan. 4), the second of four annual exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art in tribute to the genius of Eugene Atget, and ''The History of Photography V,'' the fifth edition of Beaumont Newhall's classic text, with a new chapter on developments since the 1950's.

title: LANDFILL IN BROOKLYN BECOMES SPORTS COMPLEX
description: ''It took seven years of planning and pushing to turn this dump into a field,'' Carmine Santa Maria said yesterday. ''We consider it a miracle.''

title: ETHIOPIAN EXILE STATUS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOSTON
description: DUDLEY CLENDINEN is a New York Times correspondent based in Boston. BY DUDLEY CLENDINEN

title: 'ROYAL' CHRYSANTHEMUMS
description: It is unlikely that a chrysanthemum exhibition matching next month's display at the Botanical Garden in the Bronx will be seen again in this country for some time. ''As far as we know there has never been a Kiku-Ka Ten (Chrysanthemum Flower Festival) like this in the United States before,'' a spokesman for the garden said.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: DESPITE a depressed international economic scene, the Connecticut Department of Economic Development reports that it has been successful in attracting foreign companies to open or expand operations in the state. In the last seven years, 225 overseas companies have increased their business in Connecticut. They now employ more than 30,000 residents, according to the department.

title: FOLLOWING THE FOLIAGE
description: HENRY SCOTT STOKES is chief of The New York Times bureau in Tokyo. BY HENRY SCOTT STOKES

title: Imre Cholnoky Weds Amy Cammann
description: Amy Coleway Cammann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Blackwell Cammann of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Imre John Cholnoky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Imre Cholnoky of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: Open-Door Policy
description: Question: My aunt lives in a garden-apartment cooperative. Her neighbor continually keeps the front door to the building open and has refused requests from other residents to close it. She says she needs it open to increase circulation in her apartment. The co-op's board of directors first ordered her to keep the door closed, then said she could keep it open. However, the other tenants feel this creates a dangerous situation. Is this tenant violating a law? What can other tenants do to get her to stop keeping the door open? ... I. G., Brooklyn Answer: This appears to be a matter of a tenant and board of directors neglecting their responsibility to the co-op. Several housing lawyers suggested that you may wish to pursue court action against either or both for acting in a manner that is potentially harmful to the cooperative. Read the co-op's by-laws and consult a lawyer.

title: WAGE INCREASES SLACKEN
description: Worries about rising unemployment and business bankruptcies are major reasons why consumer spending in the third quarter remains below earlier expectations, but the sharp decline in hourly wage increases could be another cause.

title: GIVING THE DEVIL HIS DUE
description: There are many excellent dishes that can be attributed to the kitchens of Russia. Some of the best-known, of course, are borsch, blini, beef stroganoff and chicken Kiev. But one of our favorites is a baked filled pastry known as a pirog, particularly when it is prepared with an outer crust of brioche and stuffed with fillings ranging from salmon and dill to meat and mushrooms to mushrooms and eggs. Pirogi, for the record, differ from piroshki in that pirogi are of a substantial size, and piroshki, their cousins, are small enough to be consumed in one or two bites.

title: Nancy Roberts Wed to R.M. Godfrey
description: Nancy Hibbard Roberts, daughter of Lieut. Col. Malcolm Roberts Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Roberts of Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to R. Michael Godfrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond V. Godfrey of Merritt Island, Fla. Maj. Malcolm Roberts 3d, Chaplain Corps, U.S.A., the bride's brother, performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Augustine's by-the-Sea in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: A HARD-WON PRIZE
description: The Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch had to put in a lot of hard, sometimes frustrating, effort for his first-place tie with the Filipino grandmaster Eugenio Torre in the Toluca, Mexico, Interzonal Tournament.

title: Man Who Resisted a Robbery Is Slain in a Brooklyn Subway
description: A 42-year-old maintenance man at Kings County Hospital was shot in the head and killed early yesterday by two young men who tried to rob him on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: FANCIFUL MEN, MORE REALISTIC WOMEN
description: On the face of it, real life takes a back seat to fantasy, adventure and escapism in this fall's new prime-time shows. Two are unabashed knockoffs of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' itself an homage to 1930's movie serials. One new series is set around a witch with psychic powers, another features two fellows with the capacity to travel into the future and a third is about a teen-age boy from another planet who has the power of telekinesis. There is also a slew of action shows in which hyperbolically dashing cops, private detectives and ex-C.I.A. operatives seek truth, justice and the American way - and invariably prevail.

title: JOB ADVICE FOR CHILDREN IN SHOW BUSINESS
description: A CASUAL comment by an actors' agent triggered the idea for J. Sutherland Gould's recent book, ''How to Get Your Child Into Show Business'' (St. Martin's Press, $12.95). ''You know,'' the agent said to Mr. Gould, ''there are many more jobs for children in show business than there are for adults, because of the enormous numbers of children used in commercials.''

title:
ART;
WHEN THE MEDIUM GETS THE EMPHASIS
description: COLOR, material and form - three basic components of many types of art, whether figurative or abstract - are the pre-eminent concerns of the three artists who are featured in the latest in the series of ''small group'' exhibitions at the Heckscher Museum.

title: AVALANCHE OF DEBT THREATENS GLOBAL ECONOMY
description: Is the world monetary system on the brink of a catastrophe? At the annual meeting here last week of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, the mood was more anxious and the warnings more dire than at any such gathering in memory.

title: 'PARUSIA,' ON WINGS OF SONG
description: BALDWIN PLACE ''PARUSIA,'' alternately described as a staged oratorio and a musical celebration, is doggedly determined to have us fly out of the Farm Playhouse on wings of redemptive song. For all its relentless efforts to soar to inspirational heights, it comes down with a thud.

title: WHAT'S TAUGHT IN SCHOOLS
description: I have news for Barbra Wagner Williams. The public schools do give courses in money management, self-awareness, family living and survival skills, only she didn't take them.

title: TOWN LIVES WITH URANIUM WASTES AND FEARS
description: Long before the atomic bomb and long before nuclear power plants, residents of this western Pennsylvania community lived with wastes buried by nuclear pioneers.

title: YOSEMITE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN FIFTH DISTRICT, CANDIDATES SPAR OVER ECONOMY
description: IN the race for the United States House of Representatives from the Fifth Congressional District, the Democratic incumbent, William R. Ratchford, and his Republican challenger, Neal B. Hanlon, seem to have settled on the economic policies of the Reagan Administration as the most effective rallying cry to the voters.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Across the River Poor New Jersey. The Encyclopedia Britanica says it suffers from ''a massive lack of identity,'' comedians - professional and otherwise - poke fun at it, and even wise Benjamin Franklin had little nice to say: New Jersey, he wrote in the 18th-century, was ''a barrel tapped at both ends.''

title: MOTHER'S EDUCATION GROWS WITH SON'S
description: THE West Side Highway was shrouded in a fine mist on this gray drizzly September morning. We were driving to Columbia College in Manhattan, where my son was about to start his freshman year.

title: Index; International
description: Monetary moves stir political tensions in Mexico 3 Foreign aid agencies controlling disbursement in Haiti 3 A melting pot is converging in Nicaragua 4 Around the World 5 Embassy gunman served jail term as a Polish spy 6 Jaruzelski ally predicts end of martial law in Poland 7 French Communists seek greater role in military 8 Environmental pollution a grow- ing problem in Eastern Europe 9 A passion for martial arts is growing in China 10 Equatorial Guinea takes a step forward 12 Archeologists find Jerusalem had bureaucrats 2,500 years ago 14 Israelis offended by German re- marks on Beirut siege 15 A blood feud divides Lebanon's Christians 16 Arab League meeting called ''disappointing'' 16 Invasion of Lebanon hinders ad- vance of Israeli-Egyptian ties 17 The harassment of Grey Advertising Agency 53

title: No Headline
description: FLORIDA UPSETS U.S.C. BY 17-9

title: FOUNDER OF GREY ADVERTISING
description: Lawrence Valenstein, who founded the Grey Advertising Agency and built it into one of the country's leading advertising companies, died of a heart attack at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., Friday. He was 83 years old and had lived in Scarsdale for more than 40 years.

title: A DISPUTE DELAYS WESTCHESTER'S POWER PLAN
description: A political squabble over the appointment of members is delaying creation of a public agency to seek cheap electric power for Westchester County.

title: PINOCHET AFFIRMS CHILE'S POLICIES
description: President Augusto Pinochet, the army general celebrating his ninth anniversary in power, said today that his ban on political activity would continue and he warned of tough action against those ''disrupting public order.''

title: RAP: THE FURIOUS FIVE
description: Elitists condemn popular music for its faddishness. But one of the things that enlivens pop is the very way in which a consensus can suddenly form about a particular group or song. Such enthusiasm is currently being felt, among rock tastemakers and New York dance-club audiences, for a rap song called ''The Message'' by Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five.

title: Kerry A. McNamara Is the Bride of Mark F. Minich; Minich
description: In St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., yesterday Kerry Ann McNamara, daughter of Mrs. Gerald C. McNamara of Saddle River and the late Mr. McNamara, was married to Mark Franklin Minich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Minich of Hartford and New York. The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Handy Has Nuptials
description: Nancy Parker Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy of Fairfield and Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Barry Grogan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Harris Grogan of Valhalla, N.Y. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn.

title: AN ADVENTUROUS LANDSCAPIST AT 93
description: A refreshing quality in today's gallery world is the favorable reception available for a broad range of approaches. An artist does not have to feel the need to pay homage to the most recent abstract tenets, and there is encouragement for figurative themes and landscape studies, as long as they are very direct, personalized interpretations.

title: VERY REAL PROGRESS ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: H.L. MENCKEN HOME IS TOPIC OF DISPUTE
description: H.L. Mencken, the sage of Baltimore, never wanted the simple row house where he lived for 70 years to be turned into a shrine.

title: BUck-Passing On Asbestos
description: There is no doubt that asbestos-related diseases have damaged or ended the lives of thousands of workers, but who will compensate the victims or their survivors, if anybody, is less clear. Suits against two major asbestos manufacturers have been frozen by bankruptcy actions, and last week the Government strongly denied that it had any responsibility in the cases.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK:

title: Korean Beauty Queen Freed From Abductor in Colorado
description: A ''badly abused'' Korean beauty queen was freed from from an abductor Saturday by detectives who acted on a friend's tip and found the pair in a hotel room, the Arapahoe County Sheriff's department said.

title: POLITICAL TENSIONS AROUSED IN MEXICO
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo's decision to reassert his political authority and stir a wave of nationalism just three months before leaving office has disrupted what was to be a gradual transfer of power to his successor, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado.

title: ARAB MODERATES OFFER OLD PROPOSALS IN NEW UNITY
description: One thing is clear: The moderates of the Arab world, the Kings of Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Morocco and, in absentia, the President of Egypt, won a major victory last week in Fez, Morocco, when Arab leaders issued a declaration that for the first time implicitly acknowledged Israel's right to exist and came out unanimously for settling the Arab-Israeli conflict through negotiation.

title: WHAT MORTGAGE OFFICERS LOOK FOR IN A BORROWER
description: KENNETH CLARK and Michele Klick badly wanted to buy a home of their o wn in time for their marriage Sept. 25. But when they found the h ouse they wanted in Edison, N.J., this summer, they began to wonder i f any bank would give them a mortgage loan. They were so young, theyh ad no credit history or large assets and were making only b eginners' salaries - he as a low-level manager at A.T.& T., she as af inancial analyst and computer programmer at the American Stock E xchange.

title: DELMARVA: THE ISLAND ON A PENINSULA
description: B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By B.DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

title: ''BARBAROSA'' PROVES THAT THE WESTERN ISN'T DEAD
description: Fred Schepisi's ''Barbarosa'' is so thoroughly entertaining and good-hearted that it comes as something of a shock to realize that it's not only the best Western in years, it's virtually the only Western in years. The Western hasn't just declined and fallen, it's almost disappeared. There are probably convincing economic reasons why this once most popular of movie genres has become such a rarity. But it can't be simply that they are too expensive to produce. All movies cost fortunes these days. The awful truth seems to be that audiences are no longer interested. The Western having been dumped, motherhood and country could go next.

title: A MODERN SICILIAN MAFIA STIRS RAGE AND FEAR
description: More than a week after gunmen assassinated the mafia-hunting Prefect of Palermo and his wife, a massive police investigation effort has failed to turn up a single witness to the ambush, which took place in the heart of Palermo at the peak of the evening.

title: 3 of 10 Escapees From a Jail In Queens Are Still Uncaught
description: Three of 10 inmates who escaped from a jail in Queens last week were still at large yesterday, authorities said. The convicts had used bedsheets tied into a rope to climb out of a third-floor window at the medium-security Queensboro State Correctional Facility last Monday night.

title: Lucretia Sias Is Married
description: Lucretia McNear Sias, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barnes Sias of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Robert Alan Yoho, son of Dr. Alan V. Yoho and Dr. Emma Jane Yoho of Kent, Ohio.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Merce Cunningham returns with the special format he calls ''Events'' in a series of studio performances beginning Friday night. Mr. Cunningham and his dance company will present a considerable amount of new choreography embedded among other fragments of dancing that he has composed for other works. Conceived in 1964, the Cunningham ''Event'' never sought to resemble a conventional dance performance.

title: LENDL OUSTS MCENROE, GAINS FINAL
description: Ivan Lendl ended John McEnroe's three-year dominance in the United States Open tennis championships yesterday and joined Jimmy Connors in the men's final.

title: RETURN OF ANDRETTI ADDS ZEST TO ITALIAN GRAND PRIX
description: Tired of long-distance travel and discouraged by three years without a victory, Mario Andretti, the 1978 world driving champion, quit the Formula One circuit at the end of the 1981 season. Today, he returns to compete in the Italian Grand Prix for Ferrari, the team that brought him his first grand prix victory 11 years ago.

title: LETTERS TO HINCKLEY JUDGE CRITICIZE ACQUITTAL
description: The judge who presided at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. has received 1,500 letters from the public since President Reagan's attacker was found not guilty by reason of insanity. A sampling of the letters indicates that the most-repeated message is a plea to keep Mr. Hinckley off the streets.

title: RESULTS OF MILITARY BONUS SYSTEM QUESTIONED
description: The military is relying increasingly on expensive bonuses to attract quality enlistees and to keep them in uniform, but there is no sure evidence that it is worth the price, Congressional investigators say.

title: New 767 Jetliner Lands Despite Mechanical Fault
description: A United Airlines 767 jetliner landed safely early this morning at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport with a malfunctioning wingflap, the airline said.

title: Doctors Monitor Machines, not Patient
description: I applaud Dr. Jesse S. Manlapaz's remarks in the article ''Technology Can Breed Neglect'' (Opinion Page, Aug. 22), in which he points out that the practice of medicine is still a human function and should not be made subservient to the monitoring of vital functions.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Aston Magna, which celebrated its 10th-anniversary season this summer in Great Barrington, Mass., is known as the American center for the authentic performance of early music, and also for the concerts it gives exemplifying its principles and practices. Most of those concerts are fairly small-scaled, however, reflecting the limitations of budget and, perhaps, the chamber-music proclivities of its participating musicians.

title: Dead Man Wins Primary
description: A dead man is the unofficial winner of a Democratic primary for constable in Pima County. The incumbent constable, Jack DeSchalit, died 11 days before the election but outpolled two write-in candidates, including his son, it was disclosed Thursday. The Board of Supervisors may declare the office vacant to enable the Democratic Party to appoint a candidate for the general election.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: LIKE children returning to school or adults getting back to work, wildlife in New Jersey is in transition. In the Cape May meadows, the streams and ponds of Burlington County, along the Kittatinny Mountains or out in the Atlantic, birds and fur-bearing mammals, reptiles, amphibians, fish and insects are stirring, responding to environmental cues signaling a change of seasons.

title: Tomorrow's Unemployed
description: The microchip now seems like the best thing since the tin lizzy, but it may be at least as devastating to modern-day equivalents of carriage makers. A study released last week warned that droves of Americans will be thrown out of work in coming decades because of automation and technological competition from abroad. Moreover, the Federal Government is not preparing very well for the crunch, the report said.

title: CITY AND H.U.D. SHARPLY AT ODDS ON HOUSING AID
description: AFUNDAMENTAL split between the Reagan Administration and New York City officials on the proper role of the Federal Government in u rban housing efforts has put the Administration's new regional a dministrator in the uncomfortable position of interpreter to the u nconvinced.

title: COSMOS RESPECT SOUNDERS IN TITLE GAME
description: The championship game of the North American Soccer League will match the Cosmos and the Seattle Sounders, the No. 1 and No. 2 teams in the regular season, next Saturday night in San Diego.

title: Helen Barton Potter, Teacher, Is Wed To H. Whitney Wagner, a Bank Aide
description: Helen Barton Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Potter of Chicago, was married yesterday to H. Whitney Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley A. Wagner of Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Charles Newbury performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck, Me.

title: Chicago Makes Offer For Best Official Song
description: The City of Chicago has announced that it needs an official song, something more formal than the tunes already written about it, and that is willing to give $5,000 to the person who can come up with the best one.

title: SODIUM LIGHTS CAST NEW GLOW ON L.I.E.
description: THE pinkish-yellow glow rising from the Island at night is growing brighter as high-pressure sodium street lights replace older mercury vapor and incandescent fixtures.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IT ISN'T such a long way from Waldwick, a small town in western Bergen County, to Broadway. Just ask Allison Smith and Alyson Kirk, 12-year-old neighbors, playmates and -until both made it to stardom in ''Annie'' - classmates at Waldwick's Traphagen School.

title: Injury Award to Jockey
description: A Dade County Circuit Court jury in Miami has awarded $10 million in damages to David Ashcroft, a 20-year-old jockey who was paralyzed from the neck down last year when thrown from his horse at Calder Race Course. The six-member jury decided that the track operator had been negligent in designing the race track, causing Ashcroft's mount to bolt and throw him last Oct. 31.

title: COMPUTER ERROR ON LEASING DATE MAY COST U.S. UP TO $35 MILLION
description: The General Services Administration said Friday that a computer error that could cost taxpayers $35 million was forcing about six Federal agencies to move their offices.

title: THEATER WITH A DO-IT-YOURSELF APPROACH
description: ALTON D. RISON is a very determined man. Because this determination has helped him attain everything he has ever wanted in life -from breaking college track records to carving an important place for himself in the field of education - the Uniondale resident sees no reason why he shouldn't succeed in his latest endeavor.

title: THE SECRET WORLD OF THE O'CONNORS
description: In the towering Chicago Board of Trade, where fortunes rise and fall with the price of grain, there are no bigger names than Edmund J. and William F. O'Connor. When the two brothers deal, the stakes are in the double-digit millions. But, like Texas' legendary Hunt and Bass brothers, the O'Connors keep their dealings shrouded in privacy, making them the object of much speculation.

title: Some Harmony In Union Talks
description: What began as a tug-of-war between city negotiators and 180,000 non-uniformed workers ended last week more like a ribbon cutting, with both sides claiming a victory.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE BILL THAT SAVED THE BUDGET PROCESS
description: LAST February I wrote that the Congressional budget process was d ying. It was. Congressional decision-making processes were in d isarray and the legislators and their staffs were in a blue funk.

title: No Headline
description: 44 ON U.S. COPTER REPORTED KILLED IN WEST GERMAN AIR SHOW CRASH

title: THE BATTLE OVER CHEMICAL LABELING
description: CINCINNATI WORKER demands for more information about the thousands of chemicals used daily in American factories have prompted nine states and a handful of cities to adopt chemical-labeling laws. But the trade unionists and job-safety activists who fought for these regulations are now battling an unlikely threat: a proposed new Federal regulation.

title: China Finesses Its Grudges; And Drudges
description: China's Communist leaders reformed their party last week and the new structure resembled, formally at least, the Soviet model. Bureaucratic affinities aside, the atmospherics suggested that the feuding Marxist-Leninist giants may again be groping, however slightly, toward normalizing relations.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN EXHIBIT WORTH THE TRIP
description: WETHERSFIELD COLLECTORS who travel to the Wethersfield Outdoor Antiques Festival each September receive an extra dividend - the visual delight as they make their way to the Wethersfield Cove of driving slowly through the historic part of this ancient town along streets lined with handsome colonial homes.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Loss of Face

title: IN PARKING PINCH, CITIES THE WORLD OVER TRY SOME NEW TACKS
description: New York's 65,000 parking meters are expensive to maintain and subject to vandals, irate drivers, thieves and schemes to avoid payment. They are tended by a force of 1,100 city agents, 376 of whom have been assaulted this year. From time to time, officials of the city's Division of Parking throw up their hands and say there must be an alternative.

title: DETECTIVES EXPAND SEARCH FOR STOLEN MAYAN ITEMS
description: An expanded force of detectives mounted a widening search yesterday for a thief and the 25 Mayan jade artifacts he stole last weekend from the American Museum of Natural History.

title: IN A NEW YORK CORNFIELD, THE BOOM OF CANNONRY
description: Reveille resounded at 9:04 this morning from one of the mobile homes at an encampment here. The embers in the nearby charcoal grills still glowed from breakfast, on this weekend eaten alfresco and known as mess.

title: F. A. King Weds Alexandra Ranck
description: Alexandra Warren Ranck, daughter of Mrs. Clayton Ernst Ranck of Hockessin, Del., and the late Mr. Ranck, was married yesterday to Fletcher Alan King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lyman King Jr. of Chatham Township, N.J. The Rev. C. Frederick Mathias performed the ceremony in the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: THE CASE AGAINST SANCTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration's frenetic efforts to obstruct the building of the Soviet-European natural-gas pipeline are marked by hypocrisy, self-deception and an astonishing ignorance of past experience. In addition - and even more important -they disclose a lamentable confusion of basic philosophy regarding the Soviet Union and the Western alliance. The pipeline episode provides a case history of how not to conduct United States foreign policy. Even should President Reagan unexpectedly do a complete about-face, the issues raised by the controversy will remain as guides to our future conduct.

title: THE INSANITY PLEA ON TRIAL
description: At one point, Judge Kaufman states, ''... it is not surprising that many excellent psychiatrists now refuse to testify at trials. At the same time, there are always going to be a few psychiatrists willing to tailor their opinions to the needs of the side paying the bill.''

title:
DINING OUT;
A GATHERING PLACE IN ARMONK
description: REVIEWED in this space last January as not only an attractive gathering place but also a serious restaurant, Covington, although retaining its reputation for the former has bewilderingly abandoned its reputation as a restaurant offering superior and exciting cuisine. A change in kitchen personnel becomes apparent as the menu continues to offer a number of the dishes made popular by the former chef, and the comparison is often cruel. The kitchen may have all of the components for its former success but the present staff has not discovered as yet the key to producing the completed article - the beguiling way wih fresh herbs, the daring touches of hot pepper, the wisps of puff pastry. Not all the dishes produced by the old kitchen were excellent, but enough were so that on balance Covington rated an easy two stars. Now an averaging of dishes (from inedible to competent) results in a rating of one star and a sinking one at that.

title: Miss McInerney, W.H. Stephens Jr.  Wed in Greenwich
description: M. Virginia McInerney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. McInerney of Greenwich, Conn., and Wianno, Mass., was married yesterday to Willis H. Stephens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephens of Brewster and Lake Placid, N.Y. Msgr. James McLaughlin performed the ceremony at the St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: STARTING A CONGRESSIONAL RACE FROM SCRATCH
description: Call it presumptuous, but the billboard that says ''Pat Haggerty, Congressman'' seeks to establish instant credibility for an El Paso alderman. Mr. Haggerty is a Republican running for the House against State Representative Ron Coleman in the 16th Congressional District, the open seat that runs from here into the open spaces of West Texas.

title: CALIFORNIAN WINS MISS AMERICA
description: Miss California, Debra Sue Maffett, was crowned Miss America 1983 tonight at the nationally televised pageant finals from Convention Hall here.

title: Self-Determination And Rye Brook
description: Being a resident of the new village of Rye Brook, I was looking forward to your coverage of our upcoming election. I was, however, disappointed in the information you selected to include in the article you printed on Aug. 22 (''New Village Prepares to Elect Its First Officials'').

title: ADIRONDACKS LAKESHORE TRACT IS ADDED TO PRESERVE BY STATE
description: New York State has bought a 439-acre tract adjoining Silver Lake in the Adirondack Mountains to add to the Forest Preserve.

title: DANBURY PRESSES AIRPORT SAFETY
description: DANBURY LAST summer, nine air traffic controllers and trainees at Danbury Municipal Airport joined the nationwide strike of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers union and subsequently lost their jobs. The five remaining tower employees were transferred by the Federal Aviation Administration to other, larger, airports in the region whose towers had lost personnel because of the strike.

title: THE BENDIX TAKEOVER BATTLE INTENSIFIES
description: United Technologies joined Martin Marietta in the move to take over Bendix, intensifying the takeover struggle. Martin Marietta said that about 14.5 million, or 75 percent, of Bendix shares outstanding, were tendered under its offer. Earlier, Bendix said it had received 58 percent of Martin's shares. Bendix has accused Citibank, the trustee of the Bendix Salaried Employee Savings and Stock Ownership Plan, with acting wrongfully in tendering 4.5 million shares to Martin Marietta.

title: One Voice Fades
description: One Soviet group that frequently sought access to the West said last week that it was disbanding because arrests, jailings and general harassment had reduced it to three active members. The Moscow Group to Promote Observance of the Helsinki Agreements in the U.S.S.R. thus confirmed what had long been evident -the decimation of a once highly vocal opposition. The 1975 Helsinki agreements provided for cooperation between East and West and the protection of human rights, but that didn't stop the Russians from sending 16 of the Soviet group's members to labor camps or internal exile for dissidence.

title: YOUNG AT WAR
description: A MIDNIGHT CLEAR By William Wharton. 242 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: PRESERVATION FOR PROFIT
description: In his tattered jeans and plaid shirt, Ernie Motteram still looks like the New Mexico cowboy he was when he came to Kenya seven years ago at the age of 25. But when he squeezes his lanky body into the cab of the Land-Rover pickup, and begins chatting with the driver in Swahili, it's clear he's come a way since then. He rests the butt of a small-bore rifle on his knee and lets its barrel protrude through the open window. The night air is cool, and the stars are so bright they compete with the lights of Nairobi, visible along the horizon.

title: LOOPHOLES SEEN IN PINELANDS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Anthony DePalma and Leo H.Carney and was written by Mr. DePalma.

title: Protecting L.I.'s Water Supply
description: The abundant subsurface supply of fresh water described as extending beneath the length of Long Island's South Shore in the recent article ''For L.I.'s Pure Water, the Threat Intensifies'' is nonexistent on the East End.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: four previously published reviews, articles and essays. FAMILY INSTALLMENTS, by Edward Rivera.

title: Lutherans Agree To Forge One Mighty Fortress
description: Four hundred years after Martin Luther decided he couldn't get along with the Roman Catholic Church, three groups of his theological descendants have decided they can get along with each other. At separate conventions last week, representatives of the three denominations voted to merge, forming a new Lutheran church whose 5.5 million members would make it the third largest Protestant denomination in the country.

title: POP: JOHNNY MATHIS CROONS
description: In the 26 years he has been making records, Johnny Mathis hasn't changed substantially. Though his ethereal tenor, with its wide, reedy vibrato, is a bit darker and fuller than it once was, his approach is still essentially that of a pop crooner. Thursday at Radio City Music Hall, where he began a four-night engagement, Mr. Mathis emphasized the continuity between past and present by concentrating on romantic ballads.

title: HEART TOLL LOWER FOR FARMERS
description: Farmers are likely to live longer than other rural residents and have less chance of dying of heart disease, according to a study of Iowa residents.

title: WHY IS HERMAN KAHN SMILING?
description: THE COMING BOOM Economic, Political, and Social. By Herman Kahn. 237 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Free and Clear
description: Perhaps no reporter was ever happier to see a sentence of his changed than Paul W. Corsetti was last week. Mr. Corsetti, who writes for The Boston Herald American, got 90 days in jail for contempt after he refused to testify at a murder trial about an interview he had promised would remain confidential. Massachusetts Gov. Edward J. King declined to pardon Mr. Corsetti, but last week he did ask the State Executive Council to commute his sentence to the eight days he had already served.

title: 2,500 YEARS OF JERUSALEM BUREAUCRATS
description: The recent discovery of some 53 ancient seals in this city suggests that Israelites who lived here more than 2,500 years ago were beleaguered by bureaucracy.

title: UNIVERSITY EXPERTS WEIGH MOTIVES FOR MUSEUM THEFT
description: Experts in art and archeology offered several theories yesterday on the theft of 25 Mayan jade artifacts from the American Museum of Natural History.

title: WHEN A TICKET IS AN INVITATION TO A GATHERING
description: I had an injured toe last week so I decided to go to the movies. Now what, you may ask, does an injured toe have to do with going to the movies? I will tell you, though a moment's thought on your part might have prevented this whole discussion. If you must go out of an evening, taking your aching extremity with you, the movies are the very best place to go because there's nobody there. Nobody to step all over you unawares, I mean.

title: Royals 9, Twins 3
description: KANSAS CITY (AP) - Frank White drove in two runs, and Hal McRae hit a home run that made him Kansas City's career single-season runsbatted-in leader.

title: A NEW SPIRIT OF ECLECTICISM IN JAZZ
description: The most significant jazz event of the coming season may have happened two weeks ago. The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, in which most of the jazz clubs in Greenwich Village joined forces to point up the variety of jazz activities taking place in the Village, was an unprecedented break with the divisive thinking that has splintered the jazz world for more than half a century.

title: DIRECTIONS IN DANCE, FROM CLASSICAL TO POSTMODERN
description: For sheer energy and verve, for variety of experimentation and the sense that new things are possible, dance is certainly among the most vital art-forms today - and New York has been one of its vital centers. This coming season promises a big new ballet from Jerome Robbins at the New York City Ballet, a lavish full-evening production of ''Cinderella'' from American Ballet Theater, a revival of Bronislava Nijinska's rarely performed ''Les Biches,'' courtesy of the Dance Theater of Harlem, and a new work by the experimentalist Laura Dean for the Joffrey Ballet, which will have sets and costumes by Michael Graves, the post-modernist architect.

title: SPREADING BANKRUPTCIES
description: After ebbing slightly in midsummer, the business failure rate has accelerated rapidly since the end of July, coming ever closer to levels not seen since the Great Depression.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE BUILDUP OF LAWN THATCH
description: THERE seems to be some misunderstanding as to the meaning of the term thatch as applied to a lawn. It has been determined through research that thatch is not the product of uncollected lawn clippings; rather it has been found to be the accumulation of the bases of the stems of old grass.

title: MISSING CHILDREN: NEW LAWS SOUGHT
description: ''THE state has a very large stake in maintaining the welfare of children,'' says Assemblyman Martin A. Herman, Democrat of Woodbury. ''They shouldn't become part of parents' hide-and-seek games with the child as a prize.''

title: The Road From Fez
description: The Arab League summit at Fez 10 months ago, to consider a Saudi plan for peace with states that were whispered to include Israel, broke up after four hours. The P.L.O. gagged on the idea, and shot it down. One war later, the conference reconvened last week and, in four days, gave the Saudis the benefit of Israel's victory. The routed P.L.O. was persuaded to endorse U.N. ''guarantees (of) peace among all states.'' Diplomats perceive this as progress. If it is, the pace is dangerously slow.

title: Kathryn Krauss Wed To James C. Higgins 2d
description: Kathryn Stearns Krauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Augustus Krauss 3d of Milwaukee, was married there yesterday in St. Christopher's Episcopal Church to James Crane Higgins 2d, son of Mrs. Decatur Sawyer Higgins of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Higgins.

title: BUSINESS SUCCESS WAS IN THE BAG
description: ''I wanted to invent, innovate and make present things better.'' Warner Jay Heuman of Great Neck was talking about the time - back in February 1963 - when he and three other Long Islanders invested $2,500 each to start a company to manufacture plastic bags.

title: Willie on My Mind
description: Through the aid of Charley Waters, the former Dallas Cowboy all-pro safety, two Giant linebackers, Brad Van Pelt and Brian Kelley, were able to visit Willie Nelson backstage at the country and western singer's concert Friday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Van Pelt and Kelley told Mr. Nelson that they had a good friend who was also a Willie fan. Yesterday, they delivered an autographed Willie Nelson picture to Doug Kotar, the former Giant halfback hospitalized with a brain tumor. ''To Doug: Get well soon, buddy, I'm rooting for you,'' Mr. Nelson wrote.

title: JARUZELSKI ALLY PREDICTS LIFTING OF MARTIAL LAW
description: A prominent Communist intellectual predicted in a newspaper interview today that authorities would gradually lift martial law despite recent protests, but would retain special police powers to keep a tight rein on dissidents.

title: Karen Moreland Married
description: Karen Lynn Moreland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Moreland of Glenmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mitchell Grossinger Etess, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. David Etess of Grossinger, N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Robert C. Williams performed the ceremony at the Grossinger Hotel, where the bride is assistant conference coordinator and her husband is executive assistant manager. Mr. Etess is a grandson of the late Harry and Jennie Grossinger, who founded the family-owned resort. His mother is executive vice president and his father, a retired psychiatrist, is medical director of the hotel.

title: EXXON BAYWAY WORKERS PONDER FUTURE
description: LINDEN TODAY is P-Day - Picnic Day - for the 1,470 employees of Exxon's Bayway refinery. They will converge on a grove in the Morris County community of Towaco for fun, food and fellowship, but there also may be a speech or two that will take note of Exxon's centennial - its history begins with John D. Rockefeller and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey - and what may be uppermost in the minds of those who operate the biggest oil refinery in the East:

title: RECESSION CREATING A 'NOUVEAU POOR'
description: SMITHTOWN THEY grew up believing that if they received a good education and worked hard, there would be no limits, that they would lead the good life and everything would be fine. Now they are in the $30,000 to $40,000 income bracket and many things are not fine.

title: DONORS PRESS HAITI ON USE OF AID FUNDS
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti - The Government of Jean-Claude Duvalier, which must rely on foreign aid for 40 percent of its budget, is increasingly being forced to change its longstanding ways of doing business as the price for the outside help.

title: Red Sox 13, Tigers 3
description: BOSTON (AP) - Gary Allenson managed only a looping single but still batted in five runs.

title: POLL RATES DEMOCRATS BEST ON TOP PROBLEMS
description: According to the latest Gallup Poll, Americans give Democrats a clear advantage over Republicans in rating the parties' abilities to handle the nation's most important problem.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: The Bloopie Awards

title:
A FINAL WORD;
'HAROLD GENEEN-GOD-BLESS-HIM!'
description: THE other day I was talking on the phone to my tough 83-year-old g randmother about the stock market, a topic that has caused some of o ur more memorable verbal clashes over the years.

title: STRONG FEELINGS SURROUND JETS-DOLPHINS
description: In a charged atmosphere more appropriate to the last game of the season than the first, the New York Jets play the Miami Dolphins today.

title: CAMPUS LIFE IS ENRICHED BY FOREIGN INFLUX
description: ESTIMATES indicate that there are more than 300,000 foreign students attending institutions of higher learning in the United States. Increasing steadily since 1945, the past 10 years have seen an even greater number of students, from every corner of the world, taking up studies in the United States. If the growth rate of the past decade continues, we may have more than one million foreign students attending our nation's schools by 1990.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THIS is one tight little island, this Long Island of ours. We hear so much about population growth, political trends, new developments, industrial enterprises and nuclear plants that it is easy to lose track of how much of old Long Island remains, how easy it is to find the rural and suburban charm that originally attracted everyone out to the Island and thereby modified its attractions. Yet a drive that steers clear of the expressway will plunge the serendipitous traveler into quaint corners and restful byways.

title: WHY YOUTHS THREATEN ADULTS
description: IT seems that the controversy surrounding video arcades, as evidenced in many towns in Connecticut, is not really an issue of video games. The real underlying issue appears to be an adult insecurity in whether we have imparted our values and morals to our youth.

title: White House Over-Reaches
description: Representative Robert H. Michel had a straightforward explanation of Ronald Reagan's defeat at the hands of his own party last week. A House vote to override the President's veto of a $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill for 1982 could not be beaten back, the House minority leader said, because Mr. Reagan's ''was not a good, solid position to defend.''

title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES
description: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City.

title: MAINE INDIANS STILL AWAITING ECONOMIC GAIN IN LAND DEAL
description: TOWNSHIP 6, RANGE 8, Me., Sept. 11 (AP) - Clifton Webster, a 64-year-old logger who has been hauling timber out of the northern Maine woods near his home in Patten since 1938, shrugs when asked if his job has changed since the Penobscot Indians bought the land.

title: Michael Weinberger Marries Julie Sandorf
description: Julie Ann Sandorf and Michael Weinberger, cum laude graduates of Clark University, class of '79, were married in New York yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Sandorf. Rabbi Paul Steinberg performed the ceremony.

title: I WRITE FOR REVENGE AGAINST REALITY
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: LAKE ERIE PROJECT CALLED TOO COSTLY
description: Property owners on the Lake Erie shoreline must learn to live with changing water levels that have caused millions of dollars in flood and erosion damage because it would be too costly to regulate the lake's level, an international study has concluded.

title: EQUATORIAL GUINEA APPROVES A LIBERAL CHARTER
description: Voters in Equatorial Guinea, a tiny West African country, have approved a Constitution that on paper is one of the most liberal in Africa.

title: Joan P. Murtagh Married in Rye To J. H. Marren
description: The marriage of Joan Patricia Murtagh, an associate with the New York law firm of Emmet, Marvin & Martin, to Joseph Hugh Marren, manager of strategic planning for the American Maize Products Company in Stamford, Conn., took place in Rye, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. James T. McGuire performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: WITH OIL OUTPUT OFF, RUMANIA TURNS TO ATOMS
description: With oil production stagnant, Rumania is planning an ambitious nuclear power program with the goal of being self-sufficient in energy by 1990.

title: POLICE UNIT LINKS 39 JURISDICTIONS
description: HAWTHORNE IT is too neat a place to serve as a set for ''Detective Story'' and too quiet for an episode of ''Barney Miller,'' but the office of the county's crime-analysis unit here grapples with the same basic problem: finding out ''whodunit.''

title: 'POTSHOTS' FROM 'COWARDLY' E.P.A. EMPLOYEES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE INSANITY PLEA ON TRIAL
description: Judge Kaufman laments the effect of strict interpretation of the M'Naghten rule which, according to him, could place ''individuals who require treatment in mental hospitals ... in prisons where they receive no meaningful psychiatric care.'' To many of us charged with the responsibility of providing this ''meaningful treatment'' to involuntarily hospitalized offenders, his concern is ambiguous and presumes expertise which does not exist.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART One of the artists I most miss is Marcel Broodthaers, who was born in 1924 and died in 1976. Among those who worked in the interstices of art after World War II he was always outstanding. He didn't really paint. He didn't really sculpt. He didn't really draw. He didn't really write. But somehow or other his compound activities came across as art and could not be defined otherwise.

title: THERE HE GOES AGAIN
description: ''Yes, recovery has been sighted,'' President Reagan said in his Alfred M. Landon lecture at Kansas State University.

title: Maria Mabee Married To Jeffrey Allen Mason
description: Maria Brattle Mabee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Williams Mabee of Edgartown, Mass., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Allen Mason, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Allen Mason of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. John A. Greely, rector of St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., performed the ceremony in the garden of the Mabee's Edgartown home.

title: BLACKLEDGE PASSING LIFTS PENN STATE
description: Todd Blackledge, who has helpedtransform Penn State from a predictable and plodding running power to an exciting team, threw four more touchdown passes today to lead the Nittany Lions to a 39-31 victory over Maryland in a passing battle at Beaver Stadium.

title: Missy Troy Becomes Bride of Toby Smiles
description: The marriage of Adele Folger Troy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Troy 2d of Bedford, N.Y., to Christopher Wiggin Smiles took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Jay Newberry performed the ceremony.

title: SHARING THE RITES OF THE WINE HARVEST
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. BY FRANK J. PRIAL

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: CANADA'S ECONOMY TROUBLES WILDWOOD
description: WILDWOOD EVERY morning throughout the summer, ''O Canada'' rang out, along with ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' through loudspeakers on the 2 1/2-mile-long boardwalk here, but relatively few Canadians heard it.

title: KNOXVILLE FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: BONES OF THE DEAD BRING NEW LIFE TO A TOWN IN ILLINOIS
description: What was once the Hanks Funeral Home is now an archeological library. There is a computer center for archeological data in the house where Brian Cress once lived. Hayn's drugstore, which also contained the post office, has become a teaching laboratory for cultural anthropology, and a human osteology laboratory is housed in what used to be Smith's Shelter Care and Convalescent Home for the Aged.

title: WHERE THE MONARCHS WINTER
description: WAYNE KING is chief of the Houston bureau of The Times and a former member of the San Francisco bureau. By WAYNE KING

title: Labor: Still Alive
description: To the Business Editor: A.H. Raskin's centennial Labor Day article, ''Frustrated and Wary, Labor Marks Its Day'' (Sept.5), was insightful and perceptive. His excellent overview of current trends in American industrial relations leaves us wondering only whether there is not more continuity in today's developments, and less cause for despair, than Mr. Raskin seems to suggest.

title: COURT TO DECIDE JURISDICTION OVER SIOUX LAND
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit will hear arguments next week in a dispute over whether the State of South Dakota has jurisdiction in crimes committed on part of the Cheyenne River Sioux Indian Reservation.

title: Jean Alison Smith Wed To Rodnie A. Nelson
description: Jean Alison Smith, daughter of Mrs. Howard Smith of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Rodnie Allen Nelson, son of Donald Nelson and Gloria Wood, both of Seattle. The Rev. Richard Pankow performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Brooklyn.

title: RULES FOR MIDWIVES ARE EASED
description: PRINCETON UNDER revised regulations approved by the state's Board of Medical Examiners last week, certified nurse-midwives in New Jersey will now be able to participate in the management of certain high-risk pregnancies.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CATHERINE MARSHALL'S STORY BIBLE Illustrated by Children. 197 pp. Lincoln, Va., & New York: Chosen Books and Crossroad. $17.50. By D.J.R.BRUCKNER

title: Giants 8, Padres 3
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Tom O'Malley hit a double and two singles and drove in two runs for San Francisco. Bill Laskey (13-10) pitched the first five innings, giving up three runs on eight hits as the Giants won for the eighth time in their last nine games. Al Holland pitched hitless ball over the final four innings for his second save.

title: Whose Beat Is The Subways
description: It's not that New York City transit patrolmen couldn't use help in the subways. But with the Guardian Angels already there and more volunteer civilian officers scheduled for subway duty, the uniformed patrolmen reject the notion that there's safety in mere numbers.

title: ZURICH
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Trone Is Bride of D.M. Chapman; Chapman
description: Leslie Ann Trone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Trone of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Monroe Chapman, son of Maj. Gen. Kenneth R. Chapman, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Chapman of Arlington, Tex. The Rev. Bruce Ingles performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church.

title: Fair to House Visitors Booked in Defunct Inns
description: World's Fair officials say that hundreds of fair visitors who made reservations to stay in two nowdefunct housing complexes have been offered free lodging in a camper village sponsored by the fair.

title: A LEADER FOR THE LITTLE GUY
description: JERRY WURF Labor's Last Angry Man. By Joseph C. Goulden. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: Matter of Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: WINFIELD CLOUTS 32D
description: As if to remind several of the 1982 pennant contenders that they, too, were once contenders, the Yankees spent the past week erupting offensively once in each series they played.

title: LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS TORN BY AN OLD BLOOD FEUD
description: Northern Lebanon, the bastion of former President Suleiman Franjieh, has become noticeably tense in the aftermath of Bashir Gemayel's election as President. Much of the atmosphere stems from a four-year-old blood feud between the two Christians. But there is also talk of war, and of Mr. Franjieh's special vulnerability.

title: One Small Step For Capitalism
description: Robert Goddard, the father of American rocketry who was called ''moon mad'' in his early days, would have felt proud last week when a privately funded missile blasted off from a Texas cow pasture. Houston-based Space Services, Inc., with the backing of only seven full-time employees and $6 million, launched its primitive Conestoga I rocket to inaugurate an age of capitalism in space. ''This showed that a group of private investors can get together and launch a rocket in a responsible way and well within a commercially feasible limit,'' said the company founder David Hannah Jr., a Texas real estate developer.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BIG BIRD? NO, JUST A CUCKOO CLOCK
description: MIDLAND PARK FLORENCE DANIEL IMPORTS at Godwin and Central Avenues is a store that may puzzle, delight or intrigue. The shop reflects the training of the owner, Florence Daniel, as an interior decorator and graduate of the Parsons School of Design. She has a penchant for the unusual, a leaning supported by her husband, Dan Daniel, and her other partner, Alex Komar.

title: Allyson Button Bride Of Christopher Phillips
description: Allyson Lyle Button, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Easton Button of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Reynolds Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Phillips of Manchester, Mass. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., by the Rev. David W. Philips, pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Old Greenwich, and the Rev. Philip E. Perkins, rector of St. Paul's,

title: RISE IN 'DOWRY DEATHS' ALARMS INDIAN WOMEN
description: Her daughter, Raj Yadav says, was 18 years old and married less than a year when she was held by the arms, doused with gasoline and set afire by her husband or in-laws or both. The daugher died.

title: Donna Caulkins Is Married to William Parsons Jr.
description: Donna Alice Van Hise Caulkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Caulkins of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married in the Congregational Church there yesteday to William H. Parsons Jr., son of Mr. Parsons of Cooperstown, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Parsons. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Taylor, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Amato, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PLAN TO SHARE WATER PROJECT COSTS IS GAINING IN WEST UNDER REAGAN
description: Western officials who rejected a Carter Administration plan to share 10 percent of the bill on new water projects in the region may soon be asked by President Reagan to pay about a third of the cost of building the giant dams and reservoirs.

title: DIAMONDS: NOT A SCOT'S BEST FRIEND
description: Every bridge expert knows in theory that the nine of diamonds is the Curse of Scotland, even if he does not recall the questionable historical legends that connect that card variously with the Pope, Mary Queen of Scots, the Massacre of Glencoe and the Battle of Culloden. But he sometimes forgets it in practice, and West blamed himself for his lack of awareness on the diagramed deal from the 1981 Maccabiah Games played in Tel Aviv, Israel. The occasion was a playoff between Canada and Great Britain for third place, as a result of which the bronze medals went to Canada.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Chicago's Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a cooperative organization that was formed in the mid-1960's, has nurtured an impressive number of jazz innovators and jazz stars - the Art Ensemble of Chicago, Air, Anthony Braxton, Leroy Jenkins, and younger musicians like the saxophonist Chico Freeman. Most of these musicians left Chicago long ago for New York and Europe, but they still consider themselves AACM members and take an active interest in the organization's programs, which concentrate on developing new talent.

title: White Sox 2, A's 0
description: Carlton Fisk hit a two-run homer as Chicago won for the 10th time in its last 12 games.

title: TEACH NATIONAL SECURITY
description: On June 12, half a million people marched in New York City in support of a nuclear freeze. These days, thousands of college students who marched are returning to campuses and continuing their efforts to end the arms race. Their return is a challenge: Only a few colleges have the faculty, courses and programs to support learning about issues of this kind. But their return is an opportunity, too: The study of national security can be an especially apt vehicle for liberal education.

title: Louisianians Back Home As Storm Moves Inland
description: Some 6,500 people who left their homes last night at the approach of Tropical Storm Chris returned today as the storm moved over southwestern Louisiana, spending its strength in a deluge of rain that threatened minor flooding.

title: School Merger
description: The Board of Education's plan was to merge two high schools on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The single high school would be housed in two buildings - the Louis D. Brandeis High School building on 84th Street and the Martin Luther King Jr.

title: AN EROSION OF 1981'S GAINS
description: OF all the arguments advanced on behalf of the Tax Equity and FiscalR esponsibility Act of 1982, or Tefra, by far the most bizarre was thec laim that this legislation was essential to promote economic r ecovery and to provide jobs.

title: AT THE HEART OF THE PALESTINE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE HEART OF THE PALESTINE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: AMATEURS RECRUITED IN WILTON; BY ROBERT SHERMAN
description: IF you'd like to play in an orchestra instead of just listening to one, heed the call of Paul Lavalle, the conductor who is recruiting new members for his Wilton Chamber Orchestra.

title: WHAT'S TAUGHT IN SCHOOLS
description: Barbra Wagner Williams cites the need for basic life skills. It is a pity that she didn't elect one or two courses in home economics.

title: Jonathon Keith Marries Dita Dantine in California
description: Dita Joanne Dantine, daughter of Nicola Schenck Dantine of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Helmut Dantine, was married yesterday to Jonathon Chilton Keith, son of Jocelyn Freer Keith of Bethesda, Md., and Norman C. Keith of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Clifton W. King of the Encino Community Church in Tarzana, Calif., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: New Approach To the S.A.T.
description: Educational Testing Service, the General Motors of test designers, says its college admissions test measures ''aptitude,'' so students cannot study for it. Many educators disagree.

title: Patricia Ann Briggs Is Wed
description: Patricia Ann Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Briggs of Branford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael Anthony Venezia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael N. Venezia of Brooklyn. The Rev. John Zalonis performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: COMPENDIUM OF CRUISES
description: T he following guide to cruise ships is arranged by destination and primarily covers saltwater cruises. Cruises are also offered on many of the world's major rivers, such as the Mississippi, the Rhine and the Yangtze, but details on these and on most freighter cruises (an exception is Delta Cruise Lines' 100-passenger cargo vessels) are not included. The list, which covers sailings from Sept. 13 to Dec. 31, is the third in a series of four this year in Travel. The next will appear Nov. 21. Information in the guide was supplied by the cruise companies, but dates, ports of call and fares are subject to change. Unless otherwise noted, the fares quoted are for one person in double occupancy and range from the lowest-to the highest-priced accommodations.

title: MUNICH'S OPEN-AIR MARKET
description: T he Viktualienmarkt, in the heart of Munich, is much more than a place to buy fruits, vegetables, chickens, rabbits, game cheeses, wines, pastries, breads, herbs, flowers and plants. It is an allcobblestone, open-air market where Munchners have been meeting friends to browse, snack, quaff, gossip and argue politics since 1807.

title: Italians Approve Law Outlawing Link to Mafia
description: A bill that for the first time in Italian history outlaws association with the Mafia cleared its last hurdle in Parliament today when a Senate commission approved it, parliamentary sources said.

title: SURVEY SHOWS FOOD STAMP USE UP 5% IN 1981
description: Food stamp use was up 5 percent last year over 1980, perhaps reflecting the higher unemployment rate, while fewer children ate school lunches, according to a Census Bureau report.

title: E.P.A. RELAXES PROPOSED TEXTILE WASTE RULES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is killing a Carter Administration proposal that would have enforced highly restrictive water pollution standards at 2,000 textile mills in the United States.

title: BENEATH THE VETO UPSET WERE DEEPER DISCONTENTS
description: WASHINGTON TONY Coelho might have been the only gloomy Democrat in Washington last week. The California Representative is head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, and as the House was voting Thursday on whether to sustain President Reagan's veto of a $14.1 billion spending bill, Mr. Coelho had his computers and copying machines humming. He could not wait to start attacking the Republicans who supported the President, voting against funds to help the elderly and the handicapped.

title: THE F.H.A. AND V.A. PROGRAMS
description: ONE fairly common myth in buying a home is that a Veterans A dministration or Federal Housing Administration mortgage is for s omebody else: The veteran thinks he has somehow used up his b enefits, or passed a time barrier and is no longer eligible for a V .A.- insured mortgage, while many middle-income people assume that a n F.H.A. mortgage is just for the poor.

title: A LOT FOR A LOT
description: Never in modern times has so large a site been cleared and offered for sale for new construction smack in the heart of Wall Street. It is the former Cities Service building site, expanded to 53,000 square feet by recent demolition, at 60 Wall Street.

title: First All-Hispanic Recruit Unit Is Graduated at a Naval Base
description: Recruit Company 116, known at the San Diego Naval Training Center as ''Los Marineros,'' has become the first all-Hispanic unit to be graduated from basic training.

title: Topics; Pious Deceptions; C.I.A. Disinformation
description: William Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, is continuing his attack on the Freedom of Information Act by posing a false choice between an open society and a secure one. ''I question very seriously,'' he told the American Legion recently, ''whether a secret intelligence agency and a Freedom of Information Act can coexist for very long.''

title: THE STATE OF THE CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: THE New York City public school system, viewed not long ago as a hopelessly lost cause, has lately been showing some cause for hope. With a surprising upturn in a variety of indicators, officials are optimistic about the school year that begins tomorrow. An important factor is rising achievement scores in reading and mathematics in the elementary and junior high schools. In the spring, these scores surpassed the national norms for the first time in at least a decade, putting New York City ahead of most other major urban systems. Authorities credit the gains to the tough promotional policy Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola put in place two years ago, a reflection of his desire to set higher standards and hold students to them. Now that they must earn their way to the next level, almost 50 percent more fourth graders and 100 percent more seventh graders were held back last year than in 1978. Progress at these levels, it is hoped, will eventually supply the high schools with better prepared students. In the meantime, however, the system continues to suffer from having too many high school students with neither the ability nor the educational background needed for a diploma. The schools also continue to suffer from crime. Though many categories have declined recently, spending time in some of the system's 1,000 school buildings is still only slightly safer than a stroll through Central Park after midnight. Like the city, the ethnic composition of the student body is gradually changing, with minority groups now accounting for 74.1 percent of an enrollment of 904,000.

title: FLORIDA OFFERING THE ELDERLY ALTERNATIVES TO NURSING HOMES
description: Florence Schlinz was playing bingo in a nursing home when two state workers arrived. It was a lucky day for the 75-year-old widow.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
FAIR WEATHER
description: Ready or not, the fall fair season is upon us, and today fairlovers have two to choose from: the Brookhaven Town Country Fair in Ridge and the Country Fair that the Environmental Centers of Setauket-Smithtown are staging in Smithtown. In addition to the usual features - exhibitions and demonstrations of traditional crafts; displays of farm and zoo animals; hayrides; Colonial games; horseplowing, and a militia encampment -the Brookhaven event, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Longwood Estate on Longwood Road, will go contemporary with a 10,000-meter road race. Registration ($5) is at 8:30 A.M. with entrants vying in seven categories. Except for what you buy to nosh, everything is free.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE BUILDUP OF LAWN THATCH
description: THERE seems to be some misunderstanding as to the meaning of the term thatch as applied to a lawn. It has been determined through research that thatch is not the product of uncollected lawn clippings; rather it has been found to be the accumulation of the bases of the stems of old grass.

title: P.G. Canby Weds Anne E. Putnam
description: Anne Eliot Putnam, daughter of Mrs. Rodman King Tilt of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Sumner Putnam, was married yesterday to Peter Green Canby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Courtlandt Canby of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: NASSAU IN KEY ROLE IN G.O.P. PRIMARY
description: NASSAU COUNTY, which in the 1980 Republican primary produced more votes than all of New York City and provided Alfonse M. D'Amato with his victory margin, will again be a critical battleground in the Sept. 23 Republican gubernatorial and senatorial primaries.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE BUILDUP OF LAWN THATCH
description: THERE seems to be some misunderstanding as to the meaning of the term thatch as applied to a lawn. It has been determined through research that thatch is not the product of uncollected lawn clippings; rather it has been found to be the accumulation of the bases of the stems of old grass.

title: Coetzee Knocks Out Ward in Second Round
description: Gerry Coetzee of South Africa pummeled Stan Ward on the ropes and stopped him at 2:10 of the second round in their scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout tonight.

title: Donald B. Powers Jr. Weds Ellen Joan Armstrong
description: Ellen Joan Armstrong, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Armstrong, was married yesterday to Donald Bernard Powers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Powers of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. George Eckstein and the Rev. Peter Loughran performed the ceremony at the Long Ridge Congregational Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: LURE OF U.S. INVESTMENTS
description: Foreign investment in United States securities and other financial instruments rose sharply during the first five months of 1982, even though short-and long-term interest rates were generally lower during that period than in the last six months of 1981. The rise is a major reason why the dollar defied expectations of many analysts and stayed at near-record levels.

title:
STAMPS;
WORLDWIDE ISSUES FOR SCOUTING ANNIVERSARIES
description: The biggest omnibus issue of the year is the observance of the 75th anniversary of Scouting and the 125th anniversary of the birth of the founder of the movement, Lord Robert Baden-Powell. It will probably result in the issuing of commemoratives from close to 100 different countries.

title: 'OVERNIGHT'-LOW-KEYED NEWS FOR LATE, LATE VIEWING
description: If you can manage to stay up until, or perhaps to get up at, 1:30 in the morning these weekdays (2 A.M. on Fridays), one of the classier new acts in television news can be found on the NBC network. ''NBC News Overnight'' was launched in early July. Reuven Frank, president of the news division, had explained: ''We believe we can provide late-night television viewers with an important service by reporting the news of the day and looking ahead to the events of the coming morning.'' As it happens, more or less the same idea has occurred to the other two commercial networks.

title: SEMINARS AT SEA, DIVERSIONS ON DECK
description: SARAH FERRELL is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. BY SARAH FERRELL

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IN ISRAEL: THE BATTLE OF ONE'S CONSCIENCE
description: DURING the recent war in Lebanon, the press seemed to focus almost solely on the destruction there and on the casualties among Lebanese civilians. It ignored the humanitarian efforts of the Israelis.

title: A FULL PLATE OF COOKING CLASSES
description: AS inevitable as the last day of summer is the first day of the fall's cooking school classes. In summer, even the best of cooks take a holiday. By now they are ready and eager to face a new season of culinary adventures.

title: PLAYING SAFE WITH FAMILIAR FACES AND PROVEN PRODUCTS
description: Anyone who has been to London lately will recognize some familiar names on Broadway marquees this season: ''Cats.'' ''Good.'' ''Steaming.'' ''84 Charing Cross Road.'' These are current West End productions that will be opening in New York before Christmas. And at least one more show playing in London, ''Song and Dance,'' is likely to open here before the season is over.

title: LOBBYIST FOR CITY'S RENTAL HOUSING
description: MAURICE S. PAPRIN believes the city is sleeping while rental housingi s dying. ''Not only are we asleep at the switch, we are killing the s witch,'' said Mr. Paprin, the president of the Associated Builders a nd Owners of Greater New York. ''We are willing to condemn any d eveloper that comes along.''

title: Brooklyn Youth, 19, Is Slain In a Dispute Over His Radio
description: A 19-year-old youth was fatally shot near his Brooklyn home last night after he refused to hand over his radio to two holdup men, the police said.

title: SUNDAY CAN BE A DAY OF PARADOX
description: SUNDAY can be a terrible day. For many of us it is a day filled with frustration and disappointment. We look forward to Sunday all week long, and when it arrives, we don't know what to do with it.

title: VERY REAL PROGRESS ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget-to-Be At the Center of Primary Battles
description: Some observers say the outcome of New York's gubernatorial primaries may already have been decided by the finances of the candidates, but that didn't stop the candidates last week from arguing about the finances of the state.

title: PROTECTING L.I.'S WATER SUPPLY
description: We are pleased to see coverage of an issue gripping the attention of many Long Islanders - the quality and quantity of our present and future ground-water reserves. As the recent article properly notes, there is a growing recognition of the fact that a broad range of land-use activities contributes to the contamination of Long Island's sole source of water, the aquifer system underlying Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Jobson Captures Lead In Etchells Class Series
description: Gary Jobson, tactician for Defender, the America's Cup 12-Meter yacht, took the lead at the Timberland Hall of Fame Regatta with a low score of 7 3/4 points after finishing 4, 1 and 3 in today's Etchells-22 class races on Narragansett Bay.

title: AN EXPLORER OF EARTH
description: ''We live in a camp,'' Wallace Stevens wrote, and I know what he meant. When as a rookie soldier I lived in an Army camp, a barren and featureless place filled with strangers, it often seemed that the world was too little with me. At such times I would go to my footlocker for the poems of Stevens.

title: COUPLE USING $100 GRANTS TO FOSTER SELF-HELP
description: A check for $100 seems small capital to start a business. But an American couple have used that amount to help poor women on the Caribbean island of Dominica market their home-brewed ginger wine and to help another group in the Solomon Islands sell their pineapple and mango jams, which are delivered to customers by canoe.

title: Yvonne Morton Is Bride
description: The marriage of Yvonne Marie Morton and John Frederick Ottavino, graduates of Franklin and Marshall College, took place at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village yesterday. The Rev. John D. O'Leary performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Sylvia A. Morton of New York and the late Robert Kittredge Morton. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Ottavino of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: THIS WALK-ON WALKS OUT ON BIG-TIME FOOTBALL
description: HOW high does a smallish linebacker from a small high school dare to set his goals for college football? Coach Ron Lombardi had made Horace Mann in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, a school for scholars, a football success. He wasn't just a weight-room ogre but an inspiring teacher and friend.

title: ANTIQUES AND FUN AT A FAIR
description: FARMINGTON WHEN Bernard and Leilah Diekman sat down to dine last weekend, they did so seated on Canadian pine chairs, circa 1840, at an early American pine work-table and before a hand-carved oak mantle flanked with framed prints made of rare bird feathers. That night they slept in early American beds, each of which cost well over $300.

title: Article 144903 -- No Title
description: Transit officials here have asked the District Attorney to find out what happened to $70,000 missing from bus fare boxes. The Orange County Transit District also is changing the method of counting the coins to have it done inhouse, rather than by employees of the Brink's security company.

title: FLORIDA LOSES A SUIT FOR PART OF TREASURE FOUND BY SALVAGERS
description: Salvagers who dredged up gold coins and other booty from the remains of a Spanish galleon off Fort Pierce may keep what they found through July 1981 and may dive for more without state interference, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: ASSESSING THE LOW TURNOUT
description: HARTFORD ''I DON'T think it's something that those advocates of a direct primary can take a great deal of comfort from,'' said James M. Fitzgerald, the Democratic State Chairman, as he assessed the returns from Connecticut's primary elections last Tuesday.

title: THE JOYS OF JOURNEYING IN OCTOBER
description: JOHN RUSSELL is chief art critic for The New York Times. BY JOHN RUSSELL

title: NEW JOBLESS BENEFITS GO INTO EFFECT TODAY
