description: About 2.2 million jobless Americans will receive six to 10 weeks of additional unemployment benefits under a temporary plan that will take effect Sunday.

title: GROOMING FOR HANDS AND FEET
description: By Deborah Blumenthal

title: AS THE SAN FRANCISCO BALLET NEARS 50
description: To see the San Francisco Ballet perform in the huge hangar-like structure that served as Wolf Trap's temporary outdoor theater this summer was to see the company perform under less than optimum conditions. As Michael Smuin, its co-director, said, one expected to see the bombers fly in any minute.

title: COMMUNISTS SEEKING ROLE IN FRENCH MILITARY
description: The French Communist Party has signaled the start of a campaign to bring its sympathizers into the ranks of officers and noncommissioned officers in the armed forces. The goal, it says, is to protect ''the democratic construction of socialism.''

title: A NEW USE FOR THE OLD STERN'S STORE
description: In 1878, when 23d Street was one of the city's major thoroughfares, Henry Fernback designed an imposing French Second Empire building for the Stern Brothers department store. But then the city, and Stern's along with it, pushed northward, leaving behind the elegantly detailed six-story building at 40 West 23d Street.

title: N.F.C. Schedules; EASTERN DIVISION; DALLAS
description: Sept. 13- Pitt.* 19-at St. Louis 26-at Minnesota Oct. 3-Giants 10-Washington 17-at Philadelphia 24-at Cincinnati 31-at Giants Nov. 7-St. Louis 14-at San Fran. 21-Tampa Bay 25-Cleveland+ Dec. 5-at Wash. 13-at Houston* 19-New Orleans 26-Philadelphia GIANTS Sept. 12-Atlanta 20-Green Bay* 26-at Pittsburgh Oct. 3-at Dallas 10-St. Louis 17-Cincinnati 25-at Phila.* 31-Dallas Nov. 7-at Clev. 14-at L.A. Rams 21-Washington 25-at Detroit+ Dec. 5-Houston 11-Philadelphia-19-at Washington 26-at St. Louis

title: From Israel, 'No'; From the Arabs, Who Knows?
description: President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative stiffened backs in Israel and softened rhetoric in Arab capitals last week.

title: ISRAELIS OFFENDED BY GERMAN CRITICS
description: One casualty of the invasion of Lebanon and the siege of Beirut has been the tenor of Israel's ties with West Germany, which have been conditioned by the memory of the horror that Hitler inflicted on European Jews.

title: GLACIER TOUT IN ALASKA
description: HARRIET KING contributes to The Times from Seattle. By HARRIET KING

title: Losing Candidate Is Taken to Task
description: For every loser, there's an excuse. A mllion losses, a million excuses. A loss is almost never the loser's fault. Gertrude W. Dubrovsky, in an extended, impassioned and error-filled plaint (Aug. 29), blamed her losing effort to gain the nomination for Democratic candidate for Mercer County Freeholder on, among other things, the ''closed club'' system, the absence of ''backing'' and a general feeling of the unfairness of it all.

title: FIGHTING INFLATION IS UPHILL ALL THE WAY
description: Embarrassed by ballooning budget deficits and record postwar unemployment, the Administration has one solid economic achievement - successfully squeezing inflation - and no doubt will make the most of it on behalf of Republican candidates this fall.

title: ON THE LOOKOUT
description: CITIZENS' groups currently involved in crime detection on Long Island include the following: Neighborhood Watch - Commonly referred to as ''the eyes and ears of the police,'' these programs are endorsed by all police departments. They consist of groups organized by blocks or neighborhoods whose members - while remaining either inside their homes or outside on their own property - are committed to observe carefully and to notify the police of any suspicious circumstances. Most have received instructions on the kind of information they should report, such as identifying characteristics of people or vehicles.

title: Masters Remembered
description: EDGAR LEE MASTERS will be forever identified with ''Spoon River Anthology,'' his 1915 collection of more than 200 poetic epitaphs of imaginary small-town Americans. ''But he published 52 books in all, poetry, drama, novels and a wonderful biography of Vachel Lindsay,'' Hilary Masters, the poet's son and himself the author of three novels, said recently. His newest book, ''Last Stands,'' which David R. Godine has scheduled for publication in November, contains the first intimate biographical statement about his famous father, whose widow has consistently refused to allow an authorized biography.

title: BEEHIVE COKE OVEN TO FIRE UP ONE LAST TIME
description: Once there were so many beehive coke ovens that old-timers here say they could read a newspaper at night from the orange glow of the ovens.

title: Jennifer Jacobs Is Bride
description: Jennifer Rose Jacobs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Jacobs of Durban, South Africa, and David Allen Kelso, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Kelso of Syracuse, were married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York by the Rev. Charles Henderson. The bride is a designer and instructor with Erica Wilson, Needle Works, a studio and retail shop, in New York. Her husband is a vice president in the securities sales department of Goldman Sachs & Company.

title: Leslie Harlow Is Married
description: Leslie Harlow and John Wilcox were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard L. Rush in the First Church Congregational in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Youth Killed and a 2d Injured As Gun Goes Off in Brooklyn
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was killed and another was injured yesterday when a gun that they were handling went off, the police said.

title: THE SHORT, HAPPY BEGINNINGS OF SCHOOL
description: SUMMER draws to a close and once again the long yellow dragon, the suburban high school bus, is seen on the roads and highways of the country. Teachers have met a day or two before the students arrive, to ready classrooms, plan lessons, review texts and materials and resolve firmly that this school year they will give more of themselves, make each lesson interesting, exciting, an inspiration that will make learning a joy, a triumph of cool beautiful reason.

title: HERE'S HOW TO REPAIR ROOF GUTTERS
description: ROOF gutters are supposed to carry water safely away as it flows off the roof so that it will not pour down the house walls and cause flooding of the basement, washing out of grass and foundation plantings, and unsightly streaks and stains on the house walls.

title: Cemetery for Sale
description: In June, New York City announced that it was putting Canarsie Cemetery in Brooklyn up for sale. The city had owned the 13-acre cemetery since World War II and had decided, in the words of Stuart Fischer, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, that ''the city should not be in the business of running a cemetery.''

title: Miss Johnson Takes 3-Stroke Lead in Golf
description: Chris Johnson, seeking her first victory on the tour, shot a three-under-par 69 today and took a three-stroke lead into the final round of the $155,000 Mary Kay Classic golf tournament.

title: HARDWARE SALES ARE BRISK, SERVICES SOFT
description: When Chemical Bank announced last week that it is offering New Yorkers the opportunity to bank at home using personal computers, it ventured into a potentially lucrative but unquestionably risky market.

title: THE HISTORIC BRONX
description: For years, pictures of seemingly endless rows of abandoned buildings gave many the impression that most of the Bronx was a bombed-out borough beyond redemption. Defenders say that the impression is false and that, indeed, there is much to preserve.

title: AMONG THE ROLES LEGISLATORS PLAY
description: THE New Jersey Legislature is a part-time body. It meets twice a week (some weeks). And so what do we do with the rest of our time? We devote part of it to our regular occupations: Running our businesses, taking care of our law practices, teaching, farming - whatever. (Just as an Assemblyman's job is part-time, so, too, is his pay).

title: THE SEASON OF SELF-PROMOTION
description: Fall may be the end of the seasonal cycle, but for the country's leading fashion retailers it is really just the beginning. As the most crucial selling season, it represents more fully than any other the crystallization of the retailers' skills. It is the culmination of their buying trips to Europe's ready-to-wear shows, their viewing of the American shows and the countless hours they have spent in store planning sessions deciding what they think their customers want. For America's and Europe's designers, it is the season to which they devote their greatest energy.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE BOOK OF CONCORD Thoreau's Life as a Writer. By William Howarth. Illustrated. 260 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $18.95.

title: Jane E. Auerbach Becomes The Bride of Neal Gelfand
description: Jane Ellen Auerbach and Neal Gelfand were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Auerbach in Rye, N.Y. Mr. Gelfand is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gelfand of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman peformed the ceremony.

title: Sports of the Times; Laborious Encore for Giants and Jets
description: In the return of the Giants and the Jets to respectability, the encore will be more laborious than the onset. As the two New York teams await their National Football League season openers today, they are seriously considered by some observers as Super Bowl XVII contenders. In one man's opinion, such exalted status is premature. Next season would be more realistic. But the mere connection of the two New York teams with the Super Bowl represents the primary burden that now confronts them - the great expectations by their Giants Stadium and Shea Stadium loyalists of a playoff team.

title: THe Fourth 'R' Is for Restraint
description: With enrollments dwindling and government aid harder to come by, school systems everywhere are financially strapped. Consequently, union officials say, teachers aren't pressing as hard for substantial wage increases this year and won't be as quick to hit the bricks.

title: THREE SISTERS
description: SASSAFRASS, CYPRESS & INDIGO By Ntozake Shange. 225 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $10.95.

title: No Headline
description: Temple Stuns Syracuse, 23-18

title: Betsy Ballenger Bride of K.Q. La Fond
description: Marie Elizabeth Ballenger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Ballenger Jr. of Flint, Mich., and Southold, L.I., was married yesterday to Kevin Quinn La Fond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. La Fond of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Alexander Sime performed the ceremony at the First Prebyterian Church in Southold, L.I.

title: OUTSTANDING IS WORD FOR BREWERS' YOUNT
description: When he was a teen-ager in California, Robin Yount raced motorcycles. Now, Yount said, ''I just play on them. I'm not competitive.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: PELHAM PARKWAY
description: ON Lydig Avenue in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx, huge t rucks still deliver rattling cargoes of seltzer bottles to dairy r estaurants and kosher delicatessens. On quiet afternoons, the gossipo f the neighborhood can still be heard in Yiddish and Russian as the a rea's older residents sit on wooden crates at street corners to talka nd pass a pleasant hour or two.

title: Joanne Hodges Becomes Bride of William Conrad
description: The marriage of Joanne Sharpe Hodges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Fox Hodges of Rosemont, Pa., to William Lacy Conrad took place yesterday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The bridegroom is the son of Anthony L. Conrad of Gibson Island, Md., formerly of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Katherine Wolfe Conrad.

title: THE SCANDINAVIAN CENTURY
description: To appreciate the triumph of Scandinavian design during the past century, one must consider the position the Norse countries held in the sophisticate's consciousness a hundred years ago. To the discerning Parisian, Berliner, New Yorker or Londoner of the 1880's, Scandinavia was a poor and remote outpost teetering on the uppermost edge of Europe - an unlikely source of influential new design.

title: Miss Clark Wed To Eric Nietsch
description: Patricia Melanie Clark, daughter of Comdr. Gordon E. Clark, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Clark, of New York and Sachem's Head, Guilford, Conn., and Eric Hollerith Nietsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Erich Nietsch of Upper Montclair, N.J., were married yesterday.

title: Mary Martin Is Grateful For Support After Wreck
description: Mary Martin, able to sit in a chair for the first time since a traffic accident seriously injured her and Janet Gaynor on Sept. 5, expressed gratitude to God, the hospital staff and her fans for helping her to survive.

title: Nixon Supports Limits On Taiwan Arms Sales
description: Declaring that the United States must ''deal with the world as it is,'' former President Richard M. Nixon said he welcomed China's efforts to improve ties with the Soviet Union and supported limiting American arms sales to Taiwan.

title: REAGAN IS REBUKED BY 33 STATE HEADS OF RIGHTS PANELS
description: The chairmen of 33 state agencies affiliated with the United States Commission on Civil Rights have signed a letter to President Reagan asserting that he is responsible for a ''dangerous deterioration in the Federal enforcement of civil rights.''

title: PAST IS PRESENT IN ODESSA
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By FRANCIS X.CLINES

title: NEW LOOD IS A PLEASANT CHANGE
description: STAMFORD IF you liked the old Ettorucci's, you'll be delighted with the restaurant in its new location, decor and general new look. The spaciousness - with tables and booths well separated from one another - may have an effect on the serving, for the staff seems less harassed, more accommodating than formerly. Perhaps there's a new staff as well. Certainly our waiter was better trained and more knowledgeable than on an occasion at the old establishment when a waitress poured red wine into the used white-wine glasses and couldn't understand why we objected.

title: M. H. Quintana Weds Martha Andrew
description: The marriage of Martha Andrew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Andrew of Madison, Wis., to Manuel Hilarion Quintana of New York took place yesterday at the Wesley United Methodist Church in East Norwich, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Manuel I. Quintana of Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic, and Edith Seyburn Quintana of East Norwich and West Rupert, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Patricia Townsend, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Murphy of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: FORMAL CLASSICS
description: By Ralph DiGennaro

title: Concern Re-emphasized On Foster Care
description: As someone who is actively involved in training foster-care workers throughout New York State in the mandates of the Child Welfare Reform Act, I want to re-emphasize the concerns raised by Nan Dale, executive director of Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, regarding the implementation of the act (''Children's Village Head Sees Foster-Care Needs Changing,'' Aug. 22).

title: A Broader View Of Community Murals
description: The comprehensive article on graffiti (Aug. 29) gave a good-enough picture of the defacement problem in Passaic and Morris Counties, but left the unfortunate impression that community murals are just another antivandalism device. This viewpoint is narrow.

title: U.S. AWARDS $509,000 FOR BRINK'S TRIAL COSTS
description: Rockland County authorities have announced that the county has been awarded a $509,000 Federal grant to help defray prosecution expenses in the Brink's robbery trial.

title: A Call for Help For the Bluebird
description: Among many noteworthy aspects of the Long Island Weekly section is its ''Nature Watch'' feature. Within the brief space allotted to it, much can be learned about various feathered and furred local inhabitants.

title: A COMMUNITY ENDS ITS ISOLATION
description: RINGWOOD TUCKED away just beyond Hope Mountain in this once-affluent summer resort is a pocket of poverty whose residents have long guarded their privacy and gone their own way.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: AGE HAS ITS PRIVILEGES
description: W hile visiting a museum in New York State recently, a photographer with prematurely white hair was surprised that an attendant handed back one of the two dollars she proffered for the entry fee. ''Senior citizens are only a dollar,'' the attendant said. The woman took back the extra dollar without protest - even though she was only in her 40's.

title: ITALIAN PLUM SEASON ENDS
description: THE first plums of the season appear in June, heralding a succession of varieties that continue to tempt shoppers throughout the summer. But when the tiny oval dark-blue Freestone plums, often called Italian plums or Italian prunes, become available, it is a signal that the season for plums is coming to a close.

title: 'L'ADOLESCENTE' FROM JEANNE MOREAU
description: If one did not know that ''L'Adolescente'' were the work of Jeanne Moreau, who has directed a second feature as substantial and charming as her first (''Lumiere''), it would still be clear that this is the work of a female director. The story centers on a teen-age French girl, Marie (Laetitia Chaveau), who is presented with none of the dewy lasciviousness to which so many male directors are prone. Though Miss Moreau presents the romantic awakening of a pretty, nubile youngster, she does it with delightful straightforwardness and ease.

title: ERROR BY CREW BLAMED IN FATAL SHIP ACCIDENT
description: ''Personnel error'' caused the grounding of the cruise ship Majestic Explorer on Friday, a Coast Guard spokesman said today. A woman was killed and two men were injured in the evacuation of the vessel.

title: Laurel Gropper Is Wed
description: Laurel B. Gropper, daughter of Mrs. Esther C. Gropper-Feldman of Hewlett, L.I., and the late Herbert Gropper, was married yesterday to Robert M. Haas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haas of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the gardens of the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I., by Cantor David Benedict. The bride is an optometrist and her husband is an associate with the Stamford, Conn., law firm of Cummings & Lockwood.

title: Margaret Moffitt Becomes Fiancee Of R. W. Rahe Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Moffitt of Fairfield, Conn., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Elizabeth Moffitt, to Roderic W. Rahe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rahe of Darien, Conn., and Rockport, Ontario.

title: Russell Lewis Marries Jane Hylas in Philadelphia
description: Jane Anne Hylas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Edwin Hylas of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Russell Shepherd Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew L. Lewis Jr., of Washington and Schwenksville, Pa. The Rev. Bernard A. Suppe performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Miss Shively Is the Bride Of Jacob May
description: Cynthia Gilmer Shively, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Cleveland Shively of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Jacob May, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon May of Nashville. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber of Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: STEAMBOAT NOSTALGIA, ON ICE, ON STAGE; A River Trip In Honor Of Fulton
description: As every schoolchild knows, the age of the steamboat was ushered in by Robert Fulton's vessel Clermont. Right? Wrong! According to the New England Steamship Company, the vessel that steamed out of a pier on the North River in Lower Manhattan at 1 P.M. on Monday, Aug. 17, 1807, was actually registered as North River Steam Boat, later with a hailing port of Clermont, N.Y. - the destination she reached after proceeding upriver for 24 hours en route to Albany.

title: Phone Trouble, Soviet Style
description: Almost all telephone links between the Soviet Union and the rest of the world were cut last week and Moscow officials blamed an equipment failure.

title: THE UPHEAVAL IN PENSION FUND PLANNING
description: THE Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 has all but w ritten the obituary of the ''professional corporation,'' the b usiness entity used by doctors, lawyers and entertainers in order t o stash away large amounts of money for retirement. The new law r educes the amount of tax-deductible money that professionals can c ontribute to their corporate pension plans and thus eliminates the m ajor tax advantage of incorporating. At the same time, it has i ncreased the amount of money that self-employed persons can c ontribute to their Keogh retirement plans, making sole p roprietorships and partnerships more attractive.

title: PIOUS DECEPTIONS; White Heat
description: In a little Georgia town not long ago, a bride in white strode blissfully down the aisle toward a makeshift altar before a cross.

title: U.S. TRAFFIC DEATHS DROP 4%;STIFFER DRIVING LAWS CREDITED
description: Traffic fatalities decreased 4 percent nationwide last year, reversing a five-year upward trend. This result, according to Federal officials, can be attributed to tougher laws on drunken driving and requirements for safety restraints.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE SECOND STAGE. By Betty Friedan. (Summit Books, $5.95.) An ''uneasy sense'' that something had gone wrong with the women's movement led the author of ''The Feminine Mystique'' to re-examine it, and she discovered that it has entered its second stage. Her prescription here calls for ''a joint effort by men and women to redefine what is meant by success at home and on the job so that the needs of both sexes for achievement, intimacy and nurturance can find adequate expression.'' Our reviewer, Hilda Kay observed that ''it is possible to applaud this strategy without embracing the reasoning that produced it.''

title: THEY SING FOR THEIR SUPPER
description: EAST RUTHERFORD IN THE maddening hours before, during and after a rock concert, there are always more than a few people looking for some nourishment. And in any shows involving the producer-promoter John Scher, the person to see for food and grog is Philip Giuliano, who holds the title of Hospitality Director.

title: INTEREST CHARGE IS PROPOSED
description: CUSTOMERS of Northeast Utilities who don't pay their electric and gas bills on time may soon have to pay interest charges of 1.5 percent a month.

title: THE BOOM IN MUNICIPAL BONDS
description: THE stock market's sizzling recovery in the last few weeks caught t he headlines, but municipal bonds have been enjoying a sustained b oom amid little fanfare. ''You've got to call it the best-ever rallyf or tax-exempts,'' enthuses George D. Friedlander of Smith Barney, H arris Upham & Company.

title: Peripatetic Promoter
description: While Don King was announcing one match and the site for another, the promoter was busy working on the sale of the World Boxing Association heavyweight title match between Mike Weaver, the champion, and Michael Dokes, the No.1 contender. According to television industry sources, Home Box Office, the subscription television company, will wind up with the fight, which would take place either in November or January - about the same time King will promote Larry Holmes's next defense of the World Boxing Council heavyweight title against Randall (Tex) Cobb.

title: GREENBURGH PONDERS ITS EMPTY SCHOOLS
description: THE reeds, weeds and other greenery that surround the Washington Avenue School in Hartsdale have grown tall now. The second-floor windows have been smashed by vandals' rocks; those on the first floor have long been boarded up. Ferns obscure the stone that reveals the date the school was built: A.D. 1919.

title: DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY CAMPAIGN FOR MANHATTAN SURROGATE INTENSIFIES
description: Distributing leaflets and shaking hands at subway stops, the three candidates in the Democratic primary race for Manhattan surrogate are stepping up their campaigns for an office that is a virtual certainty for the primary winner.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bergenfield $88,000 41 Sunset Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; recreation *2*room in basement, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $1,728. Hackensack $139,900 308 Ross Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; *2*pool and patio, full basement; taxes $2,788. Harrington Park $147,000 26 Spring Street *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace in family *2*room, new roof, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,817. New Milford $112,000 410 Martin Place *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old split level; *2*new roof, pool, deck; taxes $2,330. Paramus $82,000 174 Arundel Road *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old ranch; *2*covered patio; taxes $1,192. Tenafly $355,000 145 Serpentine Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1 1/2-year-old contemporary; fireplace in *2*family room, deck, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $5,686. OTHER AREAS Chappaqua, N.Y. $390,000 87 Valley Lane *2*5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 11-year-old stucco colonial; *2*family room, studio, wine cellar, *2*flagstone terrace, 3.4 acres, taxes $10,401. New Canaan, Conn. $450,000 Wahackme Lane *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 10-year-old French Normandy; circular *2*staircase, pond on property, two acres; taxes $4,816. Middle Island, L.I. $40,000 247 Juniper Court *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old condominium town house, *2* $65 monthly common charges; taxes $1,500.

title: School-Funding Protest Brewing
description: In an effort to help some New Jersey school districts avoid closing early in the spring for lack of funds, an education group said last week it was considering closing all schools in the state for a day in protest.

title: Jeffrey Perlstein Marries Janet E. Bashian in Jersey
description: Janet Elyse Bashian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Bashian of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Jeffrey Bruce Perlstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Perlstein of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: PASSPORT CRUNCH
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Bishop Warns Of 'Armageddon' for Blacks
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa said today that the plight of blacks in his country had worsened since the death of a jailed black activist five years ago.

title: WINE
description: JUST HUMMING ALONG High on a hill above the Napa Valley lives Eleanor McCrea, the doyenne of California wine producers, proprietor of Stony Hill Vineyard, a woman in her 70's who presides over one of the most extraordinary wine ventures in the nation.

title: A PLEA FOR... I CAN'T HEAR YOUuuuuu
description: LET'S have a moratorium on noise in the suburbs on at least one day a week. It would unjangle our nerves to be without the shriek of power lawn mowers, the putt-putt of mopeds from the street or the high whine of chain saws cutting wood next door.

title: KATHARINE MARTIN PLANS TO BE WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Read Martin Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Burke Martin, to Eric Lewis Stone, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard David Stone of Sarasota, Fla., formerly of Weston, Conn.

title: GEorge Wallace Leads the Pack In Alabama Vote
description: George C. Wallace, perhaps the nation's premier segregationist not too many years ago, understands as well as anybody what it takes to win in the New South. Ever since declaring that the political sidelines weren't for him, he has been out courting Alabama blacks, apologizing for his past race-baiting ways.

title: WANTED: 300 RECIPES
description: WHEN Alice O'Rourke accompanied her husband, Andrew, chairman of the county's Board of Legislators, to the National Association of Counties convention in Baltimore last July, it gave her food for thought. In fact, it gave her a whole cookbook.

title: McCullough Gains Lead By a Stroke on 66-202
description: Mike McCullough, a former Ohio amateur champion and a survivor in 10 years on the PGA golf tour, shot a 5-under-par 66 for a one-stroke lead today after 54 holes in the $300,000 Bank of Boston Classic.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARCHES ON
description: It's quite safe to make long-range forecasts. By the time reality catches up with you, everyone has forgotten what you said. It's short-term predictions that usually leave you with egg on your face. Which is why, in the following prophecies of things to come, I shall curb the urge to speculate and stick with low-risk pronouncements. The course of events is rarely affected by bold extrapolation.

title: Bullet Curb in California
description: Gov. Edmund Brown Jr., expressing shock at the sale of bullets that can pierce police officers' bulletproof vests, signed two bills Friday outlawing the sale, use or possession of such armor-piercing ammunition in California.

title: A DIRECTORY OF COOKING SCHOOLS IN NEW JERSEY
description: THE time when a quiche or coq au vin was unusual has long since passed. Now, food processors and pasta machines fight for counter space with blenders and mixers, and goat cheese tarts and fish tartare are the names dropped at cooking schools and cocktail parties.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE BUILDUP OF LAWN THATCH
description: THERE seems to be some misunderstanding as to the meaning of the term thatch as applied to a lawn. It has been determined through research that thatch is not the product of uncollected lawn clippings; rather it has been found to be the accumulation of the bases of the stems of old grass.

title: GAME FISH SURVEY SURPRISES SURVEYORS
description: BELMAR FAR from shore, beyond where sunbathers see the ocean meet the sky, New Jersey sports fishermen are landing 500-pound marlins and tunas with increasing regularity.

title: COAST POLICE USE ULTRA-LIGHTS FOR AIR PATROLS
description: When Lieut. Joe Santoro first proposed using a motorized hang-glider for aerial police patrols, his wife told him he was crazy. Police Chief Jon Elder said, ''I told him he was nuts and threw him out of the office.''

title: Engine Failure Blamed In Ariane Rocket Crash
description: The European rocket Ariane and two satellites it was to have put into orbit on its first commercial mission Friday probably crashed back to earth because of a simple engine failure, the European Space Agency said today.

title: REVISED COST OF MILLSTONE 3 PUT AT $3.5 BILLION
description: Northeast Utilities in Connecticut has raised by nearly a billion dollars its 1980 estimate for the cost of finishing the Millstone 3 nuclear-generating plant in Waterford. The utility now expects the plant to cost $3.54 billion.

title: No Headline
description: Phils Lose to Pirates, Get Indians' Denny

title: CONSERVATION CORPS IS FORMED
description: WITH the elimination by Congress of financing for two national youth conservation groups this year, many states, including Connecticut, have been forced to institute their own versions of the programs to meet the increasing demands for conservation work and improvements at state parks.

title: 19TH CENTURY BATTLES THE 20TH OVER WASHINGTON SQUARE PARK
description: The Parks Department has a vision of a quieter, grassier Washington Square Park - a park restored to the bucolic state of a century ago, when Henry James wrote that it possessed ''a kind of established repose which is not of frequent occurrence in other quarters of the long, shrill city.''

title: Hang on to Westway
description: The Westway controversy has dragged on for so long there must be half a generation of New Yorkers that knows little about the exciting original plan, save that ''progressive'' people are against it: Westway is a $2 billion boondoggle cooked up by the highway lobby that threatens the quality of life in New York. Why build this grotesquely expensive ribbon of concrete when the money could be salvaged for badly needed improvements in subways and other mass transit?

title: ISRAEL CHANGING FACE OF WEST BANK
description: Occupied West Bank - The boundary separating Israel proper from the occupied West Bank has become invisible. It has vanished from Israeli maps. It has dissolved into the stonestrewn hills that rise gracefully from the outskirts of Tel Aviv. It has left no reminder of the tense frontier between Jordan and Israel that it once was - no scrap of fence, no army checkpoint, no clue to the traveler that he is passing from one world into another.

title: Technology Enables Life-Saving Care
description: One could not, and would not, attempt to dispute the point Dr. Manlapaz makes in his article (''Technology Can Breed Neglect,'' Aug. 22).

title: RESEARCH THROUGH DECEPTION
description: Morton Hunt is a freelance writer with a special interest in the behavioral sciences. His most recent book, ''The Universe Within, A New Science Explores the Human Mind," was published by Simon & Schuster

title: Iraq Reports Sinking Ship in Persian Gulf
description: Iraqi warplanes sank an unidentified vessel in the Persian Gulf today in their third attack on shipping there in four days, an Iraqi military spoeksman said.

title: J.W. Leach Marries Catherine F. Morris
description: Catherine Frances Morris and J. William Leach were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin. The bride is a daughter of Lieut. Col. James D.M. Morris, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Robert E. Dawson of Tacoma, Wash.

title: CRAFTS
description: TODAY, with so much attention focused on ceramics as one-of-a-kind collectibles, one might ask how a production potter fares. Byron Temple of Lambertville is among those potters who have made and maintained their reputations through goods produced in multiples to be ordered and reordered in quantity. As he put it:

title: Miss Gullans Is Married
description: Louise Ann Gullans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Gullans of Wilton, Conn., was married in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday to Edwin Hinchman Brooks 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Bickford Brooks of Edgartown, Mass. Msgr. Francis McGuire performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: CRIME
description: Claire McCormick, described in her author's bio as a part-time faculty member at Arizona State University, has written her first mystery novel - RESUME FOR MURDER (Walker, $11.95). It does not involve a college teacher. Instead the hero recruits college seniors for business. He is named John Waltz, which is a fairly unconventional name, though the current Manhattan phone book lists three Waltzes. Come to think of it, back in the early 1700's Handel's cook and general factotum was a man named Waltz.

title: Data Update
description: Correction: The mortgage interest rate figures that appeared in last Sunday's Real Estate section for the week of Aug. 30 were incorrect. The correct figures for that week can be found in the middle column in the chart above.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY BERG THORNE AND ROSENMAN
description: Berg's Chamber Concerto dominated the concert of ''Music Today'' conducted by Gerard Schwarz in the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. This was not just because the concerto's taut structure manages to harness haunting sensations of melancholia and nostalgia. It was also because the gestures that Berg explored in the early 1920's were similar to those that Nicholas C.K. Thorne and Leonard Rosenman emulated in the 1979 works, also heard on the program.

title: SCHOOLS STRUGGLING TO FIND MATH AND SCIENCE TEACHERS
description: BACK about a decade ago, when E. Paul Hazel first became director of personnel for the Ridgefield School District, his mailbag would regularly bulge with as many as 6,000 unsolicited applications a year for teaching posts in that bucolic town.

title: Montclair Ties Wagner on a Late Kick
description: The Wagner-Montclair State rivalry, already one of the best in college football's Division III, was keener than ever yesterday as the two played to a 40-40 tie before 4,320 at Fischer Field on Staten Island.

title: Honduras Perspective
description: Robert E. White's article ''Central America: The Problem That Won't Go Away'' (July 18) distorts beyond recognition the image of democratic Honduras and our policies here. His article suggests that Honduras has an unjust political system backed with our blessing by a repressive military establishment. He also implies that human rights and press freedoms are better observed in neighboring Nicaragua. The facts are that Honduras has a freely elected civilian government and liberal democratic institutions, including a free and privately owned radio, press and television. Honduras can also be proud of its vigorous labor movement, considered a model in the region, and of its land-reform program, whose origins date back more than 20 years. The United States, continuing a policy established by the previous Administration, fully supports Honduras's commitment to this democratic and pluralistic process.

title: East German Women Set 1,600-Meter Mark
description: Marita Koch anchored East Germany to a world record in the women's 1,600-meter relay, and Steve Cram of Britain won the 1,500-meter run as the European Track and Field championships concluded a six-day run tonight before another sellout crowd of 80,000 in the new Olympic Stadium.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Traffic Ticket Called a 'Cheap Joke'
description: Police Chief Joe Ritchie says he will dismiss whoever issued a parking ticket to President Reagan, whose limousine was parked overnight outside a city hotel on his two-day Western tour.

title: TWO ANNIVERSARIES AT AXE CASTLE
description: NESTLED on a hilltop in Tarrytown overlooking the Hudson River from the highest point in the county, Axe Castle and its occupant, E. W. Axe & Company, has quietly surveyed the economic climate of the country for 50 years, surviving recurrent tides of expansion, recession, inflation and wars, amid social and political changes.

title: TRYING HARDER TO BLOCK THE BOMB
description: Judith Miller is a member of The New York Times's Washington bureau.

title: R.F. Blue Jr. Weds Elizabeth Bennett
description: Elizabeth Gant Bennett, daughter of Mrs. Clifton Clement Bennett Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Bennett, was married yesterday to Richard Fownes Blue Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blue of Garrison, Md. The Rev. James R. Whittemore performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: TAMING MEXICO'S PASSION FOR MORE
description: MEXICO CITY I T was barely five years ago that oil arrived like a beautiful dark temptress to lead Mexico out of an economic slump and along the path of rapid growth. But betrayal lay ahead. And when oil prices fell last year, Mexico stumbled headlong into its worst financial crisis in memory.

title: A MAN WHO HELPS PUT COMPANIES BACK ON THEIR FEET
description: DAVID P. MICHAELS knows the highways of New Jersey like the inside o f his BMW engine. The former race car driver works a territory that t akes in Marin Motor Oil Inc. in Trenton, the Quality Egg Products C ompany in Dayton, Ortex Industries, a small Christmas novelty c ompany in Elmwood Park, and Chapter 11, a recently renamed d iscotheque in Whippany.

title: WHO DID IT? MICHAEL GILBERT AND P. D. JAMES
description: END-GAME By Michael Gilbert. 247 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50. MR.CALDER & MR.BEHRENS By Michael Gilbert. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: ISRAEL-EGYPT LINKS HURT BY INVASION
description: Israel's invasion of Lebanon has curtailed the development of tourist, trade and communications links between Israel and Egypt, according to officials here.

title: Lisa H.
description: Lisa H., a 21-year-old college student in Philadelphia, underwent radical surgery last Dec. 9 to rid herself of disfiguring facial tumors caused by a rare genetic disease.

title: HOLLYWOOD HAS SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: After a summer spent watching the adventures of a boy and his extraterrestrial, romance at a military base and horror in 3-D, audiences will see movies take some new twists this fall.

title: GEORGIA WINS BY 17-14
description: A 1-yard touchdown run by Herschel Walker and a 44-yard field goal by Kevin Butler rallied Georgia to a 17-14 victory over Brigham Young today, marking the second time within a week that the Bulldogs beat the team with the longest major-college winning streak.

title: THE MAN WHO HAD THE DREAM
description: LET THE TRUMPET SOUND The Life of Martin Luther King, Jr. By Stephen B. Oates. Illustrated. 560 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: THE NEW APPEAL OF DESIGNER UNDERWEAR
description: Is the world ready for men's designer underwear? If the initial test-market results of the Calvin Klein line that went on sale at Bloomingdale's last month are any indication, apparently it is.

title: SCULPTURE TAKES ON A FRESH PROMINENCE
description: The 1982-83 exhibition season is, in a word, loaded. If, after recent polemical wars, there do not seem to be any predominant trends - either artistic or theoretical - in the presentation of the shows, that increased openness is in itself a change, reflecting either an unsettled or a less constrained state of the art world. There are shows on individual artists, ranging from the French iconoclast Yves Klein to the English painter John Constable, who saw his native countryside with a reverence and finality that rivals the way the English Romantic poets captured that landscape with words. There is the intriguing theme show, such as ''Jews in the Age of Rembrandt,'' and there is the rarest kind of supershow - of never-before released works from the Vatican Collections - which is likely to be the centerpiece of the season.

title: STORM IN LOUISIANA KEEPS TURNOUT LOW FOR PRIMARY VOTING
description: By The Associated Press

title: Miss Korry Wed To Y.W. Gutow
description: Deborah F. Korry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Korry of Stonington, Conn., and Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Yiannis W. Gutow, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gutow of Syracuse. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: DR. DONALD PACE
description: Dr. Donald Pace, known for research into the links between cigarette smoking and cancer, died Thursday of cancer.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. All fans will receive Yankee caps as the current home stand comes to an end. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 2 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Atlanta Falcons, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 1 P.M. Scott Brunner tries to get the Giants off winning despite the absence of Rob Carpenter, the holdout fullback. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130, 1 P.M.) Jets vs. Miami Dolphins, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 4 P.M. Late changes in the offensive line may give Richard Todd, the Jets' quarterback, the pass protection he lacked during the exhibition season. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880, 4 P.M.) Norwalk Chiefs vs. New Jersey Oaks, at Bassalone Field, Bridgewater, N.J., 1:30 P.M., and New Jersey Rams vs. Bronx Crusaders, at John F. Kennedy High School field, West 230th Street and Terrace View Avenue, the Bronx, 1:30 P.M., two Mid-East Conference semipro games.

title: U.S. SPENDING BILL HELPS NEW YORK EDUCATION
description: The supplemental spending bill that Congress sustained this week over President Reagan's veto contains $31 million in remedial-education funds for children in New York State, increases the amounts of individual Pell educational grants and provides money for 4,000 community service jobs for the elderly in the state.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN a Queens company proposed building an alternative energy farm with 40 windmills - or wind towers -110 feet high in Southold earlier this year, it ran into trouble. Residents of the North Fork town put pressure on officials to dismiss the project as too large and too problematic.

title: Dr. Kathryn Crowley Wed To James Henry McMullen
description: Dr. Kathryn Ann Crowley, daughter of the late Lieut. Col. Leo V. Crowley, U.S.A. retired, and the late Mrs. Crowley of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Henry McMullen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. McMullen of Bricktown, N.J. Msgr. John Nolan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: CHINA DISCARDS MAOIST VISION AND PUSHES PRAGMATIC PATH
description: China's first party congress in five years ended today after a week and a half of activity that discarded the fanaticism of Mao Zedong and ushered in a new era of ideological pragmatism.

title: SLIGHTED CIVIL WAR HERO IS HONORED BY TOWN
description: North met South again today in this tiny New England town to honor a Civil War hero who was mailed the nation's highest military honor in a brown paper bag.

title: A MELTING POT TAKING SHAPE IN NICARAGUA
description: So many Americans and Western Europeans have descended on Nicaragua to study and work with the Sandinist Government that a word, ''internacionalistas,'' has been coined to refer to them.

title: CITY SAYS NEW SANITATION TRUCKS PROVE WORTH
description: Six days a week, just after 6 A.M., the steel doors of the Sanitation Department's Brooklyn-South equipment garage, on an industrial stretch of Georgia Avenue, slide open for a fleet of 47 garbage collection trucks departing for the streets of the southeastern corner of the borough.

title: FROM ALBERT CAMUS TO ROLAND BARTHES
description: CAMUS By Patrick McCarthy. 359 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 CHANCES, by Jackie Collins. (Warner, $3.95.) The daughter of a Mafia leader finds herself in charge of the business: fiction. 2

title: POP MUSIC'S ESTABLISHMENT IS RIPE FOR CHANGE
description: The big business of popular music is becalmed, adrift in the doldrums. The record industry is anticipating the fall season in pop music with an attitude reminiscent of Kierkegaard's ''Fear and Trembling.'' But at the local, grassroots level, young rock and funk performers are creating excitement with vital and in some cases innovative new music. Some of this music, some of its young performers, could be the Next Big Thing. But what exactly? Who? Where? And just as importantly, when?

title: Mailbox; Tragedy Lends Its Perspective
description: To the Sports Editor: In many respects, professional sports can be seen as a microcosm of daily life. Recent events involving players on the Giants have certainly given us all reason to pause and consider things like our own very tenuous mortality.

title: Rates Mark Time
description: Compared with the feverish activity of the past few months, when key interest rates seemed to plunge almost daily, these are quiet days in the credit markets. After falling 3 percentage points in less than two months, the prime rate has stayed at 13.5 percent for the past three weeks. Analysts do not expect much change until late in the fourth quarter.

title: LEGISLATURE IN SQUEEZE ON BUDGET
description: TRENTON WHEN the Legislature returns this week, it will be under considerable pressure to find some temporary solution to the state's budget problems, a condition that is forcing the layoffs of hundreds of state employees.

title: REQUESTS FOR CORPORATE FUNDS RISE AS FEDERAL AID DECLINES
description: Long before President Reagan advised the needy to knock at the private sector's door, they knocked here to the tune of millions of dollars. A substantial portion of the money came from the city's insurance industry and was spent on job training, housing, parks, garden plots, music on the plaza.

title: A.T.P. Rankings Aren't Accurate
description: To the Sports Editor: There is something radically wrong with the ranking system of the Association of Tennis Professionals. John McEnroe has been ranked No. 1 since his United States Open victory in September 1981.

title: PIANIST: RECITAL BY DAVID DEVEAU
description: An interesting young pianist, David Deveau, played Haydn, Schumann, Schoenberg and Liszt on Friday at Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Deveau made us feel Haydn's joyous originality in the Sonata in F (Hob. XVI:23) without ever disrupting the music's tensions and flow, and he evoked with skill the intimacy and autumnal gloominess of Schoenberg's Three Piano Pieces (Op. 11).

title: Councilman's View On Glen Cove Dispute
description: The Glen Cove City Council does not realize that Glen Cove is part of the United States of America. The United States has pre-empted such fields as foreign relations and national security and so, when the Glen Cove City Council was informed that Soviet surveillance equipment was operating from its United Nations residence known as Killenworth, which is in Glen Cove, the council should have contacted the Federal Government for information and advice.

title: FORECLOSING ON A DREAM
description: Frances L. Miller was sitting in her freshly washed kitchen at her home in the residential North End of Bridgeport, Conn. ''I'm scared to death,'' she said as she nibbled nervously on a slice of chocolate cake she had baked to celebrate her older daughter's high-school graduation. Two weeks earlier, Mrs. Miller, a voluble, middle-aged blond woman, had reluctantly sold her green raised-ranch style house for $75,000 - just before it was due to be spirited away from her in a foreclosure auction.

title: POLLUTION GROWS IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: After dismissing environmental pollution as a byproduct of the capitalist system for years, Europe's Communist countries have begun to recognize that they also have a problem, in some cases a serious one.

title: Reagan Names Illinois Dean
description: President Reagan on Friday nominated Orville G. Bentley, dean of the University of Illinois College of Agriculture, to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Science and Education.

title: PHOTOS OF CONNECTICUT
description: More than 200 historic and contemporary photographs of Connecticut have been brought together for an exhibition illustrating the state's architectural and topographical variety and the evolution of some of its urban and rural locations. Titled ''Vital Signs - Connecticut,'' it may be seen Friday through Nov. 15 at the Old State House, 800 Main Street, Hartford.

title: MILLSTONE 3 COST RISES SHARPLY IN RATE REQUEST
description: NEW BRITAIN THE teams are preparing to take to the field in the Department of Public Utility Control's fall classic, the Northeast Utilities rate case.

title: Back in Beirut
description: Prospects looked brighter in Lebanon last week; 800 American marines helicoptered out of Beirut followed yesterday by 537 Italian troops, their duties supervising the P.L.O. evacuation completed. French units are expected to leave this week.

title: Illness Strikes Church Parley
description: At least 43 members of a Louisiana church group attending the National Baptist Convention of America were stricken Friday night, apparently with food poisoning, and were taken to area hospitals, the police said. Members of the Lake Bethlehem Baptist Church in Shreveport, La., were in the grand ballroom of the Radisson Muehlebach Hotel listening to a speech by their pastor when they became ill. All had eaten at a restaurant and had also reportedly consumed box lunches of chicken and potato salad, the city health director, Dr. Richard Biery, said.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: 1 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.45.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to Last week 9 Weeks on list 2

title: UTILITY ALLOWANCES PRAISED AT HEARING
description: TRENTON THE cash allowance that utilities are granted by the state's Board of Public Utilities to help pay the cost of financing their construction projects - a practice long deplored by the state's Department of the Public Advocate -may be a boon for rate-payers, according to utility executives who testified before a State Senate committee here last week.

title: Opera in Edinburgh
description: We thoroughly enjoyed Linda Blandford's article ''Jonathan Miller Meets Mozart in St. Louis'' (Aug. 1).

title: Miss Hallenbeck, Douglas Libbey Have Wedding
description: Cynthia Ann Hallenbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Hallenbeck of Rochester, was married there yesterday to Douglas Mendel Libby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Libbey of Youngstown, Ohio. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church.

title: 'Security' Cited as Honduras Ousts a Nicaraguan Diplomat
description: Honduras has expelled the economic attache at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Tegucigalpa for ''security reasons,'' the Honduran Foreign Minister, Edgardo Paz Barnica, said today.

title: TORTILLAS IN DOZENS OF WAYS
description: AMIGOS, a small, bright storefront restaurant that opened earlier this year in Port Washington, looks as though it might have been transported intact directly from downtown Mexico City.

title: Italians Issue Five Warrants In 1980 Bombing in Bologna
description: Prosecutors issued arrest warrants today for three Italians, a Frenchman and an East German in connection with the 1980 Bologna train station bombing that killed 85 people and injured 200.

title: HARTFORD THEATER REVISES SCHEDULE
description: COME spring, the artistic directors of regional theaters are obliged to announce their fall repertories, ready or not. Given the need for such advance scheduling, some changes are inevitable. With the Hartford Stage Company's new season, however, change has been the rule, rather than the exception.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE theme was familiar, but some of the actors had changed when the hearings on the safety of the Indian Point nuclear power plants resumed recently in the Ceremonial Courtroom of the courthouse in White Plains, where they have proceeded intermittently over the summer.

title: EMBASSY GUNMAN SERVED JAIL TERM AS SPY
description: New information has emerged on the identity of the four gunmen who seized the Polish Embassy in Switzerland this week. But there are still many uncertainties about the gunmen's motives and possible outside support.

title: BIG TEN OFFICIAL STRICKEN, DIES
description: Referee Richard McVay died, apparently of a heart attack, after collapsing today during the Michigan State-Illinois Big Ten football game, hospital officials said.

title: WINDSURFING GAINING POPULARITY
description: SALISBURY ONE breezy morning recently a 67-year-old woman took off from O'Hara's Landing in Salisbury and rode her sailboard across Twin Lakes.

title: BOLIVIAN BIDS REAGAN JAIL HIM
description: A man wanted on Federal charges of conspiracy to import cocaine has sent a letter to President Reagan saying he will turn himself in if his son is freed from a Federal prison and the United States pays Bolivia's external debt.

title: DANCE: RUTH BARNES
description: The dances that Ruth Barnes presented Thursday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center certainly had a lot of get-up-and-go, and once they got going there was virtually no stopping them. In fact, these dances were so manic and jittery that they appeared to be suffering from choreographic coffee nerves.

title: U.N. Chief's Burst of Candor
description: Everybody talks at the United Nations but nobody listens, the Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, complained last week. The United Nations has been ignominiously rebuffed in Lebanon, the Persian Gulf, the Falklands, Afghanistan, and Cambodia and has been shut out of the turbulence in Central America.

title: U.S. Hearings Begin Tuesday On Air Crash at New Orleans
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will begin interviewing about 30 witnesses Tuesday in hearings on the cause of the Pan American World Airways crash July 9 that killed 154 people near New Orleans in the nation's second-worst airline disaster.

title: BROADWAY SHOWS COME TO STRATFORD
description: THE boldfaced type in the advertisement states, ''Bill Hanney Presents,'' and what follows is most impressive. Mr. Hanney is presenting the national touring company of ''Amadeus'' on Oct. 29, 30 and 31 at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford. Following that, he will bring in ''I'm Getting My Act Together and Taking It On the Road,'' starring Connie Stevens, on Dec. 2, 3 and 4.

title: THE QUESTION HOUR
description: Question - Wouldn't you like to give Menachem Begin a kick in the pants? Answer - I can't wait. Q. - How about Yasir Arafat? A. - Oooh! That would be fun, and then send him to some clip-joint for a shave. Q. - Seriously, what are you thinking about the Middle East? A. - Sorry, I was thinking about the Middle West. Q. - Why? A. - I come from there, and Menachem Begin and Yasir Arafat encourage my isolationist tendencies. Q. - What an ass! Aren't you ashamed to say that with the way the world is going? A. - Sort of. But Mr. Begin and Mr. Arafat are driving me up the wall. They are on the evening television news more than Dan Rather and Roger Mudd, talking the most outrageous rubbish, driveling on about their their rights and their borders, and blaming old Uncle Sugar for all their problems.

title: THE TRANSFORMATION OF AN 'UNDERDOG'
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Letting Go
description: William S. Paley, who has rolled many a head at CBS Inc., engineered yet another resignation last week - his own.

title: PLAYING WHAT'S NOT THERE
description: MILES DAVIS A Biography. By Ian Carr. Foreword by Len Lyons. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.95.

title: Sports of The Times; At Home With Jimmy Connors
description: THE way Jimmy Connors said it, it didn't even sound like bragging: ''This is my tournament.'' He could feel the respect and the excitement and maybe even a little bit of love and he put the emphasis on the ''my.''

title: SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL WHEN BULBS ARE PLANTED IN SEPTEMBER
Diamond in the Rough
description: The old pro said he was more nervous than any of his players, but Paul Blair, the former star outfielder with the Baltimore Orioles and Yankees, had a successful debut as coach of the Fordham baseball team when the Rams defeated St. Francis, 2-0, Friday. Blair said his major concern was trying not to miss any of the signs. After the game, he said he hadn't. ... Tim Stoddard of the Orioles underwent knee surgery, and the right-handed relief pitcher will miss the rest of the season. ... Dave Parker, the Pirate outfielder who has been able to appear in only 61 games this season because of hand injuries, said he planned to play winter ball in Venezuela. ... Kent Hrbek, the Minnesota Twins' rookie first baseman, will not rejoin his team until tomorrow following the death of his father, Edward Hrbek, 53 years old, from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the disease that killed Lou Gehrig.

title: MISUSING ECONOMIC SANCTIONS
description: What do the following countries have in common: Argentina, Britain, El Salvador, France, West Germany, Iran, Israel, Italy, Japan, Libya, Nicaragua, Poland and the Soviet Union?

title: CRIME INDEX FALLS 16.7% IN 6 MONTHS
description: The number of serious crimes reported in the county took a steep plunge during the first six months of 1982, declining by almost 17 percent from the first half of 1981. County officials and criminologists, while pleased by the news, say they are somewhat at a loss for an explanation.

title: GETTING THE YOUNG ATHLETE READY TO PLAY
description: AS the summer has faded, vacations have ended and children have gone back to school, those of us who participate in, care for, and observe the fall sports begin to feel the first vague stirrings of excitement.

title: L.I. COOKING SCHOOLS OFFER A CLASS FOR EVERY TASTE
description: WITH the arrival of autumn, the outdoor barbecue grills are covered and home entertaining moves inside. The taste of charcoal-grilled steaks and barbecued chicken becomes a memory as cooking returns to the kitchen, and apples are baked into pies and served warm from the oven. Now, too, the Island's cooking schools open for the fall, and the roster of courses is, to say the least, impressive.

title: WLADYSLAW GOMULKA: NEITHER HERO NOR PATRIOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Adams Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Lois Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Adams of Darien, Conn., and Megansett, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher Crowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Crowley of Worcester, Mass., and Megansett. The Rev. Edward Howley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Adams home in Darien.

title: Reagan Urges Support For Anticrime Proposal
description: President Reagan today urged Americans to support his anticrime legislation, contending that it was needed to combat a crime epidemic.

title: THIS WILL BE THE YEAR OF THE SKYSCRAPER
description: In architecture, this is the season of realization, the year in which several of the largest and most eagerly awaited buildings in Manhattan - some expected last year but delayed - will at last reach completion. More even than last year, it will be a time in which the skyscraper will lay claim to our attention. The uncertain economy may mean that fewer new buildings are being initiated today; but nonetheless, this season will reap the crop of large buildings that recent boom years have sowed. The most important of the new buildings - I.B.M., A.T.& T., Philip Morris - are all towers; the Museum of Modern Art, the city's most venerable establishment for exhibitions on architectural themes, has planned a review of new skyscraper designs as its major architecture show of the winter season, and another important exhibition, at the Urban Center, will mark the 50th anniversary of the city's greatest assemblage of skyscrapers, Rockefeller Center.

title: 2-1 TOO CHIC WINS MASKETTE
description: For the second day in a row, a 3-year-old filly suddenly moved into contention for the divisional championship with an impressive victory over her elders at Belmont Park. On Friday, Gold Beauty humbled the best sprinters in training in the Fall Highweight Handicap. Yesterday, Too Chic scored a handy victory over older fillies and mares in the $113,200 Maskette Stakes.

title: A FALL GUIDE TO COOKING CLASSES
description: IN today's food-conscious world, learning to cook means more than a course on how to boil water. And in the county, the cuisines of the world - Chinese, French and Italian - can be learned without traveling thousands of miles.

title: FIRE DEPT. GIVES WRITTEN TEST
description: The Fire Department yesterday administered its written test for new applicants. About 43,000 applicants had signed up to take the test, but the number of people who took it will not be known for about a week, until after officials finish grading the exams.

title: The Cruel Thief
description: To the Business Editor: William Nordhaus, in ''How Not to Balance the Federal Budget'' (Sept.5) questions the conservative belief that Federal spending is excessive. He points to the poor and the increasing number of potholes in the highways.

title: RELEASED SEAHAWK PONDERS HIS FUTURE
description: When the Seahawks open their seventh season in the National Football League against the Cleveland Browns today in Seattle, Sam McCullum will be sitting before a television set, watching the game in which he expected to be playing.

title: A Second Shot At Firefighting
description: For three years, a group of women have been fighting the New York City Fire Department over a physical exam they contended - and the courts agreed - was unfair. Last week, a revised exam was given and, judging from the results, some of them will soon be fighting fires.

title: BEHIND THE SUCCESS OF SLEEPY HOLLOW RESTORATIONS
description: ''AS he approached the village he met a number of people, but none whom he knew, which somewhat surprised him, for he had thought himself acquainted with everyone. ... They all stared at him with equal marks of surprise. ... The very village was altered ... and all his familiar haunts had disappeared.''

title: Lebanese Urges Unity
description: Former Prime Minister Saeb Salam met with President-elect Bashir Gemayel today and urged Christians and Moslems to work together.

title: YANKS TOP BREWERS AFTER TRAILING BY 6
description: Roy Smalley's ninth-inning single with the bases loaded yesterday gave the Yankees a 9-8 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, a three victories in the four-game series with the first-place team in the American League East and a record that is five games over .500 for the first time this season.

title: Jobson Is Victor
description: Gary Jobson held off Buddy Melges today to win the Timberland Hall of Fame regatta sailed in an 8- to 10-knot southwesterly breeze on Narragansett Bay.

title: Woodley Keeps Active
description: There was no sense, the Miami Dolphins figured, in having their quarterback, David Woodley, sitting in the pocket all afternoon, a highly visible and stationary target for the Jets front four. Instead, Woodley's mobility could be exploited by using him as a third running back. And by using him as a wide receiver.

title: SHULTZ SAYS HOUR FOR MIDEAST PEACE CAN BE SEIZED NOW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said last night that the Middle East was at ''a moment of unprecedented opportunity'' for peace. He appealed to Israelis, moderate Arab leaders and Palestinians to agree to the American call for new negotiations.

title: 11,000 Detroit Teachers Preparing to Begin Strike
description: By The Associated Press A strike by Detroit's 11,000 teachers, closing the classroom doors for 200,000 children, appeared likely yesterday, with negotiators still ''far apart'' on school board demands for a pay cut, union leaders said.

title: RISING BEEF PRICES AROUSE ARGENTINES
description: A two-day shutdown by butcher shops last week to protest the rising price of beef hit Argentine consumers particularly hard.

title: Advertising; Psychology Today and Its 'Rebirth'
description: THE man who founded the magazine Psychology Today, Nicholas H. Charney, has just rejoined it as editorial director, and he has set about adding more articles about consumer psychology and other topics of interest to advertising and marketing people.

title: NEW YORK AREA'S SCHOOLS OPENING UNDER FISCAL STRAIN
description: As a weeklong series of school openings continues today, many suburban school districts in the New York metropolitan area are cutting back special programs in the face of the decline in Federal funds for them that totals $300 million nationally.

title: Surgical Device Maker Appoints a President
description: Spencer M. Vawter has assumed the presidency of BioSound Inc., an Indianapolis company licensed to market a tiny ultrasound probe that it hopes will become an accepted aid in the operating room.

title: Dr. Robert Winokur Weds Sara Troxell
description: The marriage of Sara Lincoln Troxell to Dr. Robert Henry Winokur took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Franklin Troxell Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J. Judge John W. Bissell of the Superior Court of New Jersey performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Howard Winokur of Encino and Mammoth Lakes, Calif.

title: Books Of The Times
description: NAMESAKE. By Michel Goldberg. Yale University Press. 192 pages. $13.95.

title: 14 Firefighters Hurt in Yonkers
description: Fourteen firefighters were injured battling a three-alarm blaze that burned for four hours in Yonkers early today, fire officials said.

title: HANDICAPPED PUPILS JOIN THE MAINSTREAM
description: Not long ago Trisha Vassello went into training to be a kindergartener. A kindergartener, she informed her mother, is someone who has a lunch box and knows how to drink from a thermos. The lunch box appeared two weeks ago, on her fifth birthday, and since then she has been eating every meal from it and painstakingly pouring milk from thermos to cup, over and over, until she could do so without spilling a drop.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Candidate as Teacher

title: A NATION SWAMPED BY LIABILITY LITIGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow's Phone Lines To West Restored
description: Telephone links between Moscow and the West were fully restored today, two days after the city's international exchange broke down and set off speculation in the West about political upheavals in the Soviet capital.

title: Bomb at Bangkok Airport
description: Airport security guards found a time bomb in the departure lounge of Don Muang International Airport, Bangkok newspapers said today. The Nation Review quoted the deputy air force chief of staff, Air Marshal Sompol Burusratanaphan, as saying that the bomb failed to explode because the electrical wires were not properly connected.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., has named Clarence E. Cobbs chairman and chief operating officer of its Phillippe of California Inc. subsidiary.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the ruling when a second baseman either intentionally or unintentionally collides with a runner going from first to second? Does it make any difference that the runner would have been safe without the collision? Or, that he would have been out even if there had been no collision?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tips for Apartment Hunters I t must be, judging from the turnout for Nat Hendricks's lecture yesterday, that there is no apartment shortage, no matter what anyone says. Only three persons showed up, and only Margo Cates - two and a half years in New York from Winnipeg, Canada, and still searching for an apartment she can afford - listened intently.

title: D'AGOSTINO CHAIN CHIEF LEAVING TO JOIN BOTTLER
description: Stephen I. D'Agostino, chief executive officer of the D'Agostino Supermarkets chain and chairman of the Food Marketing Institute, the industrywide trade organization, will leave the supermarket field on Oct. 23 after 27 years in the business.

title: CHINA PARTY VETERANS KEEP JOBS AS HUA IS OUSTED
description: Mao Zedong's chosen successor, Hua Guofeng, was dropped from the Chinese leadership today. Most of the older Communist Party veterans remained in their posts.

title: Inmate Killed by Bomb That He Was Making
description: A 24-year-old death row inmate working on a homemade bomb in his cell was killed today when the bomb exploded, a spokesman at the Central Correctional Institution said.

title: BANKERS TROUBLED IN WEST GERMANY
description: A succession of setbacks in domestic and overseas business has spread a mood of uncertainty through West Germany's banking industry.

title: WAY EASED FOR HUMANITIES NOMINEE
description: The last major obstacle to the appointment of a Dartmouth College professor to the National Council on the Humanities has been has been removed by Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.

title: NUCLEAR WAR 'PRACTICE' MOCKS U.S. SHELTER PLAN
description: On July 4, not long after the nuclear freeze rally in New York City, Bill and Diane Tomaney had some friends over for a picnic and the conversation turned to what would happen to this semirural town in a nuclear war.

title: MUSIC: NEW HOME FOR NEW ORLEANS PHILHARMONIC
description: New Orleans, Sept. 11 - What, you may might reasonably wonder, could Fatty Arbuckle, Houdini and kung fu films have in common with Tchaikovsky? Well, as of last night they have all played the Orpheum, a 61-year-old theater that once was a stop on the vaudeville circuit but now has been renovated as the new home of the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony. An all-Tchaikovsky concert conducted by the orchestra's music director, Philippe Entremont, brought out the flower of New Orleans society and assorted curiosity seekers from the outside musical world. The program, consisting of the Violin Concerto and the Symphony No. 4, was hardly a path-breaker, but it did provide first-nighters an excellent opportunity to assess the 1,938-seat hall's acoustical worth as well as its lovingly restored Beaux Arts decor.

title: BRAZILIAN GO-GETTER SETS SIGHTS ON THE PRESIDENCY
description: He appears at events to which he has not been invited. He openly courts a following by lavishing state money on fellow politicians around the country. And once, during a wedding reception, he invaded a country-club kitchen to embrace the local governor, who had taken refuge there in an effort to avoid being seen with him.

title: Market Place; Interest Rates' Effect on Gold
description: THERE is a mixed outlook for gold bullion today. Speculators who might like to enter the market have missed a major move. But investors could benefit from rising gold prices over the longer term, traders say.

title: Inspection Sought For Tainted Wells
description: Two Congressmen from Connecticut have asked the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to inspect several private wells here that are contaminated with toxic chemicals.

title: POPE-ARAFAT TALK ASSAILED BY ISRAEL
description: Israeli officials said today that the Government viewed a proposed meeting between Pope John Paul II and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, as a grave development and would seek to persuade the Vatican to drop the idea.

title: Sports World Specials Waiting in the Wings
description: Devotees of televised Sunday afternoon and Monday night football need not despair if a strike by National Football League players knocks pro action off the tube this fall. Plans are afoot to move selected college games from Saturday to Sunday or Monday to fill the video gap.

title: Once More, a Fumble Haunts the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. SUDDENLY nobody was talking about the Giants going to the Super Bowl this season. Suddenly nobody was even talking about the Giants making the playoffs last season. Instead, people were talking only of Leon Perry's fumble and remembering Joe Pisarcik's fumble four seasons ago. Another fluke fumble by the Giants that had turned a game around, that might turn a season around. Deja vu. Deja boo.

title: Bridal for Eileen Fitzgerald and Paul Rosenblum
description: Eileen Fitzgerald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Fitzgerald of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Rosenblum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Rosenblum of Brooklyn. Justice Leonard Cohen of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Butler Hall Terrace Restaurant.

title: GULF OF BITTERNESS DIVIDES WEST BANK JEWS AND ARABS
description: Occupied West Bank, Sept. 12 - From the narrow streets that wind among the stone houses of this West Bank Arab village, the Jewish settlement of Shiloh can be seen spreading down from a hilltop a few miles away. Between them lies a road, a valley and a gulf of silence.

title: THE CANDIDATES TAKE CAMPAIGN TO STREET FAIRS
description: Between campaign stops where they mingled with balloons, brass bands and beachgoers, candidates for governor traded charges yesterday on budgets, taxes and other weighty matters.

title: LEBANESE ARMY FIGHTS IN BEIRUT AGAINST LEFTISTS
description: Regular Lebanese Army troops clashed with a small group of leftist militiamen here today after the militiamen opened fire on a Moslem delegation en route to pay its respects to President-elect Bashir Gemayel.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Architecture Award Is Given to Alden Dow

title: Flagship Banks' Protest
description: Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami has announced that it has filed a protest with the Federal Reserve Board in Atlanta asking that it disapprove the change of control filed by Juan Vincente Perez Sandoval and Inversiones Credival C.A., which are seeking permission to acquire up to 24.9 percent of Flagship's shares outstanding. Flagship also said it was suing Mr. Perez and Credival for violating securities law.

title: South Korean Man Held In Abduction of Woman
description: A 28-year-old man from South Korea was held without bond here today in connection with the abduction of a Korean woman, the authorities said.

title: 60-Second Debate
description: Jack Brooks Democratic Representative from Texas

title: STILL IN TRANSITION DEVILS OPEN CAMP
description: The New Jersey Devils, an organization transplanted from Colorado and before that from Kansas City, a team that will make use of Islander influences to compete in a hockey market first cultivated by the Rangers, took its first strides on the ice today.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Milosz to Lead Off Series Of Poetry at the Donnell

title: TV: A CHARACTERISTIC FINALE FROM 'LOU GRANT'
description: WAITING for the new season to get under way in a week or two, viewers might understandably assume that tonight's episode of ''Lou Grant'' on CBS at 10, is still another rerun. It's not. It happens to be the last episode produced before the network, much to the surprise of the industry, canceled the award-winning series.

title: WHAT THE U.S. WILL AND WON'T DO IN THE MARSHALL ISLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Raiders Beat 49ers
description: Marcus Allen, the 1981 Heisman Trophy winner, accounted for 181 total yards in his professional debut, and Jim Plunkett tossed a 3-yard scoring pass today as the Los Angeles Raiders defeated the San Francisco 49ers, 23-17.

title: SALVADORAN CHIEF TO SET UP PEACE COMMISSION
description: El Salvador's President, Alvaro Magana, said today that he hoped to establish a multiparty commission before the end of the month to take up the question of whether to open peace negotiations with the guerrilla-led opposition.

title: CUT IN TREATMENT OF SEWAGE BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration, in a major reinterpretation of the Clean Water Act, is encouraging localities to scale back sewage treatment plants, which will increase the flow of organic pollutants into rivers and coastal waters.

title: News Analysis
description: After surprisingly wide defections from President Reagan on the overriding of his veto of the $14.1 billion supplemental appropriations bill last week, Congressional Republicans are now likely to fall more back in line with him except on the increasingly controversial issue of military spending.

title: SOUL: GARDEN 'SUPERFEST'
description: THE most unforgettable moment of the six-hour ''Budweiser Superfest'' at Madison Square Garden on Saturday came in the last hour, when the headliner, Aretha Franklin, was unexpectedly joined on stage by Smokey Robinson, the great Motown tenor, who had appeared earlier. Miss Franklin, who is enjoying her biggest hit in years with the album ''Jump to It,'' had started one of that album's strongest numbers, ''I Wanna Make It Up to You,'' which she sings on the record with Levi Stubbs of the Four Tops. But instead of Mr. Stubbs, Mr. Robinson appeared, and the two soul superstars tore into the song, building the hook into an intensely joyous gospel-based call-andresponse that went on and on as the singers circled each other and embraced. Though Miss Franklin's earthiness and Mr. Robinson's falsetto are theoretically a mismatch, the two voices blended with remarkable ease, and emotional sparks flew.

title: RECESSION MAKES TEXAS CAMPAIGN JUST LIKE POLITICS EVERYWHERE ELSE
