description: No longer insulated by oil money and growth, Texas politics sounds less exotic this fall. Just like campaigns everywhere else, it is focused on the recession.

title: Back-to-School Anxiety
description: New York's schools reopen today with both anticipation and apprehension. Last year's gains are reason for optimism, but were achieved in part because of a rigorous promotion policy that leaves nearly 4,000 students stranded for a third year in the same grade. To rescue them, the schools are plunging into unknown pedagogical water.

title: Washington Watch; Capital Gains Setback Seen
description: WASHINGTON WALL STREET'S last hope for 1982 legislation to shorten the holding period for long-term capital gains to six months from one year may fall victim to Senator Jesse Helms's anti-abortion and school prayer bills. The North Carolina Republican is attempting to attach both to the resolution to raise the national debt ceiling. Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, has promised to use that resolution as a vehicle to reduce the capital gains holding period.

title: GIANTS LOSE,16-14
description: With an assortment of tricks that confused the Jets' feared pass rush and kept it off balance, the Miami Dolphins defeated the New York Jets yesterday for the first time since 1977. The score was 45-28 before a frustrated opening-day crowd at Shea Stadium.

title: TIPS FOR NEW SCHOOL YEAR
description: As lunch boxes are christened with peanut butter sandwiches, pencils are sharpened and the cellophane is stripped off new notebooks, parents of New York City schoolchildren may face a few special problems.

title: Ethiopian, Blaming U.S., Calls for Arms Buildup
description: The Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, said today that his nation must strengthen its military ability because of the Horn of Africa's strategic importance and United States hostility to revolutionary movements there.

title: Fire in Vienna Disco Kills 3
description: Three people were killed and one was injured early today in a fire that broke out in a downtown discotheque. Authorities said the three died from smoke inhalation, and a woman was injured when she jumped from the second story.

title: William Nowinski, Violinist With the Philharmonic, 64
description: William Nowinski, a violinist with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra for 39 years and a teacher, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

title: Explosives Found in Ulster
description: The police defused 700 pounds of explosives on the grounds of a school in a southern area where attacks by Irish Republican Army guerrillas often occur. Authorities said today that six kegs full of explosives were found Friday at a school in Lisnaskea in County Fermanagh. British security patrols regularly pass by the school.

title: FED'S VIEW IS AWAITED BY TRADERS
description: The sharp drop in interest rates since late June has come to a halt partly because credit market participants are waiting to see how the Federal Reserve reacts to recent and prospective growth in the nation's money supply.

title: SENATE HOPEFULS IN JERSEY INITIATE SERIES OF DEBATES
description: The two major candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey had their first official campaign encounter tonight, as they began a series of five debates that will end just before Election Day in November.

title: AUTUMN'S HARVEST OF FRIENDS
description: It was the last ferry boat out of Fair Harbor, Fire Island to leave Labor Day night, and Karen Mullarkey, a magazine picture editor, who had just left her beach house in Atlantique was surprised by the camaraderie. ''It was a bittersweet scene,'' she said the other day. ''There was everybody leaving as late as possible, shaking hands and saying goodbye. It was like the end of camp.''

title: UNBEATEN COPELAN IS WINNER IN BLEMONT FUTURITY
description: The lettering on the bay colt's saddlecloth read ''Copeland,'' but after the way that Copelan won the Belmont Futurity yesterday, it is unlikely his name will be misspelled again.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SECRETARY OF STATE'S SPEECH TO THE U.J.A. ON THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's speech on the Middle East last night before the United Jewish Appeal in New York:

title: CONNORS WINS 4TH U.S. OPEN ON BIG NEW YORK SPORTS DAY
description: It was tennis and football to the east, football to the west and baseball to the north. Somewhere at or among these points yesterday were those who wanted to watch, those who wanted to find a parking spot, those who wanted to stay cool and those who just wanted to play their own games on a big sports day for New York.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM SERBIA

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On Hart Island, Trailers In Search of Occupants

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in Business Day Wednesday about the Continental Group's plans to convert an 890-mile natural gas pipeline to carry light pe- troleum products contained several inaccuracies attributable to the Fed- eral Energy Regulatory Commission. The Florida Gas Transmission Com- pany, a subsidiary of the Continental Group, plans to sell the line, which is to be converted to carry oil, to the Transgulf Pipeline Company, another unit of the Continental Group, for $236 million. Florida Gas will then modify its system to continue providing cus- tomers the same volume of gas they now receive, 725 million cubic feet a day.

title: MIAMI HOPES TO TRANSFORM RIVER FROM NUISANCE TO ATTRACTION
description: A five-year plan to transform the troublesome Miami River, regarded as one of the city's less attractive features, into a recreational, commercial and residential center was announced today.

title: Records Show Citicorp Acted to Skirt Foreign Bank Rules
description: Confidential Government and bank documents show that Citicorp has disguised billions of dollars in foreign loans and other transactions in an attempt to get around foreign banking regulations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Braving the Mean Streets

title: ARNOUX CAPTURES GRAND PRIX
description: Rene Arnoux of France drove his turbocharged Renault to an easy victory today in the 53d Italian Grand Prix, the next-to-last event of the Formula One season.

title: NEW YORK TURKEY FOR THE TABLE
description: BRINGING home the Thanksgiving Day turkey from other than the supermarket is an uncommon achievement, but New York State residents - or those who choose to hunt in the state - have a better chance than most to accomplish this.

title: FINAL REPORT ON DONOVAN INQUIRY TO BE ISSUED TODAY BY PROSECUTER
description: The special Federal prosecutor investigating charges against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said yesterday that he had completed his reopened inquiry and would issue a final report today.

title: ORIOLES BLANKED BY SUTCLIFFE
description: Jim Palmer yielded two hits and allowed no runs in seven innings in Cleveland yesterday, but the Baltimore Orioles lost to the Indians, 3-0.

title: MARCOS'S NICHE
description: Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos have long sought the additional legitimacy that the Reagan Administration will confer this week through the pomp and circumstance of a state visit to Washington.

title: Judith Stein Wed To J.F. Coleman
description: Judith Stein, daughter of Ruth Keller Schweig of Riverdale, the Bronx, and of Howard I. Stein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Plaza to Joseph Frank Coleman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Kenneth Christman, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Frederick Dworkin performed the ceremony.

title: SENATE PRIMARY IN MINNESOTA DRAWS THE WELL-KNOWN AND WELL-FINANCED
description: The most hotly contested race in the Minnesota primary Tuesday, the fight for the Senate seat held by David Durenberger, has drawn candidates ranging from a former Presidential candidate to a businessman whose campaign spending has already doubled the state record.

title: BIZARRE PROXY FIGHT FOR GLOBAL
description: When the ballots are counted today on a remote island in the British Channel, the contest for seats on the board of directors of Global Natural Resources will go on record as one of the most bizarre proxy fights in memory.

title: Helicopter Death Toll In Germany Put at 45
description: Authorities said today that the probable death toll in the crash of a United States Army helicopter carrying an international parachute team was 45 rather than 44.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1982
description: International A plea for Israelis and Arabs to back the American call for new Middle East negotiations was made by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said there is now ''a moment of unprecedented opportunity'' for peace in the region. In a speech in New York to the national leadership of the United Jewish Appeal, Mr. Shultz strongly defended President Reagan's Middle East proposals and said the parties had to sit down to overcome the signficant differences among the Arab, Israeli and American positions. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fighting in Beirut broke out between regular Lebanese Army troops and a small group of leftist militiamen after the militiamen opened fire on a Moslem delegation on its way east to pay its respects to President-elect Bashir Gemayel. It was the first major challenge to the Lebanese Army's efforts to help maintain security in the capital since the departure of the Palestine Liberation Organization. (A1:5.)

title: Chrysler Makes an Offer To Auto Workers Union
description: The Chrysler Corporation made an offer on wages and benefits to the United Auto Workers today, hours after the union's president, Douglas A. Fraser, criticized the company for its slow pace in negotiations.

title: SUN, CAMARADERIE WARM TAILGATERS
description: The sign was posted on the windshield, nearly two hours after the three men arrived from Mastic Beach, L.I., in the Beppo II, a converted food truck. The truck was once used to deliver animal food to local stores. When Chris Sabolis bought it, the truck was half-filled with hay. Now, he has converted it into a traveling den. There is a bar, refrigerator, sofa, radio, television and heating unit.

title: British G.E. Turns To Lord Carrington
description: Lord Carrington, Britain's former Foreign Secretary who resigned after Argentina invaded the Falklands, is scheduled to become chairman of the General Electric Company of Britain, that nation's biggest military equipment and electronics company.

title: DESTABILIZING ISRAEL
description: What would your reaction be if Menachem Begin invited Ted Kennedy to Israel, and in return for Democratic Party support of Israeli policy, promised to help him oust Ronald Reagan?

title: BENCH AND BAR UNITE FOR TRADING OF IDEAS
description: Bench and bar shed their robes and pinstripes, as well as the excessive politeness, wariness and defensiveness that mark their courtroom contacts. Instead, this weekend they shared frustrations, insights and suggestions about the functioning of the courts.

title: BEATINGS IN SOUTH CAROLINA JAIL SPUR RACIAL TENSION
description: When he was elected in 1976 as Williamsburg County's first black sheriff, cigar-smoking, motorcycleriding Theodore McFarlin was one of the most recognizable lawenforcement professionals in this part of South Carolina.

title: TEACHERS REJECT ISRAELI DEMAND
description: Twenty-eight foreign professors at a Palestinian university in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, including some Americans, refused an Israeli demand today that they sign a statement promising not to support Palestinian guerrilla groups.

title: Product Introductions Set a Vigorous Pace
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc. points out that new-product activity in August was ''full of pep.''

title: Article 146354 -- No Title
description: The Agriculture Department, bowing to a Federal District Court order, said Friday it had re-allocated $9.8 million to states that needed money to operate a program to feed malnourished mothers of small children.

title: Eye Doctors' Advice
description: The surging popularity of racquetball, and the continuing appeal of other four-wall sports like squash and handball, have been accompanied by an alarming number of eye injuries. One of the people most concerned about the phenomenon is Benjamin Milder, an associate professor of ophthalmology at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. He and C.A. (Dewey) Morehouse of the Sports Research Institute at Penn State University will discuss the epidemic of eye injuries during the national conference of the National Society to Prevent Blindness at the Statler Hotel on Sept. 23.

title: CONNORS OVERCOMES LENDL FOR 4th U.S. OPEN CROWN
description: Power may be the new force in men's tennis, but consistency and courage carried Jimmy Connors to a fourth United States Open men's singles title yesterday.

title: Victor Garcia, 47, Director Of Spanish Theater Works
description: Victor Garcia, an avante-garde director who specialized in 20thcentury and classical Spanish works, died Aug. 28 at a Paris hospital, reportedly of a brain virus, it was learned Thursday. He was 47 years old and lived in Paris.

title: N.F.L. Players Plan to Set a Strike Date
description: The National Football League Players Association has called a meeting of its executive committee for next Monday to set a strike date. The timing of the meeting, which will probably be in Chicago, insures that the second weekend of games will be played as scheduled on Sept. 19 and 20.

title: Meredith Jo Perl and James Kornreich Are Wed
description: Meredith Jo Perl, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Perl of Bound Brook, N.J., was married yesterday in Manhattan to James David Kornreich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Rye, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Come to the Fair
description: A friend is waxing eloquent about a recent rolling pin-throwing contest in Goshen, Conn. Another is nostalgic for the veritable sea of noble pigs spotted at a Midwestern extravaganza.

title: Bridge: A Play May Be Too Good For Needs of the Moment
description: Most bridge plays, like most chocolates, are quite mechanically produced and seem slightly stale to the experienced palate. But occasionally one meets the fresh flavor that transcends the routine commercial varieties.

title: New Listening System Installed at the Met
description: An infrared listening system has been installed at the Metropolitan Opera House to provide greater clarity and intelligibility for audiences with hearing impairments.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. The first of five games in four days against the Orioles. The Yankees then move to Milwaukee, which leads the American League Eastern Division, for three games.

title: Study Asserts Crime Articles Increase Fears Among Some
description: Reading about crime in newspapers frightens people, particularly well-educated whites, as much as being exposed to crime, a recent study concludes.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Coca-Cola International Finance N.V. is floating $100 million of notes due in 1989 at a price of 99.25, to yield 11.91 percent, through Morgan Stanley International.

title: TAIWAN REFLECTS IMPACT OF SLUMP ON EAST ASIA
description: With Taiwan's exports stagnant and its economic growth running at half the Government target for the year, gloom would seem to be the appropriate demeanor for business executives and Government economic officials here.

title: SELLING ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
description: Artificial intelligence, the science of making computers ''think,'' has long been the preserve of theoreticians who were little concerned with practical applications.

title: Ellen Goodwin Bride Of Richard D. Schmitz
description: Ellen T. Goodwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot H. Goodwin of New York, was married yesterday to Richard D. Schmitz, son of Mrs. William R. Schmitz of Halifax, Nova Scotia, and the late Mr. Schmitz. The Rev. Carleton Lee, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., performed the ceremony there at the summer home of the bride's parents.

title: BRIEFING
description: Extraterrestrial Rule

title: MARCOS, IN BOOK, DEFENDS HIS AUTHORITARIAN RULE
description: With his first visit to the United State in 18 years scheduled to begin Wednesday, President Ferdinand E. Marcos has published a 453-page book that seeks to justify his authoritarian rule and to persuade Americans to understand it as ''the third world's way.''

title: GILDER BEATS ZOELLER BY 2 SHOTS ON 67-271
description: Bob Gilder shot a four-under-par 67 to record his third victory this season in a $300,000 PGA Tour event. Gilder's round had no bogeys and included three birdies in the first seven holes and a fourth at the 17th.

title: Edythe Brownstein Is Bride
description: Edythe F. Brownstein and Marshall L. Buck were married yesterday at the Sutton Place Synagogue by Rabbi David B. Kahane.

title: 2 in Afghan Cabinet Relieved of Their Jobs
description: Two members of the Afghan Cabinet have been relieved of their duties but they will remain Deputy Prime Ministers, the Kabul radio reported today.

title: Bolivia Is Isolated by Strike Of Communications Workers
description: A strike by workers in Bolivia's state telecommunications company has cut off the South American country from the outside world and halted internal telephone and telex calls, a company spokesman said today.

title: 'This Man's Army'
description: To read the caveats many male soldiers issue about their female peers is to wonder if knighthood is not still in flower. They ask what the sight of a female soldier disintegrating under shellfire would do to discipline and morale. Seeing Guinevere in tears, the question implies, is a lot more destructive than watching Lancelot break down. Is that chivalry? Or does battle fatigue in men become, in women, a case of the vapors?

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Live 'Skin of Our Teeth' To Open PBS Drama Series

title: METS TOP CARDS ON FALCONE'S 3-HITTER
description: The St. Louis Cardinals knew that a relaxed, last-place team like the Mets can be dangerous, and they respected the threat posed by a power-hitter such as Dave Kingman.

title: BONN AIDE PROVOKES SCHMIDT
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff issued the text of a sharply worded memorandum on economic policy today that he submitted to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt last week in an action that officials said was certain to widen the rift in the coalition Government.

title: ABUSING FILIPINOS' RIGHTS
description: After President Ferdinand E. Marcos arrives in Washington on Wednesday for a state visit, perhaps our Government could stretch the bounds of hospitality and ask him why investigations of human rights violations by Filipino security forces so often come to naught.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS KNOCKING OUT ANOTHER SYRIAN MISSILE UNIT
description: Israeli warplanes destroyed another Syrian ground-to-air mobile missile launcher today in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, the military command here reported.

title: News Analysis
description: As he ended a speech during a debate in Parliament last week, Deputy Chancellor Hans-Dietrich Genscher left the impression that he had just about made up his mind to end the 13-year coalition between his small Free Democratic Party and the Social Democrats.

title: New Ecuador Oil Chief
description: President Osvaldo Hurtado has appointed Gustavo Galindo as oil minister to succeed Eduardo Ortega Gomez, who resigned last week after he was censured by Congress, Government sources said over the weekend. Mr. Galindo also will be Ecuador's representative to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: G.O.P. SENATE HOPEFULS IN A RACE FOR RECOGNITION
description: With march music thundering from a tape recorder in the background, Whitney North Seymour Jr. solemnly shook hands with hundreds of commuters the other day as they bounded onto trains at the Croton-Harmon station in Westchester County.

title: THE WAY WE LIVE
description: When Walter Lippmann was living in retirement, a visitor began to tell him about the political situation. Lippmann brushed that aside: ''Don't talk to me about politics. What are you reading?'' The visitor said he had just started a Trollope novel. ''Ah,'' said Lippmann with an envious sigh, ''never to have read Trollope!''

title: Imperial Sells Plascoat
description: The Imperial Group P.L.C. has announced that it has sold its Plascoat International Ltd. unit to a subsidiary of ACI International for the equivalent of about $13.5 million in cash.

title: ORGANIZED LABOR AS FRIEND TO THE MINORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'PONDER HEART' HAS WORLD PREMIERE
description: According to Eudora Welty's novel, Uncle Daniel Ponder may not have been too smart, but he had a big heart. He loved to give things away - flowers, ice cream, a white-face heifer calf, a pickup truck - anything he had. He wore a snow-white suit with a sweet red bow tie. Miss Welty's wry, folksy ''The Ponder Heart'' is about how Uncle Daniel - the holy innocent, the man-child bestowing love on all -came to be tried for murder.

title: LEATHER IN SUBTLE GUISES
description: Ten years ago, leather was generally considered to be too toughlooking for anything but a motorcyclist. But fashion designers who knew an untapped market when they saw one decided that with a little experimentation here and a little development there, leather could be applied to the same clothing silhouettes as fabric, that is, to dresses, skirts, blazers and suits.

title: Allied Executive to Join Economics Laboratory
description: Richard C. Ashley, president of the Allied Chemical Company and a group vice president of its parent, the Allied Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive of Economics Laboratory Inc., a maker of chemical products for cleaning and sanitation.

title: THE TENNIS FLAVOR IS INTERNATIONAL
description: For two weeks, Queens County has played host to a colorful event with international flavor. From the 256 tennis players who participated in the tournament, to the spectators who attended the sessions in record numbers, to the variety of elegant (and expensive) dishes that were bought and consumed on the 17-acre site at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, the United States Open championships were indeed a worldly affair.

title: Donna Eskwitt Married
description: Donna Lynn Eskwitt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Eskwitt of Tenafly, N.J., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Gary Robert Rosenblum, son of Ruth Slosberg of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Herbert Rosenblum. Rabbi Avraham Soltes performed the ceremony. The bride is a clinical audiologist with the Otologic Medical Group in Los Angeles, where her husband is an associate in product safety for the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: AUSTIN VOTE BACKS A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: A nuclear weapons freeze was favored by a ratio of more than 4 to 1 in a straw poll by Austin voters Saturday. The backers of the proposal say the vote is a ''clear signal'' that Americans favor ending the nuclear arms race.

title: PARKER PRODUCES AGAIN
description: Dave Parker had been expected to miss the rest of the season after undergoing surgery to his left thumb last month. But the Pirate slugger is back in the Pittsburgh lineup, and if his return has been unexpected, it has not been unimpressive.

title: Miss Spuzich Wins
description: Sandra Spuzich, at age 45, became the oldest player to capture two Ladies Professional Golf Association tournaments in a year when she shot 67 today and won the Mary Kay Golf Classic.

title: A BOMB EXPLODES IN TEHERAN
description: Iran executed four people today, including a man accused of setting off the bomb that wounded Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, last year, a Teheran newspaper reported.

title: STATE FIGHTS BOGUS CLAIMS SEEKING TAX BENEFITS FOR ELDERLY AND POOR
description: Fraudulent tax preparers have submitted thousands of bogus claims for cash payments from a New York State program that is designed to help the elderly and the poor to pay rent and property taxes, state officials said yesterday.

title: DUTCHMAN MARATHON WINNER
description: Gerard Nijboer of the Netherlands won the men's marathon and Rosa Mota of Portugal the women's as the 13th European track and field championships ended tonight. They finished not in the new Olympic stadium in the suburbs, but in the old marble stadium in downtown Athens, where the first modern Olympics were held in 1896.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said its Bunker Ramo Information Systems unit had introduced an expanded data processing system that would allow brokers to use their stock quotation terminals as personal computers.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1982; International
description: Citicorp has disguised billions of dollars in foreign deals in an attempt to get around foreign banking regulations, Government and bank documents show. The documents also show that senior bank officials were aware of or approved some of the practices. Citicorp subsidiaries in Latin America, Europe and Asia have sidestepped reserve requirements and other rules by routing funds through the Bahamas, Monaco and other countries, according to documents obtained or prepared by the S.E.C. Citicorp declined to comment on the documents. (Page A1.)

title: Bobby Allison Wins
description: Bobby Allison, who started from the pole, regained the lead from Tim Richmond with 73 laps to go today and won the $190,000 Wrangler 400 by a lap.

title: Lendl Feels The Fury
description: IVAN LENDL has felt Jimmy Connors's scorn, and yesterday he felt his fury. Grunting and gesturing, and tomahawking shots with both feet off the ground, Connors held off a late surge by the man he once called ''a chicken'' and won his fourth United States Open title.

title: One-Horse Stable
description: Investors who want to own thoroughbred horses have been banding together in syndicates to keep up with the inflated horseflesh market, but few have entered the game on as small a scale as the Railbird Stables of Denver.

title: MUSIC: 'BRAZIL NIGHT' IN 2 CONTRASTING MOODS
description: SATURDAY'S "Brazil Night in New York" began with a little cultural confusion, but a few hours of music managed in soothe it away. Brazilian tourism promoters, sponsors of the concert, seemed bent on using the opportunity to sell their country's charms. New York concertgoers, on the other hand, arrived promptly at eight, ready to hear Joao Carlos Martins and Arthur Moreira Lima exchange Bach and Chopin preludes from their respective pianos on Avery Fisher Hall's stage.

title: Man Is Held on Charge Of Promoting a Suicide
description: A 21-year-old Staten Island man was arrested yesterday on the rare felony charge of promoting a suicide attempt after he provided a gun to a woman who shot herself in the head, the police said.

title: REDSKINS BEAT EAGLES, 37-34, IN OVERTIME
description: Mark Moseley's third field goal of the game, at 4 minutes 47 seconds of the 15-minute sudden-death period, gave the Washington Redskins a 37-34 victory yesterday over the Eagles in Philadelphia.

title: DEEP-SEATED FEARS THAT DOOMED E.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE FAMILIES GOT NONCASH FEDERAL AID IN '81
description: One in six households received Federal benefits in the form of food stamps, Medicaid, housing subsidies or low-price school lunches last year, according to a new study by the Census Bureau.

title: News Analysis
description: In deciding last week to combine forces, three major Lutheran denominations moved to deal with concerns that are growing among Christians of many types: the need to conserve dwindling resources and the desire to present a unified front in talks with other Christian communions.

title: A Reagan Afterthought Pointed Out by Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, discussing President Reagan's Sept. 1 speech on the Middle East, said last night that one paragraph of Mr. Reagan's remarks did not appear in the text printed in The New York Times of Sept. 2. ''But don't blame The Times,'' he added.

title: Brink's Defendants Gathered for Trial
description: Security was tight over the weekend as defendants in the Brink's robbery-murder trial, which could take up to a year and cost $3 million, were brought here from various prisons for pretrial hearings Monday.

title: FATE OF AN EDUCATOR KIDNAPPED IN BEIRUT REMAINS A MYSTERY
description: Two months after his abduction, the fate of David Dodge, the acting president of the American University here, remains a mystery. Nor is there any definitive word on the identity or motives of his kidnappers.

title: Marina Valmy Becomes a Bride
description: Marina Valmy, daughter of Mrs. Henry Valmy-Sterian of New York, was married yesterday in the Greek Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity to Peter de Haydu of Maracaibo, Venezuela. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Stephanotolous, dean of the cathedral, and the Rev. Miltiades Efphimiou.

title: 13 Dead as Typhoon Rips Across Central Japan
description: A typhoon tore through central Japan today, causing flooding and landslides that left thousands homeless, transportation paralyzed and dozens of people dead or injured.

title: OIL OUTPUT IN LIBYA INCREASED
description: Undaunted by the Reagan Administration's effort to limit the American presence here, United States oil companies have increased production in recent months to levels in excess of the quota of 750,000 barrels a day set for Libya by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: WEAKER SOVIET TRADE SEEN
description: The Soviet Union's $4 billion surplus in trade with Western industrial countries may deteriorate to a $7 billion deficit by 1985, according to a study prepared for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: 3-PART U.S. FINANCING EXPECTED NEXT WEEK
description: The Treasury is expected to announce tomorrow a three-part financing of notes and bonds due in four, seven and 20 years - all for sale in the week beginning Sept. 20. Dealers expect the three issues to total more than $11 billion and to raise upward of $8.5 billion of new cash for the Treasury.

title: Burrowing Man Dies In a Hole in His Yard
description: The police said a man under the influence of the hallucinogenic drug PCP, apparently believing he was a gopher, burrowed into a hole and suffocated.

title: Bache Cited By S.E.C.
description: Embezzlement charges against a former Hartford broker have led Federal securities authorities to censure Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, the nation's sixth-largest brokerage firm.

title: Big Shipping Tries an End Run
description: The $15 billion cargo liner industry is hard-pressed to explain why it needs exemption from the antitrust laws. So rather than risk an embarrassing debate, the industry is trying to slip through legislation when no one is looking. It will be up to House members who believe in competition to stop this end run.

title: POP: REUNION IN TRIBUTE TO CAPITAL
description: THE first of four shows saluting the 40th anniversary of Capitol Records at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J., ran seven hours - long enough to exhaust even the most diehard pop nostalgist. By 2 A.M., when the headliner Peggy Lee was winding up an eerie, somnambulistic set, the packed 1,200-seat auditorium had thinned out considerably.

title: Insanity Defense Needed, Hinckley Writes in Letter
description: By The Associated Press John W. Hinckley Jr. says abolishing the insanity defense would be ''a travesty of justice'' by a vindictive America to avenge the shooting of President Reagan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Wimbledon is Wimbledon and it's always going to be Wimbledon. But this is different.

title:
Commodities;
Brazil-U.S. Juice Rivalry
description: SOME years ago there was a popular song with the line, ''They've got an awful lot of coffee in Brazil.'' Brazil also has an awful lot of orange juice, not to mention soybeans and cocoa.

title: HOW TO KEEP UNIONS OUT OF A COMPANY
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Rich Is Married To Michael M. Becker
description: Judith Densen Rich and Michael M. Becker, tournament bridge players, were married yesterday at Les Mouches in Manhattan by Rabbi David Posner.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intersessional Committee of the Whole of U.N.D.P. Governing Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TWO CHALLENGERS RISE FROM BOXING MELTING POT
description: There are eight million stories in the city, a few in the suburbs, and here are two illustrating that New York is also a melting pot for boxing.

title: West Virginia Hails Its Greatest Upset
description: Three huge bonfires lit up the Sunnyside section of Morgantown all Saturday night and into the early hours yesterday in celebration of West Virginia's 41-17 victory at Oklahoma, the biggest upset of the young football season. More than 5,000 people turned out to welcome the team when it got back to Morgantown at midnight Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: The Rangers said that all veterans scheduled to arrive at the opening of their training camp in Rye, N.Y., reported yesterday.

title: TRIAL OF GIBSON AND HARRIS BEGINS TODAY
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and Earl Harris, a former City Council President, go on trial Monday in Essex County Superior Court on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office. These involve the hiring of a former City Councilman for what the prosecution contends was a ''no show'' job.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Dale Susan Alban Married To Richard John Tannen
description: Dale Susan Alban, daughter of Mrs. Alan E. Ungar of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard John Tannen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Tannen of New York.

title: WIDE ABUSES FOUND IN JERSEY AGENCY
description: From ''questionable'' expenditures of $500,000 to employee thefts of $100,000, investigators say they have uncovered an extraordinary array of improper fiscal practices at the Jersey City Redevelopment Agency.

title: SUN-DRENCHED BOOK LOVERS THRONG TO FAIR
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is likely to announce in six months that it is prepared to take two or three paying passengers on each future trip into space, James A. Michener told a capacity audience yesterday at a literary brunch in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.

title: A Police Chief Is Arrested
description: Chief Dominic Antonelli of the Torrington police was arrested Saturday on seven counts of professional gambling after a weeklong investigation into an illegal sports betting operation, the state police said.

title: A NATION SWAMPED BY LIABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 50 Years on the A Train

title: GIANTS LOSE, 16-14
description: The record book will show that the Atlanta Falcons beat the Giants, 16-14, today on the first day of the 1982 National Football League season. In truth, the Giants beat themselves with mistakes, and the play that did the major damage was Bob Glazebrook's 91-yard touchdown run with a Giants fumble on a play almost everyone else thought was dead.

title: Biggest Advertiser: Procter & Gamble
description: The Procter & Gamble Company was the country's largest-scale advertiser during 1981, the trade publication Advertising Age reported last week, with total outlays of $671.8 million on advertising, not counting local newspaper advertising other than inserts.

title: English Spaniel Is Best in Show
description: A liver and white English springer spaniel, Ch. Salilyn's Private Stock, owned by Robert Gough and Julia Gasow, was gaited to top honors by George Alston today at the Westchester Kennel Club's 65th show on the grounds of Lyndhurst.

title: REAGAN HARKS BACK TO THE CAMPAIGN
description: By tradition, the political season starts the week after Labor Day, so it was fitting that President Reagan chose this time to return to the homey issues and upbeat style of his 1980 campaign.

title: 39 KILLED AS SWISS TRAIN HITS GERMAN TOURIST BUS
description: A locomotive struck a bus carrying West German soccer fans home today from a weekend tour, killing 39 of the 41 men and women aboard, officials reported.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Seminar on Book Contracts

title: DANCE: 3 PLOTLESS WORKS OFFERED BY JUNE LEWIS
description: JUNE LEWIS, who has taught modern dance to several student generations at Brooklyn College, gathered a devoted following that filled the house for her company's concert Saturday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: Accounts
description: * Chips & Twigs, a Philadelphia-based boys' wear company, to Levy, Flaxman & Associates.

title: WILFREDO LAM, 80, A PAINTER, IS DEAD
description: Wilfredo Lam, a Cuban-born Surrealist painter who lived in Europe, has died at his home in Paris, friends said Saturday. He was 80 years old and had been ill for years.

title: Clifford Hauser Weds Janice Olson on Coast
description: Janice Lynn Olson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Olson of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Clifford Hauser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hauser of Sands Point, L.I. Justice of the Peace Robert Krug of San Bernardino, Calif., performed the ceremony at the Roeder Pavilion in Coronado, Calif.

title: No Headline
description: 4 DISSIDENTS' TRIAL IS ON IN WARSAW

title: ISLANDERS IN GOOD SHAPE
description: With outside temperatures close to 80 degrees, the Islanders opened training camp today in Cantiague Park minus their star defenseman, Denis Potvin, who has yet to agree with the club on a new contract.

title: VATICAN REPLIES ANGRILY TO ISRAEL OVER POPE'S PLAN TO MEET ARAFAT
description: The Vatican rejected today as ''an outrage to the truth'' an Israeli Government condemnation of the decision of Pope John Paul II to receive Yasir Arafat.

title: It Was a U.S. Open To Be Remembered
description: When the United States Open tennis championships were shifted from Forest Hills to Flushing Meadows in 1978, traditionalists lamented that the game would never be the same. They were right, but the changes were not necessarily for the worse.

title: BOARD EXPECTED TO BACK LINCOLN WEST PROPOSAL
description: The Lincoln West housing proposal, which would transform the largest remaining piece of undeveloped land in Manhattan into a luxury complex to house 10,000 people, is likely to win approval from the Board of Estimate on Thursday if certain modifications are made, officials indicated yesterday.

title: NORTH KOREANS BAR A U.S. MEETING WITH G.I.
description: United States officials accused North Korea today of being ''unreasonable and inhumane'' for refusing to allow an American soldier to speak with his Army superiors and relatives about whether he had defected to the Communist nation.

title: Bridge: Princeton Wins a Victory With an Assist From Yale
description: One of America's oldest bridge organizations is the College Clubs Bridge League. It was founded in New York City half a century ago, and its members play a schedule of team, open pair and mixed pair events. The 1982 team championship was recently captured by the Princeton Club, which won the crucial match by 26 international match points against its old rival the Yale Club.

title: MAVERICK ON THE BEACH
description: Down at the Beach Luncheonette, the early morning coffee drinkers will tell you that Doris Gagnon lives just down the beach a ways at the edge of the tall marsh grass - one of them adding with goodly amounts of pride and respect: ''and nobody's about to move her neither.''

title: CAREY POISED TO GIVE UP KOCH-CUOMO NEUTRALITY
description: Despite an earlier pledge of neutrality, Governor Carey has discussed with Mayor Koch an endorsement of Mr. Koch's bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor over Mr. Carey's Lieutenant Governor, Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Political Signals; Obedience
description: Joseph Margiotta, the convicted extortionist who clings to Nassau County's Republican chairmanship, suspects a conspiracy to oust him before his appeals are exhausted. Last week he accused State Senator Ralph Marino of being part of the scheme.

title: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-The qr includes a $266,000 loss from discontinued operations while the 9 mos is after a loss of $1.8 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $357,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
POLITICAL SIGNALS; Experiment
description: Time-honored political theory holds that the best response to corruption is a good old-fashioned election. But modern political scientists also point to much evidence for a contradictory corollary - namely, that political re-form is usually short-lived.

title: STAGE: 'SOAP,' A MUSICAL
description: EXCEPT for one tired spoof of daytime serials, ''Soap'' belies its title in several senses of the word. It is a coarse little musical that has a pretense of sophistication, but ends up as a kind of nocalorie ''Oh! Calcutta!'' Although there is only a minimum of nudity, there is a great deal of suggestive dialogue and behavior, and there is one number - a quartet dancing behind a sheet - that might have been dropped from that long-running musical.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DIANA VREELAND'S WAY
description: JUDITH JERDE was clearly in charge, and she explained the ultrasonic bath that launders fragile old fabric by sound waves, noted that a fluff of blue silk and flowers was the crown of an important hat that was about to be joined to its newly repaired straw brim, and moved on through the back corners of the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute. In the mannequin room, she introduced the lithe, featureless dummies that are to accommodate the antique dresses, many of which were still in a state of disrepair.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE LEBANON POSITIONS OF SYRIA AND P.L.O.
description: Israel launched an all-day series of air strikes today against Syrian and Palestinian positions in central and eastern Lebanon, attacking artillery emplacements, machine guns, antitank weapons, command posts and a new Syrian anti-aircraft missile battery.

title: Murdoch in Pact For Buffalo Paper
description: Rupert Murdoch, publisher of The New York Post and other newspapers, announced today that he had agreed to take over The Buffalo Courier-Express if substantial cuts in labor and operating costs could be negotiated with the paper's unions.

title: Judge Starts to Pick Gibson Trial's Jury
description: Jury selection in the trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris on charges of conspiracy and misconduct got under way here today, and is expected to last until the end of the week.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a $752,638 extraordinary gain

title: HEARINGS BEGIN IN BRINK'S CASE AMID PROTESTERS
description: Pretrial hearings in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and murder case began today and were almost immediately overwhelmed by revolutionary slogans.

title: INTERPRETATION OF CLEAN WATER LAW UNCHANGED, U.S. OFFICIAL ASSERTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had made no reinterpretation of the Clean Water Act and that it was not encouraging a reduction of efforts to clean up municipal sewage across the country.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S.O.C. Names Lake Placid a Site
description: The United States Olympic Committee today named Lake Placid as the winter-sports training site for Olympic athletes, state officials said.

title: LOUIS WALDMAN, 90, COUNSEL TO LABOR
description: Louis Waldman, a former Socialist State Assemblyman who became one of the city's foremost labor lawyers, died Sunday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: U.N.-SOUTH AFRICA TALKS ON NAMIBIA CONTINUE
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said today that South Africa was ready to move for a cease-fire and an internationally supervised election in South-West Africa as soon as Cuban soldiers withdrew from neighboring Angola.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Case closed again.'' - Larry Speakes, deputy White House press secretary, on the investigation into allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. (A1:4.)

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Canadian Pacific Payout
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. cut its quarterly dividend by 12.5 cents, to 35 cents a share, payable Oct. 28 to shareholders of record Sept. 27, the Toronto Stock Exchange said today.

title: PRINCESS GRACE BREAKS THIGH
description: Princess Grace of Monaco received multiple fractures, including a broken thigh, and her 17-yearold daughter, Stephanie, was slightly injured today when a vintage car driven by the former American movie star lost its brakes, plunged off a mountain road and caught fire.

title: NILSSON IS HOPING FOR CHANGE OF LUCK
description: Ulf Nilsson has followed all the rehabilitation instructions. He has done all the conditioning exercises. His surgically-repaired right knee feels sound enough to give him hope that his fifth season as a New York Ranger will not be marred by injuries the way his first four seasons were.

title: STORE SALES OFF BY 0.9% IN AUGUST
description: Sales by retail outlets in the United States fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today. The results reversed a rise in July and punctured hopes that the 10 percent income tax cut of July 1 would spur sales and help pull the nation out of recession.

title: A JOB FOR SLAVE LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS POLICIES ARE ASSAILED
description: Opposition groups threatened to disrupt the start of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's official trip to the United States Tuesday and to stage protests against what they say are human rights violations in the Philippines.

title: Perrault Gets 128 for Marlboro Cup
description: Perrault, the leading candidate for horse of the year, will make his New York debut Saturday in the Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park despite being assigned the top weight of 128 pounds.

title: Chase C.D.'s Remain on List
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has retained certificates of deposit of the Chase Manhattan Bank among those that can be used to settle futures contracts.

title: Gasoline Price Moves Lower
description: Slack demand for gasoline caused prices to fall to an average $1.27 a gallon in late August and brought on sharper competition among self-service stations, Dan Lundberg, an oil industry analyst, said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Continental Group filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million of debt securities.

title: One More Wager
description: The five or six thousand racegoers at Latonia, the Florence, Ky., track eight miles south of Cincinnati, will have an unusual chance of getting even Saturday. A 10th race has been added to the nine-race card, and it is a race that will be run at Belmont Park.

title: NEWS IN THE PRESS BUILDING IS DUSTY
description: The bar in the National Press Building has been surpassed, at least temporarily, as the greatest hazard to the health of the reporters and public relations people who make up most of the building's tenants,

title: EXPERTS CHALLENGE LOW-SODIUM DIET
description: The widely held view that most Americans should reduce their salt or other sodium intake to prevent the development of high blood pressure was challenged by experts at a scientific conference here today.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intersessional Committee of the Whole of Development Program Governing Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FLAIR FOR THE OFFICE
description: No definitive guide to the way working women should dress has yet emerged from the fashion world. A few self-proclaimed seers have advised tailored suits, preferably in gray flannel or navy blue gabardine. A few shops, such as La Cabine on the East Side and Streets and Co. on the West Side, offer a more extensive range and some personalized suggestions.

title: Changes in Hockey
description: The three Stastny brothers -Marian, Peter and Anton - were absent at the Quebec Nordiques' training camp for the second day. The Stastnys, native Czechoslovaks who are now residents of Quebec, are seeking to have their contracts renegotiated.

title: Ensign-Bickford Goes To Monsanto for Chief
description: Ensign-Bickford Industries is a little known but by all accounts highly successful privately held company in Simsbury, Conn., that makes products ranging from detonators to paints.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $81,300

title: TWO DECADES LATER...
description: I didn't read many newspapers on vacation - on the theory that you can skip a month or two of media saturation, sometimes even a year or two, and miss very little - but one headline did catch my eye for autobiographical reasons.

title: MONTERREY EXECUTIVES ANGRY
description: Since the late 1800's, business here has been run by an extended family of industrialists known as the Monterrey Group who favored their independence and savored the 400 miles that separates their valley of steel, chemical and glass factories from the Government in Mexico City to the south.

title: Japan's Third Typhoon Leaves 26 Dead and Many Homeless
description: The third typhoon to pound Japan's main islands this season roared off into the northern seas today, leaving behind at least 26 people dead and tens of thousands of homes and businesses flooded.

title: TOWERS SHUT IN CONTROLLERS' STRIKE REOPEN
description: Nearly half the control towers closed at 80 small airports because of the strike by air traffic controllers last year will be reopened by early January, according to Government officials.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Q & A
description: Q. Why do the planets orbit the Sun in the ellipses of Kepler rather than the circles of Copernicus?

title: P.L.O.'S FUTURE
description: One way to explain Prime Minister Menachem Begin's hysterical response to President Reagan's initiative for Middle East peace is to look at the paradoxical outcome of the Lebanese war: the Palestine Liberation Organization's apparent decision to rely largely on political means rather than terrorist activities. As long as the P.L.O. upholds this decision, Mr. Begin has reason to be worried, since his main objective in waging the war has not been achieved.

title: Energy Sources Shifts Top Staff After Losses
description: Energy Sources Inc., an oil and gas company in Dallas that has posted losses recently, said that E. Eugene Mason, its chairman and chief executive, had resigned in a management realignment.

title: Rome Bank Is Robbed
description: Thieves working quietly during the weekend cut their way into the vaults of the Banca del Credito Artigiano and got away with $7 million, the police said today.

title: AMID HI-FI'S AND AK-47'S, A LIBYAN IDENTITY CRISIS
description: The Libyan official's office was bedecked with the badges of modernity - a video system linked to a state of the art television set, a bank of multicolored telephones, a desk whose square footage betokened status. And on the television in full color was another rerun of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's latest major pronouncement. But the official, Information Secretary Abdul Rahman Shalgam, was not altogether happy.

title: Stock Group to Sue U.S.
description: The Securities Industry Association, the trade group for the nation's brokerage industry, said yesterday that it would sue the Comptroller of the Currency in an attempt to block the nation's banks from establishing or acquiring brokerage houses.

title: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After $162,000 gain from sale of property

title: WLADYSLAW GOMULKA AND HIS REGIME
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCEL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2,000 Mass Graves Are Found In Cambodia, Vietnam Says
description: More than 2,000 mass graves have been found in the Cambodian provinces of Kandal and Soairieng, and initial excavations have uncovered the remains of about 54,000 people, Vietnam's official Hanoi radio reported today.

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically
description: When the men of the 23d Precinct talk about their female colleagues, Eileen Hemmerich's name invariably comes up. The men may not know the facts of the incident involving Officer Hemmerich last November - conflicting versions abound -but they talk about it all the same. To them the incident illustrates why, 10 years after women came on uniformed patrol in New York City, many male officers still have deep reservations about officers of the opposite sex. Of the 130 officers in the precinct, only a half-dozen belong to the new and rapidly growing generation of young women who are officers. Their performance, according to the precinct commander, Capt. John J. Murphy, ''measures up to the command as a whole.'' But the prevailing sentiment among the male officers - one that is rarely conveyed to the ''bosses'' but that has so clouded relations in the precinct that a number of men have asked not to be assigned to work with women - was expressed by Officer Harry Wolfe:

title: A Crystal Soviet Spirit
description: That was a remarkable letter that Andrei Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and political dissenter, managed to get to the recent Pugwash Conference in Warsaw. Written without rancor, it raises the argument over nuclear weapons out of the ruck of sloganeering.

title: WHITE HOUSE RESPONDS TO ATTACK ON RIGHTS RECORD
description: The Reagan Administration today denied charges of a ''dangerous deterioration'' in civil rights enforcement and contended that its rights record was ''stronger than any previous administration.''

title: STEELERS SET BACK COWBOYS BY 36-28
description: Terry Bradshaw, drilling passes to his wide receivers, John Stallworth and Jim Smith, threw three touchdown passes as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 36-28, tonight in the National Football League's first Monday game of the season.

title: Polish Minister in Moscow
description: Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski of Poland arrived here today on a two-day visit for talks. He met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to discuss Soviet-Polish relations, the press agency Tass said.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago net income includes a net gain on the sale of property of $225,000 or 23 cents a shr

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOR A NEW YORK COUPLE, 30 SECONDS FROM DEATH
description: ''How close did we come to dying? Another 30 seconds and we wouldn't have been able to breathe any more.'' That was the conclusion of Donald P. Delliquanti of Kew Gardens, Queens, who, along with his wife, Mary Gibbons, survived the crash of a charter McDonnell Douglas DC-10 as it tried to take off yesterday from Malaga, Spain. Officials said at least 46 of the 393 people on board died in the accident.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $226,000

title: Malone Clause Is Voided
description: An arbitrator yesterday invalidated one bonus clause of the offer sheet signed by Moses Malone with the Philadelphia 76ers, but reserved decision on four other bonus clauses that have been disputed.

title: PUNT RETURN HAS DOLPHINS OFF ON ROUT
description: Returning punts in professional football is a high-risk business. It takes speed, courage, good hands, sure instincts and a certain flair for the dramatic. A fumble, a missed block, almost anything can turn opportunity into disaster.

title: RISING PRESSURE IS EXPECTED FOR MORE RAILROAD MERGERS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission's endorsement of the acquisition by the Union Pacific of the Missouri Pacific and the Western Pacific is likely to increase the pressure for more railroad combinations, Wall Street analysts and industry executives said yesterday.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Raiding a Name
description: Allen Neiman, a Beverly Hills lawyer, had a clever idea in 1979. He applied to the office of the California Secretary of State for exclusive rights to the corporate name ''Los Angeles Raiders.''

title: WESTMORELAND FILES LIBEL SUIT AGAINST CBS
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, former commander of United States military forces in Vietnam, filed a libel suit yesterday against CBS Inc. for its portrayal of him in January in a documentary, ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AUTO UNION REJECTS CHRYSLER COST-OF-LIVING OFFER AS 'ANEMIC'
description: The United Automobile Workers today rejected as inadequate the Chrysler Corporation's first offer on wages. The wage offer for a two-year pact was made yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Choosing Sides

title: 12 STATES HOLDING PRIMARIES TODAY
description: Five well-known incumbents face serious challenges Tuesday in the year's fullest slate of primary elections. They are Senators Howard W. Cannon of Nevada and Robert T. Stafford of Vermont, Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts, Mayor Marion Barry of the District of Columbia and Representative Clement J. Zablocki of Wisconsin.

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BETH HENLEY'S NEW OFFBEAT PLAY IS IN REHEARSAL
description: ONE day a friend happened to tell Beth Henley an unlikely story about his uncle. It seems the poor man was kicked in the head by a cow and dropped dead. Somehow, the story lodged itself inside Miss Henley's offbeat imagination - the same one that produced the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Crimes of the Heart'' - and developed into a full-length play. Miss Henley's latest drama is called ''The Wake of Jamey Foster,'' and it will open Oct. 14 at the Eugene O'Neill.

title: Control Data Buys Firm
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it had acquired Tabershaw Associates, a computer-based employee health protection and monitoring systems company. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition will make it possible for Control Data to add a number of software components and consulting services to its own occupational health system, which has been marketed since 1980, it said.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EVERYONE was ''just back.'' That was the standard greeting among fashionable New Yorkers last w eek as the city shimmered with the glitter of early fall openings, o f fashion shows and of several dinners. European designers also a rrived, including Gianni Versace, Gianfranco Ferre, Thierry Mugler a nd Valentino.

title: Democrats Seek Fast Action In House on $1 Billion Job Bill
description: Democratic leaders, victorious last week in overriding a Presidential spending veto, today scheduled fast House action on a $1 billion jobs bill, and urged President Reagan to support it.

title: FOR NORDIC ROYALTY, THE WELCOME IS REGAL
description: A cast of royalty right out of a Nordic fairy tale strolled on a red carpet down Fifth Avenue last night. The strollers included three Nordic princes and two princesses, as well as the President of Iceland and the Foreign Minister of Finland.

title: Layoffs by Ford, Manville and G.E.
description: The Ford Motor Company of Canada Ltd. said it had laid off 4,700 workers at two assembly plants here for one week, and that they would return to work Sept. 20. It said it had idled 3,000 car assembly workers because of a shortage of certain auto parts and 1,700 truck assembly workers to reduce high inventories.

title: Protest Over PCB Dump
description: Chanting slogans and waving signs, 400 people on Sunday picketed a site planned as a dump for polychlorinated biphenyls.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CBS OPEN COVERAGE OFTEN SERVED ITSELF
description: A viewer keeping an intermittent eye on CBS's weekend coverage of the United States Open might have missed some dramatic rallies, but he could scarcely have avoided learning that Mike Wallace is working on a profile of Martina Navratilova for ''60 Minutes.'' On no fewer than three occasions on Saturday, CBS's tennis commentators reported that piece of trivia as the network's cameras panned to Mr. Wallace sitting next to Miss Navratilova in the stands. And on Sunday, the cameras panned to Mr. Wallace four more times.

title: FED POLICY ON MONEY IS PRAISED
description: A group of longtime critics of the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday in their semiannual policy statement that the outlook for the economy next year was uncertain but praised the Fed's recent success in lowering the growth rate of the money supply.

title: Big Man on Virginia's Lawn
description: The idea has occurred to the residents of The Lawn, the community of small rooms that has become the most prestigious student address the University of Virginia can offer, that perhaps there should be cards placed on each of the 54 doors to answer the inevitable tourist question.

title: Harvester Plans Share Offering
description: The International Harvester Company said it would ask stockholders to approve a new offering of common shares as part of its financial restructuring.

title: LEBANESE REPORT 40 KILLED IN RAIDS
description: The Lebanese state-run radio reported that 40 people were killed or wounded during Israeli air attacks today.

title: Captain of Cruise Ship Blamed in Fatal Accident
description: The captain of the cruise ship Majestic Explorer, which ran aground in an accident Friday in which a passenger was killed, failed to navigate the vessel properly or assure safe evacuation, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Occidental Oil Find
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced today that its Argentine subsidiary had discovered a new oilfield in Argentina, with a well testing 3,586 barrels of 32-degree oil daily in the Mendoza area. Occidental said that the discovery was the first by the subsidiary since exploratory drilling began at the end of 1981. Occidental has a 37.5 percent interest in the contract area, which covers 518,000 acres.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July
description: B-Includes a $95,076 loss from discontinued operations

title: Advertising; Woman's Day Turns To TV
description: 'Great writing, great graphics and great promotion, that's what success in magazine publishing is all about,'' said Peter G. Diamandis, publisher of Woman's Day. ''It's a very simple business. The risk is not to do it.'' He was about to shove off for the Montauk Yacht Club, where he would tell some 100 people from the business side about his ''blockbuster promotion scheme for consumer and trade.''

title: OAKLAND TRIBUNE IS TO BE RENAMED
description: The Oakland Tribune, once one of the proudest names in California journalism, will be subordinated soon as the Gannett Company moves the paper from the afternoon to the morning field.

title: Chess: Tal and Garcia Are Ahead At the Moscow Interzonal
description: After four rounds of the third Interzonal Tournament, in Moscow - the second stage of qualifications to select a challenger for the world championship - Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union and Guillermo Garcia of Cuba shared the lead with 3 1/2 points.

title: LOAN FORECLOSURES ROSE TO RECORD IN 2D QUARTER
description: The percentage of American homeowners facing loan foreclosure proceedings rose to a record in the second quarter of 1982, a mortgage lenders' association said today.

title: N.F.L. STRIKE LOOKS INEVITABLE
description: Now that the National Football League season has begun, when will it be interrupted by a labor dispute? For some, that would be a disaster worse than a fumble run back 91 yards for a touchdown. But for others, it would be a pleasure. That was apparent when a television voice shouted - why do they always seem to be shouting? - about the possibility of a strike, and the woman of the house suddenly looked up from her reverie.

title: No Headline
description: CARLTON'S 20TH PUTS PHILS IN FIRST PLACE

title: Zambian Official Is Accused Of Selling Flood Victims' Aid
description: Rajah Kunda, Minister of Power, Transport and Communications, appeared in a magistrate's court here today on charges of selling flood relief supplies for personal profit.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. COMPUTER FIGHT IN BRITAIN
description: A major dispute has broken out between United States computer companies and British officials. The Americans charge that unfair preference is frequently given to British concerns in sales to public agencies.

title: Cotton Fire in Le Havre
description: A warehouse fire here destroyed about $35 million worth of cotton, a police spokesman said today.

title: Market Place; Hanover Bank Favors Bonds
description: LET'S say you're in charge of managing $18 billion in discretionary assets at a major New York City bank. How do you slice up your portfolio pie these days?

title: SCHOOL OPENS, AND 904,000 MAKE THE BEST OF IT
description: The stuffed animal that goes everywhere with 5-year-old Eric Benderisky went to Public School 9 yesterday. It was Eric's first day of school and Puppy Dog's, too. Eric held one paw, and Eric's mother, Ruth, held the other, and that was the way they arrived at 100 West 84th Street. Eric said he was O.K. His mother said she was nervous.

title: A LAST-DITCH BID TO SAVE 'ALL SAVERS'
description: Faced with a possible heavy loss of deposits in October when the first of the tax-exempt ''all savers'' certificates mature, the savings and loan industry has mounted a last-ditch campaign to persuade Congress to extend sales of the certificates beyond 1982 and make them more attractive to savers.

title: A New Medical Network Is Announced
description: The American Medical Association today unveiled what was called the largest and most extensive medical information network ever devised to provide doctors with instant data ranging from what drugs to prescribe to how to manage their practices.

title: CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $4.4 million...C-Net loss; the company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange

title: No Headline
description: 46 DIE AS A NEW YORK-BOUND JETLINER CRASHES IN SPAIN

title: BRIEFS
description: * The Ethiopian Government said it planned a $100 million hotel in Addis Ababa, to be managed by the Sheraton Hotels unit of International Telephone and Telegraph Corp.

title: Playbill to Be Sold Via Newsstands
description: Playbill, the venerable but continually evolving theater program of Broadway, is going to try something very new next month: single copy newsstand and subscription sales.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Girl on Wagon Train Dies
description: The death of a teen-ager who fell from a mule-drawn wagon train on a bridge has been ruled accidental. The teen-ager, Tammy Edmiston of Scranton, 16 years old, had been ''clowning around,'' according to Deputy Coroner Dennis Johns.

title: PIPELINE ISSUE: BRITONS' CHIEF COMPLAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALAN HOLMES, FEDERAL RESERVE MONEY EXPERT
description: Alan R. Holmes, who had been one of the most powerful men in the nation's financial system, died yesterday morning in his Brooklyn apartment from coronary artery disease, according to Elliot Gross, New York's chief medical examiner. He was 62 years old.

title: A Dubious Deal for City Workers
description: Mammoth figures leap from the page describing the Koch administration's new labor contract with New York's non-uniformed employees. Over two years, the 8 and 7 percent annual increases will cost $1.05 billion more than the expiring agreements. Nevertheless Mayor Koch contends the deal makes him happy, and he hopes to persuade fire, police, correction and sanitation workers to settle for the same.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TRIAL TO OPEN TODAY IN LAWSUIT OVER NUCLEAR FALLOUT
description: For 12 years, beginning in 1951, more than 100 atomic bombs were detonated at a test site above the Nevada desert west of here, sending huge plumes of radioactive dust and debris across the desolate red mesas and rocky buttes of southern Utah and northern Arizona.

title: MARIETTA, ARMED WITH CREDIT, VOWS TO PURSUE BENDIX TO END
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the diversified aerospace concern that is locked in a tangled, three-way takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation, said yesterday that it would proceed with its $1.5 billion offer to buy control of Bendix even if Bendix were successful in its efforts to acquire Marietta.

title: TV: HUNT FOR A TERRORIST
description: WHEN a made-for-television movie, normally designed to fill up two hours of schedule space, comes in at 90 minutes, it is reasonable to assume the production ran into trouble. When a television movie is being dumped during rerun time before the beginning of a new season, the trouble has obviously escalated into full-fledged disaster. Such a movie is ''Moonlight,'' which can be seen on CBS at 8:30 this evening.

title: DEVELOPING CRUCIAL SKILLS FOR STUDYING
description: HIGH school students are naturally concerned about what they will learn in college; but for a great many entering freshmen, how to learn is the crucial question. According to the College Board, nearly half of all students come to college without the study skills to cope with the new academic tasks. Next week, a group of experts from Harvard University and Milton Academy, a private college-preparatory school near Boston, will publish a special student text and teacher's guide to help students develop the study skills to help them succeed in college and in life.

title: TRIAL RULED IN 1953 DEATH CASE
description: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that a trial should be held on a lawsuit concerning the death of a man who had ''unknowingly served as a test subject in an Army chemical warfare experiment.''

title: WHERE A COCAINE DEALER LOST HIS LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $355,900

title: An Added Starter
description: Glen Ryan is a 20-year-old American male whose taste in participatory sports runs to football and baseball. So how did he wind up in Australia, trying out for something called ''Footy?''

title: EPISCOPALIANS MOVE FORWARD QUIETLY
description: The Episcopal Church closes its 67th General Convention in New Orleans tomorrow, intent on mending old wounds in the 2.75-millionmember denomination and carefully choosing the struggles it will enter in the 1980's.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sentiment and Reality

title: THE DETECTIVE HAD SO MUCH TO LEARN
description: THINK of computer games, and one thinks of shoot-'em-up, gobble'em-up visuals flashing across the colored screen. For better or for worse - and one can't help but feel that in many ways it's worse - these motor coordination tests have become, in the space of a mere couple of years, probably the greatest cultural force among the youth of the Western world.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'A Day at the Races,' Unexpurgated

title: Cray Cuts Price
description: Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis said it was cutting prices on its top-of-the-line X-MP series of supercomputers and introducing the Cray-1M series to replace the S series at a lower cost. The X-MP will sell for $9 million to $11 million, compared with the previous $11.4 milion to $14.5 million. Prices on the M series will extend from $4 million to $7 million, compared with $8.5 million to $13.3 million for the comparable S series.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fashion vs. Comfort

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SUCCESS STORY

title: Sabine Asset Sale
description: The Sabine Corporation of Dallas said it had agreed to sell its Canadian assets and properties to the Cooperative Energy Corporation's exploration and development subsidiary for about $103 million (Canadian). Closing of the transaction, which covers oil and gas producing lands as well as undeveloped properties, is expected in early 1983, the company said.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1982
description: International Israeli air strikes continued all day against Syrian and Palestinian positions in central and eastern Lebanon. Officials in Jerusalem said bombings were being made because of a long run of attacks on Israeli troops, mostly by forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization using Syrian-held territory as cover. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Reagan Administration reacted to the latest outbreak of fighting in Lebanon with the statement that it was ''extremely concerned,'' adding that the fighting underscored the need to negotiate ''as quickly as possible'' the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. (A1:5.)

title: Bus Strikers Back DeCamp Contract
description: Drivers and mechanics of the DeCamp Bus Company, who have been on strike for more than seven weeks, ratified a three-year contract yesterday. As a result, bus service is expected to be restored by Saturday between New York and Essex County in New Jersey for 4,500 commuters.

title: UNITED STATES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
S.E.C. IS CRITICIZED FOR CITICORP STAND
description: A former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division told a Congressional panel today that the S.E.C. would become ''irrelevant'' if it were to adopt some of the arguments it used last year in deciding not to bring an enforcement action against Citicorp.

title: 11 Black Colleges Awarded $450,000 in Federal Grants
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has awarded $450,000 in community development grants to 11 black colleges and universities.

title: LATE RALLY SENDS DOWN UP 11.87
description: A late rally in the blue-chip and technology issues enabled the stock market to register a sharp gain yesterday in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off 1.10 points at 2:30 P.M., closed up 11.87 points, to 918.69. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 59.5 million shares from 71.1 million shares on Friday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allied Corp. said A. Clark Johnson had been named president of Allied Chemical Co., an operating unit. He had been executive vice president.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: McFeeley's Farewell

title: Bernazard Breaks Leg
description: The Chicago White Sox, a not-too-distant third-place team in the American League West, will have to make it the rest of the way without their valuable second baseman, Tony Bernazard, who fractured his left leg Sunday in a 4-2 loss to Oakland. Bernazard, who had 56 runs batted in this season, was injured when he made a backhand stab of a hit up the middle by Wayne Gross, then threw to first. When he turned to throw, he said, he ''heard something crack.''

title: CITY UNIVERSITY LAW SCHOOL TAKES A NEW APPROACH
description: BLESSED with a unique mandate and a minimum of entrenched academic traditions to block their way, the designers of the new City University of New York Law School at Queens College are creating what leading legal educators have often only wistfully called for - a thoroughly overhauled law school curriculum.

title: HOUSE DEBATES BILL TO EXTEND DRUG PATENT TERM BY 7 YEARS
description: The House today debated a bill that drug makers said would spur development of innovative cures but consumer advocates said would rob sick people of billions of dollars. A vote is scheduled for Wednesday.

title: Somali Guerrillas Tell Of Success in Combat
description: Guerrilla forces of the Western Somali Liberation Front said today that they had started new operations into the Ogaden region of southeast Ethiopia.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The fiscal 1982 results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 regarding foreign currency translation

title: Sohio Unit Accord
description: The Reserve Oil and Minerals Corporation said it had settled all litigation with the Sohio Western Mining Company, giving the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) unit a 50 percent interest in a uranium venture and half interest in the surface of a 120,000-acre ranch near Seyboyeta, N.M. The agreement cancels Reserve's $35.3 million debt to Sohio and pays Reserve's $12.7 million obligation to the Baldwin Minerals Corporation and the Chemical Bank of New York. Sohio also paid Reserve $310,000 and gave it 75 percent mineral rights to a 57,000-acre tract and about a 4 percent royalty on a 60,000-acre tract.

title: Continental Telecom Chooses Lord, Geller
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, that little gem in the JWT Group crown, has emerged triumphant from a four-way competition with the corporate advertising account of the Atlanta-based Continental Telecom.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore, twilight-night doubleheader. The Orioles start Scott McGregor and Storm Davis against Shane Rawley and Mike Morgan in an attempt to gain ground on the first-place Milwaukee Brewers.

title: RATES DIP AS FED ADDS FUNDS
description: Interest rates declined yesterday after the Federal Reserve added funds to the banking system through temporary purchases of securities.

title: BANKING AGAINST DISASTER
description: If we had a truth-in-Government act comparable to the truth-inadvertising law, every note issued by the Treasury would be obliged to include a sentence stating: ''This note will be redeemed with the proceeds from an identical note which will be sold to the public when this one comes due.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHEN THE WIND BLOWS. By Raymond Briggs. Unpaginated. Schocken. $10.95.

title: United and Delta To Share Systems
description: United Airlines and Delta Air Lines said they had agreed that each would market the other's computerized passenger reservations and accounting systems to travel agencies, commercial accounts and governmental agencies.

title: Army Copters Grounded After Weekend Crash
description: The United States Army grounded its more than 400 CH-47 Chinook helicopters today as it sought to learn what caused a weekend crash that killed 46 people at a Mannheim air show.

title: Mrs. Gandhi to Visit Brezhnev Next Week
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and Leonid I. Brezhnev will hold two meetings next week in Moscow, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: ENERGY IS ROOKIE'S KEY
