description: Pat Verbeek, the 18-year-old third-round draft choice of the New Jersey Devils, carefully unwrapped the cellophane and held the chocolate cup cake with the squiggly white line on top.

title: DEFENSE OUT OF THE CLOSET
description: If conclusive evidence were needed that peace movements have shaken up Western establishments, the International Institute for Strategic Studies has just provided it.

title: No Headline
description: COMPANY NEWS; G.M. Sees Rebound In U.S. Car Sales

title: RENEWED FIGHTING WORRYING THE U.S.
description: The United States said today that it was ''extremely concerned'' by the outbreak of fighting in Lebanon and that it underscored the need to negotiate the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon ''as quickly as possible.''

title: SENATE ABORTION FOES LOSE AGAIN
description: The Senate, despite President Reagan's urging, fell 15 votes short today in its second effort to end a liberal filibuster that has been blocking action on anti-abortion legislation.

title: A BASIC PARTICLE OF THE UNIVERSE MAY BE DECAYING
description: DEEP in the heart of Mont Blanc, in a 134-ton iron detector mounted inside a chamber alongside the highway tunnel that links France and Italy through Western Europe's highest mountain, an event has been recorded by nuclear physicists who regard it as the strongest candidate so far for the decay of a proton.

title: Dangerous Maxim?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AID TO ISRAEL, PUT IN PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: GROWTH OF A COAST LAW FIRM
description: When William French Smith left Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher in 1981 to become the United States Attorney General, his law firm scarcely missed a beat.

title: INQUIRY ON DONOVAN AGAIN YIELDS 'INSUFFICIENT EVIDENCE' TO PROSECUTE
description: A special Federal prosecutor yesterday announced for the second time that he had found no prosecutable evidence of organized-crime connections involving Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. He said some of the allegations against Mr. Donovan had been fabricated.

title: METAL CONCERN GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: A New York metals corporation, its president and 14 of its salesmen were convicted of fraud and securities law violations last night in what the State Attorney General called ''the most ambitious'' prosecution ever brought by his office.

title: Ridgewood Grove Returns to Roots
description: In 1956, after 30 years as one of the top fight clubs in the world, the Ridgewood Grove became a supermarket. Tony Canzoneri, who fought on the first card Nov. 6, 1926, and such greats and near greats as Kid Chocolate, Al Singer, Ruby Goldstein, Billy Graham, Sandy Saddler, Tony Janiro, Gus Lesnevich and Al (Bummy) Davis, were replaced, quite literally, by tomato cans and other groceries.

title: 3 RAILROADS GIVEN APPROVAL BY I.C.C. TO MERGE IN WEST
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, creating a vast new rail system linking the Middle West, Southwest and Pacific Coast, authorized today the merger of three railroads - the Union Pacific, the Missouri Pacific and the Western Pacific.

title: WILLIAM E. BROADHURST
description: William E. Broadhurst, a Tulsa oil executive and philanthropist who donated money to more than 20 colleges, died Sunday at a nursing home here.

title: FALKLAND SANCTIONS MAY END
description: The British Treasury announced from London today that Britain and Argentina had agreed to mutually lift financial restrictions tonight, but the Argentine Government denied that an agreement exists and said it was studying the proposal.

title: Korey, Kay & Partners Gets Playboy Hotel
description: Korey, Kay & Partners was dealt a good hand yesterday: the advertising account for the Playboy Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1982; The Economy
description: The I.C.C. authorized the merger of the Union Pacific, Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific railroads, creating a vast new rail system linking the Middle West, Southwest and Pacific Coast. The surviving entity, the Union Pacific, would become the nation's thirdlargest railroad in miles of track and the largest in annual revenue. (Page A1.) The decision is likely to increase the pressure for more rail mergers, Wall Street analysts said. (D5.)

title: FOUR YOUTHS KILLED IN CONNECTICUT AS TRUCK CRASHES IN POLICE CHASE
description: Four teen-aged youths were killed and two others injured in Newtown, Conn., Friday night when their pickup truck crashed while being chased by the police.

title: Chain Offers Chicken; To Baltimore; Voters
description: A restaurant chain is offering free food to voters here on primary day.

title: FRANK'S 'JOSEPHA'
description: CHRISTOPHER FRANK'S ''Josepha'' is admirably sincere and serious, but it isn't very convincing, unfortunately. As tales of marital breakup go, this one is rather lacking in emotion yet all too full of unlikely coincidences. ''Josepha'' is at the Paris.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Deadline for Ethics

title: STUDY STRESSES SHIFT IN U.S. SPENDING
description: A nonpartisan study of President Reagan's domestic program said today that it represented the most dramatic shift in economic and social policy since the time of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Chemical Fire Forces Evacuation in Charlotte
description: Thousands of people in a 12-squaremile area fled their homes tonight as chemicals, including the herbicide paraquat, burst into flame in a downtown warehouse, the authorities said.

title: WORLD COLLEGE TO OPEN U.S. CAMPUS
description: At the site of a 19th-century resort where America's rich and powerful once came for the benefits of the thermal waters, the first American campus of an experiment in international education will open Tuesday.

title: South Pacific Rebel Seized
description: Jimmy Stevens, leader of an unsuccessful rebellion in 1980 in the former French-British colony of New Hebrides, now the nation of Vanuatu, escaped from jail Sunday night but was recaptured today, official sources in Port Vila said.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-net loss; the shr earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock divd in Jan 1981

title: FRENCH ARE SILENT ON BOOK ON DE GAULLE
description: In a country where the political style is not usually one of long, telling silences, people notice quiet. Early this summer when a book of notes and papers of President Georges Pompidou was published saying President Charles de Gaulle literally ran away from trouble during a fit of depression at the height of the May 1968 riots and general strike, the reaction of French politicians was near stillness.

title: 2 Jersey Candidates Get Aid From Bush
description: Vice President George Bush went to New Jersey yesterday to headline fund-raising events for Republican candidates involved in two of the state's closest and most critical Congressional races.

title: Salvador Insurgents Assaulted on Volcano
description: The insurgents' Radio Venceremos said today that two United States-made A-37 fighter planes attacked a Salvadoran leftist guerrilla stronghold at the Guazapa volcano, 20 miles north of the capital.

title: U.P.S. Strike Ends As Another Begins
description: Striking employees of the United Parcel Service returned to their jobs in most of New York City and Westchester and on Long Island yesterday, but the company's services in northern New Jersey and on Staten Island were disrupted by a new walkout.

title: DENG, AS EXPECTED, ELECTED HEAD OF CHINESE ADVISORY COMMISSION
description: To no one's surprise, China's most powerful leader, Deng Xiaoping, was elected chairman today of a newly formed Central Advisory Commission to the Communist Party.

title: Sears Will Shed Its Spanish Unit
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, announced that it had agreed in principle with Galerias Preciados of Madrid to sell its Spanish subsidiary.

title: Open Rules, Openly Arrived At
description: Before a Federal agency can change the rules for spending public funds, it must advertise the revision and invite public comment. This often leads to sensible refinement and sometimes forces withdrawal of ill-conceived changes. But now the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Richard Schweiker, whose spending affects more Americans than any other official's, proposes to change the rules about changing the rules.

title: Koch Extending Lead Over Cuomo in Funds
description: Mayor Koch has broadened his fund-raising lead over Mario M. Cuomo, his rival for the Democratic nomination for Governor, according to the final preprimary financial filings yesterday.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After loss of $201,000 from discontinued lottery-related activities; the shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Apr 1982

title: LESSONS APLENTY FOR JETS, GIANTS
description: A fact of football life has been brought home to the New York Jets: It is better to be ahead than behind.

title: THE TUMULTUOUS DISCOVERY OF INSULIN: FINALLY, HIDDEN STORY IS TOLD
description: The discovery of insulin at the University of Toronto 60 years ago ranks with the greatest moments in the history of medicine. For the first time, diabetic men and women, many of whom were until then doomed to an ineffectual starvation diet followed by coma and death within a year or two, were offered a treatment that restored them, sometimes in just a few weeks, to rosy-cheeked health. But no comprehensive, accurate and detailed account of the course of events that led to so astonishing a leap forward in the treatment of disease has ever appeared - neither at Toronto nor anywhere else.

title: BUILT LINDBERGH'S HISTORIC PLANE
description: T. Claude Ryan, a pioneering aircraft manufacturer and founder of the company that built Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis, died Saturday at his home in San Diego. He was 84 years old.

title: DONNOVAN INQUIRY CHIEF LEON SILVERMAN
description: When he was a young child in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, Leon Silverman recalls, Friday night Sabbath dinners were as much political affairs as they were religious. The discussions, he says, were heated and wide-ranging, covering personalities from Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Rev. Charles Coughlin to David Dubinsky, and they left a mark on him. ''From them came a political awareness, a feeling that everyone has a responsibility to make the lot of the less fortunate a little more bearable,'' he said. That obligation, he added, is even stronger on lawyers, who have a state-certified monopoly in the courts, and he has taken the obligation seriously.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $231,000; the company said that in June 1981 it recorded pretax income of about $461,000 or $228,000 net of income taxes by eliminating a note payable and related accrued interest due to the Small Business Administration as a result of the expiration of the Statute of Limitations

title: Shell Credit Cards
description: The Shell Oil Company said it planned to alter its credit card policies in response to recent moves by other oil companies to collect higher prices for gasoline charged on credit cards than for that bought with cash. But the company did not elaborate. It also said it had increased the price it pays for Michigan sweet crude oil by $1 a barrel, to $32, retroactive to Sept. 1.

title: Rozelle Says Strike Would Be Mistake
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, warned N.F.L. players yesterday that they are ''making a big mistake'' if they think a strike will win them a new collectivebargaining agreement based on a percentage of the owners' gross revenues.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Briefings for Poll-Watchers

title: 'THE FED NEEDS BINOCULARS, NOT A MONOCLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES SPEAKING OUT ON REDUCING THEIR CASELOAD
description: When Justice William J. Brennan Jr. told a group of Federal judges in Philadelphia last week that the Supreme Court's docket was taxing the Justices to the limit of their ''human endurance,'' he moved discussion of the Court's workload to a new plane.

title: Public-TV Corporation Re-elects Its Chairman
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the policy-making Federal agency that oversees public television and radio, has re-elected Sharon Percy Rockefeller of West Virginia as chairman and elected Sonia Landau Corry of New York as vice chairman. Mrs. Corry, one of the two Reagan appointees to the 15-member board, all of whom must have Senate approval, defeated Jose A. Rivera of New York, the incumbent.

title: DEFICIT DOOMS CBS'S CABLE TV ARTS SERVICE
description: CBS Cable became the cable industry's first major programming casualty yesterday when CBS Inc. announced that it would fold the performing-arts network within 90 days.

title: PLANS TO REVISE HOSPITAL RULES STUDIED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration has devised new rules for hospitals that would relax or repeal many of the requirements governing hospital staff qualifications, sanitation, social services, medical libraries and the food served to patients.

title: ORIOLES TRIUMPH, TRAIL BY 2 GAMES
description: The Yankee hitters, who have virtually no chance of showing their power in postseason games, tonight continued their assault of opposing pitchers. Roy Smalley hit two home runs and Dave Winfield belted a homer with the bases loaded.

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After gains on disposition of certain properties of $16,000 for the qr and $845,000 for the 9 mos...C-After gain on disposition of certain properties of $4,409,000

title: Saints' Rogers Sidelined
description: Because of a pulled hamstring, George Rogers, the National Football League's rushing leader last season, will not be available to the New Orleans Saints for two to four weeks. The injury caused Rogers to miss the second half of New Orleans's opening-game loss to St. Louis. ... The star safety for Denver, Steve Foley, broke an arm in the Broncos' loss to San Diego and is expected to miss the rest of the season. ... Another defensive standout who will likely be out the rest of the year is Clay Matthews, the Cleveland linebacker.

title: MAXWELL LEHMAN, 73, HELPED TO DRAFT NEW YORK CHARTER
description: Maxwell Lehman, an expert on city administration who helped to draft New York City's Charter, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 4 Gunmen Kill 3 Supporters Of Pakistan's Military Leader
description: A member of the Pakistani military Government's civilian advisory council and two of his staff were shot dead today, official sources said.

title: Aoki Hurt Again
description: The powerboat racer and restaurateur Rocky Aoki was reported in satisfactory condition in St. Augustine, Fla., yesterday after surgery for leg injuries that he suffered in a race on Saturday.

title: Jury Starts Deliberations In Corona Murder Retrial
description: The jury began deliberations today in the murder retrial of Juan V. Corona after 11 days of closing arguments.

title: Creusot-Loire Order
description: Creusot-Loire Enterprises said today that it had received an order valued at about $28 million from Cimiento de Portugal to increase capacity at the Alhanbra cement works near Lisbon.

title: Local Theater Groups Topic of Seminar Today
description: A seminar on community and ethnic theater groups will be given today at 9:30 A.M. at the City Department of Cultural Affairs at 2 Columbus Circle.

title: Mitsubishi Enters Plea
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, the giant Japanese technology concern indicted in an industrial espionage case involving the International Business Machines Corporation, pleaded not guilty today to charges of buying trade secrets.

title: Mrs. Truman a Little Better
description: Bess Truman remained in serious condition today but the doctor treating her said that the former First Lady, who is 97 years old, had improved in the second week of her hospital stay. Mrs. Truman has a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Her husband, Harry S. Truman, died in 1972. Mrs. Truman still lives at the family home at Independence.

title: ABC Video and Theater On Coast Sign Pact
description: ABC Video Enterprises has entered into an agreement with one of the country's foremost theaters, the Center Theater Group/Mark Taper Forum of the Los Angeles Music Center, for first-refusal rights on live stage productions and other projects originating or presented at the Mark Taper.

title: Results Today Of Global Vote
description: The directors of Global Natural Resources, the oil and gas concern that is facing a takeover attempt by a group of dissident shareholders, adjourned their annual meeting yesterday without disclosing the results of a board election.

title: 'Fingerprinting' Insects
description: In the insect world, different species can resemble each other, even though they are not the same genetically. This may not matter to the insects, but to scientists seeking ways of controlling insect crop pests by biological means, the outward similarity that masks a genotypic difference can cause a pest control program to fail.

title: Zimbabwe Curbs Movements By Foreign Correspondents
description: The Government has restricted the movement of foreign correspondents in addition to closing areas of Matabeleland covered by a dusk-to-dawn curfew.

title: Board's Goals 'On Target'
description: The New York Insurance Exchange, the first centralized commercial insurance exchange in the United States, provides a marketplace for underwriters and brokers to transact insurance business face-toface, facilitating rapid placement of risks in property, casualty, marine and life insurance.

title: Reading Guide For Auto-Makers
description: A fifth grader can read the Ladies' Home Journal and an 11th grader can understand Time Magazine, but it takes 12 to 16 years of schooling to cope with the recall notices that auto-makers send car owners, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: DETROIT TEACHERS STRIKE OVER PAY CUT
description: Detroit's 10,000 teachers walked off the job this morning over a Board of Education demand for pay cuts amounting to about 8 percent.

title: Accounting Board Picks New Member
description: Victor H. Brown, chief financial officer of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, has been appointed to the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a seven-member body that makes the accounting and financial reporting rules that corporations must follow.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cosmos' farewell game for Carlos Alberto, originally scheduled for Tuesday night, Sept. 21, has been rescheduled for the following Tuesday, Sept. 28, at 9 P.M. The reason for the delay is that the Flamengo team of Brazil, for which Carlos Alberto once played and which is to be the Cosmos' opponent in the farewell game, may have to play on the earlier date in the Brazilian championship. ... Todd Hart, a safety for Long Beach State, is hospitalized in serious condition with a broken neck suffered when he collided with two other players in Saturday's game against U.C.L.A. A spokesman at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif., said that Hart ''has feeling in his legs and arms, but he's unable to move any part of his body from the neck down.'' There was no immediate prognosis on whether the 19-year-old sophomore would be permanently paralyzed. . . Peter Pocklington, the owner of soccer's Edmonton Drillers, said that an agreement to sell the team to Sonny Van Arnem, a Detroit businessman, had fallen through. ... Donnie Walsh is leaving as assistant coach of the Denver Nuggets, ending a five-year stint in which he served as both head coach and assistant coach but never got the front-office job he sought. Walsh plans to join a law firm in Columbia, S.C.

title: VERSATILE, AND BUSY, CHIEF JUSTICE JAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Plans Mall Operation
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would begin selling cars and trucks in a suburban shopping mall in Torrance, Calif. The automotive industry's third-largest producer after General Motors and Ford said it had selected the Del Amo Fashion Center, one of the nation's largest enclosed malls, for the first step in a national program to establish mall sales operations in two or three other major markets.

title: BROTHER, 14, GIVES GUIDRY INSPIRATION
description: Other than for his victories and strikeouts, which this year again lead the club, Ron Guidry generally keeps a low profile on the Yankees, a team that from principal owner to second-string catcher is an assemblage of eminently high profiles.

title: Nabisco Agrees To Sell Williams
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. said it agreed to sell its J.B. Williams Company toiletries business to the Beechman Group of Britain, a maker of pharmaceuticals and health-care products, for about $100 million in cash.

title: ANCIENT ROMAN SHIPS FOUND AT GERMAN SITE
description: A fleet of wooden Roman warships uncovered by hotel-construction workers has found a temporary port of call in an empty trolley barn in Mainz, West Germany.

title: REAGAN OFFERS BILL TO TIGHTEN RULES ON CRIMINAL DEFENDANTS
description: President Reagan proposed today that Congress pass three measures that he said would make it ''more likely that those who commit crimes pay a price.''

title: Mexican Curb Eased
description: The Mexican Government, modifying existing restrictions, announced Monday night that foreign investors in Mexico would be allowed to repatriate profits and royalties under its new system of exchange controls.

title: A Cable Chief Quits in Florida
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., a cable television company based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that its president and chief executive officer, Nick A. Caporella, 46 years old, had resigned.

title: DUKAKIS WINNER IN PRIMARY FOR MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR
description: Michael S. Dukakis beat Gov. Edward J. King in the Democratic primary Tuesday night, winning a rematch of the race Mr. King won four years ago, when Mr. Dukakis was the incumbent Governor.

title: Europe Steel Aid Assailed
description: Dozens of independent Western European steel producers, saying they are being forced into bankruptcy, bitterly attacked state-funded companies today. In a letter to the European Economic Community's industry commissioner, they criticized governments for giving huge subsidies to large steel companies that are intended to offset losses.

title: Vernon Porter, Artist, Is Dead; Originator of Outdoor Exhibit
description: Vernon Carroll Porter, an artist and the originator of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, died Aug. 31 at the Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 86 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Colleges Said To Win Suit
description: A Federal judge has ruled in favor of two college football powers that sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association for the right to negotiate their own television contracts, according to University of Oklahoma officials.

title: U.S. Stars Flounder
description: One season after Vince Ferragamo flopped at Montreal with the Alouettes, the new Concordes franchise there has grown disenchanted with two other American stars. They are the running back David Overstreet and the defensive end Keith Gary, both of whom were first-round choices in last year's National Football League draft - and both of whom have now been placed on the injured-reserve list for the rest of the Canadian season despite the minor nature of their ailments.

title: Valley Girls aren't just in California
description: *Copyright c 1982 Munchkin Music Okay, fine Fer sure, fer sure She's a Valley Girl In a clothing store. Okay, fine Fer sure, fer sure She's a Valley Girl And there is no cure.* By RON ALEXANDER

title: Advertising; British Air Switches To Saatchi
description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI COMPTON WORLDWIDE has landed the British Airways account for the entire planet. Current annual billings are about $28 million, according to the airline.

title: SAFETY UNIT HEARS OF CRASH INCIDENTS
description: A pilot of a small plane that took off from the New Orleans Airport shortly after a jetliner crashed, killing 154 persons, said today that he had received inadequate weather information before takeoff.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES HIRES BRANIFF OFFICER
description: To hundreds of journalists who covered the financial throes of Braniff Airways, the soft drawl of Sam Coats, its vice president for domestic and international affairs, became a familiar sound. As public relations spokesman for the airline, he rarely lost his sense of humor even during the dark days of its collapse.

title: FLAVORED YOGURTS: HOW THEY TASTE
description: A tasting of 238 flavored yogurts, packaged under 21 brand names, was recently made. Following are some of the findings. Calorie counts are for eight-ounce servings unless otherwise specified. French Style or Yogurt Drinks

title: Q&A
description: Q. At times I am served a salad dressing that looks and tastes quite creamy. It is not a mayonnaise but resembles a thin mayonnaise. Can you tell me how this is done?

title: VICTIMS OF A 'BURGLAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
DEMOCRATS PLAN AD ATTACK ON G.O.P.
description: The Democratic Party today announced a nationwide radio and television advertising campaign that will denounce Republican economic policies as unfair and contend that they are ''crushing the hopes'' of millions of Americans.

title: KOCH AIDE CITES CORRUPTION COST IN CONSTRUCTION
description: Corruption in New York City's construction industry ''costs millions and millions of dollars'' each year and is ''eventually passed along to the public in higher rents for apartments and office space,'' an aide to Mayor Koch told the State Commission of Investigation yesterday.

title: A SAMPLING OF RECIPES FIT FOR A FEAST
description: OVER Labor Day weekend, 36 of world's best-known chefs gathered to cook in Craig Claiborne's kitchen in East Hampton, L.I. The dishes they served ranged from such personal preparations as blackened redfish from the New Orleans chef Paul Prudhomme, clams with blini by Jean Vergnes, smoked chicken by Florence Lin and an English trifle done up by Guy Pascal, to such traditionally American dishes as Edna Lewis's roast squabs with basil, Laura Sandifer's chitterlings and Vivian Collyer's Mississippi-style pecan pies.

title: BISHOP TUTU IN CITY, VOICES CONCERN
description: A South African Anglican Bishop told New York church leaders yesterday he was uneasy about a governmental commission now investigating the South African Council of Churches because ''the track record of judicial commissions in South Africa is not something that makes you sleep more comfortably.''

title: Another Defendant Joins Brink's Trial
description: A State Supreme Court justice. George J. Balbach, signed an order today in Queens allowing Nathaniel Burns, who was awaiting trial there for attempted murder, to be transferred to Rockland County for pretrial hearings in the Brink's robbery and murder case.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada said it would again defer - until next July 1 - its decision on whether to exercise an option to buy six Boeing 767 aircraft. Boeing said the order had not yet been entered into its books.

title: TOUGH ROAD FOR ROOKIE
description: Dave Simpson is seeking to earn a place with the Islanders at center, a position where there is already a logjam.

title: Time for Sanity About Crime
description: What an odd title for legislation not introduced until mid-September: the Criminal Justice Reform Act of 1982. Too late for serious consideration, President Reagan's crime bill is more symbol than substance.

title: 2 Coast Doctors Plead Not Guilty in Death
description: Two physicians pleaded not guilty today to charges of murdering a comatose patient by removing lifesupport equipment, and one of them said the case put doctors nationwide ''on notice'' that they could face similar prosecutions.

title: AN ANTI-TRUST CHIEF WITH AN IMPACT
description: Antitrust lawyers are already assigning William F. Baxter a secure place in the history books because of his landmark divestiture settlement of the Government's case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and his decision to drop the 13-year International Business Machines case. This summer, Mr. Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, also published a long-needed updating of the Federal guidelines for corporate mergers.

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1982; Companies
description: I.B.M. has dismissed three executives and sued them on charges of stealing trade secrets, the company reported. It said the three had formed a company and tried to sell designs related to still-secret I.B.M. products in the personal computer field. One of the accused disputed some of the charges. The suit was filed after an undercover inquiry by I.B.M., its second in recent months. (Page A1.)

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. Ron Guidry of the Yankees and Mike Flanagan of the Orioles will be trying to gain their 15th victories.

title: DIOR MAKES FORMAL APOLOGY TO NEWARK FOR REPUTED SLUR
description: Councilman Henry Martinez is the self-appointed protector of Newark's reputation, not an enviable role given the city's history of difficulties and the barbs it often endures.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE current emphasis on salt and other dietary sources of sodium and the need to lower high blood pressure has focused public attention on a previously ignored mineral nutrient, potassium.

title: Stan Davis, Writer of Jokes For Film and TV Comedians
description: Stan Davis, who abandoned a career as a tailor to become a gag writer for such comedians as Milton Berle and Jimmy Durante, has died after a long battle with cancer.

title: Socal to Speed Up Sudan Production
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said it plans to advance commercial oil production by a year at discoveries made by its Chevron unit in the Sudan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Sunday about the primary for Manhattan surrogate incorrectly reported county Democratic screening committee ratings of the Democratic candidates. Renee R. Roth and Judge Edward H. Lehner are both rated ''highly qualified.''

title: Equitable Life
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States said it had agreed in principle to acquire Equitable Life Mortgage and Realty Investors, a real estate investment trust, for $15.25 a share. The trust has 5,660,000 common shares outstanding, indicating a value for the acquisition of $86.4 million.

title: SLAVE DESCENDANT FIGHTS RACE LISTING
description: A Louisiana woman who is a descendant of an 18th-century black slave has asked a court to declare her white. The woman's birth certificate says she is black.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF A BBC INTERVIEW WITH KING HUSSEIN OF JORDAN OF REAGAN PLAN
description: Following is a transcript of a British Broadcasting Corporation interview with King Hussein of Jordan Monday night, as recorded by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service:

title: Falkland Sanctions Removed
description: The Argentine Government has accepted a British proposal to mutually lift financial sanctions imposed by the two countries after the start of the Falkland conflict, the Economy Ministry said tonight.

title: REAGAN MODIFIES TAX CREDIT PLAN
description: President Reagan, bearing down on social issues in advance of the November elections, today indicated approval of Capitol Hill compromises aimed at bringing tuition tax credits out of committee for debate.

title: BRIEFING
description: Agency Facing the Ax

title: PHILHARMONIC TO OPEN, STILL AGLOW FROM TOUR
description: Fresh from its late summer tour of South America - 15 concerts in six countries that by all reports succeeded in warming Latin listeners in ways few diplomats could equal - the New York Philharmonic turns its attentions homeward beginning tonight at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: People
description: * Richard Edler has been named president and chief operating officer of Doyle Dane Bernbach/Los Angeles.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Called up Angel Moreno and Mickey Mahler, pitchers; Daryl Soonies, first baseman; Ricky Adams, infielder, and Gary Pettis, outfielder, from Spokane of the Pacific Coast League. CHICAGO (AL) - Called up Steve Dillard, infielder, from Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. PACIFIC COAST LEAGUE - Approved transfer of the Spokane, Wash., franchise to Las Vegas, Nev.

title: HBO: SUCCESS BRINGS CRITICISM
description: ''Home Box Office was born in a contentious environment,'' says Michael Fuchs, HBO's head of programming. ''We were fighting with the studios, the unions and the networks, because no one wanted us to get off the ground. I'm no blushing violet and I was probably quicker than some others here to man the guns. My style is confrontational.''

title: ADVICE? CONSENT? WHAT?
description: Whatever happened to the Senate? The Constitution endows it with the power to give its advice and consent to treaties. Yet it has given neither to three of the most important treaties ever negotiated and that are now physically and legally pending before it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Postal Peculiarity T he imposing General Post Office across the street from Madison Square Garden has four compartments for outgoing letters.

title: THE REGION
description: Employees of the United Parcel Service in northern New Jersey and Rockland and Orange Counties and on Staten Island remained on strike yesterday in defiance of a restraining order signed by Judge Clarkson S. Fisher in Federal Court in Newark.

title: Flurry of Promotions At Busy Ally & Gargano
description: Michael Tesch, the Ally & Gargano art director responsible for the Federal Express campaign that has been gobbling up awards, has added yet another title to his existing one as associate creative director - executive vice president.

title: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1981 figures reflect the use of F.A.S.B. No 43 regarding accounting for compensated absences

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income which includes gains of $2.8 million on sales of securities

title: Gemayel of Lebanon Is Killed in Bomb Blast at Party Offices
description: President-elect Bashir Gemayel was killed Tuesday when a bomb shattered the headquarters of his Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party in east Beirut. The Government said he would be buried today.

title: 2 Sites Are Designated As Landmarks by City
description: Pomander Walk on Manhattan's West Side and the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn won landmark status yesterday from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sculptural Symbolism

title: Italy Defeats U.S.  In Yacht Series
description: Italy's three yachts narrowly won the Sardinia Cup, the Mediterranean's most prestigious racing series, from the United States today amid calm seas and low winds.

title: AN EVENING FOR THE FANS OF FENDI
description: ''IT'S hard to believe this all started five or six years ago when we bought 16 furs,'' mused Ira Neimark, the president of Bergdorf Goodman. A crowd of women was waiting patiently outside for the showing of Fendi furs after the store closed Monday night.

title: KEY COMPONENTS OF THE U.N. OUT OF STEP WITH ITS CHARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: 1. For Nostalgic Hours
description: One of the most memorable scenes in movie history is Harold Lloyd swinging from the hands of a giant clock in the 1923 comedy, ''Safety Last.'' Silent-movie buffs should like a new clock from France that reproduces that scene. A photograph of a building and a clock face are laminated on plastic, with the works of the clock in back. A tiny figure of the comedian hangs from the minute hand and swings around as the hand moves. The clock is battery-operated and has a hanger to fasten it to a wall. It's $40 at Stephen Anson, 1058 First Avenue (58th Street).

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BLACKS TO PRESS BOYCOTT OF LAW COURSE AT HARVARD
description: Black students at the Harvard Law School,back for the 1982-83 academic year, have voted to proceed with their plan to boycott a course on racial and legal issues that is to be taught in part by a prominent white civil rights lawyer.

title: UNIMATION INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $470,000

title: ARTS DEALS FOR MOSCOW AND PEKING
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum, and Jerry Weintraub, a movie producer and personal manager, announced today a venture to import and export motion pictures, concerts, television films, theater and other cultural events to and from the Soviet Union and China.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: It is a fact that some of the tastiest of dishes require much less time than one hour to cook. One that impressed me most forcefully in this respect was a simple fish stew that I chose the label a ragout de poissons, although it could accurately be called a fish soup. I believe the name ragout is more appropriate in that the pieces of fish are a bit larger than those in most fish soups and the proporion of fish to liquid is greater than in most soups.

title: INVENTORIES GREW 0.1% IN JULY
description: Business inventories of unsold goods rose a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in July as weak sales and high interest rates continued to depress the nation's economy, the Government reported today.

title: THE NEW YOGURTS: ARE THEY REALLY YOGURT?
description: OF all the foods that have been popularized in the last few years, probably none have been taken to more extremes than yogurt. What began as simple curdled milk culture has been flavored, liquefied, solidified, frozen, turned into custard and given a variety of French or pseudo-French names. Along with any number of calorie-laden fruitflavored preserves, such ingredients as modified food starch, gelatin and sugar are now commonly found in yogurt.

title: THE PANOPLY OF PREPARATION FOR THE MARCOS VISIT
description: First came the parties, lavish nightly receptions at the Philippine Embassy designed to woo support among Filipino-Americans.

title: TOLL AT 50
description: The pilot of a DC-10 jet that crashed in flames, leaving at least 50 dead, said today that he made a lifeor-death choice to abort his takeoff but was not sure whether he ''killed people or saved a lot of people.''

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 FALL 28.6%
description: The nation's three largest auto makers reported today that sales for the first 10 days of September fell 28.6 percent from last year's levels, despite slightly lower interest rates on auto loans.

title: Stokely Plans Sale
description: United Foods Inc. of Bells, Tenn., said it had agreed to purchase the domestic frozen-food operations of Stokely-Van Camp Inc. It did not disclose the price. The acquisition includes production plants in Fairmont, Minn., and Albany, Ore., various trademarks and inventories. United Foods said the operations have about $50 million in annual sales.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest qr shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in July

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The assets figures are total invested assets at Aug 31

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Urges Support For Democrats' Job Measure
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. joined House Democrats today in promoting a bill to provide 200,000 temporary public service jobs, a measure that Republicans belittle as an election year ''quick fix.''

title: News Analysis
description: A possible engine breakup, caused either by an internal defect or ingestion of an outside object, is drawing primary attention from air-safety experts speculating on the cause of the crash of a Mc-Donnell Douglas DC-10 jumbo jet in

title: MIRANDA STILL RING MYSTERY
description: Mario Miranda, a shrinking legend from Colombia shrouded in mystery and horn-rimmed glasses, fights Juan LaPorte, a tough kid from the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant, for the vacant World Boxing Council featherweight title tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Millionth Eagle Scout Cited
description: Alexander M. Holsinger became the nation's one-millionth Eagle Scout today and received a congratulatory telephone call from President Reagan. The 13-year-old student at Chiddix Junior High School said he was ''thrilled'' by his talk with the President.

title: CHRYSLER TALKS EXTENDED A DAY, JUST BEFORE DEADLINE
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation agreed to a one-day extension of the existing labor contract late tonight, just minutes before a midnight strike deadline.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1982
description: International Lebanon's President-elect was killed when a bomb shattered the headquarters of the Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party in east Beirut. President-elect Bashir Gemayel, 34 years old, who was to have been inaugurated Sept. 23, was said to have died as he was about to address 400 of his followers at a weekly meeting. The state radio said eight were killed, and more than 50 wounded. (Page A1, Col. 6.) U.S. officials feared renewed fighting in Lebanon between Christian Phalangist forces and the Moslem leftists might follow the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel. They said a new outbreak of civil strife would also raise the possibility that Syrian and Israeli forces, confronting each other in Lebanon, might enter the conflict, destroying hopes for restoring stability. (A1:4.)

title: Support for the P.L.O.  Affirmed by Brezhnev
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev reaffirmed Soviet support today for the Palestine Liberation Organization and cautioned its leader, Yasir Arafat, against what he described as Washington's efforts to deny the Palestinians their own state.

title: RIGHTS PANEL HEAD CALLS FOR 'SUMMIT'
description: Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said today that he had urged President Reagan to convene a domestic ''summit conference'' to discuss the status of civil rights and minority groups in America.

title: STEELERS FIND GOOD KICKER IN DISCARD
description: G ary Anderson, a rookie place-kicker from Syracuse University, made his debut in the National Football League on national television Monday night with a remarkably consistent record: In the exhibition games, he had missed five field goals and made none. Then, when he tried to kick his first extra point in this game, the snap from center was bad, and he missed that one, too.

title: Profit Margin At Factories
description: After-tax profits of American manufacturers climbed to 3.9 cents per dollar of sales in the second quarter of 1982, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: Miss Martin Leaves Hospital
description: Mary Martin, the actress and musical star who was injured nine days ago in an automobile accident, left San Francisco General Hospital today for an undisclosed location.

title: EQUITABLE LIFE MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Jul
description: B-Net income; the company said that the earnings for the third qr of 1982 were negatively impacted by nonrecurring items totalling $2.6 million; these includedprovision for impossible losses of $1.9 million on a specific investment and a net loss on sale of real estate owned of $693,000

title: Stockman Announces Plans to Marry in '83
description: Budget Director David A. Stockman plans to end his bachelor days early next year, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget said today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: JAMAICAN reggae began to attract a substantial audience in North America a decade ago, when Jimmy Cliff starred in the film ''The Harder They Come'' and Bob Marley and the Wailers made their first internationally distributed album, ''Catch A Fire,'' for Island records.

title: Ethiopia a Scapegoat, Diplomat Complains
description: An Ethiopian official accused the Reagan Administration today of trying to make Ethiopia the scapegoat in new fighting involving Somalia in the strategic Horn of Africa.

title: 'TALKING' TILL IS SILENCED IN YANKEE TOWN
description: A supermarket chain muzzled its talking cash registers at one store after customers complained that they didn't like the voice and thought use of the gadget resulted in higher prices.

title: Correctness in Recipes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: REAGAN ASKS ADDITIONS TO WILDERNESS SYSTEM
description: President Reagan has asked Congress to make eight additions to the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System and three additions to the National Wilderness Preservation System.

title: Pager Dumping Inquiry
description: The Commerce Department said today that it was investigating charges by the Motorola Corporation that Japanese companies are dumping electronic pagers in the United States market at less than fair value.

title: POLISH PROTESTERS AND POLICE CLASH AGAIN
description: Renewed clashes with the police flared in at least two industrial areas Monday, according to accounts made public here today.

title: U.S. WILL RAISE $11.75 BILLION
description: The United States Treasury yesterday announced plans to sell $11.75 billion of new notes and bonds next week in a financing that will raise $9.35 billion of new cash for the Government, the most money it has ever raised from a single week's sales of notes and bonds.

title: NEVADA SENATE RACE NEAR TIE
description: Representative James D. Santini jumped to an early lead in partial, inconclusive returns tonight in his campaign to take the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from Senator Howard Cannon, who was seeking a fifth term.

title: No Headline
description: Cardinals Return To First

title: Firecracker-Throwing Illegal For Strikers, U.S. Court Rules
description: A Federal appeals court ruled Monday that throwing a firecracker at a supervisor's car was an illegal strike activity and upheld the suspension of a striker who had done so.

title: A TIRELESS SEARCH FOR ONE LOST SOUL
description: Alice Scheller met Alma Siegel just over a year ago in a coffee shop in the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Alice was just passing through, on her way to Harlem to do volunteer work, but Alma lived there, at least part of the time, one of those elderly women who shelter themselves within the public places of New York City and become dirty and disconnected and sometimes mad.

title: Addendum on Apples
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I was especially interested in Marian Burros's article (''Apples: From Eve to Granny Smith, Sept. 1) because I recently spent two fascinating days in Geneva at the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station's 100th Anniversary celebration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday misidentified a man accompanying Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark. He was David Gor- don-el, a Newark police officer.

title: MADSCAM
description: AS I was walking south on Madison Avenue near 70th Street on a recent afternoon, I noticed a young window-shopping family: T-shirted mother, designer-jeaned father, neatly bibbed baby in a stroller blissfully sucking on a pacifier. They paused to greet a passing pin-striped-businessman type. ''Excuse me, sir,'' the young father said. ''We're trying to get on the subway, and we're 50 cents short.'' The man winked at the baby, dug into his pinstripes, and forked over the 50 cents with a smile.

title: REUNION AT THE SOCCER BOWL
description: They were teammates on an amateur club as teen-agers and they attended high schools in the same school district, but only two of the three players will be on the same team when the Cosmos and the Seattle Sounders meet in the Soccer Bowl Saturday night.

title: U.S. CLEARS BENDIX-MARIETTA MERGER
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not intervene in any combination of the Bendix Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation, thus clearing the way for the two big aerospace producers to proceed with their competing bids to acquire each other.

title: ANOTHER MARATHON ARRIVES IN THE CITY
description: A new brand of group marathon came to New York yesterday when 10 men and two women plunged into the murky waters of the East River and struck out on a 27-mile race around Manhattan.

title: LOVELADY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SCHMIDT REBUKES AIDE AGAIN
description: In an unusual rebuke of a senior aide, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today publicly criticized Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, who has called for significant restraints in welfare spending to help pull West Germany out of a recession.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MASSACRES SPREAD TERROR IN THE LAND OF MAYA
description: It was just before dawn when Pedro Gualin heard the shooting, grabbed his hunting rifle and ran into the foliage. He watched helplessly as the strangers in civilian clothes fired wildly into the huts and set them on fire.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''P.L.O. is a liberation organization; it is a process toward the achievement of peace.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Transitions At the Fire Dept.

title: Careers; Weighing Majors for Cash Value
description: AS many college undergraduates realize, engineers, some science majors and most holders of a master's degree in business administration have been the most successful in finding jobs after graduation. In fact, with 56,000 M.B.A.'s being awarded each year, that degree has become what a bachelor's degree was 20 years ago - a license for an entry-level job.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today; Sept. 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.

title: REAGAN NAMES AIDE TO FIGHT A-ARMS SPREAD
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan would nominate Richard T. Kennedy as Ambassador at Large and special adviser on nuclear energy affairs and on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: OPERA: MILNES SINGS 'HAMLET' LEAD
description: AMBROISE THOMAS'S ''Hamlet'' is a work that every opera fanatic should see once. Perhaps even twice, to be absolutely sure that what goes on in this variation on a theme by Shakespeare is not, perchance, a dream. The chance of a lifetime came last night as the New York City Opera began its season of regular repertory after a weeklong operetta prelude.

title: FARMER BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bonn Reports No Growth
description: The West German economy, the most powerful in Europe, failed to grow in the first half of this year, according to Government figures released today.

title: Cadillac Fairview
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it had agreed to sell 10,931 apartment units for $270 million (Canadian) to the Greymac Credit Corporation. It said the sale is expected to close by Nov. 16, and that once the sale is completed, it will have disposed of the bulk of its apartment portfolio.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $196,000

title: Chock Full o' Nuts Stake
description: An investment group led by Jerry Finkelstein, a New York publisher, said yesterday that it had increased its holdings in the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation to 16 percent, or 778,000 shares, from 14.9 percent, or 726,000 shares. The group said it plans to conduct a proxy contest for the election of directors. Mr. Finkelstein said two additional members had joined the group - William Woodward, an investor, and the Benenson Capital Company, headed by Charles B. Benenson.

title: HOUSING REHABILITATED FOR THE QUICHE SET
description: To the Editor:

title: Todd Shipyards Opposes Purchase
description: John T. Gilbride, chairman of Todd Shipyards, said the company opposed the proposed acquisition of up to 30 percent of its common stock by the Madison Fund and Bernard L. Schwartz, the chief executive officer of the Loral Corporation.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Storm Strands Travelers In Rocky Mountains; United Press International
description: Blinding snow from a late summer storm left the northern Rocky Mountains covered with 18 inches of wet snow yesterday and disrupted traffic and electrical power.

title: Canada Backs A Getty Linkup
description: The Canadian Cabinet said today that it had approved the Getty Oil Company's acquisition of Canadian Reserve Oil and Gas Ltd.

title: Vitamin A and Eyesight
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The article by Craig Claiborne (''A Boost for Plebeian Food,'' Sept. 1) on the benefits derived from ''plebeian fare,'' i.e. foods rich in vitamin C and beta-carotene, omitted one fact that may interest your readers - the importance of beta-carotene and the vitamin A it produces to the healthy development of the eye.

title: 'REPORTERS' ON THE JOB IN PARIS
description: A month in the life of the Gamma Agency's Paris bureau, as studied in Raymond Depardon's ''Reporters,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a month full of rapid, funny contrasts. One day a photographer may be covering a wreath-laying and parade to honor President Bongo of Gabon; the next, he may be skulking outside a hotel, waiting for Woody, Mia, Christina or any of the other surefire subjects with whom he imagines he's on a first-name basis.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Yr-ago qr company did not report a loss or gain...C-Net income

title: MACY, R H, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RESIDENTS OF JACKSON TOWNSHIP, OHIO, REBEL AGAINST LIVING 'BELOW' COLUMBUS
description: An aromatic fact of nature taught people to float their garbage downriver and build their houses upstream. For that very reason, places whose names begin with ''Upper'' are likely to cost more per square inch than places that are ''Lower.'' Likewise, no country music singer ever wrote a song about a rich girl who lived down in the flats, or the bottom, or in other low-altitude places of a river town.

title: LEICESTER HEMINGWAY, WRITER AND ERNEST'S BROTHER, IS SUICIDE
description: Leicester C. Hemingway, a writer and only brother of the late American novelist and Nobel laureate Ernest Hemingway, died Monday of a self-inflicted head wound caused by a borrowed handgun at his home in Miami Beach, according to the police. His family reported that he suffered from diabetes and had been depressed after undergoing five operations in recent months. He was 67 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT TOWN MOURNS 4 STUDENTS WHO DIED IN CRASH
description: The 700 mourners, most of them the age of Vicky Hensel's children, filed into St. Rose Roman Catholic Church here this morning. Mrs. Hensel waited in the parking lot in her car. It is a common pose for a parent in the suburbs: waiting to pick up a child after school or a music lesson, waiting for a son or daughter to come home late on a weekend night.

title: Manager Arrested
description: Manager Billy Gardner of the Minnesota Twins has been charged by the police in the St. Paul suburb of Maplewood with driving while intoxicated. Gardner was arrested about 10:30 P.M. Sunday and spent a couple of hours in the Ramsey County Jail before being released in his own recognizance.

title: Transcript of interview, page A10.
description: King Hussein of Jordan, in his first public comment on President Reagan's Middle East peace plan, said in an interview that it was ''a very constructive and a very positive move.'' He added that he would play ''a very active part'' in trying to bring about a federation between Jordanians and the Palestinians.

title: HARVESTER REPORTS NEW DEBT ACCORD
description: The International Harvester Company, the debtridden manufacturer of trucks and farm implements, disclosed today that it had reached a tentative agreement with its lenders on major changes in its $4.2 billion debt restructuring plan. The proposal, the third modification of the debt plan, is expected to give the lenders a large share of Harvester's stock, but will also provide new financial liquidity.

title: Firstmark to Buy Cigna Subsidiary
description: The Firstmark Corporation said that a unit, the Firstmark Financial Corporation, had signed a letter of intent to buy the INA Standard Life Insurance Company from the Cigna Corporation for about $32.5 million.

title: A Correction
description: An article on regional cookbooks in The Living Section on Sept. 1 listed an incorrect price for ''Coastal Cookery,'' a collection of recipes published by the Cassina Garden Club, St. Simons Island, Ga. It is available from Mary Woodruff, 137 Colonial Drive, St. Simons Island, Ga. 31522, for $7.95 plus $1.50 postage.

title: PROFESSOR DESERVES TENURE
description: N ew York is a two-professor region. Up in the Bronx some Yankees call Clyde King ''The Professor'' because of his verbal ways, and over in New Jersey the Cosmos call Julio Mazzei ''The Professor'' because he has studied at colleges in Sao Paulo, Michigan and Paris.

title: Kimberly Outlays
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said it planned a $38 million expansion of its Coosa Pines pulp mill in Talladega County, Ala.

title: Minor Parties Join Connecticut Races
description: Libertarian and Conservative candidates for governor, United States senator and other offices have gathered enough petition signatures to be listed on the Nov. 2 ballot, Maura L. Melley, the Secretary of the State, said today.

title: Key Banks Inc. Plans Takeover in Maine
description: The directors of the Depositors Corporation voted today to merge their Augusta-based banking company into Key Banks Inc. of Albany.

title: 'SIBERIADE' WINNER OF CANNES PRIZE
description: AS very long epic films go, ''Siberiade,'' the Russian film that won a special jury prize at the 1979 Cannes Film Festival, is not only painless but also robust and almost jolly, at least in the last of its three hours.

title: N.F.L. TALKS RESUME FRIDAY
description: Representatives of the National Football League Players Association and the league's Management Council have scheduled a negotiating session for 10 A.M. Friday, three days before the union's executive committee will meet to decide a strike date. Both meetings will be held in New York.

title: SEEKING MORE STABILITY IN THE PERSIAN GULF
description: Concern over Lebanon and Arab-Israeli issues has rightly dominated United States foreign policy in recent months, but we cannot ignore the need for greater stability in the Persian Gulf, where the conflict between Iran and Iraq poses serious challenges for the West.

title: Letter: On Gasoline Lead To Accelerate Cleaner Exhausts
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO MANEUVERS FAIL TO IMPRESS SOME WITNESSES
description: A brigade of the 82d Airborne Division flew 10 and a half hours from North Carolina and then parachuted into a field here.

title: MARCOS LEAVES MANILA FOR U.S. VISIT
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos left tonight for his first official visit in 16 years to the United States, the Philippines' chief economic partner and military ally.

title: Texas Banker Is Sentenced
description: The president of a northeast Texas state bank that collapsed two months ago today pleaded guilty to charges that he embezzled more than $4.8 million.

title: Continental Corp.
description: The Continental Corporation said it had completed the acquisition of the CIC Financial Corporation, an insurance holding company, following the approval of CIC shareholders at a meeting today. CIC shareholders are to receive $25 a share, or a total of $40.7 million. CIC is the parent of the Casualty Insurance Company and the Hallmark Insurance Company.

title: I.B.M. ACCUSES 3 EXECUTIVES OF STEALING COMPUTER SECRETS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, following its second undercover investigation in recent months, said yesterday that it had dismissed three of its executives and had sued them on charges of stealing corporate secrets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Thomas Hearns, needing a tune-up for his bout this winter against Wilfred Benitez, plans to fight Bobby Watts of Philadelphia in Detroit on Sept. 25. ... Julius Boros and Kathy Whitworth were inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame in Pinehurst, N.C. Boros, a two-time United States Open champion, and Miss Whitworth, the winner of a record 83 titles on the women's tour, were elected by the Golf Writers Association of America. The World Golf Hall of Fame, founded eight years ago, now has 42 members. ... Rick Waits will have surgery today for a partial tear of a tendon in his right knee, ending the Cleveland Indian pitcher's season with a 2-13 record.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Macy's Net Rises 44.1% In Quarter
description: R.H. Macy & Company Inc., which operates 92 department stores in 13 states, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 31 increased by 44.1 percent, to a record $32.9 million, or $1 a share, from $22.8 million, or 69 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 13.8 percent, to $692.4 million, from $608.3 million.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $523,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Produce at Good Prices

title: LEBANON CRAZY QUILT LAND OF CONFLICT
description: Lebanon's history of violence and instability, underscored anew by the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel, is rooted in a mire of ethnic and religious strife.

title: Resource Equity Merger Planned
description: General Hydrocarbons Inc. said it plans to merge with Resource Equity Inc. of Minneapolis.

title: STOCKS RISE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices made a moderate advance yesterday in very heavy trading as late profit taking erased some earlier gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up more than 9 points at 1:30 P.M., closed ahead 4.32 points, to 923.01. On Monday, the blue-chip barometer soared 11.87 points, its first rally since it advanced 148 points in the 16 sessions ended last Tuesday.

title: BASHIR GEMAYEL LIVED BY THE SWORD
description: He began as the commander of a small Christian militia group outside Beirut, battled his way to the top of the Phalangist Party - the most powerful of the warring, near-feudal clans that have dominated Lebanon's recent bloody history - and for 22 days was President-elect of Lebanon. He would have been the youngest President in the country's history.

title: Conrail to Sell Canadian Assets
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation agreed to sell its Canadian assets to two Canadian railroads for an unspecified amount, Conrail said.

title: WINE TALK
description: EVERY so often a particular vintage will come to the rescue of wine collectors enduring the long wait for the contents of their racks and bins to mature. Often it will occur with a young vintage of mediocre quality, one that nobody took seriously at the time of harvest but that suddenly becomes attractive when it reaches a peak, usually within the first decade of its life.

title: A HUTTON EXECUTIVE JOINS ROTHSCHILD
description: Gerald Goldsmith, a managing director and executive vice president at E.F. Hutton & Company, has joined Rothschild Inc., where he will head a new subsidiary called Rothschild Trading.

title: TORONTO CONCERT OPENS SYMPHONY'S NEW HALL
description: The second of the five major concert halls opening within a two-week period in the United States and Canada was opened Monday night in Toronto. Following the opening of a new hall in New Orleans last Friday, the $40 million Roy Thomson Hall here gave ''an opening gala performance and promenade'' before a posh audience headed by Edward Schreyer, the Governor General of Canada. Also present were William Davis, the Premier of Ontario; Arthur Eggleton, the Mayor of Toronto, and other dignitaries. Tickets for the occasion were priced from $500 to $100.

title: SURGING ORIOLES SWEEP 2 GAMES
description: Earl Weaver produced more of his managerial magic tonight as his Baltimore Orioles continued to march closer to the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: CITY POLICE TO COMBAT CAR THIEVES WITH ADDITION OF 40 INVESTIGATORS
description: The Police Department is expected to announce today a new drive against car thieves that will include the addition of 40 investigators to the Auto Crime Division and the assignment of 40 uniformed officers to neighborhoods where car thefts are most frequent.

title: COMPTROLLER HOPEFULS FIGHT OBSCURITY
description: William B. Finneran gave a news conference and nobody came. Raymond F. Gallagher got lost looking for a lunch for the elderly in Bensonhurst. James F. Tully Jr. looked momentarily happy when, in Syracuse, he heard a Tully-for-Comptroller radio advertisement. Later he conceded that few New York State voters had heard of him, brightening only at the subsequent thought that ''I'm still better known than the other guys.''

title: Judge Hears of Effects Of Nevada Atomic Tests
description: The skin of residents downwind from atomic tests in Nevada sometimes turned pink and developed blisters just as if they had suffered sunburn, even under their clothing, witnesses testified today.

title: NICE GUY, TOUGH GUY
description: President Reagan is engaged these days in an interesting foreign policy gamble. He is trying to change his reputation abroad from Mr. Nice Guy to Mr. Tough Guy.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONCERT: STRING ENSEMBLE
description: THE New York String Ensemble played well under Bruce Ferden's direction at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night. Mr. Ferden has a keen lyrical sense and a technique that allows him to communicate clearly with the players.

title: CANDIDATES WHO WON'T TAKE NO FOR AN ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate; Corporate Revival In Bronx
description: FOR decades the South Bronx's Port Morris section thrived as a light industrial region whose companies profited from their close proximity to Manhattan and the transportation arteries leading to Long Island, upstate New York and New England and to New Jersey and the Middle Western states beyond.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Tradition in the Ivy League has been losing some of its luster over the years. Women are now admitted to all eight schools, and freshman beanies are no longer a rite of passage. There is another tradition that Columbia has long endured, and administrators there happily say it will also soon be gone.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Reflects a gain of $11,850,000 or 32 cents a shr from the sale of portions ofthe Hunter Plant units

title: Index; International
description: U.S. officials fear a new wave of fighting in Lebanon A1 Massacres spread terror in the land of the Maya A2 Polish protesters clash with the police in two cities A3 Marcos leaves Manila for visit to U.S. A3 NBC News ties Soviet and Bul- garia to attempt on Pope's life A3 French insistence on safeguards hinders Indian uranium deal A4 NATO maneuvers show failure to learn from past mistakes A7 Israel silent on reported Gemayel assassination A9 Israeli opposition leader denies having deal with Reagan A11 Reagan names adviser on curb- ing spread of nuclear weapons A13 Government/Politics President asks additions to wilderness system A14 Lawmaker sees Lockheed-Penta- gon ''conspiracy'' A18 Reagan's anticrime package put on Senate calendar A24 Obscurity is shrouding Demo- cratic race for Comptroller B3 Democratic Party ads attack Re- publican economic policies B11 Washington Talk Briefing B8 The panoply of preparation for the Marcos visit B8 An antitrust chief with an impact B8 General Around the Nation A16 New Rochelle police officer killed in Thruway chase B3 Doctor is shot to death in parked car in Gramercy Park section B6 Pilot of crashed DC-10 says he made a life-or-death choice B7 Education/Welfare Black law students to continue boycott of Harvard course A15 The Living Section Food The new yogurts: are they really yogurt? C1

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RIES. By Margaret Atwood. 240 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.50.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Caribbean Storm Heads For the Open Atlantic
description: A tropical storm, its winds at 50 miles per hour, turned away from the central Bahamas today and slowly churned into the open Atlantic Ocean, forecasters said.

title: MARION BARRY, WASHINGTON MAYOR, EASILY WINS 2D-TERM NOMINATION
description: Marion S. Barry Jr., a 46-year-old black who was a civil rights activist of the 1960's, easily won renomination today to a second term as Mayor of the District of Columbia. He defeated Patricia Roberts Harris, 58, a former Carter Administration Cabinet officer, and two other challengers.

title: WHAT ABOUT LEGAL ALIENS WHO WANT TO STAY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Artistic Dispute

title: EX-NBC NEWS CHIEF NAMED TO HEAD U.P.I.
description: William J. Small, the former president of NBC News, will become the new president and chief operating officer of United Press International, the news agency announced yesterday.

title: THE PUERTO RICO REVISION
description: In its efforts to reduce the tax benefits claimed by some companies operating in Puerto Rico, Congress may have inadvertently expanded the opportunities for others, tax experts say. ''I have manufacturing industry clients of various kinds who are not in Puerto Rico who have shown interest in going down there as a result of the new act,'' David H. Rosenbloom of Caplin & Drysdale, a Washington law firm, said in an interview. ''I have my suspicions that the new provision could be a revenue loser, rather than a revenue gainer.''

title: DEAL WITH REAGAN IS DENIED BY PERES
description: Shimon Peres, leader of Israel's opposition Labor Party, denied today that President Reagan had given him advance notice of American peace proposals, or had made a deal to encourage a Labor electoral victory in return for Mr. Peres's support of the President's plan.

title: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Aug 7
Scandal Suspect's Return Sought by Italy
description: Italy began extradition proceedings today against Licio Gelli, the 62-year-old former mattress salesman who became head of the secret Masonic lodge called Progaganda 2, who was arrested Monday in Geneva. A scandal surrounding the lodge last year brought down the Italian Government.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission up to 2.1 million common shares, to be exchanged for $94.4 million of Allied debentures held by Salomon Brothers.

title: THE FIRST STEPS OF A TEAM
description: In a conference room within Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 100 yards from Giants Stadium, the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League are being assembled piece by piece. The tools are computer printouts in thick notebooks, fill-in forms, soda cans, ash trays and telephones, all assembled on one large table.

title: THE MET PRESENTS: 'CANNED' MONTAND
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPOS TOP METS FOR 4TH STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: The Montreal Expos supplied Charlie Lea with three runs tonight, as many as they had provided for him in three previous losing starts. The total made a happy pitcher - and a winner - of the right-hander as the Expos defeated the New York Mets, 3-1.

title: Court Clears Craig
description: After a trial resulting from an automobile accident that killed one woman and injured two other women last spring, the Olympic hockey hero Jim Craig was found not guilty yesterday of vehicular homicide. Craig had waived his right to a jury trial and was acquitted by Judge Dennis Collari of District Court in Wareham, Mass. In his testimony, Craig had said that he had used every means possible to avoid the accident.

title: HEAD OF LNJ TOYS SEES SUCCESS THROUGH 'E.T.'
description: Jack Friedman, president of LJN Toys in New York, expects to cash in on the enormous success of the movie ''E.T., the Extra Terrestrial,'' through licensing agreements.

title: GEMAYEL OF LEBANON IS KILLED IN BOMB BLAST AT PARTY OFFICES
description: President-elect Bashir Gemayel was killed Tuesday when a bomb shattered the headquarters of his Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party in east Beirut. The Government said he would be buried today.

title: No Headline
description: SENATE DEBATE IS LIKELY THIS YEAR ON REAGAN'S ANTICRIME PROPOSALS

title: 4 Spanish Policemen Slain in Basque Ambush
description: Basque separatists ambushed two police cars on a country road today, killing four officers in what was seen as the start of a new terrorist campaign six weeks before Spain's general elections.

title: Debt to the Philippines
description: The rulers of the Philippines, President and Mrs. Marcos, are in the United States this week to be seen as much as to see. Their visit is meant to dispel any rumors, or hopes, about the failing vitality of the House of Marcos. Indeed, they seem to be rehearsing a husbandto-wife succession in the Peron mode.

title: Advertising Panel Concludes 12 Cases
description: Apparently the busiest arm of the advertising business during the dog days of August was its self-regulatory body, the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. The N.A.D. closed 12 cases, rather more than usual, 10 of which were concluded when advertisers changed the challenged claims or stopped using the advertising for one reason or another.

title: House Panel Takes Up; Immigration Measure
description: The House Judiciary Committee began work today on a bill that would penalize employers who knowingly hired illegal aliens and would grant amnesty to millions of such immigrants already living in the United States.

title: CHEWING THE FAT
description: A big corporation has this vital piece of mail. A letter sometimes, sometimes a package. It absolutely must be delivered someplace far away, first thing tomorrow. If not ... Ruination for the entire company.

title: Easco-Evans
description: The Easco Corporation of Baltimore announced an offer to buy up to 1 million common shares of Evans-Aristocrat Industries of Newark, a maker of steel measurement tapes, for $16 each.

title: HAIG, AT U.J.A., CRITICIZES REAGAN'S MIDEAST PLAN
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. attacked President Reagan's Middle East plan yesterday, describing the proposal for a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank as ''a very serious mistake.''

title: Rangers Dancing To Get Extra Edge
description: The Rangers added aerobic dancing to their training camp routine today at the suggestion of their captain, Barry Beck.

title: 2 HOUSE LEADERS URGE BILL TO ENCOURAGE BALANCED BUDGET NEXT YEAR
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee and the House majority whip today proposed legislation that would require the President and Congressional budget panels to submit balanced budgets.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Market Place; The Buying From Abroad
description: WHEN stock prices were climbing in August, foreign investors joined Americans in moving money into the market. British buyers were in the forefront, generally emphasizing the same big-capitalization blue chips favored by domestic money managers.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $369,000...C-Net income after an extraordinary credit of $1,196,000

title: NOVELIST AND POET
description: John Gardner, a novelist, poet and teacher, was killed yesterday in a motorcycle accident near his home in Susquehanna, Pa., the police reported. Mr. Gardner was 49 years old.

title: Memorable Play
description: The single-wing formation still lives, and even wins. In this football era of the T-formation, the wishbone and the buckshot, remember the single-wing?

title: For Lincoln West - Now
description: Promoters of the Lincoln West project, who propose to erect more than 4,000 units of luxury housing in the virtually abandoned mid-Manhattan rail yards along the Hudson, are casting a mighty vote of confidence in the future of New York. The Board of Estimate should reciprocate, finally approving the project before the unrenewable options on the land expire this week.

title: Pope Meets With Salvadoran
description: Pope John Paul II met today with Foreign Minister Fidel Chavez Mena of El Salvador. The Vatican said the meeting took place at the Pope's summer residence south of Rome. It gave no other details.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July
DOCTOR, 53, IS FOUND SHOT TO DEATH NEAR GRAMMERCY PARK OFFICE
description: A 53-year-old physician was shot to death as he sat in his parked car with the engine running early last evening in the Gramercy Park section, the police said.

title: PRIMARIES WON BY EX-GOVERNOR, TWO INCUMBENTS
description: A former Massachusetts Governor trying a comeback and two important members of Congress won key tests yesterday as 12 states and the District of Columbia held primary elections.

title: VACANT TV CHANNELS FOUND VANISHING BY F.C.C. STUDY
description: Broadcasters are running out of television channels to build commercial stations. A report by the Federal Communications Commission shows that in the 100 largest cities, there are 43 commercial UHF channels out of 349 allocated that remain vacant and unapplied for.

title: UNITED MCGILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Confusion In Orange, Blue and White

title: BUSINESSMAN LEADS IN WISCONSIN RACE
description: Terry J. Kohler, a businessman whose father and grandfather were both governors, held a strong lead early this morning in partial returns in Wisconsin's Republican gubernatorial primary.

title: A DAY OF TOO MANY EVENTS
description: B y telephone - they never look you in the eye - I was instructed to cover all four blue-chip New York sports events on the dappled Sunday of Sept. 12. My first mistake was asking how instead of why.

title: Teachers Return In North Plainfield
description: Striking North Plainfield teachers returned to their classrooms yesterday after reaching a tentative contract agreement with the local school board after more than nine hours of negotiations.

title: NECESSITIES FOR BAKING
description: WHETHER or not you are an avid pastry maker, a sturdy baking sheet is an important all-round cooking utensil for any kitchen.
