It is used for everything from warming up bread to catching drips from pies and casseroles. Many of the thin aluminum or tin baking sheets sold today are so flimsy that they buckle as soon as the oven heats up, sometimes with disastrous results.

title: FRENCH FUEL FOR INDIA IN DOUBT
description: France is insisting on tough safeguards for supplying enriched uranium to an American-built atomic power plant near Bombay. As a result, a compromise plan to end a dispute betweeen the United States and India over such supplies by having the French provide them appears to be in trouble.

title: HOOKY: HABIT OR ILLNESS?
description: Every student likes to play hooky occasionally, but some children are so traumatized by school that they develop stomach aches, chest pains and nausea - a disorder called ''school avoidance.''

title: U.S. FEARS NEW BURST IN FIGHTING
description: President Reagan said tonight that the ''cowardly assassination'' of President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon was a ''shock to the American people and to civilized men and women everywhere.''

title: No Headline
description: BREWERS TOP TIGERS ON MONEY'S HITTING

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANKS EASE POLISH INTEREST PAYMENTS
description: In a highly unusual move, Western banks have agreed to postpone interest payments owed by Poland as part of an agreement to reschedule $3.4 billion in Polish debts that fall due in 1982, according to banking officials of Western Europe.

title: NEW ROCHELLE OFFICER KILLED IN CHASE ON THRUWAY
description: One New Rochelle police officer was killed and another seriously injured today when their patrol car crashed during a chase after two robbery suspects on the New England Thruway.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has named Herrick A. Drake vice president, claim department, commercial insurance division.

title: 'DRAFT REGISTRATION SHOULD BE ABOLISHED'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Inco Plans Sale Of Some Units
description: Inco Ltd. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the United States, European, Canadian and Asian operations of its Rayovac battery division to ROV Industries, a private company.

title: GREAT WATCH IDEAS
description: ONCE, watches showed the time. Later, some also gave the date. Others were decked out with multiple dials for astronautics or deepsea diving, although few got higher than a 747 or deeper than a punch bowl.

title: An Aide to Kuhn Leaves the Game
description: Everybody denies that it has anything to do with the fight over Bowie Kuhn's job as commissioner of baseball, which will be decided by the club owners on Nov. 1. But, since the chief issue in the dispute is Kuhn's ability to handle the business side of baseball, eyebrows are being raised over the resignation of his right-hand man for business affairs, Tom Villante.

title: A SURGE OF FAILURES IN EUROPE
description: At no time since World War II has Europe faced a comparable flood of corporate failures. Major companies that have burst into the headlines, like Britain's Laker Airways, the trans-Atlantic carrier that announced its insolvency last February, and AEG-Telefunken, West Germany's tottering electrical giant, are merely the best known of thousands of companies that have collapsed or are in severe financial straits.

title: LOCKHEED-PENTAGON 'CONSPIRACY' IS CHARGED
description: A member of Congress testified today that he believed there had been a ''conspiracy'' involving the Pentagon and the Lockheed Corporation to lobby improperly in behalf of legislation authorizing the purchase of 50 C-5 Lockheed airlift planes.

title: NEWMAN'S SALAD DRESSING: OIL, VINEGAR AND BALLYHOO
description: ''THE reason I went into the salad-dressing business,'' Paul Newman said yesterday in his Fifth Avenue office, ''is because I suddenly realized I needed a power base.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IF YOU'RE IRISH ...

title: Magazine Publishers Elect a President
description: William F. Gorog, a West Pointer and a senior White House staff member during the Ford Administration, yesterday was elected president of the Magazine Publishers Association. On Oct. 1 he will replace Kent Rhodes, the former Reader's Digest executive who agreed to fill the job until a permanent successor could be found for Stephen E. Kelly, who died in April 1978.

title: Request for Testimony
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board has asked a Federal judge in Brooklyn to provide access to the testimony that Eddie Maple gave a grand jury about race-fixing in New York in the mid-1970's. The purpose of its request, the racing board says, is to make sure that Maple does not change his account at a board hearing Sept. 28 on the proposed revocation of the state riding license held by another jockey, Jacinto Vasquez.

title: PRINCESS GRACE IS DEAD AFTER RIVIERA CAR CRASH
description: Princess Grace of Monaco, whose stately beauty and reserve gave her enduring Hollywood stardom even long after she ended her film career, died yesterday in Monte Carlo of injuries suffered when her car plunged off a mountain road Monday. She was 52 years old.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Economic Scene; Less Jittery Financiers
description: THESE are jittery days in Wall Street and in that vast financial network that stretches from Hong Kong to Frankfurt. To be sure, the big money men are feeling a bit more secure than they did before last week's meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Toronto.

title: U.S. FARM EXPORT AID CONSIDERED
description: Under pressure from some farmers, the Reagan Administration is considering subsidies for American agricultural exports to make them more competitive with heavily subsidized Western European exports.

title: U.S. REPORTS JOBLESS RATE TOPS 10% IN 19 STATES
description: Nineteen states had unemployment rates above 10 percent in July, more than six times as many as the same time last year, the Government reported today.

title: Bridge: Bidding Sometimes Shows Exactly How the Cards Lie
description: Those who know little about the game sometimes sing the praises of some third party by announcing in tones of amazement, ''He knows every card you have in your hand, right from the start.''

title: ISRAELIS PUT OFF OFFICIAL COMMENT
description: An Israeli Government spokesman declined comment tonight on the assassination of Lebanon's President-elect, Bashir Gemayel.

title: Banks to Help AEG
description: Twenty of a group of 22 West German banks have agreed to make available to AEG-Telefunken A.G. the equivalent of $100 million of an unguaranteed $270 million credit, a statement issued today said. The statement added that the banks also would provide credits for $270 million of a Government-guaranteed credit.

title: Graham Sidelined by Injury
description: Doctors have ordered the Rev. Billy Graham to bed at his home in Montreat, N.C., for at least two weeks to recuperate from a back injury suffered in a fall, officials of his headquarters said today.

title: GEMAYEL'S IMPORTANCE
description: In the midst of unhappiness, in the distress of an endless war, a fragile hope was born in Lebanon. It was assassinated with Bashir Gemayel. The bomb that killed the President-elect confirmed one thing: Many powerful people want Lebanon to be erased from the map. On Tuesday, at Ashrafiye, someone tried to eliminate more than a man. The bomb that killed Gemayel also threatened the life of the state.

title: Plant in Queens May Be Closed
description: Closing of the Cerro Wire and Cable Corporation's plant in Maspeth, Queens, is under consideration, its parent company announced yesterday in Chicago. The plant employs 800.

title: DOW AT 930.46, 13-MONTH HIGH
description: A late rally enabled the stock market to post a moderate gain yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest closing level in more than a year.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by the International Business Machines Corporation to dismiss and sue three executives on charges of stealing corporate secrets is the second bombshell in a war the giant computer company has begun to keep competitors from exploiting I.B.M. technology.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO EASE SHIP ANTITRUST RULES
description: The House of Representatives today approved, by a vote of 350 to 33, a bill that largely exempts shipowners from antitrust laws.

title: A.T.&T. GAINS 5.3% IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that net income in the three months ended Aug. 31 rose 5.3 percent, while revenues increased 10.7 percent.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MAN ACCUSED OF PLOTTING TO HACK OFF HIS FOOT
description: A man had two friends chop off his foot with a hatchet to fool investigators in a $210,000 insurance swindle, the authorities said today.

title: Elusive Perfection
description: Glenn Allison refuses to give up the quest to have his 900 series sanctioned by the American Bowling Congress. Yesterday, Allison's four-page appeal to the high-score awards committee of the A.B.C. was mailed from Alhambra, Calif.

title: SENSING INCENSE WITH 'EARS OF THE SPIRIT'
description: THERE'S more to incense than meets the nose. For instance, although it might not have occurred to many people in this country, there's such a thing as ''listening'' to the incense scent.

title: Holders Approve Takeover by Best
description: The Best Products Company, the nation's largest catalogue showroom retailer, said its accquisition of Modern Merchandising Inc. had been approved by the shareholders of both companies.

title: Two Mideast Bombs and a Flare
description: Simultaneously on Monday, two ugly bombshells and a bright diplomatic flare lit the Middle East sky. The bomb throwers - an unknown terrorist in Beirut and a former Secretary of State in New York - certainly damaged the promise in King Hussein's message from Jordan. Sabotage is always easy in a powderkeg.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 47 Greeks Defy Ban On Marquis de Sade
description: The Government today ordered the arrest and trial of 47 publishers who it said had defied a ban on publishing the works of the Marquis de Sade.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $47 BILLION FOR HOUSING AND URBAN AID
description: The House today approved a bill providing $47 billion for housing and urban development in the 1983 fiscal year. The vote was 343 to 38.

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Former Player Sues
description: A former football player at the University of Illinois has filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against a team physician, charging that a cancer was misdiagnosed. Marty Finis, a starting guard two years ago, is asking for $2 million each in punitive damages from Dr. David Hamilton and the univerity's athletic association. Finis said that Dr. Hamilton ''carelessly and negligently'' misdiagnosed a growth on his neck as a cyst when he had what turned out to be Hodgkins disease.

title: CONCERT: LEONTYNE PRICE
description: THE New York Philharmonic has a push-button system for its seasonopening program, which is traditionally a benefit concert for the orchestra's pension fund. The one idea seems to be to engage the biggest name available as a soloist and build the evening around the star's glamour and appeal.

title: LIVING BY THE SWORD
description: In sending its forces into West Beirut in cold violation of the truce terms, the Israeli Government said it was acting to maintain order after the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel. But there can be little doubt about the larger purpose of the move - and of others likely to follow in Lebanon. That is to derail President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative.

title: ISRAEL DRIVES ON WEST BEIRUT TO PREVENT GUERRILLA GAINS AFTER SLAYING OF GEMAYEL
description: Israeli troops and tanks pushed into west Beirut in force today in a drive prompted by the assassination on Tuesday of Lebanon's President-elect, Bashir Gemayel.

title: New Chief At Doyle Dane
description: Neil R. Austrian, 42-year-old money man turned adman, yesterday became the primary buck stopper at Doyle Dane Bernbach International, replacing Joseph R. Daly, 64, as chief executive. Mr. Austrian will remain president, while Mr. Daly, with a contract to 1987, continues as chairman.

title: Police Seek Motive In Doctor's Killing
description: Detectives were seeking a motive yesterday for the killing of a Manhattan physician near his Gramercy Park office on Tuesday evening. ''As far as we know, nothing was taken, but he may have been the victim of an aborted robbery,'' said Deputy Inspector Stephen D. Kelly.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for QTr to July 31
Americans in Laos Visit 1972 Crash Site
description: Four Americans looking for relatives missing in the Vietnam War said today that they had found the wreckage, in Laos, of an Air Force C-130 and the remains of its crew, convincing a Florida woman that her husband was dead.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a special charge of $271,812 or 10 cents a shr from the previously announced sale of the company's New Jersey property...C-After extraordinary gain of $752,638 or 28 cents a shr

title: No Headline
description: Christian Ferras, 49, Violinist From France

title: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for QTr to July 31
N.F.L. PLAYERS SET TUESDAY DEADLINE
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said last night that unless the league owners were ''serious about bargaining'' when contract negotiations resume tomorrow, a player strike would begin next Tuesday.

title: 55 ARRESTED IN PROTEST AT A TOXIC DUMP IN CAROLINA
description: A four-year struggle over the disposal of soil contaminated with PCB's seemed at an end today. The state police removed 67 demonstrators from a rural road here, arresting 55, and then a convoy of 10 dump trucks began to bury the soil.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advocate Mines Ltd., which is 30.6 percent owned by Johns Manville Canada Inc., said its Baie Verte asbestos properties had been expropriated by the Newfoundland government; compensation for the mine, which ceased operation last December, will be set later.

title: JAZZ: FREEMAN-COX DUO
description: FOR more than 25 years, Willie Ruff and Dwike Mitchell have been the only jazz duo using piano, French horn and bass -with Mr. Mitchell playing piano, Mr. Ruff doubling on horn and bass. But their monopoly is now being challenged by Sharon Freeman who, with Anthony Cox, is leading a duo with the same instrumentation at Village West through Sunday.

title: HOUSE UNIT STARTS INQUIRY ON REAGAN PANEL'S WORK
description: A House panel has begun an investigation of a Presidential advisory committee of leading business executives, appointed by President Reagan to recommend ways to reduce Government waste and improve the efficiency of Federal agencies.

title: Primary Choices for the City Council
description: All except at-large members of New York's City Council are due for election in November but in many districts, next Thursday's Democratic primary will determine the winner. Our comments here are on those races that offer the voter a clear choice, and give weight to the importance of seniority and incumbency. MANHATTAN

title: AMOSKEAG CO reports earnings for QTr to June 30
Caltex Deal in Thailand
description: Caltex Oil (Thailand) said today that it had taken over the service stations and other Thailand marketing assets of Summit Oil, a Panamanian company. Caltex did not disclose the cost of the takeover, but the assets have been informally estimated as worth $30 million.

title: BEWARE THE WEDGE
description: What a thrilling 24 hours for Yasir Arafat: first hailed in a cablegram from Leonid Brezhnev for a victory through which ''the international positions of the P.L.O. have grown considerably stronger''; then buoyed by the news of the murder of Bashir Gamayel, his most effective Christian enemy in Lebanon; finally, basking in the political blessing of a personal reception by Pope John Paul II in the Vatican.

title: Rookie Holds On to a Dream
description: S teve Richmond, a rookie at the Rangers' training camp at Rye, N.Y., grew up in Chicago. His hockey hero was Bobby Hull, the former Black Hawk star who was a scoring ace, a spectacularly toothless one.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION FALLS 0.5%
description: Industrial production dropped five-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today, reflecting the continuing decline in the economy and signaling a delay in the longpromised recovery until late fall or early winter.

title: GALTIERI MUSES ON WHAT-IF'S OF FALKLAND WAR
description: Argentina should have continued its war with Britain even after Argentine forces were defeated in the Falkland Islands, former President Leopoldo Galtieri said in an interview published today.

title: Alabama Governor Vows To Ignore Prayer Law
description: Gov. Fob James of Alabama, turned away at the Supreme Court, called on the state's teachers and students today to defy a Federal court injunction banning prayer in public schools.

title: SECOND SUSPECT HELD FOR MURDER IN MASSELLI CASE
description: A 67-year-old leader of the Genovese crime family in the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of Nathan Masselli, a witness in the now-ended Federal investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: EGYPT ASSAILS ISRAELI MOVE INTO WEST BEIRUT
description: The Egyptian Government today formally deplored the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon and denounced the Israeli move into west Beirut as an ''obstacle in the way of the peace process.''

title: Braniff Funds Face Inquiry
description: Four pension funds of grounded Braniff Airways Inc. are $57 million short and Federal officials said today that they planned to investigate the deficit from a ''civil and criminal perspective.''

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SOVIET OFFERS A 6-POINT PLAN FOR PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today presented a six-point summary of the Soviet position on a Middle East settlement that he said was ''not at variance'' with the Arab plan adopted in Fez, Morocco.

title: Texas Instruments In I.B.M. Venture
description: Texas Instruments and the International Business Machines Corporation have entered a joint agreement to develop sophisticated integrated circuit silicon chips for use in business office networks that will link computers and office machines, the companies announced jointly.

title: ARAFAT SEES POPE AND ITALY'S LEADER
description: Yasir Arafat was received today by Pope John Paul II, President Sandro Pertini and Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo and was given a standing ovation before and after an address to the Interparliamentary Union.

title: U.S. IS UNEASY OVER ISRAEL'S BEIRUT MOVE
description: The United States expressed concern today that Israel's sudden military move into west Beirut could worsen an already tense situation in the aftermath of the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel.

title: 'Ear' Columnist Goes To Washington Times
description: Diana McLellan, writer of ''The Ear,'' a gossip column, quit The Washington Post today and said she would join The Washington Times ''for money and for fun.''

title: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $14,063 for the qr and $136,833 for the 9 mos...C-Net los

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DRUG PATENTS BILL IS DEFEATED
description: A bill that would have extended the term for drug patents was defeated in the House today as opponents argued that passage would keep less expensive generic drugs off the market.

title: Outlook for Telefunken
description: AEG-Telefunken expects a $400 million loss in 1982 before a return to profitability in 1984, the financial newspaper Boersen-Zeitung said today. It cited a 260-page report presented to the company's bankers Tuesday. An AEG spokesman declined to comment.

title: U.S. Exports To China Fall
description: The value of American exports to China fell 6 percent in the first six months of this year compared with the comparable period in 1981, while total trade between the two countries increased by 2 percent, the United States Embassy reported today.

title: Ogden Completes Allied Acquisition
description: The Ogden Corporation said it had completed its $112.8 million acquisition of the Allied Maintenance Corporation through a tax-free exchange of stock.

title: People
description: * Simon Kornblit named executive vice president and director of client services at Doyle Dane Bernbach/ Los Angeles.

title: Blaze Claims 24th Victim
description: A young woman who lost eight relatives in a Sept. 4 apartment fire has become the 24th victim of the blaze, officials say.

title: No Headline
description: LEBANESE UNRAVEL THE SIX HOURS OF CONFUSION

title: FMC Staff Cuts
description: The FMC Corporation acknowledged that it was laying off an unspecified number of its 600 corporate staff employees, but denied reports that the figure would be as much as 40 percent.

title: Books Of The Times
description: FAMILY HAPPINESS. By Laurie Colwin. 271 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canada's Export Development Corp. will issue a $100 million (U.S.) Eurobond, priced at 99.75 to yield 13.32 percent, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.

title: WHEN COMPOSER OFFERS WORDS ABOUT HIS MUSIC
description: We rarely have the courage to let music speak for itself. Romantic commentators a century ago saw soft breezes in a dotted rhythm, sunsets in arpeggios and tales of unhappy love in simple diminished seventh chords. Purveyors of new music - fearful that their adventurous techniques will be misunderstood (or ignored) or perhaps afraid that their compositions lack dimensions that only program notes can add - carry on the work.

title: OPERA: MILNES AS HAMLET
description: AMBROISE THOMAS'S ''Hamlet'' is a work that every opera fanatic should see once. Perhaps even twice, to be absolutely sure that what goes on in this variation on a theme by Shakespeare is not, perchance, a dream. The chance of a lifetime came Tuesday night as the New York City Opera began its season of regular repertory after a weeklong operetta prelude.

title: Devine Stays Put
description: After exploratory talks with the owners of the Arizona franchise of the new United States Football League, Dan Devine says that he plans to remain as director of the Sun Angel Foundation, a booster organization for Arizona State University.

title: Asbestos Suits Cleared To Proceed; Asbestos Suits Cleared
description: Asbestos-related damage suits against more than a dozen companies can proceed, despite a stay in cases involving two other corporations that filed for reorganization, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Standex Dividend
description: The Standex International Corporation said Tuesday that it planned to distribute to its shareholders as a dividend in early 1983 the common stock of its Dresher Manufacturing division, which makes brass beds and accessories. Details are to be determined later.

title: THE CARIBBEAN WAITS
description: With only three weeks remaining before the October recess, Congress has yet to pass more than half of President Reagan's aid package for the Caribbean region. That's unfortunate, for this foreign policy initiative has a chance to succeed.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Rodrigo Colon Sanchez, 55, Headed World Boxing Group
description: Rodrigo Colon Sanchez, president of the World Boxing Association, died of cancer Tuesday after a two-year illness, a spokesman for the Social Security Hospital said today.

title: ORIOLES AGAIN RALLY TO DEFEAT YANKEES
description: There was little different in tonight's game between the Yankees and the Orioles from the first three games of the five-game series. The Yankees took a lead, and Baltimore came back and won.

title: Gambling Inquiry Nets State Trooper
description: A state trooper was charged with illegal gambling today. He is the second police officer arrested in connection with an alleged illegal sports-betting operation in the Torrington area.

title: Copter Crash Victims Named
description: All five servicemen who died on a United States Marine helicopter that crashed into the North Sea Tuesday were from Texas, a Marine spokesman said today. The victims were identified as a Navy commander, David R. Morrison of Dallas, and four marines, Capt. William H. Coke of Court Hurst, Capt. James Huff of the Colony, Staff Sgt. Gary J. Lester of Arlington and Sgt. Timothy A. Creighton of Grand Prairie.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PREPARING POINSETTIAS
description: THE time has almost come to start the closet routine for poinsettias. Starting toward the end of this month until mid-November, the plants should be put into a closet every night at 5 P.M. and brought out again every morning at 7 A.M. If this ritual is followed for about six to seven weeks, the plants could be in bloom for Christmas. If not the plant may remain all leaves for the rest of its life.

title: Article 153980 -- No Title
description: The French Government said today that it would seek a $4 billion syndicated loan to defend the franc on foreign exchange markets.

title: ISRAELI CENSORS CRACK DOWN ON THE ARAB PRESS
description: Israeli security officials have closed down a Palestinian press service here at a time of heavy Israeli censorship of the Arab press.

title: MIDEAST PREREQUISITE FOR THE 'WEDDING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mt. Vernon Nurses Go on Strike
description: Nurses at Mount Vernon Hospital went on strike today in a contract dispute, forcing supervisory personnel to take over their duties, officials said.

title: A Heinz Man Is Named President of Star-Kist
description: Richard L. Beattie has been named president of Star-Kist Foods, the H.J. Heinz Company's largest subsidiary, and will be the first Heinztrained man to head the unit since it was acquired in 1963.

title: PLAYS
description: O ne thing about the Pittsburgh Pirates: They usually don't beat you with finesse. ''They come at you swinging,'' says Sparky Anderson, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, remembering his years managing Cincinnati in the National League. ''They swing at the first pitch, at the second pitch, at any pitch.''

title: Bridge: The Way a Player Thinks Suggests How Good He Is
description: The art of looking into the opponents' hands, by clear thinking rather than by good eyesight, is one of the most obvious ways of separating the sheep from the wolves at the bridge table. There have been a number of excellent books in this important field in the past two decades, but none of them have surpassed the first in the line: ''All 52 Cards'' by Marshall Miles, originally published in 1963.

title: Swiss Refusing to Extradite 4 Who Seized Polish Embassy
description: Switzerland will definitely not extradite the four gunmen who occupied the Polish Embassy for three days last week and is determined to try them in a Swiss court, the Justice Ministry said today.

title: BARBARA BUSH SAYS ILLITERACY IS AN EPIDEMIC
description: Barbara Bush, the wife of the Vice President, brought her national campaign against illiteracy to New York City yesterday, urging an organization of journalists to ''spread the word about the epidemic problem'' and to encourage the public to support teachers.

title: STATE PANEL TOLD ABOUT VIOLENCE IN CONSTRUCTION
description: The State Commission of Investigation was told yesterday that the city's electrical-contracting industry was beleaguered by violence, arson and bombings, apparently because of a jurisdictional dispute between two unions.

title: RCA Creates Magazine For the Video Market
description: At a press conference yesterday, the gang from RCA Consumer Electronics did not make any news with their ad budget, since they do not announce it and since there would not be much to say if they did (thanks to the economy). But they did show off a magazine they have created as a traffic builder for their dealer showrooms.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1982
description: International Israeli troops took positions in west Beirut in a drive prompted by the assassination on Tuesday of Lebanon's President-elect, Bashir Gemayel. The Israelis ran into some resistance from Lebanese Moslem and leftist militiamen. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan called for the withdrawal of the Israeli troops. (Page A1, Col.6.) Prime Minister Menachem Begin reportedly told the American speical envoy, Morris Draper, that he ordered Israeli troops into west Beruit to prevent the reorganization of the Palestine Liberation Organization and leftist Moslem militias. The move was designed to salvage Israel's political gains in Lebanon following the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel. (A1:4.)

title: Good Business
description: The vendors hawking T-shirts, caps and other mementos were not the only ones trying to make money at Flushing Meadows last Sunday. Scalpers were working the National Tennis Center and Shea Stadium in their cloak-and-dagger style.

title: Rift May Delay Hibernia Plan
description: Oil production from the Hibernia field off Canada's east coast could be delayed because of a jurisdictional dispute between the Canadian and Newfoundland governments, Gulf Canada Ltd. said today.

title: Disputed School Reopens
description: The Rev. Jim Lee, acting pastor of Faith Baptist Church, said that, despite a shutdown order, the church school reopened today with 14 students. The Rev. Everett Sileven, its superintendant, was jailed for resisting a shutdown order because it failed to meet state standards for teacher certification.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BY DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES FOR NEW YORK GOVERNOR
description: These are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Koch, Democratic candidates for Governor of New York. Crime

title: Carpenter Plan Is Liked
description: George Young, the general manager of the Giants, responding to published reports indicating that the fullback Rob Carpenter would report if the team promised to renegotiate later, said today that he would be happy to agree to the proposal.

title: Trials Under Way For Plotters in Kenya
description: A Kenyan official said today that military trials were being held for air force rebels who tried to topple President Daniel arap Moi on Aug. 1 and also that 17 men had received long prison terms.

title: 57% of Jersey Cars Fail Spot Inspection
description: Teams of roving New Jersey inspectors failed 57 percent of the vehicles randomly tested in a week-old program, the Division of Motor Vehicles said today.

title: West Europeans Voice Concern Over Lebanon
description: The British Government expressed shock today at the assassination of Bashir Gemayel, the President-elect of Lebanon, and called for restraint from all parties.

title: South Atlantic Suit
description: The South Atlantic Financial Corporation, a Miami concern, said a suit had been filed against it by the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company that could force it to liquidate its assets or file for bankruptcy. The Schroder concern, acting as indenture trustee, is seeking payment on behalf of holders of South Atlantic's $16.9 million of 6 3/4 percent subordinated debentures which matured on Feb. 15 and which are currently in default.

title: N.C.A.A. TELECAST RIGHTS ON FOOTBALL STRUCK DOWN
description: A Federal District judge, calling the National Collegiate Athletic Association a ''classic cartel,'' ruled yesterday that only an individual college has the proper authority to sell television rights to games involving its football team.

title: Trane Discloses Cash Paid to G.E.
description: The Trane Company disclosed that it bought the General Electric Company's central air-conditioning business for $135 million in cash, thus circumventing a shareholder vote that would have been required to ratify a cash-stock transaction proposed earlier.

title: WILLIAM T. FAUNTROY Sr.
description: William T. Fauntroy Sr., the father of Walter E. Fauntroy, the Delegate to Congress from the District of Columbia, died at Howard University Hospital here Tuesday.

title: O.A.U. SAID TO TRY TO REVIVE MEETING
description: On the beachfront here stand Tripoli's new hotels, the Bab el Bahar, for one, the Grand for another, white and dazzling. They were built quickly to house delegates, officials and journalists for what should have been the Organization of African Unity's annual conference in August.

title: EAST SIDE LANDMARK GROUP SET
description: WHEN the Upper East Side Historic District was created by the Landmarks Preservation Commission last year, it was hailed by preservationists as a victory second in importance only to the successful effort to save Grand Central Terminal from demolition.

title: WHAT AUTHORS DO TO PROTECT MSS
description: In 1972, the only copy of a 400-page uncompleted manuscript was stolen from the front seat of Sharon Kay Penman's automobile. The shock was such that she could not write another word for the next five years. But she eventually started over, and next month Holt, Rinehart & Winston will publish her 928-page novel of Richard III, ''The Sunnein Splendor.''

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $2,000 for the qr and $224,000 for the yr and income from discontinued operations of $105,496 for the yr

title: Big but Not Slow
description: After only one collegiate football season, William Perry became something of a 300-pound legend at Clemson University. As a sophomore, Perry continues to defy the scales.

title: POLE GOES HOME VOLUNTARILY TO FACE PLOT CHARGES
description: A leading dissident intellectual flew home today to voluntarily face charges by the military authorities of plotting to overthrow the Polish Government by force.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox player who has been in a coma since suffering a heart attack last Jan. 9, was reported in fair condition after undergoing surgery at Salem (Mass.) Hospital. Doctors removed fluid from his lungs after a recurrence of pneumonia. ... The United States track and field team has added Carl Lewis, a sprinter and long jumper, for the Eight Nations Games to be held in Tokyo Sept. 25. ... A House human rights subcommittee has approved a resolution asking the International Olympic Committee to restore the two gold medals that Jim Thorpe won at the 1912 Olympic Games, but was stripped of by the I.O.C. because he had violated amateur rules as a teen-ager. ... Gerry (Tex) Ehman, the Islanders' director of player personnel, has been appointed to the additional posts of assistant general manager and director of scouting. Ehman, 49, played right wing for eight years in the National Hockey League for Boston, Toronto, Detroit and California until his retirement in 1971.

title: V.A. ASSAILED ON DELAYING AGENT ORANGE STUDY
description: The chairman of the informal Vietman veterans' caucus in Congress charged yesterday that ''certain parties in the V.A. are deliberately trying to delay the Agent Orange study.''

title: HERS
description: HAPPINESS is still new to me, so I still notice things about it. Mainly I notice what it is and what it isn't. For example, it isn't cheeriness. I know that because, although I am cheery now, when I was miserable I was even (albeit defensively) cheerier. Nor is happiness having everything you want. If you have that you're probably dead. Same goes for the other notion about happiness: it does not mean that bad things stop happening to you. If bad things stopped happening to you, you'd probably be dead, too.

title: Hoboken to Regain 3 Piers From U.S.
description: A bill passed by Congress requires the Federal Government to sell back to Hoboken three Hudson River piers it confiscated during World War I.

title: PARENTS FIGHT IT
description: A Manhattan grand jury is trying to subpoena a 10-year-old Roosevelt Island boy in a burglary investigation, and his parents are fighting the move, contending that the experience would be too emotionally disturbing.

title: KING LOSES TO DUKAKIS IN MASSACHUSETTS RACE
description: A little after midnight today, Gov. Edward J. King faced his supporters to concede that he had lost Tuesday's Democratic primary to former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the man he defeated four years ago.

title: LEXICON
description: Washington continually generates new words to express old ideas. Here are some examples now circulating:

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The U.N. Today; Sept. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Committee - 11 A.M.

title: A BUSINESS SCHOOL'S STRUGGLE
description: Columbia University's Graduate School of Business is, by many accounts, an institution with an inferiority complex. Indeed, at this summer's student revue the biggest laugh line went something like this: ''What are Harvard, Stanford, and Columbia?'' ''Two prestigious business schools and a small country in South America.''

title: 7 Mayors Tell the President Of Pain and Suffering in Cities
description: Seven mayors told President Reagan today of widespread ''pain and suffering'' in the cities and appealed for programs to put people back to work and repair deteriorated urban areas.

title: REAGAN SENDS ADVISER ON A MISSION TO MEXICO
description: President Reagan today sent William P. Clark, the national security adviser, to Mexico City to attend Independence Day festivities, confer with Mexican leaders and raise the possibility of a meeting soon between Mr. Reagan and Mexico's President-elect.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE BACKS PENALTIES FOR THOSE WHO HIRE ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The House Judiciary Committee, in its first votes on a comprehensive immigration bill, today endorsed fines and jail terms for employers who hire illegal aliens.

title: LAPORTE STOPS MIRANDA FOR W.B.C. TITLE
description: Juan LaPorte, who began his fighting career on the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant, won the World Boxing Council featherweight title last night when Mario Miranda's handlers cut off his gloves after the 10th round.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avnet Inc. has elected to its board Salvatore J. Nuzzo, president and chief executive officer of the Hazeltine Corporation.

title: CANNON IS VICTOR IN NEVADA CONTEST
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon successfully turned back Representative James D. Santini's strong challenge Tuesday to win renomination by Nevada's Democrats to a fifth term.

title: METS BEATEN BY HOMER IN 11TH
description: After Andre Dawson hit a leadoff homer in the 11th inning tonight to give the Montreal Expos a 6-5 victory over the New York Mets, he celebrated by soaking his hands in ice.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a pretax gain of $491,445 from the sale of real estate and a tax creditof $227,671...C-Net loss

title: Paterson Steps Down As Secretary of State
description: Basil A. Paterson resigned yesterday as New York's Secretary of State and designated the first deputy secretary of state, Charles E. Williams 3d, as his successor. Mr. Williams will assume his duties on Oct. 1, when Mr. Paterson's resignation becomes effective.

title: Bluefish and Tuna Running in Local Waters
description: Margate, N.J.: Offshore catches of large bluefish continue, and a few Atlantic bonito are mixed with the blues. Yellowfin and bigeye tuna and white and blue marlin have been good in Wilmington Canyon. A most infrequent visitor this far north, an 88-pound wahoo, was caught recently. Barnegat, N.J.: Hudson Canyon anglers are boating bigeye, yellowfin and longfin tuna; flounder good two to three miles off shore. Point Pleasant, N.J.: The party boat half-day trips for fluke continue; day-and-night off-shore bluefishing. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Beach anglers are catching large weakfish in late afternoon on metal and plugs, and mixed with them are albacore and small bluefish. Small striper bass are plentiful along the beach from Sea Bright to Sandy Hook and the small porgies are plentiful.Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Good flukefishing, 8 pounds and more; plenty of blackfish and small bluefish; weakfish are scattered. Freeport, L.I.: Flounder and fluke good off Ambrose. Medium to large bluefish numerous over Cholera Bank in 60 to 80 feet. Some Atlantic bonito on top. Blackfishing good over wrecks. Captree State Park, L.I.: Flounder improving, fluke slow. Plenty of blackfish and porgies and a few small bluefish are around. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Flounder and blowfish plentiful and snapper blues up to a pound are everywhere. Angling for sea bass, sand porgies and small blackfish is good. Shinnecock, L.I.: Bigeye tuna, yellowfin tuna to 145 pounds and albacore being taken in Block Canyon. Montauk, L.I.: Small bluefin tuna are numerous between Cox's Ledge and Nomans Land Island.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: B-After tax credits of $138,000 for the qr and $422,000 for the yr...C-After tax credits of $138,000 for the qr and $386,000 for the yr

title: G.O.P. CHALLENGERS GET LOW PRIORITY
description: This is not a great year for Republican challengers running against Democratic incumbents. In a way, the current crop of Republican aspirants is falling victim to the party's overwhelming success in the 1980 elections, when 52 new Republicans won seats in the House of Representatives.

title: 16 OF THE 56 FATALITIES IN AIR CRASH IN SPAIN ARE IDENTIFIED IN FIRST LIST
description: The first list of those who were killed in the crash of a charter jetliner in Malaga, Spain, was released yesterday by the United States Embassy in Madrid, more than 48 hours after Monday's crash. The list, provided by the Spanish Government, identified 16 of the 56 bodies found so far.

title: MALONE GOES TO 76ERS FOR CALDWELL JONES
description: The Philadelphia 76ers today acquired Moses Malone, the National Basketball Association's most valuable player last season, in a trade with the Houston Rockets for the veteran center Caldwell Jones and Philadelphia's No. 1 selection in next year's draft.

title: U.P.S. Workers End 2-Day Strike
description: A two-day strike by employees of United Parcel Service in North Jersey and Rockland and Orange Counties and on Staten Island ended today after both sides agreed to arbitration.

title: A WIDER SELECTION IN CHILDREN'S VIDEO
description: RECENTLY ''Dumbo'' showed up with ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' and a few weeks ago ''Winnie the Pooh'' appeared in the company of ''Arthur.'' The Disney animations, making Billboard's video cassette best-sellers chart, are just two of the dozens of prerecorded children's programs available for playback with home videotape and videodisk equipment.

title: A TUITION ADVANCE FUND SHOULD BE PART OF THE SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 on L.I. Face Charges In Veterans' Kickbacks
description: A former New York State veterans' affairs counselor and a retired New York City police officer were indicted along with a third man yesterday by a Nassau County grand jury on charges of taking at least $75,000 in kickbacks for helping veterans to obtain Social Security disability benefits.

title: Broom Dance Is Winner
description: Broom Dance took a large step into the chaotic contest for the 3-year-old filly championship with an upset victory in the $55,600 Gazelle Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: 2 STARTERS FOR GIANTS SIDELINED
description: The Giants learned today that they would face the Green Bay Packers here Monday night without Terry Jackson and Jeff Weston, two key starters. Jackson, the right cornerback, will miss two or three games with a hyperextended right knee. Weston, the left offensive tackle, has a bone chip in the left knee. Only a ''miraculous recovery,'' said Coach Ray Perkins, can get Weston ready for the Packers.

title: SOME WALKOUTS REPORTED AS CHRYSLER TALKS GO ON
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation failed to reach agreement on a new contract Wednesday night, but continued talking, leaving it unclear whether the auto maker's plants would open in the morning.

title: SHERO GETS RADIO JOB FOR ALL DEVILS' GAMES
description: The New Jersey Devils, competing in a congested hockey market, have hired Fred Shero as an analyst on the team's radio broadcasts.

title: WHAT'S HOLDING UP ATOM WASTE REPROCESSING
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Crowds Flee Bermuda With Hurricane Near
description: The leading edge of the hurricane designated Debby struck Bermuda late today with 110-mile-an-hour winds at its center.

title: 'RETIREMENT VILLAGE' IS AN ANIMAL HAVEN
description: The tired and the toothless, the sick and the lame: beasts of all varieties can spend their final years at the Wild Animal Retirement Village.

title: OPERA GROUP IN PACT WITH PHILIPPINES
description: Despite criticism from some patrons and human rights activists, the Opera Company of Boston has completed plans to create an opera group in Manila under an agreement signed with Imelda R. Marcos, the wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.

title: KIM Il SUNG VISITS CHINA BY RAIL
description: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea arrived by rail today on his first visit to China in seven years.

title: Women and Careers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I agree with Betty Rollin's argument (''Hers,'' Sept. 2) that feature writing is as important and probably more satisfying than ''hard'' news reporting, but does it need arguing? Like novels and poetry, feature writing is important to writer and reader. That Miss Rollin prefers it to ''hard'' reporting suggests perhaps a philosophical bent rather than an ideological issue.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1981 shrs outstdng and shr earnings have been restated to give effect to the 10 percent stock divd in July 1982

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Fordham 35

title: WAITING FOR GERRY COONEY
description: I n the late afternoon, the shadows fall across Eighth Avenue as the boxers hurry along the sidewalk on West 30th Street toward Gleason's Gym, where they train. For six years, Gerry Cooney, in his tweed cap and running suit, walked along that sidewalk and turned into the gym, where the trainer Victor Valle developed him into a contender. But ever since Victor Valle ducked through the ropes and wrapped his arms around Gerry Cooney, wobbling and dazed, in the 13th round of the heavyweight championship fight with Larry Holmes last June 11 at Las Vegas, Nev., the boxer has not returned to the gym.

title: Fed Moves Push Rates Higher
description: Interest rates rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve temporarily drained reserves from the banking system. By late in the day, Treasury bill rates had increased as much as three-tenths of a percentage point, to 8.05 percent for the three-month issue, while prices of outstanding notes and bonds were lower by a quarter to three-quarters of a point.

title: JAZZ: RANDY WESTON
description: IF African talking drums were to sing and crack jokes, they might sound like the pianist Randy Weston's current trio, which is at Sweet Basil through Saturday. Mr. Weston is backed by Abdul Malik on bass and Candido on conga drums, and their music is a lesson in drive, economy and the droll use of space.

title: KRISTJAN ELDJARN, FORMER PRESIDENT OF ICELAND
description: Former President Kristjan Eldjarn of Iceland died Monday in Cleveland, Ohio, where he was being treated for a heart ailment, the Government announced today. He was 65 years old.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. While the Orioles press on in the pennant race, the Yankees try to stave off mathematical elimination by starting Dave Righetti against Jim Palmer.

title: Stock Repurchase Sought by Liberty
description: The Liberty Corporation of Greenville, S.C., said its board had authorized a tender for up to 3 million of its own shares, or about 23 percent of those outstanding, at $16 each. It added that it reserved the right to buy an additional 250,000 shares under the offer.

title: THE GULF OF MEXICO IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE KILLS PLAN TO CURB ABORTION BY A VOTE OF 47-46
description: The Senate today voted to kill a proposal to restrict severely a woman's right to obtain an abortion. The vote was 47 to 46, with Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, providing the deciding vote after the issue seemed stalemated.

title: ROCK CONCERT: FLEETWOOD MAC ON 'MIRAGE' TOUR
description: FLEETWOOD MAC'S records have always been better than its live shows. On records, the band has achieved a lovable blend of lyrical effervescence and studio polish. In concert, subtleties have been coarsened and Stevie Nicks in particular has undercut her impact with raw singing and loopy stage behavior.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $27,145 and a gain of $1.8 million or 83 cents a shr from sale of holdings in Manufacturers Bank of Los Angeles...C-After income from discontinued operations of $3,106

title: The Real Thing
description: One way to estimate an American's age is whether he calls the beautiful blonde who died this week Grace Kelly or Princess Grace. If the former, he is old enough to remember the McCarthy investigations, liking Ike, the suburban dream, and the remarkable sangfroid of a young woman swamped by reporters as she sailed to Europe to marry a prince.

title: Technology; Keeping Pace With Paints
description: THE occasional tendency of technological advances to cancel each other out seemed to be illustrated in two press releases issued this spring. The first, from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's manufacturing arm, Western Electric, announced the development of a paint remover that the company described as ''a chemist's dream.'' The product, a gel, is designed to wipe out graffiti in thousands of Bell System telephone booths.

title: HOMETOWN MOURNS GRACE KELLY, GIRL WHO NEVER LOST TOUCH
description: Before the Phillies game began Tuesday night, the television announcer Harry Kalas said on the air, ''This is a sad day for Philadelphia.''

title: News Analysis
description: Incumbents were the big winners again Tuesday as the 1982 election results continued to reflect resistance to political change. While Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts was defeated, he was the first governor to lose this year.

title: A GRIEVING MONACO IS ASKING QUESTIONS
description: A small place that usually works hard at offering its guests genteel recklessness and expensive fun, Monaco looked sad and confused today about the death of Princess Grace.

title: Carrier Layoffs
description: The Carrier Corporation announced the furlough of 433 production workers, bringing to 1,100 the number of employees laid off since May.

title: REMOVING SCREWS FROM OLD WOOD
description: In England some years ago, there was a man who made a comfortable living selling spare parts for furniture restoration. His stock in trade consisted of pieces of fine cabinet woods salvaged from furniture badly damaged in moving, or repaired so many times that further work was no longer a reasonable proposition.

title: Ford Sets Test Of Lease Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company said it is offering on a test basis a five-year, 9.75 annual percentage rate tractor lease program with the De Kalb Equipment Leasing Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: GANNETT PAPER MAKES DEBUT IN MOVE TO BE NATIONAL DAILY

title: BRIEFING
description: An Appeal Rejected

title:
NEWS OF MUSIC;
KANSAS CITY'S ORCHESTRA SURVIVES
description: ACITY whose orchestra can rise from the ashes of insolvency in the blink of an eye ought to be named Phoenix. But because there already is a Phoenix, Kansas City may have to content itself with the knowledge that it has kept at least the nucleus of its orchestra intact for another season.

title: 'Sweeney Todd' Wins Sunday Ratings Race
description: The musical drama ''Sweeney Todd'' was the most popular prime-time program last Sunday night in Manhattan households equipped with cable television.

title: NORIDC DESIGN OF 50's GAVE 'MODERN' A NEW MEANING
description: SCANDINAVIAN was modern for a generation of Americans - indeed for the whole world - in the years following World War II. The Danes established a beachhead on these shores in the late 1940's, at the Fifth Avenue and 53d Street quarters that Georg Jensen then occupied. Soon the Scandinavian style, the curvaceous walnut and teak chairs and tables, the colorful ceramic tableware and the sinuous and shimmering metal flatware, were warming the homes of the modernminded from coast to coast.

title: SACKLER ASIAN COLLECTION GIVEN TO SMITHSONIAN
description: The Smithsonian Institution has announced it will receive 1,000 pieces of Asian art works from Dr. Arthur M. Sackler, the New York collector and publisher.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES IN PEACE BID TO BENDIX
description: Breaking a long silence, the United Technologies Corporation told the Bendix Corporation yesterday that it was prepared to increase its current $75-a-share offer for a controlling interest in Bendix to $85 if the two could reach an agreement to merge on friendly terms.

title: MEXICO AND VENEZUELA IN CENTRAL AMERICA PLEA
description: The Presidents of Mexico and Venezuela have appealed to the United States, Honduras and Nicaragua to help reduce tensions and clashes along the Honduran-Nicaraguan border, it was announced here today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Jerusalem is the city of God. Jerusalem can also become the city of man in which the believers of the three great monotheistic religions, Christianity, Judaism and Islam, live in full liberty and equality with the followers of other religious communities.''

title: FIRST BOSTON IS CITY'S ADVISER
description: The First Boston Corporation has replaced Dillon, Read & Company as financial adviser to the City of New York, city officials announced yesterday.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes charges of $1.2 million or 9 cents a share for the quarter and $4.9 million or 39 cents a share for the 9 months for the effect of the devaluation of the Mexican peso

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS PROTEST A MOVE TO CHANGE RULES ON AIR POLLUTION
description: Environmental groups are protesting proposed changes in rules governing new sources of air pollution, saying the changes would substantially reduce protection of the public.

title: MEXICO HITS SNAG ON STOCK
description: When the Mexican Government nationalized the country's private banks two weeks ago, it also inherited a huge industrial empire consisting of shares owned by the banks in hundreds of leading Mexican companies.

title: SOVIET 'HERO' INFORMER, 13, LEAVES A BITTER LEGACY
description: Fifty years ago a 13-year-old boy named Pavlik Morozov denounced his father to local authorities and was hacked to death by vengeful relatives in his muddy Urals village, leaving behind a legend and a troubled legacy.

title: 2 Rob Salesman Of $60,000 in Gold
description: A jewelry salesman on his way to work yesterday was robbed of $60,000 in gold and $1,500 in cash by two men who forced their way into his car when he stopped for a traffic light in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Legal Help Not Enough
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Emily Goodman pointed out the importance of retaining a criminal lawyer in the event a child becomes involved with the law (''On Teen-Age Arrest and the Importance of a Criminal Lawyer,'' Aug. 26).

title: FED TELLS OF JUNE MOVE TO SLOW DOLLAR'S SURGE
description: The United States has intervened on foreign exchange markets only once this year, buying $21 million worth of West German marks and $9 million worth of Japanese yen on June 14 in a bid to slow the dollar's dramatic rise against other major currencies, the New York Federal Reserve Bank said yesterday.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a charge of $896,000 from an accounting change...C-Net income

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WITH do-it-yourself becoming a way of life for homeowners and apartment dwellers - as much because of the current economic pinch as the high cost of work by professional tradespeople - a continuing stream of new tools and fix-it aids is arriving on the market.

title: MIDEAST PREREQUISITE FOR THE 'WEDDING'
description: To the Editor:

title: NOW COMPUTERIZED BULLETIN BOARDS
description: VINCENT J. LANDRY JR. converses with friends he has never seen, whose names he may never know. They speak to him silently, sometimes late into the night, in words that glow a ghostly green across the screen of his home computer.

title: RAILROADS REACH PACT WITH UNION
description: The railroad industry achieved a contract accord with the United Transportation Union today but remained immersed in intense efforts to gain a labor agreement with the engineers' union.

title: A Buffalo Shuffle
description: In Buffalo's Rich Stadium, the locker usually used by Joe Cribbs was turned over to Ted McKnight, the former Kansas City running back who was signed Tuesday by the Bills.

title: Boeing to Extend Air Canada Option
description: Air Canada said the Boeing Company had agreed to extend until next year the company's options on 12 new B-767 airliners it was planning to buy.

title: HANDS ACROSS THE SEA IN PURSUIT OF DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SAYS BLACKS WERE HURT BY WORKS OF THE GREAT SOCIETY
description: President Reagan, responding to recent criticism of his Administration's treatment of the disadvantaged, said today that blacks ''would be appreciably better off today'' if the Great Society had never been inaugurated.

title: 2 FAMILIAR NAMES WIN WISCONSIN RACES
description: Wisconsin primary voters, setting the stage for one of the Middle West's crucial gubernatorial elections this fall, have chosen two familiar names from their political past to vie for the state's leadership Nov. 2.

title: SIDNEY FRIEDMAN, EX-BANKER, DEAD
description: Sidney Friedman, a lawyer and former chairman and chief executive officer of the National Bank of North America, died Monday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: PIANIST: LARS ROOS
description: LARS ROOS, the Swedish pianist, became the first artist to offer a presentation in New York for ''Scandinavia Today'' - the 15-month Nordic celebration -when he gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. On hand to hear him was a woman who already knew his playing well - Birgit Nilsson, the soprano, with whom Mr. Roos has toured Europe, the Middle East, Japan and Korea as accompanist.

title: PUBLIC TV ALLIANCE ON CULTURE SERIES
description: Five public television stations will announce the formation of an alliance today that will work to bring more cultural programming to the system though the weekly series ''Great Performances,'' which celebrates its 10th season this year.

title: E.E.C.'s Ambassador Remains Outspoken
description: The European Economic Community's new Ambassador to Washington, Sir Roy Denman, made his first public appearance in the capital yesterday to lay his views ''on the line,'' as he put it, over disputes on steel, the Siberian pipeline and farm exports.

title: AIDE SAYS PENTAGON HEEDED LAW IN EFFORT TO PROMOTE THE C-5
description: Deputy Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci said today that Pentagon officials ''did nothing wrong'' when they tried to persuade Congress to buy C-5 and B-1 planes and approve the sale of radar warning planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: Right to See Memo Is Won by Kheel
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, won a ruling in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday giving him the right to see a New York City Transit Authority memorandum.

title: Advertising; Challenges In Selling Car Import
description: DURING its 32-year history, Cunningham & Walsh has done the advertising for the British Jaguar for 13 years and for American Motors for six. On Monday, it will begin to advertise three cars and trucks of Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, some of whose automobiles - but totally different lines - are already being sold by Chrysler.

title: Stake in Newmont
description: The Amcon Group, a subsidiary of Consolidated Gold Fields, said yesterday that it had amended its 13-D statement, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, to say that it now owns or has agreed to buy 24.5 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation, up from the earlier 23.4 percent. Amcon, now the largest shareholder in Newmont, has agreed not to acquire more than 26 percent of the stock until 1984.

title: GHOTBZADEH, EX-FOREIGN MINISTER, EXECUTED IN IRAN
description: Former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh of Iran, who was accused of plotting to overthrow the Iranian Government and kill Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was executed Wednesday night, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Argentine-Chilean Pact Wins an Extension
description: Argentine and Chilean delegations exchanged documents today in which they agreed to extend a 1972 nonaggression treaty that Argentina renounced in January, the Vatican announced.

title: AMERICAN DESIGN: A STOREWIDE SALUTE
description: BITS and pieces of the vastness of America, its simplicity as well as its elegance, its regional traditions and its mixed ethnic heritage, its history and its newness, its crafts, art, clothes and food, its designers and artisans in their infinite varieties, begin unfolding today at Bloomingdale's.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IS THERE A GOOD TIME TO COLLECT GARBAGE? GREENWICH WONDERS
description: For 40 years, the sanitationmen who clean up after this town of 60,000 have moved to the task long before dawn. As crickets chirped in the darkness, tin cans rattled and diesel engines groaned. Such was the custom, and no law encroached upon tradition - until now.

title: No Headline
description: Royals Extend Streak to Five

title: IMPASSE REPORTED IN BATTLE ON FUNDS FOR MILITARY IN '83
description: President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger are reported to be in a deadlock with Congressional leaders of both parties in a new dispute over the 1983 Pentagon budget.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1981 results have been restated to give effect to changes in methods of accounting for preopening expenses

title: GEMAYEL IS BURIED AS POLITICAL LEADERS CALL FOR CALM IN LEBANON
description: President-elect Bashir Gemayel was buried today in his home village nine miles from here in a ceremony attended by political leaders deeply concerned over the possible consequences of his assassination.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LATIN CLASS

title: MCCARTHY LOSES HIS BID IN MINNESOTA
description: Mark Dayton, a wealthy young businessman and political neophyte, easily defeated former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in a primary for the United States Senate seat now held by David Durenberger, a Republican. Mr. Dayton and Mr. McCarthy were seeking the Democratic-Farm Labor Party nomination.

title: No Headline
description: G.O.P. PICKS SUNUNU TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR OF NEW HAMPSHIRE

title: No Headline
description: CARDINALS TROUNCE PHILS, 8-0

title: Excerpts from debate, page B4.
description: In one of their final debates before next Thursday's primary, Mayor Koch yesterday ticked off a series of differences with Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mr. Cuomo said that Mr. Koch's positions on the issues had been dictated by polls rather than principles.

title: RIVALS FOR SENATE APPEAL TO LABOR IN CONNECTICUT
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and his Democratic opponent, Representative Toby Moffett, are battling over Connecticut's key labor endorsement in their race for the United States Senate.

title: Herron Is Traded
description: Denis Herron got his wish to be traded from Montreal, where he did not like the idea of being rotated with two other Canadien goalies. The 30-year-old Herron became a Pittsburgh Penguin yesterday for the third time in a move he hopes will provide more playing time.

title: Nike Secures Credit
description: Nike Inc. of Beaverton, Ore., said yesterday that it had secured a new $140 million revolving credit agreement with six banks, led by Seattle-First National Bank as agent. Nike said the agreement provided for borrowing at the prime rate, or at a spread above the banks' marginal cost of funds or Eurodollar fund costs. Nike may also borrow through use of a banker's acceptance facility.

title: Peabody Weighs Plan
description: The Peabody Coal Company of St. Louis, the nation's largest coal producer, expressed interest yesterday in participating as a joint venture partner in the North Alabama Coal gasification project to convert 1.7 million tons of high-sulfur Middle Western coal annually to 375 million gallons of methanol for use in transportation.

title: Kaiser Trims Payout
description: The Kaiser Cement Company cut its quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share from 35 cents, attributing the move to the prolonged recession and clouded prospects for a recovery next year. The dividend is payable Oct. 29 to shareholders of record Oct. 8.

title: Group Says St. Bart's Misstated Lease Deal
description: A group opposed to leasing part of the property of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York for the construction of an office building charged yesterday that the church ''willfully misstated the facts'' of the deal to the parish ''in order to obtain a favorable vote.''

title: HOLLYWOOD'S LOVELY BUT LONELY LADY
description: Hollywood, where she had been a queen before she left to become a princess, reacted with distress and dismay today to the death of Princess Grace of Monaco.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: A new line of retracting and locking leashes is available in four sizes, to suit any dog from a Chihuahua to a German shepherd. These Flexi leashes have a sturdy case and handgrip made of plastic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Gavel's Rap Marks End of an Era

title: 6-Month Loss Narrows at BL
description: The state-controlled BL P.L.C. said today that in the six months ended July 3, the company posted a pretax loss of 106.5 million, narrower than the loss of 190.1 million in the corresponding 1981 period. Sales inched up to 1.46 billion, from 1.41 billion.

title: A TUITION ADVANCE FUND SHOULD BE PART OF THE SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Mobil Loss in Germany
description: The Mobil Corporation's West German subsidiary had a second-quarter loss, a company spokesman said today. He gave no figures. The chairman of Mobil Oil A.G., Herbert Lewinski, had said earlier that it lost about $120 million in this year's first four months, widened from $24 million a year earlier.

title: DRY DOCK ARRANGES DOLLAR LINK
description: Seeking to avoid being auctioned off by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the financially ailing Dry Dock Savings Bank has arranged its own merger into the stronger Dollar Savings Bank, the two banks have announced.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Industrial production fell 0.5 percent in August, after a rise of 0.1 percent in July. The fall was seen as evidence that recovery may be delayed until late fall or early winter, beyond the Congressional elections. Economists said continued high unemployment has nullified the effect of the July tax cut, the decline in interest rates and the surge in the stock market. (Page D1.)

title: SHOUTING OF SLOGANS DISRUPTS A HEARING ON BRINK'S HOLDUP
description: The courtroom for the Brink's trial in Rockland County was a scene of near chaos today as spectators shouted political slogans, lawyers argued with the judge, and one defendant, announcing that he was tired, apparently went to sleep.

title: Market Place; Bond Strategy Of Bank Fund
description: IT wasn't so many years ago that investment managers could buy bonds and go on vacation, serene in the knowledge that volatility was something that happened to stocks. Then, however, the fever chart of inflation, abrupt changes in Federal Reserve monetary policy and swings in the business cycle quickened enormously the pace of supervising bond portfolios.

title: 2 EX-STATE SENATORS VIE FOR REP. CHISHOLM'S JOB
description: Two former state senators with different political styles and backed by rival black political factions in central Brooklyn will face each other in next week's Democratic primary. The contest for the newly drawn 12th District resulted from the decision by Representative Shirley Chisholm not to seek re-election.

title: Icahn Group Buys Stake in Dan River
description: The New York-based Icahn group of investing companies disclosed yesterday that it had acquired an approximate 7 percent stake in Dan River Inc., one of the nation's biggest textile producers, and that it might seek control.

title: MAROCS ASSERTS U.S. SOMETIMES FORGETS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos arrived here today for talks with President Reagan and other Administration leaders concerning American economic aid and military bases in the Philippines.

title: Exxon Land Suit
description: The Exxon Corporation has filed a damage suit against 14 individuals, banks and businesses for more than $2.1 million, contending the defendants drilled wells and sold minerals on Exxon's land. The suit also accuses all defendants except one of filing various documents that cloud Exxon's title to the land in Mitchell County. The oil company asked in the suit filed in Federal court here that all clouds to titles be removed and that it be awarded the $2.1 million damages plus court costs.

title: STUDY FINDS DRUG ALLEVIATES MANY MENSTRUAL SYMPTOMS
description: A painkiller developed for arthritics and accident victims also relieves pain of menstrual cramps suffered by 3.5 million American women, a study reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Expanded Horizons For an Older Crowd

title: Carlos Alberto Wants to Coach
description: Like Pele and Franz Beckenbauer before him, Carlos Alberto wants to go out as a champion in his last league game for the Cosmos, the Soccer Bowl Saturday night in San Diego. But unlike Pele and Beckenbauer, the 38-year-old Brazilian sweeper wants to become a coach with the Cosmos after that.

title: Training in Computer Chips
description: The National Science Foundation and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency began a program Tuesday for training university students in designing more advanced computer chips.

title: Why Tecmar Head Favors Electronics
description: Martin Alpert is the man at the heart of the International Business Machines Corporation's trade-secrets case against three of its former employees.

title: Mitchelson Is Dismissed From Bloomingdale Case
description: The former model suing the estate of Alfred Bloomingdale for $10 million today dismissed Marvin Mitchelson as her attorney because of ''continued and fundamental disagreements,'' according to the lawyer now representing her.

title: HELMS SEEKS DELAY ON STATE DEPT. JOB
description: Senator Jesse Helms tried today to delay the confirmation of Richard Burt as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs by asking for an investigation of the effect of a 1979 news article in The New York Times written by Mr. Burt when he was a reporter for the newspaper.

title: Utah Coal Venture
description: The Paiute Oil and Mining Corporation said its Bishops Gate Coal Corporation unit and the Southern Pacific Company's Southern Pacific Land Company had formed an equally owned partnership to consolidate property interests in east-central Utah. The boards of both companies have approved the partnership, to be called Pleasant Valley Coal Partners, which Paiute said would control more than 180 million tons of coal if all acquisition efforts were successful.

title: Q&A
description: Q. About 10 years ago we put a contact-type plastic paper on our kitchen shelves, and now we want to get it off. However, we find it impossible to remove. Is there any method you can recommend? - W.P.W., Louisville, Ky.

title: L.I. BLAST KILLS 2 OFF-DUTY POLICEMEN
description: Two moonlighting Nassau County policemen were killed and nine persons were injured today when an explosion tore through an ammunition factory in an industrial park here.

title: Auto Bill Voted by Panel
description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce tonight passed a bill that would require any automobile sold in the United States to contain minimum amounts of domestic labor and other component costs. The vote on the measure was 24-to-17.

title: BAR GROUP STUDY FINDS 'RETREAT' ON CIVIL RIGHTS UNDER REAGAN
description: In a detailed study of the activities of the Justice Department's civil rights division, a Washington lawyers' association asserted today that ''the Attorney General's early promise to vigorously enforce the law has not been fulfilled.''

title: Rudolf Hess Gets a Checkup
description: Rudolf Hess, the 88-year-old Nazi, was transferred from his cell at Spandau prison to a military hospital for a medical checkup, a British military spokesman said today. The only inmate at Spandau, he has been serving a life sentence for war crimes.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SUPPORTS FOES OF CHICAGO DISTRICTING PLAN
description: The Justice Department today accused Chicago's City Council of discriminating against blacks and Hispanic Americans in the way it redrew the boundaries of city wards.

title: EL SALVADOR'S WAR CASTS PALL ON INDEPENDENCE CELEBRATION
description: It was a day of celebration in San Salvador, but the mood in the capital was bleak. Low black clouds hung over the mountains as thousands of families trudged to the national stadium to see marching troops, applaud American and Salvadoran parachutists and celebrate the nation's independence from Spain 161 years ago.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ALTHOUGH the building is four months from completion, three model apartments in Museum Tower, the new 52-story apartment building above the Museum of Modern Art, were previewed on Tuesday at a cocktail party given by Parish-Hadley Associates, Bray-Schaible Design and McMillen Inc., the design companies that decorated the apartments. Above, Robert Schaible and a guest, Lily Auchincloss, in the living room, left, decorated by Mr. Schaible.

title: IN CHICAGO, OLD BARS CAN GET A NEW LIFE
description: As part of his interest in antiques, Robert O'Connell began researching old bars, and he found himself becoming intrigued with them.

title: EMERGING YOUNG ARCHITECTS: DIVERSITY AND NEW DIRECTIONS
description: CAREERS in architecture begin slowly and advance more slowly still. The reason is simple: Rare is the client who is willing to entrust to a 30-year-old the responsibility for a $10 million or a $5 million or even a $1 million piece of construction, which is more or less what anything bigger than a house costs these days. As a result, major projects are almost always created by architects who are at or beyond middle age, and smaller, less visible jobs are what is left to their younger colleagues.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech prepared for delivery by President Reagan to the National Black Republican Council today:

title: STATE DEPARTMENT'S NO.3 HAS A HABIT OF SUCCEEDING
description: How does someone get the reputation for being a bureaucratic blackbelt, rise to the highest position for a Foreign Service officer, and as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, do things in a way that most people don't mind losing to him?

title: Hagler Bout in Italy
description: Marvelous Marv Hagler will defend his world middleweight boxing championship against Fulgencio Obelmejian of Venezuela Oct. 30 in San Remo, Italy. The fight was postponed from July because of a rib injury suffered by Hagler. ... Two of the top light-heavyweight contenders in both the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association have been matched for a bout in Las Vegas, Nev. Eddie Mustafa Muhummad, the former W.B.A. champion, and Lotte Mwale, No. 1 in the W.B.C., will meet Oct. 2.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Bigger Audience For Theater's Playbill

title: AIR FORCE AGREES ON JOINT EFFORTS WITH THE NAVY
description: Senior military officers said today that the Navy and the Air Force had agreed on a major new tactical role for the Air Force in helping to protect the nation's sea lanes, once a responsibility jealously guarded by the Navy.

title: BEAR, STEARNS HEAD WINS GLOBAL SEAT
description: Global Natural Resources P.L.C. said yesterday that a group of dissident shareholders had unseated only one of seven directors in a proxy battle. But the dissidents vowed to continue their fight for control of the company.

title: TOOL MAKERS ARE HOPEFUL DESPITE SLUMP
description: The nation's machine tool industry has been depressed for quite some time. Backlogs of orders have been declining sharply and foreign competitors have been taking over an ever larger share of the domestic market.

title: PARENTS FIGHT CHANGE IN AID FOR DISABLED
description: For Sharon Sachs, her ''full-time battle'' began six years ago when she first attempted to get her dyslexic daughter classified in the public schools as ''learning disabled.''

title: ANSPACHER TO REOPEN OCT. 26
description: The Anspacher Theater at the New York Shakespeare Festival is being restructured, with a new stage and new seating arrangement. The old stage, which was surrounded by seats on three sides, almost like an amphitheater, will now be part of the seating plan.

title: POP: 70 SINATRA MINUTES THRILL OLD AND YOUNG
description: SOME came to Frank Sinatra's Carnegie Hall concert in limousines Tuesday night, and some came on the subway. Some were wearing designer dresses and furs, and some were wearing jeans. ''Atta boy, Frankie,'' they shouted, and ''Sing it!'' Many of them were old enough to have been listening to Frank Sinatra since 1939, when he left his job as singing master of ceremonies in a New Jersey roadhouse to join the Harry James band. But a surprising number were young enough to be the grandchildren of Mr. Sinatra's early fans. They were not deterred by steep ticket prices - $50 for a choice orchestra seat. This was Sinatra!

title: Bolivian General Strike Protests Military Rule
description: A nationwide general strike began early today despite a threat by the military Government to dismiss every worker who participates.

title: Tosco Plans to Sell Gasoline Refinery
