description: The Tosco Corporation of Los Angeles, one of the nation's largest independent gasoline refiners, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Bakersfield, Calif., refinery to Koch Industries of Wichita, Kan., for about $150 million. Tosco said the facility can refine 40,000 barrels a day.

title: Matalon, juggling 2 shows, is working on tight schedule.
description: BY virtue of staging two new productions this season, Vivian Matalon has the distinction of being the busiest director working on Broadway. At the moment, Mr. Matalon is in rehearsal with Jay Presson Allen's comedy ''A Little Family Business,'' starring Angela Lansbury. Shortly after that play opens Dec. 2 at the Martin Beck, he will go into rehearsal with ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' a musical due on Broadway in April.

title: Raines's Drug Problem
description: Tim Raines, the base-stealing star of the Montreal Expos, says that he used drugs earlier this year but quit ''about four months ago'' after opening the season in a slump. But he conceded that he was still visiting a doctor at the request of the Expos.

title: SCHOOL PRAYER BILL BRINGS NEW FILIBUSTER IN SENATE
description: In a day filled with election-year maneuvering, Senate liberals opened a new filibuster today, this time against a bill that would permit officially sponsored prayer in public schools.

title: Celanese Cutback
description: The Celanese Corporation said it had eliminated a number of salaried jobs at its New York headquarters and in Charlotte, N.C., where it has computer operations, to cut costs. It said it would release 32 persons in New York and 31 in Charlotte.

title: NOT SO SMALL TALK IN THE OVAL OFFICE
description: It is not always small talk that Presidents exchange while posing for photgraphers. Today, in addition to the usual pleasantries, President Reagan talked of sudden gunfire and death as he sat, smiling, in the Oval Office next to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, who was also smiling.

title: From novelist to playwright to director.
description: ''JOSEPHA,'' the French movie that is at the Paris Theater, was written and directed by Christopher Frank. It was his virgin directing effort in films, but to him, writing and directing are not so different. ''You're telling a story,'' he says, ''but instead of a pen and paper you've got actors and a camera.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In Line for a Bargain

title: Conferees Agree on Bill For Subsidized Water
description: A House-Senate conference committee agreed today on a new formula that would sharply increase the price many Western farms pay for subsidized water from Federal irrigation projects.

title: HEART DISEASE STUDY SHOWS NO GAIN IN BID TO CUT RISKS
description: Leaders of the largest study ever done on the value of trying to diminish the major risks associated with heart disease said today they had found no significant difference in deaths between a group that received special medical treatment and one that received more ordinary care.

title: West Side Indian, East Side steaks.
description: WE have frequently been asked to suggest good inexpensive restaurants, but in recent months the demand has increased to a steady stream. There is no special trick to finding food that is merely cheap, but the search grows more difficult for those who want meals that are unusual and interesting as well. In this pursuit we are invariably drawn to small ethnic restaurants, such as the two branches of the India Pavilion, one on 56th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, and the other on 54th Street, between First and Second Avenue.

title: ACTRESS IN 1922 OPHELIA ROLE
description: Rosalinde Fuller, who played Ophelia to John Barrymore's celebrated Hamlet on Broadway in 1922, died in her sleep on Wednesday at her sister's home in London. She was 90 years old.

title: Kirin-Banyu Pact
description: The Kirin Brewery Company and the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company announced a cooperative effort in biotechnology development, drug manufacturing and sales. Banyu will issue Kirin five million new capital shares to raise $11.4 million for expansion of Banyu's research facilities.

title: GALA FOR PHILHARMONIC FAITHFUL
description: For Leontyne Price, it was ''one of the most important evenings of my career.'' For Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker, it was ''a marvelous concert and a good cause.'' Lawrence Wien, the philanthropist, said it was ''one of the few things that still gives me a thrill at my age.'' And for Brooke Shields, the actress, it was ''my formal introduction to the Philharmonic. I'm 17 years old and just becoming acquainted with it.''

title: ONCE MORE, BEIRUT HOLDS ITS BREATH FOR WHATEVER WAR BRINGS
description: In Beirut, the Cairo-born Arab writer Fouad Shaker once wrote, ''You can breathe without having someone counting your breathings.'' In Beirut, the British soldier-Arabist Sir John Bagot Glubb noted years ago, ''there is no hard and fast line between East and West.'' In Beirut of the 1950's, the Lebanese-born historian Philip K. Hitti wrote, there was a flourishing free market with ''the value of commodities still determined by supply and demand, rather than by fiats from officialdom.''

title: CONGRESSIONAL ARTS CAUCUS ELECTS DOWNEY CHAIRMAN
description: Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, today was elected chairman of the Congressional Arts Caucus, a potent force in supporting Federal financing for the arts.

title: DANT & RUSSELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Bridge: Polish Association Makes It Tough for Middle-Aged
description: In a bridge context there is little that can be called affirmative action, or efforts to induce minorities to participate. Some organizations offer reduced entry fees to student players, but nobody goes as far as the Polish Bridge Association. This body recently announced half-price entry fees for juniors, women, old-age pensioners and members of the armed forces.

title: PUBLISHING: $1 MILLION FOR EINSTEIN PAPERS
description: A $1 million donation from Harold W. McGraw Jr., chairman of McGraw-Hill Inc., has breathed fresh life into the project to publish Albert Einstein's papers in 20 volumes. Princeton University Press hopes to send the first volume to the printer by the end of 1983, but the entire publishing project will take years.

title: Stay on TV Ruling Asked by N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday that it was attempting to win a stay of a Federal judge's decision that would eliminate its control over college football telecasts.

title: Saudi Pledges to Do His Best To Get Israelis Out of Beirut
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia promised Lebanese leaders today that he would do his best to end Israel's occupation of west Beirut, which he described as inhuman and unjustified, the Saudi press agency said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart yesterday on the election races resulting from Tuesday's primaries included an incorrect picture. It showed John Sears, a former campaign manager for President Reagan, in place of John W. Sears, Republican candidate for Governor of Massachusetts.

title: STORY OF BLACK WHALERS AT COLD SPRING MUSEUM
description: The Cold Spring Harbor Whaling Museum has unveiled the first major exhibition in its 40-year history, ''The Black Man and the Sea,'' consisting of more than 50 photographs, paintings and artifacts about black whalers.

title: LABOR'S 'NO CONCESSION' MOOD GROWS
description: The conciliatory mood among many union members who made numerous wage and benefit concessions to employers in recent years has begun to evaporate, recent evidence suggests, as high unemployment and layoffs continue.

title: CITY OPERA'S NEW VIEW OF THE OLD 'MAGIC FLUTE'
description: Mozart's ''The Magic Flute'' returns to the New York City Opera tomorrow night with a new staging, a new English translation and, above all, a new attempt to tune and balance this most spiritually complex of operas.

title: Landlord Takes Cake In a Rent Settlement
description: David A. Pill, a landlord, can eat his rent settlement. Mr. Pill had sued Janice A. French, a baker, for the rent after Miss French vacated the store with four years left on her lease.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The 1981 results restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in Mar

title: EVER-CHANGING 'EVENTS' BY MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: When the Merce Cunningham Dance Company presents a series of Events this weekend at its Dance Studio, Jerry Hunt will phone in the music. Mr. Hunt, an electronic composer from Dallas, will be off in Texas and the music he'll provide will come over the wires and be made audible by means of an amplified telephone. Mr. Cunningham said in a recent conversation, ''I haven't heard any of this music yet. So I'll be curious to find out what it's like.''

title: MONSTER; The Talk of Rockport
description: When word came the other day that mechanical problems would delay the first private space launching 24 hours, nearly everybody here groaned. Everybody except Jerry and Audrey

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''SOME people may think that jazz is the devil's music, but most of it started in church as gospel music,'' the Rev. John Garcia Gensel said the other day. He books New York's highest-ceilinged jazz venue, and one of the most unlikely: St. Peter's Lutheran Church at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. ''It's a good room. The acoustics are generally excellent.'' In both its old, freestanding quarters at the same address and the modern ones that it has occupied as part of the Citicorp Center since 1977, St. Peter's has made itself New York's jazz church.

title: Folk and Sea Songs By the Clearwater
description: A free outdoor concert of folk music, sea chanteys and work songs will be given by the Clearwater Sloop Singers on Sunday from 4 to 6 P.M. at the Philipse Manor Hall State Historic Site at Warburton Avenue and Dock Street in Yonkers.

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Europe Missile Compromise Is Proposed by U.S. Experts
description: An arms control group headed by Paul Warnke, former United States arms negotiator, proposed a compromise today in limiting missiles in Europe.

title: DESPITE LISTING, 7 IN CRASH OF JET REPORTED ALIVE
description: At least seven of those on a list of 56 passengers said to be dead or missing in the crash Monday of a charter jetliner in Malaga, Spain, were reported yesterday to be alive.

title: ART DEALERS ASK BAN ON BUYER'S PREMIUMS
description: The continuing battle between art dealers and auction houses was intensified yesterday. The Art Dealers Association of America announced that it had asked Simon P. Gourdine, New York's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, to issue a rule forbidding auction houses from charging a ''buyer's premium.''

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A SALUTE TO FALL FASHION IN U.S.
description: Four men and a girl were the stars of a gala evening at Saks Fifth Avenue Tuesday, but almost everyone managed to get into the act. To give its fall fashions the proper send-off, the store asked the big five - Adolfo, Geoffrey Beene, Bill Blass, Mary McFadden and Oscar de la Renta - to name their favorite charities. Then chairmen were selected, committees formed and tickets printed. In time, some 600 people, in either black tie or festive dresses, turned up at the store to drink, party and, not coincidentally, give their attention to the new season's clothes. They paid $125 each for the privilege.

title: 'WAITRESS!'
description: TROMA INC., the small company responsible for ''Squeeze Play'' and now ''Waitress!'', maintains in its press releases that ''there is a tremendous young public which will pay to see raunchy but hilarious comedies.'' This, presumably, is the audience to which Troma is trying to pander. But ''Squeeze Play'' was a lot closer to the mark than ''Waitress!'', in which the Troma formula demonstrates that two go-rounds is one more than it can manage. This time, the raunchiness has more to do with food fights than anything else. And few of the jokes are funny or new.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TORCH IN MY EAR. By Elias Canet- ti. Translated from the German by Joa- chim Neugroschel. 372 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $16.50.

title: Sun Plans a Sale
description: The Sun Company said it had agreed in principle to sell most of its interest in its data processing unit, the Sun Information Services Company, to a group including the unit's management. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pabst Files Suit
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had sued Irwin Jacobs and three associates in United States District Court in Delaware, challenging the legality of their recent call for shareholder consents to remove the present board. The directors were elected last April 13 after an unsuccessful proxy fight by Mr. Jacobs and associates, who hold 13.9 percent of the company's stock.

title: GIANTS, CARPENTER ARE STILL FAR APART
description: Despite earlier hints of optimism, it appeared today that the Giants were no closer than they had ever been to signing Rob Carpenter, the valuable fullback who strengthened their running attack last season.

title: FESTIVE EVENINGS AT 3 DEPARTMENT STORES
description: It was a giddy night, a happy gathering flecked with those little surprises and incongruities that make the best of New York's important parties so interesting.

title: JEWISH HOLIDAYS, SOLEMN AND JOYFUL
description: SHANAH. The New Year's holiday begins tonight and continues for two days among Orthodox and Conservative Jews and for one day among Reform Jews. On Rosh ha-Shanah, according to tradition, God judges people and determines their fate for the coming year. The shofar, or ram's horn, is sounded in synagogues to inspire a spiritual awakening. The solemn festival is spent in contemplation and in dinners with family and friends. As a symbol of hope for a sweet year, it is customary to dip apples in honey and to eat other sweet foods.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METS END EXPOS' STREAK, 9-4
description: The Mets took advantage of an erratic pitching performance by Scott Sanderson, the right-handed starter for the Expos, for a 9-4 victory tonight.

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON ABORTION CURB
description: Following is the roll-call vote Wednesday by which the Senate approved a proposal to kill anti-abortion legislation proposed by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina: FOR THE PROPOSAL - 47 Democrats - 29 Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We fully support the Lebanese Government's call for the withdrawal of Israeli forces, which are in clear violation of the cease-fire understanding to which Israel is a party.

title: BILLS DEFEAT VIKINGS
description: Joe Ferguson of the Bills threw three touchdown passes tonight as Buffalo rallied from a 19-0 deficit to defeat the Minnesota Vikings, 23-22.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds fell by $525 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $226.05 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The drop was attributed partly to a switch of money from the funds into other short-term holdings that yielded more.

title: DASHED BY THE ARABS
description: Americans like myself who share Israel's concerns about America's latest peace proposal but who found reason for hope in President Reagan's speech have now suffered crushing disappointments.

title: 3 Dance Premieres
description: Three American premieres will be presented by the Contemporary Chamber Ballet of Caracas this weekend at the Riverside Dance Festival in the Theater of the Riverside Church at Riverside Drive and West 120th Street.

title: Morgan Aide Given Key Manville Role
description: John A. Payne is spending long hours these days in wearying committee meetings. As chairman of the general creditors' committee in the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy proceedings, Mr. Payne is working to settle claims against the company.

title: 2 CONCERTS FOR 'CREATIVE MUSICIANS'
description: IN the world of jazz today, no institutional name is more influential than the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians. The association has been the spawning ground for some of the most vibrant, venturesome new jazz of the 1970's, and its cooperative philosophy inspired much of the ''loft jazz'' movement of that decade, as well as playing a vital role in the formulation and expression of black cultural pride.

title: MAZZOLA OFFERS REASON FOR HIS RESIGNATION
description: John Mazzola yesterday disclosed the circumstances that led to his resignation as president of Lincoln Center in a statement intended to allay ''unfortunate rumors about my personal finances.''

title: Los Angeles Bus Strike Is Affecting 600,000
description: Since midnight Wednesday, an estimated 600,000 riders of the Rapid Transit District buses in Los Angeles have been scrambling to find alternative methods of transportation because of a strike by the district's bus drivers.

title: Rates Drop a Bit in Quiet Day; Money Data Are Awaited
description: Interest rates fell slightly in quiet trading yesterday, as many market participants waited for today's money supply announcement and next week's auctions of new Treasury notes and bonds.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
McDonald's Asia Plant
description: The McDonald's Corporation has received permission to set up a food-processing plant in Taiwan to serve its restaurants in Japan and Southeast Asia, economic officials said today.

title: UNITED STATES ANTIMONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MAN WALKING DOG IS SLAIN IN PARK
description: A 40-year-old Manhattan man was shot to death early yesterday while walking his dog in Central Park. A jogger noticed the body on the grass next to the West Drive, between 104th and 105th Streets.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Congress Budget Office Losing Chief
description: Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office since it was established in 1975, will return to the the Brookings Institution next year to head its economic studies program, Brookings announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On Deck at the Stadium: Squabble Over Repairs

title: PURCHASE OF MARIETTA TO PROCEED
description: In what appeared to be a major victory for the Bendix Corporation, the company announced early today that it had purchased a controlling interest in the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOUSE PANEL PROGRESSING ON IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The House Judiciary Committee made slow but steady progress today in writing a bill to overhaul the nation's immigration laws.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1982; Companies
description: Bendix was cleared to purchase Martin Marietta's stock after a Federal appeals court overturned a lower court judge's 10-day freeze in the three-way takeover battle involving Bendix, Marietta and United Technologies. (Page D1.)

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic City Electric Co. filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 1.5 million common shares.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amalgamated Sugar Co. said Harold C. Simmons of Dallas disclosed to the Securities and Exchange Commission that five companies he controls had raised their stake in Amalgamated to 15.55 percent of its common.

title: ONCE AGAIN, CONGRESS IS PLAYING POLITICS AS USUAL
description: As sure as the leaves turn and wives lose their husbands to the television set for weekend football, electionyear politics takes over the legislative process in this season and partisan posturing assumes as much importance as the substance of policy.

title: Why Not the Best for Surrogate?
description: Of all the New York courts that suffer from politics and public misunderstanding, the most tormented is surely the Manhattan Surrogate's Court. It handles more money than any other - more than a billion dollars in estates a year. That makes it a traditional source of lawyers' patronage - and rumors of favoritism. Reformers rail at costly probate delays, and their election-year vows to clean up the place do nothing for its image.

title: Tracor Ends Talks
description: Tracor Inc. said it had called off negotiations to acquire the Systems Engineering Associates Corporation, a New Jersey company that provides engineering and technical services to the Navy. Tracor, a major defense contractor that also makes equipment for the oil and automobile industries, did not say why the talks had ended. The companies had announced on June 28 the signing of a letter of intent.

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The U.N. Today; Sept. 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: Bennett Petroleum In Chapter 11
description: The Bennett Petroleum Corporation, a Denver-based oil and mining concern, said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: REAGAN PRAISES MARCOS AS A VOICE FOR MODERATION
description: President Reagan warmly welcomed President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines today, saying that he was ''personally delighted'' at the visit. As he spoke, protesters chanted anti-Marcos slogans beyond the White House gates.

title: Inco May Extend A Shutdown
description: Inco Ltd. said it would extend the production shutdown at its Ontario division by three months, to Jan. 3, because of the continued poor markets for nickel and copper, unless it could work out a short workweek program with unions in order to resume opearations by Dec. 1.

title: VIEWING THE SPIRES OF JERSEY CITY
description: A year ago, J. Daniel Selig, an architectural historian, joined the flock of transplanted Manhattanites who dominate Jersey City's brownstone-renovation movement in historic neighborhoods near the Hudson River. But besides the rows of grand, old homes, Mr. Selig has taken delight in studying the architectural variety in the churches of his new neighborhood and pondering what they say about Jersey City's immigrants of a century and more ago.

title: ABORTION FOES, HAILING REAGAN EFFORTS, PLAN TO RENEW STALLED DRIVE
description: The disparate parts of the anti-abortion lobby insisted today that, despite a Senate defeat Wednesday, President Reagan's personal intervention had forced greater unity on them for a stronger attempt next year.

title: A Wandering Hurricane Brushes Past Bermuda
description: A hurricane with winds up to 115 miles per hour passed near Bermuda today but there were no reports of injuries or damage other than some downed trees.

title: INJURED IN BRAIN, BABY WINS ANNUITY
description: A photograph taken in the delivery room of Stanford University Hospital 15 minutes after her birth shows Anna Younger to be a normal, healthy, red-haired baby with sapphire blue eyes.

title: PLASTIC SURGEON SAYS TEEN-AGER'S DESIRE IS VITAL TO OPERATION
description: An increasing number of teen-agers are seeking plastic surgery, but a seminar sponsored by the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons was told yesterday that surgeons should avoid operating on those whose parents were the ones who made the decision that plastic surgery was needed.

title: A GALA AT LIBRARY
description: ''I don't think I've ever been to such a dressy party,'' Bethuel Webster said at Lord & Taylor's dinner dance Wednesday night. ''Even the napkins have lace on them.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 5:35 P.M. These are the first two games of a five-game weekend set in which the first-place Cardinals will be trying to put some distance between themselves and the other Eastern Division contenders - Philadelphia, Montreal and Pittsburgh. Scott Holman, just recalled from Tidewater, starts one game tonight for the Mets.

title: Friday; PAN-AMERICAN WOMEN
description: ''Women of the Americas: Emerging Perspectives'' is an exhibition of art work by women from Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia and the United States. These are artists, according to the show's curators, ''who have achieved prominence without the sterotypical notion of distinctly feminist if separatist art.'' The exhibition is showing at two sites - at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street (noon to 6 P.M., except Monday), and the Kouros Gallery, 831 Madison Avenue, at 69th Street (10 A.M. to 6 P.M., except Sunday and Monday). Admission is free. For more information, call the center: 249-8950. RARE-BOOK SAMPLER

title: News Analysis
description: By denouncing Great Society programs of the Johnson Administration in a speech to a black audience, President Reagan provided fresh ammunition for critics who say he is trying to reverse the racial progress of the last 20 years.

title: THE FOUR-DAY ETERNITY
description: A t the risk of sounding like Captain Queeg: Who stole the baseballs? Just when we needed it most, we have had to endure four agonizing days without a live baseball game in this town. It has been like a preview of winter, December in September, with both the Mets and the Yankees not at home.

title: Mt. Vernon Nurses Settle 1-Day Strike
description: Nurses at Mount Vernon Hospital returned to work today after a one-day strike that ended with a new contract, a hospital spokesman said.

title: U.S. Says Moscow Is Stalling Progress on Nuclear Test Ban
description: The United States, in its last scheduled statement at the summer session of the United Nations Disarmament Committee, accused the Soviet Union today of blocking efforts to reach an international agreement banning tests of nuclear weapons.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Commission Seeking Site For Holocaust Memorial

title: Marlboro Draws Top 3
description: Perrault, Timely Writer and Silver Buck, the three leading candidates for horse of the year, will race against one another for the first time in the $400,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park tomorrow.

title: Economic Scene; Military Surge As Spur to Jobs
description: THE drop in industrial production by half a percentage point in August implies that unemployment, which has held at 9.8 percent of the labor force for the last two months, is likely to rise above 10 percent before the November elections.

title: Jersey Senate Gets Tax-Increase Bill
description: A State Senate committee today approved an increase in New Jersey's income tax for individuals who earn more than $50,000 a year.

title: Market Place; Growth Curve At Toys R Us
description: ALTHOUGH the recession has affected overall consumer demand for toys, Toys R Us, the nation's largest specialty toy retailer with more than 120 stores and more than 9 percent of the total toy market, has been doing unusually well.

title: CONCERT: MEHTA LEADS PHILHARMONIC
description: THE New York Philharmonic's first regular subscription concert of the season last night at Avery Fisher Hall offered a distinctively diverse selection of music with a nice bow in the direction of American experimentalism then and now. Then, with Charles Ives's ''Decoration Day''; now, with the world premiere of the orchestral version of Steve Reich's ''Tehillim.''

title: South Koreans Won't Get High Voltage Batons
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to suspend indefinitely the shipment of 500 electric shock batons to South Korea, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rangel's Lesson In Demographics

title: BRIEFING
description: Nominee for Indonesia

title: SALVADOR, BACKED BY U.S., OPENS CONTACT WITH GUERRILLAS
description: The Salvadoran Government, with the quiet support of the Reagan Administration, has begun an indirect ''dialogue'' with guerrilla leaders intended to end the civil war.

title: POLES SAY UNION FUGITIVES SPURNED BID FOR TALKS
description: Poland's security chief said today that the authorities tried last spring to meet with underground Solidarity leaders under guarantees of safe-conduct but were rebuffed.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ORIOLES COMPLETE 5-GAME SWEEP
description: The Baltimore Orioles took another step forward tonight in their relentless pursuit of a division championship in Earl Weaver's last year as manager. In the process, the Orioles enabled Weaver to give the Yankees a going-away present.

title: TIMES CO. TO ACQUIRE 11 PAPERS
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy eight daily and three weekly newspapers, bringing to 30 the number of regional papers it owns.

title: CHRYSLER UNION ACCEPTS CONTRACT
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation reached tentative agreement today on a new contract that restores cost-of-living payments for union workers but ties wage increases to company profits.

title: Alcoa Trims Fees
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it had reduced or eliminated certain extra charges for aluminum sheet and plate products, resulting in price cuts of 6 to 15 percent effective Wednesday. The products affected are used mainly in aerospace applications.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-After tax credits of $983,000 for the qr and $1,481,000 for the 6 mos

title: STATEMENT BY THE U.S.
description: Following is the text of a statement on Lebanon issued by the White House and State Department today:

title: English Court
description: ''Wanted: High-caliber American college basketball players with British parents or British passports, to play in England.'' That advertisement did not actually appear, but that's the message being spread by promoters of British basketball.

title: CREDIBLITY GAPS IN THE NUCLEAR OPPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: GHOTBZADEH, IRAN HOSTAGE CRISIS FIGURE, EXECUTED
description: Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, who was Foreign Minister of Iran during the American hostage crisis, was put to death in Teheran late Wednesday. He was 46 years old.

title: Sky Show at Airport In Lincoln Park, N.J.
description: A sky show, with acrobatics and skydiving, will take off Sunday at 1 P.M. at the Lincoln Park Airport on Beaver Brook Road in Old Lincoln Park, N.J.

title: SUN ENERGY USED IN WATER SEPERATION PROCESS
description: A method for extracting hydrogen from water with solar energy, using inexpensive preparations of iron oxide, has been found by a research group from the University of California at Berkeley. The method was described yesterday at a meeting of the American Chemical Society in Kansas City, Mo.

title: THE LOWER EAST SIDE HUMS WITH HOLY DAYS' APPROACH
description: Sweet pastries and round hallahs are piled high in the windows of the bakery on Hester Street. The shops on Orchard Street are busy as families buy new clothing. The sagging wooden benches at the 10th Street Baths are jammed. And there are still tickets left for services at the synagogue on Norfolk Street.

title: New York Chaplains Vote to Join a Union
description: The ministers, priests and rabbis who work for New York City have voted, 43 to 32, to join District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in the hope of persuading the city to raise their pay, a spokesman for the union said last night.

title: CAREY ENDORSES KOCH AND REJECTS CUOMO IN GOVERNOR PRIMARY
description: Governor Carey rejected his Lieutenant Governor yesterday and endorsed Mayor Koch for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in next Thursday's primary.

title: VINCENT LUPIANO, STATE JUSTICE
description: Vincent A. Lupiano, an associate justice in the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Guest in the House
description: About the time that Lucy was exasperating Ricky and the Mouseketeers were flaunting their ears, television became known as the ''electronic babysitter.'' Twenty-five years later Neil Postman, who teaches at New York University, says that the electronic babysitter is erasing childhood.

title: I.B.M. Sues 3 Computer Makers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a civil suit in San Francisco's U.S. District Court against Hitachi Ltd., the National Semiconductor Corporation and its subsidiary, National Advanced Systems.

title: Leaving J.W.T. Unit
description: Going over to the ''new media'' side is Arthur I. Cohen, managing director of J. Walter Thompson's Lansdowne Advertising, who is leaving to be president of the Home View Network, recently set up by ABC Video Enterprises. He is a former senior vice president, marketing, at Bloomingdale's.

title: Qume Caribe
description: Qume Caribe Inc. said it would double employment to 2,000 workers over the next 18 months at its Humacao, P.R., manufacturing site. Qume said it would add 800 employees within eight months in an effort to improve its share of market sales of "daisy wheel" printers and electronic ribbon and print-wheel products.

title: People
description: * Neil J. Katz has been appointed senior vice president-marketing at Revlon Inc.

title: MOUNTED POLICE AGAIN IN MIDTOWN QUARTERS
description: A gleaming, cobalt blue building on West 42d Street was inaugurated yesterday as the new headquarters for the Police Department's mounted division and the home of its Troop B, which returned to midtown with a colorful parade after a 15-year absence.

title: MOSLEM EXTREMISTS JAILED IN PLOT AGAINST MUBARAK
description: An undisclosed number of Moslem fundamentalist extremists have been arrested on charges of planning to topple the Government of President Hosni Mubarak, the official Middle East News Agency announced today.

title: JETS HONE DEFENSE FOR PATRIOTS
description: He used to scream to inspire the Jets' defense, but now Joe Gardi, the defensive coordinator, was screaming to scold them:

title: AIRBAGS: MORE MONEY FOR LESS SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Houston Rockets may have given up the National Basketball Association's most valuable player in Moses Malone, but they are not regretting the future payment they won in the trade with the Philadelphia 76ers. First, the Rockets get Caldwell Jones, a veteran center.

title: DOWNTOWN SITE CHOSEN FOR A VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: A brick plaza in lower Manhattan has been selected by the city as the site for a Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Harpsichord Recital
description: The harpsichordist Robert Conant will give his first solo recital in 15 years Sunday at 8:30 at the Abraham Merkin Concert Hall, 129 East 67th Street.

title: ARAFAT DEMANDS 3 NATIONS RETURN PEACE FORCE TO BEIRUT
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, demanded today that the United States, France and Italy send their troops back to Beirut to protect its inhabitants against Israel.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Squeegee Crews Breaking Camp

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Included pretax charge of $455,000 for the qr and $1,155,000 for the yr for the provision of losses associated with the restructuring of manufacturing operations...C-Net income

title: Teachers Strike In Bergen District
description: Teachers demanding higher pay went on strike yesterday in Upper Saddle River, N.J., and teachers in two other school districts began classes after ratifying new contracts.

title: GAS IS PLENTIFUL, BUT PRICE IS UP
description: The shortage of natural gas, so acute a few winters ago that many industrial plants were forced to close, has been transformed into abundance.

title: No Headline
description: THE Magazine Publishers Association has produced a 13-minute promotion film that could unintentionally be an important tool in educating the advertising community on how to survive the consumer revolution.

title: BIG STEEL'S SCAPEGOAT
description: In its drive to win wage concessions, the steel industry has tried to sell the public a new villain: the greedy steelworker who won't give up a few dimes of his bloated pay to save his industry from the dragon of Japanese imports. A few facts should break the public-relations spell.

title: MARIETTA CHIEF STALKS BENDIX
description: The day after the Bendix Corporation announced its surprise attempt to take over the Martin Marietta Corporation, one of Marietta's directors took off his necktie and gave it to Thomas G. Pownall, the 60-year-old Annapolis graduate who runs Marietta. Emblazoned on the tie were naval pennants reading ''Don't Give Up the Ship.''

title: RESISTANCE SLIGHT
description: Israeli troops seized control of most of west Beirut today after overcoming resistance by small groups of Lebanese Moslem and leftist militiamen.

title: Law Banning Pistols Signed
description: Mayor James C. Lytle signed into law Wednesday an ordinance that bans the possession and transport of pistols in this northern suburb of Chicago. Only police officers, antique collectors and gun club members are exempt. The ordinance goes into effect Sept. 28.

title: PRIMARIES TO BRING RISE IN MINORITIES ON COUNCIL
description: Primary elections next Thursday are certain to set the stage for the entry of at least four new members into New York's City Council next year and an increase in the number of black and Hispanic members.

title: ISRAEL REJECTS U.S. PLEA TO PULL OUT OF WEST BEIRUT
description: Israel today rejected a call by the United States to pull its troops out of west Beirut and said they would remain there until the Lebanese Army was able to insure security in the area.

title: 2 Accused of Plot To Defraud U.S.
description: An official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and an East Orange man were indicted today on charges of bilking the Federal housing program of more than $160,000.

title: Aide to Coast Candidate Explains '80 Tax Filing
description: Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in California, confirmed through an aide today that he paid no Federal income taxes in 1980 on an income of $75,000.

title: 7-YEAR LOW IN FACTORY UTILIZATION
description: With goods selling slowly, manufacturers used just 69.4 percent of their factories' capacity last month, the lowest rate since the 1974-75 recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: SENATOR TOUGH IN THE FRAY; Man in the News
description: No one ever accused Senator Ted Stevens of penny-pinching the military. A fighter pilot with the famed Flying Tigers in World War II, he has long been one of the leading Congressional supporters of a strong military.

title: ROZELLE SAID TO STOP SETTLEMENT ON RAIDERS
description: A Los Angeles Councilman charged today that the National Football League's owners had agreed to give Al Davis an expansion team in Los Angeles if he would have left the Raiders in Oakland, but that they changed their minds because of opposition by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

title: 'LES TURLUPINS'
description: ''LES TURLUPINS'' (The Rascals), a 1979 French film that opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a decently acted but terminally predicatble comedy about boyhood in a small town in German-occupied France in 1942. The setting is a parochial boarding school that seems to be short of meat from time to time but is otherwise not especially affected by the world outside, which may be one of the less spellbinding points being made by Bernard Revon, the director. Life goes on and boys grow into men no matter what.

title: U.S. CALLS ISRAELI ACT A 'VIOLATION' AND DEMANDS IMMEDIATE PULLOUT
description: The United States demanded today that Israel withdraw its military forces from west Beirut immediately. It charged that the entry of the troops was a ''clear violation'' of the ceasefire agreement negotiated last month.

title: Foxboro Closing
description: The Foxboro Company, a maker of instruments and systems for computers and other industrial uses, said it would close its domestic plants during the final week of the year in an attempt to avert a general layoff among its 7,500 American employees. Workers may still collect pay during the week by taking it as vacation time.

title: G.O.P. CALLS IT A 'HOAX'
description: The Democratic-controlled House, ignoring Republican charges that they were cynically playing election-year politics, today passed a large-scale public works program that they said would provide at least 200,000 new jobs.

title: MOTES IN BOTH EYES
description: Alongside the worries everyone shares nowadays, the French are having their own jolly guerrilla war about being anti-American.

title: ROYAL ROMANCE, NEW SERIES AND IDEAS ON JUSTICE
description: APPARENTLY convinced that if viewers loved the real, they will gratefully accept the fake, television is busy doing dramatizations of the royal romance between Britain's Prince Charles and Lady Diana. Tonight at 9, ABC-TV is offering ''Charles and Diana: A Royal Love Story.'' The script for this production by Edward S. Feldman was written by John McGreevey, who was long closely associated with ''The Waltons.''

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY PICKS CHAIRMAN OF INQUIRY PANEL
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has appointed a new chairman for the three-judge panel that is conducting an inquiry into the Indian Point nuclear reactors, a commission spokesman said yesterday.

title: JUSTICE AIDES TAKE CIVIL RIGHTS STEPS
description: One day after President Reagan sought to assure black Republicans of his commitment to civil rights, the Justice Department announced today that it was moving on several fronts to enforce antidiscrimination laws in voting and employment.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AMERICA NEEDS THE 3 C'S AGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Brokers to Merge
description: Two brokerage houses, Laing & Cruickshank and McNally, Montgomery & Company, are to merge Nov. 29, subject to approval by the London Stock Exchange, a joint statement said today. The merger will result in some 60 layoffs, leaving the combined company with a staff of about 350.

title: CLOSE THE BRICK LOOPHOLE
description: Suppose a group of steel companies conspire to fix the price of materials they sold to General Motors, which in turn passed on the higher costs to consumers. The antitrust laws give General Motors the right to sue the steelmakers for damages. But what about the car buyers, the parties hurt most by the conspiracy?

title: 7 More Held in PCB Protest
description: The police today hauled seven chanting protesters away from a sit-down demonstration at a toxic waste dump where a confrontation with officers the day before resulted in 55 arrests. The arrests came at the Warren County dump site where the state has begun unloading soil contaminated by polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, illegally dumped along North Carolina highways.

title: FIRST CITY PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $340,000 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 6 mos...C-After tax credits of $896,000 for the qr and $2.9 million for the 6 mos

title: MCINTOSHES ARE AT TOP OF LIST OF APPLES TO PICK
description: For city and suburbs dwellers who fantasize about somehow stepping back into the traditional life depicted in Currier and Ives prints, one of those seasons when rural fantasies may be at least partly realized is upon us. It is apple-picking time in farm regions near the New York area, and reports are that the new crop of McIntoshes is one of the biggest and best in years.

title: Man Charged in the Slayings Of Companion and Her Son, 8
description: A Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with fatally stabbing a woman with whom he sometimes lived and drowning her 8-year-old son on Tuesday, the police said.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Placed Ken Higgs, guard, on waivers. FOOTBALL

title: Playing It Safe
description: Scott Holman and Walt Terrell, two promising Met pitchers, are scheduled to make their first major league starts in twilight-night doubleheader games tonight and tomorrow against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: SOME FEDRAL MONEY FOR CITY'S BLACKSMITHS
description: There have been a lot of rude jokes over the years to the effect that the city's transportation system might be faster if it went back to using horses. Be that as it may, one of the matters under discussion at the M.T.A.'s monthly meeting yesterday was whether to accept a $1.3 million Federal grant for training blacksmiths.

title: Administration Urging Settlement in Rail Talks
description: The Reagan Administration implored the railroad industry and an engineers' union today to reach a contract settlement and avert a threatened nationwide strike Sunday. A walkout would idle virtually all railroads carrying freight.

title: Expense Clippers
description: It's hardly a secret that the San Diego Clippers of the National Basketball Association swim in red ink; their owner, Donald Sterling, has complained about it publicly. And the Clippers aren't alone; the generally accepted estimate is that 17 of the N.B.A.'s 23 franchises lose money.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD GIVES APPROVAL TO LINCOLN WEST
description: The Board of Estimate, by a vote of 10 to 1, approved the Lincoln West luxury housing project early this morning, after more than a day of behind-the-scenes wranging over details and intense lobbying of board members.

title: U.S. HAS TRADE SURPLUS OF $2.1 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The United States posted a $2.1 billion overall trade surplus in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today. The country had a deficit in merchandise trade, but that was offset by the sale of services.

title: Bell 'Express Call'
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would begin trials of a new domestic service - 30-second long-distance calls from special pay phones to any point in the United States for 50 cents. Starting in California in December, the new ''Express Call'' service will be extended to New York, Massachusetts and Michigan by Jan. 31.

title: DICK TRACY AND MUGS, A ROGUE'S GALLERY OF ART
description: The 1952 comic-strip scene is a television studio. BLOND WOMAN: Oh, by the way, Tonsils, I want you to meet Dick Tracy. TONSILS (a crooner said to have been modeled on Johnny Ray): Uh? (Tracy is visible in foreground, in profile.) TONSILS again: Dick Tracy? So what? What have I done, er - that is - TRACY: It's your agent we're after, Tonsils, he happens to be a three-time murderer. Where is he?

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Data General, Westboro, Mass., has elected Donald V. Bateman vice president, human resources, and James A. Pitts vice president, controller.

title: CROQUET: A GAME OF MALLETS AND MALICE
description: With genteel manners hiding a fiercely competitive sport, the National Croquet Championship has settled in for five days in Central Park, rain or shine.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1982
description: International Israeli troops seized control of most of west Beirut after overcoming resistance by Lebanese Moslems and leftist militiamen. They were continuing the drive that they began on Wednesday, hours after Lebanon's President-elect, Bashir Gemayel, was assassinated. (Page A1, Column 6.) A withdrawal of Israeli troops from west Beirut was demanded by the United States as the Reagan Administration charged that the entry of military forces was a ''clear violation'' of the cease-fire agreement negotiated last month. A State Department spokesman said the Israelis had told American officials that the military moves were ''limited and precautionary.'' But, he went on, the situation ''does not seem to jibe'' with the assurances.(A1:3.)

title: ART: 'THE JEWS IN THE AGE OF REMBRANDT'
description: ''THE JEWS IN THE AGE OF REMBRANDT'' is the name of a compact and beautifully hung show of engravings, etchings and mezzotints ornamenting the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street. Its curators are Ruth E. Levine and Susan W. Morgenstein of the Jewish Community Center of Greater Washington, at whose Judaic Museum the project was conceived.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The shr earnings, per Class A, are fully diluted

title: McCann-Erickson Drops Bache Account
description: McCann-Erickson dramatically resigned the $5 million Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. brokerage account yesterday, saying that it was a potential conflict with American Express, for which it does the Gold Card advertising.

title: Stephen Tyno, Retired Head Of Sports Copy Desk at Times
description: Stephen Tyno, who retired from The New York Times in 1980 after more than 40 years as an editor in the sports department, died yesterday at his home in Rye, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Cheers
description: When Fresno State University announced that the halftime entertainment for a Sept. 25 football game would feature the 34 Dallas Cowboy cheerleaders, 200 tickets were sold for the game the first day. But several faculty members aren't so sure the show should go on.

title: Scali Creates New Omega Spreads
description: The Swiss-owned Omega Watch Corporation is not increasing its ad budget from last year's $4 million, but Hugh G. Glenn, president, is expecting ''more bang for the buck'' from the first campaign from his new agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: BIG MILITARY PARADE HELPS MEXICO MARK DAY OF INDEPENDENCE
description: Mexico's first supersonic jet fighters, seven F-5E's bought recently from the United States, made their public debut here today, sweeping low over the National Palace during a military parade to mark the country's Independence Day.

title: 'INCHON,' AT LAST
description: ''INCHON'' is a hysterical historical epic, somewhat less offensive than ''The Green Berets'' and far funnier. It's the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's tribute to the late Gen. Douglas MacArthur and the 1950 United Nations amphibious operation by which the general outflanked the North Korean invaders of South Korea.

title: 8 EX-WELFARE CHIEFS ASK U.S. FLOOR ON FAMILY AID
description: Eight former Secretaries of Health, Education and Welfare called today for an overhaul of the program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, starting with a national minimum benefit for welfare families.

title: THEATER: A SOLO BY ERIC BOGOSIAN
description: WHILE the new season waits in the wings, the Public Theater is lighting only one of its many stages these September nights. And just barely. The actor-writer Eric Bogosian, who has brought his one-man show to Martinson Hall, is a fellow who prefers the dark. He works on a black, empty stage, wears black (down to his Keds) and thinks black. When he ends his 90-minute evening with an invocation of Rod Serling's ''The Twilight Zone,'' he even walks away from his spotlight to become a full-fledged creature of the shadows.

title: Holographic Clock
description: ''The Clockwork Concerto,'' an exhibition combining holography and leaded glass, will run through Dec. 5 at the Museum of Holography, 11 Mercer Street.

title: ARMY PLANS NEW COMMAND TO CURB LEFTIST INSURGENCIES
description: The Army announced today that it would establish a new special operations command Oct. 1 to speed United States responses to leftist insurgencies in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

title: No Headline
description: Royals and Angels Are Beaten

title: Tourney Incurs A $20,000 Fine
description: Top tennis players have been fined as much as $10,000 in recent years for serious code-of-conduct violations. Now a Grand Prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany, has been fined $20,000 by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council for having offered discounts on cars as an incentive for players to sign up for the $75,000 event last July.

title: MGM/UA Sets Deal With CBS
description: Debt-ridden MGM/UA, the entertainment conglomerate, yesterday executed a letter of intent to sell its music copyrights to CBS Inc. for an estimated $70 million, according to a joint announcement by the two companies.

title: A WOMAN AND HER WHISTLE BLOWERS
description: When an executive of a military contractor was asked by a reporter this week to comment on some unflattering data about an aircraft contract, his first words were, ''Oh, is Dina at it again?''

title: Old Gang at Yale
description: On the eve of Yale University's 111th football season, the head coach, Carm Cozza, has a problem.

title: CAPSULE TO TEST STRATOSPHERE LOWERED 7 MILES FROM BALLOON
description: Harvard University experimenters, in the first test of their plan for surveying deep cross sections of the stratosphere, were able on Wednesday to lower a capsule of instruments seven and a half miles below a balloon high over Texas, then haul it back up again.

title: THREE CLUBS LOSE KEY PLAYERS TO INJURIES
description: While testifying in a recent court case, Dr. Marvin Knight, the longtime physician for the Dallas Cowboys, said that almost every football player he had ever known had been injured at one time or another. The annual toll began last Sunday with the opening of the National Football League season. The teams hurt the most were the Cleveland Browns, the Kansas City Chiefs and the New Orleans Saints, because Clay Matthews, Jack Rudnay and George Rogers are so good and so difficult to replace.

title: STATE TO PROVIDE $3 MILLION IN AID TO SOUTH BRONX
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation yesterday announced the start of two economic development projects totaling $3 million in a rundown commercial corridor of the South Bronx.

title: ART SEASON OFF TO EARLY AND LIVELY BEGINNING
description: CIMABUE at the Met. Milton Avery at the Whitney. Samuel F.B. Morse at New York University's Grey Art Gallery. Suddenly - and somewhat prematurely - the New York art season has come explosively to life. While those who follow the scene are heard to complain that their opening-night clothes are still at the cleaner's, museums have made an early start with a rush of important shows, the kind that once didn't begin until late September.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: AFTER he had dazzled them at Carnegie Hall the other night, Frank Sinatra, often called ''the chairman of the board,'' helped h onor another chairman of another board: Steven J. Ross of Warner C ommunications.

title: No Headline
description: Kuwaiti Envoy Killed By Gunman in Madrid

title: Dow Declines 2.66 In Heavier Trading; Analysts Cite Profit Taking
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday as investors cashed in some of their recent profits. Trading was heavier. Some transportation issues registered the largest declines, while Crum & Forster, which is engaged in merger talks, had the biggest rise.

title: Switch to Low-Tar Cigarettes Reported of Doubtful Benefit
description: Reduced tar and nicotine cigarettes have ''doubtful'' health benefits, and the only sure way to lower the hazards of smoking is to quit entirely, a panel of experts at the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: U.N. COUNCIL MEETS ON BEIRUT
description: The Security Council held an emergency meeting today to consider a request by Lebanon that it condemn Israel's occupation of west Beirut and demand an immediate pullback of Israeli forces.

title: MR. DONOVAN'S COMPLAINT
description: It's widely believed in this country that the ''news media'' are irresponsible and intrusive. Sometimes they are. But it's not well enough understood that sometimes the press must pursue a higher value than the privacy of an individual or official.

title: BIG WEEKEND FOR TOURS IN PARKS AROUND TOWN
description: Walking tours and lectures for amateur botanists and astronomers, as well as for nature lovers in general, are plentiful in the city's parks this weekend. The tours, led by the Urban Park Rangers, are free and most of them take place rain or shine.

title: Trio Plays Upstate
description: Works by Stravinsky, Purcell, Handel, Mozart, Scarlatti and others will be performed by a trio Sunday at 5 P.M. in the last of a summer series at Pacem in Terris on Covered Bridge Road in Warwick, N.Y. The trio consists of Danielle Woerner, soprano; Sonia Gezairlian Grib, harpsichordist, and Christine Soder, clarinetist. There is a suggested donation of $2. Information: (914) 986-4329.

title: THE TURNAROUND OF BRITAIN'S FERRANTI
description: In a country where most companies have found their profits battered by recession, Ferranti P.L.C., one of Britain's foremost arms and electronics manufacturers, seems hardly to have been bruised.

title: WORKING FOR A PROPER FEDERAL JOB TRAINING LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'VICTORIAN BROWNSTONES' GOING UP IN QUEENS PROJECT
description: A broker named Dick Dickler of Lane Realty in Queens had, by his own account, annoyed a Queens property owner for years to sell certain undeveloped land about a mile from Queens College.

title: A Missing Person
description: Milt Pappas, the onetime star pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds, is appealing to the public for news of his wife, Carole Pappas, who has been missing since last Saturday. They have been married 22 years and live in Wheaton, Ill., where the 42-yearold Mrs. Pappas was last seen at a hairdressing salon.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Schoolboy Dies Of Football Injury
description: A cranial hemorrhage caused the death of Scott Reitz, a 17-year-old Doherty High School football player who suffered a head injury in a game last Friday, the El Paso County Coroner said today.

title: SCHMIDT MEETS WITH RIVAL CHIEF IN CRISIS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt met unexpectedly this evening with President Karl Carstens and Helmut Kohl, leader of the opposition Christian Democrats, amid signs of sharpening strains in his coalition government.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS YIELD TO PRESIDENT ON SPECIAL SESSION
description: President Reagan called on Congress today to convene a special post-election session to adopt 13 appropriation bills to finance the Government in the next fiscal year, and Congressional leaders reluctantly agreed. The session would probably begin in late November.

title: U.S. ACTS TO EASE SANCTIONS' IMPACT
description: The Administration, under pressure from business, is seeking to limit the impact of the trade sanctions that President Reagan has imposed on companies involved in building the Siberian natural gas pipeline.

title: OWNERS PLANNING TO FILL ROSTERS
description: With contract negotiations between representatives of the National Football League Players Association and the Management Council scheduled to resume at 2 P.M. today, the league acknowledged yesterday it had been taking steps to try to field teams in the event a strike is called.

title: Another Departure At Burroughs Corp.
description: Continuing a shift of high-level managers since the arrival of W. Michael Blumenthal as chief executive, the Burroughs Corporation announced that Thomas E. Winter is leaving as vice president for finance after 18 months on the job. His replacement will come from Burrough's recently acquired Memorex Corporation unit.

title: TAKEOVER OF CRUM IS RUMORED
description: The stock of Crum & Forster soared $11.50 today, to $41, as rumors cirulated about an impending takeover of the large property and casualty insurance concern.

title: POLICE SEEK ROBBER WHO KILLED YOUTH FOR RADIO
description: On the afternoon of Aug. 23, 16-year-old Shimon Kutchera was returning by subway to the group home on East 233d Street in the Bronx where he lived. He was carrying a portable radio-cassette player, a proud possession he had bought with his earnings from his new job at a summer day camp.

title: TITLE-GAME LINEUPS UNCERTAIN
description: Two days before the Soccer Bowl here Saturday night, only five members of the Cosmos knew for sure that they would be participating in the championship game of the North American Soccer League. They were Hubert Birkenmeier, the goalkeeper; Jeff Durgan, Carlos Alberto, Vlado Bogicevic and Giorgio Chinaglia.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The headline and part of an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday on the Democratic primary in the 12th Congressional District incorrectly described the candidates, Vander L. Beatty and Major R. Owens. Both are incumbent New York State Senators.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $3.7 million or 17 cents a shr from sale of Wilton Enterprises Inc

title: THE RETARDED PERSON IS NOT MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions Monday incorrectly identified the affiliation of a man arrested during a protest Sun- day against Secretary of State George P. Shultz at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. He had no connection with Americans for a Safe Israel, the group that organized the demonstration.

title: NEW YORK WINE BARS: A SPECIAL VINTAGE
description: THE first wine bar, it can be stated with some authority, opened for business in Asia Minor 6,000 years ago, give or take a couple of months. What authority? Common sense. The experts say wine was discovered about 6,000 years ago, and it couldn't have taken more than a few weeks for someone to start selling the stuff across a bar.

title: Truck Driver Dies At L.I. Landfill
description: The driver of a garbage truck was crushed to death today by a trash compactor at the Brookhaven Town landfill, and authorities have ruled the death accidental.

title: PRINCESS STRICKEN BEFORE CRASH, DOCTORS SAY
description: Two doctors who attended Princess Grace said today that the automobile accident that led to her death occurred because she suffered an attack similar to a stroke while at the wheel.

title: Nicaragua Gets Loan
description: Despite opposition from the United States, the Inter-American Development Bank today approved a $34 million loan to Nicaragua.

title: UMET PROPERTIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $213,000...C-Net loss...D-After a gain of real estate of $670,000 and a tax credit of $1,574,000

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The yr-ago qr restated for accounting changes; Company said that 1981 net is before reversal of prior yr United Kingdom income tax provisions which increased earnings by $2.5 million or 19 cents a shr

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS DEFEATED IN WALES
description: The new Social Democratic Party failed Thursday in an attempt to oust the Labor Party from one of its strongholds, but it avoided potential humiliation.

title: Prison Term Given In Waste Dumping
description: The former manager of the Lone Pine Landfill has been sentenced to six months in prison in connection with the dumping of hazardous wastes at the Freehold dump.

title: A U.S. SECOND THOUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lonrho Ends Fraser Bid
description: Lonrho Ltd. said today that it was ending its bid for the House of Fraser, which owns Harrods stores. Lonrho, which has 29.9 percent of Fraser, said it dropped its $435 million offer for the rest because of Fraser's unsatisfactory earnings.

title: I.T.T. Publishing Aide To Join Chilton as Chief
description: Gary R. Ingersoll has been named president and chief executive of the Chilton Company, a publisher of trade magazines, among them Iron Age and Hardware Age.

title: Price Fixing and Foul Play; No New Rules for Old Cases
description: If the National Football League decided to change its scoring rules so that field goals counted more than touchdowns, the players might scratch their heads but they would adjust their game plans accordingly. But what if the league applied the new rules retroactively and recalculated the scores of last Sunday's games? Unfair, the teams would object; they chose to kick or go for a touchdown on the basis of the rules as they were.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Included a charge of $8,000 from reversal of tax credit for the qr and a tax credit of $82,000 for the yr...C-Included tax credits of $210,000 for the qr and$400,000 for the yr

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH EXCLUSIVE BEER WHOLESALE?
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PERFORMANCE: CLOWNS
description: THE Clown Conspiracy, a chamber troupe of appealing clown-actors with a very agreeable pianist, is directed by Yuri Belov, who once taught and coached clowns in Moscow.

title: UTILITY RATES TO RISE IN JERSEY
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today approved a $21.1 million rate increase for the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and a $73.9 million increase for gas customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

title: Robinzine Found Dead
description: The police reported today that Bill Robinzine, a forward for the Utah Jazz last season, was found dead in his parked car, an apparent suicide.

title: News Analysis
description: When the Israelis entered Lebanon on June 6, the question immediately arose as to how they would eventually manage to get out. Now that they have moved deeply into west Beirut and more deeply into Lebanon's morass of internal factionalism, the question has grown more urgent and more troublesome.

title: MARYLAND REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $8,000 for the qr and $29,000 for the 9 mos

title: WHEN CONGRESS IS LAME DUCK
description: The term ''lame duck'' comes from a British reference to bankrupt businessmen, but after the 1830's it came to be used in the United States to describe politically bankrupt politicians.

title: Tentative Pact Reached In California Bus Strike
description: A tentative settlement was reached late tonight by striking bus drivers and the Southern California Rapid Transit District.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL CONDEMNS LATEST ISRAELI INCURSION
description: The United States and the 14 other Security Council members today condemned the Israeli incursion in west Beirut and demanded that Israel withdraw its forces at once.

title: Previn Accepts Post At Royal Philharmonic
description: Andre Previn, the conductor and composer, has agreed to become musical director of London's Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in June 1985.

title: BREWERS ELIMINATE YANKEES
description: The Yankees, long out of contention, were eliminated from the American League East race tonight when they were trounced by the first-place Milwaukee Brewers, 14-0.

title: PIANIST: MARK CANNON
description: It was refreshing to read the pianist Mark Cannon's biographical history before his recital in Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night. Mr. Cannon, born in West Germany in 1950, attended the Medical College of Wisconsin, took a psychiatry residency at New York Hospital and is now in private practice as a psychiatrist. So Mr. Cannon is an amateur musician, and, given his dedication to the piano over the years, an amateur in the literal sense, a lover of the instrument.

title: NATO Chief Assails Nuclear Freeze Call
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the NATO commander, said today that the movement in the United States for a nuclear arms freeze would encourage Moscow not to negotiate an arms reduction.

title: Cartier Mining
description: The Quebec Cartier Mining Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Company, said it would close two of its iron-ore mining operations from Nov. 1 until some time in January. As a result 1,200 workers at the Mount Wright operations, who have been idled since July 20 and will return Sept. 29, will be laid off again for the winter shutdown. In addition 700 workers at the Lac Jeannine-Fire Lake operation, who were affected by a June 30 to Aug. 25 summer shutdown, will also be affected by the winter closure, and 450 employees will be laid off permanently.

title: CARDINALS TOP METS BY 3-2, 7-1
description: The Mets, who have not won a doubleheader all season, failed again last night when they lost two games at Shea Stadium to the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, in 10 innings, and 7-1.

title: RAILROAD TALKS CONTINUE AS STRIKE DEADLINE NEARS
description: As a strike deadline at 12:01 A.M. Sunday drew closer, talks between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and representatives of about 100 private railroads continued until late afternoon today.

title: U.S. TO DELAY NEW MILK SALE FEE AT $100 MILLION COST TO TREASURY
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it had decided to put off for two months the collection of fees that were to have been charged to dairy farmers as part of the effort to hold down the cost of the dairy price-support program.

title: No Headline
description: Help Is Urged For Harvester

title: Group Seeks to Defeat 12 Foes of Arms Freeze
description: A new political action committee called PeacePac announced today that it had selected for defeat what it termed a ''doomsday dozen'' of House members, 10 Republicans and two Democrats, who were opposed to a nuclear arms freeze.

title: TEACHER STRIKES DISRUPT CLASSES FOR LOCALITIES
description: Public school teachers in two districts in Bergen County and one on Long Island were on strike yesterday demanding higher pay and increases in benefits.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY CLUMBS BY $4.3 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $4.3 billion in the latest reporting week, a large gain for a single week but one that was widely anticipated.

title: KENNEDY AND HART ENDORSE PAY EQUITY FOR WOMEN
description: A dozen witnesses, including Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Gary Hart, have appeared before a House hearing to endorse the idea that workers should receive comparable pay for jobs requiring comparable work.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about wine bars gave an incorrect ad- dress for Lavin's Restaurant Bar. It is at 23 West 39th Street.

title: Your Money; Property Laws And Moving
description: A significant aspect of the continuing mobility of the American p opulation is the movement of men and women into and out of the eightc ommunity property states. Because the adequacy of estate planning isa ffected by such moves, it is important to understand the different t reatment of marital property within and outside these states.

title: ELEGANT BALLOON
description: A BLOODSMOOR ROMANCE. By Joyce Carol Oates. 615 pages. E.P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: A Tax Ruling
description: In a tax case that may ultimately have a bearing on tax suits filed by 41 other hockey players, a Federal Court of Appeals in New York ruled that Peter Stemkowski, a former New York Ranger player, could not deduct hairstyling, newspapers and entertainment expenses during the offseason. But the Federal Court ordered a lower tax court to reconsider which offseason physical conditioning expenses Stemkowski might write off. The case dealt with Stemkowski's deductions in 1971 when he was a Canadian citizen playing hockey in New York.

title: MISREPRESENTED ISSUE IN SUNY CONTRACT TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Perry Loses Appeal
description: The 10-day suspension of the Seattle Mariners pitcher Gaylord Perry for throwing a spitball in a game last month against Boston was upheld Friday as the American League denied his appeal.

title: WHERE THE ELITE CAN NOW MEET
description: Time was, when diplomatic assignment to Washington was seen as something less than a coup. It was, some said, a sentence to perdition: a swampy, provincial capital where mosquitos and humidity reigned and the diplomat was entitled to hardship pay.

title: LENDERS SEEK PACT ON REFINER'S DEBT
description: John R. Stanley, an oil-industry entrepreneur who went bankrupt in 1975 with liabilities of $233 million, is in apparent danger of doing it again on a bigger scale in a few weeks.

title: Down, Not Out
description: In his role as a boxing publicist, Tom Kenville has seen some pesky managers of boxers, but Michael Longerman may top the list. Kenville works for Madison Square Garden, which is promoting a card of four 10-round fights next Friday night at the Felt Forum.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1982
description: International The Government in West Germany, a coalition that has governed for the past 13 years, collapsed. The Government fell as the Free Democrats pulled their four ministers out of the Government, and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt challenged the opposition to agree to hold new elections. (Page 1, Column 6.) More Israeli armored forces poured into west Beirut, increasing their grip on the predominantly Moslem sector of the Lebanese capital. Lebanese Christian militiamen, meanwhile, entered Palestinian refugee camps in the southern suburbs to arrest guerrilla suspects. It was reported that Israeli troops had occupied a consulate building inside the Soviet Embassy compound. (1:5.)

title: Marietta Still Fights For Bendix
description: Moving swiftly onto a collision course with the Bendix Corporation, the Martin Marietta Corporation vowed yesterday to go ahead with its plans to buy control of Bendix.

title: MOST SUSPECTS ARE CHARGED IN CRIMES IN OWN BOROUGHS
description: Each year the New York City police make more than 100,000 arrests, most of which are logged and processed without being closely scrutinized. A look at the 8,573 arrests made during a recent twoweek period provided a glimpse at arrest patterns in the city and offered some insights into day-to-day police activity - from the kinds of arrests the officers make to the ''commuting'' habits of the suspects.

title: Second Thoughts
description: John Walker of New Zealand, an Olympic champion and one of the world's top milers for almost 10 years, was an interested spectator during the recent United States Open tennis championships.

title: Apartment Strike Possible in Bronx
description: Employees in about 2,000 apartment buildings in the Bronx have turned down a proposed contract and have warned of a possible strike next week.

title: VERA STRAVINSKI, WIDOW OF COMPOSER, DEAD AT 93
description: Vera Stravinsky, second wife and widow of Igor Stravinsky, died early yesterday in her Fifth Avenue apartment. She was 93 years old. Although Mrs. Stravinsky was in her 80's when her husband died in 1971, she became more widely known to the public than she had been before. This was because of controversies that developed about the authenticity of writings attributed to Stravinsky and information about him that were published before his death and over the disposition of his multimillion-dollar estate.

title: Dome Tender Plan
description: The Hudson Bay Company did not tender any of its 7.7 million Dome Resources preferred ''A'' shares to Dome Petroleum Ltd., a company spokesman said.

title: MUSTO-CASE FIGURE SENTENCED
description: The New Jersey builder whose testimony led to the Federal conspiracy and racketeering conviction of former State Senator William V. Musto received a suspended sentence today on the ground that imprisonment would put him in danger.

title: HOW MUCH RAW SEWAGE CAN THE HUDSON TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Singers to Compete In American Semifinals
description: Twelve singers - one Briton and 11 Americans - will compete for cash and other prizes at the International American Music Competition for Vocalists next week in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street. The semifinals will be next Wednesday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Sept. 23 from 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., with the finals scheduled for Sept. 25, beginning at 1 P.M. All parts of the competition are free and open to the public.

title: INQUIRY IS TOLD
description: A panel of expert witnesses, appearing today before a Congressional hearing, contended that Federal agencies had contributed to the current crisis in international banking through lax enforcement of bank regulations.

title: Broker Convicted In Embezzlement
description: A real estate broker, William Sheppard of Fanwood, N.J., was convicted in Manhattan yesterday of Federal charges involving the embezzlement of $1.2 million from the Bankers Trust Company.

title: 3 Die in Texas Midair Crash
description: Two light planes collided in the air near a small north Texas airport late Thursday, killing all three men aboard one of them.

title: AIRPORTS FAULTED ON WIND DETECTION
description: A research meteorologist said here today that small-scale but lethal wind bursts that can slam a low-flying jetliner to the ground were not being detected by weather monitoring systems at the country's airports.

title: Maud Seligman, 91, Is Dead; Founded International Center
description: Maud Jaretzki Seligman, founder and director of the International Center in New York Inc., died Sept. 9 at her home in Manhattan.

title: Westinghouse Sets Sale of Lamp Units
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Westinghouse Lamp business to the North American Philips Corporation for $200 million in cash and notes.

title: REAGAN 'HARD HAT' BACK ON TV, BUT FOR DEMOCRATS
description: James A. Willders is the ''hard hat'' who was seen by millions in a television campaign commercial for Ronald Reagan in 1980 saying, ''If the Democrats are for the working man, how come we're not working?'' He is back on the screen this election year, but as a Democrat with his party loyalty and long hair intact.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about a swim around Manhattan gave an incorrect time for Karen Hartley, winner of the women's division. The time was 7 hours 41 minutes 2 seconds.

title: HAWAIIANS GO TO POLLS TODAY
description: Lieut. Gov. Jean King and five other Democrats will challenge Gov. George Ariyoshi's bid for a third term Saturday as Hawaii voters select candidates for Federal, state and local offices.

title: MARCOS DEFENDS HIS RIGHTS AND SPENDING RECORDS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today defended his record on human rights in the Philippines and termed ''ridiculous'' reports that he was an authoritarian and that he and his wife, Imelda, spent public funds lavishly while other Filipinos suffered in poverty.

title: Thais Urge 9 Nations To Take More Refugees
description: Thailand warned the United States and other non-Communist nations today that it would force thousands of Indochinese refugees back to their homelands unless other countries increased their refugee quotas.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's call for a special postelection legislative session, which distressed Congressional leaders of both parties, points up the conflicting perspectives that create continued antagonisms between the White House and Capitol Hill.
