title: Duncan Norton-Taylor Dies; A Retired Editor of; Fortune
description: Duncan Norton-Taylor, a former managing editor of Fortune magazine, died Monday at Memorial Hospital in Easton, Md., after a stroke. He was 78 years old and had lived in Oxford, Md., since his retirement in 1967.

title:
Patents;
Microbes Recover Oil From Tar Sands
description: Microbes can be used to recover oil from oil and tar sands, according to a patent granted this week to Irving Rabinovitch, president of Omni Biotechnology Ltd. of La Prairie, Quebec, and Howard E. Worne of Medford, N.J.

title: CHRISTIE'S WINE AUCTION IS MOVED TO CHICAGO
description: Christie's has canceled a wine auction in Washington on Oct. 16 and will hold the auction on the same day in Chicago instead, as a result of a legal dispute involving several Washington wine dealers.

title: Still Not Welcome
description: As long as he owns three race tracks, it appears that Edward J. De-Bartolo had better forget about getting into major league baseball. DeBartolo was frustrated in his attempt to purchase the Chicago White Sox two years ago, primarily because of his race-track connections.

title: Buffalo News Guild Rejects Concession
description: Members of the Buffalo Newspaper Guild voted against a concession required by Rupert Murdoch's News America Company tonight, apparently ending the chances of the failing Buffalo Courier-Express being sold to its only potential buyer.

title: Preparation Induces Synthesis of Interferon
description: A nucleic acid preparation described as effective in inducing the synthesis in humans or other primates of interferon, which is effective against various diseases, was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Judge of TV Case Rebuffs N.C.A.A.
description: A Federal judge refused today to postpone a ruling he made Wednesday that would strip the National Collegiate Athletic Association of its control over college football's television contracts.

title: 25 HONDURAN REBELS SAID TO SEIZE 200 AT MEETING
description: About 25 leftist guerrillas raided a meeting at the Chamber of Commerce headquarters tonight and held two Cabinet officials, the Central Bank president and about 200 business leaders hostage, the police said.

title: JOHN J. MURRAY
description: John J. Murray, associate director of the Office of Public Information at Columbia University, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Carmel, N.Y. He was 55 years old.

title: Guatemala Executes 4 Convicted Guerrillas
description: Four men accused of being leftist guerrillas were shot at dawn today in the first such executions since political violence became widespread in Guatemala 20 years ago, the army said.

title: BURNUP OFFERS LURE TO 17 WHO QUIT
description: Directors of Burnup & Sims Inc., a telecommunications and cable company based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., offered cash bonuses and stock incentives today to 17 disgruntled corporate officers in an effort to reverse their decisions to resign.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in the New York Times this week. Answers appear on page 45. 1. The savings and loan industry is desperately trying to persuade Congress to extend sales of tax-exempt ''all-savers'' certificates beyond 1982. Why?

title: Thais Give Scriptures to U.S.
description: Thailand has presented the United States with a collection of Buddhist scriptures that will be housed in the Library of Congress in Washington, the United States Embassy here announced today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TUGS AND TOWS

title: POLES REACH U.S. AFTER A LONG SAIL AND ASK TO STAY
description: Four Polish nationals who sailed into New York Harbor after a fourmonth voyage from Greece in a 38-foot sailboat asked yesterday for permission to remain in the United States, and immigration officials said their request was being considered.

title: Julian Saenz Hinojosa Dies; A Career Diplomat in Mexico
description: Julian Saenz Hinojosa, a career diplomat in the Mexican Foreign Service, died Sept. 8 at Sibley Memorial Hospital here after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: NEW RULES GOVERNING WELFARE ISSUED
description: The Reagan Administration, hoping to save $181 million next year, published new rules today for the nation's largest welfare program that would allow states to require applicants to look for jobs.

title: Diet Extremes
description: The Rangers' captain, Barry Beck, underwent a conversion of almost religious fervor this summer concerning health and nutrition.

title: PRINCESS EXTOLLED AT HOMETOWN RITE
description: Before 1,500 mourners in the city of Princess Grace's birth, John Cardinal Krol extolled her virtues today as an actress, a woman of faith and most of all as a mother devoted to her family.

title: BRIEFS
description: *Advant Corp. said it was suffering a severe cash shortage because of a lack of sales and that it would seek additional sources of financing. *AM International Inc. of Canada said its creditors had accepted a repayment plan under which the company will repay the $16 million (Canadian) debt incurred before its April 14 bankruptcy filing. *Budy Corp. said it had acquired Bunnell Plastics Inc. and its subsidiary, Bunnell Industries, a producer of anticorrosive piping systems, for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Hess's Family Appeals For Ex-Nazi's Release
description: The family of Rudolf Hess, the former Nazi leader, has appealed to his British, French, American and Soviet jailers in West Berlin for his release on humanitarian grounds.

title: The Union Made Him Strong
description: David Dubinsky's name was once as familiar as the garment union label whose use he championed for much of this century. From 1932 until his retirement in 1966, he was both president and driving force of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAYCrowd Cheers a Driver
description: Daniel Fleischer of Boston left his car yesterday in a No Parking zone for ''no more than two minutes,'' to drop off his fiancee and her mother so they could pick up a dress. Somehow, drivers never leave for more than two minutes.

title: STREET VENDORS ARE NOT THE PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLY DAYS BRING PRAYERS FOR PEACE
description: Scripture readings for the Jewish holy day of Rosh ha-Shanah describe Abraham's arrival in the Promised Land, and the current state of that part of the world is shaping many of the sermons preached in synagogues this weekend.

title: U.S. Brings Bribery Case
description: The Justice Department filed criminal charges today against a California company and its president, accusing them of having aided in bribing foreign officials in turbine sales to Mexico's Government-owned oil company.

title: Coke Gets Pasta Maker
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its foods division had acquired the Ronco Foods Company, a privately held maker of pasta products. Eugene V. Amoroso, president of the Coke division, said Ronco would start operating as a Coca-Cola unit on Saturday.

title: HELP REP. FENWICK
description: President Reagan came to New Jersey today to give his support to a fellow Republican, Representative Millicent Fenwick, in her race for the Senate against the Democrat, Frank Lautenberg.

title: Madison Fund Head Resigns
description: Derald H. Ruttenberg has resigned as chairman of the Madison Fund Inc., the fund announced yesterday. Mr. Ruttenberg, who is 66 years old, stepped down, it said, to give more time to other activities. A telephone call to his office was answered by a woman who said she was his secretary and declined to comment on his resignation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Variety of New Citizens

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The bravura performances went on all week at the Metropolitan Opera house. There was the lyrical rendering of a velvet bodice reboned and trimmed with fine gold braid, the clever production of dozens of Styrofoam sides of beef through the collaboration of the property and scenic design shops, and the refreshing encore appearance of a trompe l'oeil Aubusson carpet brought back with some deft brush strokes to its original rose, green and white.

title: Manning Traded To Oilers
description: The New Orleans Saints traded Archie Manning, their veteran quarterback, to the Houston Oilers today for Leon Gray, an offensive lineman who refused to sign a contract this season.

title: A NEW HURDLE FOR ALFA GROUP
description: Behind a block-long stretch of white walls stands the dramatic new headquarters of the Alfa Industrial Group. Inside, secretaries wear uniforms of blue silk blouses and white pleated skirts purchased from Neiman-Marcus, and executives work behind elegant mahogany desks.

title: THEATER FUNDS'S DIRECTOR SAYS HIS MOTTO IS 'MORE'
description: Henry Guettel, the new executive director of the Theater Development Fund - the sponsor of the performing-arts ticket booth in Duffy Square that is now doing better business than ever before in its nine-year history -says that his motto on the job will be ''More.''

title: PERFORMANCE: PILAR RIOJA IN GARCIA LORCA
description: The Spanish poet Federico Garcia Lorca loved to celebrate ''duende,'' by which he meant, in part, a mysterious gift of inspiration. Actually, ''duende'' resists translation and even simple definition. Yet the power to which it refers is real and one felt it on Thursday night when Pilar Rioja and Her Company presented ''Teoria y Juego del Duende (Theory and Play of the Duende)'' at Repertorio Espanol's Gramercy Arts Theater.

title: Money Shortages Cut School Sports
description: Because Calumet High School in Calumet, Mich., was the alma mater of George Gipp, the reports written last month about varsity football being dropped at that school were filled with sentimentality.

title: Casper Shoots 68 To Tie for Lead
description: Gardner Dickinson and Billy Casper shot four-under-par 68's today to share the first-round lead in the $125,000 Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am at the Newport Country Club. Dow Finsterwald, Peter Thomson of Australia and Marty Furgol shot 69's to share third place on the 6,566-yard course.

title: RETIRED DESPERADO FROM A 'NICE' GANG RECALLS YOUNGER DAYS
description: He can't remember the name of the town in Nebraska, but Joe Newton will never forget the sounds the night he robbed his first bank 62 years ago.

title: No Decision on Bowie
description: The stress fracture in his left leg that has plagued Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch baketball center at the University of Kentucky, for more than a year has still not healed. Bowie and Coach Joe Hall said yesterday at a news conference in Lexington, Ky., that no decision had been made yet on whether Bowie would play for the Wildcats during the coming season.

title: Ring Around The River
description: The Environmental Protection Agency thinks Americans have been washing their water too clean. Accordingly, it has reinterpreted the Clean Water Act so that we don't have to scrub the water anywhere near as hard as we used to.

title: 'Styx At Six'
description: A friend visiting from London a while back, talking about how unfettered the fare on television had become, mentioned that a few days before he had been watching a sex-change operation on British television and had now been introduced to late-night explicit sex frolics on New York's cable channels.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Rabbi Is Grateful

title: OWNERS REJECT NEW OFFER
description: Negotiations between the National Football League Players Association and the N.F.L. Management Council broke off last night, with no progress reported, no future negotiations scheduled and the season still threatened by a strike that could begin as early as Tuesday.

title: ISRAEL INCREASES ITS GRIP ON BEIRUT
description: More Israeli armored forces poured into west Beirut today, increasing the Israeli grip on the predominantly Moslem sector, and Lebanese Christian militiamen entered Palestinian refugee camps in the southern suburbs to arrest guerrilla suspects.

title: 30 More PCB Protesters Arrested in Carolina
description: Thirty demonstrators were arrested today as they lay down in a roadway in attempts to stop dump trucks hauling soil contaminated with the chemical polychlorinated byphenyl, or PCB, to a state landfill.

title: Ettore DeGrazia, 73, Burned Paintings to Protest Taxes
description: Ettore De Grazia, an Arizona artist who in 1976 protested taxes by burning paintings he valued at $1.5 million, died today of cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: TEXAS LAWYER ADMITS ROLE IN PLOT TO KILL FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Joseph Chagra, an El Paso, Tex., lawyer, pleaded guilty today to helping plot the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. Details of the plea agreement were kept secret to protect Mr. Chagra.

title: Seafirst Purchase
description: The Seafirst Corporation said its directors had approved the bank holding company's purchase of the Alaska Mutual Savings Bank of Anchorage for $33.25 million.

title: BOLIVIAN AGREES TO STEP DOWN
description: President Guido Vildoso, under pressure from the nation's military commanders, agreed to resign today to clear the way for a return to civilian government.

title: Ford Widens Buyer Aid
description: Ford Tractor Operations, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, plans to expand and extend to Nov. 30 a special low-interest financing program for customers, company sources said today. They said Ford Tractor will extend 9.75 percent financing to Nov. 30 from the end of August to buyers of all its new farm tractors and industrial-wheel type tractors.

title: 16.2% DROP IN STARTS OF HOUSING
description: Housing starts fell 16.2 percent in August, to an annual rate of slightly more than one million units, the Commerce Department reported today. The drop erased much of the gain recorded in July, when the annual rate reached 1.2 million units, its highest level in more than a year.

title: Hans-Dietrich Genscher
description: Born in 1927 in the town of Reibeburg, in what is today East Germany ... A member of the Hitler Youth and later served as an artillery helper and infantryman in the army until he was captured near the war's end by American troops ... Studied law after the war in Leipzig ... Had a serious bout with tuberculosis when he was 20 years old that kept him in and out of hospitals and sanitoriums for nearly three years ... Hospitalized in recent years with heart trouble ... Married twice and has an 18-year-old daughter ... After fleeing to West Germany in 1950's, Mr. Genscher was elected to the Parliament in 1965 ... When the present Social Democrat-Free Democrat coalition was formed in 1969 he became Interior Minister. Helmut Schmidt

title: EXCESS OF LEUKEMIA DETECTED IN FALLOUT ZONES, DOCTOR SAYS
description: Medical researchers found higher than expected numbers of leukemia cases in small towns in northern Arizona and southern Utah in the 1960's but did not pursue a possible connection to fallout from atomic testing, a Federal official testified today.

title: SCAASI: GLAMOUR AT A HEADY PRICE
description: You can't put them in your washing machine; they take up a lot of room in your closet and they're not recommended for buses or small cars. Arnold Scaasi's clothes look rich and cost a lot, and a lot of women think they're worth every penny.

title: PAYING ASBESTOS DAMAGES
description: When the Manville Corporation, the nation's largest asbestos producer, decided three weeks ago to file for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, it argued that the move to shield itself from asbestos litigation was partly the fault of the Government.

title: Company Is Fined In Turnpike Spill
description: The New Jersey state police yesterday filed three motor vehicle violations against the chemical company that owns a tanker truck that ruptured and spilled nearly 5,000 gallons of hydrochloric acid on the New Jersey Turnpike in Elizabeth on Aug. 18.

title: Contamination Survey Set for Boston Harbor
description: Federal environmental officials today announced an extensive survey of Boston Harbor to check for fish contamination from 4,000 containers of low-level radioactive wastes dumped as long as 36 years ago.

title: SCHOOLS GET A HAND FROM CITY BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola British Plant
description: Motorola Inc.'s British subsidiary, Motorola Ltd., plans to build a $17.1 million plant in Hampshire to house its radio communications operations, which have outgrown existing facilities, a company statement said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The second-highest office doesn't always get the attention it deserves. Some of my friends suggest that this is how I am dealing with my mid-life crisis.'' - Carl McCall, a candidate for Lieutenant Governor of New York. (27:1.)

title: Skeptical Celtics
description: Some key members of the Boston Celtics are not ready to concede the National Basketball Association title to Philadelphia just because the 76ers have acquired Moses Malone, the league's most valuable player last season.

title: A Guilty Plea by Reese
description: Don Reese, a former defensive lineman for the Miami Dolphins, pleaded guilty today to a charge of probation violation in connection with his admitted use of cocaine, state officials said.

title: STARTING OF WORK IS LIKELY BY APRIL AT LINCOLN WEST
description: Developers of the Lincoln West luxury housing project planned for Manhattan's West Side said yesterday that construction could begin on the $1 billion complex by April. The project, which had the active support of the Koch administration, was given final approval yesterday by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: Kaiser to Close Coast Coke Plant
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it would permanently close its coke plant by the end of 1982, resulting in the layoffs of 400 employees. It had intended to close the facility by the end of next year but accelerated the schedule because of environmental and market considerations, it said.

title: MUSIC REVIEW: PIANIST'S 2-HANDED COMEBACK
description: Leon Fleisher, the two-handed pianist, is back, doing again what he once did as well as any pianist in the world. Even a soap-opera fan might have trouble swallowing the scenario.

title: Hatch Blows Off B-1 in Flight
description: A hatch on the new B-1 bomber blew off in flight just after departure from Andrews Air Force Base today, forcing the multimillion-dollar prototype to return to the base.

title: Consumer Saturday; NEW HELP IN FIXING APPLIANCES
description: THE Whirlpool Corporation and the General Electric Company are i ntroducing do-it-yourself repair manuals for washers, dryers, ovens,r efrigerators and other major appliances. The reason, they say, is t hat consumers increasingly want to avoid the expense of repairs w hen appliances falter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Bittersweet Reception

title: Bridge: A Rule Should Be Revised If the Situation Calls for It
description: A great American player, Lew Mathe of Los Angeles, used to lay down firm rules for his partners before he turned from top-level play to top-level administration. One of the rules was: ''Never make an opening lead of a trump.''

title: Energy Dept. Denies Report Of Nuclear Security Breach
description: The Department of Energy said today that a published report that mock terrorists seized a reactor control room at a Government nuclear weapons plant in a drill two years ago was untrue.

title: BISHOPS IN POLAND WARN AUTHORITIES
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Church, in its most sternly worded statement since the imposition of martial law, today called on the nation's military rulers to compromise with the Solidarity independent union, warning them that ''all sorts of crises'' threatened the nation's very existence.

title:
Patents;
A Process For Output Of Solvents
description: WASHINGTON A process for the separation of organic materials from liquids, patented this week, is regarded by its inventors as providing at low cost a step essential for the production of common chemicals and industrial solvents such as ethyl alcohol, methyl ethyl ketone and isopropanol. The process provides a substitute for distillation.

title: WORDS AND MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL OFFERS U.S. A PLAN FOR BEIRUT
description: Israel proposed to the United States today that Israeli and Lebanese Army officers meet to work out the gradual transfer of positions in west Beirut from Israeli to Lebanese control.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIAL AND 2 OTHERS SERIOUSLY HURT IN PARIS BLAST
description: A bomb exploded in the car of an Israeli Embassy official here today, seriously injuring the diplomat and two passengers.

title: PANEL TO SEEK SUCCESSOR TO MAZZOLA
description: A seven-member committee to find a successor to John Mazzola, the president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts who is resigning at the end of this year, has been appointed by Martin E. Segal, chairman of Lincoln Center.

title: LINEN SERVICE WITH NO LINK TO ORGANIZED CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Shoreham A-Plant Suffers a Delay
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant, scheduled to be loaded with fuel in November, will not be fueled before early next year, the Long Island Lighting Company said today.

title: WHITE MOTOR
description: The Clark Equipment Company said it had agreed with the White Motor Corporation to purchase the White Motor Credit Corporaiton.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: There's Always a Way

title: THE MODERATE BROTHER
description: Searching for a presidential nominee who might be a ''consensus candidate,'' the Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party has proposed 40-year-old Amin Gemayel, the brother of the slain President-elect.

title: Indians 5, Orioles 3
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Von Hayes drove in four runs with a homer and a single as Cleveland snapped Baltimore's six-game winning streak.

title: WEST GERMANY'S COALITION BROKE MUCH NEW GROUND
description: The West German coalition of the large Social Democratic Party and the much smaller Free Democratic Party lasted 13 years, the longest in the history of the German Federal Republic, providing stability and growth in a nation burdened with a dark history.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Beneficial Corp. said its Beneficial Securities Inc. subsidiary had won approval from the S.E.C. and other Government agencies to sell notes and other company securities directly to investors.

title: BRIEFING
description: Criminal Bias?

title: DOWS FALLS BY 10.86 ON NEW RATE FEARS
description: The stock market dropped sharply yesterday because of investor apprehension that interest rates may soon turn higher. At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 10.86 points, to 916.94. For the week, the blue-chip barometer rose 10.12 points.

title: A RESERVE'S MOMENT OF GLORY
description: Nearly a month has passed since it happened, since the Cardinals' third-string catcher - out of the bullpen for the first time in a month -stole home on his own in the 12th inning to win a game in the tight National League East division race.

title: VOTERS IGNORING 2d-HIGHEST POST IN STATE PRIMARY
description: It is called the second-highest office in the state. But as the candidates for Lieutenant Governor - Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, and Carl McCall, a former State Senator and member of the United States delegation to the United Nations - took their campaigns for the Democratic nomination on the road, they found that most people did not even know what the Lieutenant Governor does or that there was a primary contest.

title: JAPAN'S 'LONELY HEART'
description: Imagine an Ed McBain mystery acted by an all-Japanese cast in a Japanese setting, and you'll have some notion of Kon Ichikawa's ''Lonely Heart,'' which is at the Public Theater. The film, which was indeed based on one of Mr. McBain's novels (''Lady, Lady, I Did It!'') transposes some very American characters and situations to Japan.

title: REAGAN SUGGESTS TIGHTER CONTROL OF CENTRAL BANK
description: President Reagan today raised the question of whether the Federal Reserve Board should be placed under the authority of the Treasury Secretary.

title: Dodgers 9, Astros 2
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Pedro Guerrero and Ron Cey hit home runs and Steve Garvey drove in three runs to lead Los Angeles 3 1/2 games ahead of the second-place Atlanta Braves in the National League West.

title: FOOD FADS AND THE CLASSICS
description: Separating the classic from the dated is as tricky in relation to food and restaurants as to clothing or any other matter of style. On one hand, we may criticize a restaurant for being dated because its menu is never changed to include new and innovative dishes. In other instances, we may mourn the passing of old favorites considered classics, such as an old-style French bistro that featured only the most authentic and traditional country cooking. What makes one dated and the other a classic?

title: Police in Greece Seize The Works of de Sade
description: The Greek police confiscated thousands of books by the Marquis de Sade today after a court ruling that also resulted in a two-year prison term for one of the Greek publishers of his works.

title: TIBET FOR THE TIBETANS, NOT CHINA'S ARMS
description: In Tibet, on the roof of the world, China is building an immense military bastion with tactical missiles and intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: Pirates End Carlton's Victory Streak, 4-2
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - A fifth-inning, three-run homer by Brian Harper, a rookie, helped the Pittsburgh Pirates snap Steve Carlton's eight-game winning at home with a 4-2 victory over the Phillies.

title: Bess Truman Remains Under Care For Ulcer
description: The intestinal ulcer that has hospitalized Bess Truman for more than two weeks showed no evidence of bleeding today, Dr. Wallace Graham, her personal physician, said.

title: Value of Food Stamps To Increase on Oct. 1
description: The Agriculture Department, as directed by Congress, announced today that food stamp benefits would be raised Oct. 1 in line with the increase in the cost of food over the past 20 months.

title: SMOKE DETECTORS: THE SOUND CAN CAUSE SOME FURY
description: A popular topic of conversation at dinner parties nowadays is the smoke detectors that are mandatory in New York City apartments. This is not because the subject of smoke detectors is so riveting. Rather, it is because some smoke detectors are so effective that a steak sizzling under a broiler is enough to set off piercing wails. This causes talk at table.

title: Primary Choices for the State Legislature
description: Thursday's Democratic primary elections will determine the outcome of many races for seats in New York's Senate and Assembly, where members serve for two years. Our comments on these contests give special weight to incumbency, since seniority confers additional influence and prestige. MANHATTAN

title: COSMOS' WORKOUT A KEY TO SOCCER BOWL LINEUP
description: The Cosmos and the Seattle Sounders will play for the championship of the North American Soccer League Saturday night at Jack Murphy Stadium. Which Cosmos and which Sounders will play is still not certain, for the starting lineups will not be decided until Saturday afternoon.

title: AUTO UNION CHIEFS APPROVE CONTRACT
description: Local leaders of the United Automobile Workers narrowly approved a new contract with the Chrysler Corporation today, raising the possibility that it might be rejected by the union's rank and file.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS ATTACK BY LEFTISTS LED TO ISRAELI MOVE ON WEST BEIRUT
description: While White House and State Department officials called again today for an immediate Israeli withdrawal from west Beirut, President Reagan was saying that the Israelis moved in after they came under attack from Moslem forces.

title: THE GOLD RUSH AT BELMONT
description: New York bettors groan when they pick up the past performances to handicap a race and have to decide what to do with a California horse. Local railbirds have the same wary contempt for West Coast racing that many New York City residents have for the southern California life style. Just as provincials here like to think that the Disneyland life of beach boys and California girls is shallow and simple, the faithful at Belmont cling to the notion that when it comes time for a regional showdown on the race track, the Californians will be exposed as phonies.

title: Women's Unit Assailed On Educational Policy
description: The National Coalition for Women and Girls in Education today announced formation of a ''shadow council'' to counter what the organization called ''unprecedented attacks'' on educational equity by the Reagan Administration.

title: Toyota Prices Up
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it would raise 1983 car prices an average of 3.8 percent, or $287, over those for 1982 models. The company added that the 1983 models included upgraded equipment, such as electronic fuel injection on the Celica GT and Starlet, a new lightweight, 1.6-liter engine and rack and pinion steering on the Corolla and a digital control microcomputer for the Supra and Celica GT.

title: PAN AM PLANS TO IDLE 5,000
description: Pan American World Airways, in a drastic move to save as much as $300 million a year, announced yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 15 percent, or about 5,000 employees, in the last three months of this year.

title: Hurricane Debby Heads North After Brushing by Bermuda
description: Hurricane Debby brushed past Bermuda with 100-mile-an-hour winds Thursday, routing tourists and toppling some trees, then headed into cool Atlantic waters where it was expected to weaken.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Television -Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens. (Television - Channel 9, 5:30 P.M., first game only; Radio - WMCA, 570, WGBB, 1240, 5:30 P.M., both games) Blue Jays vs. California Angels, at Toronto. (Television - Channel 4, 1:30 P.M.) Boxing Michael Spinks vs. John Davis, 15 rounds, W.B.A. light-heavyweight championship bout, at Atlantic City. This is the fifth defense for Spinks. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Rafael (Bazooka) Limon, champion, vs. Chung-Il Choi, 15 rounds, WBC junior lightweight championship bout, at Olympic Auditorium, Los Angeles. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Antonio de la Paz vs. Ruben Solorio, at Arena Colisea, Mexico City, 10 rounds, bantamweights (Television -Channel 41, 10 P.M., live.)

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED
description: Four persons, including a mother and her two children, were killed in a predawn fire yesterday in their apartment building in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, according to fire officials, who said the blaze was arson.

title: Black Culture Grant Made
description: The Links, a black women's organization, has given the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture $10,000 for ''improvement of the quality of black life in America.'' The gift is the second the organization has made to the Schomburg. Two years ago, the Links gave the center $15,000.

title: END NONTARIFF BARRIERS
description: Most barriers to free trade are barriers that most Americans know little about. In place of tariff walls, governments are increasingly relying on a variety of obstructions, formal and informal.

title: Common Market Asks Soviet To Restore Telephone Links
description: Common Market countries, angered by cuts in Soviet long-distance telephone service, asked Moscow today to restore normal telephone links to Western Europe.

title: BAKER SETS VOTES TO END FILIBUSTER
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., today scheduled two votes for next week in an effort to break the liberal filibuster against legislation that would permit officially sanctioned prayer in public schools.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. They are faced with the possible heavy loss of deposits in October when the first certificates mature. 2.

title: THIRD PARTY HOLDS THE BALANCE IN HAMBURG POLITICS
description: Hamburg, a prosperous city of canals and broad avenues that exudes a sense of orderliness, has embarked on a somewhat disorderly political experiment that is being closely watched by the rest of the country.

title:
Patents;
Dummy Legs Test Vehicle Safety Systems
description: Dummy legs, for use in testing passenger restraint systems in vehicles, have been invented for the Ford Motor Company. Patent No. 4,349,339, obtained this week by Roger P. Daniel, a safety engineer in Dearborn, Mich., explains that each dummy leg has a knee joint connecting the simulated femur and tibia bones, and an ankle joint connecting the tibia with the simulated foot.

title: BLEAK, BLEAK POLAND
description: Not since the imposition of martial law in December have the political lines in Poland been drawn more sharply and more implacably than now, and never has the country's future looked more grim. The Solidarity movement, driven underground, is in danger of becoming increasingly extremist as its moderate leaders are undermined by the regime.

title: BAND SETS A PROVOCATIVE COURSE
description: The drum major blew his whistle, and the Princeton University Band stepped off in a cloud of Sousa, spoofery and suspicion, beginning today what promises to be another memorable year in a history as checkered as its orange and black blazers.

title: LED GARMENT UNION
description: David Dubinsky, former president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and an influential labor leader for more than three decades, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 13-YEAR COALITION COLLAPSES IN BONN AS 4 OFFICIALS QUIT
description: The coalition that has governed West Germany for the last 13 years collapsed today as the Free Democrats pulled their four ministers out of the Cabinet, and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt challenged the opposition to agree to hold new elections.

title: Internorth Layoffs
description: Internorth Inc., a diversified energy concern, said it would cut its 1,091-member corporate staff by 7 percent to 10 percent before the end of the year. Randal Blauvelt, an Internorth spokesman, cited economic conditions as the reason for the cutback. In the second quarter ended June 30, Internorth reported earnings of $22.5 million, or 50 cents a share, on revenue of $721.4 million, compared with $39.9 million, or 89 cents a share, earned on revenue of $738 million in the same period last year.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan again broached the question of whether the Federal Reserve Board might be placed under the authority of the Treasury Secretary. The President, answering questions during a New Jersey political appearance, thus revived the sensitive issue of limiting the Fed's autonomy in setting monetary policy and influencing interest rates. The Fed's independence has been sharply criticized by Administration officials in the past, but recently, with interest rates dropping, the friction had lessened. (Page 1.)

title: TEXT OF COUNCIL RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of the resolution adopted unanimously by the Security Council tonight condemning Israel's incursions into Beirut and demanding an immediate withdrawal:

title: Budget Ducking and Lame-Ducking
description: The politics of President Reagan's call for a special session of the 97th Congress are self-evident. It is yet another maneuver to embarrass the Democrats - just like the one Harry Truman used quite effectively against the ''do-nothing'' Republican Congress in 1948.

title: HOW MUCH RAW SEWAGE CAN THE HUDSON TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAN GUERRILLAS RELEASE 14 OF THEIR HOSTAGES
description: Leftist guerrillas who are holding about 100 hostages, including three top officials of the Honduran Government, tonight released 14 of their captives as the siege entered its second day. They threatened to start killing the rest if their demands were not met.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING YOUR PLANTS READY FOR FROST
description: THE shorter days and cooler nights of early autumn remind us that frost may come at almost any time. Although the average date of the first killing frost for most of the metropolitan area is a week on either side of mid-October, the long-range forecast for this year calls for colder and wetter than normal weather. Even though such forecasts are often wrong, the gardener must be prepared.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING YOUR PLANTS READY FOR FROST
description: THE shorter days and cooler nights of early autumn remind us that frost may come at almost any time. Although the average date of the first killing frost for most of the metropolitan area is a week on either side of mid-October, the long-range forecast for this year calls for colder and wetter than normal weather. Even though such forecasts are often wrong, the gardener must be prepared.

title: Sara Parton Married to James Pelgrift; They Will Live and Work in London
description: The marriage of Sara Lawson Parton, daughter of James Parton of New York and the late Jane Bourne Parton, to James DeLancey Pelgrift took place yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: FOSSEL AND OTTINGER FACE FIRST DEBATE
description: LIKE a summer vacation, shirt-sleeve campaigning has ended for Richard L. Ottinger and Jon S. Fossel. The two contestants for Representative Ottinger's Congressional seat will face each other and a college audience tomorrow in the first of 17 scheduled debates as the political season intensifies.

title: Storm Seems to Build Off Cape Verde Islands
description: A tropical depression 2,300 miles east of Florida strengthened Friday, with winds at 35 miles per hour, and hurricane forecasters said it would likely become the season's fifth named tropical storm.

title: SONS OF THE BLACK CHAMBER
description: THE PUZZLE PALACE A Report on America's Most Secret Agency. By James Bamford. 465 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $16.95.

title: 'Monsignor Quixote'
description: In recent years Graham Greene has been availing himself of the special prerogative of an old master. With many triumphs behind him, he can now turn his hand to whatever catches his fancy without feeling obliged to make a major statement or to advance his career in some striking way. The results of this freedom have ranged considerably in subject matter, tone and intensity. If none has been first-rate Greene, all have been interesting as latter-day reflections of the master's long-standing preoccupation with doom, pity and the inscrutability of God's will. In ''The Human Factor'' (1978) Greene once again stacked the deck against his protagonistvictim, a mediocre but kindly man trapped in a barbed-wire tangle of spying and betrayal. This novel was followed by ''Dr. Fischer of Geneva, or The Bomb Party'' (1980), a chilling, even repellent story of a rich man who sadistically plays God with the poor toadies who strive to please him, tormenting and humiliating them for the sport of it. And now - again shifting course - Greene presents us with ''Monsignor Quixote,'' the gentlest and most amiable of his books since ''Travels with My Aunt.''

title: A WORD TO THE WISE
description: Taking on one of the great players of yesteryear in an end game is not a prescription for success. The correct generalship is to force the aging competitor into tortures of calculation of combinations and terrifying tactics.

title: Orioles 5, Indians 2
description: BALTIMORE (UPI) - John Lowenstein and Gary Roenicke hit two-run doubles in a four-run first inning to help Scott McGregor and the Orioles to victory.

title: U.S. SUES TO KEEP L.I. AIRPORT OPEN AT NIGHT
description: The Federal Government has gone to court to overturn a new New York State law that provides for closing the Republic Airport in East Farmingdale, L.I., at night.

title: THE ECONOMY'S ILLNESS IS BEING MISDIAGNOSED
description: To the Business Editor: It is time to face the fact that the nation's economic ills have been misdiagnosed by most of the nation's policy makers. It is obvious that most economists, business people and politicians generally believe that the current recession is simply the latest in a series of unavoidable downturns. Yet prescriptions based upon this view fail to work. One is therefore forced to draw one of two conclusions: Either the suggested antidotes have inexplicably lost their previous potency, or the illness is not what the doctors think it is.

title: BY JEREMY GERARD
description: Jeremy Gerard is theater critic of The Dallas Morning News.

title: Fieldston Is Paced By Haime
description: Fieldston, which lost only one game in 15 outings the last two years, started its new season yesterday on a winning note as it routed King, 44-0, in a Fairchester Prep School League game on the loser's field in Stamford, Conn.

title: VALENTINO'S PERIPATETIC WORLD
description: High production costs force most European couture houses to operate at a loss. What supports the luxury of their made-to-order showings twice a year are licensing arrangements, perfume royalties and /or mass-produced ready-to-wear collections.

title: Megan Rosenfeld Married to Duncan C. Spencer in Capital
description: Megan Rosenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Rosenfeld of Washington, was married there yesterday to Duncan C. Spencer, son of the late Duncan and Josephine Choate Spencer of New York. The Rev. Thomas B. Keehn performed the Congregational ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Virginia Mariani, J.W. Foster Wed
description: Virginia Anne Mariani, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Mariani of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Warwick Parish, Bermuda, was married yesterday to John William Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe S. Foster of Houston. Bishop Edwin B. Broderick, executive director of Catholic Relief Services, and Msgr.

title: IRISH HOLD OFF MICHIGAN, 23-17
description: A quick, strong and totally revised Notre Dame football team opened its season with an impressive 23-17 victory over favored Michigan tonight in the first night game ever staged at Notre Dame Stadium.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Variety of Handbags, But No Seconds

title: Mark Cammann Pyle Weds Lucy S. Rhame
description: Lucy Street Rhame, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ellis Rhame Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Cammann Pyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Noble Pyle of Washington.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
DANCE MACHINE BOWING
description: THE American Dance Machine, which for the last decade has been collecting the best of American theatrical dance and presenting it as a repertory, will open a satellite training center on Long Island this week under the direction of Lee Theodore, the founder and director of the company.

title: U.S. IS STUDYING LIMIT ON INCOME UNDER MEDICARE
description: Federal officials said today that the Office of Management and Budget was studying proposals to trim the cost of the Medicare program by requiring elderly people to demonstrate financial need as a condition of receiving benefits.

title: Letters; Checking It Out
description: To the Editor:

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Mears Captures Pole
description: Rick Mears won the pole position for the Road America 200 at near-record speed. The 30-year-old Penske Team driver, who has captured six poles in 10 tries this season, took the top spot for Sunday's 200-mile race with a lap averaging 122.335 miles an hour today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BIRDS, BEASTS AND THE THIRD THING Poems by D. H. Lawrence. Selected and illustrated by Alice and Martin Provensen. Introduction by Donald Hall. Unpaged. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95. (All Ages) By SELMA G.LANES

title: Dining Out; PEKING DUCK AS IT SHOULD BE
description: STAMFORD SUDDENLY, after a long drought, Stamford is a culinary garden with new restaurants blooming almost weekly. One of the newest is the Oriental Palace, a Chinese restaurant specializing in Sichuan and Hunan dishes.

title: SCANDINAVIAN PLEASURES; WASHINGTON, D.C.
description: How it is with the other Scandinavian activities that are bursting out all over the country under the aegis of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, I cannot say. But the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, D.C., has got itself a show of Scandinavian painting between the years 1880 and 1910 that is both a pleasure to walk through and a major contribution to knowledge.

title: Q A
description: Question:We are trying to do some early planning for a January or February week in the sun. As we will travel with a 4 1/2-year old and an 18-month-old baby, our preference is for a housekeeping cottage or similar lodging with a cook or maid, in a place where there are likely to be other children. Can you advise us how to find such a place that is modestly priced? - S.G., New York, N.Y. Answer:Going beyond the relatively easy-to-reach winter sun destinations strains mightily a family's finances - as well as its patience and endurance - when the family includes babies or small children. Look for nonstop or one-connection daytime flights of a few hours' total length during which the children may fall asleep. This should be easier to handle than spending two days changing planes and laying over to reach an exotic destination. Either coast of South Florida or the Keys are reachable from New York by nonstop or one-connection flights, and fares on the New York-Miami route, in particular, are highly competitive. (Central Florida may not have enough sun or be warm enough in midwinter.)

title: Rosemary Ripley Is Married
description: The marriage of Rosemary Livingston Ripley, an associate in corporate finance at the New York investment banking house of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, to P. Baxter Lanius 3d, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, took place in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul) yesterday.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: Louise Bernikow only hints at the critical distinction between aloneness and loneliness.

title: Trial Ordered in Gross Case
description: Roger P. Buehl, 22 years old, of Pottstown, was ordered Friday to stand trial for the killings of Courtlandt S. Gross, retired chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, his wife and their housekeeper in their mansion on Philadelphia's Main Line. No trial date was set.

title: Synder Routs Lincoln, 35-6
description: Gregory Stevens ran for 94 yards and a touchdown, and Larry Rodgers completed two passes for scores to pace Snyder High to a 35-6 victory over Lincoln yesterday at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City.

title: SURVEY OF TEACHERS REVEALS MORALE PROBLEMS
description: Most public school teachers in New York State enjoy their work, think they are doing a good job and are proud of their profession, but nearly half say they would choose another field if they had it to do over again, according to a survey conducted by The New York Times.

title: John Harvey Marries Locke Wilkinson
description: Locke Tiffin Wilkinson, daughter of Mrs. Val L. Fitch of Princeton, N.J., and Robert C. Wilkinson of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married at the Princeton University Chapel yesterday to John Locke Harvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Barton Harvey Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. John Crocker Jr., rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, performed the ceremony.

title: N.F.L. to Cut Offer in Each Strike Week
description: The value of the National Football League's contract offer to the N.F.L. Players Association will be reduced for every weekend of games canceled because of a players strike, the league's chief negotiator, Jack Donlan, said yesterday.

title: FOR 2 HEALTHY PARTIES
description: Should every good Republican want a strong Democratic Party? The answer, plainly, is yes. But why? The short answer - that all of us have a stake in a strong twoparty system - only begs the question. There are three reasons why I believe that everybody should be vitally concerned about the future of the Democratic Party.

title: SPORTSGLUT
description: I've come down with a bad case of a social disease so unmentionable that medicine hasn't even given it a name. ''Sportsglut'' is what I call it. I first noticed it in early summer at a big luncheon party where everybody was standing around a television set watching two people play tennis.

title: FEAR NOT, PROSPERITY AWAITS US
description: When Herman Kahn speaks, people listen, but for different reasons. Some because they share the conservative views of the co-founder and chairman of the Hudson Institute, others because they find his predictions and futuristic postulations amusing and at times maddening. Nevertheless, Mr. Kahn, an author of four previous books, always seems to get an audience. His newest effort, ''The Coming Boom,'' published by Simon & Schuster, continues the pattern. It is a statement of his optimism about America's future, his approbation of Ronald Reagan's economic policies and expectations for sustained economic growth and prosperity.

title: STANDARDS ISSUED ON RESUSCITATION OF DYING PATIENTS
description: The Medical Society of the State of New York has issued its first guidelines for withholding emergency resuscitation from a terminally ill hospital patient whose heart or breathing fails.

title: TAPPAN VETS DO A 2D HITCH AS DEVELOPERS
description: IN the early 1950's, Paul W. Melone helped tar 32 roofs when he and 3 1 other World War II veterans built a communal development of simpler anch houses in Hickory Hill, in the hamlet of Tappan in Rockland C ounty.

title: Indonesian Volcano Erupts
description: The Soputan volcano on the Indonesian island of Celebes erupted again Friday, its third eruption in three weeks, the Meteorology and Geophysics Office said today. No casualties were reported. About 1,000 people have been evacuated since the eruptions began Aug. 26.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: Louise Bernikow's incisive and perceptive article leaves us loners with little more to say.

title: No Headline
description: SAN JOSE STATE UPSETS STANFORD BY 35-31

title: RAIL TALKS GO ON AS ENGINEERS WALK OFF JOBS
description: Negotiators for the locomotive engineers union and the railroad industry bargained intensely early today, but spokesman in the union's Cleveland headquarters said that engineers in the Easthad walked off their jobs after a midnight strike deadline.

title: THE SOCCER BOWL NOT A SUPER BOWL
description: SAN DIEGO THERE are few corporate jets lined up at the airport; there are few lines at the restaurants; there is no trace of crowds chanting team slogans in the streets.

title: Afghan Ends Moscow Talks
description: Foreign Minister Shah Mohammed Dost of Afghanistan left Moscow for home today after two days of talks on the situation in Afghanistan with Kremlin officials, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Zimbabwe Said to Ban Rallies by Nkomo Party
description: The Zimbabwe police have banned five political rallies scheduled by the Zimbabwe African Peoples' Union, an oppositon group led by Joshua Nkomo, the political group said today.

title: A BORDER TO PLANT NOW FOR FLOWERS IN MAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Iversen is assistant professor of ornamental horticulture at New York State University, Farmingdale. By RICHARD R. IVERSEN

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: I live alone, and I, too, have some problems with loneliness, so I thoroughly enjoyed the article. I particularly commend you for the cover picture, which I found most dramatic and touching. MOZELLE VANNAIS New York City

title: ARAFAT APPEALS TO 4 WORLD LEADERS FOR ASSISTANCE
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, issued appeals today to Pope John Paul II, Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Soviet Union, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to intervene immediately to stop the massacre of Palestinians in west Beirut.

title: Amos Eno Weds Marjorie T. Belli
description: Marjorie Theresa Belli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Belli of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville School yesterday to Amos Stewart Eno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Eno of Princeton, N.J., and Hulls Cove, Me. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles B. Weiser, director of the Aquinas Institute of Princeton University, assisted by the Rev. John J. Meehan, cousin of the bride.

title: Board Gives 'Lincoln West' The O.K.
description: Construction could begin by April, but long before then - and long after - the $1 billion Lincoln West luxury waterfront housing complex is likely to be an election issue.

title: Stefanie Palermo Is Bride
description: Stefanie Cecilia Palermo, daughter of John V. Palermo of Upper Grand View, N.Y., and the late Cynthia Fava Palermo, was married yesteday to Patrick Anthony Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Reynolds of Deer Park, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Gaines, a member of the international board of the International Evangelical Church and the minister of the Helping Hand Rescue Mission in Huntington Station, L.I., at Tappan Hill, a restaurant, in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: THE COMPLEXITIES OF ORDINARY LIFE
description: DANCING GIRLS And Other Stories. By Margaret Atwood. 240 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.50.

title: W.C. Oris Weds Jeanne Murphy
description: Jeanne Marie Murphy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Murphy of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday in Manhattan to William Clark Oris, son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Oris of Galion, Ohio. The Rev. James Wentz, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Tavern-on-the-Green.

title: POWWOW BETRAYS TRIBAL CULTURE
description: CROSS RIVER MORE than 4,000 spectators appeared at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation last Sunday to witness the first powwow - in modern times - to be held in the county.

title: Vindication II
description: Like a teenager pondering his face in the mirror, Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan must have wondered for a time if things would ever be cleared up. Last week, after two investigations over ten months prompted dozens of news reports and hundreds of pages of testimony, it appeared his worries were over. Special prosecutor Leon Silverman said, as he had at the end of the first investigation in June, that there was ''insufficient credible evidence'' to prosecute Mr. Donovan on accusations that he was involved in bribery schemes with organized crime figures while he was an executive of the Schiavone Construction Company of New Jersey. Mr. Donovan said he was neither pleased nor gratified, but was angry that his family and associates had to endure the public scrutiny.

title: U.N. LEADER ANNOUNCES PLAN TO STATION LEBANESE TROOPS IN CAMPS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight that Israel had told him Lebanese soldiers would move into three Palestinian refugee camps, two of them the sites of massacres, on Sunday morning.

title: Miss Sinnott, D.R. Dwight Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Sinnott of Creve Coeur, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy John Sinnott, of Washington, to Donald Rathbun Dwight, president and publisher of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune.

title: COMEDY: UNITED MIME WORKERS
description: A vacuum cleaner suddenly starts up by itself. A coffee pot begins to percolate. The telephone rings and the television set talks. An average contemporary apartment is humming with activity before a person is in sight. All this is in a wryly computerized comedy called ''Shadows Beyond the Benefit of a Doubt: Matters of Fact or Friction,'' the centerpiece of an anthology by the United Mime Workers at the Economy Tires Theater.

title: AUDIT INDICATED FIRE HAZARDS AT STATE PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS
description: A report by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said that of the four state psychiatric centers inspected for fire safety early last year - in Manhattan, Rockland County, Buffalo and Syracuse - the most serious hazards were found at the Manhattan center.

title: WHEN LEAR SPOKE YIDDISH: 100 YEARS OF JEWISH THEATER
Tests Show Astronauts A Way to Avoid Bends
description: To avoid symptoms of the bends reported in flight tests, two astronauts, Joseph P. Allen and William B. Lenoir, will breathe pure oxygen for more than three hours before they go outside their spacecraft on the next flight of the Columbia.

title: 4 City Council Panels Will Meet This Week
description: These committee meetings of the City Council have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY: Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on Environmental Protection, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. TUESDAY: Committee on Education, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 1:30 P.M.

title: Colorful Workshops In Vermont
description: Margie MacElwee Jones, who is a painter and Vermont inn owner, decided she just had to do something special for the fall foliage season.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: On page 27 of Arts and Leisure today, the photograph that illustrates the Gallery View column is incorrectly captioned. The panel screen is an untitled work by Dan Friedman.

title: LAW FIRMS MODERATING ENTRY PAY
description: When the New York City Corporation Counsel, Frederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., called upon local law firms last February to stop paying their starting lawyers so lavishly, the response ran from indifference to ridicule. Recently, the firms have begun doing just that -though more, it seems, to placate cost-conscious clients than out of concern for the commonweal.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT WITHOUT TEARS
description: I N a period of recession and high mortgage rates, many homeowners who need a change in housing decide not to buy. Instead, they stay put and renovate their own houses to suit their new requirements.

title: BONN TAKES THE TUMULT WITH A SHRUG
description: On this morning after the collapse of West Germany's coalition Government, visitors to the capital had to search for signs that something momentous had indeed happened.

title: STEEL STILL IN SAD SHAPE
description: The domestic steel industry, despite interest rate declines that have eased carrying costs for both producers and customers, is still in sorry shape.

title: Jean Gigante Has Nuptials
description: Jean Marie Gigante, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack M. Gigante of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Andris Karlis Miesnieks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Miesnieks of East Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Zanis Kristbergs, minister of the Latvian Lutheran Church of New Brunswick and Lakewood, N.J., performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Jamaica Estates. The bride is listings editor in the publicity department of WNBC-TV. Her father is a surgeon. Mr. Miesnieks is an associate corporate counsel with Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. in Red Bank, N.J. His father is a partner of Miesnieks & Stegers, a building contracting company in Edison, N.J.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR ON MAJOR ISSUES
description: EDWARD I. KOCH 57 years old. Elected Mayor in 1977 after serving four terms in the House of Representatives and one in the City Council. ((Taxes and budget)) Says that all localities in state, not just New York City, have been shortchanged, and proposes increase in state revenue-sharing. Does not rule out tax increase to finance more aid but says tax reduction should be a long-range priority as state's economy recovers. Favors increase in commuter tax for city. ((Criminal Justice)) Favors death penalty. Suggests five-year minimum mandatory sentence for crimes committed with guns. Proposes legislation that would permit use of evidence if the police acted in ''reasonable good faith'' when seizing it. Would put burden of proof of sanity or insanity on defense rather than prosecution. (( Transportation)) Favors Westway. Defends Metropolitan Transportation Authority and opposes Cuomo proposal to abolish it. (( Education) Favors revision of school aid formula to help poorer school districts. Would not restrict spending by districts that choose high local taxes. Believes such aid can be financed by existing state revenues. Supports Federal tuition tax credits for private and parochial school parents. ((Jobs and business)) Favors allowing borrowing for public works construction without approval of voters. Says there should be consolidation of economic development efforts by 40 state agencies. Favors use of public employee pension funds as ''leverage'' to encourage private investment. (( Labor) Opposes any revision of Taylor Law barring strikes by public employees. Favors provision that requires new state workers to contribute to their pension.

title: WHY COMMERCIALS WAX LOUD
description: Before the annual tide of brand-new sound gear breaks upon us in the fall and claims our attention in the coming weeks, let's clear up a few questions that have turned up in the mail. Of course, we can deal only with questions of general interest since this column can't be devoted to private consultation.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: Loneliness is the flip side of selfishness! No one would ever be lonely if he would concentrate on helping other people. It is the preoccupation with egocentric self-interests that leads to loneliness. DONALD A. WINDSOR Norwich, N.Y.

title: Cargo Ship Sinks Off England
description: The Majorca, a Dutch cargo ship, sank today in calm seas 20 miles off the southwest coast of England, Britain's coast guard said. All five crew members were rescued.

title: HEROIN FOR THE TERMINALLY ILL: UNNECCESSARY AND UNWISE
description: To the Editor:

title: N.M. MacLeod 3d Weds Elizabeth Cooke Stevens
description: Elizabeth Cooke Stevens, daughter of Mrs. George Cooke Stevens of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Stevens, was married yesterday to Norman Murray MacLeod 3d, son of the Rev. and Mrs. MacLeod Jr., of New London, Conn. Suffragan Bishop Bradford Hastings of Connecticut performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in North Guilford, Conn.

title: 29 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: New York City's Health Department cited 29 food establishments last week for violations of the Health Code. In addition, the department named three restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations.

title: HARRY GRAY IS ON THE PROWL AGAIN
description: IT began nine years ago with a sheet of ledger paper containing 30 or so names culled from a roster of the nation's 500 largest industrial companies. Harry J. Gray's hit list, as it came to be known, has been revised many times. At one point, it vanished in the theft of a car belonging to the executive in whose briefcase it was entrusted for maximum security.

title: NAYAUG: WHERE WHIMSY REIGNS
description: In any "normal" year, the citizens of Nayaug by now would have invited major public officials to their "state" functions, sponsored a candidate to run for the United States Senate and held numerous "great books club" meetings at James Kinne's house.

title: A CONTROVERSIAL ORCHESTRA
description: Glenn Plaskin is the author of ''Horowitz: A Biography,'' to be published in March by William Morrow. By GLENN PLASKIN

title: Miss Williamson Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gibbons Williamson of Williamsburg, Va., was married in New York yesterday to Edward Graydon Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Carter of Ottawa. The Rev. William Ralston performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: PUTTING BY PESTO SAUCE FOR THE LONG WINTER AHEAD
description: Summer may be officially over this week but there is still an abundance of fresh basil and ripe tomatoes on the market. We won't be seeing them for much longer however. As the season for local produce winds up, those pallid rock-hard supermarket tomatoes in cellophane-wrapped boxes are on their way back. These are useless even for pelting boring politicians becuase, as Calvin Trillin once pointed out, they are so hard you'd be arrested for murder.

title: CORRESPONDENT'S CHOICE
description: SETH S. KING is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By SETH S. KING

title: Drs. Joseph Margolick and Linda Fried To Wed
description: George Fried and Dr. Adrienne Block, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Linda P. Fried, to Dr. Joseph B. Margolick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Moses Margolick of Putnam, Conn.

title: Where is the Line On Drug Use?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: KOCH AND LEHRMAN FAVORED IN ISLAND PRIMARY VOTE
description: BASED on polls and their own estimates, Long Island politicians are predicting that Mayor Koch and Lewis E. Lehrman will win the Island's vote in Thursday's Democratic and Republican gubernatorial primaries.

title: CO-OP TRYING TO SURVIVE
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN the New Haven Food Co-op moved into the old Food Fair building on Whalley Avenue in 1971, neighborhood businesses, politicians and residents rallied behind it, hoping it would revitalize the area while providing lower-priced, high-quality groceries.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CAN BULLION BECOME A COLLECTIBLE?
description: Bullion content and numismatic value serve as twin towers in today's coin market; people who buy bullion-type gold and silver coins concern themselves primarily with the coins' intrinsic worth, while people who buy rare coins think of them instead in terms of their value as collectibles.

title: THE FILM FESTIVAL TURNS 20, MIXING OLD AND NEW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- By ANNETTE INSDORF Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is the author of the forthcoming ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: REAGAN MAKES PLEA FOR CONGRESS TO VOTE SCHOOL PRAYER LAW
description: President Reagan appealed today for legislation that would allow officially sanctioned voluntary prayer in public schools.

title: Cynthia Ruotolo Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Ryan Ruotolo, daughter of Mrs. Joseph William Vollmerhausen of Summit, N.J., and the late Dr. Andrew Keogh Ruotolo, was married yesterday to George Dyer Sherwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sherwin of Rye, N.Y., and Fayston, Vt. The Rev. Henry Schreitmueller, an associate professor of education at Seton Hall University, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the university's Immaculate Conception Chapel.

title: Thomas M. Monahan Weds Susan L. Fritz
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Susan Lynne Fritz and Thomas Michael Monahan, 1979 graduates of the University of Colorado, were married by the Rev. Martyn Minns.

title: U.S. IS HOLDING UP PEKING ATOM TALKS
description: The United States is holding up a nuclear cooperation agreement with China because of suspicions that the Chinese are giving nuclear aid to Pakistan and other nations thought to be developing nuclear weapons, according to Government and industry officials.

title: CAMERA VS. BRUSH
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Kariene and Suzanne Koury Are Brides in Westport
description: Linda Kariene Koury, daughter of Mrs. Frederick G. Koury of Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Koury, was married yesterday to Jean-Baptiste Louis Ducruet, and her younger sister, Suzanne Koury, became the bride of Johan Olof Magnus Brag. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins performed the double ceremony at the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport.

title: STONY BROOK ASKS STUDENTS TO ENFORCE RULES OF CONDUCT
description: Administrators at the State University at Stony Brook, using student staff who live in the school's dormitories, are attempting to enforce long-overlooked sections of the ''Student Conduct Code'' including prohibitions against smoking marijuana in public places, drinking by minors and parties that violate the school's curfews.

title: A SHOW OF SUCCESS
description: Not everyone can give a party in the awesome, vaulting halls and galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. To be allowed to do so, one must be a corporate patron of the museum.

title: Ultrasonic Cane
description: A new use was proposed in July 1981 for the ultrasonic range finders used in Polaroid cameras. The Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., obtained a patent to use the equipment in a warning cane for the blind.

title: DANCE TROUPES TIGHTEN BELTS
description: From the lofts along lower Broadway to the Theater of Riverside Church, the small dance companies of New York are renewing the dance. They have distilled from teachers, traditions, varied schools and backgrounds, an art of the present. They are creating rather than repeating. And yet, in an increasingly miserly climate of shrinking funds and redirected priorities, they are struggling against growing odds.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: It was a pleasure to read Louise Bernikow's fine essay on loneliness (''Alone: Yearning for Companionship in America,'' Aug. 15).

title: Letters to the Connecticut Editor
description: Supportive Programs For Hospital's Nurses

title: A COAT OF GOLD
description: Gold leaf, 23 karats in weight but thin enough to be laid on by brush, is being painstakingly applied to the facade of 730 Fifth Avenue, a stately, 25-story office building at the southwest corner of 57th Street.

title: PUTTING BY PESTO SAUCE FOR THE LONG WINTER AHEAD
description: SUMMER may be officially over this week but there is still an abundance of fresh basil and ripe tomatoes on the market. We won't be seeing them for much longer however. As the season for local produce winds up, those pallid rock-hard supermarket tomatoes in cellophane-wrapped boxes are on their way back. These are useless even for pelting boring politicians because, as Calvin Trillin once pointed out, they are so hard you'd be arrested for murder.

title: Trophies for McLain
description: Denny McLain won 31 games for the Detroit Tigers in 1968, for which he was awarded the American League's Most Valuable Player and Cy Young Awards. In 1969, he won 24 games and shared the Cy Young Award with Mike Cuellar of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: ARTISAN OVERCOMES HANDICAP, TO BOOT
description: MONTCLAIR ALTHOUGH much of Paul Mathews Wendell's work can be seen behind the footlights of Broadway, most playgoers do not notice his contributions. But the performers do - and they appreciate them.

title: No Headline
description: Renner and Adams Tied in Golf Event

title: AFTER THE PINK SLIP: 3 CASES IN POINT
description: JIM WALLACE, an unemployed steel worker living in Trenton, said that he was better off than most people who lost their jobs during the recession, but that he was tired of being a ''house husband.'' He is 37 years old and his children are 5 and 2.

title: Reagan Prodded On Minorities
description: Whatever the Reagan Administration's sensitivity to black Americans and the issues affecting them, a strong round of criticism last week apparently touched some White House nerves. The President responded by defending his record before a group of black Republicans, and the Justice Department sought to join voting rights suits in Illinois.

title: CUTBACKS HIT STATE PENSIONERS
description: FOR 77-year-old Pauline Thyfault of Newark, it is not squeezing her own tight budget a bit more that hurts but, rather, being forced to drop the payments she had been making on her son's life-insurance policy.

title: Ann Mary Candida Di Maio Engaged to John G. Hunter
description: Ann Mary Candida Di Maio, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dominick J. Di Maio of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to John Gerard Hunter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Hunter of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Francis Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: IN MEMORY OF OUR TRADITIONAL ACADEMIC CALENDAR
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY STUDIES CHARGES AGAINST CASINO UNION
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission will decide in a week or so whether to take its first restrictive action against a casino union. Robert B. Sturges, acting director of the Division of Gaming Enforcement, told the commission last Monday that the association of the president of Atlantic City's major casino-hotel union with the reputed Mafia chief for the Atlantic City-Philadelphia area ''represents one of the most imminent threats'' to the casino industry yet faced in New Jersey.

title: 'THE OLD NEIGHBORHOOD'-L.I.
description: IT was a rainy day, and we were sitting around with the Sunday papers and the morning coffee cups and nothing special to do. ''Why don't we visit the old neighborhood?''

title:
Antiques;
RE-EVALUATING AMERICAN 'FOLK ART '
description: RIDGEFIELD WHEN Judy Lenett began buying Early American paintings and decorated objects 20 years ago, she did not think of her particular field of interest as folk art. She still doesn't, although she is well-known across the country to collectors and dealers as a folk art specialist.

title: BEGIN AND TRAJAN
description: Historical analogies are notoriously tricky but they are sometimes irresistible. After a discussion of the Camp David agreement and of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's truncated autonomy scheme, a friend brought me a collection of Pliny the Younger's letters, where there is a wonderfully relevant exchange between Pliny and the Emperor Trajan.

title: Reagan Holds Congress's Feet To Another Fire
description: As lawmakers steamed, the White House turned up the heat under Congress last week. The Administration refused to cooperate on making defense spending cuts agreed to in June, and President Reagan capped that with a call for a lameduck session to deal with outstanding spending bills. Stop-gap funding - and, by implication, Congressional procedure - is ''bad economics and bad government,'' Mr. Reagan said. Bowing to the tradition of honoring such calls, the Congressional leadership - which had been steadfastly squelching the notion whenever it had been floated from within - resignedly agreed to reconvene after the November elections.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER NEW POLICY TO SUSTAIN NATIONAL GROWTH
description: House Democrats today outlined a long-term economic policy that emphasizes investment, public and private, and the co-operation of business, labor and government in a new institution to oversee the economy.

title: THE ART OF PASTEL PORTRAITURE AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: NEWARK IN ALL of its variations, pastel is a fast medium and, by comparison with oil and watercolors, easily handled. ''Small pains and great gains'' was George Vertue's snippy comment on the technique in 1741. Vertue was an art historian of sorts - supposedly England's first - and his notes form the basis of Horace Walpole's ''Anecdotes of Painting in England.'' (Walpole was a friend of Vertue's).

title: Finsterwald Leads by 2 In Newport Golf Event
description: Dow Finsterwald had six birdies and one bogey in shooting a 67 today and taking a two-shot lead in the $125,000 Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am at the Newport Country Club.

title: U.S. Says Missing G.I.  Defected to North Korea
description: The United States announced today that an American soldier missing since Aug. 28 defected to North Korea for motives that are not known.

title: Valerie Hendy Wed To Peter Marks
description: Valerie Hendy, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James C. Hendy of Lakewood, Ohio, was married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York to Peter Marks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Marks of East Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Michael Hunt performed the ceremony.

title: FANTOCCINI AND MME. OGLEPUSS
description: Imagine, if you can, an opera company in which there are no casting crises, no contract wrangles, no last-minute migraines or attacks of 24-hour flu, no backstage feuds, no cracked high notes, no outrage over bad reviews. Imagine, further, that the artists never take exception to the director's ideas, never insist on having their current spouses or sweethearts engaged to sing leading roles or conduct, never come late to rehearsal and do not even insist on wearing costumes made for them by their dear departed mothers. Consider, finally and most unbelievably, an opera company in which the performers never conspire against their colleagues, even though string-pulling and other forms of manipulation are the management's standard mode of operation.

title: UNDER MARTIAL LAW, POLISH ECONOMY SLIPS INTO REVERSE
description: ''Nagie haki'' - bare hooks - is what Poles call their butcher shops these days. The glass cabinets are usually empty and some shopkeepers simply lock their doors. When meat appears, long lines suddenly form, as if drawn by telepathy.

title: WHERE THE CLIFFS DRAW CLIMBERS
description: Connecticut is not the first place that comes to mind when rock climbing is mentioned. Its cliffs are hardly as well known as, say, the granite walls of Yosemite Valley in California. Yet the state has been a jub of climbing activity since the 20's when New Englanders, having learned to climb in the Alps, sought out hills near home to practice their skills during the off-season.

title: JAZZ ARTISTS RETURN FOR YALE PROGRAM
description: SLAM STEWART, the jazz artist, will bring his bass Thursday for a visit to its future home at Yale University. Mr. Stewart, 68 years old, has bequeathed to Yale his bass, his papers and the royalties to his song ''Flat Foot Floogie.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doctors at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif., have said that Todd Hart, a sophomore football player at Long Beach State who suffered a broken neck a week ago in a game against U.C.L.A., has a 20 percent chance of regaining the use of his arms or legs. The 19-year-old defensive back underwent surgery Thursday and remains paralyzed from the neck down. ... Billy Ray Bates, a guard for the last two seasons with the Portland Trail Blazers, has been put on waivers. He averaged 26.7 points in six playoff games, a team record, but his regular-season average in 168 games was only 12.3 points. ... Davey Moore of the Bronx will defend his World Boxing Association junior middleweight title against Gary Guiden of Muncie, Ind., Oct. 23 at Atlantic City, which will also be the site Oct. 16 of a lightweight bout between Howard Davis Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I., and Cocoa Sanchez of the Dominican Republic.

title: OHIO NUCLEAR PLANT IS ONCE AGAIN UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The nearly completed Zimmer nuclear power station, just up the Ohio River from here, has come under growing Federal and public scrutiny for evidence of substandard work, structural defects and the circumvention of Federal reporting procedures.

title: THE ROAD TO RENTING YOUR HOUSE
