description: HOUSES for rent, traditionally a scarce commodity in the New York m etropolitan area, have come into more plentiful supply with a s welling of the ranks of owners who find themselves unable to sell h omes they are vacating, usually because the high cost of mortgage m oney has drained the pool of potential buyers.

title: CLASSES RESUME AT PHOENIX HOUSE
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS TWO days before the Phoenix House/John F. Kennedy High School opened last Monday, about 40 local residents demonstrated in front of the school here to protest against the resumption of classes and to send notice to state officials that the community intends to continue its efforts to close the school.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Television - Channel 11, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2:30 P.M.) Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens. (Television - Channel, 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Phillies vs. Pittsburgh Pirates at Philadelphia. The teams are contenders for the National League East championship. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Football Jets vs. New England Patriots, at Schaefer Stadium, Foxboro, Mass. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 1 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Dallas Cowboys, at St. Louis. Cowboys (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Broncos vs. San Francisco 49ers, at Denver. Broncos have not lost two straight at home since 1975. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) New Jersey Rams vs. Brooklyn Kings, at Vince Lombardi Field, Palisades Park, N.J. 1 P.M.; Bronx Crusaders vs. New Jersey Rams at JFK high school field, West 230th Street and Terrace View Avenue, Bronx. 1:30 P.M. Mid-East Football Conference, semipro games.

title: BIT OF LOCAL ELECTION LUNACY
description: ABIENNIAL bit of lunacy is about to be unleashed on us once again. Some of the nicest suburbanites ever to uproot a dandelion or whip up a fruit compote are about to imagine themselves Jim Farleys, Mark Hannas and Murray Chotiners. Suburbanites whose only ''pull,'' ''clout,'' ''muscle'' heretofore has been the ability to get extra cheese on their pizza without being charged for it, will now fancy themselves political power brokers of the highest order.

title: LIBERAL PARTY IS DENIED CHANCE TO QUERY KOCH
description: By United Press International A Federal judge yesterday denied a request bythe Liberal Party to question Mayor Koch immediately about reports that he planned to remove party members from the state payroll if he is elected Governor.

title: DAVID DUBINSKY - A REPORTER'S MEMOIR
description: David Dubinsky, who died last week at the age of 90, made his International Ladies Garment Workers Union a symbol of probity and responsibility in organized labor. But there was at least as much boisterous imp as there was labor statesman in this refugee from Czarist jails in Poland.

title: DANCE: MARIKO KAMATA
description: Mariko Kamata gave her Wednesday night performance at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio the overall title of ''The Profound World'' and individual items on it were solemnly called ''Structural Unity,'' ''Lonely Destiny'' and ''The Eternal Life.'' But all that solemnity did not guarantee profundity.

title: John Perkins Jr., Miss Doremus, Married in Jersey
description: Josephine Doremus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ellsworth Doremus of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to John Marshall Perkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Perkins of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. David P. Hegg 2d performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: SPINKS WINS IN 9TH AND RETAINS CROWN
description: Michael Spinks matched two of Bob Foster's records today as he successfully defended his his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight crown, stopping Johnny Davis at 2 minutes 27 seconds of the ninth round.

title: Computer Sadness
description: To the Business Editor: A feeling of ineffable sadness overcame me upon reading Andrew Pollack's ''In The Classroom, Another Mr. Chips?'' (Sept. 5). My wife and I had come to the conclusion that the reverse of the scheme outlined in the article, was not only possible now, but was socially useful.

title: St. Peter's Wins, 47-6
description: Dave Shanosky, a sophomore quarterback, passed for three touchdowns and guided St. Peter's of New Brunswick to a 47-6 rout of St. Pius of Piscataway in Piscataway.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: HOW IS New Jersey spending the $380,000 it raised earlier this year to protect nongame wildlife? The answer - from the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, an arm of the state's Department of Environmental Protection - is that none of the money has been used since early spring and none will be spent until next year.

title: PITT WINNER BY 37-17
description: When the sidelines became lakes and the hot humid sky turned into a cool sheet of rain, Florida State's Seminoles ran into the one surprise for which they had not carefully planned. The elements, usually Florida State's faithful fair-weather friend, suddenly became an opponent.

title: BATTLE
description: For a brief moment this summer, when Congress presented environmentalists with a series of victories in swift succession, many of them here believed they had prevailed in their bitter running battle with the Reagan Administration.

title:
OPINION;
WHICH SIDE OF THE MIRROR
description: IN our bathroom we have one of those flip-flop mirrors on a metal extension arm. It can spin, like a good luck charm, to present its ordinary face or its magnifying face, depending on which version of your own face you want to see.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: After an absence of two weeks, Anne Tyler's ''Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant,'' one of the very few recent distinguished best-selling novels, reappears on the hard-cover fiction list. Apparently you can keep a good book down, but not always.

title: TENANT PROTECTION BILL APPROVED
description: The City Council has voted unanimously to make it a crime for landlords in New York City to harass tenants or to evict them without a duly served court order.

title: G.S.A. OUSTS 2 IN LEASE ERROR
description: Two specialists of the General Services Administration are being dismissed for missing the deadline for a renewal option on a bargain Federal lease in San Francisco, an error that could cost taxpayers $24 million.

title: FILIPINO LEADER ENDS U.S. TALKS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines concluded his official talks in Washington today with a Defense Department ceremony in which he was hailed as an old friend and compatriot in arms of the United States.

title: DEMOCRATS FACING IRONY IN NASSAU VOTE
description: TO the dismay of Democratic Party officials in Nassau County, there will be only one Democratic name on Thursday's primary ballot for county offices - the name of an enrolled Republican whom the Democrats did not endorse.

title: JAZZ: PIANO IN TIME WARP
description: Listening to Chris Anderson, the jazz pianist who is playing at Griff's Seafood Plaza, Third Avenue at 39th Street, through next Saturday is like being in a time warp. You're back on 52d Street in the late 1940's or the Five Spot in the 50's as Mr. Anderson, playing with a seemingly casual mastery, evokes Bud Powell and, occasionally, Thelonious Monk, with the added interpretive qualities of Barry Harris.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS FAVORED IN SWEDEN
description: Sweden seems prepared to end its brief, uneasy flirtation with non-Socialist government and return to the Social Democratic Party, the creator of the welfare state.

title: AN AMIABLE GRAHAM GREENE
description: MONSIGNOR QUIXOTE By Graham Greene. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING YOUR PLANTS READY FOR FROST
description: THE shorter days and cooler nights of early autumn remind us that frost may come at almost any time. Although the average date of the first killing frost for most of the metropolitan area is a week on either side of mid-October, the long-range forecast for this year calls for colder and wetter than normal weather. Even though such forecasts are often wrong, the gardener must be prepared.

title: REPERTORY IS A KEY TO THE 'NEW' MET OPERA
description: The Metropolitan Opera that opens its season tomorrow night with Kiri Te Kanawa, Tatiana Troyanos, Judith Blegen, Kurt Moll and Luciano Pavarotti in ''Der Rosenkavalier'' is, in a basic sense, the same old Metropolitan Opera it's been for one year short of a century. It is America's international opera company, the repository for the proven masterpieces of the operatic repertory and the home for the best singers it can attract.

title: BENNINGTON NURTURED THE MODERNS
description: In the history of dance, it is modern dance that has held a special place as a form of individual expression. Unlike ballet or any other classical idioms (such as India's Bharata Natyam's dances), modern dance has not identified itself with a single codified system of training or idiom. In theory, every modern dancer is free to invent his or her own language of movement. The impetus to creation in modern dance has been a breaking of old forms. Self-renewal of modern dance as a whole has implied a series of ruptures with a mentor. Continuity is not, on the surface, part of modern dance's history although in fact, modern dance has a doctrinal unity one would be hard put to find so readily in any other of the arts.

title: AN AD AGENCY BORN IN TRAGEDY
description: ON New Year's Eve 1969, Barry Boardman's wife, Ethel, died after a long struggle with cancer, leaving the senior vice president at Ted Bates with a five-year-old daughter.

title: SPAIN DETAILS POPE'S PROGRAM
description: The Roman Catholic Church today announced the program of Pope John Paul II's rescheduled visit to Spain from Oct. 31 to Nov. 9.

title: CRAFTS
description: TRENTON ''NATURE TRANSLATED INTO GLASS,'' an exhibition at the State Museum here, offers a retrospective view of more than 100 paperweights and ''botanicals'' by Paul Stankard, an artist who lives in the Gloucester County community of Mantua. In these works, the meshing of science and art brings new vitality to an antique form.

title: SCANNING THE SEAS THROUGH THE CLOUDS
description: WHEN David E. Weissman of Northport received his doctorate in electrical engineering from Stanford University in 1968, he found himself at a crossroads.

title: IT'S TWO STEPS BACK AFTER ASSASSINATION
description: SOME 440 pounds of explosives scattered the doves of peace in the Middle East last week. The blast that ended the life of President-elect Bashir Gemayel and 25 of his followers in their Christian Phalangist party headquarters in east Beirut and led to a massacre of Palestinians also echoed in the United States where officials had hoped to seize ''a moment of unprecedented opportunity'' for peace, as Secretary of State George P. Shultz put it.

title: Wendy Maddocks Fiancee Of John Carl Kriendler 2d
description: Lieut. Col. Preston T. Maddocks, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Maddocks of La Mirada, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Alyn Maddocks, to John Carl Kriendler 2d, son of Mrs. I. Robert Kriendler of New York and the late Mr. Kriendler.

title: TOXIC SHOCK
description: Nan Robertson is a reporter on The Times's Living/Style section. I went dancing the night before in a black velvet Paris gown, on one of those evenings that was the glamour of New York epitomized. I was blissfully asleep at 3 A.M.

title: A VINEYARD SAGAL ON LONG ISLAND
description: Cooking is theater," says Patricia Lenz, former chef and co-owner, with her husband, Peter, of A Movable Feast, the highly touted and successful Westhampton Beach, L.I., restaurant that the Lenzes sold five years ago. "Wine making is theater, too," she addes, "but this time we are the audience."

title: E.P.A. MISTAKE GIVES A TRADE SECRET TO RIVAL
description: The secret formula for a highly profitable agricultural herbicide apparently was given to a rival in an ''honest mistake'' by a Federal employee, a spokesman for the Monsanto Company, which makes the weedkiller, said today.

title: LOOTING OF INDIAN GRAVES WIDESPREAD IN WEST
description: Professional looters, equipped with special probes, shovels, radio, bulldozers and backhoes, work night and day at Indian burial sites in the Arizona desert.

title: HOW LOOSE MUST THE SCREW BE?
description: THE CROCODILE MAN A Case of Brain Chemistry and Criminal Violence. By Andre Mayer and Michael Wheeler. 204 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95.

title: RACE IN THE SIXTH DISTRICT IS A BATTLE OF CONTRASTS
description: NEW BRITAIN ON the night of the Sixth Congressional District primary, an enthusiastic crowd of supporters of Nancy L. Johnson, candidate for the Republican nomination, applauded each time a campaign worker entered the results from another town on the tally sheets on the wall.

title: Miss Dunn Is Married
description: Hildreth Meiere Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paxton T. Dunn of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to John M. Kupik, son of Josephine Ann Kupik of South River, N.J., and the late Gary Nicholas Kupik. The Rev. Stephen Dabkowski, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: London Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: The Murcan Way; Jack Rosenthal has done nobly in uncovering what is the basic language of this nation, ''Murcan'' (''The Murcan Way,'' On Language, Aug. 15). It seems, however, that he and his friends are not the first to discover this phenomenon. I recall that many years back James Thurber disserted upon the same language, but gave it the name Slurvian. It must have been about the time that Wendell L. Willkie accepted the Republican Party's nomination for ''Prez Nigh States'' (c.f., Lester Young).
description: I would say that the finest current native speaker is Matthew Troy, former bashaw of Queens. He and his colleagues in the tongue inevitably make a certain amount of currency (''five dollars'') sound like a scolding administered to a Texas city (''fie, Dallas''). Down there, of course, they revere the works of that great English poet, Lowered Barn. GREGORY RABASSA Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: LURE OF MONEY MANAGEMENT ACCOUNTS
description: FOR years, Wall Street has talked of offering customers a ' 'financial department store'' consisting of a variety of personal m oney management services. Now the future is here, in part because oft he growing popularity of a universal cash account.

title: LONDON THEATER: A FEMINIST FANTASY
description: Benedict Nightingale reports periodically on the London theater scene. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON

title: BALLET: CARACAS CONTEMPORARY GROUP
description: The five dancers in the Contemporary Chamber Ballet of Caracas have all danced with established dance companies here or abroad and with this thought in mind, it is understandable why they would like to be perform with a smaller, even less-known troupe.

title: ARGENTINE RESTAURANTS ORDERED TO CURB BEEF SALES
description: The Argentine Government, trying to come to grips with a worsening economy, has banned the sale of beef in restaurants two days a week and imposed price ceilings on milk and bread.

title: AROUND MAUI, SUNRISE TO SUNSET
description: R. V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. BY R.V.DENENBERG

title: Ann C. Carter and Thomas P. Palmer Are Married
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday, Ann Claire Carter, a vice president at the J. Walter Thompson Company, was married to Thomas Philip Palmer, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: GIRL'S DEATH CITED AT FALLOUT TRIAL
description: People who knew Peggy Orton all have the nicest things to say about her, especially that she was a vivacious teen-ager with a lovely singing voice and stunning red hair. When Peggy died of leukemia in 1960, her family in the small southern Utah town of Parowan was devastated, and that is why they have taken Peggy's case to Federal Court. They blame the United States Government for her death at the age of 14.

title: Italy Seeks Fugitive's Return
description: The Justice Ministry said today that it would file a formal request Monday for extradition of Licio Gelli, the central figure in a Masonic scandal that toppled the Italian Government in 1981. Mr. Gelli, who was arrested in Geneva while trying to withdraw money from a blocked bank account, is wanted on charges of espionage, bribery and extortion.

title: PUTTING BY PESTO SAUCE FOR THE LONG WINTER AHEAD
description: Summer may be officially over this week but there is still an abundance of fresh basil and ripe tomatoes on the market. We won't be seeing them for much longer however. As the season for local produce winds up, those pallid rock-hard supermarket tomatoes in cellophane-wrapped boxes are on their way back. These are useless even for pelting boring politicians becuase, as Calvin Trillin once pointed out, they are so hard you'd be arrested for murder.

title: Miss Darlington Plans Wedding
description: Mrs. Grant G. Simmons Jr. of Atlanta, Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., and Henry Darlington Jr. of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Wilde Darlington, to Glenn Yoder 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yoder Jr. of Winston Salem, N.C.

title: On Carmakers and Women
description: THE year was 1911, and Henry Ford was dabbling in the rudiments of marketing, aiming a little blue pamphlet at a totally new kind of customer. Mr. Ford's book was addressed to women, and it promised them freedom and equality, even if the suffragettes were still nine years away from victory.

title: A RACEHORSE? YOU CAN OWN ONE
description: YONKERS ANYONE can own a racehorse. Well, almost anyone. Officials of the Old Glory Sale, the oldest standard-bred horse auction fixture in America, will spotlight that theme at the Yonkers Raceway on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, when more than 200 pacers and trotters - mostly yearlings - are offered for sale.

title: THE FAR-FLUNG WARS OF MIGHTY IBM
description: IN all corners of the globe the International Business Machines Corporation is fighting battles - not with other computer companies but with nations.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Budget Blues

title: Christine B. Nicholson Is Bride of C.S. Bowie
description: The marriage of Christine Bjork Nicholson, an associate with the Washington law firm of Hale & Dorr, to Calvert Sheriff Bowie, a partner of Bowie-Gridley Architects in Washington, took place yesterday in St. John's Chapel at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.)

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE asking price for the 23-foot Glastron Carlson boat with the 460 cubic-inch 320 horsepower Ford engine, Berkeley jet pump and blue fiberglass finish is $30,000. The special features on the boat are a missile launch and the hang glider that saved Roger Moore during a ride over a waterfall in the movie ''Moonraker.''

title: NATO Tries to Reassure Portugal Over Spain
description: The commander of NATO's Atlantic forces said today that Spain's entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would not prejudice Portugal's importance in the alliance as it would be integrated into a different military command.

title: 46 NEW YORK LEGISLATORS OPPOSED IN PRIMARIES
description: As many as 20 members of New York State's Legislature could lose in this Thursday's primaries, according to Democratic and Republican legislators and party officials. In all, 46 of the 210 members of the Legislature face opponents in the major-party primaries.

title: Laura Anne Jefferys Bride of M.C. Yearley
description: Laura Anne Jefferys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Jefferys of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to M. Church Yearley, son of Mrs. J. Grosset Yearley and Dorsey Yearley, both of Baltimore. The Rev. William. W. Rich, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's family.

title: SARDINIA
description: To the Editor: It might interest your readers to know that the island of Caprera, where Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian patriot, was born, is within a half-hour's travel of Porto Cervo, mentioned in the article on Sardinia.

title: SUPERPOWERS KEEP U.N. ON A TIGHT LEASH
description: More than 60 foreign ministers and a handful of government chiefs are expected in New York, starting this week, for the opening of the General Assembly, an annual jamboree of speeches, resolutions and, sometimes, serious diplomatic business conducted in corridors and hotel suites. This 37th session comes at a nadir in United Nations history, when many delegates question whether the organization has become as sterile as the League of Nations in the 1930's.

title: Bernards Squad Favored
description: Bernards High School of Bernardsville, N.J., has fielded what looks to be one of the metropolitan area's strongest cross-country squads ever. This year's team, led by John Carlotti, winner of the high school division of the Fifth Avenue Mile earlier this month in 4 minutes 5.6 seconds, returns all but one member from the 1981 lineup that won the Eastern State championships and the New Jersey all-group meet.

title: WHY ISN'T THE PHILARMONIC BETTER?
description: John Rockwell is a music critic for The New York Times.

title: A 58-55 Victory In 6 Overtimes
description: Rhode Island and Maine played six overtime periods today before Rhode Island, by 58-55, ended what school officials thought was the longest game in modern college football history on the last play of the four-hour marathon. The score for the loser tied the Division I-AA record in the National Collegiate Athletic Conference set by Davidson in a 63-55 loss to Furman on Nov. 3, 1979.

title: TESTS INDICATE A DECLINE IN DRUG USE IN NAVY
description: Surprise checks of Navy personnel have indicated a substantial reduction in the use of marijuana among sailors and officers, the service has reported.

title: COURT DECISION ON TV HAS COLLEGES IN A QUANDARY
description: Don Canham, the University of Michigan athletic director, said yesterday: ''I will not listen to or accept a single open-market bid to televise one of our football games for all the money in the world next week or for the rest of this season. I feel morally bound to the N.C.A.A. television contract, no matter what was ruled by this judge.''

title: SMILING RESTAURATEURS
description: As the August report on retail sales made clear, consumers are in no hurry to lead the economy out of recession. However, while shoppers are still making life miserable for merchants peddling highpriced durable items, they are bringing smiles to the faces of restaurateurs across the country.

title:
LONG ISLANDER GUIDE;
WHIPPLE COLLECTION
description: When Enez Whipple retired last winter after 32 years as director of Guild Hall, the artists and collectors associated with the East Hampton cultural center decided that the best way to honor her would be by acquiring works for the museum's permanent collection in her name. Hence, the Enez Whipple Print and Drawing Collection, a group of more than 100 works donated mostly by artists of the region, which opens its premiere run today.

title: DEATH AND TURMOIL REAWAKEN LEBANON'S DESPAIR
description: BEIRUT IT is somehow Lebanon's fate that whenever the political situation appears to inch back to normal, whenever rapprochement between Moslems and Christians appears within reach, events conspire to wreck things. So it was last week in Beirut, where sadness and doom and the stench of a massacre of Palestinians shrouded the city like a gray mist.

title: TWO CHARGED IN NEW ROCHELLE POLICE OFFICER'S DEATH
description: Two men were arrested in the Bronx early yesterday and charged with robbery and felony murder in connection with a car chase last Tuesday in which a New Rochelle, N.Y., police officer was killed and another seriously injured.

title: BREWERS HAND YANKS 7TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: A stern pregame pep talk by Manager Clyde King failed to lead to a victory tonight as the Yankees lost to the first-place Brewers and extended their losing streak to seven games, the team's longest since 1975.

title: An Unfair Trade?
description: To the Business Editor: Representative George Miller and Senator Gary Hart agree in their ''Forum'' articles (Sept. 5) that assuring asbestos victims ''adequate compensation on a timely basis'' is the ''key issue'' in advocating a Federal system for payment of asbestos disease compensation. Debating the Federal Government's role in supporting such a program, however, only obscures a key question: Is trading away the right to sue worth a promise of 'fair and timely' compensation?

title: VISITING JAPAN JAPANESE STYLE
description: HENRY PELHAM BURN is writing a mystery set in Japan. BY HENRY PELHAM BURN

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: The journalistic issue of the day may well be the dangers of and reasons for loneliness. As Philip Slater said in his book ''The Pursuit of Loneliness,'' American cultural institutions are structured to make relations among people difficult at best.

title: THE DECADE THAT FAILED
description: There are moments in history -Gershom Scholem calls them "plastic hours'' - when sentiments of hope spread across the globe. People come together, talking of fraternity and betterment. Once again a journey will begin to the shores of light.

title: Nixon Library
description: Not long after Duke University had declined to become the home of Richard M. Nixon's Presidential library, the word went out that Baker was willing. The City Council of the Oregon community of 10,000 said last April it had authorized a committee to look into the matter.

title: 'From Editor's Desk' To Mark Anniversary
description: ''From the Editor's Desk,'' a weekly discussion program on WPIX-TV, will celebrate its first anniversary Oct. 3 at 10:30 P.M. Produced by the Independent Network, the syndicated series has Richard Heffner as host and features discussions among journalists and people in the news; it is carried by 44 stations.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING YOUR PLANTS READY FOR FROST
description: THE shorter days and cooler nights of early autumn remind us that frost may come at almost any time. Although the average date of the first killing frost for most of the metropolitan area is a week on either side of mid-October, the long-range forecast for this year calls for colder and wetter than normal weather. Even though such forecasts are often wrong, the gardener must be prepared.

title: TEXTS OF AMERICAN STATEMENTS ON THE KILLING OF PALESTINIANS
description: Following are the texts of a statement issued by President Reagan today on the killings in Lebanon and of an Administration statement today on a role for the United Nations in Lebanon: Statement by Reagan

title: THREATS PRECEDED AN EDITOR'S DEATH
description: The police say they are investigating the possibility that the unsolved slaying of a Vietnamese newspaper editor here last month was in retaliation for one or more of the editor's articles.

title: NEW STORES FOR PREGNANT LAWYERS?
description: A crippled economy, lower sales and fractured profits have wrought big changes in the way major retailers think about tomorrow. The buzz word is segmentation and, according to those who use it, segmentation is likely to mean changes in the way the nation's retailers select products, design their stores and peddle their goods.

title: Pamela B. Budner Becomes a Bride
description: Pamela Barbara Budner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Budner of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dudley French Blodget, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Blodget Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Annisquam, Mass. The Rev. William B. Bryant performed the ceremony at the Greens Farms (Conn.)

title: C.W. POST TOPS MERCHANT MARINE, 16-12
description: Tom Ehrhardt, a sophomore quarterback, led C.W. Post College to a pair of touchdown drives that gave the Pioneers a 16-12 come-from-behind victory over the Merchant Marine Academy yesterday afternoon at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point.

title: Figuring Odds
description: To the Sports Editor: In the Scouting column of Sept. 4, there was a story about consecutive holes-in-one defying golf odds.

title: A SINGULAR RACE PERHAPS, BUT NOT FOR MASSACHUSETTS
description: Amid the muscular rough and tumble of any given moment in Massachusetts politics, there is the continual romantic seep of history, so that the sharp smell of ringside is mingled with more nostalgic scents.

title: Jamie FitzSimmons, Brian Thorson Wed
description: Estelle James Marie FitzSimmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Moore FitzSimmons of Whitefish Bay, Wis., was married yesterday to Brian Donald Thorson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stener Thorson of Brookfield, Wis.

title:
LITERARY FOOTNOTE;
ELLMANN REJOYCING
description: Richard Ellmann's ''James Joyce'' has been called ''the best literary biography of our time,'' and since its initial publication in 1959 it has established itself as the ultimate authority on Joyce's life. Now this classic work by the American critic currently teaching at Oxford is reappearing in a new, revised edition in honor of the Joyce centenary. The Book Review asked Mr. Ellmann to describe the new material he found since the book first came out and how he uncovered it.

title: Obnoxious
description: To the Editor:

title: AUDITIONS SIGNAL WINTER PROGRAMS
description: UNLIKELY as it may sound, this is the time of year when choirs begin to plan for Christmas and other wintry singing occasions. With rehearsals beginning this month - in some cases already under way - a number of ensembles have sent out enlistment calls for new members. Prospective Pavarottis and Sutherlands are invited to try out for the Taghkanic Chorale, the Pleasantville Cantata Singers and the Westchester Chorale, among others.

title: TRIPLE THREATENED DIPLOMACY
description: All Middle East strategy for the Reagan Administration is divided into three parts: how to keep the revolutionary flames of the Iran-Iraq war from spreading, how to restore some semblance of stability to Lebanon, and how to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict over Palestinian rights in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: PICTURE BOOK ON SEX IS WITHDRAWN
description: As the result of a recent United States Supreme Court ruling upholding a New York State law that bars child pornography, St. Martin's Press has withdrawn ''Show Me!'', a picture book for children about sex that has sold almost 150,000 copies in hardcover and paperback in the last seven years.

title: Judith Norman Has Bridal
description: Judith Lynn Norman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Layne Norman of Pensacola, Fla., was married there yesterday to Kim Gordon Davis, son of Huguette Coulais Guilbault of Gautier, Miss., and Walter Brownell Davis of San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Robert Dickerson performed the ceremony in the First United Methodist Church. The bride is an assistant treasurer of Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y. Mr. Davis is a vice president of the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, an investment concern in New York.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: NEW ROCHELLE
description: ASK City Manager C. Samuel Kissinger about the character of New R ochelle and he will say it is a community that cherishes the values a nd ambiance of the American small town.

title: SOPRANO, IN THE AUDIENCE, STEPS IN FOR SICK COLLEAGUE
description: Ashley Putnam, a 29-year-old soprano who happened to be in the audience, took to the stage at Lincoln Center yesterday and, to great ovations, completed a matinee of ''La Traviata'' after the soprano singing the lead fell ill during the performance.

title: Abrasive Preview Of Brink's Trial
description: Pretrial hearings are often formalities, but last week's opening proceedings in Rockland County for six defendants in the attempted holdup of a Brink's armored truck were a raucous political foretaste of what promises to be a long and bitter trial.

title: AMERICA HAS NOTHING TO SAY TO CASTRO
description: To the Editor:

title: Marianne Chapin Married
description: Marianne Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Chapin of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Joseph Carl Addonizio Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Addonizio of Chappaqua, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church by the Revs. George P. Thompson, a Roman Catholic priest, and Richard F. Van Wely. The bride's father is president of the Linen Shops Inc. in Greenwich. Mr. Addonizio's father is chairman and professor of urology at the New York Medical College.

title: FLU VACCINATIONS ARE URGED FOR THOSE IN HIGH-RISK GROUP
description: Everyone who has a high risk of contracting influenza should be vaccinated before the flu season this year as a precaution against possible outbreaks of flu, officials at the national Centers for Disease Control say.

title: Foreign Visitors to the U.S.  Declined in First Half of Year
description: The number of foreign visitors to the United States declined by 6 percent in the first half of 1982 as an international recession and a 10 percent rise in the dollar's value against major world currencies took their toll, the Commerce Department's Travel and Tourism Administration says.

title: Amy Boone Erlanger Is the Bride of R.D. Folkman
description: Amy Boone Erlanger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Erlanger of Redding, Conn., was married there yesterday to Randall David Folkman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Folkman of Prescott, Ariz. Judge Richard L. Emerson of the Redding Probate Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE DEBATE OVER NUCLEAR TESTING: WHERE, WHY AND HOW?
description: WHEN President Reagan's decision not to press negotiations for a comprehensive ban on nuclear weapons testing became public this summer, debate about the nation's extensive test program was renewed. After nearly 30 years of modernizing the nuclear arsenal, how much is field testing worth? If it stopped tomorrow - or, short of a total ban, if the present 150 kiloton ceiling on explosive yield were lowered - what would be the practical result?

title: WHEN A MOTHER FEELS REJECTED
description: THE parking lot at the supermarket is crowded. I maneuver a space and ease the car in. A young woman, wearing the billowing dress of maternity, is piling an overload of hefty bags into the car next to mine. My smile brings an answering one. ''Should you be lifting such loads now?'' I query.

title: WITCHING TIME
description: ENTERTAINING SATAN Witchcraft and the Culture of Early New England. By John Putnam Demos. 543 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: HOUSE NAMED FOR ROLE IN SHAPING WORLD OF SCULPTURE
description: THE classically inspired building at 825 West Hartsdale Road in the town of Greenburgh has remained largely unchanged since it was erected in 1908, its interior divided into living quarters on the east end and a large studio extending from the ground floor to the skylighted roof at the west end. But in celebration of the creative genius that was vented there for nearly 80 years, both the state and Federal governments have chosen to place the property on their registers of important historic places.

title: POTTER LEADS BROWN OVER YALE, 28 to 21
description: In defeating Yale, 28-21, today for the first time in six years, the Brown team indicated it will be a formidable force in the Ivy League this season.

title: BOlivia Tries An Un-Coup
description: Bolivia's generals put the country on rewind last week. Two disastrous years after ousting Herman Siles Zuazo, the last elected civilian President, the generals broke ranks before a paralyzing strike and headed back to the barracks ''to preserve national unity.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1982
description: International Palestinians were massacred by Lebanese Christian militiamen in a refugee camp on the southern edge of west Beirut, according to witnesses and reporters who visited the camp. (Page 1, Column 6.) The President condemned the killings of Palestinians in Beirut and called again for an immediate Israeli withdrawal from west Beirut. In a separate statement, the United States joined with France and Italy in calling for United Nations observers to be sent immediately to the sites of the murders. (1:3.)

title: GREENHOUSE TURNS 100
description: The 100-year-old, 375-foot-long greenhouse at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown has no glass in its framework, no plants in its conservatory and not a palm in the Palm Court, ''but we are having a centennial birthday party for it all the same,'' said Dick Slavin, director of the former Jay Gould estate, which is part of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: AMERICA'S MOST SUBSIDIZED 'SPORT'
description: UNBEKNOWNST to the public, taxpayers continue to foot the bill for the 0.5 percent of trappers and 3 percent of hunters residing in the Garden State.

title: ROBERT VENTURI-IN LOVE WITH THE ART OF BUILDING
description: It is common to hear Robert Venturi, the senior design partner of the Philadelphia architecture firm of Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown, discussed as an admirable theorist whose theories are more persuasive than his buildings. Mr. Venturi's 1966 book, ''Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture,'' which did more than any other single work to create the current movement away from the simple austerity of modern architecture, is surely better known than any of the architect's buildings. Even his later writings, like ''Learning From Las Vegas,'' written with Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour, while less de rigueur in every architect's bookshelf, still are at least as talked-about as most of his structures.

title: The Manning Deal
description: Ladd Herzeg, the general manager of the Houston Oilers, has disclosed that the New Orleans Saints will pay half of the $600,000 annual salary of Archie Manning for the seasons of 1982, 1983 and 1984. In 1985, the final year of the quarterback's contract, the Oilers will be responsible for all of Manning's salary.

title: BIZBUZZ
description: Nobody can apply for a job these days - or interface with a personnel recruiter in the hopes of impacting on his bottom line - without a degree in ''bizbuzz,'' the jargon that prioritizes the career path of the rising young ballpark figurer.

title: AFRICA'S URBAN MIGRATION SAPS ITS AGRARIAN STRENGTH
description: The man was old and gnarled and sat before a oneroom house that was home to nephews and nieces and others. There was no water or electricity, and a nearby rock club in Kinshasa's pulsating slums, known collectively as ''La Cite,'' provided the counterpoint for his lament.

title: Timothy S. Gray Marries Barbara A. Teichgraeber
description: Barbara Ann Teichgraeber, daughter of Bernard E. Teichgraeber of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Barbara Gerhring Teichgraeber, was married yesterday to Timothy S. Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gray of Palos Verdes, Calif. The Rev. John Olofson performed the ceremony at the First Methodist Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: NEW PATRIOTS BUT SAME LINE
description: When the Jets take on the New England Patriots today at Schaefer Stadium in Foxboro, Mass., they will find new faces and changes in every part of the opponent team except in the offensive line.

title: THE GALAXY OF THREE-STARS IN PARIS
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of the International Herald Tribune in Paris. By PATRICIA WELLS

title: WILL REAGAN RUN IN '84?
description: Every once in a while when he's tired or exasperated by the endless tangles of politics at home and abroad, President Reagan mutters vaguely about going home at the end of his first term.

title: ADVENTUROUSNESS SPURS THE INDEPENDENT LABELS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: Miss Wallace Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Gardner Wallace of Fairfield, Conn., and William Noble Wallace of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol McDonald Wallace, to Frederick Wright Hamlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Huntington Hamlin of San Marino, Calif.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: No Headline
description: Boston College, Clemson Tie

title: Lively Lilliputian
description: For the executives of many of the giant paperback houses, grimly devising ways to cut their losses, these seem the worst of times. For the head of one small, young house these seem the best of times. He's Walter Zacharius, chairman of the board of Zebra Books, which this year is selling one third more copies of its publications than it did last year. His company's total sales will approach $10 million, giving it a place in the industry just below the Big 10.

title: IS THE I-78 LINK WORTH THE PRICE?
description: AREQUIEM for a reservation? Why not? We mourn our loved ones, and I have loved the Watchung Reservation as far back as I can remember, trying for 25 years to protect this Union County preserve from destruction by Interstate 78.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
UPWARD MOBILITY ON THE CHICKEN FARM
description: THE demise of the Central Jersey ''Chicken Belt'' brought with it the end of a special way of life. Growing up in the 50's amid poultry farms, then a major industry, provided a unique set of memories and opportunities.

title: CONCERT: TAPIOLA CHOIR
description: Finland's Tapiola Choir appeared in Alice Tully Hall Thursday night as part of the Scandinavia Today celebration. These young girls and boy sopranos are also instrumentalists, and there were string ensembles, flute and piano as well.

title: No Headline
description: Ohio State Routs Michigan St., 31-10

title: A.T.P. Ratings: Merit Is Crucial
description: To the Sports Editor: The A.T.P. computer rankings, criticized by K.B. Sayeed (Mailbox, The New York Times, Sept. 12), are designed to reflect performance over a 12-month period in order to provide an international system of merit for tournament entries.

title: A Little Local Color
description: If Susie Guillory Phipps is right, she's white. Mrs. Phipps contended in a New Orleans court last week that while her ancestors do indeed include a black slave, she and her siblings are white, were raised as such and should be so classified in public records.

title: COSMOS WIN SOCCER BOWL
description: The Cosmos recaptured the championship of the North American Soccer League tonight with a 1-0 Soccer Bowl victory over the Seattle Sounders on a goal by Giorgio Chinaglia in the 31st minute.

title: JoAnn M. McGurk Is Wed to Robert F.X. Feeney
description: JoAnn Marie McGurk, JoAnn Marie McGurk, daughter of Harry F. McGurk of Hempstead, L.I., and the late Frances McGurk, was married yesterday to Robert F.X. Feeney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Feeney of Jersey City. The Rev. ward Coughlin performed the ceremony in St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hempstead, L.I.

title: PRESENCE OF THE PAST
description: ''Each of us is a steward of our environment for only a brief moment in history,'' says Caroline P. Adams of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: DELAWARE TOLLS MAY GO ONE-WAY
description: CAMDEN THE Delaware River Port Authority may begin one-way toll collections on its four massive Philadelphia-area bridges over the Delaware - if it can figure out what to do about competition from a little drawbridge upstream.

title: THE NEW C.A.B. RULES AND STABILIZED HOUSING
description: IT'S a world I never made,'' said Emanuel P. Popolizio, chairman of the New York City Conciliation and Appeals Board. But the world of rental housing may be seriously affected by the board's decision last month to demand an apartment's rent history going back to 1974 to settle overcharge complaints filed by rentstabilized tenants. Any solution to the problems housing lawyers foresee may have to be legislative rather than administrative.

title: A CAREFUL SCRUTINY IS ADVISABLE
description: PURCHASING land has proven both a wise and profitable investment form any people, but probably no other aspect of real estate has a ttracted more charlatans.

title: Greek Islands
description: To the Editor: Factually armed with the article ''Greek Islands A-Z'' (Travel, June 20), my husband and I set out to explore islands of the Cyclades chain we had not as yet visited, namely, Paros, Naxos, Santorini (Thera), Milos and Siphnos.

title: Abducted Texas Boy Freed After Ransom
description: The 8-week-old son of a bank president was safe at home today after being abducted and held for $50,000 in ransom by a man who said his application for a bank loan had been turned down, the authorities said.

title: Let the Horses Do the Talking
description: To the Sports Editor: Joe Flaherty hit the nail on the head several times in his article lamenting the retirement of Conquistador Cielo and the hyperbolic assertions that nowadays seem to accompany every new star on the horizon (''When Thoroughbred Racing Lets the Money Conquer All,'' The New York Times Sept. 5). Indeed, money talks; but in a sport such as horse racing, which is so conscious of class and dignity, it would seem that some owners would have the sportsmanship to let their horses do the talking.

title: WHAT SUMMER'S BOX OFFICE BOOM AUGURS FOR MOVIES
description: Sometimes they look like art and they are manufactured as if they constituted an industry but, more than anything else, they are a gamble. The summer results are in on this country's oldest established permanent floating crap game - the movies.

title: IMPACT AND TRIUMPHANT
description: SELECTED POEMS By Galway Kinnell. 148 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.50.

title: MArcos Gets A Boost in Washington
description: Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos sent his wife and heiress apparent, Imelda, to Moscow in July to invite Soviet investment in a million-ton cement plant and other barter deals. But last week, on his first official visit to Washington in 16 years, he was talking real money. Officials pledged expanded guarantees for a $204.5 million nuclear power plant and talks to begin in April on Mr. Marcos's dreams of quadrupling the $100 million a year Americans pay to retain naval and air bases at Subic Bay and Clark Air Force Base.

title: ADVICE AND CONSENT; Certifiably Wrong
description: The official is Chilean, and his complaint is the immemorial lament of authoritarians: outside agitators, at Moscow's bidding, are trying to embarrass Gen Augusto Pinochet, the dreariest if not the bloodiest of tyrants. Why? Because they know that the Reagan Administration is still trying to decide whether to certify to Congress that Chile's human rights performance justifies resuming U.S. aid, suspended since 1977.

title: LEMHI GOLD SCORES UPSET IN MARLBORO
description: The best horses in the country stepped into the gate for the Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park yesterday, but the only one who felt like running, Lemhi Gold, was not among those expected to be close at the finish.

title: DAY-CARE CENTER CATERS TO FRAIL ELDERLY
description: SYOSSET ''I LIKE the compassion, the feeling here,'' said a recently widowed 85-year-old former teacher, Rose Karen, as she waited for lunch to be served at the long table decorated with marigolds and celery leaf centerpieces at the Syosset Senior Day Care Center.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: And now, from the man who brought you sculptures of the Ayatollah and Jimmy Carter (which were chauffeured together through Manhattan to general incredulity after the hostage crisis), we have a sculptural prediction of this year's Super Bowl XVII football teams.

title: A BOOK MAN'S BOOK OF HIMSELF
description: THE TORCH IN MY EAR By Elias Canetti. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. 372 pp. New York: Farrar Straus Giroux. $16.50.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday incorrectly described the pi- anist Paul Jacobs. He remains a member of the New York Philhar- monic.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
A LITTLE RESPECT, PLEASE
description: What top comedian today did not crack a joke professionally until he was 40? (Hint: He worked for nothing in Greenwich Village clubs during his apprenticeship and ended up with his own club uptown, but still didn't ''get no respect.'')

title: AT 60, HELEN GURLEY BROWN TALKS ABOUT LIFE AND LOVE
description: Wearing pearl-and-diamond Cartier earrings, vibrant in magenta silk skirt and hand-crocheted sweater in her rococo office on West 57th Street, Helen Gurley Brown doesn't exactly fit the profile of your average mouseburger. This is the word she began using in the 1970's, a decade after the success of her 1962 book ''Sex and the Single Girl,'' to describe a mousy young woman driven by circumstance to rely on her native wit, grit and determination to launch her from the provinces of mousedom into the orbit of men, money and might.

title: CHAPPAQUA ACTORS EXPAND 'WASH RINSE'
description: CHAPPAQUA ''WASH, Rinse, Spin Dry'' has evolved from a prize-winning one-act play - it was first seen at the Actor's Theater of Louisville, Ky. - to the full-length play presented by the Greeley Street Theater. Anyone who didn't know that might suspect that somewhere underneath a surfeit of stuffing, a potentially nice one-act play was struggling to come out. Considering the circumstances, it seems facile to suggest that the play, as it now appears, ought to be pared to halftime.

title: CITY ASSIGNS 19,409 DISABLED STUDENTS TO CLASSES
description: For the first time in six years, New York City's public schools have created enough classes to accommodate all the disabled students who have been deemed eligible for placement, school officials said.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: It was, at a minimum, an improbable theft that the First National Bank of Chicago discovered on Oct. 11, 1977. And, as a bank spokesman noted, a tidy theft it was, too: $1 million, ''not $1 less, not $1 more,'' whisked out of the vault, with no sign of forcible entry.

title: Miss Fraser A Newlywed
description: At St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., yesterday Deborah Small Fraser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gordon Fraser Jr. of Warwick Neck, R.I., and Chatham, was married to Warren Hathaway Simmons 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simmons Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Chatham. The Rev. Whitney Burr performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
POTPOURRI REFLECTS DIVERSITY
description: ROSLYN HARBOR ALL organizations receiving public funds are, or should be, conscious of defining their commitment to the immediate audience. Thus there is a strong case to be made in favor of the annual showcase presentation of regional artists organized by the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts.

title: DIVERSITY IS THE KEY TO THE FALL SEASON
description: THE scope and diversity of quality programming in Connecticut this season should not be underestimated. Mike Sharpe, vice president of the Waveny Chamber Music Society, a new group in New Canaan named for the site of its inaugural four-concert series, the Waveny Carriage Barn, writes, for example, that ''the acoustics in the hall are outstanding, and the Tremont String Quartet will be our resident ensemble this first year. This is an excellent young faculty quartet at the State University of New York at Geneseo, and in addition to the performances, the players will offer open rehearsals to students and charter members of the society.''

title: Man Gives Up to F.B.I.  In 3d Hostage Episode
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation traded food and cigarettes for three bank workers in a 13-hour standoff that ended with the surrender of an armed former mental patient who had taken hostages twice before, officials said.

title: SCREENPLAYS ARE SKIMPY FUEL FOR THEATER
description: It is quite conceivable that a dreadful little piece called ''Inserts,'' which opened to a hush at the Actors and Directors Theater on 42d Street not long ago, may prove to be an important historical step in Broadway's long development, though I can't say I want it to. Before going into such weighty and rather panoramic matters, however, let us consider and then dismiss from our minds a few surface peculiarities that belong to this play, and this production, alone.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: Louise Bernikow's article makes many points that I can relate to, personally and professionally. As a therapist, people consult me for a variety of ills, but many fail to realize that loneliness is their real affliction.

title: PRODUCTION OF SMALL PLANES OFF
description: Slumping capital expenditures, high interest rates and the recession have been bad news for many manufacturers, and the general aviation industry is no exception. For the third consecutive year, private and corporate demand for airplanes is falling sharply.

title: INDIAN BONES GO BACK ON VIEW
description: ON a spring day in 1961, George C. Reeve's plow turned up a human skull on his farm in Aquebogue, a few miles east of Riverhead. Soon his two sons, George Jr. 12, and Bradford, 10, began digging and found more bones.

title: Former Congressman Concedes in Maryland
description: Former Representative Robert E. Bauman announced Friday that he would not challenge the results of the Republican primary in Maryland's First Congressional District despite voting machine problems in one county.

title:
CAMERA;
WHAT TO DO WITH ALL THOSE VACATION PHOTOS
JETER OUT 3-5 WEEKS WITH KNEE INJURY
description: Adding injury to injury, the Giants learned today that Gary Jeter, their defensive right end, would miss the Monday night game against the Green Bay Packers. If the strike-threatened National Football League season continues after Monday night, he will miss at least two more games.

title: Robin Ann Louis Plans to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Louis of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Robin Ann Louis, to Peter Henning Sayre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin B. Sayre also of Westfield.

title: WHO IS HUMAN, WHO IS NOT?
description: MEMOIRS OF A SPACE TRAVELER Further Reminiscences of Ijon Tichy. By Stanislaw Lem. Translated by Joel Stern and Maria Swiecicka-Ziemianek. 156 pp. San Diego: Helen and Kurt Wolff/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95. MORE TALES OF PIRX THE PILOT By Stanislaw Lem. Translated by Louis Iribarne With the Assistance of Magdalena Majcherczyk and by Michael Kandel. 220 pp. San Diego: Helen and Kurt Wolff/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $11.95.

title: Louise C. Nelson Married to Paul B. Dysenchuk
description: Louise Carvajal Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Nelson of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday in Westport, Conn., to Paul Bruce Dysenchuk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dysenchuk of Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Driscoll performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church.

title: STEEL UNION FACES CONVENTION ISSUES
description: The United Steelworkers of America, which opens its 21st convention tomorrow in Atlantic City, is again facing difficult times, as it often has in the past.

title: U.S. SAYS THE TOLL IS AT LEAST 300
description: Lebanese Christian militiamen massacred scores of Palestinian men, women and children in a refugee camp on the southern edge of west Beirut Friday night, according to witnesses and reporters who visited the camp.

title: NL INDUSTRIES SHUTS ITS SAYREVILLE PLANT
description: SAYREVILLE ECONOMIC ills have brought about what environmentalists tried in vain to do: end NL Industries' dumping of chemical wastes 15 miles off the New Jersey coast.

title: FOR THE WOMAN WHO HAS EVERYTHING
description: FAMILY HAPPINESS By Laurie Colwin. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: FOR REV. CARMINES, CHURCH IN THEATER
description: For several months after ending 20 years of ministry at the Judson Memorial Church, the Rev. Al Carmines, a clergyman widely praised for his zesty topical plays and musicals, lived a ''totally secular life,'' he says. He continued to perform at nightclubs and compose at his piano in his Manhattan Plaza apartment, but he soon felt something was missing.

title: Wife of Violin Finder Gets Reward He Missed
description: The wife of a steamship employee who found a stolen $250,000 Stradivarius has been rewarded by insurance underwriters because she - not her husband - recognized its value and alerted the authorities.

title: CHINESE DELICACIES BY THE LAKESIDE
description: TUNG TING, a new Chinese restaurant in Centerport, has been named for Lake Tung Ting in the province of Hunan. The attractive lakeside setting was the inspiration. Lunch is served in the bar, where tables take advantage of the view. Windows in the main dining room overlook the parking lot.

title: FOR THE PRINCESS'S FAMILY, THE PARTING IS FORLORN
description: Princess Grace of Monaco was brought back by her family today to the cathedral where she was married and her children were baptized.

title: Lauren Breakiron Becomes a Bride
description: Lauren Kristen Breakiron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lauren Paul Breakiron of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Paul Richard Gudonis, son of Paul P. Gudonis of Chicago, and the late Edith A. Gudonis. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph and the Rev. Rebecca L. Spencer performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church.

title: TIMES SQ. REVIVAL
description: It stands at what once was regarded as the Crossroads of the World - the foot of Times Square - but it won't be standing much longer. Demolition contracts are being let to raze the Crossroads Building, a city-owned property that now houses a police booth and a visitors' information center.

title: Elizabeth Kiloran Howard Bride of Philippe de Laperouse
description: Elizabeth Kiloran Howard, daughter of Barnaby John Howard of Bedford, N.Y., and Englishtown, Nova Scotia, and Elizabeth Mayfield Howard of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Philippe de Laperouse, son of Count and Countess de Laperouse of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Werner Papeians de Morchoven, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunziata in St. Louis.

title: GOLF'S HUMAN TRANQUILIZER
description: bargaining crisis threatens its season. College football's TV policy is in turmoil. Pro basketball's paymasters wonder if they can afford another $13 million man. But anyone who needs an antidote, if not a tranquilizer, for such intrusions on their psyche, the golfer Julius Boros is on display here, a serene symbol of another era when sports were sports instead of labor, law and finance.

title: GUNMEN RAID BELGIAN TEMPLE
description: A man fired a submachine gun into a crowd outside a synagogue here today, wounding four people.

title: INEQUITIES IN FINANCING HOBBLE SCHOOLS
description: HAVING now read and re-read the New York Court of Appeals decision on Levittown, hoping to make some sense out of it, I am constrained to admit that there is no sense to it. This recent decision by the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, that the present system of financing public schools in our state is not unconstitutional, is an abomination of illogicalities and irrelevancies; it does great damage to many children and many property taxpayers in this state by postponing, perhaps permanently, the achievement of a fair distribution of state aid to education.

title: Balanced Budget
description: To the Business Editor: William Nordhaus, in his ''How Not to Balance the Federal Budget'' (Sept. 5), claimed that economic theory should not be embedded in the Constitution. He thus ignores the numerous economic clauses of the Constitution as outlined in Article I, sections eight and 10, and the 16th Amendment, which gives Congress the power to manipulate the economy through taxing and spending.

title: A CHURCH RESTORES 6 TIFFANY WINDOWS
description: IN 1911, two years after the magnificent ''Elliot'' window was installed by Louis Comfort Tiffany in the First Church Congregational in Fairfield, a controversy began: Many in the congregation thought the window too bright.

title: AMID JOB GAINS, NEW YORK CITY FEELS THE RECESSION
description: New York City and a number of outlying communities in the metropolitan area, such as Stamford, Conn., on the east and Morristown, N.J., on the west, are experiencing substantial employment growth, largely because of the expansion of service-dominated industries like securities, business services, banking and law.

title: 'THE PLANE'S ON FIRE! GET OUT!'
description: LAST Monday, Cathy Tombari, a 23-year-old secretary from Yorktown Heights, lived through the most traumatic day of her life. ''We were going down the runway, full speed, then all of a sudden the whole plane was totally vibrating, the ceiling was shaking and some of the panels were falling on the floor,'' Miss Tombari recalled. ''That's when everyone realized something was wrong. And I remember looking out and saying, 'What the heck is going on here?' ''

title: THE YANKEES: ANATOMY OF A TEAM'S DECLINE
description: ON the day after the sixth and final game of the 1981 World Series, G eorge Steinbrenner sat at the large round table in his Yankee S tadium office and said, ''We've studied it pretty darn carefully, a nd I think we know where we have to go.''

title: Man, 23, Gets 6 Months In Subway Graffiti Case
description: A Bronx man has been sentenced to six months in jail for writing graffiti on the window of a subway car. The sentence was imposed on 23-year-old Raymond Newton last week by Judge Robert Cohen of Bronx Criminal Court. Mr. Newton had pleaded guilty to a charge of malicious mischief on Aug. 2, the day he was arrested by the transit police.

title: The Technique Used In Conducting Survey
description: The New York Times survey of teachers is based on a mail survey conducted from May 12 through June 10 with 5,702 teachers throughout New York State.

title: COUNTY ASKS U.S. TO WAIVE MAMARONECK SEWER SITE
description: COUNTY officials are proceeding with plans to increase the Mamaroneck Sewage Treatment Plant's capability to remove biological material from waste, before discharging it into the Long Island Sound, but they expect that the changes, which could cost as much as $90 million, may never have to be made.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
OLD-FASHIONED FLAVOR AT THE YORKTOWN GRANGE FAIR
description: NINE years ago, Chester Hyatt, a farmer who lived in Yorktown, gathered a few of his colleagues for a harvest supper. Bring some potatoes, he advised them, suggesting that it might be interesting to compare the size and succulence of everyone's crop.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
WHY THE FOOTBALL UNION CAN BE HIT HARD
description: THE athletes employed by the National Football League, who average $ 95,000 a year, think they are underpaid. They are demanding a 50 p ercent share of the teams' television revenues, which would give t hem a substantial increase in pay. They are threatening a strike on T uesday and have adopted the thought-provoking slogan, ''The players a re the game.'' The indications seem to be that the players will s ucceed in getting large raises, even if they do not get all they area sking for.

title:
STAMPS;
HISTORY DOMINATES THE NEW EUROPA ISSUES
description: This year's ''Europa '' stamps have been devoted to the common theme of historical events, and have produced a wide diversity of issues reflecting the rich and varied past of European nations.

title: AGE AND ARITHMETIC OVERTAKE BONN'S COALTION
description: BONN FOR some who have watched Helmut Schmidt since his re-election in 1980, it was as if he had regained his old strength and combativeness just as he was being brought down. After two years of seemingly reacting to events rather than shaping them, at home and abroad, the 63-year-old Chancellor last week stole the initiative from his shipjumping Free Democratic coalition partners and Christian Democratic foes and, in a ringing speech to the Bundestag, dared them to match their popularity against his in new elections.

title: UTRECHT TRIUMPHES
description: New Utrecht of Brooklyn, which had not won an opening game since 1975, visited Staten Island yesterday and returned home with a 25-14 victory over Curtis in a nonleague Public Schools Athletic League contest. It was a happy debut for John Burke as head coach of the Utes.

title: REAGAN'S ARMS PLAN FOR JORDAN NEARLY READY
description: The Reagan Administration has nearly completed work on a proposal for the sale of advanced missiles and fighter planes to Jordan, a nation regarded as vital to the success of President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative, according to Administration officials.

title: BRITISH MARINE ART AT MYSTIC SEAPORT
description: MYSTIC JUST about every museum has a shop of some kind. It can be a few racks of postcards in a lobby or something close to a department store, as at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: IMMIGRATION AGENCY'S MOVE OPPOSED
description: Waiting in line on the street for up to 18 hours to deal with the Immigration and Naturalization Service often makes people unpleasant. Were it not for the line, which often begins to form by midnight, a proposal to move the Federal agency's office out of downtown might set off fewer howls.

title: Building-Blocks Of Corruption
description: With corruption affecting the ultimate cost of virtually every building, tunnel and road built in New York, the State Commission of Investigation could be excused for wondering where to begin its inquiry into the construction industry. For starters, extortion, rigged bids, payoffs and organized crime influence were on its list of allegations as it opened hearings last week.

title: Rules Under Study On Search, Rescue
description: The United States Coast Guard is reviewing its policy regarding search and rescue, a step which could result in giving commercial towing operators greater scope in handling rescues at sea.

title: 1,500 TO TEST AIR IN WASHINGTON AND DENVER
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has disclosed plans to have 1,500 people carry portable pollutionsniffing devices to help researchers determine the healthfulness of the air in urban areas.

title: Indians Sue to Evict Whites
description: Citing 1939 tribal rules barring whites from remaining more than 24 hours, officials of the tiny native village of Tyonek have filed suit to evict two white families.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: IS SHERRILL'S SALARY OUT OF LINE? HISTORY SAYS NO
description: THERE'S no doubt that it was a tough start for Jackie Sherrill. His Texas A & M football team -which he is paid approximately $1.6 million over a six-year period to coach - lost its opener, 38-16, to Boston College.

title: A TALK WITH PAUL VOLCKER
description: We are hardly out of the economic woods. But last June, when Paul A. Volcker sat for the first extended on-the-record interview since he became chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, things were worse.

title: Lynn Updegrave Wed
description: Lynn Dianne Updegrave, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Charles Updegrave of Reading, Pa., was married yesterday to George Brayton Larned Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Dana Gibson of Washington, Conn. The Rev. George Spieker performed the ceremony at the Schwarzwald Lutheran Church in Jacksonwald, Pa.

title: JUNIOR KNOWS BEST: TV'S VIEW OF CHILDREN TODAY
description: Edward Stratton 3d is 35, wealthy, dim-witted, naive and hopelessly immature. He spends his days playing video games in his private arcade and riding around his mansion atop an oversized toy train. Ricky, his 12-year-old son, is a bright and sophisticated computer whiz, as responsible as dad is feckless. When Ricky tries to engage his father in a serious discussion, Edward flops to his knees to demonstrate his favorite game, Swamp Wars. Asked by Ricky if the computer controlling their household gadgets has a ''random access memory,'' Edward is the picture of slack-jawed bewilderment.

title: BELIZE
description: Donald E. Westlake is at work on a novel about Belize.While the debate over the Falkland Islands crisis raged in the British Parliament last spring, the discussion broadened to include a similar -and potentially more dangerous -dispute. In Central America, Belize, formerly British Honduras, is claimed in toto by Guatemala, a country just as militaristic as Argentina, but less stable. ''Now more than ever,'' said a Conservative member of Parliament in the debate, ''the threat to Belize from Guatemala should be taken fully into consideration.'' But, despite repeated warnings from both Conservative and Labor M.P.'s about withdrawing British forces now protecting Belize, the Government would not guarantee a military presence as permanent as the Guatemalan threat.

title: Connecticut Guide; ANTONIONI AT 70
description: Michaelangelo Antonioni, the noted film director who celebrates his 70th birthday Sept. 29, will be the speaker Oct. 1 at the final session of a six-week Antonioni film festival-seminar at Fairfield University's School of Graduate and Continuing Education.

title: EAST FARMINGDALE
description: SOME Agatha Christie mysteries are worse than others, but ''Go Back for Murder,'' which is trudging along at the Arena Players Repertory Theater through Oct. 3, might well belong at the bottom of the bushel.

title: NATO SEEKS TO MATCH SOVIET CONVENTIONAL FORCES
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, commander in chief of North Atlantic forces in Europe, says he believes the alliance could deter a Soviet attack without threatening the use of nuclear weapons if its West European members were to meet conventional force goals projected for the period from 1983 to 1988.

title:
WHO IS THIS GOD IN NEED OF HELP FROM POLITICIANS?;
We cannot know what God is. We can only know what God is not.  - MAIMONIDES
description: WHAT sort of God is this that the Jesse Helmses and Jerry Falwells want to ram down the throats of America's schoolchildren? What sort of superficial, diluted worship will it settle for? Why?

title: STATE JOINS DRIVE FOR L.I. BAY SCALLOPS
description: THERE are approximately 400 varieties of scallops in the waters of the world, but Americans generally recognize only two: large sea scallops and the smaller ones that are generally, but not always accurately, called bay scallops. Now, the four baymen's associations that represent the Long Island bay scallop industry in eastern Suffolk, in cooperation with the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, are starting a campaign to promote the distinction between bay scallops harvested in local waters and other small scallops that may or may not be true bay scallops.

title: PROGRESS BLOCKS THE SUN
description: estate people and land developers are grabbing my town's lands. I have lived in a Fairfield County town for the last 22 years. Instead of empty spaces along U.S. Route 1, and in place of a few roadside farms, there are shopping complexes and office buildings. More traffic than the town can handle now will occur once the offices are occupied.

title: IN THE CELLARS
description: based correspondent, is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. By FRANK J. PRIAL

title: A PHILOSOPHIC LOOK AT MAPS OLD AND NEW
description: ADAM NICOLSON is the author of ''The National Trust Book of Long Walks in England, Scotland and Wales.'' By ADAM NICOLSON

title: Pretoria's New Nightstick
description: South Africa continues to embarrass foreign apologists who argue that a race-obsessed society will heal itself - if only outsiders would stop carping. It has certainly been the Reagan Administration's sanguine hope that a solicitous ''constructive engagement'' would succeed where public censure failed. But in no vital respect does Pretoria show a willingness to moderate the cruel racial laws that mark South Africa as a place apart. And incredibly, those laws may soon be made worse.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO THE SUPERFUND?
description: WASHINGTON AT THE request of Representative James J.Florio, Democrat of Runnemede and one of the authors of a bill authorizing a toxic-waste cleanup ''superfund,'' the General Accounting Office has begun investigatng why, two years after the measure was passed, there is still no superfund agency.

title: BALLET: EMPIRE THEATER, BARBARA STRIEGEL WORKS
description: Although classically trained dancers often conceal their efforts to achieve effects of lightness, the nine members of the Empire State Ballet Theater really slogged their way through a Tuesday night program in the Symphony Space that included five works by Barbara Striegel, their artistic director, and one by Harry Ferris, their executive director. Unfortunately, it soon became clear that the unrelieved doggedness of this company from Buffalo resulted from pedestrian imagination rather than from any attempt to treat traditional balletic dynamics in an unconventional manner.

title: PHYSICS SOMETIMES TAKES G.U.T.s
description: IF physicists could prove that the proton, a subatomic particle, decays into smaller particles, they could better understand the origin of the universe and would move one step nearer that pot of gold at the end of the cosmic rainbow - a ''grand unification theory'' that explains all natural phenomena, except perhaps gravity. The trick is catching a proton in the act of decaying, for on average it may live more than 1,000 billion billion billion years.

title: Mansion Contest
description: When Jane Pieriboni offered her 20-room Victorian mansion in Dover-Foxcroft, Me., as a prize in an essay contest last March, she hoped to raise $50,000 through the $50 entry fees. By July 18, however, barely 300 people had entered the contest, which called for a 125-word essay on ''Why I want to win a big old house in Maine.''

title: An 'Evacuation Drill' Needed for Survival
description: Lilco has invested billions of dollars; the Federal Government offers Long Islanders millions more for civil defense. The Shoreham nuclear facility already has provided and ''on line'' will provide many local jobs.

title: On the Bowery
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertisements
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE FINDS ABUSE OF ELDERLY BY KIN
description: AN increasing number of elderly people in Connecticut are being abused in their own homes by relatives, according to a report about to be released by the state's Department on Aging.

title: CITY OPERA: RAMEY SINGS IN 'L'AMORE DEI TRE RE'
description: Montemezzi's ''L'Amore dei Tre Re'' returned to the New York City Opera on Friday evening with all its graceful melodic writing and careful craftsmanship. The continuous melody, the eschewal of set pieces and the straining chromaticism in Act III -all show the hand of Wagner, but Montemezzi's Italianate ear for orchestration and his more open, less ponderous spirit have lightened this touch considerably.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE COLONY: ON COURSE FOR 22 YEARS
description: THE one-star rating is perhaps the most versatile symbol reviewers using this rating system encounter. For some reason, it has a range broader than other star clusters, and it signals that ''good'' food might be had at a certain restaurant - good food, that is, on balance. Few restaurant kitchens produce dishes that fall neatly into a given category. More often, a rating is the result of troublesome consideration, averaging exceptionally good and exceptionally poor with whatever abilities seem to represent the kitchen's penchant. It is pleasant to report then, that The Colony in Larchmont continues to serve unpretentious, dependable dishes of the kind and quality it served at its inception about 22 years ago.

title: Article 161736 -- No Title
description: A $40,000 reward has been posted for information leading to the recovery of 25 Mayan jade artifacts stolen two weeks ago from the American Museum of Natural History, a representative of Lloyd's, the underwriter, has announced.

title: Accounts Unreceivable
description: Italian authorities apparently figured that the lure of a lot of cash might tempt Liceo Gelli to show his face in Europe, where they could get their hands on him. Last week, in any case, it did, he did and they did. Mr. Gelli, a key figure in a Masonic lodge scandal that toppled an Italian Government last year, was arrested in Switzerland as he tried to withdraw ''tens of millions of dollars'' from a blocked bank account. The funds had been transferred from a South American branch of Italy's Banco Ambrosiano, which collapsed in scandal this year. Mr. Gelli, who was believed to have fled to South America, headed a secret Masonic lodge whose many prominent members included government officials and Abrosiano president Roberto Calvi, who was found hanging from a London bridge in June.

title: REPAIRING A TUB OR SHOWER FAUCET THAT LEAKS
description: REPAIRING a shower or bathtub faucet that leaks or drips is really not much different from repairing a sink faucet - although most tub and shower faucets are horizontal instead of vertical because they stick out of the wall instead of coming up through a counter or sink top.

title: BENDIX WINS A ROUND IN ITS MARIETTA BID
description: Bendix was permitted by a Federal appeals court to proceed with its offer to buy 51 percent of Martin Marietta and said Friday that it had purchased enough stock to take control of Marietta. Earlier, Marietta said that even if Bendix succeeded in its bid, Marietta would continue with its own offer for Bendix. United Technologies, meanwhile, raised its offer for Bendix to $85 a share from $75, if Bendix would agree to a merger on friendly terms. Bendix rejected it as inadequate.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: OLD GLORY: An American Voyage. By Jonathan Raban. (Penguin, $6.95.) Inspired by Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn, the British journalist Jonathan Raban traveled down the Mississippi from Minneapolis to Louisiana's bayou country in a 16-foot motor-boat. This account of his experience, alone on the river by day, chatting with local characters at night, impressed our reviewer Noel Perrin as ''more successful than 99 percent of the books about this land since de Tocqueville's 'Democracy in America.' ''

title: ADOLESENCE MARS THE WHO'S NEW DISK
description: In recent interviews, the Who's guitarist and chief songwriter, Pete Townshend, has been hinting that the current Who tour may be their last. Those hints have helped to sell out the Who's final United States shows on Oct. 12 and 13 at Shea Stadium, and they have drawn attention to the Who's new album, ''It's Hard.'' Whether or not this is actually a farewell tour, saying so is a sound commercial gambit; but the hints may also signal real exhaustion for a band that has been working since the mid-1960's. And no one takes the idea more seriously than Mr. Townshend himself.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: four previously published reviews, articles and essays. FAMILY INSTALLMENTS, by Edward Rivera.

title: PUTTING BY PESTO SAUCE FOR THE LONG WINTER AHEAD
