description: SUMMER may be officially over this week but there is still an abundance of fresh basil and ripe tomatoes on the market. We won't be seeing them for much longer however. As the season for local produce winds up, those pallid rock-hard supermarket tomatoes in cellophanewrapped boxes are on their way back. These are useless even for pelting boring politicians because, as Calvin Trillin once pointed out, they are so hard you'd be arrested for murder.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: I was rather baffled by the article on loneliness. The article focuses on America's yearning for companionship in a society which values, above all, ''personal freedom, autonomy and independence.''

title: FROM TRASH TO M*A*S*H
description: Pity the situation comedy. It may be popular, just about monopolizing the Top 10 ratings positions year after year, but it is also scorned. When a movie reviewer or theater critic aspires to the heights of damnation, we are likely to read that the production under consideration had the depth and complexity of a sit-com. That, dear friends, is about as withering as your average analyst can get nowadays.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COOPERSTOWN
description: HAROLD FABER contributes to The Times from upstate New York. BY HAROLD FABER

title: Labor Maverick: Ray Rogers; AN ORGANIZER BESET BY PROBLEMS
description: AMONTH ago, labor activist Ray Rogers was preparing to announce new, bold actions to help 1,600 m embers of the International Association of Machinists in a bitter s trike against the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, a major m achine tool maker based in North Kingstown, R.I.

title: Primary Choices for Governor
description: Our most difficult choice on New York's primary ballots next Thursday concerns Ed Koch, for a paradoxical reason: he's been a good mayor.

title: APPLE GROWERS EXPECT LARGE CROP
description: HE had been up since 4:30 that morning helping sort and grade the season's first apples at his family's 115-acre orchard. Now Tom March sat on an upturned apple crate under a canopy at the nearby Bethlehem Fair, his sunburned face perspiring in the unseasonable September heat, and watched fairgoers examine the bags of McIntosh apples neatly arranged on a long table in front of him.

title: THE RISING STAR OF CHRIS DODD
description: WASHINGTON EVEN when he is not running for office, Christopher J. Dodd seems unable to quit the campaign trail. Connecticut's Democratic candidates, eager to be seen with the United States Senator, could not be more delighted.

title: JOB MARKET RESHAPED BY FUTURE SHOCK
description: WITH unemployment in New Jersey reaching 9.2 percent last month and the effects of declining interest rates and a sizzling stock market still over the horizon, economists say that there will never be a return to familiar patterns of past decades and that a new economy - its future rooted in high technology - is taking shape.shape.

title: Struck Jersey Bus Line Resumes Its Operations
description: DeCamp buses were on the road again today for the first time since a 46-day strike by drivers, cleaners and mechanics halted the operations of the state's oldest bus company.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS IN SUMMARY;
description: Old soldiers are surest, and none more so at the moment than Gen. William C. Westmoreland. The former commander of American forces in Vietnam filed a $120 million libel suit last week against CBS Inc., charging that the television network had damaged his reputation in a documentary called ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception.''

title: Avebury
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Political crisis leaves Bonn un- ruffled 3 NATO commander looks to matching Soviet forces by 1989 4 Around the World 5 Canadian agency comes under fire from Conservatives 6 U.N. Assembly opens annual meeting on Tuesday 7 Marcos ends official talks in Washington 8 Mrs. Thatcher visits Tokyo for economic talks 10 U.S.-Chinese nuclear talks dead- locked over safeguards 11 Arms sale proposal for Jordan is nearly done, officials say 12 Arafat appeals to world leaders to help stop massacres 15 Social Democrats favored for comeback in Swedish vote 17 Government/Politics Immigration agency's plan to move Miami office protested 28 46 in New York State Legislature face primary contest 39 U.S. sues to keep Republic Air- port open at night 46 General Around the Nation 28 Atom fallout trial hears story of leukemia victim 31 Professionial looters are destroy- ing Indian burial sites 32 Environmentalists and Adminis- tration battle to a draw 34 Picture book about sex for chil- dren withdrawn 61 Industry/Labor Rail talks continue under mid- night strike deadline 29 Steelworkers' union opens parley tomorrow 30 Education/Welfare City assigns all eligible disabled pupils to classes 38 Religion A West Side theater becomes a part-time church 40 Arts/Entertainment Empire State Ballet does Bar- bara Striegel works 66 Contemporary Chamber Ballet of Caracas performs 67 Style At 60, Helen Gurley Brown talks about life and love 68 Obituaries J. Randolph Jones, founder of or- chestra in Jersey City 42 David Lidman, former New York Times makeup editor 43

title: 'MEETINGS' AT THE CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IN PRESENTING Mustapha Matura's ''Meetings'' at the Crossroads Theater, the director, Rick Khan, his cast and the designers indicate that modern-day Trinidad looks pretty much like any other Cuisinart wonderland.

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: Americans might learn a lesson from family life in France. Meals are of long duration.

title: Shakespeare Theater To Be Dedicated Oct. 4
description: The newly renovated theater of the Riverside Shakespeare Company, at the West Park Presbyterian Church on West 86th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, will be dedicated Oct. 4, with Helen Hayes and Joseph Papp as hosts.

title: FLORIDA'S OLD CAPITAL GETS NEW LEASE ON LIFE
description: Birds, termites, falling plaster and exposed wiring managed to do what the Union Army could not do more than a century before: They drove the Florida government out of its 137-year-old Statehouse.

title: OFFICE CONDOS SEEK A PLACE IN THE SUN
description: FOR the last several years, individual ownership has been widely a ccepted in housing. But it is only recently that brokers and d evelopers involved in office condominiums have begun their struggle f or recognition in the state.

title: QUEENS LEADERS TOUT JAMAICA CENTER RENEWAL
description: A half-dozen ambitious efforts to reverse the fortunes of one of the city's more troubled ''downtowns'' were put on display Friday when business and civic leaders led elected officials on a tour of Jamaica Center in Queens.

title: CARDINALS SWEEP METS BY 2-0 AND 6-2
description: The St. Louis Cardinals continued last night to roll over the New York Mets, sweeping their second doubleheader in two nights at Shea Stadium. Last night the Cards won, 2-0 and 6-2, and increased their lead over the Philadelphia Phillies to three and a half games in the National League East.

title: Topics; Advice and Consent; The Professional
description: When Congress wants to second-guess the President's estimate of the deficit, or estimate how much energy Amtrak trains save, or find out who really benefits from college loan programs, where can it go? Since 1975 it has relied on the first-rate, determinedly nonpartisan analyses of Alice Rivlin and her staff at the Congressional Budget Office. Now, alas, Mrs. Rivlin has decided to move on.

title: Derrick Corson Niederman And Terri A. Keeler Wed
description: Terri Ann Keeler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Keeler 3d of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married there yesterday to Derrick Corson Niederman, son of Dr. and Mrs. James C. Niederman of Bethany, Conn. The Rev. Robert Giannini performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. Peter.

title: TO LET PEOPLE IN ON THE LAW - OR NOT?
description: When a Federal judge recently freed more than 1,100 Haitians from a detention camp in Florida, he was enforcing one of the more important checks on arbitrary Government action, the Administrative Procedure Act of 1946. The statute, little known outside the legal profession, should probably be part of every civics class, for it guarantees public participation in the process by which Washington makes rules that have the force of law.

title: SCHMIDT'S FOES EAGER TO TAKE OVER
description: The small Free Democratic Party appeared splintered today over the reignation of its ministers from Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government. But opposition Christian Democrats expressed confidence that they would be able to replace he SocialDemocratic minority Cabinet with a new coalition, possibly next week.

title: Lilco: A Special Kind Of Economics
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is constantly pleading poverty before the Public Service Commission when it seeks rate increases, but last month its board of directors proudly announced to its shareholders the 23d increase in its dividend rate in 24 years.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 1 1 3 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 2 4 3 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.''

title: B-1 Bomber Safety Hatch Found on Football Field
description: A 150-pound escape hatch from a prototype of the Air Force's new B-1 bomber fell off the plane at an altitude of 16,000 feet Friday night and landed in a football field in a Virginia park, the Air Force said today.

title: MUSIC HATH CHARMS FOR L.I. AUDIENCES
description: WHEN members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater take to the stage of C.W. Post's Concert Theater Wednesday it will mark the start of Long Island's fall concert season. And from all indications it will be an unprecedented season; in terms of both what will be available on stages from Brookville to East Hampton, and from the audiences' acceptance of the product.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: INVENTIONS AND INSPIRATIONS
description: THE SOCIAL CONTEXT OF INNOVATION Bureaucrats, Families, and Heroes in the Early Industrial Revolution, as Foreseen in Bacon's New Atlantis. By Anthony F.C. Wallace. Illustrated. 175 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $15.

title: THE SORCERY OF THE AMAZON
description: EDWIN McDOWELL is publishing correspondent of the New York Times. BY EDWIN McDOWELL

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: As Dr. James J. Lynch, and others, have emphasized, social isolation is a significant risk factor for coronary heart disease, but it also appears linked with cancer, cirrhosis, accidents and all the other leading causes of death. Adults under the age of 70 who are single, widowed or divorced die at rates two to 10 times higher than their married counterparts, regardless of sex or race.

title: The Hamilton Papers
description: Harold C. Syrett's letter (Aug. 29) pointed out that the review of Jacob Ernest Cooke's book ''Alexander Hamilton: A Biography'' erroneously indicated that Mr. Cooke was general editor of the initial 15 volumes of ''The Papers of Alexander Hamilton.'' I would like to point out that this was a typographical error made by our editorial department that appeared on the book jacket, especially since Mr. Syrett stated that he does not know where this information originated.

title: No Headline
description: Dartmouth Is Upset By Penn

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS IN THE WORLD OF ART
description: AFTER idling for most of the summer, the art juggernaut has started its fall roll. Because of retrenchments, cutbacks and various other financial woes, it probably will not travel at the speed it has in past seasons, but nevertheless will pick up a brisk momentum.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS IN SUMMARY;
Fallout on a Human Scale
description: The radioactive chickens are slowly coming home to roost in Utah. Last month a Federal judge ruled that the Government had deliberately concealed evidence in a 1956 lawsuit brought by sheep ranchers who claimed their stock was killed by fallout from nuclear weapons tests.

title: ARCHITECTS' DESIGNS COMMEMORATED
description: Except for the White House, it is perhaps the most celebrated residence in America, a series of cantilevered balconies jutting above a natural waterfall that spills over a massive rock ledge. Frank Lloyd Wright designed ''Fallingwater'' in 1936 as a country lodge for Edgar J. Kaufmann, a department-store magnate in western Pennsylvania, and later this month it will appear on one of four 20-cent postage stamps being issued to commemorate achievements of architecture in the United States.

title:
DINING OUT;
A FLORIDA DELICACY IN BELLEVILLE
description: textured Florida stone crab claws are the specialty at this bright neighborhood trattoria of the same name. Served as an appetizer or main course, the fat claws are mounded on a plate and accompanied by a tangy mustard sauce.

title: No Headline
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE; PHILLIES BEAT PIRATES ON HOMER BY ROSE

title: MRS. THATCHER IN TOKYO FOR ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, on a two-week tour of Asia, has arrived here for economic talks with Japanese officials.

title: Israel Asserts Its Troops Intervened To Minimize the Beirut Massacre
description: Israel today condemned the massacre of Palestinians in refugee camps in Beirut and said that Israeli troops had intervened to prevent Christian Phalangist forces from killing more people.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Essex County Courthouse in Newark has the dubious distinction of having two criminal trials of major political figures going on at the same time. Last Monday, on the fifth floor of the courthouse, the trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and his co-defendant, former City Council President Earl Harris, on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office got under way with jury selection.

title: N.L.R.B. BACKS RIGHT TO QUIT A UNION IN A STRIKE
description: In a move that could make it more difficult for unions to maintain rank-and-file discipline, the National Labor Relations Board has ruled that a union cannot flatly prohibit members from leaving the union in the course of a strike.

title: Carefree Days In Jersey City
description: This may be the age of creative financing, but there are limits. After reviewing the books - such as they were - of the Jersey City Redevelopment Agency, Federal officials were reported last week to have uncovered a wide array of fiscal irregularities, including $500,000 in questionable expenses and $100,000 in thefts.

title: Lisa A. Camalier, E.M. Diefenbach Married in Capital
description: Lisa Anne Camalier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Aloysius Camalier Jr., of Potomac, Md., and Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Michael Diefenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elmer Diefenbach of Rye, N.Y. Msgr. Joseph B. Coyne performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: No Headline
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE; ANGELS CUT ROYALS' LEAD TO 1

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was horrified to learn this morning of the killing of Palestinians which has taken place in Beirut.

title: RAIDS ON CAMPS STARTED DAY AFTER GEMAYEL DIED
description: According to foreign doctors at a nearby hospital, the military drive on the two Palestinian refugee camps of Shatila and Sabra that culminated in Friday night's killings began Wednesday morning, the day after the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel.

title: J. RANDOLPH JONES, CONDUCTOR IN JERSEY, DIES
description: J. Randolph Jones, the founder and musical director of the nowdefunct Jersey City Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, died Friday at the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Jersey City after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: THEATER OF THE DEAF RELOCATING
description: WATERFORD THE National Theater of the Deaf is looking for a new home, in many ways one not unlike the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center where it was created 15 years ago.

title: No Headline
description: Penn State Downs Rutgers

title: Sardinia
description: To the Editor: Leslie Caron's witty and informative article, ''Sardinia's Emerald Coast'' (Travel, Aug. 22), contained some misleading information on the nuraghe.

title: STRATEGIES FOR THE CORPORATE BRASS
description: AMERICA'S top business executives are delighted these days that the s tock market's burst of enthusiasm has added millions of dollars in v alue to their corporate pension funds and that it may not be long b efore they can float a new stock offering.

title: 'ANGELS' IN TROUBLE IN 2 CITIES
description: THE Guardian Angels, the controversial volunteer patrol group, recently found itself in trouble with officials in two countries at once.

title: LEGAL AID, CUT BACK, RESORTING TO 'TRIAGE'
description: IN A cramped office of the Passaic County Legal Aid Society, a legal assistant brought out a thin manila folder on Angel Diaz, who had recently lost his job and wanted to challenge the state's refusal to grant him disability pay.

title: WAS TIMES'S MAKEUP EDITOR
description: David Lidman, the makeup editor of The New York Times from 1954 until his retirement in 1973 and the newspaper's columnist on stamp collecting for more than a decade, died yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AFTER the apparent lack of interest shown by Democratic voters in the party's primary election Sept. 7 for the nomination for Secretary of the State, Representative Richard D. Tulisano, chairman of the General Assembly's Judiciary Committee, had a suggestion last week.

title: THE FEEBLE U.S. CASE AGAINST A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: OWNERS OF LUCHOW BUILDING FIGHT LANDMARK DESIGNATION
description: The old Luchow's restaurant is certainly a sentimental landmark, but the owners of both the East 14th Street building and the fixtures within it are opposed to designating it as an official landmark.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: And Now the Queen Mother

title: ON THE HUNT FOR ILLEGAL DUMPS
description: AFTER completing the first six-month phase of a search for landfill sites in Westchester that may have been used for improper disposal of waste material, the county's Environmental Mangement Council and the Health Department have discovered many active or abandoned dumps not listed on any county map, but have found no evidence that any of these locations contain toxic or hazardous materials in dangerous amounts.

title: TURNOVER IS HIGH IN LEGISLATURE
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT elects its General Assembly on Nov. 2, but the legislature that will take office next January has already been drastically altered by quests for other offices, primary elections and retirements.

title: Cologne
description: To the Editor: Permit me to add a piece of intelligence to the informative article ''What's Doing in Cologne'' by Anna Tomforde (Travel, Aug. 22).

title: AN ODD DEAL IN MINGO COUNTY
description: NASHVILLE EVER since the first New Yorkers and Pennsylvanians hiked among the scraggy peaks of Appalachia and swapped their shotguns for hundreds of acres of coal lands, a lot of people - miners and millionaires, businessmen and entrepreneurs - have been bankrupted, defrauded and derailed in big-money deals and get-rich-quick schemes in the mountains and coal fields of West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.

title: Noni McGeorge, Arthur J. Wheeler Wed in Delaware
description: Antonia Harman McGeorge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur McGeorge Jr. of Greenville, Del., and Ellsworth, Me., was married yesterday to Arthur Jackson Wheeler, son of Mrs. Frederick McGeorge Bundy of Manchester, Mass., and the late Howard Wheeler of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Jeffery W. Rowthorn, the bridegroom's brother-in-law and a member of the faculty of Yale Divinity School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the McGeorge home in Greenville.

title: F.B.I.
description: A Douglas SBD Dauntless, the workhorse of World War II naval aviation that now has great nostalgic value, has been recovered by Government agents after the Navy said it was stolen from a graveyard of the wrecked planes in Chicago.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: MUNICH 1923 The Story of Hitler's First Grab for Power. By John Dornberg. Illustrated. 385 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN THEY miss a lot, those who hear the birds of dawn and the garbage trucks only dimly through their dreams, if then; who rise to alarm clocks or clock-radios, rush through ablutions, churn through token breakfasts and hurtle out the door to the job as their spouses turn to the demands of arising children.

title:
WOODMERE PONDERS SCHOOL-LAND SALE;
WOODMERE
description: LOCAL real estate developers have made the Hewlett-Woodmere school district an offer the district feels it cannot refuse. The district has approvaed a contract to sell the Woodmere South complex - provided voters approve - for what some school officials believe is a record price of $3.75 million. The buyers are the developers Milton and Philip Geller, who plan to build luxury apartments here.

title: OUTDOORS
description: Fall Promises an Abundance of Fish As certain as the annual spring thrustings of shad or alewives up the Delaware or Hudson Rivers, the part-time summer anglers of the Northeast who visited seashore or country have migrated home a few weeks before much fishing is at its very best.

title: 'Assigning' a Lease
description: Question: What does it mean to ''assign'' the lease of a rentstabilized apartment? ... M.McC., Manhattan Answer: The Rent Guidelines Board says that if you sublet your apartment, you are temporarily leasing it to another person. If you assign your apartment, however, you completely and irrevocably surrender it to another person. Most rent-stabilization leases allow subletting or assignment with the landlord's approval. In any case, if the owner allowed an apartment to be assigned when it first came under rent stabilization, he cannot later refuse permission without good reason. If the landlord unreasonably refuses, and you wish to contest it, the dispute comes under Housing Court jurisdiction.

title: Carol A. Rooney Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Anne Rooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Michael Flanagan, son of Mrs. John J. Flanagan of New Vernon, N.J., and the late Mr. Flanagan. The Rev. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony in St. Michael Roman Catholic Church.

title: HIGH COURT NULLIFIES WESTERN SAMOA VOTE
description: The Supreme Court of this South Pacific nation has nullified the election in February of Prime Minister Vaai Kolone because of electoral fraud.

title: SOVIET ARMS COME IN SECOND IN LEBANON
description: Israel's operations against Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces in Lebanon have demonstrated that, in this test bed for modern military technology, American and Israeli weapons are superior to those provided by the Soviet Union. In light of what happened to Russian aircraft, antiaircraft systems and tanks, some recipients of these arms in the Middle East might well be wishing they had bought American.

ONE WAY in which to acquire a ''feel'' for the beauty and utility of old furnishings is to see them displayed as they might have been in a house of their own era. One such place with an interesting history is Rockingham, the farmhouse where General and Mrs. Washington stayed for several months in 1783.

title: THE VOTERS' DECISION WILL STILL LEAVE CUOMO FACING ONE
description: UNDER cloudy polls, Democrats in New York will pick their nominee for governor on Thursday. Mayor Koch was ahead of Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in a pair of pre-primary surveys released last week, but one showed him in front by 22 points and the other by a single one. When the ballots are counted, said Mr. Koch, ''someone will have egg on his face.''

title: U.N. BODY OPENS A 3-MONTH PARLEY TUESDAY
description: The General Assembly, a conclave of all l57 United Nations members, opens its annual meeting here Tuesday with an agenda thick with well-worn items.

title: BOY, 13, IS FORMING CANCER YOUTH GROUP
description: WHEN Juan B. Valera Jr. was undergoing treatment for leukemia, the loss of his hair following chemotherapy made him the target of repeated teasing from his peers. ''Hey, Kojak,'' some of the children in his class would call out.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: THE FALL OF '67, WHEN THE RED SOX REACHED THE PROMISED LAND
description: FIFTEEN years ago this month New England was up and cheering. For the first time in many of our lives the Red Sox were in a pennant race, and we were hooked. We were delighted with Dick Williams as he stared steely-eyed at the opposing pitchers. We were awed by Carl Yastrzemski and his emergence that summer as the finest player in the American League. We had Lonnie and Scottie and the Hawk - and we were determined to see it through to the end.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: It's a scene being repeated more and more often around the world: The meal is over, the traveler hands a credit card to the waiter, the waiter returns with a three-part receipt. After signing, the traveler pulls out the carbons between the leaves of the receipt and tears them up. Why? Because he has heard that some people dig out imprinted carbons from the trash and use the customer's name and number to buy merchandise by telephone.

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON THE House of Representatives voted last week to block passage of a bill that would lengthen by as long as seven years the patents that companies hold on drugs and chemicals.

title: NEW APPLE IS OFFERED TO COMMERCIAL GROWERS
description: After 45 years of experimentation, a new variety of apple tree, the Early Cortland, is being sold for the first time to commercial apple growers.

title: CABARET: JOYCE BRYANT SINGS
description: Joyce Bryant, who is singing at Sweetwaters, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, through next Saturday, does not follow the usual supperclub formulas. She opens with a song that most singers might use for a climactic moment - an intense, dramatic interpretation of Cole Porter's ''Miss Otis Regrets.''

title: A NOVEL OF VERY HIGH ADVENTURE
description: SPACE By James A. Michener. 622 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: BLOWING AWAY THE FEZ SMOKESCREEN
description: The four-day meeting of the Arab League at Fez, Morocco, produced not a peace proposal but a ploy. The ploy is the effort by the principal Arab countries concerned to blow up the importance of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, so that he may continue to be the central figure in asserting what are called the ''legitimate rights'' of the Palestinians. The Arab League attempted to play what should now be the discredited P.L.O. card. Yasir Arafat is a defeated leader of a now dispersed terrorist force, and the effort to puff up his importance flies in the face of the Arab states' own demonstrated lack of enthusiasm to take in P.L.O. fighters evacuated from Beirut.
To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: No More Free Drinks

title: A MIXED BAG; Hotel Art
description: Sept. 22 - Gala reception from 5 to 7 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria will officially open the Waldorf Cocktail Terrace, a new rendezvous in the Art Deco style, and celebrate the restoration of the hotel's Park Avenue lobby with its Art Deco murals by Louis Rigal and its "Wheel of Life" floor mosaic. The event is a benefit for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, specifically the decorative arts collection of the department of 20th century art there. Penelope Hunter-Stiebel, associate curator, was called in for consultation on the restoration and will be at the party to say a thing or two about the new feeling and appreciation of Art Deco. Tickets, $50 at the door. And The Winner Is

title: LONELINESS IN AMERICA
description: In a discussion of human loneliness, there should be some mention of the great part animals play in bringing a kind of companionship to lonely people. NANCY WINN CICCONE Norwich, Conn.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clifton $65,000 134 Beverly Hill Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; *2*full unfinished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,148. Little Falls $97,000 1 Villa Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old bilevel; *2*3 air-conditioning units, 2-car garage; taxes $1,700. Passaic $94,500 45 Ridge Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*2 porches, 2-car garage; taxes $2,248. Pompton Plains $102,000 23 Van Ness Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old split level; central *2*air conditioning,central vacuum cleaner; taxes $2,032. Wanaque $120,000 26 North Gate *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; 2-car garage, *2*full basement, aluminum storms and screens; taxes $2,400. Wayne $169,000 15 Borzotta Boulevard *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; *2*central airconditioning, fireplace; taxes $3,255. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $92,500 103 Albemarle Road *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old frame colonial; *2*full basement, laundry, flagstone patio; taxes $1,224. New Canaan, Conn. $373,000 87 Danvers Lane *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; *2*2 fireplaces, swimming pool, 1 acre; taxes $3,648. Southold, L.I. $80,000 Terry Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace in *2*living room, full basement, 3-car garage with loft; taxes $1,000.

title: Judge Bars Destruction Of Four Tigers in Detroit
description: Four Siberian tigers scheduled to be destroyed for health reasons have won a temporary reprieve from a Wayne County Circuit Court.

title: OFFICER, HURT IN CHASE, WOUNDS FUGITIVE ON L.I.
description: A Nassau County police officer shot and critically wounded a fugitive from Florida yesterday after a chase during which the officer was dragged by the suspect's car as it crashed into a parked car and into a liquor store.

title: PRO FOOTBALL STRIKE LOOMS, WITH TWO SIDES STALEMATED
description: When the National Football League's second week concludes with tomorrow night's game between the Giants and Green Bay Packers in Giants Stadium, the N.F.L.'s 63d season could also conclude.

title: Drexel Harris Jr. Marries Robin Leach in Brooklyn
description: Robin Arlene Leach, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Leach of St. Albans, Queens, was married yesterday to Drexel B. Harris Jr., son of Mrs. Victoria Harris of Brooklyn, and the late Dr. Harris. The Rev. John Carrington performed the ceremony at John Wesley United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Miss du Pont Takes Vows In Delaware
description: Joanna Smith du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexis Irenee du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Block Island, R. I., was married yesterday to Houghton Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lewis of Chadds Ford, Pa. The Rev. John C. Scobell performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: VOCAL MUSIC Competition fans can come to Carnegie Hall this week, hear 12 promising young singers and bet their favorites at the same time. All are competing for first prize in the 1982 International American Music Competition, which can mean for the winner up to $15,000 in cash awards, $35,000 towards career promotion and concert bookings and a $35,000 recording contract with New World Records.

title: STAGE: 'CONFESSIONS OF A DOPE FIEND'
description: Jeffrey M. Jones's new play, ''The Confessions of a Dope Fiend,'' is an admixture of Hogarth's ''The Rake's Progress,'' Marlowe's ''Doctor Faustus'' and Mr. Jones's autobiography. Unsurprisingly, the three diverse subjects add up to an incohesive evening of theater.

title: Leanne Carr Is Married
description: Leanne Carr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Warlick Carr of Lubbock, Tex., was married there yesterday in the First United Methodist Church to Robert Benedict Meyer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer of McConnelsville, Ohio.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS IN SUMMARY;
'Social Agenda': Much Ado, but Nothing Doing
description: In a scenario set in a cave, Plato once posed questions about how people would behave if they were unable to tell shadow from substance. He could have based a field study in Washington last week.

title: Greenwich Is Still Impressive
description: Greenwich High School lost all but one starter from last year's Fairfield County and State Class L championship team. However, the losses didn't seem to both the Cardinals Friday afternoon.

title: JERSEY PIPELINES ARE STUCK IN THE PIPELINE
description: At the height of New Jersey's water shortage nearly two years ago, an engineer who had weathered a similar crisis 15 years earlier reflected on the cyclical nature of the problem. ''One or two big rainstorms will end this,'' he sighed, ''and then all the drought experts will disappear into the woodwork.''

title: RECYCLING AN IDEA
description: Near my hometown in the Sandhills of North Carolina, stands of tall pine trees line the roadsides, the gray earth beneath them richly carpeted with brown needles. The trees grow in straight rows, as if planted that way by human design.

title: Sound and Fury
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Sound and Fury Over Poverty,'' Aug.22, Barbara R. Bergmann stated that affirmative action is the ''only program anyone has thought of to make decently paid work open to women and to black and Hispanic men.'' She thus ignores the most successful remedy ever tried: a public works program.

title: At Chrysler, No Year for Shouting
description: It was a short walk for thousands of the workers still employed at Chrysler Corporation assembly plants and component facilities last week, as the country's third largest automaker and the United Auto Workers talked past a 24-hour extension of a strike deadline until a dawn agreement was reached. But then no one had expected a strike to last.

title: POP: NATURALISM BY BONNIE KOLOC
description: With her low-keyed conversational style and flat Middle Western accent, Bonnie Koloc represents folk-blues singing at its most natural and unaffected. Miss Koloc's lack of flamboyance may have kept her from becoming a major recording star, but it serves her well in an intimate setting like the Other End's, where she opened a twonight engagement Thursday.

title: KHomeini Claims Another Victim
description: An ardent defender and former leader of the Iranian Revolution became its latest victim last week. Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, who returned from exile alongside the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in February, 1979, was executed by a firing squad after being convicted of attempting to overthrow the Government and kill the Ayatollah.

title: GRENADIAN REPORTS FRENCH HELP AGAINST U.S.
description: Grenada's Prime Minister, Maurice Bishop, left for home today after a three-day visit here, saying he had secured French cooperation for what he called his country's struggle against pressures from the United States.

title: A TENANT-LANDLORD FIGHT RESUMES
description: ONE of the county's longest rent hearings started up again last week after a three-month summer recess, as a group of Yonkers tenants tried to do two things simultaneously: get their rents reduced and stop their building from being converted to a cooperative.

title: WILLING TO GUESS WRONG
description: When the 1982 Spingold Knockout Team Championship ended in Albuquerque, N.M., in August and the winning Aces team was celebrating at a party that got under way in the small hours, a voice was heard to announce: ''Say we won it for the Gipper.'' The voice belonged to burly Bob Hamman of Dallas, and he was not, of course, talking about George Gipp, Notre Dame's great football coach. He wanted the journalists present to remember the vital role of Ira Corn Jr. of Dallas, who had died three months earlier.

title: Audrey Maynard Becomes the Bride of Kaighn Smith Jr.
description: The marriage of Audrey Maynard to Kaighn Smith Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me., took place yesterday in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sheridan Lord, stepfather and mother of the bride, in Sagaponack, L.I. The Rev. Franklin Goldthwaite Sherrill performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: THE FEEBLE U.S. CASE AGAINST A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: To the Editor: It was impossible not to do a double take after reading the following Strangelove sentence from a top Administration official, Richard Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security: ''The concept of the freeze misses the central point about nuclear weapons: They are not inherently good or bad.'' v. eapons capable of eradicating life on this planet are ''not inherently good or bad''? This was no off-the-cuff remark, but a thought-out article which presumably was cleared at the highest levels.

title: TOKYO TEXT CHANGE PROTESTED
description: More than 500 people, most of them Americans of Chinese and Korean extraction, demonstrated here today to protest revisions in Japanese textbooks that tone down atrocities committed by Japan before and during World War II.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: KEYBOARD MUSIC Back in the mid-1960's, Terry Riley seemed destined to become the most important American composer of his generation. His ''In C,'' which was first performed in 1964, introduced a new, meditative, minimalist music to American concert audiences, and Columbia's recording of the piece reached large numbers of rock and jazz fans as well as new music buffs.

title: STARTING WITH THE VIKING REVIVAL
description: Scandinavian design, which revolutionized interiors internationally in the 1950's, had its roots in much earlier, highly innovative 19th-and early 20th-century works. This is one of the many messages delivered in the multifaceted ''Scandinavian Modern: 1880-1980,'' on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street. This stunning and comprehensive review documents for the first time in this country the strong links mid-20th century Scandinavian designers had with their past.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Those who follow contemporary photography know there has been no dearth lately of staged imagery - pictures made in the studio rather than on the streets or in the wilderness. Generally such work combines the esthetics of Hollywood with the ambiance of a dollhouse, a Disneyland-like alliance that addresses social issues as much as formal ones.

title: Cardinal Spellman Has Winning Start
description: Kevin Hellmann passed for three touchdowns to lead Cardinal Spellman to a 26-0 victory over Cardinal Hayes in a nonleague game as the high school football season opened yesterday in the metropolitan area. The victory at Clinton snapped a nine-game losing streak for Spellman, whose last triumph was in 1980 when it defeated Monsignor Farrell for the division championship. Last season Hayes won the Catholic High School Football League Division II title.

title: THE EXTRAORDINARY JOYCE
description: In his new edition of ''James Joyce,'' which is revised, expanded and wonderful, Richard Ellmann observes that ''few writers have achieved acknowledgment as geniuses and yet aroused so much discontent and reproach.'' At first one supposes that Joyce antagonized his readers by demanding too much of them, a theory that would certainly hold true for ''Finnegans Wake.'' Yet if we except Joyce's last book, other great writers, such as Proust, Mann and Kafka, have been just as demanding. It is tempting to think that Joyce aroused resistance by asking people to recognize the extraordinariness of the ordinary. He may have frightened them with their own possibilities, like a psychoanalyst who tells his patient something about himself before he's ready to accept it.

title: CANADIAN UNITY AGENCY COMES UNDER ATTACK
description: A Government agency that spends $25 million a year to promote unity and federalism in Canada has come under fire from opposition leaders who say that its activities constitute misdirected propaganda.

title: REPORT FINDS CITY'S SERVICES MOSTLY BETTER
description: The level of many services in New York City improved in the last year, but some are still below where they were when the Koch administration took office in 1978, according to a city study.

title: THE SCREEN COMES INTO ITS OWN
description: The paneled screen, that decorative partition used to divide a room, conceal a doorway, or add intrigue to a boudoir assignation, is catching on as a medium for artists. At least, that's the case made for it in ''Partitions,'' a new show at the Pratt Manhattan Center Gallery (160 Lexington Avenue at 30th Street), which presents 14 examples of work by painters and sculptors who in recent years have been looking into the screen's possibilities. The show interprets ''partition'' loosely, including such examples as a beautiful freestanding wall of etched glass by Patsy Norvell in the traditional folding format; a simple set of panels plastered with media images and used as a prop by the performance artist Jeff Way, and a Venetian blind by Gilda Pervin, encrusted with pinkish concrete in which are stuck hundreds of household items.

title: CHANGING RULES FOR ROAD AND RAIL
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission cleared and approved the merger of the Union Pacific, Western Pacific and Missouri Pacific Railroads last week, creating the nation's third largest rail system with a swiftness that drew admiration from transportation specialists. It showed how smoothly the agency has been able to implement some elements of the Staggers Rail Act, a 1980 deregulation measure aimed at making the nation's freight delivery systems more efficient.

title: Basketball Player Dies
description: In an informal workout involving members of the Boston University basketball team Friday, Arturo Brown, the captain-elect of the 1982-83 squad collapsed, then died later at Brigham and Women's Hospital, apparently of cardiac arrest. Brown, a 21-year-old graduate of Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, was a senior in the School of Management and had played on the basketball team for three years.

title: PRAYERFUL ECONOMICS
description: THERE is a ''coming boom'' on the horizon, but it will not emerge f rom Herman Kahn's crystal ball. Mr. Kahn is almost always i nteresting; this hardly guarantees that his views are either correcto r useful.

title: WAS GRANDMA A CLOSET FEMINIST?
description: BACK in the halcyon 50's, I was something of a supermom. Like the rest of my pioneering generation, I escaped from the overcrowded city and proceeded to overpopulate the Long Island school system. In less than a decade, my sisters and I had made an impact on the suburban economy: P.T.A.'s flourished in every town and Brownie troops assembled in semifinished basements; shopping malls dedicated to the female consumer (and worker) rose on former potato fields; the construction industry boomed along with the tax rate; Lilco built its empire and the orthodontist's bill became the catalyst for the first double-paycheck family.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The New York Dance season swings into its usual pluralistic self this week with some rather disparate offerings. Among them one should single out the reunion of several young choreographers who graduated from New York University and who have made a name for themselves in recent years in modern-dance.

title: Bridge: Artificial Elements a Part Of Most Duplicate Games
description: The normal duplicate game, scored by match points, includes a number of elements that are artificial and against the spirit of the game. There is an unnatural emphasis on overtricks, and declarers often have to abandon the best theoretical play for their contract because they feel a need to try for an overtrick or fear losing an extra trick or two in the process.

title: CENSUS TRACES RADICAL SHIFTS IN NEW YORK CITY'S POPULATION
description: New York City's population shifted as dramatically during the decade of the 1970's as at any time in the history of the city. That is the conclusion of demographers, planners and other city experts who have now had several months to study the first reports from the 1980 census. Markedly Fewer Children

title: DELTA FESTIVAL SINGS REBIRTH OF BLUES
description: The Mojo magic of the Mississippi Delta took a blazing hot sun, positioned it over an idle cotton field this weekend and smothered the area with thousands of people eating pork barbecue, chitterlings, fish sandwiches, hot tamales and Polish sausage.

title: Waltrip Holds Off Rivals, Wins 500
description: Darrell Waltrip held off a succession of challengers today and captured the CRC Chemicals Nascar 500 Grand National stock-car race at Dover Downs International Speedway.

title: FATALITIES STIR CONCERNS OVER HIGH-SPEED CHASES
description: Nicholas Theodos remembered screaming. Mr. Theodos, an officer of the New Jersey state police, was pursuing a driver who had flashed by him at 90 miles an hour on a two-lane shore road late one recent Sunday night. He reached 110 miles an hour as the car ahead ricocheted between both shoulders of the road. And then the car seemed sure to smack into a huge evergreen - and to recoil, Officer Theodos feared, into him.

title: 2-TERM GOVERNOR WINS HAWAII VOTE
description: Gov. George Ariyoshi, the only American of Japanese descent ever elected governor of a state, was nominated by the Democrats Saturday for a third four-year term.

title: Commodities; Outlook For Prices Of Pork
description: FOR consumers, the price of pork, ham and bacon will probably continue at record levels, perhaps go even higher this winter and early next spring and remain high during much of 1983.

title: SOVIET CALLS BEIRUT KILLINGS A 'HEINOUS CRIME'
description: The Soviet Union today termed the massacre in Beirut's Palestinian refugee camps a ''heinous crime'' committed by Israel, and it urged the deployment of United Nations forces in the Lebanese capital to protect civilians.

title: FLEXI-VAN'S CHALLENGE IN LEASING
description: For 10 years at Hertz Rent-a-Car, David Bocksch learned the automobile leasing and rental business while his company tried to fight off the challenge of the industry's No.2 company, Avis, which boasted in its advertising that ''we try harder.''

title: CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE VITAL TO OUR DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: PALME WINS MAJOR VICTORY IN SWEDEN
description: The Social Democratic Party of Olof Palme won a decisive victory tonight in the Swedish general election and promised to press ahead with policies that could lead to worker control of the nation's industries in a few years.

title: Cyclist Is Injured
description: Graziano Rossi, a leading Italian motorcyclist, was critically injured today when he spun off a curve while racing at a speed of 168 miles an hour. Race officials said Rossi was given oxygen and then taken to the intensive care ward of a Bologna hospital, where he was reported in critical condition with injuries to the head and thorax. The 28-year-old racer was in second place three laps from the finish in the 500 cubic-centimeters class

title: IRISH UPSET REFLECTS CHANGES
description: Notre Dame's 23-17 victory over Michigan in season opener Saturday night at South Bend, Ind., indicated that Coach Gerry Faust really meant it when he said that changes he had made since last season were for the better.

title: Bishop Assails Massacre
description: The massacre in Beirut was called inexcusable yesterday by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the New York Episcopal Diocese. ''No human being can be excused for such an action under any circumstances; no madness of war can be given as a reason,'' Bishop Moore said in a statement on the killing of Palestinian refugees. The Bishop also called for prayers for the dead and wounded and ''for the souls of those directly and indirectly responsible for this tragedy.''

title: Burger King to Begin Taste-Test Campaign
description: Burger King, stealing a page from Pepsi-Cola, another well-known No.2, is turning to the old taste-test ploy in its ongoing war with McDonald's, a well-entrenched No.1. It will be a sub-campaign under the regular ''Aren't You Hungry?'' umbrella.

title: Cubs 7, Expos 5
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Leon Durham's two-run pinch homer in the eighth broke a 5-5 tie. The loss was the Expos' fourth in a row and dropped them six and one-half games behind the first-place St. Louis Cardinals in the East.

title: Washington Watch; Truck Dispute Near Decision
description: WASHINGTON YELLOW FREIGHT and other trucking companies have been complaining that Canadian concerns were taking advantage of truck deregulation to swarm across the border in pursuit of American business, with the Americans unable to gain reciprocal opportunities north of the border.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets to Conclude 36th Session - 3 P.M.

title: N W FED RAL SM HOLES
description: Since the beginning of his political career, Ronald Reagan has extolled the virtues of state government and railed against attempts by Washington to cure the nation's ills. Toward this end, in his State of the Union Address he launched his New Federalism policy, designed to return to the states those prerogatives he views as rightfully theirs. But since actions speak louder than words, a look at what the Administration has done makes it clear that it doesn't hesitate to give states' rights a back seat.

title: Burchfield Team Is Croquet Victor
description: Archie and Mark Burchfield, a father-and-son team from Stamping Ground, Ky., won the national doubles championship of the United States Croquet Association yesterday in Central Park by defeating Archie Peck of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jack Osborne of New York, 21-20, in the final match of a double-elimination tournament.

title: 30% OF HOMES HAD A CRIME IN '81
description: Thirty percent of the nation's households were touched by a crime in 1981, the same percentage as the year before, a Justice Department report said today.

title: Siren Test Today Near Nuclear Site
description: Seven sirens in Putnam County will be sounded at low levels Monday as part of a testing program around the Indian Point nuclear power plants, officials said.

title: CARDS SWEEP METS
description: That noise at Shea Stadium yesterday was not from a low-flying jet, but from the streaking St. Louis Cardinals, who scored their fifth straight victory over the Mets.

title: Scott Fetzer Names A New President
description: Gary A. Childress, whose tenure as president of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation was cut short earlier this month, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Scott Fetzer Company.

title: EGYPT SAYS IT MAY RECALL ITS ENVOY TO ISRAEL
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, said today that Egypt might recall its Ambassador to Israel if the Israelis did not withdraw their forces from Beirut.

title: FOR SOME SWIMMERS, SEASON IS NOT OVER YET
description: Never mind that Labor Day has passed, that temperatures are just sneaking into the 70's, that department stores are filled with bulky sweaters, fur-lined gloves and argyle socks. David Elliot was oiled up and lying on the beach here today - he even went swimming - and though he certainly wasn't fighting for space to stretch out his towel, he wasn't alone either.

title: Some Missing Links
description: Although almost two years of negotiations between New York City and Kemper Sports Management that would have Kemper leasing three of the city's golf courses broke down last summer, the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association has expressed an interest in renewing the bid to take over the operation.

title: GOVERNOR'S RACE NEARING ITS CLOSE ON A QUIET NOTE
description: The candidates in Thursday's primaries for Governor wrapped up their final weekend of campaigning on a uniformly quiet note yesterday, with a minimum of activity, a minimum of rancor and the apparently shared conviction that politicians have as much right to enjoy a sunny September day as anyone else.

title: THE EDUCATION OF QUARTERBACK BRUNNER
description: ''HUT-HUT, pass the potatoes.'' Scott Brunner smiled. It was a level-headed, intelligent smile, not overemotional, a smile in the manner he quarterbacks. When your father is a football coach and your mother a former college basketball player and women's field-hockey referee, dinner might be expected to sound like a locker room with pep talks between courses.

title: OHIO MAYOR FACES UNWANTED COMMUTE, TO DAKOTA
description: Other Republican officeholders may be worried about keeping their jobs amid the country's economic woes, but few have as pressing a problem as Melvin Griffin, the commuting Mayor of this village near Cincinnati.

title: Jersey Union Agrees to Allow Nurses to Cross Picket Line
description: Burn-unit nurses will be allowed to cross picket lines to care for three New Jersey residents injured in an airplane crash in Spain if there is a strike Monday morning at St. Barnabas Medical Center here, officials said today.

title: MURRAY R. SIEGEL
description: Murray R. Siegel, a retired vice president and treasurer of J.I. Kislak, a real estate brokerage concern in Newark, died Friday at Palisades General Hospital in North Bergen, N.J. Mr. Siegel was 89 years old and had homes in West New York, N.J., and Hallandale, Fla.

title: JAZZ: A GREAT AND EARLY, DESEGREGATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: IN A 'RECONCILIATION,' ARAFAT HAS LONG TALK WITH ASSAD
description: In what was described as something of a ''reconciliation,'' Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met today with President Hafez al-Assad and said later that the Syrian Government had agreed to ''accept any resolution and decision'' made by the P.L.O. leadership.

title: The A.M.A. Pays a House Call
description: What precautions do you take if you are contemplating a whitecollar crime? In the 60's and 70's, you memorized your lawyer's phone number, then stowed passport, traveler's checks and ticket to Rio under your pillow. In the 1980's, you form a Political Action Committee to lobby Congress for an exemption from the law.

title: DODGERS WIN, STAY 2 1/2 AHEAD OF BRAVES
description: Joe Torre, the manager of the Atlanta Braves, got a bit of good news yesterday morning. He learned that on Saturday night the Los Angeles Dodgers had lost for the first time in eight games.

title: SENATE SCHOOL PRAYER BACKERS HOPEFUL OF HALTING FILIBUSTER
description: Senate advocates of officially sanctioned prayer in the public schools, their hopes bolstered by renewed support by President Reagan over the weekend, say they have a fighting chance this week to end a filibuster by those opposing the legislation.

title: Calypso Wins
description: Calypso, ridden by Melanie Smith, won the $35,000 Mercedes American Gold Cup Grand Prix today for the second consecutive year. The 9-year-old Dutch-bred gelding completed the six-fence second jumpoff course faultlessly in the time of 24.16 seconds. Second place went to Grand Lieu, ridden by Norman Dello Joio.

title: Pirates 8, Phillies 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Manny Sarmiento pitched a six-hitter and drove in two runs as Pittsburgh set back the pennant hopes of the Phillies. It was the fourth loss in six games for Philadelphia, now four and a half games behind the National League Eastern Division-leading St. Louis Cardinals, who beat the Mets.

title: STRAVINSKY 'SACRE' MS. TO BE SOLD
description: The first working draft of Stravinsky's ballet score for ''The Rite of Spring,'' which is considered by most musicologists the most innovative composition of the first half of this century, is to be sold at auction.

title: Conferences Mull Joint TV Contract
description: The Pacific-10 and Big Ten athletic conferences would likely resume talks over a joint television contract if college football broadcasts are thrown into the open market by court rulings, the commissioner of the Pac-10, Wiles Hallock, said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NOEL COWARD DIARIES. Edited by Graham Payn and Sheridan Morley. 698 pages. Little Brown & Company. $22.50.

title: Dutch Order On Pipeline
description: A court here has ordered an American subsidiary in the Netherlands to comply with a contract for the Soviet Union's gas pipeline, despite the Reagan Administration's embargo on the shipment of pipeline parts.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Floods in El Salvador Leave at Least 70 Dead

title: The Issue Is Court-Stripping
description: Last week a weary Senate finally tabled an anti-abortion rider to the vital debt ceiling bill. Today it decides whether to cut off debate on another legislative parasite on the same bill, a school prayer rider. This time the issue is far more than a politically sensitive ''social issue.''

title: FLAWED AND IRRELEVANT MIDEAST ARGUMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Dolores M. Maniscalco Bride of Robert Ericksen
description: Dolores M. Maniscalco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Maniscalco of Levittown, L.I., was married at the Tavern on the Green yesterday to Robert P. Ericksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ericksen of Northport, L.I. The Rev. James J. Wentz, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Stores Destroyed In Boardwalk Fire
description: A block of stores and restaurants were destroyed this morning in a fire on the boardwalk of this Cape May County shore resort.

title: A DOG IS A HELPER AS WELL AS A FRIEND
description: rate and highly successful gun dog books, has joined with the Orvis Company here in offering a series of two and one-half day retriever training courses for dog owners.

title: CITY OPERA: STRONG CAST SUSTAINS 'MAGIC FLUTE'
description: THE City Opera's first ''Magic Flute'' of the season, Saturday night, was a revival only in that Beni Montresor's scenery and costumes were used. Jay Lesenger provided all new staging and direction, Gilbert V. Hemsley Jr. revised the lighting, and Andrew Porter's English translation replaced the version by Ruth and Thomas Martin.

title: RENEWING TIES YEARS AFTER CAMP
description: Blossom Weinstock Landsman of Rockville Centre, L.I., wore the serge bloomers that were part of her camp uniform 46 years ago. Jane Cohen Bergner of Bethesda, Md., put on her 25-year-old flannel jacket. Susan Taxin Baer of Scarsdale, N.Y., dug out a section of a float she had helped to build for a 1954 pageant, and Renee Kirsch Silver of Greensboro, N.C., brought a scrapbook containing, among other mementos, camp canteen bills from the early 1940's.

title: BREWERS TROUNCE YANKEES BY 14-1
description: Dave Winfield sat in the clubhouse at County Stadium before today's game discussing the challenges remaining for the Yankees, a team already eliminated from this year's division race. He cited personal statistics, preparation for next season and performing the spoiler's role in the American League East pennant race.

title: THE CUBA MISSILE SHOWDOWN: KENNEDY AIDS NOTE LESSONS
description: Twenty years after the Soviet Union touched off a major confrontation with the United States by stationing nuclear missiles in Cuba, six key Kennedy Administration officials say that the decisive military element in resolving the crisis was the availability of superior American conventional forces, not superior American nuclear forces.

title: Advertising; Expanding Geriatrics Market
description: WITH the golden-age gang the fastest-growing segment of the American population, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. couldn't very well expect to keep the gerontology field to itself.

title: Queens Couple Are Found Dead
description: A husband and wife were found dead in their Queens apartment in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said yesterday. The police tentatively identified the couple as 50-year-old Steve Sarovic and his wife, Tatjana, 39, but were trying to confirm their identities with relatives, most of whom were believed to live in Bulgaria.

title: Berkey Photo Replaces Its Longtime Chairman
description: Berkey Photo Inc. has a new chairman, A. Michael Victory, managing general partner of the Cumberland Investment Group. Mr. Victory, 48, succeeds Benjamin Berkey, 71, who founded the company in 1933. Mr. Berkey announced earlier this month that he was stepping down.

title: Services for David Lidman
description: A memorial service for David Lidman, former makeup editor of The New York Times, will be held on Thursday at 1 P.M. at the Middlebury United Church of Christ on the Green in Middlebury, Conn. Mr. Lidman died Saturday.

title: Lions 19, Rams 14
description: Bob Thomas, who was claimed off the waiver list two weeks ago, kicked four field goals, and Billy Sims accounted for 212 yards in his first start of the season for the Lions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With a soul filled with bitterness and deep pain I have learned the news of the horrendous massacres committed in the Palestinian camps in Beirut.

title: HBO FILMS TERRY FOX STORY IN TORONTO
description: Myth making and film making were both advanced on the streets of Toronto today as thousands of runners participated in a fund-raising effort that served as the backdrop for the first feature-length movie being produced in Canada for pay television in the United States.

title: GAS MILEAGE ESTIMATES FOR 1983 MODEL VEHICLES ARE LISTED BY THE E.P.A.
description: Following is a list of the Environmental Protection Agency's fuel economy ratings for 1983 model year vehicles sold in all states except California.

title: PLAYERS MEET TODAY ON STRIKE
description: Seven months of labor unrest in the National Football League could reach a decisive point today, when the executive committee of the N.F.L. Players Association meets at 2 P.M. at the Halloran House hotel in Manhattan to consider a strike against the league's 28 owners and possibly set a strike date.

title: Raiders 38, Falcons 14
description: Los Angeles scored two touchdowns in 44 seconds late in the first half today, the first on a 4-yard run by Marcus Allen and the other on a 30-yard pass from Jim Plunkett to Cliff Branch.

title: Clyde McCullough, 65, Coach With Padres, Is Found Dead
description: Clyde McCullough, the San Diego Padres' bullpen coach and minor league instructor, was found dead in his hotel room early Saturday.

title: OPERA: A VIOLETTA FROM THE AUDIENCE
description: EVERY so often, life has a way of imitating art, and so it was Saturday afternoon at the New York City Opera. The opera was Verdi's ''La Traviata,'' the tale of a young woman with respiratory problems. Playing Violetta was Carol Vaness, a young soprano who on this occasion was suffering bronchial miseries of her own. A flu-ridden Miss Vaness began Act I in an attractive, if carefully covered, voice, and all seemed well until she ran up against Verdi's coloratura in ''Sempre libera.'' At this point, Miss Vaness held up her hand, stopped the music and left the stage.

title: Cluster of Treasury Issues Scheduled
description: Treasury financings are the main event in the credit markets this week, as the Treasury has scheduled sales totaling $22.95 billion that will raise $11.15 billion of new cash for the Government.

title: CORPORATE POWERS ATTACKED
description: Big multinational corporations are coming under a far-reaching attack by nations that want to see them more strictly regulated. The attack, originating both in the European Common Market and in the Group of 77, the caucus of third world countries in the United Nations, reflects deepening concern over the wealth, power and global reach of these companies.

title: San Francisco Retires Market Street Streetcars
description: The last streetcar headed for the carbarn today, ending 122 years of operation on Market Street.

title: Casper Takes Senior Playoff
description: Billy Casper won his second straight tournament on the Senior PGA Tour today.

title: Broncos 24, 49ers 21
description: DENVER (AP) - Rich Karlis kicked an 18-yard field goal on the final play of the game to complete the rally by the Broncos.

title: FANS UNHAPPY OVER RIFT
description: Jason Siegel of San Diego would go to the zoo, Richard Somers of Miami would get his shoulder pads out of the attic and Rose Marie Hoyson of Carnegie, Pa., did not know how she would spend her Sunday afternoons and Monday nights.

title: Goalie Kept His Promise
description: THE wave of New York Cosmos surged from locker to locker, spraying champagne, pounding on plastic garbage-can covers and chanting the names of the players to the music of Jose Marti's ''Guantanamera.''

title: Los Angeles Bus Union Votes to Accept Pact
description: Bus drivers in the Los Angeles bus system voted overwhelmingly today to accept a new contract, ending a strike that affected 600,000 riders for four days.

title: Chief at Scot Lad Foods Moving Into Marketing
description: H.J. Markarian has resigned as president and chief executive of Scot Lad Foods. Scot Lad is a food wholesaler, retailer and processor based in Lansing, Mich.

title: VICTORIOUS COSMOS SEEK NEW PLAYERS
description: After the Cosmos became champions of the North American Soccer League Saturday night, the hierarchy and Coach Julio Mazzei said that the team must upgrade the quality of its players to attract more fans.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1982; Companies
description: Peking has granted Atlantic Richfield permission to drill for oil offshore. The contract, the first signed with an American oil company, took four years to negotiate. It covers 3,500 square miles near Hainan Island that Atlantic Richfield's top officers say has 20 promising geological structures and is ''probably the longest unexplored virgin coastline in the world.'' Santa Fe International is Arco's partner in the contract. (Page A1.)

title: FOR TESTIFYING EXPERTS, THE GAIN ISN'T FINANCIAL
description: From the groves of academe they are plucked like the choicest of produce. They come with their $75 per diem allowances, their graphs and charts and compendiums stowed neatly in attache cases with combination locks. They come with their expertise on matters economic.

title: Chiefs 19, Chargers 12
description: Nick Lowery kicked four field goals and Gary Green blocked a punt that was recovered in the end zone for a touchdown as the Chiefs beat the Chargers for the first time since 1978. For Green, it was the sixth kick he has blocked in his career. Lowery kicked field goals of 19, 27, 41 and 34 yards to enable the Chiefs to snap a six-game losing streak to their American Football Conference West nemesis.

title: INDUSTRY'S PURSUIT OF CANCER DRUGS
description: In the pharmaceutical industry, no area of research is more compelling than the battle against cancer. But efforts to develop effective cancer drugs have often given way to the realities of the bottom line.

title: STEEL UNION CHIEF ASKS NEW TALKS TO REDUCE COSTS AND HELP JOBLESS
description: Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said today that he hoped the union and the major steel companies could resume the bargaining that broke off in July and could reach an agreement to reduce labor costs and help unemployed steelworkers.

title: COSMOS GREETED
description: An enthusiastic crowd of about 500, carrying banners and chanting, welcomed the Cosmos at Newark Airport Sunday night. The loudest cheers came when Hubert Birkenmeier, the goalkeeper, carried the championship trophy as the players filed through the gate area. The Cosmos have four days off before practicing Friday for the Carlos Alberto Farewell Game.

title: BANK ON PARK AVENUE IS BOMBED
description: A Park Avenue bank building was shaken and seven floors of windows on its East 49th Street side were shattered early this morning when a bomb went off.

title: EAGLES RALLY FOR VICTORY, 24-21
description: Ron Jaworski, the quarterback, today rallied the Philadelphia Eagles to three fourth-quarter touchdowns for a 24-21 victory over the Cleveland Browns.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1982
description: International Sending peacekeeping forces to Beirut to prevent new killings and strengthen the Lebanese Government was discussed by President Reagan and his top aides, the White House said. A senior official said the Administration was leaning in favor of a redeployment to Beirut of about 2,000 of the 7,000-member United Nations peacekeeping force now in southern Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Lebanese forces entered the camp in west Beirut where Lebanese Christian militiamen murdered scores of Palestinian men, women and children. As troops and civil defense volunteers moved to establish order and to remove the mounds of corpses, new information emerged about the extent of the massacre of civilians and the role played by Israeli forces. (A1:5.)

title: Hunt Is On in Brussels For Synagogue Raider
description: Belgium pressed a nationwide manhunt today and tightened security measures for Jewish neighborhoods after a submachine-gun attack that wounded four people outside the city's main synagogue.

title: CHANCES DIM ON PASSING NEW IMMIGRATION LAW
description: Chances for approval of a comprehensive immigration bill in the current session of Congress seemed to decline last week when the chairman of a second House committee asserted a right to have the bill reviewed by his panel.

title: Black & Decker Promotion
description: Ronald H. Fidler, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, has been named president and a director.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When did baseball players begin wearing batting helmets? Is it true that all players will be required to wear the two-flap helmets next season?

title: Kornhauser & Calene
description: Let's all drink a toast to the crowd at Kornhauser & Calene who have just been awarded the business from Laird & Company, alcoholic beverage importers of Scobeyville, N.J. Most of the $1 million budget will be put behind Grande Cantina Classico Brut, which the agency says is the only sparkling Italian Soave Classico wine marketed in the United States. Previously the advertising was handled in-house with freelance help.

title: Su Mac Lad Dies; Trotter Was 28
description: Su Mac Lad, the gelding trotter who was a star in the early 1960's, died Saturday at Stanley Dancer's farm here, his home since his retirement from racing in 1965. He was 28.

title: Study Finds Weak Link Of Divorce and Grades
description: Family income and a child's sex have a bigger impact on school achievement than whether a student's parents are divorced, an educators' group has reported.

title: INGRID BERGMAN WINS EMMMY FOR GOLDA MEIR ROLE
description: Ingrid Bergman won an Emmy posthumously tonight for her performance as Prime Minister Golda Meir of Israel in Operation Prime Time's ''A Woman Named Golda.'' The show also won the Emmy for outstanding drama special.

title: Dealers Say Rates Could Rise; Fed May Alter Interest Trend
description: The weakness of the economy and subdued inflation continue to favor lower interest rates in the future, many economists say. However, securities dealers warn that the trend to lower rates still may be interrupted by two familiar problems - the growth in the money supply and the size of Federal budget deficits.

title: NON-IMPERIAL KIPLING
description: To the Editor:

title: KILLINGS A SHOCK, ISRAELI AIDES SAY
description: Senior Israeli officials said today that they never imagined that the Lebanese Christian militiamen would massacre scores of Palestinian men, women and children in west Beirut. They added, however, that they knew in advance that the Phalangists were planning to enter the refugee camps as part of an overall plan to root out remaining guerrillas.

title: THE SUM OF BEIRUT'S HUMAN MISERY GOES BEYOND THE MASSACRE IN CAMPS
description: Well over 200 people are known to have died violently in Beirut since Tuesday night, and more than 330 to have been wounded.

title: Holy Cross Tops Bayside
description: Bayside, the Public Schools Athletic League football champion the last three years, was upset by Holy Cross of the Catholic League, 14-13, yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field in the season opener for both teams.

title: DOLPHINS RALLY TO OVERCOME COLTS, 24-20
description: Tommy Vigorito raced 33 yards for a touchdown 1:12 into the second half, and Uwe von Schamann booted a 29-yard field goal later in the third quarter as the Miami Dolphins rallied for a 24-20 victory over Baltimore today.

title: UNUSUALLY COLD WINTER IS FORECAST BY ANALYSTS
description: The northern part of the United States from New England to the Great Plains may suffer from an unusually cold winter this year that could be the most frigid of the century, a number of leading meteorologists say.

title: CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE VITAL TO OUR DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Gives Up in Accident
description: A teen-ager surrendered to the police today in connection with a hit-and-run accident at a pre-wedding celebration that killed a 2-year-old girl and a man who tried to save her, the authorities said. The police said the 17-year-old driver of the car was being held in the Dallas City Jail, but had not been charged. They did not name him.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch on Margaret Chase Smith published Aug. 29 incorrectly named the first woman elected to the United States Senate. She was Hattie Caraway, Democrat of Arkansas.

title: TESTS OF M-1 TANK GIVE MIXED RESULTS
description: The final operational test reports on the Army's new M-1 main battle tank seem to give a mixed picture of a speedy, agile, hard-to-hit fighting machine that is still troubled by a variety of mechanical problems and is prone to break down and malfunction.

title: KLENETSKY OPPOSES MOYNIHAN WITH UNUSUAL LIST OF CHARGES
description: ''We're in different universes,'' said Melvin Klenetsky when he was asked where he stood ideologically in relation to his opponent in Thursday's Democratic primary, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: Yasue Rebecca Nao Bride of D.J. Koblitz
description: The marriage of Yasue Rebecca Nao, who will be a lawyer with the antitrust division of the Department of Justice effective Oct. 4, to Donald Jeremy Koblitz, a lawyer adviser with the Department of State, took place yesterday in Bethesda, Md. Judge William B. Bryant of Federal District Court performed the ceremony at the Sycamore Island Club.

title: ITALY ASKS RETURN OF PEACEKEEPERS
description: Italy, saying that civilians in Beirut were in urgent need of protection, announced today that it had formally asked the United States and France to join in sending an international peacekeeping force back to the Lebanese capital.

title: GIVEN A CHOICE, CHINESE PREFER CABBAGE TO IDEOLOGY
description: Cabbages have begun piling up again on the sidewalks of Peking and the shoppers, reminded that autumn is near, choose carefully before paying with crumpled small banknotes. They lash the long leafy cabbages to their bicycles and pedal them home.

title: U.S. WAS REPORTEDLY URGED TO KILL SHAH
description: Three months after the American hostages were seized in Teheran, a senior Iranian official is said to have told the Carter Administration that the crisis could be ended ''overnight'' if the Central Intelligence Agency would assassinate the ailing Shah of Iran.

title: By Majorie Hunter; The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Primary Choices for Congress
description: New York State has lost five Congressional seats to reapportionment, four of them wholly or partly within New York City. In the remaining 18 city districts, the outcome of Thursday's Democratic primary will be virtually tantamount to election in four districts. QUEENS

title: CORRECTIONMILTON AVERY
description: An Associated Press dispatch on Margaret Chase Smith published Aug. 29 incorrectly named the first woman elected to the United States Senate. She was Hattie Caraway, Democrat of Arkansas.

title: CLEANUP BEGINS AFTER AN OIL SPILL OFF STATEN ISLAND
description: A Staten Island company has begun cleaning up oil-drenched debris and tar balls that washed ashore at the Battery and on Staten Island after one of the New York area's largest oil spills this year, the Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: TEXT OF SECURITY COUNCIL RESOLUTION ON THE BEIRUT MASSACRE
description: Following is the text of the resolution on the Beirut massacre adopted by the Security Council today by a vote of 15 to 0:

title: BRIEFING
description: Compromise on Arms Aides

title: 4 Poles Remain In U.S. Custody
description: Four Polish nationals who sailed into Port Elizabeth, N.J., last Thursday after a four-month voyage from Greece in a 38-foot sailboat remained in custody yesterday pending action by immigration officials on their request to remain in the United States.

title: Dinner for Prince Moved From Men-Only Club
description: A dinner arranged for Prince Philip in Los Angeles has been switched from a men-only club accused of discriminating against minority groups, British sources said today.

title: AGING: IS OUR VIEW DISTORTED?
description: Americans are inclined to have a distorted view of aging, often associating it with such negative factors as losses, decline, poor health and dependency, and this could have serious consequences. This was the message conveyed Thursday to a seminar on ''How Aging Is Changing'' by Dr. Rose Dobrof, director of Hunter College's Brookdale Center on Aging and a professor in the college's School of Social Work.

title: STEELERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Standout defensive plays and a key call by Terry Bradshaw in overtime gave the Pittsburgh Steelers a 26-20 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals today.

title: THE SUFFERING OF JOE KLECKO
description: 7 victory over the New England Patriots yesterday, the 270-pound allpro defensive end waddled back to the line of scrimmage without a word, without a gesture, as he always does. But now, early in the fourth quarter, he was trying to pile up the Patriot tight end Don Hasselbeck, who was blocking for the running back Tony Collins.

title: LOUIS M. ZIMMERMAN
description: Louis M. Zimmerman, a former chief enforcement officer of the New York City Commission on Human Rights, died of a heart attack Saturday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 75 years old and lived in Queens Village.

title: Market Place; Watching Small Issues
description: WHEN the stock market began kicking up its heels last month, famous blue-chip companies with large capitalizations won new favor with pension funds and other institutional investors. These stocks range from Merck and General Electric to Eastman Kodak and International Business Machines - all giants in their respective fields and all, incidentally, components in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: JUDGE IN THE BRINK'S CASE
description: When the judge in the Brink's murder and robbery case, Robert J. Stolarik of State Supreme Court, enters his courtroom, the bailiff calls out the traditional ''All rise,'' and almost everyone does.

title: Body of Ohio Postmaster Found After $50 Theft
