description: A postmaster who was believed to have been abducted in the robbery of less than $50 from a northwestern Ohio post office last month has been found stabbed to death, the officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Plant Life of the IND

title: NEW TALKS TODAY
description: An engineers' strike disrupted rail service throughout much of the country today as the Reagan Administration discussed the possibility of asking Congress for emergency legislation to bring a quick halt to walkout.

title: Orioles 4, Indians 2
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Rich Dauer's two-out, 10th-inning homer gave the Orioles their 26th victory in the last 31 games on Thanks Earl Day. They remained two games behind first-place Milwaukee in the East.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Waiting for November

title: Gayle Fleischman Wed To Peter T. Crenier
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday, Gayle Ann Fleischman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Fleischman of Stamford, Conn., was married to Peter Theodore Crenier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Benners Crenier of Belleair, Fla.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: San Gennaro's Day

title: PESO CUT AIDS PLANTS AT BORDER
description: The steep devaluation of the Mexican peso has sharply pared labor costs for American companies operating assembly plants south of the border, and many industrialists and analysts expect that others will soon follow them.

title: U.N. COUNCIL VOTES TO SET UP 50-MEMBER FORCE IN BEIRUT
description: The Security Council unanimously approved a Western-sponsored resolution today calling for the creation of a 50-member force of unarmed United Nations observers to help protect Palestinians in Beirut.

title: Oilers 23, Seahawks 21
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Earl Campbell rushed for more than 100 yards for the first time in 15 games and scored the deciding touchdown on a 12-yard run with 53 seconds remaining. An illegal contact call on the cornerback Keith Simpson during an incomplete third-down pass play gave the Oilers a first down at the Seahawks' 12 just after the Seahawks had rallied from a 17-7 deficit to take the lead, 21-17.

title: Angels Tie for First
description: ''The season for us starts tomorrow,'' said Frank White of the Kansas City Royals yesterday. His team had just lost its third straight game to the Twins in Minnesota, 9-4, and dropped into a tie for first place in the American League Western Division with the California Angels. The Angels matched Kansas City's 84-65 record by beating the Blue Jays, 5-1, in Toronto.

title: FILIPINOS FIND FEELINGS MIXED ON MARCOS VISIT
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines begins a weeklong stay in New York today, he will find a Filipino community that is one of the fastest-growing ethnic groups in the city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * European American Bank has appointed Ronald L. Ilsley, G. Peter Mitchko, Wesley H. Watson and Steven C. Wimpenny vice presidents.

title: No Headline
description: HAAS WINS HALL OF FAME GOLF

title: ARCO IS THE FIRST U.S. OIL CONCERN TO WIN OFFSHORE CHINA CONTRACT
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company today became the first American oil concern to win China's permission to start drilling for oil offshore.

title: Marcos Puts Limits On U.S. Use of Bases
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the United States could use its bases in the Philippines in a crisis affecting the region but that their possible use to resupply combatants in the Middle East would be the subject of talks.

title: Detective Shot; Suspect Is Killed
description: A detective was shot yesterday afternoon as he was trying to arrest two men in the East New York section of Brooklyn. The detective and another officer returned the fire, killing one suspect, according to Sgt. Tom Fahey.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Commercial Credit Co., a Control Data Corp. subsidiary, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $200 million of medium-term senior notes, second series, in denominations of $1,000 with a $10,000 minimum investment.

title: PALESTINIAN HOPE AND CAUTION
description: There are differences of opinion among Palestinians concerning the aims of the Reagan peace initiative. Nevertheless, many people in the occupied territories agree that so far it seems to have revived the art of the possible in a region where what is necessary - a just peace - is dangerously becoming impossible.

title: 'ROSENKLAVIER' OPENS MET TONIGHT
description: Like the young Octavian gallantly bearing a silver rose to a loved woman in ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' the Metropolitan Opera will open tonight at 7:30, bearing to its loyal audience a performance of the Richard Strauss opera. It is the last of the three Lincoln Center ''opening nights'' - the New York Philharmonic and the City Opera have begun their seasons - and it will be a sterling occasion.

title: TAX LAW'S EFFECTS ON THE OIL INDUSTRY
description: In raising tax revenues, Congress went looking for businesses that paid little or no taxes. The oil industry was a prime target. While the industry pays some taxes on its American income, it pays relatively little on income earned abroad. The new tax law will force most multinational oil companies in the United States to pay somewhat higher taxes by limiting their use of credits against American taxes that reflect foreign taxes the companies pay. The measure is expected to raise an estimated $1.1 billion over the next three years.

title: Saints 10, Bears 0
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Ken Stabler threw a 10-yard touchdown pass to Larry Hardy in the first quarter, and the defense frustrated three quarterbacks to give the Saints their first shutout in 88 games.

title: THE END OF A POLICY
description: Sometimes it takes the terrible clarity of human disaster to make people understand the consequences of a policy. If this is such a case, there will be a point in the deaths of Palestinian men, women and children. The Beirut massacre will make people confront the consequences of Menachem Begin and Ariel Sharon.

title: LONG, INTENSE GRIND BEGINS FOR ISLANDERS
description: They dash across the rink to the opposite boards, stop in a flurry of ice chips, reverse swiftly and return to the starting spot. They rush the length of the ice, flop to the surface and do push-ups. They play brisk scrimmages and skate swift drills. Their practice uniforms are drenched in perspiration. Outside, where the temperatures are close to 80 degrees, they run a mile or more and they play softball - more sweat. Routines vary, but over all the grind is the same as players work to get into condition for a rugged seven months of 80 regular-season games and all the playoff games that are possible next spring.

title: New Courts for Monroe
description: Earl Monroe, the whirling dervish who flamboyantly dribbled and shot his way through National Basketball Association competition in four seasons with the Baltimore Bullets and nine seasons with the Knicks, hardly ever touches a basketball anymore in the third year of his retirement.

title: SOME ISRAELI POLITICIANS URGE BEGIN AND SHARON TO RESIGN
description: Protests erupted in Israel today over the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut, and there were calls by some politicians and demonstrators for the resignation of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Hodges Honored
description: Before the game, the late George M. Weiss, the first president of the Mets, and the late Gil Hodges, who played for and later managed them to the World Series championship in 1969, were inducted into the team's Hall of Fame.

title: 4 Tons of Marijuana Is Found Washed Up on Florida Beach
description: Four tons of marijuana washed up on a beach here Saturday, apparently after heavy seas overturned two smuggling boats, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Mr. Deng's Chairless China
description: What happened at China's 12th Communist Party Congress was mainly symbolic and mostly predictable. Maybe Deng Xiaoping didn't get all that he wanted, but it was made fairly clear that he's in charge of the party that rules a billion people. By again downgrading Mao Zedong, erasing his post of ''Chairman'' from the hierarchy and banishing Mao's chosen successor from the Politburo, the Congress reconfirmed the supremacy of Mr. Deng and his more pragmatic brand of Marxism.

title: KLECKO INJURED
description: It was like practice. Everything they tried worked, and everything the other team tried did not work. So the Jets left Schaefer Stadium this afternoon with a 31-7 victory over a weak team, the New England Patriots, in an exemplary game for New York.

title: ERRORS IN A RAPE VICTIM'S INDICTMENT OF THE PROSECUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEECHWRITER FOR EISENHOWER
description: Emmet John Hughes, a journalist who served as speechwriter for President Dwight D. Eisenhower and as political adviser to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: 3 A-Plants Closed In Connecticut
description: The three nuclear power plants in Connecticut were shut down over the weekend, but a spokesman for Northeast Public Utilities said two of the reactors were expected to be back on line in a day or two.

title: Redskins 21, Buccaneers 13
description: Curtis Jordan blocked a punt and recovered it for a touchdown, and Mark Moseley kicked two field goals that were set up by fumbles recovered by the Redskins.

title: U.S. PRESSES ISRAEL TO LET U.N. TROOPS MOVE INTO BEIRUT
description: Lebanese Army troops and civil defense volunteers moved into the Shatila refugee camp today to establish order and remove the mounds of rotting corpses, the evidence of a mass killing of Palestinian men, women and children by Lebanese Christian militiamen.

title: BUFFALO COURIER-EXPRESS PRINTS ITS FINAL EDITION
description: The Buffalo Courier-Express, the loser in a five-year struggle with The Evening News, printed its final edition yesterday. Its death added Buffalo to a steadily growing list of major cities with only one daily newspaper.

title: ALL HELL BREAKS LOOSE
description: The massacre of scores of Palestinian innocents in west Beirut, following the massacre of the Lebanese president-elect and 25 of his Christian followers last week, was a tragedy that was also a defeat for the Israeli Army.

title: Five Persons Die In Head-On Crash
description: Five persons were killed and three others seriously injured in a head-on automobile collision at about 1 A.M. today in Yaphank, the police said.

title: HONDURAN REBELS STILL HOLDING 80
description: Leftist guerrillas continued to hold about 80 business and Government leaders hostage here today as more details of their demands became known.

title: TV: 'THE ROYAL ROMANCE' ON CBS
description: IF nothing else, royalty buffs will have had their fill for a while. Last Friday, ABC broadcast a television movie called ''Charles & Diana: A Royal Love Story.'' Tonight at 9, CBS has a television movie titled ''The Royal Romance of Charles and Diana.'' The subject, needless to say, is the courtship of Britain's Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer. The wedding, in July 1981, was a splendid pomp-and-circumstance story, its live coverage enchanting television viewers throughout the world - a fact that just might be connected with the spectacle of television entertainment rushing to concoct dramatizations of the ''fairy tale'' relationship.

title: Football in Spanish
description: Spanish International Network, which gained in ratings and familiarity to sports fans around the country last summer when it broadcast all 52 World Cup soccer games from Spain, will now try an experiment with a strictly American sport. This fall the Spanishspeaking network is broadcasting on a tape-delayed basis the college football games of the University of Southern California.

title: PARENTS CONFRONTING TEACHERS
description: IN the annals of parent-teacher squabbling, the chronicle of Anna S trothers was something extraordinary. Although she had been d iagnosed as mildly retarded at the age of 7, with an I.Q. of 64, A nna's parents, Richard and Charlotte, seemed to be unable to accept t hat judgment. ''They had tremendously high aspirations for her and e xpected her to perform up to the level of her classmates,'' said D r. H. Paul Gabriel, professor of psychiatry at New York University M edical Center, who treated Anna and her family.

title: INJURY TO PERRRAULT LIKELY TO END CAREER
description: Perrault, who came into the Marlboro Cup Saturday the favorite for horse of the year but limped across the finish line in last place, far behind the race-winner Lemhi Gold, suffered a bowed tendon in his right foreleg and is unlikely to race again.

title: 4 VETERANS SUING U.S. OVER EXPOSURE IN '54 ATOM TEST
description: Twenty-eight years after the United States tested its largest thermonuclear device over the Marshall Islands, four Air Force veterans are challenging the Government's explanation of why the detonation exposed to radioactive fallout more than 236 islanders, 28 American servicemen and the crew members of a Japanese fishing boat.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Vehicular Priorities

title: 3-Year-Old Starves to Death After Father Disdains Welfare
description: The police have arrested the parents of a 3-year-old girl who apparently starved to death after her unemployed father refused to accept welfare.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankees Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Both teams are out of contention, but the Yankees will reward loyal fans, age 14 and under, with Tshirts.

title: Lendl Winner
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia breezed to a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Roscoe Tanner in an exhibition tennis match before a crowd of 2,500 at Maureen Connolly Stadium Saturday night. In another exhibition at Houston, Vitas Gerulatis defeated John McEnroe, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3.

title: Corona Jurors Take Day Off
description: Jurors in the murder retrial of Juan V. Corona, who have made many requests for second looks at exhibits and testimony, begin their seventh day of deliberations Monday. The jurors Saturday asked to see a photograph of Mr. Corona's brother, Natividad, who defense lawyers say actually murdered 25 farmworkers more than a decade ago. The jurors told the judge that they would not deliberate on a Sunday.

title: JOHN A. POPE OF FREER ART GALLERY, EXPERT ON ORIENTAL PORCELAIN, DIES
description: John Alexander Pope, director emeritus of the Freer Gallery of Art and an expert on Oriental porcelains and bronzes, died Saturday of a stroke at his home in Washington. He was 76 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TWO CITIES

title: News Analysis
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, whose eight-year-old coalition Government collapsed Friday after the defection of four Free Democratic ministers, has bequeathed to his successors a package of apparently intractable economic problems.

title: FLORIDA BANK PLANS A MERGER
description: In a move that further complicates the battle for control of the Florida National Banks of Florida, the company is seeking to acquire the Landmark Banking Corporation of Florida, Landmark announced on Friday.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Scouting Baseball at 91
description: Frank O'Rourke, who is nearing his 91st birthday, is still busy scouting young talent for the Yankees. Although he contends that since the advent of free agency, the emphasis of scouting has changed to a concentration on probable free agents from other major league teams, most clubs still like to check out young prospects in high school, American Legion and college baseball. During the height of the season, O'Rourke estimates that on some days he watches ''two or three games.''

title: POWER BALANCE IN FAVOR OF ABORTION
description: Twenty months ago, when the current Congress came to town, the legions of the New Right were vowing to reverse the Supreme Court decision of 1973 that legalized abortion. Supporters of that decision had suffered stunning defeats in the 1980 elections, and the antiabortion movement was being hailed as a potent force in American politics.

title: DANCE: JANNETTI AND ANNE FLUCKIGER
description: OFFICIALLY, Saturday night's program at P.S. 122 was called an evening of dances by Anne Fluckiger and Andrew Jannetti. Yet because three of its four dances were by Mr. Jannetti and Miss Fluckiger appeared only in the fourth, the concert was, in effect, a showcase for Mr. Jannetti, and it showed him to be a sweet - tempered, but almost too self-effacing, choreographer.

title: Poles Fine 9,000 in Campaign To End Black Market Dealing
description: More than 9,000 Poles have been fined for dealing in the black market after a campaign by the authorities to crack down on those profiting from the country's economic crisis, the official Polish news agency said today.

title: Lombard Securities
description: The Bankers Trust Company has been ordered by a Federal bankruptcy judge to release $225 million of securities it held as clearing agent for the failed Lombard-Wall Inc., Lombard-Wall has announced. In his decision, Judge Edward Ryan ruled that the securities, which Bankers Trust had refused to turn over, should be returned to Lombard-Wall so that the company, which traded in Government securities, may proceed with the orderly resolution of its business. Lombard-Wall, which is liquidating its business, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law on Aug. 12.

title: Wife of Violin Finder Gets Reward He Missed
description: The wife of a steamship employee who found a stolen $250,000 Stradivarius has been rewarded by insurance underwriters because she - not her husband - recognized its value and alerted the authorities.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Welcomed In Style by Muscovites
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi arrived here to a red carpet welcome today by Leonid I. Brezhnev and other Soviet officials.

title: The Talk of San Salvador
description: It rained again in San Salvador today, the sixth day of a driving downpour that has flooded the city's streets and drenched the green mountainsides and winding gorges around the city.

title: REAGAN TERMS ISRAELI PULLOUT 'ESSENTIAL'
description: The Lebanese Cabinet agreed today to ask that the multinational force of American, French and Italian troops return to Beirut because of the massacre of Palestinian civilians by Christian militiamen and the pervasive fear among Moslems in West Beirut that more bloodletting may occur.

title: HARVESTER DENIES BANKRUPTCY
description: The debt-ridden International Harvester Company, which has forecast a loss of $1.5 billion to $1.6 billion for its current fiscal year, denied today that it might soon file for bankruptcy.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan is trying to transform the shock and horror of events in Lebanon into new pressure for the withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian forces from Lebanon and renewed Arab-Israeli negotiations in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, Administration officials said today.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RERUNS

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Advertising; President Installed At M.J.W.
description: author of the book ''How To Advertise,'' began a new job yesterday as president of Muller Jordan Weiss, a 25-year-old agency with some $30 million in billings and offices in St. Louis and Toronto. She will also become a director along with the agency's three principals - John T. Jordan, 57, who has moved up to chairman and who remains chief executive, and Frank B. Muller and Andrew M. Weiss, who are executive vice presidents.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DeLorean Revival
description: The DeLorean Motor Company Ltd. may announce a restructuring plan later this week, according to Automotive News, the trade publication. DeLorean has been trying to arrange a $25 million export financing credit line plus $10 million in new working capital for its plant in Belfast, Northern Ireland, which went into voluntary receivership last February.

title: BURTON-TAYLOR PLAY SET
description: Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor are planning to appear together on Broadway next spring in a revival of Noel Coward's comedy ''Private Lives.'' This would be the first time that the two have acted together in a play on Broadway.

title: Kissinger Signs Contract For 3 Years With ABC
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has signed a threeyear contract with ABC News to give analysis and commentary on foreign affairs for the network's programs.

title: Life Beneath the Earth
description: A team of scientists, seeking to determine how far below the earth's surface life could be found, have discovered living organisms deep in soil zones that scientists previously thought were empty of life.

title: Business and the Law; Biggest Firms Mostly Grow
description: THE legal profession has not yet been hit by the recession, according to a survey of the nation's 200 largest law firms. The results of the annual survey appear in this week's issue of Legal Times, a newspaper for lawyers. In the last year, the top 200 firms - each has at least 90 lawyers - grew by an average of more than 8 percent, up from 6.5 percent the year before.

title: MONEY FUND IMPACT ON BANKS
description: The well-known loan losses of some of the nation's most prominent banks have prompted some money market funds to withdraw hundreds of millions of dollars from those banks and have thereby created a destabilizing force in American banking, according to Federal Reserve officials, bankers, and even some money fund executives themselves.

title: CHANCE-OF-A-LIFETIME HOME, A PRIZE, IS UP FOR SALE AS A BAD-LUCK VENTURE
description: Out on a Kansas plain 70 miles from Wichita, on a late winter evening in 1980, a farm wife clipped a coupon from the magazine Sports Afield, block-printed her name and dispatched her submission the next time the postman came around.

title: PACKERS RALLY TO BEAT GIANTS AS STRIKE BEGINS
description: Everything looked so good for the Giants tonight. They had taken a 19-7 lead over the Green Bay Packers late in the third quarter. Their passing game was doing well, and their defense was making big plays.

title: Sohio Buys Leases
description: The Sohio Petroleum Company announced that it had acquired from the McMoran Freeport Oil Company of Oklahoma 50 percent of McMoran's interest in oil and gas leases in the Anadarko Basin of western Oklahoma for $32 million. Sohio is a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), which is controlled by the British Petroleum Company.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amalgamated Sugar Co. said it had sold 374,000 shares, or about 15.6 percent of its common stock, to SKZ Holdings Inc. for $60 a share, as a first step in the previously announced merger of the two companies.

title: SURVIVORS OF MASSACRE TELL OF REIGN OF TERROR
description: A Palestinian woman who barely escaped being slain Friday night in a refugee camp on the southern outskirts of Beirut returned to the scene today and screamed for a long time.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Market Place; Storm Clouds For Insurers
description: THE nation's property-casualty insurance companies have been buffeted by heavy storms and other catastrophes so far this year, and now the hurricane season has arrived. Small wonder, then, that stocks in the group have been market laggards.

title: GOVERNMENT OF PERU VS. A 'SMALL GROUP OF TERRORISTS'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Executive at Bache Is Leaving Two Posts
description: Dalayne Dedrick Gold, whose duties at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. include supervision of mutual funds and retirement plans, has resigned as senior vice president and a director, the brokerage firm said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ALEXANDER SUIT CHARGES THAT 5 SIPHONED FUNDS
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the large New York-based insurance brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it had filed a suit in London against four former officers and a leading underwriter of its British subsidiary, charging that they had diverted some $55 million of funds into companies they owned.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trinity Church Museum Will Celebrate 285 Years

title: BONN'S NEW PARTNERS AGREE TO PICK KOHL
description: The leaderships of the Christian Democratic and Free Democratic Parties agreed tonight to choose Helmut Kohl as Chancellor, but they postponed plans to elect him in Parliament at the end of this week.

title: Winslow Is Angry
description: Kellen Winslow, the San Diego Chargers' tight end and the top receiver in the National Football League last season, says he is angry with the officiating in the league and he may retire in protest. ''The officiating was lousy as usual, but that's nothing new,'' said Winslow, who caught six passes for 61 yards in a 19-12 loss to Kansas City Sunday.

title: Turbine Deals Cited by U.S.
description: The Justice Department filed papers yesterday in the Federal District Court in Los Angeles, alleging that three turbine producers participated in a pricing arrangement to allow the payment of bribes to officials of Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's national oil company, known as Pemex.

title: Krupp-Hoesch Link
description: Technical problems will delay the planned merger of Krupp Stahl A.G. and Hoesch Werke A.G. into Ruhrstahl until March or April next year, spokesmen for the two companies said today.

title: LITTLE WENT RIGHT FOR UNIFIED GIANTS
description: It was raining and the lights went out and there was a strike to prepare for. In all, the Giants did not have a wonderful time tonight as they somehow turned a 19-7 lead into a 27-19 Green Bay Packer victory tonight.

title: NOT SO, AGENCY SAYS
description: Cincinnati's director of economic development announced yesterday that she had been appointed by the New York State Urban Development Corporation to head a $1 billion Times Square redevelopment project. But a corporation official later called the announcement premature.

title: FUTURES CONTRACTS BACKED
description: The staff of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday recommended approval of three new stock index futures contracts and the first futures contracts in six-month Treasury bills. Its action cleared the way for formal designation today of these new markets by the Federal regulatory agency.

title: Hilton Casino Plan
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said it expects to begin construction of a $225 million, 634-room hotel and casino in Atlantic City by early next year. The company said the project was suspended in January 1981 because of high interest rates.

title: MISSOURI RESEARCH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for QTr to July 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $77,000...C-AFter $15,000 incomefrom discontinued operations

title: U.N. SUPPORTS PLAN TO SEND TROOPS IN
description: United Nations officials said tonight that they were pleased that Western forces would go to Beirut but expressed disappointment that the United Nations would again be bypassed.

title: BREZHNEV BIDS REAGAN JOIN IN U.N. IN 'BRIDLING' ISRAELIS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev sent a message to President Reagan today urging joint action in the United Nations Security Council ''with a view to bridling Israel and making it comply with Council decisions.''

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: WHEN the Chase Manhattan Bank earlier this month announced a grant for a training program for New York City's school principals, designed to make them more effective as leaders, the bank put the spotlight on a newly rediscovered factor in the search for better schools.

title: A FRUITLESS SWAP
description: The Administration's latest ''new federalism'' initiative - a new version of the swap of Federal and state welfare responsibilities first proposed in President Reagan's State of the Union Address -has been heatedly debated by governors and the White House. But no pulling and hauling can change the fact that this version, like its predecessor, begs the central question of how to rationally divide Federal and state responsibilities in caring for the poor.

title: EDUCATION
description: SCHOOL systems usually demand from textbook publishers proof that the books are neither too difficult nor too easy for the grade levels for which they are intended.

title: STRIKE ISSUES AT BUILDINGS IN THE BRONX
description: PARTICIPANTS: Local 32E of the Service Employees International Union and the Bronx Realty Advisory Board. The union represents about 8,000 superintendents, handymen, porters and doormen at apartment buildings in the Bronx and Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income; the 1981 figures were restated to reflect change of method of stating foreigh exchange losses

title: Dow Off 0.64; Volume Shrinks
description: Stock prices eased slightly yesterday mainly because of concern over interest rates and the increasing tension in the Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off 8.01 points at noon, ended the session off only 0.64 point, to 916.30. Analysts said the late recovery was helped by the moderate improvement in the bond markets yesterday, where prices rose about half a point.

title: CRUM & FORSTER'S ATTRACTIONS
description: An 1896, Frederick Crum and John Forster were insurance agents who started their own concern to sell other companies' insurance. That small brokerage business has grown into the nation's 15th-largest property and casualty insurance company, with a thriving commercial insurance division that has apparently whetted the appetite of a potential acquirer.

title: FIRST NON-AMERICAN FOR U.S. SPACE FLIGHT NAMED
description: A West German physicist and an American biomedical engineer were named yesterday as the first nonastronauts scheduled to fly aboard the space shuttle. Their mission, set for next September, will also be the first time a non-American will fly aboard an American space vehicle.

title: General Mills Net Down 11%
description: General Mills announced yesterday that its net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1983 dropped 11 percent, while sales edged up 2.2 percent. The Minneapolis-based food company said that it had an extraordinary gain and unusually high earnings in the preceding year's first fiscal quarter.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, noon. The Expos are making a last-ditch effort to get back into the pennant race.

title: Ex-G.I. and Filipino Arrested On Explosion in Manila Hilton
description: A former United States Army sergeant and his Filipino uncle have been arrested on charges of illegal possession of explosives and are being investigated for links to a reported anti-Government plot, the authorities said today.

title: Long-term Disease And Liability
description: Does a law limiting a company's liability to a three-year period apply in cases involving a disease that may take 25 years to develop? No, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said in a recent decision. The issue was asbestos and the prinicipal defendent was the Manville Corporation, the manufacturer that recently filed for bankruptcy on the ground that it faces about 17,500 of these product liability suits. The decision, which was only a minor factor in the company's declaration of bankruptcy, came in a case that went like this:

title: Interest Rates Drop Modestly
description: Interest rates fell and prices rose modestly for most maturities yesterday as market participants said there was good demand for this week's heavy schedule of Treasury offerings.

title: ONE MAN'S GUIDE TO VISITING THE COLISEUM SHOW
description: COMPUTER shows used to be synonymous with either three-piecesuited professionals milling through the 100,000-plus throngs of the big-business National Computer Convention or denim-sheathed technofreaks whooping it up in the carnival-like atmosphere of the West Coast Computer Faire. Now the attendants are as likely to include Mr. and Mrs. America, the drycleaner down the block, the parents of high school students and the students themselves - for computing, while not yet Everyman's game, has established a beachhead in our personal lives.

title: SCHOOL FOR WARRIORS
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Cosmos
description: The strange visitor got sprinkled with champagne like everyone else in the champions' locker room after the Cosmos' Soccer Bowl victory Saturday night in San Diego, even though most of the players didn't know who he was until later. The alien in their midst, wearing a bewildered expression and a navy-blue Cosmos sweatshirt, was Steven Spielberg, the creator of ''E.T., The Extraterrestrial,'' as well as other major films.

title: ROZELLE THREAT DENIED
description: Dan Rooney, the president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, charged at a Senate hearing today that a member of the Los Angeles City Council lied when he testified last week that the National Football League's owners had initially approved and then rejected a compromise settlement in the Oakland Raider case.

title: Riggs Receivables
description: The Riggs National Bank said it would sell the majority of the accounts receivable of its subsidiary, Central Charge Service, to Citicorp. It said the transaction would result in an after-tax loss of about $3.8 million for the current year. However, it anticipates eventual enhanced profitability as a result of the deal.

title: AUTHOR OF 'WHITE HOTEL' CRITICIZED ON NEW WORK
description: A LITERARY dispute has broken out between Simon Karlinsky, professor of Slavic languages and literatures at the University of California at Berkley, and D.M. Thomas, the author of the bestselling novel ''The White Hotel.'' Professor Karlinsky contends that Mr. Thomas, rather than having translated a collection of poems by Alexander Pushkin from the original Russian, adapted much of the book from two earlier volumes of Pushkin translations into English. Mr. Thomas replies that ''the charge is a gross travesty.''

title: Chinese Calculators
description: The Beijing Computer Industry Corporation has started production of compact electronic calculators with Japanese technical assistance, Sanyo Electric Company Ltd. said today.

title: Bernard Mitchell Dies at 48; Ex-President of Advent Corp.
description: Bernard Mitchell, former vice chairman, president and chief operating officer of Advent Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., died of cancer last Saturday at his home in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. He was 48 years old.

title: DAVID JUSTIN
description: David Justin, an attorney who practiced criminal law in the Bronx for more than 50 years, died last Thursday at Montefiore Hospital after an illness of several months.

title: CITY AREA'S HOSPITALS URGED TO ALLOCATE BEDS IN WARTIME
description: The Department of Defense asked hospitals in the New York area yesterday to allocate a percentage of their beds to the care of American military casualties in the event of a conventional, nonnuclear war overseas.

title: LEHRMAN URGES STATE SALES TAX CUT
description: In the final debate of the campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor, Lewis E. Lehrman yesterday coupled his past pledges of a state income tax reduction with a new proposal for a reduction in the 4 percent state sales tax.

title: Hartford Seeks Stake in WFS
description: The Hartford Insurance Group of Hartford said it would buy a 25 percent equity interest in the WFS Financial Corporation of Richmond, a holding company whose principal subsidiary, Wheat First Securities Inc., is one of the largest investment banking and brokerage companies in the South.

title: Furry Detectives Retired
description: Drug smugglers at Canadian prisons and airports were becoming a problem. The authorities considered training dogs to sniff out the drugs as the prisoners or passengers walked by.

title: Dusty Aluminum Sky
description: Each time a space shuttle is launched, its booster rockets leave behind in the atmosphere about 150 tons of aluminum oxide particles. Four atmospheric scientists have calculated that the projected schedule of space shuttle flights could increase by tenfold the stratospheric abundance of particles.

title: STRUGGLE FOR A FRONTIER
description: Out on the suburban frontier, at the cutting edge of the bulldozer's blade, residents of this centuriesold farming community are beginning to resist the steady advance, over every hill and dale, of condominium complexes and of the attitude many of the people moving into them hold toward farmers.

title: Juan Corona and Juror Fall Ill And Are Taken to Hospitals
description: Juan Corona and one of the jurors in his retrial on charges of killing 25 migrant workers fell ill and were taken to hospitals today.

title: U.S. to Intervene in Suits On Chicago Voting Areas
description: A Federal district judge today allowed the Justice Department to intervene in suits charging that Chicago drew up political boundaries within the city to discriminate against minority groups.

title: BENDIX SEEKS TO BLOCK MARIETTA BID
description: The Bendix Corporation, announcing yesterday that it had purchased some 70 percent of the Martin Marietta Corporation's stock for at least $1.2 billion in cash, will go into the Federal District Court in Baltimore today in an attempt to enjoin Marietta from trying to take over Bendix.

title: Credentials of Witness In Rape Trial Doubted
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that it was investigating whether a chemist who testified as an expert witness in a rape trial had lied about his credentials.

title: Thrift Unit Links
description: Savings and loan associations in New York, South Dakota and Louisiana were given Government permission to merge with other institutions in their states, bringing to 34 the number of mergers assisted so far this year by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. In the largest of the new combinations, the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester was given permission to acquire the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York City, giving First Federal of Rochester more than $4 billion in assets.

title: SCHWEIKER ASSAILS CURB ON MEDICARE
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that he would resist proposals from the Office of Management and Budget to make elderly people demonstrate financial need as a condition of receiving Medicare benefits.

title: Avco Net Drops 14.3%
description: The Avco Corporation, a diversifed consumer finance, insurance and manufacturig company, said yesterday that its net income in the fiscal third quarter of 1982 ended Aug. 31 dropped 14.3 percent, to $22 million, or 98 cents a share, from $25.7 million, or $1.16 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased 10.3 percent, to $636.2 million, from $576.8 million.

title: Air Florida Accord
description: Air Florida said it had reached agreement in principle with its major lenders to provide additional working capital based on a plan that shows the company regaining profitability by the first quarter of 1983. Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, president of the airline, said the agreements provide for advances of approximately $6.8 million to satisfy payments on guaranteed debt and deferral of $9.2 million in lease payments for its five Boeing 727-200 aircraft.

title: IC Realigns Management
description: IC Industries of Chicago announced a management reorganization yesterday in which Robert F. Schnoes, president and chief operating officer, was named vice chairman.

title: WITH ELECTION DAY LOOMING, 'JITTERS' FILL THE HALLS
description: ''Everybody's got the jitters. You can feel it in the air.'' ''Let's face it, nothing of substance is going to happen around here until after the election.'' ''No one knows who's going to be here next year and who's going to leave. The rumors are feeding on themselves. It's like Dodge City: Everyone's looking over his shoulder.''

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets to open 37th session at 3 P.M.

title: Running in Style
description: Rush hour in Manhattan has become a time when Nikes are stepped on by Adidas as often as Toyotas are sideswiped by Volkswagens.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is now urgent that specific arrangements for withdrawal of all foreign forces be agreed upon.

title: E.E.C. Joblessness Up
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community rose steeply last month, leaving 9.6 percent of the active population out of work, up from 8 percent a year ago.

title: 'BALONEY' SANDWICH AND PLAYERS STRIKE
description: High in his Park Avenue office yesterday, Pete Rozelle sent out for lunch because he wanted to stay near the telephone. ''I'll have a vanilla malted,'' he said, ''and a bologna sandwich.'' That's bologna as in baloney. You didn't have to be Sigmund Freud to think that the commissioner's choice may have been inspired subconsciously by the unanimous vote to strike today that the executive committee of the National Football League Players Association was about to take at the Halloran House hotel a few blocks away.

title: Loss of Pro Football A Worry to Advertisers
description: While the TV networks were sweating out the outcome of labor negotiations with the National Football League, so were scores of major advertisers who know that professional football is absolutely the best way to reach a mass male audience.

title: The Horror, and the Shame
description: There are Lebanese precedents for the barbarity in Beirut last weekend. But there are no Israeli precedents for, at the very least, the negligence and ignorance that permitted mass slaughter of Palestinians whom Israel had undertaken to protect. In the face of such horror, who speaks for Israel?

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $160,000...C-After an extraordinary credit of $257,000

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS WIN, TAKE OVER FIRST

title: Hanna Acquisition
description: The Hanna Mining Company announced in Cleveland that it was considering purchasing additional common stock of the Midland Southwest Corporation of Midland, Tex. Hanna, which now owns 49 percent of Midland's 4.5 million shares, said it had no present plans to seek additional representation on Midland's board - it now has two of the 10 seats - although the purchases, which could be either private or open market transactions, could take its stake above 50 percent.

title: KENNEDY CALLS FOR NEW U.S. INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today told delegates to the United Steelworkers of America convention that the country must create an industrial policy to sustain its basic industries.

title: PRAYER FILIBUSTER WINS SENATE TEST
description: The Senate rebuffed President Reagan's repeated appeals today and refused to halt a filibuster against legislation that would permit organized prayer in public schools.

title: Basques Bomb Banks In 3 Spanish Towns
description: Basque guerrillas set off bombs today in front of six banks that they said had refused to pay ''revolutionary taxes.''

title: COMPOSER, WRITER AND LIBERAL
description: Samuel L.M. Barlow, a composer, writer and liberal activist of the 30's and 40's, died Sunday at the Springfield Retirement Residence in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 90 years old.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1982
description: International A return of peacekeepers to Beirut to help the Lebanese Government maintain order and prevent further killings has been agreed on by the United States, France and Italy, President Reagan announced. A senior State Department official said Israel must approve the reintroduction of the three-nation peace force and agree to pull back its forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) Evidence of Israeli knowledge that Palestinians were being killed in Beirut emerged in Jerusalem. The evidence indicated that senior Israeli military commanders and Government officials apparently knew about the murders 24 to 36 hours before the Israeli Army acted to halt them. The massacre has prompted widespread grief and outrage in Israel. (A1:3-5.)

title: CONOCO PLANS AN ASSET SALE
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plans to sell interests in 29 domestic oil and gas fields owned by Conoco Inc., its oil subsidiary, to the Petro-Lewis Corporation for $772 million, according to an agreement in principle announced yesterday.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1982; The Economy
description: The economy will grow at an annual rate of just 1.5 percent in the third quarter, according to a preliminary figure for the gross national product, Government sources said. The 1.5 percent figure, known as the ''flash'' number, is slightly higher than some economists have been forecasting. (Page D1.)

title: THE HUMAN FACTOR
description: After so much killing, so many arguments, the massacre in Beirut forces us back to the human factor. Cold, deliberate murder is a human trait. Outrage is another.

title: GEMS AND ESTEE LAUDER
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center first opened to a parade of silks, diamonds and big names, the ebullient Estee Lauder of the cosmetics empire had what could be described as a tiara crisis. Her ruby and diamond tiara clashed with the turquoise dress she had selected for the occasion and, after thinking the matter through, she switched to a gold and diamond crown suitable for a queen.

title: Haimovsky's Program At 92d St. Y Postponed
description: Because of a foot injury, the Moscow-born pianist Gregory Haimovsky has had to postpone his all-Debussy program scheduled for tomorrow night at the 92d Street Y.

title: RISE OF 1.5% ESTIMATED FOR G.N.P.
description: The nation's economy is expected to grow at a 1.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter, according to the first preliminary estimate for the period's gross national product, Government sources said today.

title: Envoy for Gambia Named
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Sharon E. Ahmad, a career Foreign Service officer, to be Ambassador to Gambia. If confirmed by the Senate, Mrs. Ahmad, 48 years old, will replace Larry G. Piper.

title: MODERN LIVING; Voices
description: Once upon a time, all Americans lived in a world where it was only necessary to pick up the phone and mention a few digits to the lady who said ''Number, please'' to be connected with the outside world.

title: FOR PALME, SOME THORNS ON THE ROSES
description: Olof Palme sat in his spartan office in Sweden's Parliament Building this evening, surrounded by the trophies of triumph -vases of red roses, the symbol of his Social Democratic Party, victor in Sunday's general election.

title: Winter on the Rocks
description: It is going to be a cold winter, meteorologists say, because billions of tiny parasols - drops of sulfuric acid released by volcanic eruptions - are shielding the Earth from the Sun ... because the jet stream forgot to head south and disappear last summer ... because sunspot activity is low, and that kind of solar laziness tends to herald a modest ice age ... because frigid water in the Northern Pacific says something about frigid winds in the northern United States ... because Caleb Weatherbee of the Farmer's Almanac says so.

title: Strike Could Have Wide-Ranging Effect
description: The National Football League's player strike is likely to have an immediate impact, extending from the highest levels of American banking to the local unemployment office, and from the treasuries of great cities to the neighborhood bookmaker.

title: NETWORKS PLAN FOOTBALL 'SUBS'
description: The three commercial television networks have prepared different plans to deal with yesterday's announcement of a pro football strike. NBC, believing that live football events are more attractive than reruns, will televise regular-season games of the Canadian Football League this weekend if no N.F.L. games are played.

title: BUS DEREGULATION IS SIGNED INTO LAW
description: President Reagan signed legislation today freeing the intercity bus industry from many regulations governing routes and fares.

title: Playboy Trade Account
description: Playboy magazine confirmed yesterday that it was bringing its trade advertising account, which had been at Epstein Raboy Advertising since December 1976, back in-house. Billings have been in the $1 million area. Scali, McCabe Sloves will continue to do the circulation promotion through the magazine's Chicago office.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Practical Politics'

title: New Mitsubishi Chips
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it had started mass production of 64K dynamic random access memory chips with an access time of 100 nanoseconds. (A nanosecond is a billionth of a second.) Shipment to overseas cutomers will begin in January.

title: UNSEEN WORLD OF VIOLENT STORMS FOUND ON OCEAN BOTTOM
description: THE conventional image of the lower regions of the deep sea that covers more than half the earth is of a stagnant realm steeped in darkness, through which a thin rain of sediment sifts gently down to the bottom. That picture is now being radically altered as the result of an arsenal of new devices for making prolonged and detailed observations far below the oceans' surface.

title: NEW FOCUS ON EMOTIONS OF CHILD IN HOSPITAL
description: YEAR-OLD Alice, a cancer patient at Minneapolis Children's Health Center, was taking her dolls for a ride in a wagon. ''Where's everyone going?'' she was asked by a child life specialist. ''Just for a ride,'' Alice replied. ''But my dolls are sad because they'll never get to go home.''

title: Printer At Bowne Accused
description: A printer with Bowne & Company, the big financial printer, was charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with socalled insider trading of Evans-Aristocrat Industries shares. Acting quickly, United States District Judge Charles L. Brieant scheduled a hearing for Sept.28 on the complaint.

title: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Included income from discontinued operations of $218,000 for the qr and $3,260,000 for the 6 mos, and a tax charge of $1,000 for the qr and a credit of $1,501,000 for the 6 mos...C-Included income from discontinued operations of $32,000 for the qr and $104,000 for the 6 mos and an extraordinary tax credit of $190,000 for the qr and 6 mos

title: P.L.O. HEARS DETAILS OF MASSACRE AND VOWS GREATER STRUGGLE
description: The 47-member executive council of the Palestine Liberation Organization, after hearing what it called ''detailed reports'' on the massacre of civilians in Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut, vowed today to ''intensify its armed struggle in the occupied Palestinian and Arab territories.''

title: Al Roth, 68, Was Contender For Lightweight Boxing Title
description: Al Roth, onetime contender for the world lightweight boxing title, died in Oakland, Calif., last Thursday at the age of 68. Mr. Roth, who lived in the Bronx during his boxing career, became a professional in 1931 and had 92 bouts before retiring in 1942. Only 5 feet 4 inches tall, he was a popular, scrappy performer who appeared regularly in Madison Square Garden and other arenas.

title: 4 SEEK PRESIDENCY OF AUTO WORKERS
description: The campaign to succeed Douglas A. Fraser as president of the 1.2 million-member United Automobile Workers began today with four candidates seeking the post.

title: Tape Release Protested
description: An attorney for Mercury Morris, the former Miami Dolphins' running back, who faces trial Nov.1 in Miami on charges of trafficking in cocaine and possessing the drug, has chastized prosecutors for making public several taped conversations in which Morris reportedly acted as a middleman in the cocaine deal.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: FASHIONS that seem impenetrably mysterious when they first appear o ften become remarkably lucid in terms of social change after a d ecent passage of time. The flapper's bobbed hair and boyish clothes w ere the result of the women's revolution in the early part of this c entury. Christian Dior's extravagantly romantic New Look in 1947, w ith its wasp waistlines and petticoated skirts, was a return to f emininity after the austerity of World War II, and Andre C ourreges's short white shifts in 1963 coincided with the opening of t he space age.

title: Sony Profit Falls 32.5%
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter profit tumbled 32.5 percent from a year earlier despite a 19 percent sales gain. Profit fell to $42.3 million in the quarter ended July 31, while sales rose to $1.1 billion, given a currency translation rate of 260 Japanese yen to the dollar. For the first three quarters, sales rose 11 percent, to $3.3 billion, but net fell 14.7 percent, to $166.7 million.

title: EVIDENCE SUGGESTS ISRAELIS WERE AWARE OF KILLINGS
description: Evidence emerged today that senior Israeli military commanders and Government officials knew that Palestinians were being killed in Beirut refugee camps as early as Friday morning, apparently 24 to 36 hours before the Israeli Army acted to stop the deaths.

title: Chess Guillermo Garcia of Cuba Leads Moscow Interzonal
description: The Cuban grandmaster Guillermo Garcia led the third Interzonal Tournament, in Moscow - the second stage of qualifications to select a challenger for the world championship -with 6 1/2 points after nine rounds.

title: Income Up Only 0.3% In August
description: The personal income of Americans grew by only three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain since March, as factory pay dropped and Government benefits leveled off, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Monaco Palace Retracts Brake-Failure Story
description: The Monaco royal palace formally withdrew a statement tonight that Princess Grace's car crash was caused by brake failure and said that she suffered a stroke at the wheel. The statement, issued in the form of a communique, confirmed statements by doctors who treated the Princess and her daughter after the accident.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss...C-After a $71,000 extraordinary credit

title: Israeli Speaker Is Boycotted In Vienna Atom Agency Talks
description: Arab and African delegates to a nuclear conference, some wearing black mourning bands, walked out today when the head of the Israeli delegation stood to address the opening session.

title: Pabst Dissidents Cite New Support
description: The long battle for control of the Pabst Brewing Company took a new turn yesterday as a group of dissident shareholders said it had obtained written consent from a majority of the company's shareholders for the removal of Pabst's directors.

title: SOME CITY VOTER CARDS LIST WRONG POLLS
description: A number of New York City residents - perhaps thousands - have received cards from the Board of Elections listing the wrong polling places, the board's executive director said yesterday.

title: Former Tiffany Agency Gets Black, Star & Frost
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein will not be wasting the expertise it gained in the area of class retailing as agency for Tiffany for 14 years.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
ARGENTINE ADMIRAL STIRS FEARS
description: An Argentine rear admiral was relieved as commander of a southern naval base today after he criticized his superiors' conduct in the Falkland war and said he no longer recognized their authority.

title: POLICE PLAN A UNIFORM FOR PREGNANT OFFICERS
description: The New York City Police Department has decided to commission a maternity police uniform because of the rising number of pregnant police officers.

title: A 'WRONG SIGNAL' FROM THE POPE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ADMINISTRATION'S 'DIRTY WATER AGENDA'
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Price Rein Seen for OPEC
description: Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, predicted today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would be unable to raise oil prices until 1985 and that increases from then until the end of the decade would do no more than keep pace with inflation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Before the Festival, Controlled Frenzy

title: 32 OF THE INJURED IN MALAGA CRASH ARRIVE IN JERSEY
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Sept. 21 (AP) - Thirty-two people injured in the crash of a DC-10 jet at Malaga Airport in Spain Sept. 13 arrived here Monday night aboard an Air Force medical evacuation flight.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Point Makes History
description: Beth Bates became the first girl to score in a Kentucky high school football game when her Williamsburgh team defeated Pineville, 32-0, last weekend. After her first extra-point attempt was blocked, Miss Bates added the extra point that gave Williamsburgh a 30-0 advantage.

title: 150 PCB PROTESTERS ARRESTED
description: More than 150 demonstrators, including the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, were arrested today after they tried to block trucks from entering and leaving a PCB dump site in Warren County.

title: SSP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines filed a shelf registration with the S.E.C. for up to 2 million common shares; 33 million shares are now outstanding.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When I put birdseed or bread out on my lawn, it attracts grackles, red-winged blackbirds, cardinals and sparrows. Robins look on, but never take the food. Why not?

title: G.M.-Toyota Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation and Japan's Toyota Motor Company opened a new round of talks on the joint production of subcompact passenger cars in the United States, a Toyota spokesman said. G.M. and Toyota have been negotiating the joint venture since March. The talks focus on a Toyota-designed front-wheel-drive subcompact.

title: A ROOKIE QUARTERBACK IS TORN
description: BALTIMORE Mike Pagel, the rookie starting quarterback for the Colts, came into the team's training complex yesterday afternoon with a pain in his ankle, a crick in his neck and a load on his mind.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EXPERT CALLS FALLOUT PROBABLE CAUSE OF LEUKEMIA
description: Exposure to radioactive fallout produced by above-ground atomic testing in the Nevada desert was the probable cause of excess childhood leukemia deaths in southern Utah towns a generation ago, a cancer specialist testified here today.

title: WALKOUT SNARLS TRAVEL AND INDUSTRY
description: The nationwide effects of the railroad engineers strike began almost immediately yesterday as coal mines and an automobile assembly plant closed down and more than a quarter million commuters were forced to make alternate transportation plans.

title: TV: PROGRAM ON SHOOTING OF POPE
description: SUCH striking, tragic, ominous images flash before the screen during tonight's NBC News documentary about Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk who shot the Pope in May 1981, that it seems a shame to question the accompanying words.

title: CLUE TO SOVIET MILITARY SELF-EVALUATION
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: B-Included a gain of $17,650,000 from the sale of shrs in a Mexican affiliate

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S SPEECH ON SENDING MARINES INTO LEBANON
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech yesterday on the Lebanese crisis, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: THE MIDEAST MADNESS
description: Lebanon is a dramatic case of the madness that has struck virtually all Middle Eastern societies, Christian and Moslem, Arab and Israeli, Sunni and Shiite.

title: DEVELOPER ACCUSED OF ABUSING TENANTS HAS PERMIT REVOKED
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday revoked the special permit that it had granted a developer in Chinatown last year because, it said, the developer may have attempted to force tenants from its buildings.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY AND STAFF DOCTORS AGREE ON A PACT
description: The Carey administration and the union representing 16,500 professional employees of the State University of New York reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract. The state said the contract included guarantees for a clinical practice plan to limit the outside income of physicians on the faculty of the four state medical colleges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mysterious Approach To an Apartment Hunt

title: 750 NURSES STRIKE JERSEY HOSPITAL AS TALKS FAIL
description: Nurses at the St. Barnabas Medical Center here went on strike after all-night contract negotiations ended this morning without a settlement.

title: Si, Mas, Si, Mas
description: Say it ain't so, Roberto. Bob Arum has been on the phone with Roberto Duran, saying he wants to ''rehabilitate'' him and put him on yet another comeback trail with a fight in November.

title: No Headline
description: Reuters Manager Named

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CLOUDING MEN'S MINDS
description: Long before television, political campaigns had become - by design - infernal machines that sapped the air of reason and thought, anesthetizing the electorate against the discomfort of considering serious issues.

title: WHAT'S AT STAKE IN RAIL STRIKE
description: THE ISSUES: The demand by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers that its members continue to receive 15 percent more than the pay scales of the 12 other railroad operating unions, should those unions receive a raise in return for reductions in crew sizes.

title: DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE WITHDRAWS PROPOSED CHANGES IN GRADING OF BEEF
description: Proposed changes in standards for the voluntary grading of beef were withdrawn yesterday by the Agriculture Department. The proposals would have allowed leaner, younger beef into the top Prime and Choice grades by reducing the requirements for fat in the form of marbling, the streaks of fat distributed through the meat tissue, which many consider an essential feature for tenderness and flavor.

title: Money Fund Plan by Visa
description: Officials of Visa U.S.A., the nation's largest credit card company, today urged Federal regulators to approve their plan for a new money market mutual fund intended to channel dollars back to local communities.

title: Books Of The Times
description: JAMES JOYCE. New and Revised Edition. By Richard Ellmann. 887 pages. Illus- trated. Oxford. $35.

title: Fanning Released
description: Jim Fanning, the Montreal Expos manager, was released from the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Montreal yesterday after a weekend stay for observation of severe headaches.

title: UNDER TIGHT SECURITY, MARCOS VISITS NEW YORK
description: Under some of the tightest security that the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel has seen in its 51 years of housing heads of state, President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife arrived yesterday for a weeklong visit to the city.

title: 4 IN CONNECTICUT ARGUE ISSUES IN SENATE CONTEST
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Representative Toby Moffett, meeting in their first televised debate along with two other candidates for the United States Senate, clashed tonight on their voting records and philosophies in dealing with the country's economic problems.

title: DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: WHEN Princess Grace's doctors spoke out publicly, without the family's permission, to contradict the official statements on the cause of her accident and death, their version should have clarified the matter once and for all. But it did not, at least for many American doctors who have followed her case through news reports.

title: MASSACRE
description: The heads of 30 major Jewish-American organizations said yesterday that Israel should not be blamed for the mass slayings of Palestinians last weekend in Beirut.

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Bridge: Solution to Some Puzzles Baffles Even the Experts
description: Most single-dummy problems become much easier when all four hands are viewed. But this is not true of the famous deal shown in the diagram: The player who fails to find the right road to six spades, after the lead of the heart king, is often equally baffled when shown all four hands.

title: Mets, Yanks Rained Out
description: Both New York baseball teams were rained out last night. The Mets had been scheduled to start a two-game series against the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium.

title: High-Voltage Batons Sent to South Africa
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the the issuance of an export license last April for the sale of 2,500 high-voltage batons - similar to cattle prods - to the South African police was owing to ''administrative inadvertence.''

title: DOLE SEES FLAT-RATE TAX BILL UNLIKELY BEFORE 1985
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the taxwriting Finance Committee, said today that Congress was unlikely to consider so-called flat-tax proposals for a sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax before 1985.

title: Triangle Fights Stock Purchase
description: The Triangle Corporation, a tool maker in Stamford, Conn., filed a lawsuit yesterday, charging that two New York ''commodities speculators'' had violated the law in buying more than 25 percent of Triangle's shares.

title: HOUSING STRIKE IN BRONX CURBS TENANT SERVICES
description: Building service workers went on strike yesterday at apartment houses in the Bronx, leaving tenants to face difficulties ranging from closed laundry rooms and balky elevators to a lack of both garbage removal and hot water. No serious problems were reported immediately.

title: Dead Player Mourned
description: An autopsy on Arturo Brown, the Boston University basketball captain who died of a heart attack during a pickup game last week, revealed his heart was twice the normal size with scar tissue, according to Coach Rick Pitino. ''It was probably from birth,'' said Pitino, ''which meant he had had a problem before, but never knew he had it because of the shape he was in.

title: Head of Jim Wilson Bets On New Shopping Malls
description: In the moribund market for new shopping malls and in the face of sluggish retail sales, at least one developer is plunging fearlessly ahead. He is Jim Wilson, founder and president of Jim Wilson Associates, which operates 16 centers across the Sun Belt.

title: THEATER: 'THE LIBERATION OF SKOPJE'
description: THERE is no theatrical experience in New York right now that resembles the Zagreb Theater Company's production of ''The Liberation of Skopje.'' The play is not only performed outdoors - on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and Cathedral Parkway. - but it also requires the audience to follow the troupe by foot as the action advances through three different playing areas. And what a diverse troupe it is! In addition to containing some of Yugoslavia's most admired actors, this company boasts a gaggle of young children, a rock group, a white horse, a flock of pigeons and at least one bonafide Gypsy shoeshine boy.

title: Hein the Center Of 'Dream Team'
description: In 1931, there was no such thing as a college football-player draft. So an unheralded center named Mel Hein, whose career at Washington State was ending, took it upon himself to write letters to three National Football League teams, applying for a job.

title: The Great Society Lives
description: Blacks ''would be appreciably better off today,'' President Reagan recently told a meeting of the National Black Republican Council, ''if the Great Society had never been inaugurated.'' His idea was to justify Reaganomics in the eyes of massively disaffected black voters. They are not likely to be so easily fooled.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., has named to vice president Richard C. Gozon, president of the Paper Products Group; Edward Jay Phillips, president of the Wine and Spirits Group; John Sellors Jr., president of the Specialty Manufacturers Group, and George R. Shelley, president of the Foodservice Equipment Group.

title: HEALTH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss included losses from discontinued operations of $13,624,000 for the qr and $19,110,000 for the 6 mos

title: NEIL WILL TAKE KLECKO'S SPOT
description: The business of pro football went on as usual at the Jets' training center today. The medical staff reported on Joe Klecko's knee operation; Coach Walt Michaels pondered the choice of a replacement for Stan Waldemore, the starting left guard, and the players went through the usual easy Monday practice.

title: REP. ADDABBO IN STIFF PRIMARY FIGHT IN REDRAWN QUEENS DISTRICT
description: The year John F. Kennedy was elected President, voters in the southeastern corner of Queens sent Joseph P. Addabbo to Congress. Every two years since, they have sent him back.

title: Bache Halsey Account To Kenyon & Eckhardt
description: As promised, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields came to a decision yesterday - Kenyon & Eckhardt will be its new agency. The $5 million account has been serviced by McCann-Erickson.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
N.F.L. PLAYERS START A STRIKE AS CONTRACT IMPASSE HOLDS
description: The first in-season strike in the National Football League's 63 years was called late yesterday afternoon by the N.F.L. Players Association. It was scheduled to begin after last night's game between the New York Giants and the Green Bay Packers.

title: EGYPT CALLS HOME ITS ENVOY TO SHOW ANGER WITH ISRAEL
description: Egypt abruptly summoned its Ambassador in Israel back to Cairo today in a move that a Foreign Ministry spokesman said was ''an expression of resentment'' over the massacre of Palestinian civilians in West Beirut.

title: Lazarus Chairman Is New Petrie Chief
description: In one of retailing's most unexpected management appointments this year, Michael J. Boyle, the 38-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Lazarus department stores of Columbus, Ohio, yesterday was named president and chief executive of the Petrie Stores Corporation, the retailer with 870 women's apparel shops.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Negotiators in Michigan Try to End School Strike
description: By The Associated Press The state of Michigan called negotiators into session yesterday in Detroit for a ''last-ditch effort'' at getting 11,000 teachers back to work.

title: OFFSHORE WASTE STUDY BEGUN
description: Scientists set sail today aboard a converted Navy gunboat to determine whether a former offshore nuclear waste dumping site poses any danger to humans.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income includes tax credits of $39,000

title: Publisher of Avenue Diversifies Into Posters
description: Judith Price, publisher of the highly successful, six-year-old Avenue, a slick, free magazine for dwellers at exclusive addresses mostly in New York, is broadening her horizons from magazines to advertising out-of-home, while carefully considering the electronic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bank's Employees Join the Longshoremen

title: Editor Vows to Refuse To Reveal His Sources
description: A newspaper editor said today that he would go to jail rather than tell who did or did not provide him with a deposition in a murder case.

title: Betting on Horse Races Is Issue in Oklahoma
description: Voters are to decide Tuesday whether to make Oklahoma the 32nd state to legalize horse race track gambling.

title: I.B.M. Suit Delay
description: A hearing on the International Business Machines Corporation suit against three former employees charged with divulging trade secrets, scheduled for yesterday, was adjourned until Oct. 20. A temporary restraining order preventing the employees from disclosing I.B.M. confidential information remains in effect until then.

title: COMPUTER GOES TO COLLEGE
description: IN the old clean-cut Pat-Boone-Annette-Funicello days of yore, the traditional high-school-graduation, off-to-college present was a portable typewriter. In the more precocious families, these goodgrade-getters were often doled out as early as confirmation or bar mitzvah time. Whichever the case, along with the records, tennis racquets, posters and other de rigueur student paraphernalia, the typewriters arrived in a steady stream as the September trunks and boxes flooded into the freshman dormitory rooms.

title: LINGERING FEARS HURT DAIRY INDUSTRY ON OAHU
description: The dairy industry on the island of Oahu has lost a quarter of its market and the confidence of 40 percent of its customers since milk was found to be tainted last winter with excessive levels of a hazardous chemical.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: U.S. dollar amounts are translated at the rate of 260 yen to $1.00

title: READY FOR A COLD WINTER: CLOTH COATS WITH STYLE
description: Calvin Klein's best-selling winter coats all have button-in linings. Geoffrey Beene topped a plaid wool coat with a polyurethane raincoat that can also be worn separately. It became one of his most popular numbers in the first coat collection he designed for Gallant.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Strike at a Glance
description: ISSUES: The members of the N.F.L. Players Association contend that their average salaries lag too far behind revenues produced by the league's national television contracts and the rising ticket prices charged by the 28 clubs. The union says the average player salary in 1981 was $83,811.

title: DOES 6TH SENSE FIND WATER, OR HEAT?
description: It rained here for most of the past week, but that was no surprise. They held the annual dowsers' convention anyway.

title: MISSION OF MARINES WILL DIFFER FROM PREVIOUS TASK IN BEIRUT
description: If the United States Marines go back into Lebanon as proposed by President Reagan today, they will be charged with helping to restore order and with keeping hostile factions separated, according to military officers here.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
BRIEFING
description: Conflict of Interest

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PRESIDENT URGING CONGRESS TO END 2-DAY RAIL STRIKE
description: President Reagan asked Congress today to enact emergency legislation to end the two-day strike by 26,000 locomotive engineers that has curtailed rail freight and passenger service across much of the country.

title: A $30,000 CONFERENCE CALL AT JUSTICE
description: The Justice Department spent $30,000 last week to reach out and touch a few of its own in a telephone conference call with United States attorneys in the South.

title: TURMOIL CONTINUES AT BRINK'S HEARING
description: Turmoil continued to swirl through the preliminary hearings of the Brink's murder and robbery trial today. At one point, four of the six defendants, shouting ''Long live Palestine,'' were escorted from the courtroom in the Rockland County Courthouse.

title: Arab League to Meet Today On Massacre of Palestinians
description: Foreign ministers of the Arab League nations open an emergency meeting here Tuesday to consider joint Arab action in the aftermath of the Beirut massacre.

title: OPERA: 'ROSENKAVALIER' AT THE MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera likes to begin its season with an admired older production, preferrably one grand enough in scale and volume to impress or even intimidate an opening-night audience. The choice for last night's first performance was ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' in the Nathaniel Merrill-Robert O'Hearn production that has worn so well since its first appearance in 1969.

title: KISSINGER BACKS PIPELINE SANCTIONS
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger lashed out today at what he called the ''self-righteous'' reactions of allies in opposing the Reagan Administration's sanctions against companies supplying equipment for the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Net income after a tax credit of $67,000

title: CONTINENTAL COPPER & STEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June
description: B-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,681,000...C-Net income after a loss of $30,000 from discontinued operations

title: HONDURAS LOCKED IN STRUGGLE AFTER YEARS OF RELATIVE CALM
description: Honduras, which has managed to maintain a relative internal calm as leftist turmoil swept Central America, is now locked in a struggle of political and economic interests.

title: POTVIN NEARS CONTRACT
description: Bill Torrey sounded optimistic last night and indicated that Denis Potvin is close to signing with the Islanders again, ending his free agency.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: DETROIT (AL) - Aurelio Lopez, right-handed pitcher, resigned from team for personal reasons. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed one-year development contract with Chattanooga Lookouts of Class AA Southern League.

title: WIN-OR-LOSE GAMBLE IN 6th OVERTIME
description: F ourth down, 2 yards to go for a touchdown, final play of the game. Plenty of teams have faced that moment of decision in college football. But Rhode Island is the only one that faced it on the short end of a 55-52 score in the sixth overtime period after nearly four hours of play.

title: Art Will Be Offered At Central Park Show
description: Rain or shine, a host of paintings, drawings, sculpture, prints, etchings, silk-screen prints, photographs and crafts will be on show and for sale Saturday and Sunday at the season's final Central Park South Outdoor Art Exhibit. The display will stand on the park side of 59th Street, from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle between 11 A.M. and 6 P.M. Information: (914) 356-5322.

title: ANTITRUST FAIRNESS MUST NOT BE DELAYED
description: To the Editor:

title: Modern Living; Revivals
description: The 60-year mystery of the Pulantien lotus seeds has been resolved. A Cornell botanist, David Priestley, has germinated samples provided by the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of the Late Edition yesterday, page D10 appeared twice because of a mechanical error and page B10 (Washington Talk) was omit- ted. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y.10036.

title: SENATORS TO CHECK HEALTH EFFECTS OF EARLY U.S. ATOMIC TESTS
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, chairman of the Committee on Veterans Affairs, agreed today to hold hearings next year to explore whether participants in early atomic weapons tests had suffered diseases brought on by their exposure to radiation.
