title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE BACKS MORATORIUM ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: Legislation imposing a two-year moratorium on dumping low-level nuclear wastes in the oceans was approved today on a voice vote in the House.

title: OPERA: 'ROSENKAVALIER'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera likes to begin its season with an admired older production, preferrably one grand enough in scale and volume to impress or even intimidate an opening-night audience. The choice for Monday night's first performance was ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' in the Nathaniel Merrill-Robert O'Hearn production that has worn so well since its first appearance in 1969.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at noon.

title: Getzler Firm Treats Ailing Companies
description: When Abraham E. Getzler knocks on the corporate door, he is often greeted like ''a carrier of the plague,'' to use his expression. For Mr. Getzler is usually there at the behest of a bank, insurance company or factor worried about the company's ability to pay its debts, and his job is to correct management's mistakes and try to save the company.

title: THROUGHOUT THE STATE
description: Following are the contested races in tomorrow's primary elections in New York State. Incumbent candidates are marked with an asterisk. DEMOCRATS U.S. SENATOR Melvin Klenetsky Daniel Patrick Moynihan* GOVERNOR Mario M. Cuomo Edward I. Koch LIEUT. GOVERNOR Alfred B. DelBello H. Carl McCall COMPTROLLER William B. Finneran Raymond F. Gallagher James H. Tully Jr. U.S. REPRESENTATIVE Nassau, Suffolk 3d District Robert J. Mrazek John O'Shea Queens County 6th District Joseph P. Addabbo* Simeon Golar Kings County 11th District Louis Hernandez Jack John Olivero Edolphus Towns 12th District Vander L. Beatty Major Owens Kings and Richmond 14th District Kevin Sheehy Leo C. Zeferetti* New York County 15th District Betty G. Lall George T. McDonald Bronx County 18th District Ismael Betancourt Jr.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: FOR more years than she cares to remember, Cynthia Friedland has been searching for a ''tall, fat mirror.'' Miss Friedland isn't talking about dimensions; what she wants is a mirror that won't make her look like what she is - a short, skinny person who is in danger of being twirled around in the air whenever the wind feels particularly energetic.

title: Honeywell Shuffles Computer Officers
description: Honeywell Inc. has replaced the president of its large information systems sector, which is responsible for the company's major line of computer products.

title: MRS. THATCHER IN PEKING TODAY FOR TALKS
description: Having re-established sovereignty in one of Britain's poorest colonies, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher flies to Peking Wednesday to try to prolong sovereignty in the richest.

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS DEFEAT ROYALS

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The casino in Police Headquarters is at the very back of a large office, behind the institutional file cabinets and the drab desks. There is a roulette wheel with a glossy hardwood rim, and a dice table with hand-carved racks for chips, red leatherette trim, and a playing surface of felt as green as a mansion's lawns, both mementos of a raid several years ago at an illegal casino in what was once Al Jolson's old home in Queens.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Matching the Lonely To Share Empty Houses

title: DIVERSITY OF WINE COURSES, FOR BEGINNER AND EXPERT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eunice Fried is a wine writer based in New York. By EUNICE FRIED

title: Letter: On Education Policy Tuition Credits Are No Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Comings and Goings
description: A special committee of six National Basketball Association owners, formed to study the operations of the San Diego franchise, has voted unanimously to recommend that the league try to remove Donald T. Sterling as owner. The committee found Sterling in violation of the league's constitution and bylaws, but did not elaborate. ... The University of Houston's football coach, Bill Yeoman, suspended Olen Green, a starting tight end, and Bernard Giddings, a substitute split end, for the remainder of the season.

title: MRS. HORACE HAVEMEYER
description: Doris Dick Havemeyer, wife of the late Horace Havemeyer, sugar company executive, yachtsman and patron of the arts, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92 years old.

title: Teachers in Waldwick Striking Three Schools
description: Teachers went on strike at all three schools in Waldwick, N.J., yesterday, while striking teachers in the Deer Park Union Free School District on Long Island suspended their walkout, which began last Friday.

title: Regan Urges A 'Watch Rate'
description: Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan proposed yesterday that the prime lending rate - the most widely watched measurement of the nation's interest rates - be replaced by a new gauge.

title: Motion Is Denied
description: A Dade County circuit court judge denied a defense motion to suppress the release of tapes in which Mercury Morris, a former Miami Dolphins running back, is supposed to be heard discussing an apparent drug deal. Judge Ellen M. Gable rejected arguments that release of the tapes to reporters would create prejudicial pretrial publicity. Morris is scheduled to go on trial on charges of cocaine trafficking Nov.1, in Miami.

title: SIHANOUK, CHAMPAGNE IN HAND, PLANS HIS FUTURE
description: Why would a royal exile with a taste for Western luxury choose to live in two austere Communist societies like China and North Korea?

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK RICHMOND'S SEAT IN A 3-WAY RACE
description: While battle lines were late in forming in the 11th Congressional District after former Representative Frederick W. Richmond was forced to withdraw his bid for re-election, Edolphus Towns succeeded in gaining the Democratic organization's support for the primary tomorrow.

title: New Bid for Talks Made In Detroit School Strike
description: By The Associated Press A fact-finder called both sides back for informal talks yesterday in an effort to end Detroit's teacher strike.

title: LAST CABLE CAR RIDES MARK 2-YEAR CLOSING
description: The city's cable cars began their last trips today before closing for 20 months while their propulsion system is totally rebuilt. A major question had been whether the system would hang together until the scheduled closing date.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Whatever It Is, It's Working
description: L ast year, 19 medallion-taxi drivers lost their lives in New York, starting with Juan Almonte on Jan. 20 and ending with Gilbert Williams on Dec. 29. September is well along and not one driver of a yellow cab has been killed in 1982.

title: FIRST WITNESS SCHEDULED
description: After six and a half days of intensive screening of 94 prospective jurors, a panel of 11 women and five men was sworn in late this afternoon in the conspiracy and misconduct trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris. Opening statements are scheduled Wednesday morning.

title: Ford Price Cuts
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was lowering base prices of its 1983 model cars by an average of three-tenths of 1 percent, or $26, from 1982 models, but it was raising sticker prices including the most commonly chosen options by an average of four-tenths of 1 percent, or $39. The approximate price reductions, concentrated in these lines, are: Continental ($2,000), Lynx and Escort ($400), and EXP and LN7 ($300 to $700).

title: No Headline
description: LAWMAKER LOSES RUNOFF IN GEORGIA

title: Le Monde, Paris
description: King Hussein said Monday that the time had come to start discussions with the Palestine Liberation Organization on a possible federation between the West Bank and Jordan, as envisaged in President Reagan's peace plan.

title: U.S. REACHES ACCORD ON TEAMSTER FUND
description: The Labor Department and the teamsters' union's Central States pension fund said today they had agreed to new Federal controls over the scandal-plagued $3.5 billion fund. They called the accord a ''landmark agreement.''

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES HOW HE CAUGHT BRINK'S SUSPECTS
description: An off-duty correction officer described today how he captured Kathy Boudin at a roadblock after last year's Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County, and how she told him that others did the shooting.

title: YET ANOTHER TOMORROW
description: I was startled recently to discover that Lewis Lehrman is not the governor of New York. He'd been on television so long talking about New York politics that I had gradually come to think of him as governor.

title: Southern Executives Get a New Magazine
description: The perfect Christmas gift for your favorite union bargaining agent stationed in the sunny South might easily be Sunbelt Executive, a magazine that will begin publication next January.

title: Careers; Accounting Job Market Changing
description: IN 1959-60 there were 21,183 college graduates who received a bachelor's degree with a major in accounting, according to the Government. In 1979-80, the latest school year for which figures are available, the total had more than doubled, to 42,712.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have heard of a Southern specialty called crackling bread. A friend tells me it is a form of cornbread, but that doesn't tell me what cracklings are. Do you know?

title: CONGRESS SHOCKED AT REFUSAL OF ISRAEL TO HAVE AN INQUIRY
description: The Israeli Cabinet's decision against a special inquiry into the Beirut massacre came as a new shock here today, fueling Congressional criticism of the Begin Government and dimming prospects for proposed aid increases.

title: Tandy Purchase
description: The Tandy Corporation said it had agreed to buy the 50 percent interest in Texas Peripherals held by the Datapoint Corporation for a cash sum that it did not disclose. Texas Peripherals was formed in 1980 as a joint venture of Tandy and Datapoint to develop and make computer disk products. Manufacturing operations were established in Odessa, Tex.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atco Ltd. filed with the provincial securities regulators in Calgary, Alberta, for an offering of two million 11 1/2 percent cumulative redeemable convertible junior preferred shares at $25 a share through Richardson-Greenshields of Canada Ltd.

title: 1. A Game From England
description: Omar Sharif, Yehudi Menuhin and Donald Pleasence are hooked, and the word is that when she isn't bouncing wee Prince William on her royal knee, Queen Elizabeth has a go at it, too. ''It'' is Kensington, a board-with-chips game from England. It comes packaged like a record album and the players (anywhere from two to six) move the red and blue chips on the hexagonal board. The object is to gain control of all six points of the hexagon. Named after the gardens where it was devised (by Brian Taylor, a Welsh artist, and Peter Forbes, an architectural student), Kensington has caused something of a craze on its native soil, with close to 500,000 sales. It is now available in Dry Dock Country, in Bloomingdale's stationery department, for $10.

title: FOUR IN CONTEST FOR CAREY'S POST WIND UP DRIVES
description: Trading accusations of opportunism, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Koch yesterday held their final debate before Democratic voters nominate one of them for Governor.

title: G.M. to Idle 1,100
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will begin laying off 1,100 Buick division workers for about four months beginning Friday because of production cuts mandated by poor sales. The layoffs are not related to the rail strike, which has not affected Buick operations, a spokesman said. Workers will be called back no later than Jan. 31, and earlier if sales pick up.

title: WOOLWORTH BRITISH UNIT IS FOR SALE
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company disclosed yesterday that it is holding talks with a British merchant bank that is attempting to organize a group to purchase Woolworth's 52.6 percent in Britain's Woolworth chain.

title: Bethlehem Plants
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said a money-losing Los Angeles plant employing 1,100 is likely to be shut by the end of the year if a buyer is not found. It put the plant and a profitable one in Seattle up for sale as part of a retrenchment program but said the Seattle plant, which usually employs about 950, will remain open until a buyer is found.

title: THE UNRESOLVED ISSUE IN 'TAX EXEMPT RACISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUSANDS OF HONDURANS PROTEST TAKING OF HOSTAGES BY GUERRILLAS
description: Waving banners declaring their devotion to peace and liberty, thousands of Hondurans marched through the streets of this city today to protest the continued holding of 80 businessmen and three top Government officials by leftist guerrillas.

title: MIDDLE EAST: REVERBERATIONS OF A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Policy Yet On Refunds
description: Spokesmen for the Giants and the Jets said yesterday that their front offices had not set a policy on ticket refunds resulting from the player strike.

title: BENDIX MEETING POSTPONED
description: William M. Agee, chairman of the Bendix Corporation, and Thomas G. Pownall, president of the Martin Marietta Corporation, conferred for several hours last night in Bethesda, Md., Marietta's headquarters, sources close to both companies disclosed.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
NEWARK PONDERS PLIGHT OF ITS HOUSING PROJECTS
description: The people who live in the 12-story red-brick building at 62-64 Seventh Avenue here talk freely of its squalor and perils. But the briefing is unnecessary, for the specter of this place is such that those who visit for the first time shrink at the sight of it.

title: Director of Association Of Counties Resigns
description: The executive director of the National Association of Counties resigned today, saying he had been misled about a $2 million financial crisis.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Faces More Federal Charges
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, on charges of illegally exporting weapons that were reportedly turned over to a Libyan agent.

title: BRAZIL: REASSURING FOREIGN LENDERS
description: Brazilians have always been frustrated by the habit some foreigners have of confusing this vast country with others on the continent, but the lament has now taken on a particular urgency in the financial community.

title: Stake in Phoenix
description: The Phoenix Steel Corporation said that Creusot-Loire, the French steelmaker that owns 56 percent of Phoenix's common stock outstanding, had agreed to make a new equity investment in the company. It said the new investment, which is expected to be in the form of preferred stock, will total $25 million.

title: HABIB SEES FRENCH ON WAY TO BEIRUT
description: Philip C. Habib, the former special United States representative for the Middle East, who is en route to Beirut, met here today with President Francois Mitterrand to discuss the multinational force that is expected to arrive in the Lebanese capital by Thursday.

title: NO COURT BAR SEEN TO MARIETTA
description: Federal District Judge Joseph H. Young said today that he would probably not interfere with the Martin Marietta Corporation's plans to purchase a 50.3 percent controlling interest in the Bendix Corporation after midnight Wednesday at a price of nearly $900 million in cash.

title: Dutch Are Given Tough Austerity Budget
description: The Dutch Finance Minister presented a $57.8 billion austerity budget today that includes severe public spending cuts and a record deficit.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1982
description: International Israel agreed to the return of the three-nation peace force to Beirut as proposed by President Reagan. At a five-hour meeting, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet decided to accept the American, French and Italian peacekeeping force. But the ministers rejected a call by the parliamentary opposition to set up an independent commission of inquiry into the massacre of Palestinians by Christian militiamen. (Page A1, Column 6.) The new President-elect of Lebanon is Amin Gemayel, a 40-year-old Maronite Christian. He was elected by a nearly unanimous vote of Parliament in an unusual display of Christian and Moslem unity. Mr. Gemayel replaces his brother, Bashir, who was chosen by Parliament Aug. 23 and killed in a bomb explosion Sept. 14. (A1:4-5.)

title: 7% Fare Rise Is Sought By a Bus Line in Jersey
description: With its fleet of buses back on the road after a seven-week strike, DeCamp Bus Lines is now seeking a 7 percent fare increase on its commuter lines to New York City.

title: Judge Admonished
description: A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx was admonished yesterday by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for accepting cut-rate vacations set up by a man who often appeared before him and who regularly was appointed a receiver in Bronx real-estate foreclosure cases.

title: GIANTS FIND THEIR LOCKERS BARE... AND JETS' CAMP IS QUIET
description: The day after the Giants play, they usually straggle into their dressing room, watch game films and loosen aching muscles and joints. Today, the first day of the strike of National Football League players, it was different.

title: No Rush to Sign
description: With the National Basketball Association training camps scheduled to open in nine days, only three first-round draft choices have signed -Dominique Wilkins, No.3, Atlanta Hawks; David Thirdkill, No.15, Phoenix Suns, and Mark McNamara, No.22, Philadelphia 76ers.

title: LLOYD'S SHAKEN BY FUNDS CASE
description: Lloyd's of London, center of the international insurance trade, has been shaken by charges of misconduct that have led to the suspension of Ian Posgate, one of Britain's leading underwriters, and that involve $55 million in diverted funds.

title: SENATE APPROVES REAGAN PROPOSAL TO END RAIL STRIKE
description: The Senate, at President Reagan's request, adopted a resolution tonight directing locomotive engineers to end the three-day strike that has interrupted commuter, freight, and passenger services in most sections of the country.

title: Phone Venture
description: Three companies competing to supply Indianapolis with its first cellular telephone system agreed to finance, construct and operate the system jointly, possibly ending months of vying for position. They are Cellular Mobile Systems of Indiana Inc., the Midwest Mobile Phone Corporation and Westel, which is a joint venture of the FMI Financial Corporation, the Western Union Telegraph Company, the Mobile Communications Corporation of America and a group of Indianapolis investors.

title: Shedd's Campaign Spreads Nationwide
description: With the help of financial support from its parent company, Beatrice Foods, Shedd's Food Products of Louisville, Ky., has gone national with its previously regional brand of low-calorie, cholesterol-free margarine. On Oct. 25, it will begin dipping into a seven-figure advertising budget to inform the uninformed about the rhyming glories of Shedd's Spread.

title: LOWER PROFITS AND ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY THREATEN CORPORATE PHILANTHROPY
description: Difficult choices face thousands of companies that customarily begin deciding at this time of year how much financial help to give schools, hospitals and cultural or neighborhood groups.

title: Braniff Pensions
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers said he will hear trial testimony beginning Friday before deciding when two of Braniff Airways' employee pension plans will be shut down.

title: ARABS STRIKE TO PROTEST MASSACRE
description: Arabs in Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip staged strikes in schools and businesses today, stoned a bus and several police stations and burned tires on highways to protest the massacre of Palestinian Arabs in Beirut last week.

title: Alfred R. Bachrach, 82; Led Temple Emanu-El
description: Alfred R. Bachrach, former president of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York and a longtime leader in Jewish charitable and civic affairs, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MIDDLE EAST: REVERBERATIONS OF A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS BEATEN IN HOME DEBUT
description: On their opening night at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the New Jersey Devils produced mixed results.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: High-Quality Carryout

title: The Democrats and MITI-Minus
description: From the moment Ronald Reagan was elected, Democrats started asking themselves: What will be the new liberal agenda? For many Reagan critics, the answer has become steadily clearer: the old one. They feel rising passion about jobs for the unemployed, training for the unskilled and patches for the tattered social safety net.

title: Veitch Quits Calumet
description: After six years as trainer for Calumet Farm during which time he rebuilt that Lexington, Ky., stable into one of the premier racing operations in the nation, John Veitch resigned and was immediately replaced by Frank Whiteley, who recently became general manager of Calumet's racing stable. The 37-year-old Veitch, the youngest man ever to train for Calumet, developed the outstanding colt, Alydar, plus three filly Eclipse Award winners, Our Mims, Davona Dale and Before Dawn.

title: INQUIRY INTO VESCO CALLED A DISGRACE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee issued a report today charging that the Justice Department's undercover investigation of Robert L. Vesco and his links to Libya was ''a shame and a disgrace.''

title: DENIS POTVIN SIGNS MULTIYEAR CONTRACT
description: Denis Potvin, the New York Islanders' free-agent defenseman and captain, ended two years of tedious and frustrating negotiations this morning by signing a two-year contract with Bill Torrey, the club's president and general manager.

title: A PREVIEW OF THE DEMOCRATS' NEW COMMERCIALS
description: A series of six new anti-Reagan television commercials have been getting a lot of laughs in preview showings at the Democratic National Committee.

title: RATE DROP SENDS DOW UP BY 18.49
description: A late buying surge sparked by falling interest rates sent the stock market ahead in a spirited advance yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 18.49 points, to 934.79, its highest closing in more than a year. Trading was heavy.

title: Buffalo Will Be Goldome Bank in '83
description: The Buffalo Savings Bank, the second largest in the nation, announced yesterday that it will change its name early next year to the Goldome Bank. The name represents the gold dome on the bank's headquarters building in downtown Buffalo.

title: TV, Carried to Extremes
description: P erhaps it was inevitable that the so-called thunder boxes, those outsized radios on the streets, would give way to thunder and lightning.

title: Only One No. 6
description: When Rick Davis first signed with the Cosmos, in late 1977, he was an 18-year-old Californian who had admired Franz Beckenbauer. Before long, Davis, a midfielder, was playing in the same starting team with Beckenbauer and Davis's idolization of the West German star grew stronger.

title: Albus Gets 66 To Lead by 2
description: Jim Albus, the defender in the Izod Metropolitan Professional Golf Association championship, shot a 5-under-par 66 at the Century Country Club today and took the openingday lead in the 54-hole competition.

title: The Labor 'Blip' In the N.F.L.
description: D uring Monday night's Giants-Packers game, which was the National Football League's last picture show until further notice, the lights atop Giants Stadium went out twice. The power failure was attributed later to a ''blip in the main feeder'' of the electrical system.

title: Jail Population Up
description: For the first time in almost a decade, the population in New York City's jails has exceeded 10,000 inmates, Benjamin Ward, the Commissioner of Correction, said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Books: Food, Glamour
description: A FEAST MADE FOR LAUGHTER: A Memoir With Recipes. By Craig Claiborne. Doubleday. 414 pages. $17.95.

title: Testimony Completed In Hearing on Noguchi
description: Both sides claimed victory after testimony ended Monday in the Civil Service appeal hearing of Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi, who is fighting to be reinstated as the Los Angeles County Coroner.

title: A TOAST TO VALENTINO AND TO OPULENCE
description: THERE'S a game in Rome called Waiting for Valentino. During the week of couture showings in July and January, those who attend try to anticipate what Valentino is going to show on the last night of the presentations and plan their wardrobes carefully. The opening, on the Via Gregoriana near the Spanish Steps, has a festive feeling, with opulence on the runway and in the audience.

title: MIDDLE EAST: REVERBERATIONS OF A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL PARK SERVICE OFFICIAL
description: John A. Townsley, superintendent of Yellowstone National Park since 1975 and the recipient of many honors for his work in park administration, died of cancer Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Billings, Mont. He was 55 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Brooklyn School To Be Named for Wayne

title: British Printers' Strike Halts Publication of Today's Papers
description: Printers began a one-day strike at British newspapers today, halting production of Wednesday issues to back the pay demands of workers in the Government-owned Health Service.

title: YANKEES END SLIDE AT NINE
description: Just when it appeared that the Yankees would pull ahead of Cleveland in the battle for sixth place in the American league East, they pulled out a 6-2 victory over the Indians last night in the second game of a doubleheader and ended their losing streak at nine games.

title: What Goes Up, Goes Up Again
description: ''What's up'' you ask? ''Media costs.'' says the panel. The panelists, all agency experts, were looking ahead to next year on behalf of Marketing & Media Decisions as part of an annual exercise.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FEW of the avid cineastes who flock to the New York Film Festival this week will be aware that they have been spared hours of frustration, sitting through films that aren't really ready for a New York audience. Naturally, for every festival film shown, many other highly recommended but less successful efforts have been weeded out. Lewis Burke Frumkes, that indefatigable researcher, has penetrated the veil of festival secrecy and identified three of the films that didn't make it to Lincoln Center this year. Here is Mr. Frumkes's description of these classics manques: DINDIDINDIDIN SHANKAR WALLAH (Gone in a Flash) INDIA, 1980

title: CAROLINA NBC-TV OUTLET DROPS THE EVENING NEWS
description: After experiencing four years of heavy losses and low ratings for its news programs, television station WPCQ, Charlotte's NBC affiliate, has aired its last local and national evening newscasts. The industry believes it has become the first network affiliate in a major market in the country not to broadcast its network's early evening news programs.

title: Severance Pacts Halted at Burnup
description: Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, has won a temporary court order blocking 17 executives of Burnup & Sims Inc. from bailing out with hefty ''golden parachute'' severance agreements because of his move to control the company.

title: ICE SCULPTURE TO GRACE A BUFFET (BRIEFLY)
description: ''ABUFFET without an ice carving is not finished,'' Nino Ruzzier said the other day as he hacked away with a large chisel on a big block of ice. ''It looks like it's missing something.''

title: Location of Polls Available by Phone
description: Those uncertain about where to vote tomorrow can find out by t elephoning the New York City Board of Elections at 267-9800.

title: LAWFULLY UNDERINSURED
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE WARNS SCIENTISTS ABOUT EFFECT OF THEIR WORK
description: Pope John Paul II warned scientists today against the misuse of their research and discoveries against the interests of man.

title: JOHN J. MULROY
description: The Rev. John J. Mulroy, pastor of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Marietta, Ga., and chairman of the Religious Unity Commission of the Archdiocese of Atlanta, died Monday at West Paces Ferry Hospital in Atlanta.

title: XEROX TO ACQUIRE CRUM IN A $1.6 BILLION DEAL
description: In a move that surprised Wall Street, the Xerox Corporation yesterday announced an agreement to acquire Crum & Forster, a leading property and casualty insurer, for $1.6 billion in cash and stock.

title: THE TRAGEDY OF BEGIN
description: There is no point now in lecturing Menachem Begin of Israel or in calling for his resignation. Presumably he is not immortal, and it would be a mistake to confuse him with the state he merely represents. He is not important but the state of Israel is.

title: No Headline
description: Carlton Wins 21st, Stopping Cards, 5-2

title: Northrop Sale Is Welcomed
description: The Northrop Corporation today welcomed the Reagan Administration's approval of the first sale of Northrop's new F-5G Tigershark airplane.

title: Marine Bank Lists Loans
description: The Marine Midland Bank disclosed yesterday that it has $290 million in loans to Mexico and $140 million in loans to Argentina, two countries in financial difficulty.

title: A U.D.C. CANDIDATE WITHDRAWS
description: A Cincinnati economic development official who said Monday she had been offered the job of directing the New York State Urban Development Corporation's $1 billion Times Square redevelopment withdrew her name from consideration yesterday after agency officials said there had been a misunderstanding over whether an offer had actually been made.

title: NEW PEKING-MOSCOW TALKS MAY BE IN OFFING
description: As China lavishes hospitality on the visiting North Korean leader Kim Il Sung, rumors have been circulating here that fresh contacts with the Soviet Union may take place early next month.

title: REJECTS PANEL ON MASSACRE
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today to accept President Reagan's proposal to send the three-nation peacekeeping force back to Beirut. But it rejected a call by the parliamentary opposition to establish an independent commission of inquiry into the Beirut massacre.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times yesterday gave an in- correct schedule for Computer Show- case Expo, the exhibition at the New York Coliseum. It will take place tomorrow, Friday and Saturday.

title: Market Place; Liquid Assets At Tandycrafts
description: THREE top officials of the Tandy Corporation who migrated to Tandycrafts after the 1975 spinoff of that segment of the business are attempting to apply Tandy's retailing expertise to Tandycrafts.

title: Monsanto Offers Early Retirements
description: The Monsanto Company said it was offering early retirement incentives to about 1,900 salaried employees - most of those in the United States who are 55 and over and whose age plus years of service add up to 80 or more.

title: STAGE: SPORTS COMEDY 'THE GUYS IN THE TRUCK'
description: HOWARD REIFSNYDER'S new comedy, ''The Guys in the Truck,'' at the Sargent Theater, is a good-natured, behind-the-scenes look at the world of sports broadcasting. Although it traffics in theatrical cliches, including a predictable, goal-line moral victory for the play's hero, it is unstinting in its disrespect for the four horsemen of commercialism, hypocrisy, grandstanding and malingering. Sports fans - and even the occasional weekend watcher - should laugh at this insider's retort.

title: PRAYER FILIBUSTER IS SUSTAINED AGAIN
description: Supporters of legislation allowing officially sanctioned school prayer suffered an important defeat in a Senate vote today and opponents said it now appeared the conservative agenda of ''social issues'' had little chance of becoming law in this session of Congress.

title: Why Won't Brokers Pay 12?
description: On Capitol Hill, where program costs are rounded to the nearest billion, the issue hardly seems worth a second glance. The Reagan Administration is pressing for a small user fee on transactions in commodities ''futures,'' enough to offset the $23 million annual cost of regulating the futures markets. But commodity brokers don't want to pay, and the way they are resisting says a lot about political power in America, none of it nice.

title: Kenya Sentences 7 More in Uprising
description: A court-martial sentenced seven junior-ranked air force men today to prison terms ranging from 10 to 20 years for their roles in an unsuccessful coup on Aug. 1.

title: Tosco Holdings
description: Kenneth M. Good told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he may sell his 10.6 percent holding in the Tosco Corporation - 2,168,000 shares of common - and that he will continue his 18-month-old effort to gain control of Tosco. He said that he is seeking a third party to make a tender offer for the company and that he had retained Bear, Stears & Company to find such a party and to negotiate the sale of his stock to that party.

title: Aid to Fairview
description: Citicorp has agreed to give a 45-day extension, until Oct. 26, to an arm of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation to make an interest payment on an $84 million mortgage, a Citicorp spokesman said.

title: IF TV'S THE MEDIUM, TELL ME THE MESSAGE
description: I f your son goes to a college as far away as Middle America, it is possible to communicate with him by television set. A television set may be the only way to communicate with him, not counting certified checks, since he is otherwise forever engaged in the language lab, learning Chinese; or eating bacon and drinking beer while he listens to the sort of music Solzhenitsyn abominates; or skiing at midnight.

title: MIDDLE EAST: REVERBERATIONS OF A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: Lady Donaldson's Term
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Lady Donaldson, Sheriff of the City of London, has not (''London's Ceremonial Sheriff,'' Sept. 1) continually represented the ward of Farringdon Without as Alderman for seven years. The Sheriff was elected Alderman in 1975 representing the ward of Coleman Street, although she has served on the Common Council of London since 1966. The Sheriffs of the City of London elected annually by the Liverymen number two. VICTOR DUPONT White Plains

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
S.A.T. SCORES RISE FOR FIRST TIME IN 2 DECADES
description: Both the verbal and mathematics scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test rose this year for the first time in 19 years. It marked an upturn in what has become a leading barometer for measuring the condition of the nation's schools.

title: Striking Out On His Own
description: John Madden works as a commentator on the CBS telecasts of the National Football League games and he takes the train between assignments because of his fear of flying.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of my sons needed a hernia operation when he was 2 1/2 years old, an age when being separated from his parents was much more frightening than strangers in white coats. I carefully selected a pediatric surgeon who operated at a hospital where it was possible for a parent to stay overnight with a child. When we arrived at the hospital the afternoon before surgery, I was told no beds for parents were available that day. I said I would sleep on the floor if necessary, but I was not going home without my son.

title: People
description: * Gerald J. Cutler has been appointed a senior vice president of Hicks & Greist Inc.

title: Advertising; First Wave Of Swedish Agencies
description: THERE are, according to a reliable source, three Swedish ad agencies interested in opening offices in these parts, convinced that their expertise in print advertising will make them welcome additions to the scene.

title: PACKERS A FLAWLESS REVERSE PLAY
description: I t was the last great play before the football strike began, and the memory might have to last them a long time. So the Green Bay Packer coaches spent time savoring it on film yesterday, after flying home with a 27-19 victory over the Giants Monday night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon, published last Wednesday, incorrectly described an attack by his forces on the beach home of a rival Christian leader. The rival, Dany Chamoun, was not killed.

title: California Marks Closing Of Drive on Fruit Flies
description: California officials toasted victory over the Mediterranean fruit fly with champagne today, ending a twoyear, $96 million battle to eradicate the pest that threatened the state's multibillion-dollar agriculture industry.

title: DEMOCRATS UNVEIL A 'NEW' LOOK
description: Top Congressional Democrats today unveiled an election-year manifesto designed to show voters ''a new Democratic party.''

title: HARPSICHORD: ROBERT CONANT
description: IN our performance culture, the harpsichord has taken on an aura of authenticity and propriety. But in the contemporary composer's world, the harpsichord has been the focus of quite different feelings.

title: RALPH R. WHITTAKER Jr.
description: Ralph R. Whittaker Jr., a former New York publishing executive who was associated with Street & Smith Publications Inc. for 23 years, died Saturday at Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., after a long illness.

title: 2D QUARTER G.N.P. RATE UP BY 2.1%
description: The nation's gross national product grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter of this year and is estimated to be growing at a 1.5 percent rate in this quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FOR EASIER WHISKING
description: CERTAIN kitchen tools are so utterly simple yet utilitarian in design that modern technology has not dared tamper with them; it would be like trying to redesign the egg. The wire whisk is one of them. This indispensable implement might rightly be called the chef's third hand, so often is it employed during food preparation.

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY OPENS 37TH SESSION
description: The 37th annual session of the General Assembly opened here today, and the United States made clear it would wage a determined fight against Cuba's effort to declare that Puerto Rico is an American colony.

title: 'Wonderful Real Food'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Three cheers for the Rev. Capon and his passionate defense of salt in ''In Praise of Salt, a Friend Maligned'' (Sept. 8). It is the first sane, logical statement on the subject of salt that I have read.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE THIRD WORLD WAR. The Untold Story. By Gen. Sir John Hackett. 372 pages. Illustrated with Maps. Macmil- lan. $15.75.

title: Dissent From 5 Towns
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As residents of the Five Towns (Woodmere, Lawrence, Cedarhurst, Hewlett and Inwood) we were very unhappy about the article ''They're Clothes Crazy, fer Sure'' (Sept. 15).

title: Fairchild-Brazil Case Rejected
description: The International Trade Commission, by a 3-to-1 vote, today rejected a complaint by Fairchild Industries that an imported 18-seat turboprop Brazilian airplane, the Bandeirante, is unfairly subsidized competition for American manufacturers.

title: CONCERT: GRATEFUL DEAD AT THE GARDEN
description: THE Grateful Dead played a thoroughly professional concert Monday at Madison Square Garden. In three and a half hours onstage, the group performed 19 songs while fans danced in the aisles.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amedco Inc., a health-care and funeral services company, said it had won a $38 million contract to provide consulting and marketing services for a retirement complex being built in Baltimore.

title: SPEEDING F.D.A. DRUG REVIEW
description: In retrospect the timing seemed impolitic. Just as consumer advocates and health groups were unleashing a new round of criticism of the Government's ability to keep harmful medications off the market, the Reagan Administration announced a plan June 23 to shorten the Food and Drug Administration's 20-yearold review process by about 20 percent.

title: AFGHAN EXILE: OLD DREAMS, NEW ROOTS
description: Each morning on the plains between this capital and the slate-gray walls of the Khyber Pass, in the dry flatness where hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees live in villages of tents and huts, the children pad off to school, raising cloud puffs of yellow dust.

title: NBC HAS FAMILY COMEDY
description: TWO new series have their debuts tonight and, true to formula, television is still trying to come up with something for everybody. On ABC at 8, ''Tales of the Gold Monkey'' is an action-adventure project. On NBC at 9:30, ''Family Ties'' is a situation comedy.

title: STATE'S VINEYARDS REPORT A HUGE CROP
description: THE annual grape harvest has begun in the vineyards of New York State amid great promise for a full recovery from the damage wrought by the ''Christmas massacre'' of 1980, a freeze that killed vines all over the state and curtailed the vintage of 1981. Producers reported earlier this week that all indications are favorable for a bountiful crop of healthy grapes that should yield excellent wines.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
description: B-Including capital gains of $104,000 for the qr and $165,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including capital gains of $672,000 for the qr and $1 million for the 6 mos

title: A CANDIDATE IN TUNE WITH HIS COMMUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Metals Futures Soar As Most Markets Drop
description: A sharp decline in interest rates yesterday sent futures prices of precious metals and financial instruments soaring. But the decline, though it promises to reduce the carrying cost of farm crops, failed to halt the slide in most markets for grains, oil seeds, livestock and tropical products.

title: Warning on Utah Fallout Is Termed Inadequate
description: The Government warned people of St. George, Utah, to wash radioactive fallout from automobiles after a 1953 atomic bomb test in Nevada but did not tell them to clean themselves, a former Public Health Service official told a Federal judge today.

title: DELIGHTS OF DIM SUM, AT HOME
description: THERE was a time when dim sum, the traditional food of the Chinese teahouse, was virtually unknown outside of southern China. There were teahouses in the various Chinatowns of America, but they were frequented mostly by the immigrant Chinese, most of them Cantonese, for whom dim sum was a reminder of home.

title: Mets Win, 2-1, Then Lose, 5-1
description: The Mets snapped a five-game losing streak yesterday and even won their first extra-inning game after seven straight defeats in overtime. But they still weren't able to win a doubleheader.

title: MRS. REAGAN ASSUMES CULTURAL POST
description: Invoking the names of past First Ladies who have immersed themselves in cultural activities, Nancy Reagan today assumed the post of honorary chairman of the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities.

title: SELLING WITHOUT FOOTBALL
description: The advertising community, much like a harried quarterback, was busy switching signals yesterday in response to the National Football League players' strike, now in its second day.

title: A PROLETARIAN AT U.N. HELM
description: He is ''charming,'' ''disciplined,'' ''urbane,'' ''correct,'' ''self-confident.'' This is how Western diplomats who have dealt with him for years describe Imre Hollai , the new Hungarian president of the General Assembly. Talking about himself, however, he stresses his proletarian roots.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE boyhood, I have had a passionate enthusiasm for fish and seafood, and I was fascinated to read a recent news account that compared the relative consumption of seafood in this country to that in Japan and Iceland. The average American, the account noted, consumes 35 pounds per year, whereas the average Japanese eats 148 pounds annually and the Icelander 147 pounds.

title: BONN PARTNERS DELAY CABINET CHOICES
description: The leaders of the three parties that hope to form West Germany's next government continued their negotiations today after agreeing Monday night to vote for the Christian Democratic chairman, Helmut Kohl, to be Chancellor.

title: Germaine Schnitzer, Pianist in Early 1900's
description: Germaine Schnitzer, a Parisian-born pianist who concertized widely during the early decades of this century, died Saturday night in her Manhattan apartment. She was 95 years old.

title: ALTMAN FILMS HIS 'JIMMY DEAN' PLAY
description: Robert Altman has made a film of ''Come Back to the 5 & Dime Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' the play that he directed that failed on Broadway last season. It will open in New York in November.

title: On Physical Therapists
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane Brody's Personal Health column of Sept. 8 was an excellent summary of where we are today in trying to understand the cause and prognosis of multiple sclerosis.

title: POLL HINTS DEMOCRATS COULD MAKE KEY GAINS IN THE HOUSE ELECTIONS
description: With six weeks until the elections, economic concerns rather than social issues dominate voting intentions, and Democrats are preferred over Republicans in Congressional races by a wide margin, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Gilding of Fifth Avenue

title: Newman's Brew
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: If Paul Newman is seriously considering labeling his own brew as he already has done with his salad dressing (''Newman's Salad Dressing: Oil, Vinegar and Ballyhoo,'' Sept. 15) he ought to know that there is already a brew in existence called Newman's.

title: Ban Called 'Unfair'
description: The University of Georgia's football coach and athletic director, Vince Dooley, said the National Collegiate Athletic Association was ''totally unfair'' when it placed the Bulldogs' football program on probation for one year because of irregularities last winter in the recruitment of George Smith, a fullback and tight end from Coffee County High School in Georgia. Smith, who was released from a letter of intent by Georgia last spring when the N.C.A.A. began the investigation, switched to Texas A & M, where he is a freshman.

title: MIDDLE EAST: REVERBERATIONS OF A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: The Flight From Life on Earth
description: James Ussher, the 17th-century Archbishop of Armagh, is remembered for his calculation that God created the world in the year 4004 B.C., no sooner, no later. The estimate strikes modern ears as incongruous because it offers exactness in a theological matter where scientific precision has no place. Like church and state, religious and scientific explanations are best kept separate. Hence there is reason for unease about two recent books from distinguished scientists who offer decidedly mystical explanations of how life arose on Earth.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOUBLE FEATURE

title: It's Maglie Field, Now
description: The Niagara Falls City Council voted to rename Hyde Park Stadium in that city in honor of Sal (The Barber) Maglie, a Niagara Falls native who pitched for five major league teams, including the New York Giants, New York Yankees and Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1940's and 1950's. Maglie, still a resident of Niagara Falls, suffered a stroke two months ago and is undergoing rehabilitation. Hyde Park Stadium is the home field for the Niagara Falls minor league team in the New York-Penn Baseball League.

title: MRS. GANDHI FINISHES TALKS WITH BREZHNEV
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, concluded talks at the Kremlin today and signed a joint declaration, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: A Lost Trip
description: Iona College is a Division III football school, which usually plays local teams in the New York City area.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is not time to cry. It is time to work.''

title: A BILL TO LET PROFESSIONS DEFEAT THE CONSUMER
description: Deregulation comes in two basic forms: deregulation and phony deregulation. The first kind is generally beneficial, but the second kind can be dangerous. The laatest example of phony deregulation is a bill to exempt state-regulated ''professions'' from the Federal Trade Commission Act.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M. Mets vs.

title: TREASURY ISSUES SOAR IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday in a frenzy of buying activity by investors and speculators that resulted in steep declines for long- and short-term interest rates.

title: GEMAYEL BROTHERS ASSESSED IN SYRIA
description: Amin Gemayel, the new Lebanese President-elect, is seen here as more flexible and more moderate than his brother, but at the same time more cautious and perhaps a weaker man.

title: Texas Oil, Petrofina Sign Drilling Pact
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation and American Petrofina Inc. said they had signed a letter of intent yesterday to start a $136 million drilling and development program involving about 5.4 million net undeveloped acres of leaseholdings currently held by a subsidiary of Texas Oil.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1982; The Economy
description: The gross national product grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter and is estimated to be growing at a 1.5 percent rate in the third, the Commerce Department reported. The figures, higher than some key economists had been predicting, were hailed by the Administration, but some economists, in and out of the Government, said the rise was not enough to confirm the beginning of the longawaited economic recovery. (Page D1.)

title: Yarn Executive Turns To Photography at PCA
description: William P. Mewborne Jr., president and chief executive of the Adams-Millis Corporation of High Point, N.C., is making an unusual switch - from yarn and hosiery manufacturing to the portrait photography business.

title: Panel Votes to Thin Out G.I. Ranks in Europe
description: The Senate Defense Appropriations subcommittee voted today to reduce the number of American troops authorized for duty in Europe next year from 350,600 to 331,000.

title: Economic Scene; Cost-Effective Job Creation
description: IS military spending beneficial or harmful to the national economy? As noted in a recent column, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, though stressing that the fundamental reason for the rapid military buildup is to respond to the Soviet threat, still maintained that military spending was beneficial to the economy. He asserted that every $1 billion in military spending (measured in constant 1982 dollars) would create 35,000 industrial jobs.

title: Pennant Races at a Glance; American League; East; W L F Pct.  GBMilwaukee 90 60 .600 - Baltimore 88 62 .587 2 Boston 82 68 .547 8
description: MILWAUKEE (13) - Home (5): Last night, t onight, Boston; Sept. 2 4, 25, 26, Baltimore. Away (7): Sept. 28, 29, 3 0, Boston; Oct. 1 (2), 2 , 3, B altimore. BALTIMORE (12) - Home (6): Last night, T onight, Detroit; Oct. 1 ( 2), 2, 3, Milwaukee. Away (6): Sept. 24, 25, 2 6, Milwaukee; Sept. 28, 2 9, 3 0, Detroit. BOSTON (12) - Home (7): Sept. 24, 25, 26, 27, Y ankees; Sept. 28, 29, 3 0, Milwaukee. Away (5): Last night, Tonight, M ilwaukee; Oct. 1, 2, 3, Y ankees.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for QTr to Aug 31
STEEL UNION CHIEFS BACK NEW TALKS ON CONCESSIONS
description: Heads of union locals attending the national conference of the United Steelworkers of America here voiced almost unanimous support today for a renewal of contract talks that could lead to an agreement to reduce labor costs.

title: ARABS BLAME U.S. IN BEIRUT DEATHS
description: The Arab League, ending a five-hour emergency session, accused the United States early today of being morally responsible for the massacre last week of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in West Beirut.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
description: B-Including a tax credit of $857,000

title: Bridge: A Clever Bit of Temptation; May Rescue a Lost Cause
description: Even bridge players who know no Latin should bear in mind the maxim nil desperandum. Even when the situation is hopeless, it is just possible that the opponents may not be aware of that fact and can be tempted into indiscretion.

title: Triton to Buy Tony Lama
description: Triton Group Ltd. said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Tony Lama Company, a leading producer of western-style boots and accessories, for about $81 million.

title: U.S. IRKED AS ISRAEL SEEMS TO BALK AT PULLOUT OF TROOPS FROM BEIRUT
description: Despite Israel's consent today to the landing of American, Italian and French forces in Beirut, Administration officials expressed irritation at Israel's seeming refusal to agree to President Reagan's demand for an immediate withdrawal of its troops from Beirut.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST JUMPS TO RECORD LEVEL
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest jumped 25 percent, or 24.1 million shares, in the month ended Sept. 15, to a record 120.5 million shares.

title: Sooners Sell A Game to TV
description: The universities of Oklahoma and Southern California today awarded a $250,000 contract to an Oklahoma City television station to broadcast their Saturday football game, school officials said.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: garde, more than 15 years after the release of his first album. Although he has polished his music and changed the personnel of his Magic Band a number of times since the mid-1960's, the broad outlines of his style were already in place the first time he entered a recording studio. They include fractured rhythms; dislocated country blues riffs; disjunct melodies and passages of counterpoint that sometimes recall Stravinsky; extravagantly gruff singing and croaking, and occasional bursts of clattering noise.

title: Rev. T.R. Gibson Dies; Rights Activist Was 67
description: The Rev. Theodore Roosevelt Gibson, a civil rights activist and former Miami City Commissioner, died of cancer Monday at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital here. He was 67 years old.

title: Real Estate; L.I. Project: Offices in Idle School
description: WITHIN the past 10 years more than a third of the 79 public school buildings in the town of Huntington, L.I., have been shut. In Huntington, shrinking enrollments have left localities with empty schools and often sizable parcels of property that surround them.

title: No Headline
description: INTELLIGENCE AGENCY UPHELD IN ITS REFUSAL TO RELEASE DATA

title: PROMINENT U.S. JEWS SUPPORT ISRAEL, BUT SOME CRITICIZE BEGIN AND SHARON
description: Israel's invasion of Lebanon and the presence of its troops in the area where hundreds of Palestinians were killed by Christian forces over the weekend have aroused a broad range of responses from American Jews in the cultural, political, intellectual and theological worlds. The responses also include some thoughts about the role the United States should play in the Lebanese situation.

title: GEORGE B. TURNER
description: George B. Turner, a retired partner in the Wall Street law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, died Saturday of cancer at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 72 years old and lived in Manchester Center, Vt., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: UNITED MUTUAL PURCHASE BY AMERICAN EXPECTED
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has arranged the takeover of the failing United Mutual Savings Bank by the American Savings Bank, banking sources said yesterday.

title: AMIN GEMAYEL ELECTED PRESIDENT IN A DISPLAY OF UNITY BY LEBANESE
description: Amin Gemayel, a 40-year-old Maronite Christian, was elected President of Lebanon today by a nearly unanimous vote of Parliament in an unusual display of Christian and Moslem unity.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lodging in New York On Just $18,250 a Day

title: BRIEFING
description: One Woman's Campaign

title: RESTRUCTURING OF ARMOUR SET
description: The Greyhound Corporation, operator of the nation's largest bus system, said yesterday that it planned to reorganize its Armour & Company meat-processing and consumer products subsidiary.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Astradyne Computer Industries, Garden City, L.I., has appointed Irving Fitterman executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Peter Cusick Is Dead at 72; A Foreign Affairs Consultant
description: Peter Cusick, a private consultant on government and foreign affairs, died in Manhattan Monday, apparently of a heart attack, shortly before he was to attend a meeting of the Council on Foreign Relations at 58 East 68th Street. He was 72 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: ASSERTS REAGAN IS FIRM ON BEIRUT
description: Vice President Bush flew in and out of New York yesterday, stopping to speak at a black-tie benefit dinner, meet with leaders of Jewish groups, tour the aircraft carrier Intrepid and attend a fund-raising lunch for the Republican National Committee.

title: CABARET: DUO IN PRIMA STYLE
description: THE kind of intense, rhythmic and raunchy lounge act that Louis Prima created in Las Vegas is being carried on with some degree of legitimacy by Lily Ann Carol and Joe Barone, who are at Jimmy Weston's, 131 West 54th Street, through Oct. 2. The legitimacy of the connection is that Miss Carol, at the age of 16, joined a big band that Mr. Prima led in 1939 that he called his ''Gleeby Rhythm Band.'' This band gave way to ''The Band That Plays Pretty for the People'' and, in the mid-40's to the lounge act that featured Mr. Prima and Miss Carol with a smaller group.

title: FOREIGN BANKS GET STATE TAX BREAKS
description: The New York State Job Incentive Board yesterday approved tax benefits worth $12 million over the next decade for four foreignowned banks and two Wall Street concerns. The board also rejected three applications for tax benefits from a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: WHEN MEMBERS CHANGE THEIR VOTES
description: It was a tense vote in the Senate. President Reagan's prestige was on the line. The issue was whether to override his veto of a supplemental spending bill.

title: READER'S DIGEST CONDENSES THE BIBLE
description: After seven years of planning, the Reader's Digest condensed Bible will be published today, a version 40 percent shorter than the 850,000-word text of the Revised Standard Version on which it is based. The Reader's Digest Bible contains all 66 books of the Bible arranged in their traditional sequence, but the length of the 39 books of the Old Testament have been reduced by about 50 percent and the New Testament's 27 books by some 25 percent.

title: DEFENSE DOLLARS DO LITTLE FOR THE JOBLESS
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY HAS U.S. 41ST IN QUALITY OF LIFE
description: Denmark is the best place in the world to live, Ethiopia the worst and the United States is 41st, according to a study of 107 nations by a University of Pennsylvania researcher.

title: Weinberger Fears Soviet Exploits Vietnamese
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that there was growing evidence that the Soviet Union might be using Vietnamese dissidents as forced labor to build the Siberian part of its natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: THE VALUE OF A FREEZE
description: The rapid increase in public support for a nuclear-freeze agreement - that is, a mutual freeze on the testing, production and further deployment of nuclear weapons - has been a remarkable political phenomenon. In less than a year, support has grown from a few volunteers collecting signatures on petitions to a Congressional vote in which supporters of a freeze very nearly prevailed. This fall, eight states and the District of Columbia will vote on freeze referendums. Already Wisconsin voters have overwhelmingly voted yes in such a referendum.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the maximum rate for new six-month savings certificates offered by banks and thrift institutions. It is 9.874 percent, effective today.

title: Rates Up a Bit in Erratic Day; Demand for Issues Softens
description: Interest rates rose slightly in erratic trading yesterday as the credit markets continued to digest large new issues of Treasury securities.

title: SKEPTICAL UPSTATE FARM COUNTY READY FINALLY TO GO TO POLLS
description: As the leaves redden on the rolling hills known as the ''drumlins,'' the names Koch, Cuomo and Lehrman have grown as familiar to the dairy farmers and factory workers here as the fields of ripened corn.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Albus's 138 Leads Golf
description: Jim Albus of Piping Rock, the defender in the Izod Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association tournament, shot a one-over-par 72 today at the Century Country Club to retain the lead after 36 holes with a 138.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 23, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on question of South Africa at 10:30 A.M.

title: HOW SALE OF SALOMON ENRICHED FORMER PARTNERS
description: Six former senior partners of Salomon Brothers, the investment firm acquired last year by the Phibro Corporation, will soon be able to begin cashing in $60 million or more in securities that they received as a result of the merger, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. John H. Gutfreund, Salomon's former managing partner and now co-chairman of the merged company, would receive the most - more than $13 million.

title: Prudential-Feldco Head To Take Over as Owner
description: Alan Hodes, who started his career with the Prudential-Feldco Company 15 years ago as a management trainee, wound up as the company's president eight years later. Now, he is scheduled to become the company's major owner.

title: Article 170328 -- No Title
description: A major development project along the Hudson River in Hoboken was announced today amid expressions of hope that the area would become a harbor showcase similar to those in Boston and Baltimore.

title: ANTI-LIBERAL WEAPON OF JAPAN'S RIGHT WING
description: To the Editor:

title: Runner and Driver Killed in Car Crash
description: A sports car skidded out of control on the Wantagh State Parkway in Wantagh, L.I., yesterday, killing both its 23-year-old driver and a 13-year-old student who was running on a path 10 feet from the road. The teen-ager had been running with a junior high school crosscountry team.

title: HOUSE BACKS SENATE IN DIRECTING ENGINEERS TO END U.S. RAIL STRIKE
description: Congress cleared the way today for a quick end to the nation's crippling railroad strike as the House voted, 383 to 17, to follow the Senate in directing 26,000 locomotive engineers to accept a new contract and return to work.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Thomas Cole Letters Found, to Be Published

title: U.S. MOVES TO PAROLE 49 HAITIANS HELD IN BROOKLYN
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it intended to parole 49 illegal Haitian aliens who had been detained in Brooklyn for from nine to 13 months while their applications for legal admission into the United States were pending.

title: Losing a Friend, Gaining a Brother
description: The trade of Moses Malone by the Houston Rockets to the Philadelphia 76ers for Caldwell Jones has created unusual repercussions for Major Jones of Houston, who was Malone's closest friend on the team and is the younger brother of Caldwell Jones.

title: Companies
description: Allied and Bendix have agreed to merge, making Allied the fourth entrant in one of the most complex takeover battles ever. If Allied buys Bendix, it will be taking over a company that has just bought control of Martin Marietta. The Bendix move has drawn a counterbid by Marietta, which began its purchase of Bendix shares early today, though it fell well short of control. (Page A1.) A Federal judge had authorized Marietta to proceed with its purchase. (D4.)

title: Agency Says Starlighter Crib Could Pose a Safety Hazard
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission warned parents today to stop using the ''Starlighter'' baby crib, which the agency said could pose a safety hazard.

title: G.I. Is Killed in Maneuvers
description: An American soldier on maneuvers was killed today when he was hit by a swinging tank gun, the United States Army said. The soldier's name was withheld pending notification of next of kin.

title: Acid Peril Ends on Coast
description: Hundreds of people who live near a chemical plant were back in their homes today after more than 5,000 gallons of deadly nitric acid burned through the bottom of a tanker truck and vaporized into toxic gas.

title: Ruston Faces Pemex Bribe Charge
description: The Justice Department filed criminal charges today against Ruston Gas Turbines Inc. of Houston in connection with a reported scheme to bribe officials of Mexico's state-owned oil company in exchange for contracts. The one-count Federal information was filed against the Texas subsidiary of Ruston Gas Turbines P.L.C., a British company,

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday about the sale of Conoco assets to the Petro-Lewis Corporation incorrectly stated the date on which 35 percent of the onshore oil interests involved would revert to Conoco. It is Jan. 1, 1993.

title: 'WARM FRIENDS OF ISRAEL, OPEN CRITICS OF BEGIN-SHARON'
description: Let me speak about some American Jews. We have been thrown into emotional turmoil by the revelations about the Beirut massacre. We strongly oppose the Begin-Sharon Government. Yet we know there are enemies of Israel ready to exploit both the misdeeds of Israeli authorities and the words of Jewish critics.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $70,000 or 6 cents a shr...C-Net loss

title: ICM REALTY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1.5 million from the sale of investments...C-Including a$2.3 million gain in equity in partnership

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHARON'S ADDRESS TO PARLIAMENT IN DEFENSE OF ARMY'S ROLE
description: uf1071 JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 - Following are excerpts from the text of Defense Minister Ariel Sharon's address today to Parliament, as translated from the Hebrew by The New York Times. Some interruptions from the floor are shown in brackets.

title: Speeches in Parliament, page A18.
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon admitted to Parliament today that Israel had requested and helped plan the entry of the Lebanese Phalangist forces into the Palestinian refugee camps last week, and that he and his commanders had suspicions of the killing of Palestinians a full day before the Phalangist units finally withdrew.

title: GALLSTONE SURGERY VIEWED AS OFTEN AVOIDABLE
description: Gallstone operations, now performed on 500,000 Americans each year, are ill-advised unless the stones cause pain, a study has concluded.

title: No Headline
description: LESS STEEL IS PLANNED BY E.E.C.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Murray Scureman vice president of Federal operations.

title: HOUSE PASSES CATCH-ALL SPENDING BILL
description: The House today approved an emergency, catch-all spending bill needed to keep the Government operating in the new fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. The measure would expire Dec. 15.

title: Bank Merger Proposal Gains
description: Shareholders of the Pittsburgh National Corporation have overwhelmingly approved the proposed merger with the Provident National Corporation of Philadelphia to form the nation's 27th-largest bank holding company, with assets of $10.3 billion.

title: Giants' Players Plan Workouts as a Unit
description: The Giants' players had a pep rally behind closed doors today and completed plans to resume workouts on their own.

title: MRS. THATCHER MEETS ZHAO IN PEKING
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britian arrived in China today for an official visit that is expected to center on discussions with the Chinese leadership on the future of Hong Kong.

title: VW to Cut Production
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. plans to reduce work schedules at all its German plants during the rest of this year, a company spokesman said today. He said the move was accepted by the company's works councils and had been announced in August. The exact number of workers affected has not yet been determined.

title: U.S. TEAM UNCOVERS RICH MANGANESE DEPOSIT
description: A large mineral deposit rich in manganese and possibly containing large amounts of copper, zinc and silver has been discovered on the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, 1,800 miles east of Miami, the Government reported today.

title: New Farm Attache in China
description: Norman R. Kallemeyn was named agricultural counselor today at the United States Embassy in Peking. Mr. Kallemeyn has been with the Foreign Agriculture Service since 1957, most recently served as budget chief, after years as an export trade specialist and as attache in Costa Rica and Hong Kong. He will succeed Jerome M. Kuhl, who is returning here.

title: West Riders Win
description: Fernando Toro, at 41 the oldest member of a five-man team of West Coast jockeys, won two of three races to lead a sweep of the first East-West Jockey Challenge tonight at Meadowlands race track.

title: Strike Barometer
description: Now that the National Football League players are on strike, doomsayers are warning that fans will lose interest in the sport and attendance will suffer from a backlash when play resumes.

title: ROOSEVELT ROLE IN ARTS TO BE MARKED
description: As part of the centennial celebration of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth this year there will be two special events in New York next month commemorating his support for the arts.

title: OUR ARCHITECTS OF SHAKY DEBT STRUCTURES
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EUROPEAN CHANGES AFFECT ARMS TALKS
description: The coming political changes in West Germany and the Netherlands could well lessen much of the immediate pressure for compromise at the United States-Soviet talks on intermediate-range nuclear weapons.

title: Corona Jury Reconvenes
description: Jurors in the retrial of Juan V. Corona on mass murder charges were able to resume deliberations today after the recovery of a panel member whose illness halted discussions Tuesday. But they recessed once again with no decision. This was the ninth day of deliberations in the trial, which has lasted seven months. Mr. Corona is charged with the slayings of 25 migrant farm laborers in 1971.

title: PLANTING BULBS NOW TO ENHANCE SPRING
description: IT'S not easy to think of spring now, just as the city garden (and gardener) is slowing down in anticipation of a winter's rest. But fall is planting time for the flowering bulbs that surface before the trees have revived in spring.

title: PEKING FACTORY MAKING AVON CREAM FOR CHINESE
description: Avon is coming to China, but not by its usual door-to-door method. A new facial moisture cream developed for the domestic Chinese market by the American cosmetics company Avon Products Inc. went into full-scale production today at the No.4 Daily Needs chemical factory here.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dispute on Purse
description: Claiborne Farm, the Lexington, Ky., home of many of the top throughbreds in the country, has withdrawn its support from the proposed $18 million Breeders Cup series in a dispute over purse distribution.

title: De Sade Gets His Due From Greek Socialists
description: The Socialist Government introduced legislation today liberalizing the laws on indecent publications and legalizing the works of the Marquis de Sade, after a publisher was sentenced to two years in prison for distributing them.

title: DURABLES ORDERS OFF IN AUGUST
description: New orders for durable goods fell 4 percent in August, the biggest monthly decline since October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Walker 'Ready to Go'
description: Herschel Walker of Georgia, the all-America running back whose performances in the Bulldogs' first two games were muted because of a broken right thumb he suffered Aug. 21, says that the thumb has healed since pins were removed last Friday. He gained only 20 yards in a victory over Clemson and 124 in a triumph over Brigham Young.

title: Coopers Plans Merger
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the international accounting and consulting firm, said yesterday that it would merge with Siskin, Shapiro & Company, one of Connecticut's largest accounting firms.

title: GUILTY PLEA MADE BY BALTIMORE AIDE
description: The City Council President, Walter Orlinsky, has pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to one count of extortion, admitting that he had accepted $2,532 from a concern seeking city sludge-hauling contracts.

title: Nissan Prices Up
description: Nissan U.S.A. Inc., distributor of Nissan and Datsun cars and trucks, said it had raised prices 2.6 percent on three of its 1983 cars, or an average of about $205 per car. The increases reflect upgraded equipment available on each of the models, which are to be introduced next month. Base prices for 1983 are $4,949 for the Sentra, $6,999 for the Stanza $6,999 and $10,869 for the Maxima.

title: Co-Founder Leaving Doyle-Heekin Agency
description: James R. Heekin Jr., who has been president of four ad agencies and a partner in a top marketing consulting firm, said farewell yesterday to the chairmanship and chief executive's job at Doyle-Heekin, which he founded last May with William S. Doyle.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Advertising; Statewide Radio Networks
description: OVER at Halloran House at noon today the National Association of State Radio Networks will be repeating the pitch it has been making to advertisers and agencies across the country. Part of it will be that its 18 member networks can offer greater penetration in their states than any of the national radio networks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A list of primary contests in Metropolitan Report yesterday omitted the Democratic candidates for Manhattan surrogate.

title: ECONOMICS NOMINEE DIFFERS WITH REAGAN ON GROWTH FORECAST
description: Martin S. Feldstein, whom the President has nominated to be his chief economic adviser, said today that the economy would grow about 3.5 percent next year - a forecast that is nearly a full percentage point below the Administration's current projection and one that would mean a bigger budget deficit.

title: PHH Credit Plan
description: PHH Group Inc., a Hunt Valley, Md., company that provides corporations with vehicle and relocation services, announced it had signed an $800 million credit agreement with 18 commercial banks to provide funds for expansion of its operations. The agreement provides PHH with a $500 million revolving loan and $300 million in restructued debt, the company said. PHH said Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan Bank, Citibank and Continental Bank of Chicago would assume the largest portion of the debt.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Mellon National Corporation, a Pittsburgh bank holding company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Mortgage and Trust Inc., a Houston-based, privately held mortgage banking concern, for about $95 million.

title: Pierce Deplores Epithet By Texas Congressman
description: Representative Henry B. Gonzalez called Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, a ''Stepin Fetchit,'' and although Mr. Pierce termed that epithet ''vile, abusive and racist,'' the Texas Democrat refused to apologize.

title: HOME BEAT
description: SOME might regard it as irreverent, but Mike Bell considers it a practical approach.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOUSE UNIT BACKS IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved a bill containing a comprehensive revision of the nation's immigration laws. But the bill differs from one passed by the Senate, and it was not immediately clear whether Congress could complete action on the legislation before it adjourns in early October.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ballet Theater Talks With Union Recessed

title: RUBBISH LIVES FOR A TIME AS SCULPTURE
description: Every day commuters driving to San Francisco pass an unlikely sight on the mud flats leading to the San Francisco Bay Bridge. On a bleak stretch that was once a garbage dump for this small industrial city stand large figures made of trash, driftwood and hubcaps. It looks as if the refuse had come to life.

title: MARCOS URGED U.N. TO GET RICH-POOR TALKS STARTED
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines urged an early start today on the long-delayed global negotiations aimed at shifting wealth from rich nations to poor.

title: 3 Suspects Linked To Big Heroin Ring
description: Three men, including the son of a former State Assemblyman, have been arrested and charged with running a $1 million-a-week heroin ring in Harlem.

title: ONE IN 600 BABIES AFFECTED BY FETAL ALCOHOL SYNDROME
description: Studies show that severe birth defects caused by alcohol consumed by women who are pregnant occur in as many as one in 600 babies, a Federal health official says.

title: RAILROADS EXPECT VARIED START-UPS
description: The railroads acted yesterday to get their trains rolling again, a task that could take hours or days, depending on locations and circumstances.

title: Weathermen to Clear the Air
description: ''We'll see how Pan Am does and then we'll take a look.'' So remarked the captain of a USAir plane to his co-pilot shortly before the takeoff and crash of Pan Am's flight 759 on July 9 in which 153 people died near New Orleans's Moisant airport.

title: People
description: * Robert M. McCormick appointed executive vice president of sales and marketing for The Chicago Sun-Times.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Bettelheim to Speak At Cooper Union

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Off to an Early Start At Carnegie Hall

title: IRANIANS SAY AN IRAQI MIG TRIED TO BOMB TEHERAN
description: Iran said that an Iraqi Air Force MIG-25 jet tried to bomb Teheran today as Iran marked the second anniversary of the start of Iran-Iraq war with a military parade in the capital.

title: Warsaw Is Said to Study Solidarity's Dissolution
description: The Polish Government newspaper indicated today that the authorities were considering the full dissolution of the independent labor union Solidarity, suspended with the imposition of martial law last December.

title: Military Analysis
