description: The international force of American, French and Italian troops that will take up peacekeeping duties in Beirut will face far more complicated and hazardous military problems than those encountered by the units that supervised the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization forces, according to United States and NATO military analysts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Different Strokes

title: IACOCCA INTRODUCES NEW CHRYSLER LINE
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, today presented its 1983 model cars and denounced the Reagan Administration's economic policies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GALLERY DE LUXE

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS LEAD BY 3 AFTER SWEEP

title: Philip Ober, 80, Actor Of Stage, Film and TV
description: Philip Ober, a character actor who appeared in the motion pictures ''The Magnificent Yankee,'' ''Come Back Little Sheba,'' ''From Here to Eternity'' and ''Elmer Gantry,'' died Sept. 13, it was announced Tuesday. He was 80 years old.

title: AMERICAN PAD & PAPER (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results for the yr-ago third qr reflect an inventory writedown that reducednet income by $167,000 or 30 cents a shr

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: AT MILAN SHOW, NEO-MODERN IS THE NEW LOOK
description: The 22d Salone Internazionale del Mobile, which ended here this week, may just go down in memory as the show where Il Nuovo Design, the year-old movement that the Italians also call Neo-Modern, carved a place for itself in the crowded ranks of furniture design.

title: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Crew Members Refloat Oil Rig in Bering Sea
description: Six crew members returned to their offshore drilling rig in the Bering Sea today and refloated the vessel, which lost a tow line and ran aground in stormy weather.

title: Eurodollar Futures Slip After Strong Early Gain
description: Prices of Eurodollar futures closed virtually unchanged yesterday after rising sharply early in the day, when interest rates continued to decline. A late rebound in rates erased the gains.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH winter's blasts have not arrived, it is not too soon to start thinking about conserving energy. Tiny cracks - as little as a sixteenth of an inch wide around each window, for example - can add up to an opening in an outside wall large enough to throw a football through.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: A small twist locknut used in knockdown furniture from Scandinavia can also be used to advantage by the most amateur do-it-yourselfer, according to Jack Braverman of Great North Woods Ltd., which carries furniture incorporating the device.

title: EXCAVATION IS BEGUN FOR BREEDER REACTOR AT OAK RIDGE, TENN.
description: The Department of Energy announced today that site clearing and excavation had begun for the Clinch River breeder reactor at Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1982
description: International Ariel Sharon admitted to Israel's Parliament that the Government had requested and helped plan the entry of Lebanese Phalangist forces into Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut last week. The Defense Minister also revealed that he and his commanders had suspicions of the killing of Palestinians a full day before the Phalangist units withdrew. Mr. Sharon was interrupted repeatedly by legislators demanding his resignation, but Prime Minister Menachem Begin stuck by him. (Page A1, Column 6.) A phased Israeli withdrawal from Beirut is to be completed on Sunday, according to an Israeli spokesman. As he spoke, Israeli troops were pulling out of positions southeast of downtown West Beirut along the Green Line dividing the Moslem and Christian sectors of the city. (A1:3-5.)

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split on May 6, 198

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
RATE FEARS CHOKE OFF DOW RALLY
description: In the fifth-heaviest trading in New York Stock Exchange history, prices weakened yesterday in response to rising interest rates. Also contributing to the pullback, analysts said, was a feeling that the market, which reached a 13-month high the previous day, was overextended.

title: Burroughs Assignment
description: Penchina/Selkowitz here in New York has become agency for the B20 small-business computer system of the Burroughs Corporation, Detroit.

title: SCHOOL PRAYER ADVOCATES LOSE THIRD VOTE IN SENATE
description: Tensions generated by a 20-month struggle between liberals and conservatives flared on the Senate floor today as the lawmakers refused for the third straight day to cut off a filibuster against a bill that would permit officially endorsed prayer in public schools.

title: Prince Philip, on Coast, Cites Threats to Wildlife
description: Britain's Prince Philip gently scolded Americans Tuesday for importing 120 million tropical fish a year, and said importers were either too ignorant or too selfish to consider what they were doing.

title: 53 CHALLENGE GRANTS GIVEN BY ARTS AGENCY
description: Frank S.M. Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, visited New York yesterday to announce the names of 53 winners of challenge grants and to discuss his agency's plans. The grants total $11.5 million.

title: THEATER: BRUCE SCHWARTZ IN 'STAGE THAT WALKS'
description: BY profession, Bruce D. Schwartz is a puppeteer. By extension, he is also a mimic, storyteller and clown. In his aptly entitled show ''The Stage That Walks,'' which began last night this season's American Humorist Series in the American Place Theater's Subplot Cabaret, he enters encased within a boxlike puppet stage. He is a puppet theater, surrounding himself with a jaunty array of animated characters.

title: Dutch to Stop Dumping Nuclear Wastes at Sea
description: Faced with growing opposition to dumping of radioactive wastes in the ocean, the Government announced today that it planned to halt the practice this month and try to find a land disposal site.

title: Camden Rejects State Offer on Jails
description: County officials today rejected a state offer to remove prisoners from the Camden County Jail to ease overcrowding.

title: Former U.S. Envoy Dies
description: Vinton Chapin, a Foreign Service officer who served as Ambassador to Luxembourg from 1957 to 1960, died Sept. 15 in Woburn, Mass., after a long illness. He was 82 years old. He is survived by his wife, the former Lilian Aldrich Winchester; two sons, Richard Chapin of Cambridge and Aldus Chapin of Washington; two stepsons, Charles Winchester of New York and Gordon Winchester of Oakland, California, and seven grandchildren.

title: Expert in Options Gets Key Amex Job
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Paul G. Stevens, whose background is in options trading, has been named an executive vice president with responsibility for the exchange's market operations and trading-analysis divisions.

title: WEAVER KEEPS WHIRRING
description: BALTIMORE S moke curls from behind the manager's desk in Memorial Stadium, and there are little hums and grumbles and coughs, all associated with the workings of the machine that is Earl Weaver's mind.

title: United Fare Cut
description: United Airlines said it had filed for new fares up to 63 percent lower that full coach fares between eight Eastern cities and Hawaii to become effective Jan.5. A roundtrip fare between New York and Honolulu would be $519, compared with the current full coach fare of $1,368. Analysts said the move was the latest in a fare war sparked by weak advance bookings and fierce market competition by smaller airlines.

title: Pete King, 68, Film Composer
description: Pete King, a composer-conductor whose talents were heard on the soundtracks of such motion pictures as ''State Fair,'' ''Flower Drum Song,'' ''South Pacific'' and ''Camelot,'' died Monday. He was 68 years old.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FOES SAY MARCOS HAS DRIVEN FILIPINOS TO 'BRINK OF DISASTER'
description: On the 10th anniversary of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's declaration of martial law, the three major opposition parties in the Philippines issued a joint statement today accusing the present regime of bringing the country to the ''brink of disaster.''

title: Katherine T. Hobson, A Sculptor of Horses
description: Katherine Thayer Hobson, an artist known for her sculpture of horses and war memorials, died at her home in New York City on Sept. 10. She was 93 years old.

title: Short View of Strike
description: A man with an expertise in player strikes does not foresee a long one in the National Football League.

title: Police in Seoul Break Up Three Student Protests
description: South Korean riot policemen broke up concurrent demonstrations today by more than 1,000 students at three universities in Seoul and detained an unknown number of demonstrators, according to a Christian group there.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH TO ISRAELI PARLIAMENT BY THE HEAD OF THE LABOR PARTY
description: Following are excerpts from an address to the Israeli Parliament by Shimon Peres, chairman of the opposition Labor Party, as translated from the Hebrew by The New York Times:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ponselle Estate Opens Saturday as Museum

title: U.A.W. Backs an Agreement With General Dynamics Corp.
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's council of the United Auto Workers voted tonight to recommend ratification to striking workers of a tentative contract with the corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor.

title: College TV Ruling Is Stayed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association won time today in its fight with two college powers over the televising of football games.

title: REAGAN COUNSELOR SEEN AS DISPLAYING NEW VITALITY
description: Edwin Meese 3d is more busy than ever turning out fresh strategies in his White House office these days, and it may be a compliment to President Reagan's counselor that rivals still have to wonder whether he has something weightier than paper strategems in the works.

title: HOUSE TREND: DOWNSIZED
description: GROWING number of first-time home buyers are moving into a subcompact version of the American dream: houses scaled down to reduce their price, but designed, their builders say, to give owners a feeling of quality and spaciousness. In a time of high interest rates and a severe housing-industry slump, ''downsized homes,'' as builders often call them, are selling far better than other types of new housing, the National Association of Home Builders reports.

title: AFTER DETENTE, THE GOAL IS TO PREVAIL
description: From President Truman through President Johnson, the watchword on policy toward the Soviet Union was ''containment.'' From President Nixon through President Carter, it was ''detente.'' With President Reagan, it is emerging in the phrase ''to prevail.''

title: Cessna Aircraft
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company announced plans to allow corporations to operate their own airplanes more easily. Russell W. Meyer, chairman and president of the company, which is based in Wichita, Kan., said at a news conference in New York City that the company would begin marketing the ''Company Airline,'' which supplies everything needed to operate a private airplane except fuel and incidental travel expenses.

title: PALYERS GET A WARNING
description: The strike by the National Football League Players Association made its first impact on the 1982 schedule yesterday, when the league announced that tonight's game between the Chiefs and the Atlanta Falcons in Kansas City would not be played.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
LEAVES TURNING COLOR EARLY
description: Trees in parts of New York and Connecticut, taking their cue from the weather, have got an early start in their annual color show. The change is most evident north of New York City, and botanists say the reason is the weather.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am willing to stand straight and tall in front of everyone in the country and say, 'We meant good and not bad.' '' - Menachem Begin. (A19:1.)

title: Goodyear Plant To Lay Off 700
description: Citing the prolonged auto industry slump, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced it would lay off 700 of the 1,150 employees at its Jackson plant.

title: FEW DEMOCRATS ATTACKING PRESIDENT
description: When Bob Wise, a Democratic candidate for Congress, took his door-to-door campaign to the modest one-story home at 15 Meadow Drive, he got a surprisingly warm welcome from Kathy Lanning, a Republican who voted for Ronald Reagan in 1980.

title: Internorth Filing
description: Internorth Inc. of Omaha, a natural gas pipeline distributor, said it had increased its stake in the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer of mining and construction equipment, to 9.5 percent of the 20.4 million common shares outstanding. Internorth told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now holds 1.95 million common shares of Bucyrus-Erie, but does not plan to take control of the company. However, it said it may seek representation on the Bucyrus-Erie board if the latter's board and management ''are agreeable to such representation.''

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a reversal of a portion of a tax credit of $19,367...C-Including a tax credit of $165,579 or 15 cents a shr...D-Net loss

title: UNDER THE FLORIDA SUN, AN ENCLAVE OF FINNS
description: In this land of eternal sunburn, where the only chilly winds come from overworked air-conditioners, an enclave of Finns is thriving far from their homeland.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Addenda
description: * McCann-Erickson has established a Los Angeles agency called La Agencia de McCann-Erickson, to specialize in the Hispanic market.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS HIS ONLY 'FAILURE' ON RIGHTS IS IN COMMUNICATIONS
description: President Reagan told an audience of black educators today that his Administration's only failure in civil rights had been ''a failure to communicate what's in our hearts to the black community.''

title: FIRE DEPT.'S FIRST 42 WOMEN TAKE OATH AS PROBATIONARY FIREFIGHTERS
description: Forty-two women, the first in the 117-year history of the New York City Fire Department, were sworn in yesterday by Mayor Koch as probationary firefighters. Also inducted were 105 men.

title: Socal Tar Sands
description: The Standard Oil Company of California has agreed in principle to develop commercial oil production from the GNC Energy Corporation's 2,000 acres of tar sands holdings near Sunnyside, Utah, the companies said. The first phase of the estimated $1 billion venture will further delineate the estimated 350 million barrels of economically recoverable tar sands and bitumen, and finish development of a commercial process.

title: MUSIC CONTESTS GALORE, WHERE WILL IT END?
description: WHAT is going to become of the music competition, that exciting and glamorous event that was made significant once upon a time by being relatively rare? Competitions seem to be multiplying like festivals these days, and, as everyone must be aware by now, festivals are threatening to outnumber rabbits.

title: TV: 2 UNUSUAL EFFORTS UNDERWAY ON CHANNEL 9
description: IN the land of syndication these days, outside the network terrain of prime time, can be found some of the more unusual efforts to entertain the presumably insatiable and indefatigable home viewer. Certainly one such series, which is being shown on WOR-TV (Channel 9) at 11 P.M. Monday through Friday, is ''Madame's Place,'' produced by Don Van Atta and Bob Sand for Paramount Television Domestic Distribution.

title: Drug Found in 18 Horses
description: Chemists in four states have determined that 18 horses, most of them top finishers, were helped this summer by a powerful stimulant drug banned for all but experimental use.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Norwegian Ballet To Open Brooklyn Series

title: Massachusetts Is Warned To Improve Foster Care
description: A Federal District judge who wept after hearing how a 3-month-old child died of abuse has warned Massachusetts officials to improve the care of foster children or face a loss of $3.5 million in Federal funds.

title: RECESSION CAUSES U.S. WINE BOOM TO FALTER
description: The American wine boom, now roughly a decade old, is faltering. Consumers, squeezed by a national recession and cautious about spending, are no longer buying wine the way they did a few years ago.

title: Walts Ousts Vilas
description: Butch Walts ousted secondseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 6-3, 6-4, in a first-round match tonight in a $300,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. Vilas is ranked No. 4 by the W.C.T. computer. Walts, who hasn't played much this year, is ranked No. 425.

title: New Merrill Asset Fund
description: Merrill Lynch Asset Management Inc. said yesterday that it would introduce a speculative fund concentrating on the securities of financially strained companies that it believes are capable of recovery. The fund will seek long-term growth by investing in companies experiencing poor operating results or strained liquidity positions, including those in various stages of reorganization.

title: Sundstrand Sells Unit
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Sundstrand Corporation of Rockford, Ill., said yesterday that Northwestern Mutual had agreed to buy all the stock of the Standard of America Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sundstrand. The price was not disclosed. Northwestern Mutual is based in Milwaukee and Standard, based in Park Ridge, Ill., will be operated as a subsidiary.

title: VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH
description: ''ONE of the best ways for young people to develop a sense of responsibility and to learn to handle their independence is to become important in the lives of others outside the family,'' said Dr. Lee Salk, a clinical professor of psychology in pediatrics at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Primary Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations in some contested primary races, among Democrats unless otherwise specified. As always, our strongest recommendation is bipartisan: vote. The polls are open in New York City and Nassau County from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., in Westchester and Suffolk from noon to 9 P.M. New York State GOVERNOR

title: Senate Bill Would Cut Ex-Presidents' Guards
description: A Treasury Department official argued today that the Government should not pinch pennies ''in this age of terrorism'' by reducing Secret Service protection for former Presidents and their wives and widows.

title: CHIEF OF MITSUKOSHI IS OUSTED
description: The powerful chief executive of Japan's oldest and most prestigious department store chain, Mitsukoshi, was ousted today from his post in a board room struggle that followed scandals at the 310-year-old establishment.

title: Jets Planning Ticket Refund
description: The Jets plan to make immediate ticket refunds by mail for any games canceled at Shea Stadium, according to Steve Gutman, the club's secretary-treasurer.

title: RIDING TO THE TOP IN A GOLD ELEVATOR
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. H e has pushed all the buttons in his elevators for 22 seasons but the elevators never stopped at the top. He has found cables and levers and switches that some managers never knew existed but the floors usually came out ''4'' or ''5.''

title: No Headline
description: CARDINALS LIFT LEAD TO 5 1/2

title: MISSOURI
description: The Rev. James Parker turned from the altar to give holy communion to the handful of people gathered for the daily mass at the Carmelite Monastery of St. Anne here. ''The body of Christ,'' he said softly in a voice that bore a trace of his South Carolina boyhood.

title: Ex-St. John's Coach Stricken at Game
description: Alfred (Dusty) DeStefano, the basketball coach of St. John's University from 1952 to 1956, died last night after suffering a heart attack before the start of the game between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium.

title: SMALL BONN PARTY SHOWS LOSS IN POLL
description: Amid signs of disarray within the Free Democratic Party, an opinion poll showed today that its national support had dwindled to 2.3 percent of the electorate since it decided last week to leave Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's governing coalition.

title: STREET VENDORS IN PHILADELPHIA FIGHT FOR SPACE
description: The City of Brotherly Love has a new feud among street vendors competing for space as some traditional sidewalk locations vanish under a city crackdown.

title: Rusco Industries
description: Rusco Industries of Millen, Ga., said an audit committee's investigation had charged its former president with making a series of nondisclosed insider transactions that cost the company more than $2.5 million.

title: THE NOT-SO-BLEAK FUTURE OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAN REBELS FREE 20 HOSTAGES
description: Leftist guerrillas tonight released 20 of the businessmen they have held hostage at the Chamber of Commerce here since Friday.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ROBERT AITKEN'S PATRIOTIC 1782 BIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Danish Crew Filmed Roundup of Refugees
description: A Danish television crew said today it had filmed Lebanese rightist soldiers rounding up Palestinian women and children and taking them to a refugee camp where hundreds of mutilated corpses were later found.

title: Technology; Repairing A Computer
description: THOUSANDS of stores now sell computer hardware, and some specialize in selling computer software. The next type of computer store, some businessmen believe, will specialize in repairing the computers sold by all the other stores.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Promise and Reality

title: RUBENSTEIN TO BE GUEST AT GALA BENEFIT DINNER
description: ARTHUR RUBENSTEIN is scheduled to attend a gala tribute in his honor Oct. 18 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The tribute, part of the annual dinner given by the American Committee for Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science, will include a 16-minute excerpt of an interview that David Frost videotaped at the pianist's home in Geneva in April.

title: ISRAEL TO LEAVE WEST BEIRUT BY SUNDAY
description: An Israeli military spokesman outlined plans today for a phased withdrawal from West Beirut to be completed on Sunday.

title: Cuban Exile Berates the U.S.  For Closing 2 Radio Stations
description: A Cuban exile leader, criticizing the United States for shutting down two of his anti-Castro radio stations last week, says he plans a 10-station network based in Latin America to beam programs to Cuba.

title: Republic Acquisition
description: The Republicbank Corporation said today that it had proposed to acquire the Texas National Bank of Midland, Tex., in exchange for 280,000 common shares, in a transaction worth about $7.6 million. Texas National has assets of about $39 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co. said it had sold $300 million of sinking fund debentures, due 2012, to yield 12.70 percent at 98.451, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Shell Chemical Unit Sale
description: The Shell Canada Chemical Company, a unit of Shell Canada Ltd., said it had agreed in principle to sell some of its agricultural chemical formulating and marketing activities to Ciba-Geigy Canada Ltd. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: SOVIET, ASSERTING C.I.A. LIES, DENIES ANY PLOT TO KILL POPE
description: The Soviet Union today denied any involvement in the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II. Contending that operatives of the Central Intelligence Agency planted the story, the official press agency Tass said, ''They in Washington hoped to throw a stone at the Soviet Union, but they threw a boomerang.''

title: MONDALE URGES STRONGER U.S. AID TO INDUSTRY
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, speaking at the steelworkers' national meeting here, said today that the Reagan Administration's economic policies had wrought havoc in steel and other manufacturing industries.

title: MRS. GANDHI, ON SOVIET VISIT, AFFIRMS INDIAN NONALIGNMENT
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India ended a visit today in which tributes to Soviet-Indian friendship were tempered by her care to demonstrate nonalignment.

title: Lord, Geller Retains Schieffelin Account
description: Although the odds were slight as far as the client was concerned, Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has managed to hold onto its Schieffelin & Company account, which is mostly Hennessy Cognac.

title: Bread and Circus
description: Fallen Railroad Aristocrats

title: Plea Entered In Tellco Fraud
description: A New Jersey man pleaded guilty yesterday to charges he manipulated and misrepresented the value of stock in a company he owned, Federal authorities said.

title: Rangers Defeat Islanders, 2-1
description: For the Islanders, winners of the Stanley Cup the last three seasons, it was only an exhibition game, an opportunity to test and evaluate inexperienced players.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A former air quality monitor for atomic tests at the Nevada Test Site in the early 1950's told a Federal court today that he reported at the time that fallout could be a health hazard.

title: THE LONGEST HUDDLE
description: So you think the football strike is a silly row between greedy club owners and consciousness-raised players, with the only losers the fans?

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently moved into an apartment with hardwood floors that have been professionally finished with polyurethane. How should these floors be maintained? Can they be scrubbed, and should they be waxed?

title: Apple Wins A Tax Battle
description: Apple Computer Inc. won a battle in Congress today to get large tax deductions for donations of computers to schools.

title: WATER PRIORITIES
description: Is America running out of water? Yes - but you wouldn't think so by looking at the history of water legislation in the Congress, where water has traditionally fallen victim to porkbarrel politics. Only recently has political influence and the desire for new construction money and jobs given way to the beginnings of true concern for a sound national water policy.

title: Silver Traders Sue Hunts, Ask $94.6 Million
description: A former chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Hunt brothers of Texas have been accused of taking part in a scheme that cost two investors $2.6 million in the silver futures market.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
BRAZIL PLUNGES WITH ZEST INTO NOVEL ELECTION FRAY
description: ''This space reserved for dishonest candidates,'' reads the inscription the owners of the Corazza Brothers furniture company have placed outside their warehouse in a Sao Paulo suburb.

title: Deficit Widens At Eastern Air
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said today that its loss for the first eight months of 1982 widened to $55.8 million from $8.9 million in the comparable period of 1981.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ALLIED ACQUISITIVE CHAIRMAN
description: It is fortunate that Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Corporation, belongs to the management school that believes a good executive can run any type of company. If that were not the case, he would certainly have to be nervous about the future of Allied as it attempts to merge with the Bendix Corporation.

title: MILLIONS OF BRITONS WALK OFF THEIR JOBS
description: Millions of British labor unionists staged strikes and mass rallies today in support of workers in the National Health Service who are seeking higher wages.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rare Centerfolds

title: U.N. DEBATES KILLINGS TOMORROW
description: The General Assembly has scheduled a special session on Friday to consider the West Beirut massacre.

title: MRS. ELMO ROPER
description: Dorothy Shaw Roper, widow of Elmo Roper, the public-opinion pollster, died Tuesday at her home in Redding, Conn.

title: STORE TAKES A LOOK AT THE FUTURE
description: IN September, department stores traditionally have promotions with themes that will tempt customers into shopping. The theme is usually a country or a historic city, whose merchandise is highlighted.- Gimbels has taken a different tack. Its current promotion is not so much selling products as offering information, education and a bit of fun. Called ''Touch Tomorrow Today,'' it is about the future - specifically, how space technology is affecting and will affect everyday life on planet earth.

title: AS SUMMER ENDS, CITY IS SHELTERING AS MANY HOMELESS AS LAST WINTER
description: On Tuesday night, as summer was drawing to a close, New York City provided 3,882 homeless men and women with beds, about the same number of people who sought shelter during the peak periods of winter last year, according to city officials.

title: OUT OF WOOD DEFECT, THE BEAUTY OF BURL
description: THE logs of most trees, when cut through and through as they come to the saw, expose surfaces with interesting grain patterns. Finer figurings come from selected trees where the branches spread from the trunk. Here, irregularities in the flow of the grain - accompanied by subtle but conspicuous variations in color and tone - produce the swirl-and-feather-crotch veneers mahogany is famed for.

title: THE CITY;
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has approved a $19.8 million grant to rehabilitate a waste-water treatment plant at Coney Island.

title: HOUSE REPORT CRITICIZES INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES
description: The House Intelligence Committee approved a staff report today that criticized the performance of United States intelligence agencies in Central America in the last few years.

title: Bridge: The Analyst Looks Ahead In Double-Dummy Cases
description: There is a subtle distinction between chess problems and doubledummy bridge problems. The chess solver sometimes has to look backwards and consider how the position was arrived at, using retro-analysis. The bridge solver faced with - say, a six-card end position - only looks forward, although some imaginative genius once solved an insoluble problem by demonstrating that an opponent must have revoked to reach the given position.

title: OPERA: TALVELA SINGS GODUNOV AT MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's ''Boris Godunov,'' now eight seasons old, has been one of the company's most glorious achievements in a decade when glories have not been everyday events. In part, though only in part, the production owes its undiminished luster to the continuing presence of Martti Talvela in the title role. The towering Finnish basso, the Boris of the 1974 premiere, returned Tuesday night to play out a broken old monarch's tragedy in a way that had overtones of King Lear to it.

title: ENERGY SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STATE ACTS ON BRINK'S DEFENDANT
description: Rockland County moved today to drop charges against Nathaniel Burns, one of six defendants in the Brink's robbery and murder case, so that he can face a ''more expansive Federal prosecution.''

title: AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS REVEAL HEAT LEAKS
description: TO bolster lagging energy-audit programs, some utility companies in colder parts of the country are turning to a method of heat-sensitive aerial photography that, at first glance, might seem more valuable to spies than to homeowners.

title: OUR ARCHITECTS OF SHAKY DEBT STRUCTURES
description: To the Editor:

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: BENDIX AND ALLIED AGREE TO A MERGER
description: The Allied Corporation and the Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, making Allied the fourth entry in one of the most bizarre takeover battles in American corporate history.

title: COURSES IN HOME MAINTENANCE FOR DO-IT-YOURSELFERS
description: EACH fall, do-it-yourselfers turn to continuing education centers around town for how-to workshops in home repairs and renovations. Registration is under way at the institutions in the following sampling. Most classes are held weekday evenings or Saturdays; some at the New School for Social Research are in the early afternoon. To register for courses by mail, students are usually required to complete cards that appear in fall catalogues. New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.

title: REAGAN SIAD TO SEE ISRAEL AS THE MIDEAST'S 'GOLIATH,' NOT 'DAVID'
description: The conflict in Lebanon has had what senior White House officials describe as a ''profound effect'' on President Reagan's attitude toward Israel. Mr. Reagan reportedly said recently that Israel had moved from being the ''David'' to the ''Goliath'' of the Middle East.

title: MUBARAK REBUKES ISRAEL ON KILLINGS
description: President Hosni Mubarak, in an address before some 4,000 leaders of his ruling National Democratic Party, sharply castigated Israel tonight for its role in the West Beirut massacre.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (Television -Sports@Channel, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 2:30 P.M.) Yachting Xerox Challengers Series, starting at the America's Cup buoy, Newport R.I., 11 A.M. The competition, among five foreign 12-Meter yachts is serving as a preview of challengers for next year's America's Cup.

title: Bendix and Allied Agree to a Merger
description: The Allied Corporation and the Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, making Allied the fourth entry in one of the most bizarre takeover battles in American corporate history.

title: Hyatt Hotel Unit Names Chief Operating Officer
description: Bernd Chorengel has been elected executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Hyatt International Corporation, the international hotel chain owned and operated by the Pritzker family of Chicago.

title: Market Place; Tax-Exempts: Caution Urged
description: INVESTORS are racing to lock up double-digit returns in tax-exempts and, in some cases, may be doing so without regard to safety. That's the viewpoint of one professional who follows this market closely. He is Sylvan Feldstein, a vice president and bond analyst for Moody's Investors Service. Mr. Feldstein says there are many good bonds offering yields in excess of 10 percent even now.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: U.S. IS CONVINCED ISRAEL IS LEAVING
description: The United States said today that it was satisfied Israel was taking steps to comply with the American insistence that its troops be withdrawn from Beirut.

title: Jessie Emmet, Leader In Child Development
description: Jessie K. Emmet, a leading figure in the fields of child development and education, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She would have been 73 years old today.

title: CHIEF ADVERSARIES IN PRO FOOTBALL'S LABOR DISPUTE
description: Regardless of the outcome of the strike by the players he leads, Ed Garvey's chief accomplishment of the last decade has been a significant one.

title: PENTAGON TO TEST 3 NEW IDENTIFICATION CARDS
description: The Defense Department has decided to test three alternatives to the standard paper identification card for military personnel, including one with a tiny built-in computer microprocessor.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After gains of $112,005,000 from imputed interest, special charges and credits...C-Net loss after $5.4 million charge from imputed interest, special charges and credits

title: JUDGE LETS MARIETTA PURSUE BENDIX BID
description: The Bendix Corporation last night failed in its last-ditch effort to convince a court to halt the Martin Marietta Corporation's $900 million bid for a controlling stake in Bendix, which already owns 70 percent of Marietta.

title: Man Hit by Tail Rotor Of Helicopter Is Killed
description: A man was killed yesterday when he walked into the blades of a helicopter at the 60th Street Heliport on the East River, the police said.

title: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
KNICKS NEGOTIATING FOR BERNARD KING
description: The Knicks are expected to give Bernard King, the high-scoring free-agent forward of the Golden State Warriors, an offer sheet within the next several days. Details are being worked out between Dave DeBusschere, the team's executive vice president, and Bill Pollack, King's Washington-based lawyer. The offer is expected to be a five-year pact at $750,000 a year, plus a bonus.

title: STATE VOTERS TO DECIDE MOST PRIMARIES EVER
description: New York voters will decide today the outcome of the greatest number of primaries in the Democratic and Republican Parties since statewide primaries began 14 years ago.

title: LOUISIANA PARENTS RECONSIDER SCHOOLING AT HOME AFTER YEAR
description: A year ago schools were set up in 244 Louisiana homes after a state law was enacted allowing parents with no formal training to teach their children with minimal supervision.

title: AVERTING THEIR EYES
description: In the holiest week of the Jewish year, the week of penitence, the Prime Minister of Israel has closed his eyes to evil and rejected the doctrine of personal responsibility. That has been Menachem Begin's reaction to the Beirut massacre, ending in his refusal to have an impartial commission of inquiry.

title: CHARLES BENNETT, EX-REPORTER, DIES
description: Charles G. Bennett, a City Hall reporter for The New York Times for two decades, died Tuesday at the Albany Medical Center after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had lived in Bennington, Vt., since retiring in 1969.

title: JAZZ TRIO: 'SOME MUSIC'
description: THE concert at Roulette on Monday night was called ''some music.'' And the humble lower-cased ambitions of that title were to a large extent fulfilled.

title: A.T.& T.-Philips Talks
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's A.T.& T. International Inc. subsidiary said today that it had started discussions with N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken division of the Netherlands regarding a possible joint effort in telecommunciations outside the United States. It said the initial emphasis would be on digital switching for public networks, but that no agreement had yet been reached.

title: PROSECUTION AND DEFENSE SPAR AT GIBSON TRIAL
description: The prosecution in the conspiracy and misconduct trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and a former City Council President, Earl Harris, told the jury today that the man they hired to oversee security for the city's water system ''did nothing.''

title: Venezuela to Seek Loan
description: Venezuela plans to ask foreign banks soon for a two- to five-year loan of between $600 million and $800 million, Ignacio Sandoval, director of public finances, said today in an interview.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After five months off the tennis tour, Bjorn Borg has resumed training in Stockholm. He expects to be ready for a new tournament Nov. 29 in Antwerp, Belgium.

title: Holman of Mets Gets First Major League Victory
description: Scott Holman got his first major league victory, Doug Sisk got his first major league save and the Mets got a reprieve today as they beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-2.

title: Louisiana Prison Ruling Expanded by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge examining overcrowded parish prisons in Louisiana expanded the case today to every facility in the state that holds a prisoner.

title: 1982 Steel Sales Could Fall 28%
description: A Bethlehem Steel Corporation executive predicted today that domestic steel shipments would drop to about 63 million tons this year, 28 percent below the 87 million shipped in 1981.

title: Kenya Accuses Son Of a Political Outcast
description: The son of former Vice President Ajuma Oginga Odinga was charged with treason today for conspiring to overthrow the Government at the time of the Aug. 1 uprising.

title: 20,000 Protest in Argentina Against Junta's Wage Policy
description: About 20,000 people held a rally outside the headquarters of the military Government tonight to protest low pay and high inflation.

title: Two Leave Phibro Unit
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc. said yesterday that two vice presidents of its Philipp Brothers Inc. commodities trading subsidiary had resigned to form a new commodities firm. Phibro emphasized that only two officials had left, saying that reports circulating on Wall Street that several Philipp employees had left were ''grossly distorted.''

title: YANKEES FALL INTO SIXTH PLACE
description: Doyle Alexander pitched last night and survived. So did the Yankees who played behind him. The Yankees, though, were done in by Rick Sutcliffe, who allowed them only two hits in six innings as the Cleveland Indians won, 5-0, and dumped the Yankees into sixth place in the American League East.

title: STATE SEEKING ABORTION FOR A RETARDED WOMAN
description: In a highly unusual case, lawyers from the New York State Attorney General's office won a court order last night in an effort to reverse a court decision that denies an abortion for a retarded 25-year-old woman with the mental age of a 1 1/2-year-old child.

title: LETTER BACKING RIVAL A FAKE, MINERS' PRESIDENT CONTENDS
description: Sam M. Church Jr., running hard for reelection as president of the United Mine Workers, asserted today that a document purporting to make his opponent eligible to run against him was a forgery.

title: Parting of the Ways For Milliken and B.& B.
description: The Milliken Breakfast Show was a fixture on the fashion scene for many a year and annually absorbed almost the entire promotion budget of Milliken & Company.

title: Harvester Unit
description: The International Harvester Company, the debtridden maker of trucks and farm implements, announced that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Mutual Life Assurance Company of Canada to sell Harvester's life insurance unit. The Milwaukee-based Harvester insurance division is a unit of the Harvester Credit Corporation, and has assets of about $29 million and life insurance in force of approximately $2.4 billion. The intention to sell the unit was announced several months ago, and analysts say that the sale will not result in any substantial income for Harvester.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The 1982 Election: Nebraska First of 10 articles appearing periodically on key state races.
description: On autumn Saturdays, when the University of Nebraska plays football at home, the giant stadium here turns into the state's third-largest city, a roisterous, howling congregation of 76,000 fans, most clad in bright Cornhusker red. For anyone seeking public office in Nebraska, the opportunities are obvious.

title: AEG Creates New Company
description: The United Technologies Corporation and financially troubled AEG-Telefunken signed a final agreement for the creation of a jointly owned electronic components company.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Suspect to Defend Himself
description: A judge ruled Tuesday that Edward Thomas Mann, who is accused of firing shots that killed three persons and wounded nine others at an International Business Machines office in May, could act as his own attorney. However, Circuit Judge William Miller told him, ''I think you are making a bad mistake.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting Election Results From the Polls to the People

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart accompanying an article yesterday about The New York Times/CBS News Poll listed incor- rect figures in one category. Of those respondents who said their family financial situation was worse than it was a year ago, 23 percent said they would vote Republican and 68 percent said they would vote Democratic; of those who said their family financial situation was the same as a year ago, 39 percent said they would vote Re- publican and 52 percent Democratic; of those who said their family finan- cial situation was better than it was a year ago, 54 percent said they would vote Republican and 38 percent Demo- cratic.

title: ANGRY ISRAELI ARABS IN NAZARETH CLASH WITH POLICE
description: Dozens of Israeli Arabs and Israeli policemen were injured in clashes today as Israeli Arabs staged a general strike to protest the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut.

title: ARTURO BROWN MOURNED IN BROOKLYN
description: Some mourners wore dark suits and dresses at the funeral mass for Arturo Brown, the 21-year-old Boston University senior and basketball player who died of a heart attack during a pickup game last Friday, but others wore sweaters instead of suits, and brightly colored dresses instead of black.

title: 9 PCB Protesters Arrested
description: Nine more protesters were arrested today when they tried to block trucks from entering a Warren County landfill to dump soil containing the toxic chemical polychlorinated biphenyl, or PCB. The arrests brought the number of people charged in eight days of demonstrations to 242.

title: Plucking the Chicken
description: Don Schulze, a minor league pitcher who suffered a shoulder separation when tackled by the San Diego Chicken last year, has filed a $2 million damage suit in Federal Court against the popular stadium entertainer.

title: DOMINION MORTGAGE REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Energy Sources
description: Energy Sources Inc. of Dallas said that as a result of losses incurred this year it is in technical default of certain covenants of its loans with banks and others, and has presented its bank with a plan to reduce the deficiency. The company also reported a thirdquarter loss of $4.5 million compared with a deficit of $518,000 a year earlier. As a result of its losses, the company said it it had reduced its staff by 25 percent, cut salaries 10 percent to 15 percent, realigned management, halted a planned coal project and withdrawn from a merger deal with Energy Sources Exchange Inc.

title: Judge Set to Fine Striking Teachers
description: A State Superior Court judge arranged a schedule of fines today against striking schoolteachers in Teaneck who have ignored a back-to-work injunction issued last Friday. But he delayed imposing the fines until at least Tuesday.

title: A PRUDENT REFUSAL BY SOLIDARITY LEADERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: AKE. THE YEARS OF CHILDHOOD. By Wole Soyinka. 230 pages. Random House. $14.95.

title: XEROX'S NEW LINE OF COPIERS
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced the first of a new family of copiers that it said would eventually replace its entire product line and help it compete with Japanese companies.

title: ARCHITECT'S LECTURE DISPLAY OF PORCELAIN
description: Alliance of Women in Architecture, at Knoll Showroom, 105 Wooster Street; 212-580-7369.

title: MILITARY EXPERTS URGE RELIANCE ON SUBMARINES AND BOMBERS
description: The tens of billions of dollars the Reagan Administration is seeking to spend on the MX missile would be better spent on submarines and bombers, a group of military experts says.

title: MAGELLAN PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston and Pacific stock exchanges

title: Mrs. Truman Said to Improve
description: Bess Truman, hospitalized since early this month for treatment of a bleeding ulcer, has improved and may be able to return home this weekend, her physician, Dr. Wallace Graham, said today. He added that if the 97-year-old widow of Harry S. Truman continued to improve, she might be able to return to her home in Independence this weekend.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for QTr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $45,077,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of Dannon and a gain of $31,870,000 for the 6 mos from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for investment tax credits

title: News Analysis; IN ISRAEL, ANGUISH OVER THE MORAL QUESTIONS
description: The Beirut massacre has plunged Israel into moral turmoil. To many Israelis, the old foundations of right and wrong feel shaken loose. A sudden wilderness seems to have enveloped the nation. There is no voice to speak for its conscience.

title: OROSCO EXCELS IN RELIEF
description: The Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5-4, today and completed their second series sweep of a season they would rather sweep away.

title: BOY FROM AUSTRALIA UP THERE WITH THE ROCKETTES
description: PETER ALLEN'S weeklong engagement at the Radio City Music Hall, starting tonight, promises to deliver the kind of glittering show business razzle-dazzle that is a rarity on the New York concert stage. Mr. Allen became a Music Hall institution almost two years ago when he made a sensational stage entrance astride a camel, then proceeded to hoof it up with the Rockettes. Not since Bette Midler's ''Divine Madness'' had a solo performer staged such an uninhibited extravaganza in a major New York house. And its success - the three shows originally scheduled were extended to seven - proved that Mr. Allen had finally arrived as a big-time pop entertainer.

title: TOUGHER TRAINING SOUGHT FOR PILOTS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, reacting to a series of accidents of Learjet business planes, recommended yesterday that private pilots learning to fly high-performance jets be compelled to meet much tougher training requirements.

title: Mom's Wear
description: In the 1950's pregnant women were urged to wear something with a big bow or a big collar to bring attention up and away from a temporarily lost figure. The something was usually a smock draped over a portholed skirt.

title: Dow Declines 1.84, to 925.77; Volume Off to 68.3 Million
description: Stock prices eased yesterday as volume showed a sharp contraction from the exceptionally heavy turnover on Wednesday. Analysts attributed the slower turnover to lessened trading activity by institutional investors.

title: 31 IN CONGRESS ASK BEGIN TO BACK INQUIRY
description: Thirty-one of Israel's supporters in the House of Representatives have appealed to Prime Minister Menachem Begin to drop his objections to an impartial investigation into the Beirut killings. Otherwise, they said, ''very grave consequences'' could result in Israeli-American relations.

title: JOYOUS CUOMO GRATEFUL FOR SUPPORT FROM KOCH
description: Amid scenes of pandemonium among his supporters, an ebullient Mario M. Cuomo claimed the Democratic nomination for Governor late last night and said he was grateful for the promised support of Mayor Koch in the general election campaign.

title: Provident National
description: The Provident National Corporation said yesterday that its shareholders had voted to approve a merger with the Pittsburgh National Corporation.

title: FORCED RETIREMENT FOR PROFESSORS ONLY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Penchina's Direct Way
description: THE story of how Penchina/Selkowitz Inc. won the advertising assignment for the Burroughs Corporation's B-20 small-business computer system is interesting in its simplicity.

title: MUSIC: MISS VERRETT SINGS CHAUSSON
description: FOR unannounced reasons, Shirley Verrett decided not to sing the scheduled excerpts from ''Les Troyens'' at last night's New York Philharmonic concert. That probably upset some people in the audience who remembered the soprano's spectacular feat in the Berlioz opera at the Metropolitan in 1973, when she sang both Cassandra and Dido in the same performance. However, what Miss Verrett did choose to sing on this occasion, as well as how she sang it, completely blew away any clouds of disappointment.

title: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,251,275...C-Including a tax credit of $571,134 and an extraordinary gain of $22,726,876 from the restructuring of debt

title: U.S. TO PAY FOR FALLOW CORN ACREAGE
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that corn farmers would be paid next year to idle 10 percent of the land they normally planted with corn, but that they would have to idle an additional 10 percent without payment to become eligible for commodity support programs.

title: TEXACO APPOINTS HEAD OF NEW OVERSEAS UNIT
description: Texaco Inc. yesterday announced the establishment of a new operating division, to be known as Texaco Middle East/Far East, and appointed Elton G. Yates to head it.

title: Chrysler Awaits Mitsubishi Answer
description: The Chrysler Corporation is trying to persuade the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan to join it in making a new small-car line in the United States, but Mitsubishi has made no decision, Gerald Greenwald, Chrysler's vice chairman, said.

title: TOLL FROM FLOODS IN EL SALVADOR AND GUATEMALA IS OVER 1,200
description: The death toll from flooding and mudslides in San Salvador and neighboring Guatemala climbed to more than 1,200 today as rescue teams reached isolated communities devastated by four days of torrential rains.

title: Florida Philharmonic To Cease Sept. 30
description: The Florida Philharmonic, beset by a nearly eight-month strike by musicians, will shut down for good next Thursday, ending 18 years of performances.

title: Amoco Extending Discount Program
description: The Amoco Oil Company said it would offer discounts for cash purchases at gas stations throughout its system.

title: THEATER: 'A DOLL'S LIFE,' MUSICAL SEQUEL TO IBSEN
description: THE season is still young, but it's not likely to produce a more perplexing curiosity than ''A Doll's Life,'' the dour musical that opened at the Mark Hellinger last night. On this occasion, three legendary Broadway hands -Harold Prince, Betty Comden and Adolph Green - have inflated a spectacularly unpromising premise with loads of money, good intentions and hard work, only to end up with a show that collapses in its prologue and then skids into a toboggan slide from which there is no return. These calamities happen, of course, but not usually to artists who've been leading lights in the musical theater for two generations. Call ''A Doll's Life'' a casual blunder, which, like Topsy, just grew and grew and grew.

title: House Approves C.F.T.C. Bill
description: The House of Representatives today approved legislation extending for four years the regulatory power of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. But it defeated a controversial Reagan Administration proposal to levy a users' fee on all commodity futures transactions.

title: CALIFORNIA BOTTLE BILL BRINGS COSTLY FIGHT
description: California will provide another major contest between environmentalists and an industrial group in the November election with a voter-initiated referendum on bottle control.

title: Grace M. Belt, 75, Dies; Ex-State Dept. Official
description: Grace M. Belt, a former State Department official who had been responsible for introducing distinguished foreign visitors to New York City's cultural and intellectual community, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old.

title: CORONA CONVICTED AGAIN IN 25 FARM WORKERS SLAYING
description: Juan V. Corona was convicted today for the second time of killing 25 itinerant farm workers whose bodies were hacked, stabbed and buried in peach orchards along northern California's Feather River in 1971.

title: POP: CARRACK AND LOWE
description: PAUL CARRACK'S performance Wednesday at the Ritz with Nick Lowe and his band, Noise to Go, offered a skillful blend of mid-60's-style ''blue-eyed soul''' and 70's English pub rock.

title: DOME'S CHAIRMAN ALWAYS AN OPTIMIST
description: Every summer for the past several years, ships of Dome Petroleum Ltd. have plowed through the ice to drilling sites in the Beaufort Sea. Riding with them have been the hopes of thousands of investors for a major oil find.

title: LETTER TO THE ISRAELI PREMIER
description: Following is the text of a letter concerning the Beirut massacre signed by 31 members of Congress and sent to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel Wednesday:

title: U.S. Cuts Loan Rates
description: Interest rates on Governmentbacked mortgage loans were cut today for the third time in six weeks. Effective Friday, the rate on single-family mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration will fall a half point, to 13.5 percent, their lowest level since November 1980.

title: No Headline
description: GIANTS TOP REDS, 11-7, GAIN ON DODGERS

title: LEBANESE SWORN IN AND URGES PEACE
description: Amin Gemayel took office as President today and pledged to work toward transforming Lebanon ''into a new, dynamic country'' free of foreign troops and of the long ''vicious cycle of bloody violence'' that it has suffered.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I offer no program for a new era because a single concern grips us now.

title: JAZZ: MCGRIFF LEADS QUARTET
description: JIMMY MCGRIFF, the jazz organist, has found a way out of the stereotypes into which jazz organ playing has fallen. Instead of keeping his organ in the spotlight with heavy, massive blues figures or high, shrill, agitated lines, Mr. McGriff uses it largely as a background instrument for the quartet that he is leading at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, through tomorrow.

title: IRISH CHIEF SEES NEW FUTURE IN ULSTER
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey says that the British attempt to create a new provincial assembly in Northern Ireland next month is ''doomed to failure'' and will further unsettle conditions there.

title: BEAUTIFUL AND BLOND
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Teleflex Bucks The Recession
description: TELEFLEX INC. has managed to do well in the recession despite heavy dependence on three hard-hit industries. This maker of mechanical and electromechanical controls and systems for small boats, aircraft and automobiles earned an exceptional return on equity, one enjoyed by a mere handful of companies in 1981 -partly because of increasing use of the sophisticated devices by its customers.

title: U.S. Auctions 109 Boats Used by Cuban Refugees
description: More than 1,000 registered bidders, including boat fanciers and bargain hunters from around the country, bid fiercely today for 109 boats the Government seized in the sealift of Cuban refugees in 1980.

title: RAILROADS RETURNING TO NORMAL AFTER 4-DAY STRIKE
description: Freight and passenger trains began rolling again yesterday, ending a four-day national strike by engineers that Congress ordered halted before serious damage was done to the economy.

title: Chemical Explosion Destroys Los Angeles Munitions Plant
description: Explosions that began while two workers were mixing chemicals destroyed a munitions plant Thursday, sending smoke up thousands of feet and startling residents two miles away, officials said.

title: Ex-Official Suggests Cutting Aid to Israel
description: Harold H. Saunders, former Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said today that the withholding of aid from Israel ''might be necessary at some point in the future.''

title: LEBANON'S PREMIER DEFENDS HIS ARMY'S ROLE
description: Lebanon's Prime Minister today denounced an Israeli statement that Christian militiamen were sent into two Palestinian refugee camps here last week because the Lebanese Army had refused to take them over.

title: Rare Disease Suspected
description: Arturo Brown, the Boston University basketball player who collapsed and died during a pickup game last Friday, may have been suffering from a rare heart ailment, according to Dr. Jeff Isner of Tufts-New England Medical Center. The doctor analyzed slides of Brown's heart tissue and said Brown may have had a condition known as idiopathic hypertrophiccardiomyopathy, or IHSS, which the doctor called, ''a heart that is muscle-bound, sometimes restricting blood flow.'' Dr. Isner said, ''Arturo did have a small area of heart muscle that had died. In the technical sense, he had a prior heart attack, which is often found in IHSS victims.''

title: Devils' Levo Stays in Finland
description: Less than two weeks before their regular season opener, the New Jersey Devils today were told by Tapio Levo, the Finn who was expected to solidify their defense, that he would not return to the National Hockey League.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 11American Fool* John Cougar 22Mirage Fleetwood Mac 33Abracadabra* Steve Miller Band 44Asia Asia 55Emotions in Motion* Billy Squier 612If That's What It Takes Michael McDonald 77Good Trouble REO Speedwagon 88Vacation* The Go-Go's 99Chicago 16* Chicago 1011Eye in the Sky* Alan Parsons Project Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 12Jack and Diane* John Cougar 21Abracadabra Steve Miller Band 33Hard to Say I'm Sorry Chicago 44Eye of the Tiger Survivor 55She Talks About You Melissa Manchester 66Eye in the Sky* Alan Parsons Project 77Who Can It Be Now?* Men At Work 88Somebody's Baby* Jackson Browne 915I Keep Forgettin'* Michael McDonald 109Hurts So Good John Cougar Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc. said it would build a $40 million air-separation plant in Convent, La., to supply gases to Texaco U.S.A.'s Louisiana refinery operations.

title: O'Neill Says Congress Plans To Recess by Next Weekend
description: House and Senate leaders have agreed that Congress will recess at the end of next week, returning in late November for a lame-duck session to finish its work, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today.

title: KOCH SEES SOME GOOD AS HE CONCEDES DEFEAT
description: Last night, for the first time in 20 years, Edward I. Koch had to do what he likes least to do in politics: concede defeat. ''It's better to win than to lose,'' he said, to applause from 300 dazed supporters in the Imperial Ballroom at the Sheraton Centre. ''I have no regrets,'' he said. ''I'm still the Mayor and that's not bad. In fact, it's good. It will help make me a better mayor, so don't be upset.''

title: Clampett Shares Lead in Lead
description: Bobby Clampett shot a five-under-par 65 today and shared the lead with Lance Ten Broeck after the first round of the $250,000 Southern Open Golf Tournament.

title: BUSH URGES ARABS TO ACCEPT ISRAEL
description: Vice President Bush said today that the recent implied recognition of Israel by the Arab League at its meeting at Fez was ''not enough'' and that Arab nations should state ''with clarity'' that Israel had a right to exist.

title: OIL-DRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Breeding for Brains
description: Y esterday's topic at the New York Academy of Sciences on East 63d Street was designer genes.

title: STAG-SHOW 'ROASTING' FOR THURMOND
description: It was not one of Washington's usual gala charity affairs with waltzes, champagne and a great many forks at the dinner table.

title: DOLLAR DAYS IN ANAHEIM
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. I f you rattled a metal piggy bank nearly filled with 51,273 halfdollar coins, it would make a mighty noise. So does a nearly full stadium inflamed by a Reggie Jackson home run, a Reggie Jackson strikeout, even a sloppy Reggie Jackson slide.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8:05 P.M. The Phillies enter the next-to-last weekend of the season desperate for a series sweep that could put them closer to the first-place Cardinals. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Boston. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Mark Medal vs. Daryl Penn, junior middleweights, and Jose Baret vs. Eddie Flannings, junior middleweights, 10-round co-feature bouts, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. The first preliminary on the seven-bout card begins at 7:30 P.M. The Garden, clearing out inventory to make way for the thumbless boxing gloves, will give every ticket buyer a free pair of Everlast gloves, the ones with the thumbs. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. Trevita and Prismatical are leading contenders in the $100,000-added Queen Charlotte for fillies and mares at a mile and three-eighths.

title: U.N. OFFICIAL ASSAILS KILLINGS IN LEBANON, NOT IN AFGHANISTAN
description: Imre Hollai of Hungary, the new President of the General Assembly, today discounted the Sovietinflicted deaths in Afghanistan but deplored the massacre in Beirut.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Monday incorrectly identified the net- work affiliation of WKBW television in Buffalo. It is affiliated with ABC.

title: STEVE ALLEN AND SEYMOUR GLICK DO THEIR SHTICK
description: ''THE show is actually a joke, a play on words,'' Steve Allen said the other night between shows. ''A few years ago somebody asked me, 'Have you seen ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well''?' and I answered, 'No, but I've seen ''Seymour Glick Is Alive but Sick.'' ' ''

title: A Swing In Bonn
description: Collapse of West Germany's coalition with a new chancellor expected soon and elections coming sharpens a backroom Washington debate that has been going on for over a year. Will the U.S. be better off dealing with conservatives than it was with the Socialists' Chancellor Helmut Schmidt?

title: Stastnys End Holdouts
description: The Stastny brothers - Peter, Marian and Anton - ended their holdouts and skated yesterday with the Nordiques in Quebec.

title: Time Hires 6 Agencies To Study Teletext Ads
description: Time Inc. is obviously serious about its move into teletext. Its Time Video Services, which was announced late last year and is intended to create a full-channel teletext service, has hired six of the country's largest ad agencies to investigate the advertising possibilities of teletext.

title: MOVE IS BEGUN TO REOPEN TALKS
description: While each side continued talking of the possibility of going its own way, there was movement yesterday toward opening negotiations to settle the strike by pro football players.

title: Reds Rehire Nixon
description: Russ Nixon, who has been the interim manager of the Cincinnati Reds since July 21 when John McNamara was fired, yesterday signed to lead the club through the 1983 season. Since taking over as manager, Nixon has a 22-37 record. ''I think he's done a top job under all the circumstances,'' said Dick Wagner, the club president, in announcing the appointment of the 47-year-old former catcher.

title: CALLS FOR INQUIRY MOUNTING IN ISRAEL
description: Increasing demands were voiced in Israel today for an impartial judicial inquiry into the massacre of Palestinians in two refugee camps in Beirut last week, and there were protest demonstrations demanding that the Government sanction such an investigation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE REMARKS BY CUOMO, KOCH AND LEHERMAN
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Koch and Lewis E. Lehrman, as broadcast by WABC-TV: By Mr. Koch

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose just 0.3 percent in August, the Labor Department reported. The figure indicated that the inflation rate for the year could slow to 5.5 percent or below, the lowest level in six years and less than half that of 1979 and 1980. For the year so far, the Consumer Price Index is up at an annual rate of 5.1 percent. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan hailed the new data as evidence that recovery was near. (Page A1.) Prices in the New York area rose 0.5 percent. (D3.) The Senate killed a bill that would have let investors take a longterm capital gains tax break on profits from securities and other assets held for six months. (D1.)

title: Used Books in Scarsdale
description: Thousands of used books will be on sale at a book fair sponsored by the Friends of Scarsdale Library in Westchester. The sale will go on tomorrow 10 to 3 and Sunday noon to 3 at the library, on White Plains Park and Olmsted Roads in Scarsdale Information: (914) 723-2005.

title: COONEY IS PLANNING TO TRAIN AGAIN
description: Gerry Cooney, emerging from the shadows that have surrounded his boxing career since he was stopped by Larry Holmes last June 11, said yesterday that he was ''starting to miss fighting'' and that it would not be long before he resumed training.

title: Labor Talks Continue At the Philharmonic
description: Negotiations continued yesterday at Lincoln Center for a new contract between the New York Philharmonic and its musicians.

title: Bridge:; Roman System of Signals Attracts American Players
description: Roman signals have become increasingly popular among American experts with good reason. In many situations they allow the partner of the opening leader to convey more information on the first trick than is possible with the traditional attitude signal - high to encourage, low to discourage.

title: JET TRAINER PREDICTS AN INJURY PROBLEM
description: If the National Football League strike goes into a second week, it is likely to result in a higher injury rate when players return, the Jets' trainer, Bob Reese, predicted.

title: 3 NEW SERIES AND HBO'S 'CAMELOT'
description: A FEW new weekly television series can be sampled this weekend, and one of them is ''Bring 'em Back Alive,'' which CBS (Channel 2) is previewing with a two-hour special tonight at 8, but which will then have its premiere in its regular time period next Tuesday at 8 P.M. Confusing matters further, the preview and the premiere constitute a two-part episode. One will not make much sense without the other. On the other hand, maybe sense has nothing to do with this situation.

title: Liberty isle's new statues.
description: SOMETHING has changed on Liberty Island in New York Harbor. There are sculptures there now on permanent display, five at the pier end of the promenade leading to the Statue of Liberty, eight more in the monument's lobby. They were installed during the summer under the supervision of the sculptor, Phillip Ratner.

title: Hanoi Hints at Terms On Missing Americans
description: Vietnam will permit searches for 2,500 United States servicemen missing during the war in Indochina if Washington improves ties with Hanoi, four relatives of missing Americans said today. Washington has no diplomatic ties with Hanoi.

title: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $42,890,000 for the qr and $48,110,000 for the 9 mos and a charge of $1,856,000 for the 9 mos from a donation of land...C-After a charge of $31,340,000 for plant closings, a charge of $3,504,000 for a writedown of a foreign investment and a gain of $4,943,000 on the sale of assets of television station

title: MAN JAILED FOR 2 OF THEM IS FREED
description: A grand jury has returned a 94-count indictment, including 36 charges of rape, against a prominent Columbus physician. The charges against Dr. Edward Franklin Jackson Jr., an internist, involve incidents dating to Sept. 28, 1975, and the indictment is the longest in local court history.

title: STATE A.F.L.-C.I.O. TO BE NEUTRAL IN WEICKER-MOFFETT SENATE BATTLE
description: A divided state convention of the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O. voted narrowly tonight to remain neutral in the race for the United States Senate between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Representative Toby Moffett.

title: BROOKLYN BUILDING IS RENOVATED UNDER CITY PROGRAM
description: Except for a tree in its small entrance courtyard that rises nearly to the roof, there appears to be nothing outstanding about the newly renovated, four-story apartment building at 1554 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn's Midwood neighborhood. It seems just one of the many residential apartment houses that line the five-mile thoroughfare from Park Slope near downtown Brooklyn to Sheepshead Bay on the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had agreed with British Telecom International to provide a public message service that will link the Mailgram service that Western Union provides in the United States with the Telemessage service that British Telecom provides in Britain. Users will have access to both systems, starting early next year, Western Union said.

title: U.S. Finds Recipients Of Jobless Pay Decline
description: Fewer than half of the nation's 10.8 million unemployed workers are receiving unemployment benefits, the Labor Department said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Alberto Salazar, who has won the last two New York City marathons, has entered this year's race, which will be held Oct. 24. ... Socrates, the captain of Brazil's national soccer team, has accepted an invitation to play in the Carlos Alberto farewell game Tuesday at Giants Stadium.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 24, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Rolfe Sedan, Character Actor On TV and in Films Since '16
description: Rolfe Sedan, a character actor who portrayed waiters, desk clerks and train conductors in a career that spanned vaudeville, film and television, has died at his Pacific Palisades home. He was 86 years old.

title: ALLIED MAY FREE MARIETTA
description: The Allied Corporation is negotiating a truce with the Martin Marietta Corporation that would guarantee the independence of the big aerospace company, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG THREE RISE 16.5%
description: New car sales by the nation's three largest auto makers rose 16.5 percent in the mid-September selling period, the Big Three reported today. It was the first year-to-year rise reported since the eight-tenths of 1 percent increase reported for the June 1-10 selling period.

title: Oil Exploration Off Canada
description: A group of oil companies, led by Shell Canada Resources Ltd., is beginning a $440 million (United States) oil exploration program off Nova Scotia, Shell and the Canadian and Nova Scotia governments said.

title: GIANTS KEEP WORKOUT CLOSED
description: The Giants' players worked at basic football skills during a 90-minute practice this morning on the athletic field of a Bergen County high school, Pascack Valley. ''Everybody showed up,'' Harry Carson, the inside linebacker and self-styled captain emeritus, said later. ''Everybody.''

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income figures reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translation during fiscal 1982; Sega is a 90 percent owned subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries

title: IT'S OKTOBERFEST TIME IN SEPTEMBER AROUND TOWN
description: The calendar may indicate September, but Oktoberfests are in hearty supply around town this weekend. Steuben Day festivities will begin with a traditional free concert at noon today at City Hall. Several German bands will entertain lunchtime passers-by, weather permitting.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net loss; the shr earnings for the yr-ago period was adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1982

title: Saturation Point
description: Can there be too much of a good thing? There can indeed, in the view of Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, whose sport might be used to fill up network television holes left open by the National Football League strike.

title: THE PEOPLE WHO WRITE BEFORE AND AFTER WORK
description: Maybe it isn't true, but it seems as though most of the world could and would write a book, if only they had the time. The problem, according to the thousands who have never managed to translate the perfect story tucked away in their heads into words, is that there just aren't enough hours in the day.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TOWNS WIN IN BID FOR RICHMOND'S SEAT
description: Edolphus Towns, the deputy borough president of Brooklyn, won the Democratic nomination for the 11th Congressional District. He defeated two others in the race to fill the seat vacated by Representative Frederick W. Richmond.

title: MANY OTHERS TURN BACK; STIFF CHALLENGES
description: At least five incumbent New York State legislators were defeated last night and many more turned back difficult challenges as voters across the state selected candidates in radically redrawn legislative districts.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Auto Race
description: It isn't destined to be a best seller. Full of expressions like ''incremental innovation'' and ''adversarial environment,'' heavily laden with tables and graphs, ''The Competitive Status of the U.S. Auto Industry'' is a book that only a B-school graduate would take to bed. But for those concerned about the decline of America's largest industry, this report by experts makes for interesting if grim reading. They have seen the future, and it may not be ours.

title: McDonald's Sues Over Ad
description: Angry about a scheduled advertising campaign that compares Big Macs unfavorably with Whoppers, McDonald's filed suit today to try to keep the Burger King commercials off the air.

title: BRIEFING
description: Prospects for Blacks

title: 10 Indicted for Importing Indonesians for Servitude
description: Ten people, eight of them members of one family, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of bringing 50 Indonesians into the United States illegally and selling them to wealthy residents as servants.

title: Steel Ruling Delayed
description: The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, has decided to postpone final votes on whether the American steel industry has been harmed by European imports, a ruling that could lead to import duties. The panel was scheduled to make its final decisions on Sept. 30, but, at the request of the Commerce Department, it will not act until the week of Oct.10, a spokesman said.

title: Checkup for Mrs. Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan is to undergo routine laboratory tests Friday at the the National Naval Medical Center in suburban Bethesda, Md., as part of her annual physical examination, Sheila Tate, the First Lady's press secretary, announced today.

title: Polish Primate to Visit U.S. Next Month
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Josef Glemp, will make a ''pastoral'' tour of the United States and Canada next month to thank Americans for their aid to the Polish people, particularly since the imposition of martial law nine months ago, the Archdiocese of Washington announced today.

title: Italy Condemns Israel Over Beirut Massacre
