description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo said today that Israel's responsibility for the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut was beyond discussion.

title: PASSAGE URGED FOR JOBS BILL TO REPLACE CETA
description: President Reagan today urged Congress act quickly to pass a new multibillion-dollar job training bill to replace the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, which expires Thursday.

title: Pennant Race
description: Delaware State College in Dover, Del., has an enrollment of only 2,500 students, so the college's Division I-AA football team doesn't get a whole lot of publicity outside the region. But the school believes that Johnny Rowe, its senior halfback, could be an all-American if more people knew about him.

title: PUBLISHING: MONTANA'S NOVELISTS
description: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN recently published A.B. Guthrie's novel ''Fair Land, Fair Land,'' a sequel to the author's ''The Big Sky'' and ''The Way West.'' The first two not only won wide critical acclaim, but the second also won the 1950 Pulitzer Prize. Bernard De Voto, the literary critic who hailed from the West, said of Mr. Guthrie, ''The pioneer West has found its novelist at last.''

title: School Recruiters Start to Travel
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's University basketball coach, and Brian Mahoney, his assistant, drove 800 miles throughout the East in two days this week to speak with outstanding high school prospects, their coaches and parents. Willis Reed, the Creighton University coach, is in the New York metropolitan area, doing the same work for the Omaha school.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED IN BRONX APARTMENT STRIKE
description: Building service employees and apartment house owners in the Bronx reached a tentative agreement on a new contract yesterday, four days after the start of a walkout that affected 250,000 tenants in 2,000 buildings.

title: Brooks Pact Extended
description: The contract of Herb Brooks, the coach of the Rangers, has been extended, the general manager, Craig Patrick, announced yesterday. The announcement did not include terms of the extension, but it was understood that the extension was for two years at a salary above $150,000 a year.

title: ISLANDERS GAUGE TALENT
description: In their three exhibition games, the Islanders have lost to the Philadelphia Flyers and the Rangers and tied the Boston Bruins. Their 2-1 loss to the Rangers Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden was more of a thumping than the score indicated.

title: BROWN JUG TO MERGER
description: Merger, trained and driven by John Campbell, took the lead at the three-quarter pole today and pulled away down the stretch to win the Little Brown Jug, the middle leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers.

title: American cooking and classic seafood.
description: A STYLISH and welcome addition to what is called the Upper Upper East Side, Baumer & Crooks, on Third Avenue near 92d Street, has all the overtones of a plushly upholstered supper club with an especially handsome mahogany bar. Opened last November, this restaurant, with its romantic Art Nouveau decor, is slightly marred by inadequate lighting. This may seem like a mundane consideration in such dramatic surroundings, but it becomes important when you begin to regard a beautiful piece of broiled salmon or fragrant hot steamed mussels in a mustard-brightened broth as obstacle courses. Inadequate lighting at some back tables does the food an injustice in other ways. Much of the pleasure of eating is in noting the color contrasts in foods and garnishes - the rosy red rims of peel left on sliced rounds of sauteed potatoes, the blond apple slices that highlight both the flavor and golden pink tones of sauteed calf's liver and the bright vegetables that accent ginger-glazed pork chops, all hardly discernible in dim lighting.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKING'S HOUSE OF CARDS
description: The grave disorder in the world's banking system is now plain for all to see.

title: Phelps to Resume Work at Mine
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said it would resume copper production at its Morenci, Ariz., facility, and would gradually call back 1,450 of the 2,000 employees laid off there.

title: People
description: * Bruce Levitt has been named senior vice president and creative director of J. Walter Thompson/Atlanta.

title: Party in Britain Gives Mrs. Williams Key Job
description: Former Education Minister Shirley Williams became president of Britain's Social Democratic Party today and immediately warned the new party's activists that it may have only a few months to prepare for its first general election campaign.

title: SALUTE TO WHAT'S NEW IN ITALY
description: Altman's is saluting Italy this week and next, but with ''no old photographs, no Ponte Vecchios,'' according to John W. Christian Jr., president of the store. ''The theme is Italy Today,'' he said. ''Everything is very contemporary.''

title: DOME OFFERED PLAN TO RESCHEDULE DEBT
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the debt-ridden centerpiece of Canada's National Energy Program, said today that its four main private creditors and the Canadian Government had offered it a plan to avoid default.

title: Tiger Appealing Reliance Ruling
description: Tiger International Inc. said it had appealed an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling that Reliance Group Holdings Inc. may continue buying the transportation company's stock.

title: HOW BENDIX BOARD WAS SPLIT BY SHARP DEBATE OVER ALLIED
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Corporation, reportedly led three other directors at a pivotal Bendix Corporation board meeting Wednesday night in rebelling against quick approval of a merger offer from the Allied Corporation that had not been previously presented to the board.

title: ABORTION FOR WOMAN, 25, WITH I.Q. OF 12 ALLOWED
description: An acting justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday authorized an abortion to be performed on profoundly retarded 25-year-old woman after accepting the consent of her parents as a substitute for the consent of their daughter.

title: Joblessness Soars in Yukon
description: Canada's northern Yukon Territory may lose as much as 25 percent of its 25,000 people this winter as residents leave to hunt for jobs elsewhere, according to Chris Pearson, the head of the territorial government.

title: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $897,000 from the sale of land

title: Attendance Disputed
description: Joe Axelson, who returned to the Kansas City Kings for his second term as general manager on July 1, says the National Basketball Association team padded its home attendance figures in 30 of 41 games last season. Axelson, who served the last two years as vicepresident of operations in the league office, said the Kings had announced they drew 304,955 (an average of 7,438), but that the team actually had a total attendance of 280,464 (an average of 6,843). Jeff Cohen, the general manager for the Kings last year and now executive vice-president of the Boston Breakers of the United States Football League, declined to comment.

title: MILLER, HENRY S, REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that results for the latest qr and 6 mos include a gain of $81,409 on the sale of real estate

title: BELL FLEXES A MUSCLE IN EUROPE
description: A plan by A.T.& T. to push into the international telecommunications market has helped cause a rift between Philips, the giant Dutch electronics group, and the French electronics industry.

title: Ex-Player Imprisoned
description: Leo Hayden Jr., an Ohio State running back who played three years in the National Football League with Minnesota and St. Louis, has been sentenced in Louisville to five years in prison for check forgery totaling $2,891.76. ''I'm glad I got busted because it was the only way I was going to get back on the right track,'' Hayden said.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds declined $276 million, to $225.81 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The decline, the second consecutive one, followed a drop of $525 million the previous week.

title: From South Pole to Broadway with Captain Scott.
description: THE real-life story of Capt. Robert Falcon Scott's daring and ultimately disastrous trek to the South Pole in 1911-12 is the dramatic substance of Ted Tally's ''Terra Nova,'' which Emanuel Azenberg, Ulu Grosbard and the Shubert Organization are planning to bring to Broadway. The producers hope to open the play, which Mr. Grosbard will also direct, late this season, but the timing depends on the casting of an actor to play Captain Scott.

title: No Headline
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) - The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a $201.3 billion military appropriation bill that contains $8.7 billion less than President Reagan requested and includes a provision, strongly opposed by the Pentagon, to freeze American troop strength in Europe.

title: CONSUMER INDEX IN MODEST RISE: 0.3% IN AUGUST
description: Consumer prices rose only three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department reported today. The figure indicated that the inflation rate for the year could slow to the lowest level in six years and less than half the double-digit pace of 1979 and 1980.

title: REAL CARIBBEAN AID
description: Congress is considering President Reagan's call to support a ''fresh view of development'' for the Caribbean basin, one that will bring ''economic revitalization'' through ''investment promotion, export marketing and technology transfer.'' The call is well-intended: Economies so closely tied to ours need our assistance to pull out of their doldrums. The strategy contained in the Caribbean Basin Initiative, however, is not new. It was tried in the 1960's and failed - failed to provide better conditions for most people and failed to stem rising political discontent.

title: NOTHING TOTALITARIAN ABOUT A WORKER'S ID CARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Namath Arrested By Florida Police
description: Joe Namath, the former quarterback for the New York Jets, was arrested early this morning on drunkendriving charges after he became boisterous and refused to take sobriety tests, the police said.

title: Arab Ambassadors Complain Over U.S. Briefing on Lebanon
description: Several Arab ambassadors have protested to the State Department because a senior American official walked out of a United States briefing on the Lebanese situation, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Voice of Shero
description: Fred Shero made his debut as a radio commentator for the New Jersey Devils Tuesday night, the same night the Devils made their home-ice debut. They lost their first official game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 3-2, to the Rangers - the team that Shero coached from 1978 until Thanksgiving weekend of 1980.

title: Wheeling Cutback
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation will close its mill here indefinitely, idling more than 600 workers, Mayor Anthony Scaffidi of Benwood said. He said he had been told by Lutz F. Albrecht, the plant's manager, that the facility would close in mid-December and that only only a skeleton crew would stay on to handle the remaining inventory. Mr. Albrecht referred inquiries to Wheeling-Pittsburgh's headquarters, where Ken Maxi, a spokesman, declined comment.

title: ROLL-CALL ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected a move to attach the school prayer bill to the debt-ceiling measure: FOR REJECTION - 51 Democrats - 27 Baucus, Mont. Biden, Del.

title: NUCLEAR MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Angel Lead Falls to 2 1/2 Games
description: A throwing error on a pickoff attempt by Bob Boone, the catcher, allowed Nick Capra, a pinchrunner, to score the winning run from third base with one out in the ninth inning tonight, giving the Texas Rangers a 5-4 victory over the California Angels.

title: SCHOOL PRAYER MEASURE DIES IN 51-48 SENATE VOTE
description: The conservative campaign to promote its agenda of social issues collapsed today as the Senate voted to shelve a proposal that would permit officially sanctioned school prayer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Part of the Solution

title: Oklahoma Drops Its TV Request
description: The University of Oklahoma gave up its attempt today for a live telecast of Saturday's football game with Southern California.

title: ALBUS RETAINS GOLF TITLE
description: Jim Albus of Piping Rock shot a par 71 to finish with a 54-hole total of 209 today as he successfully defended his title in the 56th annual Izod Metropolitan Pro Golf Association championships at the Century Country Club.

title: WOMAN ON BANK BUSINESS TRIP FOUND SLAIN AT WALDORF-ASTORIA
description: An executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank's Mexico City offices was found stabbed to death in a dingy gray, 19th-floor stairwell at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Wednesday night, less than two hours after she checked in.

title: Now Open Thursday
description: T he imposing doors at the top of the steps of the New York Public Library were opened yesterday for the first Thursday in seven years. Beginning Jan. 6, those doors will open regularly on Thursdays.

title: DIPLOMAT'S FONDEST MEMORY: CHINA BREAKTHROUGH
description: For most diplomats there is at least one moment in a career, a breakthrough in top-level negotiations, perhaps, or a face-to-face encounter with a legendary figure, that becomes indelibly etched in the memory.

title: AN INSURANCE FUNDS SCANDAL JARS LONDON
description: In the airy Underwriting Room at Lloyd's of London, insurance brokers still cluster around Box 137, the cubbyhole that served as headquarters for Ian Posgate, a flamboyant underwriter who is also reportedly Britain's third-highest paid executive.

title: POP JAZZ
description: IN the 37 years since Chris Anderson began playing piano in jazz clubs in Chicago, he has fascinated the musicians with whom he has worked. Clifford Jordan, the saxophonist, has called him ''a harmonic master,'' noting that what he plays is very subtle. And the pianist Barry Harris has said, ''When Chris does his thing, it's just beautiful.''

title: FOR PILAR RIOJA, SPANISH DANCE IS MORE THAN JUST FLAMENCO
description: When she is a member of the audience, Pilar Rioja feels disappointed if a Spanish dance concert does not contain any flamenco. Yet, because flamenco is only one of many great Spanish dance styles, she feels equally disappointed when a concert is all flamenco. Therefore, as a dancer, she takes care to make her own solo programs varied.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MONSIGNOR QUIXOTE. By Graham Greene. 221 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: Grand Jury Is Reported Set to Hear Belushi Case
description: A grand jury will begin hearings next week in the death of the actor John Belushi, The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported today.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
A fall preview at Sotheby's.
description: SOTHEBY'S is kicking off its season with an exhibition of what it regards as the creme de la creme of its coming fall sales. The show was designed to inaugurate Sotheby's 72d Street galleries on First Avenue as its sole quarters (after the closing of the original Madison Avenue site at 75th Street). A perambulation of the newly completed galleries, with an array ranging from scrimshaw to sculpture, is a lot like attending a museum opening.

title: MATHIAS'S COMPLAINT ON MAIL COSTS
description: If United States senators had to buy and lick all those stamps, says Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., they might forfeit some of their mass mailings now costing the Federal Government about $31 million a year.

title: ART: AFTER 2 YEARS, 'SELECTED PRINTS III'
description: NOT since the Museum of Modern Art staged the 1980 international survey ''Printed Art - A View of Two Decades,'' have we had a big, lively print extravaganza in New York, one that tells us what's going on in this teeming medium while at the same time providing some esthetic reward.

title: REPORT DOUBLES ESTIMATE OF BREEDER REACTOR'S COST
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that the Clinch River breeder nuclear reactor at Oak Ridge, Tenn., could cost about $8 billion, more than twice the Reagan Administration's estimate.

title: FOR JERUSALEM'S POOR, SOUL-SEARCHING
description: In Nahalat Shiva, a poor Jerusalem neighborhood, most residents are hard-core supporters of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. But the killings in Beirut last week caused them much soul-searching.

title: MAJOR JEWISH PAPER IN BRITAIN URGES BEGIN TO QUIT
description: Britain's most respected Jewish publication, The Jewish Chronicle, called today for the resignation of Menachem Begin and Ariel Sharon.

title: THE BIG YACHT RACE THAT EVERYONE CAN SEE
description: A visual feast will unfold in New York Harbor tomorrow as a fleet of some 200 yachts, the largest turnout in the nine-year history of the Governor's Cup race, crosses the starting line off the Battery beginning at 11 A.M. Unlike most yacht races, which take place well offshore and out of sight, this 16-mile competition takes the fleet through the Upper and Lower Bays, offering fine vantage points from shore as well as from boats.

title: Boy, 14, Charged In Mother's Slaying
description: A 14-year-old boy was charged with murder last night for allegedly stabbing his mother to death when she refused to help him with his homework.

title: House Doubles Panel Budget For Inquiry on Sex and Drugs
description: The House of Representatives agreed today to double its ethics committee's budget, adding $200,000 to finance an investigation of purported sexual misconduct and drug abuse in Congress.

title: Arizona on Notice From N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is sending a letter to the University of Arizona regarding an investigation into possible improprieties in the athletic department.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd paid in Fe

title: Papp Plans Programs For ABC Arts Station
description: ABC Video Enterprises and Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, have signed an agreement for six hours of programming to be broadcast on Hearst/ABC ARTS, the ABC cable station devoted to culture.

title: PALACE INTRUDER IS ACQUITTED BY LONDON JURY
description: Michael Fagan, the man who entered the bedroom of Queen Elizabeth II one morning last July, was acquitted by a jury in only 14 minutes today on a charge of having broken into Buckingham Palace the month before and stolen a bottle of wine.

title: Tigers 10, Orioles 5
description: BALTIMORE (UPI) - Larry Herndon hit a pair of two-run homers, and Howard Johnson hit another as Detroit overcome a 5-2 deficit to hand the Orioles their second loss in a row.

title: NO. 1 NO MORE, NEW YORK PORT SEEKS TO STRENGTHEN ITS ROLE
description: The Port of New York, once unchallenged as the premier shipping center of the nation, is scrambling to maintain its dominance as a regional port and is even gaining somewhat in the fierce competition for the lucrative North Atlantic trade.

title: Economic Scene; Analysts' Hunt For Reliability
description: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN, President Reagan's nominee to succeed Murray L. Weidenbaum as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has followed Mr. Weidenbaum's practice of trying to find reasonable security in his forecasting by taking shelter within the consensus of the nation's private forecasters.

title: 2 Lum's Owners File for Chapter 11
description: Two Florida companies that own 70 Lum's restaurants in the Eastern United States have filed for protection from their creditors.

title: Baby Sitter Denies Charge
description: Christine Falling, a 19-year-old baby sitter scheduled to be tried in November on two charges of first-degree murder, today submitted a written plea of not guilty to a third charge of murdering children in two North Florida towns. Miss Falling, who is being held without bail at a county jail in Blountstown, was indicted last week in Perry on a first-degree murder charge in the July 1981 death of 8-month-old Jennifer Daniels. Rather than appear in person for arraignment on the Perry charge, her attorneys mailed a written plea of not guilty in answer to the charge.

title: FASSBINDER'S 'VERONIKA VOSS'
description: THE showing tonight at Lincoln Center of the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder's ''Veronika Voss,'' the opening attraction of the 20th New York Film Festival, sets such a high standard that the rest of the entries may be hard put to meet it. ''Veronika Voss,'' the great German director's second-to-last film, is a chilly, tough, wicked satire disguised as the sort of schmaltzy, black-and-white, 1950's melodrama that its characters, with one exception, would never bother to see.

title: Morton Takeover Of Thiokol Backed
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said its stockholders had approved the previously announced acquisition of the Thiokol Corporation for about $540 million in cash and stock.

title: A DELICATE CEREMONIAL MATTER
description: Ron Turcotte, who rode Secretariat to victory in the first Marlboro Cup in 1973, might have presented the trophy for the 10th Marlboro Cup from his wheelchair last Saturday, but Belmont Park officials rejected the idea.

title: ZHAO SAYS CHINA PLANS HONG KONG RULE
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang acknowledged today that China planned to reassert its sovereignty over Hong Kong but insisted that residents of the British crown colony had no cause for concern.

title: Fireman Is Slain; Woman Charged
description: A New York City fireman was found fatally shot in a van parked near a highway in the Bronx late Wednesday, and a former policewoman was charged yesterday in the killing, authorities said.

title: REAGAN IN CAMPAIGN SHIFT, PLANS LESS EMPHASIS ON THE SOCIAL ISSUES
description: President Reagan's advisers, in a shift of election strategy, say they have come to recognize that abortion and other social issues do not have a nationwide impact on voters and therefore should be stressed only to selected audiences.

title: 'WOMEN SOLDIERS PROGRAMMED FOR SUCCESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Sweets for the Caribbean
description: Bad news for the Caribbean Basin has come on little cat feet, in a quiet announcement from Agriculture Secretary Block. He says the sugar import quota for the year starting Oct. 1 will be 2.8 million tons, or 500,000 fewer than he originally figured. Good weather, bigger carryover stocks and a greater use of corn-based substitutes have left the United States with an excess of sugar.

title: CHURCH GROWTH LAGS FAR BEHIND THAT OF U.S.
description: A study done for a coalition of religious groups and released yesterday provides new evidence that Americans were far less likely to join a church in recent years than they were in the past.

title: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LEHERMAN, MOYNIHAN AND; MRS. SULLIVAN WIN
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo scored a stunning upset victory over Mayor Koch for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York yesterday while Lewis E. Lehrman won an expected but overwhelming 4-to-1 victory over Paul J. Curran for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

title: LEHRMAN SET FOR NEXT LEG OF CAMPAIGN
description: Lewis E. Lehrman took the third step last night in the unusual political journey he hopes will end - for a while, at least - in Albany.

title: Lightning Kills 11 Children
description: Eleven children were killed and three seriously burned Wednesday when lightning struck the verandah of a school near Kisii in western Kenya, the police said today.

title: Turkish Assembly Approves Constitution
description: The Consultative Assembly overwhelmingly approved a constitution today to reinstate civilian rule under a powerful president and with severe restrictions on the press and labor unions.

title: Friday; MAKING BLACKSTONE APPEAR
description: The Great Blackstone was one of America's most famous magicians. These days, his 48-year-old son, Harry Blackstone Jr., is practicing the feats he learned at his father's knee. He can make elephants disappear, pick pockets, remove a man's underwear while leaving the trousers on and make light bulbs float and handkerchiefs dance. Mr. Blackstone will be at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island tonight at 8:30 (admission, $11.75) and tomorrow at 1 and 5:30 P.M. (admission, $8.75) and 9:30 P.M. (admission, $11.75). Information: (516) 333-0533. The Music Fair is on Brush Hollow Road; Exit 40 on the Long Island Expressway. CHORUSES OF THE WORLD AT YALE

title: Showing ID at the Golden Doors
description: There are, in truth, two golden doors to the United States. Anyone who wants to keep the front door open to legal immigration, despite the rising nativist and racist pressures, should like the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill. So should anyone who wants to close the back door against illegal immigration. That's why the bill, having overwhelmingly passed the Senate, has finally run the gantlet of the House Judiciary Committee. If the House leadership recognizes how broad a consensus the bill represents, it could come before the whole House next week.

title: Home of Israeli Envoy Is Hit
description: Gunmen in two autos fired bullets and tossed bombs today at the Israeli Ambassador's residence. Two guards were slightly injured. The envoy, Jaime Aron, was at the Bogota international airport at the time of the attack.

title: PRICES IN CITY AREA UP 05%
description: Consumer price increases in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area were moderate last month, up only five-tenths of 1 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis.

title: TERRY RILEY MOVES FROM MINIMALIST MUSIC TO IMPROVISATION
description: THE most enduring musical legacy of the 1960's may well be minimalism, or ''trance'' or ''pulse'' music. Some of the most influential composers of the 60's, who had come in contact with world music and popular music, rejected the Western classical emphasis on dramatic form and harmonic development. Instead, they chose to explore ideas of rhythmic and melodic development through repetition and slow change. Those ideas were to affect pop and jazz along with contemporary music.

title: RANDOLPH DISCOUNTS REPORTS OF A TRADE
description: Willie Randolph has heard the reports. He doesn't believe them; he doesn't want to believe them. But barring some word to the contrary from George Steinbrenner, Randolph will have to await the developments of the next few months to learn if the reports are true: that the Yankees plan to trade him.

title: PAVAROTTI IN 'GIORGIO'
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI has a food fight, rides in a balloon and sings ''I Left My Heart in San Francisco'' in ''Yes, Giorgio,'' a movie that means to be as broad and hearty as its star. These and other antics are the film's attempt to paint Mr. Pavarotti as a good sport, a regular guy.

title: SALVADORAN CHIEF PLANS '84 ELECTION
description: El Salvador's provisional President, Alvaro Alfredo Magana, said Wednesday night that the Government planned early next week to announce details of plans for municipal and national elections.

title: REBELS TURN AN UNWELCOME SPOTLIGHT ON HONDURAS
description: The hostage crisis that has gripped Honduras for the last six days is throwing unwelcome light on the country's problems: a decaying economy, curious relations with its neighbors and with the United States, and the continuing test of wills between the new civilian Government and the military establishment.

title: STATE LEGISLATOR IS SENATE CHOICE
description: Florence M. Sullivan, a little-known State Assemblywoman from Brooklyn, won the Republican nomination for the United States Senate last night, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, as expected, easily won the Democratic nomination.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Suspect Indicted In Rape in Queens
description: A Queens man was indicted yesterday on charges stemming from the abduction and rape of a woman, authorities said.

title: A PATIENT PINCH HITTER DELIVERS
description: Steve Braun of the St. Louis Cardinals has not started a game since last April 12. So Wednesday night when he came to the plate as a pinch-hitter for Dave LaPoint, the pitcher, in the eighth inning, it was only his 62d plate appearance this season.

title: Guilty Plea By Ruston
description: A Houston oil equipment company pleaded guilty today to paying more than $500,000 in bribes to officials of Mexico's national oil company, the Justice Department announced.

title: ART: ROGER BROWN, NEW CHICAGO PAINTER
description: IT was just over 30 years ago that a French painter, Jean Dubuffet, went to Chicago, showed his work and gave a lecture in which he argued the case for painting that was inward in feeling, instinctual in its response to the world outside it and indifferent to the fashions of the day.

title: WHEN ALARMS IN CARS REQUIRE POLICE ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,785,000 or 68 cents a shr for the qr and yr...C-Net loss...D-After a charge of $12.7 million for plant closing costs

title: NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL OPENS WITH FASSBINDER
description: IT will begin tonight in a blaze of paparazzi's flashbulbs and black-tie chic, and it will go on for more than two weeks as New Yorkers flock to such disparate films as a harrowing R.W. Fassbinder portrait of a morphine addict and an unusual work with neither actors nor dialogue called ''Koyaanisqatsi,'' a Hopi Indian word meaning ''world out of balance.'' The 20th annual New York Film Festival, which runs through Oct. 10 at Alice Tully Hall, in Lincoln Center, will offer films from West Germany, Hungary, Poland, South Africa, Italy, Lebanon, Britain, France, Turkey and the United States, with concerns as varied as their points of origin.

title: DANCE: WALLFLOWER ORDER'S POLITICS
description: WALLFLOWER ORDER, a women's dance theater collective organized in 1975 in Eugene, Ore., and now based in Cambridge, Mass., opened Wednesday night in Dance Theater Workshop's political-theater series at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: U.S. BACKS CONSTRUCTION OF SATELLITE-TO-HOME TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved construction of the first stage of a satellite system to send television programs directly to home rooftop antennas, despite reservations about how the huge venture would be financed.

title: MUSTO SUCCESSOR INDICTED BY U.S. FOR RIGGING BIDS
description: Robert C. Botti, the Mayor of Union City, N.J., was indicted today on Federal conspiracy and fraud charges. Mr. Botti took office last month after his predecessor, William V. Musto, was removed after being convicted of a Federal racketeering charge.

title: IC INDUSTRIES SETS OFF GUESSING ON NEXT CHIEF
description: Robert F. Schnoes, the recently elected vice chairman of IC Industries, the Chicago-based conglomerate, says he has already waited 33 years to become head of a major company. So the 56-year-old silverhaired executive says he is willing to wait two more years. That's when IC Industries' chairman and chief executive officer, William Johnson, now 63, plans to retire.

title: Harvester Sale
description: The International Harvester Company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell segments of its parts remanufacturing operations to Champion Parts Rebuilders Inc. of Chicago. Champion would pay cash for certain inventories and equipment in Illinois, Texas and Georgia, and it would supply the parts to Harvester, which would distribute them. The price was not disclosed, but Champion indicated that its annual sales would grow about $6 million under the agreement.

title: U.S. ISSUES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: The credit market rebounded yesterday, with intermediate Government securities posting the best gains. Prices closed up about one point from late Wednesday, when the current rally in fixed-income securities appeared to have run its course.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report from United Press International in ''Around the Nation'' on Wednesday gave an incorrect first name for a retired engineer who testified in a lawsuit arising from atomic testing in the West. He is Frank Butrico.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Becton Dickinson, Paramus, N.J., has appointed Raymond V. Gilmartin a group vice president and James W. Hulse vice presidentquality and regulatory affairs.

title: GAINS TAX CUT KILLED
description: The Senate today killed legislation that would have let investors take a long-term capital gains tax break on profits from securities and other assets held for six months. The law now requires a one-year holding period to qualify for the lower tax rates.

title: GIBSON TRIAL TOLD HOW AIDE WAS DISCHARGED
description: The city's Director of Personnel testified today that a termination notice for a former city employee accused of having a ''no show'' job was received by her office only after the Essex County Prosecutor had begun investigating the case.

title: Jerusalem And Saigon
description: Israel's muscle-flexing Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, has declaimed in the Knesset, apparently in warning to the United States: ''This is Jerusalem, not Saigon. It would be well for you to remember this.'' But it's Mr. Sharon and his supposed leader, Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who most need to remember that. Washington has not, after all, sent 500,000 American troops to Israel, nor overwhelmed that country's society and economy. Neither the Reagan nor any predecessor Administration has carpet-bombed an enemy capital to placate a petulant Israeli government.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Director who thrives on the unpredictable.
description: AFTER having directed Richard Pryor in ''Some Kind of Hero'' for Paramount, Michael Pressman went straight to directing Dan Aykroyd in ''Dr. Detroit'' for Universal. ''Dr. Detroit'' features Mr. Aykroyd as a mild-mannered professor who gets involved in leading a second life as a member of the Chicago underworld, and it finished shooting in Los Angeles this month.

title: AIR TRAVEL SAFETY GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTHING TOTALITARIAN ABOUT WORKER'S ID CARD
description: To the Editor:

title: IDENTIFICATION PROCEDURE IN BRINK'S CASE ATTACKED
description: Defense lawyers in pretrial hearings of the Brink's robbery and murder trial sought today to show that police officials were ''impermissibly suggestive'' in working with a witness to identify a defendant.

title: THE PHILIPPINES' BRINK
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'FORZA' AT MET
description: THE Metropolitan's first Italian opera of the season Wednesday night, Verdi's ''La Forza del Destino,'' helped illustrate the troubles the company has today with 19th-century Italian standards.

title: 'Price of Genius' to Open Tuesday at the Lamb's
description: ''The Price of Genius'' by Betty Neustat will open Tuesday at the Lamb's Theater, 130 West 44th Street.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: JAMES H. VAN ALEN was determined to have a birthday party, despite h is wife's reservations. ''Are you sure you want everyone to know t hat you're 80, Jimmy?'' she asked.

title: COUNCIL MAJORITY LEADER IN TIGHT RACE
description: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader since 1969, held a slight lead early this morning over a young challenger from Brooklyn for the Democratic nomination in the Council's 30th District.

title: News Analysis
description: To Hugo Black, the late justice of the United States Supreme Court and a longtime member of Alabama's trial bench, America's courts were ''Palladiums of liberty'' and ''citadels of justice,'' to be treated accordingly.

title: Massachusetts to Vote On Halting Arms Race
description: After months of rancor, the Massachusetts House and Senate agreed today on a bill that to alllow a test of public sentiment on halting the arms race in the November election.

title: Spy on the Teacher, Khomeini Tells Students
description: Millions of Iranian students started the new academic year today with a message from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urging students to spy on their teachers and classmates, the national press agency reported.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hungry, Vocal And Appreciative

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1982
description: International Lebanon's new President, Amin Gemayel, took office with a pledge to revitalize the country and rid it of foreign troops. Mr. Gemayel, a Maronite Christian, also made a gesture to Moslem leaders, vowing to maintain Lebanon's ties to the Arab countries, which he referred to as ''our Arab brothers.'' (Page A1, Column 2.) The Vice President urged Arab states to affirm ''with clarity'' that Israel had a right to exist. Vice President Bush, in an evenhanded speech on Administration policy, urged Israel to recognize that Palestinians ''have legitimate rights'' and deserved more than ''squalid camps.'' (A9:1.)

title: Kaiser Cement Asks for Duties
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation said it had filed a petition with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission asking for antidumping duties on Japanese and Australian cement in the California and Nevada market.

title: LASER SEEN AS HOPE IN AVOIDING SURGERY FOR BLOCKED ARTERY
description: A new, nonsurgical technique inspired by the movie ''Star Wars'' uses lasers to melt arterial blockages and may one day replace painful coronary bypass operations for many heart patients, a heart specialist says.

title: IVAN K. BAGRAMYAN, A SOVIET WAR HERO, DIES AFTER AN ILLNESS
description: Marshal Ivan K. Bagramyan, hero of the Soviet Baltic front in World War II, died Tuesday after a long illness, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 84 years old.

title: 3 FINALISTS CHOSEN IN AMERICAN MUSIC COMPETITION
description: For two days starting Wednesday, 11 of the best young song recitalists from all over the country, and one from Britain, gave half-hour minirecitals of mostly American music from the main stage of Carnegie Hall. Their audience was six distinguished judges as well as members of the general public, and they have been competing in the International American Music Competition for one of music's most generous and venturesome prizes. The ultimate purpose of the competition is not just to reward performers but also to foster American music and the American composer.

title: Cargo Ship Sinks Off Mexico
description: A cargo ship carrying 3,800 tons of wheat sank in a storm off of Mexico's Pacific coast, killing two crew members and injuring seven others. The Mexico City daily Excelsior said the ship, identified as El Salinero, sank Wednesday off the coast of El Paraiso in Colima state, 461 miles northwest of Mexico City. It said the navy rescued 14 crew members.

title: FILM, 'AMITYVILLE II: THE POSSESSION'
description: THE case of ''Amityville II: The Possession,'' a haunted-house movie that opens today at Loew's State I, the Orpheum and neighborhood houses, might better be discussed in the real-estate pages. Even if you have bought a house and even if the interest rates haven't driven you out of your mind before you move in, you should move out right away when you find things touching you, blood squirting from faucets and a spooky hidden basement room full of dank and crawling things.

title: CHALLENGE TO HELMS BUILDS IN CAROLINA
description: Losing the legislative battle for school prayer may have damaged Jesse Helms's standing as a national conservative leader, but an even more serious problem awaits the Republican Senator in his home state.

title: BEGIN ASKS JUDGE TO LEAD AN INQUIRY ON BEIRUT KILLINGS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin asked the Chief Justice of Israel's Supreme Court today to head an inquiry into Israel's involvement in the civilian massacre of Palestinians in Beirut.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BELLS ARE RINGING

title: Survivor Aid Is Barred For Killers of Parents
description: Children who murder their parents will no longer be able to collect survivor benefits under Social Security, according to a new rule initiated by Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
G.O.P. JUDGE WINS, BUT NOT IN HER OWN PARTY
description: A Republican incumbent whom the Democrats did not endorse won the Democratic nomination but not the Republican one in Thursday's primary vote for Nassau County Court judge.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The net income and shr earnings for the first 9 mos in 1982 include an after-tax gain of $343,000 or 7 cents a shr from the sale of Sealy Inc stock to certain Sealy Inc directors

title: RETRAINING ACCORD REACHED ON COAST
description: The General Motors Corporation, the United Automobile Workers and the State of California joined Thursday in announcing a $10 million training program designed to enable 8,400 unemployed auto workers in California to find new jobs.

title: Article 182492 -- No Title
description: The United States and Zimbabwe signed agreements today worth $7.4 million for family planning and for sugar refining projects. The United States Embassy said $6.9 million was granted to the state-backed Child Spacing and Fertility Association and $524,000 to a project to help make fuel from sugar.

title: 3 Nuclear Tests Conducted
description: The United States Thursday conducted three underground nuclear tests in the Nevada desert, the Department of Energy announced. Two of the explosions had explosive force of less than 20 kilotons, equivalent to that of 20,000 tons of TNT, the department said.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Spanish Court Sets Condition On Extraditing Ex-C.I.A. Agent
description: A Spanish court agreed today to extradite a former Central Intelligence Agency agent convicted in New York of illegal arms dealing on the condition that he be given a new trial in the United States.

title: Gromyko Leaves for U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko left Moscow today for New York, where he will address the United Nations General Assembly and is scheduled to meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: The New York Primary; LEHRMAN LINKING OPPONENT TO CAREY
description: Lewis E. Lehrman realigned his campaign targets today and tried to group Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Governor Carey in his sights.

title: Bonn Says It's Willing To Meet With Arafat
description: West Germany said today that it would consider a visit to Bonn by Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but denied there was any change in its policy toward the P.L.O.

title: CONTAMINATED MILK BLAMED FOR INFECTION IN 172 SOUTHERNERS
description: Contaminated milk from a Memphis plant has been linked to the country's largest reported outbreak of a bacterial infection called yersiniosis, according to the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WOES OF STEEL INDUSTRY
description: The American steel industry is in disarray, operating at 40 percent of capacity with scores of plants closed or having their production curtailed and with tens of thousands of workers out of jobs.

title: 'KEEP IT ALIVE...'
description: Once Northwestern broke the Division I record of 28 straight defeats last November, Wildcat followers could look ahead to this year's schedule and find relief. There it was, in the fourth game of the season - the Northern Illinois Huskies, the ninth-place team in the Mid-American Conference last season, with a 2-7 record and an overall record of 3-8. At last, The Chance to break the longest losing streak in the history of major college football at 34 games.

title: BRITISH HAIL 'RIGOLETTO' UPDATED WITH MAFIA SETTING
description: A new production of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' by the English National Opera, which moves the story out of Renaissance Italy and into New York's Little Italy in the 1950's, was hailed today as a triumph by the British critics.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,475,119 for the qr and 9 mos from the writeoff of operating rights

title: GEORGETOWN THROBS TO NEW BEAT
description: The syncopated beat of the ''live Latin band'' from Le Rigolo Bar wafts across Wisconsin Avenue and mixes with the pulsating rock emanating from Annie Oakley's Wild West Bar. Barefoot teen-agers nibble on ice cream cones, a woman peddles roses, the crowd spills into the street gyrating to the rythmic sounds of a steel-drum musical group playing in the Riggs Bank parking lot and a block up the avenue another crowd gathers to applaud straw-hatted tap dancers.

title: MINING UNION CHIEF PRESSES CHARGE OF FRAUD
description: Sam M. Church Jr., facing a strong challenge for the presidency of the United Mine Workers by Richard L. Trumka, today kept up his accusation that Mr. Trumka forged a union document and asked the Department of Labor to investigate.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates Corp. of North America will offer $75 million of 13.25 percent senior notes, due in 1985, at 100 percent, through Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: FASSBINDER'S 'STATIONMASTER'S WIFE'
description: New or previously unseen Rainer Werner Fassbinder films continue to appear. Following last night's American premiere of ''Veronika Voss'' at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, the festival is now presenting his 1977 ''The Stationmaster's Wife'' (Bolwieser), a misanthropic fairy tale so lushly designed and photographed it seems to have been conceived in a fever dream.

title: Talks in N.F.L.  Set to Resume
description: Player and management negotiators, who have not met since Sept. 17, agreed yesterday to resume negotiations this weekend in an effort to end the pro football strike. Neither side would disclose the exact time nor the place of the meeting. However, a source familiar with the arrangements indicated that the meeting would be held Sunday in an East Coast city other than New York.

title: 10 Million Bees Burned To Prevent Attacks
description: Millions of bees loosed when 500 hives fell off a truck were rounded up and burned early today because the authorities feared they would begin attacking residents of this Chicago suburb.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
Two in Malaysia Doomed
description: Two men were sentenced to death Thursday for drug trafficking in a case that the United States Drug Enforcement Administration assisted on. The defendants were identified as Han Kong Juan, 40 years old, and Tan Chor Kwee, 44. The court was told that Steven Tse, a special agent of the United States agency, and an informer posed as men from Hong Kong interested in buying 50 pounds of heroin.

title: THRIFT UNIT AID BACKED BY SENATE
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would provide Federal assistance to the nation's ailing savings institutions and give them new investment and lending powers similar to those of commercial banks.

title: Montserrat Caballe, Ill, Drops 3 Concert Dates
description: Montserrat Caballe, the Spanish soprano, withdrew yesterday from her three scheduled concerts with the New York Philharmonic next Thursday through Oct. 2.

title: Deadline for Leonard
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the world welterweight champion, has until the end of November to decide whether he will continue to box or give up his title, according to Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council. Leonard's title is also recognized by the World Boxing Association.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $9,000 or 1 cent a shr...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $27,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $52,000 or 5 cents a shr

title: AT TABLE, 'SWEET DISORDER'
description: Judging by the glossy pages of magazines devoted to food and home decorating, it is obvious that art directors and photographers feel that table settings must be arranged with immaculate precision. Never is there a wrinkle, crease or ripple on napkin or tablecloth, no flower petal drops to cloth or plate, no half-eaten morsels or crumbs are in view. Candles do not drip and glasses stand upright, empty or all exactly half full.

title: Hockey's Limits
description: When the National Football League strike became reality, certain hockey lovers, both inside and outside the National Hockey League, were eager to see N.H.L. games get onto network television, figuring the networks would be looking for sports programming to replace football.

title: PANEL VOTES BILL TO CUT F.T.C. POWER OVER DOCTORS
description: Senate critics of the Federal Trade Commission say they hope to use a stopgap spending measure moving through Congress to suspend the agency's power to regulate such state-licensed professionals as doctors and lawyers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Almy Stores Inc. said it had rejected as grossly inadequate an unsolicited offer from Donald Goebert to purchase the company's assets for $12 million.

title: Military Seeks Authority To Check Mail for Drugs
description: The Pentagon is seeking the authority to open the mail of servicemen and women for the first time since World War II, but the goal is to search for drugs rather than security breaches.

title: ...AND AN AGENCY THAT DEMANDS THEY KNOW THE 'UNKNOWABLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: In a table accompanying an article Wednesday about the New York Times/CBS News Poll, two figures were incorrect. Of the registered voters surveyed, 43 percent of those with incomes over $30,000 said they would vote for a Republican House candidate this year and 49 percent said they would vote for a Democratic candidate.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Caesars Palace Grand Prix, at Las Vegas. Final race in the 15-race series to determine the Formula One world driving championship. (Television - Channel 4; 4 P.M.). Baseball Braves vs. San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. (Channel 4; 1:15 P.M.).

title: IN MARYLAND, A CONFLICT OVER PRISON PHILOSOPHIES
description: Eighteen months ago the Baltimore police staged a raid with guns drawn on two small buses returning convicts to prison from a day on work release. They arrested 27 of the convicts on charges of committing crimes ranging from murder to prison escape while on the work release program.

title: DAUGHTER OF SIR WINSTON WAS 67
description: Sarah Churchill, whose flamboyant style of life overshadowed her acting career and sometimes dismayed her father, Winston Churchill, died early today after a long illness, her family said. She was 67 years old.

title: JET PRACTICE LIGHT IN TURNOUT AND WORK
description: Marvin Powell gave a practice today, and nobody could find it. ''Do you believe this?'' asked the exasperated Powell in a raspy voice as he drove around in his Cadillac, stereo on full blast, trying to find his missing players.

title: COMPANY NEWS Massey Completes Debt Negotiations
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the big Canadian farm-equipment manufacturer, said today that it and its major international lenders had ended three days of meetings and an announcement on a debt-restructuring proposal could be expected early next week.

title:
EGYPTIANS ASK: WHY?;
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - It is perhaps somewhat unseemly to raise the issue of Egypt's predicament, in the aftermath of Beirut, at a time when hundreds of Palestinian bodies are lying in a mass grave. Still, Egyptians must ask: why? How could the Begin administration allow such a thing to happen? These are not novel questions. The anguished American Jewish community - and indeed the whole world - are asking them today. But with this difference: We have signed a peace treaty with Israel. Inevitably, therefore, when we ask it, somewhere in the background an egotistical worry lurks: ''Why did they do this to us?''
description: The recall of our ambassador from Tel Aviv is but one way of framing the question. For if Anwar el-Sadat's initiative was of crucial importance in opening up an avenue to peace, the way for President Hosni Mubarak to salvage the Camp David accords is not through a policy of appeasement - like Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's in 1938.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1982
description: International Menachem Begin sought an inquiry into the killings of Palestinian civilians in Beirut last weekend. The Israeli Prime Minister, in an effort to quell growing outrage among Israelis, asked the Chief Justice of Israel's Supreme Court to head the investigation into any Israeli responsibility in the slayings, but the Chief Justice said it would not be proper for him to act on the request now. (Page 1, Column 6.) Anger at Ariel Sharon has reportedly been expressed by many senior officers in the Israeli Army. Many seek the dismissal of the Defense Minister. Their outrage, which has been increasing over such issues as the conduct of the war in Lebanon, was brought to a flash point by the killings of Palestininan civilians by Israel's Christian allies in Beirut. (5:4-6.)

title: Airlines Fault Staff Protection; Airlines Ask U.S. Shift On Worker Protection
description: Airline officials said today that because of deregulation the Federal Government should cease providing special protection for airline employees. But labor officials called for continued protection in the event of airline mergers or takeovers.

title: U.N. SUPPORTS U.S. OVER PUERTO RICO
description: The United States won a decisive victory on the floor of the General Assembly today, defeating a Cuban attempt to declare Puerto Rico a colony of the United States.

title: PATENTS
description: Besides patents on several heavy mechanical inventions, the Department of Energy received one this week for an alarm switch to be operated by the big toe inside a shoe.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 27
description: Results do not reflect the merger with Computer Peripherals Inc which was completed June 25

title: 6 U.S. RABBIS HAIL BEGIN'S CALL FOR AN INQUIRY
description: A group of leading Reform, Conservative and Orthodox Jews yesterday hailed the decision by Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to ask for an inquiry into the massacre of Palestinian refugees in Beirut.

title:
PATENTS;
Resilient Rail Fasteners For Curved Tracks
description: The New York City Transit Authority is planning resilient rail fasteners for its curved tracks. Patent 4,350,290 was granted this week to Charles J. Bush, the superintendent of engineering, for the assembly.

title: TUMULTUOUS TAKEOVER SAGA ENDS: ALLIED AND BENDIX AGREE TO MERGE
description: One of the most tortuous takeover battles in Wall Street history was settled yesterday when the Bendix Corporation and the Allied Corporation said they would merge.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.3 BILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by $1.3 billion in the week ended Sept. 15, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: New York Day by Day
description: The Sound Of a Different Drummer

title: BIG JAPANESE BANK POSTS FOREIGN EXCHANGE LOSS
description: In a shock to the financial community here, Japan's largest bank, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, announced today that it had suffered a loss of $36.5 million in foreign exchange dealings at its Singapore branch.

title: PANHANDLE SKED TO JUSTIFY GAS DEAL
description: The Government, concerned about rising natural gas prices, ordered the Panhandle Eastern Corporation today to justify its plans to import costly gas in liquefied form from Algeria.

title: Kenya Jails Student Leader
description: A student leader at the University of Nairobi was imprisoned for a 10-year term on sedition charges today, becoming the first civilian convicted in connection with the Aug. 1 coup attempt. Titus Adungosi Oloo, 22 years old, was found guilty of demonstrating in support of air force rebels who seized several areas of the capital. Prosecutors said that during the seven-hour uprising Mr. Oloo addressed students and slum dwellers from a hijacked city bus.

title: Your Money; Alternatives To 'All Savers'
description: WITH about $30 billion worth of 'All Savers' certificates coming due this quarter, hundreds of thousands of Americans must decide where to invest the funds they will receive. And their choices are legion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THEATER: HOTCHNER'S 'SWEET PRINCE'
description: A.E. Hotchner's ''Sweet Prince,'' at the Theater Off Park, is a play that never insults the intelligence, written by a man with a talent to amuse. Yet the evening is largely tedious, and one keeps wondering why. The answer, I think, is that Mr. Hotchner has conceived this work in the manner of his recent biographies (''Sophia: Living and Loving,'' and ''Doris Day''). He looks at his characters from a journalist's even-handed distance, and that's just not close enough to draw a theater audience into fictional people's lives.

title: Bess Truman Quits Hospital
description: Bess Truman was released from Research Medical Center today, 22 days after she was admitted with a bleeding ulcer in her small intestine. Dr. Wallace Graham, her physician, said the condition of the 97-year-old widow of Harry S. Truman was stable and her overall condition ''fair.''

title: PURCHASES OF DMSO STIR FEARS
description: FROM behind counters in pharmacies, stationery stores and h ealthfood shops around New York City these days, merchants are d ispensing all kinds of advice on the use of DMSO, a product they s ell for relief of ailments ranging from arthritis to sexual d ysfunction.

title: The Cuomo Victory
description: One could say that Ed Koch lost the Democratic nomination for governor. Only a year ago, the Mayor seemed the least beatable politician in the state while Mario Cuomo was an amiable if gloomy Lieutenant Governor who had won little more than a reputation for starting first and finishing last. But looking back over the wreckage, the fairer verdict is that Mr. Cuomo won the nomination.

title: Grade School Boycotted Because of Asbestos Fear
description: Parents kept their children out of class for a third day today because they fear asbestos ceiling insulation in the Denver elementary school may be harmful.

title: Women's Coach With a Legacy
description: When women's basketball on the college level first attracted national interest in the early 1970's, the team from small Immaculata College, near Philadelphia, was the story. The Mighty Macs won the first three national championships conducted by the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women - 1972-74 - before the championship became the province of name schools with wealthy budgets.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Is Arraigned
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency charged in an eight-count indictment with illegally shipping firearms to Libya, was arraigned today in Federal District Court here.

title: HUSSEIN AND P.L.O. AIDES START TALKS
description: King Hussein of Jordan has begun what he calls urgent consultations with the Palestine Liberation Organization seeking an early agreement on a proposed Palestinian-Jordanian federation that would be subject to a plebiscite after Israel had withdrawn from the occupied territories.

title: ALABAMA DUMP PROMOTED FOR CAROLINA PCB's
description: The president of North Carolina's largest independent environmental organization has joined with residents of Warren County in calling for the state to ship soil contaminated with the chemical insulating substance PCB to a waste facility in Emelle, Ala.

title: CUOMO STICKING WITH FAMILIAR STYLE
description: Mario M. Cuomo strode into his campaign headquarters yesterday morning and began the general election campaign much as he had pursued his nomination for Governor: with a grateful nod to the ''old Democratic coalition,'' some gentle needles for the skeptics, a denunciation of ''Reaganomics'' and at least one reference to Greek mythology.

title: No Headline
description: GIANTS DOWN DODGERS, 3-2, TIGHTEN RACE

title: Japan Steel Exports Up
description: Japan's steel exports rose 1.9 percent in August from a year earlier, to 2.42 million metric tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation announced today in a preliminary report. But shipments to the United States fell 34.5 percent, to 309,996 tons, the seventh consecutive decline this year.

title: ARMY'S ANGER AT SHARON SAID TO GROW
description: Many senior officers in the Israeli Army were reported today to be angry at Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. Some generals were understood to be on the brink of resignation and others were telling colleagues that they planned direct appeals to Prime Minister Menachem Begin for the dismissal of the Defense Minister.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BURNING HOUSE. By Ann Beattie. 256 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: SILVER SERVICES: FILLING THE GAPS
description: When people are lucky enough to inherit a set of sterling silver or silver-plate flatware, it often turns out to have so many gaps that it is almost useless. And when a complete set of silver is acquired, individual pieces tend to disappear over the years.

title: MRS. SULLIVAN ATTACKING MOYNIHAN AS TOO LIBERAL
description: The morning after she won the Republican nomination for United States Senate, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan of Brooklyn declared that the basic issue of her campaign would be the record of her Democratic opponent, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: Joseph L. Rawls Jr., Founder Of Hardee Restaurant Chain
description: Joseph Leonard Rawls Jr., who helped start the Hardee's restaurant chain, was found dead Monday at his home here.

title: RED SOX KEPT ALIVE BY YANKS
description: For one more day, the Boston Red Sox staved off elimination from the American League East race tonight by winning, 4-2, and sending the Yankees to their 11th loss in 12 games.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CORCORAN NAMES BOTWINICK DIRECTOR
description: Michael Botwinick, director of the Brooklyn Museum, was named today director of the Corcoran Gallery and School of Art, the largest nongovernmental art museum here.

title: Poland and Catholics Agree on Visit by Pope
description: The Government and the Roman Catholic Church agreed today on a new date for a visit by Pope John Paul II.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,690,000 or 44 cents a shr from an exchange of 400,000 shrs of common stock for $13,354,000 of long-term notes

title: A Different Shot
description: Moses Malone, wearing a Philadelphia 76er uniform, and Quinn Buckner, wearing the Boston Celtic green, will not be the only new sights when their teams meet in an exhibition game on Oct. 9 at Convention Hall in Atlantic City.

title: AT A SHAKEN CITY HALL, THE RUINS OF WHAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN
description: In the center rotunda of City Hall is the renowned hanging staircase, so called because it is a completely self-supporting set of steps rising to the building's second floor. It curves round gracefully in two directions from one central starting point, each wide marble tread dependent on the one below it. One side arcs toward the end of the building in which the Mayor has offices, the other toward that side occupied by the City Council President.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Bicoastal Seals

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY CONDEMNS MASSACRE AND CALLS FOR A SECURITY COUNCIL INVESTIGATION
description: The General Assembly tonight voted overwhelmingly to condemn the massacre in the Beirut refugee camps and called for an investigation by the Security Council.

title: HAITIAN LEADER GRANTS CLEMENCY TO 22 PROMINENT DISSIDENTS
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 24 (AP) - President Jean-Claude Duvalier has granted executive clemency to Haiti's most celebrated dissidents -Sylvio Claude and 21 followers from his tiny Haitian Christian Democratic Party.

title: A 38-YEAR-OLD PASTOR IS SHOT AT HIS BEDFORD HILLS CHURCH
description: A 38-year-old pastor was shot and critically wounded yesterday while he was working in his church in the Westchester County community of Bedford Hills, the police said.

title: Court Bids U.S. Give Data to a Newspaper
description: A divided Federal appeals court panel ruled today that the Government must give The Washington Post information about non-Government scientific consultants employed by the National Cancer Institute.

title: Ford Set to Begin Japan Expansion
description: The Ford Motor Company will begin an aggressive sales campaign to expand its markets in Japan, the company's chairman, Philip M. Caldwell, said.

title: American Gets United Mutual
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that it had merged the failing United Mutual Savings Bank into the stronger American Savings Bank. As a result of the merger, which became effective yesterday, all depositors in United Mutual automatically become depositors in American.

title: 'BURNING BRAZIER,' 1923 FRENCH SILENT
description: ''The Burning Brazier,'' a 1923 French silent film that has been resurrected for this year's Film Festival at Lincoln Center, is justifiably renowned for the startling dream sequence with which it begins. A woman who has been reading the memoirs of a famous detective dreams of a man tied to a burning stake, of a beggar, a priest and an opium den. Her dreams unfold quickly in several different stages, each punctuated by the question ''Where are you going?'' and each involving this same detective's face. Soon after the woman has awakened, the detective turns up in her waking life, which becomes a series of incidents no less wild than those of her nightmare.

title: 'EATING RAOUL'' COMEDY WITH AN OFFBEAT COUPLE
description: If you could press them for an answer, Paul and Mary Bland would probably acknowledge that they are members of the Silent Majority, but they are the kind of preposterously self-deluding people who are convinced that they are not only different from - but superior to - everybody else.

title: West Virginia Coal Mines Hurt by Railroad Strike
description: West Virginia's coal industry lost $12 million a day in the nationwide strike by railroad engineers, the state Chamber of Commerce estimates.

title:
PATENTS;
Pollutant Is Removed From Gas Streams
description: The removal of a pollutant, sulfur dioxide, from gas streams such as those from power plants will be the subject of patent 4,351,810, to be issued next week to the Department of Commerce's National Bureau of Standards.

title: LEAD ORIOLES BY 4
description: The battle for first place in the American League's East opened tonight when the Milwaukee Brewers battered the Baltimore Orioles, 15-6, and widened their lead to four games with nine to play.

title: News Analysis
description: It was the end of a long and losing day, and Jesse Helms was sipping coffee and talking about the Senate, which had just handed him a string of defeats on his proposals to legalize school prayer and ban abortions.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL ON HOUSING, 73-11
description: The Senate passed a $47.5 billion housing and urban development bill today, making it the first regular appropriation measure for the next fiscal year to clear both houses. The fiscal year 1983 starts Oct. 1, and there are 12 other regular appropriation bills awaiting action.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy Looks Ahead

title: GIBSON TRIAL WITNESS SAYS COUNCIL GOT NO COMPLAINTS ON BONTEMPO
description: The City Clerk, who also serves as the clerk of the City Council, testified today that no one had ever complained to the Council that a former city official was not showing up for work as head of security at the city's Pequannock Watershed.

title: Suspects in Slave Case Ordered to Surrender
description: More suspects indicted on charges of running a slave ring that reportedly sold Indonesian aliens as servants to wealthy homeowners were ordered today to surrender to the authorities.

title: PRIMARIES' VICTORS CLASH OVER ISSUES IN GOVERNOR RACE
description: A key ingredient in the Cuomo victory was an old-fashioned drive to get voters to the polls. Page 31. City and state vote totals, page 33. By FRANK LYNN

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: BISCAYNE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAUDI POLICE DISPERSE IRANIAN RALLY IN MECCA
description: Security forces dispersed a group of Iranian pilgrims in Mecca today, seizing portraits of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and revolutionary leaflets, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Britain's Liberals Assail Tories Over Falklands
description: The Liberal Party leader, David Steel, accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today of exploiting Britain's victory over Argentina in the Falkland Islands war this year for political gain at home.

title: ISRAELI OFFICER IS REPORTED SLAIN IN BEIRUT
description: An unidentified gunman opened fire on Israeli soldiers in West Beirut this afternoon, reportedly killing one and wounding the two others.

title: SUNDAY, BLOODLESS SUNDAY
description: Tomorrow will be a day of terror for the millions of Americans who live with football addicts. Deprived of their regular Sunday fix by the strike of professional players, these wretched addicts will require the most delicate and sympathetic handling by their next of kin and loved ones.

title: New York Day by Day
description: The Mayor, c/o City Hall, One Dead-End Street

title: DR. FRANKLIN B. PECK Sr.
description: Dr. Franklin Bruce Peck Sr., who became internationally known for diabetes and insulin research, died Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz., at the age of 84. His work on the clinical staff of Eli Lilly & Company led to the development of more efficient insulin preparations.

title: Back to Winnipeg
description: The New Jersey Devils of the National Hockey League yesterday announced that Dan Geoffrion, the 24-year-old son of Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, would be returned to the Winnipeg Jets. The Devils also announced the signing to a multiyear contract of Pat Verbeek, a third-round draft choice, who played at center last season for Sudbury of the Ontario League. ... Chris Kotsopoulos of the Hartford Whalers, a defenseman who played during the 1980-81 season with the Rangers, is under investigation by the N.H.L. on a charge of striking Paul Baxter of the Pittsburgh Penguins on the head with his stick during an exhibition game Wednesday.

title: IMPROPER YARDSTICK FOR PSYCHOMETRICS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT DOLINS
description: Robert Dolins, former assistant commissioner of the New York State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, now the Division of Substance Abuse Services, died last Saturday of a heart attack at Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla. Mr. Dolins, a resident of Clifton Park, N.Y., and Rockville Centre, L.I., was 72 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
description: B-Including tax credits of $399,000 for the qr and $1,046,000 in the 9 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $1,225,000

title: BRITISH AND CHINESE AGREE TO TALK ON HONG KONG
description: China and Britain agreed today to negotiate the future of Hong Kong through diplomatic channels but did not reach any consensus on the fundamental question of who would have sovereignty over the colony.

title: REAGAN TERMS WOES DEMOCRATIC 'LEGACY'
description: President Reagan, delivering a spirited defense of his economic policies, accused the Democrats today of mistaking compassion for practical solutions and insisted that voters still endorsed ''the sea change in American politics'' that he said his program had wrought.

title: Real Montand
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Glass, 80, Dies; Socialist Party Activist
description: Joseph G. Glass, a labor lawyer and a frequent Socialist Party candidate for public office, died Tuesday at Booth Memorial Medical Center in Queens after a heart attack. He was 80 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: CABARET: HAL SCHAEFER PIANO
description: Hal Schaefer brings an unusual list of credentials with him when he sits down at the piano at La Camelia, a restaurant at 225 East 58th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. He was a big-band pianist in the 1940's with the orchestra of Harry James, Benny Carter and Boyd Raeburn.

title: EXQUISITE FORM BRASSIERE (CANADA) LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 3
description: B-After a charge of $3,318,000 on the writeoff of investments in a bankrupt West German subsidiary and a provision for an estimated loss on the sale of a British subsidiary...C-Yr-ago results were not provided

title: Singer Leaves Hospital
description: Teddy Pendergrass, the rhythm and blues singer who has been paralyzed from the waist down since a car accident last March, has been released from a hospital here. Mr. Pendergrass will be confined to a wheelchair, although he is regaining the use of his hands and arms.

title: Echoes of Beirut
description: There is a poignant echo of El Salvador in American appeals to end the bloodletting in Lebanon. In Central America as well as the Middle East, alien forces have fed the flames of a bitter civil war, prolonging the cycles of massacre. But the massacres in Salvador have faded to the inside pages, as if the civilized world can deal only singly, and erratically, with its savagery.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Dialing for Scholars

title:
TAKING REAGAN'S ROUTE, OR NOT;
WASHINGTON - Does the public want changes in Federal policy that break fundamentally with the past, or only a modest correction that preserves the basic principles of the post-New Deal era?
description: As President Reagan has stated, last year's tax and spending cuts reflected ''a turnaround of almost a half a century of a course the country has been on.'' That course was one of rising tax burdens to finance government activities that cushioned people from economic hardship and promoted more equal access to valued goods and services. It was one of an increasingly interventionist economic policy and of a growing Federal-state partnership, with Washington footing more of the bills and the states dancing more and more to its tune.

title: Guerrillas Free 7 Hondurans; Progress In Talks Is Reported
description: Guerrillas freed seven more hostages today, and the Government said it expected the rebels' weeklong occupation of the Chamber of Commerce building to end early Saturday.

title: Mythology Takes A Beating
description: It's easy to be cynical about our political process, so endemic and so public are the compromises which fuel that cynicism. But once in a while, there occurs an event with a different message. Mario Cuomo's underdog victory on Thursday in the election for the Democratic nomination for governor was such an event.

title: MEXICO CURBS: BORDER SUFFERS
description: Mexicans here have lived for years in a dollar economy, maintaining accounts in El Paso department stores and enjoying everything from vegetables to television sets that come across the three bridges from El Paso. Economists estimate that 60 percent of the goods consumed in Juarez and other border towns come from the United States.

title: TALKS CONTINUE AT DAILY NEWS
description: Officials of The Daily News and representatives of the paper's 11 unions negotiated past a midnight deadline and into this morning in efforts to reach agreement on extending labor contracts for three years.

title: The New York Primary; NONE OF THE POLLS PUBLICLY SHOWED CUOMO LEADING
description: The public opinion polls were sharply at odds in predicting the outcome of Thursday's Democratic primary, in which Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo defeated Mayor Koch. None of the surveys released publicly ever showed Mr. Cuomo with a lead.

title: Carpenter Gets Offer
description: Rob Carpenter, the free-agent running back who has been a holdout in a contract dispute with the Giants, has been offered a contract by the Denver Gold of the new United States Football League, according to Gary Wichard, Carpenter's agent.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.P.S. DELIVERS A CHALLENGE
description: In the last 10 years, the Federal Express Corporation has made a name and a lot of money in the overnight package delivery business. But Federal Express, the pioneer of the $2 billion-a-year industry, as well as a handful of other established companies in the field are now facing a formidable new challenger: United Parcel Service of America.

title: SUMMER, ONLY SKIN DEEP, YIELDS TO SWEATERED WOMEN, MAN'S FALL
description: Our long national nightmare is, at last, over. I don't mean Watergate, inflation or interest rates. I mean summer. History and literature provide many examples of colossal frauds, but surely summer is the most brazen. Popularized as the ideal season, summer, in fact, is almost completely rotten. Summer is sticky, stagnant and monotonous, since you can't even get to the office without your suit collapsing in a rumple of sweat. When the sun is out, it's too hot to walk, stand or sit. Even after the sun goes down, it's still too hot to sleep and too hot to touch, which doesn't leave many options.

title: CCI Management Bids for Company
description: The CCI Corporation, a diversified industrial holding company, said that its board of directors planned to review a proposal by certain members of the company's management to acquire the entire equity interest in CCI.

title: BANKS AND ADRI WIN COTY AWARDS AND CHEERS
description: Geoffrey Beene opened the envelope handed to him by Brooke Shields and announced that Adri, whose designs epitomize the American sportswear tradition, was the Coty Award winner for women's fashions. Moments earlier, on the other side of the stage, Ben Vereen had handed another envelope to Bill Blass, who proclaimed Jeffrey Banks the winner for men's clothes. Each time, the audience of 700, mostly members of the fashion industry, roared its approval of the selections of what are officially called the American Fashion Critics' Awards.

title: 299 Victories Confirmed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has confirmed that Coach Eddie Robinson of Grambling will be trying for his 300th football victory today against Florida A.& M. Robinson's record had been questioned because the 1981 Grambling press guide said that his first team in 1941 went 0-8 and that his 1942 team improved to 8-0. N.C.A.A. officials said that in 1941 Grambling's record was 3-5 but that school officials had altered the record to make Robinson's turnaround of the team look more impressive.

title: PENN STATE GIRDS FOR NEBRASKA
