description: Penn State had just finished trouncing Rutgers last Saturday when word reached here that Nebraska - the opponent Saturday - set four national collegiate offensive records, including 883 total yards, in trouncing New Mexico State, 68-0.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: B-Including tax credits of $51,000 for the qr and $137,000 for the yr...C-Including a tax credit of $80,000

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS WIN, 10-1

title: ALBANY'S EGG OPENS FULL SEASON
description: From a distance, it looks as if E.T. has landed in the state capital: a large, saucerlike disk rests on a broad, open plaza. The structure is nicknamed the Egg, but actually it is less ovoid than poached.

title: EASCO BID DRAWS 42% OF ARISTOCRAT
description: The Easco Corporation announced that a preliminary count indicated it had received about 865,000 common shares, or 42 percent, of Evans-Aristocrat Industries outstanding common in response to its $16 a share bid for 1 million Evans-Aristocrat shares.

title: PALESTINIANS IN U.S. DENOUNCE ISRAEL
description: Many Palestinians in the United States blame Israel for the deaths of Palestinians in two refugee camps in Lebanon last week, saying the Israelis not only let Christian militiamen enter the camps but also encouraged the stereotyping of all Palestinians as terrorists.

title: EL SALVADOR'S LAND PROGRAM SEEMS TO RUN OUT OF STEAM
description: Eight weeks after the Reagan Administration certified that the Salvadoran Government was making progress in its efforts to redistribute land, agricultural experts and union leaders say the program has bogged down abruptly under renewed pressures from rightist officials.

title: Phillies Fail to Gain In Beating Mets, 2-1
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, hanging on in the National League East race, scored one run in the fourth inning and another in the sixth last night at Shea Stadium, then hung on for a 2-1 victory over the Mets.

title: SOUTH AFRICA APPEARS EAGER TO OUST NAMIBIAN REGIME
description: The South African Government appears determined to replace the multiracial interim regime it set up in the disputed territory of South-West Africa four years ago as an alternative to the black nationalist movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Her husband, the Rev. James Parker, is a Roman Catholic priest. The former Episcopal clergyman was recently ordained under a special dispensation from the Vatican.

title: Dow Off 6.25, to 919.52; Volume at 7-Week Low
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday as investors worried over the uncertain course of interest rates and the timing of the economic upturn.

title: SHORTCUT TO IMPROVED READING SCORES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BETTER APPROACH TO MANAGING BUS SHELTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Article 182401 -- No Title
description: The State Controller's Office today sought an official audit of the expenses of Juan V. Corona's retrial, which are estimated to total $5.1 million, acting one day after a jury found Mr. Corona guilty of 25 counts of murder.

title: RESULTS OF PRIMARY RACES THROUGHOUT THE STATE
description: Following are unoffical results of Thursday's primary elections. Incumbents are marked with an asterisk. Complete results are marked with a dagger(+). DEMOCRATS U.S. SENATOR Daniel Moynihan*........894,645 Melvin Klenetsky........162,764 GOVERNOR Mario M. Cuomo..........670,804 Edward I. Koch..........597,751 LIEUT. GOVERNOR Alfred B. DelBello......597,535 H. Carl McCall..........436,956 COMPTROLLER Raymond F. Gallagher....305,371 James H. Tully Jr.......297,612 William B. Finneran.....256,900

title: FINAL PACT FOR BENDIX AND ALLIED
description: A takeover battle that changed the shape of three major American corporations ended yesterday with an announcement by the Allied Corporation that it had acquired the Bendix Corporation for nearly $1.9 billion and had freed the Martin Marietta Corporation to become once again an independent company.

title: Bell to Address Convocation Friday at Bob Jones University
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell will address the 6,300 students and faculty at Bob Jones University at a special convocation on the Greenville, S.C., campus next week, an aide said today.

title: The New York Primary; ANALYSTS FEEL CUOMO WON THE OLD-FASHIONED WAY
description: On days when morale began to lag in the Cuomo for Governor camp, Norman Adler, a slightly portly, hyperactive deputy campaign manager, would deliver little inspirational messages to the troops.

title: NUCLEAR SAFETY: CRITICS UNFIT TO CRY 'WOLF'...
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge:; A Trip to Honolulu Lures Grand National Qualifiers
description: As in most sports, and the wider affairs of life, good timing is essential at bridge. And this is not simply a technical observation related to bidding and play. In 1981 several New York experts were guilty of bad timing: By qualifying to represent the United States in the world championships they earned a trip all the way to Port Chester, N.Y., a distance of 25 miles. If they had waited, they could have gone to Biarritz, France, next month; to Stockholm next year; to Mexico in 1984, or to New Delhi in 1985.

title: Bendix, Anyone?
description: The Bendix/Martin Marietta takeover battle -four giant corporations vying for higher position in the Fortune 500 - has been a tawdry spectacle with little discernible public benefit. It raises serious questions about how free a rein the Government should permit big companies afflicted with merger fever.

title: PROGRESSING TOWARD STARDOM
description: It all seemed to come so easily for Darryl Strawberry. It was June 1980 and he was 17 years old, and the Mets had just chosen him in the draft as the first player in the nation, and paid him a bonus of $200,000.

title: Now, a Fans' Union
description: Marilyn Barnewall, upset by the pro football strike, stood on the 50-yard line at Mile High Stadium in Denver yesterday and announced formation of the National Football League Fans Union.

title: POLES WHO TOOK VESSEL TO JERSEY GRANTED ASYLUM
description: Four members of the Polish labor union Solidarity who sailed into Port Elizabeth, N.J., in the dark last week were granted political asylum today, and freed from a detention center to find homes and jobs in the United States.

title: Scientists Give the Pope An Antiwar Statement
description: A meeting of presidents and other leading members of national academies of science today gave Pope John Paul II a declaration condemning nuclear arms and the international armaments race.

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28

PATENTS;
Blood Platelets Utilized To Aid Cancer Work
description: The isolation and purification of substances that promote growth of human cancer cells are discussed in patent 4,350,687, issued this week to two Pennsylvania State University inventors.

title: JUDGES TESTIFIES IN HOUSE INQUIRY ON INDIAN POINT CONSERVATION AND POWER HEARING
description: The former chairman of a three-judge panel investigating the Indian Point nuclear reactors told a Congressional committee today that he had resigned because the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had swept aside the legal process needed for fair and thorough hearings on safety questions.

title: 'ANOTHER,' HUNGARIAN
description: Does the lesbian love affair in ''Another Way'' mirror the political rebelliousness of at least one of the two women? To a certain extent, yes. But Karoly Makk, the Hungarian director of this film, doesn't belabor the point. He tells his story simply and romantically, using the characters' politics almost as a backdrop to their courtship.

title: More Illinois Teachers Walk Off the Job
description: By United Press International Teachers walked off the job in two more Illinois districts yesterday, bringing to almost 300,000 the number of students affected by the strikes that have also hit schools in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Michigan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We were playing a game of musical chairs and we all wound up in the same chairs.'' - City Council President Carol Bellamy on the primary election. (1:3.)

title: U.S. WALKS OUT AS ATOM PARLEY BARS THE ISRAELIS
description: The United States and other Western countries withdrew their delegations from the final sessions of the annual general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna today in protest after the agency voted to withdraw Israel's credentials.

title: N.C.A.A. Approves Sunday TV Games
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said today that individual colleges would be permitted to negotiate independently for one live telecast each Sunday during the strike against the National Football League. The telecasts could begin next Sunday if the strike continues.

title: Mrs. Reagan's Test Reports
description: Preliminary tests given to Nancy Reagan as part of her annual physical show ''everything is fine,'' Sheila Tate, the First Lady's press secretary, said today. She said final results would be known in about a week. Mrs. Reagan has also had part of her checkup in the White House medical office. ''Preliminarily everything went well,'' Mrs. Tate said. Mrs. Reagan had gum surgery last week but continued her duties.

title: Sometimes, Justice Requires Mercy
description: At first, the Brooklyn Haitians seemed lucky. By comparison, the much larger group of Haitians detained elsewhere had few friends. There were not enough lawyers to press their claims for asylum as political refugees and hence they stayed, forlorn and sometimes even suicidal, behind the high wire fences in Miami and other camps.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Included in last yr's results was nonrecurring income resulting from the settlement of two antitrust lawsuits amounting to $177,000 or 10 cents a shr

title: Poetry and Jazz Series Gets Start Tomorrow
description: ''In the Tradition: A Celebration of Jazz and Poetry,'' a four-part series of poetry readings and jazz performances, begins tomorrow at Small's Paradise, 2294 Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

title: FRED A. BANTZ
description: Fred A. Bantz, who was Under Secretary of the Navy in the Eisenhower Administration, died Wednesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: WOOLWORTH CALLS IT QUITS ON WOOLCO
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it would shut its 336 Woolco discount stores in the United States because it did not like the financial odds of trying to save the flagging chain. The company said it would establish an after-tax provision of about $325 million in the fiscal third quarter to account for the closings.

title: Prison Farm Official Indicted In Louisiana 'Hot Box' Deaths
description: The superintendent of a rural Louisiana prison farm was indicted today on charges of violating the civil rights of two black teen-age prisoners who died after being confined for 15 hours in the farm's ''hot box.''

title: U.S. NATO Plane Crashes
description: A United States Marine Corps aircraft crashed at sea during a NATO manuever early today, American and West German spokesmen reported. American sources said the plane was an AV-8 Harrier, which usually carries only a pilot.

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $68,518 on the early retirement of debt

title: AN AREA TOO COSTLY FOR ITS WORKERS
description: One morning not long ago, Lorna McKiethan arose as usual at 4:30 and boarded the 5:48 train from Bridgeport for Stamford and her job as a nurse at Stamford Hospital. She bought a cup of hot chocolate and pulled her coat over her head to nap until the conductor, as usual, awoke her before her station.

title: Dukakis Gains Endorsement Of Massachusetts Governor
description: Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts announced his support Thursday for the state Democratic ticket in November, including Michael S. Dukakis, a liberal who defeated the Governor in the Sept. 14 primary.

title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR
description: A.D. BRONX CUOMO KOCH CURRAN LEHRMAN 73. Mott Haven, Hunts Point 6,210 6,203 65 101 74. Soundview, Bronx River 5,815 4,886 114 314 75. Canarsie, Mill Basin 5,634 13,127 349 971 40. Brownsville, East New York 5,867 4,101 54 150 41. Flatlands, Sheepshead Bay 7,296 12,234 278 1,067 42. Midwood 4,232 3,815 162 617 43. Gravesend, Bensonhurst 6,511 6,798 232 1,047 48. Borough park, Dyker Heights 4,319 7,515 242 985 49.

title: 500 in Manila Protest At the U.S. Embassy
description: Addressing some 500 youths at a rally in front of the United States Embassy here, critics of President Ferdinand E. Marcos charged today that he had betrayed national interests to the economic and military objectives of the United States.

title: ROBBERY IS TERMED A POSSIBLE MOTIVE IN SLAYING AT THE WALDORF
description: Robbery may have been the motive in the fatal stabbing of a 30-year-old bank vice president at the Waldorf-Astoria, the police said yesterday. The body of the victim, Kathleen J. Williams, was found Wednesday night in a hotel stairwell.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1982
description: Companies

title: Sugar Concern Gets N.C.L. Bid
description: The Amalgamated Sugar Company announced that it had received an offer from Harold C. Simmons, chairman of National City Lines, proposing that the two companies make a joint tender offer to acquire all outstanding shares of Amalgamated common stock other than shares controlled by Mr. Simmons at $65 a share in cash.

title: LABOR UNIONS STEP UP ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS
description: At first glance, the television commercial is puzzling. A man, clad in work clothes with a spool of wire slung over his shoulder, stands in front of a factory and speaks Polish.

title: U.S. SEES NEW HOPE FOR ARAB BACKING OF HUSSEIN
description: A senior State Department official said today that there was ''a very good chance'' that King Hussein of Jordan would receive enough support from other Arab nations and the Palestinians to enter into negotiations on the West Bank and Gaza Strip with Israel and others.

title: OFFICER KILLS 1 of 4 WHO ATTACKED HIM
description: A New York City police officer whose wife had been warned against testifying in a criminal trial shot and killed one of four masked, armed men who attacked him in the driveway of his Flushing, Queens, home early yesterday, the police said.

title:
Patents;
Microbes Made Into Endorphin
description: WASHINGTON A method of synthesizing beta endorphin, a potentially valuable medication, from microbes has been invented by staff members at the University of California in San Francisco.

title: IN EL PASO'S STORES, A NERVOUS QUIET
description: The streets are very quiet here. It is the kind of quiet that makes for empty cash registers, bored salesmen and nervous shop owners.

title:
STAMPS;
HONORING FOUR GREAT AMERICAN ARCHITECTS
description: The four most illustrious American architects of the 20th century share the final segment of the four-year American Architecture Series, which is being issued this Thursday in Washington, D.C. The first-day ceremonies for the final block of four will be held at the American Institute of Architects in Washington. The Postal Service pointed out that the series is intended as a tribute to the entire architectural profession, not just to the architects and the distinguished examples of their work that the stamps depicted.

title:
OPINION;
AT THE PARKING LOT, A RUEFUL ENCOUNTER
description: LATELY every morning when I approached the parking lot at the train station, I would feel the annoyance begin to rise inside of me. It was not precisely annoyance, some days it even had a touch of anger. But mostly it was impatience. Simple impatience with the waste of the few precious minutes I had calculated in my mad rush for the 7:41 from Port Washington.

title: WASTE CHARGED IN AIR TRAVEL BY U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Congressional investigators say J. Lynn Helms, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, did not take a single commercial flight on business in his first eight months in office. Instead, he used Government executive jets, often taking the controls himself.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
COLLEGE FOOTBALL ON TV: WHO SHOULD CONTROL?
description: IF ''competition'' means ''chaos,'' then perhaps all the analysts of Judge Juan Burciaga's college football decision earlier this month are right.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LANDSCAPE RENOVATION
description: WITH home construction virtually at a standstill, publications that serve the landscape trades report little landscaping activity for new houses. Even so, planting has held steady and even increased because of a rise in interest in replanting or renovating gardens surrounding dwellings that are 20 years old or older.

title: Separate and Equal
description: ''If you buy a vegetarian cookery book, do not concentrate on the tomato and bread-crumb dish because it happens to be easy to make,'' admonished George Bernard Shaw in a 1918 newspaper column. Nutritionally sound advice, no doubt, but it glossed over the difficulties of preparing meals with both the minimum daily requirements and a minimum of fuss - especially in households where meat eaters and vegetarians break bread together on a regular basis. Who knows whether Shaw's wife, Charlotte, wished her husband would redevelop an appetite for steak and kidney pie?

title: A NEW ERA IN BONN DAWNS SLOWLY BUT SURELY
description: A ''new era'' is supposed to be dawning in West Germany as 13 years of Social Democratic rule come to an end and Helmut Kohl and his Christian Democratic Party, exiled for so long in the opposition, stitch together the coalition that could bring them to power this week on a parliamentary vote against Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: 2 IN EL SALVADOR'S NATIONAL GUARD ARE SEIZED IN 3 SLAYINGS IN 1981
description: Two national guard officers have been arrested in connection with the 1981 slayings of two Americans and a Salvadoran land redistribution official.

title: WHAT A 'FREEZE' MEANS TO L.I.
description: ARE we living in a fool's paradise here on Long Island? I got that impression after attending two meetings of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, July 12 and Aug. 9.

title: Elizabeth Claiborne Married to Everett Smith 3d
description: At the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Elizabeth Warren Claiborne, an oncology nurse clinician at the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Medical Center, was married to Everett Smith 3d, an assistant secretary in the Chemical Bank's energy division. The Rev. Donald Thiel performed the ceremony.

title: ABUNDANT BLUEFISH ARE STRIKING JOY IN THE HEART
description: SHARKS inspire terror in the waters they inhabit but pound for pound, the bluefish should be considered a more fearsome predator. Roving bands of bluefish, like sea-going Hell's Angels, slash their way through schools of other fish, voraciously cutting up more of them than they can possibly consume. For that reason, fishermen call adult bluefish ''choppers.'' Even baby blues no more than six inches in length share the reputation and are called ''snappers.'' That term is particular to the coastal areas from Chesapeake Bay northward because that is where the bluefish spawn in summer.

title: MARINES' LANDING IN BEIRUT DELAYED BY LACK OF ACCORD
description: The United States said today that the Marines would not land in Beirut on Sunday, as planned, because no accord had been reached on the Israelis' pullback from Beirut International Airport.

title: A Medical Complaint
description: Question: I recently purchased a co-op medical office in an older Park Avenue building. The maintenance charges and the number of shares assigned to this office are greater than those of similar medical offices in the building. I have been told that no original prospectus was available because the building went co-op over 20 years ago, that the medical offices were never assigned shares but had been owned and rented by the co-op for many years and that the number of shares assigned to my office as well as the maintenance charges were apparently determined by a real estate appraiser hired by the co-op board. Can shares and maintenance charges be assigned in this manner? ... D.B., Manhattan Answer:The fact that the maintenance charges and shares assigned to your office are greater than those assigned to similar offices may be proper. Such factors as floor area, natural light and access to the street must be taken into account.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Brewers vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Milwaukee. This is the last home game of the season for the first-place Brewers, who go to Boston tomorrow for three games starting Tuesday and then finish up the season with four games against the Orioles in Baltimore. (Television, Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Braves vs. San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. After closing out their final home stand, the Braves go on the road for games against the San Francisco Giants and the division-leading Los Angeles Dodgers. (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Boston (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 1:30 P.M.) Football Professional: ''N.F.L. Today'' - Super Bowl XVI, highlights of this year's matchup between the San Francisco 49ers and Cincinnati Bengals and update on the strike, including history of N.F.L. Players Association, and preseason strikes of 1970 and 1974. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.); ''N.F.L. '82'' - Strike update (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Canadian League: British Columbia Lions at Toronto Argonauts; Calgary Stampeders at Edmonton Eskimos; doubleheader (Television - Channel 4, 1:30 P.M., to conclusion for first game with cut to second game in progress about 4 P.M. College: All taped telecasts of yesterday's games: Purdue at Notre Dame (ESPN, 9 A.M.); Rutgers at Temple (MSG Cable, 10 A.M.); Syracuse at Indiana (Channel 21, 11 A.M.); Southern California at Oklahoma (Channel 41, 1:45 P.M., play by play and commentary in Spanish); Michigan State at Miami (USA Cable, 5:30 P.M.); U.C.L.A. at Michigan (ESPN, 8 P.M.) Yachting Ninth annual Governors Cup race, 11 A.M. Approximately 150 yachts will compete over the six-mile course just off the Battery at Lower Hudson River to buoy in Gravesend Bay, Brooklyn.

title: ALBORETO CAPTURES CAESARS GRAND PRIX
description: Michele Alboreto of Italy drove a Tyrrell racer to an easy victory today in the Caesars Palace Grand Prix as Keke Rosberg of Finland drove a steady race in a Williams to finish fifth and win his first Formula One world championship.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: A 10-year-old'S birthday is a time for sentiment, and I feel wistful these days. I am talking, of course, about the New York Islanders, who were created chaotically in 1972. Now, a decade after that first September training camp, they are flexing their muscles as they limber up in Cantiague Park.

title: EXPERT CALLS FOR LEGALIZING HEROIN FOR MEDICAL USE
description: A leading expert on drugs and criminal justice has sounded a new call for making heroin legally available to treat addicts and to relieve pain for other people, but only through doctors' prescriptions.

title: Elizabeth Roach Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Melton Roach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Keeling Roach of Aylett, Va., was married in New York yesterday to Jay deWitt Titus, son of Mrs. Samuel Sloan 3d of Little Silver, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., and J. deWitt Titus of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. William E. Smythe performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: GETTING PAST THE DOOR
description: When I was very young and had an idea worth millions, I was always scared away at the door. I would look through the glass panels and see the security guards inside and say to myself, ''If I walk in there and tell them I have a multimillion-dollar idea for the president of the company, they will probably have me arrested.''

title: EXPLORING ENGLISH FOLLIES
description: By Dona Guimaraes British garden follies are very special buildings. They are the lonely relics of the great age of ro-mantic landscape architecture. And if the gardens themselves have been fortunately preserved, many of their ornamental garden buildings - the Greek temples, rustic stone pyramids, pebbled grottoes and miniature Gothic castles - have long since fallen to ruins.

title: RAJASTHAN: GLITTER OF A PRINCELY PAST
description: M.M. KAYE is the author of ''The Far Pavilions,'' ''Shadow of the Moon'' and ''Trade Wind,'' all historical novels; she is now working on her autobiography. By M.M.KAYE

title: THE MASSACRE BRINGS ON A CRISIS OF FAITH FOR ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM AFTER the events of last week, Israel may never again be able to feel the same way about itself. Something snapped. The belief, the conviction that Israel was somehow different, somehow special amid the brutality and hypocrisy of the world's nations, was profoundly shaken if not swept away.

title: SIEGE IN HONDURAS ENDS AS GUERRILLAS FLY OUT
description: A group of leftist guerrillas released their 32 remaining hostages today and left Honduras aboard a Panamanian plane.

title: Jersey Trooper Killed by Auto After Seizing Man on Turnpike
description: A state trooper arresting a suspected drunken driver was hit and killed by a car early today in the southbound lane of the New Jersey Turnpike in East Rutherford, the state police said.

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO HORMATS
description: WASHINGTON Not yet 40, Robert D. Hormats has been in the upper reaches of power in Washington for the last 13 years, serving three Republican and one Democratic Administrations. Starting as an aide to Henry A. Kissinger on the National Security Council, he went with Mr. Kissinger to the State Department, then served in the Carter Administration as Deputy United States Trade Representative. He has just resigned as Assistant Secretary of State for business and economic affairs to work in the private sector.

title: FEUDS BETWEEN MOSLEMS AND CHRISTIANS ENDURE OVER DECADES
description: The explosion at the Phalangist party headquarters that killed President-elect Bashir Gemayel, and the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian and Lebanese civilians at the Sabra and Shatila camps are part of the cycle of violence that has been a fact of life in this country for decades.

title: Algiers Police Prevent March By Students to U.S. Embassy
description: About 40 students tried to march to the United States Embassy today to protest the Beirut refugee camp massacres but they were stopped by the police.

title: PLEASANTVILLE WINS BY 22-0
description: Chris Meyer, a senior quarterback making his first varsity start, threw three touchdown passes to lead Pleasantville to a 22-0 victory over Bronxville. Meyer combined with Bob Wagman for a 21-yard score in the second quarter and threw a 40-yard touchdown strike to Scott Cahill later in the quarter.

title: MONTCLAIR STATE TURNS BACK KEAN, 26-14
description: Mark Casale, Montclair State's outstanding quarterback, threw three touchdown passes in a 26-14 triumph over Kean yesterday in a New Jersey State Conference game at School Stadium in Newark.

title: NORTH JERSEY
description: This is the inaugural season for the Marcus Recital Hall, the handsome new addition to the William Carlos Williams Center for the Performing Arts in Rutherford.

title: Wendy Gordon Has Nuptials
description: Wendy Ryan Gordon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Lloyd Gordon of Englewood, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Palisades Interstate Park to Laurance Rockefeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurance S. Rockefeller of New York. The Rev. Julia Fuller Renz, pastor of the United Presbyterian Church of the Eternal Hills in Granby, Colo., performed the ceremony on the bank of the Hudson.

title: THE GLUT IN WOOL
description: Consumer interest in natural fabrics may be undergoing a renaissance, but the change is not happening fast enough for sheep farmers around the world. In the United States and elsewhere, available supply is rising far faster than demand, pushing up stocks and sending prices tumbling.

title: PALMER AND ORIOLES DEFEAT BREWERS, 7-2
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, who have averaged six runs a game this season as the strongest hitting team in baseball, found a master tonight: 36-year-old Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: VIGIL HELD FOR WOUNDED BEDFORD HILLS PASTOR
description: A minister shot Friday in his Westchester County church here remained in critical but stable condition yesterday as dozens of his parishioners maintained an around-the-clock prayer vigil and detectives sought clues to the identity and motives of his assailant.

title: ECONOMY AGGRAVATES BUDGET WOES
description: Mayor Koch, his gubernatorial ambitions shattered, is returning full time to the problems of New York City, some of which grew more acute during his unsuccessful five-month campaign for the Democratic nomination. Of particular concern to many officials is a deteriorating economic picture, which has magnified the city's budget woes.

title: I.B.M. Takes Issue
description: To the Business Editor: Andrew Pollack's article, ''The Far-Flung Wars of Mighty I.B.M.'' (Sept.19), is so filled with innuendo, distortion and bias that one hardly knows where to begin correcting it.

title: ILLUSTRATED POEMS, SHAKESPEARE TO CREELEY
description: A young, attractive couple (the woman in what used to be called a cocktail dress, the man in white shirt, tie and jacket), holding drinks, smiling at one another. To the side a brunette, index finger pressed thoughtfully to chin, something mean around the eye.

title: Senate Panel to Discuss Funds Use by Williams
description: The Senate's ethics committee is planning to discuss whether former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a Democrat of New Jersey, should be disciplined for converting leftover campaign funds to personal use.

title: Miss Ringgold, Peter Williamson Are Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. James Richard Ringgold of New York and Athens of the engagement of her daughter, Constance Niki Ringgold, to Peter Anthony Williamson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Schenk Williamson of Sayville, L.I.

title: D.H. Frank Weds Patricia F. Lowy
description: Patricia F. Lowy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lowy of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel H. Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Frank of New York. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony at Esterwood House, at the Masters School, in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: TREE PEONIES CAN BE A BOON TO THE LAZY GARDENER; BY JOANNA MAY THACH
description: Louis Smirnow insists that he was first attracted to tree peonies more than a half century ago because they are ''a lazy man's plant.'' Yet, at 86, the ebullient hybridizer is far from idle as he readies thousands of specimens for fall shipment to home growers, universities and arboretums around the world.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: REPUBLICANS and Democrats clashed at last Monday's meeting of the County Board of Legislators over whether the sale of magazines that promote and encourage the use of illegal drugs was any of its business.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Inducted into the World Boxing Hall of Fame last night in Los Angeles were Max Schmeling of Germany, Carmen Basilio, Lou Ambers, Sandy Saddler and the late Marcel Cerdan of France.

title: SMITH OF PORT CHESTER TAKES WESTLAKE CROSS-COUNTRY RUN
description: Anthony Smith, a senior at Port Chester High School, ran 15 minutes 37 seconds over the 5,000-meter course today to win the first of four boys' varsity races and set a course record at the Westlake Cross Country Invitational here.

title: Half-Lives in; Arms Control
description: President Reagan paid a toll on the rocky road to arms control last week, jettisoning a senior appointee under threat of filibuster by Senate conservatives. In what the White House thought was a deal with Senator Jesse Helms, it abandoned Norman Terrell, its nominee for assistant director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in hopes of keeping Robert Grey, its choice for deputy director. But three other conservative Republicans - Orrin Hatch of Utah, Jeremiah Denton of Alabama and Roger W. Jepsen of Iowa - insisted that even so, they would oppose Mr. Grey on the Senate floor. Mr. Terrell and Mr. Grey have been serving on an acting basis.

title: Palenque
description: To the Editor:

title: And Laurie Michel, Lawyer, Married
description: Laurie Michel, daughter of Representative and Mrs. Robert H. Michel, Republican of Peoria, Ill., was married at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington yesterday to Mark B. Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradbury Thompson of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. John C. Harper, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Swahili
description: To the Editor:

title: DECLINE EXPECTED IN ECONOMIC INDEX
description: The Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators will probably register a decline for August after rising for four months, but that does not necessarily mean the recession is continuing, a senior department official said today.

title: OLD IDEAS FOR THE NEW SEASON
description: The new season is just getting under way, but it is already apparent that the television industry is up to its old tricks of cloning and recycling. One rule of thumb about programming has long been that if, say, a Western becomes a hit during one season, the next season is going to be cluttered with Westerns. More prominent among recent successes has been ''Magnum, P.I.,'' a CBS series about a rakish private investigator living luxuriously in Hawaii. Tom Selleck, the star, has been seriously challenging Burt Reynolds for the distinction of being the nation's leading male sex symbol. Question: Will Selleck lookalikes soon be popping up on the home screen? Answer: see ''Matt Houston,'' which begins its ABC weekly run tonight at 8 with a special two-hour premiere.

title: THE APPEAL OF OZU, THE MOST JAPANESE OF FILMMAKERS
description: Donald Richie, a leading Western authority on the Japanese film, is the author of ''Ozu,'' a biography (University of California, 1974).TOKYO Nearly 20 years after his death, the Japanese continue to think of Yasujiro Ozu as the most Japanese of all directors. He is regarded as a kind of spokesman. One is told that his films had ''the real Japanese flavor.''

title: TEN BELOW, $28.80, CAPTURES REALIZATION
description: Runaway Groom, who beat the best 3-year-olds in the country in the Travers Stakes five weeks ago, was unable to beat a single horse in the Lawrence Realization Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park, including a former claiming horse named Ten Below, who finished 19 lengths ahead of him and won the race.

title: WHEN LIBERAL MEETS MODERATE THE CENTER CAN GET CROWDED
description: Representative Toby Moffett, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, was answering the phones on a radio talk show in Waterbury the other day when a caller wondered why the state's largest labor organization was split between him and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Mr. Moffett talked about the difficulty of challenging an incumbent who is on the Senate Labor Committee and ''has cast a few votes for labor.'' ''It is hard,'' he said.

title: North Edison Tops Sayreville, 27-7
description: Mike Mofsowitz scored two touchdowns and Jim Schedeneck passed for a touchdown and returned a punt for another for North Edison, which opened its season yesterday with a 27-7 victory over Sayreville in Sayreville.

title: Anita M. Driscoll Becomes Bride of George M. Feiger
description: Anita Marie Driscoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clement J. Driscoll of Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to George Mark Feiger, son of Anita Feiger of Melbourne, Australia, and the late Karl Feiger. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at the bride's home in New York.

title: Kimberley Loftus Wed
description: Kimberley Ann Loftus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Loftus of Glen Rock, N.J., was married there yesterday to Joseph Michael Carroll, son of Mrs. Joseph J. Carroll of Lenox, Mass., and the late Mr. Carroll.

title: John McDermott And Miss Hiscano Married in Jersey
description: Margaret Heyn Hiscano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael A. Hiscano of Short Hills and Andover, N.J., was married yesterday to John Joseph McDermott, son of Eileen Frances McDermott of Norwalk, Conn., and Peter A. McDermott of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. David Ernest, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr.

title: MAKING THAT SMALL BUILDING PROFITABLE
description: REAL estate may have fallen out of fashion as an investment in the m ind of the average consumer, but as Lawrence Perlaki, vice presidento f Joseph A. Del Forno Real Estate in Jersey City points out: ''It's t he people with a little backbone who will make out well.''

title: Miss Pardoe Married To Andrew K. Rooke
description: The marriage of Margarita Ver Planck Pardoe, daughter of Mrs. Michael Wild Bristol of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and E. Devon Pardoe of Fort Washington, Pa., to Andrew Kreamer Rooke took place yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Edwin Rugby Auer performed the ceremony.

title: SYRIANS REARMING QUICKLY, U.S. SAYS
description: American intelligence officials said today that the Soviet Union seemed to be quickly replacing, and even upgrading, the large amounts of arms that Syria lost in recent combat with Israel in Lebanon.

title: TRIAL OPENS FOR SEVEN ACCUSED IN SALE OF QUAALUDE AT 'CLINICS'
description: Seven defendants have been portrayed by a prosecutor as operators of ''phony clinics'' that distributed prescriptions for millions of dollars of methaqualone, or Quaaludes, a sedative drug illicitly used for its euphoric effect.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ANA PLANNING TO EXPAND SEMINAR PROGRAM
description: Education has always been a fundamental objective of the American Numismatic Association. Originally its educational services were limited for the most part to books, magazines and other materials that members had to obtain by mail. However, these days the ANA is offering education in a much more personal form through classroomtype seminars - and plans are in the works for significant expansion of that program.

title: PUSHKIN REUNITED
description: THE BRONZE HORSEMAN Selected Poetry of Alexander Pushkin. Translated by D. M. Thomas. 261 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $15.95.

title: Ronni Graham Married
description: Ronni M. Graham, daughter of Howard P. Graham of Sagaponack, L.I., and New York, and Janet B. Graham of Sydney, Australia, was married yesterday to Michael I. Hass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Hass of New York. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Women Voters League Defends County Board
description: The League of Women Voters of Monmouth County takes issue with a statment in the Environews column of Aug. 1 that described a proposed ''consortium of health officers'' to take over the duties of the Monmouth County Board of Health. Contrary to that article, we have found the board to be effective, efficient and publicly responsive - all qualities of good government.

title: J.M. Keene 3d Marries Kathleen Griffith
description: Kathleen Corcoran Griffith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Corcoran of Elkins Park, Pa., was married yesterday to John Macauley Keene 3d, son of Mrs. John M. Keene Jr. of Glenview, Ill., and the late Mr. Keene. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Byers Wins 3:53.18 Mile After Injuring His Knee
description: Tom Byers of Eugene, bruised in a collision that delayed the start, passed Graham Williamson of Scotland in the final lap today to win the mile run at the Oregon invitational track and field meet with a time of 3 minutes 53.18 seconds.

title: Lorraine Gossett Wed To Alec R. Anderson
description: Lorraine Abigail Gossett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. Milton Gossett of South Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alec Ross Anderson, son of Marilyn Glyn-Jones of Dallas and Colin S. Anderson of Paget West, Bermuda. The Rev. Roy Hassell performed the ceremony at the Jesse Lee Methodist Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: WOMEN EARINING RESPECT AS POLICE
description: BETTE LOU FLETCHER said ''ten-four,'' put her radio microphone back on its rack, reached for her Hagstrom's atlas to check a location and then headed for some trouble in her squad car as she began another tour of duty as a Suffolk County police officer in the Sixth Precinct.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
TREASURE HUNT
description: Those people wandering around Eisenhower Park today with their eyes glued to the ground - and their ears tuned to metal detectors - aren't eccentrics. They're treasure hunters, after a lode of coins that have been planted for their pleasure. It's the Fifth Annual Long Island Treasure Hunt, sponsored by the Atlantic Treasure Club, and from 9 A.M. to dusk, spectators can come to Parking Field 1 of the East Meadow park, via the Merrick Avenue entrance, and watch them at work and play, ferreting out the coins, and then mining another bounty in the First Annual Long Island Gold Panning Championship. There's no charge to watch - and no samples, either.HARVEST FARM FESTIVAL

title: ST. TROPEX A LA MODE
description: LESLIE MAITLAND is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By LESLIE MAITLAND

title: ELECTRICITY CHANGES LIFE ON THIMBLE ISLANDS
description: FOR the last few months, some residents of the Thimble Islands have been enjoying 20th-century conveniences along with the 19thcentury serenity provided by their isolation. Electricity was brought to three of the 24 inhabited islands - Davis, East Crib and Dogfish - in the summer, and while residents of two other islands in the chain have expressed an interest in seeking electricity, others are grumbling.

title: COSA NOSTRA AT HOTCHKISS
description: 19 PURCHASE STREET By Gerald A. Browne. 432 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95.

title: 3 Students Die in Auto Crash
description: Two Virginia Military Institute students and a student from Randolph-Macon Women's College were killed in a high-speed automobile accident near here early today, the state police said.

title: LOBBYISTS TAKE AIM AT F.T.C. ANTITRUST RULES
description: WASHINGTON CHAIRMAN James C. Miller 3d's booming voice could be heard far down the corridor as he delivered a mock pep talk to his top Federal Trade Commission aides. The final legislative battles against the roving bands of lobbyists in ''white coats and stethoscopes'' now deployed throughout Capitol Hill will be muddy and hard, he told his troops, but victory over the nation's doctors could nevertheless be theirs.

title: A DARK NOVEL OF EASTERN EUROPE
description: THE LOSER By George Konrad. Translated by Ivan Sanders.315 pp. New York and San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: WALLACE IS ISSUE IN ALABAMA RACE
description: There is no clear-cut leader in the governorship race in Tuesday's Democratic primary runoff, polls indicate, but there is a clear-cut issue dominating the contest: George C. Wallace.

title: Indian Police Hold 3 Leaders Of Opposition Political Group
description: The police today detained three senior officials of a political organization headed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's estranged daughter-in-law, Maneka Gandhi, the Press Trust of India news agency said.

title: EASING THE COST OF COLLEGE
description: IF you're about to send a child to college or already putting one t hrough, the financial aid outlook is far rosier than one would have p redicted six or eight months ago.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, a number of environmentalists warned that New Jersey's new odd-even system of motor-vehicle inspection would cause a reduction in air quality.

title: COURT IS TOLD FIVE CONSPIRED TO SMUGGLE GUNS TO THE I.R.A.
description: Five men, including an 80-year-old leader of a controversial Irishaid group, have been pictured in Federal District Court in Brooklyn as conspiring to smuggle machine guns and other weapons to the Irish Republican Army.

title: THE CITY'S PROCESS OF REVIEW
description: ANYONE who lives near the mostly vacant city-owned land at Poplar Street between Henry and Hicks Streets in Brooklyn Heights, in the very shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, must wonder when - if ever - construction will begin there.

title: BURNS LEADS BY SHOT AFTER 66
description: George Burns shot a four-under-par 66 today to take a one-stroke lead over Bobby Clampett after three rounds of the $250,000 Southern Open.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS
description: A hundred years ago, Morningside Heights was a tranquil patch of land on the northern periphery of t he city, almost empty except for the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum and t he Leake and Watts Orphanage. But by the beginning of the 20th c entury, it was well on its way to becoming the Acropolis of New Y ork.

title: ISRAEL'S SOUL AND SECURITY
description: To its credit, Israel is in turmoil. Whatever the profit to its enemies, however great the hypocrisy of many of its critics, it is a society that refuses to let its leaders avert their eyes from the blood of innocent Palestinians. Along with pained friends the world over, Israelis are struggling to hold their government to standards that no one, in seven years, demanded of Christian and Moslem murderers in Lebanon. Even as Prime Minister Begin and General Sharon hurl back the ugly charge of treason, waves of Israelis, including soldiers, are spurred by horror and shame to assert their humanity.

Jutland, the penninsula that forms the mainland of Denmark, has gently rolling farmland that is punctuated with evergreens and redtrimmed, whitewashed farmhouses. And it is one of these houses that the Danish architect Torben Stokholm chose to remodel into his own home. The architect, who has his practice in the nearby city of Aalborg (the Danish national drink, aquavit, comes from here), feels that he has managed to combine the best of the city and the country in his home.

title: SEARCH REVEALS 'MISSING' PRINT BY BLAKE
description: NEW HAVEN WANDERING through derelict rooms and galleries in a Victorian mansion in search of a missing painting was only part of the adventure and hard work of putting together ''William Blake: His Art and Times,'' now at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: REAGAN REBUKES THOSE WHO SAY JOBLESSNESS AIDED INFLATION POLICY
description: President Reagan, differing sharply with his nominee for chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that it was ''the most cynical form of demagoguery'' to suggest that recent progress on inflation had contributed to unemployment.

title: THE MEDDLER ON THE ROOF
description: LONG ago in the old country, in the village of Conglomera, an e ligible young man from the wealthy Shmendrix family approached the m atchmaker with a strangely honest request.

title: CHINA DENIES SELLING URANIUM TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Chinese Government today described as a ''sheer fabrication'' a report that China had sold reactor-grade uranium to South Africa and other countries.

title: GORING CONFIDENT HE CAN HELP ISLANDERS
description: Butch Goring, the veteran Islander center who confounds the opposition by seeming to skate in three directions simultaneously, is quick to correct a questioner.

title: Cathryn Williams Wed To Mitchell McGuire
description: Cathryn May Williams and Mitchell McGuire were married yesterday in at the couple's new home in Saugerties, N.Y. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Donald E. MacInnis, a Methodist minister who is coordinator for China research for the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers in Maryknoll, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Gerulaitis Withdraws
description: Vitas Gerulaitis withdrew from the $75,000 Martini Open tennis tournament today because of a groin injury, enabling Tomas Smid to play the Swedish favorite Mats Wilander in the final Sunday.

title: Debra J. Dronge Becomes Bride of John D. Rickard
description: Debra J. Dronge, daughter of Mrs. Leo H. Linzer of New York and the late Alfred Dronge, was married yesterday to John Darke Rickard, son of Mrs. Carol Lippincott of Warren, Vt., and Eric M. Rickard of New Britain, Conn. Justice of the Peace Robert Long of Warren performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN THE AWE OF AGES TRANSFORMED A BALLROOM
description: WHEN my widowed friend suggested that I join her at a Catskill Mountain hotel for the Yom Kippur holiday, I hesitated. I knew that the holiday would be difficult for me because there no longer was a husband with whom to share it and each of our three children was living far away. I also knew that I did not want to be alone.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOLIDAY HOUSE EXCHANGE
description: O sha B. Reader, a California naturopath, has a new solar-heated lakeside house with indoor pool and hot tub in the High Sierras that she would like to swap for vacation quarters in New York City or Los Angeles.

title: Hillevi Vaisanen Is Married to Merek Evan Lipson
description: Hillevi Vaisanen, a physiotherapist, and Merek Evan Lipson, a lawyer with the Pacific Gas & Electric Company in San Francisco, were married yesterday at the Sea Cliff, L.I., home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lipson. Nassau County Court Judge Abbey Boklan performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Connecticut Audubon Society will dedicate its first satellite nature center from 1 to 4 P.M. Saturday in Glastonbury. ''We're very excited about it,'' said David Emerson, the assistant director of the parent facility in Fairfield. ''Although it may be chancy to start something new in this economy, we have a great deal of support and there seems to be a great demand for what we do.''

title: No Headline
description: DODGERS FALL, 5-4 LEAD BY 1

title: FANS AREN'T CHEERING FOR UNIONS IN SPORTS
description: DICK MOSS recalled the time a friend persuaded him to attend a c oncert given by Liberace. The piano player was dressed in customary a ttire - a shimmering sequin suit and enough glittering jewelry to f ill a display window at Tiffany's. But this wasn't the only manner i n which Liberace flaunted his wealth. Moss said the entertainer s pent more than half the performance talking about it, too. What i ntrigued Moss even more was how the audience apparently enjoyed l istening to this discourse on opulence.

title: Turkey Gets Its 1983 Budget
description: Turkey's Finance Minister proposed a budget today for 1983, emphasizing a continuation of the country's two-year-old battle against inflation and state spending. His proposals envisage spending of $14.8 billion and general revenues of $13.7 billion, with the shortfall made up mainly through bond issues and domestic borrowing.

title: No Headline
description: South Africa Intends to Build New Generation of Warships

title: FOR 36 CHILDREN, HOPE ON ASTHMA
description: WHEN Jason came home and announced he had made the football team at Ossining High School, there was special cause for celebration. Home to Jason is the Asthmatic Children's Foundation of New York, a nonprofit residential treatment center in Ossining for severely asthmatic children.

title: KEVIN HARMON CONTINUES BAYSIDE FAMILY TRADITION
description: SINCE 1977, Jesse and Jacqueline Harmon have had a lot to cheer about when they watched Bayside High School football games. Four of their sons have been among the city's finest schoolboy stars, with usually two of them in the lineup at any one time as the Commodores have dominated the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Spinoff When Norman Lear's ''All in the Family'' electrified television audiences in 1971, Sally Struthers certainly played a share in that success. After all, she created the role of Archie Bunker's married daughter, Gloria Bunker Stivic, and stayed through the 1977-78 season. Now, in yet another Bunker spinoff - ''The Jeffersons'' was one, ''Archie Bunker's Place'' was another - Miss Struthers stars in ''Gloria.'' She portrays a working parent - an assistant to a veterinarian -the mother of an 8-year-old who is separated from her husband Mike the ''meathead.'' The half-hour comedy will have its premiere Sunday on CBS at 8:30 P.M. Burgess Meredith, Christian Jacobs, Jo de Winter, Lou Richards, and Janet Clarke round out the cast.

title: Jennie Hollyday Wed to I.W. Iglehart 3d
description: Virginia Carroll Hollyday, daughter of Elizabeth C. Hollyday and Guy T. Hollyday, both of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Iredell Waddell Iglehart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Iglehart of New York. The Rev. Lawrence M. Estey performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: DRAFT RESISTANCE 80's STYLE
description: When David Harris's article appeared, Benjamin Sasway had not yet been convicted and held without bail.

title: 5 Killed in Car-Truck Crash
description: Five men were killed and one seriously injured today in the fiery crash of a car and a small truck, the state police said.

title: BELOW THE PALISADES, A RICH POTENTIAL
description: IT lies within sight of Manhattan, a mostly vacant or abandoned 1 8-mile sliver of land hugging the base of the Palisades on the west b ank of the Hudson River. Although development has proceeded apace inr ecent years on top of the Palisades, where a long column of luxury h igh rises stand guard, the narrow strip of land below has lain f allow.

title: Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: PEKING IS READY TO NEGOTIATE BUT HONG KONG IS STILL JITTERY
description: For more than three decades, Hong Kong has been China's compromise with reality. The British colony is a vestige of 19th century Western imperialism, evoking memories of opium wars and China's humiliation at the hands of foreigners. Since it came to power in 1949, the Communist regime has always had the option of snatching control of Hong Kong, which is defenseless and dependent on China for half its food and most of its water.

title: ISRAELIS TO BE OUT OF WEST BEIRUT BY TONIGHT
description: Israeli military officials said today that they expected their troops to have completely withdrawn from West Beirut by Sunday night, making way for the deployment of the multinational peacekeeping force.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Breathing Room

title: PICASSO REVOLUTIONIZED SCULPTURE, TOO
description: What New York needs is another Picasso show, right? We've barely had time to digest the mammoth Picasso banquet laid on by the Museum of Modern Art in 1980. Yet without even ascertaining that we're ready, the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, which represents the Picasso heirs, now invites us to a lavish feast of its own, this time ''The Sculpture of Picasso.'' Nearly 100 objects, from the famous early Cubist assemblage, ''The Absinthe Glass,'' to works of cut and painted sheet iron from the artist's later years, are on display here, most not seen in the 1980 MoMA show, and including a few that have never been publicly exhibited. And however you may balk at the thought of Picasso again, this one mustn't be missed.

title: ATOMIC VETERANS PRESS FOR BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON IN 1953, Joseph Rovenski crouched in a trench in the Nevada desert, waiting for an atomic bomb to explode 4,000 yards away. ''When it went off, the ground shook like Jell-O,'' he recalled. ''I had my hands over my face and my eyes were closed. I could see the bones in my hands, the light was so bright.''

title: TOWNS TO CONSIDER GAME-ROOM RULES
description: IN Huntington and Brookhaven, moratoriums on game room and video machine permits have been in effect since the beginning of the year. Now town officials have scheduled public hearings - on Tuesday in Huntington and a week later in Brookhaven - on proposals that would allow applications for permits to resume.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am wondering if you know of any university programs that do excavations in Pompei. I am very interested in this type of experience and any tips would be greatly appreciated. - Z.B., Houston, Texas Answer:Although there are no universities known to be currently sponsoring digs at Pompeii, the kind of travel or vacation experience you are seeking may be found elsewhere in Italy and around the world through an organization called Earthwatch. It is a membership organization ($20 a year) that matches volunteers of all ages over 16 with university- or museum-sponsored research expeditions.

title: OTHER SIDE OF THE DELAWARE
description: RESTAURANTS along the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River seem to have a special charm. Even when the food is not extraordinary, it is often remembered as such because of the atmosphere of the restaurant and the beauty of the surrounding countryside.

title: HOUSTON'S GREAT THIRST IS SUCKING CITY DOWN INTO THE GROUND
description: It started to the east of the city some years ago, when homes and industry began to slide into Galveston Bay. Now the entire city of Houston is sinking into its base of sand and clay, including the glittery new residential, commercial and retail developments that have sprung up like weeds in the prairie to the west of downtown.

title: PHYSICS NEWEST FRONTIER
description: We TALK OF ''the universe'' as if it were far away, but of course it is right here, too. Its history concerns not only the remote stars and galaxies, but our world as well - down to the atoms that make up these words, this page, you and me.

title:
Dining Out;
AN ITALIAN 'BABY' IN EASTCHESTER
description: YES, there are really an Alex and a Henry. The Recine brothers, now well beyond retirement age, still greet old friends at their Bronx restaurant, opened 36 years ago, as well as at their ''baby,'' the 8-year-old in Eastchester. Alex and Henry's Roman Gardens, the Westchester restaurant, is a complex of patios, gardens, private rooms, lounges and a capacious bar -every inch filled on a weekend evening. The large public dining room that adjoins the other areas, however, seemed stark despite the gleam from dark-golden wall covering, mirrors and crystal chandeliers. Had the red table lamps been lit at all tables rather than at only those occupied, the room would have offered cheerier welcome.

title: Toronto
description: To the Editor: Margaret Atwood's article ''Toronto - the City Rediscovered'' (Travel, Aug. 8) brought back so many memories that I thought I would pass them on, partly because mine are so different from those of the author.

title: LIBRARY ART EXHIBITS: TOO OFTEN THE POOR RELATIVE
description: ROSLYN A recent visit to the exhibition of collages by Mildred Hermann, on view through Sept. 30 in the Helen Glannon Meeting Room at the Bryant Library, has prompted some thoughts on the showing of art in libraries on the Island. Mrs. Hermann will probably feel shortchanged because this column is not devoted exclusively to a discussion of her work, but in truth it is the library, not this writer, who has given her less than her due.

title: BEERHOLM WAS THERE
description: IN 'VANITY FAIR' By Roy T. Matthews and Peter Mellini. Illustrated. 275 pp. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press. $45 until Dec. 31, $55 thereafter.

title: Fairfield Prep Streak at 18 Against Bridgeport Central
description: Fairfield Prep's football program has always ranked among the finest in Connecticut. Since Earl Lavery took over 18 years ago, the school has never experienced a losing record and it appears that this year will be no exception.

title: Dr. Jean Harwick Wed To Dr. Barry E. Hirsch
description: Dr. Jean Harwick, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Dean Harwick of Wyncote, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Eliot Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Hirsch of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. The Rev. William Gardener, minister of the Unitarian Church of Germantown, Pa., and Rabbi Edward Maline of Temple Judea in Philadelphia performed the ceremony at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: NTA: PERIL OR CLEANER WASH?
description: HAUPPAUGE IT was laundry week at the State Department of Environmental Conservation, and experts here carefully weighed two bundles of testimony relating to the chemical NTA. One load of evidence indicated that the addition of NTA to detergents would produce whiter whites and brighter brights, but the other load suggested that longterm exposure to the chemical could pose a health hazard.

title: RUNNING AROUND RETIREMENT
description: You see them in Central Park, along the rivers, anywhere else that runners run. They wear the same colorful racing clothes, the same thick-soled shoes. The major difference is their age: They are over 60, their hair is often gray and, when they run in races, spectators sometimes call out things like ''Come on, Grandma, you can do it.''

title: THE INTERNATIONAL MARKETPLACE
description: The American market has become a distil- lation of the international marketplace. What is not produced at home is imported, whether it be in the form of actual merchandise, or in the form of something as intangible as inspiration. As a result, most of the goods on the American market have a multinational heritage. They may be designed in America and produced elsewhere, or designed abroad and manufactured here. In addition, a number of designers from overseas are now putting together collections geared specifically for the American market, while other designers have simply moved -lock, stock and barrel - to this country.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: NEW MUSIC Steve Reich and Musicians will open the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''The Next Wave'' series with concerts Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the BAM Opera House. These evenings of music constitute a survey of Mr. Reich's music past and present, and there will also be a premiere to be repeated at all three concerts -''Vermont Counterpoint'' for solo flute and tape, with Ransom Wilson as the soloist.

title: Ai Fang Calling
description: We're sorry they aren't going to have the thrill of that bell whose bing-bong precedes a cheery ''Avon calling.'' (House calls were found to be impractical.)

title: CLOUDED FUTURE ON PRESERVING PAST
description: AMERICANS were at the half-way mark of this century before we woke up to the fact that many of the buildings and surroundings with which we felt comfortable, which we loved and revered to the point of goose pimples, were being threatened and eliminated. It was a yearning to preserve the tangible part of our American heritage that led to the preservation movement.

title: FREE TIME URGED FOR TARGETS OF INDEPENDENT POLITICAL UNITS
description: A proposal to give Congressional candidates free radio and television time to balance the growing influence of spending by independent political action committees has received preliminary support from several members of Congress.

title: 2 AMERICANS KILLED IN LEBANON
description: Four members of a special United Nations observer force, including two American officers, were killed Saturday when their jeep hit a mine near Beirut, the Defense Department announced.

title: POLICE QUESTION WALDORF'S WORKERS IN HUNT FOR BANK EXECUTIVE'S KILLER
description: Detectives trying to determine who fatally stabbed a 30-year-old bank executive and left her body in a stairwell at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Wednesday night have focused their attention on the hotel staff, the police said yesterday.

title: ARTISTIC REAPPRAISAL
description: VICTORIAN SCULPTURE By Benedict Read. Illustrated. 414 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $60.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 1 1 4 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 2 8 5 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film.

title: OPERA WAS TRANSFORMED BY GLUCK'S 'ALCESTE'
description: One of any opera company's primary functions is to re-acquaint us with our operatic roots. This goes beyond its curatorial duties in the preservation of the standard, primarily 19th-century repertory. It means the freshening of our knowledge of the foundations on which that standard repertory was built.

title: BLACK AND WHITE
description: ''I went to white schools,'' says Susie Guillory Phipps, ''was raised white, and married white twice. I am white.''

title: Ethridge's Running Leads Kennedy Past Jackson
description: Darnell Ethridge of John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx turned in the outstanding performance of the first full week of action in the Public Schools Athletic League. Ethridge, a senior running back, rushed for 239 yards on 20 carries and scored two touchdowns to lead the Knights to a 27-8 defeat of Andrew Jackson in a non-division game at Kennedy Field.

title: Whale Watching
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION IS EXPECTED TO REJECT NEW OFFER BY OWNERS TODAY
description: Negotiations between the National Football League Players Association and the Management Council are scheduled to resume Sunday at a location near New York City that neither side would disclose. Management is prepared to make the players a new offer, but the union is expected to reject it.

title: THE BEIRUT MASSACRE: THE FOUR DAYS
description: The massacre of more than 300 Palestinian and Lebanese men, women and children at the Shatila refugee camp by Christian militiamen has left many unanswered questions.

title: THE WASHINGTON BALLET ABROAD
description: The Washington Ballet - a regional dance company that turned professional just six years ago - is to open a week of performances at the legendary Champs-Elysees Theater in Paris tommorrow night and follow that with a three-week tour of France, Germany, Luxembourg and Italy. Then, in December, the troupe will travel to Singapore to dance in the Singapore Arts Festival.

title: BEIRUT MASSACRE: 'TIME TO SPEAK WITH FORCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: PINGRY FINALLY DEFEATS POLY PREP
description: For the first time in 12 years, Pingry beat Poly Prep yesterday, 27-26, as Alan Crooms scored four running touchdowns, including one with 52 seconds to play.

title: The Call of The Wild In Maryland
description: Wild geese are calling. And so are teal, mallards, mud ducks and their ilk. The occasion is the 12th annual Waterfowl Festival, scheduled for the weekend of Nov. 12 to 14 in Easton, on Maryland's Eastern Shore.

title: Debra S. Perskie Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Berger Perskie of Tenafly, N.J., and Washington, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter, Debra Susan Perskie, to Michael Eric Leeds, son of Marcia Gettinger of Wayne, N.J., and New York City and Byron Leeds of Flanders, N.J., and Washington.

title: Texas Arms Issue
description: When the Mayor of Whitewright, Tex., bought four submachine guns to protect the town of 1,760 residents, Whitewright's Police Chief, David L. Montgomery, got his back up last January. That was twice as many machine guns as there were police officers in the community, some 60 miles northeast of Dallas.

title: POPULATION DECLINE HID BIG CHANGES
description: IT is no secret that New York City's growth has stopped. Indeed, the city's population declined during the 1970's. But what has received less attention in the months since the Census Bureau released its latest count are significant population shifts within the city.

title: THE CHEROKEE REMOVAL
description: How the Cherokee Nation was uprooted from its home in the East and deported, so to speak, to Oklahoma in 1838, is the subject of a new play to be presented in New Haven in October and November.

title: Exxon Is Sued by Oysterman For $1 Million Over Spilled Oil
description: An oysterman has sued the Exxon Corporation for $1 million, charging that an oil spill at Pelican Island killed or contaminated more than 20,000 sacks of oysters.

title: CRIME
description: As early as the 1920's there was Max Carrados, the blind detective in the Ernest Bramah series. Today we have Dan Fortune, the one-armed private eye created by Michael Collins. But a deaf detective? Jack Livingston has introduced one in A PIECE OF THE SILENCE (St. Martin's, $13.95). His name is Jack Binney, he works out of New York, and he lost his hearing when an underwater device went off while he was working as a frogman.

title: WAshington Intervenes In Rail Strike
description: As the economy has worsened and unemployment has climbed, the White House and organized labor have agreed on less and less. Last week, both swallowed principle and turned to pragmatism to bring an end to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers' crippling four-day rail strike.

title: Nigerian Zoo
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING LOCAL HISTORY EXCITING FOR FOURTH GRADERS
description: LET'S hear it for the people at the New York State Department of Education. At last, they've done something truly sensible: They have mandated that, starting this year, the fourth-grade social studies curriculum be devoted to the study of local history.

title: MISS ARMSTRONG WED TO DR. WILLIAM AYERS
description: Virginia Dexter Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Stuart Armstrong of East Orleans, Mass., and Dr. William McLean Ayers of Princeton, N.J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Ayers of Squantum, Mass., were married yesterday in Truro, Mass. The Rev. Raymond E. Dronsfield performed the Presbyterian ceremony in the First Congregational Parish.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The 12th Quarter

title: POP: PETER ALLEN
description: Two years ago, Peter Allen made show-business history of sorts by riding onto the stage of Radio City Music Hall on the back of a camel. This year, in a weeklong return engagement at the Music Hall that began Friday, there are no animals, but the production is considerably more extravagant.

title: Law of the Sea Pact To Be Signed in Jamaica
description: The United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea will culminate nine years of negotiations in December by signing a treaty in Kingston, Jamaica.

title: EAST END SINGS THE RECESSION BLUES
description: VOLUME was up, dollars were down. That's how Ron Ifft of Sheila C. Devlin-John F. McNiff Real Estate summed up the season now that the books are closing on summer 1982. ''I thought it went fairly slowly myself,'' he said, expressing a view widely held by brokers and businessmen up and down the East End, some of whom already sounded nostalgic as they recalled the boom years that preceded it.

title: LEBANON'S DOUBTERS ARE MANY, AND ARMED
description: Amin Gemayel was sworn in as President last week and embarked on Lebanon's desperate version of a presidential honeymoon. He was riding the crest of near-universal agreement that after the assassination of his brother, President-elect Bashir Gemayel, the new President's survival was absolutely necessary.

title: MANMADE MOUNTAIN
description: The most energy-efficient buildings, architects say, are those built into mountains. Officials of East Windsor Township, N.J., wanted an energy-efficient building, but didn't have a suitable mountain.

title: NORRIS POULSON, MAYOR WHO LURED DODGERS TO LOS ANGELES, DIES AT 87
description: Former Mayor Norris Poulson of Los Angeles, who was responsible for bringing the Dodgers from Brooklyn to Los Angeles in 1958, died early yesterday at a convalescent hospital in Orange, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Mackinac
description: To the Editor: The fort pictured with the story on Mackinac Island ''Mackinac: Newport North'' (Travel, Aug. 15) is not Fort Mackinac on the island, but rather Fort Michilimackinac, its neighbor on the south side of the Straits in Mackinaw City. v. hereas the latter is an impressive wooden stockade on the edge of the water, the former is an elegant whitewashed stone fortress on the top of a hill overlooking the island's principal harbor.

title: No Headline
description: Connors To Face McEnroe

title: RIDING HORSES ISN'T JUST FOR THE RICH ANYMORE
description: AUTUMN in Connecticut - a time for quiet country drives, bustling church fairs, exquisite antique sales and sweet apple cider. And for many, a time for horse shows. In fact, more riding enthusiasts are saddling up than ever before, according to Robert Brooks of the Connecticut Horse Council Inc.

title: SUPPLY AND PRICE OF FUEL EXPECTED TO HOLD STEADY
description: AFTER several years of erratic performance, the supply and price of home heating oil on Long Island this winter are expected to be stable and not much different from last season, according to oil industry and government officials.

title: Jack Sprat Will; Eat More Fat
description: Lean beef is not slim pickings for steak lovers, the Agriculture Department has argued, saying studies show lean beef is as flavorful as beef streaked with fat. Consumer groups, restaurateurs, meat wholesalers and retailers disagree.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER FACING CHALLENGE
description: With three weeks to go before candidates register for elections for the leadership of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, several contenders are moving to challenge Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki for his position.

title: Frederic M. Darche Jr.  Weds Katherine Long
description: Katherine Carroll Long and Frederic Marcel Darche Jr. were married yesterday in the Church of the Holy Trinity, a summer chapel in Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. James E. Hulbert, an Episcopal priest of Sea Girt, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: TOO many cooks might spoil the broth, but it would be hard to gather enough of them to hurt the lasagna. Not when it measures 200 square feet and requires 40 pairs of hands just to slosh the tomato sauce onto it and to spread the mozzarella.

title: No Headline
description: LATE FLORIDA SURGE TOPS MISSISSIPPI ST.

title: PORTRAIT OF A TORTURED DIRECTOR FLIRTING WITH DEATH
description: ''I am running out of fantasy,'' says a weary Werner Herzog in the course of Les Blank's cunning documentary feature, ''Burden of Dreams.'' The German director is weary not because he has just eaten his shoe, as he did in Mr. Blank's ''Werner Herzog Eats His Shoe,'' made in Berkeley, Calif., some years ago. In that film, to settle a bet, he ate his shoe - a large boot, really - after it had been carefully stewed with garlic, oregano and other spices.

title: Avocados for Dogs
description: With a record crop of avocados but wholesale prices depressed, growers represented by the California Avocado Commission in Irvine debated last January whether to offer the fruit for dog food. Some saw it as a fantastic opportunity.

title: Liverpool in Lead
description: Liverpool surged back to the top of the English League First Division soccer standings today with a 5-0 victory over Southampton.

title: Ellen H. Kemp Is Married To Philip Dixon in Albany
description: Ellen H. Kemp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar N. Kemp of Londonville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Philip H. Dixon, son of Caroline H. Dixon of Washington and the late Marvin H. Dixon of Chicago. The Rev. Robert C. Lamar performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Albany.

title: THE STORM OVER WOMEN FIREFIGHTERS
description: Karen Stabiner is a Los Angeles-based freelance writer. By Karen Stabiner In the shadow of a seven-story scaling tower, the 33 new recruits in the Seattle Fire Department begin the second four-hour exercise period of a grueling 10-hour workday. On cue, teams of four raise and lower 260-pound aluminum ladders, while pairs haul 85-pound bundles of hose. They each take turns climbing a ladder with a 35-pound box fan, an oxygen tank or a chain saw strapped to their backs. Department instructors tease overly cautious trainees, telling them to count their buttons when they're done, since the buttons can pop off if recruits cling to the ladder rungs. Worse than caution is laziness. If any of those recruits performs poorly, all 33 will have to climb that tower.

title: CAROL BURNETT PLAYS IT STRAIGHT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. BY STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES The license plate on Carol Burnett's Rolls-Royce reads ''11 YRS,'' in reference to her long reign as the queen of one of the most successful comedy series in the history of television. But the fans who know her only as the TV comedienne who created a huge gallery of vivid loonies in some 2,000 movie parodies and satiric sketches have not seen all the faces of Carol Burnett. She has appeared on stage (in ''Once Upon a Mattress'' early in her career, and more recently in a revival of ''Same Time Next Year'') and in films (''Pete 'n Tillie,'' ''A Wedding,'' ''The Four Seasons,'' and ''Annie'') as well as on television. She has excelled in drama as well as in comedy, most notably in ''Friendly Fire,'' in which her portrayal of a Midwestern woman obsessed with learning the truth about her son's death in Vietnam earned her an Emmy nomination.

title: David Kilian Sullivan Weds Katherine Kane
description: Katherine Marion Kane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew F. Kane of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to David Kilian Sullivan, son of Col. Martin F. Sullivan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Sullivan of Falls Church, Va. The Rev Patrick J. Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Conservation Group Clarifies Kean Position
description: In the article on Sept. 12 about the land dispute in Jefferson Township involving the family of Governor Kean, the wording conveyed the impression that Mr. Kean had not yet resigned from the board of trustees of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation.

title: 4 POUNDS IMPERILING JOB OF A DRUM MAJORETTE
description: A 130-pound drum majorette has been ordered by her high school band instructor to lose four pounds by the next home football game, which is next Friday, or sit in the stands.

title: HARD-WON ADVICE FOR FIRST-TIME VISITORS
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, chief of the Ottawa bureau of The New York Times, was until recently chief of the New Delhi bureau. By MICHAEL T.KAUFMAN

title: PREMIERS ABOUND ON STATE'S REGIONAL STAGES
description: THERE'LL be premieres aplenty - local premieres, American premieres, world premieres - on the stages of the state's four major regional theaters this season.

title: DARING TO LOOK AT ITALY'S PAST
description: Like the children of great men, Italian artists and designers tend at once to be proud of and burdened by their heritage. On the one hand, they believe - with considerable justification - that nothing in the history of the world can match their artistic legacy; on the other, they are at a loss as to how to improve on what already has been done.

title: WATER PLAN HEARING IN OCTOBER
description: A YEAR ago, environmentalists and sportsmen were embroiled in a dispute with the Metropolitan District Commission over its proposal to divert waters from the west branch of the Farmington River to the Barkhamsted Reservoir.
