This year, the M.D.C., which supplies water to seven Hartford area communities, is proposing two hydroelectric projects for the area, a plan that has had little organized opposition.

title: BANKING ON AIR-POLLUTION CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVEST OF WAR
description: Dr. Motoharu Kimura, a Japanese nuclear physicist, oversaw filming in the cities of Nagasaki and Hiroshima between Aug. 14 and Aug. 18, 1945, the week after they were leveled by atomic bombs. The footage was shot by cameramen from the Nippon Movie News Company Limited.

title: Corinne Higgins, of F.B.I., Married to Thomas Miller
description: Corinne Frances Higgins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Higgins of Dumont, N.J., was married there yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to Thomas Francis Miller, son of Lieut. Comdr. Rolland E. Miller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Miller of River Edge, N.J. The Rev. Donald E. McLaughlin performed the ceremony.

title: WHY DON'T GHOSTS BEHAVE PROPERLY ON OPERATIC STAGES?
description: Why is it that the brains of most opera directors seem to freeze over when they have to deal with ghosts? I don't say all directors, because for all I know there is one somewhere, perhaps in Inner Transylvania, who understands about ghosts and knows how to put them onstage convincingly, even frighteningly. But your every-day, run-ofthe-season opera production treats ghosts badly and I am at a loss to know why. Just the other evening at the New York City Opera, in Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet,'' the shade of the murdered king walked on twice in the most unscary fashion imaginable. Luckily, the dialogue led one to understand that this figure was Hamlet's dead father, but it might as plausibly have been someone coming to deliver a singing telegram.

title: DRINKING LAW CAUSES CAMPUS CONFUSION
description: FRESHMAN orientation was different this year at Western Connecticut State College in Danbury. So was last Sunday's Fall Ball, an annual student celebration held at Wesleyan University in Middletown.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: ALLIED CHAIRMAN SAYS MERGER HELPED 2 RIVALS
description: The chairman of the Allied Corporation said yesterday that his company's takeover of the Bendix Corporation ''eliminates a real threat'' to the economic well-being of Bendix and the Martin Marietta Corporation. Bendix and Marietta had been locked in a bitter takeover struggle of their own before Allied's late intervention ended the long dispute.

title: WEST GERMAN STATE HAS KEY VOTE TODAY
description: In a touch that could hardly have been intentional, the Dixieland combo struck up the song ''Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone'' as a thin crowd of young people drifted toward the rally of the politically endangered Free Democratic Party.

title: WITNESSES AT CODY TRIAL TESTIFY ABOUT THREATS
description: Threats of violence and requests for kickbacks were part of dealing with John Cody, the teamsters' union leader, according to testimony in Federal District Court here.

title: MAKING SCHOOLS BETTER FOR STUDENTS
description: Frank J. Macchiarola is Chancellor of the New York City publicschool system. s Chancellor of the New York City public-school system, I was able to appoint myself interim principal of Jamaica High School for two months last December. I wanted to get a firsthand appreciation of the problems of running a school and of the students it serves. And I did.

title: DROP IN HOME REPAIRS
description: For the housing industry, even the worst of overall slumps generally produces isolated pockets of good news. The current downturn is proving an exception to the rule.

title: DESIGNING A NEW ECONOMICS FOR THE 'ATARI DEMOCRATS'
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. HIS articles have appeared in everything from The Harvard Business Review to The New Republic. He acts as a consultant to Fortune 500 companies and shares his thoughts with Walter Mondale and Senator Edward M. Kennedy. At age 36, Robert B. Reich, a public policy professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, has gained a wide following among both businessmen and liberal politicians with his intriguing prescriptions for what ails our economy.

title: PRISON PRESSURES MUST HAVE A VALVE
description: F.LOVELL BIXBY, who ran New Jersey's prison and parole system in the 1960's, used to say that the state's informal motto was: ''Progress Through Catastrophe.''

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.3% IN AUGUST
description: Consumer prices rose only 0.3 percent in August, the Labor Department said, indicating that the inflation rate could slow to the lowest level in six years and less than half the rate set in 1979 and 1980. Monthly rises of about .04 percent are generally predicted for the rest of the year, which would result in a a 5.5 percent annual rate.

title: HUNTING THE MOOSE IN MAINE
description: MAINE'S second moose hunt in 47 years was a curiously public affair. Stimulated in part by the cries of those who have an aversion to all hunting and to moose hunting in particular, a concentration of onlookers and newspaper and television reporters, both regional and national, were on hand last Monday for the opening of the sixday season in which 1,000 permit-holders - 900 resident, 100 nonresident - went after the largest member of the deer family.

title: NEW RULES HELP THE HANDICAPPED
description: THE State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has extended the coverage of regulations making commercial b uildings accessible to physically handicapped persons, and a dditional proposals are under review for residential buildings, a ccording to Richard A. Berman, the state's Housing Commissioner.

title: TOURISM: NOT A PRETTY JOB
description: FACED with the expected failure of Connecticut's tourist season this year, the concerned residents of this state must ask a serious question. What will induce the camera-toting, Bermuda-shorted, trailer-towing, T-shirted and sunglassed horde to spread its filthy lucre across our lovely state?

title: A Hopeful Blip At Last in the S.A.T. Scores
description: There was a time when cars were big and houses were cheap and kids did great on their Scholastic Aptitude Tests. Lots of things deteriorated in the 1960's, however, including S.A.T. scores.

title: TIBETAN DANCE IN GREENBURGH HALL
description: THE fall season of the Greenburgh Arts and Culture Committee opens today with a performance of the Ling Dro Dechen Rolmo, a Tibetan Buddhist dance ritual, by the Yeshe Nyingpo Dance Troupe under the direction of Dr. Lin Lerner. Co-sponsored by the Westchester Dance Council, the performance is free and will take place at 3 P.M. at the Greenburgh Town Hall in Elmsford.

title: COLLEGE TEST SCORES INCREASE IN STATE
description: THE State Education Commissioner, Mark R. Shedd, said last week that he thought there was ''cause for optimism'' over the higher scores of Connecticut students on the Scholastic Aptitude Test this year.

title: 11-MONTH UNDERCOVER PROJECT LED TO 2 GAMBLER'S INDICTMENT
description: For 11 months, Louis Sommella, a New York City police detective, pretended to be a corrupt officer ''on the pad'' - a term used by the police to denote systematic payoffs to officers to overlook illegal actions.

title: A NEW TEST FOR COLLEEN DEWHURST
description: Glamour had fled; chic was absent. The big photograph of Colleen Dewhurst in the window outside the Plymouth Theater showed the face of a woman gaunt, a woman abstracted, a woman who looked as if she had just run a four-minute mile. In fact, the picture didn't matter to Miss Dewhurst; she hadn't noticed it, and even if she had noticed she wouldn't have cared, anyway. Other actresses have albums; she had only the single glossy. It had been blown up and mounted; eventually, it was retouched. Miss Dewhurst still didn't notice. Glamour, after all, is temporal. Why should she worry about that?

title: Paul G. Bigler 2d Weds Miss Burr
description: Rebecca Beasley Burr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith Corbin Burr Jr. of Memphis, was married there yesterday to Paul Gray Bigler 2d, son of Marika Kalnay Bigler of New York and Edward Madden Bigler of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Henry Strock Jr. performed the ceremony at the Idlewild Presbyterian Church.

title: Rene Miville Weds Susan Sharp, Writer, in Boston
description: Susan Inman Sharp, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Inman Sharp of Baltimore and the late Dr. Sharp, was married yesterday to Rene Armand Miville of Boston, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rene Miville of Methuen, Mass. The Rev. Robert Malm performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: M-1 Saga: Perils Of Procurement
description: The best place to deploy the Army's new $2.8 million M-1 tank may be on the front lawn of an American Legion hall. According to official reports made public last week by the Project on Military Procurement, a private watchdog group, only about half of the vehicles in a critical test were working by the end of five days.

title: Miss Faron, Edward Mell Are Married
description: Elizabeth Sherman Faron, daughter of Mrs. John Gray Faron of Summit, N.J., and the late Mr. Faron, was married yesterday to Edward Lloyd Mell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Knisely Mell also of Summit. The Rev. William Strain performed the ceremony at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit.

title: Rescue Missions
description: Now that the promotional hoopla about new fall titles is beginning to die down, it pays to take a look at a quiet but persistent publishing phenomenon: the systematic rescue of books consigned too early to oblivion. Editors in a wide variety of houses have been searching out neglected serious works of prose and poetry and republishing them for some time now, long enough so that their efforts can be evaluated, and results on the whole are encouraging. Apparently the economic constraints on publishers today needn't stop them from providing relatively small, selective audiences with reading matter that can stand the test of time.

title: LAFAYETTE TROUNCES COLUMBIA
description: Columbia registered its highest point total in five years yesterday, but Lafayette's offense was even more potent as it scored a 55-23 victory at Baker Field.

title: WHEN TIME IS SHORT
description: When time and the tournament are running out, it's appropriate to live dangerously. If a draw is as good as a loss, there is no point in worrying about whether what you are doing is scrupulously sound.

title: The Bible Gets; Tightened Up
description: In the beginning was the 850,000-word Bible, the best selling book of all time, but daunting. In the end, then, was the 510,000-word condensed Bible, published last week by Reader's Digest.

title: INTERNATIONAL LIVING
description: Despite the similarities that modern thinking has brought to home design throughout the world, there is plenty of evidence of national individuality.ver the last decades, modern approaches have affected home design in cultures as diverse as Brazil and Japan.

title: DRAFT RESISTANCE 80's STYLE
description: David Harris contends, ''Today's draft resistance has sprung up without a pre-existing political network, without an infrastructure of experienced organizers and without the framework of a political agenda larger than itself.'' In fact, thousands nationwide, working through hundreds of grass-roots groups and a number of national organizations, have been actively organizing against draft registration since it was reinstated in 1980.

title: MUSEUMS ASSESS THEIR FUTURE ROLES
description: IT was a surprisingly good year, not for wine but for another cultivated taste, museums, and New England museums particularly. ''Penny-pinching, conservative Yankees are uniquely gifted in the art of preserving what they have,'' was the consensus of the New England Museum Association, an arm of the American Association of Museums, in a conference last week in Hartford. More than 300 representatives of art, history, natural history museums and nature centers from six states attended.

title: LIFE WITHOUT FOOTBALL
description: At first, the thought of being without Sunday football seemed unbearable. For years, I had spent the Day of Rest watching the Redskins being tossed to the Cowboys or the Giants being devoured by the Lions, but with the players on strike, even the thought of not having to listen to Howard Cosell on Monday night was no consolation.

title: Carlstrum Lifts Maria Regina
description: Brian Carlstrum passed to Roger Pollard for two touchdowns to lead Maria Regina of Uniondale to a 13-0 victory over St. Dominic's of Oyster Bay yesterday in a Catholic High School Football League game.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm telling my deputy commissioners that this is the beginning of the second term of the Koch administration. No more distractions, no more sideways looks.'' - Anthony B. Gliedman, the Housing Commissioner. (1:1.)

title: BELGIAN PASSION: MOULES ET FRITES
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: COUNTDOWN TO DAMAGE CONTROL
description: Whenever anybody in politics or corporate life goofs, commits a gaffe, or makes a boo-boo (all are current vogue terms for blunder, having replaced foot-in-mouth disease), the people who race to minimize the reaction or fix the glitch are said to be engaged in damage control, or if they want to make it even more dramatic, in a damage-control operation.

title: THEATER: A REVIVAL, 'NOT NOW, DARLING'
description: For 40 years, the Equity Library Theater has been giving professional actors and directors and backstage people a showcase to let producers, agents and the public meet the great store of talent in New York. Now it has started its latest decade with a British farce, ''Not Now, Darling.''

title: No Headline
description: ELWAY RALLIES STANFORD TO UPSET OHIO STATE BY 23-20

title: PRAYER WAS NOT THE ISSUE
description: For all their talk about staging a full Senate debate on school prayer, Senator Helms and his small band of court-strippers never held up their end. Save for a few verbal insults, it was the opponents who, with their filibuster, managed to identify the real issue. It was not prayer, not morality, but a sneak attack on the Federal courts to remove them as a bulwark for religious liberty.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: NEVER AT REST A Biography of Isaac Newton. By Richard S. Westfall. Illustrated. 908 pp. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. $49.50.

title: IN SENATE RACE, THE STRATEGIES EMERGE
description: WITH just over five weeks to go in the campaign for the United States Senate, the strategies of the candidates have come into sharp conflict, which may make it more difficult for the voters to sort out who stands for what.

title: ANY MAIL IS BETTER THAN NO MAIL AT ALL
description: MY mail was disappointing today. A letter I wrote to my cousin in Illinois was returned to me undelivered. He isn't at the address I have for him, and he left no forwarding address. Now all I can do is hope that he'll contact me again some day, so we can stay in touch, at least by mail. Probably because I live 1,200 miles from my original family, letters are very important to me. Each day's mail is welcomed, even the bills and the solicitations, because I know that tucked away in the large pile of advertisements, magazines, meeting notices and political flyers, there may be a letter from a friend I haven't heard from for a long time or an invitation to a party or a pair of ballet tickets I've ordered.

title: SPELLBOUND ON THE MERRITT PARKWAY
description: ''YOU should see that road, it's like driving through a park,'' one Chicagoan said to the other. He was describing for his friend, who had never been in Connecticut, one of our tourist attractions. Not Mystic Seaport, or Mark Twain's house, or a covered bridge - but the Merritt Parkway.

title: THE PSYCHIC TOLL OF THE NUCLEAR AGE
description: When I first heard that the United States had dropped an atomic bomb on a Japanese city, I reacted in a way I am not proud of. I remember telling a friend that if a single American life had been saved, the bombing was the right thing to do. I was 19 years old, a medical student, and I wanted what other Americans wanted - a quick and victorious end to the war.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: RABBIT IS RICH. By John Updike. (Fawcett, $3.95.) ''For me, 'Rabbit Is Rich' is the first book in which Updike has fulfilled the fabulous promise he offered with 'Rabbit Run' and 'The Centaur' 20 years ago,'' Roger Sale declared in his review of the third novel about Harry ''Rabbit'' Angstrom (''Rabbit Redux'' appeared in 1971). Now making nearly $50,000 a year running the Toyota agency out on Route 111, Rabbit is still overweight and a veteran of more than two decades of marriage to Janice, who has some of the best lines and scenes in a novel that won a Pulitzer Prize, an American Book Award and an award from the National Book Critics Circle.

title:
The Lively Arts Long Island Philharmonic;
BENEFACTOR UNITES DIVERSE GROUPS
description: OLD WESTBURY AT first glance, Sharon Moe, the principal French horn player with the Long Island Philharmonic who will offer a free public master class on her instrument Thursday at Bay Shore High School, would seem to have little, if anything, in common with Shinnecock Indians engaged in oyster farming in Southampton, the elderly working with former mental hospital inmates in Sayville, Hispanic families in Glen Cove who are being tutored in English, or Levittown High School students learning how to identify and solve community problems.

title:
BEAUTY FITNESS;
WHAT IT TAKES TO BE IN FASHION
description: Searching to be in fashion, women sometimes overlook one of the basic principles: Beauty and fashion mix and mingle constantly. This fall's shapes - slim and sleek or controlled and curved - require a good body underneath. They also suggest stylish, shorter hair. And the dominance of the color black for day and evening wear underscores the need for vibrant makeup. But women are not alone in discovering the benefits of looking better with healthy, cared-for bodies. Men are devoting increasing energy to keeping fit and thus looking better.fashion pointOlder women who have kept in shape can wear modern clothes. Carmen, the 51-year-old model, proves it with Zoran's blouson, $340, and skinny pants, $360, both in cashmere. At Bergdorf Goodman. Saks Fifth Avenue.upkeep

title: Grunfeld a Knick
description: Ernie Grunfeld officially became a Knick yesterday when the Kansas City Kings failed to match the offer sheet the Knicks gave the 6-foot-6-inch, 220-pound swing man Sept. 10. Under the right of first refusal, the Kings had 15 days to match the offer and either keep or trade Grunfeld, who was a star at Forest Hills High School in Queens and later for the University of Tennessee.

title: CHINA MAY NOT DIG AT EMPEROR'S TOMB
description: The 2,200-year-old tomb of Qin Shi Huang, the first man who dared to call himself Emperor of China, will probably not be opened soon, even though the area around it has already yielded 7,000 life-size ceramic figures of the warriors and horses that made up the imperial honor guard.

title: No Headline
description: CARDS CUT NUMBER FOR CLINCHING TO 3

title: YALE GETS GRANT TO HELP RAISE LEVEL OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: A victory in the effort to end the conflict between town and gown has been declared with the award of a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to assist a Yale University program aimed at raising the teaching level in the public schools in New Haven.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: DAILY NEWS AND UNIONS AGREE ON LONGER PACT
description: The Daily News and its 11 labor unions tentatively agreed early yesterday morning to extend the unions' contracts until March 1987. The paper says the agreement will enable it to do extensive cost cutting.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE TIME TO DEREGULATE IS NOW
description: THE most challenging problem in energy policy for Congress in this d ecade is to pass legislation that would ease the economy's a djustments to shocks in natural gas supplies and prices. On the lastr ound of gas policy, after the 25 percent shortages of 1975 and 1976,C ongress failed the challenge by passing the Natural Gas Policy Act o f 1978.

title: CRAFTS
description: NEWARK AFRICAN cloths that document events with the urgency of news reports are the subject of ''In Praise of Heroes,'' an exhibition now at the Newark Museum.

title: CHILDREN OF DIVORCE AS EXPERTS
description: NEW HAVEN A GROUP of teachers sat in a classroom this summer, listening attentively to unusually expert speakers on the effects of divorce on children.

title: Gail Kelly Has Bridal
description: Gail Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ward Kelly of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James F.X. Hiler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hiler of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of SS.

title: ECLECTIC ELEGANCE IN BRAZIL
description: By Warren Hoge Warren Hoge is The New York Times's bureau chief in Brazil. The house that Betsy and Olavo Monteiro de Carvalho built on top of one of the highest hills in the middle of Rio de Janeiro had to be eye-catching or guests might have spent all their time looking out the windows. On one side, the city stretches out to Guanabara Bay and Sugar Loaf Mountain. The other side is presided over by the faithinspiring presence of the Christ the Redeemer statue on the peak of Corcovado Mountain. Theirs is one of four spacious houses that members of the Monteiro family have built in a compound whose 30 acres still leave room for new generations to plant their ideas in the choice location. Betsy and Olavo Monteiro's idea was to come up with a place that could serve as home for them and their three small daughters, and a reception spot for the many social evenings Mr. Monteiro's professional life requires. He is the head of the family-run holding company, Monteiro Aranha S.A., that, as one of Brazil's most innovative and successful, brings people such as Arab sheiks, German automobile makers and American bankers to Rio on business. The neighborhood, called Santa Teresa, is one of the few in Rio that high-rise builders have not bulldozed into plaster dust. The city's last surviving trolley winds along its narrow, cobbled streets. Above mews and cul de sacs of townhouses climb driveways leading to precipice-hugging mansions, castles and other fairy-tale confections that tropical imaginations threw together in a cheerful, eclectic jumble.

title: JOANNE CARNER SHARES LEAD
description: Kathy Whitworth is far from impressed with a one-stroke lead going into the third round of the $175,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Safeco Classic.

title: No Headline
description: West Virginia 43 Richmond 10

title: Letting Go
description: As a teacher of prekindergarten and kindergarten children, I have emphasized for years that the most important element of a child's readiness for the formal learning experience is self-reliance (''Letting Go,'' by Marguerite Kelly, Aug. 22). Too many parents fail to realize that doing for their children often does them out of their own sense of control over and participation in the world. IRENE NOWELL TIETZE, Garden City, L.I.

title: WITH RADIATION, HOW LITTLE IS TOO MUCH?
description: BETWEEN 1951 and 1958, at least 97 atomic bombs were detonated above-ground in the Nevada desert. Winds carried radioactive fallout from dozens of these tests for hundreds of miles, exposing not only the soldiers assigned to maneuvers near ground zero, but distant civilian populations in surrounding states. Congressional investigations and scientific studies have suggested an association between the fallout exposure and illnesses among these groups, but the Government has consistently denied responsibility. This year, related lawsuits are forcing intense scrutiny of radiation and human health.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LANDSCAPE RENOVATION
description: WITH home construction virtually at a standstill, publications that serve the landscape trades report little landscaping activity for new houses. Even so, planting has held steady and even increased because of a rise in interest in replanting or renovating gardens surrounding dwellings that are 20 years old or older.

title: PANEL TO PROPOSE CANADA JOIN O.A.S.
description: After a year and a half of study, a special nonpartisan parliamentary committee is reportedly ready to recommend that Canada join the other nations of the Western Hemisphere in the Organization of American States.

title: A REPROGRAMMING AT DIGITAL
description: SINCE its beginnings, the Digital Equipment Corporation's marketing strategy has consisted of what the computer industry calls ''pumping iron.'' Digital simply spewed out its highly regarded minicomputers, processors, holding sales technique, worked well as long as Digital's customers were engineers, scientists, and other specialists who used such D.E.C. hardware to build their own systems.

title: New York Times Magazine September 26, 1982
description: William Safire 12 On Language Countdown to Damage Control Russell Baker 27 Sunday Observer Getting Past the Door Timothy Ferris 36 Physics' Newest Frontier Emily Vermeule 48 Odysseus at Fenway Of bat and ball and great men we sing, of giants and tigers and Rooster and sacrifices and beer, of sun-drenched arena and victors and vanquished as another not very epic baseball season draws to a close on a more or less gallant shipwreck in Boston. Richard Eder 50 A Farewell to France Precise, muddy, kindly, cold, the French elude definition.

title: The Lively Arts; THEATER SEASON OFFERING FEW SURPRISES
description: ''THE sun shone, having no alternative, on the nothing new.'' So begins Samuel Beckett's novel ''Murphy.'' With its tone of resignation and inevitability, the image comes to mind as a new and yet not so new Island theater season begins. There's affirmation in local theaters of resiliency and sheer survival, but don't expect surprises.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LANDSCAPE RENOVATION
description: WITH home construction virtually at a standstill, publications that serve the landscape trades report little landscaping activity for new houses. Even so, planting has held steady and even increased because of a rise in interest in replanting or renovating gardens surrounding dwellings that are 20 years old or older.

title: BEIRUT MASSACRE: 'TIME TO SPEAK WITH FORCE '
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT R. DIEFENDORF
description: Robert R. Diefendorf, retired partner in the stock brokerage concern of Ritter & Company in New York City, died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 80 years old and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: PARAQUAT VICTIM IS GIVEN A RARE LUNG TRANSPLANT
description: A Florida man who inhaled toxic paraquat fumes last month and was near death underwent a rare lung transplant at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx early yesterday, and his surgeon later expressed guarded optimism on his chances of survival.

title: Mayor by Air
description: It is about 750 miles from Elmwood Place, Ohio, to Sioux Falls, S.D., as the Mayor flies.

title: DANCE: THE ARTISTRY OF MARGIE GILLIS
description: One doesn't come across the flamelike intensity of a dancer like Margie Gillis too often. The heart jumps when she flips through the air like an exhilarated dolphin. The eye follows her regal beauty gliding through waves of fabric; the gut is touched by her confessional displays of pain. In short, this dancer from Montreal is a knockout.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: New School Year: Optimism and Energy

title: Columbia Is Victor By 8-7
description: Ed Ricci scored a 2-point conversion on a fake extra-point play as Columbia edged Seton Hall Prep, its crosstown rival, 8-7, yesterday in South Orange in a game between New Jersey powers .

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: STROLL down Lollipop Lane in Hackensack, and you'll come to a mocha-colored house with a chocolate-colored roof, a place where about 30 children disappear every day. There's no wicked witch inside, but a staff of five who teach, feed, play with and care for the children of Hackensack Hospital employees from dawn to dusk.

title: U.S. PUSHES TO GET CUBANS OUT OF ANGOLA
description: The United States has sent a high-ranking State Department official to Angola in a renewed effort to bring about the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola -the key remaining problem holding up an agreement on the independence of South-West Africa, State Department officials said today.

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1982
description: The Massacre The massacre of more than 300 Palestinian and Lebanese men, women and children at the Shatila refugee camp by Christian militiamen has left many unanswered questions. The slayings, which began Wednesday, Sept. 15, and continued until Saturday, Sept. 18, raise questions that focus on the role played by the Israeli Army in what is certain to be regarded as one of the most important events in the modern history of the Middle East. Much is at stake in the answers to these questions. (Page 19:1-6.)

title: N.A.A.C.P. SETS DALLAS EVENT
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will hold its 1985 convention in Dallas. About $10,000 delegates are expected to attend it.

title: Trenton Honks For New Insurance Bill
description: Whether or not New Jersey drivers deserve their reputation, insurance companies in the state may soon be prevented from placing a fat premium on it. Last week, in the first step of what is expected to be a smooth trip through the Legislature, the Assembly Banking and Insurance Committee unanimously approved a plan that would limit the wide disparity in auto insurance rates.

title: Lilly Kaplan Married
description: Lilly Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Kaplan of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Anthony Combias, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Combias of Summit, N.J. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg performed the ceremony at the Beacon Hill Club in Summit.

title: EAST TIMOR NEEDS THE WORLD'S ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Fans Stun Chicagoan
description: To the Sports Editor: I am newly arrived in New York from Chicago, and I have been surprised by strange and new attitudes toward sports that I have encountered among the New York fans I have met. A number of baseball fans rant and complain, threatening to switch loyalties to another team because their team did not win this year. Now, I have not been around the city long enough to know if this talk is mere idle mouthing or whether these fans really mean to switch; but either way I was shocked.

title: Corrections
description: As the result of misinformation from a company spokesman, an incorrect phone number was given in the Practical Traveler column of Sept. 19 for the office to which holders of Visa cards may report a lost or stolen card.

title: TOWARD FAIRER TAXATION
description: Almost every year, Congress creates new exclusions, credits, deductions and other special provisions that feed the ordinary citizen's suspicion that he has to pay too much tax because others pay too little.

title: No Headline
description: Angels Win by 6-5; Lead Is 3 1/2 Games

title: ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CENTER FOR YOUNG AND OLD
description: BASKING RIDGE UNTIL recently, David Malinski of Elizabeth had no idea where his tap water came from. Nor did he care. He could turn the faucet and water would come out. That was enough for him.

title: 'CENTURY OF REVIVALS'
description: The 19th century was a period of revivals in the decorative arts - a time when the shaping of furniture was done by cabinetmakers who looked to the past, not the future. This is the view of Ulysses G. Dietz, curator of decorative arts of the Newark Museum, and it is the message of ''Century of Revivals,'' an exhibition of Neo-Classical through Victorian styles that opens at the museum today and remains on view through July 5, 1983.

title: Learning His Trade
description: Shawon Dunston of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, who was the No.1 selection in last spring's baseball amateur draft, has been busy since he signed a reported $150,000 bonus contract with the Chicago Cubs soon after being selected June 8. Dunston, a 19-yearold shortstop who batted .790 and stole 37 bases in 37 attempts in his senior year in high school, is playing for the Cubs' team in the Arizona Instructional League, which ends its season on Oct. 30.

title: 60 Worshipers Killed In Storm in El Salvador
description: Sixty people killed by a mudslide that razed a church during services last Sunday were the latest deaths reported in seven days of flooding that killed 600 people in El Salvador, relief workers said today.

title: LENOX HILL ASSOCIATION LEADER RETIRING AFTER A LONG CAREER
description: On the Upper East Side, among luxury high-rise dwellers, rent-poor singles and the impoverished elderly, Celine G. Marcus has spent the last 23 years establishing a grass-roots network of social services and support.

title: SNAGS IN A FLAT TAX
description: There is something very seductive about the flat-tax idea. Almost everyone complains about the maze of deductions that seems to allow the rich to escape the tax net and forces the rest of us to line the pockets of accountants at tax-return time. And the supplyside advocates are not alone in arguing that restructuring the tax code to reduce marginal rates would increase the incentive to work.

title: ADULT EDUCATION: SELF-HELP IN ACTION
description: PARADOXICALLY, the first cool days at the end of summer feel like the breath of spring to me. Just as the rain and warm sun awaken the sleeping plants from winter, so I revive from the summer coma with the first touch of fall. I begin to think of going back to school, and the excitement and high adventure of a new term. School, for me, means Continuing Education for Adults, at night.

title: Monterey
description: To the Editor: The article on ''The Lure of Monterey (Travel, Aug. 15) made no mention of what may be the California peninsula's most enchanting spot - Asilomar State Park on the ocean southwest of Pacific Grove in a forest of considerable beauty.

title: MRS. THATCHER LAUNCHES A SHIP IN SHANGHAI
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain named a ship for a Hong Kong millionaire in a Chinese shipyard today and described it as a symbol of the close relationship between China, Britain and Hong Kong.

title: We Are Still Not Amused
description: Buckingham Palace intruder Michael Fagan had his day in court for his days at court last week. Considering the row raised when he confessed breaking into the palace once to sip royal wine and entering again to chat with Queen Elizabeth II, he got off rather lightly. Mr. Fagan, who had not been charged in the trespass involving the Queen (trespass is a civil, not a criminal matter in Britain), was found not guilty of criminal break-in the month before, when he stole a bottle of wine - an Austrailian vintage, he thought - belonging to the Prince of Wales.

title: RELIABLE ITALIAN IN RIDGEFIELD
description: RIDGEFIELD ITALIAN is one of the world's great cuisines. One wouldn't always think so if one's experience were limited to the Italian restaurants of Connecticut. Too often a raw tomato sauce serves as the be-all and end-all of the Italian restaurant kitchen, covering fish, fowl and meat indiscriminately.

title: BALL TEAM MAY LEAVE STATE
description: WEST HAVEN WHEN David Goldstein bought the West Haven baseball franchise in the Eastern League two years ago, he said he felt he was living out a fantasy. A lifelong baseball fan, whose only previous involvement in the game had been as a high school player on Long Island, he reveled in the life of a baseball club owner that first year.

title: DRAFT RESISTANCE 80's STYLE
description: David Harris's article leaves the reader thinking that the Selective Service System is presently concerning itself strictly with the registration issue and is doing nothing in the way of implementing the return of the draft. The truth is that the Selective Service has already selected and trained all the local draft-board members for every region of the country.

title: BEIRUT MASSACRE: 'TIME TO SPEAK WITH FORCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Analysis
description: The Soviet Union is reportedly producing four new types of combat aircraft and improving the performance of two other standard types as part of a program to raise the quality of its air force, which has more than twice as many planes as NATO.

title: FINDING WAYS TO COPE
description: Bruce Fisher, an accountant from Whitestone, Queens, said: ''Sunday afternoon will still not be spent with the in-laws. I like watching reruns of 'Let's Make a Deal,' and there's always racing at Monticello.''

title: COngress Skirts The Big Ones
description: The prospect of an early release -Friday instead of Oct. 8 - and a post-election session in November moved Congress to unusual dispatch last week. In starting to pack their bags, the lawmakers were leaving behind the heftiest questions. The 1983 fiscal year will begin this week, likely with no spending bills passed and a deficit projected by the Congressional Budget Office at nearly $155 billion and by the White House at a only relatively less staggering $115 billion.

title: AYLA LOVES JONDALAR
description: THE VALLEY OF HORSES By Jean M. Auel. 502 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title: PARK OF DISNEY'S DREAMS NEARS REALITY IN FLORIDA
description: It was to have been an environmentally controlled community where the best qualities of life and nature could be meshed and improved in an orderly way, serving as a model for enhancing the life of all human beings.

title: CONGRESS TO TRY TO BAN OIL LEASING IN WILD AREAS
description: Congress is set to try again to prevent the Interior Department from issuing petroleum leases in wilderness areas or in areas being considered for wilderness designation.

title: ALBANY RACE COULD HINGE ON DIFFERING TAX POLICIES
description: ''I hope to make this election a referendum on economic growth,'' Lewis E. Lehrman said last week, the day before his landslide victory over Paul J. Curran in the Republican gubernatorial primary officially gave him the opportunity.

title: Miss Crossman, Rex Pingle Wed
description: Katharine Febiger Crossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Farrell Crossman of New York and Norfolk, Conn., was married yesterday to Rex Eugene Pingle, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Kenneth Pingle of Fostoria, Ohio. The Rev. Peter Holroyd, chaplain of the Taft School, performed the ceremony at Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk.

title: Nancy L. Nichols Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Lynne Nichols and Donald Vincent Dougherty were married yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Nils B. Blatz, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Francis T. Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A CONSERVATIVE'S ABC'S
description: PREJUDICES A Philosophical Dictionary. By Robert Nisbet. 318 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: Dining Out; ELEGANT SETTING, UNEVEN KITCHEN
description: A number of years ago, Pappagallo, a restaurant that was started in a small building in Glen Head, moved to rather elegant new quarters nearby with a spacious, hexagonal main dining room. Although more French and continental dishes were added after the move, the fine quality of the cooking of what was originally a Northern Italian kitchen seemed to have been maintained. Now, however, both the food and the service have slipped, so that the restaurant deserves no more than one star.

title: Headliners; Twice Convicted
description: Try again is what California was forced to do when its Court of Appeals in 1978 overturned the conviction of Juan Corona, found guilty in 1973 in the slayings of 25 itinerant farm workers near Yuba City.

title: MADMAN'S REVENGE
description: THE WHITE PLAGUE By Frank Herbert. 445 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: The 'Very Sorry' Plea
description: In ''The Insanity Plea on Trial'' (Aug. 8), Judge Irving R. Kaufman argues for a verdict of guilty but mentally ill. According to his view, such a verdict would best express society's ''conflicting desires'' to disapprove of ''violent and reprehensible acts'' and to provide ''mercy to those whose diminished mental capacities render them unable to control themselves.''

title: Recent Sales
description: Jackson Township $68,900 100 Buckingham Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8 1/2-year-old ranch; sauna, humidifier, *2*wallto-wall carpeting; taxes $1,600. Manalapan $80,200 8 Lowell Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; *2*patio, outdoor lighting; taxes $1,400. Monmouth Beach $159,000 1609 Channel Drive *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old luxury high-rise condominium; *2*butcher-block kitchen counters, marina views, *2*monthly maintenance $272; taxes $2,447. Neptune $62,000 24 Maplecrest Drive *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; *2*screened porch, skylights; taxes $1,137. Ocean Township $100,000 19 Overhill Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old ranch; *2*hardwood floors, deck; taxes $2,125. West Long Branch $275,000 27 Muncy Drive *2*5-bedroom, 5-bath, 4-year-old ranch; cathedral ceilings, double *2*fireplace, whirlpool room, decks, skylights; taxes $3,671. OTHER AREAS Farmingdale, L.I. $71,600 *2*67 Michel Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bathroom, 19-year-old high ranch; formal dining *2*room, 2 kitchens, 70-by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,800. Bedford, N.Y. $162,000 Brett Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old frame colonial; *2*family room, deck, 2 acres; not yet assessed. Cheshire, Conn. $140,000 96 Jinny Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; Florida room, *2*in-law apartment, screened porch, 1.6 acres; taxes $2,122.

title: A MIXTURE OF OFFERINGS OPENS BUSY FALL CONCERT SEASON
description: IF you have any doubts that the county's concert season is off to an unusually busy start, take a glance at the cultural calendar for the next weekend: one dance and two major chamber music series are beginning, and there is also a major organ recital, the county debut of a remarkable trio, a choral program, an operatic double-header and more.

title: 9-2 Reinvested Takes $500,000 Super Derby
description: Reinvested, the third-place finisher in this year's Kentucky Derby, came from two lengths back in the final stretch strides to defeat El Baba by a nose in $500,000 Super Derby at Louisiana Downs today.

title: CALIFANO SUSPENDS 2 INVESTIGATORS IN CONGRESS SEX AND DRUG INQUIRY
description: Two investigators working on a special inquiry into allegations of drug use and improper sexual conduct on the part of Congressmen are themselves being scrutinized by the Justice Department and have been suspended.

title: GLENN GOULD REVISITS A BACH MASTERWORK
description: Some 27 years ago, a 23-year-old Canadian pianist was making his debut recording for Columbia Records. On the warm summer day of the first recording session, he arrived at the recording studio wearing a winter coat, a beret, a muffler and gloves. He carried a batch of towels, bottles of spring water, several varieties of pills and a 14-inch high piano chair to sit on. He soaked his arms in hot water for 20 minutes, took several medications, adjusted each leg of his chair, and proceeded to play, loudly humming and singing along. After a week, he had produced one of the most remarkable performances of Bach's Goldberg Variations on record.

title: PENN STATE WINS ON LATE PASS
description: Todd Blackledge, Penn State's junior quarterback, stole victory from favored Nebraska today when he tossed his third touchdown pass with 4 seconds left.

title: Steel Beam Kills 3 in Mexico
description: A 30-ton steel beam dropped 16 feet from the roof of a baggage area being built at Mexico City's International Airport on Friday, killing three workers and injuring four others, airport officials reported.

title: Peter Thomas, Deborah Richardson Are Married
description: Deborah Griswold Richardson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George O. Richardson Jr., of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Thomas, son of Mrs. James Ramage and Bruce Thomas of Auckland, New Zealand. The Rev. Edwark Danks performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan's Running A Major Factor For Bergen Catholic
description: Bergen Catholic of Oradell opened its season in powerful fashion with a 35-0 blanking of Bergenfield today in Oradell. Bergen Catholic, which had 316 yards total offense, was paced by the running of Mike Morgan, who scored on runs of 4, 12 and 66 yards. The junior tailback carried 13 times for a total of 124 yards. Bob Murray led the passing attack with 146 yards on 7 completions out of 12 attempts.

title: Heather Leigh Douglas Married to Jan Carlee
description: Heather Leigh Douglas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bowman Douglas 2d of Saddle River, N.J., and Orangeburg, N.Y., was married yesteray to Jan Carlee, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Carlee of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. David C. VanSickle of the Upper Ridgewood Community Reform Church in America performed the ceremony in the garden of the farm of the bride's parents in Orangeburg.

title: STORIES FROM THE AMERICAN FRONT
description: THE BURNING HOUSE By Ann Beattie. 256 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Though celebrated as the inventor of the telegraph, Samuel F.B. Morse (1791-1872) was also a major artist, a portraitist whose brilliance at capturing character made him one of the 19th century's greats. While still in his 20's, concerned over the lack of art schools and galleries in New York, he helped to found the National Academy of Design - America's version of the Royal Academy in London - and served as its first president.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
COUNTRY PEOPLE WERE HIS INSPIRATION
description: It sometimes happens these days that magazine photographers who start showing in galleries repudiate the magazine work that made them famous in favor of new work made specially for gallery exhition or old work that has not previously been seen. Russell Lee missed an opportunity to do this when selecting the photographs for the small retrospective of his work at the Witkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, through Oct. 23.

title: A WHOPPER OF A LEASE
description: It doesn't look like much: 19,075 undeveloped square feet in Chinatown beneath the Manhattan Bridge that has been used mostly as a parking lot. Earlier this month, the city put the lot on the auction block hoping to get a minimum of $40,000 a year in rent.

title: THE ISRAELI STATEMENTS ON THE EVENTS IN LEBANON
description: Thursday, Sept. 16. Israeli Army spokesman: ''The I.D.F. is in control of all key points in Beirut. Refugee camps harboring terrorist concentrations remained encircled and closed. The I.D.F. calls on citizens to return to normal activity and on all terrorists and other armed persons to lay down their arms.'' Friday, Sept. 17. The Cabinet: ''Following the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel, the I.D.F. took positions in West Beirut in order to prevent the danger of violence, bloodshed and anarchy, while about 2,000 terrorists, equipped with modern and heavy weapons, remained in West Beirut, thus blatantly violating the departure agreement.''

title: No Headline
description: Gabor Peterdi is scarcely a forgotten artist but, frequent exhibitor though he is, he has not enjoyed the kind of attention paid to his associates and near contemporaries, the primary Abstract Expressionists. Probably there are some practical reasons for this, because the artist has devoted much of his energy to prints, for which he is best known, and to teaching.

title: Sale at Doyle Galleries Sets Mark at $1,688,000
description: The William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street, had its most successful sale to date Wednesday, with 134 paintings bringing in $1,688,000.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ For jazz fans who like to be off the streets and gathered around the home hearth of a heatolator by the time darkness sets in, Elaine and Paul Weinstein, a pair of early-to-bed advocates, are beginning two series of concerts this week that provide twilight opportunities to hear jazz artists who are usually available only to night owls.

title: ISRAELIS, AT HUGE RALLY IN TEL AVIV, DEMAND BEGIN AND SHARON RESIGN
description: Several hundred thousand Israelis demonstrated tonight against Prime Minister Menachem Begin's handling of the question of Israeli involvement in the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.

title: ROSBERG WINS DRIVING TITLE
description: No world champion driver has ever compiled a less auspicious Formula One record prior to his title-winning season than Keke Rosberg. The 34-year-old Finn was hoping to secure the 1982 championship yesterday in the final race of the season at Las Vegas, Nev., but the best he had to show for three earlier seasons of grand prix racing was a third-place finish in the 1980 Argentine Grand Prix.

title: The Many Faces; Of the New China
description: What do an oil rig and a skin cream have in common? Ask Deng Xiaoping, who thinks both Western breakthroughs are necessary for the new China.

title: INDIA RELAXES AFTER FILM IDOL ESCAPES DEATH
description: A movie star named Amitabh Bachchan went home from the hospital Friday, and all across India hundreds of thousands who had prayed for him in Hindu temples, Moslem mosques and Sikh shrines breathed a sigh of relief.

title: GERMANY'S QUEST FOR A NEW MIRACLE
description: WHEN West Germans returned home earlier this month to the cloudy skies of Hanover and Frankfurt from their sunny summer vacation spots in Greece and Spain, there was an unmistakable air of apprehension and nervousness about the country's future. For many, that uneasiness was something of a tradition, reflecting the tendency of bankers and businessmen in Germany to play down their prospects for the coming year. This time, however, things were different.

title: CONCERT SEASON UNDER WAY
description: NEW JERSEY'S formal 1982-83 concert season begins this month with a wide variety of musical events in store. Just about every college, plus many high schools, museums and libraries, have professional concert series.

title: BRITISH LIBERALS TRY TO MEND ALLIANCE FENCES
description: The Liberal Party gathered this week in this relaxed coastal town, where its greatest leader, William Gladstone, spent his dying days, for a conference designed to breathe new life into its alliance with the Social Democratic Party.

title: ANOTHER HOPEFUL ENTERS MAGAZINE DERBY
description: MANHASSET REMEMBER Paumanok? On the Sound? Of Nassau? Suffolk? Long Island? All were slick and shiny magazines designed to attract a Long Island audience. As it was, the readership never materialized, the money dried up, and one by one they died.

title: SIBELIUS'S 'SWAN' INSPIRES A NEW BALLET
description: David Bintley, an ambitious young British choreographer, has just staged his first three-act ballet, and if it is not entirely successful, at least it is something other than yet another retelling of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Othello'' or ''Cinderella.'' In fact, in his ''The Swan of Tuonela,'' created for the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet, Mr. Bintley has tackled refreshingly unfamiliar subject matter taken from Finnish mythology and has set this material to music by Jean Sibelius, a composer whose works are not ordinarily associated with dancing.

title: Oslo
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from a trip to Scandinavia and want to thank John Canaday for his article ''An Art Critic Reviews Oslo''(Travel, July 11). We took it with us and covered most of the sights and museums which he discussed.

title: 'SUBWAY' FOR RENT
description: For more than a decade, New York City had been digging a hole in Manhattan called the Second Avenue subway, but by last month it had only two empty tunnels barely a mile long. With the project deferred indefinitely for lack of money, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced that the tunnels were for rent to any ''imaginative'' entrepreneur.

title: TOWARD NEW INTERNATIONAL STYLE
description: Is there an international style? It is half a century since Henry-Russell Hitchcock's and Philip Johnson's celebrated exhibition of modern architecture, ''The International Style,'' was thrust upon a slightly startled world at the Museum of Modern Art, and nearly as long since the phrase that they and Alfred Barr coined to de-scribe that sleek, austere style of European modernism became a part of our language. It now is a part of our vocabulary, certainly; regardless of what one thinks of glass-and-steel modernism, almost no one challenges the use of this phrase as a description.

title: CECIL B. DE MILLE'S 'MADAM SATAN'
description: In his review in The New York Times Oct. 6, 1930, Mordaunt Hall, then the film critic, wrote, ''Cecil B. De Mille's latest audible film, 'Madam Satan,' is a strange conglomeration of unreal incidents that are set forth with no little technical skill.''

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: A BARTHES READER, edited by Susan Sontag. (Hill & Wang, $20.) A selection of the late French philosopher's work. A BLOODSMOOR ROMANCE, by Joyce Carol Oates. (E.P. Dutton, $16.95.)

title: OREGON EASES BID ON RESIDENTS' WASHINGTON LOTTERY WINNINGS
description: Oregon officials are not pressing forward with a threat of legal action against state residents who win big when a state lottery begins in neighboring Washington in November.

title: THE VALUE OF RAPID PAYOFFS
description: THE latest wrinkle in home mortgages is a financing mechanism that g oes by several different names: GEM, for growing equity mortgage; r apid payoff mortgage; equity building loan, and RAM, for rapid a mortization mortgage.

title: A SMALL 'C' VICTORY
description: Most of the headlines and too many television reporters have been calling it a ''defeat for conservatism.'' In fact, the Senate's rejection of the Helms court-stripping bill on school prayer was a signal victory for traditional conservatism with a small ''C.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in last Sunday's paper incor- rectly identified a Vietnamese news- paper editor who was slain in Hous- ton.

title: REAGAN TIPTOES AROUND SOME ECONOMIC LIABILITIES
description: With the economy's stresses threatening to cause an earthquake for Republicans in November, just about every move President Reagan makes these days registers on a political seismograph at the White House.

title: Rich Treasure; Beyond Reach
description: First the good news. Scientists from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration last week reported finding an undersea treasure of strategic metals in an area 1,800 miles east of Miami.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
THE VACATION I NEVER WANTED
description: FOR the first time in eight years, I won't devote an autumn weekend to football. Something that I thought would happen for several months has happened. The National Football League Players Association has gone on strike. The strike is affecting approximately 1,500 players, and it affects each one differently. The strike has already altered my day-to-day routine in several ways.

title: RENAISSANCE IN HOBOKEN
description: Built in 1907, the Erie Lackawanna Terminal once served 100,000 railroad and ferry passengers a day. The ornate steel-and-concrete structure was considered, at the time of its opening, the finest waterfront passenger station in the world.

title: Mideast Politics; In Atomic Forum
description: In world politics, countries get their revenge where they can. In Vienna last week, Arab members of the International Atomic Energy Agency, with the backing of the Soviet bloc, tried but failed to get a two-thirds majority to expel Israel from the Agency.

title: A FAREWELL TO FRANCE
description: Richard Eder was, until recently, chief of the The New York Times's Paris bureau. By Richard Eder Once or twice a year, some 70 years ago, the authorities in the Breton town of Carnac would receive a neatly addressed envelope with a blank sheet of paper inside. It had been mailed the day before by a sorrowful little boy.

title: TROUBLE IN VINELAND
description: VINELAND THIS sprawling 69-square-mile city, where unemployment, as computed on a regional basis, is the highest in the state and the eighth highest in the nation, faces a crisis that its Mayor says could push it over the brink.

title: Silver Apricot
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD TO HOST 100 EXHIBITORS
description: THE country's largest exhibit and sale of Early American furniture and decorative objects will be held next Friday through Sunday at the 16th Annual Connecticut Antiques Show in Hartford.

title: Losing Winner
description: John Batt, a print shop proprietor from Demarest, N.J., won $50,000 in the New Jersey Lottery in May 1979. It was a case of winner take nothing.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Beans and Teas In Pleasantville

title: No Headline
description: Northwestern Finally Wins

title: Coffee Producers Set Export Limit in London
description: Coffee-producing nations, with the backing of consuming countries, agreed today to continue to limit the amount of coffee entering the world market.

title: BEGIN MUST GO
description: Menachem Begin may not resign tomorrow or next week, but he has lost the power to govern effectively. A Prime Minister of Israel can survive blunders at home, deep strains with the United States and disagreements within world Jewry. He cannot remain in office if he has squandered Israel's fundamental asset: its respect for itself and the respect of the world.

title: PAUL ROBESON
description: To the Editor:

title: Y BEGINS A CENTER ON FAMILY PROBLEMS
description: SCARSDALE ''THE community felt the need to have something all-encompassing,'' Bernard Kimberg was saying. ''Something they could start at one stage of their lives and progress through as a family.''

title: Natural Gas Leak in Mexico
description: Firefighters were working today to plug a natural gas leak feeding a four-day-old fire near an offshore oil rig in Campeche Bay, a Pemex oil company spokesman said. Workers began the plugging effort Friday by injecting sea water into the mouth of the well to stop the flow of water and gas.

title: Soviet Paper Says Poland Still Has Long Way to Go
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that Poland was still facing enormous economic, political and social problems and had a long way to go before it recovered from the upheavals of the last two years.

title: Offense Intended
description: Name-calling is almost as popular as name-dropping in Washngton, but when the epithets are racial, apologies usually follow. Not so last week for Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, who had called Housing and Urban Development Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. a ''Stepin Fetchit.'' The reference to a black comedian known for his diffident shuffle and ''yowsuh boss'' drawl came in a Gonzalez speech criticizing Mr. Pierce for carrying out Administration-ordered cutback. Mr. Pierce protested, but Mr. Gonzalez responded, ''I meant what I said and I said what I meant.''

title: OLDER WOMEN: GOLD - OR LEAD?
description: EVERYBODY is afraid of getting old. In our youth-worshiping culture, they have good cause. The older woman has more to fear than her male counterpart; the legacy of discrimination based on sex becomes a crushing burden as she enters her ''golden'' years, perhaps long before.

title: PIANIST: WILLIAM DEVAN
description: There was very little in William DeVan's playing at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night that wasn't well thought through. The young pianist, who studied with Ania Dorfmann at Juilliard, with Hans Leygraf in Germany, and with Jeaneane Dowis in New York, knew in every work he played where he was going and how he was going to get there.

title: LITTLE NEMO ON THE MOVE
description: BEFORE MICKEY The Animated Film 1898-1928. By Donald Crafton. Illustrated. 413 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $25.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Even for a folk-dance buff, the Bulgarian troupe that goes under the name of Pirin, is something special. When this amazing company made its New York debut three years ago, it shattered all expectations.

title: Amy Roberts Has Nuptials
description: Amy Louise Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Roberts of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Andrew Frawley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark W. Frawley Jr. of White Plains. The Rev. Dr. Peter Samson of the Community Unitarian Church at White Plains performed the garden ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: BEIRUT MASSACRE: 'TIME TO SPEAK WITH FORCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GOLD BUG BITES SMITHKLINE
description: They do not know why it works, but physicians have ample proof that gold can be effective in reducing the crippling, and eventually fatal, symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis. For 50 years, patients with advanced stages of rheumatoid arthritis have had the option of being injected with a liquefied gold compound.

title: Mourning, Anger And Moral Outrage
description: IN a world numbed by political brutality and terror, images of slaughtered Palestinian women and children brought gasps of horror last week, and profound consequences. Lamenting relatives and Red Cross workers in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps near Beirut covered their faces against the odor of death as they unearthed several hundred corpses and parts of bodies that had been bulldozed into hasty graves. The Palestinians were massacred last weekend by Christian militia men, rampaging after the bomb assassination of dozens of Christian Maronite leaders, including Bashir Gemayel, Lebanon's President-elect. In the scramble to disclaim responsibility, Israeli authorities at first denied, but later implicitly admitted, they had known about the killings for at least 24 hours without calling a halt. Israeli flares lighted the sky after the militia entered the camps through the Israeli lines.

title: THE HUDSON IS SHAPING UP AS THE RIVER OF BIG RETURN
description: In raw form, the data compiled last week by the state's Water Quality Surveillance Network are not overly impressive. But for many scientists and conservationists, the bare facts confirm reports that the Hudson River is getting cleaner.

title: N. ROCKLAND STOPS KINGSTON
description: North Rockland, the defending Rockland County Public Schools Athletic League champion, yesterday scored its second straight victory by defeating Kingston, 14-7.

title: Bridgewater East Is an Upset Victor
description: Bridgewater East upset Watchung Hills, 14-6, today in Warren behind the defensive play of Brian Resnick and Jeff Wertmuller's pair of fourth-quarter touchdowns.

title: OUT OF THE ASHES, A CITY CENTER WILL RISE
description: Seventeen years after fire destroyed its convention center, the city of Saratoga Springs is finally going to get a new one - and something more. Last week, city officials approved a $4 million city center that will be built adjacent to a new $9.5 million hotel.

title: Challengers in Newport Test
description: It was America's Cup weather, a sparkling September afternoon on the ocean off this coastal resort with a fresh breeze. And with nine 12-Meter yachts on the horizon Friday, it was evident that America's Cup fever had arrived a year early.

title: PARISIAN ARTISTRY
description: By Suzanne Slesin he traditional high ceilings, large windows, overhanging balcony and clear, light-filled space are typical of many Parisian ateliers des artistes - artists' studios. But, according to Virginia Zabriskie, a major dealer in Man Ray's works based in New York, his studio in Paris had a particular aura. The celebrated Dadaist artist and photographer occupied the apartment with his wife, Juliet, from 1950 until his death in 1976. ''It was what the French call a musee d'ambiance,'' said Mrs. Zabriskie, ''a space that creates a feeling of something special. Man Ray is not a single painting or object, but a total thing. In his studio, you are confronted not with paintings in racks, but everything that he made and put together himself. Somehow, you feel that he has just walked out the door.''

title: Justice Uncoils More Haitians
description: The Reagan Administration began last week to tie up the final loose ends of a badly tattered detention policy on Haitian refugees. Three months after a Federal District Court judge in Miami ordered the parole of 1,774 Haitians held in camps around the country and in Puerto Rico, the Justice Department announced that it would parole 49 Haitian refugees who have been confined to a former Navy prison in Brooklyn for 13 months.

title:
ANTIQUES;
NEWARK MUSEUM: RARE FURNITURE
description: NEWARK OPENING at the Newark Museum today is a show, ''Century of Revivals: 19th Century American Furniture,'' that takes one through America's diverse furniture styles from 1810 to 1900.

title: ALONG ENGLAND'S ANTIQUES CIRCUIT
description: based writer, has a family connection with the antiques trade. By DONALD GODDARD

title: 'MOONLIGHTING' OFFERED BY JERZY SKOLIMOWSKI
description: Working in a style that appears to have little connection with any of his earlier films, including the French-language ''Le Depart'' and the English-language ''The Shout,'' Jerzy Skolimowski, the Polish film maker who has been living in England for years, has made a new film of the sort of introspective intensity seldom achieved on the screen. Movies journey into men's minds at some peril.

title: Deborah Buganza Bride
description: Deborah Michele Buganza, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Giancarlo Buganza of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Jan William Scheck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Tucker Scheck of Melvin, N.H. The Rev. Joseph P. Nagle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs in Forest Hills, Queens. The bride's father is a gastroenterologist. Mr. Scheck's parents are retired high school teachers.

title: CENTER IS A LIFELINE FOR INJURED WILDLIFE
description: ANYONE who has found a wounded animal on a roadside is famliar with the feeling: panicky indecision at the sight of fluttering wings or twitching paws. Should the police be called, or a veterinarian, or an animal shelter? Who will rescue the creature and how?

title: CUOMO'S WIN SETS THE STAGE FOR A CLASSIC CLASSY DUEL
description: ONLY four or five days ago, some top-ranking Republican politicians were not only expecting Mayor Koch to be the Democratic nominee for governor, in private conversations they were hoping he would be.

title: SHEPLERS: WESTERN OUTFITS
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times. By RUTH ROBINSON

title: Inside Namibia
description: As an organization of exiled South African military resisters, we read Joseph Lelyveld's article with great interest. On the whole, it showed a grasp of the conflict in South-West Africa that is rarely seen in American newspaper articles. There is, however, one aspect of the article that we feel compelled to respond to: the racial and national composition of the South African armed forces stationed in Namibia. There are two parallel military organizations in Namibia, both fully under the control of the General Staff of the South African Defense Force. There are the actual military units that are South African. Composition of the South African units is over 97 percent white, forming the bulk of the occupation troops in Namibia. There is also the South-West African Territorial Force. The S.W.A.T.F., as it is known, was originally part of the South African Defense Force apparatus. In 1972, units of black Namibians were formed for the first time. In the last 10 years, increasing numbers of black Namibians have been pressed into service in the S.W.A.T.F.

title: BERIUT KILLINGS MAY LEAD TO BASIC MIDEAST CHANGES
description: In the violent and bewildering kaleidoscope of the Middle East, moments occasionally appear when the political pieces are so shaken that old patterns are irrevocably altered, paving the way for new and unpredictable trends. The Beirut massacre of Palestinian civilians, coming after the long and controversial Israeli seige of Beirut, may be one of these events.

title: Seeking With; Forked Tong
description: Dowsers say their practice, commonly viewed by others as a dubious way of finding water, actually has more uses than you can shake a stick at. More than 50 of them gathered in Danville, Vt. last week, with claims ranging from discovering oil and gas to preventing traffic accidents.

title: PERMISSION DENIED
description: To the Editor:

title: BEIRUT MASSACRE: THE FOUR DAYS
description: Today, The New York Times publishes a reconstruction of the massacre of more than 300 men, women and children in the Shatila refugee camp of West Beirut from Sept. 16 to 18, and of the events that led to the killings.

title: PALME'S VICTORY COULD MAKE 'MIDDLE WAY' JUST A MEMORY
description: On Sept. 13, just a week before the Swedish elections, a man called Marcus Wallenberg died at the age of 82. He had been the dominant figure in this country's commercial life, with interests in banks, hotels and industry, including Saab, the car manufacturer, SKF, the ball-bearing maker, Electrolux, Ericsson, the telecommunications giant, and Atlas Copco, the toolmaker.

title: MCKINNEY NOT WORRIED BY PHILLIPS' CAMPAIGN
description: ALONG the Connecticut Turnpike near Norwalk stands a billboard that says simply, in letters 10 feet tall, ''McKinney.'' About a mile down the highway is a toll plaza. And above several of the baskets for exact change, along with stickers for the Grateful Dead and N.R.B.Q. rock bands, are several saying, ''John Phillips - Congress.''

title: Jury Reform Called A Judicial Priority
description: We read with considerable interest L.B.Chase's impressions following his recent experience as a juror in Union County (Opinion Page, Aug. 8). Jury reform is a priority of the New Jersey Administrative Office of the Courts and of every judge, court administrator and jury manager in the state.

title: ROHMER ADDS TO HIS INTIMATE COMEDIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joan Dupont lives in Paris and is English-language editor of Le Film Fran,cais. By JOAN DUPONT JULLOUVILLE, France

title:
ART;
WORKS OF ART IN GLASS
description: NEW ROCHELLE A sometimes astonishingly beautiful exhibition of glassware will be open at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle until Nov. 12. Entitled ''Glass: Artist/Designer/Industry,'' the show focuses on works by four artists.

title: Sad Precedent; for G.O.P.
description: According to form, the party in control of the White House loses Congressional seats in midterm elections, and in bad economic times the loss can be severe. Last week, a New York Times/CBS News Poll suggested how bad things could be.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LANDSCAPE RENOVATION
description: WITH home construction virtually at a standstill, publications that serve the landscape trades report little landscaping activity for new houses. Even so, planting has held steady and even increased because of a rise in interest in replanting or renovating gardens surrounding dwellings that are 20 years old or older.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Stimulating Clear Thinking

title: 4 Americans See No Sign Of Missing G.I.'s in Laos
description: Four Americans looking for traces of missing United States servicemen in Laos searched today through a cave used to hold prisoners of war during the Vietnam War. No sign of missing Americans was found.

title: Around the Nation; Man Arrested on Coast In Airline Bomb Plot
description: An unemployed man was arrested early today and charged with trying to extort $400,000 from American Airlines by planting a large time bomb in its terminal at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: THE PLAYERS MOVE INTO AN EARLY LEAD
description: Here is a first-period score from the National Football League: Players 1, Owners 0. By daring to go on strike, the players have broken the roles laid upon them by fans, by the massive commercial power of the N.F.L., by much of the press and by football tradition.

title: MONEY STILL BUYS AUDIO VALUE
description: If Adam Smith or Milton Friedman wanted a striking illustration of the beneficial workings of a free market, they could hardly pick a better example than the audio industry. No trusts, conglomerates, cartels or gentlemen's agreements have ever softened the edge of competition in this field, and the result has been an astounding relation between price and value.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
F.Y.I., IT'S P.D.Q.
description: ''The Intimate P.D.Q. Bach,'' which makes a mockery of serious music to the delight of even its most stodgy devotees, will be presented Friday at 8 P.M. at the John Harms Englewood Plaza for the Performing Arts in Englewood.

title: TREATIES THE SENATE CAN TAKE OR LEAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: YANK'S 6-2 VICTORY ELIMINATES RED SOX
description: Two Yankees whose status for next year is undetermined hit home runs today in helping their team defeat the Red Sox, 6-2, and eliminate Boston from the American League Eastern Division race.

title: APPLES HAVE THEIR DAY
description: APPLE DAY, an annual harvest festival at Terhune Orchards, will be held Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: WHAT'S RIGHT WITH NEW JERSEY
description: IN PREPARING an article on what is wrong with New Jersey, I reflected on the recent upset among the residents of Newark over the advertising slogan:

title: J.D. McMahon to Wed Elizabeth Kirby; Peter Sanderson Fiance of Susan Kirby
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. James C. Kirby of Rumson, N.J., of the engagements of their daughters, Elizabeth Ann Kirby and Susan Sherman Kirby, to James David McMahon and Peter Barber Sanderson, respectively.

title: British Unions Meet Briefly on The Barricades
description: With unemployment hitting 14 percent, Britain's unions are mighty angry but their might isn't what it once was. Millions of workers, defying new penalties for secondary strikes, staged walkouts that ranged from one hour to all day in support of pay demands by 600,000 nurses and other Government health workers.

title: THE WORLD OF VIDEO
description: Television, which started the electronic revolution in the American home, isn't quite the cornfed na-tive development some think it is - but, then again, it isn't as Japanese as others think it is. Electronic television itself is the product of largely independent inventions and developments by scientists in Germany, the Soviet Union, Great Britain, France and the United States.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE / PART 2
description: SEPTEMBER 26, 1982 17 INTERNATIONAL LIVING

title: NEW DISKS AND REISSUES FOCUS THE EAR ON VOCAL BEAUTY
description: Vocal recitals on records usually come in two kinds. In one, the singer attacks a particular body of music. In the other, what matters is the voice itself. The material may leap in century and in style with minimal coherence, but it is the beauty of the sound and technique of the singer that draws our attention.

title: WASHINGTON SEEKS ITS SPOT IN THE SUN
description: SEATTLE THE University of Washington Huskies have been ranked No.1 for the last two weeks in The Associated Press college football poll, yet they know they still have some convincing to do.

title: GOOD GUYS, BAD GUYS
description: CLOAK OF DARKNESS By Helen MacInnes. 342 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95.

title: DEMOCRATS SEE UPHILL STATE SENATE BATTLE
description: WHITE PLAINS BECAUSE success can be a hard thing to argue with, the three Democratic candidates in the 35th, 36th and 37th State Senate Districts concede they may be in for a tough campaign. They are trying to unseat three of the county's most influential Republican Senators.

title: It's Getting to Be a Tradition
description: Such is the influence of William V. Musto that when he was removed as Mayor of Union City, N.J., earlier this year and sentenced to seven years in prison on Federal racketeering charges, he picked Robert C. Botti as his successor and the City Commission went along.

title: IT THE PLAY IS BAD, THE REVIEW IS HARD WORK
description: I know I am never, never, never going to convince anyone that reviewers, as a breed, aren't a malicious lot whose primary occupation and principal delight is the shredding to pieces of bad plays. But I am, for the 65th time, going to give it a try - in spite of the fact that bad plays do indeed abound.

title: Carole Austin Hackes Is Bride of John G. Duckett
description: Carole Austin Hackes, daughter of Peter S. Hackes and Mary Ellen Propper Hackes, of Washington, was married in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul) yesterday to John Gerard Duckett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Duckett of Pittsburgh.

title: POLITICAL FOES JOIN HANDS AT STEUBEN DAY PARADE
description: Lewis E. Lehrman beamed at Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo held Mr. Lehrman's young son's hand. Mayor Koch shook hands with Mr. Cuomo. Alfred B. DelBello and Mr. Lehrman clasped hands above their heads in a victory salute. It all happened at the annual Steuben Day Parade, a time when New York politicians forget campaign clashes and German-Americans celebrate their heritage.

title: U.S. PLANS TO FREE CITIES IN SPENDING COMMUNITY GRANTS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development says it will no longer review the way cities use money from a major Federal grant program to see if they are assisting families with low or moderate incomes.

title: Around the Nation; Intruder Kills a Boy, 11, Defending His Mother
description: An 11-year-old boy who tried to save his mother from an apparent sexual attack was stabbed to death in a struggle at their home early today.

title: ODYSSEUS AT FENWAY
description: Game then runs down, stops, dies, thanks to Luis Tiant, Bost. pitcher. Tiant, noted for odd pitching mannerisms, is also a famed mound dawdler. Stands on hill like sunstruck archeologist at Knossos. Regards ruins. Studies sun. Studies landscape. Looks at artifact in hand. Wonders: Keep this potsherd or throw it away? Does Smithsonian want it? Hmm. Prepares to throw it away. Pauses. Sudd. discovers writing on object. Hmm. Possible Linear B inscript.? Sighs. Decides. Throws.'' -ROGER ANGELL, ''Five Seasons: A Baseball Companion'' (1977).

title: STRANGE TIMES FOR COAL
description: These are strange times in the coal mines. Compared to a year ago, when the 72-day strike by the United Mine Workers virtually wiped out output in the second quarter, production is up, and is likely to exceed 1981 year-end levels, suggesting that demand remains strong.
