Yet analysts and industry officials alike say conditions are in fact quite weak, and could remain that way for another year or more.

title: INSIDE NAMIBIA
description: I'm sure readers were struck by the photograph of the white settlers disporting themselves in white robes with pointed hoods (''Inside Namibia,'' by Joseph Lelyveld, Aug. 1). I didn't find it terribly reassuring to be told that they were only ''ethnic Germans celebrating the traditional carnival of Wika.'' C. CLARK KISSINGER Washington

title: Frankfurter And Brandeis
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Smith Benson Wed
description: Amy Smith Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Benson of Woodbury, Conn., was married yesterday to William Maas Cutting Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cutting of Sun City Center, Fla. The Rev. Bernard Harrington, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Jeffrey Middleton, a Baptist minister, officiated at the ceremony in the Westover School Chapel in Middlebury, Conn. College after studying at Trinity College in Hartford during her

title: No Headline
description: U.S.C. Shuts Out Sooners

title: GUNMAN KILLS 13 IN A PENNSYLVANIA RAMPAGE
description: BARRE, Pa., Sept. 25 -A state prison guard killed 13 people, including seven children, in a rampage through two houses early today, the police said. A 14th victim was critically wounded.

title: A GENTLE NAIF FROM ALABAMA
description: Bill Traylor (1854-1947) was no Douanier Rousseau, for his pictures are not fantasies but unvarnished memories. He worked, moreover, not in oil but in pencil, crayon and tempera, and the ground was as likely to be an old piece of cardboard stained with tobacco spittle as a fresh piece of paper. And, while an untutored late starter, Traylor differs from most other naifs for exhibiting neither a religious vision nor signs of infantile regression. Nevertheless, his work increasingly arousing interest among collectors of naif art and the 32 examples now on view through Oct. 9 at Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery, 24 East 81st Street, though apparently a tiny percentage of his total output, are enough to show why.

title: FRANCE MOVES TO AVOID THIRD DEVALUATION OF FRANC
description: France's Socialist Government plans to introduce new and even stricter controls over the movement of money into and out of the country to prevent a third devaluation of the franc, French officials said today.

title: BOYD AND ROBERTS LEAD HEMPSTEAD PAST CALHOUN, 30-6
description: Kenny Boyd scored two touchdowns, and Michael Roberts ran for 193 yards and scored once as Hempstead defeated Calhoun, 30-6, yesterday in an American League Conference II-A season opener. Hempstead was last season's Conference III-A champion.

title: Chinese Give Festive Farewell To North Korean After Visit
description: China gave Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, a festive sendoff today as he left by special train after a visit in which he and Chinese leaders proclaimed lasting friendship and identical world views.

title:
INVESTING;
MARKET TALK: NO CORRECTION IN SIGHT
description: WHENEVER there's a sudden buying rampage in stocks there is likely t o be a sizable correction. It happened in 1962, 1966, 1970, 1974 and1 980, and the subsequent declines chopped off an average of 65 p ercent of the new gains each time. But the 1982 rally may be d ifferent, according to seven respected market timers and portfolio s trategists interviewed last week. They said that any market c orrection, if there was one, would be mild by comparison. In fact, t heir optimism was such that they were telling their institutional i nvestors and retail customers that a classic bull market of p rolonged duration had already begun.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN FRANKFURT
description: ANNA TOMFORDE is a writer who lives in Bonn. By ANNA TOMFORDE

title: Pension Upheaval
description: To the Business Editor The article by Deborah Rankin on ''The Upheaval in Pension Fund Planning'' (Sept. 12) reflects a number of misunderstandings about the function and purpose of corporations for ''professionals.'' The writer overstates it when she says that the new tax law ''has all but written the obituary of the professional corporation.''

title: CUOMO PASSES KOCH ON THE OUTSIDE AND FACES LEHRMAN FOR GOVERNOR
description: NEW YORKERS will still have Mayor Koch to kid around. Less than a year after he won a second term at City Hall, Mr. Koch could not persuade voters to give him a big sendoff, and in a primary that had politicians and pollsters scurrying to justify their assumptions, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last week defeated him for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination by a 53 to 47 margin.

title: Paige Callen, T.L. James Have Bridal
description: Paige Palmer Callen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Holmes Callen Jr., of Rumson, N.J., was married here yesterday to Thomas Lipscomb James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allan James of Meadville, Pa. The Rev. George J. Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church.

title: VAN BUREN'S HOUSE TO OPEN IN OBSERVANCE OF BIRTH
description: The partially restored home of Martin Van Buren, the eighth President of the United States, will be open to the public next week as part of an observance of the bicentennial of his birth.

title: INNS AND OUTINGS IN SWITZERLAND
description: SUZANNE READE is a writer who lives in Westport, Conn. BY SUZANNE READE

title:
INTERNATIONAL LIVING;
A JAPANESE HOUSE FOR ALL SEASONS
description: Peach Garden Cave is the name of the house, and it is situated in the eastern hills overlooking Kyoto, the cultural center and one-time capital of Japan. Although the house is only minutes from downtown, it is light years away from the bustle of modern Japan.

title: 43 TEAMS COMPETE IN SOFTBALL FINALS
description: MOUNT VERNON TEAMS from 43 communities in Westchester - from as far north as Lewisboro and as far west as Irvington - came to Mount Vernon last week hoping to win the county's 28th yearly slow-pitch softball championship. But when the two-day tournament came to an end, the winner was a team that didn't have to travel at all.

title: Dutch Arrest the Supervisor Of a World War II Work Camp
description: A 63-year-old Dutchman who was a supervisor at a German work camp in World War II has been arrested here and charged with crimes against humanity, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Author Fumbled
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Why the Football Union Can Hit Hard,'' (Sept.19), Barbara R. Bergmann indulged in a transparent piece of sophistry. She asked whether football fans came to see the players or management. The obvious answer becomes the rationale for her argument that the players do in fact deserve a major part of the gate.

title: EX-NIKE BASE BECOMING AN ARTS PARK
description: LIVINGSTON IT'S a chill wind that whips over Riker Hill on these early autumn days, blowing unhampered around the beige cinderblock buildings of the old Army Nike missile base.

title: THE AMERICAN LEFT STILL SEARCHES FOR A CLEAR POLITICAL DIRECTION
description: IS there a future for left-wing politics in this country? The old leftist parties of the first half of the century seem moribund, and the 1960's, for all their tumult, did not give birth to new ones. Among leftists now there is a growing debate about what to do. It is a debate confused by the decline of the liberal wings of the two major parties to which leftists in the past have looked for support.

title: Robert Lawrence Weds Sarah Mott
description: Sarah Geraldine Mott, daughter of Rear Adm. William C. Mott, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Mott of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Robert Francis Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Lawrence of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. John Howenstein performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: SEWAGE AIDE TELLS OF E.P.A. MEETING
description: REPRESENTATIVES of New Jersey sewerage authorities were encouraged by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to apply for exemption from standard treatment for ocean-bound sewage, one of the authority officials said last week.

title: PITT OVERCOMES ILLINOIS BY 20-3
description: The highly publicized passing duel between Dan Marino of Pittsburgh and Tony Eason of Illinois did not materialize today because of extenuating circumstances. In its 20-3 victory, Pitt disappointed both Illinois and fans of the passing game.

title: Opinion; BLOCK GRANTS TERMED DISGUISE FOR CUTBACKS
description: The Assembly Standing Committee on Mental Health and the Assembly Standing Committee on Ways and Means held a public hearing last month in New York City on the impact on mental-health services of the Reagan Administration's use of block grants to disburse funds. The following was testimony given by Dr. Jack C. Schoenholtz, medical director of the Rye Psychiatric Hospital Center and a resident of Mamaroneck. By JACK C. SCHOENHOLTZ

title: FLUTIE'S PASSING DEFEATS NAVY
description: He has the innocence of a choir boy in his eyes, but look out when he has a football in his hands. His name is Doug Flutie and he is the quarterback for Boston College. Because of him, the Eagles will be competitive in every game they play this season, including the one against Penn State Oct. 30.

title: Previews and the Like
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Always a First Time Sept. 29 - The American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research, established in 1980 - new as charities go - has its first benefit ever from 6 to 9 P.M. at Sotheby's New York Galleries, 72d Street and York Avenue. Isabel Hammond, director of the foundation that numbers among its objectives the active exchange of information between American and Italian researchers, calls it ''a coming out party.'' The benefit consists of a preview of an exhibition of European paintings and works of art selected by Mostra Mercato Internazionale Dell' Antiquariato (International Antiques Dealers Show, which is held biannually in Florence), plus cocktails and an auction of exotica with an Italian theme. For example, a week's Mediterranean cruise on a private yacht. Regular tickets, $50. Patron tickets, $150, entitle bearers also to dinner at Club A with Maurizio and Patrizia Gucci.

title: FOCUSING ON HEARTS
description: The world championships due to begin at the end of this week in Biarritz, France, are sure to set a number of records. The team championship will be contested by 130 teams, more than double the number that competed when the event was introduced four years ago. Entries in the pair events have almost doubled, with 360 pairs in the Open series and 140 in the Women's series.

title: MOTHERS AND DAUGHTERS
description: GRACE ABOUNDING By Maureen Howard. 175 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $13.95.

title: Catholic Group Provokes Debate on Homosexuals
description: A proposal by a group of priests, nuns and lay leaders to open Roman Catholic Church doors to practicing homosexuals has ignited renewed debate of the Church's longstanding disapproval of homosexual behavior.

title: STUDENT AID PROGRAMS BESET BY UNCERTAINTY
description: TRENTON ''IT PEELS like an onion - it gets worse and worse.'' So said an official of the state's Department of Higher Education in assessing the Reagan Administration's handling of financial aid for postsecondary education in the 1982-83 school year.

title: SPECIAL ZONE RULES CHANGING
description: A year ago, when the Gruzen Partnership was designing Dag Hammarskjold Tower, a condominium on Second Avenue and 47th Street, the architects made room for a subway entrance, gave the Transit Authority an easement on the property and then sealed the whole area with concrete.

title: SWAN AND METS BEAT CARLTON
description: Like the wine he ages in the cellar of his Missouri home, Steve Carlton seems to improve with the years. But even his collection occasionally produces a bottle that has gone sour and even a threetime Cy Young Award winner can have a bad day.

title: EVEN ALUMINUM WINDOW UNITS NEED SOME CAREFUL ATTENTION
description: TRACK aluminum storm-and-screen window units and aluminum combination storm-and-screen doors require much less maintenance than the separate wood storm sashes and screens that are still found on some older homes. Aluminum screens and storm windows don't have to be painted, and the aluminum won't rot or work loose in the joints the way wood-frame windows and doors will.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: KEEPING THE BEST
description: OVER a dinner of seafood and veal stuffed with mushrooms, washed down with two types of wine, brandy and jokes about ''bleak moments when we thought it would all never happen,'' 60 members and guests of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation toasted the opening of a 20-panel photographic exhibit at the Old State House in Hartford recently.

title: Toms River Is Paced By Harvey
description: Sheldon Harvey threw four touchdown passes to pace Toms River South to a 28-3 victory over Southern Regional yesterday in Manahawkin. Southern Regional took a 3-0 lead on Dawn Cleeland's 26-yard field goal in the first period, but Toms River South came back in the next period to move ahead, 14-3. Harvey hit Dwayne King with a 13-yard scoring pass and then connected with Ernie Williams for a 42-yard touchdown. John Forrester added two of his four extra-point kicks.

title: Letters; Defiant Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: D.F Hogan 3d Married Holly Blanchard
description: Holly Blanchard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Blanchard of Bedford, N.Y., was married at the Bedford Presbyterian Church yesterday to Daniel Francis Hogan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hogan Jr. of Massapequa, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Hughart, assisted by the Rev. Terence Quinn, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: No Headline
description: Connecticut Passes Upset Yale by 17-7

title: ARISTOTLE'S WAY TO LOOK
description: THE IMAGE AND THE EYE Further Studies in the Psychology of Pictorial Representation. By E. H. Gombrich. Illustrated. 320 pp. Ithaca, N. Y.: Cornell University Press. $38.50.

title: EXHIBITION TRACES ROLE OF BLACKS IN AVIATION
description: The history of blacks in aviation, not documented in most history books, includes a bit of the romance of early aerial combat and a great deal of the struggle over segregation.

title: NORTHPORT TRIUMPHS BY 30-7
description: Alan Squeri completed 18 of 28 passes for 300 yards and four touchdowns as Northport defeated Half Hollow Hills West, 30-7, in a nonleague Suffolk opener. Sarko Yepremian, whose uncle Garo starred for the Miami Dolphins, kicked four extra points.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN hundreds of polling places on the Island last week, some familiar sounds were in the air -the swish of voting booth curtains closing, the click of ballot machine levers being pulled. It was Primary Day, but not in the 34th Election District, an electoral noman's land in Plainedge. There are no polling places in the 34th. It contains a golf driving range, a firehouse, a gas station, a lumber yard, a bank and a used-car lot, but no homes or registered voters.

title: COMPOSER MAKES DEBUT AS NEW DEAN
description: WHEN Alvin Brehm, the new dean of music at the State University of New York at Purchase, was in the third grade, his teacher asked the class about their future careers.

title: LEFTIST REBELS IN EL SALVADOR SAID TO EXPAND AREA OF WAR
description: Salvadoran rebels are taking their guerrilla war into previously quiet parts of the country, according to American and Salvadoran military analysts.

title: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN FASHIONS A COMPELLING, AUSTERE MESSAGE
description: Rock and roll at its best has always been something more than entertainment; it has been a way of looking at the world. The ostensible subjects of most early rock and roll songs were girls, cars and fun, fun, fun, but the very sound and rhythm of the music and the attitudes implicit in the lyrics conveyed a sense of freedom, an opening up of possibilities (particularly possibilities for the young) that ran against the grain of the generally conservative 1950's and anticipated the social upheavals of the next decade.

title: DELAY IN PUBLIC HOUSING RENT RISES IS BACKED
description: An amendment to the 1983 appropriations bill for the Department of Housing and Urban Development that would prevent rent increases for tenants in public housing for three months has been approved by the Senate.

title: ROBERT E. DENNARD
description: Robert E. Dennard, an investment concern president who served on the boards of more than 20 corporations, died of cancer Friday at his suburban Dallas home.

title: Hope Springs Eternal; Water Proof
description: The ancient craft of dowsing, or water divining, is on the upswing. Some 2,700 people now belong to the American Society of Dowsers, which last week held its annual meeting in Danville, Vt.

title: WOMEN'S PAPER IS UNDER WAY
description: THAT'S not the mighty roar of the presses you hear on the other end of the line when you call Westchester Women's News, the newest addition to county journalism. More likely than not, it's Merna Popper's dishwasher.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
COLLEGE FOOTBALL ON TV: WHO SHOULD CONTROL?
description: FOOTBALL has been the showcase of college sports for the better part of this century. The sport has been popular at the gate and on television, thereby generating constantly increasing revenues, which in large part have supported the majority of all other intercollegiate sports. For the vast majority of National Collegiate Athletic Association members, this success has been made possible by football television controls that the members have imposed upon themselves during the last 30 years. That success and the continuation of football as a college activity engaged in by students is threatened by the recent decision of the United States District Court in University of Oklahoma and University of Georgia v. N.C.A.A..

title: JERSEY SETTLES A LAWSUIT OVER JAIL OVERCROWDING
description: State corrections officials have settled a lawsuit by agreeing to find new housing for 300 state prisoners held at the Essex County Jail and to limit new admissions there.

title: Ann Louise Allen Married to Gerald Lee Amon Jr.
description: Anne Louise Allen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Allen of Whispering Pines, N.C., was married yesterday to Gerald Lee Amon Jr., son of Mrs. Gerald Lee Amon of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mr. Amon. Capt. Henry C. Duncan, Chaplains Corps, U.S.N., retired, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the nondenominational Village Chapel in Pinehurst, N.C.

title: LETTING GO
description: I agree with Marguerite Kelly that parents should give children a sense of personal responsibility, but calling the weather ''to find out if he needs a jacket''? Come on now. Isn't a first grader allowed to talk to his parents? Can't he say, along with the rest of us, ''It looks cold. Have you heard the temperature this morning?'' To require that a child dial a recording in lieu of engaging in a little oldfashioned conversation is like telling him to dial a joke when he's feeling depressed. MARGO BARTLETT Delaware, Ohio

title: THE 'ERASED' LABOR LEADER
description: CREIGHTON MILLER has always laughed about it, about having been ''erased'' from an official Cleveland Browns team photo on Coach Paul Brown's orders, as if he were Stalin in disgrace. But the 59-year-old Cleveland attorney, whose unforgiveable crime was organizing the National Football League Players Association in 1956, is not laughing about the current strike. He believes the strike could have been avoided if Ed Garvey, his successor, had negotiated more realistically.

title: Miss Welch Wed To R. F. Taugner
description: Sarah Kimberly Welch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Harold Welch Jr. of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday in New Haven to Robert Frank Taugner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Taugner of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church on the Green.

title: A STYLE FOR DEATH
description: I sometimes wonder how much the act of writing means to the novelist and how it connects him to his life, or perhaps to his death. I was given one kind of answer to this question when a close friend of mine, a writer named Paul Breslow, died of cancer in August. He spent his last three or four months trying to finish a novel, and in talking to him about his book, his life and his death, I learned quite a lot about how they fitted together.

title: JoAnn A. Prelich Becomes a Bride
description: JoAnn Alecia Prelich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Prelich of Garfield, N.J., was married last evening to Roger Halloran Goodspeed, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Goodspeed of Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. James Borstelmann performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title:
ART;
EXPLORING WHITMAN'S 'EXPRESSION OF AN AGE'
description: HUNTINGTON WALT Whitman may have been a Long Island native son who celebrated the ''isle of salty shore and breeze and brine'' in poetry and prose, but his vision was broader, and, in time, he came to epitomize late 19th-century America as a whole.

title: UNFLAGGING ZEAL IN MINORITIES' CAUSE
description: WHAT'S new with Charles T. Williams of East Hills is that he is a freshly elected director of the Schenley Affiliated Brands Corporation, the selling arm of Schenley Industries.

title: Asbestos Memoirs
description: To the Business Editor: Representative George Miller, in ''Don't Let Industry Shirk Its Duty'' (Sept. 5), and other writers, have talked about the ''asbestos industry'' as if the more than 200 companies involved in asbestos litigation were one and the same - equally involved, equally negligent and equally responsible. This simply is not true.

title: THE UNIVERSAL LANGUAGE
description: By Hans Fantel Like music itself, audio is international in its nature and scope. Broadcasting and recording provide, as it were, a worldwide stage. The singers of La Scala may be heard any day in the Bahamas, and the Vienna Philharmonic is as familiar to New Yorkers as is their own orchestra. No musical idiom remains regional when the magic carpet of electronics carries it around the world at the speed of light. This is why the rise of audio in our times is perhaps the most important turning point in the history of music since Guido d'Arezzo invented musical notation a thousand years ago.

title: Touro Synagogue
description: To the Editor: Vacationers in Newport, R.I., might like to know that when George Washington wrote the memorable words, ''To bigotry no sanction, to persecution no assistance,'' that appear on the commemorative stamp for Newport's Touro Synagogue, he was only repeating the words that had been written to him by Moses Seixas, warden of the Newport Jewish Congregation on Aug. 17, 1790:$''...Deprived as we have hitherto been of the invaluable rights of free citizens, we now (with a deep sense of gratitude to the Almighty Disposer of all events) behold a Government (created by the Majesty of the People), a Government which to bigotry gives no sanction, to persecution no assistance - but generously affording to All liberty of conscience, and immunities of citizenship - deeming every one, of whatever nation, tongue or language equal parts of the great government machine....''

title: HIJACKER OF PLANE IS SEIZED IN SICILY
description: A hijacker seized an Alitalia Airlines jet carrying 109 people on a flight from Algiers to Rome today and forced it to land in Sicily where he was captured by the police, an airline official reported.

title: GRANDEUR IN ENGLAND
description: Castle Howard's distinctive dome became familiar as Brideshead to the millions who watched the popular Grenada Television serialization of Evelyn Waugh's ''Brideshead Revisited,'' but, under its real name, this grand estate in Yorkshire is the family home of George Howard. Although part of the house is now open to visitors, the private quarters still house the family.

title: WHY A $4 MILLION MUSICAL LASTED ONLY FOUR DAYS
description: Like too many theater stories, it was a story of expectation and failure, hope and disappointment. What made yesterday's closing of ''A Doll's Life'' different, however, was not simply the fact that the season's first major musical had run for only five performances and cost its producers $4 million, but that the show involved three of Broadway's most gifted and successful artists: the innovative director and producer Harold Prince, and the celebrated libretto team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green. Indeed the show's untimely demise underlined the sad axiom that even enormous talent, hard work and passionate commitment are not always enough to guarantee success.

title: IMPACT OF THE PRO FOOTBALL STRIKE: A LOST SUNDAY AND LOST DOLLARS
description: The 12 stadiums where games had been scheduled were deserted, 15,000 people were out of work, restaurant and hotel business plummeted, 800,000 fans stayed home, television stations ran re-runs or showed Canadian football, and losses mounted to more than $70 million yesterday on the first weekend of the National Football League players' strike.

title: Market Place Robert Metz The Outlook For Auto Parts
description: AS the American car fleet ages, fortunes of companies offering replacement parts usually improve. Automobiles are older now than at any time since 1950, but parts makers have not done as well as some analysts had expected.

title: BRIEFING
description: A.B.A. Grants Rejected

title: The Editorial Notebook; Don't Write Off East New York
description: The Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York doesn't look like much anymore. Once a stable community of starter homes and substantial businesses like a Piels Brewery and more modest enterprises, the neighborhood suffered a precipitous decline beginning in the 1960's. Though the area still has a few meticulously maintained streets, it is mostly vast stretches of ravaged blocks.

title: LETTER TO SHARON; Yom Kippur, 5743
description: Dear Arik: You know that I have been one of your strongest supporters in the American press. Let me put some hard-gained experience on Watergate's burning deck at your disposal in examining what I imagine to be your reasons for resisting demands that you resign.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. The Pirates' Willie Stargell, who is retiring after this season, will play his final Shea Stadium series.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With two outs, the bases loaded and a full count on the batter, the runner at third attempts to steal home just as the pitcher throws the ball. If the pitch is ball four, does the runner automatically score or can he be called out for stealing?

title: EX-ARTIST, AT 100, RECALLS ROLE IN SUFFRAGE BATTLES
description: A petitioner and a 27-year-old painter crossed paths here in 1909, setting the young artist off on a campaign to win for women the right to vote.

title: New Roles for Bendix and Agee
description: What began as an all-out assault ended as a negotiated surrender for the Bendix Corporation and its chairman, William M. Agee. Unsuccessful in its attempt to take over the Martin Marietta Corporation, Bendix is to become a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation and Mr. Agee an employee.

title: Wienerwald Filing
description: The 135 West German operating companies of the Swiss-based Wienerwald Holding A.G. have filed bankruptcy petitions in the last few days, a Wienerwald G.m.b.H. spokesman said. Wienerwald Holding said last month that it had requested reorganization proceedings for Wienerwald G.m.b.H., the West German subsidiary. It added that it had sought similar proceedings for its Luxembourg financing subsidiary, Gastrofinanz, and for the Munich-based Vierlande Gastronomie-Handels G.m.b.H.

title: SADLOWSKI SERVES HIS UNION IN QUIET
description: A man walked along the Boardwalk one day this week in a slow, almost haughty manner. He had a defiant, solemn expression on his face. He seemed alone in the Boardwalk crowd.

title: G.E. Fills its Top International Post
description: The General Electric Company has named John A. Urquhart to be its top international executive, replacing Robert E. Frederick, who earlier this month was elected president and chief operating officer of the RCA Corporation.

title: 320 Ethiopians Killed In Battle, Somalia Says
description: Somalia said over the weekend that 320 Ethiopian troops were killed and 200 others were wounded in three days of fighting last week.

title: VW'S STRATEGY OF EXPANDING IN AMERICA IS HURTING BY SLUMP
description: Slumping auto sales in the United States are causing Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, to pull back sharply on its North American plans, delaying indefinitely the start of production at two new plants in the United States and Canada.

title: POLAR BEAR IN THE CENTRAL PARK ZOO KILLS MAN WHO CLIMBED INTO CAGE
description: A man the authorities described as homeless and irrational was found dead yesterday morning inside the polar bear cage at the Central Park Zoo. He apparently scaled a series of fences to get inside the cage and was killed by the animal, the police said.

title: HUSSEIN AND HABIB HOLD TALKS ON LEBANESE CRISIS
description: King Hussein discussed the crisis in Lebanon with Philip C. Habib for two hours today after the special American envoy arrived from Tel Aviv, Jordanian officials said.

title: Zimbabwe Eases Curbs In Area of Kidnapping
description: The Government today eased restrictions on the movement of vehicles in western Zimbabwe's Matabeleland Province, where the police and army troops are searching for army deserters suspected in the kidnapping of six foreign tourists, including two Americans.

title: Padres 3, Braves 2
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Joe Pittman singled home the tie-breaking run with one out in the ninth inning as San Diego won with the help of a crucial and controversial four-base error.

title: 'SILENT SPRING,' 20 YEARS A MILESTONE
description: Twenty years ago today a Boston publisher issued a book by a Maryland biologist that was to become one of the most influential books in the history of modern publishing. The book was Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' whose warning about the environmental dangers posed by indiscriminate use of pesticides is widely credited with having begun the modern environmental movement.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: An Appraisal
description: It is now just over a decade since the management of the Plaza Hotel decided to replace the Edwardian Room, the hotel's grand dining room on Central Park South, with a restaurant called the Green Tulip. And it is just over eight years since that same management realized that the whole thing was a terrible mistake and put the Edwardian Room back where it belonged. The Green Tulip looked like a restaurant in a suburban shopping mall that specializes in quiches.

title: VIDEO GAME MAKER AIDS MOHAWK VALLEY UPSWING
description: The new animal kingdom of electronic creatures that is beeping out of the realm of fantasy into the living rooms of America is also reviving the stagnant economy of the Mohawk Valley.

title:
NUCLEAR WASTE UPSTATE;
New York Federal court has ruled that the transportation by truck of ''spent fuel and other large-quantity radioactive materials'' through New York City and other densely populated urban areas is unsafe for citizens. The result? Anxiety in rural New York State, where the ruling doesn't apply.
description: In February, Judge Abraham D. Sofaer of the District Court in Manhattan in a crucial decision overturned a Federal Department of Transportation rule that would have allowed trucks to carry large amounts of waste through the city. He concluded that there had been insufficient testing carried out on the steel-and-lead shipping casks, that the routes the trucks travel were arbitrary and that serious accidents were inevitable.

title: Chicago's Kobs & Brady Arriving in New York
description: The crowd from Kobs & Brady Advertising, direct marketing specialists in Chicago, will be opening up their New York office at 1515 Broadway on Friday with about $6 million in new business.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Beats Connors

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Action Tungsram Inc., East Brunswick, N.J., named Alan J. Rubinfeld a senior vice president.

title: OPERA: PATANE LEADS 'LA GIOCONDA'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of Ponchielli's ''La Gioconda'' on Saturday night was only partly generous to this most generous of Italian operas. Beni Montresor's sets retained their massive, gloomy, if slightly seedy, splendor, but the menace that these backdrops promised visually never really materialized on stage.

title: AHMED HUSSEIN
description: Ahmed Hussein, a leader and elder statesman of Egypt's Socialist opposition party, died early today, the Government news agency reported. Mr. Hussein, who was 71 years old, had been completely paralyzed since 1969. He was hospitalized last week with heart problems.

title: DR. MAX HELFAND
description: Dr. Max Helfand, who had been a professor of neuropsychiatry at New York Medical College and an emeritus professor in that field at Metropolitan Hospital, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Retarded Woman Has an Abortion
description: A severely retarded 25-year-old Brooklyn woman successfully underwent an abortion yesterday after a State Supreme Court justice accepted her parents' consent on Thursday as a substitute for her consent.

title: SCOT WINS U.S. MUSIC COMPETITION
description: year-old Scottish baritone living in London, won the 1982 International American Music Competition on Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Herford is the first person from outside the United States to win the event in its five year history.

title: Commodities; At Last, Options On Futures
description: AFTER wandering for more than four decades in an often bizarre legal and regulatory wilderness, the commodity industry will finally - this Friday - get to open markets in options based on futures. A three-year pilot program has been approved by Government regulators.

title: Tabasco Captures Governor's Cup
description: In the largest New York Harbor race ever, with 175 boats from the five boroughs, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut, Tabasco won the grand prix fleet in the ninth annual Governor's Cup Race Saturday.

title: GOVERNING PARTY IN BONN REBOUNDS IN KEY STATE VOTE
description: In a striking reversal for the new alliance that hopes to govern West Germany, voters in Hesse state today denied the Christian Democrats a majority, gave a strong endorsement to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats and eliminated the Free Democrats from the state legislature.

title: Cray Officer Becomes President of Applitek
description: Peter Appleton Jones has decided to take the step from an established computer company, Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis, to a start-up company that has a product but is not yet in production.

title: Batboy's Jackpot
description: Jason Kirschner's favorite baseball team, the Yankees, will not be going to the World Series this year. But Jason will. The 12-year-old first baseman for the Little League Tigers of Hillside, Queens, will be the honorary batboy in the first two games, on Oct. 12 and 13. He will wear the uniform of the National League home team, meet some of the players on the field before the games and then join his parents and his 10-year-old brother, Mitchell, in a V.I.P. box seat to watch the action.

title: Pamela Getz Married To Scot Alan Raynor
description: Pamela Mary Pauline Getz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stan Getz of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scot Alan Raynor, son of Alan Raynor of Avon, Conn., and Janet Raynor Lewis of New Hartford, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Cutler performed the ceremony in St. Joseph of Arimathea Episcopal Church in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: TOOL ORDERS SLIPPED 22% IN AUGUST
description: New orders for machine tools fell in August to the year's lowest level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported yesterday.

title: BALLET: EGLEVSKY OPENER HONORS THE ROMANTICS
description: A NOD to 19th-century Romantic ballet was the theme of the Eglevsky Ballet's first weekend series of the season. On Saturday night at the Hofstra Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I., Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell were guest artists in a staging of Act II of ''Giselle''; two world premieres paid tribute to the 19th-century ballerinas Fanny Elssler and Carlotta Grisi.

title: RESIDENTS OF A BEIRUT CAMP PONDER ISRAELI ATTACK
description: Nestled below Beirut's old Mar Elias Greek Orthodox Church, one of the city's smallest refugee camps is quietly struggling to recover from what its people describe as an unprovoked attack 11 days ago by Israeli forces advancing on Beirut.

title: Deficit Tops $100 Billion
description: For the first year ever, the Federal deficit has soared past $100 billion, the Treasury Department says. With a month still to go in the fiscal year 1982, the deficit stands at $108.95 billion, according to a Treasury report issued last Friday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Tobacco Trance

title: Rangers Welcome Nilsson and Hedberg
description: Among the Rangers and their fans, there is a widespread conviction that, after their fine 1981-82 season, this is the season they will win their first Stanley Cup since 1940.

title: MINERS' TRUST AIDES SAY DATA ON CANDIDATE MIGHT BE WRONG
description: An official of the United Mine Workers pension trust conceded today that ''possibly incorrect'' figures had been released about the mining experience of the man challenging the incumbent for the presidency of the union.

title: TROUT BOUNTIFUL IN MAINE
description: GREENVILLE, Me. IT is altogether fitting that, signaling the arrival of his annual spawning urge, the male brook trout's flanks blaze with colors akin to those of fall. For, above all others, his species is a symbol of the deep woods of the Northeast.

title: SCHOOLS: WHEN TESTING PREVAILS OVER LEARNING
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPER QUESTION FOR A SURROGATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Hong Kong just wants to mind its own business: making money A2 Brezhnev stresses China in tem- perate foreign policy speech A3 Jordanian King discusses Leba- non crisis with U.S. envoy A4 A refugee camp in Beirut tries to recover from Israeli attack A6 Around the World A7 Marcos's visit: ''A net plus'' A8 Argentina, after losing Falkland war, sets moderate course A9 Government/Politics White House rebuffs Donovan bid to hold up nomination of judge B2 Suit revolves around Nevada nu- clear tests B5 Washington Talk Political consultants of both par- ties and their advice A12 Days, months and years to remember A12 Required Reading A12 The Calendar A12 Briefing A12 General Around the Nation A10 Experts oppose transfer of child food aid to states A16 At 75, Plaza Hotel is determined to stay old B1 Video game producer paces Mo- hawk Valley economic revival B2 Industry/Labor Incorrect work data possibly given on union challenger A16 White House rebuffs Donovan bid to hold up nomination of judge B2 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. SportsMonday Baseball: Brewers' lead falls to 2 games after loss to Orioles C1

title: AIDE BIDS REAGAN STRESS HIS FAIRNESS
description: A senior official at the Office of Management and Budget says that the Reagan Administration is perceived by many Americans as ''uncaring, perhaps even cruel'' and that the President should reply more forcefully to those who question the fairness and moral value of his economic and social policies.

title: Gemayel Said to Plan U.S. Trip To Visit U.N. and See Reagan
description: The Lebanese television said today that President Amin Gemayel was expected to go to New York sometime next month to address the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Patty Sheehan Is Golf Winner
description: Patty Sheehan shot par on the 18th hole to break a tie with JoAnne Carner today and win the Ladies Professional Golf Association Safeco Classic.

title: AEG'S BOARD FAVORS PLAN
description: The supervisory board of AEG-Telefunken A.G. has endorsed the corporate reorganization concept proposed by AEG's management on Sept. 10, the company said.

title: Swiss Final Reset
description: The scheduled final in the $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament between Mats Wilander of Sweden and Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia was postponed today because of rain. It will be played Monday.

title: LEHRMAN AND CUOMO DIVIDE ON DEBATES' CAMPAIGN ROLE
description: The extent that the campaign for Governor of New York should be based on candidate debates divided the two sides yesterday. Mario M. Cuomo criticized Lewis E. Lehrman for ''playing games'' with paid commercials, and urged instead that their campaign center on a series of ''Lincoln-Douglas'' discussions.

title: TOP JUDGES OFFER NEW TRIAL RULES
description: The top policy-making body for the Federal courts has adopted proposals that could substantially change the conduct of Federal trials.

title: NEW PROPOSAL BY OWNERS IS REJECTED AS TALKS STALL
description: Whatever optimism existed at the National Football League labor negotiations to get closer to a contract settlement and the end of a players' strike dissipated in the usual manner tonight.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS LEAVE URBAN WEST BEIRUT
description: Israeli forces withdrew from urban West Beirut today, leaving only a squad of troops at the port and a small unit at the international airport.

title: Red Sox Win, 5-2; Guidry Takes Loss
description: Jim Rice's seventh-inning triple over the raised glove of Jerry Mumphrey drove in the winning run today in the Red Sox' 5-2 victory over the Yankees and Ron Guidry.

title: Kin of Missing G.I.'s Ending Mission in Laos
description: Relatives of missing American servicemen held a ''very friendly'' two-hour meeting with Laotian officials today on stepped-up efforts to produce a final accounting of some 2,500 missing Americans in Indochina.

title: NEW CARDINALS NEAR TITLE ON QUICKNESS AND DEFENSE
description: ST. LOUIS WHAT Whitey Herzog instituted in 1980 was his own urban renewal plan. He went to the baseball winter meetings in Dallas, traded 13 players and acquired 10. The idea was to give the St. Louis fans a new look downtown, where the Cardinals play at Busch Stadium. And he decided it made more sense to remodel the team to suit the needs of a roomy ball park covered in artificial turf than to ask August Busch, the owner and famous beer baron, to contemplate tinkering with the outfield fences.

title: Beaten Woman, 18, Dies in a Plunge
description: A Queens teen-ager either fell or was pushed to her death from the roof of her apartment building early yesterday, after she was stripped of her clothes and beaten, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: ANGELS LOSE AFTER WILD START

title: TUITION CREDITS FROM THE MANY FOR THE FEW
description: To the Editor:

title: Abbott Labs Narrows Murine Agency Field
description: Abbott Laboratories has confirmed that it is down to three ad agencies in its search for a new home for its Murine eye drops.

title: Companies Merge Mobile-Phone Bid
description: The Graphic Scanning Corporation of Teaneck, N.J., said its subsidiary, Cellular Mobile Systems of Wisconsin Inc., had agreed with the Westel-Milwaukee Company to combine their competing proposals for establishing a cellular mobile telephone system in Milwaukee.

title: ISRAELI GENERAL IN BEIRUT SAYS HE DID NOT KNOW OF KILLINGS
description: The senior Israeli commander in Lebanon, Maj. Gen. Amir Drori, said today that he had no ''specific information'' that a massacre was taking place in the Shatila Palestinian refugee camp in West Beirut until Saturday morning, Sept. 18, after it was all over.

title: BREZHNEV STRESSES ISSUE OF CHINA TIES
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today underscored the importance he ascribes to improving relations with China in a brief survey of foreign affairs that was marked by its temperate tone.

title: Gas Company Customers To Help Poor With Bills
description: Customers of a Minnesota gas company will start making voluntary contributions in November to help the elderly and handicapped who have trouble paying their heating bills.

title: Arafat Among Pilgrims Assembled Near Mecca
description: Almost two million Moslems, including Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, assembled today below Mount Arafat, near Mecca, on the last day of the annual Islamic pilgrimage.

title: Bridge: When Things Went Awry, This Convention Was Born
description: The origins of many bridge conventions are quite obscure, and some are named after players who not only did not invent them but do not wish to play them. But there is one device, now popular throughout the world, that can be traced to a particular deal. It is shown in the diagram, and was played in the 1956 Spingold Knockout Teams with two famous New York partnerships in opposition.

title: Clampett Takes Southern Open
description: Bobby Clampett, a 22-year-old Californian, shot a six-under-par 64 today and won the Southern Open by two strokes over Hale Irwin.

title: FRUITLESS OIL DRILLING IN GEORGES BANK HALTS
description: Oil exploration in the Georges Bank came to a halt last week, leaving behind eight dry holes and diminished hopes for finding oil or natural gas off the New England coast.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Going to Bat for the Babe

title: CHRISTMAS PAST BACK IN FORM
description: The Christmas Past that won the Coaching Club American Oaks by six lengths earlier this year reappeared at Belmont Park yesterday. The gray filly, a dull fourth in the Gazelle Handicap 12 days ago, recaptured her best form and almost certainly clinched the 3-yearold-filly championship with a five-length victory in the Ruffian Handicap.

title: Bert Lance Picked as Leader Of Georgia Democratic Party
description: Bert Lance, the former Federal budget director who resigned under fire in 1977 and later was acquitted of bank fraud charges, has been named chairman of the Georgia Democratic Party.

title: CHILD FOOD FUNDS BACKED IN HEARING
description: Several nutrition experts have warned that approving President Reagan's plan to turn child nutrition programs over to the states would have serious consequences.

title: FRANCO CALAMANDREI
description: Franco Calamandrei, a Communist Senator best known for his work as vice chairman of a parliamentary commission set up to investigate the Masonic lodge scandal that brought down the Government of Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani in 1981, died today in a Rome hospital, his family announced.

title: Brazilian Opening at the U.N.
description: The United Nations General Assembly too often substitutes a windy ventilation of the silly or the obvious for serious diplomacy. But there are special reasons to pay heed to Brazil, by custom the first member of the Assembly to speak.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OLD AND NEW

title: Selective Service Job To Henry J. Kaufman
description: Henry J. Kaufman & Associates of Washington, already the agency for the Coast Guard and the Public Health Service, also quietly become the agency for the Selective Service System in July.

title: Marietta's Autonomy Is Costly
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation appears to many analysts to have been battered and bloodied by its costly victory to retain its independence. They believe that its scope has been reduced, its equity cut, its debt load inflated and its earnings potential dimmed. Its future appears cloudy, they add, and the giant aerospacealuminum-cement producer may bear lasting scars.

title: Hammermill Net Off
description: The Hammermill Paper Company, citing the recession and the ''traditional summer slowdown,'' said that its third-quarter profit tumbled 28.1 percent from a year earlier on a 1.6 percent decline in sales. Hammermill said earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 12 fell to $5.97 million, or 58 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or $1.01 a share, a year earlier. Sales slipped to $312.6 million from $317.8 million.

title: YOM KIPPUR: A TIME FOR REFLECTION
description: Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, began at sundown yesterday with the chanting of the Kol Nidre prayer, asking God's forgiveness for transgressions of the last year and pledging renewed efforts in the coming year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Koch, Some Heartfelt Advice

title: Maxim Shostakovich To Lead Philharmonic
description: Maxim Shostakovich, the conductor and son of the Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich, will conduct the New York Philharmonic Orchestra for the first time Oct. 6 at the Concert Theater of C.W.Post Center of Long Island University.

title: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's First article of a series appearing periodically
description: More so today than at any time since the early part of this century, when boatloads of Irish, Italians and Eastern Europeans spilled onto the city's shores, New York is a city of immigrants. Beginning 17 years ago with a loosening in the Federal immigration law, the latest surge of foreigners from virtually every nation has reached dimensions not seen since the last great wave of immigration ended in the 1920's as the heyday of Ellis Island came to a close, Federal immigration records show. More than a million immigrants now live in New York City. According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, there are more than 650,000 legal immigrants here, and the city estimates that there are 750,000 illegal aliens as well.

title: Margaret Whiting Plans Ethel Merman Tribute
description: ''Margaret Whiting: Hooked on Merman,'' a revue of music associated with Ethel Merman and sung by Miss Whiting, will open tomorrow night at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, and run through Oct. 23. Miss Merman will be present on opening night to cheer on Miss Whiting, who will perform at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday.

title: Ex-Florida Court Justice Accused in Drug Case
description: David L. McCain, who was forced to resign from the Florida Supreme Court in 1975, was arrested Saturday on charges of conspiring to import and distribute more than 10,000 pounds of marijuana, the authorities said.

title: NEW PHASE IN STRUGGLE ON DEFICITS
description: Friday marks the beginning of a new year - the fiscal year 1983 - and it marks as well the beginning of the Reagan Administration's effort to draft a budget for the fiscal year 1984 that will show a shrinking trend in the deficit. For the White House and its Republican allies in Congress, the deliberations promise to be even more painful and divisive than those that characterized the battle over the budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: CITY OPERA: THE 'TOSCA' THAT EMPHASIZES SCARPIA
description: IT may be that the impression given in the first ''Tosca'' of the season at City Opera was correct. In the generally fine performance on Saturday night, it seemed as if Scarpia were at the center of the work rather than Tosca herself.

title: AMERICAN SHIPS SLOWED BY RED TAPE
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Chrysler Is Adding 2d Agency
description: THE Chrysler Corporation, all of whose advertising has been done by Kenyon & Eckhardt since 1979, when it consolidated its business in the biggest account switch in history, confirmed Friday it is looking for a second agency.

title: Cleaning Up Henry Hudson's River
description: When Henry Hudson entered it, the river that now bears his name produced succulent oysters and bass, sturgeon and the beaver that appears on New York's seal. That was nearly 500 years ago, and it may no longer be possible to meet the same standard for water quality. But great progress has been made toward permitting swimming in the Lower Bay, reopening the South Shore Beaches on Staten Island and restoring fish life through the whole New York Bight.

title: GETTING USED TO FOOTBALL'S SILENT SUNDAY
description: ON the morning after pro football's Silent Sunday, the sun came up in its usual shape - round, not oblong. America had survived the absence of its Sunday diversion. In the New York area, a television doubleheader had been scheduled for yesterday afternoon. But at 1 o'clock, when the Giants were to have collided on the kickoff with the Steelers in Pittsburgh, a view of empty Three Rivers Stadium was on the screen. And at 4 o'clock, when the Jets were to have played the Colts in Baltimore, a Canadian Football League game was on display.

title: Italian Output Climbs
description: Italian industrial output, seasonally adjusted, rose 3 percent in July after declining 4.2 percent in June, Istat, the national statistics institute, said. The June output reflected the impact of a one-day general strike that month.

title: ARGENTINA SETTING MODERATE COURSE
description: Argentina, which will be arguing its claim to the Falklands in the United Nations General Assembly this week for the first time since losing its battle for the islands to Britain, is pursuing a much more moderate foreign policy than the West had feared at war's end.

title: Clippings of World Telegram In Danger of Being Destroyed
description: About 60 million newspaper clippings from the morgue of The New York World Telegram may be heading for a landfill.

title: GLANCING BLOW AT CARIBBEAN NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon has emerged as a major issue in Israelis' concern over questions of their army's responsibility in the Beirut massacre.

title: THE DANCE: MISS VAN PELT
description: SATURDAY night's performance by Susan Van Pelt and Dancers at the White Dog Studio contained works in several styles. But Miss Van Pelt never proved really at home in any of them.

title: Illinois Broker Is Suspended
description: An investment house in suburban Oak Brook, Ill., has been ordered shut down temporarily as a result of Federal charges that hundreds of its customers had been defrauded of a total of $30 million in illegal trading.

title: CORPORATIONS MAY RUSH DEBT ISSUES TO MARKET
description: The Treasury market faces a three-week lull in new note and bond financings, and some investment bankers said that might lead to more corporate financings that are not yet formally scheduled.

title: SURGE IN APTITUDE SCORES TERMED NOTHING TO CHEER
description: William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has warned that a report last week of a modest rise in the average verbal and mathematics scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test possibly reflected a ''bottoming-out that is not a cause for self-congratulations.''

title: Softsoap's Maker Decides on a Shop
description: Minnetonka Inc., a very important and successful holdout, finally has decided to take unto itself an advertising agency. And after being courted by scores of agencies since it introduced Softsoap in 1978, it has chosen Advertising to Women without any agency competition.

title: 300th VICTORY BRINGS A CALL
description: Eddie Robinson, the football coach at Grambling State University, said his feet were still off the ground from his 300th coaching victory at the school when President Reagan called to offer congratulations today.

title: ELECTRO-ACOUSTIC CONCERT HALL OPENS IN OREGON
description: September's quintuplet of major concert halls, from New Orleans and Toronto to Baltimore and Peoria, came to full term last Friday evening, when the electro-acoustic Silva Concert Hall of the Hult Performing Arts Center was inaugurated in the little university city of Eugene. The concert hall alone cost, with parking facility, some $26 million, and the adjoining convention center raised the total cost to around $52.5 million.

title: Washington Watch; Twilight Time On 'All Savers'
description: exempt savings certificates beyond Dec. 31. But it appears that Mr. Rostenkowski had already slammed the window shut.

title: GIANTS TIE BRAVES IN 2D PLACE
description: Darrell Evans hit a two-run homer to cap a three-run fifth inning, and San Francisco hung on for a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today, giving the Giants a sweep of the three-game series.

title: FANS FIND OTHER DIVERSIONS
description: Americans reacted in various ways yesterday to a most unusual phenomenon - a September Sunday without live National Football League games in stadiums across the country or on network television. The stadiums were empty, and the networks presented two games from the Canadian Football League and a rerun of last January's Super Bowl XVI.

title: Four Officers Promoted At Golub Grocery Chain
description: The Golub family started in business as grocers in Schenectady, N.Y., and built the Golub Corporation into what is now a chain of 55 Price Chopper supermarkets.

title: CONSULTANTS' CURRENCY: INFORMATION
description: Ray Strother thinks Democrats will run particularly well this year among working women, so when he tries to reach this voting group, he buys time for his candidates on the evening news program.

title: FLUTIE IMPROVISING VICTORIES FOR EAGLES
description: year-old quarterback spoke in the confessional tone of a penitent at a meeting of Gamblers Anonymous. ''I've done some pretty wild things with the ball,'' the Boston College sophomore was saying here the other day. ''I probably try too hard to make something happen when the play isn't there. I do a lot of fundamental things wrong.''

title: El Salvador Is Accused Of Covering Up Killings
description: El Salvador's most active human rights group told President Reagan today that the Salvadoran Government was covering up abuses by the military and rightist groups to insure continued United States aid.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Rural Problem Comes to Town

title: WILDCATS STILL HUNGRY
description: In the aftermath of what had to be one of the most important victories in Northwestern history on Saturday, the Wildcats still found themselves looking to stop a losing streak. Northwestern has lost 37 straight in the Big Ten since a season-opening 0-0 tie with Illinois in 1978.

title: U.S. BLAMES ISRAEL FOR MARINES' DELAY IN BEIRUT LANDING
description: The Reagan Administration said today that Israel's refusal to withdraw its forces from Beirut International Airport as well as from East and West Beirut was the major obstacle to the landing of United States marines in Lebanon.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dark Days for Fans - And for Bookies

title: Dr. Dagobert Runes, Founder Of the Philosophical Library
description: Dr. Dagobert D. Runes, founder and editor in chief of the Philosophical Library, died Friday at Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FOLK PROGRAM: DANNY O'KEEFE
description: AMONG the West Coast singer-songwriters of the Jackson Browne ilk who came to prominence in the early 1970's, Danny O'Keefe has enjoyed the least commercial success relative to his talent. Mr. O'Keefe, who appeared at Folk City on Saturday, is a first-rate craftsman of the contemporary folk ballad. The signature style of many of his songs is a chromatic guitar line that gives his reflective, sometimes darkly humorous lyrics, an extra dash of plaintiveness.

title: TV: DICK VAN DYKE FACES MIDLIFE IN 'DROP-OUT FATHER'
description: ''DROP-OUT FATHER,' on CBS tonight at 9, is still another television turn about midlife crisis, this one from a comic point of view. It offers Dick Van Dyke and Mariette Hartley as a married couple who suddenly discover that life in suburbia is empty and meaningless. Pity those poor benighted surburbanites who actually like and enjoy their lives.

title: Cusick Memorial to Be Friday
description: A memorial to Peter Cusick, a private consultant on government and foreign affairs who died last Monday, will be held at noon on Friday at the Council on Foreign Relations, 58 West 68th Street, in Manhattan. Mr. Cusick, a resident of Somers, N.Y., was a member of the council at his death.

title: Governor of Alabama Charged With Contempt
description: Gov. Fob James of Alabama will be ordered to defend himself against a criminal contempt of court charge for encouraging teachers to ignore a Federal District judge's ban on school prayer, an attorney says.

title: 3 KEY AIDES INSIST BEGIN APPROVE INDEPENDENT INQUIRY ON MASSACRE
description: Three key Government ministers are insisting that Prime Minister Menachem Begin reverse his position and permit an independent inquiry into the Israeli military's conduct during the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut.

title: Marina Re, Actress, Bride Of Michael Leo Poisson
description: Marina Re, daughter of Edward D. Re, Chief Judge of the United States Court of International Trade, and Mrs. Re of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday to Michael Leo Poisson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo W. Poisson of New Bedford, Mass.

title: FONDEST FAREWELLS FOR STARGELL
description: THE testimonials actually began in spring training when the Pittsburgh Pirates played the Florida circuit. The fans turned out for what they figured was their last look at Willie Stargell as an active player and they began what has become a seasonlong round of applause. In a state that has a large retirement community, many of the people probably thought that Stargell was one of them. His teammates do call him ''Pops.''

title: LONG-TERM RATES POST A DECREASE
description: With little fanfare outside the financial markets, long-term interest rates passed a milestone of sorts last week when they dropped below the levels that prevailed at the start of the Reagan Administration. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, a benchmark for all other long-term rates, including those on home mortgages, stood at 11.82 percent late Friday, compared with about 12.04 percent on the afternoon of Jan. 20, 1981.

title: Officers Rescue Man, 20, Buried in Box for 4 Days
description: A 20-year-old man was abducted and buried for four days before being rescued today shortly after the authorities arrested three people, the police said.

title: JOBS AIDE SAID HE GOT MONEY TO BLOCK HIRING
description: A man who in testimony once acknowledged accepting payments from an organized crime figure to keep nonwhite workers off construction jobs has been hired by the state's Urban Development Corporation as a consultant on minority hiring.

title: SHULTZ IS MEETING WITH GROMYKO WITH HOPES OF PROGRESS DIM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, will meet Tuesday in New York at a time when little remains of the detente relationship of the early 1970's and Administration officials believe that the Soviet leadership is paralyzed at home and on the defensive worldwide.

title: Hathaway Departing From Ogilvy & Mather
description: That man in the eyepatch wearing the Hathaway shirt is leaving Ogilvy & Mather for the second time. During their first relationship, which lasted from 1953 to 1970, they helped make one another famous.

title: Bruins 7, Islanders 0
description: Bruce Crowder scored two goals and Craig MacTavish, his linemate, added another as the Boston Bruins overwhelmed the New York Islanders, 7-0, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: For Allied, Gains May Take Time
description: Even before it acquired the Bendix Corporation, the Allied Corporation had convinced Wall Street that the company's decision last year to drop ''Chemical'' from its name made sense.

title: NORTHROP SEES HOPE IN F-5G
description: Executives of the Northrop Corporation, the aircraft maker, like to point out that the company has designed its F-5G Tigershark fighter, built prototypes and flown them without financial help from the Government.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 27, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Catcher Who Steals
description: FOR five major league seasons, John Wathan squatted behind home plate, trying to stop runners like Rickey Henderson from stealing bases. But John Wathan didn't just want to negate these basestealers; he wanted to emulate them. Behind the stolid mask and chest protector and shin guards of a guardian of the base paths, there lurked the flamboyant soul of a thief.

title: REGAN TRIES TO LESSEN PRIME RATE'S INFLUENCE
description: Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan has started a campaign to discredit the prime rate as the benchmark of the nation's interest-rate structure.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1982
description: International The main obstacle to the landing of American Marines in Lebanon is Israel's refusal to withdraw all its forces from Beirut International Airport as well as from East and West Beirut, according to the Reagan Administration. An Administration spokesman said the number of Palestinians estimated to have died in the Beirut massacre was ''now around 600.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli forces withdrew from urban West Beirut, leaving only a squad of troops at the port and a small unit at the international airport. An Israeli spokesman said the last Israeli soldiers would leave Beirut on Wednesay. He attributed the delay to the start of Yom Kippur. (A4:1-3.)

title: 8 Homes Washed Away As California Dam Bursts
description: A dam burst, freeing the rainfallswollen North Lake and prompting the evacuation of about 800 people today, while 14 miles away, in Big Pine, overflowing creeks and streams washed away at least eight homes.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1982; The Economy
description: The start of the fiscal year 1983 on Friday will also mark the opening of President Reagan's campaign to reduce the Federal budget deficit for 1984. White House watchers say the new campaign may be even more divisive than the battle over the 1983 budget. (Page D1.) The 1982 deficit will set a record. (D5.)

title: Pipe Bomb Found At Stock Exchange
description: A pipe bomb with a lighted fuse was found taped to the main door of the American Stock Exchange in lower Manhattan last night. The fuse died out shortly after members of a Fire Patrol unit were alerted by passers-by.

title: VISIT CALLED 'NET PLUS' FOR MARCOS
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos returns to the Philippines on Tuesday, he will carry with him a generous package of economic and trade agreements and promises of more American aid to come.

title: Wounded Pastor Talks to Police
description: The Rev. Robert Butler, who was shot in his church here, remained in critical condition today, but he was able to speak to police officers investigating the shooting. Members of the Bedford Community Church, where the shooting took place, maintained a prayer vigil at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center.

title: New Trends in Consumerism
description: At Yankelovich, Skelly & White, the future is where the money comes from. It's the research outfit that many manufacturers turn to to find out about the marketplace of tomorrow.

title: LIFE WITH A LIVE-IN SERVANT
description: They live under the same roof, tend to the needs of the same children, see one another at breakfast and dinner, and share private occasions that are off limits even to friends. So it is inevitable that relationships between employers and live-in housekeepers or governesses run deeper than the standard boss-worker connection.

title: An Aid Nostrum Backfires
description: President Reagan's foreign aid policy - what's good for Uncle Sugar is good for Upper Volta - is rooted in the belief that free-market private enterprise is the road to economic development for rich and poor nations alike. For that reason, he has de-emphasized America's contribution to multilateral aid for the truly truly needy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I came to New York so that I could learn English.

title: POLL LEADS BROWN'S OPPONENT TO SHIFT TACTICS
description: Campaign strategists for Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego are revamping their tactics after a poll suggesting for the first time that Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. had advanced to within striking distance in the race for the United States Senate.

title: Jersey Slot Machine Pays Out $919,559
description: Alberta Joyce Kidd had been plunking dollars into a slot machine at Harrah's Marina Casino Hotel for about 15 minutes early today when she hit it big - a $919,559.85 jackpot.

title: Proving Ground
description: At about 3:30 on a humid late summer afternoon, the lights go up in Carmichael Auditorium. Without a word, the court clears of all but past and present members of the University of North Carolina basketball team. Almost as quickly, a pair of returning players, preferably seniors, choose sides for the first in a series of pickup games between the ''shirts'' and ''skins.''

title: TRIAL HINGES ON SAFETY OF ATOM TESTS
description: The early 1960's were stressful years for Arthur Bruhn, who was serving as president of a small but growing college in southern Utah. Rarely, however, was he so busy that he could not find the time to watch the spectacular bursts of light from the atomic bomb test site across the green-gray floor of the Mojave Desert.

title: WILKES-BARRE KILLINGS: RACIAL PRESSURES CITED
description: BARRE, Pa., Sept. 26 - An image began to emerge today of the prison guard being held here in the slayings of 13 people: that of a complex man, seething with resentment against members of the two races whose heritages he shared.

title: THE VIOLENT CHILD: SOME PATTERNS EMERGE
description: A new portrait of violent children and adolescents is emerging from recent research that has linked their behavior to physical and psychological abnormalities and to the effects of abuse and violence in their families. The research, which suggests ways of predicting whether some children will be repeatedly violent, may lead to strategies for treating these youngsters before they become violent adults.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot in Yonkers
description: An off-duty Yonkers police officer was shot and critically wounded early yesterday while working as a night clerk at the Deegan Motel in the Bronx.

title: CHARLOTTE B. WINSOR
description: Charlotte Biber Winsor, director of graduate programs for teacher education at the Bank Street College of Education from 1951 until her retirement in 1966, died Friday in Ann Arbor, Mich., where she was visiting. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PHILLIES DEFEATED BY METS
description: A broken-bat single by Mookie Wilson scored two runs in the seventh inning and enabled the Mets to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-4, at Shea Stadium yesterday. The Phillies did not lose ground to the division-leading St. Louis Cardinals, who lost to the Cubs, but time continued to run out for their chances in the race for the National League East title.

title: Required Reading; Aiding the Farmers
description: Representative Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, in discussion of his amendment to allow farmers to defer payment of certain farm loans. Sept. 9, 1982:

title: TENSION RISES IN WAKE OF DEATH AT SIOUX CAMP
description: Russell Means, the American Indian Movement leader, and Bruce Ellison, a lawyer who has figured in several controversial Indian causes, have been drawn into a murder investigation that is being carried out amid rising tensions between the white and Indian communities here.

title: WHITE HOUSE REBUFFS DONOVAN BID TO HOLD UP NOMINATION OF JUDGE
description: An attempt by Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan to hold up the nomination of a judge for the Federal District Court in New Jersey has been rebuffed by the White House, according to a senior White House aide.

title: THE FAILURES OF NUCLEAR FUEL REPROCESSING
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD NEIGHBORS
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN STATE'S DRILLS LED TO LATE HEROICS
description: A well-practiced late-game offense, usually known as a two-minute offense, gave Penn State its last-second 27-24 victory over Nebraska on Saturday. Actually, the winning drive lasted 74 seconds and 10 plays, and ended with only 4 seconds left when Todd Blackledge threw his third touchdown pass of the game.

title: MANEUVERING STARTS OVER WHO WILL RUN THE SCHOOLS OF BOSTON
description: The Boston school district is one of 436 districts regulated by the state of Massachusetts, but for years there has been no real communication between the city's Superintendent of Schools and the state's Commissioner of Education.

title: SUZUKI, IN CHINA, TRIES TO SOOTHE STRAINS
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived in China today on an official visit commemorating a decade of close Chinese-Japanese relations, which were strained recently by a revival of bitter wartime memories.

title: Electronic Game Plan
description: Computers seem to be making an increasingly heavy impact on professional football. Currently they're receiving a bit of a rest because of the National Football League's labor problems. But when play resumes, more than half the league's 28 teams will be making use of computers for scouting, grading of players, analysis of the tendencies of both teams in preparation for a game and for up-to-theminute analysis of the opposition's tendencies during an actual game.

title: United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell part of its Stromberg-Carlson telephone-switching business to the Plessey Company, which is the largest maker of telephone equipment in Britain. The sale, valued by the companies at $57 million, includes operations in Rochester, Lake Mary, Fla., and Ardmore, Okla., but not those in Orlando, Fla. United Technologies acquired Stromberg-Carlson from the General Dynamics Corporation in July.

title: 'IN THE NAME OF GOD, GO!'
description: In the spring of 1940 British forces in Norway were overwhelmed by the Nazis. On May 7 Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain faced a critical motion by the Labor opposition in the House of Commons. His Conservatives had a big majority. But a respected Conservative backbencher, Leopold Amery, rose and addressed to Chamberlain the words that Cromwell had said to the Long Parliament 300 years before:

title: ORIOLES CUT BREWERS LEAD TO 2
description: The Baltimore Orioles silenced the Milwaukee Brewers' bats again today, winning the second straight game of their critical series and moving to two games behind the first-place Brewers in the American League East. Each team has seven left to play.

title: UNABASHEDLY, THE BUSINESS OF HONG KONG IS MONEY
description: A foreign banker new to Hong Kong tells of how, shortly after being posted here, he decided to close the office at 8 o'clock every night so his Chinese staff could spend more time with their families. He was taken aside and politely but firmly told to discard that notion, since nothing would be more likely to foment an office revolt than limiting working hours.

title: Javelin Mark Set
description: Sofia Sakorafa of Greece set a world record in the women's javelin with a throw of 243 feet 5 inches today, bettering the previous mark of 237-6 set by Tina Lillac of Finland earlier this year. Miss Sakorafa, who is 25 years old, was participating in the Greek track and field championship at the Chanea National Stadium in Crete. She was second in the event at the European Games held in Athens earlier this month.

title: Mazda's '83 Prices Firm
description: Mazda, the Japanese auto maker, said it would hold the price of its 1983 models at about the same levels as last year.

title: IN A NINTH-GRADE CLASS, NUCLEAR WIND BLOWS
description: Fifteen teen-agers, ninth-grade students at the Dalton School, sat in a sixth-floor classroom the other day and talked of death by nuclear fallout, but not in terms of mass onslaughts of bombs and millions of casualties.

title: HARRIET LABELL
description: Harriet LaBell, a New York artist who since 1967 had lived and worked in Sarasota, Fla., died Friday at her home after a brief illness.

title:
IN CHINA, DIVISIONS;
NEW HAVEN - China has presented the 12th Communist Party Congress as a triumph for Deng Xiaoping's pragmatic brand of socialism, but the facade of unity conceals many significant cleavages. These divisions portend continued shifts in policy rather than the widely predicted stability.
description: The recent congress formally endorsed sweeping economic and political reforms that Mr. Deng has promoted since his return to power in 1977. It endorsed the increased use of markets and prices in place of total state control of the economy, and made important changes in the party structure to prevent a repetition of Cultural Revolution horrors. Many Western observers regard the appropriateness of these reforms as self-evident and predict that these policies will endure for years.

title: Race Postponed
description: Rain forced the postponement of today's $202,700 Old Dominion 500 Nascar Grand National race at Martinsville Speedway. The 500-lap, 262.5-mile race has been rescheduled for Oct. 17 at 12:30 P.M., Dick Thompson, a track spokesman, announced. He said the 31-car field, with Ricky Rudd of Chesapeake, Va., on the pole, will be the same.

title: COACHES SAVOR A SUNDAY OFF
description: Ray Perkins, the coach of Giants, chose to play golf. Chuck Noll wanted to, but it rained in Pittsburgh, so the bookish Steeler coach stayed home and read. ''Non-football subjects,'' he said. The Jets' Walt Michaels drove to Pennsylvania to visit his mother, and Dick Vermeil of the Eagles paid calls on antique shops in the countryside with his wife, Carolyn. They came home with a chair. ''A Morris chair,'' Vermeil said yesterday by telephone.

title: Books Of The Times
description: GOOSEFOOT. By Patrick McGinley. Dut- ton. 245 pp. $13.95

title: Bell Helicopter Sales Set
description: Textron Inc. announced over the weekend that its Bell Helicopter subsidiary had won four contracts totaling $113 million. Jordan is to buy 24 AH-19 modernized Cobras for $41 million; Turkey is to buy 25 UH-1H utility helicopters for $36 million; Pakistan ordered 10 AH-1S Cobras worth $18 million, and the United States Army ordered 12 AH-1S Cobras in a contract that was also valued at $18 million, the company said.

title: LAWYERS TO ASK CHANGES IN TOXIC-WASTE SUITS
description: Congress should establish a new fund to compensate victims of toxic pollution and make sweeping legal changes that would make it easier to sue for damages, a major report recommends.

title: Lindner's Stake In Penn Central
description: American Financial Enterprises Inc. and the American Financial Corporation said they had increased their holdings in the Penn Central Corporation to the equivalent of 31.7 percent of the common shares outstanding.

title: Ivy League Goal
