description: Four members of the United States national youth soccer team, including the two goalkeepers, are attending Ivy League colleges instead of such better-known soccer powers as Duke, Virginia, Indiana or the University of Connecticut.

title: AT THE SOVIET CROSSROADS
description: Secretary of State George Shultz will meet his Soviet counterpart, Andrei Gromyko, in New York Tuesday. The encounter comes at a crossroads, a time of tensions and choices for both countries when small steps can fix a fateful direction.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1982
description: International French and Italian soldiers entered Shatila and Sabra, the two refugee camps in Beirut where hundreds of Palestinians were killed by Christian militiamen more than a week ago. The French and Italian peacekeepers moved in after Israeli troops virtually completed their withdrawal from West Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) The number of American Marines expected to land in Beirut this week may reach 1,200, according to a State Department spokesman. A Pentagon official said the Marines would be given more freedom of action in safeguarding lives and public order than was authorized for the 800 Marines stationed in Beirut to help oversee the withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization forces. (A8:5-6.)

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
AUTO UNION AND CHRYSLER ACT TO MAKE PACT MORE PALATABLE
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation met today to modify their tentative contract in an effort to increase its chances of ratification by the union's rank and file.

title: Internorth Ruling
description: Internorth Inc. of Omaha said a ruling by a Federal District Court in Delaware had effectively rendered invalid a $311 million Department of Energy overcharge allegation against it. A company official said the court's decisions had affirmed that Internorth's natural gas liquids pricing policies were correct and in compliance with Department of Energy regulations. Internorth had sought the court opinion in response to overpricing charges brought by the Energy Department, which had sought refunds totaling $203 million plus $108 million in interest on the sale of natural gas liquids between 1973 and 1978.

title: NEW ADVANCES PROMISE AID IN PREVENTION
description: TODAY, in places unknown but probably thousands of miles beyond our shores, the influenza virus is preparing its next seasonal assault on the American people. Doctors and clinics are taking steps now against the invasion by giving vaccinations against the potentially serious infection. Flu usually arrives in late fall or early winter, but immunization must be given well in advance for immunity to have time to develop.

title: Family Circle Campaign
description: The special project that Wyse Advertising was doing for Family Circle (a spot TV test with the theme 'There's nothing square about Family Circle'') will blossom into a full-fledged assignment as of Friday.

title: A PILOT PRESIDES OVER C.A.B.'S DEMISE
description: When he arrived in town last fall as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Dan Clinton McKinnon, a San Diego broadcaster and businessman, knew almost intuitively that he was in alien territory.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why don't fish like tuna and flounder, which live in salt water all their lives, taste salty when eaten?

title: Zenith-Erin Training
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation's Zenith Data Systems unit said today that it had agreed with Erin Computer Learning Centers of Great Neck, L.I., to provide customers for Zenith desktop computers with coupons for rebates on Erin software training. A coupon will be good for $110 of the $200 training program.

title: HOUSTON PONDERS PUBLIC TRANSIT PLAN
description: Houston, a city grown rich and prosperous on the basic creed of every man for himself, is coming to realize that that does not make sense anymore when it comes to getting to work in the morning.

title: Massey Bankers Devise Debt Plan
description: International bankers have worked out a tentative refinancing package for debt-laden Massey-Ferguson Inc., but banking sources say that the farm equipment giant must reduce its operations.

title: SCHMIDT'S FOES VOW TO PRESS OUSTER BID
description: The leaders of the center-right, three-party coalition that wants to govern West Germany pledged today to follow through on their plans to replace Chancellor Helmut Schmidt on Friday despite a poor showing in the Hesse state elections on Sunday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Elevated Pleasures

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the obituary page yes- terday gave an incorrect address for a memorial service for Peter Cusick. It will be held at noon Friday at the Council on Foreign Relations, 58 East 68th Street.

title: MAN HELD IN DEATHS SOUGHT MENTAL HELP BUT WAS SENT HOME
description: BARRE, Pa., Sept. 27 (UPI) - A suicidal prison guard accused in the slayings of 13 people had sought help at a mental health unit eight days before the killings but was not institutionalized because he did not qualify as homicidal, an official said today.

title: THAT HELPLESS FEELING
description: IN the history of printing, books produced before 1500 are referred to as incunabula, from the diminutive of the Latin cunae, meaning cradle. Surprisingly, during this infancy of printing, it is estimated, some 20 million volumes were produced - in a Europe whose population was roughly 70 million. Books, then, were not so rare as one might suppose. Their accessibility, on the other hand, was.

title: Strike at Crown Zellerbach
description: A strike by 750 union workers forced officials to shut a Crown Zellerbach paper mill today, but a spokesman said that the company planned to get the plant reopened within a week. The strike came after rejection of the company's final offer by a vote of 412 to 253. Plant officials hoped to use salaried workers to reopen the plant, which can produce 850 tons of paper daily.

title: BEGIN CABINET SAID TO BACK FULL INQUIRY
description: All members of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet are ready to support a full judicial inquiry into the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut, Israeli television reported today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages last Saturday incorrectly identified a National Basketball Association photographer. He is Jim Cummins.

title: 88 UTILITIES TO CONSIDER HUGE BOND REFINANCING
description: Eighty-eight utilities in the Washington Public Power Supply System voted in Vancouver, Wash., yesterday to examine a plan to refinance $2.25 billion in bonds issued for two nuclear power plants whose construction was abandoned earlier in the year as too expensive. The plants, known as Projects 4 and 5, had been under construction for several years.

title: Scott Expansion
description: The Scott Paper Company announced plans for a $38.5 million expansion of the finishing and warehouse facilities at its plant in Winslow, Me., and the start-up of its recycled fiber mill there. The expansion project, scheduled for completion in 1985, includes the installation of modernized finishing equipment and a warehouse and distribution center, Scott said. The company said its recycled fiber plant, completed recently at a cost of $25 million, would enable the Winslow plant to use low-cost, recycled fiber in its paper-making process.

title: ANOTHER GIANT MIRACLE?
description: N early two months ago, on July 30, the San Francisco Giants were 13 1/2 games out of first place in the National League West; nearly four weeks ago, on Sept. 3, they remained nine games out. But last night, as they returned to Candlestick Park for the final week of their astounding season, the Giants had a chance to complete their most theatrical scenario since the New York production of ''The Little Miracle of Coogan's Bluff'' in 1951.

title: Della Femina Post
description: Ned H. Gelband, 40, has come to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners as senior vice president, media services. He is replacing Herbert Maneloveg, who remains on the payroll as a consultant. Mr. Gelband has been vice president, media and programming, at Jordan, Case & McGrath, having previously worked at Young & Rubicam, Benton & Bowles and Kelly, Nason.

title: Reluctant Cavaliers
description: John Bagley, the 6-foot guard from Boston College who was Cleveland's first choice in the National Basketball Association's draft, failed to report to the Cavaliers' four-day rookie camp. Bagley has not signed a contract, and Ted Stepien, the owner, said the two parties were ''about $25,000 apart.''

title: BRAVES BLANK GIANTS
description: The Atlanta Braves defeated the San Francisco Giants, 7-0, tonight and moved into a first-place tie with the Los Angeles Dodgers. The Giants remained one game back in the National League West race.

title: ILLITERATES WHO NEED MORE THAN COURSES
description: To the Editor:

title: Civilian Rule to Return To Bolivia on Oct. 10
description: Bolivia's military rulers said today that they would transfer power Oct. 10 to a civilian president elected by Congress, which is to convene on Friday.

title: MINORITIES GAIN IN CITY PRIMARY, BUT ONLY A LITTLE
description: Black and Hispanic candidates made only slight gains in Thursday's New York City primary elections for seats in Congress, on the City Council and in the State Legislature, despite nearly two years of intense controversy over how the city's district boundaries should be drawn to guarantee minority rights.

title: Credit Card Policy Ruling
description: A Federal court today ruled against the American Express Company's policy of automatically canceling women's supplementary credit cards when their husbands die.

title: No Headline
description: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS THROW U.S. PACT INTO DOUBT

title: WAITING IN LINE AND HOPING: 296 JOBS AND 4,508 APPLICANTS
description: ''Real jobs,'' said Gerard DeToia, with a touch of awe and hope. ''They say that they have real jobs in there.'' The 20-year-old Mr. DeToia has had quite enough in recent months of combing the classifieds, pounding the pavement and trying to track down people said to know people who think a job might open up somewhere if the economy ever picks up. Finally he stood at a door with ''real jobs'' behind it.

title: PHILIPPINE LEVERAGE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos returns today to the Philippines after 10 days in the United States, confident that President Reagan will yield him even more economic and military aid than President Carter did. Mr. Marcos's leverage stemmed from his power to decide whether or not we can continue to use our largest overseas military bases, Subic Bay Naval Base and Clark Air Field, both located on the Philippine island of Luzon. He was able to bargain so confidently in large part because of the Administration's shortsighted view of the Philippine political forces that may eventually curtail our ability to use these bases effectively.

title: Bridge: Witchcraft in Modern Age Is Sometimes Unpunished
description: Long ago it was the custom to punish suspected witches by tying them to a ducking stool and plunging them repeatedly into a muddy pond. In our more enlightened age, those who employ witchcraft or wizardry at the bridge table are sometimes involved in a ducking procedure. And they do not get wet, although they may be feared by the hoi polloi.

title: PESO REFUGEES
description: The current economic crisis in Mexico will increase the pressure of illegal immigration on the United States border. This strengthens the case for the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, now before the House of Representatives. Simpson-Mazzoli seeks to limit the increased flow of illegal immigrants without curtailing civil liberties in the bargain.

title: Lights on Seventh Planet
description: Astrophysicists have discovered an aurora on the planet Uranus that is similar to the brilliant aurora borealis, or northern lights, on Earth. This provides the first evidence that Uranus is surrounded by a strong magnetic field like that around Earth, Jupiter and Saturn.

title: Mobil to Pay Alabama $2.5 Million in Dumping
description: The Mobil Corporation will pay Alabama $2 million in penalties and $500,000 more in cleanup costs this week because the oil compaany illegally discharged drilling wastes into Mobile Bay.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CRIMINAL INQUIRY ON PENN BANK SET
description: Federal bank regulators investigating the collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City have referred 30 cases to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution, according to confidential documents obtained by a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Advertising
description: to-18 set.

title: Reward Offered In Waldorf Slaying
description: A $10,000 reward for information leading to the killer of a 30-year-old vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank who was found stabbed to death in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Wednesday was offered yesterday by the bank and the hotel, according to New York City police officials.

title: Dives Begun to Test Endurance
description: Three men entered an 8-foot-diameter pressure chamber today to begin a 47-day series of experiments aimed at extending man's ability to work comfortably below the surface of the ocean.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Texas Instruments To Cut Workers
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the Dallas-based electronic instruments maker, said it would reduce its work force by 2,600 employees between now and the end of the year, bringing the total number of layoffs to more than 12,000 for this year and 1981.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: At 3:30 one morning in our time, Roger Damon is awakened from a pleasant sleep by a telephone call. "I heard the good news and I wanted to beone of the first to congratulate you," says a "rough and hoarse" voice that identifies itself as belonging to one Zalovsky from Chicago. "Oh, quit, mister, and let me sleep," says Damon, who's never heard of any Zalovsky from anywhere. "Roger, you've been a bad boy and you're going to have to do something about it." "I'm hanging up right now," says Damon. "Before you hang up, Roger, one last warning. It's a matter of life and death. Your life and your death. You've been warned, Roger. I may not call again."

title: No New Massacre Toll Offered at State Dept.
description: Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said today that officials in Washington had no new or authoritative information on the number of people killed and the number of bodies found at the sites of the massacre in West Beirut.

title: Topics; Devils, Digits and Dials; Sixes
description: As every diabolist knows, the figures 666 signify the Antichrist beast. It is written in Revelation: ''Let him that hath understanding count the number of the beast ... and his number is six hundred threescore and six.''

title: PUERTO RICO SHOULD BE INDEPENDENT, VENEZUELA SAYS AT U.N.
description: Venezuela declared in the General Assembly today that Puerto Rico should be independent of the United States.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT VW OF AMERICA
description: James W. McLernon resigned as president and chief executive officer of Volkswagen of America today, apparently as a result of the company's severely depressed sales.

title: F.C.A.'S GAMBLE ON MORTGAGES
description: While most residential mortgage lenders retreated from the market under the press of high interest rates in the past two years, Charles W. Knapp and the Financial Corporation of America plunged ahead.

title: Fight Fire With Fire on Exports
description: Practically everyone agrees that subsidizing exports with low-cost Government loans is a bad idea. Cheap credit, like any form of export subsidy, is just another ''beggar-thy-neighbor'' policy, creating jobs in one country at the expense of jobs in another. What everyone does not agree about, though, is how to get rid of it.

title: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in extremely quiet trading attributed to the Yom Kippur holiday. At the regular weekly auction of new Treasury bills, rates fell slightly from a week earlier. The three-month issue fell to 7.801 percent from 7.849 percent, while the six-month issue fell to 9.196 percent from 9.443 percent.

title: PACT COULD GIVE NEWS'S WORKERS A SHARE OF PROFIT
description: Workers at The Daily News could get a share of the newspaper's future profits under the terms of a tentative contract settlement reached last weekend.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: Guerrillas in Cambodia Report Killing 30 Vietnamese Troops
description: Cambodian guerrillas said they attacked a checkpoint in western Cambodia last week, killing 30 Vietnamese troops and wounding 50.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, has elected Alain Belda vice president of the company and president of Alcoa Aluminio S.A., a partly owned subsidiary; Richard L. Fischer vice president and deputy general counsel, and Albert E. Germain vice president, taxes and tax counsel.

title: DOCTOR LURED AWAY FROM HOME TWICE AND KNIFED
description: When Dr. Robert Frederick Boedy told newspaper interviewers that he had diagnosed more cancer in 17 months than he expected to find in a decade, he touched off a furor.

title: The Lesson of Representative Lee
description: The Republican primary in New York's newly consolidated 27th Congressional District, which pitted two incumbents against each other, attracted little attention outside the Syracuse area. But George Wortley's razor-thin victory over Representative Gary Lee sends a message their peers would be wise to heed: Opportunistic congressmen who flack for special economic interests may wind up paying with their jobs.

title: DECISION FOR GEMAYEL: INVESTIGATING THE MASSACRE
description: President Amin Gemayel is said by knowledgeable Lebanese officials and foreign diplomats to be about to make important decisions on key issues, including one on the question of a Government investigation into the killings of Palestinian civilians this month.

title: BRAZILIAN LEADER, AT U.N., FORESEES MAJOR DEPRESSION
description: The President of Brazil said today that the world was facing a depression of 1930's magnitude, and he accused the major powers of destroying rather than creating wealth .

title: Investment Chief At Yale Is Leaving
description: Jerald L. Stevens, who has been responsible for Yale University's investments, is leaving to become president and chief operating officer of the Vanguard Group of Investment Companies in Valley Forge, Pa. The group runs 14 mutual funds with $5 billion in assets.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Beatrice Foods Co. filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for $150 million of debt securities and warrants for debt securities, with terms to be set at the time of sale.

title: Harvard Professor Is Chosen As a Deputy Solicitor General
description: The Justice Department is expected to announce this week that Paul M. Bator, a Harvard law professor and expert on the jurisdiction of the Federal courts, will become a deputy solicitor general. Mr. Bator will also be a special counselor to Solicitor General Rex E. Lee.

title: U.S. ASSERTS GAP ON GAS PIPELINE BARS ON ACCORD
description: Differences between the United States and its key allies over the Siberian pipeline sanctions are so wide that they have agreed that there is no point in discussing possible compromises at this time, an American spokesman said yesterday.

title: Southern Bancorp Bid Is Rejected
description: The National Bank of South Carolina said its board had rejected an offer by the Southern Bancorp to acquire up to 51 percent of National Bank's stock at $18 a share.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
UNITS FROM FRANCE AND ITALY ARRIVE IN 2 BEIRUT CAMPS
description: French and Italian soldiers today entered the two Palestinian refugee camps where hundreds of Palestinians were killed by Lebanese Christian militiamen more than a week ago.

title: MEXICO PROTESTS TO GUATEMALA ON INCURSIONS
description: Mexico for the first time has protested publicly about recent incursions into Mexican territory by Guatemalan troops involved in counterinsurgency operations in border regions.

title: CARDINALS CLINCH EASTERN TITLE
description: The St. Louis Cardinals clinched the National League's Eastern Division title tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Expos, last season's division champions.

title: Cribbs in Workout
description: Joe Ferguson led the Buffalo Bills though their first workout since the National Football League players strike began last week, and among those participating was Joe Cribbs, the running back who has been holding out for a new contract. The Bills, dressed in sweatsuits, ran plays but no contact drills for one hour at Erie Community College, across the street from Rich Stadium in Buffalo.

title: INSTILLING THE DESIRE TO READ
description: ''IF we could get our parents to read to their preschool children 15 minutes a day, we could revolutionize the schools,'' says Ruth Love, the superintendent of Chicago's public schools. Jim Trelease agrees, and he has written a handbook on why and how to do it. ''The problem,'' he says, ''is that we have concentrated exclusively on teaching the child how to read, and we have forgotten to teach him to want to read.''

title: Bendix Up 16 3/4 in Dull Market
description: Shares of the Bendix Corporation soared 16 3/4 points yesterday in an otherwise featureless stock market. The dramatic run-up came as the market rendered its verdict on an agreement, announced after the close of trading on Friday, that changed the shape of three major corporations.

title: 2 Executives Leaving Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that two of its top executives in the office systems division in Palo Alto, Calif., had resigned ''to pursue other entrepreneurial interests in the office systems field.''

title: BILL ON TV SHOWS GAINS
description: A bill that would increase the protection of television broadcasters against unauthorized transmission of their programs by cable-television operators has been approved by the House Energy and Commerce Committee and sent to the House.

title: COVERLY FISCHER
description: Coverly Fischer, a former president of the Home Title Guaranty Company of New York, died yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and had resided in Southbury for 12 years.

title: ARAPAHO PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The present economic policy of the great powers is destroying riches without building anything in their place.'' - President Joao Baptista Figueiredo of Brazil. A10:6.)

title: JUST ANOTHER LITTLE PARTY By Charlotte Curtis
description: MR. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney were in town the other night, and, after August at Saratoga and a respite in the Adirondacks, they gathered up their pals for one of those intimate little dinners New Yorkers are forever aspiring to attend.

title: Burroughs Adds A Small Computer
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would sell a new entry-level computer system of smaller size and higher performance in its mediumto large-scale computer line.

title: CHINA SEEMS COOL TO SOVIET OVERTURES
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang was quoted today as having said that China's attitude toward the Soviet Union had not changed, despite expectations here of new contacts between the two Communist neighbors.

title: GOODBYE TO STARGELL IN METS' VICTORY
description: It was a moment of drama in a game of little significance to both teams. It was the ninth inning, two out, two men on base, the Pirates trailing last night by three runs. Willie Stargell, age 41, strode forward as a pinch-hitter, the tying run at the plate.

title: President Will Hold News Session Tonight
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference at the White House at 7:30 tonight, his aides announced.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Ex-Premier Testifies At Moro Murder Trial
description: Former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said today that his Government had feared that the kidnapping of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro in 1978 might be part of a plot to start a revolution.

title: CANADIAN FOOTBALL DONE WELL BY NBC
description: S ome people cannot imagine a Sunday afternoon in autumn without professional football. NBC Sports couldn't abide the idea, either, so, with the National Football League idled by its player strike, the network headed north last weekend for two games from the Canadian Football League. The assumption that football was essential - were other, intriguing events available? - might be debatable, but NBC did a good job with its six-and-a-half-hour presentation.

title: YANKS, INDIANS GRANTED CHANCE TO TALK TO MARTIN
description: The Yankees and the Indians have requested and received permission from the Oakland A's to negotiate with Billy Martin about leaving his fifth-place team and managing next year in New York or Cleveland.

title: Small-College TV Set
description: Searching to fill the programming void caused by the National Football League players' strike, CBS-TV today received approval from the National Collegiate Athletic Association to televise four Division III football games Sunday.

title: WEICKER AND MOFFETT TRADE VIEWS ON DEFENSE IN CONNECTICUT DEBATE
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Representative Toby Moffett sought to stress their differences on defense issues last night in their second of six televised debates with two other candidates for the United States Senate from Connecticut.

title: Berlin Philharmonic Revises Program
description: The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, under the direction of Herbert von Karajan, has announced a change in the program of its first concert on Oct. 19 in Carnegie Hall.

title: PESTICIDE BARRED IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: It is never easy to be a peach grower in South Carolina, but to many growers it seems that this year has been particularly difficult.

title: A TROIKA OF FORECASTERS
description: They are like sculptors' assistants, people who cut a block of marble into the rough form of the finished work. The assistants, in this instance, are three little-known men who have just begun preparing the economic forecast that will become the foundation of the Reagan Administration's budget for the fiscal year 1984.

title: Another Streak
description: Eastern Michigan University has dismissed Mike Stock as its football coach - two days after the Hurons lost their 22d consecutive game and inherited the nation's longest losing streak. When Northwestern won Saturday it ended the previous longest streak at 34 games.

title: Murderer in Missouri Wants Early Execution
description: A man who wants to die before his 3-year-old daughter is old enough to understand his crime should be granted his wish, an assistant prosecutor argued today.

title: CARACAS DOLLAR ACTION
description: The Government today ordered all state-owned enterprises, including the lucrative oil industry, to give control of foreign currency reserves to the central bank of Venezuela in a move aimed at strengthening the country's finances.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WHITE WAY

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: heeled chic and an enduring effervescence. Should they visit Milan today, however, they would discover that their fantasies do not have a heel to stand on. Milan has probably never looked more pared down. Perhaps ''austere'' is a better word. Whatever word one uses, it is evident that the residents of a city known for its flourish with fashion are holding back.

title: Bankruptcy Plan
description: Continental Mortgage Investors, which has been operating since 1976 under Chapter 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said that the Guardian Industries Corporation was seeking to reduce terms of a $25 million investment proposal to aid Continental's reorganization plan.

title: News Analysis
description: In the hue and cry over the massacre in Beirut's Palestinian camps, few voices have sounded as shrill and furious as Moscow's.

title: L.I. Sound Ferry To Speed Service
description: A new 276-foot ferryboat will be added next year by the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company, which will be celebrating its 100th season as a link between Connecticut and Long Island.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
AIDE SAYS REAGAN VISIT FOR LEHRMAN IS UNLIKELY
description: President Reagan is not expected to visit New York State in support of Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, according to Richard B. Wirthlin, the pollster for both the President and Mr. Lehrman.

title: British Soldier Killed by Bomb Hidden in a Barrier in Belfast
description: A British soldier was killed today by a bomb hidden in a security barrier, the police said.

title: Precious Metals Slump On Outlook for Rates
description: The spot September gold and silver futures contracts expired yesterday amid plunging prices on New York's Commodity Exchange. Copper futures, including the expired September delivery, declined in sympathy with gold and silver.

title: BRITISH LABORITES MOVE AGAINST LEFT
description: The Labor Party, after a tumultuous debate today, approved a measure designed to purge key members of its extreme left wing in the hope of improving its chances of winning the next general election.

title: CRAWFORD ENERGY INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Shcharansky Said to Start Hunger Strike in Prison
description: Anatoly Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, began an indefinite hunger strike today because of repeated confiscation of his mail, his mother reported.

title: RUFFLES AND GLITTER APLENTY AT FIRST PARTIES OF FALL
description: It started, as usual, the week after Labor Day. The fall season began slowly, but soon the pace accelerated, so that by the third week in September, anyone in the social set who wanted to go out every night in New York had the opportunity to do so.

title: A PLAYFUL '57 DOCUMENTARY ON SIBERIA
description: A FILM about Siberia making virtually no mention of the region's political history would seem to be on the frivolous side. But Chris Marker's ''Letter From Siberia'' is a cinematic essay with many eccentricities, and this is only one of them. Mr. Marker, who made this film in 1957 and is now best known for his 1976 ''The Battle of Chile,'' uses this hourlong documentary as an opportunity to describe Siberia playfully. Improbable as this may sound, Mr. Marker manages it wittily and well.

title: CONSUMER CHALLENGE
description: To the Editor:

title: RECLUSIVE PANDAS BEGIN TO REVEAL PRIVATE LIVES
description: Many years ago a young girl grew up in the company of giant pandas who then were all white. One day as she was playing with her animal friends, a leopard attacked a baby panda, The girl fought to defend it, and saved its life, but in the process she herself was badly wounded and died. Other pandas heard of her bravery, and came down from the mountains to pay her tribute. They wore black on their shoulders, arms and legs to show their grief, and, when they wept, they rubbed their eyes with their front paws and created eye patches; they put their heads in their paws, making their noses black, and then reached up and stained their ears. That is how the panda got its distinctive markings. - ANCIENT CHINESE LEGEND By BAYARD WEBSTER

title: Fahd Pledges to Aid Lebanon
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia pledged financial aid for the reconstruction of Lebanon today and called on Islamic nations to give all possible help to the Palestine Liberation Organization. He also called for an end to the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.

title: Chewing for Good Teeth
description: The high incidence of displaced teeth and misshapen jaws among Americans that has made many orthodontists rich and parents poor may be the consequence of our highly refined diet, according to a new study in monkeys.

title: Wienerwald Will Go On
description: Wienerwald, the international restaurant concern that owns the Lum's and International House of Pancakes chains in the United States, will be able to keep operating under a court decision made public today that gives it time to work out a deal with its creditors.

title: ALLYN COX, 86, PAINTER OF MURALS FOR U.S. CAPITOL
description: Allyn Cox, a prominent American mural painter whose work adorns the rotunda and corridors of the United States Capitol in Washington and a former member of the New York City Art Commission, died Sunday at the Washington Medical Center. He was 86 years old and had recently lived in the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lodging a Small Claim To Judicial Respect

title: Carpenter Stays In the Running
description: The running back Rob Carpenter has yet to report to the Giants this season because of his contract impasse. But Carpenter's name appears on a list of three Giant nominees for the National Football League's Man of the Year award.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1982; Companies
description: Federal bank regulators have referred 30 cases in the collapse of Penn Square of Oklahoma to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution, according to confidential documents obtained by a House panel. They show a wide range of potential violations, including kickbacks, misapplication of bank funds, fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property. (Page A1.)

title: P.L.O. AIDE KILLED IN AMBUSH
description: Abu Walid, chief of military operations for the Palestine Liberation Organization, was killed in the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon today when his group was ambushed, a P.L.O. spokesman here said.

title: TAKEOVERS SPUR MORE 'PARACHUTES'
description: As a result of the recent upsurge in hostile corporate takeover bids, 15 percent of the nation's largest companies have installed ''golden parachute'' employment contracts for top management, according to a survey released yesterday by Ward Howell International Inc., an executive search firm.

title: THE WARSAW PUGWASH CONFERENCE DID NOT 'COWER' TO THE SOVIETS
description: To the Editor:

title: DODGERS DEFEATED, ARE TIED FOR FIRST
description: The possibility of southern California's first freeway World Series has run into an unexpected and severe traffic problem.

title: THEATER: AN EDITED TENNESSEE WILLIAMS
description: IF Tennessee Williams wants to depend on the kindness of strangers, that's his business -but perhaps he should get references first. In ''a/k/a Tennessee,'' which opened at the South Street Theater Sunday night, the playwright has permitted some well-meaning but misguided souls to create a trivial, anthological revue out of his life's work.

title: GUBERNATORIAL ELECTION IN OREGON EXPECTED TO FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY
description: Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh could lose his re-election campaign because of a sagging economy that he says has been weakened by President Reagan's decision not to strive for a balanced Federal budget.

title: RONCO TELEPRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes a nonrecurring credit of $751,520 from previously deferred income taxes relating to recently passed legislation in the United Kingdom

title: Apartment Employees Ratify Bronx Contract
description: Members of Local 32E of the Service Employees International Union have ratified a new contract with the Bronx Realty Advisory Board that will provide wage increases of $65 a week over three and a half years, a union spokesman, Armand Politucci, said yesterday.

title: Western Loan For Hungary
description: Central banks of Western industrialized nations agreed today to grant Hungary $300 million of short-term credit to help it cope with a cash crisis.

title: Bankruptcy Rumor Denied at Republic
description: In an unusual action, the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker in terms of tonnage, ''flatly and categorically'' denied what it termed continuing rumors that it was giving any consideration to filing for bankruptcy.

title: No Practice
description: A rifle-shooting team from the Falklands Islands has gone to Brisbane, Australia, for the Commonwealth Games, a multisport, Olympic-type competition among British Commonwealth countries that starts Thursday.

title: Garvey Sought Labor Support
description: The strike by the National Football League Players Association comes after several months of diligent effort by the union to establish friendly ties to other labor organizations.

title: U.S. JEWS AND ISRAEL: THE BASIC CONSENSUS
description: To the Editor:

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Arbed Plans Restructuring
description: The Luxembourg Government, trade unions and Arbed S.A. agreed on a steel industry modernization plan requiring major new public subsidies, according to Prime Minister Pierre Werner.

title: Stopping to Pray
description: She was getting ready for this Saturday's Avon half-marathon in Central Park, doing her customary jogging in McCarren Park in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Glimmer of Commerce On the Street of Diamonds

title: Bathurst Price
description: Consolidated Bathurst Inc., a Montreal paper maker, said it would increase its prices for newsprint sold in the United States by 4 percent, to $520 a ton, from $500, effective Jan. 1. Canadian prices will remain unchanged, it said.

title: Italian Premier to Visit U.S.
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy will visit Washington on Nov. 3 and 4 to meet with President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other senior officials, the White House announced today.

title: NEW N.F.L. TALKS SET FOR THURSDAY
description: Though neither side was pleased by the results of the most recent negotiations meeting, held Sunday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., representatives of the pro football players and management agreed yesterday to try again.

title: Chrysler Begins Search For Additional Agency
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was beginning a ''closed and confidential'' search that should turn up an agency for its Dodge division within the next 30 to 45 days.

title: St. Regis Tax Gain
description: The St. Regis Paper Company said it had received about $38 million in cash from the sale of accelerated depreciation tax benefits, which would result in a $1-a-share gain in the third quarter. The transaction was a tax benefit transfer related to the expansion of certain manufacturing facilities, the company said.

title: FINAL SALUTE TO CARLOS ALBERTO
description: Carlos Alberto practiced with the Cosmos for the last time today in preparation for his last game for them. The way he had made order out of chaos in the Cosmos' defense will be remembered for a long time, according to Franz Beckenbauer.

title: WOMAN, 81, IS FOUND SLAIN IN 'VILLAGE' APARTMENT
description: An 81-year-old woman who lived in a historic building across from Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village was found dead in her apartment yesterday. The police said she apparently had been killed during a robbery.

title: MISUNDERSTOOD FLY BALL
description: Q uestion: When an outfielder catches a fly, how long must he hold the ball to make it an official out? Answer, according to the baseball rule book: ''It is not a catch if, simultaneously or immediately following his contact with the ball, he collides with another player or with the wall or if he falls down and, as a result of such collision or falling down, drops the ball.''

title: DEVILS, DIGITS AND DIALS; Reach Out
description: Chapter One: Editorial writer needs new extension phone for home. Learns that New York Bell now sells plain rotary-dial handsets for $45.

title: Midland Bank Purchase
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. said today that it had acquired a 69 percent stake in Handelsfinanz Bank, a Geneva-based commercial bank, from Banca Commerciale Italiana. The terms were not disclosed. Industry sources valued the deal at about $25 million.

title: 'TEX,' PARENTLESS BOYS IN OKLAHOMA
description: AN an unexpected but certainly major force in movies at the moment, S.E. Hinton (with four of her novels being adapted for the screen), created in ''Tex'' an utterly disarming, believable portrait of a small-town adolescent. Tim Hunter's film version captures Miss Hinton's novel perfectly. If the movie does nothing else, it will make a star out of Matt Dillon, who plays its moody, vulnerable hero, and it will forever alter the way moviegoers think about Walt Disney pictures. ''Tex'' may be a Walt Disney production, and it may be about young characters as they come of age, but it is by no means a film that only teen-agers might enjoy.

title: Searle Sweetener
description: G.D. Searle & Company said today that it had filed a petition with the Food and Drug Administration for the use of its low-calorie sweetener, aspartame, in carbonated beverages, under the brand name Nutrasweet. If approved, the United States would become the third country in which aspartame would be available in soft drinks. The sweetener has already been approved for use in Canada and South Africa.

title: U.S. INDICTMENT NAMES 5 PERSONS IN F.A.L.N. CASE
description: Five advocates of Puerto Rican independence who refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the F.A.L.N., the terrorist group seeking such independence, have been indicted on charges of criminal contempt of court, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: International Prize Won By Rumanian Violinist
description: A 23-year-old violinist from Rumania has won the first prize in the first quadrennial International Violin Competition of Indianapolis. The prize includes $10,000, a gold medal, a Carnegie Hall recital in May, a recital at the Library of Congress, appearances with orchestras and chamber groups in 38 United States and 4 Canadian cities, two recordings released on the Vox Cum Laude label and concerts and recitals in Europe.

title: Bankruptcy Courts Are Going Bust
description: As if the soaring rate of business failures was not enough cause for worry, the Federal bankruptcy courts themselves are in danger of going under. If something isn't done within the week, those courts will lose their powers, including the power to rescue some companies capable of recovering.

title: U.S. Carrier Leaves Port
description: The United States aircraft carrier America sailed from this southern English port today, four days ahead of schedule, for an undisclosed destination, port authorities said. They said the conventionally powered carrier had been due to stay in the Solent Waterway, off the English Channel, for a week of shore leave for her crew of 5,000 but left after only three days.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Import Duties Asked on Bikes
description: Four major United States bicycle makers today asked the Government to investigate charges that bicyles imported from South Korea and Taiwan had taken an unfair share of the American market. The companies want the Government to impose countervailing duties.

title: RAISIN INDUSTRY TELLS OF ITS LOSSES FROM RAINS
description: Torrential rains that fell recently have wiped out much of the country's new raisin crop and struck hard at the canning tomato crop, industry officials said today.

title: MINE UNION CHALLENGER COUNTERS ACCUSATION
description: Richard L. Trumka, the insurgent challenger for the presidency of the United Mine Workers whose eligibility to run for office has been under attack, said today that he had obtained what he called ''irrefutable'' evidence that he has worked seven years in the mines.

title: BRIEFING
description: Gain for Homosexuals

title: ROOKIE OFFICER QUICK TO MAKE LASTING MARK
description: Precinct 23 - One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically When Mitchell Kolpan, a 24-year-old Manhattan doorman, took the Civil Service test in 1981 to become a police officer, several thousand other candidates scored higher than he did. His record during six months in the Police Academy earlier this year was no better than average.

title: Congressman and 120 Arrested at PCB Protest
description: About 120 people, including the District of Columbia's Delegate to Congress, were arrested today in a protest against the dumping of PCB-tainted soil at the Warren County landfill.

title: Morgan Stanley Aide Knows Forest Products
description: Morgan Stanley has hired Donald P. Brennan to head a newly formed group that will specialize as investment bankers to the forest products industry.

title: No Headline
description: Football Ratings; WRITERS POLL

title: Pastor Who Was Shot Gives Leads to Police
description: The pastor of a Bedford church who was shot in the head and stomach at his office in the church last Friday has given the police ''a few more leads'' on his assailant, a police spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bekins Co. said its Ace Termite and Pest Control Co. subsidiary had acquired Bead Termite Control Co. of North Hollywood, Calif., for an undisclosed price.

title: St. Louis Area Black Leaders Demur on Boycott of Busch
description: An organization representing 30,000 blacks has denounced a boycott against Anheuser-Busch organized by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and his Operation PUSH.

title: FOR REPUBLICANS: ONE ELECTION, TWO CAMPAIGNS
description: Between Congress and the White House, there are two sometimes conflicting Republican campaigns this year, and only one of them is sure of its themes.

title: Chilean Triumphs
description: Hans Gildemeister of Chile defeated Pablo Arraya of Peru, 7-5, 6-2, today in the final of the $75,000 Bordeaux Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 28, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: German Parts for Pipeline
description: West German industry plans to defy a United States ban by shipping compressor stations this week for the Soviet natural gas pipeline, West German officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: DISCARDING CAMPAIGN TRASH
description: There would be little need for remembrances of things past, such as elections, if people didn't keep doing post-mortems that jar common sense.

title: Kean Spurs Drive For Prison Bonds
description: Governor Kean announced today the formation of Citizens for a Secure New Jersey to work for public approval of a $170 million prison construction bond issue on the Nov. 2 ballot.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company noted that in 1982 it adopted the new F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 which deals with foreign currency exchange translation; the yr ago shr earnings are restated for 10 percent stock divd declared yesterday

title: 5,200 Workers Approve Pact At General Dynamics Plants
description: About 5,200 employees of the General Dynamics Corporation put down picket signs and returned to the assembly line today after aproval of a contract calling for substantial increases in wages and benefits.

title: EDUCATION
description: THEY are everywhere - people who have the ability to read, but never look between the covers of a book, seldom glance beyond the headlines of a newspaper and search only for the pictures in magazines. Their reading centers around the bare essentials: road signs, labels on food packages, television listings and product instructions.

title: Airwick Shifts Account To Drossman Yustein
description: Drossman Yustein Clowes has just about doubled its Airwick Industry billings, to $10 million, because the client decided to consolidate its Consumer Products division advertising.

title: REAGAN TO MEET WITH MEXICAN PRESIDENT-ELECT
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan will meet with President-elect Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado of Mexico on Oct. 8 in San Diego for an informal, private discussion.

title: China and Angola Plan Talks On Setting Up of Embassies
description: China and Angola have agreed to mutual diplomatic recognition and will start talks immediately on the establishment of embassies, the official Angolan press agency said today.

title: People
description: * Gerald D. Oakes named executive vice president of Spiro & Associates, Philadelphia.

title: Beckman Instruments Shuffles Top Managers
description: Beckman Instruments Inc. has appointed three of its top executives to new positions. William F. Ballhaus, 64, Beckman's president, was named vice chairman and chief executive officer.

title: 2 Accidents Snarl Jersey Rush Hour
description: Two accidents involving tractor-trailers on New Jersey highways tied up morning commuter traffic yesterday and injured two persons, authorities said.

title: VALERIE BETTIS, CHOREOGRAPHER AND MODERN DANCER, IS DEAD
description: Valerie Bettis, a dancer and choreographer noted for her versatility, vivid stage presence and flamboyant theatricality, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital after a brief illness. She was 62 years old.

title: Van Brunt & Co. Adds Two Travel Accounts
description: For the management of Van Brunt & Company, vacation planning became that much more difficult yesterday as the agency picked up two more travel-oriented accounts to add to the seven it already had.

title: U.S. SAYS 1,200 MARINES MAY JOIN BEIRUT FORCE
description: The number of United States Marines expected to land in Beirut this week could reach 1,200, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: More Concorde Flights Are Cut
description: Air France announced today that it would stop supersonic Concorde flights from Paris to Washington on Oct. 29 and to Mexico City two days later.

title: Nuclear Fallout Trial Hears Cancer Victims
description: Plaintiffs today tearfully described repeated bouts with cancer that they say was caused by above-ground nuclear tests, as a lawsuit entered its third week in Federal court here.

title: Seoul Police Break Up Protests by Students
description: Riot policemen broke up student demonstrations today that criticized the Governments of South Korea, the United States and Japan.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
JERSEY PITCHER A GEM FOR METS
description: M ost Met fans know all about Darryl Strawberry. Big. A powerhitter. The team's No.1 draft choice of 1980 who has become the hope of the future.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Morgan Hires Bond Official
description: Arthur J. Kalita, executive director of the Public Securities Association, is leaving to work in the public finance department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: GUYANA OUTBACK A LURE TO MINERS AND VENEZUELA
description: This place, which looks deceptively like the middle of nowhere, is at the center of a gold rush, an oil find, a uranium expedition, a diamond cache, a manganese mine, a timber trove and an international dispute.

title: Chinese and American Scientists Hold 'Milestone' Conference
description: Chinese botanists meeting with American counterparts say their trip marks a ''milestone'' in scientific cooperation and has given them a chance to study plants they have never seen.

title: Wallin of Rangers Assigned to Tulsa
description: The Rangers trimmed their roster to 31 players yesterday by assigning Peter Wallin, Mike Backman, Pat Conacher and Gary Burns - all forwards - to Tulsa, their top farm team in the Central Hockey League.

title: WHAT'S THE REAL MEANING OF 'CASABLANCA'? OR OF A ROSE?
description: WHAT does it mean when a man wears cowboy boots, even though he lives in a city? Why do advertisements often show laughing young women being carried piggy-back by young men? And what accounts for the extraordinarily enduring appeal of the movie ''Casablanca''?

title: OHIO WINS BID FOR HARVESTER OVER OLD FORT WAYNE PLANT
description: A yearlong bidding war over International Harvester's domestic truck assembly operations ended today when the ailing company announced that it would phase out its Fort Wayne truck assembly plant and consolidate operations at its more modern Springfield, Ohio, facility.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE RULES EX-SPY MUST STAND TRIAL
description: A Federal district judge rejected arguments today that the Government illegally lured Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency operative, from his haven in Libya to an arrest in New York City.

title: CENTURA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Revs figures exclude discontinued operations and net losses reflect discontinued operations

title: Johns Hopkins Giving Contraceptives to Pupils
description: Johns Hopkins Hospital is distributing free contraceptives to junior and senior high school students here who participate in a sex education program aimed at curbing teen-age pregnancies.

title: British Air Cuts Routes
description: British Airways today announced plans to eliminate 17 routes and close seven offices. The Government-owned airline, trying to become profitable after a period of large losses that included a 1981 deficit of $254 million, said it hoped the cuts would save $17 million.

title: GERMAN STOCKS AND MARK FALL
description: Prices on the Frankfurt stock exchange tumbled today in what bankers said was the sharpest drop in the postwar era, and the value of the mark fell to its lowest point against the dollar in 13 months.

title: U.S. JEWS AND ISRAEL: THE BASIC CONSENSUS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MIGHT SUPPORT ANTIBUSING MOVES
description: The Justice Department said today that it might support the legal efforts of some local school boards to modify judicial decrees that require busing as a means of school desegregation.

title: Papal Official Replaced
description: Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, organizer of Pope John Paul II's previous foreign trips, has been replaced as Vatican coordinator of the coming papal visit to Spain, Vatican sources said today.

title: REALTY GROUPS' SUIT ON RENT RISE LIMITS DISMISSED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit by real estate groups that sought to require the Rent Guidelines Board to reconsider the amount of rent increases allowed for rent-stabilized apartments in New York City.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $117,000 for the qr , a tax credit of $2,150,000 in the yr and losses from discontinued operations of $34,000 for the qr and$143,000 for the yr...C-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $281,000 and a loss of $59,000 from discontinued operations...D-Including a tax credit of

title: LABORATORY OFFERS ANSWERS ON THE NATURE OF STREET DRUGS
description: When anxious parents or nervous drug users want to know what kind of drug they have on hand, they send a sample to Street Pharmacology Laboratories, which is one of the rare laboratories licensed to identify drugs for clients who do not have to give their names.

title: BURIED 4 DAYS, ABDUCTION VICTIM FEARED HE WOULD DIE IF HE SLEPT
description: A 20-year-old man who was kidnapped and buried alive for four days in a coffin-like box with a bottle of water and a loaf of bread says he was poked by nails, bitten by insects and terrified of dying if he fell asleep.

title: MARIETTA CHIEF CONCEDES BATTLE CAUSED DAMAGE
description: Thomas G. Pownall, president of the Martin Marietta Corporation, acknowledged today that his company had been financially hurt by the takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation, but he said it could recover through possible divestitures, debt restructuring and the sale of securities.

title: YANKS GET 6 IN FIRST AND ROUT RED SOX
description: The Yankees jumped on Brian Denman, the Red Sox' rookie starter, for six first-inning runs tonight and cruised to a 10-3 victory behind the pitching of Dave Righetti.

title: CABLE TV PROGRAMMERS FIND PROBLEMS AMID FAST GROWTH
description: Two years ago, cable television prompted all the unquestioning passion of a first love. Drawn by the potential of a new technology, large corporations rushed to promise lavish 100-channel systems and networks that offered everything from 24-hour news to banking and ballets. Euphoria eventually collides with reality, however, and during the last several months the practical prob-lems of building an industry have begun to command as much attention as its continuing opportunities. The concerns are focused not so much on the cable systems through which programming is delivered to subscribers, but on the prospects for individual programming services.

title: MARIN TESTS WITS IN POLITICAL ARENA
description: It was inevitable, particularly in North Carolina, where basketball is akin to religion, that the television commercials of the Congressional candidate Jack Marin would be virtually devoid of political content. After all, Marin's views on the issues were not what set him apart from the two other conservatives seeking the Republican nomination from the state's Second District. Nor were they what won the political novice the support of the nation's largest political action committee, Senator Jesse Helms's National Congressional Club.

title: OHIO SUPERMARKET IS SELLING INSURANCE AND MUTUAL FUNDS
description: The Kroger Company, a supermarket chain with 1,200 food stores and 500 pharmacies in 21 states in the South and the Middle West, has begun selling insurance, money market funds, mutual funds and individual retirement accounts in one of its stores.

title: The 1982 Election: Illinois - Second of 10 articles appearing periodically on states with important gubernatorial races.
description: Near the center of this central state is a tiny town named Carlock where livestock easily outnumber the 450 human residents. Yet this small farming community maintains two large cemeteries.

title: Courtney Sale, Film Maker, Is Fiancee of Steven J. Ross
description: Steven J. Ross, chairman and chief executive of Warner Communications Inc., and Courtney Sale, a producer of documentary films dealing with art, plan to be married Oct. 10 at the Plaza Hotel.

title: VIOLINIST: ANDOR TOTH
description: THERE is no direct correlation between talent and constant concert appearances in New York. Proof of that came last Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House, where the violinist Andor Toth gave his first New York recital in four years.

title: DEBUT OF LIFE, WITHOUT THE GAMBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIAL SET TO BEGIN IN JUDGE'S KILLING
description: On May 29, l979, Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., known as ''Maximum John'' because of the long sentences he gave drug dealers, stepped into his station wagon to drive to his office and begin work.

title: Talking Business With Bjorndahl of Security Pacific; Consumer Loan Rates
description: Consumers are often cited by economists as the key to economic recovery. If the average American were to increase his spending, especially for big items, the entire economy would benefit, the economists say. But some fear that the high cost of consumer credit is discouraging such spending.

title: Europe's Inflation Ebbs
description: Inflation in the European Economic Community declined to 10.7 percent in the 12 months ended in August, down from 11 percent in July and the lowest for three years, the community's statistics office reported.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The small journeys began yesterday in the morning, a short time after sunrise. In clusters the people set off on foot, coming together at intersections and on busy corners, in their best clothes. Some of the men carried the embroidered velvet pouches in which reposed the striped tallit; some of the women carried their children, to expose them before the age of intellect to the emotions of their religion, and their tradition. On the West Side, some of them arrived at last at an orange brick temple called Ansche Chesed on the corner of 100th Street and West End Avenue, feeling joy in their own numbers on a day set aside for repentance and reflection.

title: Chess: Kasparov Wins in Moscow; Belyavsky Also Advances
description: Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union, at 19 the youngest grandmaster, won the third Interzonal Tournament, in Moscow, with a blazing 10-3 score.

title: QUESTIONS RISING OVER U.S. STUDY AND ROLE OF COMPANY EXECUTIVES
description: Scores of business executives who are working with a Presidential commission to help reduce the cost of government have been assigned to examine agencies that regulate the executives' corporations.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Class A common...C-Class B

title: NOBELISTS SAY U.S. AID WAS VITAL TO WORK
description: A poll of American Nobel Prize winners in science, conducted by Senator John Glenn, indicates that Federal financial support was vital to the work of the majority of them.

title: Alcan to Shut Plant
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd.'s West German unit, Alcan Aluminiumwerke G.m.b.H., said today that it would close its Ludwigshafen aluminium plant. It said electricity prices offered to it under a new contract are too high to allow the works to remain competitive. The plant is currently operating at its full capacity of 44,000 metric tons of primary aluminium a year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Electoral Lineup

title: MUSIC: TERRY RILEY USES A QUARTET
description: TERRY RILEY'S ''In C,'' which was composed 18 years ago, was for most listeners an introduction to minimalism and repetition in new music. Since its appearance on a Columbia Masterworks disk, its admirers have been awaiting a sequel.

title: Alexander Seeks Bank
description: In a swift move to recover some $7 million of diverted funds from former officials of the Alexander Howden Group P.L.C., Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. is attempting to gain control of a small bank in Switzerland in which those officials hold an 83 percent stake.

title: SURGERY FOR HARRAH
description: TOBY HARRAH, the Cleveland Indians' third baseman who has played in 457 consecutive games, is scheduled to undergo heart surgery on Monday, the day after the baseball season ends, at the Cleveland Clinic. Harrah said the surgery would be to correct a heart murmur that he has had for some time. "I was told it is a relatively safe operation, and I will be out of the hospital in five days to a week," he said. ... Rollie Fingers, the Brewers' best relief pitcher, who has been out of action since Sept. 2 because of a muscle tear in his pitching arm, said he may be ready to play this weekend in Milwaukee's four-game series against Baltimore that could decide the winner of the American League's Eastern Division.... The Detroit Tigers plan on retiring the uniform numbers of two former stars, No. 2 for Charlie Gehringer and No. 5 worn by Hank Greenberg.

title: Market Place; Data Services: Varied Niches
description: COMPANIES that provide information services have been good performers lately in the stock market. And the word from the Value Line Investment Survey, an advisory service, is that future prospects appear bright for selected purveyors of information.

title: Ralph N. Baldwin, a Trainer Of 2 Hambletonian Winners
description: Ralph N. Baldwin, who trained two winners of the Hambletonian, died Sunday morning in Pompano Beach, Fla., after a long illness, the United States Trotting Association said today. Mr. Baldwin was 66 years old.

title: I.B.M. 'STING' ROLE ASSAILED BY HITACHI
description: In a brief to be filed in the Federal court here Wednesday, lawyers for Japan's Hitachi Ltd. accuse the International Business Machines Corporation of playing an ''improper role in orchestrating a criminal investigation and resulting indictment for anticompetitive and other purposes.''

title: Building Better Waterholes
description: Tailor-made artificial watering holes that save rainfall are spelling survival for wildlife and livestock in at least four Western states, according to a study by the Agricultural Research Service of the Department of Agriculture. Experiments have shown that as much as 90 percent of rainfall in a specified area can be captured and stored in the artificial waterholes, losing only a fraction to evaporation.

title: GAF Pension Plan
description: The GAF Corporation said it would terminate its pension plan for salaried employees and substitute an improved benefits program that offered immediate vesting.

title: Angels Top Royals, Lead by 4 1/2 Games
description: What Tommy John wanted most a month ago was a new place to pitch, preferably in California. John got his wish, and more, when the Yankees traded him to the California Angels on Aug. 31. He became involved in a pennant race and tonight he helped the Angels take another step toward the American League West title when he defeated the Royals, 3-2.

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $802,877 for the qr and $1,592,877 for the yr...C-Net income

title: TV: TOM SELLECK STARS IN A WESTERN ROMP
description: ''THE SHADOW RIDERS,'' tonight's movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock, takes a number of solid ingredients and comes up with the kind of neat western romp that supposedly isn't being made anymore.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT HITS $7.1 BILLION
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit soared to a record $7.1 billion in August, widened by a renewed American appetite for foreign-made goods, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HOUSE UNIT PUTS OFF WORK ON MILITARY MONEY BILL
description: Thwarting the wishes of the White House, a House subcommittee today accelerated the struggle among the House, the Senate and the President over military spending.

title: SCOUTING
description: Chinese Flavor Since this is the Chinese Year of the Dog, the Suffolk County Kennel Club's 44th annual all-breed show in Lake Grove on Saturday will have a decidedly Oriental flair for the 1,154 entries.

title: POTVIN HELPS ISLANDERS WIN
description: Denis Potvin, the Islanders' all-star defenseman who missed a week of training camp because of a contract impasse, returned to the lineup tonight in typical style. He scored the Islanders' first goal as they beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-3, in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: 1. Past Glories
description: Should you pay a visit to Sylvia Pines's Uniquities? Yes and no. Yes, if you want to see a stunning array of antique evening bags and antique and Art Deco jewelry. No, if you don't want to be tempted beyond endurance. The jewelry is too varied to be summed up briefly. The bags are guaranteed to snaffle all the fashion attention at any party. The beaded bags, most of them handmade and one of a kind, go back to the Victorian period and up to the flapper era. The prices range from $40 to about $200. There are also some wonderful bags with marquisette sterling frames (a few also have semiprecious stones). The bag part of a good many of these has to be redone, but the frames are knockouts. These range from $250 to $600. The shop is at 1102 Lexington Avenue (77th Street).

title: ROLLS-ROYCE CHAIRMAN
description: William Duncan, the 59-year-old deputy chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, will become chairman of Rolls-Royce Ltd., Britain's state-owned producer of aircraft engines. Next April the Scot will succeed Lord McFadzean, 66, who will retire after having been chairman since 1980. Mr. Duncan will begin a five-year term in which he hopes to see the company begin moving toward denationalization.

title: Remember Crime Victims
description: With plenty of reason, crime victims liken themselves to the patients of a doctor who focuses so much on the technical problem of curing disease that he ignores his patients' feelings. Courts and prosecutors, the victims say, pay attention to the victim only as he may help prosecute the case; otherwise they treat him with indifference.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $437,534 from the extinguishment of debt

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RAW CLAMS IMPLICATED IN HEPATITIS CASES
description: IT was not a good summer for New Yorkers who like their clams on the half shell. At least 40 of them became seriously ill with hepatitis A, and raw clams have been implicated. Victims of hepatitis A, a viral disease that inflames the liver, are incapacitated for two weeks to two months; some of the most severe cases must be hospitalized. Raw clams have also been blamed for 300 to 400 cases of gastroenteritis, a mild influenzalike illness. The figure may be far higher because most of those afflicted think they have a stomach virus.

title: A.C.L.U. Says Abscam Inquiry Became 'Fishing Expedition'
description: The Government's Abscam investigation into corruption by members of Congress and other public officials was a ''fishing expedition'' that violated the rights of innocent people, the American Civil Liberties Union said today.

title: Eastern Air Keeps Plan to Buy Jets
description: Eastern Airlines will proceed with its plan to buy five of the Boeing Company's 757-225 jets at a cost of $426 million, an airline spokesman said.

title: SHULTZ THE HOST AT GROMYKO TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz conferred for three hours today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union on the range of issues that divide their countries, and they agreed to meet again next Monday.

title: POLITICS ON FRENCH TV: NOT HOW MUCH BUT WHOSE
description: A year and a half into Socialism, French television has not become so politicized that it could not offer 40 minutes of its taxpayer-s@upported time recently for the definitive program on the history of the garter belt. But the politics is there.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aeicor Inc. said it would hold a special shareholders meeting Dec. 17 to consider a recapitalization plan under which common stock will be issued and exchanged for all of Aeicor's series A and B preferred.

title: 2 Suspects Are Arrested In Attack on Policeman
description: Two Queens men who the police said were members of a gang of four or five armed and masked men who attacked a police officer in the driveway of his Flushing, Queens, home on Friday were arrested yesterday.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a goodwill writeoff of $1,890,350

title: Bolivian Debt Payments
description: Bolivia will stop all payments on its foreign debt until the new civilian Government takes office on Oct.10.

title: G.O.P. FUND RAISING IS GOOD FOR AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * The State of Alaska has tentatively scheduled for Oct. 20 a sale of $185 million of bonds maturing from 1983 to 1993.

title: FAMILIES EAGER TO GREET ASIAN-BORN OFFSPRING
description: Ruth Everton of Sacramento, Calif., is among the Americans expecting to greet some of the half-Vietnamese children arriving in this country next week, but the children are not hers. They are her grandson and granddaughter, children of her son, Dennis, a civilian aircraft mechanic who was killed in an airplane accident in Vietnam in 1972.

title: Arrest in Attack on Priest
description: The police have arrested a 15-year-old boy in an attack on a 68-year-old Roman Catholic priest in which the priest's throat was slashed in an apparent robbery attempt, officials said. The youth's identity was withheld because of age. Hospital officials said that the priest, the Rev. Edward J. Norton, was in stable but guarded condition with a throat wound.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am quite fond of skate, which I can occasionally find in my fish market. I think it is one of the most delectable of fish. Can tell me why it is not more popular in this country?

title: Real Estate; A.T.& T.  In Role of Landlord
description: IN the midst of what many realty experts say is a softening Manhattan office market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is adding more space to the pool. A.T.& T. has decided not to use all the office space in its distinctive new Madison Avenue headquarters building. Instead it will lease out about half, or 300,000 square feet, of the space.

title: Index; International
description: Politics on French television: Not how much but whose A2 Bonn party caucus affirms switch in alliances A3 Britain's Labor Party shifts to the right A4 At U.N. open debate, nations set out their view of the world A7 Egypt openly urges U.S. to press Israel on leaving Lebanon A8 In Egypt, second thoughts about peace with Israel A8 Text of statement by Israeli Cabinet on Beirut massacre inquiry A8 P.L.O. aide killed in ambush was a top strategist A9 Shultz and Gromyko confer at length in New York A11 U.S. lifts military sanctions imposed on Argentina A12 Soviet and U.S. teams back in Geneva for missile talks A13 Government/Politics U.S. moves to fine shops removing catalytic converters A20 Urban renewal of the West Side plods along B1 City board rescinds a tax exemption for New York Hilton Hotel B3 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Working Profile: Rep. Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts B8 Pending bill pits the District against Congress, again B8 General Around the Nation A16 Gannett Company must get rid of its Oakland newspapers A21 Casino panel orders union to remove three officers B28 Features/Notes New York Day by Day B2 Woman in the News: Marie Garibaldi, future court nominee B3 Sports People B14 Going Out Guide C21 The Living Section Food A vintage year to start a wine cellar C1

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1982; Companies
description: Citicorp of New York acquired Fidelity Savings and Loan of California. Citicorp acted within hours of Federal Reserve Board approval of the acquisition. The Fed's decision, which may affect interstate banking guidelines, ended intense lobbying by Citicorp to establish a position in California's booming deposit market. (Page D1.)

title: 7 Collegians Charged
description: Second-degree misdemeanor charges have been filed against seven University of Florida football and basketball players, including Lorenzo Hampton, who scored three touchdowns in Florida's 27-17 victory over Mississippi State last Saturday. Eugene Whitworth, a state attorney, filed the charges in connection with $1,626 worth of telephone calls said to have been improperly billed to the school's athletic association.

title: Israel Finds Its Voice
description: The people of Israel have broken the resistance of their Government to force a full and fair inquiry of its negligence, or worse, in permitting the slaughter of defenseless Palestinians in West Beirut. Are there people of comparable honor and courage in the Arab world who can appreciate Israel's revulsion? Will the Lebanese dare to press a parallel search for the actual killers?

title: DOCTORS, AND THE PEOPLE, AGAINST INTERFERENCE BY THE F.T.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUTSIDE, INSIDE

title: WORKAHOLISM: PAYING THE PRICE
description: A 33-YEAR-OLD doctor was recently taking a six-month vacation, spending his days playing tennis, skiing, reading books, going to plays and museums, camping out and generally discovering, as he put it, ''what life is really all about.'' He explained that all his life he had worked to please his parents and mentors. He studied hard in college and harder in medical school and went on to complete two medical residency programs and get board certification in both specialties.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec 10, 1981 and assume conversion of outstndg convertible bonds issued in Apr 1981

title: BRITISH LABOR PARTY SHIFTS TO RIGHT
description: The Labor Party continued its turn to the right today with major shifts in the composition of its powerful National Executive Committee.

title: LACE COLLARS EVOKING FASHIONS OF LONG AGO
description: THE revival of the lace collar, which began a couple of years ago, when small, almost dainty versions began peering out over sweaters, appears to have taken on a whole new dimension lately. Now, much more elaborate and more romantic antique collars are turning up - or, rather, down - on both the street dresses and the evening wear of women in New York.

title: AMERICAN CYCLIST MOVES UP
description: After a month spent worrying about breakaways, punctures and time trials, Greg Lemond was brooding about jet lag, not usually a concern of professional bicycle racers accustomed to cruising speeds of 25 miles an hour.

title: Yastrzemski Signs Again
description: Carl Yastrzemski, 43 years old and insisting ''I can still hit,'' signed a contract today 1983, his 23d and ''final'' season with the Boston Red Sox.

title: CITY SETTLES SUIT FOR $2 MILLION
description: New York City, in an out-of-court settlement, has agreed to pay $2 million to a man who was paralyzed from the waist down when he was shot by a police officer, officials announced yesterday.

title: People
description: * James McCullagh named publishing director of New Shelter magazine.

title: News Analysis
description: The Justice Department's announcement that it might support legal challenges to court-ordered busing plans does not, by itself, foreshadow an imminent end to the use of busing in the effort to desegregate public schools.

title: Small Colleges on TV
description: CBS Sports chose yesterday the four Division III college games it will televise on a regional basis Sunday, complete with pro-football broadcasters, in place of National Football League games called off by the player strike.

title: Goodbye WE 6, Hello 976
description: T o those of us who go to pieces when faced with numbers of more than five digits, there was something rather endearing about the telephone company making it possible for all these years to dial WEather 6-1212 to find out about the weather.

title: LET'S LOOK AT THE RECORD
description: At the end of the fiscal year and the beginning of another reappraisal of world politics at the United Nations, it would be helpful if President Reagan gave an account of his record as he sees it.

title: FAVORITES FROM THE 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALMOST all the recipes that have run in the 60-Minute Gourmet over the years have been innovations of one sort or another. Some were pure creations, dishes that were not based on anything I had read about or dined on before; they were stimulated instead by a particular occasion or an item of food that was on hand. Others have been improvisations, coming from dishes that I have either heard about or recall from my travels here and abroad. Still others are reproductions of dishes that I first cooked as a professional chef or have known about since childhood.

title: HONG KONG MARKETS SLUMP AFTER TALKS
description: The one clear reaction to the Chinese-British talks over Hong Kong's future has been in the colony's financial markets.

title: AGAIN, THE 'LAST COLONY' VS. CONGRESS
description: Since 1974 the District of Columbia, the nation's 15th largest city, has been under a nominal grant of home rule from Congress.
