title: Italian Socialist Tells Of Effort to Free Moro
description: The Socialist leader Bettino Craxi said today that his party made contacts with representatives of the Red Brigades in a vain attempt to free former Prime Minister Aldo Moro in 1978.

title: Interest Rates Decline Sharply; Liquidity Rise Cited
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, spurred by what money market analysts said was a temporary aberration caused by a surge of liquidity in the banking system.

title: ACTORS STUDIO NAMES MISS BURSTYN AND PACINO
description: Ellen Burstyn and Al Pacino have been named co-artistic directors of the Actors Studio, succeeding the late Lee Strasberg, the father of Method acting in the United States and the guiding force of the acting school since the late 1940's.

title: TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 26
Albania 'Liquidates' Armed Group of Emigres
description: Albania said today that its security forces ''liquidated'' an armed group of emigre Albanians who landed on its shores Saturday night.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Allis Seeks to End Venture With Fiat
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, the Milwaukeebased maker of industrial machinery and equipment, disclosed that it had filed suit in the Circuit Court of Cook County to dissolve its nine-year-old venture with Fiat S.p.A. of Italy. Fiat said in Turin, Italy, that it would contest the suit.

title: SCUBA DIVING'S NEW WORLD
description: Despite sharks and despite the recession, 2.6 million scuba-diving Americans periodically struggle into wet suits, strap on tanks and descend into the deep. For this underwater pleasure, they spend $500 million a year on travel and equipment.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POLICE IN LARCHMONT DROP CHARGES AGAINST MAN WHO AIDED IN RESCUE
description: The Larchmont Police Department agreed tonight to drop its criminal charges against Edward McGuire, a 22-year-old college student who earlier this month wrestled to safety an 18-year-old man who was threatening to jump from the roof of a sixstory apartment building.

title: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the qr and $335,000 for the yr and extraordinary credits of $67,000 for the qr and $197,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $13,224,000 for theqr and $13,588,000 for the yr

title: BONN PARTY AFFIRMS SWITCH IN ALLIANCES
description: After a marathon meeting, the parliamentary group of West Germany's Free Democratic Party agreed today to vote for Helmut Kohl, leader of the Christian Democrats, for Chancellor in a vote scheduled in Parliament for Friday.

title: United Jersey
description: United Jersey Bank and Richard Blackman & Company, based in Paramus, N.J., said they were in talks that that could result in the bank holding company acquiring the discount brokerage firm. Such an agreement would enable United Jersey, based in Hackensack, N.J., to offer brokerage services through its statewide network of 118 offices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 11 Children, 4 Pets, Immeasurable Warmth

title: Match Not Made
description: Tom Watson, the United States Open golf champion, will miss the $250,000 World Match-Play Championship, Oct. 14-17, in Wentworth, England, because the tournament organizers have refused him extra appearance money, according to Mark McCormack, an agent for the tournament.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: All Scallops Are Not Equal

title: CASINO PANEL ORDER UNION TO REMOVE 3 AIDES
description: Citing links to organized crime, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission ordered a casino union today to remove three officers by Oct. 12 or stop collecting union dues.

title: No Headline
description: SENATE PANEL APPROVES A STATE DEPT. NOMINEE

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $690,000 for the qr and yr

title: KEENE GETS CITY OPERA ARTISTIC POST
description: Christopher Keene, a 35-year-old American conductor, was named artistic supervisor of the New York City Opera yesterday. In his new post, Mr. Keene will be second in command to Beverly Sills, the company's general director, advising her in all artistic areas from repertory to productions, casting and conducting.

title: A VINTAGE YEAR TO START A WINE CELLAR
description: If you've ever dreamed of having your own wine cellar but put it off, delay no longer. Prices are down on almost all wines and there is a good chance that they will go even lower in the next six months. The biggest reductions so far are in European wines, mostly because of the strength of the dollar. But the California wines are following suit. If you have been waiting for bargains, your time may have come.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses of $1,019,000 and $561,000 from discontinued operations for the latest and earlier period, respectively...C-A fter a loss of $1,983,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $924,000

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE IN NEW HAVEN BY GOVERNOR AND HIS G.O.P. OPPONENT
description: Following are excerpts from a debate held here today between Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat who is seeking election to his first full term, and State Senator Lewis B. Rome, the Republican challenger. Introduction

title: Dome Studies Plan
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which has two days to pay a major debt, said it is still considering a bailout package put together by its banks and the Canadian Government. A Dome spokesman said that ''significant matters'' are unresolved. He gave no details.

title: Thrift Units' Deposit Drain
description: Americans withdrew $2.1 billion more from savings and loan associations than they deposited last month, the Government reported today.

title: MASSEY IN ACCORD TO REFINANCE DEBT
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the big Canadian farm-equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had reached preliminary agreement with its 200 lenders to restructure $1.27 billion in debt by exchanging a large portion for equity in the company.

title: A LONG LINE DRIVE AND A TITLE
description: A n inside-the-park home run is a rarity in major league baseball. Through Monday night, 3,246 homers had been hit this season, but according to the Elias Sports Bureau, the National League's official statistican, no more than a dozen have been of the inside-the-park variety. No official records are kept.

title: N.L.R.B. RULING FAVORS PLAYERS
description: The National Football League Players Association, which has filed 35 unfair-labor-practice charges against the N.F.L. during the current collective bargaining process, received good news about two of them today.

title: CLINCH RIVER PROJECT IS RIGHT AT HOME IN OAK RIDGE
description: At 7:00 P.M. last Tuesday, the first tree fell. ''It was a red oak!'' exclaimed Percy Brewington Jr., acting director of the Clinch River breeder reactor project, who personally felled the tree, as his wife, daughter and dog cheered him on.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
SCOUTING
description: Inflation Spiral Inflation is everywhere in professional sports. For some top tennis professionals, whether to play for their country or in bigmoney events, has become a controversial issue.

title: Conservatives Win In Prince Edward Island
description: The opposition Conservatives have retained Prince Edward Island, Canada's smallest province, and gained an extra seat in the provincial legislature, according to election results today.

title: Steve Reich Will Give Series of Four Concerts
description: Steve Reich and Musicians will open the 1982-83 series of ''The New Wave: New Masters at the Brooklyn Academy of Music'' with four concerts in the academy's Opera House, tomorrow through Sunday.

title: GRANGER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,551,000 for the latest yr and $1,325,000 for the previous yr; shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split approved Sept 27

title: EAST GEMRMAN DISSENT
description: Almost unnoticed, the most significant development since Solidarity is unfolding in Eastern Europe. It is a brave, resiliant, entirely home-grown peace movement, which has mushroomed suddenly in one of the most rigid, loyal Soviet satellites, East Germany.

title: A SCHOOL GETS ITS OWN MCDONALD'S
description: Culinary-arts students at the Minuteman Regional Vocational High School have an unusual opportunity to learn the fast-food business - there's a McDonald's restaurant on campus.

title: 8 Palestinian Prisoners Hurt
description: Israeli guards shot eight prisoners while breaking up a riot today at a prison camp in Insar, Lebanon, the military command said.

title: On Student Athletes
description: Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame basketball coach, told a high school coaches clinic in Cincinnati that his fellow college coaches would ask the National Collegiate Athletic Association to crack down on athletes who don't crack the books. He said there would be a request made to require athletes to maintain a 2.0 grade average, carry 12 credit hours and be paid to go to summer school. ''Academically, we've lost our credibility,'' he said.

title: Royal Wedding Aids Charity
description: Souvenir sales and special appeals connected with the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer last year raised almost $1.7 million for charity, fund administrators said today. The money came from sales of commemorative chinaware, programs, records and cassettes, private donations and entrance charges at exhibitions of the presents received by the couple.

title: YEN FALLS TO 5-YEAR LOW AGAINST DOLLAR IN TOKYO
description: The yen fell to a five-year low in trading against the dollar here today - finishing at 269.50 yen to the dollar - and Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said ''there were no signs whatever'' that the yen's weakness would end soon.

title: ONE BEGIN CRITIC'S 'OVERKILL'-- OR 'COURAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: END THE TAX SUBSIDIES FOR CORPORATE MERGERS
description: In the wake of the latest corporate-acquisition game - the four-way Allied-Bendix-Marietta-United Technologies deal - there is public confusion about who has done what to whom and what it all means. But more important, there is a public outcry, including voices of leading businessmen in the United States, that ''enough is enough.''

title: Bloomingdale's Mistress Loses in 'Palimony' Case
description: A judge threw out most of Vicki Morgan's $10 million suit against the estate of the late Alfred Bloomingdale today, saying their relationship was ''no more than that of a wealthy, older, married paramour and young, well-paid mistress.''

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
DOUBTFUL LEGALITY OF A TROOP DISPATCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Plant Outlays Abroad Slow
description: Foreign affiliates of American companies are planning to increase spending on new plants and equipment next year by less than five-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Santa Fe Counsel Is Accused
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the general counsel of a unit of Santa Fe International of illegally using confidential information on the merger of Santa Fe to earn $90,658.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. WILL KEEP ITS MARINE FORCE IN LEBANON TILL ISRAELIS AND SYRIANS GO
description: President Reagan said tonight that the Marines would land in Beirut on Wednesday and would remain until Israeli and Syrian forces were withdrawn from Lebanon.

title: Opel Sees '83 Profit
description: Adam Opel A.G., the major West European subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, will make a profit again next year, Ferdinand Beickler, managing director, predicted today. Speaking at a news conference on the eve of the Paris Auto Show, Mr. Beickler said, ''We consider that after improvement this year, Opel will be back in the black in 1983.'' One factor is expected to be the company's new Corsa mini-car, which is to receive its world premiere at the show.

title: Superior Tests Well
description: The Superior Oil Company said today that it had tested oil and gas from three zones in a discovery well in the British North Sea. The well is 155 miles northeast of Aberdeen, Scotland.

title: Racing Director Resigns
description: David A. Stevenson, the director of racing at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga since 1979, has resigned to take a job in private industry.

title: BAY STATE REPUBLICAN WITH AN INDEPENDENT STREAK
description: Every polling place he went to in his western Massachusetts district on primary day, says Representative Silvio O. Conte, he found a message: ''Call Dave Stockman.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Deadline for Cohn

title: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $776,000; yr-ago results reflect a gain of $2.7 million from the termination of the company's U.S. pension plan

title: SAMUEL JACKSON, NIXON AIDE IN HOUSING MATTERS, IS DEAD
description: Samuel C. Jackson, a former Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Nixon Administration who was an outspoken civil rights spokesman throughout his legal career, died Monday of cancer. He was 53 years old.

title: CITICORP ACQUIRES FIDELITY
description: In a ruling that may set a precedent for interstate banking, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday gave Citicorp of New York permission to acquire the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of California.

title: COMPUTERLAND STILL RIDES HIGH
description: The first retail stores that specialized in the sale of personal computers to individuals and businesses did not have much competition in the mid-1970's. As a result, profit margins were high and price competition among manufacturers was minimal. But the lack of cooperation between what few stores there were and lack of communication with the manufacturers of the equipment inhibited the growth of the retail industry.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Soviet-Bloc Units in Bulgaria Intensify Military Exercises
description: Warsaw Pact forces have intensified combat exercises in Bulgaria as part of the annual ''Shield-82'' maneuvers, the Bulgarian press agency reported today.

title: BRINK'S SUSPECTS ALLOWED TO QUIT PRETRIAL HEARING
description: Four of the six defendants in the Brink's murder and robbery case were excused today from pretrial hearings after abandoning their legal right to challenge a key element of the state's case against them.

title: Alexander Plans To Back Claims
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said that all proper claims on business undertaken by Alexander Howden Group P.L.C. and its subsidiaries, including Sphere Drake's Underwriting, would be met.

title: PRESIDIO OIL reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Market Place; Growth Curve At Wang Labs
description: THE rocketing growth in word processor sales will wane when saturation arrives in the middle of the decade. By that time, Wang Labs may have lost its leadership in the text preparation market to International Business Machines. But most analysts are betting that Wang will not falter.

title: TAX BREAK FOR NEW YORK HILTON RESCINDED
description: The city's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board yesterday rescinded a tax exemption given to the New York Hilton Hotel because the hotel did not carry out its plan to add a new wing to its midtown site, at 1335 Avenue of the Americas, at 53d Street.

title: MONEY CRISIS PERILS MEXICANS WHO HOLD REAL ESTATE IN U.S.
description: Mexico's currency crisis is forcing Mexicans who own billions of dollars worth of real estate in the United States to offer it at fire-sale prices or lose their investment entirely through foreclosure.

title: Mubarak Pledges to Support Lebanon in Rebuilding Effort
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has sent a message to President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon pledging support in efforts to rebuild the country, the official Middle East News Agency said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Treasury refinancing chart in Business Day Friday incorrectly stated the second-quarter average yield on seven-year notes. It was 14.42 percent.

title: Masco to Purchase Evans-Aristocrat
description: Evans-Aristocrat Industries, a maker of measuring tapes based in Newark, said it would merge with the Masco Corporation, a Taylor, Mich., producer of plumbing fixtures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Port's Past Grandeur And Hopes for Its Future

title: Midtown Muggers Rob The Mayor of Tel Aviv
description: The Mayor of Israel's largest city said yesterday that he and his wife were robbed at gunpoint in midtown Sunday night, the night of Yom Kippur, by four men who took their jewelry, cash, airline tickets and passports.

title: WINE TALK
description: AGALLIC invasion of California vineyards is under way, and the latest beachheads have just been established, attesting to the growing esteem in which California wines are held by leaders of the French wine trade. The invasion began in the early days of the American wine boom, and now seems to be gathering momentum.

title: Second of two articles.
description: The film ''Star Wars,'' the biggest box-office hit ever, came to television last week. But only about 1.5 million viewers could watch it. Their sets are equipped with pay-per-view devices that enable them to tune in to special programs that they select. In this case, viewers mailed in about $8 each to see ''Star Wars'' two years before it will be broadcast by CBS-TV. The ''Star Wars'' showing was the first in a series of pay-perview experiments being conducted over thenext six months. Cabletelevision programmers will be closely watching the experiments, along with a number of other developments that are shaping the future of the cable-television industry.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-After a loss of $640,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations and a gain of $242,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr from the sale of land in Fullerton, Calif

title: Emons Records $8.4 Million Loss
description: Emons Industries, a York, Pa., company that rents out railroad freight cars, reported an $8.4 million loss for the year ended June 30 and said its auditor believes that Emons ''may be unable to continue as a going concern.''

title: RENEWAL OF THE WEST SIDE A SLOW-MOVING STORY
description: Nikita Khrushchev took power in the Soviet Union and Charles de Gaulle was summoned to leadership in France. Angelo Giuseppe Cardinal Roncalli was crowned Pope John XXIII. The Dodgers and Giants, after quitting New York, opened in Los Angeles and San Francisco. Elvis Presley joined the Army. ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' captured seven Oscars. And on Broadway, Leonard Bernstein's ''West Side Story'' was packing them in for a second year.

title: REPO BACKING IS UNDER CLOUD
description: When the Mount Pleasant Bank and Trust Company failed last month, the Iowa community from which the small institution operated was shocked and rattled. But the confusion generated by the bank's failure pushed far beyond the Mount Pleasant city limits.

title: Kenyon Gets Stake In David Deutsch
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt has bought a minority position in David Deutsch Associates, an 11-year-old agency with $12 million in billings. About the only apparent change in the D.D.A. agency life style will be the addition of Murray L. Smith, a K.& E. senior vice presidentinternational, to its board.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
UNITS STILL AT AIRPORT
description: Israel removed its troops from the port of Beirut today but not immediately from the international airport in the southern suburbs, a deployment that continued to prevent the United States Marines from landing here from Sixth Fleet ships waiting offshore.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IT WOULD CONSIDER WESTWAY TRADE-IN
description: A trade-in of Westway funds for mass transit would get a sympathetic White House hearing if Lewis E. Lehrman, who opposes the project, is elected Governor and requests it, President Reagan's chief of staff said yesterday.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Construction Value Up 14%
description: The Dodge Index of construction contract value rose 14 percent in August, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: THE GRAPES OF REAGANOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'NIGHT OF SHOOTING STARS' FROM ITALY
description: ''THE Night of the Shooting Stars'' is one of those life-affirming films made to order for urban neurotics who behave badly over the breakfast table, on the subway or in the office. They can attend this Italian film and, by agreeing with its decent sentiments, feel cleansed in some small, vicarious way. Then they can go out and be rotten all over again. It's not a work that makes one think a lot.

title: Two Victims Escape In a Texas Kidnapping
description: Two men escaped today from the trunks of separate cars after being held captive by a man who was being sought on charges of burying another victim underground for four days last week.

title: OPERA: MARISA GALVANY IN 'MEDEA'
description: CHERUBINI'S ''Medea'' has returned to the New York City Opera, and Sunday night's performance featured Marisa Galvany in the fierce and demanding title role. Miss Galvany threw herself into the part with an appropriate ferocity, and if her soprano sound was not always beautiful it was at least powerful and - though there were lapses - sometimes penetratingly true.

title: Bridge: Bidding a Three-Card Suit; Takes Some Time to Learn
description: Beginners soon learn that it is permissible on occasion to open one club with a three-card suit. They learn it too well, and start worrying about that rather infrequent possibility whenever their partners bid one club.

title: Smith Barney Officer Starting Own Venture
description: Charles H. Davison has left his post as vice chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the Wall Street brokerage firm, to go into business for himself.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock divd paid in May 1982

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1982
description: International U.S. Marines will land in Beirut today and will remain there until Israeli and Syrian forces are withdrawn from Lebanon, President Reagan announced at a televised news conference. An American official said the Marines could be in Beirut ''for some time.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) A full inquiry on the Beirut massacre of Palestinians was approved by Prime Minister Menachem Begin. The Israeli leader dropped his opposition to establishing a judicial commission to carry out a thorough investigation in the face of intensive pressure from within his governing coalition as well as mounting criticism by many Israelis. (A1:4-5.)

title: Boat May Have Snagged Soviet Sub in the Pacific
description: A 68-foot shrimp boat operating in the Pacific Ocean off Washington snagged what may have been a Soviet submarine last Tuesday, the Pentagon said Monday.

title: GIANTS ARE TAKING PRACTICE SERIOUSLY
description: Memorial Field in this rustic town in northern Bergen County has never been mistaken for Giants Stadium. The baseball infield and the edge of the outfield are a mass of dirt. The grassy part of the outfield is marked off with white stripes for a Peewee football league. The wooden bleachers hold perhaps 175 spectators.

title: TV: CAROL BURNETT STARS IN BIOGRAPHY OF ALCOHOLIC
description: ''LIFE OF THE PARTY: The Story of Beatrice,'' this evening's TV movie on CBS at 9 o'clock, is another of those sociological-uplift concoctions so dear to network programmers. This one, though, does have one outstanding asset: The title role is played by Carol Burnett.

title: No Headline
description: For those who like to know what days, weeks or years they are supposed to be observing, here is the latest primer, representing recent House action on resolutions previously approved by the Senate:

title: PARIS FRANCHISE RULING TO BE APPEALED
description: The owner of the 14 McDonald's restaurants in the Paris area says that he will appeal a judge's order that he quit using the McDonald's name on 12 of them.

title: WORD OF CAUTION: AVOID QUICK FIX
description: A fitting coda to the wretched baseball season in New York is the bizarre but inevitable news that George is courting Billy again. They are the Taylor and Burton of baseball. They can't get along together, but they can't forget each other, either.

title: TEACHERS TOLD TO HALT STRIKE OR FACE ARREST
description: A New Jersey judge said yesterday that he would have teachers in Teaneck taken into custody this morning if they continued to defy his order to stop striking and return to their classrooms.

title: Rejuvenating Prometheus
description: P rometheus has come unbound a bit in Rockefeller Center. Over the last few days, workmen have clambered over the bronze statue of the Titan in Greek mythology who brought fire to man - stripping him of old coats and tarnish and sanding him down.

title: DODGERS LOSE 7th IN ROW AND FALL TO 2d
description: One night after they tried to help end a losing streak with a loud party in Manager Tom Lasorda's office, the Los Angeles Dodgers fell out of first place in the National League West when they lost to the Reds, 4-3, in 10 innings tonight.

title: Panel Asks Removal of Judge Accused of Racist Comments
description: A judge who was accused of having made racist and sexist remarks from the bench while under the influence of alcohol should be removed from office, the state's Commission on Judicial Conduct recommended today.

title: METS WIN, 3-2, FOR 4th IN ROW
description: ''Absolute luck,'' was the way Rusty Staub described it, but the record book will show that his bouncing single in the 10th inning last night enabled the Mets to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2, and match their longest winning streak of the season.

title: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $31,400 for the qr and $644,700 for the yr on the disposition of segments

title: EAST PALESTINE KINGDOM
description: To the Editor: It is Prof. James Hudson, not Prof. Jerold S. Auerbach, who ''garbles'' the history of Transjordan (letter Sept. 20).

title: Potential Bombs vs. Potential Business
description: Secretary of State Shultz says curbing the spread of nuclear weapons is one of his main objectives. Then why does he name a fox like Richard T. Kennedy to guard the chicken coop? Appointing Mr. Kennedy as his chief adviser on nonproliferation is yet another example of Reagan Administration carelessness with the issues of The Bomb.

title: Pan Am Sees No 3d-Quarter Profit
description: Pan American World Airways will not show a profit this quarter, despite repeated predictions to the contrary by the company's chairman, an airline spokesman, Jeffrey Kriendler, said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard SPACE. By James A. Michener. 622 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: ONE BEGIN CRITIC'S 'OVERKILL'--OR 'COURAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. EASING CURBS AGAINST ARGENTINA
description: The Reagan Administration has lifted the last sanctions imposed against Argentina five months ago during its war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, a spokesman said today.

title: FINES LEVIED IN CATALYTIC CONVERTER REMOVALS
description: ''Save Fuel, Save Money,'' proclaim the advertisements for gadgets that allow motorists to get rid of a pollution control device that some consider a waste of money.

title: POP: MANY VOICES OF KAREN BLACK
description: THE movie actress Karen Black, who is presenting a cabaret act at Les Mouches, uses several different singing voices that are so distinct from one another it isn't clear which one belongs to the ''real'' Miss Black and which to the characters she plays. Those characters range from a cocaine-sniffing charwoman, to a proper English lady, to a leathered-jacketed rock-and-roller.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambassador Group, North Bergen, N.J., has elected to its board Jay Wells, a New York investor.

title: Reagan on Strike: 'Hate to Comment'
description: President Reagan declined to say during his news conference tonight whether or not he missed professional football during the strike.

title: So Saith the Lord, Briefly
description: It came to pass that one day The Reader's Digest cast its eyes upon the Good Book and said, let us see what a paring and a pruning will do to the verbiage that hides its mighty message as the bushes the house.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Wood Murder Trial
description: Jury selection for the trial of three people accused in the contract slaying of Federal District Judge John Wood began today.

title: PAUL KOLLSMAN, 82, AVIATION ENGINEER
description: Paul Kollsman, an aeronautical engineer whose invention of the altimeter in the late 1920's helped revolutionize aviation, died Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif., and Manhattan.

title: WITNESS AT GIBSON TRIAL REFERS TO FALSE LETTER
description: A former Director of the city's Public Works Department testified today at the trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris that none of his subordinates had ever informed him that Michael A. Bontempo was not showing up for work as head of security at the city's Pequannock Watershed.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AS the music librarian of Harvard University, Michael Ochs is a resident of Massachusetts, and has long savored the joys of Boston. Nevertheless, the experience of a Manhattan boyhood may induce irreversible physiological changes. Though you can take the boy out of the stickball games on West 98th Street (the old stamping ground of Dr. Ochs), you can't take the stickball games on West 98th Street out of the boy. Dr. Ochs thinks of himself as a New Yorker in exile and has, from time to time, offered Bay State bulletins to Metropolitan Diary readers. Here is his latest report:

title: President to Step Down At Y.& R. International
description: Alexander Brody, 49 years old, will be stepping out of the presidency of Young & Rubicam International with the new year and devoting more time to his condominium in Hawaii. A replacement is to be named before that time, the agency promises.

title: CARLOS ALBERTO SAYS FAREWELL TO SOCCER
description: The Cosmos-Flamengo game at Giants Stadium tonight had more significance than marking the retirement of Carlos Alberto.

title: FIRST O'NEILL-ROME DEBATE HELD
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill and his Republican challenger, Lewis B. Rome, traded charges of incompetence, irresponsibility and dishonesty here today in their first debate of the campaign.

title: Advertising; For a 3-D Camera, A 3-D Ad
description: HAVING raised $60 million by going public in Britain and the United States, and having developed a camera that takes three-dimensional photographs with regular film, the Nimslo Corporation, with 700 workers in Atlanta turning out its 35-millimeter, four-lens product, is finally, after 12 long years, ready to go out and try and make some money.

title: Careers; Openings Found in Agriculture
description: AGRICULTURE is big business -bigger than most people realize. In fact, American agribusiness probably is the largest single business in the world, partly because of huge exports.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of a New York artist on Monday misspelled her name. She was Harriet LeBell.

title: BEGIN AGREES TO ESTABLISH A PANEL TO INVESTIGATE THE BEIRUT MASSACRE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin bowed to relentless political pressure within his governing coalition today and agreed to establish a full-fledged judicial commission to investigate the Beirut massacre.

title: FOR GRILLING A SANDWICH
description: IF the French have a counterpart to the Big Mac or corned beef on rye it is the croque-monsieur, which is essentially a grilled ham and cheese sandwich. It is basic bistro fare and, when prepared well, is as satisfying a meal as you'll find in France for about $2. A slight variation is the croque-madame, which is garnished with a fried egg on top. The American grilled cheese sandwich is a close, if more austere, relation.

title: Memorial for Grant Gilmore
description: A memorial service will be held at Yale University Law School in New Haven at 2 P.M. on Sunday for Grant Gilmore, an authority on admiralty and commercial law and a member of the law faculty for 25 years. Professor Gilmore died at the age of 72 last May at his home in Norwich, Vt. His two-volume work ''Security Interests in Property,'' published in 1965, won the Ames Prize awarded by the Harvard Law School faculty for the most distinguished work of legal scholarship over a five-year period.

title: Sheik Arranges Woolco Talks
description: Richard Hirschfeld, the attorney for Sheik Mohammed al Fassi of Saudi Arabia, will meet this week with Kidder, Peabody & Company, the investment bankers for the F.W. Woolworth Company, to discuss the possibility of buying the Woolco discount stores, a Woolworth spokesman said.

title: News Analysis
description: A pall of uncertainty has been cast over the future of West German politics after the election last weekend in the state of Hesse.

title: C.I.A. Allowed to Keep Campus Contacts Secret
description: A Federal appellate court ruled today that the Central Intelligence Agency can keep its relationships with universities secret because of the danger that disclosure would pose to the agency's intelligence operations.

title: Patent Office Charges Rising
description: Fees charged by the Patent and Trademark Office will be sharply increased on Friday under a new law meant to make the processing of patents entirely self-supporting and to reduce the huge backlog of applications.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Red Sox vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Boston. The Red Sox are out of the American League's Eastern Division race, but first-place Milwaukee must keep winning to retain the edge on Baltimore. Tigers vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Detroit. The Orioles have to keep within three games of the Brewers this week. The two leaders will then meet on the last three days of the season, in Baltimore this weekend. Jim Palmer, whose 15-4 record gives him the best winning percentage in the league (.789), will start for the Orioles tonight and could be ready to go again on Sunday if needed. Royals vs. California Angels, at Kansas City, Mo. This is the final confrontation between the American League's Western Division leaders. The first-place Angels return home to play Texas, while the Royals remain in Kansas City to play a season-ending series against Oakland. Giants vs. Houston Astros, at San Francisco. The Giants try to sustain a late-season rally before playing host to the Dodgers this weekend, concluding a tight race in the National League's Western Division. Dodgers vs. Atlanta Braves, at Los Angeles. The Braves need to win here to stay in the thick of a three-team race. Tonight's game is the first of their final two with the Dodgers, and they are finished with the Giants already. Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: No Headline
description: 5 GUARDS AND 3 INMATES HURT IN MARYLAND ESCAPE ATTEMPT

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; the Verna Corp auditors will qualify their opinion relating to their company's financial statements for the yr ended June 30

title: NESTLE PLANNING SERIES OF CHANGES
description: Nestle Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that David E. Guerrant, who is responsible for Nestle food operations in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico, would retire at the end of 1983. As a result, several executive changes were announced.

title: DERAILMENT AND TOXIC FIRE FORCE EVACUATION OF 2,000
description: Part of a 101-car freight train carrying explosive and poisonous chemicals derailed early today, igniting a fire and explosions that forced evacuation of residents as far as five miles away.

title: A HINCKLEY THREAT REPORTED
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. recently tried to send a letter to an unidentified woman in the Middle West seeking her help in shooting and killing Jodie Foster with a .38-caliber pistol, knowledgeable sources confirmed this evening.

title: GANNETT SEEKS OWNER FOR TWO OAKLAND DAILIES
description: A decision by the Gannett Company, one of the nation's largest communications organizations, to get rid of its two newspapers in Oakland so that it can buy a television station in San Francisco has provided a new twist in what was already a complex, vigorous competition for Bay Area readers, viewers and advertising dollars.

title: American to Lease 20 McDonnell Jets
description: In an unusual transaction, American Airlines said it had agreed to rent 20 twin-jet Super 80 aircraft, beginning in May. Financial details of the accord, with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation, were not disclosed.

title: Economic Scene; Shift Toward Pragmatism
description: IN American politics, the classic question of voters has been, ''What have you done for me lately?'' But in hard times the question becomes, ''What have you done to me lately?''

title: LEAD BY 1
description: The Atlanta Braves regained sole possession of first place in the National League West race tonight by beating the San Francisco Giants, 8-3, for their second straight victory at Candlestick Park.

title: BRAZILIAN PLAYBOY: THE LAST OF A BREED
description: RIO DE JANEIRO THE time was World War II, and Nelson Rockefeller was serving as the Government's Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs. He took on a polished young Brazilian man about town named Jorge Guinle, who moved to Hollywood and put his own interpretation on the job.

title: An Uphill Task
description: There was no snow on the ground in the Pike Creek area near Newark, Del., last Monday, but that didn't stop Frank Masley from taking some practice runs on his luge, a racing sled.

title: The Pop Life; Peter Gabriel's Philosophy and Output
description: FIFTY THOUSAND British rock fans are expected to trek to an outdoor arena north of London on Saturday for a one-time-only reunion. Peter Gabriel, who was the founder, lead singer and principal songwriter for Genesis before he abruptly left the group in 1975, will be getting back together with his old bandmates. Genesis has remained one of the most popular British bands, notching up gold albums and Top 10 singles; Peter Gabriel's innovative and provocative solo disks have enjoyed solid but unspectacular sales. But for millions of diehard fans around the world, the fancifully elaborate albums and stage shows that Mr. Gabriel and Genesis created together in the early- and middle-1970's remain among British art-rock's most impressive achievements.

title: 11 AMERASIAN CHILDREN DUE TO LEAVE VIETNAM FOR A LIFE IN U.S.
description: Eleven children of mixed American and Vietnamese background are scheduled to leave Ho Chi Minh City on Thursday for the United States, State Department officials said today.

title: Money Possibility For the Marathon
description: An announcement on whether the New York City Marathon will offer sanctioned prize money for the first time is expected later this week or early next week. The recent decision by the International Amateur Athletic Federation to approve ''awards money'' for such races, with the funds being channeled through national federations, enhances the possibility that as much as $150,000 from sponsors might be awarded for the Oct. 24 race.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes income of $2,250,000 or 13 cents a shr after tax, from the sale of assets of a Univar subsidiary, Pacific Resins & Chemicals Inc

title: North Korean at U.N.  Accused of Sex Abuse
description: A suspect identified as the third secretary of the North Korean observer delegation to the United Nations has been charged with sexually abusing a 43-year-old Bronx woman.

title: Israel Is Not to Blame, Foreign Minister Says
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, said yesterday that Israel was being wrongly blamed for the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut.

title: P.L.O. AIDE SLAIN IN AMBUSH HAD A KEY ROLE
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization lost one of its top military officers and strategists with the killing Monday of Brig. Saad Sayel, better known as Abu Walid.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is no gainsaying that if you observe the tastes of anyone who writes a food column, his or her predilections will become evident in a fairly brief time. It must be obvious to anyone who reads this column that I have a particular fondness for chicken. It may be just as well, for chicken is one of the finest bargains, month by month and year by year, to be found at the meat counter.

title: POP: PETER NERO RETURNS
description: PETER NERO, the pianist, is making his first appearance in a New York club in more than a decade. He is at the Cafe Carlyle with his bassist, Richard Nanista, for the next two weeks.

title: A WOMAN FOR THE COURT
description: When Thomas H. Kean visited a prominent Newark law concern during his campaign for Governor last year, the lawyer assigned to guide him was absent and Marie L. Garibaldi, a partner, filled in.

title: 3 DROPPED FROM I.B.M. CASE
description: A Federal judge today dismissed charges against three defendants in connection with the ''sting'' operation conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in California's Silicon Valley after the Government refused to provide documents sought by defense lawyers.

title: CUTBACKS EXPECTED AT CBS NEWS
description: CBS News is expected to make cutbacks next year that could include a reduction in the number of overseas bureaus as well in the number of documentaries, according to sources in the news division.

title: NEW ELEMENT CREATED BY WEST GERMAN PHYSICISTS
description: Scientists in West Germany have created a new element of matter in what one expert hailed as ''an incredible technological feat.''

title: Perfect-Game Bid Foiled
description: Jim Clancy came within three outs of a perfect game tonight before settling for a one-hitter as he pitched the Toronto Blue Jays to a 3-0 triumph over the Minnesota Twins.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stocks Fall a Bit; Volume Up
description: Semiconductor issues declined yesterday as the stock market eased slightly in expanded trading. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.57 points, to 919.33, erasing Monday's gain of 1.38 points. Volume grew to 65.9 million shares from 44.8 million in the previous session. Monday's slow trading reflected the observance of Yom Kippur by many investors.

title: 10TH FUND DRIVE TO AID DANCE OPENS
description: Citing an ''ongoing partnership between business and dance,'' a group of leading business excutives, artistic directors and choreographers yesterday marked the 10th anniversary of the National Corporate Fund for Dance and began the fund's campaign to raise $750,000 campaign for 1983.

title: No Headline
description: ROYALS TOP ANGELS; BREWERS WIN BY 9-3

title: WALLACE WINS DEMOCRATIC GUBERNATORIAL RUNOFF
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace claimed victory tonight for the Democratic nomination for Governor in a close runoff that hinged in large part on his ability to attract black voters, whom he had shunned in earlier campaigns.

title: EGYPTIANS BITTER OVER BEIRUT KILLINGS, HAVE SECOND THOUGHTS ABOUT ISRAEL
description: In the beginning, Ahmed el-Soudani was excited about peace with Israel because it would bring new tourists to his tiny shop in Cairo's teeming Khan el-Khalili marketplace.

title: SERVED AS AN ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE
description: Norman Armour, a career Foreign Service officer who served as minister or ambassador to a dozen countries and was at one time Assistant Secretary of State for Political Affairs, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: DIVORCE APPEARS TO DIP WITH ECONOMY
description: Breaking up may be too difficult for many couples in these tough economic times. New Government statistics show a slight drop in the American divorce rate.

title: STATEMENT BY ISRAELIS
description: Following is the official translation of the text of the Israeli Cabinet communique issued today on a judicial inquiry into the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut:

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $1,311,000 from discontinued operations and a loss provision of $800,000 for the disposal of discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $1,110,000 from discontinued operations

title: BREWERS WIN BY 9-3
description: George Brett, struggling at the plate during the last two weeks as his team struggles to stay in the American League West race, helped the Kansas City Royals to avoid elimination tonight as he singled home the deciding run in a 5-4 victory against the California Angels.

title: FLAT TAX SPLITS SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Finance Committee today began considering proposals to adopt a flat-rate income tax. Within minutes, it was evident that committee members agree widely that much is wrong with the present Federal income tax - and disagree widely about how to fix it.

title: DOCTORS, AND THE PEOPLE, AGAINST INTERFERENCE BT THE F.T.C.
description: To the Editor: Your Sept. 21 editorial, ''The A.M.A. Pays a House Call,'' should have been titled, ''The A.M.A. Pays Off.'' It is no secret that the American Medical Association and other groups have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in an effort to buy influence in Congress. The ultimate goal: to curtail competition among its members.

title: Caracas Now Belongs To Third-World Group
description: Venezuela has joined the grouping of nations who call themselves nonaligned, the Venezuelan Foreign Ministry said today.

title: EGYPT URGES U.S. TO 'RESTRAIN' THE ISRAELIS
description: Egypt, the one Arab nation formally at peace with Israel, urged the United States today to press Israel to withdraw from Lebanon.

title: JUDGE REVOKES BAIL OF L.I. UNION CHIEF IN RACKETEERING CASE
description: A labor union leader's bail was revoked last night even though his appeal of a racketeering conviction is still pending, and he was taken from a Brooklyn court to begin serving a five-year prison sentence.

title: Ford's Steel Unit
description: The sale of Ford Motor Company's Rouge Steel subsidiary to a group of Japanese companies could be delayed because of snags over the price and the plant's union agreement, an official of the Nippon Kokan Company said. Ford is negotiating to sell a major share of its steel operations to the steel company and Japanese financing concerns. Haruki Kamiya, senior managing director of Nippon Kokan, said there were complications ''which we hadn't expected.''

title: 'PURIFYING,' ISRAELIS CALLED IT
description: The shock of the massacre in the Shatila and Sabra refugee camps is sharp and intensely dramatic. Yet if it doesn't illuminate the larger pattern of hostility of which it is a part, then we are all shedding useless tears. This pattern includes not only the killings, brutal as they were, but an assault on Palestinian culture. Today, we would do well to recognize a common constituency of reflective Jews and Palestinians who are anxious to end the disastrous string of violence and counter-violence that characterizes our joint modern history.

title: Honduran Guerrillas Arrive in Havana
description: Twelve leftist guerrillas who held two Cabinet ministers and dozens of businessmen hostage for eight days in Honduras arrived in Cuba today, the official Cuban press agency said.

title: King Signs Knick Offer
description: The Golden State Warriors received a contract offer sheet yesterday from the New York Knicks for Bernard King. King, 25, a five-year forward, became a free agent after last season.''

title: Short Memories
description: Barry Switzer, the football coach at the University of Oklahoma, has one of the best career coaching records in college football, but only a 1-2 record this season.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rickover's Foundation

title: REAGAN DATA ON ECONOMY ARE DISPUTED
description: President Reagan cited a variety of economic data at his news conference tonight to make the case that his economic program was working. But based on published Government data, some of his references were subject to dispute.

title: U.S. BROUGHT BACK FROM FISCAL BRINK, PRESIDENT ASSERTS
description: President Reagan defended his economic program tonight by contending that the nation had been brought back from the ''brink of disaster'' and that political delay in Congress on budget legislation was aggravating the recovery.

title: YANKEES SET BACK INDIANS, 6-4
description: Two teams that may be vying for Billy Martin's managerial skills and box office appeal played a game of little importance tonight before a sea of empty seats, with the Yankees prevailing, 6-4, over the Cleveland Indians.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 29, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: STAGE: 'PRICE OF GENIUS'
description: THOUGH based on fact, Betty Neustat's ''The Price of Genius'' seems as farfetched as a fairy tale. Her play opened last night at the Lambs Theater after a previous showcase production at the Interart Theater. It is a simplistic sentimentalization of the life of Sister Juana Ines de la Cruz, the 17th-century Mexican poet and scholar. The play makes her seem like a mixture of Leonardo da Vinci and the Singing Nun. If only she could fly!

title: U.S. TO INCREASE MILITARY FUNDS FOR SPACE USE
description: The Defense Department plans a swift increase in spending for military uses of space over the next five years, according to a senior official in the department.

title: Minton Wants More
description: Greg Minton, whose relief pitching is one of the major reasons the San Francisco Giants are battling for the National League West title, said he is absolutely serious about leaving the team after the season, even if the Giants win the pennant. ''What's been going on these last few weeks is a very good sign for next year,'' said Minton, who has 30 saves and 75 appearances this year, both club records.

title: Hutton Ends Link With Benton & Bowles
description: The 14-year relationship between Benton & Bowles and E.F. Hutton & Company, the brokerage firm, that produced the memorable campaign, ''When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen,'' has ended as the client has decided to move the business in-house.

title: Braniff Route Study Begins
description: A Federal agency opened a hearing today on whether grounded Braniff International should lose two of its overseas routes, despite the airline's efforts to stop the proceeding.

title: U.S. AND MOSCOW TRADE CHARGES AT MISSILE PARLEY
description: The Soviet delegate to the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles said today that the Soviet Union had taken steps to halt its nuclear buildup in Europe and called on the United States to ''act now'' to lower tensions in the area.

title: Maple Contradicts Testimony
description: Eddie Maple, one of the leading jockeys in New York for the last decade, told a Federal grand jury in 1979 that the jockey Jacinto Vasquez ''asked me if I would take some money to hold my horse.'' Yesterday, however, Maple repeatedly contradicted that testimony, saying Vasquez had never attempted to bribe him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Basically what we have I think in this peace proposal is a situation where, on one side territory is the goal and on the other side security.

title: Florida Banks
description: The Landmark Banking Corporation ended merger talks with the Florida National Banks of Florida, citing Florida National's attempt to thwart an unwelcome bid from the Southeast Banking Corporation. J. Joseph Tuohy, president of Landmark, said Florida National's ''extensive litigation with Southeast Banking Corp. and other general uncertainties surrounding Florida National'' helped convinc Landmark that ''it was just not in the best interests of Landmark, its shareholders or depositors to proceed.''

title: BANKERS TRUST SETS 13% PRIME
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's 10th-largest commercial bank by deposits, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday by onehalf percentage point, to 13 percent, the lowest level for the benchmark rate in two years.

title: IT'S POLITICS AS USUAL AT THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: The 37th session of the United Nations General Assembly, while billed as open debate, is, in the eyes of many veteran diplomats and others here, mostly a collection of set speeches prepared and delivered apparently with little thought to dialogue or polemic.

title: BRINK'S DEFENDANT CONTENDS HER JAIL DINNER WAS DRUGGED
description: Kathy Boudin, a defendant in the Brink's murder and robbery case, asserted in court today that she was drugged in the Rockland County jail Saturday. This, she said, violated her ''Sixth Amendment and human rights.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIG WE MUST

title: THE IMAGE OF JOSE STABLE JR.
description: PLAYERSIra Berkow

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
Brezhnev Seems Irked Over Aid to Laos
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev met the Communist leader of Laos today and appeared to criticize the way his country uses Soviet development aid.

title: Scandinavian Airlines Counters Budget Trend
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System, at a point when most of its competitors are cutting back, is increasing its ad budget in order to tell business travelers just what it has done for them.

title: Explosions in 8 Spanish Cities Damage Buildings and Offices
description: The police said 16 explosions shattered gates and windows in government buildings and industrial offices in eight cities early today, but caused no injuries.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Prices declined and interest rates rose slightly in the credit markets yesterday, but securities dealers said that investor demand, nevertheless, continued to be strong for new issues of corporate and tax-exempt bonds.

title: Blue Bell Division Head Gets Top Corporate Job
description: Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-biggest jeans maker after Levi Strauss & Company, announced yesterday that Edward J. Bauman, president of the company's Red Kap divison, had been named corporate president and chief operating officer, a member of the management committee and a director.

title: Economic Analysis on the Run
description: Six weeks before Election Day is no time to ask politicians for a clear fix on the American economy. President Reagan's acknowledgment that things are worse than he expected them to be is refreshing, but incomplete. According to independent economists, the current outlook for 1983 is worse than he expects even now. Most think that at best, the country is still bumping along near the bottom of the recession. If an upturn has occurred, it is slight and not yet confirmed. Next year's growth is widely expected to be weak.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1982
description: International As the marines arrived in Beirut, statements by President Reagan and other Administration officials left uncertainty about the precise nature of the marines' mission and how long they would stay. Mr. Reagan told Congress the marines would be in Beirut ''only for a limited period.'' But later he said they would leave Beirut only when the Lebanese authorities said they themselves could insure the nation's security. (Page A1, Column 6.) The marines landed by ship and helicopter and took control of the Beirut International Airport minutes after the last Israeli soldiers withdrew from the area. About 800 marines arrived yesterday, and 400 more are expected today, joining the French and Italian contingents of about 1,100 men each that make up the multinational peacekeeping force. (A12:1-2.)

title: VENEZUELA SEEKS DEBT CONVERSION
description: Acknowledging that his country had been experiencing a crisis of confidence, Luis Ugueto, Venezuela's Finance Minister, asked international bankers yesterday to convert their short-term loans to Venezuelan Government agencies into longer-term credits to the central Government.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: LA JOLLA, Calif. ONE way to understand the contemporary culture of a country is to visit its flagship department stores as though they were national museums: GUM in Moscow, Galeries Lafayette in Paris and Harrods in London.

title: NO 'AULD LANG SYNE' FOR THE FISCAL YEAR '82
description: The fiscal year 1982 is passing away without anybody, not even a Government accountant, giving it a backward glance.

title: Count Changes Result In Bronx Council Race
description: An official count yesterday reversed the results of a Democratic primary for a City Council seat in the Bronx.

title: HENRY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
An Appraisal
description: The construction that began yesterday on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was full of promise for the future of New York City. It represents not merely the continued growth of one of the city's greatest works of architecture, but also the success of a remarkable work program: the cathedral's decision in 1978 to give young residents of Morningside Heights, Harlem and Newark employment by training them in the ancient art of stonecutting.

title: PHILHARMONIC PAY OFFER REJECTED BY MUSICIANS
description: Labor negotiations between the New York Philharmonic and its musicians continued at Avery Fisher Hall this week following the orchestra's rejection of a management contract offer last Thursday by a vote of 97 to 7. The Philharmonic's previous three-year contract expired on Sept. 20 at midnight, but the season has proceeded without interruption.

title: AMERICA'S CUT-RATE PROFESSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, has elected Robert E. Harris a group vice president and chief executive of its Houston-based National Supply Company, an operating group of Armco.

title: GLITTERING PREVIEW OF ANTIQUES SHOW
description: THE atmosphere was there -the moon reflected in the Hudson River, the lights of the city sparkling like stars, the buffet tables groaning under an autumn bounty of hams, beef fillets, chutneys, muffins, pears and grapes. There was the chance, too, of ogling the likes of Robert Redford, Harry Belafonte, Tom Brokaw, Phyllis George Brown or Ralph Lauren.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GARDENING
description: WHEN horticulture advances to art, one result can be bonsai. Pronounced ''bone-SIGH,'' this Japanese word, written with the same characters in singular or plural, means ''dwarf tree culture.'' It is the ancient practice of growing beautifully proportioned trees in small dishes or trays. The art, initiated by the Chinese imperial court more than 1,200 years ago, is known in China as penjing.

title: Arco-Union Bid
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company and Union Oil Company of California, in a 50-50 partnership, were apparent high bidders on 24 Alaskan North Slope oil leases.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
F.B.I. WILL SEEK ARREST WARRANT IN LOAN SCHEME
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it would seek a fugitive warrant today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn for the arrest of a Long Island businessman who they believe has fled after obtaining under false pretenses $10 million in loans from three banks.

title: Begin and Sharon Get; Less Backing in; Poll
description: An opinion poll disclosed today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon still appear to have the backing of the Israeli public, although their popularity has declined markedly in the aftermath of the mass slaying of Palestinian civilians in Beirut by Lebanese militiamen.

title: Twirler Fails by 1 1/2 Pounds To Lose Enough to Perform
description: Peggy Ward, the majorette who was told to drop to 126 pounds or be barred from marching with her high school band on Friday night, was 1 1/2 pounds over the limit today.

title: MARINES RETURN TO BEIRUT AS ISRAEL LEAVES AIRPORT
description: United States Marines landed here today by ship and helicopter and took control of the Beirut International Airport minutes after the last Israeli soldiers withdrew from the area.

title: CABARET: MARGARET WHITING
description: ANY singer who undertakes a program of songs associated with Ethel Merman is making things difficult for herself. Miss Merman's brassy, penetrating attack is so distinctive that it has become an essential part of the songs to which she has applied it.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt CRISIS. The Last Year of the Carter Presi- dency. By Hamilton Jordan. 431 pages. Illustrated. Putnam. $16.95.

title: Bridge: 2 Colorful Partners Found Way to Outwit Opponents
description: Two colorful young men, both brilliant players, formed a partnership in the 1982 Spingold Team Championship, played recently in Albuquerque, N.M. One of them was Ken Lebensold, a New York mathematician who plays the piano, runs marathons and aims to be an environmental lawyer. The other was Joe Silver, an ebullient lawyer from Montreal who won the Vanderbilt Team title eight years ago.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $6,847,380 for the qr and 6 mos

title: Cluster Bomb Device Still Shipped to Israel
description: The explosive grenade that gives the cluster bomb its devastating punch has been shipped to Israel despite President Reagan's order stopping the supply of cluster bombs, CBS News said tonight.

title: Belushi Grand Jury Hears Robin Williams
description: The actor Robin Williams, one of the last people to see John Belushi alive, testified today before a county grand jury that concluded two days of hearings on the death of the comedian by a drug overdose.

title: Devils Are Beaten By Islanders, 4-3
description: Chico Resch yielded a goal to his former teammates five seconds after he entered the exhibition game in the second period tonight. It proved to be the winner as the Islanders defeated the New Jersey Devils, 4-3, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: AEG Talks Broken Off
description: Electrolux AB has broken off talks with AEG-Telefunken A.G. on management of AEG's household appliances division. An Electrolux spokesman said the talks had been ended because AEG's situation ''turned out to be more complicated than anyone could have foreseen.''

title: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE VOWS TO KEEP U.S. CONTROL OF AID FOR CHILD NUTRITION
description: The House voted today to oppose any attempt by the Reagan Administration to shift responsibility for Federal child nutrition programs to the states.

title: HERS
description: ONE of our children is distressed because she cannot find an affordable house to share within walking distance of her job - in a high-priced neighborhood. She could go across the river and find an apartment for less on a busline in an old, down-at-the-heels suburb. But her goals are defined and her tastes are expensive. We have spent her entire life forming those tastes and now, with the lessons well learned, she cannot afford what we taught her to want. The neglected lesson of compromise is still around the corner - or, perhaps for her, across the river. For now she is suffering, as do most of us, withdrawal from the Good Life.

title: 'CITY LOVERS' AND 'COMING OF AGE'
description: The subject of racism links two of the shorter films in this year's New York Film Festival, a South African dramatic film and an American documentary. Barney Simon's ''City Lovers,'' based on a story by Nadine Gordimer, tells of an unlikely and illegal love affair, while Josh Hanig's ''Coming of Age'' studies interracial encounter groups in a setting that could only be California.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Down 4% in August
description: The Publishers Information Bureau reports that its member publications - which include most of the country's important magazines - were down 4 percent in advertising pages in August compared with August 1981, but, thanks to rate increases, were about even in ad revenues.

title: STUDY SEES FLAWS IN LAWS ON ALIENS
description: Laws establishing penalties for employers of illegal aliens have generally not been effective in foreign countries, according to a study issued today by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
AMERICAN CAN TO BUY THIRD INSURER
description: The American Can Company, continuing a shift away from the packaging businesses, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Penncorp Financial Inc., a general insurance company, for $295.4 million in cash, notes and cash.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After extraordinary charge of $1,281,000 related to flood loss

title: SEX BIAS IS FOUND AT V.A. HOSPITAL
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Female veterans are discriminated against in Veterans Administration health care facilities even though the number of women in the armed services is increasing, according to Congressional auditors.

title: COUNCIL ENDORSES BILL TO PUT ART IN CITY BUILDINGS
description: Budgets for new public buildings in New York City, including police stations and shelters for the homeless, would have to include money for art works under a measure approved yesterday by the City Council Finance Committee.

title: CONFEREES CLEAR BILL TO SHORE UP SAVINGS INDUSTRY
description: A joint Senate-House conference committee approved landmark legislation today to subsidize the nation's ailing savings institutions and give them broad new lending powers similar to those of commercial banks.

title: ROBIN YOUNT'S BANDWAGON
description: BOSTON T he bandwagon is rolling and its loudspeaker is blaring: vote for Robin Yount for the American League's Most Valuable Player award. But the Milwaukee Brewers' shortstop is a reticent candidate. He prefers not to discuss it now, thank you, not even with those teammates stumping for votes up on the bandwagon he's trying to ignore.

title: News Analysis
description: By seeming to say Tuesday night that the United States Marines would not be withdrawn from Beirut until Syrian and Israeli forces had left Lebanon, President Reagan apparently transformed an expectation into a condition.

title: PANEL BACKS SMALL-COMPANY TAX AID
description: A bill that would help small, closely held companies avoid corporate income taxes was approved by the Senate Finance Committee Tuesday night.

title: New Head at Berkley Group
description: Roger Cooper, editor in chief of Berkley Books since 1979, has been appointed editorial director of the Berkley Publishing Group. Nancy Coffee, former editor in chief of Ballantine Books, has been named editor in chief of Berkley. In addition to Berkley and Jove books, the group includes the recent Ace Books and Playboy Press acquisitions.

title: WALLACE DEFIED NEW SOUTH POLITICS TO WIN RUNOFF
description: After the voting that marked former Gov. George C. Wallace's latest comeback from political retirement, the candidates' voices told almost as much as their words about this state's Democratic gubernatorial runoff.

title: Leonard May Fight
description: The world welterweight champion, Sugar Ray Leonard, says he has grown comfortable in his life away from the ring but that he may return for one more fight. The opponent: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the undisputed middleweight champion.

title: PRO-PIPELINE BID IN HOUSE NARROWLY FAILS
description: The House of Representatives declined today by a tiny margin to hand President Reagan a symbolic setback on his handling of sanctions against construction of the Soviet Union's new gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LEWELLYN IS CONVICTED OF IOWA EMBEZZLEMENT
description: Gary Lewellyn, a former stockbroker, was convicted today by a judge in United States District Court on charges stemming from the embezzlement of $16 million from two Iowa banks.

title: Utilities Win Oregon Test
description: A judge in Oregon ruled yesterday that 10 Oregon utilities were not required to meet their financial obligations for two nuclear plants that had been planned and later terminated by the Washington Public Power Supply System. A spokesman for the supply system said it would appeal.

title: LIBRARY REVIVING AS CULTURAL CENTER
description: A half-dozen major public events during the next several years - everything from a centennial salute to Franklin D. Roosevelt to an exhibition on censorship to mark the nightmarish year predicted in George Orwell's ''1984'' - are the most visible part of a new program that is reversing the decline of the New York Public Library. After almost a decade of financial and physical deterioration, the institution, which by any standard ranks among the world's top six libraries, has become a vital part of the city's intellectual life.

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $242,362 and a tax credit of$560,000

title: MUSIC: INTERNATIONAL CHORUSES FESTIVAL
description: CHORUSES OF THE WORLD helped celebrate its fifth International Festival with a visit to Avery Fisher Hall Monday night. There were 11 university choirs from 10 countries, a lot of nice music, and after intermission everyone crowded on stage together and boomed out Handel, Bruckner, Kodaly, Arbeau, Bach and a little folk music, too.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Financial Ills Force Delaware Park to Shut
description: Delaware Park, the state's only thoroughbred race track, went out of business today. The decision, according to officials, was a result of increased competition and a poor economy, among other things.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Where the Voice Of the People Is Not Heard

title: Smoke Disrupts PATH Service
description: Smoke from a train caused an hourlong suspension of PATH commuter rail service on two of four routes between New Jersey and New York City this morning, officials said.

title: Suspect in Texas Abductions Held After High-Speed Chase
description: A self-described ''political terrorist'' whom the police have linked to three southern Texas kidnappings was captured tonight after a high-speed automobile chase, a Department of Public Safety spokesman said.

title: KEY PHALANGIST AIDES IMPLICATED IN OPERATION THAT LED TO KILLINGS
description: The operation that started in the Shatila Palestinian refugee camp in Beirut and resulted in the massacre of more than 300 civilians was directed by the top Phalangist military commanders and involved the elite corps of the Phalangist militia, according to Phalangist and Western diplomatic sources in Beirut.

title: Monroe Crypt Roses Ended
description: Joe DiMaggio, who was married for three years to Marilyn Monroe, has ended a 20-year standing order for thrice-weekly delivery of roses to her crypt, a Parisian Florist spokesman said today. The florist said Mr. DiMaggio gave no explanation.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO RUN GOVERNMENT BEYOND TODAY
description: The Clinch River breeder reactor barely survived a Senate vote today as senators began floor debate on a catchall interim spending bill needed to keep the Government operating in the fiscal year that begins Friday.

title: THE TIMES, THEY ARE TOUGH IN KILKENNY, IRELAND
description: The world recession finally caught up with Kilkenny one day last spring. In the rest of Ireland and the world the process had been like a drought: slowly parching and cracking and drying up economies. In Kilkenny it came like a thunderclap.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 30, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: IF THE QUESTIONS SOUNDED HARSHER, THEY WERE
description: To many who watched last night's news conference from the White House, the reporters seemed more aggressive, even emotional, and their questions on economic policy and the Middle East more hostile than usual in the 20-month Presidency of Ronald Reagan.

title: AN UN-SUPREME COURT
description: There is no apparent reason why good judges can't be good managers. But Justice John Paul Stevens seems to think otherwise, and has produced a very bad idea.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid May 12, 1982

title: TESTS FIND TWO CURES FOR TRAVELER'S DIARRHEA
description: Two common antibiotics will quickly relieve travelers' diarrhea, a disorder that upsets the vacations of millions of Americans who go to warm-weather countries, a study shows.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Don't Kiss the Cabby

title: Sun in Coal Deal
description: The Sun Company said it had agreed to buy the Whitaker Coal Corporation, a privately owned concern in Hazard, Ky., that produces 1.2 million tons of steam coal a year and has properties in eastern Kentucky with proven reserves of 70 million tons. Sun said the payment would be in cash with a provision for partial payment in notes; the amount was not disclosed.

title: THE BIBLE AS A TOOL IN POLITICAL HANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Barnes Joins C.B.A.
description: Marvin Barnes signed a contract to play the 1982-83 season for the newly formed Detroit Spirits of the Continental Basketball Association. It will mark the second time the 30-year-old Barnes has played in Detroit.

title: CAREER COUNSELING INDUSTRY ACCUSED OF MISREPRESENTATION
description: NEW rules to regulate more closely the career-counseling industry in New York City are being proposed today by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The department's proposals, which have to be approved by the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs after public hearings, follow an undercover investigation by the department into consumers' complaints about the industry and two recent State Supreme Court decisions.

title: REP. FENWICK REJECTS INVITATION TO DEBATE AT NEW YORK TIMES
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of Bernardsville, N.J., has declined an invitation to debate Frank Lautenberg of Montclair, N.J., her Democratic opponent for United States Senate, before a panel of reporters and editors at The New York Times because other news organizations might attend.

title: 'BRIDESHEAD' REVIVES CASTLE HOWARD
description: LONDON FOR four decades, the tall windows of the magnificent south front of Castle Howard - now one of Britain's most familiar buildings, thanks to the television series ''Brideshead Revisited'' -have looked blindly across terraced lawns to the now equally familiar fountain where Charles Ryder and Julia Flyte Mottram loved and lost each other in the moonlight. For what wasn't shown on the screen was the total desolation of the rooms behind those windows, which were ruined by fire in 1940.

title: Grey Is Named Dietac Agency
description: Grey Advertising yesterday was assigned Dietac, an appetite suppressant product, by the Menley & James Laboratories division of the SmithKline Company. The billings were about $3.2 million.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1982; The Economy
description: A landmark bill to aid ailing thrift institutions was approved by Senate-House conferees. The bill, expected to be approved by both houses this week and signed by President Reagan, gives savings institutions a form of Government subsidy and broad new lending powers like those of commercial banks. It also calls for a new account equivalent to money market funds. (Page A1.)

title: FOES IN SEPTEMBER, FRIENDS BY NOVEMBER
description: To the Editor:

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
Nurse on Coast Pleads Not Guilty in 12 Deaths
description: Robert Diaz, a nurse, pleaded not guilty today to charges he murdered 12 patients by injecting them with huge doses of a heart regulating drug while he worked at two rural hospitals last year.

title: MIDDLE EAST CHOICES
description: It is time to return to the agenda of peace in the Middle East. And the item at the top remains President Reagan's initiative.

title: POP: THE MERCURIAL PUBLIC IMAGE LTD. AT ROSELAND
description: PUBLIC Image Ltd. has been conditioning its followers to expect the unexpected since the release of its first album almost five years ago. Fans and critics expected a punk-rock apotheosis from an alliance between John Lydon, formerly known as Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols, and Keith Levene, a founder of the Clash.

title: Penney Franchises
description: The J.C. Penney Company said it would close its five franchised Wendy's hamburger restaurants in Belgium within the next month because of their poor earnings performance, and not exercise options to operate Wendy's stores in France, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. Penney said the costs of closing the Belgium stores ''are not significant.''

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Red Sox vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Boston. The Brewers are trying to increase their lead in the American League's Eastern Division before meeting Baltimore in a season-ending series this weekend. Their shortstop, Robin Yount, has become the first American League player at that position to get 200 hits in a season since Harvey Kuenn, who is now his manager, got 201 in 1954. Tigers vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Detroit. Earl Weaver, the Oriole manager, would like to go into retirement a winner, but time is running out. Dodgers vs. Atlanta Braves, at Los Angeles. If Joe Torre's Braves can win tonight and then do well at San Diego over the weekend, they'll be in good shape. Reason: The Dodgers and the Giants clash at San Francisco in their final three games, and at least one of those clubs is likely to be knocked out as a result. Giants vs. Houston Astros, at San Francisco. Frank Robinson needs a victory here if he is to have a good chance of achieving his ''Miracle of Candlestick.'' Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.)
