Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Buffalo Sabres, exhibition, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8:05 P.M. This is the Islanders' final game before next Tuesday's regular-season opener in Vancouver, and it is accompanied by bad news.

title: SHARON SUGGESTS SYRIA WAS TIED TO SLAYING OF GEMAYEL
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that information obtained so far by Israel pointed to Syrian involvement in the assassination of Bashir Gemayel on Sept. 14, nine days before he was to be inaugurated as Lebanon's President.

title: FAMILIES EAGERLY AWAIT FLIGHT FROM BANGKOK
description: In the American Embassy in Bangkok and in homes scattered around the United States preparations were being made yesterday to receive the 11 Amerasian children who are scheduled to come out of Vietnam today.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for 12 wks to
description: B-Including a tax credit of $4,970,000; C-Net loss; results are weeks and 28 weeks for the latest periods and 13 weeks and 26 w the year-ago periods

title: Fed Adopts New System
description: To help it control the nation's money supply, the Federal Reserve Board voted today to adopt a new management technique, known as contemporaneous reserve accounting, on Feb. 2, 1984.

title: UP TO 10 DIE IN SOVIET JET CRASH
description: A Soviet jetliner carrying 77 people veered off a runway, crashed into a grove of trees and burst into flames just after landing at the Luxembourg airport tonight. The police said that as many as 10 people were killed and that the others suffered burns and fractures.

title: SANTA FE DIRECTOR IN INSIDER TRADING AGREEMENT
description: A director of the Santa Fe International Corporation has agreed to return $278,750 in profits he had made from stock purchased in the company two weeks before it was taken over, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.

title: Morris Is Charged
description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris, the former Miami Dolphin running back who was arrested Aug. 18 on charges of possessing cocaine, now faces a charge of writing a worthless check to buy a $498 pistol. He surrendered last Thursday after having been notified by mail that an arrest warrant was issued, the police said today. He was booked and then was freed on $1,000 bond.

title: Technology; Why Allied Bought Bendix
description: WHAT induced the Allied Corporation to lay out an estimated $1.9 million to acquire the Bendix Corporation last week? At Saturday's post-takeover news conference, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's chairman, cited four special attractions. One is domestic income to balance Allied's overseas earnings from oil and gas. The three others center on technology.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cities Service Unit
description: The Columbian Chemical Company, a unit of Cities Service Company, said in Tulsa, Okla, that it would quit the butyl rubber business and close its Lake Charles, La., plant by the end of April 1983.

title: F.T.C. Opposes Legal Bar to Oil Mergers
description: Recent mergers involving oil companies have not significantly reduced competition in the industry and a legislative ban on such combinations is ''unwarranted,'' the Federal Trade Commission declared today.

title: JUDGE IS TOLD C.I.A. SOUGHT WILSON'S AID TO GET SOVIET MISSILE
description: A former Federal official told a judge today that an officer of the Central Intelligence Agency had met with Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent, to discuss obtaining a Soviet antiaircraft missile and jet from Libya.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Caesars New Jersey Inc is 86.7 percent owned by Caesars World Inc

title: Motorola Ruling
description: Motorola Inc. said the International Trade Commission had ruled on the company's antidumping petition against Japanese manufacturers of high-capacity pagers sold in the United States and had made a preliminary determination of material injury to the American paging industry.

title: People
description: * Peter Tate has been elected a senior vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Although it is not possible at this time to predict the precise duration of the presence of U.S. forces in Beirut, our agreement with the Government of Lebanon makes clear that they will be needed only for a limited period to meet the urgent requirements posed by the current situation.'' - President Reagan in a letter to the leaders of Congress. (A12:1.)

title: AL LAST, LINER NOTES FOR CASSETTES
description: THE increasing popularity of recorded cassettes vis-a-vis disks has had some welcome results at CBS Masterworks, where the decision has been made to include liner notes with all cassettes - finally.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Antitrust Critic
description: The passage of legislation to give the National Football League further exemptions from antitrust laws would be like ''putting the fox in charge of guarding the hen house,'' a noted law professor testified today.

title: Phone Line Charge Up
description: For the second time in five months, the Federal Communications Commission today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance competitors to increase their payments for access to A.T.& T.'s local phone lines.

title: Carlton Wins No. 22
description: Steve Carlton pitched a two-hitter to pick up his 22d victory of the season tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 4-0 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: WARSAW MAY END SOLIDARITY UNION
description: The Polish martial law authorities appear to be preparing to outlaw and eliminate the now-suspended trade union Solidarity.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S LETTER TO CONGRESS ON MARINES IN LEBANON
description: Following is the text of a letter concerning the use of American forces in Lebanon that President Reagan sent today to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate: Special to the New York Times

title: A Hidden Motive?
description: His full name is Socrates Brasileiro Sampaio de Souza Vieira de Oliveira, but in the soccer world he is known simply as Socrates. He was one of two men invited to play for the Cosmos in Carlos Alberto's farewell game at Giants Stadium Tuesday night.

title: SHULTZ MEETS ALLIES ON SOVIET TRADE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, putting the controversy over the pipeline issue with the European allies aside, has undertaken a discussion with them on overall East-West economic issues as the first step toward devising a more coordinated allied policy on trade with the Russians.

title: G.M. Notes Gains From Steel Plan
description: The competitive bidding system for buying steel that the General Motors Corporation began last spring to improve quality and lower prices is working better than expected, Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman, told a convention of the Association of Iron and Steel Engineers in Chicago.

title: Escaped Inmate Captured
description: A prisoner who escaped from a jail bus was captured today in Los Angeles after the authorities got an anonymous telephone tip, sheriff's officials said. The prisoner, Ricky Bland, 21 years old, was among seven prisoners who escaped Tuesday by jumping from a moving bus in the foothills north of Los Angeles. Two prisoners were recaptured earlier and another was killed after leaping from the bus, the authorities said.

title: DISNEY BANKING ON 'TEX' TO REWIN TEEN-AGERS
description: HOLLYWOOD WALT DISNEY'S problems in enticing back the teen-age audience it lost a decade ago continue. The Disney studio has tried sciencefiction (''The Black Hole''), slightly racy PG-rated high school hijinks (''Take Down'') and electronic games (''Tron'') without denting the teen-agers' belief that Disney movies are ''for kids.''

title: WHEN ONLY HEROIN CAN EASE UNBEARABLE PAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Metropolitan Home magazine to Bradley, Dimmock & Hungerford Inc.

title: ANTONIONI'S MYSTERY 'IDENTIFICATION OF A WOMAN'
description: ''IDENTIFICATION of a Woman,'' the new film by Michelangelo Antonioni, is about an Italian film director named Niccolo (Tomas Milian) who is looking for a subject for a new film. So is Mr. Antonioni and, unlike Niccolo, he never finds it.

title: Advertising; Eastern And Chevy Share Ads
description: A new kind of premium promotion starting tomorrow will link C hevrolet with Eastern Airlines. ''Buy Now and Fly'' was announced and explained yesterday in the H elmsley Palace Hotel by Robert C. Stempel, general manager of the G eneral Motors division and Frank Borman, chairman and president of t he airline. For the former it means more sales of its cars and p ickup trucks. For the latter, it means more full seats on its f lights. For the consumer it is supposed to look like a good deal - t wo free round trips to all but the most distant Eastern destinationsw ith the purchase of a Chevrolet car or Chevy or G.M.C. pickup truck.

title: Blues, Flounder and Porgies Are Running 1
description: Bluefish of all sizes offshore. Albacore and bonito have been sporadic. Early this week, there were some dazzling catches of longfin tuna. One charter boat, the Slammer, brought in 52 of the fish, over a ton, after a day on the edge of Wilmington Canyon. Barnegat, N.J.: Plenty of bluefish over Barnegat Ridge; good catches of longfin tuna over Hudson Canyon when weather permits. A few weakfish being caught offshore. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Half-day boat trips for fluke and bluefish continue, as do all day and all night chumming excursions for bluefish. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Small porgies plentiful in Shrewsbury and Navesink Rivers; good size catches of spot reported in the Shrewsbury; mediumsize bluefish still being caught near Sandy Hook; winter flounder are moving in; schools of 5 to 8 pounds striped bass are moving up and down the beach from Sandy Hook, westward. Crabbing is good in the lower part of the Shrewsbury. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Angling for small bluefish is excellent; porgies plentiful and getting larger; a few bonito are about and blackfishing is fair. Freeport, L.I.: Bluefish of all sizes over Cholera Banks; Hudson Canyon angling still producing yellowfin tuna and albacore; fluke have petered out, but winter flounder fishing is improving. Angling for cod fish and blackfish is getting better. Captree State Park, L.I.: Good fishing for winter flounder, blackfish and large blues. A few stripers are being caught from the beaches at night. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Winter flounder catches improving rapidly; blowfish still plentiful, as are snapper blues up to three-quarters of a pound.

title: Dickey Penalized
description: A District Court judge today placed Curtis Dickey, the Colt running back, on three months' unsupervised probation. Caught for speeding, Dickey pleaded not guilty to a charge of transporting an unregistered handgun. He said he had been unaware of the registration law.

title: Democracy Recouped in Bolivia
description: For more than a century and a half, coup-prone Bolivia averaged a new president a year. Lately, the pace has quickened.

title: Surgery for Powell
description: Marvin Powell, the Jets' all-pro tackle and player representative, was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital where he was scheduled to undergo minor throat surgery last night for removal of a benign polyp, a team spokesman said. Powell, 27, was expected to remain hospitalized for one or two days. The wide receiver Wesley Walker will assume Powell's duties as player representative.

title: Inland's Chief Picks His Heir-Designate
description: Frederick G. Jaicks, chairman and chief executive of the Inland Steel Company, has picked a successor to run the nation's seventhlargest steel maker. The company said yesterday that Mr. Jaicks, 64 years old, would recommend to the company's directors at their October meeting that they designate Frank W. Luerssen, president, to be chief executive officer effective Dec. 1, 1982.

title: Market Place; Lexidata's Viewing Aid
description: THE problem of viewing a three-dimensional item on a twodimensional computer screen has plagued computer-aided designers for years. Now a small company called the Lexidata Corporation appears to have solved that problem. Lexidata may thus be nailing down its position as a leading vendor of graphics display systems.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SHOPPING FOR BRITISH ANTIQUES BY COMPUTER
description: In a corner of a small office above the American Hamburger Restaurant in this London suburb sits a small Honeywell computer that is one of Britain's great locaters of antiques. Within a matter of seconds it can find pieces ranging from Regency mahogany saber-leg chairs to stuffed male lions.

title: Wild Jails, Closed Minds
description: A series of articles in The Washington Post this week about the jail in nearby Prince George's County, Md., inspires fascination, disgust and a message for political leaders everywhere. The articles document that rape has become a routine part of prison life. Though the act is homosexual, it has become an expression of manhood in the perverse subculture that flourishes beyond the view of inattentive or frightened guards.

title: Allen's Travels
description: Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser who resigned in January after it was disclosed that he had accepted $1,000 from Japanese journalists meant as an honorarium for Nancy Reagan, seems to have more than enough work to keep him busy.

title: A HELPING HAND FOR INJURED WILDLIFE
description: Carol Odell rises with the sun, dons blue jeans, an old shirt and a pair of oversize rubber boots and journeys from her tidy country home into the wilds of her own backyard. There, she spends up to 18 hours a day doing her part for the world's ecosystem.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $1.5 million for the qr and yr from discontinued operations

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Foes of Marcos Condemn His Trip to U.S.

title: CHLORDANE PROBLEM IN HOUSES ON SLABS
description: A pesticide used to kill termites has leaked into the ventilation systems of more than 1,500 houses at United States Air Force bases across the country, according to studies made public recently by the Air Force. The pesticide, chlordane, was found to have entered heating and air-conditioning ducts in dwellings built on concrete slabs, allowing it to circulate in the air freely.

title: Habib Visiting Cairo For Talks on Lebanon
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, arrived here today, and the authoritative Al Ahram newspaper said he would meet with top Egyptian officials to discuss the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: 5-1 WHAT'S DAT TAKES COWDIN
description: The horse that won the $84,700 Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday figured to become the top challenger to Copelan for supremacy among the 2-year-olds in the East, but the winner of a cheaper race earlier on the card emerged as a better prospect.

title: Free Is Free
description: A woman phoned The New York Times sports department the other day to ask when the New York City Marathon would be run. Oct. 24, she was told.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Partnership Is Formed For Software Magazine
description: A former Time Inc. chap and a Boston advertising woman have combined their talents with some cash from E.F. Hutton and have formed the Redgate Publishing Company in Vero Beach, Fla. It will bring out a publication called List, a twice-yearly advertising medium (of course) which will be a directory of personal-computer application softwear that follows on editorial material and display advertising.

title: Wendy's Sues Burger King
description: Wendy's International Inc. has filed a $25 million lawsuit against Burger King, charging that advertisements that tout the Burger King Whopper hamburger as better tasting than Wendy's are ''false, misleading and deceptive.''

title: STREAK OF FUTILITY BEWILDERS DODGERS
description: When the baseball season ends and Dodger Stadium's huge television screen is turned off for the winter, the most appropriate final image might be one of Steve Garvey, hands on hips, standing near first base and staring toward left field, unable to understand why the Dodgers are falling through a trap door.

title: A Way to Relax
description: What makes a 35-year-old woman want to swim half a mile in the Atlantic Ocean, ride a bicycle 20 miles and run 10 miles - all in the same day?

title: YANKEES TROUNCE INDIANS
description: The Yankees continued to gain tonight in their contest for fifth place in the American League East as Jerry Mumphrey and Ken Griffey drove in nine runs between them in a 13-6 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: ENVOY IN SEX ABUSE CASE REFUSES TO SURRENDER
description: A North Korean diplomat facing charges of sexually abusing a Bronx woman in an Eastchester park decided today not to surrender, according to his lawyer, as Westchester County police officers continued to search for him as a fugitive.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cagneys Celebrate 60th Anniversary

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Index; International
description: The times, they are tough in Kilkenny, Ireland A2 Pro-pipeline move narrowly fails in House A3 Shultz meets allies on Soviet trade A3 British Laborites reinforce disarmament stand A4 Around the World A7 An unsung staff makes the U.N. hum A10 Proposed Polish labor legislation expected to end Solidarity A11 Government/Politics House votes curb on drunken driving in U.S. A16 Balanced-budget supporters gain votes to force House showdown A19 Worldwide survey sees flaws in illegal alien curbs A20 Congress speeds action on series of environmental bills A21 Newark official tells Gibson jury of blank payment requests B2 Senator Moynihan to base cam- paign on his record as a liberal B4 Rep. Fenwick declines invitation for debate at The Times B10 Wallace defied New South poli- tics in winning B14 Republican stake in Virginia election races is large B15 Washington Talk Briefing B12 Analysis: John Herbers on the President's news conference B12 No ''Auld Lang Syne'' for the fis- cal year 1982 B12 General Around the Nation A18 Brink's defendant contends her food was drugged in jail B3 Color suit recalls lines drawn under slavery B16 Education/Welfare More schools offer classes on tak- ing the college extrance exams B3 The Home Section Home Designers' assistants practice what mentors preach C1

title: MONDALE TELLS HOMOSEXUAL GROUP REAGAN RECORD IS BIASED ON RIGHTS
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale appealed to more than 1,000 homosexual rights activists and their supporters last night to join the Democratic Party in fighting what he called the ''irrational discrimination'' of the Reagan Adminstration.

title: Endorsement for Martin
description: Dave Garcia, the manager of the Cleveland Indians, says he thinks he will be replaced after this season, and he endorses Billy Martin to succeed him. ''It would be great for Cleveland to get Billy Martin,'' Garcia said of the Oakland A's manager.

title: REPUBLICANS PLAY FOR HIGH STAKES IN VIRGINIA RACE
description: The Republican stakes are high here this year in a conservative, formerly ''solid South'' Democratic domain where the Republicans have had nearly two decades of ascendency.

title: BELL ENDS PLAN TO EASE SOME RULES FOR EDUCATION OF THE HANDICAPPED
description: The Department of Education today withdrew a number of proposed regulations that critics said would severely hamper efforts to provide an adequate education for the nation's four million handicapped children.

title: FRANCE AND ITALY SUPPORT REAGAN ON USE OF TROOPS
description: The Italian and French Foreign Ministers said today that their joint force with the United States was likely to stay in Beirut until other foreign troops had left Lebanon.

title: 35 SENT TO JAIL FROM TEANECK IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: Thirty-five of the 541 striking teachers, secretaries and aides in the Teaneck school system were jailed for up to three hours today for defying a court-imposed backto-work order.

title: Top Operating Officer Named at Square D Co.
description: Charles B. Yates, executive vice president of the Square D Company of Chicago, has been elected vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: A New Career
description: It has been almost two years since Rita Jenrette made headlines as the wife of Representative John W. Jenrette, the South Carolina Democrat convicted in connection with Abscam. Now, with sales of her autobiography topping a quarter million copies and a 10-page feature in Playboy behind her, she says she is ''doing exactly what I want to do, for the first time.''

title: U.S. Press Is Rebuked Over Sandinist Activities
description: A Reagan Administration official told a meeting here today of the Inter American Press Association that American news organizations and human rights groups had failed to report adequately on what he said were threats to the independence of the Roman Catholic Church in Nicaragua.

title: BANKRUPTCIES CLOG COURTS AND MAY SLOW ECONOMY'S REVIVAL
description: A record number of bankruptcies this year among American businesses and individuals is clogging the courts, prompting Congressional debate and, some economists say, impeding the economic recovery. The number of personal bankruptcies is expected to exceed 440,000 for the second consecutive year, the most since the Great Depression. As for businesses, according to Dun & Bradstreet, a creditinformation service, more than 17,500 commercial and industrial concerns alone have failed so far this year, already the highest annual total since World War II and approaching the record of 19,859 set in 1933.

title: MOYNIHAN PLANS TO STRESS RECORD AS LIBERAL FORCE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that he would base his re-election campaign on his record in the Senate as a liberal.

title: Arafat at Burial of Aide
description: Yasir Arafat marched at the head of 200,000 mourners today as Brig. Saad Sayel, the operations chief of Mr. Arafat's Al Fatah guerrillas who was slain in an ambush Monday, was buried in a refugee camp near here, the Palestine Liberation Organization press agency Wafa reported. ''The revolution will continue to victory,'' the agency quoted Mr. Arafat as saying in a eulogy.

title: Rose Rotter Dies at 101
description: Rose Rotter, one of the oldest residents of Queens, died Monday at the age of 101 after a long illness. Mrs. Rotter lived in Woodside, where her husband, Marcus Rotter, a tailor, died in 1975, also at the age of 101. She is survived by a daughter, Clara, and two sons, Alex and Leonard, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

title: CHRYSLER'S WISH UPON A STAR
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been through a few challenges of its own, is hoping to attract the attention of college students with an elaborate puzzle called ''The Pentastar Challenge.''

title: Rangers Tie Flyers On Late Goal, 3-3
description: Although they were tired from a dawn flight from Minneapolis-St. Paul, the Rangers rallied to score two goals last night in the final period and tie the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-3, at Madison Square Garden in an exhibition game.

title: FOR THE DRINKER, THERE IS BAD AND GOOD NEWS
description: Liquor, even in moderate cocktail party drinking, damages red blood cells, but the damage is temporary and can be balanced by eating vegetables, a doctor reported today.

title: CAPITAL PUNISHMENT IS A FALSE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HOLD YOUR WOOLIES'
description: To the Editor:

title: CANCER ISSUE COSTS DOCTOR STATE LICENSE
description: The State Board of Regents has revoked the medical license of a Scarsdale surgeon on the ground that his promises of curing cancer so deviated from accepted medical practice that they were ''tantamount to quackery.''

title: N.F.L. STRIKE UPSETS TV RATINGS
description: This was to be the season in which prime-time television returned to normal after the last two years of disruptions by striking actors and writers. But yet another strike, this time by players in the National Football League, has upset customary viewing patterns.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,513,000 for the qr and $2,361,000 for the yr and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $6,319,000 for the qr and yr...C-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $467,000...D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,968,000

title: METS LOSE TO CARDS, WASTE TRIPLE PLAY
description: Not even a triple play, their second of the season, could preserve the Mets' four-game winning streak last night. Instead, they incurred a 4-1 defeat by the Chicago Cubs in their penultimate game of the season at Shea Stadium.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: PORTABLE panels have proved to be a practical way to divide open offices. In the prevailing limited market in housing, in which people have to adjust to what they already have or perhaps live in an open space like a loft, such panels provide an easy way to create rooms or divide an existing one.

title: LABOR PARTY REINFORCES STAND ON DISARMAMENT BY BRITAIN
description: The Labor Party bound itself more tightly than ever today to the doctrine of nuclear disarmament by Britain after a debate at its annual conference that was punctuated by stinging criticisms of American policy.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY homeowners may not realize that beyond installing weatherstripping and adding insulation, substantial fuel savings can be realized by keeping their heating systems in good repair and insuring that they are at maximum efficiency.

title: On Auto Safety
description: In 1974, the Department of Transportation originated a $30 million program to ''push the state of the art'' in automobile safety engineering.

title: THE LIBS ARE COMING!
description: For 14 occasionally glorious years, the Great Shift Rightward was in full swing. In national elections, setting aside the aberrances after Watergate, the trend has been unmistakably conservative, and in local elections voters have been turning away from ''turn-'em-loose Bruce'' judges toward sheriffs who never heard of a root cause.

title: DAVIS HURT IN GIANTS' VICTORY
description: The San Francisco Giants found a knuckleball pitcher they could handle tonight, defeating Joe Niekro and the Houston Astros, 6-1, at Candlestick Park to remain in the torrid National League West race.

title: Too Snappy a Center
description: The tendency of Dave Rimington, the senior center for Nebraska, to snap the football just before the count is completed may cost him playing time Saturday at Auburn, according to Charlie McBride, the Nebraska defensive coordinator.

title: A.&.P. HAS $8 MILLION NET IN PERIOD
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday that it had net income of $8 million in the second fiscal quarter ended Sept. 11. That represented profits of 21 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $11.4 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The latest quarter included a tax loss carry-forward credit of $2.4 million. A year earlier, A.& P. had a loss of $11.4 million.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DOW FALLS BY 13.06, TO 906.27
description: Against a drab economic background, the stock market suffered its biggest setback in five weeks yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 13.06 points, to 906.27. Heavy-equipment issues came under particular selling pressure.

title: Chemical Bank Suing Daon
description: The Chemical Bank said yesterday that it had filed a $36 million lawsuit against the Daon Development Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, over two land deals.

title: RADIOFONE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After expenses of $166,000 or 8 cents a shr, related to the company's pendingmerger with a unit of Metromedia Inc

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $12.3 million for qr and the 9 mos

title: DEMOCRAT SAYS PRESIDENT USED FALSE JOB DATA
description: Calling President Reagan the Great Prevaricator, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee today accused him of falsely asserting that the percentage of Americans working was at a record high.

title: Vice Adm. William Ellis, 74; Ex-Chief of Staff in Atlantic
description: Vice Adm. William Ellis, retired, a former chief of staff for the Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic, died Sunday at a hospital here.

title: California Plans Fight On Carcinogens in Air
description: The chairman of the state Air Resources Board says that California will make a major effort to control what she says were cancer-causing chemicals in urban air.

title: SUIT ON RACE RECALLS LINES DRAWN UNDER SLAVERY
description: A Louisiana woman who the state contends is black has gone to court to have herself declared white, and that is but the short of it.

title: BRIEFING
description: Move for James Buckley

title: AS THE ASSEMBLY SPEAKERS DRONE, AN UNSUNG STAFF MAKES U.N. HUM
description: To outsiders, the tall Secretariat building at United Nations headquarters here harbors an impressive agglomeration of diplomats. In fact, it is home to a collection of civil servants - world civil servants -who go about their business regardless of what the diplomats may be doing on the floor of the General Assembly next door.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * City Investing Co. said it had sold $100 million of 14.50 percent senior notes, due 1992, to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Jet Replacement
description: Pro football fans from the metropolitan area who are starved for some sort of weekend activity are being courted by C.W. Post for its home opener Saturday against Central Connecticut State at Hickox Field in Greenvale, L.I.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day last Friday incorrectly identified a company that plans to offer direct broadcast satellite service.

title: Auto Plant Closing
description: New England's only auto assembly plant will close Friday for an indefinite period, leaving 3,400 jobless and eliminating $105 million from the local economy. The General Motors Corporation said slow sales of the Pontiac J-6000 and the Chevrolet Celebrity produced at the plant had led to the shutdown, which is the first in the plant's 34-year history.

title: 2 Quakes Rock Salvador
description: Two earthquakes shook San Salvador Tuesday night, rattling windows but causing no damage, preliminary reports from the Seismological Observatory said today. Both quakes were centered in Guatemala, 72 miles northwest of here, the spokesman said.

title: Strike Could Cut Playoffs In N.F.L.
description: The National Football League is considering the cancellation of not only some regular-season games but also the wild-card round of the playoffs as a result of the player strike.

title: Israeli Reservists Ask Not to Go to Lebanon
description: A petition asking not to be sent for military reserve duty in Lebanon, signed by 1,000 officers and soldiers, was delivered today to Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, the radio said.

title: CONGRESS IN PUSH TO APPROVE ENVIRONMENT BILLS
description: Over the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House today passed a bill that would require the Department of the Interior to identify any development near a national park, either on private or public lands, that might be detrimental to the park's environment.

title: Soviet Air Raid On Afghans Reported
description: Soviet helicopter gunships backed by MIG jets bombed and strafed the main market in the Afghan town of Pagman this month, killing or wounding dozens of people, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: Metal Futures Tumble On Rate Expectations
description: Gold futures plummeted yesterday in uncommonly volatile trading. Trading on New York's Commodity Exchange, the largest metal futures market, was punctuated by periods when gold futures sellers could not find buyers, leading to price gaps.

title: German Zinc Sale
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said it had agreed to sell 50 percent of its wholly owned zinc-producing subsidiary, Ruhr-Zink G.m.b.H., to an Australian company, Mim Holdings. Mim will also buy one-third of Rheinzink G.m.b.H.

title: Egypt Investment Pact
description: The United States and Egypt have signed an investment treaty that the Reagan Administration hopes will be the first of several pacts with other developing countries, the United States trade representative's office said today. The treaty, which must be ratified by the Senate, will require Egypt to maintain favorable conditions for United States investment, including free transfer of interest, dividends and capital.

title: ISRAELI SOUL-SEARCHING NEEDS A LARGER FOCUS
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN DIEGO MAN TO GREET HIS VIETNAMESE FAMILY
description: One of the first things Luis Villegas did when each of his three children was born in Vietnam was to register them at the American Embassy in Saigon. That was, he now believes, the providence of foresight.

title: Phillips Signs With the Nets
description: At a time when only four of the National Basketball Association's first-round draft choices are under contract, the Nets are expected to announce today the signing of one of their two first-round selections, Eddie Phillips of Alabama.

title: GIBSON JURY TOLD OF EARLY SIGNING OF JOB VOUCHERS
description: A city official testified today that Michael A. Bontempo, the man Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris are accused of helping through a no-show job, signed batches of blank payment requests for submission at a later time.

title: Glenz Cards a 66
description: David Glenz of Morris County took the lead today in the Michelob New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship with a five-under-par 66 in the opening round.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
CHINA IS BUILDING ATOM POWER PLANT
description: China has started construction of its first nuclear power station and plans to put it into operation in 1988. The station, which will have two generators of 300 megawatts each, is being built near Shanghai at a budgeted cost of $290 million, according to Shijie Jingji Daobao, a Shanghai economic newspaper.

title: CHEATING AIR TRAVELERS
description: Before Congress adjourns, two little-understood treaties that could severely restrict the rights of all international airline passengers and their families will be coming up for Senate ratification.

title: STAGE: POLAND RECALLED
description: AS she hangs the laundry on a clothesline in a Bronx tenement backyard in 1945, a pregnant immigrant mother, Raisal (Karen Ludwig), lets her mind wander. She recalls her childhood in prewar Poland, and her memories are less wistful than guilt-filled. Borrowing her timid sister's passport, she had left her family and traveled to America; in her absence, her mother, her sister and the sister's daughter all became victims of the Holocaust.

title: THE BIBLE AS A TOOL IN POLITICAL HANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE Marimekko store here, long known for its colorful fabrics, sheets and clothes, is celebrating its third anniversary with the introduction of furniture designs by Alvar Aalto, the Finnish architect.

title: DESIGNERS' ASSISTANTS PRACTICE WHAT MENTORS PREACH
description: known interior designers, they spend their days matching paint chips, picking fabrics and shopping for accessories, helping to create meticulously detailed and decorated rooms.

title: REAGAN HARDENING TONE OF CAMPAIGN
description: President Reagan, campaigning to protect the Republicans' control of the Senate, today delivered a solidly partisan attack on the Democrats as primarily responsible for ''today's pounding national hangover.''

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO CURB DRUNKEN DRIVING IN U.S.
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today to set up a national driver register and to provide grants to states that agree to suspend the licenses of drunken drivers on the first offense and to jail repeaters.

title: Koch's Loss Means; A Loss for Education
description: C ollege calendars have to be made up early, and plans were in the works at the New School for a political course next spring. It was to be a firsthand look at the 1983 mayoral race, on the seemingly reasonable assumption that Edward I. Koch would be wintering in Albany.

title: Westway Weasel, Subway Sympathy
description: Clever politics is not always good policy, and in the matter of Westway this left Lewis Lehrman with a problem. The Republican-Conservative candidate for governor had been swinging freely against the Manhattan development project, suggesting upstate that it somehow hurt road-building outside New York City. Now that he aims to broaden his appeal, he needs to prove that his opposition is also good for the city.

title: Houston Transit Panel Approves Rail System
description: The construction of a mass transit rail system for the traffic-choked Houston area was approved unanimously today by the Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County.

title: Ex-Astronaut Tells of Cancer
description: Jack L. Swigert Jr., the former astronaut, said today that he was being treated for cancer in his bone marrow, but he would continue his campaign for election to Congress. Mr. Swigert, the Republican nominee in the Sixth Congressional District, said he was continuing the campaign because of ''the optimism expressed by my doctors in the ability to control the cancer.'' The former astronaut underwent surgery several months ago for another malignancy, a tumor in his nasal passage.

title: Doyle Dane Expects Lower Third Quarter
description: Third-quarter earnings of Doyle Dane Bernbach International could be substantially below those of the same period last year, Robert G. Pfundstein, executive vice president and chief financial offier, told a group of dignified Wall Street types visiting the agency yesterday. The major causes, he said, would be the second devaluation of the Mexican peso and a decline in recruitment advertising spending by clients of its specialty subsidiary, Bernard Hodes Advertising.

title: Dismissed Man Dies in Crash After Killing Boss and Worker
description: After being dismissed from his job of 36 years today, a man returned to a gasoline plant with a rifle, killed his supervisor and wounded a co-worker, then died in the fiery crash of his truck as he fled, the authorities said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Seminars at McDonald's

title: HOUSE SHOWDOWN IS SET ON BUDGET-BALANCING PLAN
description: Supporters of a proposed constitutional amendment to require balanced Federal budgets gained enough signatures today to bypass a committee where the measure had been stalled and to force a showdown on the floor of the House of Representatives.

title: PUTTING THE FED UNDER TIGHTER CONTROL
description: With a recent offhand remark, President Reagan revived the question of whether the independence of the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, should be restricted. There are moves afoot that could lead to major limits on the Fed.

title: Museum Business Committee Names Chairman
description: Carl Spielvogel, chairman and chief executive officer of the Backer & Spielvogel advertising agency, has been named chairman of the business committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He succeeds Edward L. Palmer, retired chairman of the executive committee of Citibank N.A.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ANTIQUES AND GLASS
description: Westchester Antique Show, Westches- ter County Center, White Plains.

title: PARTIES REJECT 2 ON STATE COURTS FOR NOMINATION
description: Two Supreme Court judges were rejected for nomination to full terms yesterday by the Democratic and Republican Parties for different reasons in two counties, New York and Suffolk.

title: EX-BOSTON AIDE INDICTED ON PERJURY CHARGES
description: A former Boston Redevelopment Authority aide who was convicted of extortion last spring was indicted today on perjury charges by a Federal grand jury investigting corruption among city employees.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $350,000 for the qr and $510,000 for the yr...C-Net loss includes a tax credit of $215,000...D-Net income includes a tax credit of $560,000 and proceeds from the insurance of $565,000

title: TIRED OLD FINISHES CAN BE SALVAGED
description: How can one salvage a basically good but tired old finish on a favorite piece of furniture, one that, through age or neglect, has become dirty, discolored, crazed or alligatored and bad enough to obscure the wood?

title: 400 Laid Off in Jersey By Hospital Walkout
description: More than 400 technicians and office and maintenance workers were laid off at strikebound St. Barnabas Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Automated Medical Laboratories Inc. said it its subsidiary, Viragen Inc., had retained D.H. Blair & Co. as investment banker and financial consultant.

title: STRACHAN SENTENCED TO 3 YEARS
description: Mike Strachan, the former professional football player, was sentenced today to three years in Federal prison for conspiracy to distribute cocaine and for selling it.

title: Northwestern Mutual Merger
description: The Milwaukee-based Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, the nation's ninth-largest life insurance company, and the real estate investment trust which it advises, Northwestern Mutual Life Mortgage and Realty Investors, jointly announced that they had entered into an agreement in which Northwestern Mutual Life will acquire the trust for $65.5 million.

title: Ruling on Hitachi
description: A Federal District judge granted motions filed by the United States Attorney's office and the International Business Machines Corporation to quash subpoenas filed by Hitachi Ltd. and four of its employees related to the F.B.I. ''sting'' case and asked that both sides agree on a narrower body of information to be subpoenaed. Hitachi is trying to show that I.B.M. ''controlled'' the investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that led to charges that the Japanese computer company and some of its executives had stolen confidential I.B.M. computer information. Hitachi's attorneys have charged that I.B.M. sought to harass its competitors.

title: The Yankees to Pay $100,000 To Ex-Officer Injured by Fans
description: The New York Yankees agreed to pay $100,000 to a former New York City police officer who suffered back injuries while attempting to control disorderly fans during the final game of the 1977 World Series, it was disclosed today.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: An underground nuclear weapons test was detonated at the Nevada Test Site just after dawn today. The test had an explosive force equal to that of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT and was conducted without incident, according to an announcement from the Department of Energy.

title: Report Says the U.S.  Is Spying on British
description: A highly secret United States intelligence unit has routinely spied on official British Government communications between London and British officials in Washington, according to an unpublished Congressional report.

title: ROYALS TRIUMPH AND STAY ALIVE
description: If the California Angels are going to win the American League West Division title, they will have to do their celebrating elsewhere. The Royals, who have dominated the division for the past six years, winning four titles, rallied for the second night in a row and defeated the Angels, 6-5, tonight.

title: CLASSES FOR S.A.T. GROWING
description: Shortly after 7 on Tuesday evening, at a time when many teen-agers in Roslyn are normally sprawled in front of television sets or cruising Northern Boulevard, 120 students were at their desks in Roslyn High School, voluntarily sitting in classrooms for one of the few programs that could lure them back after school hours.

title: LOEB'S PAPER SERVES NEW HAMPSHIRE LESS VENOM
description: Before he died of cancer last year, William Loeb, the powerful and conservative publisher of The Union Leader and Sunday News in Manchester, N.@H., declared his support for Robert Monier, a Republican, as the best man to be the next Governor of the state, regardless of who else should run.

title: Ex-Town Justice Slain in Bail Fight
description: A man armed with a knife and a hatchet went on a rampage over $40 in bail money in this Catskill Mountains community Tuesday and killed a former town justice, the state police reported.

title: EUROPE'S BALANCE OF NUCLEAR ARMS IS SAID TO SHIFT FROM WEST TO EAST
description: The balance of nuclear forces in Europe is shifting against the West despite the new Poseidon and Trident systems, the International Institute of Strategic Studies said today.

title: Dr. Mayer to Quit As Health Chief
description: Citing stress related to the demands of her position, New Jersey's Health Commissioner, Dr. Shirley A. Mayer, announced today that she would resign in five days.

title: Ship Loading Gas Turbines
description: Dock workers today began loading a ship with turbines manufactured by a unit of AEG Telefunken for the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: U.S. Charges Bias At a Jersey College
description: The Justice Department charged in a civil suit today that Burlington County College in New Jersey discriminates against women in teaching and administrative positions.

title: 'ASSURANCES' ON PENN SQUARE RECALLED BY MICHIGAN BANKER
description: Officials of the Michigan National Bank, which held more than $190 million in questionable loans from the Penn Square Bank when it failed, said today that they were lured into dealings with the Oklahoma institution by ''assurances and offers of assistance'' from the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently purchased a small house that has cedar shakes painted a dark brown. This paint is peeling badly. Rather than scrape, sand and repaint, I would like to strip all the paint and then just use a wood preservative. Is there a method, like sandblasting, that will take all the paint off that is easier than sanding and scraping?

title: U.S. Aid Awarded To Apollo Theater
description: The Apollo Theater on West 125th Street in Harlem, which closed in 1976 after being the showcase for such performers as Bessie Smith, Ella Fitzgerald and Duke Ellington, received a $1.5 million Federal grant today for its restoration.

title: Chromalloy Credits
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation said it had signed a credit agreement with eight American banks, providing for a four-year revolving credit, followed by a four-year unsecured term loan covering a total of $140 million. Chromalloy said the banks include the Irving Trust Company, Security Pacific National Bank, North Carolina National Bank and the National Bank of Chicago, and said that the funds would be used for general corporate purposes.

title: Dome in Agreement On $1.4 Billion Debt
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. reached an agreement today with the Canadian Government and four Canadian banks to save the company from bankruptcy, Colin Kenny, Dome's corporate affairs director, announced.

title: FINDING ELEGANCE IN OLD BATH FIXTURES
description: OLD bathroom fixtures evoke the style and solidity of an earlier time. Old tubs and sinks are generous and comfortable. The large brass spigots and handles are elegant and speak of a time when space was not at a premium.

title: SPILLED CHEMICALS SPREAD FARTHER
description: State employees in protective suits and air masks discovered contamination today on the ground and in a stream half a mile from blazing derailed chemical tank cars. Firefighters have been forced to abandon efforts to put out the fire.

title: MUSIC: 'L'HISTOIRE' IS STAGED WITH BAIRD MARIONETTES
description: STRAVINSKY'S ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' is notoriously difficult to put across on the stage. It rarely fails entirely in a professional performance, simply because the irresistibly jaunty music will not allow that, but it is theater of such a special and fragile sort that solutions to its many problems come hard.

title: No Headline
description: Brewers Win, 6-3; Lead by 4

title: Hoechst U.S.  Chief Yields Post to Aide
description: The American Hoechst Company, a unit of Hoechst A.G., the West German chemicals concern, has named Dieter zur Loye president and chief executive. Mr. zur Loye, 54, succeeds John G. Brookhuis, 62, who has served 12 years as chief executive.

title: Perdue Suit Is Dropped By the U.S.
description: The Justice Department has dropped a 20-month-old suit in which it charged Frank Perdue, the poultry producer, of engaging in illegal restraint of interstate commerce involving his distributors and competitors in the New York City area.

title: MONTY STRATTON, 70, PITCHER WHO INSPIRED MOVIE, IS DEAD
description: Monty Stratton, whose attempt to make a baseball comeback after losing a leg inspired a movie, died today at Citizens General Hospital. He was 70 years old and had long been ill with cancer.

title: Delta Sells Planes
description: Delta Air Lines said it would sell 11 of its Boeing 727-295 planes and five spare Pratt and Whitney JT8D-15 jet engines to Piedmont Airlines. The price was not disclosed. Delta said it would modify the aircraft extensively for Piedmont and that five would be delivered before the end of 1982 and the other six before June 30,1983.

title: ROLE IS UNCERTAIN; Text of Reagan letter, page A12.
description: As a detachment of United States Marines arrived in Beirut today, statements by President Reagan and other American officials left uncertainty about the precise nature of their mission there and how long they would stay.

title: REGAN SAYS JOBLESSNESS WON'T DROP BELOW 6%
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the country faced a permanent unemployment rate of 6 percent to 6.5 percent, even if the economy recovered from the recession.

title: TV: 2 COMEDY SERIES HAVE THEIR PREMIERES
description: WHAT quickly looks as if it could be the best new situation comedy of the season has its premiere tonight at 9 on NBC-TV (Channel 4). ''Cheers'' has been put together as a Charles Bros./Burrows Production. Les and Glen Charles, writers, and Jim Burrows, the director, were closely associated with the series ''Taxi,'' which just happens to move from ABC to NBC this evening, at 9:30 after ''Cheers.''
